title: Candidates Deserve Medical Privacy
description: Bill Bradley has been regularly updating us on his episodes of irregular heartbeat, just as he promised he would do ever since he alerted us to his atrial fibrillation earlier in the campaign. On Friday, he reported that he had suffered his fifth episode within a month and that three times since 1996, he had received a procedure known as cardioversion, in which the heart is jolted with electricity.

title: F. I. Herzberg, 76, Professor And Management Consultant
description: Frederick I. Herzberg, a psychologist who became one of the most influential management teachers and consultants of the post-World War II era, died in Salt Lake City Jan. 19 from a heart attack and injuries sustained in a related fall, according to Mark Herzberg, his son. He was 76.

title: Chancellor to Review All Superintendents
description: Showing that he intends to be more than a caretaker, New York City's interim schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy, has warned the system's 32 district superintendents that he will evaluate them in June using a long list of criteria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, JOHN M. (JACK)
description: DUFFY-John M. (Jack). On Jan. 31, 2000. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Kasten), cherished father of John, Ellen, Caryl Avellino, and Maribeth Cinelli. Proud grandfather of Bennett, Kirstin, Sean, Devin, John, Brook & Ruthanne. Devoted brother of Mary Cotter. CEO of Buildings and Properties, Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, Founder and President of D&D Construction. Honorary member of Christian Brothers. Reposing Hillebrand Funeral Homes, 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Friday, 9:30 AM Immaculate Conception RC Church in Jamaica Estates. Interment is at St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Cancer Research, SloanKettering Memorial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREY, WARREN C.
description: KREY-Warren C. On January 29, 2000. Beloved husband of Margaret, loving brother of Nathalie and father of Lewis, Russell, and Douglas. Adored grandpa of Rebecca, Lauren, Nathaniel, Kathleen, Mary Margaret, Adrienne, Jocelyn, and Theodore. He was Vice President and Director of Art Services at Dancer, Fitzgerald & Sample until 1986, then he contributed actively in several advisory capacities to the government of his home town of Teaneck, N.J. His love, counsel and support will be always remembered and cherished. Visitation, February 1, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Volk-Leber Funeral Home,Teaneck Rd Teaneck NJ. Funeral service 11 AM, February 2, at Trinity Lutheran Church, 167 Palisades Ave, Bogota, N.J. Burial at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Parkinson Disease Assn or the National Parkinson Disease Fndton. or Trinity Lutheran Church Bogota, NJ.

title: C.I.A. Inquiry of Its Ex-Director Was Stalled at Top, Report Says
description: Top officials of the Central Intelligence Agency impeded an internal investigation into evidence that the agency's former director, John M. Deutch, mishandled large volumes of secret material, a classified report by the agency's inspector general concludes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTWINICK, JOSEPH
description: BOTWINICK-Joseph. 88, of Edison NJ on January 31, 2000. Born February 1, 1912. Husband of the late Helen (Shlisky), father of Paul and Jill Botwinick, Michael and Harriet Botwinick, grandfather of Jonathan, Daniel, and Lora. A founding member of The Endymions in Bayonne NJ, he worked for the B. Manischewitz Co. from 1931 until his retirement as company Safety Director in 1977. Funeral services 10AM Wednesday February 2 at Bernheim-Apter Funeral Home, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood NJ. 973-763-3505

title: In the Final Round of Rallies, It's Bill Bradley, the Professor
description: Senator Paul Wellstone, a former college wrestler who knows a thing or two about cheerleading, got a crowd of nearly 1,000 Bill Bradley supporters here fired up this morning in his high-energy style, pumping his arms and screaming at the top of his lungs, ''We're going to win in New Hampshire!'' over and over again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYER, BETTE
description: BYER-Bette. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Devoted mother of Stephanie Byer-Malkin, Allan, Erica & Mindy (a.k.a. Martine). Cherished grandmother of Sacha and Gabriel. We will love you forever. Service private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPISELMAN, HERBERT C.
description: SPISELMAN-Herbert C. Age 79; Born New York City; B.A. and Clemens Fencing Medal, Columbia University, 1941; M.A., Hofstra University; Captain U.S.A.A.F., WWII; Awarded Distinguished Flying Cross; Assistant Chief Air Traffic Control J.F.K. Airport (retired 1972); Beloved husband of the late Jane and cherished life partner of Judith Sagan; loving father of Anne Spiselman & Wynne Black; devoted grandfather of Jessica and Edson Black; loving brother of Selma (Bernard) Praga. Services will be held at Guttermans in Woodbury, Long Island. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Herbert Spiselman Memorial Fund for Fencing, Columbia University, Dodge Fitness Center MC 1931, 3030 Broadway, New York, New York 10022.

title: Suit Accuses Sony Music of Unfair Online Acts
description: Sony Music Entertainment was sued by retailers who say the company illegally steers customers to its online stores by including hyperlinks on music compact discs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUERLANDER, BEATA E.
description: SAUERLANDER-Beata E. Of Manhattan, on January 29, 2000. Survivors include two daughters, Muki W. Fairchild of Durham, N.C. and Monica Wachstein Schmid of Stuttgart, Germany, and three grandchildren. Also, two brothers and one sister in the U.S. and two brothers in Germany. Memorial contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, N.Y.

title: Congress Wants Only What's Best for Elian
description: To the Editor:

title: A Black Hole, Made From Scratch
description: Astronomers believe that nothing, not even light, can escape after it has been captured by the powerful gravity of a black hole in space and goes, so to speak, down the cosmic drain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISCHLER, STANLEY, M.D.
description: TISCHLER-Stanley, M.D. The Alumni Society of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn wishes to record with deep sorrow the passing of a most esteemed colleague, and expresses heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. Dr. William Kahan, President Dr. Martin Bandler, Treasurer Diane Shapiro, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Versace men's pants on the Fashion page last Tuesday, with an article about the recent men's collections in Milan and Paris, was published in error. The pants were shown last July, not last month.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the presidential candidates' positions on abortion misstated the history of planks on the subject in the Republican Party platform. The first such plank was included in 1976, not 1984; every platform since then has opposed abortion and the use of federal funds to pay for it. The plank has never allowed exceptions for rape, incest or to save the life of the pregnant woman.

title: Audible Jumps After Amazon.com Deal
description: February 1, 2000

title: Give the Rest of Us Voters a Say
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Plan to Revise Nassau Tax Formula
description: Democratic lawmakers said today that they would overhaul Nassau County's archaic tax assessment system, but said that they would need up to a year to come up with a reassessment plan.

title: Trying to Reproduce Engineering Feats of Long Ago
description: In a five-part series beginning tonight, ''Nova'' applies a technological spin to some celebrated engineering accomplishments of centuries long past. The ingenuity of engineers well before their profession had been accredited is brought back with explorations, explanations and demonstrations of what the program calls ''Secrets of Lost Empires.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBSTEL, JEANNE (FRIEDBURG)
description: EBSTEL-Jeanne (Friedburg). Devoted and loved wife, gifted, intelligent and able. Legal secretary, photographer and painter. She will be forever missed by many. Died January 27 at 2:30AM.

title: Keyes Finally Gets Attention, but Not Support
description: From the stage at a hotel ballroom in nearby Nashua a few nights ago, Alan Keyes was scorching another Republican audience with a speech about, among other things, the depravity of President Clinton, the moral crisis endangering the Republic, and most of all, Mr. Keyes's conviction that he alone could save his party from losing the White House for a third time in a row.

title: Clever Young Man Raises Sweet Little Brother
description: A HEARTBREAKING WORK

title: With Fanfare and a Delay, Amtrak Unveils a Faster Train
description: Amtrak unveiled new fully electrified train service between Boston and New York yesterday, but the day was marred by technical problems that seemed symbolic of the difficulties the company has faced in a $2.6 billion high-speed rail venture.

title: Vermeil's Triumph Is Worth The Wait
description: Dick Vermeil, the St. Louis Rams' famously emotional coach, said today that Sunday's stirring Super Bowl victory did not move him to tears in the team's locker room afterward.

title: Fluently Hitting High Notes With the Native Tongue
description: When James Levine auditions singers for the Metropolitan Opera he insists on hearing them sing at least one work in their native language. Usually this reveals the innate sound and colors of a voice. Singers also tend to be more vivid communicators when performing in their own tongues.

title: 3 Israeli Soldiers Killed in Lebanon, Marring Peace Effort
description: Three Israeli soldiers were killed today in southern Lebanon as Iranian-backed guerrillas continued to escalate their attacks during a lull in peace negotiations between Israel and Syria, Lebanon's power broker.

title: Japan Puts Gas-Attack Sect Under Scrutiny
description: A public commission ruled today that Aum Shinrikyo, the religious group that killed 12 people in a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway in 1995, continues to pose a threat to society and it instructed security authorities to put the sect under surveillance for up to three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLOCK, LEONARD
description: POLLOCK-Leonard. Beloved husband of the later Geri, devoted father of Barbara and John Molinari, David and Marion Pollock, loving grandfather of Michael, Sara, Peter, and Elizabeth. Dear brother of Ruth Ritter. Funeral service Wednesday 1PM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. Family request contributions to be made to The Alzheimer's Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOFFSKY, DAVID
description: KOFFSKY-David, 63, of Westport, CT. (Formerly of White Plains). On January 29, 2000. Husband of Judy Koffsky; father of Bruce & Paula Koffsky of Weston, CT., Marcea Koffsky of Norwalk, CT., Daniel & Laura Koffsky of Miami, FL.; Brother of Edward & his wife, Lynn Koffsky of Atlanta, GA.; grandfather of Rachel, Jordana, Zev, Jacob, Andrew & Emily Koffsky; uncle of Mark & Jay Koffsky & son-in-law of Miriam Brightman. Services & interment were held Sunday in Connecticut. Memorial contributions to Beit Chaverim Synagogue, Conservative Synagogue of Westport, The United Jewish Appeal or The American Heart Association.

title: Inefficient English Programs Being Revised : Koreans Redouble Efforts To Conquer Language Bar
description: SEOUL  In a country where everyone studies English grammar from primary school through high school, Koreans are awakening to a disturbing reality: No one can speak it without private language lessons, and the ability to use it has become a requirement for everything from college to the workplace.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Montreal Journal; Trudeaumania Lingers but the Policies Fade Fast
description: To newcomers thronging a busy food court at lunch time here, there is something familiar about the elderly lawyer standing patiently in line at the Lebanese food counter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVOE, MURIEL M.
description: DEVOE-Muriel M. 89, of Bayside, NY and Pompano Beach, FL. We sadly note the passing of our sister and aunt lovingly known as Mums on January 26. Beloved wife of the late Vincent E. and sister of J. Clement and the late John C. Sweeney, and Maree Bock. Aunt of K.B., Marguerite, Michael, Christopher, and Maree and spouse John Hartley. Great-aunt of Peter Hartley. Viewing at F. X. Hatton, Monday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM, 36-46 Bell Blvd., Bayside, NY. Funeral services Tuesday 9:45 AM Sacred Heart Church, 215-35 38th Ave., Bayside, NY.

title: A Two-Beatle Reunion, But It's Just Imagination
description: It's 1976, six years after the breakup of the Beatles and four years before the death of John Lennon. Paul McCartney, whose band, Wings, has the No. 1 record in both the United States and Britain, has come to New York for some concerts. He decides to drop in on John unannounced. They get together and talk. And talk. And talk. They sing briefly. And talk. They take a walk. They stop for coffee. And . . . you get the idea.

title: Sports of The Times; Woods's Misleading Winning Streak
description: WHEN Tiger Woods tees off Thursday in the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, he will be seeking his sixth consecutive victory in a P.G.A. Tour event. But it's misleading to think that, if he were to win, he would be halfway to breaking Byron Nelson's record of 11 consecutive P.G.A. Tour triumphs in 1945.

title: Russians Wary of U.S. Pitch For Missile Defense System
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright came here today to try to convince Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov, whom she has often called her good friend, about the wisdom of a new American missile defense system.

title: Foreign Affairs; 1 Davos, 3 Seattles
description: Every year at the World Economic Forum there is a star or theme that stands out. The star of Davos 2000 was, without question, Seattle. Seattle was talked about everywhere. The only problem was that the business and government leaders here were actually talking about three different Seattles -- the Seattle that is afraid of the future, the Seattle that is demanding a slice of the future and the Seattle that is building the future.

title: Top 3 Republican Contenders Are on Some Absentee Ballots
description: New York election officials agreed yesterday to put the three leading contenders in the Republican presidential primary on absentee ballots for members of the military while a court fight continues over who will appear on the regular ballots.

title: The Uses of Negative Campaigns
description: Shortly after a speech in which he had, by implication, questioned George W. Bush's readiness to be commander in chief and linked him to Clintonesque fund-raising techniques, Senator John McCain was asked if he was violating his promise not to indulge in negative campaigning. ''I think I'm close,'' Mr. McCain said with a laugh. As usual, he was being more candid -- and wittier -- than the other leading candidates about a game that all of them are playing to some degree.

title: ONLINE INVESTMENT BANKING
description: Monex Securities Inc., an online brokerage firm, will sell shares to raise 3.1 billion yen, or roughly $29 million, to help it expand into investment banking services like underwriting. Monex was established by the Sony Corporation and Oki Matsumoto, a former partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company. Among those that will buy Monex shares are Soros Fund Management L.L.C. and Tudor Proprietary Trading L.L.C, two large hedge fund managers, as well as Goldman and JWM Investment Partners, the new investment vehicle of the former fund manager John Meriwether. Stephanie Strom

title: Russia's Corrupt Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARON, PHYLLIS
description: ARON-Phyllis, 63. Of Stamford, CT, died Wednesday, January 26, 2000 at the Hospice Residence in Stuart, FL. Born in Stamford, CT, she was a winter resident of Stuart, FL., and summer resident of Stamford. She attended Beaver College in Jenkintown, PA., and earned her B.A. degree from the University of CT. Prior to retirement, she was a manager for M. Aron Corp. in New York City for 25 years. She was a member of Temple Beth El in Stamford. Survivors include her husband, Richard Aron of Stuart, FL and Stamford, CT; daughter, Jennifer Aron of Manhattan, NY; son and daughter-in-law, William and Barri Aron of Stamford, CT; and brother and sister-in-law, Dr. Alan Weinstock and Madeline of Potomac, MD. Services were Sunday, January 30th, 1:30 P.M., at Temple Beth El in Stamford, CT. Burial was in Beth El Cemetery, Stamford, CT. Contributions may be made to The Brain Tumor Research Program Comprehensive Care Center DUMC Post Office 3828 Durham, NC, 27710. For information: Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Stamford, CT., and Aycock Funeral Home, Stuart, FL.

title: Shares of a British Cement Concern Jump on Possible Offer
description: Shares in Blue Circle Industries, a British cement company, rose more than 20 percent today on reports that the world's No. 1 building materials group, Lafarge S.A. of France, was about to bid as much as $5.7 billion for Blue Circle.

title: Jakarta's Military Chiefs Accused of Crimes
description: An Indonesian human rights panel today accused top military officials, including the former armed forces commander, of involvement in ''crimes against humanity'' in East Timor and handed the case to the attorney general for formal investigation.

title: Mannesmann Said to Weigh Dropping Opposition to Vodafone Bid
description: Mannesmann A. G. reversed its opposition to talks with Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. today and began to consider a face-saving friendly merger, executives close to the talks said.

title: Air Carrier Has Grown Over Years
description: Alaska Airlines has grown over its 68-year history from a single three-passenger plane chugging across the tundra to the nation's 10th-biggest carrier, as ranked by Aviation Daily, which closely monitors the industry.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Jan. 25 about a paradox in game theory, a discipline that seeks to extract rules of nature from the gains and losses observed in games, misspelled the name of its discoverer. He is Dr. Juan Parrondo, not Parrando.

title: SANTANDER DEAL WITH SOCIETE GENERALE
description: Spain's largest bank, Banco Santander Central Hispano, will cooperate with Societe Generale S.A. of France on asset management and other services. The two banks will try to benefit jointly from Banco Santander's strength in Latin America and Societe Generale's strength in Asia. Banco Santander's co-chairmen said the deal was not a prelude to a merger. Societe Generale will buy a 3 percent stake in Banco Santander, worth about 1.1 billion euros, and Banco Santander will purchase nearly 2 percent more of Societe Generale, worth about 410 million euros, to increase its stake to 7 percent.

title: Gun Violence: A Turning Point
description: To the Editor:

title: JASON TO BE ACQUIRED BY MANAGER-LED INVESTOR GROUP
description: The auto parts maker Jason Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by a group consisting of senior managers and the private investment firm Saw Mill Capital Fund II L.P. for $335 million. The group is offering $11.25 a share, and Jason's shares rose, gaining $3.25, to $10.375, in Nasdaq trading. The group is led by Jason's chairman, Vincent L. Martin, and its president and chief executive, Mark Train. They will own about 40 percent of the corporation after the transaction.

title: Refusing to Coast on Familiar Songs and Arias
description: With all that the compulsively busy superstar tenor Placido Domingo has managed to do during his long career, he had never given a song recital in the United States.

title: Stories From the Naked City, And Every Picture Tells One
description: The 1990's were generous to Manhattan, scouring the island with good fortune and better publicity. And while prosperity is something no sane New Yorker will complain of, many feel nostalgic now and then over the rapid disappearance of an older, more raffish city, a place whose lurking shadows and patchwork dereliction were at least distantly related to the movies, detective novels and tabloid images that taught us what a city was.

title: TRANSPORTATION TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO A BUYOUT
description: Transportation Technologies Industries said yesterday that the company had agreed to be acquired by an investor group led by members of its management for $221 million. The group offered $21.50 in cash for common shares of the Chicago-based maker of components for trucks and buses. The stock rose $2.625 a share, to $20.4375. The investor group buying the company originally offered $20 a share in December. Its members include Thomas M. Begel, Transportation Technologies' chairman and chief executive, and Andrew M. Weller, its president and chief operating officer.

title: America Online to Take Stake in Netcentives
description: America Online to Take Stake in Netcentives

title: Consumers Kept Spending In December
description: Consumer spending rose in December at the fastest rate in four months, a sign that the economy may be picking up speed as it nears a record for the longest expansion in the nation's history.

title: Gun Violence: A Turning Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Left Hand, Right Brain
description: To the Editor:

title: LYONDELL AND OCCIDENTAL WON'T BUY EQUISTAR CHEMICALS
description: The Lyondell Chemical Company and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation declined yesterday to buy out the 29.5 percent stake held by Millennium Chemicals Inc. in the companies' Equistar Chemicals L.P. joint venture, valued by Millennium at $800 million. Lyondell owns 41 percent and Los Angeles-based Occidental owns 29.5 percent of Equistar, a maker of basic chemicals like ethylene, polyethylene and propylene. Millennium, based in Red Bank, N.J., wants to sell to focus on more profitable specialty chemicals. Houston-based Lyondell said it had rejected the offer because it wanted to reduce debt. A spokesman at Los Angeles-based Occidental said the company told Millennium it was not interested in the offer.

title: Ads Lift Gannett Profit by 14%
description: The Gannett Company, the largest newspaper publisher in the United States, said here today that fourth-quarter profit increased 14 percent, spurred by more growth in advertising sales at USA Today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, SAMUEL J.
description: SILBERMAN-Samuel J. On January 29. Beloved husband of Lois. Cherished father of Douglas, Allen, Rita Rothenberg, Alfred, Jayne and Peter. Grandfather of six. An innovative leader in philanthropic, civic and educational agencies, and in business. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., 2-5 and 7-9 PM on Monday, January 31. Services 11 AM on Tuesday, February 1 at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Why I Changed My Mind About Elian
description: When I agreed to provide a neutral meeting place at the Barry University president's house for 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez and his grandmothers, I expected to witness a meaningful visit. But I had no idea that what I saw would be so powerful that it would change my mind, persuading me that Elian should not be returned -- at least for now -- to his father in Cuba.

title: A Day's Surge in Shares Can't Erase a Weak Month
description: Stocks ended their first losing month since September with a rally yesterday, as investors bought beaten-down telecommunications and financial shares.

title: Curcic on His Way Back to Europe
description: METROSTARS

title: Merrill Lynch Is Set to Move Into Banking
description: For more than a year now, Wall Street analysts have been wondering whether Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, would buy a commercial bank or be bought by one.

title: America One's Tactics Close the Gap on Prada
description: With its bright hopes of challenging for the America's Cup beginning to dim, Paul Cayard's America One syndicate sailed a strong, confident race today and scored a wire-to-wire victory over Italy's Prada Challenge in the fifth race of the five-of-nine-race Louis Vuitton Cup finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPAVASILIOU, LEONIDAS
description: PAPAVASILIOU - Leonidas. On January 30, 2000 of Roslyn, NY. Beloved husband of Pat. Loving father of Constantinos. Cherished son of Georgia and brother of Vasillos. Son-in-law of Costas and Elli and brother-in-law of Elenitsa, Damianos and Paul. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset Tuesday and Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass 10 A.M. Thursday at Archangel Michael Greek Orthodox Church, Roslyn.

title: Hope for Mars Lander
description: Evidence is growing that the lost Mars Polar Lander is the source of the mysterious signal -- about as strong as that of a cell phone -- that NASA began investigating last week. The space agency plans to increase efforts to talk to the craft in the hope that it is alive.

title: Q & A
description: Synthetic Blood

title: Rival Scottish Banks Increase Takeover Bids for NatWest
description: The Bank of Scotland and the Royal Bank of Scotland Group raissed their bids for National Westminster Bank P.L.C. today.

title: Pat Cetta, 66, the Gregarious Host of Sparks
description: Pat Cetta, who with his brother, Mike, owned Sparks, a renowned New York steakhouse, died on Jan. 24. He was 66.

title: STRONG CANADIAN ECONOMY
description: With a burst of growth in November and signs of strength in December, the economy in Canada is likely to show a 4 percent expansion for 1999, economists said. Statistics Canada said the economy grew 0.6 percent in November, after three months of declining momentum and a gain of only 0.1 percent in October. The economy has grown for 16 consecutive months, the longest uninterrupted expansion in a decade. Timothy Pritchard

title: EXPEDIA INC. AGREES TO BUY TWO TRAVEL WEB SITES
description: Expedia Inc., the online travel company controlled by the Microsoft Corporation, agreed yesterday to buy Travelscape.com Inc. and VacationSpot.com Inc., for about $161 million in stock and assumed debt, gaining Web sites that specialize in renting hotel rooms and vacation homes. Expedia, based in Bellevue, Wash., said it would issue about 2.6 million shares and stock options, worth $70.9 million, for VacationSpot.com. It will issue three million shares, options and warrants, worth about $81.8 million, for Travelscape.com. It will also assume $8 million in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLLINGER, ISIDORE
description: DOLLINGER-Isidore. We mourn the passing of Justice Isidore Dollinger, devoted husband of the late Rose Dollinger, father of Edmund Dollinger, grandfather of Michael and Jeffrey Dollinger and greatgrandfather of Eric and Jack Dollinger. Services today, February 1, 2000 at 12 noon Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY.

title: The Patsy's Connection; Two Competing Pasta Sauces Share a Name and a Trademark Lawsuit
description: To some people, this seems like a simple story about spaghetti sauce. To others, mainly lawyers, it is about technical things like trademarks.

title: What We All Spoke When the World Was Young
description: In the beginning, there was one people, perhaps no more than 2,000 strong, who had acquired an amazing gift, the faculty for complex language. Favored by the blessings of speech, their numbers grew, and from their cradle in the northeast of Africa, they spread far and wide throughout the continent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNON, JILL
description: GANNON-Jill. Wife of Jasper Gaunt. On January 30th at home after a long illness, borne with great courage and grace. Service is on Tuesday, February 1, at 2 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering 1275 York Ave, NY NY 10021

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, KENNETH M.
description: FREEDMAN-Kenneth M.. 72, formerly of White Meadow Lake, NJ, died peacefully in his home January 26 surrounded by his family. He is survived by beloved wife Sarah, children Ellen Carron, Karen Quigley, Eric and Nancy Freedman, grandchildren Benjamin, Rebecca & Michael Carron, and Kadyrose & Julia Quigley, and sons-in-law Barry Carron & Christopher Quigley. Born in Chicago, IL, he graduated from the Univ. of Illinois and served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. His successful business career included exec. positions at Revlon, American Home Products & President of Popular Services, Inc. He'll be fondly remembered as a loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather as well as a generous friend and community leader, supporting many causes focused on helping the Jewish community.

title: Baseball Suspends Rocker Till May for Comments
description: Commissioner Bud Selig, saying John Rocker had dishonored Major League Baseball by disparaging many groups of society with his harsh comments in a magazine interview, suspended the Atlanta Braves' No. 1 relief pitcher yesterday for 73 days, marking the first time a baseball player has been disciplined for speech.

title: Exploring Alzheimer's Early Roots
description: Alzheimer's remains a poorly understood disease, but one study suggests a possible link between it and early life.

title: A Couple of Cats in Love. Really, Cats. The Feline Kind.
description: The subtitle of ''Leonard and Minky'' says it all. The piece, performed on Friday night at Dance Theater Workshop, is ''an urban ballet'' about two decidedly uncute cats who fall in love. New Yorkers will recognize instantly in Leonard the unwashed eccentric on the subway from whom one hasn't the heart to move away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVA, PHYLLIS (NEE RUDNER)
description: KAVA-Phyllis (nee Rudner), 67, died January 31st, 2000. Beloved wife of H. Wallace, M.D. Loving mother of Bradley, Laura, Candy, Larry and Jody. Adoring grandmother of Nerissa, Andrew, Ryan and Allie. A dedicated teacher in Irvington and Scarsdale for over 20 years. She had everything from A to Z. We will love her forever. Donations may be made to the Columbia Presbyterian Transplantation Program. Graveside service Wednesday at Sharon Gardens. For info, call Zion Memorial Chapel in Westchester, 1-888-381-1809.

title: Accounts
description: Crunch Fitness, New York, to DiMassimo Brand Advertising, New York, to handle its account, which had been at Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Illinois, Citing Faulty Verdicts, Bars Executions
description: Citing a ''shameful record of convicting innocent people and putting them on death row,'' Gov. George Ryan of Illinois today halted all executions in the state, the first such moratorium in the nation.

title: In Town but Leaving The Blockbusters Behind
description: Is it only New Yorkers who, in their chronic arrogance, think that a New York appearance should be something special for orchestras from around the country and the world? Evidently not, to judge from the blockbuster programs those orchestras have tended to flaunt here, including, in recent decades, Mahler and Bruckner symphonies to a fault.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Mr. Rocker should understand that his remarks offended practically every element of society and brought dishonor to himself, the Atlanta Braves and Major League Baseball.''

title: Republicans Offer Tax Cut For Couples
description: House Republicans unveiled their own proposal today to give a tax cut to married couples, stepping up pressure on President Clinton and Democrats to agree to an election-year compromise on taxes.

title: U.P.S. Results Meet Forecast, But Fail to Impress Investors
description: United Parcel Service Inc. said today that fourth-quarter earnings rose 37 percent, disappointing investors who had expected the company, the world's largest provider of package delivery service, to get a bigger lift from holiday-season shipments by online retailers.

title: The Silicon Godfather; The Man Behind Taiwan's Rise in the Chip Industry
description: The assembly lines at the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation were running full tilt after midnight last Sept. 21, when the floor began to heave. A huge earthquake had struck central Taiwan 60 miles south of here. But for the luck of geography, this futuristic technology park could have resembled a scene from the most expensive disaster movie ever made.

title: Worker Falls to His Death From Smoke-Filled Building
description: A man who tried to escape a smoky fire in a garment district building was killed yesterday when he slipped from a makeshift rope and fell from a 10th-floor window, fire officials said.

title: Dangerous Stall by the I.R.A.
description: Less than four months before the Irish Republican Army is supposed to disarm completely, a monitoring panel is expected to report that the I.R.A. has yet to turn in a single gun or bomb. By failing to take that modest but symbolically important first step, the I.R.A. has pushed Northern Ireland's mainstream Catholic and Protestant parties, along with the Irish and British governments, into an extremely difficult position and jeopardized the progress that has been made toward a fair and durable peace in Northern Ireland.

title: City's Expense in Keeping Stock Exchange Here Goes Up
description: The projected cost of building a heavily subsidized trading complex to keep the New York Stock Exchange in Lower Manhattan has climbed by tens of millions of dollars as city and state officials have struggled to formalize an agreement struck with the exchange 13 months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINRACH, BARBARA KAYE

A talented artist, teacher, beloved daughter to Rachel, loving mother to Maggie and Robert, Douglas and Jeanne, and Elizabeth and Keith, chesrished sister to Irwin and Mary, adoring grandmother to Jake, Matthew, Alex and Jacqueline and aunt to Jillian and Gregory. Services took place Monday at 11:00 AM from Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Rd., Westport, with interment at Temple Israel Cemetery in Norwalk. A woman with a great passion for life-we will miss you forever. Memorial contributions may be made to the Yale University Oncology Dept.

title: Impact of Trucking Garbage Across Hudson Challenged
description: Contending that New York City is seriously polluting Manhattan's air with its new system of trucking the borough's garbage to New Jersey, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer of New York has sued to force the city to submit a detailed environmental study and, if necessary, to reduce diesel emissions from the trucks.

title: Red Storm Gives Orangemen a Scare
description: The trap had worked all game and it looked as if it would again now: score tied, 1 minute 58 seconds on the clock, Syracuse's Jason Hart pinned between Erick Barkley and Chudney Gray of St. John's at the Carrier Dome tonight.

title: Clinton Campaign Hires Agency That Created Advertisements Tweaking Mayor on City Buses
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has hired the Manhattan advertising firm whose ads for New York magazine in 1997 enraged Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to produce the media campaign in her bid for the United States Senate, officials said yesterday.

title: EL PASO TO BUY NATURAL GAS BUSINESSES OF P.G.& E.
description: The El Paso Field Services Company, a unit of the El Paso Energy Corporation, agreed yesterday to acquire the natural gas businesses of three P.G.& E. Corporation units for about $279 million. It will also assume debt of $561 million. Under the agreement, El Paso Field Services will acquire the natural gas and natural gas liquids businesses of P.G.& E. Gas Transmission, the Texas Corporation and P.G.& E. Gas Transmission Teco Inc. El Paso Field Services said the assets included natural gas gathering, processing, transmission and storage businesses in Texas. The sale is expected to add immediately to El Paso Energy's earnings.

title: SARA LEE COMPLETES $3 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it had completed a $3 billion repurchase of about 114 million shares five months ahead of the company's target of June 30. Sara Lee also said its board had approved the repurchase of an additional 73 million shares, up from 23 million previously authorized. The Chicago-based food and consumer products giant currently has about 883 million shares outstanding valued at approximately $16.2 billion. The commitment to repurchase $3 billion worth of common stock by the end of the 2000 fiscal year in July was part of a revamping announced in 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, PAUL
description: MILLER-Paul. Beloved husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Alan and Barbara Spellen. Dear brother of Abraham, and Nancy Hankel. Adoring grandfather of Michelle, Jeffrey, David and Marc. Services Wednesday, 11:30 A.M., at ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Timeout on the Death Penalty
description: Gov. George Ryan of Illinois has shown political courage and integrity in being the first governor in a death penalty state to put a stop, at least temporarily, to executions in light of overwhelming evidence that the capital punishment system is prone to make mistakes. He said yesterday, ''I now favor a moratorium, because I have grave concerns about our state's shameful record of convicting innocent people and putting them on death row.'' Since capital punishment was reinstated in Illinois in 1977, 12 death row inmates have been executed while 13 have been exonerated after their cases were reopened, many with the help of volunteer lawyers.

title: Giving the Play by Play for Met's Listeners
description: AND all these years you thought that Peter Allen was alone in the broadcast booth at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMORRIS, LEROY SELLS
description: McMORRIS-LeRoy Sells. Durham, NC resident, age 74, died Tuesday evening, January 25, 2000 at his home. Mr. McMorris was a veteran of the U.S. Army and the U.S. Air Force, having served during both WWII and Korea. He was retired from the City of New York where he worked as an accessibility assessor for the Mayor's Office for the Handicapped. He was a member of Christ Church Bay Ridge Episcopal of Brooklyn. He served in numerous volunteer organizations including the DAV and the Amateur Astronomers Association, and was an officer in the Benevolent Society for Retarded Children. Mr. McMorris was the son of the late Daniel MacMorris, the noted Kansas City artist and the grandson of the late Elijah Watt Sells, co-founder of the accounting firm of Haskins and Sells. Surviving are his wife, Mrs. Marion Louis McMorris; a son, Louis McMorris of Brooklyn; a daughter, Ms. Mary McMorris and her husband, Leonard Santoro, of Chapel Hill, NC; a sister, Lee MacMorris of Laguna Niguel, CA; and grandsons, Evan McMorris-Santoro and Stefan McMorris-Santoro, of Chapel Hill, NC. A memorial service will be conducted Saturday, February 5, at 2:30 PM in Clements Funeral Chapel in Durham, NC, the Rev. Harold W. Morcombe officiating. Memorial contributions may be made to the Benevolent Society for Retarded Children, 1150 Forest Hill Road, Building L, Staten Island, New York 10314.

title: Contented Electorate Is Also Happy With Campaign
description: Vivian Poirier, a 44-year-old massage therapist, smiled broadly today when asked at the post office in Portsmouth, on the eastern edge of the state, to judge how this year's primary campaign for president had been conducted. ''There doesn't seem to be as much -- what's the word I'm looking for? -- viciousness,'' she responded. ''They aren't as vicious, which is nice.''

title: EUROPEANS  MOVE AGAINST AUSTRIANS ON NATIVIST PARTY
description: The European Union warned today that its 14 other members would diplomatically isolate Austria if its anti-immigrant Freedom Party led by Jorg Haider enters a coalition government.

title: Man Held in Threats Of 2nd Seton Hall Fire
description: A Jersey City man who the authorities said sent a threatening e-mail message to Seton Hall University the day after a dormitory fire killed three students was arrested yesterday and charged with making terrorist threats, law enforcement officials said.

title: As the Hours Melt Away, The Hard Edges Soften
description: With the last hours before this state's presidential primary ticking away and plenty of undecided voters out there, it was time today for the candidates to make their final pleas, show their best sides and conclude their campaigns on memorable grace notes.

title: When Musical Brilliance Is Scarce
description: If the intention of the Focus festival at Juilliard last week was to hold a mirror up to contemporary composing, that happened. Every concert was a medley of music remarkable and completely unremarkable, with the balance in favor of the latter. This is, the audience was duly informed, an age like any other. Brilliance is scarce.

title: On Health Report Card, the 'F' Stands for Fat
description: Well, folks, the year 2000 is here and the bad news is that Americans failed to achieve many of the health goals established by the surgeon general in 1979 in an ambitious report called Healthy People 2000.

title: Op-Art
Jet Carrying Almost 90 Crashes Off California
description: Alaska Airlines jetliner bound from Mexico to San Francisco crashed into the Pacific Ocean northwest of Malibu this afternoon with nearly 90 people aboard after reporting mechanical difficulties. Coast Guard boats, rescue helicopters and a Navy search plane scoured the choppy waters for hours into the winter twilight and long past darkness, finding several bodies but no immediate survivors, the authorities said.

title: ANGER OVER DELAYED TRADE DEAL
description: President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa lashed out at the European Union, criticizing it for not carrying out a free-trade accord with his country because of objections by Greece and Italy to the use of the terms grappa and ouzo in labeling wines and spirits. Both countries contend that South Africa should not be able to use the terms. Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Mr. Mbeki said the European Union had shown bad faith in raising objections after the accord was signed. Henri E. Cauvin

description: When the durability and longevity of spacecraft have counted most, on long voyages to the outer planets of the Sun, fortune has smiled on American space scientists.

title: Bluegrass in a Big Brown Truck; A Mandolin Picker Is Hailed as a Master, but He's Keeping the Day Job, Thanks
description: Johnny Staats slid open the door of his United Parcel Service truck and crept cautiously through the snow toward the door of a dilapidated red house, carefully inspecting the yard for clues indicating the presence of a dog. ''These kind of calls right here are where you have to watch out for Fido,'' he said, hiding a package behind a shovel on the porch and jogging back to the safety of his truck.

title: Study Documents Homelessness In American Children Each Year
description: About 1.35 million children in the United States -- nearly 2 percent of the nation's total -- are likely to become homeless at some point in the course of a year, a new analysis of national census and survey data being presented today has found.

title: Hospital That Suspended Doctor Met Him Later About Joint Project
description: Two months after an obstetrician was suspended from Beth Israel Medical Center for carving his initials into a patient's belly, hospital officials met with him to discuss sending nurse midwives to work at a Queens clinic where the doctor had a new job, the hospital acknowledged yesterday.

title: PROGRESS IN MALAYSIAN SHARE DISPUTE
description: Singapore and Malaysia took a step toward resolving a 17-month dispute over $4.5 billion worth of Malaysian shares frozen on a Singaporean market. The Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange told investors that they should accept a plan aimed at freeing the shares, which Malaysia had banned from trading when it imposed capital controls in September 1998. After talks in Kuala Lumpur with its Singaporean counterpart, the exchange called the plan ''part of a comprehensive and expeditious solution.'' Singapore's exchange said it would distribute the plan to the roughly 172,000 investors affected. Wayne Arnold

title: For the Mentally Ill, a Gap in Cardiac Care
description: Mentally ill people who have heart attacks are less likely to be offered the kind of treatment customarily available to other patients, a new study reports.

title: Manholes Across City Disrupted by Corrosion
description: Corrosion caused by salt used to melt snow and ice on city streets caused sparks, smoke, fire or explosions in more than 200 manholes across the city yesterday, according to Con Edison.

title: Evidence Builds That Mars Lander Is Source of Mystery Signal
description: Evidence is growing, though slowly, that the lost Mars Polar Lander is the source of the mystery signal that NASA began investigating last week, and the space agency plans to step up efforts to talk to the craft in hopes that it is alive on the red planet.

title: DAEWOO BONDS TO BE REDEEMED
description: Beginning on Wednesday, almost a week earlier than originally planned, South Korean investment trusts and brokerage firms have decided to allow individual investors to redeem up to 95 percent of the bonds issued by the ailing Daewoo Group. To stave off a run on deposits at investment trust companies since the financial crisis at the Daewoo Group became public last summer, the government had prohibited investors from redeeming the total value of bonds issued by the conglomerate. Samuel Len

description: A British medical journal has reported that Monday is the most common day for the Scots to suffer fatal heart attacks, and researchers believe that increased drinking during the weekend may explain the death rate.

title: Theory, Reality and Skeptical Tourists in Physics Land
description: Like a Fodor's guide to Manhattan, the science of physics is generally sold as the ultimate, indispensable, up-to-the-minute guide to reality. The parallel is far from exact: physicists cannot credibly tout their research as inexpensive and easy to use. But if there is one thing that the painstaking experiments and deep thinking of physics are meant to produce, it is theories that explain both the delights and the details of natural reality at its most fundamental level.

title: EURO DROP COULD SPUR INFLATION
description: Further declines in Europe's common currency, the euro, could spur faster inflation in the region, the president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, said. The euro sank to a record low of 97.35 United States cents on Friday, down 16 percent since its inception in January 1999. ''Continued weakening of the euro would pose a risk to our objective of maintaining price stability,'' Mr. Duisenberg said to reporters at a monthly meeting in Brussels of the finance ministers of the euro region.

title: Why Children End Up in the Hospital
description: Asthma and infections like pneumonia and bronchitis accounted for more than half the hospitalizations of children from 1 to 4 years old in a major study of children's health in the United States. The research, the most comprehensive in a decade, also found that the conditions were responsible for nearly a third of hospital stays for 5- to 9-year-olds.

title: Puerto Rico Allows Navy To Resume Some Use of Base
description: Puerto Rico agreed today to let the Navy resume limited training on the island of Vieques as part of a deal that includes up to $90 million in aid if residents of Vieques vote to allow exercises with live ammunition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKINS, EDNA (FERRELL)
description: HASKINS-Edna (Ferrell), of Westport, CT, beloved wife of Caryl Parker Haskins, passed away January 30, 2000, at the age of 88. Edna Haskins was born September 26, 1911 in Blyth, Northumberland, England. She attended King's College, Durham University, from which she was graduated with first-class honors in physical chemistry in 1933. Following graduate work at her home university, she came to this country and worked for two years at Radcliffe and at Harvard as a recipient of the Augustus Anson Whitney Fellowship from King's College, and as a Ross Sidgwick Fellow of the British and American Associations of University Women. She received her M.S. in chemistry from Radcliffe in 1937 and her Ph.D. from King's College in the same year. Following her return to England, she became a member of the senior research and administrative staff in the War Department, carrying on research in diagnostic explosives and working with mist dissolving for aircraft, the results of which were recognized as important in the British war effort. She was then appointed His Majesty's Inspector of Factories in the Ministry of Labor and National Service, the first woman to occupy the post. In 1940, Edna Ferrell returned to the United States and married Caryl Parker Haskins, the founder of Haskins Laboratories, a private non-profit research laboratory established in 1935. Edna Haskins published several works on her chemical research in alkalimetal hydrides by atomic hydrogen and her investigations of electrolytic dissociation. She and her husband Caryl shared a consuming interest in entomology. Together, they were responsible for some of the most important research in ant biology to date, coauthoring a number of conclusive works, together and with others. Edna Haskins was deeply interested in foreign affairs; she and Caryl Haskins traveled the wold extensively. Dr. Haskins was a member of several organizations and clubs, including the American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Chemical Society, American Association of University Women, American Museum of Natural History, the Cosmopolitan Club of New York City, the Colony Club of New York, and the Sulgrave Club of Washington, D.C. Donations may be made in her memory to Haskins Laboratories, c/o Alice Dadourian, 2 Granite Road, Guilford, CT 06437. Information: Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church St., Guilford CT.

title: SLOW RESTART AT VW PLANT

Union leaders and plant managers agreed last week to reopen the plant with an understanding that workers would end their strike, fomented by a few hundred employees angry over the union's suspension of 13 shop stewards. Henri E. Cauvin

title: When Real Men Had the Nose Jobs
description: Women may be its primary beneficiaries now, but men were the customers in days of yore when techniques for repairing noses and ears lost to swordplay were zealously guarded by barber-surgeons. The Renaissance writer Gaspare Tagliacozzi was the first to document these practices in a book published in 1597. A first edition of Tagliacozzi's work and other rare classics of the trade from the library of Dr. Eugene H. Courtiss, a plastic surgeon, will be for sale in an auction at Christie's Los Angeles on Feb. 9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKIN, NORMAN E.
description: HENKIN-Norman E. On January 30, 2000. Age 79. Beloved husband of Helen D. Henkin, brother of William Henkin, father of Louise Henkin Quigley and Alice Henkin. Father-in-law of Chuck Quigley and John Nicolich, adored grandfather of Ruth, Leah and Sophie (Sunshine). Lifelong Brooklyn resident, practicing attorney for 50 years, former member of the Board of Higher Education of New York City, Trustee of Congregation Beth Elohim, long active in UJA and many other community affairs. title: Insiders Offer Details Of Corrupt Rankings By Officials of I.B.F.
description: For years, the pattern had struck many people in the boxing business as fishy. One after another, Colombian fighters with almost no experience outside Colombia would appear out of nowhere, rise rapidly up the International Boxing Federation's rankings and get a shot at a title. Most of them then lost the title fight and disappeared.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Cutbacks at Titanium
description: Hurt by a downturn in the aerospace sector, the Titanium Metals Corporation announced the departure of top managers last week and said it would cut 250 jobs in a reorganization intended to save money. The company said results were hurt by lower aerospace and industrial demand, adding that the outlook for 2000 was weak. J. Landis Martin, the chairman and chief executive, said he would also be president. Andrew Dixey, president and chief operating officer, is resigning, along with the vice presidents for corporate development, finance and service center operations. Mark A. Wallace was named chief financial officer and executive vice president.

title: BRADESCO'S EARNINGS RISE
description: Earnings at Banco Bradesco S.A., a large Brazilian bank, rose 5.5 percent, to 365 million reais, or $202 million, in the fourth quarter, and were up 9 percent for the year, to 1.1 billion reais, or $625 million. Still, the results were far below the 22 percent gain in 1998, reflecting Brazil's sharp currency devaluation last year. Simon Romero

title: Give the Rest of Us Voters a Say
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNSON, OLIVER CROMWELL
description: MUNSON-Oliver Cromwell, 75, passed away January 13, 2000 in the loving arms of his wife Sheryl. He was President and CEO of Grinnell Lithographic Inc. for the last forty-two years. He was a resident of Fort Lauderdale and Babylon, NY. He was an alumnus of Princeton University-Class of 45. He served in W.W. II in the U.S. Navy as an Ensign. His hobbies were cruising, bridge, fishing and orchids. He was a lifetime member of the NY Athletic Club and a member of the Coral Ridge Yacht Club, the Fort Lauderdale Bridge Club, The Plantation Orchid Society and the Fort Lauderdale Orchid Society. In 1995 the Vanda ''Oliver Munson'' was named in his honor. He is survived by his beloved wife Sheryl, loving father of son Raeburn and daughter-in-law Joan, beloved grandfather of Pamela and Paige. Memorial service 4:00 PM, Sunday, February 6, 2000 at the Presbyterian Church of Islip. Pastor James Wenker officiating. Family suggests donations to the North Shore Animal League ''Gift Planning Department'', 70 Port Washington Blvd., Port Washington, NY 11050, Att: Lynne, because of his best friend Beluga.

title: A Citizenship Incubator for Immigrant Latinos
description: At one time, Pacific Boulevard was where the residents of this hip-pocket city in southeast of downtown Los Angeles came to realize their fondest middle-class desires. The boulevard was the apotheosis of the postwar California dream, an all-white working-class Beverly Hills with swank department stores, auto dealerships and first-run cinemas.

title: Estrogen Offers Hope Against H.I.V.
description: Estrogen strongly protected against infection by the simian AIDS virus in experiments with female monkeys, offering hope that it might be used to protect against the human AIDS virus in women, researchers have reported here at a meeting on the disease.

title: Race Issue Raised as 5 Jurors Are Chosen for Diallo Trial
description: Five jurors, including two black women, were chosen today as jury selection began in the trial of four white police officers accused of murdering Amadou Diallo, a West African immigrant who was shot 19 times as he stood unarmed in the lobby of his Bronx apartment building one year ago.

title: SUPER BOWL XXXIV: Dynasty: The Mini-Series; Rams' N.F.L. Title Is No Gateway to Perennial Greatness
description: Kurt Warner had stayed up Sunday night reliving the pass. Yes, that pass. The one that gave his St. Louis Rams a 23-16 victory over the Tennessee Titans only hours before. The one that probably has Hollywood agents calling screenwriters for a script on Warner's hard-to-believe life.

description: A High Court judge issued a tough-worded judgment today supporting the British government's decision to release Gen. Augusto Pinochet and let him return home to Chile, but Belgium held up any final action by lodging an appeal against the ruling.

title: AmeriServe in Chapter 11
description: AmeriServe Food Distribution Inc. filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition today in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. The company, based in Addison, Tex., operates 39 distribution centers serving the fast-food industry and 12 distribution centers serving casual- dining restaurants. AmeriServe Food is owned by Holberg Industries, a privately held diversified service company that also has subsidiaries in the parking industry in North America.

title: Group Sues New Jersey Over State Law Limiting Truck Traffic
description: A group representing about 3,000 of the nation's largest trucking companies sued New Jersey in federal court yesterday, saying that a state regulation banning interstate trucks from local roads violates the Constitution's protection of interstate commerce and will lead to arbitrary traffic stops.

title: Power-Sharing Could Be Suspended, Ulster Unionist Warns
description: Northern Ireland's new power-sharing government could be indefinitely suspended if an imminent report on disarmament does not disclose moves by the Irish Republican Army to scrap its arsenal, the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble warned on Monday.

title: Review/Fashion; An Electric Moment For a Men's Designer

The audience for the sort of clothes shown on the men's runways is too small, and the designers who get the most attention, like Tom Ford, Miuccia Prada and Calvin Klein, do so largely because they already rule in the women's field.

title: Hormone Replacement: Weighing Risks and Benefits
description: ''Should I or shouldn't I?'' It's a question millions of women ask themselves these days, as baby boomers near or recently past menopause try to decide whether to take hormone replacement. Joining them are millions of older women, many of whom have been taking estrogen or a combination of estrogen and progestin for years and wonder if it is wise to continue, as well as many others who wonder if it is wise to start.

description: Showing that he intends to be more than a caretaker as New York City's interim schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy has warned the system's 32 district superintendents that he will evaluate them in June using a long list of criteria, like test scores and teacher recruitment tactics.

Fortis offered nine of its shares and 33 euros for each share of the bank, Luxembourg's second biggest. That values each Banque Generale share at 310.5 euros.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT TO SELL FINLAND BUSINESS
description: Waste Management Inc., the largest United States trash hauler, agreed to sell its business in Finland to Lassila & Tikanoja P.L.C., a Helsinki-based packaging and waste company, for about $100 million. The division had sales of $65.4 million last year. Waste Management said last week that it expected to get as much as $3 billion from selling its international operations and some of its North American assets. The Houston-based company will use the money to repay debt, buy back stock and make acquisitions.

title: DUPONT CONSIDERS ISSUING A TRACKING STOCK
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company is considering issuing a tracking stock for one or more of its nonchemical units, altering its original plan to issue shares reflecting the performance of its entire life science business. One option for the company, the top United States chemical maker, may be to issue shares that track its drug unit alone to reflect ''industry changes,'' the chief executive, Charles O. Holliday Jr., said at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Mr. Holliday's comments come after The Financial Times reported that DuPont was poised to abandon the plan. A tracking stock tracks the performance of a unit of a company and represents partial ownership of the parent.

title: A Second, and Quieter, Mingus Grouping

But a new Mingus repertory band with a slightly different sound cropped up in the beginning of January; it appears every Monday night in a pleasant downstairs theater at City Hall, a restaurant on Duane Street.

Or you can give up on talking entirely and lose yourself in the food.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Clinton administration's policy on Iraq misstated the circumstances under which international weapons inspectors left that country before American and British air strikes in December 1998. While Iraq had ceased cooperating with the inspectors, it did not expel them. The United Nations withdrew them before the air strikes began.

description: The four white police officers accused of murdering Amadou Diallo, who had contended that they could not get a fair trial in the Bronx, learned today who will decide their fate: four blacks and eight whites chosen after a barrage of objections that each side was trying to exclude jurors based on race.

title: March Forecast: Sadness for St. John's, Madness for Syracuse
description: Three minutes on the last day of January, the final three of a pretty good basketball game, have supplied the best clue about where two Big East teams appear headed in March. For undefeated Syracuse, 7 straight points meant an 18th consecutive victory and perhaps a journey into April and to Indianapolis, to the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Management; Creating Waves In Nonprofit Sea
description: Several years ago, a success story at the John G. Shedd Aquarium in Chicago came perilously close to morphing into a public relations disaster.

title: Sprint's Profit Rose 9.9% in Fourth Quarter
description: The Sprint Corporation, which is being bought by MCI WorldCom Inc., said that its fourth-quarter profit rose 9.9 percent, as revenue growth from its telephone operations more than offset spending to build a high-speed data network.

title: What a Delicious, er . . .
description: A FIFTH columnist has infiltrated the menus of Manhattan. It has a deceptively attractive name, so close to another French name that it passes almost unnoticed by most diners. Once on the plate, it has already undergone a metamorphosis, so its identity remains obscure. The time has come to unmask it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILANO, ROBERT J.
description: MILANO-Robert J., who passed away January 29 at the age of 87 was a self-made man with a passion for public service and educational opportunity for all Americans. Kind, generous, canny and tireless, he was a rare human being who inspired and energized every organization he served. The members of the Board of Trustees of New School University convey their heartfelt condolences to his wife, Sidonia, and son, Robert Scott. A memorial service will take place a New School University in March. We have lost a priceless friend. John L. Tishman, Chairman of the Board New School University Philip Scaturro, Chancellor Edward J. Blakely, Dean Robert J. Milano Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy

title: New Jersey Senate Race: Not Just Money
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman withdrew from the race for United States Senate last September, Representative Bob Franks, a two-time chairman of the Republican state committee who had spent years planning a statewide run, quickly entered the contest and tried to paint himself as the clear favorite, hoping to gain major endorsements early enough to scare away potential rivals.

title: Indonesian General Denies Guilt in Timor Abuses
description: Indonesia's most prominent general denied today that he was responsible for human rights abuses in East Timor and sidestepped a suggestion by President Abdurrahman Wahid that he resign.

title: Sports of The Times; Listen Up: Caution Is the Word
description: IT was a few days before Super Bowl XXXIV, and security officials from the National Football League were worried about another incident in which one of its players would be caught with his pants down, maybe literally, the week of the big game. So they lectured players from the two teams about staying out of trouble. The players were told to avoid strip clubs, to not drive drunk and to scalp game tickets at their own risk.

title: Bringing Ice Cream Out of the Cold
description: EVEN in the most frigid months, ice cream doesn't go into hibernation. A hot apple tart still comes with a scoop of vanilla. But pastry chefs do change their focus when eating ice cream becomes an indoor sport.

title: Lincoln Center Plans Busy Jazz Season
description: The 10th season of Jazz at Lincoln Center, beginning in September, will embrace more than 450 events worldwide, including extended touring residencies by the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra in France, Italy, Germany, the Czech Republic and England.

title: Before the Voting Was Over, Cable News Drops Hints
description: All day long, as the voters of New Hampshire pulled levers, the commentators on television dropped hints about the likely outcome.

title: South Carolina Seems to Be Bush Terrain
description: For a few savory hours, Senator John McCain will know the elation of victory as he flies out of New Hampshire tonight. But as soon as he lands at the airport here shortly after midnight on Wednesday, he will find that Gov. George W. Bush is already several laps ahead of him.

title: In Austria, Shadows and Worries
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You can't help but be amazed by the size of this. It's across the board, came from all sectors.''

description: To the Editor:

title: As Inquiry Into Carving by Doctor Goes On, Hospital Official Quits
description: The chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at Beth Israel Medical Center resigned from his post yesterday amid inquiries involving a doctor who was suspended in September for carving his initials into a patient's belly, the hospital said.

title: Belichick Adds 2 Ex-Jets Coaches
description: Patriots Coach Bill Belichick officially added two former Jets assistants to his staff, naming Charlie Weis his offensive coordinator and Eric Mangini as a defensive assistant.

title: United We Stand': Exploring the European Union
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Investigators Describe Worsening Control Failure on Doomed Alaska Airlines Jet
description: The Alaska Airlines jet that plunged into the Pacific Ocean while trying to make an emergency landing at Los Angeles on Monday appears to have suffered a progressive failure of its control system, disappearing from radar about 11 minutes after the crew first advised air traffic controllers of a problem, according to a sketchy chronology given by the senior air safety investigator here this afternoon.

title: Chief of Intelligence Defends Role in Inquiry of Ex-Director
description: The director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, said today that he had taken ''decisive action'' last year after receiving the results of an investigation by the C.I.A.'s inspector general into evidence that a former agency director, John M. Deutch, had mishandled classified documents.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: A Suitable Sweetie For a Frog Prince

title: Joint Effort to Reclaim City Parks and Young Lives
description: This is a story about recycling.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREAVES, JEMIMA K.
description: GREAVES-Jemima K. Passed January 31, 1995. ''Alive in our hearts always''. Son Reynold and family

title: When Children Become Parents of Their Parents
description: EQUAL LOVE

title: The Case of John Deutch
description: John Deutch was an effective and enlightened head of the Central Intelligence Agency. But his handling of classified information was sloppy, and he was stripped of his high security clearances last August, more than two years after he returned to a teaching post at M.I.T. Now it is disturbing to learn that Mr. Deutch's former colleagues at the C.I.A. may have tried to shield their former boss from an immediate and exacting investigation when they first learned of his misconduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHER, ANNE SHERLIN
description: ASHER-Anne Sherlin. Died peacefully January 30, 2000. Age 94. Wife of the late Max Asher and mother of the late Elizabeth Josephson. Survived by daughters, Susan Picard, and Ellen Asher, and by six grandchildren and one great grandchild.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, EMILY CLARKSON
description: FULLER-Emily Clarkson Hurry. Age 89 passed away quietly after a long illness, on January 30, 2000 at home in Oyster Bay, New York. Beloved wife of the late Stephen Dow Fuller, devoted mother of Emily Fuller Kingston of New York City, Ann B. Fuller of Big Horn, Wyoming, and Stephen W. Fuller of Joplin, Missouri. Six grandchildren, Samuel Kingston, Sage and Aeron Daly, Cary, Jane and Emily Fuller also survived her. She attended Skidmore College, was a member of the National Society of Colonial Dames, The Descendants of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence, The Daughters of the Cincinnati, and for many years, a member of the Colony Club of New York. The funeral service will be Thursday, February 3 at Christ Episcopal Church, East Main Street, Oyster Bay, New York. Friends may call at the Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South Street, Oyster Bay. For hours call 516-922-7442. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Mrs. Fuller may be sent to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590.

title: Baseball's Speech Police
description: Despite the common myth that we can say anything we please in this country, the fact is that our Bill of Rights does not grant Americans any general right of free speech.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Where the Beef Is

title: Bush Is Brand of Republican South Carolina Favors
description: For a few savory hours, Senator John McCain will know the elation of victory as he flies out of New Hampshire tonight. But as soon as he lands at the airport here shortly after midnight on Wednesday, he will find that Gov. George W. Bush is already several laps ahead of him.

title: Consecrations of U.S. Bishops by Episcopal Officials Overseas Challenge Church Hierarchy
description: In a highly unusual challenge to the Episcopal Church's leadership, the top officials of two Anglican church provinces overseas, in Africa and Asia, have consecrated two conservative American priests as bishops to minister to Episcopalians who feel alienated from the denomination in the United States.

title: Winter Meltdown: Real Hot Chocolate, Secret No More
description: I AM willing to bet that very few people have whiled away hours thinking about hot chocolate. Why should anyone?

title: HOUSE APPROVES EXPANSION OF TIES TO TAIWAN'S ARMY
description: The House voted overwhelmingly today to expand military ties between Taiwan and the United States, a move that China and the Clinton administration warned could aggravate regional tensions and jeopardize a landmark trade agreement.

title: Auditing Rules For Accountants
description: The accounting industry, reeling from the disclosure that most partners at PricewaterhouseCoopers had violated rules barring them from investments related to audit clients, announced a new effort yesterday aimed at monitoring compliance with the existing rules.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: U.S. Will Reconsider Ties If Haider Joins Coalition
description: White House officials said today that the United States would consider joining the European Union in diplomatically isolating Austria now that the Freedom Party, which espouses an anti-immigrant platform, and the People's Party have agreed to form a coalition government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, HERBERT I.
description: SCHILLER-Herbert I. Beloved husband of Anita, magnetic father of Dan and Zach, visionary grandfather of Lucy and Ethan, fierce and witty foe of injustice. Memorial tribute at 11:00 AM, Sunday, February 13, at La Jolla Woman's Club, La Jolla, California.

title: AIDS Virus Originated Around 1930, Study Says
description: Using a new statistical method and one of the world's most powerful computers, scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory said today that they had traced the origin of the AIDS epidemic to around 1930, nearly 30 years before the earliest known infection in humans.

title: VerticalNet, British Telecom, Internet Capital Group Form European Alliance
description: February 1, 2000

title: OKLAHOMA COMPANY BUYING DYNEGY NATURAL GAS ASSETS
description: The natural gas company Oneok Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Dynegy Inc.'s gathering systems, processing facilities and transmission pipelines in Oklahoma, Kansas and the Texas Panhandle for $308 million. The assets include Dynegy's eight gas processing plants, interests in two other plants and about 7,000 miles of gas gathering and intrastate pipeline systems. Oneok, based in Tulsa, Okla., said the acquisition would complement its existing natural gas assets. The stock of Houston-based Dynegy rose $1.25 a share, to $32.25.

title: TWO BIDS FOR NIPPON BANK
description: Michio Ochi, the cabinet minister who heads the Financial Reconstruction Commission, said the government had received two bids for the bankrupt Nippon Credit Bank. While Mr. Ochi did not identify the bidders, bankers said Cerberus, a United States investment fund that specializes in purchasing distressed assets, and a consortium led by Softbank, the Japanese technology financing company, had submitted formal bids. Lehman Brothers and Paribas also considered making offers but did not submit bids, bankers said. Mr. Ochi said the outcome of the sale should be known by mid-February. Stephanie Strom

title: As School Spending Rises, Less Is Going Into Classrooms
description: New York City public schools spent 7.5 percent more per pupil last year than the year before, but the portion allocated to classroom instruction declined while a higher percentage went to services such as wiring schools for computers and building maintenance, the Board of Education reported yesterday.

title: Giuliani Outlines Some Foreign Policy Views, From Austria to the West Bank
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who was criticized for sharing a dais last month with the controversial Austrian politician Jorg Haider, expressed support yesterday for the European Union's efforts to prevent Mr. Haider's anti-immigrant political party from joining the Austrian government.

title: Solemn Time Precedes Popular Event
description: Payne Stewart would have celebrated his 43rd birthday last Sunday. And this week, he would have tried to defend his championship at the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

title: O'Connor Flying to Rome To Meet With the Pope
description: Cardinal John O'Connor will fly to Rome today for a brief visit with Pope John Paul II that church officials say will be largely personal.

title: Alan Pryce-Jones, 91, Editor And Eminent Man of Letters
description: Alan Pryce-Jones, a London-born book critic, author and journalist who was editor of The Times Literary Supplement, the prestigious British weekly, for a decade, died on Jan. 22 in Galveston, Tex. He was 91 and lived in Newport, R.I.

title: New Pressure for Gun Control
description: President Clinton has moved the nation's gun control debate an important step forward with his State of the Union proposal for a national system of photo licensing and safety testing for handgun buyers. The proposal puts fresh political pressures on an indifferent Republican Congress, which has yet to approve the more modest gun control measures the administration called for last spring following the Colorado school shootings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVA, PHYLLIS (NEE RUDNER)
description: KAVA-Phyllis (nee Rudner), 67, died January 31st, 2000. Donations may be made to the Columbia Presbyterian Renal Transplantation Program. Graveside service today at Sharon Gardens, 10:30. For information Zion Memorial Chapel, 1-888-381-1809.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFINGS: AMERICAS; AIRLINE WORKERS PROTEST
description: Employees at Mexico's third largest airline, Taesa, blocked two principal thoroughfares in Mexico City during a protest march to demand a government rescue of the company, after the airline's executives temporarily suspended labor relations with its 3,700 employees. Although company employees were told not return to work until further notice, Taesa executives insisted that no workers would be laid off and insisted the airline was not on the brink of bankruptcy. Dan Fineren

title: Raines Gets a Shot At Resuming Career
description: Soon after doctors began treating him for lupus, Tim Raines shook hands with George Steinbrenner at Yankee Stadium and assured him that he would come back to baseball and do so with the Yankees. As what? Steinbrenner replied. A coach?

title: GAZPROM MONOPOLY IS THREATENED
description: The world's No. 1 natural gas company, Gazprom, should split transport and gas production assets and give up its monopoly, Russia's energy minister said. Russia's government, owner of 38 percent of Gazprom, wants a company that provides independent producers with access to pipelines, the Fuel and Energy Minister, Viktor Kalyuzhny, said. Rem Vyakhirev, left, chief executive of Gazprom since 1992 and opposed to such a shift, has offered only to break off service units.

title: Chechen Rebels Announce Retreat From Battered Capital
description: Separatist rebels announced today that they were abandoning the Chechen capital and would carry out attacks on Russian forces from the mountains and countryside of the breakaway republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDER, ROSALIND W.
description: LINDER-Rosalind W. Of North Lynbrook, N.Y. and Royal Palm Beach, Fla. Loving wife of the late Dr. David O. Linder. Beloved mother of Hope and Jack File. She enjoyed a long career as an educator of distinction. Family and friends deeply mourn the loss of this special lady.

title: Austria's Uglier Voice
description: Three years ago, on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of Austria's liberation from Nazism, an extraordinary rally took place on the Heldenplatz in central Vienna. Beneath the balcony from which Adolf Hitler had once harangued his roaring gang, Austrian artists, intellectuals and politicians, as well as their friends and supporters from elsewhere, united to celebrate Hitler's downfall, and by doing so to cleanse the old square of its association with evil.

title: And So Just What Good Were the Good Old Days?
description: It's only right for governors, presidential candidates and mayors to demand that schools improve. In a democracy, elected leaders should hold public schools accountable. But if politicians don't properly inform themselves about complex educational problems, they risk making decisions by cliche.

title: Reckonings; Trillions and Trillions
description: An old classmate of mine, who went on to become a Latin American finance minister, once brought his technical experts to a meeting with a U.S. Treasury official. The official was furious. ''Get your [expletive] numbers guys out of here,'' he yelled -- which was how the U.S.-educated technical team subsequently referred to themselves.
