description: In percent

title: Business Travel; No-nonsense weather forecasts are vital for those on the road, as the last week has demonstrated.
description: WICHITA, Oklahoma City, Dallas, Shreveport, Little Rock, Memphis; Birmingham, Atlanta and up the eastern corridor to Washington, Philadelphia, New York City and into southern New England and Boston.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIN, JOEL
description: MARGOLIN-Joel. With extreme sadness and a tremendous sense of loss, we mourn the passing of our very dear friend. He will live forever in our hearts. Our deepest sympathy to Elisa, Wayne, Evan and Elise. The Lichtenstein Family

title: People
description: * Steven R. Isaac was named chief executive at DMW Worldwide, New York and Wayne, Pa., part of the Dimac Marketing Corp., succeeding Tom McClure, who retired. Mr. Isaac had been executive vice president at the Cadmus Communications Corp., Richmond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, JEAN DECKINGER
description: MORRIS-Jean Deckinger. 90, of Flushing, NY, died February 1, 2000 at New York Hospital. Beloved wife of the late Florian, loving mother of Miriam Lastoria and husband, Michael, aunt of Susan, Alan, and Shea Meyers. She will be fondly remembered and missed by family and friends. Memorial service Thursday February 3, 2000, 10:30 A.M. at Parkside, 9860 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, followed by interment at Mount Hope Cemetery.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mannesmann and Vodafone Are Said to Be Negotiating
description: Klaus Esser, the besieged chief executive of Mannesmann, discussed the possibility of a friendly merger today with Chris Gent, the head of Vodafone AirTouch, people close to the talks said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARDOS, LESLIE, (LASZLO), MD
description: BARDOS-Leslie, (Laszlo), MD, died peacefully at home on January 30, at age 91. Born in Hungary, received medical diplomas from Szeged, Hungary and Vienna, Austria. Practiced internal medicine in Manhattan. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Susan Bardos, his daugher, Judith Lichtmann, son-in-law, Dr.Albert L.Lichtmann, grandchildren Katherine (Kitty) and Evan Dockser, Vivian and Eric Keller; great-children Samantha, Drew, Julia and Benjamin.

title: Kmart to Sell Its Stock on Its BlueLight.com Web Site
description: February 01, 2000

title: In a Changing City, New York Character
description: MANHATTAN has at least 30 shops that have a superb selection of cheeses. It has only one Di Palo's.

title: Metro Business; For Sale on Fifth Avenue
description: Rodamco, a Dutch real estate company, is putting a retail and office building at Fifth Avenue and Central Park South up for sale, people with knowledge of the company's plans said.

title: When Going Gets Tough, Nets Are Turning Soft
description: It was just three weeks ago that a jovial group of Nets celebrated on Miami's new home floor. They had used a late free throw and smothering defense on Alonzo Mourning to outlast one of the Eastern Conference's best teams, 90-89, and the overall feeling of the players was that they had finally arrived.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD TO SPIN OFF MARKET INFORMATION UNIT
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced yesterday that it was spinning off DeepCanyon, a company that runs a Web site providing information to marketers. The new company, to be based in Seattle, aims its services at small and midsize companies that might not be able to afford market research firms. Membership provides access to the opinions of industry leaders and market analysts and to an e-mail service alerting companies to the activities of competitors. DeepCanyon has signed Lisa Wellman, a former Apple executive, as its chief executive.

title: That Sink Is Familiar
description: To the Editor:

title: Des Renford, 72, Channel Swimmer, Is Dead
description: Des Renford, who began marathon swimming at the age of 39 and went on to swim the English Channel in each of his 19 attempts, died of a heart attack on Dec. 31 while swimming in his local pool in Sydney, Australia. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVERA HEALY, CECILIA
description: RIVERA HEALY-Cecilia. Her friendship has been a gift. Always in our hearts. Ovarian Cancer Continuation Support Group, SHARE, NYC.

title: Thais Being Asked to Dig Out Savings and Buy Bonds
description: Blinking behind crooked, wire-rimmed spectacles, Niteya Saraikan, a 65-year-old retiree, listened patiently as a central bank employee explained how to fill out the forms needed for her to help Thailand finance the rescue of its banking system and return to economic health.

title: The Knicks' Ewing for the Wizards' Howard? Let the Talks (or Rumors) Fly
description: The Knicks' continuing dialogue with the Washington Wizards concerning trade options has gone beyond point guard Rod Strickland and now includes an exploratory discussion concerning the possibility of an exchange of Juwan Howard for Patrick Ewing, two Eastern Conference officials said yesterday.

title: Intensity With a Debt to Vermeer and Vermont
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra is brave, though it almost seems redundant to say so. The group has always played without conductor, after all, despite taking on the most challenging repertory.

title: Long Island Wine Estate Is Sold for $5 Million
description: In a deal likely to ratchet up the status of the young Long Island wine industry, Bedell Cellars, which has acquired a worldwide reputation as the region's leading producer of merlot, was sold on Monday for $5 million.

title: Judge Overrules F.C.C. on Wireless Licenses
description: A United States bankruptcy judge has nullified a decision by the Federal Communications Commission that would have canceled 90 wireless telephone licenses claimed by NextWave Telecom Inc.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS AGAIN. The euro hit its lowest level ever against the dollar in New York, at 96.65 cents, but rose slightly late in the day. The euro finished at 97.28 cents, down about 16 percent since its introduction in January 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, SAMUEL J.
description: SILBERMAN-Samuel J. The Alumni Association of the Hunter College School of Social Work offers its sincere condolences to the family of Samuel Silberman. His enormously generous support in establishing and maintaining the School has enabled thousands of persons to be trained in the profession and has had a beneficial impact on the people whom we serve. We are deeply grateful. The Board and Members of The Alumni Association Hunter College, School of Social Work

title: Metro Business; Rising Tower Adds Tenant in Times Sq.
description: Bain & Company, a management consulting firm, has leased 50,000 square feet of space in the Reuters Building, the 30-story office tower under construction in Times Square.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, JEROME
description: GLICKMAN-Jerome. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear brother and uncle. Jerry, we love you and you will live in our hearts forever. Rhoda & Len Frischer Peggy, Steve & Erin Schwartz Julie, Paul, Kate & Jack Frischer

title: At the S.E.C.'s Request, Aetna Is Restating Earnings for 7 Quarters
description: Aetna, the nation's biggest health insurer, said yesterday that it was restating earnings for seven quarters of 1998 and 1999 at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Paramedics Divert Patients, Hospital Says
description: The New York Fire Department has suspended two paramedics without pay and is investigating several others after a Bronx hospital complained that ambulance crews were steering patients away because of a labor dispute.

title: McCAIN ROMPS IN FIRST PRIMARY; GORE WINS, EDGING OUT BRADLEY
description: Senator John McCain swamped Gov. George W. Bush Tuesday in the New Hampshire Republican primary, piling up the widest margin here since Ronald Reagan defeated Mr. Bush's father 20 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELCH, MILDRED E. (NEE) SILVER
description: WELCH-Mildred E. (nee) Silver. Died January 31, 2000. Beloved wife of James for 57 years, loving mother of Janet, Lauren and John, cherished grandmother of James Jan. She was born in Boston, MA (West End), March 29, 1916, where she spent the happiest years of her childhood. She married her husband, James, in 1942 and following World War II moved to New York City. Along with her husband, James, a gifted trombonist, they enjoyed Manhattan life, especially the finest pastry shops the city has to offer. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (81 St), Saturday, February 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. She will be laid to rest near her beloved mother and sister, Eva, on Sunday, February 6 at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. (781-828-7216)

title: Seeking to Keep Tight Control of Senate, G.O.P. Leaders Shift to Center
description: Seeking to protect the slim majority that they hold in the State Senate, Republican leaders have been steering their house toward a more moderate course on several important issues, from health care and abortion rights to lobbying reform.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTWELL, MARY (LESCHER)
description: CANTWELL-Mary (Lescher). On Tuesday, February 1. Beloved mother of Katherine and Margaret Lescher, loving mother-in-law of Jonathan Samuels, adoring grandmother of Anna Hope. Sister of Diana, daughter of Mary, niece of Esther. Gifted writer. Services St Joseph's Church, 371 Ave of the Americas, NYC, Friday, February 4, 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St Vincent's Supportive Care Program, 153 West 11 Street, NYC 10011.

title: Candid Schools Chief Asks for State Money
description: In his first appearance before the Legislature as New York City's interim schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy displayed an easy confidence with lawmakers today as he asked for more money for the city's beleaguered public schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKEY, JOSEPH L.
description: LARKEY-Joseph L. On Monday January 31, 2000, Joseph of Tewksbury Township, NJ formerly of Livingston, NJ. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Wolfson) Larkey. Loving father of Cheryl Larkey, Lisa Martins, Adam Larkey, Dean Larkey, and Nicole Witchendahl. Dear father-in-law of Clario Martins, Ann Larkey, and Robert Witchendahl. Dear brother of Michael Larkey, and Linda Levitt. Devoted son of Leonard Larkey. Loving grandfather of four. Funeral services 11:30 am on Weds February 2, 2000 at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Qualcomm Jumps on China Deal
description: February 1, 2000

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: George McT. Kahin, 82, Dies; Was Expert on Southeast Asia
description: George McTurnan Kahin, an authority on Southeast Asia who was an influential critic of Washington's policy during the Vietnam War, died on Saturday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 82 and lived in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: G.O.P. Shifts to Center
description: Seeking to protect the slim majority that they hold in the State Senate, Republican leaders have been steering their house in a moderate direction on several issues, from health care and abortion rights to lobbying reform. The maneuvering has surprised and angered many conservatives within the party and has placed Senate leaders in direct conflict with Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Following The Films, Not the Cash, At Sundance
description: Each year at the Sundance Film Festival, you sigh and prepare yourself for the snap assessment: it's ''the year of the . . . ,'' which generally refers to the impact that a few of the pictures make. (Almost no one sees enough of the roster to grasp the year's programming trend. I scrambled to see 16 films in three days last week, most of them dramatic.)

title: History, Unprotected
description: To the Editor:

title: Ayutthaya Journal; Glory That Was Asian Art (Made, Perhaps, Today)
description: The best stone carvers here are the artistic descendants of the craftsmen who built the great temples of Asia, shaping images of Buddha and Shiva with age-old skill and passion.

title: SOUTHERN CO. IN TALKS WITH UTILITY IN VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: The Southern Company said yesterday that it was in talks to buy 80 percent of the Virgin Islands Water and Power Authority for about $100 million. The Virgin Islands' government will retain the other 20 percent of the utility, said Marce Fuller, chief executive of the company's Southern Energy unit. Southern expects to reach a purchase agreement this quarter. The Atlanta-based company owns electric utilities in Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi and Florida.

title: Coalition Deal by Austria Defies Europe
description: Defying threats of diplomatic isolation by the European Union and now the United States, the Freedom Party of Jorg Haider and the People's Party announced tonight that they would form a government.

title: A Beginning, Not an End
description: It was not a great night for the dauphins of 2000, though worse for George W. Bush than for Al Gore, and the results suggested strongly that both parties now face long, costly struggles for their presidential nominations. As they have so often before, the voters of New Hampshire upset the apple cart of conventional wisdom, throwing both races into doubt.

title: Editors' Note
description: A report in the Funds Watch column of Money & Business on Sunday examined the performance of a closed-end fund, Engex, with a share price that has almost tripled in the last three months because of its large holdings in a single biotechnology company, Enzo Biochem.

title: Liberties; Rebel With a Cause
description: John McCain has been on a wild ride. Now he's going to drag the Republican Party on one.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Sprint Pays Top Dollar To Be Where It Wants
description: When new owners bought the 56,500-square-foot Gotham retail condominium at 86th Street and Third Avenue last August, they knew that the annual market rent for space on 86th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues was about $150 a square foot.

title: Clinton Views Economy With Careful Pride and Calm Concern
description: President Clinton said today that he was concerned about the nation's rapidly growing trade deficit and about the debt loads being carried by individuals and businesses, but he said his worry was tempered by the strength the economy derives from the federal budget surplus.

title: Pentagon Orders Training to Prevent Harassment of Gays
description: Every member of the armed forces, from four-star generals to privates, will undergo training by the end of the year to prevent anti-gay harassment, the Pentagon announced today in a sweeping admission that its ''don't ask, don't tell, don't harass'' policy is poorly understood in the ranks.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, MARGARET
description: ANDREWS-Margaret. On January 31, 2000. Survived by her son Neal of Mechanicville, N.Y., daughter Leslie of Seattle, Wa., brother Robert Cherry of Tucson, Az., and also many friends. A celebration of her life will be held at the All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave(80th St) NYC, Thursday, February 3rd. at 11am. Reception to follow. For further information please contact the John Krtil Funeral Home; Yorkville Funeral Service, Inc. 212-744-3084. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in her memory to the American Cancer Society or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: NBCi to Acquire AllBusiness.com for $225 Million in Stock
description: NBCi to Acquire AllBusiness.com for $225 Million in Stock

title: Health Web Sites Fail to Keep Personal Data Private, Study Finds
description: Internet health sites collect some of the most personal information about their users, but few follow their own declared policies about maintaining the privacy of that data, according to a survey made public today.

title: To Understand Lyrics
description: To the Editor:

title: Croquettes by Way of Tokyo
description: WITH several bustling Japanese restaurants, a sake bar, a Japanese bakery and a Japanese hairstylist, the little triangle formed by East Ninth Street and Stuyvesant Street, between Second and Third Avenues, comes as close to Tokyo as anywhere in New York. The latest Japanese business to open on this block, OTAFUKU , is the most unusual and interesting place yet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCILKEN, MARVIN H.
description: SCILKEN-Marvin H. 1926-1999 Midwinter brought remembrance and praise; the stars shine on. We love and miss you every day. Polly and Jon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, RENEE
description: ROSENBLATT-Renee Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member Renee Rosenblatt. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to her family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Alisa Doctoroff, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, ELLIOTT W.
description: WILLIAMS-Elliott W. died suddenly on Wednesday, January 26, in Los Angeles, CA. He is survived by his mother Dolores Williams; three sisters Wandra WilliamsPerkins, Denise and Teri Williams and a host of relatives and friends. Visitation at Holy Redeemer Church Friday, February 4th from 7-9 PM and Mass of Christian burial on Saturday, February 5th at 11 AM at the Church, 206 New York Avenue, NW, Wash, DC.

title: Several Media Companies Form Web Site Partnership
description: In a move that allies a media-watchdog magazine with several of the major industry players that it covers, Brill Media Holdings -- the company that publishes Brill's Content magazine -- has agreed to form a partnership with CBS, NBC, Primedia, Ingram Book Group and EBSCO, a company that provides magazine subscription services and databases of already-published magazine content.

title: Alaska Airlines Plane Took a Nosedive : 88 Feared Dead as Jet Crashes Off California
description: WASHINGTON  The U.S. Coast Guard, Air Force and Navy continued an extensive search off the California coast Tuesday after an Alaskan Airlines jet airliner with 88 people aboard plummeted nose-first into deep waters northwest of Los Angeles.

title: Folk-Hero Myth Enveloped Indian Fugitive in Slayings
description: For more than a year, the police combed dense forests and remote backwaters in search of India's most wanted fugitive -- the man suspected of killing an Australian missionary and his two young sons.

title: Sports of The Times; Vermeil Not First To Rejoice And Retire
description: IT seems that it was only yesterday -- actually, it was two days ago -- when Dick Vermeil was still the coach of the Super Bowl champion St. Louis Rams.

title: Rules that Sidelined Athletes As Freshmen Are Repealed
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has redefined what constitutes an acceptable high school course for incoming college athletes, ending more than four years of battle with parents and school officials who complained that the course parameters were arbitrary and often irrelevant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, ETTA
description: JACOBS-Etta, 90, of Brooklyn, NY on January 31, 2000. Loving wife of the late Henry. Cherished mother of Miriam Ravad, David Jacobs and his wife Melinda, and Ellen. Devoted sister, aunt. Grandmother of Guy, Sharon, Dina, Seth and Andy, great-grandmother of Evan. A woman of faith, generosity and courage. Contributions: Avenue N. Jewish Community Center, 321 Avenue N, Brooklyn, New York 11230 or the Alzheimer's Association of New York.

title: Despite a 'Troubling' Setback, Bush Remains Confident
description: Gov. George W. Bush and his advisers were never under any illusions.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Assemblyman Pledges State Aid to Put Sprinklers in All College Dorms
description: The chairman of the State Assembly's Committee on Housing said today that the Legislature would help pay to install sprinklers in every New Jersey college dormitory that does not have them, although he predicted that the total cost could run as high as $300 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COCKBURN, SARAH
description: COCKBURN-Sarah Caudwell, MA (Aberdeen), BA, BCL (Oxon) daughter of Jean Ross Cockburn and Claud Cockburn, lawyer, Banker and crime writer. Beloved niece of Billee, beloved of her family and friends and, indeed, beloved of all who had the privilege to know her, has died aged 60, on January 28th at her home in Whitehall. A thanksgiving party in celebration of Sarah's wonderful life and marvellous books, which have enlarged the happiness of all her readers, will be held on Friday, 31 March, at the Reform Club, London, England. Funeral Private, no flowers, but any donations if desired to Oxfam.

title: A Flutist Makes a Challenge, And a Climax Goes Uncrashed
description: Thrilling occasions in contemporary music are bound to be rare. Monday evening brought one of them when the Columbia Sinfonietta, a new label for the cohort of tireless virtuoso musicians who give a hearing to recent music, presented the first New York performance of the opening three parts of ''Les Espaces Acoustiques'' by Gerard Grisey, who died over a year ago at 52. The players clearly knew they had something important on their music stands in Merkin Concert Hall. Their approach was intense, committed, direct. And a very remarkable work was revealed, or half-revealed: the cycle has three further parts, and some day they should all be played here.

title: Who Should Spend
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Technology Issues Surge on Debut Day
description: Shares of Turnstone Systems Inc., Sequenom Inc., and Quantum Effect Devices Inc. soared in their first trading day yesterday.

title: Long-Term Lyme Disease Study Is Encouraging About Symptoms
description: In the largest study of the long-term effects of Lyme disease, patients who received conventional treatment report no greater level of health problems years later than those who never had the disease, researchers said yesterday.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Founder Leaving School Group for Startup

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, HARRY A.
description: FRANKLIN-Harry A. Beloved husband of the late Tillie and treasured father to Roger and Alfred. Family and friends mourn the loss of this special man. Services 12:30 PM, Wednesday, February 2, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: In Austria, Shadows and Worries
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTEL, JOEL
description: MARTEL-Joel, 53, Jewish activist. Harvard Law Review, lawyer, former N.Y. Law professor. Service today, 7:30 P.M., 53 Charles St.

title: Who Will Judge Elian's Mind-Set?
description: To the Editor:

title: NYT Article
description: Hewlett-Packard Spins Off DeepCanyon

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a warning by the European Union that it would isolate Austria diplomatically if an anti-immigrant party entered the Austrian government referred incorrectly to the conservatives in France who are engulfed in scandals, which were cited as another example of political turmoil in Europe. They are Gaullists, not Christian Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JIMENEZ, VICTOR A.
description: JIMENEZ-Victor A. A resident of Park Slope for more than 25 years, a marine engineer and veteran of World War II, died at his home on January 29, 2000. He was 99. The cause was heart failure, his family said. He served as an engineer during the war in the Pacific and the Atlantic and was honorably discharged in 1945, but continued working on the ships until he retired in 1966. He is survived by his wife, Etelvina of 53 years, five daughters, Ethel Zogg, Mary Ann Kratz, Victoria McKenna, Helen Jimenez Ulloa, and Virginia Augello. He will be cremated and his ashes inurned at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, Water Street.

title: Acting Editor, Specialist in Business Coverage, Is Made Permanent at The Post
description: The New York Post, which has built its rowdy reputation on front-page coverage of crime (''Headless Body in Topless Bar''), sports (''Bellichicken'') and politics (''Shame on Hillary'') is naming as its editor a journalist who has spent her entire career covering business (as in ''You've Got Deal'').

title: An Infection Kills a New Jersey Woman's Unborn Septuplets
description: Less than a week after a 31-year-old woman joyously announced to the world that she was pregnant with septuplets, all seven fetuses died on Monday because of an infection in her uterus, her doctors said today.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN
description: Ballot Rules Overturned

title: Alfred R. Zipf, 82, Pioneer in Electronic Banking
description: Alfred R. Zipf, a pioneer in computer technology and electronic banking and a former executive at the Bank of America, died on Jan. 1 in Oroville, Calif. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOARDMAN, DR. MARTIN V.
description: BOARDMAN-Dr. Martin V. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the untimely passing of their fellow member Dr. Martin V. Boardman, Secretary Emeritus, and offer their deepest sympathy to his wife, Pearl, his children and the entire Boardman family. Alpine Country Club Harvey Nagin, President

title: Friends Calling Lewis A Loyal Hard Worker
description: Ray Lewis entered the National Football League in 1996 intent on separating himself from the average linebacker. His desire was to become a great linebacker, one always mentioned among the game's best. With a 6-foot-1-inch, 240-pound body, with imposing muscles and strength, with speed and a flair for making big plays from the first whistle to the last, Lewis was well on his way to a distinguished pro football career.

title: British, Irish and Americans Scramble to Save Ulster Power-Sharing
description: Britain, Ireland and the United States struggled tonight to preserve the power-sharing government in Belfast after the leader of that two-month-old government said shutting it down had become ''inevitable.''

title: Pork and Seafood: Opposites Attract
description: ALTHOUGH the American concept of surf and turf is hopelessly old-fashioned, it retains an odd appeal. Having seafood and meat on the same plate lets you alternate bites and flavors from two realms.

title: NBC INTERNET AGREES TO BUY ALLBUSINESS.COM
description: NBC Internet Inc., an online company 47 percent owned by the NBC unit of the General Electric Company, agreed to buy AllBusiness.com for about $225 million in stock. The closely held AllBusiness.com offers products and information aimed at owners of small businesses and people who are starting a business. The company, founded in 1998 and based in San Francisco, has more than 100 employees. The acquisition is NBCi's largest since it was formed late last year and furthers the company's plan to expand into business-to-business services on the Internet.

title: Concentrating On One State Was the Key For McCain
description: Senator John McCain's great gamble paid off tonight.

title: ASPECT COMMUNICATIONS TO ACQUIRE SOFTWARE PRODUCER
description: The Aspect Communications Corporation, a maker of online customer-service software, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held PakNetX Corporation for $55 million. PakNetX, based in Salem, N.H., will help Aspect make software that integrates video, voice and conferences over the Internet, the company said. Shares of Aspect, based in San Jose, Calif., rose $6.03125, to $54.90625. News of the acquisition was released after the close of trading in New York.

title: Fate Leads An Airline To Grieve For Itself
description: Every major airline has meticulous plans for responding when the awful news comes that one of its planes has gone down. And within moments of hearing that Flight 261 had plunged into the Pacific northwest of Los Angeles, Seattle-based Alaska Airlines called in grief counselors and put its ''critical incident response team'' to work, ready to console the relatives and friends of the missing passengers.

title: Ravens' Lewis Remains in Custody on Charges of Murder
description: Ray Lewis -- the Baltimore Ravens linebacker who was supposed to be in Hawaii for the Pro Bowl this week -- remained in custody in an Atlanta jail yesterday on charges of first-degree murder. The charges stem from a double homicide that occurred near an Atlanta nightclub early Monday morning, just hours after the Super Bowl ended.

title: Nothing Gaudy but Sales Figures; No-Frills Queens Center Outshines Most Luxury Malls
description: There is no marble, no chandeliers, no gourmet food court or Neiman Marcus at the Queens Center Mall, an aging shopping plaza where the landscaping consists of fake ficus trees and the atrium is highlighted with neon lights and a giant plastic Bugs Bunny statue.

title: INDIA RELAXES INVESTMENT BARRIERS
description: The Indian government widened the scope of industries that can accept foreign investment without a special license, as part of a broader effort to stimulate economic growth. Under a directive announced by Pramod Mahjan, the parliamentary affairs minister, foreign investment will be allowed without a license in all major business sectors except for alcohol, cigarettes, aerospace electronics and industrial explosives. P. J. Anthony

title: Agency Failed to Monitor Patients in Gene Research
description: Officials at the National Institutes of Health said yesterday that they had failed to keep track of how patients fared during gene therapy experiments and had outlined steps to ensure that scientists followed rules requiring them to report information about harmful side effects.

title: William Eckart, 79; Designed Sets on Broadway
description: William Eckart, a scenic designer whose innovative sets and costumes enlivened many Broadway productions during the 1950's and 60's, died on Jan. 24 in Dallas, where he lived. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISCHLER, STANLEY, M.D.
description: TISCHLER-Stanley, M.D. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Stan. Our thoughts and prayers go out to Randi, Henry, Fran, Michael, Alicia, Heather, Harris and Eric. the Evans Family

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; CMS, a utility company formerly loved on Wall Street, cuts its dividend and faces disdain.
description: HAVING almost gone broke in the 1980's back home in Michigan, CMS Energy -- the parent of Consumers' Power -- wowed Wall Street in the 1990's by going global and expanding into almost every part of the energy industry.

title: NOKIA PLANS STOCK SPLIT
description: The world's largest cellular phone maker, Nokia, said it planned a stock split of four shares for one as it reported its fourth-quarter profit rose 46 percent. Net income rose to 853 million euros, or $827 million, from 585 million euros in the corresponding period a year ago. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: CALENDAR
description: Grilled Cheese With an Accent

title: For Now, a Real Campaign
description: Senator John McCain's big victory in New Hampshire's Republican presidential primary and Vice President Al Gore's narrow triumph on the Democratic side send a powerful message. Voters are not ready to anoint, at least for now, the candidates picked by each party's establishment. As a result of this rebuff to the entitlement strategies of Mr. Gore and Gov. George W. Bush, Americans may get to witness one of the more competitive nomination battles in memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADE, ROBERT P.
description: WADE-Robert P. On January 31. Beloved husband of Deborah E. Cohen, devoted father of Aryeh Cohen-Wade and Samuel J. Cohen-Wade. Former Public Relations Director for American Friends of Hebrew University. Services Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ, Wednesday noon. Memorial donations to American Friends of Hebrew University, 11 East 69 Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: Judge Backs Forbes in Fight Over Primary
description: Describing the rules for New York's Republican presidential primary as infuriatingly unfair, a federal judge yesterday forced the party on Long Island to drop its attempt to toss Steve Forbes from the ballot and suggested that he would allow Senator John McCain to qualify across the state.

title: Henning Puts Jets' Offensive Staff in Place
description: Dan Henning was officially elevated to the Jets' offensive coordinator's position yesterday with a simple mandate from the team's new head coach, Al Groh.

title: Knicks Are Less Than Stellar in Loss to Magic
description: There was the normal pregame routine by the preparation junkie, Jeff Van Gundy, last night, but the distracted players around him had turned the normally serious setting of the Knicks' locker room into the chatty atmosphere of a smokers' lounge at the office.

title: Criticism for Company Offering Free Computers to Schools
description: February 2, 2000

title: Gore Shifts To Past Tense For Opponent
description: Thrusting his fists into the air in a Rocky pose of triumph, Vice President Al Gore claimed victory in New Hampshire tonight and immediately spoke of his lone rival, former Senator Bill Bradley, in the past tense.

title: Extracting Metaphors From Life's Detritus; A Sculptor Entwines Found Objects With His Experiences and Human History
description: Visitors to Leonardo Drew's studio in Brooklyn should be prepared to stand; there is simply no place to sit. His sculptures, in varying states of completion, cover the floor and the walls. Others lean against mounds of his raw materials -- half-open bales of cotton, containers of screws, paper, fabric remnants and just plain junk. Wood -- in blocks, in sheets, in little square boxes -- is everywhere. Here and there is a tool -- a blowtorch, a table saw. Nearly everything is tinged with rust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATIN, IRVING
description: KATIN-Irving. Co-founder of Roadside China in Yonkers. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Marj, Cathy and Neil. Loving grandfather.

title: Our Towns; Extending A Hand, Not Cuffs
description: THE police here are facing the same happy fate befalling departments around the country -- only more so.

title: G.M. Is Said To Choose A New Chief
description: The General Motors Corporation is expected to announce on Wednesday that it will promote G. Richard Wagoner Jr., its president and chief operating officer, to chief executive as John F. Smith Jr. relinquishes that job but stays on as chairman.

title: Shopping for Specialties of the House
description: Some specialties worth the trip.

title: Pinedale Journal; A Town Has Mixed Feelings on Its Day in the Sun
description: Big-time sports seldom reach a place like this. Heck, small-time sports seldom reach a place like this.

title: Kiss, Kiss: The International Language of Love
description: ''I represent todos paises (all countries),'' Fragancia (Wilfredo Crispin) proclaimed during DLG's farewell concert on Saturday night at Irving Plaza. His Spanglish declaration summed up the group's successful plan to find an international audience by mixing and fusing rhythms from across the Caribbean and New York City, starting with salsa and reggae and adding rapping, rhythm-and-blues ballads, dance-club music and all kinds of Latin-American styles.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JAFFE, EDDA
description: JAFFE-Edda. The passage of time cannot diminish our love. Missing you deeply, Susanne and Brett

title: Kosovo's Ex-Guerrillas Turn to Ice-Clearing Duty
description: Former fighters of the Kosovo Liberation Army have turned their attention to more mundane tasks in recent weeks, performing their first public service job as the newly formed Kosovo Protection Corps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZENTNER, SI
description: ZENTNER-Si. Your loved ones mourn the passing of Si Zentner, bandleader, who passed away on January 31. We all love you and will miss you. Blanche Weingarten

title: Talk by Putin Skips the War, But Albright Reminds Him
description: In a surprise appearance at a Middle East conference here, the acting president of Russia, Vladimir V. Putin, sat down two chairs away from the secretary of state, Madeleine K. Albright, and delivered his first foreign policy statement, which within 15 minutes delineated the differences between the two countries.

title: The Big City; To Win a Seat In the Senate, Stand Off
description: AS she prepares to make a formal announcement of her Senate candidacy on Sunday, Hillary Rodham Clinton is in danger of making a fatal mistake. Once again, she may be listening to the experts who got her into this race.

title: Microsoft Promotes Windows Wireless Net Technology
description: Microsoft Promotes Windows Wireless Net Technology

title: Metro Business; Con Ed to Sell Reactor
description: Consolidated Edison said yesterday that it planned to auction off its nuclear reactor in Buchanan, N.Y., this year.

description: To the Editor:

title: ABC Is in Shape For the Sweeps
description: The Super Bowl always gives an enormous bounce to whichever network is broadcasting it; this season, combined with the buoyancy provided by three doses of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' every week, the Super Bowl has lifted ABC into the ratings firmament.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Gene Therapy Lapses Cited

title: Strikes Against Shorter Workweek Snarl France's Roads and Rails
description: Isabelle Dupont was trying to make the best of her hour-and-a-half walk to work today. Ms. Dupont, a 35-year-old civil servant, wore sneakers, strolled slowly and ate a croissant on the way. But like many other Parisians inconvenienced by today's subway and bus strikes -- yet another demonstration against the new 35-hour workweek -- Ms. Dupont understood none of the details of the protest and wondered whether it was necessary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGSAM, ALEXANDER E.
description: LANGSAM-Alexander E. Age 92. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. Industrialist and benefactor, died in Rockville, MD. on January 31, 2000. Funeral service will be held at Schwartz Bros Chapel, Flushing, N.Y. Friday, Feburary 4, 10AM. Please send contributions to Boys Town Jerusalem, 12 W. 31 St, Su 300, NY NY 10001 in lieu of flowers.

title: Tearful Vermeil Goes Out on Top
description: Dick Vermeil, who popularized the phrase ''coaching burnout'' when he resigned suddenly in 1983, but returned to the sideline 14 years later, did something even more unexpected yesterday. He quit as coach of the St. Louis Rams less than 48 hours after winning Super Bowl XXXIV.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Still Fighting For That Million

title: Salsa, Pesto Or This Sauce
description: OCCASIONALLY I come across a culinary combination so obvious that I marvel at how I could have missed it for so long. This was certainly the case with the dipping sauce of oil, scallions, ginger and salt that I had in two Cantonese restaurants recently.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit filed by retailers against Sony Music Entertainment misstated the given name of the president of the National Association of Recording Merchandisers. She is Pamela Horovitz, not Paula.

title: America One's Effort Ties Challenger Finals
description: Coming from behind after an early tactical error and holding on for dear life to fend off a last-ditch Prada charge, Paul Cayard's America One syndicate eked out a nine-second victory today to deadlock the series to determine the next America's Cup challenger, 3-3.

title: The Reality of Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INFANTINO, JAMES JOSEPH
description: INFANTINO-James Joseph. Died on January 30th, 2000, at age 67. Beloved husband to Lynda, loving father to James and John. Dear brother to Carmine. We will miss this wonderful, creative man. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Alzheimer's Association.

title: Ignorance on Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders
description: Ziggy Palffy took a few shots against the Islanders on Monday night, then took a few shots at them. He finished with three assists against his former team in the Los Angeles Kings' 5-2 victory.

title: Commuting Long Distances and Loving It
description: Like millions of other Americans, Lillian and Philip Silver drive from their house in the suburbs on Monday mornings and head for work. But the similarity ends there.

title: A Family Builds Values Despite Upsets of Illness
description: Lucy and Rob Hernandez call the last two years together a great learning experience, even though they've been married for 13 years. They take playful verbal jabs at one another, and when they are with their children, Deanna, 5, and Kayla, 2, they act the part of an old married couple. Mrs. Hernandez says jokingly of her husband, ''Trying to think like a 5-year-old is like trying to think like a man.''

title: Bell Atlantic and GTE Swap Wireless Systems With Alltel
description: In the first of several billion-dollar wireless telephone deals that Bell Atlantic and the GTE Corporation are likely to make early this year, the two telecommunications giants announced yesterday that they would swap wireless operations in 13 states with the Alltel Corporation.

title: Accounts
description: * CountryCool.com, Fairfax, Va., and Nashville, a country music Web site, to E. James White Communications, Herndon, Va., to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at more than $6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDOR, ISABELLE
description: SEIDOR-Isabelle. On January 31, 2000. Beloved mother of Steven Hymowitz. Loving sister of Rose Lande & George Astor. Cherished grandmother to Emily. Dear mother-in-law of Barbara. Services on Wednesday, 11:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Newest and Trendiest Autos Bring Americans to Dealers
description: Americans flocked to dealerships last month to buy the most recently introduced and most fashionable cars, minivans and sport utility vehicles available, automakers said today, as every manufacturer except DaimlerChrysler A.G. announced big gains in sales.

title: Director of Emergency Agency Is Leaving for a Corporate Job
description: After spending four years building what is regarded as the premier emergency preparedness program in the country, Jerome M. Hauer, the director of the mayor's Office of Emergency Management, is to leave today to take a corporate job.

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN we were planning our menu at the restaurant, we had to decide what to offer people while they waited to order. We wanted to serve something like bread, but not the usual sourdough, because of the menu's Japanese overtones.

title: Network Solutions Jumps After Investigation Ends
description: February 1, 2000

title: Amazon.com Jumps After Living.com Deal
description: February 1, 2000

title: Apples With a Kick
description: A SIDE from the grape, only the apple has made a name and a taste for itself among fruit-based alcoholic beverages. Yes, you can find any number of brandies made from blackberries, peaches and other fruits, and pear brandy in particular can be beguiling, but apple brandy stands by itself as a credible alternative to such exalted grape brandies as Cognac and Armagnac.

title: Sun-Netscape Alliance Targets Wireless Internet
description: Sun-Netscape Alliance Targets Wireless Internet

title: Scale of Serial Murderer's Crimes Shocks Britain
description: LONDON  The trial of Dr. Harold Shipman, accused of murdering 15 elderly patients by injecting them with fatal doses of heroin, had captivated Britain for four months as people wondered whether a respected family doctor could really be a serial murderer.

title: A Wedge in the Cuban Embargo
description: Cubans have been told for many years that the decades-long American trade embargo against their country prevents them from buying even aspirin from their northern neighbor. President Fidel Castro has long used American restrictions on the sale of medicines and medical supplies to Cuba as an example of Washington's apparent inhumanity -- and a source of his own legitimacy. So last week's American health care exhibition in Havana raised eyebrows, if not actual sales. The exhibition was evidence of incremental changes in the embargo over the last few years that suggest the Clinton administration knows what ought to be done even as it avoids actually doing it.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS 4 PERCENT. Cocoa fell to its lowest price in 27 years as beans from the Ivory Coast and other growers arrived at export docks just as demand is slowing. Cocoa for March delivery fell $32, to $763 a metric ton.

title: What's That Glow on East 50th?
description: EVEN by the exacting standards of Midtown, 50th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues stands out for its absolute lack of character. It is perhaps one of the most faceless blocks on the island of Manhattan, a Bermuda Triangle of boredom, whose single point of visual excitement is a searingly lit parking garage.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER TO EQUIP VEHICLES WITH SATELLITE RADIO
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. will invest $100 million in Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. and install its receivers in its cars and trucks, giving customers access to uninterrupted radio across the United States. The company said it would install Sirius receivers in its vehicles sold in the United States, including those sold under the Mercedes-Benz, Jeep, Dodge and Chrysler brands, as well as in Freightliner and Sterling heavy trucks. Sirius's digital satellite-radio system will provide coast-to-coast coverage with up to 50 channels of commercial-free music and another 50 channels of news, sports and entertainment for a $9.95 monthly fee. Sirius, formerly named CD Radio, expects to begin broadcasting nationally by the end of the year. Shares of New York-based Sirius rose $3.625 each, to $45, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Poor Showing Deflates Forbes
description: Steve Forbes's disappointing third-place finish in the New Hampshire primary makes it even more difficult for him to establish himself as his party's conservative standard-bearer, especially in light of the lavish amounts of time and money he spent here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BITTNER, JUNE H.
description: BITTNER-June H. On January 31, 2000. Beloved mother of Shawn. Cherished grandmother of Jackie, Katie and Greg. Loving sister of Lorraine Hermann, Eleanor Kobetitsch and Gloria Donegan. Fond aunt of Eileen Tipple and dear friend of Charlotte Lescher. Reposing at Morton Funeral Home/ Ridgewood Chapels, 663 Grandview Ave, Ridgewood, N.Y. until Friday, 9AM. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal R.C. Church, 9:45AM. Interment Evergreen Cemetery. Visitors may call Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: New Deal Gives Women Parity in Pay and Full-Time Status
description: In an agreement that for the first time creates salary parity between the American men's and women's national soccer teams, the United States Soccer Federation and the women's team formally announced yesterday a new five-year contract on which they reached agreement last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINTELS, RUTH WYZANSKI
description: RINTELS-Ruth Wyzanski. Of Teaneck, NJ, formerly of NYC and Brookline, MA, on February 1, 2000. Beloved mother of Constance Schnoll and David W. Rintels. Cherished grandmother of Suzanne Stempinski and Michael and Stephen Schnoll. Loving greatgrandmother of David and Lisa Schnoll. Devoted sister of the late Honorable Charles E. Wyzanski, Jr. Following her education at Wellesley and Simmons Colleges she spent her professional life working to help others at such organizations as CARE, The Beth Israel Hospital in Brookline and Brandeis University. For 7 years she devotedly ran the 25th reunions at Harvard College for which she was made an Honorary member of the Harvard College Class of 1932. Funeral services 10 AM Thursday ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of flowers the family request contributions to the Teaneck Volunteer Ambulance Corps or the United Jewish Appeal.

description: Law Firms Raise Salaries To Compete With Internet

description: To the Editor:

title: William McCleery, 88, Playwright and Editor
description: William McCleery, a playwright and editor, died on Jan. 16 at a hospital in Princeton, N.J. He was 88 and lived in Princeton.

title: A Daughter Who Shares Her Folks' Ways
description: IT is 1965 and Nora Guthrie, 15, is jumpy: her date is waiting, but Woody, her father, has come to her Queens home for his weekend visit. She doesn't even like folk music; whenever that Bob Dylan drops by to play for his idol, she stomps off to listen to the Shirelles. There's Woody on the couch, conscious but unable to speak, stinking of incontinence, his limbs flailing grotesquely from degenerative Huntington's disease. If she gets too close, he might kick her.

title: Leo and MacManus Complete Merger
description: The Leo Group in Chicago and the MacManus Group in New York said yesterday that they had completed their merger, as anticipated, and were pursuing plans to go public. Terms of the deal, announced on Nov. 3, were not disclosed.

title: THE BOSS; Little Bells That Mean a Lot
description: My father had ulcers that were a complication from eating raw pork when he was in the service during World War I. Before the war, he had been a sales manager for H. J. Heinz. But after he became ill, he couldn't go out and do the routes anymore. He had no compensation, no disability.

title: Job Cuts by Big French Auto Parts Maker Send Shares Lower
description: Investors often reward companies that eliminate jobs and reorganize themselves to become more efficient. But shareholders in Valeo S.A. of France, one of Europe's largest automotive parts companies, sold heavily today on news that it would cut 6,000 jobs, or 12 percent of the total, in the next two years, and invest heavily in Latin America and Eastern Europe to shift its presence away from economically mature regions like North America and Western Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKS, LESTER
description: MACKS-Lester. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Lester Macks, husband of Sheila Macks, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Mary Cantwell, 69, Author and Times Writer
description: Mary Cantwell, who wrote essays, books and editorials for The New York Times, many about the changing public and private lives of women in America, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 69.

title: Filing Offers a Way to Find Microsoft Violated the Law
description: A Harvard legal scholar told the judge in the Microsoft antitrust case yesterday that the company's decision to bundle its Web browser into the Windows operating system had ''obvious benefits'' to computer programmers and consumers. But he then proceeded to provide a legally innovative road map for determining that the bundling strategy violated the law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIENSTOCK, WILLIAM
description: BIENSTOCK-William, 89, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, on January 31, 2000. Beloved husband of Sara. Loving father of Errol and Paula, David, Michael & Sophie. Adored grandfather of Lori, Michelle and Kristen and the late Bradley. Cherished brother of Roz and Rae. Graveside service at Menorah Gardens, West Palm Beach, FL, Wednesday, February 2, 1:00 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAR, LEON D. M.D.
description: STAR-Leon D. M.D. 13 long years since you left us, but your love and dynamic spirit pervades our lives. Your Famil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREY, WARREN C.
description: KREY-Warren C. On January 29, 2000. Beloved husband of Margaret, loving brother of Nathalie and father of Lewis, Russell, and Douglas. Adored grandpa of Rebecca, Lauren, Nathaniel, Kathleen, Mary Margaret, Adrienne, Jocelyn, and Theodore. He was Vice President and Director of Art Services at Dancer, Fitzgerald & Sample until 1986, then he contributed actively in several advisory capacities to the government of his home town of Teaneck, N.J. His love, counsel and support will be always remembered and cherished. Visitation, February 1, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Volk-Leber Funeral Home,Teaneck Rd Teaneck NJ. Funeral service 11 AM, February 2, at Trinity Lutheran Church, 167 Palisades Ave, Bogota, N.J. Burial at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Parkinson Disease Assn or the National Parkinson Disease Fndton. or Trinity Lutheran Church Bogota, NJ.

title: Easy Stroll by McEnroe Fills Up With Obstacles
description: In preparation for his first competition as the United States Davis Cup captain, John McEnroe passed on telephoning Phil Jackson or Pat Riley and requesting the crash course on becoming a genius coach. McEnroe had Andre Agassi and Pete Sampras lined up for the first round against unimposing Zimbabwe, and what more did he need than that?

title: Expensive Super Bowl spots seem to work for many dot-coms as traffic to their sites grows.
description: Every year after the Super Bowl, Madison Avenue assesses the performance of the advertisers that spent the huge sums required to run commercials during the game. This time, with Super Bowl XXXIV being considered the first Dot-Com Bowl -- 17 of the 36 companies sponsoring the broadcast were related to the Internet -- the results are being more closely followed.

title: New Law Draws More Campaign Donors With Smaller Gifts
description: The city's revised program for public financing of election campaigns is reshaping the pattern of political contributions, with candidates tapping a wider array of donors for smaller amounts of money, figures compiled by the Campaign Finance Board show.

title: Syrah Takes Root In America
description: A LOT of people have been credited with being the first to import the syrah grape to America. Leon D. Adams stated flatly in ''The Wines of America'' (McGraw-Hill, 1978) that it was Howard Olmo of the University of California at Davis who brought in the first vines, some 50 years ago. Others contend that the first syrah vines were to be found a century earlier in vineyards the pioneer Italian growers in California called ''mixed black'' -- a jumble of various vines.

title: AMAZON.COM TO BUY INTO NET HOME-FURNISHINGS SELLER
description: The Internet retailer Amazon.com Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire an 18 percent interest in Living.com Inc., a closely held Internet home-furnishings retailer based in Austin, Tex., for an undisclosed amount. In exchange, Amazon, based in Seattle, will receive $145 million over five years for marketing Living.com on the Amazon Web site. Amazon also will receive rights to buy another 9 percent of the company. Amazon.com's stock rose $2.875 a share, to $67.4375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIRSTMAN, ALBERT
description: FIRSTMAN-Albert, died peacefully on Tuesday, February 1. Beloved husband of Lorraine. Devoted father of Kenneth and Chantal and Michael. Dear sister of Marjorie Levy. Loving grandfather of Deborah, Naomi and Adeena.Cherished nephew of Geraldine and Bernice. Loving brother-in-law to Rhoda and Leon Carp, Seymour and Cynthia Reich, and the late Helyn Reich. Caring uncle to Keith, Audrey, Leslie, Dana, Jaime and Avi, and Marc, Shelley, Michael, Michele, Jeffrey, Patricia, Ned and Kate. A wonderful man of great dignity and class, strength and character, intelligence and kindness. A devotee of the theatre and the arts. Past President of Shore Parkway Jewish Center. A commercial real estate agent associated with New Spectrum Realty. Funeral services 11am Wednesday at Sherman's Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (between Avenues I & J), Brooklyn.

title: TOUGH FIGHT AHEAD
description: Vice President Al Gore held off a strong challenge by former Senator Bill Bradley in the New Hampshire primary today, but both candidates vowed a long, tough fight for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: 37 Hurt and 248 Held in Clash Of Students and Mexico's Police
description: Students and workers opposed to a nine-month strike at the national university clashed today with strikers in a battle that left at least 37 people injured and 248 under arrest. It was the worst violence since the strike began.

title: Houston Is Lone All-Star on the Hudson
description: Yesterday's unveiling of the reserves for the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game brought feelings of relief, disappointment and shock to the Knicks and the Nets.

title: Fighting Sioux Move Up
description: NORTH DAKOTA

title: SCHLUMBERGER TO BUY MAKER OF ENERGY DATA NETWORKS
description: Schlumberger Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy the money-losing CellNet Data Systems Inc., whose wireless networks gather information about energy use, for $55 million in cash. Schlumberger will also assume about $120 million in debt. CellNet, based in San Carlos, Calif., said it planned to file for Chapter 11 protection in Delaware on Friday. It expects the bankruptcy court to approve its sale to Schlumberger by April 30. Schlumberger, the world's second-largest oil field service company, has headquarters in Paris and New York. Its shares rose $2.875, to $63.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADRIAN, BERTA
description: BADRIAN-Berta. Beloved mother of Doris (Marvin) and Ruth. Beloved grandmother of Philip, Stuart, Laura, Renee, Dena, Cindi and Mitchell. Beloved great-grandmother of 14. Born in Lemberg, Poland in 1908. Survivor of the Holocaust and one of the 982 refugees of Roosevelt's Safe Haven in Oswego NY. We will miss you, you will be forever in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINGOLD, HENRY
description: GINGOLD-Henry. Died on Sunday, January 30. Funeral will be held at Parkside Memorial, 9860 Queens Blvd and 66th Ave at 10AM on Friday, February 4.

title: All G.I.'s to Take Gay Policy Class
description: In a sweeping admission that the military's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy is poorly understood in the ranks, the Pentagon said that every member of the armed forces would undergo training intended to prevent anti-gay harassment by the end of the year.

title: Home, Office and Vegetables
description: CALL it ''The Broccoli Problem.'' Every few months, dozens of business executives travel to the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania for an intensive week spent sharpening their negotiation skills. That they are sent by their companies is a sign of their authority. These folks are important. It is their job to tell other people what to do.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: W. R. GRACE & CO., Columbia, Md., a specialty chemical company, acquired Crosfield Group's hydroprocessing catalyst business from Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. Terms were not disclosed.

title: When Stoppard Sends His 'Love,' San Francisco Reciprocates
description: Even Tom Stoppard admits that his drama ''The Invention of Love'' is a bit difficult. The play, about the British poet and classicist A. E. Housman, has a dreamlike quality. It lasts three hours, the characters sometimes speak Latin, and there are allusions to Greek myth. Broadway producers have not been enthusiastic about staging the sprawling drama.

title: Albright Visits Post-Tudjman Croatia and Hails the New Leadership
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright came here today to praise the government that was recently formed from the democratic opposition.

title: Federal Reserve Gives a Nudge To 2 Key Rates
description: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point today and signaled that further rate increases would probably be needed to keep the persistently strong economy from generating inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOONEY, ANNA
description: MOONEY-Anna. Passed away October 8, 1999. On your birthday we miss you all the more. Love, Gigi, Peter, Nathalie, William, Harrison and Bill

title: HONG KONG COMPANY IS ACQUIRED
description: The venture capital firm Hambrecht & Quist Asia Pacific Group and other investors are paying $26 million for Acme Landis Holdings Ltd. to use as a base for Asian Internet investments. Acme Landis will be renamed i100 Ltd.

title: Art World Nightmare: Made-to-Order Theft; Stolen Works Like Oxford's Cezanne Can Vanish for Decades
description: The intruder smashed a skylight and lowered himself down a rope, the police say, before tossing a smoke canister onto the floor of the Hindley Smith Gallery. In an instant the room filled with smoke, obscuring the view from the security cameras. The burglar and fire alarms went off, throwing the museum into chaos that bought the intruder a few precious moments. The police responded to the alarm at 1:43 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, EDITH HODES
description: ROSEN-Edith Hodes, 78. Passed away peacefully at her home in Key Biscayne, FL, on February 2, 2000. She is survived by her daughters, Margery Hadar of Manhattan and Victoria Simons of Key Biscayne, her son-in-law, Dr. Robert Simons, her grandchildren, Eric (Allison) Hadar and Joshua Hadar, Matthew Simons and Ilana Simons, and her great granddaughter, Anna Joe Hadar. She is also survived by her brother, Stuart T. Hodes. She was an elegant woman who shared her great strength and wisdom with her children and grandchildren. She was much loved and will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Florida Philharmonic, 3401 Northwest 9th Ave., Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33309, (305)-476-1234.

title: Primary Lessons Of McCain's Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Federal Agency Fines Farms Where 2 Died
description: The federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has fined two farms in southern New Jersey where two migrant workers died of heat stroke last summer, the agency said yesterday.

title: Robert J. Milano, 87, Self-Made Industrialist
description: Robert John Milano, a self-made millionaire industrialist who briefly served Mayor Edward I. Koch as deputy mayor for economic development, died Saturday at a hospital in Palm Springs, Fla., where he lived. A former New York resident, he was 87.

title: Cell Phone Thieves Try to Stay a Step Ahead
description: NOT long ago, Helen Fisher was exiting the subway at 34th Street and Broadway when someone grabbed the cell phone out of her hand and ran. ''I was holding it till I could put it back into my pocketbook,'' she said.

title: Gay Couples Ruling Is Dividing Vermont
description: Six weeks ago the Vermont Supreme Court ruled that gay couples deserve the same rights and benefits as heterosexual spouses and must be granted them. But Vermont remains a state divided, even polarized, as it takes its new position at the center of the country's long-running debate over gay marriage.

title: X Marks the Spot for Riders at Mount Snow
description: A lot has changed since the woolly days of snowboarding nearly a decade ago at the Un Blanco Gulch halfpipe in Mount Snow, Vt. Not only is the riding steeper and faster these days, but the moves are also trickier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADISON, ELIZABETH C.
description: MADISON-Elizabeth C. On February 1, 2000. Beloved wife of Bernard. Loving mother of Bernard, Denise and Gary. Adored grandmother of Laureen, Keith, William, Stephanie, Russell and Gabriele. Great-grandmother of Loren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Thursday 2-5 & 7-9 p.m. A Mass of Christian Burial, Friday 10 a.m. at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 84th St. and Park Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to Mary Manning Walsh N.H., 1339 York Ave., NY, NY 10021, Attn: Sean William.

title: Magnetic Polls
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Knicks' Leaders Fall Short Of Duties
description: Patrick Ewing was the last player out of the Knicks' locker room today, but when he finally emerged, he rushed to a waiting car with little to say.

title: Unfair Sentencing Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Find Frustration Once Again From Devils
description: For almost two periods at Madison Square Garden last night, the Rangers did everything in their power to let the Devils know there is not much difference between the two teams.

title: A Way to Talk on a Cell Phone Without a Word Being Spoken
description: BELL LABORATORIES, the research and development arm of Lucent Technologies, and the Bell Atlantic Mobile division of the Bell Atlantic Corporation have announced a technology that will allow people with hearing and speech impairments to make digital cellular calls using text-telephone, or teletypewriter, devices.

title: That 30-Year Benchmark? Think 10-Year, Treasury Says
description: Since 1977, when the federal government began regularly issuing 30-year bonds, they have been the benchmark of the American bond market. But yesterday the Treasury signaled that those days should soon be over.

title: Consultant to Help Find Chancellor
description: The New York City Board of Education will soon hire a consultant to help conduct the search for a permanent schools chancellor, board officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIFRANCESCO, JOHN
description: DIFRANCESCO-John, M.D. On February 2, 2000 at age 82. Noted ophthalmologist and retired member of the Attending Staff at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York for over 35 years. Beloved husband of the late Joan DiFrancesco, devoted father of Louis, Anne and Nina and grandfather of Joseph and Amara. Funeral arrangements private.

title: Metro Business; DEET in Tested Products
description: The president of a product testing service admitted in federal court yesterday that she failed to warn 300 people that a combination sunscreen and insect repellant tested on them contained an insecticide, officials said.

title: T. D. Boardman, 87, Newsreel Businessman
description: T. Dennie Boardman, a retired businessman, died last Friday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 87 and lived in Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: All in the Details
description: WITH 2,900 exhibitors and 45,000 visitors, the New York International Gift Fair, which occupied the Javits Convention Center and four Passenger Ship Terminal piers last week, was the size of 14 football fields, but it had the heft of a badminton match. It is the home accessories industry's biannual Feather Bowl. Every Malaysian-made Provencal-style olive oil crock, aromatherapeutic powder-room soap and triwicked pedestal candle known to man was there. And people were shopping, including six Mennonite women from Waynesboro, Pa., buying toys and gifts for their store, Violets and More, housed in a 70-foot trailer, where they also sell crafts made by the community. ''We found a lot of nice things,'' said Noella Martin, who attended with her mother and the others. ''We did a nice amount of ordering.''

title: Bookstores Loaded; No Outs
description: The nonfiction sports book is not a genre that has traditionally produced much literature or many best sellers, so it's surprising that in the past month some of the biggest action in book publishing has been in the biographies or memoirs of figures from actual sports or of bulked-up actors in fake athletic contests. Which makes particularly interesting the news that Roger Angell, arguably the most elegant of baseball writers, is going to conduct a sort of Socratic dialogue with the Yankees pitcher David Cone, perhaps the most cerebral of baseball players.

title: I.B.M. Taps Other Manufacturers to Sell Storage Systems
description: I.B.M. Taps Other Manufacturers to Sell Storage Systems

title: Modest Super Bowl Hero Savoring Time in Spotlight
description: Not all the members of a professional football team are household names. Mike Jones, a linebacker for the St. Louis Rams, certainly was not. He wasn't even the only Mike Jones playing in the Super Bowl last Sunday. The Tennessee Titans also had a defensive player named Mike Jones.

title: Amazon Loss Soared 543% In 4th Quarter
description: Amazon.com, the leading proponent of losing money on the Internet to fuel rapid growth, said yesterday that it lost $323 million in the fourth quarter of last year, more than expected and 543 percent more than it lost in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Health Agency Admits Shifting Funds From Study of Deadly Virus
description: The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention acknowledged yesterday that several million dollars designated by Congress to be spent for research on the deadly hantavirus was actually spent on other work, and the General Accounting Office was called in to investigate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAFFE, ELEANOR BLUMBERG
description: YAFFE-Eleanor Blumberg. Died February 1, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Maurice Yaffe. Devoted mother of Maxine and Martin Solomon, and Stephen and Barbara Yaffe. Adored grandmother of Dr. Marcy Solomon Baker and Andrew Solomon. Adoring great grandmother of Samantha Anne Baker. Loving daughter of distinguished philanthropists Max and Lena Blumberg. Formal services at Frank E. Campbell, Friday, February 4, 9:30AM, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: New Art's Interior Motive
description: JAMES HYDE, an artist whose new paintings -- six- and nine-foot-square throw pillows -- are slumped against the walls at the Brent Sikkema gallery in Chelsea, quoted Matisse when asked about his interest in interior design.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Saving Cyclamen

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: House Vote on Aid to Taiwan Angers China
description: China today vehemently protested the vote in the United States House of Representatives to expand military ties with Taiwan, calling it a ''serious encroachment on China's sovereignty'' and a ''gross interference in China's internal affairs.''

title: Thomas Keesee, 84, Chief of Securities Firm
description: Thomas Woodfin Keesee Jr., the retired chief executive of the Bessemer Securities Corporation, died Sunday in his sleep at a hospital near the family's Mount Kisco, N.Y., home, his son, Thomas W. Keese III, said yesterday. He was 84 and had been ill for some time.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Many Play Online at Work (And Some Look for New Jobs)
description: Solitaire is no longer the only game in town for employees killing time at work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWER, JOAN B.
description: TOWER-Joan B. Of Aiken, South Carolina and Vinalhaven, Maine. On February, 1, 2000. Beloved mother of Elin Elisofon, Vinalhaven and Jill Elisofon, West Palm Beach, FL, loving sister of Dr. Harold Spear, Miami Beach, FL, and Nancy Spear Rossbach, Elberon, NJ.She was formly married to the late Eliot Elisofon,a Life photography and Whitney Tower a horse racing authority.Memorial services will be planned in Aiken and Vinalhaven.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper fell more than 2 percent, the biggest drop in four months, on concern that higher interest rates will crimp demand. Copper for March delivery dropped 2.05 cents, or 2.4 percent, to 82.25 cents a pound.

title: Dressing Up Your E-Mail By Putting In Some Emotion
description: For all its utility, e-mail is not an emotional form of communication. Expressions of deep feeling are pretty much restricted to emoticons (the '':)'' happy face, for example), capital letters (''Don't show this message to ANYONE''), elaborate punctuation (''didn't you get my message!!!??!!!) or some combination of all three (''STELLA!!!!!:('').

title: TODAY'S AVAILABLE SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Sumter, S.C., and Dewey Beach, Del.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEROUSSYDESALES
description: deROUSSYdeSALES-Count Aymon. Of New York. Died February 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Elisabeth, devoted father of Pauline. He also leaves behind his children, Chantal, Monica, and Michael. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Thursday February 3rd, from 4-6 P.M. A service in The Frank E. Campbell Chapel will be held on Friday at 1:30 P.M.

title: Under a Canvas of Snow, a Garden of the Imagination
description: SWIRLING snow, cars turned to soft lumps on the street, the city as silent as a Vermont woods. I felt an irresistible need to go to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. I bundled up as if I were in the north country and walked a mile to the garden, pleasantly disoriented because familiar landmarks were veiled by the storm. Yet, other perceptions were sharpened: how the long hill rises from the sea in Red Hook, crests at Court Street and then rolls down to the Gowanus, where it starts its long, slow climb to Park Slope.

title: Sales Help at Your Elbow
description: To the Editor:

title: Suddenly, Everybody's an Expert
description: OSCAR WILDE is said to have defined an expert as an ordinary man away from home giving advice. Today, those words may be truer than ever, with a few tweaks. An expert, it seems, is now an ordinary person sitting at home, beaming advice over the Internet to anyone who wants help.

title: In 3 Capitals, Leaders Seek Ulster Solution
description: British and Irish leaders and Ulster politicians worked feverishly in three capitals today in a desperate effort to save the new Northern Ireland government from being shut down by a dispute over paramilitary disarmament.

title: THE LOST SEASON: A special report.; A Hard Winter in Vermont
description: This cold college town is warmed in the winter by hockey heat, and nobody knew it better than Corey LaTulippe. He was the only member of the Vermont Catamounts who was actually born here, and he grew up in a nearby suburb. A goalie, LaTulippe's boyhood ambition was to play for the university.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 21 about the sale of $3 billion in notes by the World Bank misidentified the first issuer of a debt offering to retail investors through the Internet. It is Fannie Mae, the former Federal National Mortgage Association.

title: Gil Kane, Comic-Book Artist, Is Dead at 73
description: Gil Kane, a comic-book artist who infused the Atom, Green Lantern and other characters with vibrant new life even as his own artistic aspirations propelled him to draw comic books of Wagnerian operas, died on Monday at a hospital in Miami. He was 73 and lived in Aventura, Fla.

title: Cookies That Hide In a File
description: Q. What is a cookie file? How does it get on my computer? Does this file permit a third party to gain access to my data?

title: A Growing New Industry In Delivering Information
description: With demand surging for computerized medical records, at least a dozen companies are selling electronic systems that can help hospitals and large medical groups avoid dangerous errors.

title: Rocker Affair: Is Speech the Issue?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, SIDNEY
description: SHEPARD-Sidney. Died peacefully February 2, 2000, after a courageous fight against heart disease and cancer. Sidney is survived by his wife, Helaine, with whom he was madly in love for over 53 years. They were best friends who always traveled life's pathways together through good times and bad. He was a wonderful father to Steven and Bruce and his wife, Emily. Sidney's strength and courage was an inspiration to his cherished grandchildren, Michael, Eric and Brian, who saw how hard he tried to stay alive for them. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''BoulevardRiverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Gore Abortion Scramble
description: Vice President Al Gore chose a dramatic way today to demonstrate his support for abortion rights, diverting his campaign from New York to race back to Washington to be on hand for a possible tie vote in the Senate, jumping on a commercial flight (with an aide ferrying the nation's nuclear codes) for the trip.

title: Sales Help at Your Elbow
description: To the Editor:

title: Vodafone, Stock Price Rising, Presses Mannesmann Talks
description: Faced with the growing prospect of succumbing to a $160 billion hostile takeover by Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C., Mannesmann A.G. continued to negotiate today for a peaceful surrender.

title: The Hidden Cost of Haggling
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Confronts Charges That He Is Confrontational
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented a vigorous defense today against the suggestion that he is not compromising enough to serve in the United States Senate, directly rebuffing one of Hillary Rodham Clinton's principal criticisms.

title: A Composer And a Pharaoh Rattling the Status Quo
description: It's impossible to overstate the impact that the avant-garde operas by Philip Glass had upon the contemporary music scene when they were new. ''Einstein on the Beach,'' which received its premiere in 1976, was especially rattling to the status quo. At a time when contemporary composers were generally perceived, however unfairly, as elitist purveyors of aggressively discordant and forbiddingly complex music, Mr. Glass offered music that was jubilantly consonant and purposefully simple.

title: FUTURELINK IS IN $57.5 MILLION DEAL FOR CONSULTING FIRM
description: The FutureLink Corporation, which performs computing services for businesses through the Internet, agreed yesterday to buy Madison Technology Group for $57.5 million in cash, stock and debt securities to expand into the northeastern United States. FutureLink said it would pay $43.8 million in stock, $6.5 million in cash and $7.25 million in short-term notes for the closely held Madison Technology and its sister companies in New Jersey. The New York-based Madison sells technology training, consulting, installation and maintenance. The shares of Future-Link fell $2.125 each, to $17.3125.

title: Huskies Are Human, Too, and Suffer First Loss
description: The undefeated Connecticut women had squandered a 14-point lead and had retreated from a hyper-aggressive style of play, and now they were trying desperately to protect a 1-point margin in the final seconds against Tennessee. The lead had changed hands four times in the last three and a half minutes and here was Semeka Randall, the Tennessee guard who had been particularly upset when the No. 1 Huskies beat the Lady Vols in Knoxville three weeks ago, looking at Shea Ralph and taking a step to her right.

title: U.S. MOVES TO HALT $30 BILLION UNION OF OIL COMPANIES
description: Moving to stem the trend of huge consolidation in the oil industry, the federal government decided today to try to block BP Amoco's $30 billion proposed acquisition of the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: Forced Into Action on Gay Marriage, Vermont Finds Itself Deeply Split
