description: In her piping soprano, 10-year-old Courtney Dozetos told hundreds of Vermonters crammed into the state House here late Tuesday night: ''It would make me feel special and good if my moms could get married. I don't and probably never will understand why they can't.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELINGER, SIGMUND
description: SELINGER-Sigmund. The entire family of the Hebrew Academy of the Five Towns and Rockaway express their sorrow on the passing of Sigmund Selinger A''H, father of our immediate past president, Teddy Selinger. May the family be comforted among the mourners in Israel and know no future sorrow. Iris Sturm, President

title: U.S. Still Sailing Uphill Against Prada's Secret Weapon
description: A forecast 15-knot westerly breeze failed to materialize today, forcing the cancellation of Race 7 in the Louis Vuitton finals between San Francisco's America One syndicate and Italy's Prada Challenge. The five-of-nine series to select the next America's Cup challenger remains tied at three apiece.

title: Working on the Fringe of Retrievability
description: Talking about performance at Carnegie Hall last November, Pierre Boulez recalled an occasion when he conducted some medieval music in Munich in the 1960's. Since there was no tempo indication on the score, he asked the editor for some advice, only to be told that nobody had a clue. For Mr. Boulez, that was the end of the matter. If such a basic quality as speed is unknowable, then the music has effectively been lost.

title: McCain and Bush Revving Up Their Campaigns
description: Riding the wave of his decisive victory in New Hampshire, Senator John McCain tore across South Carolina today arguing that he is the candidate who can ''attract people to our party who have been alienated and disenchanted'' and carry Republicans to victory in November.

title: Despite Recruiting, Few Women Do Well in Firefighter Tests
description: Despite an expanded effort to recruit hundreds of athletic women for careers as firefighters, city officials say that only 11 scored high enough on a battery of exams, including a physically demanding test, to have a chance at being hired for the overwhelmingly male force.

title: Computer-Aided Football
description: To the Editor:

title: Discrepancy By Race Found In the Trying Of Youths
description: Minority youths are more than twice as likely as their white counterparts to be transferred out of California's juvenile justice system and tried as adults, according to a study made public yesterday by the Justice Policy Institute, a criminal-justice research center.

title: Primary Lessons Of McCain's Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice for Pinochet
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGOGLIA, VINCENT T.
description: AGOGLIA-Vincent T. Retired NYC Police Inspector. Of Deerfield Beach, Fla. formerly of Staten Island, on February 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Carol (Nee Hefty), loving father of James and John, father-in-law of Ruth and Nancy, dear brother of Rocco, Joseph, Frank, Anthony, Raymond, Theresa Pagano, Carmela Canna and the late John, Rosemarie Agoglia and Antionette Pasciuto. Cherished grandfather of Christopher, Alyson and Andrew. Funeral from Matthew Funeral Home, Inc., 2508 Victory Boulevard at Willowbrook Road, Staten Island on Saturday 10:15am. Mass of Christian burial St. Claire's R.C. Church 11am. Committal Rosehill Crematory (Private). Friends may call Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Heart Association or to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: At Play, It Takes the Army to Save a Village
description: HISTORICALLY, the military always had the best toys. Hundreds of millions of taxpayer dollars were spent on macho accouterments -- Kevlar vests, Humvees, night-vision goggles and satellite phones -- that became available to corporate executives and rap stars only years later. For gearheads, the Defense Department is the Emerald City of high-tech goodies: a secret treasure trove of classified gizmos far more advanced than the ones available to mere civilians.

title: Official Resigns At Nordstrom
description: Nordstrom Inc., an operator of upscale department stores, said today that its co-president, Jim Nordstrom, had resigned to pursue technology- and Internet-based business opportunities after a 24-year career in retailing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLAN, SHARYN
description: DOLAN-Sharyn. The trustees, headmaster, faculty and students of Poly Prep Country Day School mourn the loss of Sharyn Dolan. Beloved teacher, coach, dean, colleaque and friend for 22 years. ''Her absence is a presence''. A memorial service will be held in the School's Chapel at 9:30am on Friday, Feburary 11, 2000.

title: Essay; 'Bush Can't Win'
description: Senator Henry (The Great Compromiser) Clay was all set to get the Whig nomination to challenge President Martin Van Buren. Thurlow Weed, a New York political boss in 1840, came up with a strategy to undermine Clay's wide support among Whigs. His sorrowful message: ''Clay can't win.'' It worked, and the Whigs went on to defeat the sitting president with Benjamin Harrison and not Henry Clay.

title: Closing the Digital Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, EILEEN MARY
description: KAY-Eileen Mary. Of Newark, New Jersey on February 1, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Stephen, devoted mother of Colin Kay and Eva Marie Murphy, loving grandmother of Elizabeth Murphy. Dear sister of Margaret Hegarty of Dublin, Ireland and the late Father Norbert Maguire. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend the funeral Saturday, February 5, at 9:30 AM from the Laskowski Funeral Home (Union Funeral Home), 1600 Stuyvesant Avenue, corner of Stanley Terrace, Union, NJ. Funeral mass 10:30 AM at St. Stanislaus Church, Newark, N.J. Visitation on Friday 2-4 and 7-9. Entombment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to the Newark Beth Israel Medical Center Critical Care Unit, 201 Lyons Ave., Newark, New Jersey 07112 would be appreciated.

title: Newark Airport Monorail Shut Down by Bitter Cold
description: Cold weather has caused a shutdown of the monorail that links three passenger terminals and parking lots at Newark International Airport, leaving 30,000 daily riders to walk or to use shuttle buses, officials said.

title: 2 Officers Trapped In Fire Rescue Effort
description: Two police officers were trapped last night after they got on an elevator that took them to the heart of a fire in a burning Queens apartment building.

title: Improve Public Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer for Officer on Trial Says Diallo's Actions Led to His Death
description: Acknowledging that Amadou Diallo was a victim who did not deserve to die, a lawyer for one of the four police officers on trial for firing 41 shots at him told the jury in opening statements today that Mr. Diallo's own actions led to his death.

title: Avenue Named for a Hero, Perhaps Even for a Baron
description: When the DeKalb Avenue station in Brooklyn opened in 1915, the area around it was already the borough's crowded downtown, a magnet for shoppers, theatergoers and those with business in its concentration of borough and city government offices.

title: Exploring the Store Online
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: R. R. DONNELLEY LOGISTICS SERVICES, Chicago, a unit of R. R. Donnelley & Sons Co., a directory and catalog publisher, bought CTC Distribution Direct, Minneapolis, a mailer of parcels. Terms were not released.

title: Financial Aid Is Vital, but a Teddy Bear Never Hurts
description: A group of 18 children in East Harlem watched their teacher as she taught a little about bears, and a little bit of English.

title: Adrian Lajous, 79, Opponent Of Mexico's Nationalized Banks
description: Adrian Lajous Martinez, a finance official who resigned his cabinet post in 1982 to protest the nationalization of the banks, died of a heart attack here on Jan. 24. He was 79.

title: Blockbuster Shows Lure Record Crowds Into U.S. Museums
description: The museum world's proven standbys -- exhibitions on Impressionism, Egyptian art, Picasso and most of all van Gogh -- lured record numbers of people into American art museums last year.

title: Searchers Find 'Black Box' In Alaska Airlines Jet Crash
description: Searchers today recovered one of the ''black boxes,'' the cockpit voice recorder, from the Alaska Airlines jet that crashed on Monday and said they had heard electronic pinging from the other, officials said this evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, ELLIOTT W.
description: WILLIAMS-Elliott W. died suddenly on Wednesday, January 26, in Los Angeles, CA. He is survived by his mother Dolores Williams; three sisters Wandra WilliamsPerkins, Denise and Teri Williams and a host of relatives and friends. Visitation at Holy Redeemer Church Friday, February 4th from 7-9 PM and Mass of Christian burial on Saturday, February 5th at 11 AM at the Church, 206 New York Avenue, NW, Wash, DC.

title: Op-Art
Luxury's Expanding Frontiers: The New Dakotas Are Downtown
description: CHRISTOPHER HYLAND wants to evoke Venice. So the rooms in his grand new apartment will be arranged enfilade, one after the other like pearls in a necklace, to provide an unbroken interior view. (Imagine a fancier version of a railroad flat.) The walls will be covered in silk damask. And from the 13-foot ceiling of the sitting room, Mr. Hyland, 52, and his partner, Constantino Castellano, 50, will suspend a six-foot-long model of the Confederacy, a ship commissioned by Congress during the American Revolution.

title: A Dwindling Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: RECOVERY FOR AIR CANADA
description: Air Canada reported a strong recovery in its profit for the fourth quarter and for all of 1999 and said it had begun to reorganize the Canadian Airlines Corporation, which it acquired last month. Fourth-quarter profit for Air Canada was 13 million Canadian dollars, or $9 million, reversing a loss of 20 million Canadian dollars a year earlier. Profit for the year was 213 million Canadian dollars, in contrast to a 1998 loss of 16 million Canadian dollars.

title: Suddenly, The Game Was Lost
description: PREDATORS 6, ISLANDERS 4

title: Tufted Treasures
description: WITH 2,900 exhibitors and 45,000 visitors, the New York International Gift Fair, which occupied the Javits Convention Center and four Passenger Ship Terminal piers last week, was the size of 14 football fields, but it had the heft of a badminton match. It is the home accessories industry's biannual Feather Bowl. Every Malaysian-made Provencal-style olive oil crock, aromatherapeutic powder-room soap and triwicked pedestal candle known to man was there. And people were shopping, including six Mennonite women from Waynesboro, Pa., buying toys and gifts for their store, Violets and More, housed in a 70-foot trailer, where they also sell crafts made by the community. ''We found a lot of nice things,'' said Noella Martin, who attended with her mother and the others. ''We did a nice amount of ordering.''

title: A New AIDS Mystery: Prostitutes Who Have Remained Immune
description: One of the mysteries of the AIDS epidemic is that a small number of female prostitutes in Africa seem resistant to the virus that causes the disease even though they often have sex with infected men.

title: British Telecommunications Profit Off 24%
description: British Telecommunications said today that profit in its third quarter was lower than expected, falling about 24 percent, and said the fourth-quarter would probably not be much better.

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: February 3, 2000

title: Turning On the TV May Soon Require Real Expertise
description: TURN a 10-year-old television set around and you are likely to see just two things: a power cord and a hole for an antenna. Turn a large-screen 2000 model around and you'll be excused for thinking that you are looking at the cockpit of a jet airliner.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; CREDITORS TAKE OVER BUFETE
description: Creditors of Bufete Industrial S.A., a large Mexican construction company, took control from Jose Mendoza Fernandez, who founded it 50 years ago. Led by Citibank Mexico, Banca Serfin and the Bank of New York, the creditors agreed to exchange $80 million in loans for 90 percent of the company's shares and to reschedule the remaining $80 million in debt. Mr. Mendoza's stake was reduced from 41 to 10 percent, and he was removed as chief executive. Dan Fineren

title: General Motors Chief to Hand Over Reins to Company's President
description: John F. Smith Jr., the chairman and chief executive of General Motors announced today that he would hand his chief executive title and day-to-day responsibility for running the company, the world's largest automaker, to G. Richard Wagoner Jr., 46, the president and chief operating officer, starting in June.

title: A Gambler at Heart Rakes In a Planetarium
description: RAPID-REWIND with us now to the days of yesteryear when, at the age of 8, Ellen V. Futter began mastering the dialectic of the tennis courts of Port Washington, N.Y. ''I learned to value baseline play, because steady players go a long way,'' recalled Ms. Futter, who is now president of the American Museum of Natural History. ''But what I really liked best was coming to the net.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, MARJORIE
description: MELTZER-Marjorie. February 1, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Nathaniel Meltzer. Sister of Eleanor Spector, Jean Klein, and the late Lewis R. Friedman and the late Ruth Friedman. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral private.

title: Massacre Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: HILFIGER CONSIDERS STRATEGIC OPTIONS TO BOLSTER STOCK
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, a clothing designer whose stock has fallen by two-thirds in six months, said yesterday that it had hired the investment firm Morgan Stanley Dean Witter for advice on acquisitions and other ways to increase its value. The company, a maker of casual clothes, is not for sale, a spokesman said. Among the options being considered are purchases, new business opportunities and buying back shares. Hilfiger warned last month that third- and fourth-quarter earnings would miss forecasts because of lower-than-expected Christmas sales, and price cuts and promotions at the department stores that carry its fashions. The stock has fallen from a recent high of $41 in August, erasing about $2.6 billion in value. The shares rose $1.437 yesterday, to $13.8125.

title: Finally Reviving a Play That Amused the Sun King
description: A play that carries the names of both Moliere and Corneille might seem a likely candidate for posterity, above all here, where the Comedie Francaise was created largely to perpetuate the legacies of the two playwrights and their colleague-cum-rival Racine. Yet until this winter ''Psyche'' had not been staged since 1671, when it had its premiere before Louis XIV.

title: Woods Stalks 6th Straight Tour Victory
description: As he walked to meet Tiger Woods at the driving range this morning, Butch Harmon was asked if Woods expects to contend every week. Harmon laughed at the question.

title: INSIDE
description: Rocket Attack Kills Serbs

title: Sending a Wish List: Is It Nasty or Nice?
description: FOR the record, my daughter Ella would like to point out that there are only 15 more days until her ninth birthday. Also, she does not want to pressure anybody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, MURIEL S.
description: KAYE-Muriel S. On February 1, 2000. Beloved wife of Stanley. Devoted mother of Michael and Jon. Dear sister of the late Glenda Levine. Cherished great-aunt of Lauren and Amanda. Adored aunt of Eileen, Steven, Amy, Bruce, Jim, Craig and the late Ellen. Loving mother-in-law of Emily. Cherished sister-in-law of Bernice Levy, and the late Sheldon Levy, and brother-in-law Harold Levine. Services Friday 12:00 noon at ''Guttermans Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Pfizer and Warner-Lambert Are Seen in Merger Deal
description: Pfizer Inc. has reached a tentative agreement to buy the Warner-Lambert Company for a sweetened price of $87 billion, people close to the companies said yesterday, potentially ending a contentious battle that began more than three months ago when Warner announced another merger only to be surprised by Pfizer's bid.

title: C.I.A. Admits Slow Move in Security Slip
description: The head of the Central Intelligence Agency, George J. Tenet, acknowledged today that the agency had been too slow in notifying the Justice Department and Congress about evidence that his predecessor, John M. Deutch, had improperly placed large amounts of classified material on unclassified computers in his home.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Beijing Journal; Who Needs TV? They Pedal Hard to Peddle Ads
description: On a recent bitter-cold morning, the 15 teenagers suited up in neon-yellow warm-up jackets and matching baseball caps, climbed on 15 identical mountain bikes and rode off in formation onto the icy Beijing streets.

title: Justice Dept. Sues Passaic Over Voting
description: The Justice Department sued Passaic, N.J., yesterday under the Federal Voting Rights Act, charging that the city's system of electing its seven council members on a citywide basis discriminates against Hispanics.

title: Elian's Family Connections to Cuba Are Deeper
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDOR, ISABELLE
description: SEIDOR-Isabelle. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to George Astor on the loss of his sister, Isabelle Seidor. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Boy Scouts Cast Aside Derby Car Maker, 87
description: For generations of Cub Scouts, the Pinewood Derby has been a rite of passage -- a pint-size version of a Soap Box Derby in which each Scout saws, whittles, sands and assembles his model race car from a simple kit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DAVID
description: MILLER-David Jr. of Tenafly, New Jersey on February 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Gulbransen). Devoted father of Walter E. of Saratoga, CA and Lynne M. Miller of Great Falls, VA. Dear brother of Walter S. and Jean of Morristown, brother-inlaw of Gil Brandsen of N.Y.C. Loving grandfather of Lauren and Jack. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenalfy, NJ on Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Service Saturday 9:15 AM. Interment Mt. Hope Cemetery Hastings on Hudson, NY.

title: Israel Plans to Recall Envoy Over Right-Wingers in Austria
description: Israel announced today that it would recall its ambassador to Vienna if President Thomas Klestil of Austria authorized a new coalition government that included the rightist Freedom Party led by Jorg Haider.

title: Ernst & Young Cutting Consulting Jobs
description: Ernst & Young L.L.P., the world's third-largest accounting and consulting firm, is eliminating 400 consulting jobs as the firm shifts its focus to electronic commerce.

title: 156 Mexicans Are Jailed After University Melee
description: Mexico's federal authorities jailed 156 strikers from the national university today, including 86 adults and 70 minors, who took part in violent clashes on Tuesday with a faction opposed to the strike. They face charges ranging from disturbing the peace to terrorism, which is a federal felony.

title: Russia Sees Imminent Capture of Grozny, and of Rebels Inside
description: The Russian military insisted today that it had thwarted a rebel attempt to break out of the besieged city of Grozny and would soon capture it.

title: Evicted Mother Also Loses Vital Medical Equipment for Son
description: Katherine Taveras's 4-year-old son lost most of his small intestine to a genetic defect. Nevertheless, he was able to go home from the hospital many weekends, aided by expensive medical machinery that helped him survive while away from the care of doctors.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Defense and Sharpton Carry the Sparring Outdoors
description: For every battle in the courtroom, it appears there will be another outside: between defense lawyers, specifically Stephen C. Worth, and the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVI, ENRICO
description: LEVI-Enrico. The Board of Trustees, President David C. Chang, Chancellor George Bugliarello and other members of the Polytechnic University community are saddened by the passing of Enrico Levi on January 30, 2000. Professor Levi was a 1956 and 1958 graduate in electrical engineering, Polytechnic professor for twenty-five years and recipient of the University's 1998 Distinguished Alumnus Award & numerous international awards for his work in electrical machinery and magnetoplasma technology. We are honored to have known such a brilliant and inspiring teacher and express our heartfelt condolences to his family.

title: Central Bank's Statement On Interest Rate Increases
description: Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term interest rates:

title: Clinton Enlists Top-Grade Help for Plan to Increase Computer Use
description: President Clinton sought to build support today for his $2.3 billion initiative to bridge what he calls the digital divide by convening computer executives, including Stephen M. Case of America Online, at an inner-city high school struggling to wire all its computers to the World Wide Web.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Raises Interest Rates And Hints at Further Action

title: Welfare Plan In City Suffers A Setback
description: The city comptroller yesterday rejected three contracts for organizations hired by the Giuliani administration to help people on welfare find work, ruling that the contracts violated the City Charter and city bidding rules.

title: The Prototypes
description: TODAY'S amenity-rich buildings hark back to Manhattan's first luxury apartment houses, which began to pop up in the 1880's. Developers offered wall safes, filtered water, elevators, barber shops and manicure parlors. Here is a sampling, with pictures from ''Luxury Apartment Houses of Manhattan'' (Dover, 1992). ELAINE LOUIE

title: A Radio That Can Travel Into the Wilderness
description: Motorola's new 6000 series of Talkabout two-way radios are the S.U.V.'s of talk. The series offers all the features of Motorola's previous two-way radios -- 14 channels on the public Radio Service band, 38 privacy codes and a range of up to two miles. The new radios also have a clock with a stopwatch and an alarm, FM stereo radio, a headset, channel scanning (so that you can quickly find your partner with the other radio) and channel scrambling (so that no one can listen in on your conversation).

title: AOL Sued Over Alleged Problems With Software
description: AOL Sued Over Alleged Problems With Software

title: Good Start in the Diallo Case
description: Almost exactly a year after Amadou Diallo's death in a fusillade of 41 police bullets prompted an outpouring of anger over police tactics in minority communities, the trial of four white New York City officers charged with killing the unarmed West African immigrant got underway yesterday in the Albany courtroom of Justice Joseph Teresi of State Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINTELS, RUTH
description: RINTELS-Ruth. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the passing of its beloved member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her entire family. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum Ellen R. Saxl, President

title: James V. Neel Is Dead at 84; Leading Genetics Researcher
description: Dr. James V. Neel, whose work helped uncover the genetic basis of sickle cell anemia and who led extensive studies of radiation's effects on the survivors of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, died on Tuesday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, SAMUEL J.
description: SILBERMAN-Samuel J. (Buddy). Fairleigh Dickinson University sincerely regrets the passing of our long-time friend and benefactor. The University community joins us in extending our sincere sympathy to his wife Lois, his children and grandchildren. Mr. Silberman served as a member of our Board for thirty years and continued as trustee emeritus until his passing. In 1968, in recognition of his outstanding generosity and dedicated service, the University was honored and privileged to name The Samuel J. Silberman College of Business and to confer upon him an honorary doctor of laws. We will sorely miss his wisdom, counsel and presence. J. Michael Adams, President Fairleigh Dickinson University, Paul Lerman, Dean The Samuel J. Silberman College of Business

title: New Fabrics Can Keep Wearers Healthy and Smelling Good
description: FRENCH scientists are developing fabrics that make you not only chic but also protect you against odors, bacteria, fungi and yeast.

title: Experts Warn of Web Surfing Risk
description: Experts Warn of Web Surfing Risk

title: The Nets Take Control, Then Slip Into Despair
description: Nets Coach Don Casey began a somber post-game spiel that included such words as ''aura'' and ''karma'' with a harrowing description of his team's play in tonight's hard-to-stomach loss to the Atlanta Hawks.

title: INTEL PLANS TO SPEND $1.5 BILLION FOR ROCKWELL FACTORY
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest semiconductor maker, said yesterday that it planned to spend about $1.5 billion to buy and refurbish a Colorado computer chip factory from the Rockwell International Corporation. Neither company would disclose the purchase price for the vacant plant in Colorado Springs. Much of the money will be for new equipment, an Intel spokesman, Chuck Mulloy, said. Intel expects the factory will eventually employ more than 1,000 people. Intel is trying to expand production and to make chips more efficiently.

title: Account Decisions By 2 Advertisers
description: Two advertisers have made decisions on accounts.

title: Metro Matters; In New Venue, Diallo Trial Is Settling In
description: IT begs to be said that the trial of four police officers accused of murdering Amadou Diallo -- as sad, politicized and polarized as it is -- nonetheless betrays unmistakable signs of being better off here than there. Here being Albany, there being the Bronx.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It would be wrong to create the impression that the physical exam is an insurmountable barrier for women applicants, when in fact, with sufficient training and sufficient numbers of women applying, the Fire Department could have a much higher success rate of hiring women.''

title: A 3-Hour Talk With Putin Leaves Albright Encouraged
description: After a month of what she called ''psychobabble'' from people trying to decipher Russia's new leader, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met Vladimir V. Putin today on his turf and said she was taken with his ''can-do approach'' and his lack of dogma.

title: The Case of the Flickering Pixels
description: IF anyone should know how hard it is to read from a computer screen, it is Dr. James Sheedy. A clinical professor of optometry at the University of California at Berkeley and founder of its Computer Eye Clinic, Dr. Sheedy has treated patients with computer-related eye strain for nearly 15 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, ROBERT
description: REID-Robert. 82, suddenly on January 30. Bob Reid's encyclopedic knowledge of music and recordings was legendary and he will be sorely missed by his many friends and associates in the music world. He is survived by his brother Richard, sister-in-law Connie, many nieces and nephews, and by Jack McNeil, his loving companion for 48 years. There will be no service, but friends may make a donation to the Lesbian & Gay Community Services Center, 1 Little West 12 St, New York, New York 10014.

title: Rocker Affair: Is Speech the Issue?
description: To the Editor:

title: Splitting the Pixel
description: Splitting The Pixel

title: Bruised Front-Runner Rethinks Strategy
description: Hours after his stinging defeat in the New Hampshire primary, Gov. George W. Bush and his advisers began moving today to contain the damage, imploring supporters and donors to remain on their side and trying to tamp down a controversy in New York State over whether Senator John McCain would be on the primary ballot.

title: U.S. INTERACTIVE AGREES TO BUY SOFTPLUS FOR $372 MILLION
description: U.S. Interactive Inc., an Internet consulting firm founded by Vice President Al Gore's technology adviser, agreed to buy SoftPlus Inc. for about $372 million in stock, cash and new debt. Investors in the closely held SoftPlus will receive 4.8 million U.S. Interactive shares, $20 million in cash and a one-year $80 million note. U.S. Interactive advises clients on topics including electronic commerce, digital-marketing strategies, and the installation and use of technology. Its chairman is Eric Pulier, a Gore adviser. SoftPlus, based in Cupertino, Calif., makes software that integrates wireless telephones and other products for e-commerce by businesses. U.S. Interactive rose $2.875, to $56.75.

title: Independents' Ballots Hold Promise for McCain and Bradley in Future Primaries
description: Independents had a major impact on both parties' pivotal primary elections in New Hampshire on Tuesday, and it was by no means the last that will be heard of them this year.

title: His Success in New Hampshire Brings McCain an Overnight Infusion of Cybercash
description: Moving quickly to capitalize on his startlingly lopsided defeat of Gov. George W. Bush in New Hampshire, Senator John McCain raised more than $500,000 over the Internet in less than 24 hours after the polls there closed, the McCain organization said today.

title: Jets Add a Coordinator And Cut Underachievers
description: In moves that symbolized the topsy-turvy nature of the Jets, the club yesterday cut three players who did not live up to their billing after being acquired last season and brought in a defensive coordinator who was fired from his last job.

title: Noting a Sign of Danger (And Passing) Proves Wise
description: The traditional format of world championships requires the members of a team (of a pair, too) to represent a single country. There was a notable exception at the Orbis championships in Bermuda last month. The Transnational Teams, as its name implies, permitted formations from more than one country. Four of the 76 competing teams took full advantage of this and had members from four nations. One had two players from Denmark, two from the United States, one from Germany and one from China, demonstrating that bridge can promote international friendship.

title: Senators Press For Answers On Gene Trials
description: Under pressure from Congress to explain lapses in oversight of gene therapy, federal health officials acknowledged today that they could not be certain whether experiments had hastened, or possibly caused, the deaths of patients other than the 18-year-old man who died at the University of Pennsylvania last fall.

title: Jergens Chooses Kirshenbaum Bond
description: The Andrew Jergens Company in Cincinnati, a subsidiary of the Kao Corporation, has named Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York to handle its Biore skincare line. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

title: Interim Schools Chancellor Wants 9% Budget Increase
description: Harold O. Levy, the interim New York schools chancellor, said yesterday that he would ask for a 9 percent increase in the Board of Education's budget next year, to $11.4 billion, with roughly half of the new money going to programs to help students meet tough new graduation and promotion requirements.

title: Holik Discovers Extra Meaning Against Rangers
description: Bobby Holik had a simple explanation for the Devils' extended reign over the Rangers in the wake of last night's 3-1 triumph at Madison Square Garden, which ran New Jersey's streak against New York to 17 games without a loss: it's a neighborhood rivalry.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Another Increase by the Fed Brings Just a Yawn From Investors
description: WHO'S afraid of the Federal Reserve? Not Wall Street, it would appear.

title: Precautionary Rate Hike by the Fed
description: Perhaps the Federal Reserve acted prematurely yesterday when it raised short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point in order to reduce spending and thereby weaken inflationary pressures. After all, inflation remains subdued. But the Fed has evidence on its side, and the support of many experts. Its decision is reasonable.

title: Two Workers Killed In Collapse of Plant Under Construction
description: A power plant under construction collapsed yesterday in Milford, Conn., killing two workers, injuring a third and toppling a crane, whose operator was trapped for hours as rescuers worked to free him.

title: A Sport for Purists: Belt-Sander Races
description: WHATEVER happened to no-frills sports?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, MARY J.
description: CLARKE-Mary J. (nee Hodgins). On February 1, 2000 of Forest Hills, New York. Wife of the late Frank J., M.D. Graduate of St. Joseph's College for Women, 1931. Dear mother of Maureen E. Burk of Forest Hills, NY, Michael F. of Hartford, CT, Andrew J. of Baldwin, NY, Angela C. Duff of Forest Hills, NY and Kathleen ClarkePearson of Chapel Hill, NC. Sister of John J. Hodgins & Anne Carlin. Also survived by ten grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Ave, Forest Hills, NY 11375 Thursday 2-4 & 7-9. Funeral mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs RC Church, Queens Blvd at Ascan Ave, Forest Hills Friday, February 4, at 10:15 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Francis Friends of the Poor, 134 West 32 Street, NYC 10001 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, HAROLD M.
description: ROBERTS-Harold M. Of New York City and Southampton, died on February 1, 2000. Loving husband to Jill Louise Curry. Most wonderful and cherished father of Stephanie Emma Bliss. His spirit will live in our hearts. He will be forever loved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, CHARLES
description: NADLER-Charles. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Leonard and father-in-law of Leta, and Annette Kroll. Father-in-law of Erik. Cherished grandfather of Bonnie and Glenn. Services today 11 AM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Age Bias Suit Filed Against Citigroup
description: A former Citigroup executive filed suit against the corporation yesterday, accusing it of age discrimination and of inventing reasons to fire him late last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JOHN FRANCIS
description: ROSS-John Francis. Of Tewksbury Township, NJ. Marine Colonel and President of New York State Industries for the Disabled in Manhattan on Monday January 31, 2000. Beloved husband of Heather Arling Greenagel Ross. Loving father of Christine Ross DeWeese and Kathleen Ross West, both of Baton Rouge, LA, Johnny of Mission Viejo, CA. Dear step-father of Jill Heather Greenagel Garman of San Diego, CA and Frank Lewis Greenagel, Jr. of New Brunswick, NJ. Dear brother of Francis Ross of Worcester, MA. Seven grandchildren, one niece and two nephews. A memorial service will be held at 1 PM on Saturday, February 5, 2000 in the Lamington Presbyterian Church, 300 Lamington Rd, Bedminster, NJ 07921. Funeral Services Kearns Funeral Home, Whitehouse, New Jersey. Memorials may be to the Lamington Church or Printmaking Council of New Jersey, Somerville, NJ 08876 or the Clark Fund for Student Scholarships, Clark University, 950 Main St, Worcester, MA 01610.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHHORN, ELLEN S.
description: HIRSCHHORN-Ellen S. of West Orange, NJ, died February 1, 2000 after a short illness. Age 76, she was a Founding Member and Vice-President of the Jewish Historical Society of MetroWest and a co-President of the Essex County Chapter of the Brandeis National Women's Committee. She served as a Board Member of the Daughters of Israel Geriatric Center in West Orange and the United Jewish Federation of MetroWest. She is survived by her beloved husband of 52 years, Isidor S. Hirschhorn, her son, Robert, her daughter, Susan Hirschhorn and son-in-law, Arthur Klebanoff, two grandsons, Alexander and Jonathan Klebanoff and her mother, Anna Stein. Funeral services will be held at Temple Sharey TefiloIsrael, South Orange, NJ, on Friday, February 4, 2000 at 10:30 AM. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in her memory to either the Brandeis National Women's Committee c/o Sylvia Baron, 806 Morris Turnpike, Short Hills, NJ 07078 or the Jewish Historical Society of MetroWest, 901 Route 10 East, Whippany, NJ 07981

title: Lama's Escape Inflames Buddhist Rivalry
description: Deshin Shekpa was born in the year of the male wood mouse (1384), and it is said he could be heard chanting a mantra and reciting the alphabet while still inside his mother's womb. At the moment of his birth, he boldly proclaimed himself to be the fifth incarnation of the Karmapa, one of Tibetan Buddhism's holiest figures.

title: New Jersey Has Eye on Leon Smith
description: Leon Smith, the troubled rookie who attempted to commit suicide in November, was released by the Dallas Mavericks today. Now that he is available, the Nets will very likely interview and work out the 19-year-old forward soon.

title: Isn't It Romantic? That Shimmery Spell
description: ANYONE who has walked into a room and looked up at a dazzling chandelier knows the statement it makes. ''A chandelier can set the tone for the whole room,'' said William Papp, of Florian Papp, an antiques dealer in Manhattan. He suggests decorating from the ceiling fixture down. Most sparkly chandeliers are made of highly leaded manufactured glass, not natural rock crystal. Yet, it is the leaded glass that is called crystal, or crystal glass.

title: London Looms
description: WITH 2,900 exhibitors and 45,000 visitors, the New York International Gift Fair, which occupied the Javits Convention Center and four Passenger Ship Terminal piers last week, was the size of 14 football fields, but it had the heft of a badminton match. It is the home accessories industry's biannual Feather Bowl. Every Malaysian-made Provencal-style olive oil crock, aromatherapeutic powder-room soap and triwicked pedestal candle known to man was there. And people were shopping, including six Mennonite women from Waynesboro, Pa., buying toys and gifts for their store, Violets and More, housed in a 70-foot trailer, where they also sell crafts made by the community. ''We found a lot of nice things,'' said Noella Martin, who attended with her mother and the others. ''We did a nice amount of ordering.''

title: Campaigns Must Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: WELLS FARGO IN $480 MILLION DEAL FOR FIRST COMMERCE
description: Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire First Commerce Bancshares Inc., a Nebraska bank holding company, for $480 million in stock. First Commerce, based in Lincoln, Neb., has assets of $2.55 billion. It posted 1998 earnings of $26.6 million. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, has assets of $202.48 billion. It earned $1.95 billion last year. Upon closing, Wells Fargo will fold First Commerce into its Norwest Bank Nebraska unit. First Commerce shareholders will exchange their shares for Wells Fargo shares worth about $35.95 a share. The Class B shares of First Commerce rose $2, to $34, and the Class A shares were up $1 each, at $34.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the passengers on an Alaska Airlines jet that crashed on Monday in the Pacific Ocean northwest of Los Angeles misspelled the given name of a victim. She was Coriander Clemetson, not Coriande. The article also misstated relationships in the Clemetson family. Coriander and her sister, Blake, were the stepchildren, not the children, of Carolyn Clemetson. Their parents were Dr. Claire Barnett and David Clemetson. Carolyn and David Clemetson were the parents of Miles and Spencer Clemetson.

title: Escaping Into Nostalgia or Seeking a New Order
description: Organizers of 20th-century musical thought had best use a loose-leaf notebook. The categories, the motives, the themes and the languages are almost infinitely rearrangeable. Perhaps chaos theory has applications to music.

title: Porcelain Serenity
description: WITH 2,900 exhibitors and 45,000 visitors, the New York International Gift Fair, which occupied the Javits Convention Center and four Passenger Ship Terminal piers last week, was the size of 14 football fields, but it had the heft of a badminton match. It is the home accessories industry's biannual Feather Bowl. Every Malaysian-made Provencal-style olive oil crock, aromatherapeutic powder-room soap and triwicked pedestal candle known to man was there. And people were shopping, including six Mennonite women from Waynesboro, Pa., buying toys and gifts for their store, Violets and More, housed in a 70-foot trailer, where they also sell crafts made by the community. ''We found a lot of nice things,'' said Noella Martin, who attended with her mother and the others. ''We did a nice amount of ordering.''

title: First Store Opens at the First Shopping Mall in Harlem
description: As dozens of headset-sporting store workers handed out dark blue mesh tote bags to use in place of shopping carts, a two-level Old Navy store began welcoming customers yesterday, becoming the first retailer in the long-awaited Harlem U.S.A. complex to open its doors.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the selection of Hans Blix as the chief inspector of the United Nations' new disarmament commission for Iraq rendered a word incorrectly in a quotation from the United States ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency, and a correction on Friday misspelled the ambassador's surname. He is John Ritch, not Ritchie. He said that new inspection authority and investigative technologies acquired by the agency when Mr. Blix was its director were ''now'' being put into effect worldwide; he did not say ''not.''

title: Seton Hall Will Install Sprinklers In Dormitories
description: Two weeks after a dormitory fire here killed three students and injured 58 others, administrators at Seton Hall University said today that they would install sprinklers -- or upgrade existing ones -- in all of the school's residence halls even though it was not required by law.

title: A Gadget Bookmarks The World
description: IMAGINE you are in your sport utility urban assault vehicle, heading to work, when a new and unknown song on the radio tickles your fancy. Knowing that modern radio D.J.'s no longer announce the name of the artist or the title of a song, you simply point your Xenote iTag clicker at the radio, click it and go about your day.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the appointment of Xana Antunes as the editor of The New York Post referred incorrectly to the position of Marc Kalech at the paper. While assigned to head the arts and entertainment section, he remains a managing editor.

title: Fresh Samantha Acquired
description: Odwalla Inc., a maker of fruit and vegetable juices, said today that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Fresh Samantha Inc. for about $27 million in stock to increase sales. Odwalla will exchange about 3.8 million shares of its common stock for Fresh Samantha, which sells juices and soy shakes in New York, Philadelphia, Florida, New Jersey, North Carolina, Washington and New England. Doug Levin, chief executive and founder of Fresh Samantha, which is based in Saco, Me., will become president of Odwalla, based in Half Moon Bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARDOS, LESLIE
description: BARDOS-Leslie (Laszlo ) MD Judith and her family mourn the passing of a dear friend. He was honest and warm, a wonderful man, a true gentleman in everyway. We will miss him. Our sincere condolences to Zsuzsi, Judith, Albert, his grandchildren and their families. Judith, Samuel, Shelly Kellner

title: Study Says Children With Cancer Suffer More Than Necessary
description: Children who are dying of cancer suffer greatly because they are not given adequate treatment for pain, shortness of breath, profound fatigue, nausea and other distressing symptoms, according to a study being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Behrens Is Favored In a Field of 12
description: Behrens, one of the racing stars of last year, was made the favorite yesterday when 12 horses were entered in Saturday's Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park in Hallandale, Fla., the inaugural race of the handicap season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSTON, ELBERT
description: JOHNSTON-Elbert. February 3, 1978. So long as we remember, you live. Mom and Wilvena

title: Police Break Up Car-Theft-Insurance Ring
description: They were regular folks -- dentists, schoolteachers, cooks, housewives, even two New Jersey police officers -- who thought they could make some easy money by collecting on their car theft insurance, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, HELEN GARY
description: MORAN-Helen Gary, 93, of Manhattan, on February 1. Daughter of Hampson Gary, Ambassador to Egypt and Switzerland under President Wilson. Widow of industrialist Bernard A. Moran. Helen is survived by her sons Bernard Moran Jr., John P. Moran and Michael Moran. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., Friday, 6-8PM. Funeral service Saturday 1PM, St. Thomas Episcopal.

title: After One Tough Test, The Torture of New York
description: After being trounced in Iowa and surviving a four-point loss in New Hampshire on Tuesday, Bill Bradley managed to make it to the next phase of his campaign yesterday, flying into New York in preparation for a primary that his advisers say is critical to any hope he has of being the Democratic candidate for president.

title: The Mystery of Flight 261
description: The crash of Alaska Airlines Flight 261 is the latest in a stream of ocean crashes -- the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 off Long Island in 1996, the Swissair crash off the Canadian coast in 1998, the EgyptAir plane crash off the Massachusetts coast last year and, just this past Sunday, the Kenya Airways disaster near the Ivory Coast.

title: Artists Find Scientific Support for High-Tech Projects
description: February 3, 2000

title: STEEL PROFITS SURGE
description: Profits at Companhia Siderurgica Tubarao, one of Brazil's main steel exporters, surged to 99.8 million reais, or $55.8 million, in the fourth quarter of 1999, compared with a loss a year earlier. A weaker currency helped exports of steel slabs to climb 41 percent to 1.32 million tons. Revenue more than doubled to 451 million reais, or $252 million.

title: Now, A Few Words From Friends and Sponsors
description: If you are one of the few people on this planet who has never received an advertisement via e-mail, just wait.

title: Overkill on Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Mouring's 22 Points Pace UConn Men as They Finally Shake Villanova
description: Connecticut does not score in bunches the way it did when it won the national championship last season. So when a hot hand emerges, the No. 7 Huskies gratefully accept it.

title: SOFTBANK FAVORED TO BUY BANK
description: The shares of Japan's largest Internet investment company, the Softbank Corporation, rose to a record after Japanese officials said they favored its bid to take over Nippon Credit Bank Ltd. The stock closed the day, however, down 3,000 yen, at 103,000. Acquiring Nippon Credit would give Softbank a banking license.

title: In America; Webs of Influence
description: Al Gore believes his role in streamlining the federal bureaucracy was one of his major achievements as vice president. The sale at auction of the huge, government-owned Elk Hills oil field in Bakersfield, Calif., to the Occidental Petroleum Company grew out of that effort. The winning bid was $3.65 billion. It was the largest sale of a government asset to private industry ever, and it got the federal government out of the oil business.

title: Few Women Achieve Fire Dept. Standards
description: Despite an intensive recruiting effort, New York City officials said only 11 women have scored high enough on tests, especially a tough physical exam, to qualify to be firefighters. There are only 36 women in the 11,000-member Fire Department, whose failure to hire female recruits has led to lawsuits and left it facing the issue of how to draw women to a force known for male bravado.

title: Closing the Digital Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOLOWICZ, PETER
description: JOLOWICZ-Peter. Age 87 of New Haven, CT, died January 29, 2000. Father of Katherine of Los Angeles, brother of Raymundo in Mexico and Franz Dieter Jolowicz of NYC. Also survived by stepdaughter Sasha Dobush of Tenafly, two step-grandchildren Jennifer and Nick, two nephews Alan and Ivan. Mr. Jolowicz received his engineering degree from the Technische Hochschule in Zurich and was a long time New Haven resident. He was fluent in Spanish and during his professional career was frequently sent to Latin American countries to supervise construction projects or feasibility studies. After retirement he continued to accept such assignments in Egypt, Panama Canal and the Phillipines. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINSSON, JACQUES
description: VINSSON-Jacques. On February 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Paula. Loving uncle of John, Larry and Michael. Devoted cousin.

title: Foreign Aid Donors Approve $4.7 Billion More for Indonesia
description: International donors meeting in Jakarta gave Indonesia's government a powerful show of support today, agreeing to provide as much as $4.7 billion in credit to fill a shortage in the nation's budget and keep its tenuous economic recovery alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAL, RICHARD D.
description: MORGAL-Richard D. Of Dix Hills. Retired Vice President of Dale Carnegie. Beloved husband of Dixie H. Loving father of Michael J. and Sherry McCloskey. Cherished grandfather of Alison and Bridget. Caring brother of Donnabelle Lindow. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 5, 2000 at 10 AM, the Congregational Church of Manhasset, 1845 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to an educational charity of your choice.

title: SENATE APPROVES A BILL TO TOUGHEN BANKRUPTCY RULES
description: The Senate approved a sweeping overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws today, decisively passing a measure that would make it harder for people to seek legal protection from payment of their debts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALY, CECILIA RIVERA
description: HEALY-Cecilia Rivera. The Catholic Child Care Society (Saint Joseph Services) mourns the death of its Executive Director. We are deeply grateful for having had her come in to our lives and hearts. Deepest sympathy to her husband John, her mother Julieta and the entire family. John J. Bennett, Jr., Pres. Belinda M. Conway, Acting Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, MARGARET
description: ANDREWS-Margaret. On January 31, 2000. Survived by her son Neal of Mechanicville, N.Y., daughter Leslie of Seattle, Wa., brother Robert Cherry of Tucson, Az., and also many friends. A celebration of her life will be held at the All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave(80th St) NYC, Thursday, February 3rd. at 11am. Reception to follow. For further information please contact the John Krtil Funeral Home; Yorkville Funeral Service, Inc. 212-744-3084. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in her memory to the American Cancer Society or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: Israeli Lawmakers Hold Quick Debate on Nuclear Arms
description: Israel's Parliament today begrudgingly held its first public discussion in more than 35 years about the country's long-secret nuclear arms programs, and the usually loquacious body had so little to say that the debate was over in 52 minutes.

title: Sports of The Times; Tennis Tries to Take Root in Unlikely Soil
description: There were four tennis courts and a wall to hit against, all surrounded by acres upon acres of poverty. On this oasis of athleticism, there were kids with big smiles hitting forehands, and a few of them had bare feet.

title: Tax Traffic Swamps H & R Block's Site
description: H & R Block, the tax preparation concern, said yesterday that it had shut down its tax preparation Web site Tuesday night because an unexpected surge of customers overwhelmed its software.

title: A Colorado Import Finds A Sense of Shared Purpose
description: Regional ballet companies don't drop into New York as often as in the past. All the more reason to see the excellent dancers that the Colorado Ballet put on display in its Manhattan debut on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Finger Lakes Authentic
description: WITH 2,900 exhibitors and 45,000 visitors, the New York International Gift Fair, which occupied the Javits Convention Center and four Passenger Ship Terminal piers last week, was the size of 14 football fields, but it had the heft of a badminton match. It is the home accessories industry's biannual Feather Bowl. Every Malaysian-made Provencal-style olive oil crock, aromatherapeutic powder-room soap and triwicked pedestal candle known to man was there. And people were shopping, including six Mennonite women from Waynesboro, Pa., buying toys and gifts for their store, Violets and More, housed in a 70-foot trailer, where they also sell crafts made by the community. ''We found a lot of nice things,'' said Noella Martin, who attended with her mother and the others. ''We did a nice amount of ordering.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates and traders speculated that the European Central Bank might follow suit. The euro gained 0.46 cent, to 97.57 cents, in New York.

title: Untangling Knots in the Subway; Architect's Challenge Is to Make DeKalb Station Flow
description: When Lee Harris Pomeroy was a student at Brooklyn Technical High School in the 1940's, he thought that the DeKalb Avenue subway station in downtown Brooklyn, part of his daily commute to class, was ''old and tired and looked as if it could use work.''

title: The High-Speed Train That Thought It Could, but Can't
description: INSPIRATION for the new logo for Amtrak's Acela train began, strangely, with a turtle.

title: A D.S.L. Success Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Poll Results Show Vulnerability In Calling Primaries Accurately
description: Polls of New Hampshire voters taken before Tuesday's primary election mostly got each party's winner right but were often not so accurate in measuring the size of each victory.

title: Accompanying a Robot on an Antarctic Quest
description: Nomad, the very otherworldly robot that is currently searching Antarctica for meteorites, is sharing its discoveries on the World Wide Web.

title: Israeli Says U.S. Fears Endanger Major Purchase of Apache Copters
description: American reluctance to share secret military software with Israel threatens a possible $800 million Israeli purchase of Boeing combat helicopters, the air force commander said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIM, EDITH
description: HAIM-Edith. On February 1, 2000. Loving wife of the late Joseph. Beloved ''Ma'' of Margaret and Tony Nanni. Cherished grandmother to Elizabeth and John Roddy. Loved by all who knew her. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at the Second Presbyterian Church, 6 West 96 Street, New York City. Burial will take place Saturday in Rockville, Maryland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REUTERSHAN, DONALD E.
description: REUTERSHAN-Donald E. Skidmore College notes with great sadness the death of trustee emeritus and long-time supporter, Donald E. Reutershan. As a member of the Board of Trustees for 25 years and as its chair from 1979 to 1983, he helped to lead Skidmore through a period of monumental change and growth. His bold advocacy of coeducation, diversity, and the construction of a new campus helped to shape the college he served with such intelligence, loyalty, and affection. The Skidmore community sends its condolences to the Reutershan family. Jamienne S. Studley, President Skidmore College

title: Corrective Medicine; New Technology Helps Health Care Avoid Mistakes
description: Every morning, Stan Pestotnik, a pharmacist, studies reports on several dozen patients at LDS Hospital, one of the nation's most technologically advanced hospitals. He zeros in on two or three who have been flagged by a computer as dangerously close to being harmed by medications they are taking.

title: Peeking at an Atom in a Hall of Mirrors
description: Crossing a barrier that once seemed impassable, physicists in recent years have used a delicate instrument called a scanning tunneling microscope to reach down into the very substrate of matter, feeling the bumps and grooves of atoms and even picking them up and moving them around like so many grains of sand.

title: String Games: More Than Just Child's Play
description: CAT'S CRADLE is one of the world's simplest string games. Along with its cousins -- Jacob's ladder, cup and saucer, crow's feet -- it is played by schoolchildren everywhere.

title: Tracking Down Nashville's Soul at Last
description: For the last five months I have been writing from Nashville, searching for the heart of Music City. I have gone to the mansions of country stars, the shotgun shacks of forgotten singers, the offices of music executives, the dressing rooms of the Grand Ole Opry and the basements where the wax figures of yesterday's country stars lay vandalized. And then one day I found it: the soul of a city that residents often say lacks one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIENSTOCK, WILLIAM
description: BIENSTOCK-William, 89, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, on January 31, 2000. Beloved husband of Sara. Loving father of Errol and Paula, David, Michael & Sophie. Adored grandfather of Lori, Michelle and Kristen and the late Bradley. Cherished brother of Roz and Rae.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about talks between Vodafone AirTouch of Britain and Mannesmann of Germany misstated the affiliation of a telecommunications analyst, Roderick Chisholm, who was quoted on the the prospects of a deal. He is with HSBC Securities in London, not Salomon Smith Barney.

title: Mr. Bush and Free Elections
description: Maybe a few months ago, New York's Republican leadership figured that rigging the state's primary election for George W. Bush was a smart, tough political move. But according to reports in The Times today, Bush strategists have decided that the ballot trickery endorsed by Gov. George Pataki is working against them and playing into Senator John McCain's image as a reformer who does not have to be protected from competition by the party establishment. So one of the side effects of Mr. McCain's upset victory in New Hampshire is that New York Republicans may now be able to vote in an open election featuring a full slate of Republican presidential candidates in the March 7 primary.

title: Bush Kept Off Ballot in South Bronx After Party Admits Fraud
description: The New York Republican State Committee, which wants to bar Senator John McCain from the presidential primary in some parts of the state for submitting flawed nominating petitions, made a surprising concession yesterday: its workers fraudulently assembled petitions for the party favorite, Gov. George W. Bush, in a Congressional district in the South Bronx.

title: G.O.P. Considers Dropping McCain Ballot Fight
description: Worrying that the state Republican Party's attempts to knock Senator John McCain off the presidential primary ballot have backfired, Republican and Bush campaign officials said today that they might abandon their court fight with Mr. McCain.

title: 2 Killed as Rocket Hits a U.N. Bus for Serbs in Kosovo
description: A rocket attack on a bus filled with Serbian civilians killed two elderly villagers and wounded three more people today, just yards from their armed NATO escort.

title: Cell Phone Thieves Try to Stay a Step Ahead
description: Cell Phone Thieves Try to Stay a Step Ahead

title: Rocker Affair: Is Speech the Issue?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBOWITZ, HARVEY
description: LIBOWITZ-Harvey, on February 1st. Devoted husband to Fran. Loving daddy to daughters, Syd and Marla. Very special grandpa to Baruchi, Andy and Ronnie. Beloved brother of Thelma. A truly unique and incredibly talented man, cherished by all extended family. He will live on in our hearts forever. If desired, contributions in Harvey's name may be made to: Lighthouse International, 111 East 59 Street, NYC 10022.

title: Isle Haunted by the Past And a Grumpy Presence
description: GREENE ON CAPRI

title: Hernandez to Tutor Mets at First Base
description: When Keith Hernandez had back surgery in 1991, he knew his playing career was over. Back problems still bother the former Mets first baseman, and they have imposed on him a certain realism. When baseball ended, it was over, and Hernandez has no desire to be ruled by its schedule again.

title: Inquiry Grows Into Reports Ambulances Avoided Some Hospitals
description: The Fire Department is expanding its investigation into allegations that unionized city ambulance crews are diverting patients away from hospitals that have contracted with private ambulance companies, fire officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHNER, RUTH
description: KUSHNER-Ruth, died February 1. The widow of Samuel Kushner, she was the mother of Kenneth, deceased, and Judith Felsenfeld, married to Carl. Also she is survived by her grandson, Peter Felsenfeld; great-granddaughter, Sierra; sister, Hilda Baker and brothers, Abe and Leonard Mokover. Her funeral will take place on Friday, February 4, 9:30 AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. Donations are encouraged to the Palliative Care Program at Mount Sinai Hospital, Box 1070, One Gustave Levy Pl, NY 10029; or the Dept. of Social Services at the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, New York 10471.

title: Bringing Back A Swedish Classic
description: WITH 2,900 exhibitors and 45,000 visitors, the New York International Gift Fair, which occupied the Javits Convention Center and four Passenger Ship Terminal piers last week, was the size of 14 football fields, but it had the heft of a badminton match. And people were shopping, including six Mennonite women from Waynesboro, Pa., buying toys and gifts for their store, Violets and More, housed in a 70-foot trailer, where they also sell crafts made by the community. ''We found a lot of nice things,'' said Noella Martin, who attended with her mother and the others. ''We did a nice amount of ordering.''

title: Publicis Group is acquiring Fallon McElligott, catching Madison Avenue off guard.
description: ON Sunday, Fallon McElligott, the creatively focused agency known for risk-taking, rule-breaking work for brands like Holiday Inn, Miller Lite, Timex and United, enjoyed what was deemed its biggest day ever, running four clutter-busting spots during Super Bowl XXXIV for BMW, EDS and Nuveen Investments.

title: Anne Hebert, 83, Poet and Novelist of Quebec
description: Anne Hebert, a poet and novelist who brought the violent passions of her native rural Quebec to wider audiences in France and the United States, died on Jan. 23 at a hospital in Montreal. She was 83 and lived in Quebec City.

title: After His Smashing Victory, McCain Is Now the Talk of the Diner
description: It is virtually illegal in this state to acknowledge that any event in New Hampshire might possibly influence the thinking of a South Carolinian. But today, just hours after Senator John McCain's smashing victory up North, there seemed to be a lot more McCain admirers eating lunch than there did last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NETANYAHU, TZILA
description: NETANYAHU-Tzila. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the loss of the mother of former Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu. We pray that the entire family will be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Shows, Walks, Talks and Gardens
description: All Antiques

title: Agassi Already a Force in Zimbabwe
description: Sure, he admitted that he could have used the time off between winning the Australian Open and playing in San Jose, Calif., by the middle of next week. But Andre Agassi had committed himself to the flag and John McEnroe, though not necessarily in that order.

title: Editor of I.D. Is Leaving
description: AS the editor in chief of I.D. magazine for seven years, Chee Pearlman has made lead stories out of such unlikely subjects as pasta, prosthetic devices, plastic coffee cup lids and bugs. In the process she has transformed I.D., a trade journal for design, into a zippy platform for new products with a high-tech edge.

title: Time Warner Reports Gain In Results for Fourth Quarter
description: Time Warner Inc., which has agreed to be acquired by America Online Inc., said its fourth-quarter profit from operations rose on higher magazine advertising sales and new subscribers to the cable channel HBO, home of the hit drama ''The Sopranos.''

title: Modern Looks For Mission Style
description: WITH 2,900 exhibitors and 45,000 visitors, the New York International Gift Fair, which occupied the Javits Convention Center and four Passenger Ship Terminal piers last week, was the size of 14 football fields, but it had the heft of a badminton match. title: As Anti-Haider Protests Rise, Move on Coalition Stalls
description: As thousands marched here to protest the prospect of including a rightist party led by Jorg Haider in the government, President Thomas Klestil met today with party leaders but failed to announce whether he would accept such a coalition.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Biased Words in '38 Led to a Suspension
description: It turns out that John Rocker is not the first baseball player to be suspended for speech. At least one player was previously suspended for something he said, and he was a teammate of the Hall of Famers Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio, Bill Dickey, Red Ruffing and Lefty Gomez.

title: Direct-Mail Solicitations Get Most Money in Senate 'Noncampaign'
description: Direct-mail fund-raising campaigns by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton have cost the two candidates for the United States Senate in New York more than $3 million in the last six months, by far the largest chunk of spending in what is on track to become the most expensive Senate race in history.

title: Hobe Morrison, 95, a Drama Critic for Variety
description: Hobe Morrison, a longtime drama critic for Variety, died on Jan. 22. He was 95 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sites and Events This Week
description: Sites and Events This Week

title: Beyond Pottery: Chic Cylinders
description: WITH 2,900 exhibitors and 45,000 visitors, the New York International Gift Fair, which occupied the Javits Convention Center and four Passenger Ship Terminal piers last week, was the size of 14 football fields, but it had the heft of a badminton match. It is the home accessories industry's biannual Feather Bowl. Every Malaysian-made Provencal-style olive oil crock, aromatherapeutic powder-room soap and triwicked pedestal candle known to man was there. And people were shopping, including six Mennonite women from Waynesboro, Pa., buying toys and gifts for their store, Violets and More, housed in a 70-foot trailer, where they also sell crafts made by the community. ''We found a lot of nice things,'' said Noella Martin, who attended with her mother and the others. ''We did a nice amount of ordering.''

title: For a Fee, or Pro Bono?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIMAN, HAROLD I.
description: LEIMAN-Harold I. Distinguished Rabbi and Educator, author of Koheleth: ''Life and its Meaning'' and co-author of ''Science and Judaism''. A disciple of Rav Shraga Feivel Mendlowitz, he served as Assistant Principal of Mesivta Torah Vodaath, 1933-1936; Principal of Mesivta Rabbi Chaim Berlin, 1936-1948; Principal of the Hebrew Institute of Long Island, 1948-1960 and 1970-1971; Lecturer, Department of Education, Brooklyn College, 1960-1962; Dean of the Hebrew Academy of Essex County, 1962-1965; and as teacher and administrator at Michlalah and Boys' Town in Jerusalem and at Mosdot Ponievez in Ashdod. Beloved husband of Harriet; devoted father of Yehoshua (and Chana) and Shnayer (and Rivkah); dear brother of Sheila; also survived by grandchildren, great-grandchildren and countless students. Shiva at the Ramat Tamir Hotel in Jerusalem and in Kew Garden Hills, NY.

title: Metro Business; Times Sq. Tower Planned
description: The Milstein family, a real estate group in New York, is planning to build a 1.1-million-square-foot office tower near Times Square, a spokesman for the developer said.

description: News Watch: Accompanying a Robot on an Antarctic Quest
