title: The Art of Virtual Chat Is Still a Work in Progress
description: FIFTY years ago, the British mathematician Alan M. Turing predicted that by about the turn of the century, the average person would not have more than a 70 percent chance of distinguishing a human from a computer program trying to imitate a human in a question-and-answer session.

title: Victories That Will Be Fleeting
description: New Hampshire's returns were not only a case of the suppposed winning candidates losing, but of men losing whose whole rationale for being in the race at all was that they are winners. The Republican establishment backed George W. Bush early (and lavishly) because this time out, it preferred winning to principle. What happens, then, when the winner does not win?

title: Elian's Family Connections to Cuba Are Deeper
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Focuses 'Super Tuesday' Strategy on a Few Key States
description: Since the beginning of the presidential campaign, former Senator Bill Bradley has asserted that his entire strategy was founded on building toward ''Super Tuesday,'' March 7, when 16 states, including New York and California, will select nearly 30 percent of the Democratic Party's presidential delegates.

title: A Five-Hour Train Ride Dedicated to Schmoozing
description: As the Schmooze Express rolled down the New Jersey rails toward the nation's capital today, the biggest attention getters were not the half-dozen candidates for the United States Senate aboard, or even the three Men Who Would Be Governor, but the most creative giveaways.

title: Antoni Tapies
description: PaceWildenstein

title: Police Are Captivated By Courtroom Drama
description: The dozen police officers in the back room of the American Diner and Restaurant yesterday scanned their menus, ordered their meals and, as the waitress took their orders to the grill, promptly spun their chairs to face the television.

title: SWISS REINSURANCE SAYS IT TRIED TO ACQUIRE PARTNERRE
description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company, the world's second-largest reinsurer, disclosed yesterday that it offered in November to acquire the Bermuda reinsurer PartnerRe Ltd., a month before it agreed to pay $725 million to buy Underwriters Re Group Inc. Swiss Re would have had to spend about $1.2 billion for PartnerRe. Swiss Re, which already has a 26 percent stake in PartnerRe, said the two sides could not agree on a price, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Swiss Re told PartnerRe it had disclosed the talks to the S.E.C. because it might raise its PartnerRe holdings to 30 percent, a PartnerRe spokeswoman said.

title: C.E.O. Candidate Facing a Hard Task
description: Norman Blake Jr. said yesterday that it was important to restore public confidence in the United States Olympic Committee in the wake of last year's bribery scandal surrounding Salt Lake City's successful bid for the 2002 Winter Games. But he does not expect the task to be easy.

title: Expect the World
description: Here is a sampling of performances of world music in Manhattan in the next few months. Locations include Blarney Star, 43 Murray Street, TriBeCa, (212) 732-2873; Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 496-7070; Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; S.O.B's, 204 Varick Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940; Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, (212) 840-2824; Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 545-7536 or (212) 864-5400; Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 545-7536; World Financial Center, Winter Garden, West Street between Vesey and Liberty Streets, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, JACOB P.
description: ROSENBAUM-Jacob P., on February 2, 2000. Beloved husband of Esther. Loving father of Janet and Lawrence. Devoted grandfather of Jonathan Axelrod. Private service.

title: Power Uses All His Skills To Win Title
description: The Canadian Jonothon Power, using his attacking style and trademark anticipatory skills, won his third DLJdirect Tournament of Champions squash title yesterday, defeating Scotland's Martin Heath, 3 games to 1, at Grand Central Station in Manhattan.

title: Residential Real Estate; Assisted-Living Project With a Twist
description: Work has begun in the Manhattan neighborhood of Clinton on a building containing both a community health center and 84 rental apartments for low- and moderate-income elderly tenants, who will be supplied with meals and a modest level of personal service.

title: Start-Up Lawyers, Now at Cyber-Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: EL PASO ENERGY PLANS TO BUY PART OF SOUTHWEST PIPELINE
description: The El Paso Energy Corporation, a fast-growing natural gas company based in Houston, agreed yesterday to buy part of an oil pipeline in the Southwest from Plains All American Pipeline L.P. for $129 million. Under the agreement, El Paso's El Paso Natural Gas Company is to acquire a 1,088-mile portion that runs from McCamey, Tex., to near Bakersfield, Calif. El Paso is to spend $75 million to convert the oil pipeline to a natural gas pipeline. The project would enable El Paso to replace its existing natural gas compression operations, reducing costs. Plains All American Pipeline, an oil transportation and storage partnership, is controlled by Plains Resources Inc. of Houston.

title: Even as Deals Fly, Wireless Remains a Tower of Babel
description: Though Vodafone AirTouch of Britain's $183 billion deal to acquire Mannesmann of Germany would be the biggest takeover in corporate history, reactions to the deal yesterday from telecommunications analysts and wireless telephone executives in the United States were characterized mostly by profound ennui.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Theater; Tailoring Intimate to a Larger Size
description: In its corn-tassel golden heyday, the American musical presented its own happy vision of a democratic society. True, its plots were usually about the willfully individual: lovers who wanted only to be alone together, comic wild cards and trouble-making malcontents. But you could also count on moments in which the whole cast would sing together, with melding voices and synchronized smiles and movements, from the title song of ''Oklahoma!'' to the top-hat-and-tails finale of ''A Chorus Line.''

title: Pit Bulls and Statesmen
description: To the Editor:

title: So Where's Virginia Woolf When You Need Her?
description: Near the end of ''Lighthouse,'' the grade-C British horror thriller that sneaks into local theaters today, its damsel in distress, Dr. Kirsty McCloud (Rachel Shelley), a comely criminal psychiatrist, is dangling from a frayed, burning rope on the side of a lighthouse amid a cloudburst lighted with exploding electrical fireworks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKIN, NORMAN E.
description: HENKIN-Norman E. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Norman E. Henkin, exemplary member of CUNY's Board of Trustees from 1969 to 1973. Attorney & community leader. His many contributions will be long remembered. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Herman Badillo, Chairman Baord of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELLA, DOROTHY ANNE
description: CELLA-Dorothy Anne, 74 of Glen Rock, NJ, died February 2. Mrs. Cella was a Vice President with U.S. Trust Co., NY, NY before her retirement in 1995. Survived by her husband Carlo D. Jr., 3 daughters: Dorothy K. Gallagher, Margot A. O'Connor, Elena V. Cella., four sons, Carlo D. III, John D., Michael F., James C., a brother Frederick J. Driscoll Jr., ten grandchildren and one great grandchild. A Mass will be held at 10 A.M., Saturday, February 5th, at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Ridgewood, NJ. Friends may call from 2-4 and 7-9 Friday at the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 E. Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood, New Jersey.

title: ISRAELI COMPANY AGREES TO ACQUIRE WORLD ACCESS UNIT
description: World Access Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Telco Systems unit to BATM Advanced Communications Ltd. of Israel for $326 million in cash and stock. Telco Systems, based in Norwood, Mass., manufactures network products for telecommunications services. World Access, based in Atlanta, said the sale was part of a plan to focus on its core voice, data and Internet operations. Separately, World Access reduced the amount it will pay for Star Telecommunications by as much as $175 million. Instead of the $10.50 a share minimum that it offered last month, World Access said it was proposing to pay $7.50 to $8 a share, or $440 million to $469 million. World Access said Star agreed to accept the reduced price in return for ''significant capital.''

title: Just Before Crash, Pilots Called Mechanic for Help
description: A few minutes before an Alaska Airlines jet crashed offshore here on Monday, the crew radioed a company mechanic in Los Angeles that the device that forms most of the horizontal section of the tail was pushing the nose down, and they asked if there was a way to cut power to the device.

title: INSIDE
description: The Other Chechen Conflict

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Downhill With an Expert, Polishing Skills on the Fly
description: Every season my first day on skis is a bit of an adventure. As I feel the brisk wind on my face, gaze out at the blanket of white covering the mountain, I wonder why we treat the arrival of winter as if it were an invitation to the Donner party. Then as I approach the top of the chairlift, I peek at those long planks of fiberglass, Kevlar and polyethylene attached to my feet and wonder, ''Do I really remember how to work these things?''

title: An Unwelcome Austrian Government
description: Now that Austria's president has approved formation of a new government that includes an intolerant far-right party, the rest of the world has to decide how to respond. The appropriate reaction is to cool relations with Austria, which is what the European Union, the United States and Israel seem prepared to do.

title: Neo-Classicism That Is Red in Tooth and Claw
description: Think of the artist George Stubbs (1724-1806), and you probably think of racehorses as sleek as Maseratis and grouse-fed country gents posed under spritzy English skies. Those are the subjects he painted most often, and supremely well.

title: Americans Just One Victory From Final
description: In dominating, take-no-prisoners fashion, the San Francisco-based America One syndicate pushed Italy's Prada Challenge to the brink of elimination today in Race 7 of the Louis Vuitton series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWINGS, ABRAHAM L.
description: COWINGS-Abraham L. On February 1. Services John H. Joyce Funeral Home, 2332 Adam Clayton Powell Jr Blvd, NYC Saturday, February 5, 12 noon.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: NEW DIRECTIONS: ''New Directions'' (Blue Note). The history of Blue Note Records in the 1950's and 60's is both routinely fetishized and dulled. There's no other period of jazz from which the documents are so beautiful: Reid Miles's constructivist album-cover designs, Francis Wolff's tenebrous photographs of musicians in the studio, the intimate, resonating sound created for them by the engineer Rudy Van Gelder. And yet when the average group of young jazz musicians these days decides to play a classic tune associated with the label from that period, like Lee Morgan's ''Sidewinder'' or Joe Henderson's ''Recorda Me,'' watch out for musical diffidence, the stuff that gives jazz a stodgy name, with no apparent will to update those strong little melodies and small-group arrangements.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Republicans of New York, rejoice! You're free!''

title: The Ultimate Scream: Still Mad, Still Slashing
description: At this point it goes without saying that the ''Scream'' movies are like episodes of ''Scooby Doo.'' Like the others, ''Scream 3'' belongs on the Cartoon Network. This time for a better reason: the film is funny and brisk, with enough good lines to make the comedy more satisfying than the somewhat routine but still unsettling jolts to the spine.

title: The Shortage of Health Aides
description: The shortage of workers willing to bathe, dress, feed, clean and care for the elderly, in their homes and in nursing homes, has grown worse in the last two years as the economy has continued to soar, creating many other jobs that pay as well or better for much less demanding work. Fast-food restaurants and Target stores now may offer equal wages, steadier work and better benefits, and zookeepers, toll-takers and manicurists actually earn more.

description: February 4, 2000

title: Not Easy to Like, but Impossible to Forget
description: HIS general note is lyrical understanding of the street, trained observation of it, special feeling for patina, eye for revealing detail, over all of which is thrown a poetry.''

title: Richard G. Kleindienst, Figure in Watergate Era, Dies at 76
description: Richard G. Kleindienst, who was President Richard M. Nixon's attorney general for less than a year in the Watergate era and who pleaded guilty to a crime in a peripheral scandal, died today at his home in Prescott, Ariz. He was 76.

title: Jets' New Coordinator Tackles Past
description: It is indicative of the plight that Mike Nolan endured with the Washington Redskins last season that on the first day of his new job with the Jets, Nolan answered more questions about the miseries of the old position than about the hopes for the new one.

description: SCANDALMONGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELCH, MILDRED E. (NEE) SILVER
description: WELCH-Mildred E. (nee) Silver. Died January 31, 2000. Beloved wife of James for 57 years, loving mother of Janet, Lauren and John, cherished grandmother of James Jan. She was born in Boston, MA (West End), March 29, 1916, where she spent the happiest years of her childhood. She married her husband, James, in 1942 and following World War II moved to New York City. Along with her husband, James, a gifted trombonist, they enjoyed Manhattan life, especially the finest pastry shops the city has to offer. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (81 St), Saturday, February 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. She will be laid to rest near her beloved mother and sister, Eva, on Sunday, February 6 at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. (781-828-7216)

title: The Self-Made Charmer Who Runs Albany
description: THIS is Albany, so that dapper fellow in the camel's-hair coat must be Mayor Gerald D. Jennings, a two-term statesman with sufficient stage smarts to turn on the charm and put up his dukes simultaneously. Central casting might want credit, but he's self-made (just ask), and right now he's brandishing a welcome mat the way his father and grandfather taught him back at their Jennings's Broadway Tavern. Though the tavern is defunct, he's still in Albany and loving it. As the top-of-the-ticket Democrat in a city that he says tends to embrace his party by an 11-to-1 margin, what's to hate? Not even Republicans.

title: SHARES OF METROCALL TRIPLE ON NEWS OF BIG INVESTMENT
description: Shares of Metrocall Inc., the second largest United States paging company, more than tripled yesterday after the investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst and two other companies agreed to invest about $51 million in the company. The stock of Metrocall, based in Alexandria, Va., jumped $4.28125, to $6.3125, in trading of more than 56 million shares. Metrocall said separately that the AT&T Corporation would swap its preferred shares in Metrocall for 13.3 million common shares, making AT&T the largest holder of Metrocall's common stock, with a 16.9 percent stake.

title: Citing Currency Weakness, Europeans Raise Key Rate
description: Declaring that the weakness of Europe's year-old single currency had created concern about price stability, the European Central Bank raised interest rates today for the second time in three months.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: The Big Fella Is Not Quite Done
description: The campaign to make Patrick Ewing get with the program has gone on for, oh, the past three years. It centers around the belief that a former All-Star cannot push aside his stubbornness and pride long enough to realize his physical limitations at 37 years old.

title: Britain to Retake Reins of Ulster If I.R.A. Doesn't Move to Disarm
description: Britain moved tonight to suspend the power-sharing government in Northern Ireland by next week, but said it would intensify efforts to get paramilitary groups to begin disarming before using that authority.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Nightmare: Owner Awakes as Tenant
description: It is a real estate story that Franz Kafka might have concocted.

title: U.S. Seizes Russia Tanker Said to Carry Oil From Iraq
description: Two American warships enforcing United Nations sanctions against Iraq seized a Russian tanker in the Persian Gulf today after boarding it and discovering evidence that it might be smuggling oil out of southern Iraq, a Pentagon spokesman said.

title: Senate Ratifies Nomination Of Greenspan to 4th Term
description: The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed Alan Greenspan's nomination to a fourth term as chairman of the Federal Reserve today after members of both parties lauded his performance over the last dozen years in nurturing the economy's long expansion.

title: Memorial for Derek Jones
description: A memorial for the director Derek Anson Jones is to be held on Monday at 5:30 p.m. at the Union Square Theater, 100 East 17th Street, Manhattan. Mr. Jones, who directed the play ''Wit,'' died last month at the age of 38. Among those scheduled to take part are Margaret Edson, the play's author, and Kathleen Chalfant, who headed the original cast. Also expected to take part in the tribute, which is open to the public, are Wendy Wasserstein, the writer; Ming Cho Lee, the set designer; and Doug Hughes, artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.

title: Bond Market Turmoil
description: Chaos swept through the bond market as traders and investors tried to make sense of a spectacular and damaging 3 percent rise in the prices of longer-term Treasuries. Traders said that losses were surely large at many institutions.

title: Hardships Teach a North Carolina Girl Lessons
description: Most afternoons 13-year-old Cherrie Redwine goes outside to do her homework, even when the temperature is in the 40's and snow is on the ground, as it was this week.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL RISES. Heating oil prices rose more than 3 percent as cold weather persisted in the Northeast and supplies dwindled. In New York, heating oil for delivery in March rose 2.37 cents a gallon, to 77.80 cents.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILANO, ROBERT L.
description: MILANO-Robert L. Sam Walter Foss' tender epitaph from the late 19th Century reappears as we bid farewell to our beloved Daytop Governor, Bob Milano: ''Let me live in my house by the side of the road and be a friend to man!''. And a Friend, indeed, he has been for a quarter-century to captive generations of this Town's young caughtup in the web of drug abuse and successfully seeking freedom through Daytop Village. May the bright sunshine of Heaven welcome him home. And may our prayerful support be felt by his beloved Sidonia and Robert and the Milano Family. Msgr. William B. O'Brien President, Daytop Village, Inc.

title: Metro Business; Contract Approval Eases Hospital Sale
description: Nurses at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Smithtown, N.Y., voted to approve a revised contract yesterday, removing a major hurdle that had threatened a plan to sell the financially troubled hospital to Catholic Health Services of Long Island.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Books; Pages of Classic Gauges And Dashes With Flash
description: I'VE always taken my car's dashboard for granted. Other than fiddling with the radio or tape player, an occasional glance at a gauge or warning light is about the extent of my involvement with that structure between me and the engine.

title: Health Officials Fine Hospital Where Doctor Carved Patient
description: The State Department of Health fined Beth Israel Medical Center $14,000 yesterday and ordered it to improve its oversight of doctors after an inquiry into a hospital obstetrician who carved his initials into a patient's belly.

title: Corrections
description: An erroneous cross-reference to SportsThursday appeared yesterday on some copies of the first Business Day page. The sports pages appear at the back of that section in the national, New England and Washington editions only.

title: Long Day's Journey Into Morning Finds Gore Long on Talk
description: Even with Michael S. Dukakis nodding off in the second row, Al Gore kept talking. One of the Secret Service agents standing at the edge of the crowd had his eyes closed, too, and the press corps was literally moaning for mercy -- so loudly, in fact, that many of the real people at the town hall meeting here at Los Angeles City College turned around to look.

title: RIGHTISTS TO JOIN AUSTRIA'S CABINET
description: Austria's president announced today that he would swear in a new government on Friday that includes Jorg Haider's anti-immigrant Freedom Party, setting the country on a collision course with the European Union, which regards Mr. Haider's party as xenophobic and extremist.

title: Witness Says She Heard No Warning by Police to Diallo
description: A woman who lived across the street from Amadou Diallo in the Bronx testified today that she saw four white men in casual clothes approach Mr. Diallo's building early last Feb. 4, and, moments later, heard a volley of rapid gunfire. She did not, she said, hear the men shout out any warning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASSBERG, JOSEPH H.
description: NASSBERG-Joseph H., (aka Joey Nash). Loving partner of the late Doreth Levy, beloved uncle, noted singer & writer. Graveside service 2:30 PM today, Mount Neboh Cemetery, Cypress Hills, N.Y.

title: Horse Racing and Other Rigged Games of Chance
description: The playwright Sam Shepard doesn't create characters so much as conjure up colliding forces of nature. As his cowboys and city slickers lunge at each other in an American landscape that resembles a corrupted suburban province of Marlboro country, we have the sense that they are divided halves of the same soul groping for an impossible reconciliation in a blighted land.

title: Muzzle Chafes Chechen War Media
description: ''No filming the corpses,'' a military press officer barked as a group of correspondents jumped off a Russian Army helicopter on the outskirts of the Chechen capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINO, VINCENT
description: MARINO-Vincent ''Vinny''. Born December 22, 1938 in Manhattan, NY died January 31, 2000. He was 61. Vinny battled liver cancer and hepatitis C for 3 years. Vinny was the founder and executive director of Habilitat, Inc. one of the country's most successful non-profit substance abuse programs located in Hawaii. He is survived by his wife, Victoria M. Marino; 2 daughters, Lila Camacho-Marino and Victoria Marino; his granddaughter, Alicia-Marie Camacho and his brother, Joseph Marino. Viewing on February 9, 6 to 9 PM at Hawaiian Memorial Park, 45-425 Kamehameha Hwy, Kaneohe, HI. Memorial service will be held on February 10, 10 AM at St. Ann's Church, 46-129 Haiku Road, Kaneohe, HI. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers monetary gifts may be made in Vinny's memory to Habilitat, Inc. PO Box 801, Kaneohe, HI 96744. For info call 800-872-2525; 808235-3691; Fax 808-235-3326; E-mail habilit@aloha.net, or see our website www.habilitat.org

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about the popularity of sports books, misstated the length of time the boxer Hurricane Carter spent in prison for murder before being exonerated. It was 19 years, not 30.

title: Everyman Tries to Save the Earth, One Image at a Time
description: Although human beings depend on the land for life itself, European painters did not put landscape at the center of the program for many centuries. The land as artists saw it was mainly background or the site of seasonal chores and pleasures. Not until the 16th century, when Northern European painters inserted small holy figures into enormous wildernesses, did landscape even begin to become the real subject of painting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEON, BETTY
description: McKEON-Betty, on February 2, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late Cornelius and Elizabeth (nee Ambler). Sister of Florence Cutts and the late Genevieve Schade and Marie St. Amour. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 9:45 A.M., at St. Saviour Church. Interment private.

title: Turning a Candidate Into a Lightweight
description: As the Republican presidential campaign moves to South Carolina, Gov. George W. Bush must be thinking hard about what to leave behind in New Hampshire. To those who saw him in action there, the answer is obvious.

description: BASEBALL

title: Frederick Burdett Warder, 95; Decorated Submarine Skipper
description: Rear Adm. Frederick B. Warder, a submariner whose exploits in World War II won him a Navy Cross and a nickname he detested, died on Tuesday at his home in Ocala, Fla. He was 95.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neigborhood Report pages of the City section on Sunday about the Lunar New Year celebration in Chinatown referred incorrectly to the role of traditional lion dancers. They will not be limited to marching in a new American-style parade. Five lion dance troupes have been issued permits to walk the streets in the traditional fashion from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. tomorrow while the parade is being held, and on Feb. 13 from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.

title: Austrians Defend Austria, but Views on Haider Party Range Wide
description: O.K., tell the truth, a young reveler at Jorg Haider's birthday celebration on an Alpine ski slope was prodded recently -- isn't all your Freedom Party's talk about the economic threat posed by immigrants really just a cover story for not liking dark-skinned people?

title: IN SEPARATE DEALS, INTEL IS BUYING AMBIENT AND THINKIT
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's biggest semiconductor maker, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Ambient Technologies Inc. for about $150 million in cash to get technologies for high-speed Internet access. In addition, Intel agreed to buy the closely held Thinkit Technologies Inc., which designs chips used in networking and communications products like switches and routers. Terms were not disclosed. Ambient, based in Fremont, Calif., would give Intel a new chip set that provides in a single device high-speed Internet access through digital subscriber lines or analog modems. Intel's shares rose $4.125, to $104.1875.

title: Ratings Agency Considers Dropping Nassau's Bond Status Even Lower
description: Nassau County received more bad news about its finances today, as Standard & Poor's warned that it was considering further downgrading the county's bonds, which hover just two notches above junk-bond status.

title: Microsoft Offers Tax Software to Texas Town
description: Microsoft Offers Tax Software to Texas Town

description: STROM-Grace. Survived by her cousins, Andrea Greenfield, Frederic Roehner of McLean, VA, Jill Drachman, Jonathan Greenfield, Jaclyn Lipman & Alex Roehner of Washington, DC. We will miss her deeply. Services, Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Ave (Ave. L), Brooklyn, today 10 AM.

title: PC's Vulnerable to Security Breaches, Experts Say
description: Unless a home PC is placed in an isolation tank, computer security experts say, it is vulnerable to a panoply of potential intrusions.

title: PARKER HANNIFIN ACQUIRES GRESEN HYDRAULIC FROM DANA
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the Dana Corporation's Gresen Hydraulic business for an undisclosed sum. Gresen Hydraulic, with 1999 sales of $128 million, makes hydraulic pumps, motors, cylinders, control valves, filters and electronic controls for vehicles. It employs about 1,000 people. Parker Hannifin, based in Cleveland, makes hydraulic and pneumatic components and systems. Dana, based in Toledo, Ohio, supplies parts to vehicle manufacturers.

title: Kodak and Hewlett-Packard Form Photofinishing Venture
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Hewlett-Packard Company announced a joint venture yesterday to develop and market retail and consumer photofinishing products using the Internet and Hewlett-Packard's inkjet printer technology.

title: Detained Reporter in Swap
description: In an episode that underscores the limits imposed on reporting from Chechnya, Russia handed over a Radio Liberty correspondent to Chechen rebels today in exchange for two Russian soldiers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGRAD, PAULINE KLEMES
description: BOGRAD-Pauline Klemes. Age 91, of Hackensack, NJ. A supporter of Planned Parenthood for 50 years. The Paterson, NJ center is named in her honor. Founder of Womens' American Ort in Paterson, first female president of Jewish Family Services of North Jersey. Mother of Joseph and Marcia Bograd, Naomi and Edward Robbins, Harriet Bograd and Kenneth Klein. Grandmother of Louis, Mark, Stephanie, Joyce, Richard, Marjorie and Sarah. Great-grandmother of Evan and Benjamin. Service Schoem's Memorial Chapel, Paramus, NJ, Sunday, 10AM Contributions to Planned Parenthood of Metropolitan NJ, 151 Washington St, Newark, NJ 07102

title: Jackson Pollock 'The Colored Paper Drawings'
description: Washburn Gallery

title: Kantarian to Run Business Unit
description: Arlen Kantarian, a marketing executive, has been appointed to run a new business unit of the United States Tennis Association. His official title is chief executive, United States Open and professional tennis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, ROBERTA
description: MANN-Roberta. Beloved wife of Leslie. Devoted mother of Lauren and Jenna. Loving daughter of Jacob and Minnie Storch. Dear sister of Edward Storch. Services today 12:45PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, L.I.

title: Another New Year
description: The year 2000 may have seemed impressive, but it pales before 4698, the Year of the Dragon, which begins tomorrow. To celebrate the Chinese New Year with a feast, here are 11 places to visit, many offering special New Year menus. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- College Park, Md.

title: Bronx Man Arrested In Baby's Shaking Death
description: A 28-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and accused of fatally shaking a friend's 15-month-old son on Jan. 31, the police said.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; ONLINE TRADING ADVANCES IN MEXICO
description: Securities regulators in Mexico announced rules governing online trading, effective April 3. The nation's largest bank, Grupo Banamex-Accival, which in January became the first to offer Internet stock trading in Mexico, said the rules issued by the securities commission would lead to an expansion of online trading. Dan Fineren

title: Security Breach: Punishment Gap?
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Move.com, San Francisco, a real estate portal owned by the Cendant Corp., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAMORE, ELEANOR (NEE SHIENTAG)
description: ZAMORE-Eleanor (nee Shientag). Wife of the late Harry. Mother of Joseph (Fran) Zamore and Esther (Robert) Rosenthal. Grandmother of six. Sister of Daniel (Irma) Shientag and Beatrice Smirnow. Services Thursday, Februay 3, 9:30 A.M. at I.J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Ave. Friends who wish may contribute to the Eleanor Zamore Scholarship Fund, C/O Bolton Landing New York High School or the Montefiore Home of Cleveland, Ohio.

title: Jail Guard Convicted For 3 Deaths on Highway
description: A Suffolk County jury rejected murder charges today against a New York City jail guard, Edwin Rodriguez, 37, who was driving while drunk on New Year's Eve 1998, when his car struck another vehicle, killing three of its occupants.

title: To Be a Circus Animal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Searches for Source of Tainted Beef Sent to Switzerland
description: The discovery by Swiss health inspectors last July that imported American beef was contaminated with DES, an illegal hormone, has prompted an effort by the United States government to trace its source.

title: Knicks Hire Frank Layden
description: Frank Layden came to New York this week from Utah to visit his son, Scott, the Knicks' vice president and general manager, and his grandchildren. But his plans took an odd turn when Dave Checketts invited the Laydens to dinner.

title: Rocker on the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Urban-Renewal Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: A. E. van Vogt, 87, Forceful Science-Fiction Voice
description: A. E. van Vogt, a writer who smuggled raw emotion into modern science fiction, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 87 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Toll Booth Camera Yields Clue to Killing
description: Two young men were charged yesterday in the death of an 18-year-old Russian immigrant after they were photographed by a toll booth camera driving the dead man's car moments after his body was found, officials said.

title: Metro Business; Wine Law Challenged
description: A Washington law firm sued yesterday to overturn New York laws prohibiting direct shipments of wine by out-of-state wineries to New Yorkers.

title: Thrashers Outdo Rangers in Poor Play
description: The Rangers turned in one of their worst outings of the season here tonight. Fortunately for them, it came against the expansion Atlanta Thrashers because it was doubtful that they could have played this poorly against any other team and emerged with a victory.

title: Before Play Starts, Zimbabwe Gets Lift
description: The No. 1 player in Zimbabwe stood shoulder to shoulder with No. 1 in the world here today. At the Davis Cup draw to determine the pairings for Friday's opening matches, Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, might have been hoping that Andre Agassi's magic is contagious.

title: Finally, an Open Primary
description: With a begrudging nod to how long it has taken Gov. George Pataki and Gov. George W. Bush to recognize the need for an open presidential primary in New York, it is time to celebrate the news that the state's March 7 vote is now likely to be open to all major national contenders. Mr. Bush, after being trounced by Senator John McCain in New Hampshire this week, has finally said the right thing -- that it is time ''to put him [Mr. McCain] on the ballot.'' Governor Pataki did much the same, saying, ''I believe that John McCain should be on the ballot.'' His communications director, Zenia Mucha, added that the New York governor will ''take appropriate steps'' to make certain that Mr. McCain is on all the ballots around the state.

title: To the Beat of a Different Drum
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, HELEN GARY
description: MORAN-Helen Gary, 93, of Manhattan, on February 1. Daughter of Hampson Gary, Ambassador to Egypt and Switzerland under President Wilson. Widow of industrialist Bernard A. Moran. Helen is survived by her sons Bernard Moran Jr., John P. Moran and Michael Moran. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., Friday, 6-8PM. Funeral service Saturday 1PM, St. Thomas Episcopal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, LILLY
description: BLUM-Lilly. The American Jewish Historical Society and The Center for Jewish History extend their condolences to our Trustee and friend, George Blumenthal and his family on the loss of their beloved aunt, Lilly Blum. She dedicated her professional life to unselfish medical research and in her private life enriched the lives of her family and friends. Kenneth J. Bialkin, President American Jewish Hist. Society Bruce Slovin, Chairman Center for Jewish History

title: All Venetians Look Alike, Except for the Silly Pants
description: Carlo Goldoni labored throughout most of the 18th century to reform the theater from the improvised hamming that was commedia dell' arte into structured plays that were a sort of cross between farce and comedies of manners. ''The Servant of Two Masters,'' written in 1746 during one of his occasional retreats into practicing law to replenish his purse, combines elements of both schools. A current revival by the Jean Cocteau Repertory tries to resolve this identity crisis by turning the play into a burlesque.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; BIG CZECH BANK SOLD
description: The Czech government will sell the country's largest savings bank, Ceska Sporitelna, to the Austrian bank Erste Bank der Osterreichischen Sparkassen. Erste, which agreed to pay $515 million for a 52 percent stake in Ceska Sporitelna, plans to build the largest savings bank in Central Europe. Ladka Bauerova

title: Ford to Offer Workers PCs and Online Access at Low Cost
description: Ford to Offer Workers PCs and Online Access at Low Cost

title: Some Intimate Emotions Flung to the Last Balcony
description: As Linda Eder told it to a thunderously adoring audience from the stage of Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, what set her on the course to become a Broadway belter was watching Judy Garland sing ''Over the Rainbow'' on television when she was an 8-year-old growing up in Brainerd, Minn. That resolve was redoubled with her discovery of Barbra Streisand, whom she humorously referred to as ''you know who'' before delivering a roof-raising ''Don't Rain on My Parade.''

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: 'Dirty Blonde' Hunting a Home

title: California's Tobacco Tax
description: On the March 7 ballot, California voters will be asked to repeal Proposition 10, a groundbreaking anti-tobacco initiative that raised the state cigarette tax by 50 cents per pack. Nullifying Proposition 10 would be a serious public-health mistake. In 1998, Californians set an admirable example for the rest of the nation by passing this measure, which generates about $680 million a year to pay for smoking prevention programs and an array of early childhood education and health programs.

title: Jason Dodge
description: Casey Kaplan Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBOWITZ, HARVEY
description: LIBOWITZ-Harvey. The Board and staff of Lighthouse International are saddened by the passing of Harvey Libowitz, husband of longtime employee, Fran Libowitz. Harvey unselfishly gave of his time as a volunteer and friend of the Lighthouse. Our condolences to the family. Barbara Silverstone President & CEO William B. Follett Chairman of the Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, MILDRED E.
description: DANIELS-Mildred E. Beloved sister of Estelle Lee, Walter Danilowicz and Delores Danilowicz Gabriel. Died on January 24, 2000 after a prolonged illness. She was a pediatric nurse and director of nursing of premature unit at Mount Sinai Hospital for many years. Friends and family will meet at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St 7-9 PM Friday February 4 with funeral mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89 Street, Saturday, 9:30 AM. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAFFE, ELEANOR
description: YAFFE-Eleanor. Beloved aunt and dearest friend. How we will truly miss your love and goodness. Joan and Sol, Richard and Pat, Jerry and Carole, Judith, David and Honey, Tom and Lainey, Max, and David

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, WILLIAM BELLEVILLE III
description: WEAVER-William Belleville III, 78, died February 1, 2000. Served in WW2. Received a BChE from Cornell University 1949. Retired from Burroughs-Wellcome in Greenville, NC, 1984. Survived by wife Margaret of Bedminster, NJ, three daughters Diane Loffredo, Susan Felker and Carol Weaver-Harlan, brother Robert, and four grandchildren. Donations may be made to VA NJ Healthcare System, Lyons Campus, 908-647-0180 ext 4190. Memorial at future date.

title: To Ease the Burden Of Cancer in a Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYDE, MARGARET WILLETS
description: HYDE-Margaret Willets, 73, of Devon, PA., wife of the late Donald R. Hyde, passed away on Wednesday, February 2, 2000, in her home after a lengthy illness. She is predeceased by her brother Chester Austin Willets, Jr. and is survived by her sister, Barbara Willets Hatfield, her sons Jeff, Ron, Larry as well as Joyce, Jim, Beth and 3 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held 10 AM Monday February 7 in the Chapel of St. Davids Episcopal Church, 763 Valley Forge Rd., Wayne, PA. In lieu of flowers contributions in her name may be made to The Audubon Society, 950 Third Ave., New York, N.Y. 10022 or to Hospice at 104 Ardmore Ave., Ardmore, PA. 19003. For information Stuard Funeral Home, Ardmore 610-649-0243

title: A Serving of American, Garnished With Russian
description: There was a distinctively American quality to the program presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. The light and dark of American life and culture were suggested in all their quirky glory, as seen through the eyes of George Balanchine, a Russian who loved things American, and Eliot Feld, an all-American choreographer.

title: MORE VOLKSWAGEN STRIKERS RETURN
description: Production resumed at Volkswagen's South Africa plant after about 75 percent of the factory's production employees returned to work after a wildcat strike over an internal union dispute. Volkswagen reopened the plant on Monday but had been unable to resume normal operations. The company had threatened on Tuesday to fire any of the 4,000 employees who were not back on the job by yesterday. Management said it was making plans to replace those who held out. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFRA, INA
description: SAFRA-Ina. The Brotherhood Synagogue notes with great sorrow the untimely passing of our beloved Trustee. Ina touched the hearts of so many and will always be remembered in the congregation which she loved and served. A memorial service will be held at the Synagogue on Sunday, February 13 at 7:00 PM.

title: Europe Moving Cautiously In Punishment for Austria
description: The European Union, which warned that it would shun Austria if the far-right Freedom Party joined the government there, is now preparing to carry out its threat.

title: Learning to Tackle Life's Frustrations Productively
description: In the past, when Selena Elliott was frustrated, she would get angry and lash out at whoever had caused her frustration. Her outbursts were counterproductive, her counselor said, pushing her further from her goal: being reunited with her children.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALLEN, JARED DAVID
description: ALLEN-Jared David. We will love you forever, we will miss you for always. Grandma Fay, Grandpa Allen, Aunt Sheila, Uncle Jeff, Gregory and Greer.

title: 'Youth' rhymes with 'Truth,' and both are central to a big new national campaign against smoking.
description: WHAT is intended as the largest single national anti-smoking initiative starts today amid continuing debate over some commercials that are to be part of the campaign.

title: Jeb Bush Roils Florida on Affirmative Action
description: From school vouchers to the death penalty, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has had one political success after another in his first year in office. But his sweeping program to end affirmative action in the state, modeled partly after the one in his brother's state, Texas, has inflamed black leaders, even some who had supported him, and looms as the first real test of his administration.

title: Snowy Idyll in a College Town (and No Midterms)
description: When winter comes to other cities of the world, like Helsinki or St. Petersburg, where snows fall almost daily, the hushed atmosphere of the streets in their winter whiteness is broken only by the muffled sounds of city life. In the evenings, deep snow drifts lining frozen sidewalks glow in intermittent pools of lamplight from above. Magical winters like these are so rare in New York City that they form precious memories for people who treasure bundling up for the adventure in the otherwise quiet month of February before the awakening of spring.

title: 4th-Quarter Earnings Rose 24% at the Times Company
description: The New York Times Company reported a rise of 24 percent in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, exceeding analysts' estimates, on gains in advertising for technology products, financial services and Internet sites.

title: Nets Look For Ability To Finish
description: While the Nets have worked to improve their offensive execution and their defensive focus at the end of games, Kendall Gill thinks the team's failure to pull out close games goes beyond simple X's and O's.

title: Political Memo; President's Budget Plans Put Mayor on Spot
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton begins her official United States Senate campaign, her husband has presented Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani with two disagreeable alternatives: Criticize billions of dollars in Clinton education and anticrime initiatives that would help New York City, or praise the husband of his political enemy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTULLO, G. ROBSON
description: PATTULLO-G. Robson ''Rob'' died peacefully on February 3, 2000 in New York City. Cherished friend and husband of Susan. Beloved father of Claire. Devoted son of Elizabeth and Pat Pattullo, brother of Betsy, Ann, Greg and Ronald. Uncle of Jess, Gabe, Alissa and Sasha. Associated for nearly 25 years with ABC News. A joyous light in the lives of all who knew him. Funeral services will be held in Winchester, MA. A memorial celebration in New York City will follow. Donations in Rob's memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Easthester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HELD, JAMES D. JAMIE
description: HELD-James D. Jamie, we miss you,''Madly Deeply Truly''. Patty, Sharon, Mom and Dad

title: More Data Disclosed On Web Site Use
description: A second Internet measurement service has released data indicating that computer users visited many Web sites of dot-com companies that advertised during Super Bowl XXXIV.

title: Fourfold Rise in Contracts Highlights E.D.S. Earnings
description: Electronic Data Systems, the Texas computer services concern that is rebounding from two disastrous years, reported fourth-quarter earnings today that topped Wall Street estimates, and announced a more than fourfold increase in new contracts during the quarter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Vodafone and Mannesmann In $183 Billion Merger Deal

title: Frank E. Morris, 75; Once Led Boston Fed
description: Frank E. Morris, who was president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston from 1968 to 1988, died Monday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 75.

title: $183 BILLION DEAL IN EUROPE TO JOIN 2 WIRELESS GIANTS
description: Two of the world's leading companies in wireless communications agreed today to combine in a $183 billion takeover deal, the largest ever.

title: Foreign Affairs; Corporations on Steroids
description: Yasir Arafat came to Davos this year, and there were two people he insisted on meeting with: Bill Clinton of the United States of America and Steve Case of America Online.

title: Ewing Saves His Best To Beat The Blazers
description: Beneath the weighty speculation concerning his future and the constant inspection of his every unhappiness, Patrick Ewing's inflated pride acted as a life preserver last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: McCAIN ON BALLOT ACROSS NEW YORK AS PATAKI GIVES IN
description: Fearing that they were energizing Senator John McCain's candidacy, Gov. George W. Bush and his chief supporter in New York, Gov. George E. Pataki, abandoned their efforts to keep Mr. McCain out of the state's presidential primary yesterday and said they would ensure that he is on the ballot.

title: CANADIAN RATES RISE
description: Canada's central bank raised interest rates by a quarter percentage point, as expected, in step with the increase on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve Board in the United States. The Bank of Canada's bank rate was bumped to 5.25 percent to damp inflationary pressures and to maintain a spread of 50 basis points, or fifty-hundredths of a percentage point, with the United States federal funds rate of 5.75 percent. Timothy Pritchard

title: The Epilogue of a Chat Room Flirtation
description: Not every cyberspace romance ends like Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan's in ''You've Got Mail,'' with the golden couple embracing in an urban flower garden while the dog frolics at their feet. Chopin6 and Sorry12, for instance, meet in a computer chat room and decide to try an in-person date early on.

title: Bradley Blasts Bush for Talk At Bob Jones U.
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley was just getting into a part of his stump speech today where he usually blasts Vice President Al Gore, his rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, when he veered instead into criticizing a Republican candidate, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Spice Maker Will Accept F.T.C. Review
description: McCormick & Company, the world's largest spice maker, agreed today to let antitrust enforcers review its sales contracts for 10 years to head off a lawsuit contending that it had illegally charged some grocers more than others.

title: The Justice Americans Demand
description: Must we make the same mistakes over and over again? On Monday, the Republican governor of Illinois, George Ryan, suspended executions in his state while he investigates how 13 men could have been wrongly sentenced to death. (Fortunately, none of the executions were carried out.) Opponents of capital punishment, like the unfortunately named Quixote Center, have seized on Mr. Ryan's action as an opportunity to call for a moratorium on all executions nationwide.

title: Officer's Dismissal Sought in Squeegee Man's Shooting
description: A Police Department administrative judge has recommended the dismissal of an officer who was acquitted of criminal charges for shooting an unarmed squeegee man in the Bronx, according to a report given to the participants yesterday.

title: Giuliani Faults Mrs. Clinton On Trip Costs
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani accused Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday of failing to fully reimburse taxpayers for the cost of using government airplanes on political trips to New York and elsewhere. The White House and Mrs. Clinton's campaign said prompt reimbursements had been made.

title: DINING OUT
description: That character caught on an overhead monitor is you, the diner, looking like a videotaped A.T.M. bandit. It snares you as you enter, and throws your image up on the first in a long string of television sets over the bar. As each new diner enters, you get moved on down the line. The video display is just one tip-off that the new Brasserie in the Seagram Building is very different from the original, which opened in 1959 and closed in 1995 after a fire.

title: Alamosa Joins Soaring IPO Market
description: February 3, 2000

title: For Many, Abortion Is Lost in the Crowd of Issues
description: Solidly in the Republican camp, Tom Miller rattled off the issues most important to him: taxes, the economy, health care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, MAX
description: TAYLOR-Max, of CosCob, CT. July 5, 1904-January 30, 2000. Survived by wife Edith, sons Michael and Abbott, daughter Anique, 6 grandchildren, stepsons Joel and Jon Shimberg, 5 step-grandchildren. Prominent maritime attorney. Member MLA, Justice Department. Partner, Kriesel Beck & Taylor. Partner, Burke & Parsons. He was deeply loved. We will miss him. Services February 6, 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLUM, LIVIA. ALL OF ELEM
description: BLUM-Livia. All of ELEMouth in Distress in Israel send our sincere condolences to George Blumenthal and his family on the death of his beloved Aunt Lilly. We will all remember her warmth and caring and we will miss her. Ann Bialkin, President ELEM

title: McCain Gets Big Payoff On Web Site
description: Do not be surprised if every resurgent, cash-poor presidential campaign begins shamelessly plugging its campaign Web sites, where Visa, MasterCard and Discover are accepted, no matter how small the donation.

title: Firearms Agency Intensifies Scrutiny of Suspect Dealers
description: The federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms is embarking on the most aggressive campaign in its 30-year history to crack down on corrupt gun dealers who help put firearms in the hands of criminals and juveniles, White House and Treasury Department officials said yesterday.

title: DE BEERS BUYING DIAMOND STAKE
description: The world's leading diamond producer, De Beers, agreed to pay Anglovaal Mining Ltd. about $590 million for Avmin's stake in the De Beers flagship diamond mine, Venetia. Venetia is De Beers's biggest producer. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about a court filing in the Microsoft antitrust case made by a Harvard legal scholar and software expert misspelled his given name. He is Lawrence Lessig, not Laurence.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Sauerkraut And Memories

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Japanese Star Tries English

title: Security Breach: Punishment Gap?
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: Public Interests; Guys Just Want to Get Votes
description: ''LAAAAADIES and gentlemen. Would you please welcome. The winner of the New Hampshire primary by a landslide . . . JOOOOOOHN MCCAIN!!!'' Several hundred college students begin to stamp their feet. Cue the heavy metal music.

title: Bus Ambush In Kosovo Costs NATO Faith of Serbs
description: Serbs who survived a bus attack in northern Kosovo on Wednesday huddled around a wood stove in the village school today, saying they felt more trapped and worried than ever.

title: Raindrops Take Over (As Usual) At Pebble
description: It happened again at Pebble Beach. Everybody was wet, and nobody was surprised.

title: BEST DAY EVER FOR SOFTBANK
description: Shares of the Softbank Corporation, the Japanese venture capital and investment company, leapt 20 percent after a Lehman Brothers analyst quadrupled his previous target price for the stock. The shares rose 21,000 yen, to 124,000, their biggest gain in a single day, making Softbank Japan's fourth-largest company in terms of stock market valuation. Stephanie Strom

title: Dusseldorf and Mannesmann
description: Had it not been in large part for Mannesmann, this old industrial city might well have suffered a decline similar to that of Gary, Ind., or Birmingham, England.

title: Think Globally, Listen Locally
description: THE world's music has never been more accessible, speeded to new ears by everything from jet travel to the Internet. And the whole world comes to New York: if not in person, then through its songs. Onstage or on CD's, music from far-flung places offers easy transport to distant lands and times. The Babel of different musical languages promises not strife but diverse pleasures, available amazingly close to home.

title: NISSAN LOWERS FORECAST
description: The shares of the Tokyo-based Nissan Motor Company fell after the company, an affiliate of Renault of France, said it was likely to miss its operating profit forecast for the year ending next month, citing weaker-than-expected auto sales in Japan. The automaker, which sold a 36.8 percent stake to Renault last May, said late on Wednesday that it did not have a new target.

title: And Let the Lawyers Sing: 'Glory to the Salary King'
description: The frenzy over law firm salaries reached new heights yesterday and spread for the first time to a law firm based in neither New York nor Silicon Valley.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: State to Ask for Removal Of a Cemetery's Overseer
description: The state attorney general's office plans to ask a state judge in Brooklyn to dismiss the court-appointed receiver who has been overseeing the Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Auctioneers Trading Up

title: National Black Fine Art Show
description: Puck Building

title: Distilling Emotion by Freezing Motion
description: The Irish artist James Coleman had his first New York solo show at the Marian Goodman Gallery in 1991, 20 years after his career began in Europe and 13 years after his work was shown at the Venice Biennale. Mr. Coleman works in film, video, performance and slide projection and is probably best known here for the latter: elaborately orchestrated sequences of projected images in which images of professional and amateur actors are shown in shifting tableaux accompanied by voice-overs.

title: A Parent's Dream, Circa 2000: Be the Next Denise Savoie
description: THERE was a time when children were told they could hope to be president, but for many Americans the envied footsteps are no longer those of Al Gore or George W. Bush. Now people dream of being like P. Kingston Duffie, Richard N. Tinsley or M. Denise Savoie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, THOMAS AUSTIN
description: BURKE-Thomas Austin, 75, died January 25, 2000 in Vero Beach, FL. Formerly of Greenwich, CT. Father of Candace Burke of Stamford, CT and Tamzine Kouns of Weston, CT. He was a Vice-President at BBDO and a member of the American Yacht Club. Burial will be later in Tarrytown, NY.

title: Larry Kagan
description: 'Substance and Shadow'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, E.
description: COOPER-E. Thorne, 69, of Bethlehem, died Thursday, February 3; owned former The Park Ten supper club in Manhattan, also retired stockbroker. Tulane graduate and USAF Reservist. Life partner 40 years of Robert Estey, brother of Mildred Seymour. Private services. Contributions to Humane Society of United States. For information Trexler Funeral Home, Allentown, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFEN, BETTY A., (NEE GOTTHEIL)
description: GEFFEN-Betty A., (nee Gottheil), wife of the late Jacob N. Geffen. Survived by daughter Jo-Ann Geffen and grandson Jeremy of Los Angeles, California. She had three sisters, Gertrude Goldstein and Rosalee Heller, and the late Anna Bucker all of Montreal. The family appreciates contributions to Cystic Fibrosis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHL, VIOLET
description: FISCHL-Violet. Beloved wife of Bruce. Devoted mother of Burt Wolfson and the late Kenneth. Cherished sister of Sanford Emil. Loving grandmother of Ryan Wolfson. Services today 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ROBERT, M.D.
description: ROSENTHAL-Robert, M.D. of Delray Beach, formerly of Greenwich, CT, passed away unexpectedly on February 2, 2000. Bob was a board certified internist and cardiologist who served as Co-Medical Director and past Chief of Cardiology at Boca Raton Community Hospital. He was singular in his dedication to his patients. His colleagues admired him and relied on his judgment. He was and will always be a role model to his sons, Michael and Marc, whom he so deeply loved. His adoring wife of 25 years, Janet, worked with Bob throughout his medical career. They were partners in every sense of the word. Bob's kindness to everyone he encountered was his greatest asset. He was an unmatched husband, father and friend who cannot be replaced. He was a gentle, kind and generous son, son-in-law and brother. He will never leave our hearts. In addition to his wife and sons, he is survived by his mother, Lillian Rosenthal, and brother, Allan Rosenthal, of Boca Raton. Services will be held at 11:00am on Friday, February 4th at Congregation B'nai Torah, 6261 S.W. 18 Street, Boca Raton with interment following at Eternal Light Cemetery, 11520 State Road 7, Boynton Beach. A Robert Rosenthal, M.D. Memorial Fund has been established at the Boca Raton Community Hospital Foundation.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on Tuesday with an article about the mood of voters in New Hampshire on the eve of the presidential primaries misspelled the name of a city in New Hampshire. It is Windham, not Wyndam.

title: New Hearings On Arena Plan For Newark
description: Conceding that they may have failed to give residents adequate opportunity to comment on a plan to build a basketball arena in their downtown neighborhood, city officials have agreed to hold a new round of public hearings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKERMAN, AUDREY
description: ACKERMAN - Audrey. Beloved wife of Arthur, devoted mother of Elissa Green (Jodie), Seth and Alan. Loving grandmother of Robin and Austin. Lifelong educator whose teaching career began in NYC elementary and high schools and extended into Kingsborough & Nassau Community Colleges. She was a master quilter who showed the joy of quilting to others. Died February 2nd, 2000. Services at 10:30 AM, Friday, February 4th, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turpike, Woodbury, L.I. (Directions: 516-921-5757).

title: Nancy Azara
description: Donahue/Sosinski Gallery

title: Bauer Is Said to Plan to Leave Race Today
description: Gary L. Bauer will end his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination on Friday at a news conference in Washington, where he will not endorse any of the other Republican candidates, a friend close to the campaign said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMINICK, BAYARD
description: DOMINICK-Bayard, of New Canaan, CT and Southern Pines, NC, died January 25, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth Yallalee Dominick., Loving father of Joan, Gayer, Margot, Ned and Wilder and big, wonderful ''Bear'' to twelve grandchildren and seven great grans. Formerly Chairman of Dominick & Dominick, Inc., he served as Governor of the NY Stock Exchange, President of the Association of Stock Exchage Firms and member of the Business Advisory Committee of the U.S. State Department. He was the Founding President of the New Canaan Community Foundation, and served on the boards of Waveny Care Center, the Fairfield County Council of Boy Scouts, and Westover School, Trustee of Union Theological Seminary and Roosevelt Hospital. Memorial services at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, February 12,11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to New Canaan Community Foundation, PO Box 1285, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: Marius and Jeannette

title: Old Union Appeals Labor Ruling
description: An irreversible resolution to the umpires' intramural scrap remains out of reach.

title: Study Finds Welfare Changes Lead a Million Into Child Care
description: About a million additional toddlers and preschoolers are in child care because of changes in the welfare laws, but many are in low-quality care and are lagging in language and social development, according to a new study of how welfare revisions have affected young children.

title: Devils Head Into Break With an All-Star Procession
description: Any fear of a letdown by the Devils after their emotional victory over the Rangers in New York one night earlier was erased early in the second period tonight against the Nashville Predators.

title: LATIN AMERICA INVESTMENT
description: Latin America attracted more foreign direct investment last year than Asia, according to 1999 figures released by the United Nations Trade and Development Agency. Such investment in Latin America and the Caribbean increased by one-third last year to $97 billion, moving ahead of investments in other regions. Much of the increase was attributable to the quadrupling of investment in Argentina, to $25 billion from $6 billion, largely as a result of the takeover of the oil company YPF S.A. by Repsol S.A. of Spain for $17 billion. In Asia, foreign direct investment in 1999 totaled $91 billion, a 1 percent increase over 1998. Elizabeth Olson

title: McCain's Victory Unnerves Some Colleagues
description: Once again Senator John McCain has managed to irk his Senate Republican colleagues, and he was not even in town to do it.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Desires That Fall Between the Chasm of Head and Heart
description: There's something going on in the director Ventura Pons's melodrama ''Beloved/Friend,'' though you've got to work hard to get past what feel like intentional obstacles that he's set for himself -- the score, for example, which drizzles over the picture like a caramel coating. And the static setups: the camera perches in front of the players, resting comfortably in the front row of the theater, as if recording a play. But Mr. Pons has made a career out of drama in plain sight. He doesn't go for the operatic, but rather a soft earnestness that could be drab in the hands of the wrong director. He toys with the chasm between the heart and the head.

title: New York Festivals Dispenses Awards
description: Awards have been presented in two competitions sponsored by the New York Festivals.

title: PBS Reported Ready to Name A CNN Executive to Top Post
description: The Public Broadcasting Service has chosen Pat Mitchell, a longtime program executive for Turner Broadcasting, to take the job of president, a PBS executive said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STAGE STORES INC., Houston, a specialty retail chain, said it would close about 60 of its clothing stores this year and cut an undisclosed number of jobs to reduce costs.

title: Jury Is Selected for Second Louima Trial
description: After a grueling selection process that lasted a month, the jury in the second trial stemming from the police assault on Abner Louima was seated yesterday.

title: Pollster Re-evaluates South Carolina
description: An influential South Carolina pollster whose poll recently showed Gov. George W. Bush with a 20-point lead here, said today that far more independents and Democrats might vote in the Feb. 19 Republican primary than he had earlier anticipated. As a result, he said, the race may now be too close to call.

title: Tough on the Outside, Pudding on the Inside
description: Pop culture coincidences can be plainly unnerving. Last spring saw both a film comedy (''Analyze This'') and a cable series (''The Sopranos'') about gangsters forcing themselves to unload to a shrink. This year, in ''Gun Shy,'' we get a shaken undercover Fed, Charlie Mayo (Liam Neeson), seeing a psychiatrist on the down-low. ''You need to share more than anyone I've ever known,'' his analyst (Michael Mantell) says softly.

title: Grim. Giddy. Scared. All of the Above.; 4th Graders Take Statewide Test That May Determine Their Futures
description: When Lily Sacharow got to her fourth-grade classroom yesterday, she was met with an eerie sight. Brown paper wrapping and black plastic garbage bags covered the walls of the girl's classroom as if something improper were underneath.

title: Giuliani Defends Forgoing the Competitive Bidding Rules
description: A dispute over $500 million worth of New York City welfare-to-work contracts erupted into open warfare yesterday as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended his decision to bypass normal bidding rules and speculated that the city comptroller acted on a political vendetta when he blocked the first of the contracts awarded this week.

title: Breaching a Frozen Blockade
description: The inch-thick steel bow plates on this 140-foot, bluff-nosed cutter thundered as it pulled away from the wharf of the United States Military Academy at dawn and quickly began ''hardwater sailing,'' the term its commander uses to describe ice breaking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDLEY, RICHARD ALLEN
description: DUDLEY-Richard Allen, ''Dick'', of Lancaster Co., Pa, on February 2, 2000. Formerly of NYC. Famed NBC radio & television announcer for 60 years as ''The Voice of NBC''. Beloved father of John K. & Bradford S., loving grandfather to 3. Memorial service in NYC at a later date. Funeral services will be held in Nashville, TN. Interment: Mt. Calvary Cemetery, Nashville. In lieu of flowers, memorials to Hospice of Lancaster Co., 685 Good Dr., POB 4125, Lancaster PA 17604-4125. For information, Andrew T. Scheid Funeral Home, Millersville, PA: 717-872-2266.

title: Tyson-Briggs Bout In March Is Unlikely
description: It seems as if Shannon Briggs is off Mike Tyson's dance card for a March 25 fight.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
Buyback at PaineWebber
description: The PaineWebber Group Inc. said yesterday that its board had approved an increase of 18 million shares in its repurchase program, bringing the total authorization to about 35 million shares. The New York-based brokerage firm has about 142.7 million shares outstanding. The stock rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $39, on the New York Stock Exchange. PaineWebber said its board had also increased the firm's quarterly cash dividend to 12 cents a share from 11 cents. The dividend is payable on April 5 to shareholders of record on March 3.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: A Drag Queen And a Mobster

title: Tony Feher
description: Storefront for Art and Architecture

title: Jordan Links Terrorist Plot to bin Laden
description: Jordanian security agents said this week that 13 men imprisoned here on charges of plotting terrorist attacks in Jordan were trained in Afghan camps operated by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi fugitive.

title: Jeter Takes First Step: One-Year Deal
description: If George Steinbrenner is waiting for Juan Gonzalez to accept a mammoth contract from the Detroit Tigers before completing a $118.5 million deal with Derek Jeter, he may have to come up with another strategy. Gonzalez is not certain he wants to stay in Detroit beyond this year, even if he could earn $140 million doing it, a longtime friend of the slugging outfielder said yesterday.

title: Another Legal Defeat for Victim of Online Hoax
description: February 4, 2000

title: Put on the Defensive, Bush Talks Tough As McCain Rides High on His Victory
description: Gov. George W. Bush struck an unusually combative posture toward Senator John McCain today, accusing him of running a misleading television commercial and insinuating that he had not lived up to his own call for integrity in government.

title: Despite Diallo, Data Show Gun Restraint
description: ON this, the first anniversary of Amadou Diallo's shocking death at police hands, the city weeps for its adopted son. But through the tears, and certainly through the shouts of the many antipolice protesters over the last year, a significant fact tends to be obscured. It is this:

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: VA Linux Buys Andover.Net
description: February 3, 2000

title: Grandpa's Chocolate Burns Inside a German Potboiler
description: To see ''The Giraffe,'' the new film by Dani Levy and Maria Schrader that anchors this week's retrospective of Mr. Levy's work at Anthology Film Archives, is to be confronted by a series of mysteries. The first involves the film's English title, the significance of which is revealed rather late in the game. In Germany, ''The Giraffe'' was released as ''Meschugge''; the title comes from a German word that, like its familiar Yiddish cognate, means, roughly ''nuts,'' and has no particular zoological connotation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARROW, ROSE
description: DARROW-Rose, 87. Beloved wife of the late William. Cherished sister of the late Vivian. Devoted mother of Carey (Diane) and Lawrence. Grandmother of Kiersten, Kimberly, Nicole, step-grandmother of Lisa (Joe), Joshua (Cherie). Memorial service on Sunday, February 6th, at 1 PM at the Village Temple.

title: Internet Revolutions
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Dictates Date for Russia On Station Part
description: Frustrated by Russia's repeated delays in launching a crucial component of the International Space Station, NASA said today that it was preparing to use an American substitute to get the project moving again.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: F.D.A. Draws Fire for a Rule on Supplements and Pregnancy
description: Saying they feared dietary supplements' unknown effects on fetuses, two leading experts in birth defects asked the Food and Drug Administration today to revoke a new rule that allows supplement manufacturers to market products for morning sickness and leg swelling in pregnancy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   L.A.P.
description: L.A.P. February 4, 1944-May 5, 1991 Happy Birthday.

title: TV Weekend; Poor Dad Seems Confused, And He's Not the Only One
description: What's worse than having one of those hostile family Christmases ornamented with guilt, sibling rivalry and intergenerational tension -- the kind during which one person blows up and leaves the room in a huff, upsetting the children? Answer: Getting a telephone call shortly afterward announcing that that person has commited suicide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, LEON
description: STEINMAN-Leon. Beloved husband of Ray. Loving father of Monte Steinman, Amy and Peter Blauzvern. Cherished Poppy of Adam, David and Sara. Services Sunday 12:45 at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Trnpk, Woodbury, LI

description: To the Editor:

title: More Than Just Movies
description: Imagine an array of children's films and videos with plenty of folk tales (but no Disney), lots of Japanese animation (but no Pokemon) and many science-fiction quests (but no ''Star Wars'' sequels or prequels).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, DOROTHY LORRAINE
description: WAGNER-Dorothy Lorraine. December 30, 1999 in her 85th year. Born in Lumby, B.C. Dorothy moved to NY in 1934. She is predeceased by brother William Lewis Wagner and sister-in-law Mollie (nee Bell). Loving aunt of Mary Gural and her husband Andy Gural of Totronto, Joan Wagner and her husband Bruce Patterson of Victoria, B.C. Great aunt of Amy and Michael Gural. Memorial services will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Bay Ridge, on Saturday, February 5 at 9:30 AM. Interment Flushing Cenetery.

title: Merrill Names Head of Technology Unit
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had hired Joseph M. Schell, a longtime investment banker on the West Coast, as head of its global technology investment banking operations in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Step by Step, a Path To a World Record
description: Forty-five steps. John Smith, coach of the world's fastest man, has divided the 100 meters into the equivalent of a hurdles race. Forty-five steps from starting line to finish line, each stride producing 500 foot-pounds of pressure, each step allotted 0.083 seconds on the ground, the balls of the feet striking below the center mass of the hips for maximum efficiency, the spikes pawing the track instead of braking. The perfect race. A world record.

title: In Dutchess Politics, Sex, Suicide And a Big Man Behind the Curtain
description: For those who thought the fight to keep John McCain off the Republican ballot played out like a grand political potboiler, try this one.

title: Sports of The Times; Tennis Is Part Of Farmer's Charmed Life
description: THE grounds are out of a dusty colonial storybook, from another time and a privileged place. This is where Don Black raised a tennis family, where the grass is lush and the fruits are plenty and labor was love.

title: ATTRACTIONS
description: Museums and Sites

title: Fight Over Ballot in Presidential Primary Might Prove Costly to Pataki
description: In the end, the word came from the office of the man who had insisted that the dispute had nothing to do with him. Aides to Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that Senator John McCain would be on New York's presidential primary ballot after all.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 25 in Science Times about repairing spinal cords in rats misidentified a neuroscientist who expressed hope for the work. He is Dr. Wise Young of Rutgers University, not Dr. Joy Young.

title: Bonds' Rise Sends Traders Into Turmoil
description: Chaos swept through the bond market yesterday as traders and investors tried to make sense of a spectacular and damaging rise in the prices of longer-term Treasury bonds. Rumors of significant losses sustained by banks, brokerage firms and hedge funds said to be on the wrong side of the Treasury market's move roiled the market, reminding many participants of the crisis created by the near collapse of the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund that gripped the market in September 1998.

title: A New Faith In Medieval Artworks
description: More than ever, people seem to be in search of what is truly ''authentic.'' They want authentic political candidates, authentic experiences on their adventure vacations and authentic works of art.

title: Betty Woodman
description: Max Protetch Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCH, ARMAND O.
description: BOCH-Armand O. Devoted husband of Rose and loving father of Richard. Peacefully on February 3, 2000, after a long illness. Funeral service private. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, L.I. Donations is his memory may be made to: God's Love We Deliver.

title: Ford Offers Its Workers PC's And Internet for $5 a Month
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that each of its 350,000 employees worldwide, from factory workers in India to car designers in Michigan, would be offered a high-speed desktop computer, a color printer and unlimited Internet access for just $5 a month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MOSES
description: KAUFMAN-Moses. On February 1, 2000 at age 88. Beloved husband of Gisele. Loving father of Joyce, Arthur, James and Harry. Cherished grandfather of 14 and greatgrandfather of three. Dear brother of Anne Rose. Services were held at ''The Riverside''.

title: Chief of Mattel Steps Down After Reporting Loss in 1999
