description: The executive who made Barbie into a megabrand stepped down from the top post at Mattel yesterday as the toymaker reported a loss for 1999 and continuing problems in its software unit.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY PLANS TO CUT UP TO 600 MORE JOBS
description: The Storage Technology Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 500 to 600 more jobs and that its chief executive, David E. Weiss, would step down. The company expects to post a loss of about 10 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Its shares fell 18 percent. StorageTek, as the company is known, is the No. 1 maker of corporate computer tape storage systems. It hired Goldman, Sachs & Company in October to explore a possible sale after it lost business to rivals. Yesterday, the company said it would cut its number of units to two from six and would try to remain independent. The shares dropped $2.75 each, to $12.9375. StorageTek has cut about 600 jobs of the 1,500 to 1,750 the company said in October that it would eliminate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLMAN, STEPHEN S.
description: WOLMAN-Stephen S., 48, of New York City, died February 2, 2000. Services at the McMahon Lyon Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY, 914-949-7777, on Saturday, 9-10AM. Interment Rose Hills Memorial Park, Putnam Valley, New York.

title: BRAZIL BOND OFFERINGS
description: In an innovative transaction, the government's National Bank of Economic and Social Development sold $190 million of securities backed by the proceeds from jet exports. After financing the sale of jets by Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. to the AMR Corporation, the bank will back the two-and-a-half-year bonds with accounts receivable from the deal. Simon Romero

title: Frustrated Arafat and Barak End Session
description: Israeli and Palestinian leaders ended a summit meeting here today in frustration, still bogged down in disagreement over interim issues and far from bridging gaps on the thorny final issues that stand between them and a permanent peace.

title: The Reeve Commercial
description: To the Editor:

title: Their Gender Will Bend Every Which Way It Can
description: ''Nature can be more inventive than culture,'' observes Monika Treut, musing on the sex lives, and the sex organs, of the African spotted hyena. But aside from the hyenas, which show up only in a precredit sequence, ''Gendernauts'' seems devoted to a contrary proposition. Hyenas, after all, don't design Web sites devoted to Gertrude Stein, or organize talent shows for drag queens and drag kings, or participate in hormone therapy.

title: Storagetek Gets Slammed After Huge Restructuring, Warning
description: February 3, 2000

title: C.I.A. Director Emphasizes Differences in Security Cases of Ex-Chief and Scientist
description: Wading into a growing political debate already tinged by accusations of racism and special treatment, the director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, dismissed comparisons today between the way the government had responded to evidence of computer security lapses by a former director who lost his security clearance and by a nuclear scientist who is in jail waiting trial.

title: Roller Coaster Brake Faulted in Two Deaths
description: A roller coaster accident that killed a woman and her 8-year-old daughter last August was caused by the failure of a brake mechanism that had been improperly replaced, a state report has found.

title: January Sales Are Enough To Warm Retailers' Hearts
description: Retailers' same-store sales rose 4.9 percent in January from a year earlier as a brisk economy fueled spending on clothing, home furnishings and appliances.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RATNER, EVELYN
description: RATNER-Evelyn. We miss you''Let us count the ways...'' Your caring presence is with us always. Len, Raven, Ros

title: Russians Will Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Jan. 25 about a newly synthesized molecule with explosive properties misidentified some components of the molecule. They are nitro groups, not nitrogen dioxide molecules, which have the same elements but different properties.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the killings of three ethnic Albanians in Kosovo misstated the day they occurred. It was Thursday, not yesterday.

title: The Death Penalty in a Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Takes No Holiday From Thwarting Lovers
description: George Balanchine rarely took the viewer onto the plains of allegory and when he did, as in ''La Valse,'' he arrived directly at his destination.

title: Acquisitions Approved at Telefonica of Spain
description: Shareholders of Telefonica, Spain's largest telephone company, approved a 28 percent capital increase today worth 26.6 billion euros, or about $26.1 billion, for a buyout of four affiliates in Latin America.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: FORMER CHAIRMAN OF FEDERATED LOSES SUIT FOR BACK PAY
description: Federated Department Stores Inc.'s former Chairman and Chief Executive Allen Questrom has lost a lawsuit seeking $47 million in back pay from his ex-employer. Judge Lewis Kaplan of the United States District Court, who had rejected most of Questrom's claims last year, dismissed the remaining claim Friday, ruling that a valuation of an increase in Federated's stock had been correctly calculated. Questrom filed a complaint in federal court against Federated in 1998, claiming he was owed $63 million in compensation for 1990 to 1995 but received only $16 million.

title: Begay Shows Talent and Character
description: Later this month, Notah Begay will begin serving seven days in jail for aggravated drunken driving, an embarrassing incident that has forced him to take an introspective look at himself and his life.

title: LUCENT AGREES TO BUY ASSETS FROM COMPONENT SUPPLIER
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the products and the design, marketing and sales teams of VTC Inc., a privately held supplier of semiconductor components to manufacturers of hard disk drives. The assets of VTC, based in Bloomington, Minn., will be acquired for about $100 million in cash. Lucent said it might also pay as much as $50 million more over the next two years, if specific goals were achieved. Lucent said VTC's manufacturing operation, which is not a part of its acquisition, is being spun off as a new company, which will do contract work for Lucent and other companies. Lucent is based in Murray Hill, N.J.

title: Help Is Offered to Evicted Family
description: A woman who lost vital and costly medical equipment for her 4-year-old son during an eviction has been flooded with offers of help from charities, city officials and regular New Yorkers.

title: Pfizer Said to Be Near $87 Billion Deal for Warner-Lambert
description: After three months of bitter fighting, Pfizer Inc. is putting the finishing touches on its deal to acquire the Warner-Lambert Company for $87 billion, a union that will create America's largest drugmaker, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: Where Elian Gonzalez Can Grieve and Heal
description: To the Editor:

title: McEnroe's Davis Cup Fears Prove Real
description: It was never easy being John McEnroe on a tennis court, but today he found out that living through someone else can be much worse.

title: Lee Hills, 93, Knight Ridder Official and Pulitzer Winner
description: Lee Hills, who began a journalism career as a teenage reporter covering mining disasters in Utah, continued it as an editor by bringing Pulitzer Prizes and national renown to The Miami Herald and The Detroit Free Press, and finally spread the gospel of quality journalism around the country as chief executive of the Knight Ridder newspaper group, died Thursday in Miami. He was 93.

title: Canadian Software Deal
description: The FutureLink Corporation, which helps run Internet sites for businesses from remote locations, agreed today to buy the closely held Charon Systems Inc. for $31.4 million in cash and stock in a move to expand into Canada. FutureLink, which is based in Irvine, said it would pay 1.073 million of its shares, or $24.4 million, and $6.95 million in cash for Charon, which resells software that allows different computer systems to work together. Charon, which is based in Toronto, has 90 employees and had revenue of $13.6 million in the fiscal year that ended July 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOBOTKIN, YETTA (NEE GERSTEIN)
description: SLOBOTKIN-Yetta (nee Gerstein), February 4, 2000, of Cherry Hill, NJ. Wife of the late Ralph Slobotkin. Mother of Bernie (Eileen) Slobotkin, Alan (Diane) Slobotkin, Fred (Carryl) Slobotkin and Jay (Hilary) Slobotkin. Sister of Rose Feldsher. Grandmother of Tracy, Scott, Stephanie, Brad, David, and Chloe. Funeral service Sunday 12 noon, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., 2001 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, NJ. Interment Roosevelt Memorial Park. The family will be at the home of Alan and Diane Slobotkin Tuesday evening. Contributions to CARIH or The Parkinsons Disease Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, DOROTHY LORRAINE
description: WAGNER-Dorothy Lorraine. December 30, 1999 in her 85th year. Born in Lumby, B.C. Dorothy moved to NY in 1934. She is predeceased by brother William Lewis Wagner and sister-in-law Mollie (nee Bell). Loving aunt of Mary Gural and her husband Andy Gural of Toronto, Joan Wagner and her husband Bruce Patterson of Victoria, B.C. Great aunt of Amy and Michael Gural. Memorial services will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Bay Ridge, on Saturday, February 5 at 9:30 AM. Interment Flushing Cemetery.

title: GLEASON, MAKER OF GEAR MACHINERY, CHANGES BUYOUT
description: The Gleason Corporation, a maker of gear-production machinery, said yesterday that it had reduced the number of shares needed to back a management-led buyout after objections from its biggest shareholder. Gleason's board agreed to accept fewer shares in its $23-a-share buyout offer. Management now will accept as few as 4.86 million shares instead of its initial requirement that 6.3 million shares be tendered. The company had about 9.59 million shares outstanding as of September. Gleason management's initial offer in December valued the company at $332 million. Artisan Partners L.P., owner of about 12 percent of Gleason, said last month that $23 was too low.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, KENNETH J.
description: DWYER-Kenneth J. Of Belleville, NJ, formerly of Jersey City on February 3, 2000. Beloved husband for 54 years of Margaret McCarthy Dwyer. Father of William, Thomas, Ann Dwyer, Regina Urban and Leo Dwyer. Brother of John & Donald Dwyer and the late Catherine Coughlin. Grandfather of ten grandchildren. Funeral from The Kiernan Funeral Home, 101 Union Avenue, Belleville, on Monday at 9AM. Funeral liturgy in Saint Peter's Church, Belleville at 10AM. Interment Immaculate Conception Cemetery Montclair. Visiting Sunday 2-6PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Covenant House, POB 731, Times Square Station, 340 West 46 St, NY, NY 10108 would be preferred.

title: U.S. Senate Rivals Question Each Other's Loyalty to Democratic Party
description: The tit-for-tat exchanges between the two Democratic contenders for United States Senate, former Gov. Jim Florio and Jon S. Corzine, grew more intense today as they questioned each other's loyalty to the Democratic Party.

title: Another Beth Israel Injury Case Is Investigated
description: A day after fining Beth Israel Medical Center and ordering it to hire an outside monitor to oversee its quality of care, the State Department of Health said yesterday that it was investigating another case in which a patient had been harmed in the hospital.

title: Ewing's Big Night Has 'Em Buzzing
description: The day after Patrick Ewing's 20-point performance against the Portland Trail Blazers, his Knicks teammates were still talking about how well he had played in Thursday night's victory and what a difference he had made for the team.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACCARINO, JOSEPH J. (JOJO)
description: YACCARINO-Joseph J. (JoJo). Fourth birthday away. So few, yet it seems so many. Happy birthday, dear friend. Ton

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; OVERSEAS CALLS STRENGTHEN TELMEX
description: International long-distance earnings at Telefonos de Mexico almost tripled, to $271 million, in the fourth quarter of 1999, compared with a year earlier. Telmex attributed the rise to increased telephone traffic and a delayed interconnection-fee payment of $132 million from rival telecommunications companies that must use Telmex's lines to connect their own long-distance calls. More than 3.1 million new users also joined Telmex's cellular phone subsidiary, Telcel, in 1999. Dan Fineren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, MARY JANE
description: KENNY-Mary Jane. On February 3, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late William Francis and Mary Ellen Hickey Kenny. Survived by her beloved nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday, February 11, 5-7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, February 12, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, NY.

title: NEW DELL PLANT IN IRELAND
description: With the opening in Limerick of a third European manufacturing plant, Dell Computer passed Intel this week as Ireland's largest foreign employer. Dell's 5,700 employees in the country make the company eligible for grants of more than 50 million Irish pounds, or $62 million, from the Irish Development Agency, according to industry estimates. Dell first began operations in Ireland in June 1991, with 120 workers. At the opening ceremony Prime Minister Bertie Ahern asserted that Ireland received 28 percent of American investments in Europe. Brian Lavery

title: 'Walkure' as Overture to the 'Ring' to Come
description: Like Fafner the dragon reluctantly stirring to semiconsciousness in ''Siegfried,'' the Metropolitan Opera production of Wagner's four-opera cycle, ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' raised a weary eyelid after three years of slumber with a performance of ''Die Walkure'' on Thursday evening. After one more blink, another ''Walkure'' on Monday, the production is to nod off for six more weeks (should that be Fafner the groundhog?), then return with ''Das Rheingold,'' preparatory to three full cycles of the ''Ring.''

title: A Son's Echoing Question, a Father's Burning Mission
description: TWO weeks before he was shot to death at Columbine High School, Daniel Mauser approached his father, Tom, as the family gathered in the kitchen for dinner and asked if he was aware of the gun show loophole in the Brady crime bill.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile yesterday about Mayor Gerald D. Jennings of Albany misstated the name of one of his predecessors. He was Erastus Corning 2nd, not Augustus Corning.

title: In Cuba, Family Isn't Everything
description: The Clinton administration has made up its mind about Elian Gonzalez. It intends to send the boy back to Cuba, depriving him of the freedom he would find in America. I understand that this is not in bad faith: just like millions of well-meaning Americans, the government insists that this is a simple child custody case.

title: EBay Bans Hate Material in Auctions
description: EBay Bans Hate Material in Auctions

title: Indonesia Opens the Bidding for a Stake in an Automaker
description: Indonesia's government opened the bidding for its controlling stake in the nation's automaker today, a new phase in its struggle to sell assets seized from former President Suharto's family and friends to help finance a bailout of insolvent banks.

title: An Ancient Tale Told By Puppets and Actors
description: The Talking Band dips into the dark side of myth for ''Black Milk Quartet,'' its production at the Ohio Theater, and, while each of the four stories on a shared theme raises the surprised laughter one associates with this company, the evening leaves the audience puzzled, spooked and perhaps a little upset.

title: Arms Inspector Seeks Bigger U.N. Role in Iraq
description: The United Nations' new chief arms inspector for Iraq, Hans Blix, said today that his inspection teams would not force their way into suspected weapons sites in Iraq but would defer to United Nations headquarters to resolve any confrontations.

title: Tight Space. No Privacy. Soviet Decor.
description: By the identifiably Russian logic of Tanya Konyenko, there is a good reason why she must leave her apartment, trudge five flights downstairs, cross Nevsky Prospekt, the city's prosperous main street, and walk to the local bathhouse, all simply to take a bath.

title: Indonesia Army Chief Says He Opposes a Coup
description: The army commander warned today that a standoff between the president and a top general had created a ''dangerous and uncertain'' situation and said that he was lobbying with his men not to stage a coup.

title: Post and News Considered Shared Tasks, But Declined
description: The New York Post and The Daily News, whose rivalry has generated flashes of rapier tabloid journalism and multimillion-dollar losses, have held exploratory talks on combining their printing and distribution operations to cut costs, but the discussions have gone nowhere, officials of both papers said yesterday.

title: Bush Begins Taking Shots at McCain
description: In a new offensive against his surging opponent, Gov. George W. Bush today attacked Senator John McCain for accepting campaign contributions from corporations he helps regulate as head of the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: In a Valley Pockmarked by Poverty, Developing a Cure for Suburban Blight
description: Martin Munoz, his wife and two children live in a home the couple fashioned around a broken-down school bus and a camper trailer. Just across the way, a fighting cock is tethered near another home, which is nothing more than a camper shell on a pickup.

title: Chronicling the Ever-Fading Past; Amateurs Work to Capture History's Untold Stories
description: About 135 years ago, the people who loved Cpl. Joseph B. Simpson invested in a 10-foot granite obelisk that seemed a challenge to time itself. The young corporal was killed while planting his regimental colors at Petersburg, Va., on April 2, 1865, seven days before the end of the Civil War. The imposing monument, in a sprawling cemetery here, dwarfs the headstones around it -- formidable enough, it would seem, to stand forever.

title: The Death Penalty in a Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ex-Premier Primakov Drops Out Of Presidential Race in Russia
description: Former Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov today took himself out of the running in the March 26 presidential election, deserting a field that is already dominated by Acting President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: A Good Start by Chancellor Levy
description: In his first month on the job, Harold Levy, the interim schools chancellor, is demanding both more accountability for administrators and more funding for New York City schools. He startled the system's 32 district superintendents recently by issuing a long list of performance criteria by which they would be evaluated at the end of the year, a crucial first step in removing incompetent superintendents. This week he unveiled a realistic budget for next year that focuses on preparing more students to meet new standards for promotion and graduation.

title: Former C.I.A. Director Retains Security Clearance at Pentagon
description: Although the former director of central intelligence, John M. Deutch, had his security clearances revoked by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency, he has kept his security clearance at the Pentagon, a senior Defense Department official said this evening.

title: Judge Orders Faster Review In Benefits Suit
description: Nearly eight years after the Social Security Administration agreed to review the cases of thousands of New Yorkers who claim that they were wrongfully denied disability benefits during the Reagan administration, a federal judge in Manhattan has criticized the agency for moving too slowly, saying people are dying before their claims can be processed.

title: U.S. Bias Suit on Passaic Elections Upsets All Sides
description: Over the last 15 years, Hispanic immigrants from throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean have flooded into this gritty old mill town. By everybody's estimate, they now make up well over half the voting-age population. Yet throughout most of the 1990's, there was only one Hispanic member on the seven-seat City Council. Last May, a second made it.

title: Mets Bolster Their Staff By Signing Three Pitchers
description: Dennis Springer worked 196 1/3 innings last season, a total surpassed by only one Mets pitcher, Al Leiter. Springer's innings came with the Florida Marlins, the worst team in baseball, and it is doubtful he would have gotten as much work on a contender. But his versatility appealed to the Mets, who signed him to a minor league contract yesterday.

title: Shoddy Defense by Lawyers Puts Innocents on Death Row
description: As Illinois examines what went wrong with a justice system that sent 13 innocent men to death row, one common thread has already emerged: poorly financed, often incompetent defense lawyers who failed to uncover and present crucial evidence.

title: Beliefs; Long before Elian Gonzalez, there was a case pitting a powerful pope against Jewish parents.
description: All analogies are imperfect, and this one may be more imperfect than most. But the political and emotional tumult over Elian Gonzalez may illuminate an international incident over a child's destiny, religious rather than national, that stirred emotions on both sides of the Atlantic 140 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREDITH, MORLEY
description: MEREDITH-Morley. Age 77, Metropolitan Opera baritone for over 30 years, formerly of Scarsdale, NY died of cancer at Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center (Florida) on February 3, 2000. Born in Winnipeg, Canada, graduated from University of Manitoba before serving in the Canadian Navy. Preceded in death by Erlene, his wife of 48 years. Survived by his sister, Cecille Feldman, and her husband, Herman, of Minneapolis, MN, his aunt, and many loving nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Burial private. Memorial service at a later date.

title: Bonnie Cashin, Who Helped Introduce Sportswear to Americans, Is Dead at 84
description: Bonnie Cashin, one of the first designers to create and popularize that uniquely American approach to dress called sportswear, died Thursday after open heart surgery at New York University Medical Center. She was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Group Finds Health Care In Prisons Inconsistent
description: Medical care for New York State prison inmates varies greatly because of inadequate external oversight and a shortage of qualified doctors in the prisons, according to a study made public this week by a watchdog group.

title: NYT Article
description: Virginia Winery Sues New York Over Ban on Internet Wine Sales

title: Layoffs Are Avoided At City-Owned Laundry
description: After more than a year of battling New York City's plans to contract out 200 jobs at a city-owned laundry, District Council 37, the giant union of municipal employees, has reached an agreement with the city that avoids layoffs.

title: STRAYER EDUCATION HIRES ADVISER TO STUDY POSSIBLE SALE
description: Strayer Education Inc., the holding company for Strayer University, said late on Thursday that it had hired Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. to advise it on strategic alternatives, including the sale of the company. Ron Bailey, president and chief executive, received ''an indication of interest from an outside party'' to buy all of the company's shares, Strayer said. Mr. Bailey and a committee are considering the offer. Strayer University, founded in 1892, offers working adult students career education at campuses in Washington, Virginia and Maryland, as well as on the Internet. Shares of the Washington-based company jumped $6.3125, to $25.9375, in Nasdaq trading. At that price the company's stock is worth more than $408 million.

title: Warming To Songs From a Cold Climate
description: Barbara Bonney has been bringing her radiant lyric soprano voice and fair-haired beauty to the opera stage for some 20 years. In recent seasons she has been increasingly devoted to the song recital. She is not going to disappear from opera: in December she sang a much-praised Susanna in Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' at the Metropolitan.

title: KEYSPAN SERVICES DOUBLES ITS SIZE WITH 3 ACQUISITIONS
description: The KeySpan Corporation said yesterday that its KeySpan Services Inc. unit had acquired three engineering and construction companies in the New York metropolitan area with combined revenue of about $170 million. Financial terms were not disclosed. The three companies, with more than 900 employees, will double the size of KeySpan Services. KeySpan Services acquired Paulus Sokolowski & Sartor Inc., a Warren, N.J., engineering-consulting company; WDF Inc., a Mount Vernon, N.Y., plumbing and mechanical contracting concern; and Roy Kay Inc., a Freehold, N.J., mechanical contracting and heating, ventilation and air-conditioning company. KeySpan, based in Brooklyn, is a utility holding company.

title: Golf Ball Market in Uproar Over New Callaway Entries
description: The golf ball wars are on.

title: The Death Penalty in a Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Big City; @ Wits' End, Envious and in a Mood to Taunt
description: WHAT do you call a dot-com lout? Readers happily responded to last week's call for an updated version of Eurotrash that would apply to today's rich invaders. Unfortunately, the most popular one is not printable, but there are alternatives.

title: Military Rumblings in Indonesia
description: Indonesia's passage from army-backed dictatorship to freely elected civilian government over the past two years, though accompanied by terrible economic hardships, is one of Asia's great political success stories. But that achievement is now threatened by a tense confrontation between President Abdurrahman Wahid and Indonesia's most powerful military figure, Gen. Wiranto. For democracy to survive in the world's fourth largest country, Mr. Wahid must prevail.

title: Bauer Ends His Quest for G.O.P. Nomination
description: Gary L. Bauer dropped out of the presidential race today, vowing to keep preaching his message of conservative religious values and declining, for now, to endorse anyone else for the Republican nomination.

title: At Age 6, Behrens Returns to Track Looking for Respect
description: At the ripe old age of 6, Behrens has a score to settle and a championship to win, and he will take his shot at both on Saturday against some of the best handicap stars in the East.

title: Octogenarian Who Scales Olympic Heights
description: A dynamic Swiss octogenarian named Marc Hodler is perhaps the only person to have made a major impact in three areas. He has been a member of the International Olympic Committee since 1963, and his name became known to the wider world in 1998 when his efforts to expose corruption in Salt Lake City and elsewhere bore fruit.

title: Cabbage Is Cabbage? Not to Kimchi Lovers; Koreans Take Issue With a Rendition Of Their National Dish Made in Japan
description: Ever since Japan colonized the Korean peninsula during the first half of the 20th century, Koreans have harbored an underlying resentment toward the Japanese. But the latest incarnation of that resentment is not an uproar over newly disclosed wartime atrocities by Japan's military or a fresh instance of discrimination against ethnic Koreans living in Japan.

title: BIG SWISS COMPANIES PRESSURED
description: The Swiss financier Martin Ebner is seeking a voice in how the Credit Suisse Group, the country's second largest bank, and the drug giant Roche Holding are run. Mr. Ebner, who helped to push the Swiss banking giant UBS to merge with the Swiss Bank Corporation, has written the chairmen of Credit Suisse and Roche to ask for a seat on each company's board.

title: Corrections
description: The Wine Talk column on Wednesday, about the increased popularity of the syrah grape in America, misstated the given name of the plant geneticist who some say was the first to import the vines. He is Harold Olmo, not Howard.

title: Expansion Provided 387,000 New Jobs In U.S. Last Month
description: Far from easing off as the American economic expansion was becoming the longest in history, the nation's employers added more jobs in January than in any other single month in more than two years -- drawing in people who had given up looking for work and easing the struggle of millions of workers to make ends meet.

title: Gold Tops $300 on Job Data And an Altered Sales Strategy
description: The price of gold surged past $300 yesterday, gaining 8 percent after a leading gold producer said it would adjust its sales strategy in anticipation of higher prices.

title: Finding a Niche Under the Sun
description: The South Beach section of Miami Beach would seem a strange place to search for anonymity. But there amid the models, the movie stars and the paparazzi, Pavel Bure, at long last, may have found peace of mind.

title: Early Vote Magnifying Importance of California
description: With the quirky preliminaries over, the presidential race has moved squarely into even odder and untested terrain: a new kind of ''national primary'' on March 7 in which more than a dozen states seem all but certain to determine the major parties' nominees.

title: South African Leader Warns Unions Not to Impede Development
description: In his sharpest challenge yet to South Africa's powerful trade unions, President Thabo Mbeki vowed today to relax restrictive labor laws, speed the pace of privatization and reduce spending in the bloated public sector.

title: The Death Penalty in a Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Greene Kicks Off Olympic Year With a Swift 60 Meters
description: They introduced the sprinters as if they were prizefighters, with spotlights and a haughty, pugilistic walk to the starting line. And as usual, it was Maurice Greene, the world's fastest man, who delivered a knockout punch in the 60 meters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLODNEY, RIMA
description: KOLODNEY-Rima. Died February 4, 2000. Sister of David and Nathan, sister-in-law of Ellen, aunt of Akiba and Leah. We will always remember you, Rima. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services.

title: NYT Article
description: Free Scholarships Site Reports Technical Problems From Huge Demand

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JONAY, ADRIENNE
description: JONAY-Adrienne. 2/9/43-2/5/94. Dearest Ady, we all love and miss you so very much. Take good care of Jane until we can be together. Forever, Linnie

title: INSIDE
description: Cancer Study Retracted

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, LEON
description: STEINMAN-Leon. Beloved husband of Ray. Loving father of Monte Steinman, Amy and Peter Blauzvern. Cherished Poppy of Adam, David and Sara. Services Sunday 12:45 at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Trnpk, Woodbury, LI

title: U.S. Recalls Ambassador to Vienna, Temporarily
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that the United States was temporarily recalling its ambassador to Vienna as one of several ''initial'' steps to distance the United States from a governing coalition in Austria that includes a far-rightist party that has preached racial and religious intolerance.

title: A Bronx Man, 35, Is Charged With the Sexual Abuse of Boys
description: For the last six months, a 35-year-old Bronx building superintendent has been inviting young boys into his apartment with the promise of Pokemon cards and Chinese food. Once there, according to the police, he showed them pornographic videos, plied them with marijuana and sexually abused them, sometimes secretly videotaping the illicit sex acts.

title: Letterman, on the Mend, May Return by Mid-Month
description: David Letterman has been making an exceptionally fast recovery from heart surgery and might return to his ''Late Show'' on CBS as early as Feb. 14, the show's executive producer, Rob Burnett, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, HELEN GARY
description: MORAN-Helen Gary, 93, of Manhattan, on February 1. Daughter of Hampson Gary, Ambassador to Egypt and Switzerland under President Wilson. Widow of industrialist Bernard A. Moran. Helen is survived by her sons Bernard Moran Jr., John P. Moran and Michael Moran. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., Friday, 6-8PM. Funeral service Saturday 1PM, St. Thomas Episcopal.

title: The G.O.P. Battle For New York State
description: To the Editor:

title: Oracle to Expand Venture Capital Fund
description: Oracle to Expand Venture Capital Fund

title: The Death Penalty in a Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing the Fun of a Minor Sin
description: Imagine an audience excitedly filling a theater to see a ''sublime and affecting tragedy.'' Then, suggests the 18th-century philosopher Edmund Burke, imagine that just as everybody is finally seated, an announcement is made that in an adjoining square a ''state criminal of high rank'' is about to be publicly executed. In an instant, Burke suggests, the theater would be deserted, proving just how paltry the pleasures of staged tragedy are compared with the delight that can be taken in the ''real misfortunes and pains of others.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLAISTED, BARBARA ROES
description: PLAISTED-Barbara Roes. Age 63 of Somers, New York. Sister of Mrs. Rodney (Doris P.) Peterson, Reverend David and Mrs. Janet Buehler, beloved aunt of Jacob Buehler, Paul and Kevin Peterson. A memorial service will be held Sunday, February 6, 2000 in Emmanuel Lutheran Church, Manville Road, Pleasantville, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice Outreach, Inc., 502 Bedford St., Fall River, MA 02720 or Emmanuel Lutheran Church Library Fund, Manville Rd, Pleasantville, NY 10570. For information, The Dartmouth Funeral Home of Sullivan-Waring, 230 Russells Mills Rd., Dartmouth, MA

title: Hazardous Planetarium
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEISNER, SELMA
description: HEISNER-Selma. On February 3, 2000. Beloved wife of Randall. Loving mother of Carol Lee and Linda Heisner. Dear sister of Robert Morgan. Retired NYC public school teacher, lifetime member National Council of Jewish Women. Services Sinai Chapel, Sunday, February 6, 1:00 PM, 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows. Contributions to NCJW, 53 W. 23 St., NY, NY 10010.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFRA, INA JUDITH
description: SAFRA-Ina Judith. Age 52, of New York City, formerly of Philadelphia, PA. Passed away February 3, 2000. Beloved daughter of Meyer Safra and the late Cicely Safra. Beloved step daughter of Ruth Safra. Beloved sister of Andrew (Anita) Safra and Nona (Jon McGaa). Beloved aunt of Justin (Heather) Matz, Casey Matz, Cory Safra and Raquel Safra. Interment Sunday, February 6th at LevittWeinstein, Hollywood, FL. 800343-5400. Memorial services will be held at the Brotherhood Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South, New York, N.Y. February 13, 2000, 7PM. Contributions in Ina's memory may go to the Brotherhood Synagogue.

title: 7 Killed and 9 Hurt in Kosovo Rampage, Worst Since War
description: In the worst violence Kosovo has seen since the end of the war, seven Albanians were killed and at least nine wounded on Thursday night when about 500 people rampaged through the streets, bursting into apartments, firing guns and throwing grenades.

title: Ex-G.O.P. Chief Enters Plea
description: Two months after he was convicted of taking bribes from a user of a town landfill, John Powell, a former Suffolk County Republican leader, avoided a second trial today by admitting he had helped to run a truck theft ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIFRANCESCO, JOHN, M.D.
description: DiFRANCESCO-John, M.D. The Ophthalmology Department of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center of New York notes with sadness the death of John DiFrancesco, M.D. An esteemed physician and active staff member for over 35 years, his clinical acumen, surgical skills and practical good judgment earned him the respect of his patients and colleagues. His gentle, compassionate manner and warm smile won him their affection. He will be greatly missed. Robert A. D'Amico, M.D., Chairman, Dept of Ophthalmology

title: Great Performers Series Plans 96 Classical Concerts
description: A celebration of Czech music by the London Symphony Orchestra, a multimedia tribute to Stravinsky and the New York recital debut of the Metropolitan Opera soprano Jane Eaglen are among the highlights of the 2000-01 season of Lincoln Center's Great Performers.

title: Donations Lag in Last Weeks of Appeal
description: From Wall Street power brokers to young children with small allowances, people across the metropolitan area and beyond have given more than $5 million this year to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which supports seven of the city's oldest and most respected social service organizations.

title: STRONG GAIN IN BRAZIL OUTPUT
description: In a signal that Brazil's economic recovery is gaining momentum, industrial production climbed 3.1 percent in December, the largest such increase in 19 months. The increase in output reversed a decline of 0.3 percent in November. For all of 1999, industrial production declined 0.7 percent.

title: A New Challenge for Bush: Showing He Wants to Win
description: In the past, when Gov. George W. Bush pondered his astonishingly charmed political career, he sometimes sought metaphors to describe the feeling of being propelled and kept afloat by forces that were larger than he was, and beyond his control. He once compared himself to a cork in a stream.

title: Mu-Ziq Man, Twiddling, Tweaking And Toying
description: Mike Paradinas, the one-man electronica band who records as Mu-Ziq, never stopped twiddling when he performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night. Standing behind a table full of electronic boxes and cords, but with no turntable or keyboard in sight, he rarely let a sound repeat without tweaking it. He toyed with volume, brought out highs or lows, added fuzz or turned whole mixes inside out. The music was restless, and often hilarious.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about the presentation of awards by the New York Festivals misstated the client for which Ogilvy & Mather New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of the WPP Group, won the Best of Show award for best product and service. The client was I.B.M., not the Hilton Hotel and Towers.

title: Beyond Total Recall: The Musician's Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANFORD, LATHAN WADE
description: SANFORD-Lathan Wade, age 63, of Austin, Texas died Monday, January 31, 2000. He graduated from the University of Texas at Austin, where he was a professor in the Department of Theatre and Dance for 31 years. In the Army he was crytographer in special services. As a dancer on Broadway he worked with Bob Fosse and other luminaries. He was a director of many musicals around the country and in Tokyo. Born in Piedmont, Alabama he will be laid to rest in Piedmont in the spring. He is survived by his loving wife, Renata and daughter, Samantha Sanford. A memorial service will be held at 3 P.M. Sunday, February 6, 2000 in the Colonial Chapel of Cook-Walden Funeral Home, 6100 North Lamar, Austin. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Holistic Health Care Center, 410 West Craig, San Antonio, Texas 78212 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Updating 'Black Boxes'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEB, ALYCE E.
description: LIEB-Alyce E., 88. passed away peacefully February 1, 2000 after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Myron (Mac) Lieb and her daughter Ann Carol Mabuchi. She is also survived by her granddaughter Kayla Ritt Yamada, her great-daughter Chelsea Skye Yamada and her grandson Scott Brian Mabuchi. All remember the lovely Alyce and her delightful sense of humor. She will be greatly missed. Service Sunday, February 6, 11:30AM at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens, N.Y.

title: Campaign to Oust Elitist Politicians Picks Up Steam Before Vote : In South Korea, a Quiet Revolution
description: SEOUL  The young people believed they had the perfect spot to push their message: the plaza in front of Seoul Station as crowds rushed to board trains for the three-day holiday marking the beginning of the Lunar New Year.

title: That Bovary Woman, Making Trouble Mostly for Herself
description: Despite the sunny hours of adulterous passion, Emma Bovary is even better known for her lifetime of yearning discontent. Tomorrow night's sharply drawn adaptation of Flaubert's 1857 novel by Heidi Thomas captures the predicament of the young wife, scornful of the affection of a devoted husband, who demands more of her handsome lovers than they prove able or willing to give. But who could meet the needs or desires of a self-absorbed woman who squandered her emotions on dreamy memories of dancing with a gallant viscount much as she squandered the family savings on fripperies?

title: DOUBLECLICK SET TO SELL SHARES TO FINANCE ACQUISITIONS
description: DoubleClick Inc., the biggest online advertising company, said yesterday that it planned to sell as many as 8.63 million common shares, which will raise about $805 million to help finance expansion and acquisitions. The company plans to sell 5.86 million shares, while investors will sell 1.64 million. It filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell the shares at $93.25, or about 13 percent below Thursday's price. The shares fell $9.6875 each, to $97.625, in Nasdaq trading. DoubleClick, based in New York, sells advertising space on almost 1,500 Web sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, JANET
description: KRAUS-Janet. We mourn the loss of our dear and dedicated colleague. Janet was a wonderful person who never had an unkind word to say about anyone. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Tony, to her children Tom and Joanne, to her son-in-law Peter, to her four loving grandchildren, and to her brother, Leonard. We will miss our good friend. May God be with her always! Tishman Speyer Properties

title: Five Senators Rebuke Bush For Criticism of McCain
description: Gov. George W. Bush was slammed today by five senators who, like his chief rival, fought in Vietnam for using a veterans activist to criticize Senator John McCain's record on veterans issues.

title: Family Feud: Tension Mounts Between Top 2 In State G.O.P.
description: The tension between the state government's two top Republicans has escalated to the point that several Republican senators said this week that Gov. George E. Pataki may be plotting to oust the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno.

title: Panel Recommends Reparations In Long-Ignored Tulsa Race Riot
description: Nearly 80 years after this city erupted in what many historians regard as the nation's bloodiest race riot, a state commission today recommended reparations be made to the aged black survivors who watched as people were shot, burned alive or tied to cars and dragged to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANOVIC, LILLIAN B.
description: JANOVIC-Lillian B. Passed away January 31, 2000. Mourned by sons Evan and Neil, grandchildren Joseph, Adam and Julie, great grandchildren Valerie and Maxwell.

title: The McCain Appeal
description: Every once in a long while the placid waters of the Republican Party are roiled by an unruly character. At the turn of the last century there was Teddy Roosevelt, in 1940 Wendell Willkie. And now, John McCain.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Arts & Ideas last Saturday with an article about disputes over Europe's shared cultural heritage referred incorrectly to the sponsorship of a planned Museum of Europe. It is private, not paid for by the European Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIPPER, BETTE JAYNE
description: SHIPPER-Bette Jayne. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Brian C. Rappaport, President

title: Reform Party Casts an Eye On a McCain-Bradley Ticket
description: The Democratic and Republican challengers are not just attracting attention in their own parties.

title: Phillips-Led Union Makes Final Appeal
description: Making a last-ditch effort to salvage the existing union and Richie Phillips's job as its chief, the Major League Umpires Association told the National Labor Relations Board yesterday that a hearing officer got it wrong in upholding the results of an election that paved the way for a new union to represent the umpires.

title: New York's Tax Delinquents Appear at Click of a Mouse
description: Combining a trendy new method (publication on the Internet) with the tried and true (public humiliation), the city of New York this week tried to induce delinquent taxpayers to settle up by listing them on the World Wide Web.

title: Don't Isolate Austria
description: To the Editor:

title: NYT Article
description: Petsmart.com Seeks $115 Million in Offering

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Tokyo Journal; This Elder Statesman Told Them So
description: At 82, the former prime minister still sits bolt upright, his hands folded in his lap throughout an interview, and the sphinxlike impression he gives, talking almost in a murmur for nearly two hours, is only reinforced by his near absolute stillness.

title: Sports of The Times; An Old Pro On Handling An Aging Pro
description: FRANK LAYDEN met a handful of reporters Thursday evening to talk about his new position in basketball. This was during intermission of the Knicks-Trail Blazers game. Layden was being introduced as the Knicks' new basketball consultant, a position created over dinner -- where else? -- by his son, Scott, the general manager of the Knicks, and Dave Checketts, the president of Madison Square Garden. Frank Layden says his role is to provide insight and advice in a wide range of matters.

title: Czingler Leaps To an Upset
description: Zsolt Czingler of Hungary pulled off a big upset in the triple jump yesterday, beating the 1999 world champion Charles Friedek of Germany at the International Indoor Gala in Budapest.

title: THIS WEEKEND'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- No events on Saturday. New York City on Sunday.

title: SUDDENLY, A KING
description: Abdullah II of Jordan can trace his heritage to the prophet Muhammad, talks regularly with Clinton, Barak and Assad and watches sitcoms. Is it possible to be a modern guy and a Middle East potentate? A report by Jeffrey Goldberg in The Times Magazine.

title: A Year Later, Diallo Memorials Reflect the Discord Over His Death
description: A year to the day after Amadou Diallo died in a police fusillade outside his Bronx apartment, his death was marked yesterday in the city's largest cathedral and at a weathered police station, at City Hall and in front of the vestibule where he died.

title: Breast Cancer Researcher Admits Falsifying Data
description: A South African researcher has admitted that he falsified data, and is retracting a widely publicized study claiming that bone-marrow transplantation and high-dose chemotherapy could prolong the lives of women with advanced breast cancer.

title: Cor Therapeutics Rises 59% After Trial of a Heart Drug
description: Shares in Cor Therapeutics Inc. soared today after the company disclosed that its heart drug Integrilin had performed so well in a clinical trial that the test had been ended ahead of schedule.

title: Phone Stocks Rise in Europe After Big Deal
description: Vodafone AirTouch's triumphant $183 billion takeover agreement for Mannesmann of Germany aroused an appetite for telecommunication stocks across Europe today, and Vodafone, the British mobile phone leader, hinted that its expansion was not yet complete.

title: A Building Hovers Over Pedestrians' Shoulders
description: Developers traditionally reach skyward to create more floor space for their buildings. Sometimes they reach downward into bedrock. Rarely do they reach outward -- over a public sidewalk.

title: President to Ask for Increase In Help for Manufacturers
description: In the budget he will send to Congress on Monday, President Clinton will propose increased spending to help manufacturers who have been hit by competition from abroad and a shortage of skilled workers at home, administration officials said today.

title: NYT Article
description: Intel to Acquire Ambient for $150 Million

title: Appellate Court Upholds Dutchess County Election Result
description: In the latest wrinkle in the topsy-turvy world of Dutchess County politics, a New York State appellate court yesterday upheld the November results of a close and controversial race for county clerk, nullifying the need for a special election that was scheduled for Tuesday in a small, remote town.

title: REJECTING RULES, U.S. JUDGE OPENS NEW YORK BALLOT
description: With the state's Republican leadership in retreat, a federal judge made Senator John McCain's victory over the New York primary system official yesterday, placing him on the ballot and even adding another candidate, Alan Keyes. The judge's order means that Republicans in New York will for the first time in memory choose from the same presidential contenders running in other states.

title: Taiwan Military Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Repairing Relations With Russia
description: In June 1992, Russian President Boris Yeltsin came to Washington to celebrate ''partnership and friendship'' with the United States. ''We have left behind the period when America and Russia looked at each other through gun sights,'' he told a joint session of Congress.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO SLIPS. The euro slipped against the dollar after economic reports showed a decline in factory orders in Germany and lower unemployment in the United States. The euro fell to 98.29 cents, from 98.95 on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: The Q & A column in Circuits on Thursday about cookies, which Internet sites send to browsers as identification tags, misstated the address of the Cookie Central Web site. It is www.cookiecentral.com.

title: Nuclear Anxieties In a New World
description: Although the cold war is over, some arms control analysts say that the threat of a nuclear war is actually greater now.

title: Tobacco Ally Takes On McCain
description: The National Smokers Alliance, a group subsidized by the tobacco industry, has begun running a 30-second advertisement in South Carolina that sharply attacks Senator John McCain of Arizona for his sponsorship of an antismoking bill to impose fees on tobacco that would have raised the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.10. South Carolina holds its presidential primary on Feb. 19.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND CLOSE TO SALE OF PUMP BUSINESS
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company, a maker of machinery and construction equipment, expects to reach an agreement soon to sell its pump business, Herbert Henkel, chief executive, said yesterday. Mr. Henkel declined to comment further on the sale of the Ingersoll-Dresser pump unit , which the company had earlier proposed selling. Analysts have estimated that the unit could fetch about $1 billion. The sale is part of a plan to focus on climate control, security and industrial equipment businesses. The company is based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Where Elian Gonzalez Can Grieve and Heal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, JOHN FRANCIS
description: HOGAN-John Francis. On February 4, 2000, at age 89. Oakwood School 1928, Fordham Class 1936, WWII Captain in Army of the United States, and past Commander Ad Men's Post #

title: $3.47 Billion Bid for Italian Conglomerate
description: Compart, an Italian holding company, offered today to pay $3.47 billion for 100 percent ownership of one of Europe's biggest energy and food conglomerates, Montedison.

title: Executive To Lead U.S.O.C.
description: The United States Olympic Committee yesterday chose Norman P. Blake Jr., a veteran financial executive, to run an organization that admitted it failed to oversee Salt Lake City's scandal-pocked bid for the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is no statute of limitations on a moral obligation.''

title: Judge Korman's Election Order
description: By approving a legal settlement yesterday opening the ballot of New York's March 7 Republican presidential primary, Federal District Court Judge Edward Korman gave Republicans in the state something Republicans elsewhere take for granted. That, of course, is the opportunity to choose from a full slate of presidential candidates, including John McCain, George W. Bush, Steve Forbes and Alan Keyes. Gov. George Pataki's attempt to rig the election for Mr. Bush by keeping Mr. McCain off the ballot in many parts of the state led to a humiliating political reversal for the governor.

title: Why Austria Faces Anger
description: The two weeks of diplomatic whipping that Austria has absorbed over the inclusion of Jorg Haider's anti-immigrant Freedom Party in its new government has been quite extraordinary.

title: The Pitter-Patter of Little Feet
description: On an indoor track overflowing with little girls running, hurdling and squealing, Ashley Armand caught Cheryl Toussaint's eye.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GE POWER SYSTEMS, Schenectady, N.Y., a division of General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., won a $500 million contract to supply 16 turbines to the NRG Energy unit of Northern States Power Co., Minneapolis.

title: The Difficult Case of John Rocker
description: John Rocker's comments in Sports Illustrated in December were ignorant, offensive and worthy of the condemnation that his teammates, the public and now the commissioner of baseball have heaped upon them. Rocker, a relief pitcher for the Atlanta Braves who had earlier won notoriety by berating Mets fans during the National League Championship Series last October, broadened his target to include foreigners, gays and others. He also called one of his black teammates ''a fat monkey.''

title: I.R.A. and the Arms Principle
description: The Irish Republican Army, now in the third year of a cease-fire, is trying to convince people of its peaceful intent by not using its guns. But it has cast doubt on that objective by insisting on keeping them.

title: Austria Coalition Sworn In as Diplomatic Fallout Rises
description: President Thomas Klestil swore in a coalition government today that includes members of the anti-immigration Freedom Party. That prompted the United States to recall its ambassador ''for consultations'' and European governments to begin downgrading relations in protest.

title: Prada Puts End to Skid To Force Deciding Race
description: A day after a humbling defeat that pushed it to the verge of elimination, Italy's Prada Challenge rebounded to beat America One today and set up a decisive ninth and final race in the challenger finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANELA, HARRIETTE
description: MANELA-Harriette. Age 73, of Fair Lawn, NJ. Born in Belgium, emigrated to New York City in 1948 after surviving the Holocaust. Survived by her husband Marc, daughters Marlene (John) Sincaglia and Jacqueline (Jerry) Novin, brothers Chalom, Marcel and Albert (Dr. Lynne) Fremder, brother-in-law Willy Manela, grandsons Teddy and Zach Novin and Matthew Sincaglia; and numerous nieces and nephews. Services are 2:00 pm, Sunday , at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: How Albany Failed English
description: The primal image of an adult's potential for cruelty toward children was stamped on my 12-year-old brain by Christina Crawford's account in ''Mommie Dearest'' of being forced by her glamorous mother to scrub vast expanses of floor with a toothbrush. Last week, I felt some of the same horror when I proctored and began grading New York State's new Regents examination in English language arts.

title: Guard's Family to Sue Over Care at Rikers
description: The family of a prison guard plans to sue New York City and its hospitals agency for malpractice, saying that the man died of a heart attack last year after receiving poor medical care at a clinic on Rikers Island, according to documents filed with the city comptroller's office.

title: CANADIAN JOBLESSNESS UNCHANGED
description: Canada's unemployment rate was 6.8 percent in January, unchanged from December and holding at the lowest level since April 1976, Statistics Canada reported. The robust economy added 44,000 jobs last month, but a comparable number of people joined the labor market, the statistical agency said. In the last 12 months, 442,000 full-time jobs have been created, a 3.8 percent increase, while part-time employment has dropped by 39,000, or 1.4 percent.

title: Quality Nursing Care
description: To the Editor:

title: NYT Article
description: Wine Sellers Toast E-Commerce Craze

title: 2 Loud Sounds From Tail Preceded Crash of Alaska Airlines Jet
description: The crew of Alaska Airlines Flight 261 heard two loud sounds from the tail of the plane before it crashed offshore here on Monday, the National Transportation Safety Board reported today. The sounds probably mean that the crash was caused by more than a simple jam of the horizontal control system.

title: Nets Wilt Under Pressure Once Again
description: Trying desperately to spark change, Kendall Gill had challenged his Nets teammates over the past two days, saying that some of them lacked a killer instinct, that too many of them crumbled during the tense moments of a game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULRY, SISTER MARY ADELAIDE, OP
description: MULRY-Sister Mary Adelaide, OP, of the Dominican Congregation of Our Lady of the Rosary, Sparkill, NY died on February 3, 2000. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10:30am at Dominican Convent, Sparkill, NY. Burial St. Agnes Cemetery. Visitation at the Convent Sunday from 3:30-8:30pm.

title: Paradise Lost: Can Mankind Live Without Its Utopias?
description: Utopia may be ''no place'' (as one of the word's original meanings suggests), but when imagined, it is always some place. Just not here. It is across an ocean (like Sir Thomas More's noplace that was the first to be called utopia), atop a mountain (like H. G. Wells's) or in interstellar space (like the science fiction writer Ursula K. LeGuin's).

title: NYT Article
description: CMGI to Take Stake in Chicago Company

title: TERAYON, CABLE MODEM MAKER, AGREES TO BUY TYCO UNIT
description: The cable modem maker Terayon Communications Systems Inc. said late on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Tyco International's Raychem Access Network Electronics unit for $90 million in stock. The acquisition is part of Terayon's plan to provide voice, data and video services over a variety of media. Raychem Access makes digital subscriber line systems, which allow fast Internet access over regular phone lines. Its products are used by SBC Communications, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth and GTE, among others. Separately, Terayon, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it had agreed to acquire Combox Ltd. of Israel, a privately held maker of cable data systems, for 775,000 shares, or about $89 million.

title: Rights Agency Said to Be Studying New York Life Bias Complaint
description: A federal civil rights agency is conducting an investigation into how the New York Life Insurance Company, the nation's fifth-largest life insurer, treats its minority employees, according to lawyers representing some of those employees.

title: On Bandwagon, Worry About Early Boarding
description: The way some Republicans tell it, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas had the best night of his campaign on Tuesday when he lost the New Hampshire primary by 19 points to Senator John McCain of Arizona.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTULLO, G. ROBSON
description: PATTULLO-G. Robson, 49, died peacefully on February 3, 2000 in New York City. Cherished friend and husband of Susan. Beloved father of Claire. Devoted son of Elizabeth and Pat Pattullo, brother of Betsy, Ann, Greg and Ronald. Uncle of Jess, Gabe, Alissa and Sasha. Associated for nearly 25 years with ABC News. A joyous light in the lives of all who knew him. Funeral services will be held in Winchester, MA. A memorial celebration in New York City will follow. Donations in Rob's memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Big East Tries to Keep Tradition in Two-Division Format
description: Once the decision was made to add Virginia Tech to Big East basketball for next season, Commissioner Mike Tranghese and the conference athletic directors knew they were heading into the territory of two divisions. To divide them, the commissioner kept tradition in mind.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Unemployment Rate Fell To Just 4 Percent in January

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Oman Letting Seized Russian Tanker Dock
description: Oman has agreed to accept the Russian tanker seized by two American warships that were enforcing United Nations sanctions against Iraq, a Pentagon official said today.

title: Let's Get Ready to Fumble: A No-Holds-Barred League
description: THERE'S a foreign object in the ring!

title: Voices Raised in Conservative Circles Are Urging Forbes to Drop Out of Race
description: For Steve Forbes, who promotes his business acumen on the campaign trail, the calculation is a tough one. Already, Mr. Forbes has spent $28.7 million of his own money on his presidential effort -- not including the bills still to come from the contests in New Hampshire and Iowa. And all that this money has garnered is 55,880 votes -- with half from a race that was only symbolic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, IRVIN, DR.
description: STEIN-Irvin, Dr. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Philadelphia, died on February 3, 2000 at Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD. He was 93. Dr. Stein was born in Fayetteville, NC and graduated from the University of North Carolina. He received his medical training at Jefferson Medical College and his Intern and Resident training at Johns Hopkins University Medical Center and the University of Pennsylvania. He was Chief of Orthopedic Surgery at Philadelphia General Hospital and at the Albert Einstein Medical Center. He was Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. Dr. Stein served on the Board of the Phildelphia Orchestra and was the doctor to famous musicians including Ormandy, Serkin, Toscanini, and Van Cliburn. He received the Lily Award from the Easter Seal Society in the 1970's. He was a member of the Locust Club, the Philmont Country Club, and Rodeph Shalom Synagogue. His interests included golf and travel. Dr. Stein was married to Dorothy Bluthenthal for 51 years before her death in 1985. He is survived by his wife, Bunny Levy Hutzler, three daughters, Jane Finerman, Margery Schab and Kathy Sachs, 10 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Sunday at 2 PM at Joseph Levine & Son, 4737 Street Road, Trevose, PA. Interment is at Roosevelt Memorial Park, Trevose, PA. Contributions in his memory may be made to the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Viewer Challenged To Negotiate Space
description: INSTEAD of shaping a space, as sculpture does, installation art fills up a space, usually with an arsenal of objects, and leaves it up to the viewer to make sense of it all. Such a challenge is flamboyantly posed at the Brownson Gallery at Manhattanville College here.

title: Japan's New Generation of Composers
description: ASK an American who follows new music to name some contemporary Japanese composers, and you are likely to hear the name of Toru Takemitsu -- and no one else. True, the New York Philharmonic recently gave the premiere of a work by Somei Satoh, but since Takemitsu died in 1996, no other Japanese composer has similarly captured the attention of the new-music world in the United States.

title: McCall Calls for a Moratorium on the Expansion of Gambling
description: In an indirect challenge to Gov. George E. Pataki, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall called today for a moratorium on the expansion of gambling in New York and said the state must devote more attention to gambling's social and economic consequences.

title: Sundance Gives Signs Of Renewal
description: WE have come to expect a great deal of the Sundance Film Festival, the independent film world's annual gathering in the snowy, condo-packed valleys of the Wasatch Range. Besides offering a great confluence of buzz and celebrity, a career-advancing opportunity for young filmmakers, a meat market for agents-on-the-make, a bazaar for indie-film distributors and a stage for artiste poseurs and hustler manques, it is also regarded as the year's prime opportunity to take the pulse of American independent filmmaking.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: DON VICENTE

title: Officials Investigate Why Train Dragged Girl
description: A New York City Transit spokesman said yesterday that an investigation had not yet determined why a 12-year-old girl was dragged along a station platform on Friday when her foot got caught between subway car doors. Trains are not supposed to be able to move unless the doors are closed.

title: Putnam Is Home to Four Weeklies
description: IN contrast to the many indigenous periodicals in Westchester County, Putnam has only four, all weeklies.

title: She's Fast on Her Feet and Full of New Steps
description: IN her three and a half years as the artistic director of the Encores musical concert series, the choreographer Kathleen Marshall has become something of an expert in the fine art of instant entertainment. Productions at Encores, after all, rarely rehearse for more than 10 days before showing off the results for 3,000 spectators a night at City Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, MURIEL S.
description: KAYE-Muriel S. On February 1, 2000. Beloved wife of Stanley. Devoted mother of Michael and Jon. Dear sister of the late Glenda Levine. Cherished great-aunt of Lauren and Amanda. Adored aunt of Eileen, Steven, Amy, Bruce, Jim, Craig & the late Ellen. Loving mother-in-law of Emily. Cherished sister-in-law of Bernice Levy, and the late Sheldon Levy, & brotherin-law Harold Levine. Services were held Friday, February 4th at ''Guttermans Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Saving Home of a Heroine Who Saved Many
description: THE home of Connecticut's official heroine is about to be rescued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANON, JOSEPH
description: DANON-Joseph. On February 2, 2000. Beloved husband of Maxine. Dear sister of Alice. Loving uncle Joe to Michael, Jeffrey and Nuri. Service Sunday, February 6th, 2PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Native Daughter Speaks Softly, Caught in a Cultural Limbo
description: SO here I am in Darty, a huge discount appliance store, trying to buy a dishwasher. So far, it's going really well. I am just another customer -- more important, just another French customer -- and the saleswoman is eager to make a sale.

title: So You Think Playing at Home is Easy?
description: The first of a long line of game shows on the small screen - ''The CBS Television Quiz''- had its premiere on July 2, 1941. More than half a century later, the stakes may be higher (the first contestants did not play for money), but the basic formats are not at all that different. Like ''Jeopardy!'' today, ''The CBS Television Quiz'' gave contestants the answer and asked them to pose the question. The quiz that follows will test your knowledge of other spinoffs, and spin-outs, of the past, some of which can still be seen on the Game Show Network and in syndication.

title: Anthony Wong and Elly Karp
description: Elly Juliet Karp, the daughter of Irene and James Karp of Louisville, Ky., was married last evening to Anthony Chi Wai Wong, the son of Teresa and David Wong of Freehold, N.J. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony at the ''21'' Club in New York.

title: Warming Up to Salsa at Sea
description: AT the close of our seven-day Caribbean cruise aboard Carnival Cruise Lines' Inspiration, our final edition of Carnival Capers, the daily newsletter, listed 66 events that had taken place that week, in case we had ''forgotten about some of the fun you joined in with during the week.'' The newsletter then asked, ''How much did you get involved with?'' Our answer: almost none.

title: McCain Basks in the Applause, but the Whispered Party Line Favors Bush
description: As long as the Republican of the Hour was standing on a podium, the Republican Party of California was standing right behind him.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Claudia Shear; A Mae West Appetite
description: IT was snowing and sticking -- a meteorological event that even die-hard Weather Channel fans didn't expect -- and it made the atmosphere inside Il Buco seem like a ski lodge in the Italian Alps, even if this was Bond Street on a Thursday night. The crowd was loud, exuberant and well dressed, which made the place perfect for the little woman with the big presence about to make her entrance, a curvaceous blonde in a white Dr. Zhivago hat parting a sea of skinny dark clothes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, JACOB P.
description: ROSENBAUM-Jacob P. The Board of Governors and we of North Shore Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed former member, Jacob Rosenbaum. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Jerome H. Grossman, President Enid Rosenthal, Secretary

title: Alan North, 79, Character Actor On Stage, Screen and Television
description: Alan North, a character actor whose career spanned more than 50 years, died on Jan. 19 at a hospital near his home in Port Jefferson, N.Y. He was 79 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: So You're A Millionaire. Now What?
description: WOULD you like to be a millionaire? That's a question that four major television networks are posing, one way or another, these days and that everyone can no doubt quickly -- and predictably -- answer. Unfortunately, though, you can't necessarily become one just by winning $1 million or even more on a quiz show.

title: Food; Shellshocked
description: I began to understand life when I began to understand oysters. And I began to understand oysters under duress. There I was -- a young woman in the male bastion of a restaurant kitchen in Provincetown -- with two bushels of the shellfish, 500 people for dinner, a nasty chef and a stubby knife.

title: Herbert I. Schiller, 80, Critic of the Corporate Control of Television
description: Herbert I. Schiller, a teacher, writer and critic who studied the subject of communication, died on Jan. 29 in La Jolla, Calif. He was 80 and a longtime La Jolla resident.

title: Jobs Outside the Ivory Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKAY, LLOYD L.
description: McKAY-Lloyd L. 68, of Laurelton, NY, on February 3. Loving father of Jennifer, Michelle, and Natasha. Grandfather of Jillian. Viewing O'Brien-Sheipe Chapel, Elmont, today 3-7PM. Services St. Boniface Church, Elmont, Feb. 7th. 9:30AM

title: Cayard's Style: It Isn't Nasty
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Bankruptcy Bill Approved
description: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a major overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws, making it more difficult for people to seek legal protection from paying off their debts. The House passed a bill last year that is even tougher on debtors, and lawmakers will now meet to try to reach a compromise that President Clinton is willing to sign. He has said both versions now are unacceptable.

title: Economic Problems Hinder Croatia's Effort at Changes
description: The new Croatian government is moving quickly to keep its promises of social equality and justice, with plans to cut official salaries by 40 percent, and to arrest a former Cabinet minister and an infamous tycoon.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The doctors told us they were vitamins and we believed them.''

title: Another Crossroad In Messier's Career
description: Mark Messier's days as a Vancouver Canuck may be coming to an end.

title: Bishop Laughlin And St.Joseph's Win Meet Titles
description: St. Joseph's By the Sea took the New York team title and Bishop Loughlin captured the Brooklyn-Queens crown yesterday in the Catholic High School Athletic Association girls sectional championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan. St. Joseph's of Staten Island won for the second straight year with 54 points and Cardinal Spellman finished second at 45.

title: Lisa Ruckel, Christofor Tella
description: Lisa Marlene Ruckel and Christofor Scott Tella were married yesterday in Georgetown, Conn. The Rev. Mark Grimes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOFFE, HELEN GEWERTZ
description: JOFFE-Helen Gewertz. 6/4/30-2/7/ 97. Beloved sister, aunt, friend. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Are Auto Headlights In Need of Regulation?
description: It's time the government got involved in regulating and standardizing the number and height of headlights on all non-commercial vehicles, including S.U.V.'s.

title: Suffolk Overrides Veto On Peconic Warnings
description: In a unanimous vote on Tuesday, the Suffolk County Legislature overrode a veto by County Executive Robert J. Gaffney of a measure requiring the county to place signs along the Peconic River warning of possible contamination from Brookhaven National Laboratory.

title: Hate the Weather? This Man Doesn't
description: DAVID A. ROBINSON was in the fourth grade at MacKay elementary school in Tenafly when he made his first weather chart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, JANET
description: KRAUS-Janet. We mourn the loss of our dear and dedicated colleague. Janet was a wonderful person who never had an unkind word to say about anyone. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Tony, to her children Tom and Joanne, to her son-in-law Peter, to her four loving grandchildren, and to her brother, Leonard. We will miss our good friend. May God be with her always! Tishman Speyer Properties

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDERS, FIRA
description: LANDERS-Fira. Of East Hampton, LI, NY, Thursday, February 3, 2000. Visitation: Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan, CT, Friday, February 11th. from 4 to 7 PM. Burial private.

title: A Moral Beacon Amid the Darkness Of a Tragic Era
description: A CENTURY ago the equation of great music with spiritual uplift was a prevailing article of faith. To John Sullivan Dwight, the Boston critic who fathered American classical music, Beethoven's symphonies seemed ''sacred.'' To Theodore Thomas, the itinerant conductor who fathered the American orchestra, symphonic concerts were ''sermons in tones.'' Music making and music listening were cherished as inherently wholesome activities. Concerts were morally empowering.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: DARKLING I LISTEN

title: Traffic-Slowing Measures In Bronx Fall Short . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: So It Snowed. It's Cold. What's the Fuss, Wimp?
description: MAYBE it's because your average suburbanite, hard by a cul-de-sac or a Fresh Fields, lives such an insulated life, cozy in a thermo-paned, centrally heated home. Who knows? But the prospect of snow -- any amount -- turns local newscasters into shrieking Cassandras and brings school systems to a halt.

title: In His Old Form, Short Runs Through Field at Pamplona
description: Is Nigel Short making a comeback try for the world championship?

title: Correction
description: A picture caption Jan. 23 with an article about the the play ''The Memoirs of Gluckel of Hameln'' misidentified two actors. The seated woman was Adrienne Cooper and the standing woman was Clare Dolan.

title: The Forbes Game Plan
description: After registering just 13 percent in New Hampshire, a defiant Steve Forbes announces he has no plans to drop out of the Republican presidential race. He moves on to Delaware with a new slogan: ''Vote for Forbes and get a plane.''

title: Pensions That Get Bigger Than Their Sponsors
description: In a time of hard-to-explain stock valuations, many investors wonder what makes a company a true value play. One possible answer is this: when the company's pension plan is worth more than its stock market capitalization.

title: Varsity Sweaters From Mink U.
description: The mink sweater with a yawning neckline has arrived, and is favored by young women who find a classic mink coat too formal for their casual lives. Some women are having their fur coats remodeled into sweaters, which stand alone in mild climates or fit over turtlenecks farther north. The idea of a fur sweater has been a novelty with designers for decades, but the furrier J. Mendel has popularized the idea. Other furriers have expanded it into rabbit, pony and sable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLLERS, JOSEPH E., SR.
description: VOLLERS-Joseph E., Sr. Age 86. Died on January 30, 2000 in Richmond, California. Retired from New York City Fire Department as Battalion Chief in 1967. Survived by his beloved wife Josephine E. Vollers of El Cerrito, CA; sisters Gertrude Leibel and Florence Miller; sons Joseph E. Vollers, Jr. and Charles S. Vollers; daughters Judith Martin and Maryanne Vollers Campbell; eleven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

title: Dubya Agonistes In Austin
description: Reports are dribbling out of Austin about the Can This Campaign Be Saved powwow there this weekend.

title: THE GUIDE
description: One-Woman Comedy Show

title: Kidnapped?
description: To the Editor:

title: Matter of Degree
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. ANTIDRUG PLAN TO AID COLOMBIA FACES SKEPTICISM
description: The Clinton administration's $1.3 billion plan to help Colombia fight drug trafficking and leftist insurgents is facing skepticism from military and law-enforcement officials concerned that the United States could be dragged into a long and costly struggle that may ultimately have little impact on the drug trade.

title: The Caring, and Ambiguous, Arzner Touch
description: THREE days into the last century, the wife of a San Francisco cafe owner gave birth to a child who would grow up to be the lone female filmmaker of Hollywood's golden era. Dorothy Arzner will not receive a fraction of the tributes accorded that other recent centenarian, Alfred Hitchcock. But Arzner warrants a place in film history, and not simply because she broke into the super-macho profession that movie directing was in the 30's and 40's. Looked at today, Arzner's films are startling in their pre-feminist probings of women's place in American society.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00: On Language; Squeezewords
