description: Rush Limbaugh, the radio philosopher, was appalled. Thousands of his listeners were sending in messages protesting the increased number of commercials on his program. Because he was talking the same amount of time every day, and the show ran the same three hours, how could this be?

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Crime of Sheila McGough

title: Cell Phone Cautions
description: Recent studies in The New England Journal of Medicine show that drivers using mobile phones are four times more likely to be involved in a collision, the county's Office of Consumer Protection reports.

title: Anna Clark, Adviser to La Guardia, Dies at 95
description: Anna Holbrook Clark, who transcended a secretarial job to become an influential policy adviser to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and worked at five levels of government, died on Jan. 28 in a Manhattan nursing home. She was 95.

title: The Masters Of Memory Are Tested
description: It was a tough scene of chewed lips and rapier minds, working.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, BONNIE
description: CASHIN-Bonnie. The Fashion Institute of Technology acknowledges with sadness the death of Bonnie Cashin, innovative designer of simple but elegant clothes for the modern woman. With Ms. Cashin, the Museum at FIT has been planning a major retrospective of her work for exhibition in September. Although she will not be able to receive the acclaim she so deserves, Bonnie had put her mark on the show, and will be there in spirit.

title: Jobs Outside the Ivory Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Pact on Puerto Rico Base
description: Puerto Rico agreed to let the Navy resume limited training on the island of Vieques as part of a deal that includes up to $90 million in aid if residents of Vieques vote next year to allow exercises with live ammunition.

title: BRIEFING: TRANSPORTATION
description: As of last week, these state-owned car inspection stations, which have had the longest waiting times since Dec. 13, reverted to the old method of emissions testing. The state reported shorter waiting times.

title: The Arrow Leads to Beaujolais
description: Like clockwork, as Feb. 14 approaches, winedom's commercial representatives of cupid lead buyers to the Beaujolais shelf. What could be a more symbolic Valentine's gift, they ask, than a bottle from Saint-Amour, the northernmost appellation in earthy Beaujolais country?

title: SOAPBOX; Future Shock in Central Park
description: WELCOME to the Central Park Conservancy's Fence and Foliage Museum. Our tour begins right here at the Diana Ross Simulated Playground. As most of you know, public playgrounds were closed back in 2015, after O'Shaughnessy v. City of New York was settled for $1 billion. But the chain link fencing was so classic, we decided to keep this installation. With the digital soundtrack of giggles and squeals, you could swear those rubberized figures were authentic youngsters at play.

title: In Search of Patterns
description: The mechanical problem that led to the crash of the Alaska Airlines jet here on Monday night was unusual to the point of being unprecedented. But that is the problem with many high-profile crashes lately: The pattern of recent accidents is that there is no pattern.

title: As Golf Foes Near Solution, 'Fore!' Is Not a Far Cry Away
description: Just weeks after city officials announced final approval for a championship golf course in Ferry Point Park, with a driving range, restaurant, pro shop and waterfront walkways, some residents and cycling advocates complained that the plan would curtail their access to the park. Now it appears that a solution may be in sight, at least down the road.

title: Bettman's Plate Includes Olympics, Crease Rule and an Assist
description: Commissioner Gary Bettman said in his state of the game address this evening that he was pursuing efforts to have National Hockey League players in the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: Missing From List
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/Elliot Magaziner; At 78, Violinist Finds Career Going Strong
description: AT 12, Elliot Magaziner won a violin competition that had as its prize a chance to play at the Westchester County Center. By the time he was 19, he was touring the world with the American Ballet Theater. And in World War II, he was part of the Army Air Corps entertainment unit, working with Charlton Heston, Donald O'Connor and Red Buttons.

title: Jagr Advocates 4 on 4
description: Jaromir Jagr of the Pittsburgh Penguins is leading the league in scoring with 80 points and is again a candidate for the Hart trophy as most valuable player. He said the increasing number of injuries in hockey is a matter of size and space, not equipment, and he favors a radical solution.

title: Boy, 5, and His Grandparents Are Killed in Queens Fire
description: A Queens couple and their 5-year-old grandson were killed yesterday morning and the couple's son was severely burned in a fire started in their home by an overturned candle, fire officials said.

title: Anthony Blum, 61, Dancer of Unmistakable Style for City Ballet
description: Anthony Blum, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet in the 1960's and 70's, died on Dec. 28 at the Wesley Health Center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 61 and lived in Saratoga Springs.

title: David Levy, 87, TV Executive Who Produced 'Addams Family'
description: David Levy, a television executive and producer who created ''The Addams Family'' series for ABC, died on Jan. 25 in Beverly Hills, Calif., where he lived. He was 87.

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Military Training on Gays
description: In an admission that the armed forces have failed to implement its ''don't ask, don't tell, don't harass'' policy, the Pentagon announced that it will require all members of the armed forces to undergo training this year to prevent anti-gay harassment. Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen ordered the leaders of each service to insure that their members understand that anti-gay harassment will not be tolerated. ELIZABETH BECKER

title: Cruises Let Kids Play Like Adults
description: WHAT does a child think is the most fun on a cruise? For Bill Driscoll of Wilmington, N.C., who has sailed more than most third graders, it is ''going where you can't usually go.'' Specifically, he said, last month it was getting into the casino aboard Carnival's Ecstasy, where a scavenger-hunt clue was taped to the side of a slot machine.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Sticky Stuff
description: Stuck out in a drafty sheep farmers' cabin in deserted eastern British Columbia, Augusta Olsen finds little comfort in her skinflint husband, Karl. Nothing helps -- not even sneaking into town -- until she dusts off her mother's apiary equipment and begins, quite literally, to put some honey into her life. The craft of beekeeping provides some of the most memorable moments in Gail Anderson-Dargatz's second novel, A RECIPE FOR BEES (Harmony, $23). What sticks in the mind here, oddly enough, is not so much Augusta's ingenuity or her struggles, but Karl's unquestioning loyalty. Throughout the journey that started on a hardscrabble farm and brought them to an overprotected life in an old-age home in Vancouver, you wonder: what did Karl think of his wayward wife? He becomes a considerate husband late in the novel, and it's a conversion that doesn't make a lot of sense -- particularly when the lingering image of Augusta is of a nervous young woman in a fading flowered dress, nervously sipping tea in a downtown cafe as she awaits her lover. Honey is a miraculous sweetener, and it makes a handy metaphor for discoveries and compromises made late in a marriage. In this novel, it's not nearly as effective in its other role, as glue. Sally Eckhoff

title: In Kosovo, More Clashes Between Peacekeepers and Albanians
description: Peacekeepers clashed with Kosovo Albanians for a second day today in this town, firing percussion grenades and tear gas to push back angry crowds from the bridge that divides the city.

title: New Rules Proposed on Fire Safety
description: THE New York City Fire Department held a public hearing last month and solicited written comments on a proposed rule that would require the posting of fire safety plans in every apartment in virtually every residential building. According to fire officials, the rule is a result of a mandate contained in Local Law No. 10 of 1999, enacted after seven people died in two fires in December 1998.

title: Questioning the Aims Of Tower Opponents
description: In presenting the view of Ossining cell tower opponents (''Suit Filed Over Plan for School Antenna,'' Jan. 30), your article failed to ask if the opponents themselves used cellular telephones. You would have discovered that many of them do.

title: North Carolina Art Museum Says It Will Return Painting Tied to Nazi Theft
description: After confirming that one of its most prized paintings had been stolen by the Nazis during World War II from an Austrian Jewish art collector, the North Carolina Museum of Art announced plans this week to give the painting back to its rightful owners, two sisters in Austria.

title: Renata Adler Is Making Enemies Again
description: I've read and enjoyed some of Adler's articles. She's obviously intelligent. However, like our present-day Iago, Linda Tripp, she lacks a conscience and a soul.

title: Sarah Caudwell, 60, Lawyer And Author of Mystery Novels
description: Sarah Caudwell, the British author whose modest but ecstatically received output of three erudite and maliciously witty mystery novels led at least one critic to compare her to Oscar Wilde, died on Jan. 28 at her home in London. She was 60.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DACK, SIMON, M.D.
description: DACK-Simon, M.D. February 7, 1994. Lovingly remembered, sadly missed. Jackie, Jeri and Lenny

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASTOR, HAROLD C.
description: CASTOR-Harold C. Memorial services will be 12 Noon Sunday February 13, 2000 at Christ UMC, 1200 N. Avenue, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, JUNE CANNELL
description: BIRNBAUM-June Cannell. Of Sea Bright, NJ, on January 31, 2000. Beloved wife of Roger, loving mother of Cara and Amy. Scholar, teacher, writer, editor, educational consultant. Donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Role Modeling in Classic Costumes for Opera's Gala
description: AN opera costume fashion show was featured at the Aida-Golden Millennium Ball of the New Jersey State Opera, at the Canoe Brook Country Club in Summit.

title: After Mouldwarp
description: THE PLATO PAPERS

title: Lives Lived Well, More for the List
description: In the article on lives lived well, I believe that you missed one of the most important ones in the state. On April 3, 1999, Peter Thacher passed away in Stonington, at the age of 72. Mr. Thacher was Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations, who with others initiated the United Nations Environmental Program. As deputy director of this somewhat undervalued, yet so important, branch of the United Nations, he was the architect of the United Nations Stockholm conference in 1972, which was the first international meeting in which Chinese, Soviet and American diplomats sat around the table together.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Who Needs an Image Makeover?; Sure, Van Gundy Seems Dour, but He Gets Results From His Knicks
description: Amid the feel-good vibes emanating through the sheen of the National Basketball Association finals last June, Jeff Van Gundy was still in character. More rumpled than bedsheets in the morning, he peered through his raccoon eyes during a news conference and uttered a line fit for a mob scene.

title: One Church, Two Visions
description: In its 14-year history, the ChoDae Presbyterian Church in New Jersey has blossomed into one of the biggest Korean-American congregations in northern New Jersey. Its membership has grown to about 700 people from 50, and many of its three Sunday services in a rented 250-seat Lutheran church in Paramus are filled to overflowing.

title: 'Cocktail' Toss: Bartending As Extreme Sport
description: ON a stage recently vacated by David Cassidy, a young Lithuanian man was walking on broken glass. In bare feet. While juggling three liquor bottles. The crowd in the Copacabana Showroom in the Rio All-Suite Casino Resort were clapping like seals. Even in the land of Siegfried, Roy and Buddy Hackett, they've never seen anything quite like Mindaugas Gradeckas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILANO, ROBERT J.
description: MILANO-Robert J. In memory of a much-loved member of the Board of Citizens Union and Citizens Union Foundation. Ogden N. Lewis, Chair, CU Robert Abrams, President, CUF Member of CU and CUF

title: Suddenly, It's a National Campaign
description: FRESH from his victory rally in New Hampshire, Vice President Al Gore boarded Air Force Two around midnight on Tuesday and headed for New York City, and on to Washington and Ohio, winding up in Los Angeles for a town hall meeting that ended at 1:20 a.m. Later that morning, Mr. Gore mingled with voters in Venice, Calif., flew to Olympia, Wash., for a labor event and returned home to Washington around 4:30 a.m. on Friday.

title: Manufacturers' Driving Schools: The Homework Is Your Commute
description: IF you had your last driving lesson just before you got a license, you may be ready for a refresher course. Three European carmakers are offering instruction:

title: Another Production
description: To the Editor:

title: The Many Ways to Treat a Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; 88 Killed in Airline Crash
description: For Alaska Airlines, the crash of Flight 261 into the Pacific Ocean near Los Angeles was a family tragedy: more than a third of the 88 people aboard, all of whom died, had some connection to the airline itself.

title: A.T.M. FEES
description: The Woodbridge Township Council introduced an ordinance last week that would prohibit banks from charging noncustomers the usual $1 or $1.50 fee for using their automated teller machines. The ordinance, which could be in place by next month, would not affect fees banks charge their own customers, nor would it affect fees charged for using machines in locations other than banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPMAN, FRIEDA (ALTSCHULER)
description: LIPMAN-Frieda (Altschuler), died peacefully in her 95th year on February 1, 2000. Wife of the late Harry Lipman, mother of Betty Weisberger and the late Irving Lipman. Private service was held at the graveside.

title: Throwing an Elbow at 'Old Politics'
description: As a basketball player, Bill Bradley had a reputation for being a stealthy fouler, brilliant at holding, hooking and elbowing his opponents without getting caught.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a photograph of a restaurant on the Queen Elizabeth 2 on Page 16 of the Travel section today, with a listing of cruises, is reproduced in mirror image. The windows should appear at the right.

title: Crime
description: In Alex McKnight's rugged neck of the woods -- a town called Paradise, right across from Canada, in Michigan's Upper Peninsula -- anything under a foot of snow is just ''scattered flurries,'' and any fistfight that doesn't require skin grafts qualifies as civilized discourse. A former Detroit cop and failed private eye who drew first blood in Steve Hamilton's strong debut mystery, ''A Cold Day in Paradise,'' Alex returns in WINTER OF THE WOLF MOON (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's Minotaur, $23.95) to duke it out with a roughneck team of hockey players whose postgame rituals extend to dealing drugs and beating up Indians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISCHLER, STANLEY, M.D.
description: TISCHLER-Stanley, M.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Stanley Tischler, M.D., former professor of OB/GYN. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. John C. LaRosa, M.D., President Eugene B. Feigelson, M.D., Dean of the College of Medicine

title: Don't Put Sinatra on a Pedestal, Some Say
description: The Giuliani administration wants to put a statue of Frank Sinatra in the heart of Times Square with the help of the singer's family. But some people are complaining that community groups have not been consulted about the monument or its impact.

title: In Support of Safety On the Merritt Parkway
description: I am writing in support of the efforts of Dr. Barry Boyd to alleviate the dangerous situation arising out of the curve in the Merritt Parkway between the North Street and Lake Avenue Exits (''After Fatal Crash, Road Is Studied,'' Jan. 30).

title: The Old Factory May Be Gone, But the Softball Team Remains
description: YEARS before the UConn women's basketball team would make a name for itself, there were the Raybestos Brakettes, a female softball team named after the brake linings they manufactured at the East Main Street plant.

title: Passing the Regents
description: Ninety-two percent of high school seniors who are required to pass the English Regents Exam have taken and passed it as of the start of the school year, State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills announced on Monday. Four percent have taken the exam but not passed, and 4 percent have not taken it, he said.

title: OUTDOORS; The Ones That Got Away on Isla de Vieques
description: z

title: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
description: ON MY COUNTRY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEB, ALYCE E.
description: LIEB-Alyce E., 88. passed away peacefully February 1, 2000 after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Myron (Mac) Lieb and her daughter Ann Carol Mabuchi. She is also survived by her granddaughter Kayla Ritt Yamada, her great-daughter Chelsea Skye Yamada and her grandson Scott Brian Mabuchi. All remember the lovely Alyce and her delightful sense of humor. She will be greatly missed. Service Sunday, February 6, 11:30AM at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens, N.Y.

title: The Big Risk That Few Workers Protect Against
description: WAYNE GOEHRING ran a successful cabinet refinishing business until about two years ago, when he began noticing strange sensations in his feet and hands. Multiple sclerosis was soon diagnosed.

title: The Bigger The Better, Even in Lingerie
description: PERHAPS it was a slow news night in New York, but there was a ''Day of the Locust'' feel -- screaming and pushing paparazzi, press and hangers-on -- outside Industria Superstudio in Manhattan Tuesday evening for the Lane Bryant runway show of intimate apparel. A publicist muttered to me: ''Whoever thought they'd turn out like this to see the big gals.''

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; Addition for Montclair Art Museum
description: The Montclair Art Museum, its permanent collection having increased to more than 15,000 objects while annual attendance has climbed to six times that figure, will soon expand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISIG, JOSEPH E.
description: REISIG-Joseph E. It is with deep sorrow and affection that we record the passing January 28, 2000 of our devoted member and past president (1993) of The General Society of Mechanics & Tradesmen of The City of New York. For many years, Joseph served on various committees and taught in Mechanics Institute, The School, supported by The General Society. Joseph joined the Society in 1982. Sincere condolences are sent to his wife Winnie, son Richard, daughters Winnie and Janice, daughter-in-law Eileen and their families. The membership of the society will miss him.

title: Flying Blind in A Dangerous World
description: CONSIDER the following:

title: IN BRIEF; Northport Closes School Rifle Ranges
description: The last two school-based rifle ranges in Suffolk County were ordered permanently closed Monday night by a unanimous vote of the nine-member Northport school board.

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Expanded Ties With Taiwan
description: The House voted decisively to broaden military ties between Taiwan and the United States, a largely symbolic gesture that carries potentially damaging diplomatic consequences. China denounced the measure, saying it would increase the chance of war between Taiwan and the mainland. ERIC SCHMITT

title: Pushing Dance Until It Offers The Thrills of a Carnival Ride
description: SINCE the Brazilian choreographer Deborah Colker established her dance troupe in Rio de Janeiro in 1994, it has attracted enormous audiences. ''Sometimes I'm criticized for being too popular,'' she explained on a visit to Manhattan last November. ''But why else make dances, if not for everyone?'' Her sleek, 14-member Companhia de Danca Deborah Colker makes its North American debut at the Joyce Theater on Feb. 15 through 20 with the full-evening work ''Rota'' (''Route''), a hit in South America and Europe that has been seen by more than 200,000 people since 1997.

title: Not-So-Brave New World: Sci-Fi TV Runs Aground
description: WHEN television sprouted up in the living rooms of postwar America it must have seemed like a techno-wonder straight out of science fiction. In fact, television and science-fiction appeared to be a match made in the heavens -- an imaginative literary genre that had already excited the masses on radio (''War of the Worlds,'' anyone?) could now be melded with pictures to give audiences something truly new to think about. But for those expecting new horizons of literate entertainment and provocative visions of the future, sci-fi television has largely failed to live up to its promise.

title: The Stevenson Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Times For Restaurant Patrons
description: Hooray for Patricia Brooks's column ''Maybe It's Time for a Diners' Bill of Rights'' (Dining Out, Jan. 2). The article should be posted in every restaurant in bold type.

title: Another Book in 1928
description: To the Editor:

title: Winners Don't Yet Have the Final Answer
description: EVEN before the heady effects of sudden wealth -- like the $1.12 million won by a Harvard law student on NBC's ''Twenty One'' last week -- begin to dissipate, the mundane details of how to handle such sums always intrude.

title: Surfing for options before you sail
description: THERE is a virtual ocean of information for prospective voyagers these days, so if you're in the market for a cruise, you might want to surf a bit on the Web before you set sail. Browsers can find last-minute bargains, ships that match particular needs or fantasies, or reviews of ships and cruises from ordinary travelers and professional cruise critics. You may not even have to disconnect when you go aboard: more and more cruise ships are getting wired for Internet and e-mail capability.

title: The Portable High-School Hoops Factory
description: Wearing one of the nike warmup suits that seem to compose his entire wardrobe, a whistle hanging from his neck, Stu Vetter is watching what he calls his family -- a group of extremely athletic, abnormally tall teenage boys who make up the Montrose Christian School basketball team. It's a preseason practice, and Vetter has just introduced his team to the ''55 defense,'' a full-court zone press he wants to use in the coming months. Now, standing in a corner of the Rockville, Md., school's dingy gymnasium, he looks on as the second-stringers, playing on offense, continually beat his starters down the court for easy layups and dunks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, JOSEPHINE
description: RAYMOND-Josephine. February 4, 2000. Beloved wife of Dana. Loving mother of Catherine, Peter and John. Cherished grandmother of David, Nicholas, Anne, Jane, John, Kaila and Briana. Devoted sister of Gerard. Her spirit and energy will live on with us always. Memorial service Friday, February 11, 3 PM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St.

title: The French Have Landed, With Swimwear and Jewelry
description: Until last November, 436 West Broadway, between Spring and Prince Streets in SoHo, was one store: a women's clothing store called Lulu's. Three now have replaced it. Vilebrequin, which sells swimwear for men and boys in locations throughout France and on islands like St. Barthelemy and Mauritius, opened on Dec. 13. The chain has plans to open two more New York locations and expand in the United States and Europe. Vilebrequin means crankshaft in French (the original designer of the line, Fred Prysquel, worked as an auto mechanic until he came up with a swim trunk sketch in 1970). His suits, which are made with two holes for air circulation, quick-dry material and a waterproof pocket, come in plain colors or prints and cost $111 for men and $50 to $55 for boys.

title: Same-Day Voting For Libraries and Schools
description: The race is under way between school districts and libraries to pitch their wares to the voting public [''Library Voters vs. School Voters,'' Jan. 23], but it is hardly a fair race. Calling a universal voting day in May that covers both libraries and schools makes sense: It simplifies the process for voters and will help to level a very uneven playing field between unequally vested entities.

title: Vienna Riots Leave 50 Hurt As Protests Rise
description: Clashes overnight between the police and demonstrators left more than 50 people injured in Vienna today after a coalition government including members of the anti-immigration Freedom Party was sworn in.

title: A Tale of Vocal Courage
description: MARIAN ANDERSON'S most famous recital was sung into a microphone. It was only half an hour, outdoors on a cold Washington Easter in 1939, and the selections, including ''Ave Maria'' and ''America,'' were not showy or virtuosic.

title: The Grand Exit
description: How does it feel to tell the boss you're leaving? More and more workers are finding out, as the record-setting economic boom creates more jobs and job-hopping. Some people go with a laugh, some with a snarl, some with a dash of creativity. What has been your most memorable manner of leaving a job? Or the most striking voluntary departure you have witnessed? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBLANC, JOHN
description: LeBLANC-John of Voorhees, NJ formerly of NYC., husband of the late Ann (nee Mallon). Survived by Edward, Kenneth, Suzanne LeBlanc & Valerie LeBlanc he was father of the late Michael. Also 4 sisters & five grandchildren. Mass 10AM Monday St. Andrew the Apostle Church Gibbsboro, NJ. Viewing Sun eve Bradley Funeral Home, Route 73 & Evesham Rd. Marlton, NJ. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Donations to Scleroderma Research Foundation, 2320 Bath Street, Santa Barbara, CA 93105.

title: The Benefits of Strong Financial Backing
description: EVERYONE knows Kip Bedell makes good wines, especially merlot. Quality and sales have risen steadily since the early 1980's, when Bedell Cellars' first wines began to appear. For the usual reasons that govern technical, artistic and commercial progress, it has been reasonable to assume that his wines will keep getting better and better.

title: Texas Writer Wields a Chain Saw With Two-Party Politics as Victim
description: THE SETTING -- Among the art books at the Borders bookstore in the World Trade Center, Jim Hightower, author, Texas talk show host and former Texas agriculture commissioner, was standing at a lectern, a long arm's length to the left of a book titled ''Surrealism: The Dream of Revolution.''

title: Hudson River Ices In
description: There has been more ice on the Hudson River in recent weeks than environmentalists have seen in a decade.

title: INVESTING WITH: James B. Conheady; Concert Investment International Equity Fund
description: JAMES B. CONHEADY, lead manager of the $156.2 million Concert Investment International Equity fund, is fond of playing the odds on thoroughbreds at Belmont Park.

title: More Women, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: EgyptAir Pilot Seeking Asylum
description: An EgyptAir pilot claiming to have information about the crash of the airline's Flight 990 last year has requested asylum in Britain, EgyptAir officials said today.

title: Not All Violets Shrink From American Climates
description: IN England, where violets grow so willingly that gardeners can afford to be snooty about varieties, dog violets are about as welcome as curs at an American Kennel Club show.

title: Postings: Lamont-Doherty Observatory Addition; A New Home For Climate Prediction
description: Sitting on a promontory overlooking the Hudson River in Palisades, N.Y., a new academic building houses the International Research Institute for Climate Prediction. It is the latest addition to the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, the earth sciences division of Columbia University.

title: Understudies in Spotlight
description: When Eve Queler founded Opera Orchestra of New York 28 years ago, she consistently identified little-known singers and gave them a chance. Her 1979 concert performance helped put Donizetti's ''Lucrezia Borgia'' back onto the musical map after a half-century of neglect, and it is of her that the celebrated soprano Renee Fleming wrote: ''She has singlehandedly enabled me to continue singing this great repertoire.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, ROSE
description: GROSS-Rose. Wife of the late Abraham Gross. Cherished mother of Felicia and Isador Levitt. Adored Grandmother, greatgrandmother, sister, aunt.

title: Globalization: If You Can't Beat It, Reshape It
description: WITH security agents toting submachine guns, army helicopters buzzing overhead and protesters breaking windows in yet another McDonald's, Davos man, the elite agent of global capitalism, is under siege.

title: Grozny News: All Quiet on the Chechen Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Dana McAleer, Shane Wallace
description: Dana Ann McAleer, the daughter of Teresa A. McAleer and Robert T. McAleer of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., was married yesterday to Shane Michael Wallace, the son of Sheila Riley of New York and Ron Wallace of Yellville, Ark. The Rev. Dr. Richard M. Cromie, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The Bad Father
description: THE HOUSEGUEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HAROLD JOSEPH
description: MILLER-Harold Joseph. 76, of Mountain Lakes, NJ, died January 25, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth Jane Haggerty Miller. Father of Colleen Exter and Maureen Hallock. Grandfather of Emily Exter, Cody Exter, Katharine Hallock and James Hallock, Jr. Memorial services, Wednesday, February 9, 2000, at 2 PM in the Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, NY, NY, followed by a reception at the Church. Memorial donations to Columbia University, c/o The Harold J. Miller Memorial Account, Cardiology Division, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, 630 West 168th St., floor PH3, NY, NY 10032.

title: A Team Can Never Have Too Many Pitchers or a Payroll Too Low
description: In the course of dismantling the 1997 World Series champions, the Florida Marlins made 16 trades and acquired 33 players. Twenty-four of those players were pitchers. Dave Dombrowski, the Marlins' general manager, gobbled up pitchers as if they were becoming extinct.

title: Road Overkill, Also Known as Billboards
description: PEEVED, perhaps, at all the attention being lavished on those zillion-dollar Super Bowl commercials, the lowly billboard has been making all sorts of news lately. Attention-getting billboards urging tolerance for gay people appeared recently on Route 80 in Hackensack and Route 17 in Paramus. The Turnpike Authority got an earful of criticism with a plan to raise money by leasing sites for eight new billboards on the northern end of the highway, where there is already a forest of them on private land. And the Archdiocese of Newark drew widespread publicity with a billboard campaign aimed at getting people back into the confessional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, FLORENCE M.
description: BRILL-Florence M., on February 4, 2000, devoted wife for 56 years of the late Jerome; loving, proud and generous mother of Judy and Jerry, Arthur and Carol, and Connie and Jerry; doting grandmother of Irene, Robert, Jonathan, Paul, and Matthew; delighted greatgrandmother of Sophie; caring and affectionate aunt, friend and confidant. She loved and was loved by so many for nearly nine decades. An attorney, she lived a wonderful and bountiful life, brimmed full of education, artistic talent and, above all, family. Services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNSTINE, VERA
description: BURNSTINE-Vera. Beloved matriarch of Joanna, Deidre, Benjamin, Bethany, Peter, and Barbara, peacefully at Peter and Joanna's home, February 4, 2000. Services Sunday, February 6, at 12:15 PM, at the Temple Israel Chapel on Saw Mill River Road, Hastings-onHudson, NY. For directions call (212) 854-2370. In lieu of flowers, please make a gift to a favorite charity in her sweet memory.

title: Huntington Board Finds Ethics Violation
description: The Huntington Ethics Board found a Huntington Town Board member guilty of violating two provisions of the town's Code of Ethics. The violations stemmed from a relationship the member, Susan J. Scarpati-Reilly, had with a town employee.

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Illinois Halts Executions
description: In a decision hailed by opponents of the death penalty, Gov. George Ryan of Illinois ordered a halt to all executions in the state, the first such moratorium in the nation.

title: Amy Swartz, Michael Rosen
description: Amy Beth Swartz, a daughter of Judi Swartz and Steven Swartz of North Reading, Mass., was married last evening to Dr. Michael Eric Rosen, the son of Patty Rosen and Dr. Jay Rosen of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Loring J. Frank officiated at the Breakers hotel in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: TEST PATTERN

title: Where Tenants Find a Haven
description: In a city where finding and keeping an apartment can verge on the Kafkaesque, it may be comforting to know that a renter-friendly Web site appeared on the scene before there was even an Internet for it to call home. Tenant.net, which guides visitors through the complexities of renting in New York City, started as an electronic bulletin board in 1990 when John Fisher, a computer consultant, decided to use the wisdom he had gained as a renter in New York.

title: Michigan State Leaves UConn Doubting Itself
description: If the Connecticut Huskies were looking for a break from the rigors of Big East Conference basketball, they went to the wrong place today.

title: Losing a Muse and Moving On
description: THE first six films by the Chinese director Zhang Yimou had a strong structuring device in the stunning form of Gong Li, China's best-known actress. From their debut feature, ''Red Sorghum'' (1988), through the international hits ''Ju Dou'' (1990) and ''Raise the Red Lantern'' (1991), to ''The Story of Qiu Jiu'' (1992) and ''To Live'' (1994), Mr. Zhang was involved personally and professionally with Ms. Gong. But during the production of ''Shanghai Triad'' (1995), she terminated the relationship, and, within a year, married a wealthy Singaporean businessman. Filmmaker and performer have not collaborated since.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Bob Love Story

title: Tales of Intrigue for a Museum of Unnatural History
description: THE exhibitions that chronicle the activities of the Royal Excavation Corps, a shadowy organization formed by demobilized officers in the years following World War I and involved in everything from intelligence gathering to archaeology to parapsychology, constitute a compelling if little known slice of history. Among the expeditions the corps scrupulously recorded in panoramic photographs and firsthand accounts were an attempted trans-Atlantic flight that ended in disaster and a secret mission to Siberia in the closing months of the war.

title: Casey Loses Patience With Kittles
description: Don Casey dropped hints during the Nets' recent West Coast road trip about how exasperated he was with the slumping play of Kerry Kittles. In two games, Casey benched his starting shooting guard for entire fourth quarters and included him in a rant in which he challenged the Nets' top players to produce more.

title: Hairdresser For a Day
description: WHEN I was a girl my mother used to warn, ''If you don't study and get good grades, you'll wind up in beauty school.'' I did study hard and graduated from an Ivy League college, followed by an M.A. in art history. But last summer I found myself bent over a black sink, a nozzle in one hand and a bottle of shampoo in the other, washing a socialite's hair.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORMAN, ETHEL
description: GORMAN-Ethel. February 6, 1990. We think of you and laugh with you every day. Love, Linda, Doug, Abby & Richard

title: Going by freighter: a cruise of one's own
description: Lavish entertainment, dancing and gambling, a different tropical island every day: it's not for everyone. Those with simpler tastes (and plenty of time) can cruise the Caribbean at a leisurely pace and almost alone. Two freighters that offer regular service in the Caribbean visit four ports on three islands in about 21 days. They are the Zim Mexico III and the Zim Caribe IV, operated by Rickmers Reederei and represented in the United States by Freighter World Cruises of Pasadena, Calif.

title: Reckonings; Advice and Dissent
description: The chief economic adviser of one candidate is the co-author of an exuberant book claiming that investors ain't seen nothing yet; unfortunately, the exuberance is a bit, well, irrational. The chief adviser of the other is a pessimist, deeply skeptical about the durability of our current prosperity. One candidate proposes huge tax cuts that will break the budget unless the long boom not only continues but accelerates. The other prefers not to count his fiscal chickens before they hatch. Which is which?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADRIAN, BERTA
description: BADRIAN-Berta. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Berta Badrian beloved mother of our devoted members Doris and Marvin Schechter, grandmother of members Dena and Scott Magram, great grandmother of Day School student Teddy. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: BEST SELLERS: February 6, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Another Italian, but Worth the Short List
description: DOES Long Island need another Italian restaurant? The answer is yes if it is Bocca Di Rosa. This new Great Neck storefront says welcome with its creamy walls, original oil paintings, comfortable dark wood chairs and tables covered in cloth and crowned with a single rose.

title: A View That Needs No Windows
description: LIKE Bill Gates and Michael Dell, Larry Augustin spent his spare time in college toying with computers and wound up starting a company that made him a zillionaire. But unlike them, Mr. Augustin earned a college degree, at Notre Dame, and later a doctorate, at Stanford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKHARD, RICHARD
description: BECKHARD - Richard. Beloved people-developer, dies at 81, on December 28, 1999. Pioneer and innovator in field of Orgnization Development. Consultant world wide to senior executives in managing complex change. Assisted organizations and individuals to function in a more humane, high performing and socially responsible manner. Sailor, learner, author, master teacher includg MIT Sloan School, mentor, and stage manager on Broadway. Lived in NYC and Center Lovell, ME. Survived by wife Sandra Barty and sister Barbara MacNeill. Celebration of Life on Sunday, February 13, 3 P.M., at Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street, New YorkY City.

title: Online Revolution's Latest Twist: Job Interviews With a Computer
description: With a pick comb in his hair and his shirt untucked, Roland Martin wandered into the Good Guys electronics store this afternoon and immediately secured a 30-minute employment interview. Not only did the store disregard his appearance, it welcomed his impulsive job hunt. Besides, the interviewer could not see him.

title: If You Slip and Fall, You're Out of Luck
description: Most accidents, they say, happen close to home. Not close enough, if you ask the school administrators, employers and insurance agents who in times of snow would have people stay there.

title: Rutgers Comes Up Short in Several Categories, Including the Score
description: It was a game of ifs for Rutgers against the University of Miami at the Louis Brown Athletic Center this afternoon.

title: Tracking More Sectors
description: Last week, Merrill Lynch introduced two versions of one of its hottest investment products -- Holdr's (pronounced ''holders''), securities that track specific industry sectors.

title: Looks Like a Diner, but Don't Call It One
description: QUESTION: when is a diner not a diner? Answer: when it's the Crazy Dog in Westhampton Beach. No wonder its owners don't want their restaurant to be called a diner any more. Yes, that's what it looks like from outside. In fact, come to think of it, the inside of this gleaming l950's Art Deco spot seems like the Mercedes of diners. But how many diners have a heralded Johnson and Wales-trained chef in the kitchen, a Wine Spectator award on the wall and a rose on every table? How many diners have etched-glass partitions separating their booths, white linen-covered tables and their own pastry chef (the chef and co-owner Eric Rifkin's wife, Nicole)? And how many diners charge $20 or more for all but 4 of their 18 a la carte evening entrees?

title: Would Black Dots Make a Difference?
description: I am writing in support of the efforts of Dr. Barry Boyd to alleviate the dangerous situation arising out of the curve in the Merritt Parkway between the North Street and Lake Avenue Exits (''After Fatal Crash, New Look at an Old Road,'' Jan. 30).

title: St. Thomas
description: St. Thomas is feeling good these days, perked up by millions invested in hotel and museum restorations and a steady flow of cruise ship visitors spending their money on the island, one of the Caribbean's most popular shopping spots.

title: N.C.A.A.'s New Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article Jan. 23 on the unusual number of left-handed candidates running for president incorrectly included Bill Bradley. He is right-handed.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Making Connections

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOHAI, RUDY
description: YOHAI-Rudy, 70, of Chicago, IL and Naples, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of Joyce, loving father of Janine (Mark) Juster and Dr. Robert Yohai of Santa Rosa, CA. Grandfather of Michael, Nicholas and Benjamin Juster. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the ALS Research Foundation, 1150 NW 14 St, #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, THOMAS J.
description: O'CONNELL-Thomas J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas J. O'Connell, associated with The Times from 1950 until retiring in 1991.

title: Hempstead Voting Changes to Churn Town
description: NASSAU'S Republican and Democratic leaders are already gearing up for what promises to be the mother of all town political campaigns on Long Island, although they do not know yet exactly when this year the election will be. In fact, they are even fighting over the timing of the election, a dispute that a federal judge is expected to decide soon.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00: Questions for Yo La Tengo; Band Mates
description: Q: Which collaboration came first -- the relationship or the band?

title: In Manhattan, a New View of the Firmament
description: Visitors to Manhattan, earthbound since the old-fashioned but beloved Hayden Planetarium closed in 1997, will once again be able to scan the galaxies beginning this month. The $210 million Frederick Phineas and Sandra Priest Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History in New York opens two major spaces on Feb. 19: The new Hayden Planetarium and the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Hall of the Universe. The center's third hall, the David S. and Ruth L. Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth, opened in June.

title: At New Diner Incarnations, Latte Replaces Two-Bit Java
description: At Relish, a gleaming silver diner on Wythe Street, white plastic letters in glass panels spell out a list of standards. Sliced egg, ''bologny'' or liverwurst sandwiches are $1.85. Tapioca pudding is $1.50; American cheese omelet, $1.25.

title: Methods of the Great Leader
description: Mao

title: 'New Soul,' Maybe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIPPER, BETTE JAYNE
description: SHIPPER-Bette Jayne. Of Woodmere, NY. Beloved wife of Justin. Devoted mother of Faith Moskowitz, and Randy Shipper. Loving grandmother of Seth, Andrew, Alexandra and Eric. Services Sunday, 11 AM, at the Beth Israel Chapel, Woodbridge, NJ. For information ''Wein & Wein,'' 1-800-378-1892.

title: Australia Highlights Aboriginal Tourism
description: MORE than a half-century ago the Australian Unesco Committee for Museums put together a traveling exhibition of the country's Aboriginal culture, which toured the United States and Canada. The accompanying catalog extolled the rich heritage of the Aborigines, the indigenous people who came to Australia more than 30,000 years ago, and it concluded with the hope that the exhibit would ''engender a curiosity about Aboriginal life.''

title: We Can Engineer Nature. But Should We?
description: JUST as 130 nations were meeting in Montreal recently to forge the first global treaty regulating genetically modified crops, Frito-Lay Inc. was telling its farmers in the United States not to grow genetically engineered corn for use in Doritos chips and other snacks. The problem, the company said, was not a risk to health from the corn but a risk that consumers wouldn't want it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROER, EDWIN M.
description: ROER-Edwin M. Died on February 5. Funeral arrangements not yet completed. Please call Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Ave, 212-769-4400, for specifics. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Sloan-Kettering Institute at Memorial Hospital.

title: When Officials Ignore The Island's Bus Needs
description: For many years I have commuted to New York using the bus to and from the Great Neck train station, and I have often experienced the frustration of seeing my bus disappear down the block as I emerged from my slightly tardy train. The mile and a half walk home gave me plenty of time to fume.

title: A NEW BIG BOX
description: The trademark brick facade of Wisconsin-based Kohl's Department Stores is becoming increasingly familiar to New Jersey shoppers. Kohl's, based in Wisconsin, is planning to open 11 more stores in New Jersey on March 10, in addition to the six that opened in the past year in Cherry Hill, Marlton, May's Landing, Turnersville, Princeton and West Hampton The new stores will open in Paramus, West Paterson, Morris Plains, Ridgewood, Secaucus, Watchung, South Plainfield, Holmdel, Marlboro, Brick and Toms River.

title: Playing With Fire
description: At Rutgers, the deafening sound of fire alarms was almost commonplace. In fact, some residence halls were being evacuated as many as three times a week during the 1997-1998 school year.

title: Cabaret: Allowing The Actors To Expand
description: FROM the back streets of Montmartre in 1881, where the intellectual avant-garde and the artlessly trashy converged after dark, to the ever darkening spread of decadent night life in Berlin in the early 1900's, the evolution of cabaret as an alternative entertainment form has encompassed sleaze, sophistication and numerous, complex and subtle periods of transition.

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; A Computer in Every Pot
description: The latest employee perk at the Ford Motor Company and Delta Air Lines has nothing to do with cars or airplanes. Ford said each of its 350,000 employees worldwide, from factory workers to executives, would be offered a powerful home computer, a color printer and unlimited Internet access for just $5 a month. Delta Air Lines announced a similar but less subsidized program for its nearly 80,000 employees, charging them up to $12 a month.

title: India Tries to Plug a Cash Drain: Its Power System
description: Throughout India, billions of dollars worth of electricity is stolen each year by consumers in league with utility workers, bureaucrats and politicians, according to the nation's ministry of power. Line workers are bribed. Meters are fixed.

title: Museum Vignettes Revive Fashions From the 1890's
description: DRESSING mannequins for the current exhibition at the Hudson River Museum here gave Lidia Fouto and Kathy Craughwell-Varda a palpable sense of the past. They served as museum consultants for ''Dressing for a Victorian Day,'' a display of vignettes featuring antique fashions, which can be seen through June 4.

title: Myth: It's Not You, It's the Other Guy
description: So the snow and the sleet and the glop are pelting your car or van as it inches painfully along the New Jersey Turnpike, or maybe Interstate 78, staying a safe distance from the car in front of you. All of sudden -- AARGHH! -- in your rear view mirror you see it coming up, another vehicle, moving through the slush and and gunk like a hot knife through butter on a June day.

title: East End Heat in '99 Speeds LIPA's Plans
description: WITH the Long Island Power Authority's settlement of its tax dispute over the Shoreham nuclear power plant, it can now focus on a battle of another kind: convincing the state Public Service Commission that a 22.5-mile power line is needed on the East End by summer to avoid blackouts.

title: Where Have All the Teddy Bears Gone?
description: In the last 15 years, the St. Moritz Hotel, with its picture postcard views of Central Park South, has changed hands more often than a struggling sports franchise.

title: Thomas Leonard, Victoria Plummer
description: Victoria Lynne Plummer and Thomas Nelson Leonard were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George Koury in a nondenominational ceremony at a private club in New York.

title: Crude Oil Prices Cause Air Fare Surcharges
description: Crude oil prices have soared, and air passengers are paying for it. All of the major domestic airlines are imposing a fuel surcharge on domestic tickets. The charge is $10 on one-way tickets and $20 on round trips, except for Alaska Airlines, a mostly short-haul carrier on the West Coast that is charging half as much, and US Airways, which is limiting the surcharge to advance-purchase fares.

title: Corrections
description: The A La Carte column last Sunday misspelled the names of two Great Neck restaurants that have opened recently. One is Bocca Di Rosa, not Bocca D. Rosa; the other is Darvish, not Darbish.

title: Postings: 43rd Annual Trade Show; Seminars on Co-op Life
description: An opportunity for co-op board members and shareholders to have their legal questions answered free -- if you don't count the entrance fee -- will be offered today at the 43rd annual Trade Show and Seminars sponsored by the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives.

title: . . . And Let's Ban Sport Utilities in Midtown
description: To the Editor:

title: Love Potions and Other Notions
description: Little Things For the Big Night: For women wondering how to wear the latest low-slung pants without flashing the tops of their thong underwear, lingerie makers are coming up with microversions. In an informal test, a reporter crouched in a pair of waistless hip-huggers from Intermix. The least visible styles were a minuscule rosebud thong by Shoshanna ($35 at www.girlshop .com); Deborah Marquit's lacy thong ($65 at Barneys New York); Cherry Pie's pink-and-white cotton thong ($18 at Henri Bendel); and for discreet logo wearing, Gucci's ''G'' mesh thongs ($105 in black and white at Gucci stores).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BACHMANN, LOUIS, JR.
description: BACHMANN-Louis, Jr. Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health will hold a memorial service to mark the passing last month of generous long-time benefactor Louis Bachmann, Jr., whose philanthropy to Mount Sinai included joining his daughter Bonnie Strauss, and son-in-law Thomas W. Strauss, our esteemed Trustee, in the naming and endowment of the Bachmann-Strauss Professorship in Neurology for the study of dystonia. Along with his daughter he also was instrumental in the establishment of The Bachmann-Strauss Dystonia & Parkinson Foundation which provides major support for the Movement Disorders Program at Mount Sinai. Trustees, faculty, staff, students, family, friends and admirers are invited to attend at 4:00 PM, Friday, February 11, in the Goldwurm Auditorium, East Building, 1425 Madison Avenue at 98th Street.

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Good News Continues For the Booming Economy
description: The economic expansion became the longest on record at 107 months, surpassing the 1960's boom. As if to emphasize the point, unemployment dropped again, to 4 percent.

title: State House Journal; A Kaleidoscopic Look at Attitudes on Gay Marriage
description: Imagine, nearly four hours of State House testimony late into the night and not a moment of tedium, not a single slide into the low-level murmur that means the chamber's attention has drifted, not a seat or a spot on a railing left vacant.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 6, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN BOKKELEN, SALLY
description: VAN BOKKELEN-Sally. 77, on February 3, 2000 in Bradenton, FL, formerly of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, NY, and Remsenburg, L.I., NY. Survived by her sister Virginia of Bradenton and brother Libertus of Nevada. Memorial donations may be sent to St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31 St., NYC, NY 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, MARJORIE
description: MELTZER-Marjorie. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company Continuum Health Partners, Inc. and with the physicians and staff of the Nathaniel Meltzer MD Division of Chemical Dependency in acknowledging with sadness the passing of a true friend of our institution Marjorie Melzter. Ms. Meltzer's extraordinary support of chemical dependency services, was recognized with the naming of the division in honor of her beloved late husband who served its patients with great distinction for over 16 years. In addition, Ms. Meltzer exemplified philanthropic leadership through generous contributions to cardiac research and other patient care services. She will be greatly missed by all whose lives were touched by her personal warmth and commitment to help those less fortunate. To her family and all who loved her, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Boards of Trustees, Continuum and BIMC Robert G. Newman, MD, President and CEO Continuum Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO, BIMC Henry Singman, MD, President Medical Board, BIMC Stanley R. Yankcovitz, MD, Chief Nathaniel Melzter MD Division of Chemical Dependency Steven F. Horowitz, MD Chief of Thomas Killip MD Division of Cardiology

title: Doping's Sad Toll: One Athlete's Tale From East Germany
description: In 1972, a committee from the swimming federation in the East German town of Halberstadt went to the local primary school looking for children who wanted to take part in a swimming program. Six-year-old Martina Fehrecke loved to play in the water, so she raised her hand.

title: This Blessed Plot
description: ACROSS THE OPEN FIELD Essays Drawn From English Landscapes. By Laurie Olin. Illustrated. 352 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. $42.50.

title: A Day To Recall Arlen's Classics
description: NEXT Sunday, at 4 p.m. in the Unitarian Church of Westport, the clarinetist Ken Peplowski will recall some of the classic songs of Harold Arlen, in company with the singer Dena DeRose, the pianist Ted Rosenthal and the bassist Jay Leonhardt. Eileen Wiseman, executive director of the sponsoring organization (the Westport Arts Center), said ''Peplowski's great talents and those of the fine musicians he brings along, have made him a perennial favorite (203-222-7070).

title: MacInnis Is the Fastest Shot
description: In the skills competition, Al MacInnis -- who just returned to action after missing five games with a collapsed lung -- delivered the fastest shot for the sixth time, and for the fourth consecutive All-Star Game. MacInnis, a St. Louis Blues defenseman, edged Philadelphia's John LeClair, 100.1 miles an hour to 100.0 m.p.h.

title: Opinion; A Town's Awkward Silence
description: WHEN the Moxleys of Greenwich could no longer abide living across the street from a young man they suspected of murdering their daughter, they sold their house to an actor named Jon Lee.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title:
Paid Notice: Deaths
PAYNE, HALBERT E.
description: PAYNE-Halbert E. Of Greenwich, CT, on February 2, at age 75 of complications from Progressive Supranuclear Palsy. Choate Class of '42. Pilot 47th Bombardment Group WWII. Cornell Class of '48. Former marketing executive. Hal leaves his wife, Kathryn Madden Payne, their daughter Martha M. of Boston, MA and four children from a previous marriage, Oliver E. of Kennebunk, ME, Elizabeth P. Johnson of Greenwich, Walter T. of Scarsdale, NY, Donald E. of Huntington, NY and six grandchildren, Hannah, Riley, Dylan, Logan, Madeleine, and Ethan. Donations to Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy, Greene Tree Rd. Baltimore, MD, 21208. Memorial service to be held in the spring.

title: INSIDE
description: More Kosovo Unrest

title: Elias's Pleasant Surprise
description: Not so long ago, there was no way Patrik Elias thought he would be named to his first All-Star Game this season. Not after a contract dispute with the Devils led to his giving in to the team's demands. Not after the start Elias had after he finally signed.

title: A Better D.H. Idea
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Streetscapes/The 1906 Home Club Co-op, at 11 East 45th Street; A Remnant of a Midtown Full of Homes, Not Offices
description: THERE was no place like home -- that is, like Pliny Fisk's 1906 Home Club, a luxurious nine-story co-op at 11 East 45th Street, built for only six families. But since it was converted to an office building in 1921, its refined Florentine-style facade has been only a tantalizing reminder of the days when Midtown was a place to live, not work. Now shrouded in black demolition netting for a new office building, Fisk's remarkable structure will soon disappear.

title: Back Home, Tough Path For an Entrepreneur
description: MASSATA THIOUNE left Senegal for New York in 1986 with just $250 in his pocket. He had no Western education and spoke no English. But he knew how to sew clothes; he had been apprenticed to his father, a tailor, from the age of 6. He was also imbued with the credo of the Sufi Islamic brotherhood to which his family belongs: ''Pray as if you will die tomorrow, and work as if you will live forever.''

title: What No School Can Do
description: According to James Traub (Jan. 16), the daily experience of failure in ghetto families and neighborhoods overwhelms the effects of even the best schools. He calls for more comprehensive preschool programs, but admits these would not transform the inner-city environment, which is the root of the problem. Such transformation would require jobs programs, housing, health care and a ''living wage'' -- proposals currently on ''the fringes of political discourse.''

title: Forget the Kid. The Real Custody Fight Is Over an Island.
description: WHILE they have yet to appear in one of those pop-psych quizzes that offer instant analyses of your home life, here are two questions to see if your family problems have gone from domestic dispute to full-blown dysfunction:

title: St. John's Wins Minus Barkley, And Jarvis Fumes
description: St. John's difficult season took a strange turn yesterday when the Red Storm outlasted Boston College, 59-58, without its star guard Erick Barkley, who was declared ineligible by the university after the National Collegiate Athletic Association said he had violated one of its regulations.

title: A Gritty Portrayal Of Police Life Gets A Kind of Closure
description: FOR seven years, ''Homicide: Life on the Street'' struggled to survive. The ensemble show about homicide detectives in Baltimore had few car chases or shootouts. There was little of the sexual drama of the far more successful ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' And the show's time slot, Friday night at 10, was hardly choice.

title: Noted: An Absence Of Bikers' Helmets
description: As the father of two sons who enjoy BMX and trail biking, I applaud the efforts of Monica Shay and the town of Woodbury in creating a facility for youth biking with private funds and donations (''Bikers Leap Into the Heart of Woodbury,'' Jan. 2).

title: Singing in the Buff: The Pure Beefcake Video
description: ON a recent sub-Arctic Tuesday night, an army of bundled-up New Yorkers filled the Chelsea nightclub Centro-Fly for a party celebrating the long-awaited release of D'Angelo's album ''Voodoo.'' The club was packed and sweaty, with decor and soul music out of a 1970's time warp: multiple video screens playing images of Curtis Mayfield and vintage ''Soul Train'' episodes, replete with dancers in Day-Glo bell-bottoms.

title: Mrs. Clinton Vows Fight on Issues and Image
description: Moving to steady a candidacy that she acknowledges has stirred concern about her political skills and spirit, Hillary Rodham Clinton says she is now prepared to press an aggressive campaign against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the race for United States Senate, drawing distinctions on issues ranging from school vouchers to tax cuts, and arguing that Senate Republicans ''don't need any more votes'' in Washington.

title: When Battling Candidates Agree
description: The intense battle among George W. Bush, John McCain, Al Gore and Bill Bradley for their parties' nominations has brought with it a striking thematic development. Despite their claimed ideological differences, the candidates are often quite close together in endorsing the need for improvements in education, health care and programs for the poor. Although Mr. Bush's tax cut proposal has an anti-government tinge to it, the candidates have defined an unacknowledged consensus over the desirability of a strong federal role in critical areas of domestic policy. Clearly, they are responding to signals from the voters about governing from what the pollster Mark Penn and others call the ''vital center.''

title: The Revolutionary War, Through Different Eyes
description: 'The Revolutionary War'

title: Corrections
description: An article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about increased popularity of town houses, and the caption for a rendering with it, misstated the location of the Carriage Gate complex. It is in Raritan Township, not Readington Township.

title: The Other Maestro
description: To the Editor:

title: Spring Street As Winter Refuge
description: AQUAGRILL **

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Habitats column last Sunday, about the hunt by four bachelors for an apartment to share, misidentified the bedroom shown with an air mattress on the floor. It belonged to Scott Siverling, not Jason Metoxen.

title: The Unequal Glow Of Liberty's Lamp
description: GLENDY SAGASTUME, who is 13, will not spend Valentine's Day dreaming of hearts and flowers or the cute boys at her school in Far Rockaway, Queens. Glendy and her mother, refugees from the long nightmare in El Salvador, will mark the day with an asylum hearing in their quest to stay together in this country after years apart.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LINCOLN

title: Interest on Security, Less a Fee
description: Q. I have received a formal notice from a bank saying that I received $33.45 in interest on my security deposit. The notice also indicates that $16.13 of that amount was being deducted by the bank as an ''agent administration fee.'' What right does my landlord have to give any part of my interest to others? May I insist that the full amount of the interest be paid to me? . . . Richard Ferris, Manhattan.

title: Esther Levy and Garth Symonds
description: Esther Levy, the daughter of Mollie and Albert Levy of Clearwater, Fla., is to be married this evening to Garth Justin Symonds, the son of Lady Fairfax of Sydney, Australia, and the late Cedric R. Symonds. Rabbi Jacob J. Schacter will perform the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Absolut Zero
description: IN SIBERIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREDITH, MORLEY
description: MEREDITH-Morley. Age 77, Metropolitan Opera baritone for over 30 years, formerly of Scarsdale, NY died of cancer at Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center (Florida) on February 3, 2000. Born in Winnipeg, Canada, graduated from University of Manitoba before serving in the Canadian Navy. Preceded in death by Erlene, his wife of 48 years. Survived by his sister, Cecille Feldman, and her husband, Herman, of Minneapolis, MN, his aunt, and many loving nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Burial private. Memorial service at a later date.

title: Q & A
description: Vienna Performances

title: New Season's Start Finds Stephen Got Even in Gear
description: In the first race of the season for senior handicap horses, Stephen Got Even got even for three losing efforts in last year's punishing Triple Crown series when he outran Golden Missile and Behrens in the Donn Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; $183 Billion Wireless Deal
description: In a huge wireless communications merger, Vodafone AirTouch of Britain agreed to acquire Mannesmann of Germany. The deal was remarkable not just for its size -- at $183 billion, it's the largest ever, surpassing even the recent $165 billion AOL-Time Warner deal -- but as proof that hard-nosed takeover tactics have migrated far beyond Wall Street. It also shows vividly the cross-border thinking that has taken hold in corporate Europe. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, JEROME
description: LEVENSON-Jerome. 75. Beloved husband of Lillian, loving stepfather of Julie, caring father-in-law of Joshua, devoted and proud grandfather of Gideon and Daniel, and loving brother of Herbert. An honest and valiant heart and a member of ''the greatest generation.'' His generosity and his sense of humor will be missed. Services will be held today at The Riverside, Mt. Vernon, 1:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ROBERT
description: LEVINE-Robert, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died February 2, 2000. Retired printer, Marine Purple Heart recipient, Battle of Iwo Jima. Survived by wife Shirley, sister Esther, son Stephen, daughter Sheila and children Annettte, Robert and Sheryl. Grandchildren Shari, David, Dan, Jeffrey, Lauren, Alyssa and Corey. Great grandchildren Tyler and Samantha.

title: A Crucial Election in Iran
description: For nearly three years, reform-minded political leaders allied with President Mohammed Khatami have been challenging the power of Iran's clerical conservative establishment. The election of a new Parliament this month could prove a pivotal event in that long-running struggle. A strong reform majority could push for structural changes that would shift power over Iran's leading institutions from the clerics to the elected political leadership. Such changes would start transforming Iran from a clerical dictatorship to an electoral democracy and greatly improve chances for better relations between Washington and Tehran.

title: Have Health Care Funds Become Too Fashionable?
description: THE boom-and-bust cycle of biotechnology stocks has definitely been in a boom phase, and health care mutual funds -- some of which are chock full of the stuff -- have turned in sweet returns this year in an otherwise sour market.

title: A Mortician's Confessions In Shades of Boozy Gray
description: THE face is pale and pouchy, the mustache threadbare, the body pudgy and hunched, the clothing mostly black. Is this an upended turtle glumly trudging about on its rear legs, or a bloated walrus ill at ease on land, or an aphasic hippo, or a great beetle afraid it may fall onto its back and stay there? No, it is the actor Brian Cox, his every fissure suggesting what he is supposed to be: a mortician, an alcoholic and a man so out of love with life that you feel he would willingly follow his latest client down below the sod.

title: Science Lessons Change With Standards
description: WITH goggles on their faces and pencils poised above lab sheets, the sixth graders in Alan Cass's classroom at the Seely Place Elementary School here gathered around the rug, staring at a small clear plastic film container. It was filled with water and a dissolvable antacid tablet as part of an experiment designed to demonstrate how pressure propels rockets. Except it just sat there, on the simulated launch pad. A dud.

title: Police Retirements Stir Budget Pot in Nassau
description: FEARING what Nassau County's budget crisis might mean for their jobs and their pensions, 60 members of the Nassau County Police Department have already put in for retirement this year, a significant increase from the 35 officers who retired in all of 1999.

title: Artists Help Music School Celebrate 70th Year
description: SEVENTY years is a long time to be doing the right thing, so the Music Conservatory of Westchester is certainly entitled to give itself a blowout birthday party. Next Sunday at 3 p.m., an All-Star Salute will bring an extraordinary array of artists to Purchase College, among them the violinist Ani Kavafian, a member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Insurance and Profiles
description: To the Editor:

title: Ustad Alla Rakha, 80, Master Of Hindustani Classical Music
description: Ustad Alla Rakha, the most important tabla drummer of his generation, died Thursday at his home in Bombay. He was 80.

title: The Extraordinary Thrill of Watching Ordinary Winners
description: IF ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' has done anything to enrich my life, it's this: I no longer have to feel immodest about telling people I attended a high school for academically gifted students. No after two of my fellow alumni have a grand total of $1,000 to show for their appearances in Regis Philbin's hot seat in the last few weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINDIENST, RICHARD G.
description: KLEINDIENST-Richard G. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our good friend and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Margaret and his children. Laurence W. Levine Jay H. Levine

title: Novel First, Plot Later
description: TULA STATION

title: First, Commit No Crime
description: A NEW YORK City obstetrician lost his license last week for carving his initials into the belly of a patient after he delivered her first child.

title: As Ye Profit, So Shall Ye Pay
description: As the number of Americans who own stock has reached record levels, capital gains have grown as a share of all income, but dividends have not. The results show tax policy at work.

title: Further Opportunity For Education
description: The account of land trusts in Connecticut describes noble but sometimes flawed activities. Over the years the land trusts will change leaders; they may stop monitoring property lines or give land over for other uses such as soccer fields, or even try biological experiments in land management.

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Diallo Jury Is Chosen
description: A jury of four blacks and eight whites was chosen to decide the fate of four New York City police officers

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CAPITALISM RUSSIAN-STYLE

title: A Brush With the Law Increasingly Ends With a Night in Jail
description: After stewing for 24 hours in crowded holding cells, Robert Schenck found himself in a drab first-floor courtroom of the Manhattan Criminal Courts building one night last month, exhausted, confused and charged with trespassing in a Washington Heights apartment building.

title: Laced With Fun
description: Calling forth spirts and styles from the past.

title: Habitats/Broadway Near 125th Street; Finding a Roommate Using a Bus-Stop Note
description: THEY'RE all over Manhattan, taped to bus shelters, tacked to bulletin boards in Laundromats, their multiple telephone numbers hanging from the bottom like so many paper legs, trying to make matches in a city of millions. ''Wanted: Nanny for adorable child'' or ''Nonsmoking neat male needed'' or ''Moving sale: Everything must go.''

title: Dungy Makes Necessary Call
description: Tampa Bay Coach Tony Dungy should have enjoyed the sun and fun of Hawaii this past week at the Pro Bowl. Instead, he agonized over his decision to fire Mike Shula, his offensive coordinator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAIBORNE, CRAIG
description: CLAIBORNE-Craig. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Craig Claiborne, associated with The Times from 1957 until retiring in 1988.

title: What No School Can Do
description: The ''social capital'' necessary to provide children with community bonds hardly exists, according to Traub, in black communities. The implication is that there are no community bonds in black families, no traditions, no heroes, nothing significant to add to the human, much less the American, experience. That this article appeared on the weekend that we celebrate the achievements of Martin Luther King Jr. is, perhaps, a commentary on how far we have yet to go to reach his dream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, JOHN FRANCIS
description: HOGAN-John Francis. On February 4, 2000, at age 89. Oakwood School 1928, Fordham Class 1936, WWII Captain in Army of the United States, and past Commander Ad Men's Post #

title: Drama in Nature: Burning Oil Fields, Cascading Water
description: THE Conceptual artist Les Levine has long waged a campaign against group shows. His slogan is ''group shows distort the group,'' meaning that the designated theme of a group show forces the art in it to conform. Individual statements get separated from their original intentions. While Mr. Levine's attitude is jarringly hard-nosed, he has a point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINN, RONNIE
description: LINN-Ronnie. Congregation Beth Shalom records the passing of our esteemed member Ronnie Linn. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President

title: Wall Sculpture Celebrates Diversity and Rewards Patience
description: With traffic detours and nighttime jackhammer work, projects like the planned rebuilding of three miles of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway always unnerve communities. So the State Department of Transportation has decided to bestow on Jackson Heights, Woodside and Astoria, the neighborhoods that surround this work, a huge $1 million roadside sculpture that many consider a first for the city and perhaps for the state.

title: Taking Movement to Its Outer Limits
description: YOU'VE probably heard that you can't put your elbow in your ear. Well, don't tell it to H Art Chaos, an all-female dance group from Japan. A seeming hybrid of Pilobolus and Gumby, these 11 hyperlimber women have complete disregard for the laws of physical possibility: they hang from their heels, pirouette at whiplash speed, writhe convulsively on the floor, launch themselves violently into the air and occasionally fly around the stage carrying chairs and sometimes one another.

title: In an Outcast's Story, Defiance of Iran's Mullahs
description: But for his battered brown brogues, Hossain Khorram might never have told his story. But there was something in the overstretched, heavily scuffed leather of his shoes, and the back seams held together with string, that suggested that the heavyset Mr. Khorram, quietly sipping tea in an artists' workshop in old Tehran, was harshly down on his luck.

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Primary Gazing in Moscow
description: Americans weren't the only ones watching the New Hampshire primary closely. The Russian leadership, it turns out, was focusing on it just as closely as the State Department tracks the vagaries of Russian electoral politics these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATSUSHIMA, ANNE, MD.
description: MATSUSHIMA-Anne, MD. Thirtysix, passed away on Thursday January 20, 2000 in Minneapolis. She worked as a physician at the Presbyterian Hospital of Columbia University, New York, from 1989-1998, and thereafter at the University of Minnesota Medical Center. Her husband Matthias J. Szabolcs, mother Reiko Matsushima, and brother Peter Matsushima mourn her death with deep sadness. A memorial service will be held Thursday, Feb. 10 at 3 P.M. at the Columbarium of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine at 110 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made in her memory to this church.

title: When Officials Ignore The Island's Bus Needs
description: Nassau County officials are about to sell our future short again, this time by collapsing public bus service. Halving the annual county subsidy will eliminate north-south bus service for Levittown, Bellmore, Massapequa, Bethpage and Plainview, disconnecting them from the Hicksville hub. This will exacerbate traffic congestion, isolate people without ready car transportation and eliminate environmentally progressive transport. Thirty thousand weekly riders and our quality of life will be forced to take a hike.

title: Don't Forget Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00; Incompetence Is Bliss
description: Eighteen years ago, I worked as a researcher on a psychiatric ward. One of the central diagnostic indices used to determine the severity of patients' illnesses was to assess their ''insight.'' Did they understand how and the degree to which they were not well? They usually did not. But over the course of their treatment, the cure was frequently more painful than the affliction, never more so than when patients first became aware of their past behavior, their dementia-fueled outbursts against loved ones, staff and themselves. They now found themselves stranded in a no-man's land between delusion and clarity -- often sad, occasionally humorous. One psychiatrist picked up the phone one day to a panicked, unidentified voice warning of an impending attack at a certain foreign embassy.

title: Redrawing the World
description: National Geographic Atlas of the World

title: Remember the Indian?
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: The Labor Shortage: Color It Gray
description: BEVERLY GOLDBERG has a warning for corporate America: Change your attitude toward older workers or face the consequences.

title: Iona Accreditation
description: The Hagan School of Business at Iona College has received accreditation from the International Association for Management Education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, RENEE
description: ROSENBLATT-Renee. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Renee Rosenblatt, beloved Mother of our devoted Members, Drs. Marc and Kathy Rosenblatt. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President
