title: Bookend; Two Things That Depress Me When I Open a Novel
description: I. The Family Tree

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; The Evanescence of Inevitability
description: Surprise! John McCain's 19-point victory in New Hampshire last week rudely knocked the crown of inevitability off George W. Bush's head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELROTH, DOROTHY G., DR. (PH.D.)
description: AXELROTH-Dorothy G., Dr. (Ph.D.) Wife of Robert S. Mother, grandmother, scholar, linguist, teacher, temple administrator and friend to many. Services Monday, February 7, 2000, 10 AM, at Temple Sinai of Roslyn, 425 Roslyn Rd, Roslyn Heights, LI. Family asks that memorial contributions be made to Hospice Care of Long Island, 900 Merchant Concourse, Westbury, LI 11590 or charity of your choice.

title: When Officials Ignore The Island's Bus Needs
description: It only figures that the county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, the man who drove Nassau into debt, would try to balance the budget on the back of the poor and disabled by cutting the already feeble bus system [''Missing the Bus,'' Jan. 30]. I am disabled and unable to drive. I take the bus to the train so I can get to work, and to take me shopping. It gives me enormous independence. The passengers are usually elderly and/or poor or don't drive. Some people at my stop come from a local group home to take the bus to work.

title: Kara Ackerman and Robert Grien
description: ANITA GRIEN MEDWIN, the mother of Robert Grien, believes that when meeting someone new, ''you only need five hours of conversation about important topics'' to know whether you can marry them.

title: Walking On Ahead, Alone
description: WHERE to walk before dark, I asked the genial proprietor of my B & B in North Wales late on a September afternoon. She pointed up the idyllic hill behind the inn where sheep grazed. ''There's a youth hostel at the top and then the road curves back down,'' she said. ''It's steep.'' She offered to drive out to find me if I didn't make it back by 6.

title: $1 Billion in Projects for Johns Hopkins in Baltimore
description: JOHNS HOPKINS is known for its medical center and university, but its impact on its hometown is more concrete. Together the Johns Hopkins University and its medical center, with the help of their own development company, are the biggest builders in Baltimore. Over the next five years they plan to complete or begin work on $1 billion worth of buildings to expand and update their facilities.

title: CHAOS IN CONGO: A primer.; Many Armies Ravage Rich Land In the 'First World War' of Africa
description: Congo and the nine nations around it sit on what may be the richest patch of this planet: there are diamonds, oil, uranium, gold, plentiful water, fertile land and exquisite wildlife.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Andrew Gristina, Margaret Kaelin
description: Margaret Lillian Kaelin, the daughter of Ruth and James F. Kaelin of Sea Cliff, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Augustus Gristina, a son of Susan Schley Gristina of Reston, Va., and the late Dr. Anthony G. Gristina. The Rev. Donald Brouillard performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Prada's Victory Means No Americans in Finals for First Time in 149 Years
description: For the first time in the 149 years of competition for sailing's oldest and most revered prize, there will be no American boat in the America's Cup.

title: Publisher Steps Down After 18-Year Tenure
description: MERNA POPPER, for 18 years the editor and publisher of Women's News, a monthly news magazine, stepped down seven weeks ago after selling her publication to a group of investors. ''Today you have to be a Rupert Murdoch to own a newspaper,'' she said. ''I couldn't afford to keep it.''

title: Deals and Discounts
description: SPRING ON THE RAILS -- Fares for the Euro star train between London and Paris or London and Brussels have been reduced for travel between Feb. 15 and April 15. The one-way Spring Special fare in second class (called standard class in Britain) during this period is $89 instead of the leisure fare of $119 for either route; the first-class fare is $149 instead of $199. The fares cannot be booked until Feb. 15; they are nonrefundable and may not be exchanged. Travel between London and Paris takes three hours; London and Brussels, 2 hours and 36 minutes. For reservations, contact Rail Europe, which distributes Eurostar tickets in the United States, at (800) 387-6782 or at www.raileurope.com on the Internet.

title: Renata Adler Is Making Enemies Again
description: Renata Adler and her ''precious'' friends from The New Yorker suffer from the delusion that anyone west of the Hudson really cares about their thoughts and consequent writings (Arthur Lubow, Jan. 16). They suffer from the delusion that because they are intellectually superior in various rather narrow fields, they are somehow absolved from having to observe the decencies of civility and the rules of a life well lived that the rest of us take for granted. Betraying friends and being gratuitously cruel to colleagues are among the most despicable personal acts one can commit.

title: Doubles Loss Threatens Americans In Davis Cup
description: They are preparing to party here, stoking the passions and cueing the clown. They are planning a parade on rationed gas. The mighty United States is on the verge of losing in the first round of the Davis Cup to a team from the northern suburbs of Harare.

title: CHRISTINA FERRARI
description: As managing editor of Teen People magazine, Christina Ferrari has seen its circulation surge from zero to 1.53 million in just two years. Recently, her work has required celebrating these gains at Teen People parties with thousands of squealing fans. But her magazine can also assume a measure of gravity -- reporting on the Columbine massacre, for example, and issues like gay rights.

title: The Burning Van, And Other Tales Of Relocation
description: Many people aspire to become movers and shakers. Few may reach that goal. But nearly everyone, it seems, has to pack up and move sometime. In the workplace, moving vertically often requires moving horizontally -- in other words, geographically. Employers insist on having the right people in the right places, and an increasing number of job-hoppers initiate their own relocations. But judging by the mail, many movers get the shakes.

title: From Beer To a Bar To a Brasserie
description: If there's a place between beer nuts and blue bloods, Judy Joice seems to have found it.

title: The Many Ways to Treat a Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Dial M for Mega (or A for Amor, or L for Latin Mix)
description: WITH a Latino listening audience four times smaller than New York City's and much more homogeneous, the Dallas-Fort Worth market just got its 17th all-Spanish radio station on Tuesday.

title: There Goes the Neighborhood
description: THE RISE OF THE NOUVEAUX RICHES Style and Status in Victorian and Edwardian Architecture. By J. Mordaunt Crook. Illustrated. 354 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: John Murray/Trafalgar Square. $45.

title: The Health Hazard From Cell Phones Is Real
description: The general public is unaware of the significant weaknesses underlying the wireless industry's claims that cell phones and their base station antennas are safe.

title: Goal Is 17 Feet in Women's Pole Vault
description: Just as Stacy Dragila prepared to break her indoor American record in the pole vault Friday night, organizers of the Millrose Games clumsily began a Hall of Fame ceremony in the infield. The meet stopped, her rhythm was interrupted. The lights went out at Madison Square Garden, and so did any chance for a record.

title: Congo Leader, Once Neighbors' Puppet and Now Their Foe, Clings to Power
description: After languishing for three decades in the mountains of eastern Congo, a little-known rebel was picked by the Rwandans to lead the overthrow of the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in 1997. And so Laurent D. Kabila suddenly found himself president of a country a third of the size of the United States.

title: For an America That Can Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Austria Throws Europe a Curve
description: IN the basement of the History Museum of this wistful city the head of the Turkish grand vizier, Kara Mustapha, is preserved. The public is no longer allowed to see this Austrian trophy, a souvenir of the last Ottoman siege of Vienna in 1683. But this severed head says much about European identity, Austrian history and the vagaries of nationalism, the issues beneath the rightist Jorg Haider's explosive intrusion on the politics of the old continent.

title: To the Rescue
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; One Man Carter Movie Ignored
description: THE Hurricane'' is an acclaimed motion picture. Denzel Washington, who portrays the wrongly convicted boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, won the Golden Globe for best actor in a drama and is expected to be nominated for an Academy Award; the movie might also be nominated for an Oscar. It's advertised as the ''most inspiring film of the year.''

title: Cold to You, But Warm for Eagles
description: EACH winter weekend, when the weather is fine and the air is clear, drivers tool along Old Mine Road in the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area in search of another visitor, the bald eagle.

title: Some Seedlings Really Need a Head Start
description: ALL too often when the garden season begins, there is a dash to the garden center, supermarket or hardware store to buy young plants. The choices may be limited, depending on the retailer, or the stock of a particular favorite may be gone.

title: Fed's Faulty Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: Here Lies a Reminder of the History of Slavery in the State
description: Nothing is recorded about the life of a slave named Jack who belonged to a Woodbridge family beyond what is marked on a headstone in the cemetery of the First Presbyterian Church, which dates his death at 1825.

title: Ralph and Lucy
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property; New Jersey Fits the Prescription
description: IF you want to run with the big dogs, you have to go where the big dogs are,'' said Gerald P. Belle, the president of Aventis Pharmaceutical, about the company's decision to shift the operating headquarters of his newly merged company from Kansas City and suburban Philadelphia to Parsippany, N.J.

title: On Skis, a Legend Unto Myself
description: A VERY small amount of snow on Long Island creates a lot of excitement. Weather forecasters reach for superlatives, cars slide off the highways in all directions, the Long Island Rail Road falls apart, the airports close, schools shut down and everyone acts as if two inches of snow is the most amazing, unexpected catastrophic event of this century.

title: Further Opportunity For Education
description: In the coverage of Connecticut land trusts (''Using Fame to Save the Land,'' Jan. 16), various missions served by the trusts were mentioned, and I would like to add one that the small Chester Land Trust has found beneficial: education. It recently held a full-day symposium devoted to the benefits of riparian buffer zones for waterside properties. Experts were stationed at nine sites on rivers, lakes and ponds to explain how certain plantings can protect water quality, thus demonstrating that trust missions can extend well beyond land acquisition.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the aging of the city's population misspelled the surname of the commissioner of the Department for the Aging. He is Herbert W. Stupp, not Stupps.

title: Believing In the Future Of Amazon
description: IT'S probably a stretch for most people to imagine that the former Mets relief pitcher Tug McGraw and Jeff Bezos have much in common. But they do.

title: Technology Defies Another Dictum
description: IT'S one of the fundamental principles of the stock market: When interest rates go up, stocks go down. And along with financial companies and cyclicals, technology companies -- with their sky-high price-to-earnings multiples -- should be among the biggest losers in an environment of rising rates.

title: The Matchmaker; In a Certain Rarefield World, Few Loom Larger Than a School's Director of College Admissions
description: ON the last day of school before Christmas break, Cara Thomas rushed home and waited for the letter carrier in the lobby of her apartment house. Cara, a redhead with clear blue eyes, is a 17-year-old senior at Nightingale-Bamford, an elite private girls' school on East 92nd Street in Manhattan. Earlier that day, two of her classmates had already received glad tidings: a yes from Harvard on early action. Cara had fallen in love with Brown during a campus visit the previous summer and applied early in the fall. One freshman course in particular, on physics and poetry, had signaled, in her mind, the kind of intellectual journey she longed to take.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, MARY JANE
description: KENNY-Mary Jane. On February 3, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late William Francis and Mary Ellen Hickey Kenny. Survived by her beloved nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday, February 11, 5-7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, February 12, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, NY.

title: Guyana's Capital, Tropical Victorian
description: THE Guyanese woman, a noted painter, shifted restlessly in her chair as I spoke. We were by the swimming pool at the Meridien Pegasus Hotel in Georgetown, a concrete building from the late 1960's, sipping tall, iced rum punches. I had spent the day looking at some of the city's colonial architecture -- seductive, sensitive wooden structures from an age when the British were overlords -- and was anguished by the state of slovenly disrepair into which many had fallen. It wasn't merely a question of peeling paint, overgrown gardens, broken windows and scarred facades. It was a question, I quickly realized, of the very survival of an architectural genre.

title: The Inside Outsiders Behind John McCain
description: It was just about this time three years ago that John Weaver, a tall, terse Texan, dragged Senator John McCain from a Senate Commerce Committee hearing to tell him he should run for president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANELA, HARRIETTE
description: MANELA-Harriette. Age 73, of Fair Lawn, NJ. Born in Belgium, emigrated to New York City in 1948 after surviving the Holocaust. Survived by her husband Marc, daughters Marlene (John) Sincaglia and Jacqueline (Jerry) Novin, brothers Chalom, Marcel and Albert (Dr. Lynne) Fremder, brother-in-law Willy Manela, grandsons Teddy and Zach Novin and Matthew Sincaglia; and numerous nieces and nephews. Services are 2:00 pm, Sunday , at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Record Housing Sales Bring Sharp Inventory Drop
description: WHILE real estate agents in Westchester County posted a record number of sales in 1999 -- with more than 400 houses selling for $1 million or more -- the result has been an unprecedented lack of inventory, especially in the all-important category of single-family houses.

title: Renaissance Hobbies
description: INGENIOUS PURSUITS Building the Scientific Revolution. By Lisa Jardine. Illustrated. 444 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $35.

title: A Catholic Parish Finds Its Black Voice; Priest in Brooklyn Helps Reconcile Racial and Religious Identities
description: Above all else, the Rev. Martin J. Carter, 70, is a man of determination. Raised in rural North Carolina during the Great Depression, he knew early on that he wanted to be a priest. It was an unusual choice, even with a Catholic mother. Back then, black priests were about as common as black sheriffs, and seminary after seminary rejected him because of his race.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00: The Ethicist; The Talented Mr. Rip-Off
description: I'm an assistant to a screenwriter in Los Angeles. Here your boss is your mentor who will guide you to Your Next Big Opportunity. I believe in this system and I depend on it, as it has served me well, but now I'm being held back. Our scripts are valued at over $100,000 a draft, and these days every script is half mine. Meanwhile, I can't afford a new muffler for my car. It would be simple to get a job if I told the studio executives that the pages they were ''loving'' were mine. But this would mean breaching a business relationship with my boss. May I do it? -- Anonymous, Los Angeles

title: What No School Can Do
description: Traub gets to the core of the problem when he says at the end of his article that parents must take active responsibility for the rearing and education of their children. And when he writes, ''The language of personal responsibility makes many liberals flinch,'' he hits the nail on the head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDA, CHARLES WILLIAM
description: BENDA-Charles William. Of Miami, FL, formerly of Katonah, New York. Born September 15th, 1912. Graduate of City College of New York. Employee of The New York Times 1926-1976. Survived by his wife Mary Kathleen, his daughters Gabrielle Palmiotto and Mary Tillman, his sons John, Charles and Christopher Benda, and eight grandchildren.

title: Wearing Your Heart On Your Portfolio
description: IF you're interested in security, get a blanket.

title: Landmark Status Is Sought For 'Bastions of Elegance'
description: Nearly lost amid the jumble of glass-and-steel high-rises of Midtown, a group of town houses dating from 1869 to 1934 is tucked away on East 54th and 55th Streets between Park and Lexington Avenues. For a year, neighborhood residents and prominent supporters, like Brooke Astor and the architect Philip Johnson, have urged that the area be declared a historic district. Last week, city officials said they would consider conferring landmark status on 2 of the 12 buildings.

title: Learning to Laugh at Chevy Chase
description: I NOTE that something called ''Snow Day'' looms on the horizon, starring my old classmate Chevy Chase. Chevy and I were at Bard College together in the late 60's -- years before he became famous on ''Saturday Night Live'' as the good-looking guy who won the Emmys for his acting and writing, for his imitations of Gerald Ford, for starting Weekend Update by saying, ''I'm Chevy Chase and you're not,'' and for falling down staircases and ladders and off chandeliers. (At Bard, he was a literature major.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREUHAFT, IRENE
description: TREUHAFT-Irene. On February 4, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Alfred. Loving mother of Barbara Fagan and Sheilah and Perry Ashley. Adoring grandmother of Diane and Tom Mumm, Nancy, Kenneth and Sabine Fagan, Jonathan and Susan Ashley, Melissa and Jennifer Ashley. Proud greatgrandmother of Alec and Zachary, Paul and Jeremy. Private service.

title: Kaukenas's Magical Night Means Romp for Seton Hall
description: Seton Hall's Rimas Kaukenas trekked around the right side of the court tonight as though he were a hiker determined to find the best place to pitch his tent and set up camp. He explored the range of the curving 3-point line, peered under the basket and tested the ground at the top of the key.

title: A Ship and a Theme for Everyone
description: FOR decades, passenger ships have featured music, lectures and other entertainment, at first to ease the passage, more recently to compete with vacation resorts. But one of the first cruises devoted to a specific theme was the jazz cruise offered by Norwegian Cruise Line on the Norway in the early 1980's.

title: Punishing Rocker
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cliche Lives On
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Outside Vaults Over Prison Walls
description: WHO wants to come with me around the world today?'' Michael Harrold asked.

title: Forget What Psychics See. At Least They Listen.
description: WHEN the news broke recently that New York City, in its zeal to place welfare recipients in jobs, was sending some of them to work at a psychic hot line, the future was easy to divine. Embarrassed city officials promptly called a halt, leaving some low-income New Yorkers with reduced employment prospects.

title: Style; Rock Climbing
description: A friend of mine has always dressed with elegant austerity. When she takes the subway to and from work on Wall Street, her only adornments are a single string of large pearls at the base of her throat and a pair of matching pearls on her ears. One day she revealed that her necklace was made of the finest of South Seas cultured pearls and had cost a quarter of a million dollars.

title: In Search of Serious Tea (Scones Optional)
description: ONE of the challenges of restaurant dining is finding a cup of brewed and steeped tea, made with loose tea instead of with tea in bags. Devout tea drinkers care about such things, but admittedly we are a beleagured minority. Any fussy coffee drinker would be grossly offended if served instant coffee in a three-star restaurant. But tea bags are standard operating procedure at the finest establishments.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENMARK, PAMELA D.
description: DENMARK-Pamela D. 8/31/602/6/98. Pamela, your family and friends all miss you and love you.

title: Columbia Student Slain, and Suspect Kills Himself
description: A 19-year-old Columbia University student from Long Island, a star of the women's varsity lacrosse team, was found slashed to death yesterday afternoon in her dormitory room, and an hour later a former boyfriend believed to be her killer leapt to his death under a subway train in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: AS a young black actor, Robert Townsend found it hard to get work - and when he did, he always seemed to be playing a hoodlum, an Uncle Tom, a pimp or a slave. He turned the story of his frustrations into HOLLYWOOD SHUFFLE (1987), a terrific, high-energy satire - even if it is basically just a series of skits - with exactly the mean-spirited tone it should have. The cast includes Mr. Townsend, Anne-Marie Johnson and Keenen Ivory Wayans - Monday at 8 and 11 p.m., Tuesday at 5 p.m on Bravo.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE TRULY NEEDY And Other Stories. By Lucy Honig. University of Pittsburgh, $22.50.

title: CUNY Tests, A Last Hurdle, Stump Many
description: Hundreds of students -- both freshmen and transfers -- who otherwise met the admissions criteria at four senior colleges of the City University of New York were recently barred from registering at these colleges because they failed the university's English or mathematics placement tests.

title: Corrections
description: The A La Carte column on Jan. 23 misstated the telephone number of Cafe Picasso in Williston Park. It is (516) 294-4454.

title: Blue-Collar Jobs Complement Liberal Arts Courses
description: When her beeper went off on a Friday night last November, Clair Jenne, an art student, was in a studio here at Warren Wilson College, applying charcoal to a giant canvas depicting the central female relationships in her life.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Little Feat

title: Fine and Dandy
description: Diamonds are nice, but platinum, sapphires and pearls are nothing to sneer at.

title: The Hudson, Minus Bridges or Tunnels
description: For many New Jerseyans, the Hudson River is what you cross to get to New York City. But it is also a worthy destination unto itself, another shoreline so to speak. For those who want to explore it, Rutgers University Press has published a book, ''Paths Along the Hudson: A Guide to Walking and Biking.'' It was written by Jeffrey Perls, a freelance writer and environmental activist who leads outings along the river. He describes the river's geography and history at length, discusses problems of pollution and recreation and directs readers to programs and groups involved with the area. Of course, there are many trails in New York State. But, he says, to see perhaps the most magnificent path along the river, the 13.5-mile Shore Trail, with Paleozoic rocks, Colonial houses and gorgeous waterfalls, New Jerseyans need never cross the river or the state line. The paperback, $20, is 320 pages and has 20 maps.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Ex-Official Keeps Pentagon's Clearance After Loss of C.I.A.'s
description: Although the former director of central intelligence, John M. Deutch, had his security clearances revoked by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency, he has kept a security clearance at the Pentagon, a senior Defense Department official says.

title: Dukakis In 'Antigone'
description: Olympia Dukakis goes home again and again to Montclair, where she was a longtime resident and theatrical force, having co-founded the Whole Theater, which closed in 1990 after 17 years.

title: Measuring and Trimming Shutters
description: IN Colonial times, homeowners used shutters to control the amount of light coming into the house; curtains were less usual. The standard interior shutter was a paneled piece without openings. It had a central raised panel, much like a cabinet door, and it faced the window. The other side of the shutter was flat. By the second half of the 19th century, louvered or Venetian shutters became increasingly popular.

title: Look Who's Falling for John McCain
description: It was last Thursday evening, New Hampshire Primary Day Plus Two, when the phone rang. I didn't immediately recognize the voice, but the name rang a giant glockenspiel. She was a Hollywood star who, like me, is performing a community service by appearing frequently on cable news talk shows.

title: Steel Library Card in Velvet Glove: Firmer Approach With Scofflaws
description: A 30-year-old Brooklyn woman conceded recently that she owed almost $300 in overdue-book fees to the New York and Brooklyn Public Libraries. That figure reflects both the cost of the books and the late fees that have accumulated since she borrowed the Gothic novels last year.

title: Murder Trial Reveals More Than a Killing
description: It looked like the handiwork of a brazen killer. On a busy shopping corridor in Jackson Heights, Queens, a man gunned down a couple at point-blank range as they sat in their Lexus. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, went to the crime scene himself. When a local grocer named Peter Bok Lee was charged with the slayings two days later, prosecutors considered seeking the death penalty.

title: Parents and Teachers Scramble as Snow Hits
description: WHEN a winter storm is predicted, many residents go to sleep the night before, wondering if their morning plans will be disrupted by a delayed school opening or a cancellation and planning to listen to the radio by 6 or 6:30 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISER, STEVEN R.
description: WEISER-Steven R. 6/25/472/6/93. Love you forever, miss you for always. Robin, Jessica, Lauren and Jil

title: Celebrating la Difference and Three Objects of Desire
description: IN ''Day for Night,'' Francois Truffaut's 1973 comedy about filmmaking, a young actor with girlfriend problems goes around asking everyone he knows, ''Are women magic?'' The other characters stare back at him with pity and horror. Doesn't he know? Any French film could tell the poor boy the answer: ''But of course.''

title: Proposed Bank Merger Prompts Claims of Bias
description: While the longest economic expansion in history trickles down fitfully to city neighborhoods, a coalition of community groups working to rebuild them is recalling a problem that seemed to fade with the 1970's: the old-fashioned practice of redlining.

title: Commitment, Redefined: Rodman Returning
description: Dennis Rodman, wayward soul in need of shelter and minimum salary, found a home last week. Mark Cuban, the incoming owner of the Dallas Mavericks, offered up his 4,000-square-foot guest house and a chance for Rodman to resume his career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLETTE, PATRICIA J.
description: COLLETTE-Patricia J. of Chicago 79, died January 31. Former Social Science Researcher at Columbia University in New York. Funeral information, 630-668-0016.

title: THEATER; Instant Theater: No Fuss or Frills, Just the Plays
description: BY 10 o'clock on the night of Jan. 22, 47 people had gathered at the Chopin Theater in Chicago. A fireman, a lawyer, a journalist and a candy store clerk were among them. Each had brought a prop and costume, knowing that in less than 24 hours he would be performing before an audience that had paid $10 apiece to see theater. Some of those present had never been on a stage before. No one had learned his lines. No one knew what part he was to play. As a matter of fact, none of the roles had been created. The plays had yet to be written.

title: 'I Knew It Would Be Rough': Excerpts From Interview With Mrs. Clinton
description: Following are excerpts from Hillary Rodham Clinton's interview on Thursday with The New York Times:

title: From Traditional to Niche, Newspapers Keep Piling Up; Publishers Say There Is Room for All Publications to Meet the Need
description: THE growing number of local newspapers in residents' mailboxes and on newsstands around the county is just the right mix to satisfy Westchester's sophisticated readership, publishers say, adding that their weeklies, dailies, business journals and special-interest newspapers are thriving.

description: When Peter Schoenhardt looks at the red brick fortresslike building that towers above the houses lining the Fourth Avenue in Sunset Park, he is one of the few people who sees more than the crumbling, graffiti-smeared walls.

title: Memories on Videotape: Alas, They Fade
description: Since I am in the business of archiving photographic collections, the Jan. 30 Long Island Journal column, ''Preserving a Lifetime's Memories on Video,'' was of special interest.

title: Reading the Signals Of a Baffled Bond Market
description: THE Treasury bond market went haywire last week. What exactly does the chaos in this huge and hugely significant market mean to investors?

description: The success of earlier generations of immigrants attests to the power of cultural values and attitudes. Today the same factors predict whether students are immunized against or victimized by destructive elements around them as they pursue an education.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Twelfth Night' in 2000
description: ''Twelfth Night,'' ''Antony and Cleopatra'' and ''Othello'' are on the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's schedule for this year. The state's only theater devoted to Shakespeare and classic drama announced that the 2000 season will also include ''The Forest'' by Alexander Ostrovsky, ''Rhinoceros'' by Eugene Ionesco and ''The Blue Bird'' by Maurice Maeterlinck. The season begins in June and continues through December. (973) 408-5600.

description: IN 1896, the grandparents of Nancy Delmerico Vitagliano, a freelance graphics designer, emigrated from Zungoli, a small town in Italy, to the hilly Westchester village of Dobbs Ferry, where Ms. Vitagliano's father was born and lived all his life.

description: JUST about the last thing most people would expect to find in a high-rise building that is home to a variety of real estate agents, lawyers and accountants (not to mention the Westchester Youth Soccer League) is an artist's studio.

title: Elitism of Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pain Inflicted By Family
description: HAPPY families are all alike, Tolstoy said, but that was then. In theater, happy families are oxymoronic. Assuming that they did exist, nobody's writing plays about them. That is not to say families are not loving, but every loving family worth a playwright's bother shows or arrives at love in its own way. That long journey into enlightenment is invariably hurtful, laden with animosity, denial, illusion essential for survival and at the very least a lifetime of misunderstandings.

title: Learning How To Be King
description: ''THE THING IS,'' says His Majesty Abdullah II, the 38-year-old king of Jordan and 43rd-generation direct descendant of the prophet Muhammad, ''is that I've become a bit like Elvis.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL / Saab 9-5 Aero and 9-3 Viggen; New Turbo Jets From Air Saab
description: WHEN I bought a new 900 Turbo in 1985, Saab was basking in its image as the purveyor of eccentric Swedish sport sedans for 30-somethings who couldn't afford BMW's and couldn't abide anything as sensible as a Volvo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHEIDER, FRED
description: GOLDSCHEIDER-Fred of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. on February 3, 2000. Beloved husband of Marlaine (nee Grant). Loving father of Julie. Devoted brother of Robert and uncle of Eric and Tom Goldscheider. Family will be receiving friends on Saturday and Sunday between 7 & 9 PM at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, N.J. Service on Monday, February 7th at 10:30 AM. Interment will be in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: Getting to Laos Ahead of the Guidebooks
description: THE stranger approached. He wore a tie-dyed shirt and a nylon zippered waist pouch. A gray ponytail; late 50's, I'd say. ''So,'' he opened, ''You're going to Laos?''

description: Julia Margaret Durney and Vladimir Yurievich Obrevko were married last evening by the Rev. Stephen Garmey at the Calvary Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

description: I especially enjoyed reading ''Lives Lived Well and the Lessons That They Teach'' (Jan. 2), which was truly inspiring.

description: CANTWELL-Mary L. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Mary L. Cantwell, associated with The Times from 1980 until retiring in 1996.

description: LOWER MANHATTAN

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00: Salient Facts: Armored S.U.V.'s; Gangsta on Board
description: According to law-enforcement officials, Puffy Combs -- the rapper recently charged with throwing a 9-millimeter handgun out the window of his speeding Lincoln Navigator -- had installed a secret trap door to hide a weapon. The problem? The trap door's security system was so elaborate that in the heat of the moment no one in the car could figure out how to get it open. According to a report in The New York Post, one witness told the grand jury that Combs yelled: ''Trap! Trap! Open the trap!'' (Combs has pleaded not guilty to charges of illegal gun possession.) Police say that secret gun vaults are increasingly common among certain high-risk drivers. And for those who have enough money and know the right auto-body mechanic, they are just one of the many options available.

title: Campaigning For the Charts That Teach
description: EDWARD R. TUFTE'S books have a certain austere elegance about them, starting with ''The Visual Display of Quantitative Information'' (1983), which sold hundreds of thousands of copies and made his reputation as a guru of information graphics. So when Professor Tufte was surfing Amazon.com recently for books about business graphics, he was perversely delighted with what he found.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 4 of Arts & Leisure today misstates the opening date for the musical ''Saturday Night.'' The show will open on Feb. 17, not Feb. 14.

title: Tired of News That Rocks the Boat? Visit Japan
description: WHEN Japan's largest newspaper recently refused advertising from two of the country's most popular weekly magazines, citing their sexually explicit content, it put Mizuho Fukushima in a quandary.

title: Church Sells Building to N.Y.U. but Keeps a Say in Design
description: After 12 months of negotiations, Judson Memorial Church has sold its beloved but frail Judson House to the New York University School of Law. The $3.6 million agreement allocates space for the church and gives it the right to comment on the design of whatever new building N.Y.U. puts up.

title: A Paul Zindel Comedy on Stage in Croton Falls
description: IT is an essential act of humanity to root for a well-intentioned playhouse laboring to reclaim integrity after credibility was tarnished by a group of big city wannabees. Even though Pamela Moller Kareman's staging of Paul Zindel's minor 1971 play, ''And Miss Reardon Drinks a Little,'' is not quite the restorative needed by the Schoolhouse here after its lamentably misjudged ''Housewives on Prozac'' last month, it does signal a welcome return to literacy, rationality and purposeful irrationality.

title: DAILY DECLARATION
description: Senator Gerald Cardinale seems to be getting closer to getting his wish to require schoolchildren to recite daily the passage of the Declaration of Independence that begins ''We hold these truths to be self-evident.''

title: Kidnapped?
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Rubbernecking With Class
description: Appreciating the Empire State Building or the Chrysler Building is easy: their greatness is agreed upon. It is a lot harder to say something intelligent about the hulking Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square. In MANHATTAN SKYSCRAPERS (Princeton Architectural, $45), Eric P. Nash manages to do both. The book, which features 75 extant examples built since the skyscraper was invented a century ago, is admirably grounded in the details of stone, steel and glass. In fact, nonarchitects will find themselves consulting the handy glossary when words like ''chamfered'' and ''intrados'' come up. Each skyscraper gets a two-page spread (four for a few heavy hitters like the Empire State Building). The full-page photographs by Norman McGrath help the reader better understand both good and great buildings. Nash, a researcher at The New York Times Magazine, writes a deft prose: in his entry on the postmodern Conde Nast Building, he compares buildings that look different from various sides to ''politic but perhaps hypocritical gentlemen.'' The magnificent Lever House, financed by a soap-manufacturing fortune, remains ''bright, minty-fresh, and smacks of prosperity.'' His take on the Marriott Marquis acknowledges its ''ghastly'' elements but finds the anti-urbanist design, which encourages guests to shun the city, ''insidiously brilliant.'' Even an architecture writer should be able to empathize with the villain of the piece. Ted Loos

title: Singh Is 8 Shots Ahead of Woods
description: If Tiger Woods is to continue his winning streak, he will have to overcome an eight-stroke deficit.

title: New Life, New Trouble For a Hotel
description: Kevin P. Maloney was eating Thanksgiving dinner with residents of the Martha Washington, a former welfare hotel, when the city informed him that plans to turn it into a tourist hotel could proceed. His company, Property Markets Group, bought the hotel on East 30th Street last July. ''I said I want everyone to know we're a go,'' he said. ''And all these women were in tears, happy, screaming.''

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: 'Chinese Woody Allen' Leavens Pain With Humor
description: Once a week, Don Eng works his material in front of a much smaller audience. He tells the one about his mother's new boyfriend, and the one about the students at Cornell University. He tells the one about a job he held at a group home, and the one that helps explain why he is a manic-depressive.

title: BackTalk; Figure Skater's Injury Stirs Plea for Helmets
description: I've had some anxious moments in my 39-year career as a figure skater and a coach, but all of them pale compared to the 10 seconds last Sept. 29 when I watched in horror as one of my rising stars, the pairs skater Paul Binnebose, crashed onto the ice in a near-fatal fall during a routine practice at the University of Delaware.

description: The Trouble with Principle

description: In a decision that has angered local residents, state and city officials have decided that American Marine Rail, a company planning to build a waste transfer station on the Hunts Point waterfront, does not need to undertake an environmental impact study of the proposal.

description: SIMPLE STORIES

title: Sailing the Caribbean With a Few Pals
description: THE name tags scared me. They were the first thing I saw -- lined up neatly in alphabetical order on a table -- when I entered the observation lounge of the Nantucket Clipper on Sunday afternoon.

title: A Stalinist Antibiotic Alternative
description: In a barely heated ward for newborns on the top floor of the Georgian Republic Children's Hospital, Tamila Gogitidze carefully opens a glass ampul filled with amber liquid. The hospital, in the Degomi suburb of Georgia's decaying capital city, Tbilisi, is a spartan affair: its radiators are ramshackle, the electricity intermittent and the raw concrete heavy on the eyes. A few American posters of babies cavorting in cabbages seem direly out of place. The liquid trapped inside the ampul, meanwhile, can be identified from a box on the floor. Its label is Latin: Bacteriophagum Intestinalis Fluidum. Gogitidze, a nurse on the intensive care unit for newborns, cracks open the ampul, pours the liquid onto a teaspoon and prepares to administer it to one of her babies, a 3-month-old boy abandoned at the hospital a few days before by his impoverished family. He is screaming lustily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTULLO, G. ROBSON
description: PATTULLO-G. Robson, 49, died peacefully on February 3, 2000 in New York City. Cherished friend and husband of Susan. Beloved father of Claire. Devoted son of Elizabeth and Pat Pattullo, brother of Betsy, Ann, Greg and Ronald. Uncle of Jess, Gabe, Alissa and Sasha. Associated for nearly 25 years with ABC News. A joyous light in the lives of all who knew him. Funeral services will be held in Winchester, MA. A memorial celebration in New York City will follow. Donations in Rob's memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: In Montreal, A Multimedia Festival
description: Montreal loves festivals, and is starting a new one Friday: the Montreal High Lights Festival. Through March 4, the city will celebrate the culinary arts, performing arts and museums and lighting arts, with more than 2,000 artists participating.

title: In Europe, The Fleet Of Riverboats Gets Bigger (But Not Too Big)
description: Those who prefer rolling rivers to the high seas have some new vessels to choose from this season -- at least in Europe.

title: A Poignant Case of a Patent
description: It is far from the longest or biggest patent suit on record, but it must be among the most poignant. Frank Calabrese, 58, an engineer in Waynesboro, Pa., who was too ill with cancer to attend the trial, won a $13.2 million verdict late last month against the French-owned Square D Company for infringing on his patent for a data system used in complex manufacturing.

title: Dead Men Do No Time
description: CHAOS THEORY By Gary Krist. 347 pp. New York: Random House. $24.

title: Lindros Makes Voice Heard
description: Eric Lindros, the captain of the Philadelphia Flyers, is not the only player who complains about poor ice conditions that hinder skating and cause pucks to bounce and roll out of control.

title: What No School Can Do
description: The real message of James Traub's article, and it's a good one, is that it takes more than the 8-to-3 school day to make a difference in the lives of disadvantaged children; that any effective reform can be seen not from standardized test to standardized test but from generation to generation. Traub suggests that it isn't enough to throw money at the current system of public education -- but one must invest money in order to exert influence at an earlier age and for more hours of the day than public education does now. This message is very different from the blanket assertion that ''schools are not the answer.''

title: Rumblings Outside the Ring
description: Vince McMahon, chairman of the World Wrestling Federation, wants nobody to think he is making a bid for respectability by locating his entertainment company's new theme restaurant in Times Square, just chair-throwing distance from the offices of some of the world's largest media companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINS, JANE L.
description: JENKINS-Jane L. On February 3, 2000 at age 81. Beloved wife of the late William Jenkins and loving mother of the late Steven Jenkins.

title: Sports of The Times; For Butch's Players, 23 Hoop Dreams And One Nightmare
description: AFTER 40 years, the old boys from Hofstra University agree on one thing: that buzzer shot on a bleak afternoon may have ruined an undefeated season, but it did not ruin their lives.

title: Zulu Nation Arrests Inspire Anger and Perhaps a Lawsuit
description: The arrest in December of 34 members of the Universal Zulu Nation has sparked a controversy -- and a potential lawsuit -- involving the police and members of the organization, a self-described community service group. The arrest occurred at Markham Playground, which is near Forest Avenue and the Martin Luther King Jr. Expressway in an isolated corner of northwest Staten Island.

title: Writing Competition
description: The county's Millennium Commission is looking for Westchester writers to submit essays, poems and short stories about life in Westchester now or in the past or future.

title: Recreating 'Jane Eyre' With a New Intimacy
description: WHAT is left to discover about ''Jane Eyre'' after at least four film versions and various important critical writings, not to mention Charlotte Bronte's 1847 novel itself?

title: Exploring Space and Time, Here and Now
description: OTHERS may care about parallel universes, black holes or the possibility of punching through our local space-time configuration into past or future states. What matters to me is the challenge of punching into the present. This trick is harder to pull off than one might think. But Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, the New York architects, have been performing it, with increasing success, for nearly 20 years. Two recent projects, both realized in ephemeral forms, have expanded the New York audience for the work of these gifted space-timers.

title: Not Young Anymore but Still Misbehaving
description: IN his dressing room backstage after a sold-out show here, Mark McKinney of the Kids in the Hall took off his jeans and then, once his robe was secured, his pantyhose.

title: When the Future Is a Return to the Past
description: An 1855 painting by James Bard titled ''Long Island Sound Steamboats'' gives historical perspective to the proposed Glen Cove ferry. In the center of the picture is a long, sleek paddlewheeler. From its bow flies a blue flag with white ''GC'' circled with white stars, and at the stern and on the sides are painted the words ''Glen Cove.''

title: Cold Winter Nights Are Perfect for Quick Pasta Meals
description: FOR those who work all day, cooking the kind of food one yearns for on a cold winter night is not always practical. Long-simmered stews and braised meats are fine if you have the afternoon to prepare them, but they are out of the question when you get home after 6 p.m. One answer is a hearty pasta that can be made in less than an hour.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Costly Active-Adult Homes Find a Niche in Chester
description: FROM a distance the big new homes rising just off Old Chester-Gladstone Road in Chester Township look like most others rising in and around this wealthy Morris County community. But they are attached homes, side-by-side, designed to look like one of their stately neighbors -- and they are only for active adults age 55 and older.

title: 300 Long Islanders, Tied to Connecticut; The Dwindling Population of Fishers Island Is Isolated by State Borders and Winter's Winds
description: WILLIAM BLOETHE pulled his grocery van up to the pier at Silver Eel Cove at 7:30 one January morning to collect his morning delivery, a bundle of newspapers and magazines. With the temperature in the single digits and the wind blowing to make it feel like 30 below, he left the engine running while he went aboard the ferry, but even a few minutes outside was enough to leave his fingers near frozen.

title: TRUCKERS FILE SUIT
description: A coalition of more than 2,000 of the country's largest trucking companies filed a lawsuit against Governor Whitman and other state officials last week, charging that a state regulation prohibiting big trucks from using local roads violates the Constitution's protection of interstate commerce. The state rule, issued in July, requires that big trucks stick to Interstate highways, the turnpike and several connecting arteries unless their trip begins or ends in the state.
