description: POLLY'S GHOST

title: Rights Group Says Russians Executed Grozny Civilians
description: Russia's seizure of Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, did not bring much security for Hedi, a 40-year-old resident of the battered city. When she and two other women returned to Grozny to check on their homes, they stumbled across a group of Russian soldiers who were looting their devastated neighborhood. The women were blindfolded and shot.

title: The Long Tale of Madonna the Iguana
description: Greenhouse's essay was touching indeed. The real story, however, is not about her feelings but about her daughter's stunning lack of emotion: the pet she had ''desperately'' wanted had become an ''embarrassment''; she was anxious to replace its cage with a sofa so she could ''stretch out.'' Perhaps Greenhouse and her husband should have had their daughter accompany them to the pet store so that she might experience a poignant moment. I certainly hope her parents don't become an embarrassment when they grow old; sofas are too easy to come by.

title: Barbara Glasser and Steven Blinn
description: Barbara Glasser and Steven Blinn were married last evening at Arqua, a restaurant in Manhattan. Rabbi Sanford Hahn, an uncle of the bride, officiated.

title: Bill to Control Toy Guns Moves Forward
description: A PROPOSAL to control toy guns that look like the real thing may soon be enacted in Westchester.

title: A Surprisingly Good Show to the North
description: Put aside all salivations over technology stocks in the Nasdaq composite for a moment. Consider a market to the north that has been scorchingly hot of late, one that features stocks that also trade here.

title: The Long Tale of Madonna the Iguana
description: Linda Greenhouse has been the very best of all reporters on the Supreme Court. Now, in her Lives column (Jan. 16), she proves that she can make the simplest thing seem so very interesting.

title: Still an Old Boys' Club
description: To the Editor:

title: A Winding Way to Serenity
description: IT can be hard to find peace in this city. A seemingly unending flow of traffic and people rush through the streets like water from a broken dike, and New York City is known throughout the world for being in a state of perpetual motion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWARD, CHARLES JACKSON II
description: STEWARD-Charles Jackson II, born in Augusta, GA on March 29, 1920, passed away in Las Vegas, NV on January 16, 2000. The beloved husband of Rose, he is survived by four of his six children, Harris, Robert, Janet, Michael and his loving brother, Williams Dean. His life was marked by devotion to his country, his family and his friends. He enriched the lives of all those he touched.

title: What No School Can Do
description: Adults with all of our ''social ecology'' programs assume that we must do more for or to young people. We operate as if they are objects that we still haven't learned to manipulate effectively. Many teenagers perceive this as oppressive. They put their efforts into resisting us while creating their own society.

title: Fill Feeder, Hunt Insects, Cut Amaryllis
description: As the supply of fruits and berries dwindles and seeds become buried under the snow, it is important to keep bird feeders full and water available. A mix of black oil sunflower seeds and white proso millet will be the most appealing to the largest variety of birds and a good source of protein and fat.

title: Loss of a Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALMUTH, FAY
description: BALMUTH-Fay. The Officers and Directors of Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Foundation sadly mourn the untimely passing of Fay Balmuth, beloved and esteemed daughter of our late founders, Phillip and Dora Brenner. Her involvement with our organization dates back, along with that of her dear family, more than half a century to the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, The Long Island League and other affiliates. A devoted friend and ardent supporter Fay will be greatly missed. May her legacy act as a source of inspiration to all those whom she touched. Our profound sympathy and sincere condolences to the family. John H. Wolff, Pres. Eli S. Feldman, Exec VP & CEO Norman B. Gildin, Exec. Dir.CDO

title: 2 Disciples Of Charlie Parker Go Their Own Ways
description: THE alto saxophonists Jackie McLean and Lee Konitz might appear to have nothing in common except their refusal to coast despite their advancing years, and the debt to Charlie Parker they share with all saxophonists of their generation. Mr. McLean, a mighty blower whose new album ''Nature Boy'' is something of a departure for him -- a program of standards, most of them ballads -- is 68. The prolific Mr. Konitz, who has released four new albums in recent months and recorded in so many different contexts over the decades that nothing he could do would qualify as a departure, is four years older. As young men, he and Mr. McLean were among those forced to wrestle with Parker's influence or risk being overwhelmed by it. Each met this challenge in his own way, drawn by individual sensibility to a different aspect of Parker's style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, ROSEMARY (NEE FRIEL)
description: WALLACE - Rosemary (nee Friel). Of Maple Shade, NJ, suddenly on February 3, 2000, age 72 years. Beloved wife of William E. Wallace. Dear mother of Nora Ann Wallace, William E. Wallace, Jr., both of NYC and Robert M. Wallace of Allentown, PA. Grandmother of Claire and Andrew Wallace. Sister of John Friel, Joseph Friel, Michael Friel, William Friel, Patrick Friel, Nora T. Friel, Kathleen Gibbons, the late Lawrence Friel and the late Edward Friel. Relatives and friends are invited to attend her funeral Tuesday starting 8:30 AM at Inglesby/Givnish of Maple Shade, 600 E. Main St. Funeral liturgy will follow 10:00 AM at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery. Viewing Monday evening 7:00-8:30 PM at the funeral home.

title: Imaginative, Audacious And Overlooked
description: THE alto saxophonist Charles McPherson is held in high esteem by musicians both long seasoned and young, ranging from Jimmy Heath and George Coleman to Greg Osby and Wes Anderson. Yet Mr. McPherson is barely noticed by the jazz press, another example of the quandary faced by some master practitioners of this art form. Exceptional players are often lost in the cracks of critical attention if they do no more than become great individuals because the jazz press seems intent on ferreting out the innovators, the next direction, the flavor of the moment.

title: What No School Can Do
description: Whether inadvertently or by design, Traub exposes the intellectual dishonesty of multiculturalism. Although there is overwhelming evidence, for example, that nuclear families are superior to single motherhood, and that middle-class values place more emphasis on education than the ''gangsta'' worldview, the drumbeat of the ''all cultures are equally valid'' crowd continues unabated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, SIDNEY
description: SHEPARD-Sidney. To our dear, dear friend of many years-the good times, the bad times have all been better having been shared with you. You will be with us in our hearts forever. Love, Jimmy, Sande, Scott, Barry, Jeff and Chris

title: Breaking Into the Club
description: No Place For a Woman

title: Tire Chains Are Rare, Telephone Chains Aren't
description: If snow days are among the most evocative memories of childhood, then children in Warren will have rich recollections of their past. At least the ones who were in school in the winter of 1994, when the the schools were closed 19 times for snow or ice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTSWORTH, DORCAS D.
description: COTSWORTH-Dorcas D., 82, of Bay Head, NJ, formerly of Short Hills, NJ, on January 29, 2000. Beloved mother of John G. Berry, C. Bruce Berry, Hollace Riordan, and Dorcas Beatty. Grandmother of Caroline E. Berry, Dorcas Blake Beatty, Leigh T. Beatty, Katherine H. Riordan, John Gaines Riordan, Samuel Chase Riordan, and Benita Berry. Memorial funeral services will be held on Sat., June 3, 2000 at 11AM at the All Saints Episcopal Church, Lake Ave., Bay Head, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to All Saints Women's Guild, 500 Lake Ave., Bay Head, NJ 08742. For further information contact Van Hise & Callagan, Leber Funeral Home, Pt. Pleasant Beach, NJ.

title: Bradley's Quandary
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/White Plains; School's 'Family' Concert to Benefit Its New Home
description: THERE was a time when the phrase ''music lesson'' conjured up images of a disciplinarian who hovered over a young pupil dutifully plunking out notes on a piano, wistfully eyeing the world beyond the parlor window.

title: BENEFITS
description: Hearts on Park

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, MAXINE STERN
description: JOSEPH-Maxine Stern. Age 81, passed away February 4, 2000 after a brief illness. She was the Medical Director for the Methadone program for the New York State Narcotics Addiction Control Commission. She was the beloved wife of the late S. Seymour Joseph, M.D. Loving mother and motherin-law to Marilyn Joseph and Warren Regelmann, cherished grandmother of Adam Gustave Regelmann and David Joseph Regelmann. Devoted sister to the late Frederic Stern, also survived by dear sister-in-law Diane Stern. Memorial services will be held in St. Paul, MN. Contributions are preferred to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association in memory of her late husband.

title: Climb the Walls, Hoist the Sails
description: THE year 2000 brings the arrival of at least 12 new ships, the refurbishment of older ones and the loss of at least one: Tall Ship Adventures' 82-year-old Sir Francis Drake, which vanished in Hurricane Lenny while secured to a cruise ship buoy in Marigot Bay off St. Martin without crew or passengers. Lenny had stalled there for three days, and when it passed no trace of the 165-foot, three-mast, 30-passenger Drake was found except a floating life raft.

title: For Indie Films, It's Get Thee Behind Me, Blockbuster
description: Quentin Tarantino once called Blockbuster Inc. ''the Great Satan,'' poised to annihilate the country's mom-and-pop video stores and the independent films they often carried. But now, Dean Wilson, the chief merchandising officer of Blockbuster, is eager to be the independent film industry's champion.

title: Planned Parenthood Gets Limited Permit
description: EMOTIONS on the abortion issue have run deep on Long Island for years. The front line is now Massapequa, in the Town of Oyster Bay, where Planned Parenthood struggled for months to open a new facility, before finally getting a permit on Wednesday.

title: Our Towns; Asserting Right to Bear LeSabres
description: MOTOR vehicle agencies everywhere are the bread lines of democracy -- maddening organizational beasts that demand much and offer little. But in New Jersey, the lines have grown longer, and the bread stale.

title: 'Navigating the Bias Minefield'
description: To the Editor:

title: Decorous Hulas and No Sequins
description: A ONE-WEEK American Hawaii Cruise among the Hawaiian Islands, calling at five ports on four islands, sounds like exactly the ticket for alleviating the winter drearies.

title: BackTalk; Outside the Norm: The Mind-Set of the Elite Athlete
description: Michael Miletic had recently finished his psychiatric residency when he was called to the bedside of a young National Hockey League player, barely conscious in intensive care, who had swallowed an overdose of sleeping pills, painkillers and antidepressants. He was near death when his fiancee found him.

title: The Retreat of French Art Began in Flanders Fields
description: PARISIANS awoke on the morning of Sept. 3, 1914, to stifling heat and a blitz of placards informing the ''Army of Paris, Citizens of Paris'' that the French government had fled. The German Army was 40 miles from the Champs-Elysees. For three days Parisians prepared to fight and die in the streets, and on the third day the Germans were halted at the Battle of the Marne, so close to town that 600 Paris taxicabs managed to rush troops to the front, come back for gas, and do it again.

title: Defining Black Dance, In Its Dizzying Variety
description: DANCE and music were considered the best ways of keeping slaves healthy and thus salable as they traveled to America in packed slave ships. ''The men could only jump up and rattle their chains but the women were driven in one among another all the while singing or saying words that had been taught them,'' an observer noted in 1789. ''But there was another time when the women were sitting by themselves, below, when I heard them singing other words and then always in tears. Their songs then always told the story of their lives and their grief at leaving their friends and country.''

title: U.S. Is Facing Wider Issues In Its Actions Over Austria
description: President Clinton's top foreign policy adviser says Washington's decision this week to impose diplomatic sanctions against Austria is driven partly by a desire to send a message that the United States will not stand by idly if other anti-immigrant, far-right parties try to join other coalition governments in Europe.

title: Cupid at the Water Cooler
description: The workplace can indeed be cozy. At some point in their careers, 59 percent of workers have had an office romance, according to a recent survey of 1,118 people by Vault.com, an online career information site.

title: A Race Card?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Trashy Art: That's the Point
description: AN artist known as Rayberry has made art from what other people throw away. ''A Day @ the Beach'' for example (pictured above), is compiled from debris he collected one August afternoon from a 50-yard-wide stretch of beach at Far Rockaway, Queens. His construction contains plastic golf balls and spoons, cigarette lighters, 12-gauge shotgun shells and more. Rayberry, who comes from South Carolina, calls this work a thought piece in the hopes that it will make people think before they litter the world. ''A Day @ the Beach'' is on view through Tuesday in a show called ''Rayberry $; America 1975-2000,'' a collection of 62 images that the artist feels reflect themes like global politics, the environment and technology. Rayberry says he uses the copyright symbol as his ''art-business name to express the educational, social and political rights of intellectual property invention for all visual artists of the future,'' and to reflect his concern that copyrights have become the currency of the digital age.

title: Knicks Look Dull
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ON THE (FROZEN) WATER WITH: THE ICEBOATERS; Speeding Across Water You Would Slip On
description: IT'S a combination of sights and sounds not heard on Long Island for five years: figures bundled against the cold, riding under taut sails aboard spindly wooden hulls on knife-sharp runners, flying across Lake Ronkonkoma and Mecox and Great South Bays with a rumble like the muted roar of far-off jets.

title: Learning to Think Smaller at Coke
description: AT Coca-Cola, Roberto C. Goizueta remains a legend, the chief executive whose vision and drive transformed the giant company into a global power. For his successor, M. Douglas Ivester, mastery of the inner workings of the Coke system could not make up for an uninterrupted streak of falling profits and personal faux pas.

title: Invigorating the Blues, And Growing a Label
description: IN a renovated colonial, where the garage once was, is the two-desk, one-computer office of a fledgling record company. The shipping department -- the front porch, overlooking a street specked with shrinking snowmen -- is filled with product awaiting UPS pickup.

title: Post Mergers: A Modest Proposal
description: IT'S not even Valentine's Day, but recording companies are getting mightly cuddly. Universal Music, owned by Seagram along with Universal's movie and television companies, swallowed Polygram in 1998, and late last year Time Warner announced plans to merge with America Online. Then in January, Time Warner announced it intended to take control of EMI Music. Meanwhile, reports continue to circulate that BMG is negotiating to buy Sony Music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, HAROLD M. (BOB)
description: ROBERTS-Harold M. (Bob), of New York City and Southampton, died on February 1, 2000. Loving husband to Jill Louise Curry. Most wonderful and cherished father of Stephanie Emma Bliss. His spirit will live in our hearts. He will be forever loved.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00: Word & Image; Plots for Hire
description: The politicians and propagandists who wage our war on drugs have really outdone themselves. After bloating the prisons and creating a vast antidrug industrial complex, they have now bribed our networks to deliver prime-time audiences for indoctrination and even corralled many newspapers as do-good collaborators.

title: An Extension of the Artist's Eye
description: IT is almost impossible to imagine a time when there were no photographs. Few may have painted with oils, used a chisel, etched a metal plate, worked a potter's wheel, or blown glass; but most have held a camera and snapped a shutter. There is an immediate understanding about the process of picture taking that makes photography one of the most accessible of all art forms.

title: After Much Delay, a Plan for Raymark Site
description: IT looks like the world's biggest parking lot. Just off Interstate 95 in Stratford, the 34-acre site where thousands of workers once produced brake linings and one of the best women's softball teams played is now paved over and vacant. But after years of delays, a massive cleanup of hazardous waste and several lawsuits, the area is about to become a mall.

title: The Many Ways to Treat a Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgical Stitches, in Style
description: Philip Guarascio, General Motors' vice president in charge of advertising and corporate marketing, is home recovering from triple-bypass surgery last Wednesday. Mr. Guarascio, 58, may not be a household name, but in the advertising world, he looms larger than a Chevrolet Suburban. He decides where General Motors spends its advertising dollars -- 2.1 billion of them in the first three quarters of last year alone, more than any other company.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article in this section on Jan. 23, about the life of a window washer, misstated the location of a building where he worked, the Luxembourg Mission to the United Nations. It is on Beekman Place, not Sutton Place.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: SKATEAWAY By Michael Grant Jaffe. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.

title: What No School Can Do
description: In every community, no matter how poor, there will be some children who are capable and desirous of learning. The real measure of a school is whether it can teach those children. The answer, all too often, is no.

title: Traffic-Slowing Measures In Bronx Fall Short . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: A Poster Boy On the Move
description: Joel Nasar is closing 3-D Art Inc., at 508 Broadway (between Spring and Broome Streets) in Lower Manhattan, after seven years. He is looking for a new location uptown or further downtown. Mr. Nasar's poster business, which includes contemporary and Pop Art originals from artists like Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein selling for about $100 to $10,000, has been in his family for more than 30 years in several locations. He said he needed to find an area frequented by tourists. ''People come to New York to buy this kind of art.'' ALLISON FASS

title: In the Footsteps Of the Impressionists
description: Paris, always a city for browsers, is even more so if you have in hand ''Impressionist Paris: The Essential Guide to the City of Light.'' Written by Julian More and published by Pavilion/Trafalgar Square ($19.95 for the paperback), the book provides detailed itineraries for 30 walks and drives in and around the city, along routes well worn by Monet, Manet, Cezanne, Pissarro, Sisley and their artistic brethren. It provides a way to see, or at least imagine, the charm and elegance of late 19th-century Paris through their eyes.

title: The Taste and Look of Italy in Mount Kisco
description: IN the daytime, Cafe Antico spills over with natural light. At night, however, the rooms are rendered in chiaroscuro, which indeed suggests the antique cafes across the Tiber. Flickering light from candelabra and blue votives, wrought-iron grilles, arched ceilings and dark velvets lend a shadowy, sacral quality to the place. The scene is intimate, even romantic, especially if one dines in a cozy corner of an alcove on the second floor.

title: Hustle and Tussle Mark Colgate 400
description: The 26th annual Colgate Women's Games at Madison Square Garden yesterday brought out the best and the worst in the youthful athletes.

title: Hearts of Darkness
description: Pieces of Light

title: Ha Jin's Cultural Revolution
description: On a bright fall morning in 1985, xuefei jin walked out of Logan airport in Boston and took his first real gulp of American air. It almost sent him to his knees. ''There is a unique American smell that hits you when you arrive here,'' he says. ''It is very sweet, like chemicals or a kind of perfume. It makes you sick for a while.'' Jin had flown from Beijing, a student visa stuffed into his pocket, to study American literature at Brandeis University. ''I know people who came here from Asia and vomited for days. They couldn't even brush their teeth because the water smelled so different.''

title: New Structure Symbolizes Mormon Growth
description: In October 1867, when the now-famous Mormon Tabernacle opened, members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints created a traffic jam of horse-drawn carts on nearby dirt streets as they arrived for the first church conference held within.

title: The View From/Norwalk; Schools Face Yet Another Challenge: Superintendent vs. Board
description: DEPENDING on who's talking, Dr. Victor Herbert, Norwalk's superintendent of schools, is either a dedicated, brave visionary, or an underhanded, obstinate monarch.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Eulogy For A Private Man

title: Amy Bamford, Michael Gallagher
description: Amy Katherine Bamford, the daughter of Barbara and George F. Bamford of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Patrick Gallagher, a son of Mary Kay and Michael E. Gallagher of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Path to the Top Job Is Biased
description: Look no further than the case of Art Shell and the New Orleans Saints to see why it so difficult for blacks to get head coaching jobs in the National Football League.

title: Alyse Graham, Colin Stretch
description: Alyse Graham and Colin Sullivan Stretch, lawyers in Washington, were married there last evening at Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Charles Zanoni performed the ceremony.

title: Yale Will Recreate Glenn Miller Concert
description: IN 1994, the Yale University Band packed Woolsey Hall on campus when more than 2,000 people attended its Glenn Miller tribute concert. This Friday, the band marches onto the same stage with a second installment, ''Glenn Miller Returns! Music of the Fight for Freedom.''

title: Jan. 30-Feb. 5; Atlanta Pitcher Suspended
description: Freedom of speech has its limits -- even for a baseball star. That message was loud and clear when Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, suspended the Atlanta Braves pitcher John Rocker for 73 days for making derogatory remarks about foreigners, gays and others. Rocker must also undergo ''sensitivity training'' and pay a fine of $20,000, but he will still draw his salary while he's on the sidelines. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREITAG, TAUSSIG, HERTA
description: FREITAG-TAUSSIG-Herta. A legendary, internationally renowned mathematician, died in Roanoke, VA, on January 25th, 2000. Her specialty had been research in Fibonacci's theories. She had this rare gift: combining a limitless enthusiasm for her subject with a remarkable talent to teach it, and even to inspire a love for it to anyone. She is survived by her brother, Walter Taussig, and his wife, Lore, of New York, and by her niece, Lynn Taussig, of San Francisco. All who knew her agree that she was-in addition to her scientific excellence-an outstanding and extraordinary person with fabulous charm; she will always be remembered with greatest love.

title: 'The Enduring Figure'
description: At the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers in New Brunswick, figures are full-blown and vital. ''The Enduring Figure 1890's-1970's'' features sculptors from the National Association of Women Artists, and is the kind of intensive survey this museum specializes in. Rutgers has a comprehensive collection of work by members of this organization, but this show was drawn from the collections of more than 25 galleries and individuals.

title: Designing a Medicare Drug Benefit
description: The recent decision by drug manufacturers to work with Congress and the White House to add a prescription drug benefit to Medicare this year is encouraging. It may even be what led President Clinton to forgo anticipated attacks on the industry's pricing practices in his State of the Union address. But it is premature to celebrate. Unless Congress passes the right kind of drug benefit -- generous and properly designed -- it could do future Medicare recipients more harm than good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAITMAN, MARGUERITE (PEGGY)
description: LAITMAN-Marguerite (Peggy). On February 4, 2000. Devoted daughter, sister and aunt. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: All This Talk of Alienation, Then Comes New Hampshire
description: Amy Handlin is a Monmouth County Freeholder with a gripe that more and more people in public life express these days: although voters complain, they don't care enough to get involved; they disapprove, but they don't pitch in.

title: SOAPBOX; Bee in Her Bonnet
description: THE admirable goal of raising money to improve the collection in Montclair's public school libraries was one factor in my organizing a team to compete in Montclair's first adult spelling bee on Jan. 28. But truly, it was the memory of my sixth-grade spelling victory. I remember missing a school day as I represented P.S. 222 in Brooklyn. I still recall the tension of the contest juxtaposed with the euphoria of lunch in a restaurant with my mother. Brandishing my Scripps Howard pen (my glorious prize), I returned to class the next day a celebrity. Whether it was the spelling bee or the absence without a medical excuse, I'll never know.

title: I Am Lawyer, Hear Me Whine
description: IN late December, a small Silicon Valley law firm, tired of losing lawyers to Internet start-ups, raised salaries for its associates by a remarkable 40 percent. Within a few weeks, larger firms in the Bay Area -- including some with offices in New York -- matched the raises. By last week, many prestigious New York firms felt compelled to follow suit and pay first-year lawyers as much as $140,000 a year before bonuses.

title: N.H.L. Goals Are Up, But Not TV Ratings
description: The family, friends and high school coach of Scott Gomez walked toward the white stretch limousine outside the elegant hotel. All had come from Alaska to see Gomez, the Devils rookie, in his first National Hockey League All-Star Game.

title: Protest Lit
description: Scar Vegas

title: Lives; The Orphans' War
description: Aysa, who is 8, fled Grozny three years ago after her father died and her mother disappeared. Since October, she has been staying with hundreds of other orphans and refugees near Ingushetia. Some old trains, in which the refugees sleep 54 to a car, provide temporary shelter.

title: Images With Roots in Asian Calligraphy
description: PETER ARAKAWA comes by his style naturally. His great-grandfather was calligrapher to the emperor of Japan, according to Evan Brownstein, owner of B. Beamesderfer, where Mr. Arakawa's work is being exhibited through Feb. 26.

title: ABUSE OF ELDERLY GROWS
description: Complaints of elder abuse and neglect filed against nursing homes and other long-term facilities doubled from 1996 to 1999, the state reported last week. The overall number of complaints, about a third of which are for abuse or neglect, rose from 2,445 to 4,778, according to the Office of the Ombudsman for the Institutionalized Elderly, which originally compiled the figures for The Courier-Post of Cherry Hill. Dennis McGowan, a spokesman for the State Department of Community Affairs, said the increase was partly due to rising numbers of people in extended-care facilities, and to a patients' rights awareness campaign.

title: A Long Way From Tipperary
description: THE MARRIAGE

title: It's Easy To Overdo Excess
description: HOW little does it take? How much can it bear? Guy Livingston played 36 one-minute piano pieces at the Miller Theater not long ago. A few days later, the young Arnold Schoenberg's ''Gurrelieder'' rattled through Carnegie Hall, pushing the envelope of size and length as it went.

title: Temperament Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Times For Restaurant Patrons
description: For the most part I agree with Patricia Brooks's comments on diners' rights, but I do offer one exception. I do not feel that a water glass should be filled unless requested by the patron. For the most part the glasses go back into the kitchen untouched. Since we frequently worry about droughts, dry conditions and water reserves, perhaps it would be just as nice to see a clean empty glass on the table waiting to be filled by request.

title: Moving Out of Bonds
description: Bond mutual funds experienced net redemptions of $12.8 billion in December, according to the Financial Research Corporation, a Boston consulting firm.

title: Shift to 'No-Kill' Shelters Leaves Towns Deluged by Strays
description: Dogs and cats do not just drop in at a private animal shelter here. First comes the appointment. Then the screening. And, if they are lucky, an invitation to stay. They must endure the indignity of having their tails yanked and their mouths pried open during the interview. If they hiss or claw or bite, they are shown the door.

title: When Red-Hot Mama Goes Marchin' In
description: As Julie Wilson has shown time and again in her cabaret shows, she can be everything from a flirtatious comic to a romantic tragedian to a spectral Kabuki-influenced clown twirling a feather boa and turning the nightclub stage into a ritualistic space. And in her gloriously playful new show, ''Julie Wilson in Dixieland,'' the 70-something singer reveals still another side of her musical personality.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: EVENTS

title: Rights Group Says NATO Killed 500 Civilians in Kosovo War
description: The NATO air campaign in Kosovo led to the deaths of 500 civilians in 90 separate attacks, more incidents than the Pentagon has acknowledged but a much lower toll than Yugoslavia said, according to a human rights study issued today that documents each incident and lists the names of the victims.

title: Nets' Kittles Listens Up And Lets Loose
description: There was no telling how Kerry Kittles would respond to the disparaging comments his coach made about him on Saturday.

title: Winstar Chooses Margeotes/Fertitta
description: Winstar Communications, a telecommunications company, has named Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York, which is majority owned by the MDC Communications Corporation, as its agency of record. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Out of Africa, but Not Out of Character
description: AUnited States Embassy employee held up a sign during the Davis Cup doubles match here Saturday. It said: ''Hi Mom. Send Diesel.''

title: Clifford H. Keene, 89, Surgeon And Kaiser Permanente Chief
description: Dr. Clifford H. Keene, a health care executive who helped build the Kaiser Permanente system of staff doctors, hospitals and clinics into the nation's largest nonprofit provider of health care, died Jan. 25 at the Hospice of the Central Coast Counties in Monterey, Calif. He was 89.

title: A Portrait in Words For a Wordless Artist
description: ''Words don't cut it. That's another reason I don't talk too much.''

title: Journal Escalates Battle With British Rival
description: The Wall Street Journal, long an also-ran to The Financial Times in the competition for European consumers of financial news, has begun marketing its way across the Continent to challenge its rival's dominance -- and The Financial Times is responding in kind.

title: Women as Firefighters
description: To the Editor:

title: Brill Editor Is Wearing Two Hats, One Electronic
description: His new job was only hours old, but already the editor in chief of Brill's Content was promising ''evolution, not revolution'' at the magazine that offers a sober leveling gaze at the media industry.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVY, SENATOR NORMAN
description: LEVY-Senator Norman. February 7, 1998. I think of you every moment of every day with such love and wonderful memories. Your kind deeds and generosity touched the lives of so many and will never be forgotten. Your goodness and kindness will last forever. Your loving wife, Joy

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROER, EDWIN
description: ROER-Edwin. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Edwin Roer, and extend to his bereaved wife Dorothy and the members of his family our sincere condolences. Jeffrey Citron, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: GQ's Cover War May Be a Pyrrhic Battle
description: GQ magazine, Conde Nast's sophisticated men's magazine, has been known for its quiet good taste in fashion, snappy fiction by James Ellroy, intelligent food writing by Alan Richman, thoughtful essays by Andrew Corsello.

title: Virtual Publishing: From Arthur Clarke To Psoriasis Tales
description: The demand for Arthur C. Clarke's science fiction novel about a malevolent computer named HAL has endured for three decades, but interest was rather tepid for the author's six-page, double-spaced essay about ''TV's Time-Travel Future.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, JOHN FRANCIS
description: HOGAN-John Francis. On February 4, 2000, at age 89. Oakwood School 1928, Fordham Class 1936, WWII Captain in Army of the United States, and past Commander Ad Men's Post #

title: Car Theft and Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Assured Elsewhere, McCain Worries in Arizona
description: There is a history in presidential campaigns of candidates' winning their home state primaries by hefty margins, often by more than 40 percentage points. Outsiders seldom can overcome the ''favorite son'' factor.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Launch
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton officially started her candidacy for the Senate yesterday with a polished speech designed to reintroduce her to New Yorkers as a capable campaigner. Her confident delivery struck a sharp contrast with the gaffes of last fall. President Clinton's silent role fit with a plan to present the first lady as someone with an independent identity as a lawyer and child advocate who nonetheless will carry on his political causes. Having endured months of questioning about her political skills, Mrs. Clinton will get good reviews for this political performance, which probably explains why Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's campaign immediately attacked the ''Hollywood'' staging of the event in Purchase, N.Y.

title: A Peaceful Raid Ends Students' Long Siege in Mexico
description: Forcing a sudden end to a nine-month student strike, hundreds of federal police officers took over the main campus of the national university today and arrested more than 600 students who had occupied Latin America's largest center for higher learning.

title: To China via India
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing by Europe's New Ground Rules Gave Vodafone a Victory
description: The words came quietly, spoken without a hint of threats or gloating: ''Klaus, you're going to lose.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAMULARE, ETHEL
description: FAMULARE-Ethel. On February 6, 2000, at the age of 74. Loving wife to R. Anthony. Devoted mother of Dr. Charles I. Famulare. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. Services Tuesday, February 8, at 12 PM, at Congregation Beth Shalom, Babylon, NY.

title: Philip Jones, 71, Trumpeter And Music Educator in Britain
description: Philip Jones, a leading British trumpeter and a music educator, died on Jan. 17. He was 71 and lived in London and Switzerland.

title: McEnroe and Americans Save Their Best for Last
description: The American no one expected to faint almost did, and the one who many believed would shrink stood tall.

title: The Durable Expansion
description: Economic expansions do not die of old age. The current expansion, the longest in recorded history, will not end from exhaustion. A nine-year-old expansion is no more likely to end than a two-year-old expansion. Indeed, the term business cycle is a misnomer. Recoveries and recessions do not occur in regular cycles. There are ups and downs but no pattern.

title: Jerry Springer on People, Internet and Chewing Gum
description: To hear Jerry Springer talk about the impact of the Internet, you would think the future was already here. And the future looks a lot like Mr. Springer's television show.

title: In the Slaying of a Columbia Student, Mourning and Mystery
description: They clung to one another in the stricken, uncomprehending manner of young people confronting death for the first time.

title: Army's Newest Objective Is Livable Family Housing
description: For Amanda Rowan, wife of an Army staff sergeant, just as for Sgt. Flora Wilson, housing on this base is the worst part of military life.

title: She Sidled Up to a Man's World and Made It Hers
description: No, I must disagree with Woody Allen: Mae West is a comic genius. He rated her just below Chaplin and Keaton in a recent interview, and it's true that she lacks their near-infinite physical variety. She's a physical minimalist whose comedy depends on words that incessantly praise and mock her own deeds.

title: Retooling to Portray Bush As the Real Man of Action
description: Hoping to steal some of Senator John McCain's thunder, Gov. George W. Bush is poised to argue that Mr. McCain has made little to no headway in his battle against the sway of special interests in government and that Mr. Bush has accomplished much more in this regard, advisers to Mr. Bush said today.

title: Haider Opens Old Wound Over Germans Czechs Ousted
description: Jorg Haider, the rightist leader whose Freedom Party is part of the new Austrian government, said today that ethnic Germans expelled from what was Czechoslovakia at the end of World War II should be entitled to the same compensation as Austrian Jews persecuted by the Nazis.

title: Sports of The Times; In an Era of Hyperbole, People Can Go Adrift
description: MIKE JARVIS, the head basketball coach at St. John's University, is one of a handful of big-time college basketball coaches who takes his role as an educator seriously. But after Saturday's narrow victory over Boston College, Jarvis used his position and podium to lambaste the National Collegiate Athletic Association for its investigation of Erick Barkley, the sensational point guard who was declared ineligible by the university for an N.C.A.A. rules violation.

title: Still Striving to Hit a Long Ball
description: Mike Schmidt was ready to tee off at the 10th hole of the Royal Caribbean Classic when someone yelled, ''Mike, you can't play every sport.''

title: N.B.A. Finds Minimal Use Of Marijuana In First Tests
description: Richard Dumas, who was suspended for drug and alcohol abuse by the National Basketball Association twice in the early 1990's, once said that if the league ever tested players for marijuana, ''there wouldn't be no N.B.A.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SICHERMAN, ARANKA
description: SICHERMAN - Aranka. Died peacefully in her 92nd year on February 6, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Morris; cherished mother of Lorraine Whitman Check and husband Ron; devoted grandmother of Michael and Adam Whitman; dear sister of Mike and Ernie Funk. Service held at graveside.

title: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and the government's quarterly refunding including five-year notes, 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.

title: St. John's Takes a Day Off But Only From Practicing
description: On Saturday St. John's earned a 59-58 victory over Boston College without Erick Barkley, who had been declared ineligible by St. John's after the National Collegiate Athletic Association said the star guard had violated an N.C.A.A. rule. After the game, in a fiery news conference, the school's athletic officials expressed their frustration with the N.C.A.A. and now they wait for college sports' governing board to rule whether Barkley will play tomorrow when the Red Storm plays Providence.

title: NatWest Says It Wants to Stay Independent
description: National Westminster Bank, Britain's third-biggest bank, indicated today that it was determined to remain independent even as its biggest shareholders prepared to side with one of two hostile bids by Scottish rivals.

title: New Era Approaches: Gigabyte Chips
description: To a gigahertz and beyond.

title: CLINTON, IN BUDGET, SEEKS TO BOLSTER MEDICARE PROGRAM
description: President Clinton on Monday will submit a $1.84 trillion federal budget for next year and will call for using much of the projected budget surplus over the next decade to strengthen and expand the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly, administration officials said today.

title: Gore and the Politics of Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Ah, a Subway Station Grows in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCTIGUE, THOMAS V.
description: McTIGUE-Thomas V. Born June 7, 1911; died February 4, 2000. Last guy on the block from Hell's Kitchen. A true New Yorker. A page of New York history is closing. Beloved husband of the late Margaret J. (nee Gallagher). Dear father of Patricia Dorsey and Thomas B. Loving grandfather of Margaret, Thomas, Patricia, Thomas A., Terrence, and Kerry Ann. Cherished great-grandfather of five. Reposing Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway at 214th St., NYC, Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Good Shepherd R.C. Church, Thursday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENSON, LEONARD H.
description: GOLDENSON-Leonard H. Founder and Chairman of the Board of ABC, Inc., 1953-1986, died in Sarasota, Florida on December 27, 1999 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife, Isabelle Weinstein Goldenson, his two daughters, Loreen Arbus and Maxine Goldenson, both of Los Angeles, and one grandson, Lucas. A Memorial Service will be held Friday, February 11, 10:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. Contributions can be made in his memory to The Dr. William Berenberg Fund for Handicapped Children, C/O Children's Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

title: The Bush Comeback
description: A tradition in this space has been to exhort flattened candidates to get off the floor. Ten tips for George W. Bush to become the latest ''Comeback Kid'':

title: INSIDE
description: Mexico Seizes Campus

title: Review/Fashion; Puff Daddy's Cut: 'Not Too Baggy, Not Too Tight'
description: He is all of 29, likes diamonds, occasionally swears, wears a rosary, and let's not forget the matter of his indictment on charges of possession illegal handguns or, for sheer tabloid value, whether he is still involved with the actress Jennifer Lopez. Life isn't easy for Sean Combs, music mogul and aspiring fashion star. But he's persevering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOUDEMIRE, ALAN, M.D.
description: STOUDEMIRE-Alan, M.D., 49, of Atlanta, GA, on February 2nd, 2000. It is with profound sadness that the Board of Directors of the Society for Liaison Psychiatry mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague, Alan Stoudemire, M.D., after his second valiant battle with cancer. He was a leader in our field and an example to us all. We offer our condolences to his wife, Susan, and his children, William and Anna. Donations in his memory may be sent to Children's HealthCare of Atlanta, 1680 Tullie Circle, Atlanta, GA 30329.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN BOKKELEN, SALLY
description: VAN BOKKELEN-Sally. 77, on February 3, 2000 in Bradenton, FL, formerly of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, NY, and Remsenburg, L.I., NY. Survived by her sister Virginia of Bradenton and brother Libertus of Nevada. Memorial donations may be sent to St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31 St., NYC, NY 10001.

title: This Week's Equity Offerings
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Officials Identify Rikers Inmate Who Died
description: A teenager who died after being found unconscious in his cell at Rikers Island was identified yesterday by the City Department of Correction.

title: First Woman Is Elected Governor in Japan
description: A former civil servant from Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's party today became the first woman to win a governorship in Japan in a race seen here as an important gauge of support for Mr. Obuchi.

title: A Rare Evening With Enescu, Not Without Perils
description: The American Symphony Orchestra's annual season at Avery Fisher Hall is an exercise in listener frustration. The programs are so fascinating, they cannot be ignored; the execution of those programs sends one home despondent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, PETER (FRANK L., JR.)
description: THOMPSON-Peter (Frank L., Jr.). 59, of New York City, died suddenly February 4, 2000. Pianist, arranger, musical director. Loving husband of Lanie Dommu; brother of Marilee and David Thompson and the late Edward Thompson; brother-in-law of James Bialek and Judy and Michael Guthman; uncle of several nieces and nephews. His remarkable musical gifts enriched the lives of those he touched in his native St. Louis, as well as Aspen, Dallas and New York. His generous spirit will forever be remembered by his friends, and the donation of his time and talent to many causes in the community will long be appreciated. Private interment. Memorial serivce to be announced. Contributions can be made to Cancer Care, 275 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10001, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Forever Linked to Clinton, Ferociously Loyal to McCain
description: HE has been signing autographs for the past year, but Lindsey Graham knew he became a celebrity for sure just last week. Not everybody, after all, is invited to a celebrity quail hunt.

title: Pfizer Approves $90 Billion Deal for Warner-Lambert
description: Pfizer's board of directors voted last night to buy Warner-Lambert for more than $90 billion in stock, and Warner-Lambert's board was expected to follow suit, people close to the companies said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOKAYER, EDITH
description: TOKAYER-Edith. Of Riverdale, NY, and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved mother, sister, aunt, died on February 5, due to complications from Alzheimer's Disease. She was 81 years old. She was a graduate of Hunter College and an elementary school teacher in the Bronx for more than 30 years. Member of Brandeis Women. Dear wife of the late Barney L. Survived by her loving children, Marilyn, Douglas and daughter-inlaw Susan; sister Thelma; nieces Debra and Linda; nephews Eric and Jonathan. Services will be at Riverside Chapel in Mt. Vernon, NY, on Monday, February 7, at 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimer's Association appreciated. Family will receive friends at 158 Ogden Ave, Dobbs Ferry.

title: Big Kickbacks Under Kohl Reported
description: Prosecutors estimate that more than $70 million was illegally paid in kickbacks to middlemen on the sales of tanks and a dilapidated oil refinery during the rule of Helmut Kohl, the former chancellor whose once glowing reputation has already been battered by revelations of secret party financing.

title: 2 to Testify of Interruption In Gunfire in Diallo Killing
description: The trial of the police officers charged with the murder of Amadou Diallo will resume Monday, with at least two more people who were near Mr. Diallo's apartment building on Wheeler Avenue that night expected to say they heard a pause in the volley of shots that killed him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ISOBEL (NEE LESSER)
description: MARCUS-Isobel (nee Lesser). Of Hackensack, NJ (formerly of Forest Hills, NY). Beloved wife of the late Mortimer; devoted mother of Susan E. Berg and Victor A. Marcus; dear sister of Evelyn Just, Norma Steinberg and the late Mildred Meshberg, Dorothy Frieder, Rubin Lesser and Helen Lesser. Loving grandmother of Stacey Bieber and Stephen Marcus; adoring great-grandmother of Max, Jake and Andie Bieber. Graveside service Monday, 1 PM, at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions to American Cancer Society.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Patents; Measuring pain on a universal scale, and comparing it with the pain of fellow sufferers.
description: PAIN is a very personal experience, but it soon may be possible for one person to evaluate another's discomfort. Some doctors, scientists and researchers believe there is a pattern to pain that can be rated on a universal scale.

title: Ewing Is Knicks' Center of Attention
description: All of the painstaking steps Patrick Ewing has made toward his rebirth as a dominating center became much more critical yesterday after tests revealed Marcus Camby partly tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee during the Knicks' 94-80 victory over Miami yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: 2 Moonlighting Officers Are Accused of Theft
description: Two police officers who were working off-duty as security guards for a Harlem clothing store were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing $11,000 worth of merchandise from their employer, the police said.

title: BRADLEY CONCEDES HE'S GOT ALL EGGS IN MARCH 7 BASKET
description: Bill Bradley said flatly today that he must win primaries in several states on the next big day of voting, March 7. And to do so, he said, he must sell his agenda more powerfully to hard-core Democrats who streamed to Vice President Al Gore in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary.

title: Report Rings Alarm Bells About Privacy On the Internet
description: A report last week that most health-related Web sites were not honoring their promises to keep personal information about visitors private offered a somewhat alarming snapshot of the state of privacy on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTULLO, G. ROBSON
description: PATTULLO-G. Robson, 49, died peacefully on February 3, 2000 in New York City. Cherished friend and husband of Susan. Beloved father of Claire. Devoted son of Elizabeth and Pat Pattullo, brother of Betsy, Ann, Greg and Ronald. Uncle of Jess, Gabe, Alissa and Sasha. Associated for nearly 25 years with ABC News. A joyous light in the lives of all who knew him. Funeral services will be held in Winchester, MA. A memorial celebration in New York City will follow. Donations in Rob's memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Big Men Switch Roles
description: The Knicks once turned to Marcus Camby as their safety net when Patrick Ewing partly tore his left Achilles' tendon during last year's conference finals, and they found enough energy in their young forward's effort to sustain them for a ride to the National Basketball Association finals.

title: Another Transition For America's Cup As Italy Celebrates
description: When the sleek, silver sloop representing Italy's Prada Challenge skimmed across the finish line Sunday to win the Louis Vuitton challenger series and the right to face Team New Zealand for the America's Cup, it set off a symphony of honking air horns and unrestrained cheers, beginning a celebration that shook the Auckland waterfront until the wee hours.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Man in Queens Stabbing
description: Two police officers fatally shot a Queens man Saturday morning as he was stabbing his girlfriend with a 12-inch knife, the police said yesterday.

title: Jakarta Journal; Indonesia's Chinese Win a Happy New Year at Last
description: Two years ago Sri Hariati hid in a bedroom as rioters shouted and burned buildings in Jakarta's Chinatown. This weekend the noise and crowds and smoke told a very different story: for the first time in more than 30 years, Indonesia's Chinese were allowed to celebrate their New Year in public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ELAINE
description: SMITH-Elaine. On February 4. Loving mother of Andrea, mother-in-law of James, grandmother of Michael. Service private.

title: Rutgers Men Upset Seton Hall to Win
description: Rutgers upset Seton Hall, the defending champion, in the men's division, but Seton Hall won the women's title last night in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in northern Manhattan. Rutgers edged its New Jersey rival, 119-115, for the men's crown, while the Lady Pirates decisively outscored the runner-up, Columbia, 186-155.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, JOSEPHINE
description: RAYMOND-Josephine. February 4, 2000. Beloved wife of Dana. Loving mother of Catherine, Peter and John. Cherished grandmother of David, Nicholas, Anne, Jane, John, Kaila and Briana. Devoted sister of Gerard. Her spirit and energy will live on with us always. Memorial service Friday, February 11, 3 PM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St.

title: Sitcom Icons, Pushing 60, Can't Shake Their 30's
description: Television characters age differently from other fictional people, and not only because in Hollywood cosmetic surgery is more common than tap water. In endless reruns characters repeat the same actions and recite the same words until we know them by heart. You would have to be insanely obsessed with a book or movie to have its characters seared in the memory as precisely as Archie Bunker is, forever telling Edith to stifle herself, or Samantha Stephens twitching her nose.

title: 3 Acquisitions Will Complete Sterling Forest
description: For decades, environmentalists dreamed of acquiring and preserving for all time the vast, privately owned tracts of beguiling woodlands, rugged ridges, hiking trails and crystalline streams and lakes known as Sterling Forest, 40 miles northwest of New York City.

title: A Smooth Road to the Death House
description: Regardless of the extent of compassion in his ''compassionate conservatism,'' Gov. George W. Bush of Texas could show some concern for justice by following the example of his presidential campaign chairman in Illinois, Gov. George Ryan, who last week announced a moratorium on executions in his state.

title: Hearing Loss, but Now Not Loss of Opportunity
description: When she was growing up in Honduras, Maria Bustamante never went to school. When she was older, she never held a job. Because she is deaf, those around her thought Ms. Bustamante was incapable of work, and they did not see a need to educate her. She spent most of her time doing housework with her mother.

title: Speaking of the Speaker
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REHBINDER, MICHEL
description: REHBINDER-Michel. Died January 5, after a prolonged illness which he faced with usual great courage. Surviving: his wife, cousin, nieces, nephews, step-daughter, step-grandson with family, and friends. Michel's warmth, kindness and humor will be greatly missed. Memorial service Sunday, February 13, after Mass at Cathedral Our Lady, 93 and Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, FLORENCE M.
description: BRILL-Florence M., on February 4, 2000, devoted wife for 56 years of the late Jerome; loving, proud and generous mother of Judy and Jerry, Arthur and Carol, and Connie and Jerry; doting grandmother of Irene, Robert, Jonathan, Paul, and Matthew; delighted greatgrandmother of Sophie; caring and affectionate aunt, friend and confidant. She loved and was loved by so many for nearly nine decades. An attorney, she lived a wonderful and bountiful life, brimmed full of education, artistic talent and, above all, family. Services will be private.

title: S. J. Silberman, 84, Executive And New York Philanthropist
description: Samuel J. Silberman, a philanthropist and former cigar manufacturing executive, died on Jan. 29 in Manhattan. He was 84 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, HARRIET
description: FALK-Harriet. Of Leonia, NJ. Died peacefully in her sleep on February 6, 2000. Wife of the late Norman K. Falk. Mother of Adam, Abigail, David, Michael and Penelope. Sister of Herbert Krane. Graveside service Monday at 11 AM, at the Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ. For information, call ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 800-522-0588.

title: Sharpton Seeks Debate on Race Issues
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton called on Vice President Al Gore yesterday to debate former Senator Bill Bradley on race and urban issues, and he hinted that he would encourage black voters in New York to support Mr. Bradley if Mr. Gore did not do so.

title: A Vain Call for Help, as Serbs Killed His Wife
description: Gani Gjaka buried his wife Nerimane today, laying her shrouded body in a muddy field on the southern edge of this tense and bitterly divided town, where Mrs. Gjaka was one of the eight Albanian victims of an eruption of violence by local Serbs.

title: Quiz Show's Popularity Makes It a Weapon
description: ABC has begun using its game show hit, ''Who Wants to Be A Millionaire,'' as a club, slotting it against potential hits on other networks to squash them. The competing networks charge that the slash-and-burn tactic could threaten the health of the broadcast business.

title: Washington Leads No. 10 Knights in Rout
description: Carlita Washington had been waiting all season to make an impact for Rutgers.

title: Another Glass Ceiling
description: The bad news is that 16 percent of the women in this country and 17 percent of the men say they would not vote for a woman for president.

title: Clinton, Tottenville Win Boys and Girls
description: Clinton and Tottenville swept the boys and girls team titles yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League borough championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIEBRUGGE, JANE
description: NIEBRUGGE-Jane. Of Westboro, MA, formerly of New York City. February 4. Age 91. Sister of Ruth Fiero of Westboro. Services Thursday, 11 AM, at The Willows, 1 Lyman St, Westboro. Donations to National Wildlife Federation.

title: Correction
description: An obituary of Carl Albert, a former speaker of the House, in The Times yesterday misstated the year of his birth in some copies. He was born in 1908, not 1905.

title: Things Besides Music May Be Afoot
description: Riccardo Muti was a familiar presence in New York during his dozen years at the helm of the Philadelphia Orchestra, and he has visited since then with the Vienna Philharmonic and with La Scala's orchestra and chorus, which he has directed since 1986. He also made an auspicious if belated debut with the New York Philharmonic a year ago, and quickly found his way onto the short list of conductors being considered to succeed Kurt Masur as music director. There have been contradictory reports of Mr. Muti's status on that list. One published account asserted that he turned down a $1 million offer. But the official word from the Philharmonic and Mr. Muti's representatives is that no offers have been made, and that neither side has yet ruled out the prospect.

title: An 18-Minute View With a New Image
description: With an 18-minute video that was a cross between a political campaign commercial and a home-produced episode of ''This Is Your Life,'' Hillary Rodham Clinton sought yesterday to influence how New Yorkers view her beyond the imagery of her as first lady of the United States, by offering a complex portrait of her as a woman, a lawyer, and a mother.

title: Mayor Has Busy Morning On 5 TV News Programs
description: Long before Hillary Rodham Clinton took the stage yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had spent hours in interviews, hopping from one television studio to another to promote his Senate candidacy on five morning news programs, and then tending to mayoral obligations including a hospital party for children with heart problems.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOHMAN, GERTRUDE
description: LOHMAN-Gertrude. Beloved sister and aunt. Lovingly remembered. Lillian, Vivian, Richard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, MARLA KACE

Services Monday, 1 PM, from Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Rd, Westport, CT. Memorial contributions to Cancer Hope Network of Chester, NJ. Always a beautiful woman. You will be dearly missed.

title: For An Open Ballot
description: To the Editor:

description: LEVY-Rose. On February 5, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Dear sister of the late Teddy, Julius, and Justin Morgenroth. Loving aunt of Steven Morgenroth and Lynn Morgenroth Friedman and the late Marty Morgenroth. Loving great-aunt of Teddy, Jon, Marty, Julie, Carolyn and the late Stacy. Memorial sevice Monday, 4 PM, at Rose Levy's home.

title: Outsiders Share Lead; Woods in Hunt
description: After the fog lifted at Pebble Beach today, nobody gained a clear advantage.

title: GOLDEN OPPORTUNITY: A special report.; Brooklyn Boom In Elderly Care Is Laid to Fraud
description: The clients would come in shifts, morning, noon and night. Mostly older Russian immigrants, they would step down from ambulettes and into one of two Parkshore adult day care centers in Brooklyn to use the beauty parlors, watch Russian-language television and dine on food specifically chosen to attract them: herring, gefilte fish and borscht.

title: Koch Finds a New Calling in a Consumer Legal Site
description: Compressed Data: Koch Finds a New Calling in a Consumer Legal Site

title: Jorg Haider's Other Message
description: Jorg Haider, leader of the Austrian Freedom Party, smirks a lot and wears flashy loden suits. He also trawls in the same rank pool of populist fears and resentments -- mainly of foreigners who ''swamp'' the nation, ''steal our jobs,'' have criminal habits, and so on -- as Jean-Marie Le Pen in France, the Republicans in Germany, unsavory fringes of the Conservative Party in Britain, and Pat Buchanan in the United States.

title: E-Commerce Report; Critics Press Legal Assault On Tracking Of Web Users
description: DOUBLECLICK, a company that tracks consumers as they make their way around the Web, has never been popular with privacy advocates. In recent weeks, though, mere tension has grown into all-out war with the announcement that the company has begun adding information about consumers' offline behavior to its huge database.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Now I know, some people are asking why I'm doing this, here and now. And that's a fair question. Here's my answer, and why I hope you'll put me to work for you: I may be new to the neighborhood, but I'm not new to your concerns.''

title: It's Official: First Lady Is Now Candidate Clinton
description: With her husband seated as a mere onlooker at the rear of the stage, Hillary Rodham Clinton declared her candidacy for the United States Senate this afternoon, presenting herself as a ''new Democrat'' who views government as neither the cause of nor the solution to the nation's problems.

title: Clinton to Seek Big Increase in Funds to Fight Child Labor Abroad
description: President Clinton plans to ask Congress to more than double the nation's spending on reducing child labor overseas, administration officials said yesterday.

title: A Young Quartet From Berlin, Notable for Maturity
description: Given the number of fledgling, often worthy string quartets that are trying to gain a footing in a terribly competitive field, it is difficult for a new ensemble to stand out. The Artemis Quartet, which made its New York debut at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night, is an exciting exception. The musicians, three Germans and one Russian, met as students in Lubeck, Germany, 10 years ago and are now based in Berlin. This concert was part of their second American tour.

title: Weaving a Future From Old Threads; Connecticut Town Ties History And High-Tech in Comeback Plan
description: History in this battered eastern Connecticut city has long been both a curse and an opportunity.

title: Moxley Murder Case Is a Circumstantial Challenge for Prosecutors
description: It took a quarter-century for the police to make an arrest in the killing of Martha Moxley, the 15-year-old Greenwich girl bludgeoned to death with a golf club on the evening of Oct. 30, 1975.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUELER, C. RICHARD
description: SCHUELER-C. Richard. 77, of Brookline, MA and Camden, ME. Beloved husband of Gay (Esdale) and proud father of Linda, Leila, Molly, Charlie, Jenny and Liz; sister of Barbara Lowry; two stepsons: Stephen and Kenneth Chipman and eight grandchildren. Died of leukemia, peacefully at home, February 4. Graduate of Andover and Princeton. Founder of John Douglas, Inc. and C.R. Schueler and Co. Service Thursday at 11AM, Church of the Redeemer, Chestnut Hill, MA. Family requests contributions to the C. Richard Schueler Scholarship Fund, Phillips Academy, Andover, MA 01810.

title: The Bures Talk, and Play, a Great All-Star Game
description: Jaromir Jagr, Pavel Bure, Paul Kariya and Eric Lindros spent most of Friday on a frozen pond an hour and a half from here, filming a television spot with Gordie Howe, Wayne Gretzky and Mario Lemieux.

description: JENKINS-Jane L. On February 3, 2000 at age 81. Beloved wife of the late William Jenkins and loving mother of the late Steven Jenkins.

description: STOGEL-Philip. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of Yale and Leslie, Lawrence and Debra. Cherished grandfather of Chase, Chad and Alison. Dear brother of Sanford and the late Dorothy Fagelman. Services at the Hebrew Institute of White Plains, 20 Greenridge Ave, White Plains, NY, today, at 12 noon. Donations can be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Unable to Trade Top Pick, MetroStars Pull a Surprise
description: The MetroStars' reward for finishing last in Major League Soccer this past season was to have the first choice in the league's first Super Draft, staged yesterday in Florida. The MetroStars were hoping to trade the pick, but they failed to make any deals to help the struggling team and instead made a surprise pick, the U.C.L.A. defender Steve Shak.

title: Accounts
description: * 3DO, Redwood City, Calif., a video game publisher, to Towne Silverstein Rotter, New York and Carlsbad, Calif., to handle its account, which had been at Publicis & Hal Riney, San Francisco, part of Publicis S.A. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $35 million.

title: William S. Heckscher, Historian Of Art and Museum Director, 94
description: William S. Heckscher, a German-born art historian who fled Hitler's Germany and became a professor at Duke University and the director of its art museum, died on Nov. 27 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 94.

title: Gore and the Politics of Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DACHS, MARTIN R.
description: DACHS-Martin R. Of Somers, NY. Age 73 years. Died Saturday, February 5, 2000. He is survived by his wife Janet.

description: * Neil Fox, chairman and chief executive at Lowe Fox Pavlika, New York, the direct marketing subsidiary of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, is leaving. A successor is being sought. Lowe Lintas is part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, MARY JANE
description: KENNY-Mary Jane. On February 3, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late William Francis and Mary Ellen Hickey Kenny. Survived by her beloved nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday, February 11, 5-7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, February 12, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, NY.

title: Procter & Gamble tries a new approach in spots for Pampers.
description: THE push by the Procter & Gamble Company to improve the creativity of its advertising accelerates today with a campaign for one of its most important products, Pampers.

title: Gold Rush In Silicon Alley; Venture Capital Moves East
description: It was the sort of ''elevator pitch'' that Timothy C. Draper listens to impatiently every day -- a business plan breathlessly delivered.

title: Argentine Heat Near The Icy Hudson
description: Julio Bocca was the most retiring of international ballet stars on Thursday night, when he and his Ballet Argentino appeared at the World Financial Center Winter Garden. But Mr. Bocca knew what he was doing. His natural charisma as a performer illuminated the immaculate training, youthful charm and enjoyably straightforward dancing of the company, which appeared as part of the free Celebrate Buenos Aires festival at the center.

title: Israeli Killed in Lebanon, Spurring Calls to Retaliate
description: An Israeli soldier was killed and seven were wounded today in southern Lebanon in the latest of a series of deadly guerrilla attacks that have intensified pressure on Prime Minister Ehud Barak to mount a significant retaliatory strike.

title: After Tudjman, Croatia May Look to a Low-Key Leader
description: Croatia votes on Monday for only its second president in a tightening race that hinges more on personality than on policy. But after the death in December of the autocratic Franjo Tudjman, who ruled Croatia from its independence in 1991, voters seem likely to choose the man who has presented himself as least ambitious and power hungry, the avuncular Stipe Mesic, 65.

title: Classified Material: Handle With Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Industry View; Smart appliances may be offering some features that now seem silly, but every technology has to start someplace.
description: JUST how smart are the designers of ''smart'' appliances, when it comes to meeting the needs of modern people like me -- technically inclined, but harboring no dreams of connecting their coffee pots to the Internet or having live stock quotes scroll across a liquid crystal display on their refrigerators?

title: Classified Material: Handle With Care
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Surprise Review By Compaq Computer
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation has unexpectedly placed in review its worldwide advertising account, with billings estimated at $250 million to $300 million. The assignment has been handled by DDB Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, which will take part in the review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, JANET
description: KRAUS-Janet. We mourn the loss of our dear and dedicated colleague. Janet was a wonderful person who never had an unkind word to say about anyone. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Tony, to her children Tom and Joanne, to her son-in-law Peter, to her four loving grandchildren, and to her brother, Leonard. We will miss our good friend. May God be with her always! Tishman Speyer Properties

title: Jeter Hopes to Stick Around for a While
description: If he needed to make it official, Derek Jeter got the proof last night. Jeter, the Yankees' shortstop, received the Joe DiMaggio Toast of the Town award at the 77th annual dinner for the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America. He told the crowd at the Sheraton New York -- and the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner -- that he wanted to stay that way.

title: Unofficial but Hard-Won Title
description: The February issue of the magazine of the American Contract Bridge League announces that Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., has won the unofficial title of Player of the Decade. The editors arrived at this conclusion by counting major national titles won in the 1990's. Meckstroth's regular partner, Eric Rodwell, finished a close second.

title: Voting Rights Undermined
description: In a deeply troubling voting rights decision last month, the Supreme Court greatly weakened a powerful tool that the federal government has long used to end racial discrimination in voting rights. The tool, known as ''preclearance,'' has acted as an important deterrent to efforts by local communities to change their voting laws in ways that could discriminate against minority voters.

title: Magazines Make McCain Man of the Hour; Bush Aides Watch the Clock
description: The publicity avalanche set off by his New Hampshire victory swept Senator John McCain onto the covers of the three national newsweeklies yesterday, a rare journalistic hat trick that capped a week of the kind of attention that might make a Nobel Prize winner or even a Person of the Century feel a little underexposed.

title: Richardson's 27 Lift Flying Dutchmen
description: Norman Richardson scored a career-high 27 points and Speedy Claxton came up with several big plays when Hofstra took the lead for good in an 82-70 victory over Delaware yesterday in Hempstead, N.Y., the Flying Dutchmen's ninth straight victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, STEPHEN M.
description: ROBERTS-Stephen M. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted father of Alyssa. Loving son of Natalie and the late Dr. Daniel Rosenberg. Dearest brother of Bob and Marni Rosenberg and Jayne and Marshall Bohrer. Dearest companion of Susan Popko. With love & kisses Bubba and Blondie. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to the American Cancer Society or North Shore Animal League. Services today, 1:30 PM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: After Turbulent Week, Treasury Says Bond Market Will Be Orderly With Less Supply
description: A top Treasury Department official sought to assure bond investors on Saturday that they will be able to adjust to the government's new policy of reducing the supply of Treasury bonds.

title: Reporters Square Off Over Clinton Scandal
description: Call it the battle of the welterweight Clinton-scandal authors.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREDITH, MORLEY
description: MEREDITH-Morley. Age 77, Metropolitan Opera baritone for over 30 years, formerly of Scarsdale, NY died of cancer at Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center (Florida) on February 3, 2000. Born in Winnipeg, Canada, graduated from University of Manitoba before serving in the Canadian Navy. Preceded in death by Erlene, his wife of 48 years. Survived by his sister, Cecille Feldman, and her husband, Herman, of Minneapolis, MN, his aunt, and many loving nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Burial private. Memorial service at a later date.

title: The Guthrie Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Winners? Take Your Pick; No Sure Bets for This Year's Academy Awards
description: It is one measure of the dizzy uncertainty of this year's Oscar race that one of the handful of sure bets for a nomination goes to a screenwriter, Alan Ball, who came from television to write the dark and acidly funny ''American Beauty.'' He seems more likely than most to hear his name read at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at the hideous crack of dawn on the morning after Valentine's Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, MEREDITH
description: JOHNSON-Meredith. Age 53. Painter, writer, TV producer, and beloved friend of many who shared her love of art, music and living in the fullness of life, died in New York of cancer on January 30. After studying at San Francisco State, Hunter College and in Italy, she was 20 years on the Public Programs staff of the Metroplitan Museum. Her work as a painter of abstract expressionism has been exhibited here and abroad, and her book ''Lovers in Art'' was published in 1991. She has frequently conducted art tours of Tuscany and held seminars in Japan on museum management. Until her death she was Program Director of Crosswalks, New York City's educational cable channels. The daughter of James Day, former president of WNET, and the late Beverly Day, she was married last year to film director Harvey Mandlin after six years of a loving relationship. She is survived also by three brothrs, Douglas and Alan, both of California, and Ross, librarian of the Metropolitan Museum's Goldwater Library. A celebration of her life and work by her family and friends is planned for later in the spring.

title: Open Holocaust Files
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Denies Sinclair's Request To Modify Digital TV Standard
description: By a 5-to-0 vote, the Federal Communications Commission decided on Friday to deny a petition from the Sinclair Broadcast Group asking the commission to modify the nation's digital television standard.

title: Injuries Force a Test (Is Ward the Answer?)
description: With Marcus Camby out a minimum of six weeks, the Knicks' resiliency is going to be tested again.

title: Frazier's Daughter Has Fast Debut
description: After four hours of undercard bouts, which included a 6-foot-7-inch Bosnian heavyweight and a last-minute substitute for a boxer who slipped on a package of jelly at the Philadelphia Airport and ended up with double vision, Jacqui Frazier-Lyde climbed into the ring at the Scranton Cultural Center here for her professional debut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUSTON, JAMES W.
