title: Russian Troops Capture What Remains of Grozny
description: Nearly five months after he dispatched Russian forces to Chechnya, Acting President Vladimir V. Putin announced today that the Russian military had captured its capital, Grozny, and that the Russian tricolor was flying over it.

title: McCaw Group Expected to Offer Financing for Iridium
description: A group of investors led by Craig O. McCaw, the cellular telephone pioneer, is expected to provide at least $20 million of emergency financing to Iridium L.L.C., the troubled global satellite telephone company which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last August, according to people close to the talks.

title: Frederick Vanderbilt Field, Wealthy Leftist, Dies at 94
description: Frederick Vanderbilt Field, who supported Communist causes in the 1930's, 40's and 50's and was once described as ''the Reds' pet blueblood,'' died Feb. 1 at the Walker Methodist Health Center in Minneapolis. A great-great-grandson of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt and a descendant of several other prestigious American families, he was 94 and had lived in Minneapolis for almost two decades.

title: Do Viewers Even Want To Interact With TV?
description: The companies working to bring interactive television to the United States are endlessly optimistic that the big breakthrough for their industry is just around the corner, despite nearly 50 years of miscast experimentation and failure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIZARRO, GRATIANA ONICIU
description: PIZARRO-Gratiana Oniciu. On February 3rd, 2000. Teacher and linguist, beloved wife of the late Miguel Pizarro. We celebrate the beauty of your life even in sorrow. Your loving daughter Agueda, granddaughter Sara, son-in-law Omar Rayo. Funeral information, call Frank E. Campbell at 212288-3500

title: Moscow Takes Step To Ease U.S. Fears On Plutonium Use
description: In a major agreement aimed at safeguarding nuclear fuel that could be used to make weapons, Russia has promised to stop making plutonium out of fuel from its civilian power reactors as part of a $100 million joint research and aid package from the United States, Clinton administration and Russian officials say.

title: N.H.L. Goalies Fear One-Man Power Play
description: Mike Richter, the Rangers goalie, was talking yesterday about how Al MacInnis of St. Louis injured two goalies this season with his hard, heavy slap shot. Chris Osgood of Detroit and Jocelyn Thibault of Chicago hurt their hands trying to stop pucks fired by the veteran defenseman.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Investor Group May Provide Emergency Funds to Iridium

title: A New Agency Is Opened
description: A former top executive of Left Field, an agency in San Francisco that was dissolved in October after differences emerged among its three managing partners, has opened a shop of his own, named Exile on Seventh.

title: New Coach, New Contract, New Experience for U.S.
description: In her debut today as head coach of the United States women's soccer team, April Heinrichs decided to follow a philosophy embodied in a quotation she particularly likes: Leaders begin with the end in mind.

title: Judge to Rule on Newspapers' Request to Open Hearings
description: The presiding judge in the murder case against Michael Skakel, Maureen Dennis, is to meet today with lawyers for five newspapers that have asked her to open the proceedings to the public and the news media.

description: The lesson for the eighth graders was to indulge their ''holler'' talk without guilt.

description: Edward I. Koch was sitting in his 30th-floor law office in Rockefeller Center one day last fall when he got a phone call from a 28-year-old lawyer who wanted to start a legal Web site for consumers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, ARTHUR
description: BENNETT-Arthur. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Arthur Bennett. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Yearning, Earnest, Sincere And So Sad
description: It's hard to find a rock star more achingly sincere than Fran Healy of Travis, the Scottish band that performed on Thursday at the Bowery Ballroom. It's especially hard to find one in the realm of Britpop, where grand posturing is usually part of the act. Oasis sneers; Radiohead projects icy despair; Robbie Williams congratulates himself; Pulp waxes cynical. But Travis has set out to be the nice-guy band of Britpop, with considerable success. Its second album, ''The Man Who'' (Epic), reached No. 1 in Great Britain last year, and is due for American release in April.

title: Mrs. Clinton Turns Focus to Plans to Ease Upstate Economic Troubles
description: With her official declaration for the United States Senate behind her, Hillary Rodham Clinton flew into a region of New York today that is likely to be a prime battleground in the race this fall, turning her attention to what has long been a dominant concern among voters here: the region's long-suffering economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCHTERHAND, PATRICIA

Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife Giselle and his children Joyce, Arthur, James and Harry. Eli Haas, Pres., DDC

title: The Flaw in Buckley v. Valeo
description: ''Money is property; it is not speech.'' So wrote Justice John Paul Stevens late last month, using his concurring opinion in a campaign finance case from Missouri to attack the basic equation of money- equals-speech that was the analytical basis for the Supreme Court's 1976 Buckley v. Valeo decision. In the helpful part of the Buckley decision, the court upheld the constitutionality of campaign contribution caps, a position wisely reaffirmed in the Missouri case. But it prohibited spending limits on spurious free-speech grounds. Any effective campaign finance law must address both contributions and spending. Justice Stevens' observation signals that the court may be getting ready to take another look at the question of spending limits.

title: Devils Get No Breaks After the All-Star Game
description: The Devils have scored the most goals in the Eastern Conference, and that could be bad news for the Rangers Tuesday night when the teams open a home-and-home series at Madison Square Garden.

title: Christie's Is Changing Its Fees in Face of Suits and U.S. Investigation
description: Faced with class-action lawsuits and a three-year-old antitrust investigation into possible collusion between Sotheby's and Christie's, the world's two largest auction houses, Christie's announced yesterday that it was changing the fees it charges buyers and sellers.

title: France Provides Morning-After Pill to Schoolgirls
description: The students stopping in at the high school infirmary on a recent morning here were making their usual requests. Some wanted aspirin, others cold medicine. One just wanted a place to cry because she had flunked a math test.

title: NEW HEAD FOR MILLENNIUM DOME
description: The chief executive of the Millennium Dome in Greenwich, England, was replaced by a French executive who turned around the Euro Disney park ner Paris. The Millennium Experience Company said Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, operations director at the Disney park, would become chief executive. Last week, the company reported that just 366,000 people had visited the dome in the little more than the month the attraction has been open.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; Cutting the Risk of AIDS in Infants
description: In a study of pregnant monkeys and their offspring, researchers have given the offspring temporary immunity to a form of the AIDS virus, using a procedure that could offer a more effective way of blocking H.I.V. transmission during delivery.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CIGNA CORP., Philadelphia, named H. Edward Hanway, currently its president and chief operating officer, to the post of chief executive. He succeeds Wilson Taylor, who remains chairman.

title: Review/Fashion; Now, Even Rebels Are Looking Ladylike
description: Until now, the difference between being a lady and dressing like a lady was usually a drag queen. The whole notion of dressing up had degenerated into such a parody, a freak show of Upper-East-Side-luncheon-suit gaiety, that only a few designers would try it. But after last season's tony Prada show, and with a new generation of women dressing like their mothers, even their grandmothers, it's apparently safe again to be a lady.

title: NISSAN GIVEN 'JUNK' RATING
description: The credit rating of the Nissan Motor Company was lowered below investment grade by the Standard & Poor's Corporation after the company, a Japanese automaker, said a weak performance in its home market would pull down its operating profit. S.& P. lowered Nissan's long-term credit rating to BB+/B, the highest level of junk grade, from BBB-.

title: Kana Communications to Buy Silknet Software
description: February 7, 2000

title: Owners Want to Ask Mayor: Who Razed Our Building?
description: In their two-year attempt to find out who ordered the demolition of a Lower East Side apartment building after a wall collapsed, lawyers for the owner have interviewed 16 city officials. None recalled who had given the order, one of the lawyers said yesterday.

title: U.N. Increases Peacekeepers in Sierra Leone
description: The Security Council increased a peacekeeping force for Sierra Leone today to 11,000 from about 6,000 and told the troops not to shrink from using weapons against some of the most brutal rebel armies anywhere.

title: The Battle of the Decades; Reaganomics vs. Clintonomics Is a Central Issue in 2000
description: By the reckoning of the National Bureau of Economic Research, the independent group that has the final say on these matters, the current economic expansion -- as of this month the longest on record -- dates from March 1991.

A Memorial Service will be held Friday, February 11, 10:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. Contributions can be made in his memory to The Dr. William Berenberg Fund for Handicapped Children, C/O Children's Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about a conference of microprocessor manufacturers and semiconductor engineers misstated the measurement that describes a chip that cycles a billion times a second. It is a gigahertz, not a gigabyte.

description: FISCHL-Violet. She was my lady. My lady is gone. I will always love her and miss her. Goodbye, my love. Bruce.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell after Japanese officials said the economy probably shrank in the last three months of 1999, raising concern about an easier monetary policy. The yen slipped to 108.78 per dollar from 107.35 on Friday.

Mr. Schiff gave outsize recitals on Wednesday and Saturday evenings at Alice Tully Hall, with another to follow on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall; he returns with more Bach next fall at Carnegie Hall.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, the final line was omitted on Saturday from the Beliefs column comparing the case of Elian Gonzalez with that of a Jewish child taken from his parents by Roman Catholic officials in 1858. The affected sentence, quoting from Catholic New York, the weekly paper of the New York archdiocese, should have read: ''Barring serious dereliction, it editorialized, a parent's right 'is paramount,' even, quoting the catechism of the Catholic Church, 'primordial and inalienable.' ''

title: Winning Streak Bringing Fans Out
description: HOFSTRA

title: Doris Kenner-Jackson, 58, Singer In the Original Shirelles Foursome
description: Doris Kenner-Jackson, a founding member of the Shirelles, one of the first and most emotionally affecting of pop's girl groups, died on Friday at a hospital in Sacramento, Calif. She was 58.

title: 3 Are Accused Of Many Lies After Assault On Louima
description: Asserting that the truth was betrayed by officers' loyalty to one another, a federal prosecutor said yesterday that three officers accused of covering up the brutal attack on Abner Louima had conspired in dozens of telephone calls to tell ''lie after lie after lie'' to protect one of their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZ, EDMUND P.
description: KURZ-Edmund P. Of Southbury, Connecticut, age 88 years. Professor Emeritus Queens College, City University of New York, died on Sunday, February 6, 2000. He is survived by Barbara Lathrop Kurz, and sons Peter of Ravena, N.Y., and Roger of Southbury, CT.

title: COREL RAISES BET ON LINUX
description: A Canadian software maker, the Corel Corporation, will buy the Inprise/Borland Corporation of Silicon Valley in a $1 billion stock deal that reflects Corel's bet on the Linux operating system as a rival to Windows. Corel, best known for graphics software, has focused on Linux in recent months. Inprise/Borland has developed Internet access for Linux and other systems. Corel will swap 0.747 of its shares for each Inprise/Borland share. Michael Cowpland, Corel's founder, will be president and chief executive.

title: Chrebet and Ex-Giant Arrested in Bar Brawl
description: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet and the former Giants running back Keith Elias were arrested early Sunday morning after a barroom brawl in Seaside Heights, N.J., the police said yesterday.

title: At Yellowstone, an Ecosystem Teetering on a Tree
description: At the very top of a rocky, wind-whipped ridge above this sprawling ski resort west of Yellowstone National Park stands a towering grove of ancient whitebark pine trees. They are one of the few living things that thrive in the harshness at such altitudes, and they produce a large nut that is rich in fat and critical to wildlife.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRUCKER, ELLA
description: DRUCKER-Ella. Dear sweet gentle Ella, it is now eleven years without you. I miss you so. I send you all my love and many kisses. V.

title: Point, Counterpoint and the Duration of Everything
description: Like many journalists who write about science, I have received what might be called the delta-t lecture from Dr. J. Richard Gott, a folksy and engaging professor of physics at Princeton. The lecture, which revolves around survival times, or delta-t's, explains Dr. Gott's theory that the likely future duration of anything, from the human race to a musical playing on Broadway, can be predicted. All you need to know is the time that has passed since the entity in question came into being until the moment when you asked, ''How long will this last?''

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Witness at Diallo Trial Says She Heard Talk After Police Gunfire
description: A woman who heard the gunshots that killed Amadou Diallo testified today that moments after the shooting stopped, someone outside her bedroom window said, ''O.K., O.K., we just want to say this.''

title: Corrections
description: A list of members of the Tulsa Race Riot Commission on Saturday with an article about its recommendation for reparations to survivors of the 1921 violence included a name erroneously in some copies. Blake Wade is no longer a member.

title: Pitching Democrats' Cause, Rangel Advances His Own
description: There is a jingle to Representative Charles B. Rangel's step now, a little like the ka-ching of a cash register swallowing up dollar bills.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Richter Hurts Knee and Will Miss Game With Devils
description: The Rangers had only one thing to fear over the All-Star Game weekend. Sure enough, it came true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, ANN M. (NEE MILBERT)
description: WIENER-Ann M. (nee Milbert). Of 'The Harborage' North Bergen, NJ, on Sunday February 6, 2000. Mrs. Wiener led a full, active and charitable life spanning three centuries. A long time resident of Manhattan, NYC, Mrs. Wiener was the beloved wife of the late Dr. Isadore Wiener, loving sister of Dr. Arthur H. Milbert, and devoted aunt of William Mauskopf and dear great-aunt of Eric and Susan Mauskopf. Graveside services 3PM, Tues., Feb. 8, 2000 at Riversville Cemetery, Riversville, Ct. Information: Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ. Donations in Mrs. Wiener's memory may be made to the United Jewish Appeal or any charitable organization related to saving sight or aiding the blind.

title: 2 Giants Assistants Promoted As Fassel Delegates Authority
description: The Giants promoted the quarterbacks coach, Sean Payton, to offensive coordinator yesterday, a move that officially recognizes a shift of duties first made late last season.

title: One Step at a Time, Clinton Seeks More Help for Poor and Elderly
description: The budget unveiled today by President Clinton shows his extraordinary persistence as an architect of domestic policy. In health care and other social programs, he is pursuing many of the same goals as in 1993, though often by different means.

title: BESTFOODS BUYING INTO BRAZILIAN COMPANY
description: Sharply increasing its exposure in Latin America, Bestfoods, the maker of Hellman's mayonnaise and Skippy peanut butter, will pay $490 million for a controlling stake in Arisco Produtos Alimenticios S.A., one of Brazil's leading makers of processed foods. The deal accelerates the consolidation of Brazil's processed food industry. Bestfoods, based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., already relies on Latin American business for roughly a fifth of its earnings.

title: Islamists' Policies Win Allies in Malaysia State
description: KUALA TERENGGANU, Malaysia  Side-by-side in the corridors of the state capital building here are men wearing flowing robes and pin-striped suits, turbans and silk ties.

title: One Killed and Another Badly Injured in Attack
description: One man was shot to death and another critically wounded outside a fast-food restaurant in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Far From Politics, School Life Goes On; Who's In? Who's Out? I.S. 62 Has Better Things to Worry About
description: Tension was running high at 110 Livingston Street the morning last month when the members of the Board of Education, voting 4 to 3 over the objections of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, appointed Harold O. Levy as the city's interim schools chancellor.

title: Bush and McCain Vie on Truth
description: The airwaves are getting uglier in South Carolina. On Friday, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas introduced a sharply worded 30-second spot that attacks his principal opponent, Senator John McCain of Arizona, for what Mr. Bush says were distorted statements about his tax-cut plan in an earlier advertisement by the McCain campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEMAN, LEOLA JOHNSON
description: HAGEMAN-Leola Johnson. Beloved widow of Rev. Lynn Hageman, died Feb. 1 after a long illness. Loving mother of Hans, Ivan, Erika Robinson, and loving grandmother Jamila and Kiana. Memorial service Thursday, Feb. 10 at 11AM, St. Mary's Episcopal Church, 521 W. 126 St, near Bway.

title: 8 More Are Freed From Afghan Jet Hijacked to Britain
description: Day and night negotiations with gunmen who seized an Afghan jet on a domestic flight and eventually ended up in this suburban London airport succeeded today in gaining the freedom of eight passengers and providing supplies for the 150 still trapped on board.

title: Depression Debunking
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians Freeze Peace Talks And Release a Militant Leader
description: The Palestinian Authority froze peace talks with the Israelis on Monday and released from prison a charismatic Islamic fundamentalist leader from Gaza who is an outspoken opponent of the peace effort and of the authority.

title: Hospital in Boston Halts Gene Therapy Research
description: Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston has temporarily suspended a gene therapy experiment to permit further discussion of the issues underlying such work after a young man's death last year in a similar trial in Pennsylvania.

title: Where a Boy Can Live in Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Are No Match, On the Inside and Out
description: Each time the Hornets' sinewy Eddie Jones saw the Knicks' faith in themselves start to crest or their belief in upsets begin to swell, he would snip the stitches holding his patchwork opponent together.

title: California Raisins Make Comeback in Campaign
description: The California Raisin Marketing Board is bringing back the ''dancing raisins'' in a promotional campaign scheduled to begin on Thursday.

title: VITAL SIGNS: CAUSE & EFFECT; A Warm Wind and a Bad Headache
description: Cold winds cause headaches everywhere. Out in western Canada, there's a warm winter wind called the Chinook that many blame for migraines.

title: For Now, He's McCain In Tabloids
description: SENATOR JOHN McCAIN may be a hot number, having conquered New Hampshire and outfoxed New York State's Republican mandarins to win a spot on the March 7 primary ballot. But he has yet to make inroads with an important, if unheralded, group of opinion shapers. We're talking about the men and women who write those eye-grabbing headlines for New York's tabloid newspapers.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; Snow Shoveling Imperils Young Men, Too
description: Heavy snow and heart attacks go together like sidewalks and ice, health officials have long known. But how deep does the snow have to be for the risk to go up? Not all that deep, a study of winter deaths in Pennsylvania has found: a combination of just over an inch of snow and temperatures below 20 degrees caused death rates from heart attacks to triple among men 35 to 49 years old.

title: Jack Scott, a Prominent Critic Of Sport's Excesses, Dies at 57
description: Jack Scott, a prominent critic of organized athletics during the 1960's and early 1970's who later gained national attention when he was suspected of helping Patricia Hearst elude capture in the Symbionese Liberation Army case, died Sunday night in Eugene, Ore. He was 57.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELLETIER, MADELINE NUALA
description: PELLETIER-Madeline Nuala on February 6, 2000 at her home in Sparkill, NY. Beloved mother of Alexandra, Etain and Kieran. Grandmother to Ryan and Connor. Daughter of Madeline Moran. Sister of Cecilia Moran, Marie Long, John Moran, Robert Moran, Clare Salvaggio and Joseph Moran. Predeceased by husband Robert and son Colm. Friends may call at Stevenson Funeral Home, 790 Piermont Ave, Piermont, NY (914-359-0243) on Tuesday evening, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday morning, 11AM, St. John the Baptist Church, Piermont, NY. Donations may be made in her memory to United Hospice of Rockland, or the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIEBERMAN, JUDY
description: LIEBERMAN-Judy. June 21, 1940-February 8, 1995. Our thoughts and love will always be with you. Love, Your Family.

title: Foreign Affairs; Liars' Poker, Intercontinental Style
description: The Big Lie had a Big Week last week.

title: Primate Expert Explores Motherhood's Brutal Side
description: Everybody knows what a good mother is. She is a lot like apple pie: reassuringly firm on the outside, but soft, sweet, warm and bland within. A good mother gets pleasure from the comfort and pleasure of others. A good mother gets pleasure from being sliced, diced and eaten alive.

title: Camby Set for Surgery To Find Extent of Injury
description: Marcus Camby awoke today to find his nightmarish fall against the Miami Heat a reality and to hear that he would require diagnostic arthroscopic surgery Tuesday before the Knicks' physicians can know the extent of the partial tear in the anterior cruciate ligament of his right knee.

description: February 07, 2000

description: To the Editor:

title: Pfizer Gets Its Deal to Buy Warner-Lambert for $90.2 Billion
description: When many drug companies decided to cut their sales forces in the early 1990's because of the push into managed health care, William C. Steere Jr., then the new chairman of Pfizer Inc., hired more sales representatives.

title: He Who Has the Most Toys Never Says Die
description: IT'S not so bad if Al Kahn, the toy marketing whiz, is a little late to a meeting, because then you get to play with his toys.

title: State Senate Seeks to Suspend New Emissions Test
description: In a move to distance themselves from New Jersey's troubled auto emissions testing system, state senators voted today to suspend all of the complex new inspections until June 30.

title: Coke Recalls Hi-C Beverage
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that it had recalled some of its Hi-C beverages because the drinks had a peculiar taste.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Gad Rausing, 77, Swedish Innovator of Beverage Containers
description: A milk carton made Dr. Gad Rausing, who died on Jan. 28 at the age of 77 in Montreux, Switzerland, one of the wealthiest men in the world.

title: Man and Woman Shot On a Subway Train
description: A man and a woman were shot and wounded on a subway train in Brooklyn last night during an attempted robbery, the police said.

title: Russia's Empty Victory
description: The year may be 2000, but Grozny could easily be mistaken for the smoking rubble of a European city circa 1945. Russian forces, using the blunt weapons of World War II, have shelled and bombed the Chechen capital into an uninhabitable hell, a city so devastated that it will most likely be abandoned by the Chechens who long called it home and by the Russians who now cruelly declare that it has been ''liberated.'' For a world that has watched the Russian military offensive with revulsion, the Russian tricolor flag that now flies over Grozny seems a symbol of shame.

title: A New Technology That Colors the World (Sort of)
description: Bill Cunerty, a college teacher and coach in Southern California, has always had trouble picking color-coordinated clothes and socks that match. And like many ''colorblind'' people, he tells the color of a traffic light by its position, not its hue.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ralph Lauren and NBC Form A Joint Multimedia Venture

title: Domestic Violence Occurs on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslav Defense Chief, a Milosevic Ally, Is Slain
description: Yugoslavia's defense minister was shot and killed tonight when unidentified gunmen fired automatic weapons through the windows of a Belgrade soccer club where he was eating, the Belgrade police said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Almost all environments in the universe are terrible for life. It's only Garden of Eden places like Earth where it can exist.''

title: HUNTINGTON TO BUY EMPIRE, A MICHIGAN BANKING COMPANY
description: Huntington Bancshares Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Empire Banc Corporation for about $138 million in stock. Huntington, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, is a bank holding company with about $29 billion of assets. Empire Banc is a bank holding company with headquarters in Traverse City, Mich., and $505.7 million in assets. It has 10 offices in northern Michigan. In the transaction, Huntington is to exchange 2.0355 of its shares for each Empire Banc share. Based on Huntington's closing price on Friday, the deal values Empire Banc's shares at $43.25. Huntington's shares were down 37.5 cents at $20.875 in Nasdaq trading. Empire jumped $7, to $38.

title: VITAL SIGNS: CONSEQUENCES; When Cold Pills Don't Stop at the Nose
description: The American Heart Association has issued a reminder that colds can be bad for high blood pressure, or at least that many decongestants can be.

title: NEWFIELD EXPLORATION TO INVEST IN TEXAS GAS FIELDS
description: The Newfield Exploration Company agreed yesterday to acquire interests in south Texas gas fields from an undisclosed seller for $142 million. The producing gas fields are in Hidalgo, Brooks and Kenedy counties. About 90 percent of the acquired reserves are natural gas, and Newfield will operate two of the three fields. Newfield, based in Houston, is an independent crude oil and natural gas exploration and production company. It reported revenue of $242.2 million for the last 12 months.

title: Review/Fashion; From Singular Visions To the Gently Used
description: To sit through a succession of fashion shows requires a certain kind of stamina. It isn't the sort a trek through Patagonia demands -- though the women who have been making their way to the fall 2000 collections wearing bare sandals through the icy slush make one wonder why Outward Bound hasn't raided the ranks of fashion magazines to find its expedition leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORCH, ROBERT D.
description: STORCH-Robert D. Died February 2, 2000. Loving husband of Sharon; proud father of Steven and Susan; beloved father-in-law of Cheryl; adored opa of Cory and Allison and cherished brother of Michael. Retired after 43 successful years in the advertising industry.

title: Leaning Toward Bush But Interested in McCain
description: As he struggled to fix a broken tractor by the side of the road, Donald Hall underscored why South Carolina is sometimes called ''Bush country,'' but also why Gov. George W. Bush of Texas may be vulnerable here.

title: Chip Sales Rose 19% Worldwide Last Year
description: Worldwide sales of semiconductors jumped 19 percent last year, to a record $149 billion, fueled by demand for mobile phones and computer memory, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association.

title: Chief Themes of Military Budget: Modernizing and Troop Welfare
description: The $291.1 billion Pentagon budget proposed by the Clinton administration today not only reflects peacetime concerns about improving the lives of those who serve but also looks ahead to the challenges of a national antimissile defense and quick-and-dirty regional combat.

title: A Fledgling Publisher Will Rush Yeltsin Book
description: Less than a month after ceding power, Boris N. Yeltsin is preparing to publish his memoirs of two tumultuous terms as president of the Russian republic with a new American publisher that has offered the enticement of speed rather than an outsize advance.

title: Pet Bird Is Suspect In Death Of Patient
description: For months, the 72-year-old woman had not been herself. Her mind seemed to have dulled, and her mood had turned flat. Doctors at one hospital diagnosed depression.

title: Akamai Technologies to Buy InterVu
description: February 7, 2000

title: CANADIAN CABLE DEAL
description: Canada's largest cable television company, Rogers Communications Inc. of Toronto, is buying the cable operations of the Montreal-based Groupe Videotron through an exchange of shares valued at $4.1 billion. The combination, creating the seventh- largest cable provider in North America, puts Rogers in a stronger position to compete against the giant Bell Canada on a range of services covering telephone, Internet and business communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON STADE, SANDRA C.
description: VON STADE-Sandra C., 61, of Peapack, NJ, on Monday, February 7th, 2000 after a long illness. Wife of John T. von Stade of Peapack, mother of John, Jr. of Darien, CT, sister of David H. Carnahan of NYC. Also survived by a granddaughter Lily of Darien, CT. Funeral services will be Thursday, February 10th, at 11 AM, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Matheny School and Hospital, Peapack, NJ 07977 or the ASPCA, 424 E. 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WEYERHAEUSER CO., Federal Way, Wash., a major seller of wood products, agreed to sell its custom-made door business to Saunders Karp & Megrue, Stamford, Conn., a private merchant-banking investment firm. Terms were not disclosed.

title: So Would the Computer Hire Bill Gates?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Would-Be Washingtons Cross Into Little Delaware; 1 Doesn't
description: For Steve Forbes, the Republican primary in Delaware on Tuesday is a chance to prove there is life left in his candidacy.

title: Woods Fashions an Unforgettable Comeback
description: The streak is alive, and so is the magic of Tiger Woods. In a comeback of epic proportions, on one of the world's great golf courses, Woods overcame a seven-stroke deficit with seven holes to play to win the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am by two strokes over Matt Gogel and Vijay Singh.

title: Conservative Leader Says G.O.P. Can Do Better Than Mayor
description: All but ruling out his party's support for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Senate run, the Conservative Party leader said today that he would prefer that the mayor drop out of the race, and said his party would readily nominate Representative Rick A. Lazio.

title: President Stuns Brown U. by Leaving to Be Vanderbilt Chancellor
description: After just two years as president of Brown University, E. Gordon Gee abruptly resigned yesterday to become chancellor of Vanderbilt University, stunning Brown's campus and the higher education community nationwide.

title: Prosecutors Say Rapper Wanted Friend Freed
description: Sean Combs, the rap producer charged with weapons possession after a shooting at a Times Square nightclub in late December, asked the police whether his companion, the actress Jennifer Lopez, would be released if someone claimed ownership of the gun found inside his vehicle, according to prosecutors.

title: Sports of The Times; Here Comes The Judge For Rocker
description: JOHN ROCKER surely did not realize that the foot he was putting in his mouth might someday judge him, too.

title: Accounts
description: Brandwise.com, New York, a home shopping comparison Web site, to Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG, New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising. The account had been at Stein Rogan & Partners, New York, a unit of True North Communications. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Last-Lap Budget
description: The $1.8 trillion budget proposed by President Clinton yesterday was for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, when he will have only a few months left at the White House. But Mr. Clinton's fiscal priorities could long outlive his tenure. The president called once again for using projected surpluses to shore up Social Security and Medicare, rather than to grant big tax cuts. He would also spend additional money for education and other domestic needs. Republicans in Congress may rewrite the numbers but are unlikely to reorder his priorities in this election year. In part that is because Senator John McCain's challenge to party orthodoxy in his presidential campaign has thrown Republicans on Capitol Hill into disarray.

description: Spinal Curvature

description: GRANDIS-Estel. My love, my thoughts, always my dearest. Gene

title: Barkley's Eligibility Is Awaiting Decision
description: With the National Collegiate Athletic Association not yet ruling on an appeal over his eligibility, St. John's point guard Erick Barkley was left behind in Queens yesterday when his teammates boarded a bus for Providence, where they will play the Friars tonight.

title: Where a Boy Can Live in Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting a Grip on a Clump of Molecules
description: I am plastered against the side of a large rock, 15 feet above a patch of trampled dirt in Central Park. My fingers are wedged inside a fissure. My left toe is balanced on a protrusion about the size of a golf ball and my right toe is balanced on . . . I don't know what it's balanced on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDEL, BESS
description: HANDEL-Bess. Of Hollywood, FL. Formerly of Manhattan, NY. Passed away Sunday, February 6, 2000. She is the beloved wife of the late Louis Handel. Loving mother or Barbara Handel and Larry Handel. Dear sister of Leon Kobrin. Cherished grandmother of Jay, Sandi, Jeremy, Ellie and Sophie. Graveside services Wednesday, February 9, 2000, 10AM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island, NY. Information: Blasberg Rubin Zilbert Memorial Chapel, Miami Beach, FL. 305-865-2353.

title: Pause in Shooting Emerges As a Key Issue in Diallo Trial
description: As the prosecution continues presenting its case this week against four officers charged with murder in the death of Amadou Diallo, a pause in the fusillade of 41 shots that the officers fired is becoming almost as central as the gunfire itself.

title: ROBOT POPULATION RISING
description: Worldwide orders for industrial robots rose 20 percent last year, according to United Nations figures. An annual report by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said the rise was driven by increasing automation in the United States and Canada, where orders rose 60 percent in 1999 over the previous year. In Europe, orders were up 12 percent. Elizabeth Olson

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, IRVING
description: JORDAN-Irving. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our member, Irving Jordan. We extend profound condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: New Asteroid That May Threaten Earth Is Found
description: For the fifth time in two years, astronomers have discovered an asteroid hurtling through space that might collide with Earth.

title: A Party With Politics And Plenty of Dancing
description: Walking into the Steel Pulse concert sponsored by Guinness at Irving Plaza was one of those border-crossing experiences popular music sometimes offers. Outside, winter rained its gray mood on a flinching city. Inside, a huge crowd in spring-break casuals and tropical regalia generated enough heat to create an instant Sunsplash festival.

title: CLINTON'S BUDGET STRESSES SURPLUS AND HAVING IT ALL
description: President Clinton today sent Congress a budget built on the idea that the burgeoning surplus will allow the nation to have it all, from increased spending to tax cuts and big reductions in the national debt.

title: A Vallone Bill Bars Purchases In Sweatshops
description: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone proposed legislation yesterday that would bar New York City from buying uniforms or other apparel from companies unless they paid at least what he called ''nonpoverty wages.''

title: VITAL SIGNS: MUSCLE GROUPS; A Therapist's Touch on Arthritic Knees
description: A twice-a-week, monthlong program of physical therapy and exercise training significantly reduced pain levels and surgery rates among patients with arthritic knees, according to a study in this month's issue of The Annals of Internal Medicine.

title: Man Kills Himself After Shooting Westchester Student
description: A man, apparently enraged over the end of a relationship, shot a Westchester Community College student today as she fled down the hallway of a campus building. The man then dashed across campus to a small hill by the student center and fatally shot himself as a few students watched, the authorities said.

Grandmother of Daniel, Gabriel and Sarina Sassoon. Relatives and friends are invited to services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, Joseph Levine & Son, 4737 Street Rd., Trevose, PA. Interment Roosevelt Memorial Park. Family will return to the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Sassoon. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Elem Youth in Distress in Israel.

title: Megadrought Appears to Loom in Africa
description: Lately, it has become increasingly clear to scientists that in the 10,000 years since the last ice age ended, the world's climate has often served up droughts far surpassing anything seen in the last 150 years, resulting in some cases in the collapse of entire ancient civilizations.

title: After Seattle, Trade Group Scales Back Its Agenda
description: The World Trade Organization, seeking to move beyond its highly publicized failure in Seattle to start a new round of global trade negotiations, has agreed instead to begin negotiations limited to opening markets in agriculture and services.

title: School Board And CUNY Are to Expand College Plan
description: Showing a new cooperative spirit, the Board of Education and the City University of New York are teaming up to expand a program that tries to make sure high school graduates do not need remedial work when they enter college.

title: Tsabong Journal; An Embarrassment of Camels (It's in Police Hands)
description: How can you possibly patrol this blazing hot desert, wondered the British colonialists who once ruled this sleepy patch of the Kalahari as their police horses dropped dead from thirst and disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIES, SARAH (ASNIN)
description: KIES-Sarah (Asnin). On February 6, 2000. Wife of the late Saul Kies. Beloved sister of Frieda Goldberg and Dorothy Friedman. Stepmother of David Kies. title: Promise And Peril Of New Drugs For AIDS
description: In less than four years, the euphoria over the success of new drug combinations to treat AIDS has yielded to the sobering challenge of dealing with the drugs' complications and failures.

description: BEER-Abraham. The Philip and Sarah Belz School of Jewish Music of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, Yeshiva University, and its affiliate organization, Cantorial Council of America, express their condolences to Cantor Bernard Beer, Director of the Belz School of Jewish Music and Executive Vice President of Cantorial Council of America, and to his family upon the loss of his beloved father, Abraham Beer. Shiva being observed at 1429 47th Street, Brooklyn, New York.

title: PBS Names Turner Broadcasting Executive as Its New President
description: The Public Broadcasting Service yesterday announced the appointment of Pat Mitchell, a longtime news producer and executive for Turner Broadcasting, as its president.

description: In percent

title: Copying Reagan's Strategy, McCain Courts Democrats
description: Touching on themes more common in Democratic primaries than Republican ones, Senator John McCain campaigned today in auto factory towns in Michigan, praised unions, called his rival's tax plan too generous to the rich and said he welcomed the support of independents and Democrats.

title: Police Say Brooklyn Couple Died in Murder and Suicide
description: Firefighters discovered the badly burned bodies of a man and a woman, believed to be a husband and wife, in their Brooklyn apartment yesterday morning shortly after their children had left for school, investigators said. The deaths were believed to be a murder and suicide.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the European edition of The Wall Street Journal misstated its circulation. The Journal sells 16,000 copies in Britain, not 67,000. The total European circulation -- not the total for copies sold in Europe outside of Britain -- is 83,000.

title: Iraq Suspected of Secret Germ War Effort
description: With a new arms inspection system now being devised for Iraq, some arms control experts are looking anew at Iraqi biological weapons programs and finding evidence of at least one more secret project still to be uncovered.

title: INVIVO RAISES TAKEOVER OFFER FOR PROTOCOL SYSTEMS
description: The Invivo Corporation said yesterday that it had increased its bid to acquire Protocol Systems Inc., offering $100.6 million in cash and stock for the company, a Beaverton, Ore., maker of patient-monitoring systems. In November, Invivo offered to buy Protocol for $84 million in cash and stock. In December, Protocol's board rejected the proposal. Under the latest offer, Invivo, a maker of vital-sign monitoring systems, based in Pleasanton, Calif., offered $6 in cash and $6 in stock for each of Protocol's outstanding shares. Shares of Protocol rose 56.25 cents, to $10.1875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: U.S. FIRMS INVEST IN JAPAN
description: Two United States investment firms, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Goldman Sachs, are leading a group of investors providing $43 million in seed capital to eAccess Ltd., a new company that plans to offer Japanese consumers asymmetric digital subscriber line technology a faster, cheaper way to pull data off the Internet. The company, founded by Sachio Semmoto, a founder of the DDI Corporation, and Eric Gan, a former telecommunications analyst at Goldman, later intends to expand its business to become an Internet protocol service provider. Stephanie Strom

title: INTERVU TO BE BOUGHT BY AKAMAI, WEB SOFTWARE MAKER
description: Akamai Technologies Inc., a maker of software that speeds Web browsing, agreed yesterday to buy InterVU Inc. for about $2.8 billion in stock to offer more audio and video services over the Internet. Akamai will swap 0.5957 of a share of its own stock for each InterVU share, or about $139.99 based on Friday's closing price. Akamai increases the speed of content delivery to Web sites through its FreeFlow service. . Akamai's shares fell $6.375 each, to $228.625, in Nasdaq trading, where InterVU rose $12.375 each, to $129.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, BONNIE
description: CASHIN-Bonnie. The Women's Forum records with sorrow the death of its longtime esteemed member, Bonnie Cashin. Her star will continue to shine. Joni Lysett Nelson, President

title: Naming Names: An Alley Roll-Call
description: February 8, 2000

title: A Gender War at the Ballot Box
description: Usually, the differences between Republican and Democratic voters in the primaries are socioeconomic. Republicans, it can safely be said, are generally richer and better educated.

title: A Rested Gore Goes After Hard-Hat and High-Hat Votes
description: After a two-day respite from the campaign trail, Vice President Al Gore stepped up his New York campaign in earnest yesterday, paying homage to the labor unions he is counting on to mobilize for him in the March 7 primary and spending the evening courting arts patrons at Lincoln Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, PETER (FRANK)
description: THOMPSON-Peter (Frank). Our deepest sympathy to Lanie Thompson, his wife, and to all the family at the sudden and unexpected loss of our dear friend and colleague. Peter was our esteemed pianist and collaborator and a pillar of musical genius. His joyous and exuberant approach to life will remain with us forever. Lynn Starling, Sam Kaufman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREDITH, MORLEY
description: MEREDITH-Morley. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our colleague and friend Morley Meredith. A baritone with the company for thirty-one seasons, he is fondly remembered by all those who worked with him. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: AXA REVENUE UP 22%
description: The world's largest insurer, Axa S.A., indicated that fourth-quarter revenue rose 22 percent, helped by acquisitions and demand for life insurance. Revenue rose to 18.6 billion euros ($18.3 billion) from 15.3 billion euros a year earlier. Full-year revenue rose 17 percent, to 66.5 billion euros, or 10 percent when adjusted for acquisitions. Like its rivals, Axa benefited from rising sales of life insurance, while its property and casualty insurance premiums came under pressure as competition intensified. Guardian Royal Exchange P.L.C., the British insurer that Axa bought last year, contributed to revenue for the first time.

title: British Airways Cut Its Losses Last Quarter
description: British Airways P.L.C. reported better-than-expected third-quarter financial results today but still showed a loss from fare discounting and a surge in fuel prices, and its shares fell more than 4 percent.

title: 1.6 Million Cyberlings Go a-Hunting for Aliens
description: Earthlings are so enamored of aliens that 1.6 million of them in 224 countries have recently joined an effort that harnesses home and office computers to the job of sifting through a few zillion radio bands to hunt for signs of intelligent life among the stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELEN, ARTHUR
description: SEELEN-Arthur. On February 7, 2000. Owner of The Drama Book Shop. Beloved husband of Rozanne. Loving uncle and greatuncle. Services Thursday, 12:30 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Wednesday, 7-9 P.M. Interment at Beth David Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROER, EDWIN
description: ROER-Edwin. Temple Israel Center of White Plains, NY, shares deeply in the grieving for Edwin Roer, a past President of this congregation, a constant source of cheer and encouragement to everyone, a devoted husband, father, grandfather, and brother, a sweet soul. Our condolences go to Dottie, Robert and Marjorie, Sara, Ricki & Paul, Lynn & Itai, Harvey and Janet. May Ed's memory endure as a blessing to those who loved him and love him still. Gordon Tucker, Rabbi David Glasser, President

title: Infielder Claimed From Devil Rays
description: The Mets added to their reserve infield options yesterday by claiming David Lamb off waivers from the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.

title: A Sunny Start Turns Melancholy in Shostakovich's String Quartets
description: Once not terribly long ago, Russian music had the capacity to dream. It filled the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th with romance (Tchaikovsky), exoticism (Borodin), fantasy (Rimsky-Korsakov) and the ecstatic (Scriabin). There was suffering (again Tchaikovsky) and despair (Mussorgsky), but both were born with a fullness of heart. What came after this now-dead Russian epoch is best encapsulated in the 15 string quartets of Shostakovich, the subject of five concerts by the Emerson String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall. The series began on Sunday afternoon and runs until the end of the month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONROY, EDWARD M. REVEREND SR.
description: CONROY-Edward M. Reverend Sr. Priest at St. Raymond's Church, Bronx, NY. Beloved brother of Dennis J., Charles P. and the late M. Elizabeth McCarthy, Joseph J. and Veronica T. Casey. Survived by many nieces and nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Reposing at Castle Hill Funeral Directors, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx, NY. Mass of Christian burial today at St. Raymond's Church, 10:45am. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Father Benedict Groeschel, St. Crispins Friary, Bronx, NY.

title: Veteran Gore Fund-Raiser Goes on Trial
description: A longtime fund-raiser for Vice President Al Gore went on trial here today on charges that she helped disguise illegal campaign donations to the 1996 Clinton-Gore campaign, including at least $55,000 connected to a controversial appearance by the vice president at a Buddhist temple in California.

title: A Futile Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: NBC helps Ralph Lauren fulfill a multimedia dream.
description: RALPH LAUREN, the pre-eminent peddler of aspirational clothes and other merchandise, has dreams, too. He wants to have a multimedia presence like Martha Stewart, the omnipresent home guru.

title: A Mix of Azerbaijan and the West
description: Continuum, the new-music series directed by Cheryl Seltzer and Joel Sachs, checks in regularly on dominant styles and prominent composers, but it has always been at its most exciting when it looks beyond the mainstream. Its Thursday evening concert at the Miller Theater was devoted to the music of Franghiz Ali-Zadeh, a composer from Azerbaijan whose works draw on both the conventions of contemporary Western music and the ornate modal flourishes and timbres of Islamic music.

title: Giuliani Courts Upstate Voters
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Giuliani campaign began broadcasting throughout upstate New York on Thursday.

title: Four Players Are Recalled
description: The Islanders' shuttle between Uniondale, N.Y., and Lowell, Mass., did not take a break over the All-Star Game weekend.

title: McCain's Lost 'Issue'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULLWINKEL, DOROTHY DEMLING
description: BULLWINKEL-Dorothy Demling. Essex, CT. Died on January 30th. She will be remembered with love by daughter Joan Demling Reingold of Virginia Beach, VA. and sister Georgene Keller of Las Vegas, NV. as well as four grandchildren and two great-granddaughters. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on February 26th, Rye Presbyterian Church, Rye, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOULTON, SCHROEDER
description: BOULTON-Schroeder, on February 6th, aged 91. Survived by daughters, Janet Boulton and Nancy Boulton-LeGates. Memorial service Saturday, February 12, 2 PM, First Unitarian Church, 50 Monroe Place, Brooklyn Heights, NY.

title: Coolidge's Democratic Disciples
description: One party claims that the budget surplus will be small and that a central goal should be to eliminate the debt. The other says the surplus will be big and we can do ambitious things with it. You'd be forgiven if you thought that the first party was the Republicans and the second the Democrats. But it is the reverse. The Democrats are marching under the banner of fiscal austerity, and the Republicans are proclaiming this the era of large ambition.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Mystery of Ball Lightning

title: McCain Aide's Conservatism Runs Deep
description: Senator John McCain has recently been accused by Republican opponents of being a shadow liberal, but no one has ever leveled such a charge against his South Carolina political consultant and the architect of his Southern campaign, Richard M. Quinn.

title: Public Interests; For Those of You Who Are Just Joining Us . . .
description: The public seems to have gotten interested, temporarily, in the presidential races. I can't tell you how exciting this is for those of us who write about politics for a living and normally have all the social cachet of an exterminator who specializes in mole eradication. In case you tuned in late, here's what has happened so far.

title: Re-educating Rocker
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lonely Universe? 2 Scientists Say Yes
description: Drawing on findings in astronomy, geology and paleontology, two leading scientists are questioning the prevailing notion that there is advanced life elsewhere in the cosmos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, JO
description: RAYMOND-Jo. Guild Hall honors the memory of Jo Raymond, a valued Trustee and a dynamic and vital part of the everyday life and events of Guild Hall for more than thirty years. Her contributions to the institution were many and her generosity of spirit unmatched. Melville Straus, Ch of Board Ruth Appelhof, Exec Director

title: U.S. Preparing For Gold Cup
description: UNITED STATES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOGEL, PHILIP
description: STOGEL-Philip. The Board of Governors and members of Willow Ridge Country Club sadly note the passing of Philip Stogel, a distinguished member of this club. Our deepest condolences are offered to his wife Florence and to his entire family. Myron Melnikoff, Pres. Board of Governors

title: Metro Business; Manhattan Homes Average $569,000
description: An increase in buyers from outside New York and a short supply of apartments have pushed the average price of a Manhattan home to more than $500,000, a survey has found.

title: Man Is Shot in Thigh At Manhattan Nightclub
description: A man was shot and slightly wounded early yesterday at the Tunnel nightclub, which has drawn criticism from city officials for its history of violence and drug use.

title: Maybe We Are Alone in the Universe, After All
description: In the last few decades, a growing number of astronomers have promulgated the view that alien civilizations are likely to be scattered among the stars like grains of sand, isolated from one another by the emptiness of interstellar space. Just for Earth's own galaxy, the Milky Way, experts have estimated that there might be up to one million advanced societies.

title: Edgar Bowers, 75, a Poet in the Formalist Style
description: Edgar Bowers, a poet whose luminous, finely wrought prose earned him the Bollingen Prize, died on Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 75.

title: Welfare and Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Where a Boy Can Live in Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuala Pelletier, Office Manager, 63
description: Nuala Pelletier, the office manager for The New York Times Company Foundation, died of breast cancer on Sunday at her home in Sparkill, N.Y. She was 63.

title: UTILICORP UNITED TO PURCHASE TRANSALTA'S ALBERTA UNIT
description: UtiliCorp United Inc., which sells power and natural gas in the United States and four other countries, agreed to buy the TransAlta Corporation's Alberta electric utility for $450 million to expand its reach in Canada. UtiliCorp, based in Kansas City, Mo., will get 350,000 customers and about 54,000 miles of power-distribution lines in Alberta. The company has spent more than $3 billion on energy acquisitions since 1985. It has 4.5 million customers in eight states and Canada, Britain, New Zealand and Australia. TransAlta, based in Calgary, Alberta, said in January that it planned to sell the Alberta business and a New Zealand utility to focus on generating power in North America. The sales will help finance its $554 million purchase of a power plant in Washington.

title: AOL Reportedly Eyeing Bid for Remainder of AOL Europe
description: February 7, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAER, HERMAN
description: SCHAER-Herman. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood and Couples Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of our devoted member, Judith Wilner. We extend heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: East German Doping
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Money Machine Needs a Helping Hand
description: Until reports of hundreds of millions of dollars in losses made the headlines, few Americans had ever heard of hedge funds, the invention of Nobel Prize mathematicians that promised to take the risk out of investing in the stock market. To get in on a company formed in 1992 called Long-Term Capital Management, created to bring about that miracle, you had to invest at least $10 million for three years.

title: Cadillac Chief Moves to G.M. Service Unit
description: Call him Mr. Goodwrench. John F. Smith, charged three years ago with fixing the General Motors Cadillac division, was named today as general manager of the company's service and parts operations.

title: It Only Gets More Interesting for U.S. Davis Cup Team
description: Now that John McEnroe is 1-0 as Davis Cup captain, he gets to experience what Jeff Van Gundy does as coach. He has to dole out the minutes.

title: Careful With Melody And Hooked on Romance
description: Some jazz bands like to make a tune explode on the stage, treating its structure like a half-remembered blueprint. The trumpeter Ron Horton's sextet, on the evidence of its Friday show at the Museum of Modern Art's Garden Cafe, isn't one of those bands. But that approach wouldn't hang right on Mr. Horton anyway: he's a structuralist, a carefully melodic composer and improviser, and the contrasting moods he writes into his pieces are meant to stay put.

title: A Day for Twists, Taunts and Snubs On Campaign Trail
description: After a weekend in Texas, Gov. George W. Bush returned to the campaign trail with a more aggressive tone and a new slogan: ''a reformer with results.'' Mr. Bush was attempting to paint his main opponent in the presidential race, Senator John McCain, as someone who only talks like a reform candidate.

title: STRONGER RESULTS AT ADIDAS
description: Despite weak demand in the United States, Adidas-Salomon A.G., a large maker of sporting goods and apparel, reported surprisingly strong 1999 results. Earnings at the German company rose 11 percent, to $225 million, on a 6 percent increase in sales, to $5.3 billion. Analysts said the company still faced sluggish demand and fierce price competition. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages yesterday misstated the month for appearances by the New York City Opera National Company in several Northeastern cities. The dates -- all in April, not March -- are: Tilles Center, Greenvale, N.Y., the 14th; New Jersey Performing Arts Center, Newark, the 15th; Schubert Performing Arts Center, New Haven, the 16th; Flynn Theater, Burlington, Vt., the 17th.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PROVITCH, WILLIAM
description: PROVITCH-William 9/26/15-2/8/95 Poppy, we miss you more than ever. Love, Michelle, Judy, Harol

title: Corrections
description: The daily stock market report in Business Day on Saturday referred incorrectly to the precedents for the 9.1 percent rise in the Nasdaq composite index last week. It was the best weekly performance since 1974, not the best in history.

title: Where a Boy Can Live in Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Woods Wins 6th Straight

title: Construction Worker Is Killed In World Trade Center Accident
description: A construction worker was killed instantly and another was severely injured yesterday when a two-ton piece of heating equipment landed on them after tumbling off a platform at 1 World Trade Center, officials said.

title: Bush Takes Tougher Line And Emphasizes Reform
description: Signaling a new, aggressive tone to his campaign, Gov. George W. Bush proclaimed today that he was the true reformer in the Republican field and portrayed his chief opponent, Senator John McCain, as someone who ''says one thing and does another.''

title: Judge Orders Preliminary Injunction Against Canadian Web Site
description: Judge Orders Preliminary Injunction Against Canadian Web Site

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted in Circuits on Thursday for images with the Game Theory column, about the military's use of game software. The images came from the Information Sciences Institute at the University of Southern California.

title: Airline Wants to Take Web All the Way
description: February 8, 2000

title: Arts in America; Big Names, Big Bucks: A Museum's Shopping Spree
description: Four years ago, when the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art unveiled its new home, a $63 million brick-clad building designed by the Swiss architect Mario Botta, the trustees quickly saw their problem. The museum's painfully skimpy art collection was dwarfed by the large, sun-filled galleries.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY: Columbia, S.C., and Cleveland.

title: Family Caught in the Gap Between Welfare and Work
description: An icy wind blew through the streets of her Bronx neighborhood that January morning, so Tonika Webster, three hungry children at home, hurried her pace to the local check-cashing store.

title: Indonesia's President Says He Will Forgive Former Foe
description: Easing a strange long-distance confrontation with his top general, President Abdurrahman Wahid has suddenly taken a new tack, saying in newspaper reports today that he trusts the general and is ready to forgive him.

title: Another Setback for a Much-Delayed Road
description: Dealing a new delay to a proposed highway link in central New Jersey that has been stalled for decades, the Army Corps of Engineers said today that the much-studied Route 92 plan would require still more study: an environmental impact review that could take up to a year and a half.

title: Pirates Crash Orangemen's Loud Party
description: The din inside the Carrier Dome grew almost unbearable, reaching a pitch usually reserved for those old high school gyms rather than the cavernous facility that housed 23,735 fans tonight. The crowd was shouting as loudly and frantically as it could for the Orangemen.

title: The Fatty Nut Finds Its Place at the Table
description: There is good news on the nutrition front. Nuts -- yes, fatty nuts -- are back on the menu, even for people on diets to prevent heart disease or cancer or to lose weight.

title: Austrians Consider the Cost Of Extremism in the Cabinet
description: Austrian economists and policy makers fear that the protests and sanctions against the new government could dampen investment in this country and raise capital costs for companies already doing business here.

title: For Purloined Stamps, Return to Collector
description: A million-dollar collection of stamps and envelopes from 1869 that was snatched on a New York City street in November 1998 has been recovered by the F.B.I. and returned, the owner said. So far, however, there are no suspects in the case, he added.

title: RUSSIAN COMPANY HIRES MORGAN
description: Russia's third-largest oil company, Surgutneftegaz, retained Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company as an adviser on how to proceed with a plan to consolidate its subsidiaries with the holding company. The plan has aroused protests from minority shareholders, who fear that a new equity issue of up to 12 billion shares and subsequent stock swap could dilute their position. Shareholders have until Thursday to authorize the new issue. The company's stock has fallen 22 percent in the last month. Neela Banerjee

title: G.O.P. Senate Leaders Back Bill on Insuring Infertility Treatments
description: The Republican leaders of the State Senate said today that they intended to pass a bill on Tuesday that for the first time would require health insurance companies to pay for some infertility treatments, edging the Legislature closer to action on the highly contentious issue.

title: Evolving Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists Do the Math to Fight Breast Cancer
description: For women who are facing difficult decisions because they carry a gene that heightens their risk of breast cancer, doctors have developed a bracingly rational, cut-to-the chase method of helping them weigh the pros and cons of various strategies for reducing risk.

title: Marathoner's Mental Map Leads to the Olympic Trials
description: The Olympic trials for the women's marathon will take place Feb. 26 in Columbia, S.C. But Anne Marie Lauck, who finished 10th in the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, has already run the 26.2-mile course over and over in her mind.

title: Russian Justice: Crime and Harassment
description: Timur Dakhkilgov is a soft-spoken man who toils for long hours in a gritty dye factory to support his pregnant wife and two small children. He is also a victim of the Kremlin's war against terrorism.

title: Two Online Companies Sign Up With Agencies
description: Two dot-coms have named agencies to handle accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $85 million to $100 million.

title: Beware of Nets' Newman When He Gets That Look
description: Johnny Newman seems to be one of the most serene players in the National Basketball Association. He speaks in a quiet, affable tone and regularly attends the team's pregame chapel.

title: Clinton Plans A Good Year For New York
description: Whether it was Hillary Rodham Clinton's run for the Senate or just Democratic politics at work in a prosperous election year, President Clinton's proposed budget lavishes New York City with money for important programs.

title: Pay the Survivors Of the Riot in Tulsa
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders' Step Forward Comes Up a Goal Short
description: HURRICANES 4, ISLANDERS 3

title: Review/Fashion; Oscar de la Renta Revels In His Youthful Side
description: Somewhere between a boiled wool skirt and a divine silk rumba dress, two anti-fur protesters briefly interrupted Oscar de la Renta's fall fashion show yesterday in the main tent in Bryant Park. The women were tackled by security guards, dragged to an exit and detained by the police as the models resumed their sultry progress down a white runway left stained with black scuff marks.

title: Apparel Accounts Are Reassigned
description: Two divisions of VF Jeanswear, part of the VF Corporation, have reassigned creative and media accounts that had been at the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Illinois Mulls New Tactic Over Violence Based on Sex
description: The Illinois legislature is considering what could become the first state law in the country specifically tailored to allow victims of wife-beating, gay-bashing and other violence based on gender or sexual orientation to sue their attackers.

title: Chicken Little Can Relax
description: Astronomers sounded an all-clear yesterday one day after raising the prospect that a newly discovered asteroid had a one-in-a-million chance of hitting Earth in 2022.

title: Islanders
description: The group looking to buy the Islanders could walk away from the stalled $180 million sale because of what it calls the unyielding position of Nassau Coliseum's landlord.

title: Spitzer to Join Suit On Taxes in Nassau
description: Nassau County's antiquated property tax assessment system, which has already been called discriminatory by the United States Justice Department, the state comptroller and the Democrats who control the County Legislature, has a new opponent: the state's attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FTI CONSULTING INC., Annapolis, Md., a litigation and claims-management consulting company, agreed to buy Policano & Manzo L.L.C., Saddle Brook, N.J., for about $50 million in cash and stock. Policano & Manzo provides bankruptcy-related consulting to large corporations and lenders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MILDRED
description: COHEN-Mildred. On Feb. 5, 2000, beloved wife of the late Jacob, most caring and loving mother of Julian and Carol, devoted motherin-law to Sylvia and Seymore, and grandsons, Jeffrey Scott Stuart, and the late Richard Sarnoff. Adoring great grandmother of Rachel, Chloe, Michael, Jordan, Max, Alyssa, and Andrew.

title: McCain, Sure on Military Issues, Is Less Certain on Domestic Ones
description: It was telling to hear John McCain proclaim his impatience with President Clinton's last State of the Union address.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERT, JOYCE
description: LAMBERT-Joyce. Died February 6, 2000 after a short illness. Greatly missed by family and friends around the world. Memorial service to be announced.

title: People
description: * Larry Kaufman was named to the new post of general manager at the Internet Advertising Bureau, New York. He had been vice president for member services at the Magazine Publishers of America, New York.

title: Chiefs' Thomas Dies Unexpectedly During Hospital Stay
description: Derrick Thomas, the Kansas City Chiefs' Pro Bowl linebacker known for his ferocious play on the field and his charity work off it, died unexpectedly yesterday morning in a Miami hospital, 16 days after a car crash had left him paralyzed from the chest down.

title: Duke's Stars Are Gone, Not Its Star Power
description: It was an October luncheon and Mike Krzyzewski was supposed to be offering a forecast for Duke's coming season. But the coach could not look forward, or touch his sandwich, until he tried one final explanation of what happened to last season's team. Looking back at the Blue Devils team that won 37 games, was crowned as a team for the ages and ended up losing to Connecticut in the national title game, he could not hide his irritation.

title: Accord Ends Boycott By Japan Opposition
description: In a carefully worked out compromise, opposition politicians agreed today to return to Parliament, ending an 11-day boycott.

title: Tobacco Companies Are Sued By Distributors Over Pricing
description: United States cigarette wholesalers filed a lawsuit today against the five leading tobacco companies, accusing them of illegally fixing prices.

title: Coalition Sues New York Over New Car Insurance Rules
description: A coalition of groups representing lawyers, doctors and consumers charged in court yesterday that new no-fault auto insurance regulations New York State recently adopted would benefit insurance companies and unjustly penalize accident victims.

title: Wonders Old And New
description: Four years ago a British producer, Anthony Geffen, announced what sounded like an enormously ambitious and one-of-a-kind project: He said he would use the breakthroughs in computer and digital technology to recreate the ancient civilizations of Rome, Greece, Egypt and China, bringing viewers the experience of walking through the Parthenon or riding a chariot at the Roman Circus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGA, CARLOS M. COSTA
description: BRAGA-Carlos M. Costa December 10, 1943-February 3, 2000. Of Forest Hills, N.Y. Loving father of Christian and Dani. Dear brother of Joao. Former husband of Karin Oliveira. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc. of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Road. Visiting Thursday and Friday 7-10PM.

title: AMR TO SPIN OFF STAKE IN SABRE HOLDINGS NEXT MONTH
description: The AMR Corporation set March 15 for the spinoff of its 83 percent stake in the Sabre Holdings Corporation, the world's biggest travel-reservation company, in a transaction valued at $5.69 billion. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, will distribute 107 million shares of Sabre to AMR stockholders as of March 1, at a rate of about seven-tenths of a Sabre share for each AMR share. Sabre also will pay a one-time cash dividend of $675 million on Feb. 18 to its shareholders as of Feb. 15. In December, AMR announced its decision to spin off Sabre, giving the travel company more freedom to negotiate with rival airlines and expand Internet services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACK, JANET PEARL
description: WALLACK-Janet Pearl. Passed away February 8th in her 92nd year. Beloved wife of the late Arnold, devoted mother of Frances and William Deutsch, and Maurice Wallack. Loving grandmother of Stephen & Jennifer Deutsch, Peter & Lisa Deutsch, Susan and Torben Weis, and Jennifer Wallack. Adoring great-grandmother of Alexander, Rebecca, Scott, Julia, and Natasha. Services on Thursday, February 10th, 10:30AM, at Gallaghers Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RETREATS. The yen fell to a five-month low against the dollar and a three-week low against the euro on concern Japan's economy is slipping back into recession. The yen fell to 109.35 a dollar from 108.78 in New York trading.

title: U.S. PRODUCTIVITY ROSE AT 5% RATE IN 2ND HALF OF '99
description: The efficiency of American workers surged in the last six months of 1999, the Labor Department reported yesterday. With these final numbers, the 1990's entered the books as the decade that produced the greatest improvement in productivity since the golden 1960's.

title: Flying Fingers on Guitar
description: Kelly Joe Phelps has a wise right hand. When playing his lap-steel acoustic guitar at the Knitting Factory, he would sometimes anchor that hand by the pinky and pick, his thumb and three other fingers whirling across the strings. On other songs, he would hold three fingers still and get a steadier but equally swift flow of notes from his index finger and thumb. Occasionally that right hand would run free across the guitar's body, strumming lightly up the fretboard and down to the bottom of the strings.

title: Indoor Gardening: How Dreams of Spring Yield Fields of Leeks
description: FEBRUARY is the end of the leek season -- and the beginning. Once the last of the fall crop has been sauteed, the garden catalogs set the mind to dreaming of how green the frozen landscape once was and will be again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEST, MORTON
description: WEST-Morton. Died February 8, 2000. Adored husband of Bette. Loving father of Susan and Robert. Beloved father-in-law of Warren and Mindy. Proud and loving grandfather of Melissa, Allie and Ross. Cherished brother of Babs. Services at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, 11:15A.M. Thursday, February 10.

title: Tiger's Streak
description: If you are a professional golfer, you do not want to be on the same course with Tiger Woods these days -- whether a stroke or two behind him, or tied with him or even ahead of him by a commanding margin -- because chances are you are going to lose. Woods won his sixth straight victory on the P.G.A. tour at Pebble Beach on Monday, coming from seven shots down with seven of the most difficult holes in golf left to play. Obviously, someone had to lose this tournament (it was a rookie named Matt Gogel, who made four bogeys down the stretch), but then again, Woods had to play spectacularly well to turn Gogel's lapses into victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLS, LEE
description: HILLS-Lee. The Trustees and Staff of the American Federation of Arts are profoundly saddened by the passing of their beloved friend, Lee Hills, a steadfast Trustee of the AFA and active champion of the arts, education, and freedom of expression. We will miss his enlightened leadership, farsighted thinking, and moral resolve. Heartfelt condolences to Lee's cherished wife Tina and the family. Robert Meltzer, Chairman Jan Mayer, President Serena Rattazzi, Director

title: China's Pipa Has an Ally In the Harps Of Uganda
description: Alliances that politics and music history never imagined were tested at Town Hall on Saturday night when the World Music Institute presented its 15th-anniversary benefit concert. For one night, the institute's usual purism was suspended.

title: Mending Russian Fences
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column of Business Day on Monday, about a new system of measuring human pain, misstated the affiliation of an inventor, Dr. A. Vania Apkarian. He is a neuroscientist at SUNY's Upstate Medical University in Syracuse, not at SUNY in Albany.

title: New York City Subway and Bus Workers Approve Contract
description: Despite a vigorous effort by dissidents to reject the contract, New York City's subway and bus workers have ratified the proposed agreement that was negotiated in December under the threat of a strike and huge fines, the Transport Workers Union announced yesterday.

title: EU Investigates Windows 2000
description: EU Investigates Windows 2000

title: Fashionably Early: New York Starts Buzzing Before Dusk
description: THE early-bird special. Is there a more mocked and maligned dining ritual? Who eats before 8 o'clock? It's so Boca Raton, so AARP, so tacky as to be ripe for reinvention as New York's next big dining trend -- as long as everyone agrees to call it something else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, EDITH
description: WEINER-Edith, on February 8, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Hyman. Loving mother of Mark and his wife Rose and Jerome and his wife Paula. Cherished grandmother of Robin and Rebecca. Dear sister of Diane Port and Penny Bigelow. Services Thursday 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to The Leavitt Family Jewish Nursing Home, Longmeadow, MA.

title: Such a Pleasure, So Brief a Stay: Maine Shrimp
description: EVEN as some places in New York are trying to jump-start spring with soft-shell crabs and shad roe in February, a shellfish with its own short season is suddenly turning up in fish markets and restaurants all over town.

title: ECI TELECOM TO BUY HUBBLE UNIT FOR AROUND $90 MILLION
description: ECI Telecom Ltd., Israel's largest telecommunications equipment maker, said yesterday that it would buy a division of Hubble Inc. for as much as $90 million.
