ECI said the acquisition of WavePacer, a unit of the Hubbell subsidiary Pulse Communications, would give it technology and marketing channels to compete for the business of regional United States telephone companies. ECI, which is controlled by Koor Industries, said the acquisition would help it sell at least $15 million worth of high-speed modems in the United States in 2000.

title: Aim a Little Higher
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZYWOTOW, SAMUEL
description: ZYWOTOW-Samuel. 2/9/93. I will alway give you life. You were my happiness, my everything. Yours, Lorrain

title: Doctor Links Diallo Death To Early Shot
description: The pathologist who performed the autopsy on Amadou Diallo's body testified today that the bullet that tore through his aorta and spinal cord, and probably caused his death, came early in the barrage of 19 shots that struck him as he stood in the lobby of his Bronx apartment building one year ago. And, the doctor said, at least one bullet hit Mr. Diallo while he was lying on the floor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENSON, LEONARD H.
description: GOLDENSON-Leonard H. Founder and Chairman of the Board of ABC, Inc., 1953-1986, died in Sarasota, Florida on December 27, 1999 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife, Isabelle Weinstein Goldenson, his two daughters, Loreen Arbus and Maxine Goldenson, both of Los Angeles, and one grandson, Lucas. A Memorial Service will be held Friday, February 11, 10:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. Contributions can be made in his memory to The Dr. William Berenberg Fund for Handicapped Children, C/O Children's Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVAK, EDMUND T.
description: SPIVAK-Edmund T. On February 8. Beloved husband of Joyce. Father of Mariann Kump and the late Edmund T. Jr. Dear brother of Barbara Hayes, Thomas, Richard and the late Ruth Haag. Also survived by six grandchildren. Reposing at the Hess-Miller Funeral Home, 64-19 Metropolitan Ave, Middle Village, NY until 9AM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal RC, 9:45am followed by cremation.

title: PRIMUS TO EXPAND IN EUROPEAN MARKET WITH ACQUISITION
description: Primus Telecommunications Group, an Internet and telecommunications service provider, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held LCR Telecom Group for about $105.3 million in stock. The London-based LCR resells voice and data services to 10,000 customers in Britain, France, Spain and Belgium. Primus offers long-distance, Internet access and data services in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region. The company, based in McLean, Va., is aiming at the fast-growing European telecommunications market. Primus shares rose $4.25 each, to $42.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASQUALE, MARGARET
description: PASQUALE-Margaret. The New York County District Attorney's Office notes with profound sadness the death of Assistant District Attorney Margaret Pasquale. Maggi was a valued member of the legal staff for 13 years who served as Deputy Bureau Chief of the Family Violence and Child Abuse Bureau. We will miss her kindness, her friendship, and her wise counsel. Her abilities as a trial lawyer and her compassion for victims and witnesses were unparalleled. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Kevin Berry, and their two young children, Kevin and Bridget. Robert M. Morgenthau, District Attorney of New York County

title: In France, Pill Is Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Religion is not just religion here. It is a thing of social identity. The Christians do not want to give in and the Muslims do not want to give in.''

title: French and Indian, in Harmony
description: RAJI JALLEPALLI, the chef and owner of Restaurant Raji in Memphis, was a late bloomer. In her book, ''Raji Cuisine: Indian Flavors, French Passion'' (HarperCollins, $35), she writes that she began her restaurant after having had another career and after having children. She was just a home cook, with no professional training.

title: CRITIC's NOTEBOOK; A Winning Formula For Players and Listeners
description: With the notable number of important American orchestras looking to fill vacancies in music director positions right now, it was just a matter of time before one of them tapped Robert Spano. The 38-year-old conductor has been a notable presence on the international orchestra and opera circuit and has won particular attention for his accomplishments with the Brooklyn Philharmonic. Yesterday the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra appointed him its next music director, starting full time in the 2001-02 season.

title: Nets Release Frustration With First-Half Outburst
description: If all the misery, sadness and frustration the Nets endured over the last three weeks could be made up for in 48 minutes, the recompense would look something like what transpired tonight at Continental Arena.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Can He Carry Vote As Well as a Tune?

title: The Big City; Vouchers, A Trade-Off To Look At
description: IN her speech announcing her candidacy on Sunday, Hillary Rodham Clinton told of visiting an overcrowded school in Queens.

title: To Take a Test, Perhaps to Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Whole Leaves, No Strings For a New Tea Bag

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEWIS, MOLLIE B.
description: LEWIS-Mollie B. A memorial service for Mollie B. Lewis, deceased on January 11, 2000, will be held on Friday, February 11, 2000 at 2PM at the Lotos Club, 5 East 66 St.

title: Siegel & Gale, a brand and image makeover consultant, decides to practice what it preaches.
description: A CONSULTING company known for rebranding advertisers is rebranding itself.

title: Judge Asked to Bar Gang From Gathering
description: The New York Police Department asked a judge yesterday for a new tool to combat prostitution and other crimes by street gangs: an injunction that would prohibit people identified as members of the Bloods gang, or their associates, from congregating at night in a particular part of Queens.

title: Pinochet Foes Are Granted An Appeal
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet's hopes of being freed from house arrest and allowed to return home to Chile soon suffered a setback today when a British court said it would hear an appeal of Britain's decision that he was not medically fit to stand trial on torture charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMILTON, THOMAS PARKER, JR., DR.
description: HAMILTON-Thomas Parker, Jr., Dr. Died February 8, 2000. Retired surgeon. Resided Tenafly, N.J. He is survived by his wife Ruth, sons Thomas P. Hamilton, III of Seminole, Fla., Lawrence R. Hamilton of Saratoga Springs, N.Y. and his daughter Virginia H. Idyll of Toronto, Ca; granddaughters Holly Boldrin, Kimberly Hamilton, Parker B. Hamilton, Candy R. Hamilton. Additional survivors are stepdaughter Betsey Colby, Wayland, Ma., step-son Ned Taft of Wellesley, Ma. and step-grandchildren Kate, Charles and Caroline Colby and Betsey and Ben Taft. Dr. Hamilton was a graduate of Mercersburg Academy, Princeton University and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Dr. Hamilton was a surgeon with the US Army Medical Corp. His unit landed on Omaha Beach on D-Day. As a Major, he was awarded the Bronze Star for heroic service. Contribution in his memory may be made to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 6931 Arlington Road, Bethesda, Maryland 20814. A private memorial service will be held in May.

title: Regarding Customers as Business Collaborators
description: C.K. PRAHALAD believes a Copernican revolution is putting the consumer at the active center of the business universe. That is his vision of the Internet economy, and he isn't by himself.

title: Labor Federation to Give Teamsters $500,000 in Support for Trucking Strike
description: In an unusual move, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. pledged yesterday to give $500,000 to the Teamsters union to help strengthen its hand in a 16-week-old strike against the Overnite Transportation Company, one of the nation's largest nonunion trucking companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELEN, ARTHUR
description: SEELEN-Arthur. On February 7, 2000. Owner of The Drama Book Shop. Beloved husband of Rozanne. Loving uncle and greatuncle. Services Thursday, 12:30 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Wednesday, 7-9 P.M. Interment at Beth David Cemetery.

title: Reckonings; The Japan Syndrome
description: When Japan's Kansai International Airport was being planned, there was considerable uncertainty over how much the artificial island on which it sits would sink. The officials in charge chose to accept the lowest, most favorable estimate; as it turned out, the reality has been worse than even the most pessimistic estimate, and despite expensive emergency measures -- and continual assurances from those officials that everything is under control -- the island is still sinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSER, RABBI MAX RAPHAEL
description: WASSER-Rabbi Max Raphael. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1944, he served several pulpits including congregation B'rith Shalom in Bethlehem and Congregation of Mercy and Truth in Pottstown, PA. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Judith, children, David, Deborah, and Shari, siblings, Rose, Leah and Sam and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Running Town the Clintons Now Call Home
description: NO, Marion S. Sinek didn't switch her Lexus for a Welcome Wagon and tool over from Town Hall to bestow a Welcome-to-Chappaqua casserole on the luminaries who still carry keys to the 132-room White House but have moved into the white colonial (vintage, too, but with 121 fewer rooms to rattle around in) that's the namesake of Old House Lane here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, STELLA A.
description: KOENIG-Stella A. On February 7, 2000. Age 99. Adored and adoring wife of Mortimer H., mother of the late Dr. M. Glenn Koenig. Beloved grandmother of Mark A. and Scott R. Koenig. Also survived by Constance R. Koenig McIntyre, the remarkable widow of Glenn, and her husband Tom McIntyre; greatgrandchildren Alexandra M. and Samuel M.; Mark's wife Debra; and many nieces, nephews and friends galore. Stella, dear Stella rest in peace. Service Thursday, February 10 at 12 noon at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to M. Glenn Koenig Fund at Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tenn.

title: Bulldogs Get Lesson In Losing
description: WOMEN

title: F.B.I.'s New York Office Head Leaving for a Delaware Bank
description: Lewis D. Schiliro, the head of the New York office of the F.B.I., is to retire next month after a 25-year-career in which he oversaw investigations ranging from racketeering by Mafia figures on the streets of Little Italy to terrorist attacks on United States citizens around the world.

title: F.B.I. Casts a Wide Net With Plenty of Tangles
description: Anthony P. Hodgson thought he had the right stuff to make it in the aerospace industry.

title: Groups Reconsider Bookings at Hotels Accused of Racial Bias
description: The Adam's Mark hotel chain, facing a federal racial discrimination suit, has lost the patronage of two national organizations, and two other groups that had booked rooms for national conferences are considering cancellations.

title: Friends Fear for Radio Reporter Still Missing in Chechnya
description: Friends and colleagues of a Russian reporter for the American-funded Radio Liberty have been making increasingly frantic appeals for information about him five days after Russia announced that it had handed him over to Chechen rebels.

title: THE CHEF
description: CRAB cakes should just taste of crab, in an almost unaltered state. The meat is so sweet and rich that it needs very little enhancement to elevate it into a decadent eating experience. And that means crab cakes themselves should be anything but the dense, heavy hockey pucks seen in so many restaurants.

title: To Take a Test, Perhaps to Learn; Fear and Fourth Grade
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Clinton Favors American Access to Cheaper Canadian Medicines
description: Wading back into an area that brought her both national prominence and a high-profile defeat, Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged today to push anew for universal health care coverage, proposing legislation that would give consumers unrestricted access to low-cost prescription drugs sold in Canada.

title: ASTRA PRESIDENT DISMISSED
description: Indonesia's Bank Restructuring Agency succeeded in ousting the president of the automaker Astra International in an extraordinary shareholders meeting. The agency called the meeting to seek permission to replace the management over what it said was executives' opposition to selling a 43 percent stake. Rini Soewandi, above, was removed as president and will be replaced by Theodore Rachmat, a member of the family that founded Astra in 1957. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a program in France that provides morning-after abortion pills to students in high school and junior high misstated the name of another drug, known as RU-486, which can terminate pregnancies up to 12 weeks after conception. It is mifepristone, not methapristone.

title: ALITALIA TO CUT FLIGHTS
description: Italy's national airline, Alitalia, said it would reduce flights and stop hiring after delays in switching routes to a new airport at Malpensa near Milan hurt its profit. Alitalia's strategy, and its alliance with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, center on transferring business to Malpensa from the Linate airport in Milan. The transfer was halted in December after the European Union said it discriminated against some airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOULTON, SCHROEDER
description: BOULTON-Schroeder, on February 6th, aged 91. Survived by daughters, Janet Boulton and Nancy Boulton-LeGates. Memorial service Saturday, February 12, 2 PM, First Unitarian Church, 50 Monroe Place, Brooklyn Heights, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERRY, EDWARD NORMAN
description: SHERRY-Edward Norman, a prominent attorney retired from the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, passed away at home on February 4, 2000 after a long courageous fight with cancer. He was born in Schenectady, NY on August 25, 1920. He received his B.E.E. at Syracuse Univ. (1943), LL.B Yale U. 1948, Bar NY 1952, US Supreme Ct. 1965, US Court of Appeals (3rd Cir.) 1953, (2d Cir) 1968, (5th Cir.) 1971, (9th Cir.) 1981, US District Ct (so. Dist) NY 1953, US District Ct. (no. Dist) Okla 1955, US Dist. Ct. (we Dist) NY (1953), US Dist Ct (ea Dist.) NY (1978). Served with USN 1944-46. Fellow American College of Trial Law yers; member ABA, Assn. Bar City NY, NY State Bar Assn; member Am. Judicature Soc. Clubs; Yale, Down Town (NYC); Nantucket Yacht (Mass); Club Colette (Palm Beach, FLa); Indian Harbor Yacht Club (Greenwich, Ct) Old Port Yacht Club (N. Palm Beach, FLa.) He leaves behind his devoted wife Jeanette, five children and two grandchildren. One grandson predeased him in 1998. A memorial Service will be held graveside at Riverside Memorial Park, 19351 S.E. County Line Road, Tequesta on Friday, February 11 at 2 pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue West Palm Beach, FL 33407. For information Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, Jupiter, FL.

title: Buy.com Stock Nearly Doubles Issue Price
description: Buy.com Stock Nearly Doubles Issue Price

title: Atlanta Selects Brooklyn Conductor
description: Robert Spano, who has won high praise as conductor of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, was named music director of the Atlanta Symphony today, beginning with the 2001-02 season. Donald Runnicles, music director of the San Francisco Opera, was named principal guest conductor. But both men will keep their current affiliations.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Just Play It Cool

title: Electronic Exchange in Sweden
description: Electronic Exchange in Sweden

title: Bouley, in His Klimt Period
description: DAVID BOULEY does not do things in a small way. His ambitions are boundless, and his complex, ever-changing schemes to establish a personal culinary empire make him one of the more attention-getting and baffling figures on the restaurant scene. He is the Stanley Kubrick of New York chefs -- difficult to get a read on, by most accounts difficult to deal with, but always pointed in a direction that feels as though it will lead straight to the next big thing.

title: Teacher Incentive Plan Pays Off Despite Fears
description: When a group of corporate leaders announced in 1998 that it would award cash bonuses to school superintendents, principals and teachers who improved test scores in several troubled districts, supporters praised the plan as a revolutionary effort to make schools more like businesses. But critics warned that the experiment would hurt morale and even encourage cheating.

title: Armstrong's Group To Give Information
description: The cyclist Lance Armstrong knows well the panic and frustration of knowing too little about cancer. After learning that he had testicular cancer in late 1996, Armstrong could not find a central place with the information he needed about cancer and how to treat it. He didn't know the questions to ask his doctor.

title: A Big Chef, a Tiny Target
description: IT is no secret that many great chefs are perfectionists. They are precise technicians in the kitchen and just as demanding in running their dining rooms. But Charlie Trotter, the chef and owner of Charlie Trotter's in Chicago, might take his drive for perfection a step further than others.

title: Devils' Penalty Killers in Spotlight
description: The Devils' penalty-killing unit is one reason they have the best record in the National Hockey League, and last night it was responsible for earning a point against the Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Cisco's Revenue and Profit Soar, as Do Its Shares After Hours
description: The love fest between Wall Street and Cisco Systems reached a new level of ardor today as the company surpassed earnings estimates and reported a 53 percent gain in revenue for the second quarter, prompting investors to send its shares to a 52-week high.

title: Harmony and Bottom Line: Hmm . . .
description: Last spring, everything seemed to go wrong at Lunch at the Ritz Earwear Inc., a maker of custom jewelry in Lake Katrine, N.Y., about 100 miles north of New York. Several wholesale dealers it had served went out of business and sales plunged 30 percent. Key employees quit for no apparent reason and absenteeism soared.

title: Preschool Program Serves Whole Family's Needs
description: Eight years ago, Carmen Casas begged a neighbor to help her escape the civil war in El Salvador that had been raging for more than a decade. Young women were being taken from their homes in the middle of the night and not returning, Ms. Casas recalls. Despite the risks and expenses, she said she felt ready to move to a new country and be responsible for her own life.

title: Hijackers Still Hold Jet, But Make No Demands
description: More than 150 passengers spent their third night aboard a hijacked Afghan airliner today, held prisoner by an armed gang who perplexed police by giving no explanation for their seizure of the plane or making any political demands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, BONNIE
description: CASHIN-Bonnie on February 3, 2000. A memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Innocents on Death Row
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Former Trader Sues Goldman, Charging Firing Was Illegal
description: A former bond trader for the Goldman Sachs Group contends in a lawsuit that the investment bank fired him last year because he was having an extramarital affair with a co-worker, and his boss had religious objections to the relationship.

title: Pay the Survivors Of the Riot in Tulsa
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Real Estate; Hall for Midsize Exhibits Is Planned for Pier 94
description: A new exhibition hall called the Unconvention Center, one mile north of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and about one-third its size, is being planned for Pier 94 by the Giuliani administration and private developers.

title: Mexican Police Release 654 Arrested in Raid on University
description: Moving swiftly to blunt protests against the police occupation of the national university, Mexican justice authorities announced today that they have freed 654 of the 745 people arrested in the raid on Sunday that ended a nine-month student strike.

title: What Labels Don't Tell You (Yet)
description: FOR nearly a decade, genetically engineered food has been sold in the United States just like any other food. There are no labels telling consumers that their tortilla chips contain genetically altered corn -- about a third of the total crop -- or that almost all canola oil is made from genetically altered rapeseed.

title: Banks React With Shock to a Plan by Tokyo to Tax Profits
description: Shares of Japan's major banks fell today after the Tokyo metropolitan government announced a startling plan to impose a temporary tax on their operating profits.

title: Reuters' Shares Soar on Internet Strategy
description: Reuters Group said today that it planned to reposition itself as a highflying Internet concern. Word of the financial news service's ambitions caused shares of Reuters to soar 23 percent, their largest one-day gain in more than a decade.

title: EBay Says Flood of Fake Data Crashed Web Pages
description: EBay Says Flood of Fake Data Crashed Web Pages

title: South Africa Preparing to Sell Its 4 Big State-Run Companies
description: Eager for more foreign investment, South Africa is promising to expand privatization in coming months to its biggest state-owned companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, ROBERT M.
description: COLLINS-Robert M. On February 6. Husband of the late Joyce (Reardon). Father of Scott N. Collins. A Memorial Service will be held in Dennis Union Church, Dennis, MA, on Friday, February 11th. at 11 AM. Memorials in his name may be made to The Gavin Foundation, PO Box E15, South Boston, MA 02127.

title: Sports of The Times; Heartbreak Strikes Good People
description: WHILE Violet and Adam Graves's twin sons fought for their lives, there was no moratorium of outward grace from this most generous of families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELSENER, ACKLEY VINCENT
description: DELSENER-Ackley Vincent, February 8, 2000, at age 90. Beloved husband of the late Ethel (nee Klein) for 68 years. Devoted father of Harriette Delsener and Ronald Delsener. Devoted father-in-law of Ellin Delsener. Cherished grandfather of Robert, Jeffrey, Riley, Scott David Riley and Samantha Leigh Delsener and great-grandfather of Enzo Riley, Marina Riley and Lily Maya Marvin. Devoted brother of Minnie Delsener. Friends may call Wednesday, February 9, 2-5 & 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue & 81st Street. Service on Thursday, February 10, at 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell. Interment private.

title: Gore, the Artist, Detours From the Trail to the Stage
description: Not every politician gets to grace the salons of the New York art world, as Al Gore did on Monday night.

title: Not to See, but to Be Believed; Family Artisans Design Artificial Eyes for Real Needs
description: Her canvas is a small nugget of acrylic, and Annette Kirszrot will work on it for an hour, painting a portrait smaller than a dime, checking back and forth between her work and the person sitting a few feet away in her examining chair.

title: Louima Questioned on Conflicting Statements
description: Three defense lawyers led Abner Louima through a thicket of questions yesterday during more than two hours of tense cross-examination intended to damage his credibility by exposing inconsistencies in his testimony.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Gold declined as a drop in charges for lending gold renewed concern that some producers are selling borrowed gold as a hedge against falling prices. The April contract fell $2.80, to $301.70 an ounce.

title: Yankees Put Mendoza On the Trading Block
description: Ramiro Mendoza has been a coveted member of the Yankees' organization the last few years because he has been an effective and relatively inexpensive pitcher. But now that Mendoza's salary is beginning to spiral upward, the Yankees are considering trading him for a pitcher who is just as effective but less expensive.

title: For Rangers, a Meaningful Game Is Rendered Meaningless
description: The Rangers did not defeat the Devils in a regular-season game for the first time in more than three years. But they did not lose again, either.

title: More Top Web Sites Brought Down
description: More Top Web Sites Brought Down

title: Harmful Cuba Embargo
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis Is Fighting Grant And Looking for Tyson
description: They stood Michael Grant and Lennox Lewis between a scale model of the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building on the left and the twin towers of the World Trade Center on the right. They're calling their April 29 bout at Madison Square Garden ''13 Feet and 500 Pounds of Fight.''

title: Rocker's Grievance Hearing Set for Today
description: Baseball's commissioner, Bud Selig, and the player he punished with the stiffest penalty for speech in baseball history will come face to face today as the players association tries to have John Rocker's 73-day suspension overturned or, at the least, reduced.

title: More Foreign High-Tech Workers Sought
description: More Foreign High-Tech Workers Sought

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURR, BERYL L.
description: BURR-Beryl L. on February 1, 2000 of Garden City. Loving mother of Dr. Timothy L. and Beth Turnbull. Cherished grandmother of Seicha and Kira. Service at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, Wednesday at 11:00 am.

title: Amazon Subsidiary Subject of FTC Probe and Two Lawsuits
description: Amazon Subsidiary Subject of FTC Probe and Two Lawsuits

title: Morley Meredith, 77, Baritone Who Sang 40 Roles at the Met
description: Morley Meredith, a versatile baritone who sang 40 roles in 31 seasons at the Metropolitan Opera, died last Thursday at the Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center in Florida. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, WILLIAM GEORGE
description: O'Donnell-William George, 63, of Manhattan on February 6, 2000. Friend and husband of Frances. Father of Sean. Mr. O'Donnell was the former president of American Business Press.

title: Conflict Resolution in Congo:  Is There an Answer?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Metro Business; Times Square Loses Its Mouse for Now
description: The Disney store that has come to symbolize the recent transformation of Times Square from a sleazy neighborhood to a family-oriented tourist attraction has temporarily gone dark. Yesterday, workers removed an 800-pound Mickey Mouse clock from above the doorway and got it ready for shipment to California.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bond Market Seems Wary Of Amazon
description: Investors have long been happy to suspend their disbelief when they buy shares of Amazon.com. Jeff Bezos's plan to spend whatever he must to build Amazon.com into the must-stop for Web shopping has produced losses of $882 million since its creation in 1994. And even though the company reported that its book business actually made money in the most recent quarter, Amazon.com's overall business is still years away from turning a profit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, ARLYNE
description: LANGER-Arlyne, 80, formerly of Brooklyn & Belle Harbor, Queens died on Monday, February 7, 2000 in Olivebridge, NY. Wife of Arthur Langer, mother of Andrew and Richard Langer, sister of the late Florence Sass and Ann Levy. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of Ulster County, 34 Broadway, Kingston, NY 12401. For information, Call SimpsonGaus Funeral Home (914) 331-0631

title: A Bumpy Path For Miami Kin Of Cuban Boy
description: For more than two months the Florida family of Elian Gonzalez has been a staple of the nightly news. There is Elian, the 6-year-old refugee, swinging a baseball bat in front of the little stucco house in a working-class neighborhood of Little Havana. There he is kicking a soccer ball with his great-uncle Lazaro Gonzalez and hugging Marisleysis, his cousin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERETY, JOHN L., REV.
description: GERETY-John L., Rev. Msgr pastor emeritus of St. Mary R.C. Church, South Amboy, New Jersey died January 25, 2000. Brother of Archbishop Emeritus of Newark, Archbishop Peter Leo Gerety, The Honorable Thomas C. Gerety, Dr. Robert P. Gerety, Dr. Edward J. Gerety, the late Richard, William, Eugene and Pierce Gerety. Funeral services were held January 29, 2000 at St. Mary R.C. Church, South Amboy. Interment Mt. St. Peter Cemetery, Derby, CT.

title: INSIDE
description: New Warship for China

title: ANACOMP PLANS TO EXPLORE SALE OR MERGER OF COMPANY
description: Anacomp Inc. said yesterday that it was exploring a merger or sale of the company and had hired the New York investment banker Allen & Company to help it evaluate alternatives. Anacomp, based in Poway, Calif., also said it had ended a stock buyback announced in September. The company had planned to buy back up to 2 percent of its common stock through Sept. 30. As of Jan. 4, the company had 14.3 million shares outstanding. Anacomp provides digital document-management services using the Internet and other technologies. Its shares climbed 56.25 cents each, to $18.1875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: The Colossus That Became a Choir's Mainstay
description: With Bach performances already thick on the ground in the 250th-anniversary year of his death, it is remarkable to realize that 100 years ago his great B minor Mass had yet to be performed in the United States. That gap was remedied on March 27, 1900, by the Bach Choir, which had been formed for the purpose two years earlier by J. Fred Wolle in Bethlehem, Pa., and which offered the work on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall to celebrate the centenary of its achievement.

title: Doug Henning, a Superstar Of Illusion, Is Dead at 52
description: Doug Henning, the ebullient, shaggy-headed magician who sparked a renewed interest in the craft and breathed new life into some of history's most famous illusions, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 52 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Elective Office: What's Gender Got to Do With It?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Neighborly Wine Bar With the Emphasis on the Food
description: IN Paris, a wine bar is a specific type of informal, convivial restaurant, somewhere between a cafe and a bistro, a hangout where wine is not invested with great importance but is always present. Satisfying food is a crucial component, too. It may be only charcuterie or bread and fragrant goat cheese, but often it's much more, hearty dishes like choucroute or confit.

title: Our Teachers' Other 'Careers'
description: THERE is a shoeshine stand at the elegant Nordstrom store in the Westchester Mall, and on Sundays the man snapping a cloth over loafers and oxfords is Timo Hughes. Although the customers tip him well, his is not the classical tale of a pauper or immigrant trying to buff his way up the American ladder on a smile and someone else's shoeshine.

title: To Take a Test, Perhaps to Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooling Consumer Demand for Athletic Shoes Shrinks Nike's Profit
description: Americans just are not sneaker mad like they used to be, and no amount of priming and pumping the advertising spigot by Nike can make it otherwise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBBS, KATHRYN BARRY
description: DOBBS-Kathryn Barry of Stamford, CT., on February 7, 2000. Mother of Kathryn Liljestrand, Kevin McCormack, Christopher McCormack and Sheila Schreyer. Sister of Patricia Eigo, Maureen Meaney & Desmond T. Barry, Jr. Friends may call on Thursday, February 10, 2000 from 5 to 8 PM at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, Feb. 11, 2000 at 1 PM at St. John's Church, Darien, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to VNA Hospice Care, P.O. Box 110 315, Stamford, CT. 06911-0315.

title: Markets Stage Broad Rally On Strength of Labor Data
description: Stock prices staged a broad advance yesterday after a government report indicated the economy could continue to expand without an appreciable increase in inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REVSON, JULIE PHELPS
description: REVSON-Julie Phelps. Former wife of Revlon co-founder Martin Revson, died sunday, Febraury 6 in California. She is the mother of deceased race car driver Peter Revson and Douglas Revson. She is survived by her two daughters Julie Revson of Richmond, VA and Jennifer Revson of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. She also leaves behind her two grandsons Matthew Cox of Waitsfield, VT and Jason Sheldon of New York City and a sister Mrs. Elizabeth Graessle of White Plains, NY. Funeral service will be held this Saturday, February 12, at 11am at the Ballard Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, NY followed by interment at the Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REITMAN, EDWARD
description: REITMAN-Edward. Your spirit and love are with us always. Your family

title: Bridgemarket Brasserie
description: Picture a restaurant in a Gothic cathedral and you have a sense of the setting for Guastavino's, a 300-seat brasserie-style place opening next week at 409 East 59th Street in the Bridgemarket. The larger of two restaurants being installed there by Sir Terence Conran and Joel Kissin, Guastavino's will have a French-American menu with English touches. Several dishes will feature brains, kidneys and the like. The chef, Daniel Orr, was previously at La Grenouille.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRYFOROS, PETER
description: TRYFOROS-Peter. Mission Viejo, CA. February 5, 2000. Husband of Betina Tryforos. Brother of Electra Tsucalas and Nicholas Tryforos. Formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y. Member of St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church, Irvine, CA. Member of, and active in, local and national floral organizations.

title: Several Web Sites Attacked Following Assault on Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 -- Hackers mounted what appeared to be coordinated attacks on the world's largest electronic commerce sites today.

title: THAILAND RECOVERY
description: Citing a speedy economic resurgence in Thailand, the International Monetary Fund said it would not draft new policy conditions when its agreement with Bangkok expires at the end of March. Thailand is scheduled to emerge in June from the I.M.F.'s program of quarterly reviews, part of a $17.2 billion economic aid package signed in August 1997. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: After Upset of Syracuse, Seton Hall Assumes the Role of the Hunted Against Rutgers
description: While preparing for Syracuse, Seton Hall Coach Tommy Amaker told his players the improbability of a team going undefeated. If a loss was inevitable, he asked, ''Why not us?''

title: U.S. Offers U.N. Resolution For 5,500-Troop Congo Force
description: After a series of high-level meetings last month about how to end a widening war in Congo, the United States introduced a Security Council resolution today to create a peacekeeping force of 5,500 troops for the country, but said they should not be deployed until the warring factions had stopped fighting.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/9/94. Wish you could have made it to 2000. Thought of you then, as always. Miss you. Vicki

title: Corrections
description: The introduction to a chart in Business Day on Feb. 1 tracing the performance of the Nasdaq composite index during years in which it fell in January -- as it did this year -- referred incorrectly to the behavior that followed in those years. As shown on the graph, the index later rose in three of the years; it did not fall in all seven.

title: Andro Study Finds Increased Hormones
description: The over-the-counter diet supplement androstenedione has been found to increase the male hormone testosterone, but scientists still do not know if it helped Mark McGwire hit 70 home runs in 1998. They plan to try to find out.

title: New Chinese Guided-Missile Ship Heightens Tension
description: China's first Russian-built guided-missile destroyer is expected to arrive in the East China Sea as early as this week, enhancing Beijing's ability to threaten American aircraft carriers in any future encounters over Taiwan.

title: GALILEO AGREES TO ACQUIRE REMAINING STAKE IN TRIP.COM
description: Galileo International Inc., which runs a global computer-reservation system for the travel industry, agreed yesterday to acquire the 80 percent of Trip.com it did not already own for $269 million in stock and cash. Galileo International, based in Rosemont, Ill., is the No. 2 computer-reservation system worldwide based on the number of transactions booked last year. The company said it planned to combine its existing Internet assets with those of Trip.com, which had been a closely held company. Trip.com, once part of U S West Inc. of Denver, started in 1996. Galileo purchased its initial 20 percent stake last year. Trip.com has 3.5 million registered users. Shares in Galileo were down 37.5 cents each, to $23.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARGER, HENRY
description: KARGER-Henry. On February 7, 2000. Beloved brother of Ilse and Marie Karger, and uncle of Ralph Meyer. Visiting hours Thursday 1:00-2:00 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, to be followed by burial in Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAKLOW, SALLY L.
description: ZAKLOW-Sally L. Beloved wife of the late Myron. Loved mother of Jill, Betsy and Lenny. Adored ''G.G.'' of Allie, Max, Meir, Akiva and Shmuel. Devoted sister of Marilyn and Jorome Weiss.

title: Man Charged in Attack On Woman in Subway
description: An 18-year-old woman was attacked on an East Harlem subway platform shortly after midnight yesterday by a homeless man who tried to carry her to another part of the station to assault her sexually, the police said.

title: Religious Warfare On Indonesian Isles Bodes Wide Chaos
description: The most frightening sound is the wild banging of stones on metal light poles, a ringing crescendo of panic that begins nobody-knows-where and spreads in moments around this violent, broken seaside town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITKEI, ERVIN
description: LITKEI-Ervin, February 8, 2000. Beloved husband of Andrea; loving father of Dr. Cathy Litkei and her husband Jeffry Greene. Cherished grandfather of Phillip, Amy, Alexandra and Jamie. A prominent composer whose works are recorded in the Congressional Record and the Songwriters Hall of Fame. He composed the Presidential Marches from Franklin Delano Roosevelt through and including William Jefferson Clinton. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, MARGARET (MAGGI)
description: BERRY-Margaret (Maggi) Pasquale, of Rockville Centre, NY on February 7, 2000. Deputy Chief Family Violence and Child Abuse Bureau of the Manhattan District Attorney's Office. Beloved wife Kevin. Loving mother of Kevin and Bridget. Devoted daughter of Florence and John Pasquale. Dear sister of Casey and Catherine Stern. Reposing today and Thursday 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 pm, Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre. Funeral Mass, St. Agnes Cathedral, Friday 10:00 am. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to Memorial Cancer Center, Breast Cancer Research, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021, in Maggi's name is appreciated.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: WORLD TRADE; RECORD IN FOREIGN INVESTMENT
description: Foreign direct investment grew worldwide by 25 percent in 1999, to a record $827 billion, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development said in an annual report. The main reason was cross-border mergers and acquisitions. The report also showed Britain replaced the United States as the largest investor. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Doctor Is Indicted In Carving of Patient
description: The obstetrician who carved his initials into a woman's belly after delivering her baby at Beth Israel Medical Center has been indicted, one of his lawyers said last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERBESH, NESSIM
description: ERBESH-Nessim. Beloved husband of Neama. Dear father of Morris and Tina. Adored grandfather of Neil and Vidal.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Chief Asks to End His Security Clearance
description: A former Central Intelligence Agency director, John M. Deutch, asked the Pentagon today to drop his last remaining security clearances, which had remained in effect even after the agency's current director suspended his highest clearances last August.

title: BUSH EASILY BEATS FOES IN DELAWARE
description: In the first contest after his bruising defeat in New Hampshire a week ago, Gov. George W. Bush handily won the Republican primary in Delaware today.

title: Waking Up to Taxes
description: Hillary Clinton told this newspaper that she was stunned to discover how high taxes are in New York State. Yet in announcing her candidacy on Sunday, she didn't seem inclined to do much about our burden: the only tax cuts she embraced were a deduction for college tuition and a credit for the care of aging or disabled family members.

title: McCain Launches a New Salvo
description: This 30-second advertisement from the McCain campaign is a companion to another attack ad that also began running on Monday in South Carolina.

title: Bush and McCain, Sittin' in a Tree, D-I-S-S-I-N-G
description: Minutes before their first face-off in a presidential debate two months ago, Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain shared a gesture that distilled the remarkable and seemingly durable amity between them. With their arms extended and their faces lit by smiles, the two embraced.

title: Editorial Observer; When Personal Appeal Trumps Party Labels
description: Political consultants, pollsters and commentators like to nurse the impression that political outcomes are highly predictable along proven analytical lines, and sometimes they are. For example, a Democratic presidential candidate with A.F.L.-C.I.O. backing is very hard to defeat in the Iowa caucuses, as Bill Bradley wishes he had remembered.

title: Metro Business; Investment in Wiring
description: Intellispace, which has wired Rockefeller Center and other large buildings for high-speed Internet access, said yesterday that it had received a $35 million investment from Chase Capital Partners and Weston Presidio Capital to help it expand.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Honors
description: * The Association of Independent Commercial Producers, Los Angeles and New York, re-elected national officers for 2000. Alex Blum, partner at Headquarters, New York and Santa Monica, Calif., continues as chairman, and Alfred Califano, partner at OneSuch Films, Los Angeles and New York, remains vice chairman.

title: Setbacks to Mideast Peace
description: Shortly after being sworn in as Israel's prime minister last July, Ehud Barak announced an accelerated timetable for reaching broad new peace agreements with the Palestinians and Syria. Seven months later there seems little chance he can realize those expectations as quickly as he hoped, but the delays and renewed turbulence in the Middle East do not mean a durable peace is unattainable.

title: G.M. PENSION FUND REDUCES STAKE IN E.D.S. BY $1.5 BILLION
description: The General Motors Corporation's largest pension plan will reduce its stake in the Electronic Data Systems Corporation by about $1.5 billion. The G.M. pension fund for hourly employees, E.D.S.'s largest shareholder, will sell 20 million common shares, cutting its stake to 12 percent. E.D.S., the No. 2 United States computer-services company, was bought by G.M. in 1984 and spun off in 1996. The pension plan for G.M., the world's largest automaker, has sold E.D.S. shares periodically. The most recent sale lets the fund benefit from a turnaround that E.D.S.'s chairman and chief executive, Richard Brown, has engineered since taking over 13 months ago.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE POLLS

title: Elective Office: What's Gender Got to Do With It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * LuckySurf.com, South San Francisco, Calif., a lottery-style Web site, to Red Ball Tiger, San Francisco, to handle its first account. Spending was estimated at $15 million. Media planning and buying are handled by Hawk Media, San Francisco.

title: At Least One Yankee Team Gets Its Wish
description: The Giuliani administration is nearing completion of a deal to construct what would be the country's most expensive minor league baseball stadium, a $71 million complex near the Staten Island ferry terminal that would be built entirely with taxpayer money.

title: Christopher Rios, 28, Rapper Recorded Under Name Big Pun
description: Christopher Rios, a 698-pound rapper who sold more than a million albums under the name Big Pun, died on Monday. He was 28.

title: Clinton Aides Push Budget to Congress
description: Clinton administration officials fanned out across Capitol Hill today to sell the merits of the president's budget plan, but found no takers among the Republican majority in Congress.

title: China Blocks Donations For Tiananmen Victims
description: The police have blocked a messenger from delivering $25,000 in foreign donations to help the families of people who were killed in the crackdown on the Tiananmen student democracy movement in June 1989, calling such aid a threat to national security,

title: CUNY and the Public Schools
description: The vitality of the City University of New York is inextricably tied to the success of the New York City school system. Almost half of the university's incoming freshmen are graduates of the city's public schools, and many are ill prepared for college-level courses. Yet there has been too little collaboration between the two systems to solve their mutual problems. The announcement by Matthew Goldstein, the chancellor of CUNY, and Harold Levy, the interim schools chancellor, about expanding a program to prepare high school students for college-level work is a welcome sign that the two systems are forming a real partnership.

title: Liberties; She's Dropping Names!
description: I just love the perky campaign slogan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEMAN, LEOLA JOHNSON
description: HAGEMAN-Leola Johnson. Beloved widow of Rev. Lynn Hageman, died Feb. 1 after a long illness. Loving mother of Hans, Ivan, Erika Robinson, and loving grandmother Jamila and Kiana. Memorial service Thursday, Feb. 10 at 11AM, St. Mary's Episcopal Church, 521 W. 126 St, near Bway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUARDINO, ALPHONSO V.
description: GUARDINO-Alphonso V. 88, of Pompano Beach, FL, and Sheepshead Bay, NY, on February 7, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Rita (nee Carvell), loving, proud and generous father of Anthony and Robert, caring father-in-law of Eleanor, devoted and proud grandfather of Victoria. Friends may call at John J. Healey Funeral Home, 2977 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, Wednesday, February 9th from 7 to 9:30 P.M. & Thursday February 10th, 2-5 P.M. and 7-9:30 P.M. Services will be held at Long Island National. He will be greatly missed. A lawyer's lawyer.

title: Our Towns; Plague Robs A Lobsterman Of His Identity
description: AS a boy in Queens Village, Joe Finke was inexplicably drawn to fishing. Fleeing his neighborhood's blacktop for the East River, he snagged his first fish in the shadow of the Throgs Neck Bridge.

title: CVS TO OPEN UP TO 450 STORES NATIONWIDE THIS YEAR
description: The CVS Corporation said yesterday that it planned to open 400 to 450 stores this year. The drugstore chain, which is based in Woonsocket, R.I., reported $17.1 billion in revenue for the last 12 months. As of Jan. 1, CVS operated 4,098 stores in 26 states and the District of Columbia. The company said it opened 49 stores and relocated 75 others in the fourth quarter of 1999. It finished the year ahead of its real estate goal by opening a record 445 new or relocated stores. Shares in CVS closed up $3.5625 each, at $40, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Charity Watchdogs Warn of Potential for Online Fraud
description: Charity Watchdogs Warn of Potential for Online Fraud

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- St. Louis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LOUIS J.
description: BERMAN-Louis J. Passed away on February 8, 2000 in Tamarac FL. Beloved husband of the late Clara. Devoted father of Steven, Dennis and Ronald. Special fatherin-law of Mina, Marcia and Lynne. Loving grandfather of Erica, Marshall, Andy, Cindy and Tiffany. Caring companion of Frances Mayer. His kindness, wisdom and commitment to Judaism will be a legacy to those who knew him. Services on Wednesday at 1PM at Schwarz Bros., Forest Hills NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON STADE, SANDRA C.
description: VON STADE-Sandra C., 61, of Peapack, NJ, on Monday, February 7th, 2000 after a long illness. Wife of John T. von Stade of Peapack, mother of John, Jr. of Darien, CT, sister of David H. Carnahan of NYC. Also survived by a granddaughter Lily of Darien, CT. Funeral services will be Thursday, February 10th, at 11 AM, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Matheny School and Hospital, Peapack, NJ 07977 or the ASPCA, 424 E. 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128.

title: Man Arrested in Brooklyn Was Sought in 2 Murders
description: A man arrested in Brooklyn on a weapons charge on Sundayis wanted for murder in Pennsylvania and Virginia, the police said.

title: Going Local, the Baltimore Museum Loosens Up
description: The staid Baltimore Museum of Art has undergone something of a makeover, literally reopening its front door and exhibiting the work of a local artist in a successful effort to attract more of this city's diverse population.

title: LYCOS PLANS TO EXPAND ONLINE CLUBS WITH ACQUISITION
description: Lycos Inc., one of the most popular Internet search services, bought Valent Software yesterday for $45 million in stock. Valent's NetClubs is the software behind Lycos Clubs, which links 62,000 online clubs. The company was run by nine employees working in their homes and is based in Waltham, Mass., where Lycos has its headquarters. Lycos Clubs are chat rooms for people interested in a variety of topics, including rock bands, cars and politics. They feature message boards, free e-mail, instant messages and Web site building. The purchase will allow Lycos to expand these clubs.

title: Woods's Short Game Has Field in Distance
description: On Sunday at dusk, after many of his competitors had left the course, Tiger Woods was on the Pebble Beach practice green, working on his putting as the sun set over the Pacific Ocean.

title: Miscellany
description: * Sears, Roebuck & Co., Hoffman Estates, Ill., agreed to become the official supplier of home appliances for the 2002 Olympic Winter Games as well as for United States Olympic teams in 2000, 2002 and 2004. This is the first time Sears has been an Olympic sponsor. Though terms were not disclosed, Olympic sponsorships are estimated to cost $5 million to $20 million. Sears will also supply the United States Olympic Committee with products and services for American athletes.

title: General Electric Launches Personal Finance Site
description: General Electric Launches Personal Finance Site

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, STEPHEN M.
description: ROBERTS-Stephen M. Daddy, a part of you has grown in me, together forever we shall be. Never apart, maybe in distance, but not in heart. You will forever live inside of me. Please take care of Mommy and Papa, Jason will take care of me. Rest in peace, Daddy. Your loving and devoted daughter, Lisi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, JOSEPH
description: BRENNER-Joseph. On February 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Adele. Cherished father of David and Linda, Harvey and Anne, Stu and the late Susan Mellan. Devoted grandfather to Larry, Barbara, Tara, Stacy, Jamie and Eric. Dedicated brother to Sam, Jack and Mary Rauch. He enriched the lives of all those he touched.

title: As DNA Aids Rape Inquiries, Statutory Limits Block Cases
description: Just as the use of DNA in criminal investigations is on the verge of becoming routine, rape survivors and law enforcement experts are finding that in the realm of sex crimes, science has outpaced the law.

title: Clinton Bans Use of Genetic Makeup in Federal Employment
description: Setting what he hopes will be a precedent for employers nationwide, President Clinton issued an order today that prohibits federal agencies from using genetic information in any decision to hire, promote or dismiss workers.

title: Nature, Up for Sale
description: George W. Bush has been raked over the coals for his environmental record in Texas. The Sierra Club, for example, has aired ads pointing out that Mr. Bush has gone easy on polluters. This is all fair and good, but why is his surging opponent for the Republican nomination, Senator John McCain, getting a free ride on environmental issues?

title: No Humor Impairment Here
description: I lost my hearing six years ago in November. I went to bed one night -- I had watched ''Seinfeld,'' so I know it was a Thursday night -- and I woke up about 11, nauseated and dizzy, and I couldn't hear, and went to the hospital. Evidently there was a virus that had attacked the cells in my inner ear.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRODSKY, MILTON
description: BRODSKY-Milton We treasure so many precious memories. Love, Grace and Ruth

title: After Air Raids, Beirut Returns to Power-Deprived Routines
description: After the Israeli air raids that lighted the midnight sky, the people of Beirut returned to time-tested routines today, firing up generators, lighting candles, putting new batteries into flashlights and preparing with quiet stoicism for the expected months without a regular power supply.

title: Oneok Buys Gas Plants
description: Oneok Inc., a natural gas utility, agreed today to buy Kinder Morgan Inc.'s natural gas processing plants and pipelines in Oklahoma, Kansas and Texas for $114 million. Oneok is buying six plants that can process 1.26 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day, along with 12,000 miles of pipeline and three storage facilities. The Tulsa, Okla., company is expanding through small acquisitions after canceling its $1.8 billion purchase of the Southwest Gas Corporation of Las Vegas.

title: Israeli Jets and Hezbollah Renew Attacks in Lebanon
description: The conflict in Lebanon continued to heat up today as Shiite Muslim guerrillas killed another Israeli soldier, the sixth in two weeks, and Israeli warplanes retaliated less than 24 hours after their first bombardment shut down civilian life in Lebanon.

title: Coolant Leak May Be Tied To the Failure Of Missile Test
description: Pentagon investigators said today that a leak in a coolant pipe in a missile interceptor might have caused its failure last month in a test critical to plans to create a national missile defense system, but they said it was too early to determine if it was the sole error.

title: To Take a Test, Perhaps to Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTON, CHARLES P.
description: MORTON-Charles P. Former Republican First Selectman of New Canaan, CT on February 8, 2000. Survived by his wife Mary; three sons, Charles P. Morton Jr., John Paul Morton, and David Peter Morton; and three grandchildren. Funeral service Friday, February 11, 10AM at Hoyt Funeral Home, Main St., New Canaan, CT. Visitation Thursday 2-4 and 7-9. Contributions to New Canaan Historical Society, 33 Oenoke Ridge Rd, New Canaan, CT 06840 or New Canaan Red Cross, 51 Main St, New Canaan, CT 06840 or Family Fourth Fund, C/O Waveny House, South Avenue, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: Sudden Explosion of Game Shows Threatens the Old TV Staples; Costly Sitcoms and Dramas Scramble for Space and Survival
description: Quite suddenly, the television landscape has turned positively Darwinian for comedies and dramas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCPADDEN, CATHERINE M. (NEE GRAY)
description: McPADDEN-Catherine M. (nee Gray). On February 7, 2000. Beloved wife of the late James Vincent. Devoted mother of Joan Snow, Brian, Patricia Monteforte and the late James. Loving grandmother of 13 and great-grandmother of 13. Fond aunt of many. Funeral Friday 9:45 AM from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Funeral Mass 10:30 AM, Our Lady Help of Christians RC Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM.

title: Judge in Moxley Case Postpones Arraignment
description: A juvenile court judge has postponed the arraignment of Michael Skakel on charges that he murdered Martha Moxley in Greenwich 25 years ago, saying she needed time to rule on a request to open the proceedings to the press.

title: Parliament Gets Bill for Direct Ulster Rule
description: Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson introduced a bill in Parliament today that could bring the province back under direct rule from London by Friday unless there is movement on disarmament by the Irish Republican Army.

title: Making the Most of the Internets Potential for Education
description: February 9, 2000

title: Brunswick Share Buyback
description: The Brunswick Corporation, a maker of bowling balls, boats and other recreational products, said today that it planned to buy back as much as $100 million of its outstanding shares to improve shareholder value. Under the program, announced after the close of trading, Brunswick could buy back 5.67 million shares, or about 6 percent of its outstanding shares.

title: By One Measure, at Least, Work Is Less of a Pain
description: The epidemic of job-related aches and pains is abating.

title: Bradley Attacks G.O.P. Over the Confederate Flag
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley today leveled his harshest attack yet against the two leading Republican presidential candidates, saying Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain were pandering for conservative votes by failing to condemn the Confederate battle flag flying over the State Capitol as a symbol of hatred and segregation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Productivity Soared 5% in Second Half of 1999

title: Pot Roast Goes Asian
description: POT ROAST with Asian flavors is becoming more common, but the recipe usually calls for a full shelf of ingredients and a day or two of marination, both of which defeat the purpose of this super-simple main course.

title: Shivers of Rage or Cold at Record Oil Prices
description: The finer points of worldwide oil production, marketing and the laws of supply and demand are lost on people like Donna Sciukas, 74, who lives in an 11-room house in Seymour, Conn., with her husband, Jonas.

title: It's Bird! It's a Plane! It's a Loony Philosopher!
description: The little girl is disappointed. This pale, limp man with the skittish gaze and the spastic skip in his step surely isn't Friedrich Nietzsche, is he?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Circuits on Dec. 30 with an article about new schools that teach video game development and animation misidentified the one shown. It was the Digipen Institute of Technology in Redmond, Wash., not the Ex'pression Center for New Media, near San Francisco. A student in the photograph reported the error in an e-mail message on Feb. 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINS, ANN NEE DWORTZAN
description: ATKINS-Ann nee Dwortzan. Of Sonoma, CA. Formerly of West Orange, N.J. Died on Friday, February 4. Beloved wife of Nigel, dear sister of Mollie Dwortzan Mandell. Services will be held at Gutterman Musicant, Hackensack N.J. on Thursday, February 10 at Noon. Memorial week will be observed at the Mandell residence.

title: Investigators Focusing On A 2nd Dive In Jet Crash
description: The initial problem with equipment that keeps a plane level, which led an Alaska Airlines jetliner to a harrowing drop of more than a mile, was not the problem that triggered the plane's second, fatal dive, air safety investigators said today.

title: More Limber Than Tongs
description: THOUGH tongs have become ubiquitous as a chef's second set of hands, they are not the right tool for every task. Chefs also depend on another utensil, a fish spatula, to be their extended fingers.

title: So Who Needs Vintage Charts?

title: Sepulchral Snapshots Of a Vanished Culture
description: They teeter and lean, poking up from overgrown fields like so many rotting teeth or falling soldiers. The tombstones stand in village cemeteries throughout the part of the Russian empire that was known as the Jewish Pale, their intricate carvings depicting images like fighting lions, blossoming flowers and praying hands over Sabbath candles. In the late 1930's, surreptitiously but steadily, David Goberman began sketching these grave markers, then photographing them.

description: Interbrew S.A. has expanded its relationship with units of McCann-Erickson North America, part of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, by assigning creative and media buying duties for several Labatt Breweries beer brands to McCann offices in New York and Toronto.

description: St. John's players wore strips of bandages on their left cheeks for their 61-46 victory over Providence tonight, a symbol to honor their point guard, Erick Barkley, who earlier today was ruled ineligible for three games for violating a National Collegiate Athletic Association bylaw against receiving preferential treatment and extra benefits.

In a merrily recursive tangle, songs become videos shown on television to promote movies gaining attention for albums connected to tours and T-shirt sales.

description: WHEN Americans think of Spanish red wines, they most likely think of Rioja, Spain's best-known red wine region. Yet, Spain's most prestigious winery, Vega Sicilia, whose long-lived wines have often been likened to first-growth Bordeaux, is not in Rioja but in Ribera del Duero, just southwest of Rioja and due north of Madrid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, PETER W., M.D.
description: STONE-Peter W., M.D., 75, of Irvington, NY on February 8th. He was born and raised in Great Kills, Staten Island. Dr. Stone attended Cornell University and graduated from Cornell Medical School in 1947. Dr. Stone interned in surgery at NY Hospital and completed a fellowship in vascular surgery at Emory University in 1948 and completed a surgical residency at Bellevue Hospital between 1949 and 1952. He was a Lieutenant in the US Naval Medical Corps until 1954 at which time he entered private practice until his retirement in 1990. He was a diplomate of the American Board of Surgery, a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons and the NY Surgical Society. He was an Associate Professor of Clinical Surgery at NYU Medical Center until his 1990 retirement. He was an Attending Surgeon at Bellevue and Doctor's Hospital and Associate Attending Surgeon at NYU Hospital; Chairman and Director of the Department of surgery at Wycoff Heights Hospital. Dr. Stone was the author of twenty published articles in the fields of vascular and general surgery. He leaves his loving family: His wife of 51 years; Dorothy Harper Stone and his sons and daughter-in-law; Paul D. and Lisa Stone, and Philip C. Stone and grandchildren, Paul and Evan. He was predeceased by his son Peter W. Stone, Jr. Services at 11:00 am, Saturday, February 12th, at St. Barnabas Church, North Broadway, Irvington, New York. Memorials to the Church of St. Barnabas of Cornell University Medical College appreciated.

title: Lamb Designated For Assignment

title: David Boehm, 86, Record-Keeper to the World
description: David Alfred Boehm, a publishing entrepreneur who brought the Guinness Book of World Records to the United States and gave the book its name, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Humpty Dumpty Hires a Designer
description: Konstantin Grcic's hand-thrown porcelain egg cup and spoon may seem expensive ($185 for the set), but they also make it possible to coddle someone special. The cup and spoon (also perfect for caviar) is the first new design since the 1950's at the Nymphenburg Porcelain Manufactory in Munich, founded in 1747. Mr. Grcic won the Brooklyn Museum of Art's Young Designer Award this winter; he has also designed salt and pepper shakers and a vase. The egg set can be ordered at Moss, 150 Greene Street (Houston Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

description: Yahoo, eBay and other companies whose Web sites came under attack this week would not say yesterday whether they carried insurance to cover their losses.

I was about to rent an electric car, which can cover about 120 miles before its nickel metal hydride battery needs to be recharged. And so I would have to plan my itinerary around charging stations -- giant electric outlets scattered in shopping center parking lots and municipal garages. Death Valley wasn't a sensible destination.

title: LANDRY'S SEAFOOD RESTAURANTS TO BUY RAINFOREST CAFE
description: Landry's Seafood Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Rainforest Cafe Inc. for $125 million in stock and cash to add Rainforest's chain of theme restaurants. Under the agreement, 65 percent of the purchase price will be in Landry's stock and 35 percent will be in cash. The price values Rainforest shares at $5.54 each, Landry's said. Rainforest, based in Hopkins, Minn., operates restaurants and stores with a rain forest theme. The stock of Landry's, which is based in Houston, was down 31.25 cents yesterday at $9.8125. Rainforest closed at $4.375, up 31.25 cents. The agreement was announced after the close of regular United States trading.

description: Jayalalitha Jayaram, while not India's most credible politician, is surely its most ornamented. For the past week, a judge in a criminal court in Madras has been busy with the laborious task of cataloging her jewelry collection.

title: Club Med Buys Ski Resort
description: Club Mediterranee, Europe's largest vacation resort company, agreed today to buy the Crested Butte Marriott Resort for an undisclosed price, giving it a second Club Med ski village in Colorado. Club Med, which is based in Paris, plans to convert the Crested Butte resort into a family ski village that will open in November. The new club will join Club Med Copper Mountain, which opened in 1981.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEN, MORTON IRVING
description: SEIDEN-Morton Irving, Professor of English at Brooklyn College, died on February 8, 2000. He was 78 years old. A native New Yorker, Professor Seiden attended New York University and later Columbia, where he received his master's degree and with ''very high distinction'' his doctorate. His teaching career spanned well over half a century. He taught at NYU and Columbia, Smith and Brooklyn Colleges. He joined the Brooklyn College faculty in the fall of 1953. At Brooklyn he served on a number of administrative committees; he gave a variety of undergraduate and graduate courses in English and comparative literature, though his field of major interest was the history of literary criticism; and he received a presidential award for teaching excellence. In addition to public lectures on contemporary American poetry and fiction, as well as articles on English and Continental literature in learned journals, he was the author of ''William Butler Yeats: The Poet as a Mythmaker''. and ''The Paradox of Hate: A Study in Ritual Murder''. At the time of his death he was completing a book on James Joyce. ''Gladly did he learn and gladly teach''. He will be deeply mourned by family and close friends. Services at BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Avenue L), Brooklyn, Friday at 1 PM.

title: Vail's Blue Sky Basin Still Touches Nerves
description: It's not often that 6,000 skiers and snowboarders are waiting in line for a single chairlift. But a scene reminiscent of a 19th century land rush occurred here early last month when Vail cut the ribbon on the vast back country of its controversial Blue Sky Basin.

title: Serbs Nurse Rage After Attack in Kosovo City
description: United Nations police officers apprehended a man here today who was slashing the tires of their cars and who lashed out at one policeman, injuring his eye, a spokesman for the peacekeepers said. It was a minor incident compared with the violence of last week, but it reflected the continuing tension and anger of Serbs living on the north side of the city.

title: A Tentative Deal: Griffey to Reds
description: Just when it appeared that the Seattle Mariners and the Cincinnati Reds had exhausted their attempts to work out a trade that would send Ken Griffey Jr. to the Reds, the clubs reached agreement on a contingency deal yesterday, a baseball official said last night.

title: Sic Transit Steve Forbes
description: Don Imus, the radio personality who likes to torment politicians, says that Steve Forbes spent $100 million to make himself a laughingstock. That is, as they say in politics, a harsh formulation. Other tabulations put his personal spending in two campaigns at something like $70 million. As for the campaign, it would be kinder to call it a quixotic venture that taught some worthy civic lessons.

description: KATZ-Emanuel, on February 8, 2000. Beloved brother of Louis Katz and Pearl Davis. Cherished uncle of Morton Katz, Charles and Glen Davis and Phyllis Engel. title: Spread of Attacks on Web Sites Is Slowing Traffic on the Internet
description: As anonymous assaults on major Web sites continued yesterday, computer vandals crippled a large online brokerage operation and a media site. The Justice Department pledged to find those responsible, but computer experts questioned whether any defenses could easily be deployed against the attacks.

title: CONCERN ABOUT EURO'S DROP
description: The chief economist of the European Central Bank, Otmar Issing, said he was worried that the euro's drop against the dollar was damaging public confidence in the 13-month-old single European currency. ''I'm concerned about a possible loss in confidence,'' Mr. Issing told the German weekly newspaper Rheinischer Merkur. The euro has fallen 15 percent since its inception on Jan. 1, 1999. Mr. Issing said that the euro's drop was largely a reflection of the ''picture book'' state of the United States economy, but that European growth was set to catch up with the United States this year and next.

title: PEREGRINE SYSTEMS AGREES TO ACQUIRE TELCO RESEARCH
description: The software maker Peregrine Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Telco Research Corporation, a Canadian provider of voice network management services, for about $110 million in stock. Peregrine, which is based in San Diego, will issue 1.28 million shares for Telco. Shares of Peregrine were up 25 cents at $88 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: News Corporation Profit Down by 26%
description: The News Corporation said yesterday that its profit fell by 26 percent in its most recent quarter on lower movie sales and losses at British Sky Broadcasting, in which it owns a 40 percent stake.

title: Vermont Panel Shies From Gay Marriage
description: In the first strong signal of how Vermont lawmakers will address the issue of gay marriage, a pivotal committee polled its members today and found them leaning heavily toward guaranteeing equal rights and benefits to gay and lesbian couples, but not letting them legally marry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOULTON, SCHROEDER
description: BOULTON-Schroeder, on February 6th, aged 91. Survived by daughters, Janet Boulton and Nancy Boulton-LeGates. Memorial service Saturday, February 12, 2 PM, First Unitarian Church, 50 Monroe Place, Brooklyn Heights, NY.

title: Mrs. Clinton Offers Plan To Attract New Teachers
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton turned her attention yesterday to the teacher shortage threatening schools nationwide, outlining a plan to lure more college students into teaching with federally financed scholarships worth up to $10,000 a year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Automobiles section on Jan. 14 about a Volvo car radiator that is said to reduce pollution misattributed a statement by a company executive. It was William Shapiro, director of regulatory compliance and environmental affairs for Volvo Cars of North America, who said the company had been investigating and testing the technology for three years. It was not Petter Halling, who works in environmental communication for Volvo in Sweden. Mr. Shapiro reported the error on Jan. 17, but his letter was misdirected at The Times.

title: PAXAR TO SELL ITS INTERNATIONAL IMAGING MATERIALS UNIT
description: The Paxar Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 92.5 percent of its International Imaging Materials Inc. unit to closely held Centre Partners for $127.5 million in cash and stock. Paxar, based in White Plains, makes labels and tags for the apparel and textile markets. Paxar will receive $120 million in cash and $7.5 million in International Imaging preferred stock for the unit, which makes thermal transfer ribbons. Paxar said it would continue to collaborate with International Imaging, but seeks to focus on its apparel-identification and bar-code operations.

title: An Adoption Dream Turns Nightmarish
description: For a while, to judge from their home videos, Jesse and Crystal Money and their newly adopted daughter made a happy family. But that did not last long. Within weeks of bringing the blond, blue-eyed 9-year-old Russian girl to their home in Atlanta, they discovered that she was angry, destructive and something of a thief.

title: N.H.L.: ISLANDERS; Weekes Recovers From Dehydration
description: Islanders goaltender Kevin Weekes, who left Tuesday night's game against the Carolina Hurricanes in the second period because of cramping caused by dehydration, appeared fully recovered and showed no signs of distress yesterday as he went through a two-hour practice in Uniondale, N.Y.

title: DIEBOLD PURCHASES EUROPEAN A.T.M. BUSINESSES
description: Diebold Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the automated teller machine operations and products of Getronics N.V. of the Netherlands and Groupe Bull of France for about $160 million. The acquired businesses, which manufacture cash dispensers and other self-service terminals as well as A.T.M.'s, have annual revenue of about $250 million. The agreement includes a factory in France and a maker of specialized financial self-service terminals in Brussels. They employ about 1,300 people. Diebold, based in Canton, Ohio, had revenue of $1.26 billion in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEMAN, LEOLA JOHNSON

title: W.T.O. LEADER WANTS CHINA THIS YEAR
description: Alarmed over the possibility that the United States Congress could reject a trade deal with China, the World Trade Organization's director general, Mike Moore, said he wanted to see China become a member of the 135-nation group this year. Mr. Moore, who began pressing for China's admission when he was appointed last year, is set to visit Beijing next week. For more than 13 years, China has sought to become a member of W.T.O., the organization that establishes the rules for global commerce. Elizabeth Olson

title: Carrying a Torch For Giacometti and Brancusi
description: Figurative art by Giacometti and Brancusi inspire the repeating geometries and classical forms of Andrew Margolin, 34, a furniture designer who studied sculpture at the Otis Art Institute of Los Angeles.

title: Lawrence of Arabia and the Web
description: COMPARED with books, the Internet has a reputation only slightly better than the local bar when it comes to scholarship. Yet there is no reason the Web and the printed, footnoted, peer-reviewed page cannot complement each other. The author of an acclaimed biography is showing the way.

title: Israel's Air Raids: A View From Beirut
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PLATINUM ADVANCES. Platinum surged to a 10-year high as a shortfall of supplies from Russia forced manufacturers to draw from stockpiles. Platinum for April delivery rose $31.10, or 6.2 percent, to $529.60 an ounce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSS, LOUISE
description: SCHLOSS-Louise. title: EMBRATEL EARNINGS NEARLY DOUBLE
description: Benefiting from the opening of Brazil's long-distance market to competition, earnings at Embratel Participacoes S.A., MCI WorldCom's Brazilian unit, nearly doubled in the fourth quarter of 1999. Embratel earned 194.6 million reais, or $110 million, on higher revenue from data transmission and long-distance services. Simon Romero

title: To Outlaw Gay Group, District May Ban Clubs
description: Under the protection of a court but in defiance of a school board's wishes, a group of gay teenagers and their supporters held a long-awaited meeting today at El Modena High School here. But whether the group will ever do so again remains uncertain.

title: Whitman Says Crimes Are at a Low Level
description: Reported crimes fell 10 percent statewide during the first six months of 1999, with reports of murder, rape, robbery and aggravated assault hitting their lowest levels since 1976, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Tuesday with the Personal Health column, about nuts, misstated the allergenic risk of nut oils. Most nut oil refined in the United States is free of protein, the allergen in nuts, and therefore does not cause problems for people with nut allergies. But oil extracted by certain methods, like the cold-pressed process, may still contain protein and can indeed pose a risk. Information is available from the Food Allergy Network at www .foodallergy.org or (703) 691-3179.

title: Professor Picked as Interim Leader at Brown
description: Two days after the abrupt resignation of its president, Brown University yesterday chose a veteran professor with extensive administrative experience to be its interim leader until a permanent successor is selected.

title: Getting Colors Right With New Technology
description: YOU still can't brush your cheek against that fuzzy blue blanket before you buy it online. But E-Color, a San Francisco-based computer graphics company, has introduced a technology to help reassure online shoppers that what they see, at least, is what they get.

title: Investors to Finance Revamping of Iridium
description: A group of investors led by Craig O. McCaw, the cellular telephone pioneer, has agreed to provide $74.6 million in emergency financing to Iridium L.L.C., the global satellite telephone company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in August.

title: In America; Looking for Votes . . .
description: Wave goodbye to that fantasy of a more inclusive Republican Party.
