title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar after a report of rising industrial production in Germany signaled economic growth may be picking up in Europe. In New York, the euro increased to 99.27 cents from 98.61 cents.

title: Dust Settles: Israel-Syria Peace Effort Is Set Back
description: A tense state of anticipation gripped much of the Middle East today as Israelis and Arabs waited to see whether the conflict in Lebanon would defuse or intensify further and revive active hostilities between Israel and its neighbors.

title: Particle Physicists Getting Closer To the Bang That Started It All
description: Scientists in Geneva have re-created a primordial form of matter that physicists believe last existed in abundance when the universe was an exploding fireball only a fraction of a second old.

title: Business Officials Urge Extension of Internet Tax Ban
description: Business Officials Urge Extension of Internet Tax Ban

title: Party Turns Inside Out To Oppose Residences
description: Local battles over housing for the elderly often grow noisy, but they don't usually lead to a coup d'etat.

title: Costly Stubbornness by the I.R.A.
description: It would be tragic if the Irish Republican Army undermined the nearly two-year-old peace settlement in Northern Ireland by refusing to turn in even a small component of its arsenal. Yet that is just what the I.R.A. seems determined to do, despite pleas from the Irish government, Northern Ireland's largest Catholic party and the Catholic bishop of Londonderry to begin disarming.

title: GOLF COURSE OWNER HIRES ADVISER TO STUDY ALTERNATIVES
description: Golf Trust of America Inc., the fourth-largest golf course owner in the United States, said yesterday that it had hired Banc of America Securities to review its ''strategic alternatives.'' The move by Golf Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Charleston, S.C., comes less than two weeks after Schooner Capital L.L.C., which owns an 8.8 percent stake in Golf Trust, said it had talked with the company's management about taking it private. Golf Trust's shares rose 50 cents each, to $18.50, on the American Stock Exchange. The company owns or has a stake in 47 golf courses around the country.

title: Bradley Urges $80 Billion Plan to Improve Quality of Schools
description: Declaring that the quality of education in America unfairly depended on the wealth of the district, former Senator Bill Bradley today unveiled an $80 billion education proposal that he said would improve the quality of teachers, hold schools accountable for student performance and give parents the safety valve of taking their children out of inferior public schools for better ones.

title: In Welfare-to-Work Dispute, Giuliani Seeks to Limit Hevesi's Power
description: Escalating the feud over $500 million in welfare-to-work contracts, the Giuliani administration is pushing to severely restrict the city comptroller's power to review and approve municipal contracts, which now total $7 billion a year.

title: Metro Business; E-Trade to Establish A Physical Presence
description: E-Trade Group Inc., which carved out a name for itself as the second-biggest online broker, is putting down roots with its first sales office, planned for Midtown Manhattan.

title: Fight Over a Chinese Prisoner Goes Public
description: Frustrated after six months of fruitless inquiries to Chinese officials, American legislators are mounting a public campaign on behalf of a prominent Muslim businesswoman from China's Far West who was jailed on vague charges of revealing state intelligence to foreigners.

title: Frederic Lord, Who Devised Testing Yardstick, Dies at 87
description: Frederic Lord, a mathematician whose doctoral work at Princeton a half-century ago laid the foundation for scoring the fill-in-the-bubble examinations that have tormented generations of No. 2-pencil-wielding applicants to colleges and graduate schools, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Naples, Fla. He was 87, and had lived in Naples since 1993.

title: Sports of The Times; 'It Just Happened To Go In'
description: WHENEVER the Chicago Bulls needed a last-second basket during their run of six championships, everybody knew who figured to be taking the shot, especially the other team. And one night, when a timeout was winding down with only a few seconds remaining in a playoff game, Coach Phil Jackson even announced, loud enough for anyone nearby to hear, who would take the shot.

title: Mural Painters Arrested but Then Released
description: To pay homage to the rapper known as Big Pun, who died on Monday, members of a celebrated Bronx mural company spent much of Tuesday drawing a 35-foot-long mural to remember him.

title: European Oil Talks Are Disputed; Stocks Thrive Anyway
description: Two of Europe's second-tier oil companies, ENI of Italy and Repsol-YPF of Spain, are looking to dance, but seem unable to agree on a flamenco or a tarantella.

title: National News Briefs; 2 High School Students Are Slain in Washington
description: The captain of a high school football team and his girlfriend were shot to death late Tuesday as they unloaded groceries in front of the girl's house in a quiet residential section of Northeast Washington.

title: Period Costume for Midcentury Furniture
description: IF it's time to reupholster that midcentury sofa or chair, why not pick a fabric pattern with a pedigree of its own? Paul Hazlett, a restorer and upholsterer of modern furniture in Orangeburg, N.Y. (914-398-1315), enjoys combing shops for bolts of vintage fabric. ''If the material has been stored properly,'' he said, ''the fibers will be strong enough to use.'' Mr. Hazlett also uses new wools and other materials true to the spirit of the period. ''It's the colors that are sometimes different,'' he said, ''and there are more synthetics today.''

description: To the Editor:

title: The High Price of Oil
description: Home heating prices in the Northeast, the region that relies primarily on oil to heat homes, have doubled over the past year. Indeed the residents of the Northeast have suffered a double blow. First OPEC, the consortium of oil-exporting countries, conspired last spring to cut production by millions of barrels a day. As a result, crude oil prices nearly tripled by December and gasoline prices rose by over 30 percent during the past year. Then a cold wave struck last month, drawing down inventories of home heating oil and sending its price soaring. Residents are demanding relief from Congress, but it is already too late to push down heating bills before spring.

title: Arthur Seelen, 76, of the Drama Book Shop
description: Arthur Seelen, a former actor who with his wife, Rozanne, owned the Drama Book Shop in Manhattan, the oldest performing-arts bookstore in the United States, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: Getting Bush Back On Track
description: The George W. Bush campaign promised to ''come out charging'' in South Carolina after Governor Bush lost his aura of inevitability in the snows of New Hampshire. The Op-Ed page asked some veteran Republicans what he can do to reinvigorate his candidacy.

title: Issue of Elderly Housing Separates Suburban Generations
description: In a span of 35 years, Ruth Dewey has led the Girl Scouts here and presided over both the Board of Education and the Friends of the Library. Now, at 77, she looks forward to living out her final years here and believes she has the perfect place to do it: a proposed continuing-care retirement community, the sort of place that lets you decline gently into old age with a range of supports.

title: Treatment for Arrestees
description: To the Editor:

title: Detective Tells of His Torment Informing on His Peers in Louima Assault Case
description: In the days leading up to his sudden decision to tell Internal Affairs investigators what he knew about the police assault on Abner Louima, a Brooklyn detective struggled to overcome what he called ''the biggest hurdle'' -- informing on his peers.

title: A Modern French Aristocrat in Trade's Fractious Arena
description: Pascal Lamy is known as ''the Exocet'' for a personality as direct and aggressive as the missile built in his French homeland. But now that he is Europe's top trade official, Mr. Lamy's subtle diplomacy may be a more useful weapon.

title: Tentative Get-to-Know-You Becomes Clamor of Voices
description: Nelly Myers and Hilda Oker-Bogle sat anxiously waiting for their Saturday morning guests by two large frosted windows. Both elderly women sat in the community center of Tanya Towers, a residence for the deaf or blind, on East 13th Street, where they live.

title: Architecture's Forrest Gump: Getting a Rare Look
description: Ralph Rapson, 85, once designed furniture for Knoll. In 1954, he designed the United States Embassy in Stockholm, top. He did the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis in 1963, above, while he was dean of architecture at the University of Minnesota. ''Ralph Rapson: 60 Years of Modernism,'' at the Octagon Museum in Washington through May 28, has some 100 drawings, models, furniture, photos and videos. The facade of the Guthrie ''shows the inspiration of Ray and Charles Eames,'' said Christopher Monkhouse, curator of architecture at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, which originated the exhibition in 1999 with the Weisman Art Museum at the University of Minnesota. Information: (202) 638-3105.

title: Radio Industry Sets Annual Revenue Record
description: The radio industry set another annual revenue record in 1999, according to the Radio Revenue Index survey compiled by the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York.

title: DRUGMAKER HIRES FIRM TO ADVISE IT ON STRATEGIC OPTIONS
description: Struggling to get Food and Drug Administration approval for its cancer drug Evacet, the Liposome Company said yesterday that it had hired the investment firm Warburg Dillon Read for advice on strategic alternatives. Mergers, acquisitions and product-licensing opportunities are among the options that Liposome said it might consider. Liposome, based in Princeton, N.J., is one of the few profitable biotechnology companies. Its shares plunged 59 percent Sept. 17 after the drugmaker failed to win support for Evacet, its second product, from an F.D.A. advisory panel. Shares have recovered some since then. Liposome shares fell 28.125 cents, to $11.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BACHMANN, LOUIS
description: BACHMANN-Louis, Jr. Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health will hold a memorial service to mark the passing last month of generous long-time benefactor Louis Bachmann, Jr., whose philanthropy to Mount Sinai included joining his daughter Bonnie Strauss, and son-in-law Thomas W. Strauss, our esteemed Trustee, in the naming and endowment of the Bachmann-Strauss Professorship in Neurology for the study of dystonia. Along with his daughter he also was instrumental in the establishment of The Bachmann-Strauss Dystonia & Parkinson Foundation which provides major support for the Movement Disorders Program at Mount Sinai. Trustees, faculty, staff, students, family, friends and admirers are invited to attend at 4:00 PM, Friday, February 11, in the Goldwurm Auditorium, East Building, 1425 Madison Avenue at 98th Street.

title: ESSAY; E-Communities Build New Ties, but Ties That Bind
description: NO subject lends itself to a false dichotomy like that of virtual and real communities. But the two are not opposites, not exclusionary and not necessarily good for the same things.

title: Inside the Techno-Turret
description: Giant moving images on the eight-story Nasdaq tower at 4 Times Square wash across a curved screen of nearly 10,000 square feet. The swirling pictures leave some people craning their necks to spot the projector. But the images are all produced within the tower wall by panels of light-emitting diodes, below. There are 8,900 panels, each about a foot square, affixed to the curved tower by a steel grid. The screen was designed by Saco Smartvision of Montreal. In mid-March, an interactive display within the tower will open to the public with computer games for potential market investors and a five-minute informational film on initial public offerings. ''We've taken Wall Street to Main Street,'' said Don Bosic, a senior vice president for marketing at Nasdaq.

description: Steve Forbes abandoned his quest for the White House today after lavishing $35 million on it, further sharpening the already intense South Carolina showdown between Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTKE, PAUL. G.
description: WITTKE-Paul. G. Schirmer, Inc. mourns the death of our friend and colleague on February 6. Associated with our firm for nearly half a century, he was the devoted editor of composers Samuel Barber, Leonard Bernstein, Gian Carlo Menotti, Leon Kirchner, John Corigliano, John Adams, and many others, as well as the guiding spirit behind the journal ''The Musical Quarterly''. His astute observations on all the arts, and his intellect, wit, advice, compassion, elegance, commitment, integrity, and modesty will be sorely missed by his many colleagues in our field. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Margaret, her brothers, and their families.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GROUP 1 AUTOMOTIVE INC., Houston, which operates automobile dealerships, said it had purchased six dealers for undisclosed terms, to expand into Boston, New Orleans and northern Florida.

title: CAMBIOR REJECTS TAKEOVER BID
description: A Montreal-based gold-mining company, Cambior Inc., has rejected a hostile bid from Aur Resources Inc. of Toronto. Cambior's board said that the Jan. 17 offer of one Aur share for each 1.1 shares of Cambior, worth about $117 million, was inadequate. It also said that a change of control could accelerate Cambior's obligations to creditors. The company is heavily in debt after losing $33 million in a gold-hedging program last fall. Timothy Pritchard

title: At Battery Park City, Developers See a New Kind of Green
description: IN a crowded conference room last month, Timothy S. Carey, the president of the Battery Park City Authority, talked about plans for a ''green'' apartment building to developers who usually associate green with the color of money.

title: Sid Abel, 81, a Hockey Star On a Famed Red Wings Line
description: Sid Abel, the Hockey Hall of Famer who starred with the Detroit Red Wings and was later a coach, general manager and broadcaster in the National Hockey League, died Tuesday at a hospital in Farmington Hills, Mich. He was 81.

title: Interpublic in Deals For Two Agencies
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York is making two acquisitions for undisclosed terms.

title: AOL 5.0: Takeover Artist
description: SOME 21 million people now use America Online as their portal to the Internet, because it is easier to use than most alternatives. And for people who are just getting started in the online world, AOL does have many advantages. It streamlines the process of setting up an Internet account and offers a large collection of content and services, including highly popular services like instant messaging, buddy lists and chat rooms.

title: Big Bang Gets Louder
description: Scientists have re-created a form of matter, a highly compressed gas of the particles called quarks and gluons, they believe last existed in abundance when the universe was an exploding fireball a fraction of a second old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a statement by the Austrian politician Jorg Haider, that Germans expelled from Czechoslovakia after World War II should be entitled to the same compensation as Austrian Jews persecuted by the Nazis, misstated the family background of Joschka Fischer, Germany's foreign minister. He is not descended from Germans expelled from Czechoslovakia; his parents are Germans who fled Hungary after the war.

title: Modern Chooses Architect
description: The Museum of Modern Art has chosen Michael Maltzen Architects, a Los Angeles firm, to design a temporary art center in Queens, Glenn D. Lowry, the museum's director, announced yesterday.

title: Vienna's Woe Is Heartening Isolationists Among Swiss
description: Resentment against what is viewed as European Union meddling in Austrian affairs has given isolationist groups in Switzerland an unexpected lift. After months of trying, opponents have quickly gathered enough signatures to try to derail long-planned Swiss ties to the European Union.

title: Deal Blends Day Trading And an Electronic Network
description: Tradescape.com Inc., one of the nation's largest day trading firms, has agreed to pay $100 million in stock to acquire MarketXT Inc., an electronic trading system that offers stock trading in the evening.

title: EUROPEAN INQUIRY ON WINDOWS 2000
description: Opening a new line of investigation into the business practices of the Microsoft Corporation, the European Commission has begun an inquiry into Windows 2000, the new operating system scheduled to go on sale on Feb. 17. The commission said other software companies had complained that the new system could help Microsoft extend its dominance from personal computer software to the systems that run servers and manage electronic commerce. Microsoft said that it would provide the information by the start of March but that the investigation would not delay Windows 2000's introduction. Edmund L. Andrews

title: F.B.I. Releases File on Murray Kempton, Whose Columns Angered Hoover
description: For four decades, Murray Kempton was known to New York City newspaper readers as the bicycle-riding, jazz-loving, pipe-smoking newspaper columnist whose bon mots and independent views filled the pages of The New York World-Telegram, The New York Post and New York Newsday.

title: Hack Attack
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: IXAM: Movies
description: THESE days, digital artists love to bandy about the term 3-D. There are so-called 3-D computer games like Quake. There are graphics called 3-D in films, like those used to anthropumorphize Mr. Potato Head in ''Toy Story.'' In reality, though, these are little more than two-dimensional images with depth and shadows. They don't jump off the screen - at least not yet.

title: Devils Put Up a Fight to Maintain Mastery of the Rangers
description: The calendar reads February, but the Rangers and the Devils displayed playoff intensity tonight before the first sellout crowd of the season at Continental Arena.

title: Diallo Witness: Man Cried 'Gun!' But Police Shot Without Warning
description: A neighbor of Amadou Diallo's testified reluctantly for the defense today that she had heard someone say ''Gun!'' just before the four police officers accused of his murder began firing at him as he stood in the vestibule of his Bronx apartment building last February.

title: An Alter Ego Escapes From the Attic
description: Everyone calls her ''Miss,'' but from the time the novel that bears her name was published in 1847, Jane Eyre was a ''Ms.'' waiting to be christened. Capable, intelligent, forthright and even tactless in the face of a perceived injustice, Charlotte Bronte's famous heroine, who undergoes her emotional education within the grueling repressiveness of Victorian England, has long been received as a cultural progenitor of modern womanhood.

title: Graham Will Be Cut In Salary Cap Move
description: Four Giants with featured roles in recent seasons -- quarterback Kent Graham, center Brian Williams, running back Gary Brown and wide receiver David Patten -- will be among six players released by the team today in an effort to trim a roster bloated with million-dollar contracts, according to players, their agents and National Football League officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMIT, LEO
description: SMIT-Leo. The directors and officers of the Aaron Copland Fund for Music deeply regret the passing of our colleague and founding board member Leo Smit. A composer and pianist of skill and sensitivity, Leo was fervently devoted to the art of music and especially to the work of contemporary American composers. He communicated his love of life through music with courage and good humor. Leo Smit was an exceptional musician and very special person who will be missed and remembered by all who knew him.

title: Bush and McCain Exchange Sharp Words Over Fund-Raising
description: The two leading Republican presidential rivals tangled over campaign fund-raising today, with Senator John McCain calling Gov. George W. Bush the ''unwitting pawn'' of special interests. The Texas governor, seeking to tarnish Mr. McCain's reform credentials, questioned the senator's acceptance of donations from political action committees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTROSE, MILDRED
description: MONTROSE-Mildred. On February 8, 2000 at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Madeline Montrose and Elaine and Jerold Usdane. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside service at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, L.I. 1PM Thursday.

title: TRUCKING COMPANY'S STOCK FALLS WITH BUYOUT DEAL OFF
description: Shares of the Transport Corporation of America Inc. fell yesterday after the company said fourth-quarter profit declined more than forecast and the USFreightways Corporation scrapped a plan to buy the company for $132.7 million in stock. Stock in Transport, a long-distance trucker, slid $5.625, to $9.4375, in Nasdaq trading. The stock of both companies tumbled after they said on Jan. 18 that shareholders of Transport, which is based in Eagan, Minn., would receive 0.412 share of USFreightways for each of their shares, a 31 percent premium at the time. The stock of USFreightways was up 75 cents yesterday, to $39.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Talks Stall At Boeing, And Engineers Go On Strike
description: More than 16,000 engineers and technical workers at the Boeing Company went on strike yesterday after contract negotiations broke down over wages and health care coverage.

title: World Briefings
description: EUROPE

title: Packaging Graphics
description: Q. I need to save and scan copies of black-and-white cartoons as TIFF files because they print well, but I worry that this is not a good format for e-mail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARMEN, BELLE
description: KARMEN-Belle. 92, widow of Hyman Karmen, beloved mother of Arthur and Steve and mother-inlaw of Marcia, cherished grandmother of Peter, Carol and Lawrence, Richard and Patty, Lisa, Abbe and Tom, Carrie and Santo, devoted great grandmother of Matthew, Mark, Erin and Jack, Savannah, Sean, Henry and Alex. She rests at peace with God. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Childrens Hospital Foundation, Westchester Medical Ctr, 1 Kids Corner, Valhalla, NY 10595.

title: People
description: * Gretchen Parker, vice president for entertainment marketing at McCracken Brooks Communications, Minneapolis, a unit of True North Communications, was named general manager at Promotional Services Group, Wilton, Conn., and Minneapolis, a recently formed new-business division of Marketing Drive Worldwide, also part of True North.

title: 7 Federal Inspectors Plead Guilty in Kickback Scheme at Produce Market
description: Seven federal food inspectors who graded shipments of fresh fruit and vegetables at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx pleaded guilty yesterday to taking bribes in a broad kickback scheme that allowed wholesalers to cheat their suppliers.

title: Magnificent Seven Bail Out the Knicks
description: This was one of those nights when Latrell Sprewell operated in his own time zone and arrived at his own pace, when his hometown family and friends pulled on him harder than his team's schedule.

title: Lobbyists for McCain
description: Dozens of lobbyists are assisting John McCain's campaign. Some say they are seeking access to a powerful senator, but others say they agree that the capital's culture of money and power should be overhauled.

title: U.S. Role in Congo War
description: To the Editor:

title: Charges of Fraud At Sterling Foster
description: Former managers and sales representatives with Sterling Foster & Company, a defunct New York brokerage firm, were accused yesterday of defrauding investors in what authorities said was a $75 million securities swindle.

title: Turn (Biff!) And Spin (Shazam!)
description: Something compelling, to say the least, emerges from H. Art Chaos, the all-female dance troupe from Japan that landed with such Wonder Woman impact on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Wish List Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Modern Is Focus Of a New Dispute Over a Painting
description: In what is nearly a mirror image of the two-year-old trans-Atlantic legal battle over the ownership of an Egon Schiele painting that had been lent to the Museum of Modern Art, a German court has issued an injunction seeking to bar the return of a painting with a clouded provenance to its American owner: the Modern.

title: NatWest Is Said To Concede It Will Be Bought
description: Britain's third-largest bank, National Westminster Bank P.L.C., privately conceded defeat today in its effort to stave off a hostile suitor, Royal Bank of Scotland, executives close to the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRUP, BERNARD L.
description: WALDRUP-Bernard L. On February 6th, 2000. He is survived by 3 daughters, Elizabeth Waldrup, Carey Gross and Leslie Waldrup, a son, Chip Waldrup, son-in-law, Brian Gross and 3 grandchildren, Christopher, Jennifer and Andrew Gross. A memorial service will be held 11AM, Saturday, February 12, at the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: When Mercury Isn't Quicksilver
description: This season, mercury-glass bowls have appeared in harlequin colors -- blue, purple and gold -- at Felissimo, a stylish emporium. ''I enjoy taking an antique process to a different level,'' said Nick Munro, the British designer of the glassware. Historically, mercury glass (double-walled clear glass with a painted silver lining) is silver. But like the English who experimented with the idea in the late 19th century, Mr. Munro has used colored glass. Last year, Felissimo gave Mr. Munro's simple porcelain dinnerware and his classic silver mercury-glass bowls their American debut. The collection of colored bowls and platters is $48 to $115 at Felissimo, 10 West 56th Street. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Video Tells Little About Russian Reporter's Fate
description: A Russian reporter for Radio Liberty who has been missing since last week is being held by rebel commanders in Chechnya, a representative of the government there told a Moscow radio station today.

title: Find Me A File, Cache Me A Catch
description: COMPUTERS are now involved in many of life's chores and amusements. Should you let them find your soul mate?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the agreement by Vodafone AirTouch to acquire Mannesmann misstated the name and job title of an official of Hutchison Whampoa, a Hong Kong company that holds a big stake in Mannesmann. He is Canning Fok, not Clay Falk. Mr. Fok is a managing director of Hutchison Whampoa, not its lead adviser.

title: Teacher's Aide Charged In Rape of Girl, 13
description: Brooklyn detectives have arrested a teacher's aide in a special education program and charged him with rape after discovering that a 13-year-old girl he had dated was eight-and-a-half-months pregnant. The girl had been a student last year at Intermediate School 14 in Sheepshead Bay, which is housed in the same building as the special education program, the police said yesterday.

title: Shocking Old Brands Back to Life
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald said ''there are no second acts in American lives.'' But he never heard of the new Volkswagen Beetle or the Apple iMac -- to say nothing of the comebacks of entertainers like Cher and Tony Bennett.

title: Investment Group Makes Bid for Ben & Jerry's
description: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. received a buyout offer last week from a group that calls itself a ''socially responsible'' alternative to the giant multinational companies seeking to acquire the quirky ice cream company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRYMIOTIS, ANDREW
description: DRYMIOTIS-Andrew MD., of Garden City, NY on February 8, 2000. Beloved husband of Yvonne. Loving father of Dr. James Drymiotis Otis and loving father-in-law of Diane Otis. Dear grandfather of Melissa and James. Brother of Prof. Phoebus Dhrymes and Col. Renos Drymiotis. Reposing Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Inc., Franklin Avenue, Garden City. Friday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Service Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul, Hempstead, NY Sat 10am. Interment Wayland, MA

title: Linux Users Protest Lawsuits On DVD Encryption Codes
description: Users of the Linux operating system are sounding alarms this month about a series of recent lawsuits concerning DVD technology. The lawsuits, the users say, unfairly punish people who are trying to make it possible to run DVD movies on Linux-based machines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEBASTIAN, GETTA
description: SEBASTIAN-Getta (Strok Adler). Peacefully on February 9, 2000, at age 92. Remembered by four generations.

title: Denver Police Chief Pushed Out After a Series of Problems
description: Mayor Wellington Webb began a search today for a new police chief after a series of problems, including the accidental shooting death of a man in a botched drug raid, led him to seek the resignation of a 30-year veteran of the force who served less than 18 months as its chief.

title: CLINTON IS RAISING MILLIONS  TO  PUSH EARLY  'ISSUE  ADS'
description: President Clinton, still the Democratic Party's marquee attraction and chief fund-raiser, is soliciting millions of dollars in soft money donations to pay for an aggressive, party-financed advertising campaign that will begin immediately after the Democratic presidential nominee emerges from the primary fight.

Bush Attacks McCain on Finance Plan

description: Gov. John G. Rowland laid out a proposed $12.27 billion budget today for 2001 that includes substantial tax cuts and credits for Connecticut consumers, families and corporations, and fundamental changes to the state treasurer's office and county sheriffs' systems.

title: Man Charged in Shooting Of His Son's Friend
description: A Queens man shot a 15-year-old boy who was skipping school and hiding in a closet with the man's son, police officials said.

title: The Watergate Tapes: Nixon and Dean Online
description: Many people have a favorite moment from the Nixon White House tapes. For Jerry Goldman, a professor of political science at Northwestern University, it is the point at which John Dean sneaks up on the phrase ''cancer on the presidency'' in a conversation with President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Chase and Deloitte Form a Joint Venture
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the second-biggest United States bank, and Deloitte Consulting formed a new venture to tap into the growing demand by companies to do business on the Internet.

description: To the Editor:

title: Man Who Shot Woman at College Had Been Sought by the Police
description: The man who shot his former girlfriend at Westchester Community College on Monday, and then killed himself, had been sought by the police here the week before, after he smashed windows in the woman's house, the police said today.

description: The White House now says President Clinton's proposal to provide Medicare coverage of prescription drugs will cost 35 percent more than it estimated just seven months ago.

description: ''I couldn't even try it. It looks so sad.

title: From Barns to Barbershops, History in a Small Format
description: The light and shadow that splash across the pastures of Bucks County, Pa., or strike the lavish ironwork in New Orleans have always inspired the sorts of images that Carol Wallace creates in her watercolors. So, too, have the historic landmarks of America.

title: Tobacco Companies Are Sued by Consumers
description: Consumers filed three lawsuits in New York and California yesterday against the leading tobacco companies, contending the companies had conspired to fix the prices of cigarettes sold in those states since 1993.

title: Israel Reports Abuses in Past Interrogations of Palestinians
description: An official report made public today said Israel's Shin Bet security service had committed systematic abuses while interrogating prisoners during the Palestinian uprising and that its agents had lied about their actions in court.

description: FOR the romantically inclined, a deserted tropical beach or an elegant restaurant may be the place to propose marriage. But Bob Shrum got down on bended knee amid the buzz of power tools.

description: Bill Blass didn't retire. He just came back as Michael Kors.

title: No revenues, but shares soar. How does Loch Harris do it?
description: LOCH HARRIS is a company that often seems to have grand plans. In the last three years, it has announced that revenues were expected imminently from businesses as diverse as solar water pumps, oil production and cattle genetics. It said it had developed a security system that was to be installed at the home of Yasir Arafat.

description: There are times confronting a sherbet-green entryway in a house for sale or a globe light fixture from the ''Brady Bunch'' era -- when Ken Fulk thinks of himself as a pair of glasses, correcting people's vision.

For info call Kelley & Spalding Funeral Home, phone 847-831-4260.

description: NEUWIRTH - Elizabeth (Betty). Passed away peacefully on February 8, 2000. Loving mother of Claudia Annis, Suzy and Geoffrey Mazel. Cherished grandmother of Leonore, Abe, Max and Mandy. title: I.R.S. Accepts First Business Return on Net
description: The Internal Revenue Service accepted its first business tax return over the Internet yesterday, expanding on a program that since 1995 has allowed some types of business tax returns to be filed over telephone lines from desktop computers.

description: STRAUSS-Lauri. December 17, 1957-February 10, 1984. Your love and laughter are always with us. Lentch-Bentch. Mom, Dad, Julie, David, Gregory, Emily

title: Companies Want You To Like Internet Radio
description: There are now more than 3,000 radio stations that stream their broadcasts over the Web and hundreds of Internet-only radio stations have also sprung up, enough to restore the romance of the lonely disc jockey taking to the airwaves before the days of strict Federal Communications Commission regulations and golden-oldie formats.

title: Concerns on Car-Seat Safety Lead to Focus on Education
description: In the midst of major changes in the design of children's car seats, auto makers are stepping up efforts to show parents how to use the seats properly.

title: Pirates Take Advantage Of Timeout That Wasn't
description: Seton Hall Coach Tommy Amaker sat in a quiet corner of the Louis Brown Athletic Center tonight, an hour before his team was to play Rutgers. He looked straight ahead, occasionally greeting a well-wisher, but he did not watch his team practice at the other end of the court. He had already given his players what he likes to call ''the landscape of the situation.''

description: The largest American scientific satellite, the 17-ton Compton Gamma Ray Observatory, is in danger of premature death.

title: Owner Says City Had Better Baseball Offer
description: Months before the Giuliani administration struck a tentative agreement to build a $71 million stadium for a minor league affiliate of the New York Yankees, the general manager of a successful ball club in Bridgeport, Conn., offered what he said was a far better deal to bring a professional team to his boyhood home, Staten Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBRUN, ZVI
description: SCHONBRUN-Zvi. Beloved husband to Frieda; father to Jeffrey, a lawyer in Newburgh, NY, and Benjamin, a lawyer in Venice, Calif.; father-in-law to Chaya, grandfather to Bree and Sarit. Born October 7, 1927, in Sombor, Yugoslavia, died February 8, 2000.

description: There were 13 literary dinner parties in New York last night to raise money to support the programs of a writers' organization, and naturally none of them were given by poor people.

title: F.D.A. Bars Marketing of Supplements to Pregnant Women
description: Under pressure from experts in birth defects, the Food and Drug Administration today withdrew, at least for now, a new rule that allowed dietary supplements to be sold for common pregnancy-related conditions like morning sickness and leg swelling.

title: Leetch Comes Out Fighting in His Return
description: Most turnovers don't turn out as well as this one did for Brian Leetch. The Ranger captain, back after missing 32 games with a broken arm, lost the puck at the Devils blue line last night in the first period at Continental Arena. The Devils rushed the other way but their attack was squelched by Kirk McLean, guarding the New York net in place of the injured Mike Richter.

title: Kwan Finds Artistry Battling Athleticism
description: She has been the anointed female skater of her generation, the establishment favorite, a two-time world champion and a three-time national champion. And yet Michelle Kwan feels a twinge of unfulfillment in her career, forged as much in gracious defeat as in spectacular victory.

description: LIPTON-Joseph. Of Winston Towers, Cliffside Park, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Gladys. Cherished father of Laurie Rosario and Robert Lipton. Dear brother of Marge (Herman) Friedman. Adored grandfather of Krysti Rosario, India and Kelly Lipton. Great-grandfather of Cody Rosario, and Cameron Martinez-Lipton. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, NJ, Friday 1PM (1-800378-1892).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about the complexities of connecting home entertainment equipment misstated the ability of older home audio receivers to reproduce Dolby Digital sound from certain DVD players. While Dolby Digital players can be used to play DVD's through older receivers that use a less sophisticated system called Dolby Pro-Logic, most such hookups will not produce sound of Dolby Digital quality.

description: The women huddled over an oval-shaped dining room table on a recent Saturday night. Some were stalwarts of the women's liberation movement of the 1960's and 70's. Others were simply swept up in the spirit, if not the actions, of the movement's high tide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGER, SYLVIA
description: MAGER-Sylvia. Beloved mother of Peter and Alison, loving wife and devoted widow of Nathan, and for many years the beloved friend and devoted companion of Sam Levy and a gracious relative to her extended family and loyal supporter of her many friends, died Sunday, February 5 of a heart attack in Cartagena, Colombia after being evacuated from a cruise ship. A private memorial service will be held Sunday, February 13 at the Marvel Platoff Memorial Chapel of Mt. Moriah Cemetery. The family is requesting that in lieu of flowers gifts may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

title: Ex-Argentine Soccer Star Makes News Again, Now in Cuba
description: Diego Maradona, once the sensation of the soccer world, was on the cover of one of Argentina's most prominent political magazines, Noticias, last week. He looked vastly overweight, his hair was dyed orange, and there was a huge tattoo of Che Guevara on his right arm. Beside him was the headline, ''Therapy Cuba Style.''

title: Euro RSCG Acquires Majority of 2 Agencies
description: Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, a unit of Havas Advertising, said yesterday that it had acquired majority stakes in two health care agencies and named a new chief executive for its health care agency operations.

description: Jets wide receiver Wayne Chrebet said yesterday that he expects the disorderly conduct charges he faces stemming from an alleged bar fight last Sunday to be dropped.

title: Bologna Journal; Coming to a Deli Near You: A Long-Taboo Sausage
description: In the 1971 film ''La Mortadella,'' Sophia Loren played a feisty would-be immigrant who is arrested by United States Customs officials in New York for refusing to surrender a 20-pound mortadella, the traditional pork sausage of Bologna. A cult classic in Italy, the satire was aimed at what the director, Mario Monicelli, called the ''authoritarian rigidity'' of American society.

title: U.S. Supports Tightening Of Sanctions on Belgrade
description: In an effort to tighten pressure on the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, the Clinton administration said today that it supported a plan to expand some sanctions against Belgrade while allowing some commercial airline flights to resume.

title: St. John's Set to Appeal To Get Barkley Suited Up
description: St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis said the university will appeal the three-game suspension of Erick Barkley because it is the right thing to do for his star guard, as well as for college basketball, and not because the Red Storm will need him for a game against Villanova on Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

description: To the Editor:

description: KOENIG-Stella A. On February 7, 2000. Age 99. Adored and adoring wife of Mortimer H., mother of the late Dr. M. Glenn Koenig. Beloved grandmother of Mark A. and Scott R. Koenig. Also survived by Constance R. Koenig McIntyre, the remarkable widow of Glenn, and her husband Tom McIntyre; greatgrandchildren Alexandra M. and Samuel M.; Mark's wife Debra; and many nieces, nephews and friends galore. Stella, dear Stella rest in peace. Service Thursday, February 10 at 12 noon at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to M. Glenn Koenig Fund at Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tenn.

title: Increasingly, E-Mail Users Find They Have Something to Hide
description: WHEN Spencer Grey sent a message to a group of friends and colleagues last fall notifying them of his new address, he thought nothing of putting all of the recipients' e-mail addresses in the To field of the message.

title: The Strength of the Internet Proves to Be Its Weakness
description: The Internet's greatest strength has proved to be its most disturbing weakness.

title: Obstetrician Pleads Not Guilty in Carving
description: A Manhattan obstetrician pleaded not guilty to felony assault charges yesterday for carving his initials into a woman's belly after performing a Caesarean section last fall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, ROSE
description: HIRSCHHORN-Rose. From the table of my memory, I draw nourishment from every crumb of recall of what you meant to me. Herbert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSS, LOUISE FILER
description: SCHLOSS-Louise Filer. In her 78th year. Died peacefully on February 4, after a long illness. Loving wife of Walter, beloved mother of Stephanie Scott, Edwin and sister Elizabeth (Betty) Filer. Nana to Katie, Emily and Jamie. Laid to rest February 9. Contributions in her memory would be appreciated to the Children's Book Committee of Bank Street College, 610 W. 112 St, NYC 10025, or the Mental Health Association of NYC, 666 Bway, NYC 10012.

title: Extra Layer of Protection For All of Those Discs
description: CD's and CD-ROM's are manufactured with a layer of clear plastic on the bottom to protect the encoded data from scratches caused by the slings and arrows of modern life. But sometimes one layer just won't do, particularly when young gamers sling their disks all over the place.

title: Mayor Unfairly Using Religion, First Lady Says
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had injected religion into the race for United States Senate. She added that she was ''appalled'' that he had attacked her in a fund-raising letter for what the mailing called her ''hostility toward America's religious traditions.''

title: Lobbyists Are Friends And Foes to McCain
description: When Senator John McCain appears, via satellite from Charleston, S.C., at a $500-a-person fund-raiser here on Thursday night, he will probably repeat his vow to ''break the Washington iron triangle of big money, lobbyists and legislation.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Bill Bradley's criticism of the Republican presidential candidates and the party on matters of race misstated the timing of Gov. Jeb Bush's order for an end to affirmative action in Florida. It was in November, not last week.

title: FOAMEX DISCUSSES ACQUISITION WITH INVESTMENT GROUP
description: Foamex International Inc., North America's largest maker of polyurethane foam used in carpets and furniture, said yesterday that it was in talks to be acquired by a group that includes its chief executive, John Johnson Jr. The company's market value is about $230 million. Besides Mr. Johnson, a former chief executive of the Safety-Kleen Corporation, other company managers and undisclosed investors also belong to the buyout group, Foamex said. Foamex, based in Linwood, Pa., said the potential all-cash sale is tied to last year's bankruptcy of its largest shareholder, Trace International Holdings. Trace, headed by Foamex's chairman, Marshall Cogan, distributed Foamex shares to creditors, reducing its stake to 29 percent from 46 percent. Foamex shares rose 31.25 cents, to $9.0625.

title: Nothing Is Something To Get Exercised About
description: ZERO

title: Pataki Calls for End to Limit On Prosecuting Rape Cases
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today called for an end to the legal time limit for prosecuting accused rapists and other violent criminals, because rapidly expanding DNA databases could now be used to identify them long after the crime was committed.

title: A Third-Generation Player Is Canny at 14
description: Children often follow their parents into bridge expertise, and Denmark now has what is perhaps the first such family to span three generations. Forty-five years ago Lizzie Schaltz was a member of the winning Danish team in the European Women's Teams, and she and her husband, Jorgen-Elith, were selected by their country to play in European Open Teams.

title: Marbury's Stroll Is Costly For Nets
description: Just when it seemed as if the Nets had lost a game in every way imaginable, the pitiable team came up with a new and practically unprecedented blunder in tonight's debacle at the First Union Center. After blowing a 21-point second-quarter lead, the Nets blew a chance to win on the final shot when their star point guard, Stephon Marbury, committed the strangest of turnovers.

Mass of Christian Burial at Murray-Weigel Chapel, on Friday, 11:30 AM. For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors, 718654-0500.

title: Kurdish Rebels Tell Turkey They Are Ending Their War
description: Kurdish rebels who have been fighting for self-rule in Turkey since 1984 announced today that they had given up their war and would press their cause ''within the framework of peace and democracy.''

description: WENDELKEN - Adelaide, born Brooklyn, NY February 14, 1912. Died on February 5 in Cherokee Village, AR. Preceded in death by husband Geo. Wendelken, brothers Carl Jackens, Herman, John and Richard Jachens. Survived by one daughter Carol Halvorson of Cherokee Village.

title: Scudder Kemper Cuts Number of Fund Offerings
description: Scudder Kemper Investments Inc. said today that it was merging 23 mutual funds and shutting 6, as it sought to strengthen its partnership with AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, and reverse withdrawals of $3 billion last year.

description: For more than 24 hours, Marcus Camby kept picking up the phone and hearing the voices of concern coming from his mother, friends and Knick teammates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENSON, LEONARD
description: GOLDENSON-Leonard H. Founder and Chairman of the Board of ABC, Inc., 1953-1986, died in Sarasota, Florida on December 27, 1999 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife, Isabelle Weinstein Goldenson, his two daughters, Loreen Arbus and Maxine Goldenson, both of Los Angeles, and one grandson, Lucas. A Memorial Service will be held Friday, February 11, 10:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. Contributions can be made in his memory to The Dr. William Berenberg Fund for Handicapped Children, C/O Children's Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

title: SFX Still Wants To Back an Arena
description: SFX Entertainment, the sports marketer and event producer, wants to help finance a new arena for the Islanders, but not by buying any part of the team, executives involved with the situation said.

title: I'm Sorry About Your Disaster. (Hurray!)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Florida family of Elian Gonzalez, the Cuban boy at the center of a custody dispute, misspelled the given name of a great-uncle in some editions. He is Delfin Gonzalez, not Deflin.

title: DiCaprio Swims With the Plankton in Paradise
description: ''The Beach'' is an attempt by all the major talents involved to try something new. For the first 10 minutes, the movie slices forward like the prelims of the latest adrenaline splurge at the Extreme Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, AUGUSTA K.
description: MAYER-Augusta K.., age 106, February 7, 2000 formerly of Hershey, PA and Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of the late Henry A. Mayer. Loving mother of Jeannette A. Sanger and the late Wallace R. Mayer. Cherished grandmother of Ronald H. McGlynn, Nancy J. McGlynn, Patricia M. Henry and Richard R. Mayer, great grandmother of four and great great grandmother of three. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St, Garden City, 10AM Saturday, Religious service to follow at funeral home 10:45 AM. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro slipped against the dollar, pressed partly by data showing that the German trade surplus had narrowed more than expected. In New York, the euro fell to 98.62 cents, from 99.27 cents on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGAL, VIVIAN W.
description: SIEGAL-Vivian W.. February 9, 2000. Loving mother of Frederick P. Siegal and his wife Marta and Marian Krauskopf & her husband Jack. Cherished grandmother of David, Nina, Lewis and Katie. Adoring sister of Leonard Weiner. Former wife of the late Dr. Sheppard Siegal. Memorial service Friday, Feb. 11th, 11AM in the art gallery of the 92nd St. Y.(Lexington Ave at 92 St.). Contributions in her memory may be made to the Tisch Center of the 92nd St. Y.

title: Despite Advantage, Bush Backers Worry Over McCain in New York
description: ''The McCain organization?'' Thomas J. Kirwan, a New York State assemblyman, replied, laughing at the question. ''In my district, that's me and three fellows I've never met.''

title: Gene Therapy Might Have Exposed 20 Children to Lethal Viruses
description: As many as 20 children with brain cancer may have been accidentally exposed to the viruses that cause AIDS and hepatitis C during a gene therapy experiment at hospitals in Houston and Memphis, a Clinton administration official said tonight.

title: Greenspan Urges Congress To Fuel Growth of Derivatives
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, urged Congress today to encourage the growth of complex financial contracts known as derivatives before the United States share of that market and associated benefits are lost to other countries.

title: Quiet Virtuoso
description: Tilman Riemenschneider's name now adorns a banner outside the Metropolitan Museum, announcing the most comprehensive survey of his work. It includes his St. Matthias, above, carved about 1500.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It's getting difficult to keep track of Douglas Rodriguez. Mr. Rodriguez, the chef who helped put Pan-Latino on the map, abruptly left Patria last month. But Unico, a restaurant he is developing with Michael Ginor, the co-owner of Hudson Valley Foie Gras, is still a work in progress. Now Mr. Rodriguez has unexpectedly touched down at Chicama, in ABC Carpet and Home, in quarters formerly occupied by the Italian restaurant Colina.

title: On the Republican Trail, and Off
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Couples'
description: Cheim & Read

title: Police Corruption Inquiry Expands in Los Angeles
description: A long-simmering corruption scandal has widened to encompass a broad swath of the Los Angeles Police Department, with the district attorney saying today that his office has now found more than 40 people who were wrongly prosecuted, and in several cases shot, through police misconduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, HARRIET
description: LEIBOWITZ - Harriet. Beloved wife of Harvey. Devoted mother of Hank and Marc. Loving sister of Howard. Adored grandmother of Michael, Samantha, Cassi and Sari. Services 12:30 Friday at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, RONALD ARIAH
description: ROSEMAN-Ronald Ariah., February 10, 2000. Loving husband of Okkyu. Devoted father of Remie and John. Pre-eminent oboist, inspired composer and beloved professor of music. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72nd St. Wake 6-9, Friday. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10:30am, at Holy Trinity Church, 213 W. 82nd St. Interment at Sacred Heart Cemetery, Southampton, L.I. In lieu of flowers, as a tribute to him, donations may be made for the CD re-release of his recording of Handel's Oboe Sonatas. Checks to Bridge Records, with memo ''Roseman's Handel Project,'' may be sent to Remie Roseman, c/o Marakon Associates, 245 Park Ave., NYC 10167.

title: Lebanon Fighting Ebbs in Claims of Victory
description: A flare-up of fighting in Lebanon subsided today as people in northern Israel emerged from bomb shelters and the United States called a meeting of a monitoring group to curb the hostilities.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: MOUSE ON MARS: ''Niun Niggung'' (Thrill Jockey). Ghosts of dance music waft through the instrumentals on ''Niun Niggung,'' the fourth album by the German duo Mouse on Mars. As synthesizers tick and whir, nibble and chirp, horn-section arrangements hint at ska in one tune, cha-cha in another; strings and a chunky beat briefly hark back to early disco.

title: You're Only Happy With Your Own Kind? Oh, Pooh
description: In 1966 Walt Disney produced a short animated film, a featurette in company parlance, called ''Winnie the Pooh and the Honey Tree,'' adapted from A. A. Milne's beloved children's book. Three more installments followed, and in 1977 Disney released ''The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh,'' which may be among the most frequently watched videos in a great many American households. I know it is in mine.

title: Graham, Released by Giants, Feels the Best Man Didn't Win
description: Kent Graham insisted he was not bitter, but the Giants' former starting quarterback said yesterday that he thought he had been treated unfairly and believed the team was making a mistake.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Tuesday about Tiger Woods's winning golf round at the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, misstated his score at the 15th hole. It was an eagle 2, not an eagle 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKEL, EDWARD
description: MARKEL-Edward. The family of Edward Markel mourn the death of their husband, father and grandfather. Mr. Markel was the former city editor of the New York Daily Mirror retiring in Nov. 1963. He was a former trustee for the Manhattan Savings Bank and a member of the board of directors of the Madison Square Boys Club. Contributions in Mr. Markel's memory may be made to the Madison Square Boys Club or the John E. Markel Park. For information Beecher Funeral Home, 1 Putnam Avenue, Brewster, NY

title: Frantisek Vobecky
description: Photomontages 1935-1938

title: Health-Aide Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Clinton Judicial Choices Are Approved After Lott Forces Votes
description: Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, forced through the confirmation of two federal judges today, putting a sudden end to an insurrection by members of his party who had vowed to block consideration of any of President Clinton's choices for the bench.

title: Forecast: Deep Slush, Followed by Scattered Snickers
description: ''Snow Day'' should be taken for what it is: a scheme -- likely to be successful for a week or so -- to separate a few million 10-year-olds from their allowances. You expect a movie like this to be pretty stupid. Why else would you pay good money to watch Chevy Chase don a Hawaiian-print shirt, a snowman costume and something that looks like a fur-trimmed Persian rug?

title: Fire Department Worker Arrested on Rape Charge
description: A Fire Department employee was arrested early yesterday on charges of raping a co-worker inside the computer room where they worked.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Mirror, Mirror, What Comes Next?
description: IN 1911, as he prepared to drive in the first 500-mile race at Indianapolis, Ray Harroun thought it might be useful to know what was going on behind him without having to turn around in the seat of his Marmon Meteor. So he attached a small mirror to the dashboard.

title: New Airline To Emphasize More Flights For Upstate
description: The nation's newest discount airline, JetBlue Airlines, is to begin operations today out of its new home base at Kennedy International Airport with flights that, among other things, seek to ease air travel to an underserved upstate New York market.

title: GENERAL CABLE IS SELLING SEVERAL BUSINESSES TO PIRELLI
description: Moving to reduce debt, the General Cable Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its energy cable businesses in Europe, Africa and Asia to Pirelli Cavi e Sistemi of Italy, a unit of Pirelli S.p.A., for $216 million. General Cable acquired the businesses as part of its $440 million acquisition of the British cable maker BICC in April. They include most of General Cable's operations in Britain, all of its operations in Italy and Africa, and its joint ventures in Malaysia and China. The businesses accounted for 22 percent of the company's revenue in the fourth quarter, General Cable said. General Cable, based in Highland Heights, Ky., makes copper, aluminum and fiber optic wire and cable products for the communications, energy and electrical markets.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Needing Another Hero, After All, in a Punk Western Series Set in the Future
description: ''A new breed, ferocious and wild,'' Tina Turner snarled about the characters populating George Miller's ''Mad Max'' series. Mr. Miller's directorial debut, ''Mad Max,'' has so much comic-book volatility that it triumphed over the wretched dubbing it received when it was released in the United States in 1979.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSNER, HELEN KUNZE (TUPPY)
description: MESSNER-Helen Kunze (Tuppy)., on February 9, 2000 in Trumbull, CT, formerly of the Bronx and Sag Harbor, NY. Beloved wife of the late William A. Messner. Devoted mother of Elizabeth Bales, William Messner, Katherine Coffey and Mary Messner Martin. Grandmother of seven, great-grandmother of one, and friend of one special dog, Rudi. Longtime volunteer of Southampton Hospital Thrift Shop and cook who loved her home in Sag Harbor. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Inc. Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-5 PM Sunday. Services at the Village Lutheran Church, Bronxville on Monday, February 14th at 11 A.M.

title: Cardinal Meets With Pope In Rome for Farewell Visit
description: Cardinal John O'Connor had a private farewell audience with Pope John Paul II today shortly before the Vatican held a special Mass for thousands of sick and terminally ill believers.

title: China Reportedly Detains 2,000 Members of Falun Gong Sect
description: At least 2,000 followers of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement have been detained in China in the last week, the official holiday period for the Lunar New Year, a Hong Kong human rights group said.

title: French Prosecutor Seeks Graft Trial for Ex-Foreign Minister
description: A French prosecutor has asked that former Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, together with a past mistress and six other people, stand trial on corruption charges stemming from a sex-and-kickback scandal involving the former national oil company.

title: Pablo Elvira, 62, Baritone Known To New York Opera Audiences
description: Pablo Elvira, a Puerto Rican-born baritone who became a regular member of the New York City Opera in the 1970's and 80's and sang frequently with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Saturday at his home in Bozeman, Mont. He was 62.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: McCain Finds Support From Odd Corner: Lobbyists
description: Senator John McCain appeared by satellite tonight before a roomful of Washington lawyers and lobbyists who paid $1,000 each to hear him denounce Washington's ''iron triangle'' of money, lobbyists and legislation.

title: Ben & Jerry's Stock Rises on Report of Offer
description: Shares of Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., the second-largest United States maker of premium ice cream, rose today after it was reported that the company had received a buyout offer for about $268 million.

title: De La Hoya Drops Clancy
description: In the wake of his loss to Felix Trinidad, Oscar De La Hoya has dropped the veteran trainer Gil Clancy and turned up the heat in his training camp in preparation for his Feb. 26 fight against Derrell Coley at Madison Square Garden.

title: WORRIES ON SONY CONSOLE
description: Shares of the Sony Corporation fell on worries that the new PlayStation 2 game console would not live up to expectations. The company said on Wednesday that some games designed for the original PlayStation did not work on the second-generation machine, and investors are worried that Sony cannot meet its target for producing the new machine. Ken Kutaragi, who heads the PlayStation business, insisted that Sony would meet its targets and said only ''a few more than 10'' of the roughly 2,500 existing software titles were not compatible with the new machines. Stephanie Strom

title: Each Day a Tabula Rasa, Ready to Be Dirtied
description: ''Fuddy Meers,'' which recently had a limited run at the Manhattan Theater Club, reopened last night at the Minetta Lane Theater, 18 Minetta Lane, Greenwich Village. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Nov. 3.

title: Idealizing Handmade As a Virtue
description: Most design movements reflect the political regimes that spawn them, whether Ming or Louis XIV. Just as Louis Seize furniture was designed to reflect royal glory, Empire furniture was part of Napoleon's brilliant propaganda machine. But Britain's Arts and Crafts Movement grew out of the politics of protest. It began in the mid-1800's as a reaction to the human cost of rapid industrialization.

title: Arrest Made in Dumping Of Medical Waste
description: A 36-year-old salesman of medical waste disposal equipment was arrested by federal agents yesterday and accused of dumping medical waste and a container marked with anti-Semitic material on the lawn of a Stamford synagogue last summer.

title: Public Interests; New York's Holy War
description: A U.S. Senate race in New York is a rare and wondrous thing. Who among us can forget the one that Alfonse D'Amato won on the issue of whether ''Fascist'' was an anti-Italian slur? In 1998 Charles Schumer was elected after a contest dominated by a debate over the meaning of the word ''putzhead.'' Now we venture forth once again, and the latest controversy of the Year 2000 campaign is whether or not Hillary Clinton is an enemy of religion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, LILLIAN
description: KRAMER-Lillian., on February 10, 2000, in Hollywood, Fla. Beloved wife of the late Rube. Loving mother of Judy Katz and her husband, Stanley, and Phyllis Gumbrecht and her husband, Gary. Cherished grandmother of Andy and Cheryl.

title: Waiting in Guatemala
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey Finds Disparities in Train Service
description: Residents of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx pay substantially higher fares than suburban commuters do for traveling the same distance on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North, but their service is more sporadic and their stations are much more dilapidated, according to a survey of the commuter railroads released yesterday by the Public Advocate's office.

title: Airlines Told to Check 1,100 Planes Like One in Crash
description: Alaska Airlines said today that a check of the mechanism that moves the horizontal stabilizer on jetliners of the MD-80 series had turned up metal shavings on two of the carrier's planes, and the Federal Aviation Administration promptly ordered all domestic airlines to complete inspections of similar planes for signs of damage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICK, LIONEL A., M.D.
description: DICK-Lionel A., M.D.. Age 75, eminent dermatologist, after a long illness. A wonderful and gentle man devotedly cared for by his beloved wife, Karen. Lovingly remembered by his brother, Dr. Frederick (Marion) S. Dick, niece Barbara Rich, nephew Michael (Marjatta) Dick.

title: On the Republican Trail, and Off
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Foreign Affairs; Mr. Bush's Homework
description: The Times Op-Ed page sponsored a forum yesterday for people to give advice to George W. Bush on how to reinvigorate his campaign. I'm a day late, but here's my entry:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBLER, JOYCE
description: LEIBLER-Joyce. On February 10. Darling wife of Charles. Loving mother of Mara and Guy. Dear sister of Bernard Schwartz. Mother-in-law of Renee' and Joel, and devoted grandmother of Isabelle, Samantha and William. A memorial service will be held in the Spring.

title: Senate and Clinton Still Stalled on Nuclear Waste Disposal
description: Seventeen years ago, Congress ordered the Energy Department to choose a place for permanent storage of the tons and tons of radioactive nuclear waste building up at reactors in 40 states.

title: Bradley Gains a Superstar For His Ads: Michael Jordan
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley got a big lift from an old friend today, announcing that the former Chicago Bulls superstar Michael Jordan would appear in a 30-second television commercial for the Bradley campaign that will begin running in several important primary states on Friday.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO REDUCE TAXES FOR THE MARRIED
description: The House today passed a Republican-sponsored bill that would cut taxes for married couples by $182 billion over the next decade, brushing aside the Clinton administration's position that any such tax cut should be far smaller and be enacted only after more pressing issues are resolved.

title: 2 Canadian Paper Companies Said to Be Discussing Merger
description: Trading in the stock of two major Canadian paper companies was halted yesterday as one of the companies, Abitibi-Consolidated Inc., announced that it was in ''advanced'' merger talks.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: EQUIFAX AGREES TO BUY POLK CONSUMER INFORMATION UNIT
description: Equifax Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the consumer-information division of the closely held R. L. Polk & Company for about $260 million. Equifax, based in Atlanta, is a credit information and payment services company. Polk, based in Southfield, Mich., is a leading provider of marketing information services. The Polk unit's products include consumer credit information, as well as electronic commerce, customer relationship management and payment services. The acquisition would give Equifax a bigger presence in mining demographic and lifestyle databases to select customers for marketing.

title: Metro Business; Airline Cuts Workforce
description: Tower Air, a low-fare and charter airline, is eliminating 300 workers worldwide, or 19 percent of its workforce, and pulling a plane from its fleet in an attempt to return to profitability.

title: Safety Issues Looming as Number of Shuttle Flights Increases
description: The space agency has managed to launch space shuttles safely with a reduced work force, but critical shortages of skilled engineers and little past efforts to replace them could pose increased safety problems as the flight rate increases in coming years, an advisory panel said today.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Everybody's Neighborhood

title: After Benitez and Mets Talk, Arbitration Seems the Answer
description: The Mets have made little progress during contract talks with Armando Benitez, and the team appears headed for its first arbitration hearing in eight years.

title: Indictment of Lewis and 2 Others Will Be Sought
description: Prosecutors plan to ask an Atlanta grand jury to indict Ray Lewis, the Baltimore Ravens' All-Pro linebacker, and two other men on Friday in the slayings of two young men outside a nightclub hours after the Super Bowl, the authorities said today.

title: British Troops Replace French in Riot-Torn Kosovo Town
description: British peacekeeping forces took over guard duties on a bridge in the ethnically divided town of Mitrovica in northern Kosovo today, replacing French troops that had been accused of failing to protect ethnic Albanians and Serbs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTHING, FRANK
description: WORTHING-Frank. The Lincoln Hall Board of Managers notes with deep regret the passing of Frank W. Worthing who served on the Board from 1983 to 1995. Frank's extensive background and epertise regarding the insurance industry made him an invaluable asset as Chairman of the Audit and Insurance Committee. The Board and staff extend sincere condolences to his wife, Grace, and his family on their loss. James G. Nugent President Board of Managers Douglas W. Wyatt Vice President Board of Managers

title: Court Says Software Maker Can Emulate Sonys PlayStation
description: Court Says Software Maker Can Emulate Sony's PlayStation

title: Champ (Briefly) of the Sexual Olympics
description: One thing is clear about the star of the documentary ''Sex: The Annabel Chong Story.'' She craves attention.

title: More Now Leaving Silicon Valley Than Arriving
description: More Now Leaving Silicon Valley Than Arriving

title: Curmudgeon's Rebirth, With Infidelities and Fits
description: EVERYTHING YOU KNOW
