description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENSON, LEONARD H.
description: GOLDENSON-Leonard H.. Founder and Chairman of the Board of ABC, Inc., 1953-1986, died in Sarasota, Florida on December 27, 1999 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife, Isabelle Weinstein Goldenson, his two daughters, Loreen Arbus and Maxine Goldenson, both of Los Angeles, and one grandson, Lucas. A Memorial Service will be held Friday, February 11, 10:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. Contributions can be made in his memory to The Dr. William Berenberg Fund for Handicapped Children, C/O Children's Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

title: For Romance
description: Monday is Valentine's Day, and the 12 very romantic restaurants below are probably already booked for that night. But true romantics never let anything so mundane as a date on a calendar discourage them. So you may want to tuck this list away for another romantic evening. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANKIN, DOROTHY
description: RANKIN-Dorothy. February 4, 2000, Locust, NJ. Wife of the late Frank Rankin, mother of Susie Gavigan, Neil Rankin & the late Jim Rankin. Survived by nine grandchildren & five great grandchildren. Memorial Mass at Holy Cross Church, Rumson, NJ, Saturday February 12, 2000 at 10AM.

title: NO BID FOR RETAILER
description: Philip Green, a British retail investor, said he would not bid for Marks & Spencer P.L.C. to avoid a battle with the new management of the company, Britain's biggest clothing retailer. The shares of Marks & Spencer fell to the lowest closing price since 1991. Mr. Green said in December that he was considering a bid. A new executive chairman was named by Marks & Spencer three weeks ago, and the company earlier named a new marketing director and announced plans to add employees and revamp its image.

title: Brazil Beer-Merger Partners Charge Obstruction by Coke
description: Two Brazilian breweries that agreed last July to form Latin America's biggest beverage company accused the Coca-Cola Company today of trying to derail their $3.9 billion deal in order to suppress a competitive threat in one of Coke's most important overseas markets.

title: McCain Attacks Unions And Vows Better Schools
description: Repeatedly attacking teachers unions and ''self-serving union bosses,'' Senator John McCain called today for an experimental program of school vouchers, for merit pay for teachers and for judges who would allow voluntary prayer and the posting of the Ten Commandments in schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUFIERI, THERESA TESTA
description: AUFIERI-Theresa Testa. On February 9, 2000. Loving mother of Joan and Father Robert. Devoted sister to Nicholas & Clarice. Caring grandmother to Joseph. The family will receive Friends at the Flower Funeral Home, Inc., 714 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, New York. On Friday from 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Barnabas R.C. Church, Bronx, on Saturday at 11:00 AM. Interment is at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Jack Tworkov
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: Legislators Keep Jobs In Spite of Error
description: Oops. It seems that, technically, the Democrats may not have taken control of the Nassau County Legislature after all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, JAMES M.
description: EDWARDS-James M.. Died Feb. 7, 2000. Age 68. Beloved husband of the late Veronica. Devoted and loving father of Nina and Philip, brother of Robert and Harold. Memorial service, St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue, Saturday, February 12th, at 2:30.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- Seattle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, GEORGE W. SR
description: BRANDT-George W. Sr. of New York City died February 5, 2000 at age 85. He is survived by his wife, Lillian Sampson (Fuhrtz), two children, The Rev. Canon George W. Brandt, Jr. of New York and Judyie Ellen and her husband Shahid Al-Bilali of Edgartown, Mass., and two grandchildren, Hanan and Muhammad Al-Bilali. Memorial service Tuesday, February 29th at Noon, at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Ave. at 99th Street. Interment private.

title: RUSSELL SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 800 MORE JOBS IN U.S.
description: The Russell Corporation, maker of Russell Athletic sportswear, is cutting 800 more jobs in the United States as part of its plan to move more than 90 percent of its assembly plants to Honduras and Mexico by the end of the year. The cuts will probably be at plants in North Carolina, Virginia and Alabama, a Russell spokeswoman said. The company has eliminated 4,241 United States jobs over the last 18 months, shrinking its domestic work force to about 10,250. Russell has 16,000 employees worldwide.

title: FOUR-YEAR SENTENCE FOR TAX EVASION
description: The chairman of South Korea's flagship carrier, Korean Air, received a four-year prison term for tax evasion. A Seoul district court also ordered Cho Yang Ho, 51, to pay 30 billion won ($26.7 million) in fines for evading 27.3 billion won ($24.3 million) in taxes. Samuel Len

title: Vast Wasteland? Fast-Paced Land!
description: NO one has taken the measure of that awesome monster television with more audacious ingenuity than Nam June Paik, the Korean-born electronics wizard who started his career in Germany as a renegade musician. With boundless energy and manic obsession, he has made television his own subversive creature, pushing it beyond the banalities of network and cable into the realm of art and critique.

title: Marino Voids Contract, And Buffalo Releases 3
description: On a day when Dan Marino, the National Football League's leading career passer, voided the final two years of his contract, the Buffalo Bills yesterday broke their last ties with their American Football Conference championship teams of the 1990's.

title: Defending Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils' Sale to YankeeNets Expected Within 2 Weeks
description: The $175 million purchase of the Devils by the YankeeNets could be completed by the end of the month, two people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Mrs. Clinton Is Ready for Her Close-Up and Attuned to How It's Used
description: To the eternal domestic question -- Can she cook? -- Hillary Clinton offers an unequivocal response in her new campaign video, ''Hillary.''

title: Inspired by Movies, Commoners Practice the Noble Art
description: Take your typical Big Apple fender bender, transpose it to Paris in, say, 1720, and odds are that swords and seconds would be summoned. From 1600 to 1780, 40,000 Frenchmen died in duels. That averages out to 222 a year, and the Hungarians and Italians were surely as passionate. (Though it was a Frenchman, Moliere, who summed up the essence of the duel: ''The entire secret of arms consists of only two things: to give, and not to receive.'')

title: In Griffey, Reds Get a Bargain In More Ways Than One
description: The Cincinnati Reds had their cake yesterday, and they ate it, too. Icing? They had plenty.

title: Wilfred C. Smith Dies at 83; Scholar of Religious Pluralism
description: Wilfred Cantwell Smith, a scholar of Islam and comparative religions who took an early lead in urging intellectual understanding of religious pluralism and dialogue among faiths, died on Monday in a hospital in Toronto. He was 83 and lived in Toronto.

title: Healthy Rangers Begin Playoff Chase
description: Still nursing their wounds from bumps and bruises sustained in a pair of tough games with the Devils the previous two nights, the Rangers took the ice today for an optional practice with just eight players choosing to put on their skates. Among them was Adam Graves, trying to shake off pain far worse than his teammates' physical ailments.

title: SUNSOURCE SAYS IT IS SELLING MAJORITY STAKE IN TWO UNITS
description: SunSource Inc., an industrial management services company, will sell a majority stake in its repair-parts units to affiliates of Glencoe Capital L.L.C. for $105 million in cash to raise money for an acquisition. SunSource, based in Philadelphia, agreed to contribute Kar Products Inc. and A&H Bolt and Nut to GC Sun Holdings L.P., a partnership with Glencoe, in exchange for the cash and a 49 percent stake. Affiliates of Glencoe, a closely held equity firm based in Chicago, will hold the rest. The agreement would give SunSource most of the capital it needs to acquire Axxess Technologies Inc., of Tempe, Ariz., a maker of key-duplication and identification machines that SunSource agreed to buy in October. SunSource shares rose 81.25 cents, to $5.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLOWE, PHYLLIS H.
description: BERLOWE-Phyllis H.. Died peacefully on February 9, 2000 at the age of 77. Devoted and loving aunt, great aunt and great-great aunt, and highly respected and well-known public relations executive. Will be deeply mourned by her family and friends. A private family service will be held on Saturday, February 12. Contributions in Ms. Berlowe's memory may be made to The Humane Society.

title: Gus Johnson, 86, Who Gave The Beat to the Giants of Jazz
description: Gus Johnson, a drummer for some of the great jazz bands from the 1930's to the 50's, including those led by Count Basie and Benny Goodman, died on Sunday at Clear Creek Care Center in Westminster, Colo. He was 86 and lived in North Glen, Colo.

title: Socialist Is Charting Middle Way For Chile
description: With a month to go before he becomes the first Socialist to lead Chile since Salvador Allende, President-elect Ricardo Lagos is showing a strong streak of independence from his party leadership and has appointed a relatively conservative, American-educated economic team that promises to keep down budget deficits and inflation.

title: Success Story for the Bundeswehr / 10% of Its 30,000 Officers Come From the East : German Army Smoothly Makes Room in the Ranks for Former Foes
description: BERLIN  Among the many Western institutions trying to spread democratic stability in Central Europe, few boast a greater success story than the German Army, the Bundeswehr.

title: U.S. Military Checking Computers
description: U.S. Military Checking Computers

title: Don't Count Him Out: Woods 6 Shots Off Pace
description: While Tiger Woods struggled with his swing today, Davis Love III gained confidence in his.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD GAINS. Gold prices surged after more mining companies said they would end a selling strategy that is popular when prices are falling. In New York, gold for delivery in April rose $10.10 an ounce, to $318.70.

title: INSIDE
description: French Replaced in Kosovo

title: Fur Protesters Interrupt Shows, but Barely
description: As major Web sites came under day-by-day attack by computer pranksters this week, so have Bryant Park's fashion shows been disrupted by rolling anti-fur protests.

title: Syd Cassyd, 91; Envisioned TV Academy
description: Syd Cassyd, whose idea it was to found the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, which gives the Emmy Awards, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 91.

title: Upstate New York Holds Rare Sway in Senate Race
description: By the usual rules of statewide political campaigns, upstate New York is for Republicans. The green and gritty expanse of small towns and cities, farmland and mountains that roll north and west from Westchester County to Canada has for 50 years been the part of New York where Republicans could turn to counterbalance the lopsided Democratic vote that inevitably emerges from New York City. For Democrats, it was a place to just hold down the losses.

title: On the Republican Trail, and Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Weiss Is Subpar, but Good Enough to Take Lead Over Goebel
description: There is a conflicting sense of desperation and possibility at the national figure skating championships, of uncertain champions and resourceful challengers, of rapid, inevitable change that is being faced with unsettling anticipation and eager innovation.

title: IRISH AIRLINE EXECUTIVE QUITS
description: Garry Cullen, chief executive of Aer Lingus of Ireland, has resigned only four months before the state-run airline had hoped to sell shares to the public. Mr. Cullen, a 35-year veteran of the airline, cited personal reasons for his resignation after only 16 months as chief executive. Brian Lavery

title: An Innovator on the Threshold of the Renaissance
description: Call it semantic sentimentality of the softest kind, but the names of geniuses often seem to echo their achievements. Bach's surname suggests orderly, one-note-at-a-time precision; Beethoven, the play of roiling emotion. The second syllable of Copernicus, rhyming with ''turn'' and ''burn,'' intimates its owner's discovery of the solar system. Newton ends appropriately with a small thud.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: St. John's Barkley Appeals Suspension and Wins
description: St. John's guard Erick Barkley will play against Villanova tomorrow after a National Collegiate Athletic Association subcommittee yesterday upheld the university's appeal and sliced one game off what was supposed to be a three-game suspension.

title: National News Briefs; Campaign Finance Critic Named to Election Panel
description: President Clinton has nominated Bradley A. Smith, a critic of campaign finance laws who has supported ending limits on the amount of money candidates can raise and spend, as a commissioner of the Federal Election Commission.

title: His Lead Shaken, Bush Tries a Breezier, Less Ceremonial Style
description: There was, for starters, his altitude.

title: Scores on Hijacked Afghan Plane Ask Unhappy British for Asylum
description: No sooner had the government orchestrated a peaceful end to a four-day hijacking of an Afghan airliner at Stansted airport this morning than it was faced with another crisis: how to sort the hijackers from the hostages and deal with all those suddenly clamoring for political asylum in Britain.

title: For Relaxing, Luxury Helps
description: ''So do I need to curtsy when I go in?'' Gabriela wanted to know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, ROSE (NEE FORD)
description: GREENE-Rose (nee Ford). Native of Drumlish County Lonford. Wife of the late Michael, mother of James and Frances Brew, grandmother of James, Christina, Claudia, Catherine, Susan and Stephen Greene and Damian, Kieran and Timothy Brew. Visitation Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx. Mass Monday St. Helena's Church, Monday 9:30 AM. Interment St. John's. Contributions may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Administration Takes a Bow In Final Economic Report
description: With a technological revolution, low inflation and global integration in full swing, the current United States economic expansion, already the longest in American history, shows few signs of old age, President Clinton said in his administration's last annual survey of the economy.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about a program in France that provides ''morning after'' pills to students in high school and junior high misstated the name of the drug. And a correction on Wednesday described it incorrectly. The pill is Norlevo, not Norvelo. The Population Council, an international nonprofit research organization based in New York, considers it an emergency contraception drug, not an abortion drug.

title: Through A Glass, Darkly
description: DO you cower in your car when a tall sport utility menaces you from behind, its headlamps reflecting from your mirrors into your eyes? Your next vehicle may have mirrors that instantly darken to block that glare. It could also have windows that go dark on command, keeping the outside world somewhat at bay.

title: SOUTH KOREA RAISES RATE
description: South Korea's central bank raised the one-day call rate to 5 percent from 4.75 percent. It was the first increase since an economic crisis started in December 1997. The call rate, which is the interest paid when one financial institution borrows money from another, is a key index for short-term interest rates. The measure was taken to narrow the gap between short and long-term rates. The yield on three-year corporate bonds now stands around 10 percent. Samuel Len

title: The Undecided
description: New York's Senate race is likely to turn on a surprisingly small group of undecided voters, many with strong and conflicted opinions about the well-known candidates. The choices of these voters may have as much to do with personal circumstances and gut feelings as political philosophy.

title: Sports of The Times; Going Home Is Good Deal For Junior
description: A COLLECTIVE sigh of relief was exhaled yesterday in the old baseball town of Cincinnati -- and a good portion of Seattle, too.

title: Editorial Observer; The First Lady's Voyage of Self-Definition
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton drew a good crowd when she dropped by the Strong Memorial Hospital's new research wing earlier this week. Some listened intently as she ticked off a somber list of promises on health care. Others seemed to be using their lunch hour to observe a historical phenomenon, the first first lady running for public office.

title: Internet's Rich Are Giving It Away, Their Way
description: At 25, Nicholas Lovejoy left his $27,000-a-year job as a math teacher in suburban Seattle, took a pay cut and went to work for a friend, Jeff Bezos, just then establishing a start-up site on the World Wide Web. He was the fifth employee in the door at Amazon.com.

title: An African Pinochet
description: Even as British courts ponder whether the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet should be excused from trial in Spain on human rights charges because he is medically unfit, the enduring legacy of his case has been demonstrated on another continent. Last week a Senegalese court indicted the exiled former dictator of Chad, Hissene Habre, on torture charges. It was the first time that a former African head of state had been charged with human rights violations by a court in another country, and it opens a welcome new chapter in the evolution of international criminal law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKSTEIN, GLORIA
description: DICKSTEIN - Gloria. Beloved mother of Reba Dickstein and Eli Ben Avner and grandchildren Dawn and Mike and Maya and Shaun. Shiva will be observed at the home of Reba.

title: Ion Gheorghe Maurer, 97, Romanian Premier From 1961 to 1974
description: Ion Gheorghe Maurer, who was prime minister, foreign minister and titular head of state of independent-minded Communist Romania from the 1950's to the 1970's, died Tuesday in Bucharest, the Romanian capital, where he lived. He was 97.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, ROXANNE
description: MASON-Roxanne., on February 9, 2000, a longtime loyal and devoted friend of St. Paul's House. Reposing at John J. Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 W. 51 St, NYC, Friday 6-8PM. Interment Rosehill Cemetery, Linden, NJ, Saturday 9AM.

title: U.S. Releases Money to Help The Poor Pay Rising Heat Bills
description: Reacting to the combination of higher oil prices and a winter cold snap, the federal government today released $130 million to offset the heating bills of low-income families across the country.

title: Shavian Laughs
description: ''Arms and the Man,'' Shaw's sendup of martial affairs and romantic illusions in a Ruritanian world -- a crowd pleaser since it opened in 1894 -- is back, this time in a high-strung production at the Gramercy Theater. The revival, which stresses the play's farcical aspects, is directed by Roger Rees with a cast that includes Katie Finneran and Paul Michael Valley, above.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Toast to Larry Summers, Bond Salesman of the Year
description: LARRY SUMMERS is taking heat for the way he has handled the bond market. I say it's a bum rap. He just saved the taxpayers a billion dollars while leaving Wall Street baffled. He is the salesman of the year.

title: Levy Joining Construction Board
description: The New York City School Construction Authority is getting a trustee who knows something about the condition of the city's 1,574 school buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODRICH, VIRGINIA O.

Loving mother of Ernest C. Goodrich, Jr. and motherin-law of Kathleen Maher. Proud grandmother of Jasper, Nicholas and Alec. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Joseph College, 1678 Asylum Avenue, West Hartford, CT. 06117 or to the Wadsworth Atheneum, 600 Main Street, Hartford, CT. 06103.

title: Web Attacks Have Government Revisiting Laws and Security

title: Letter Hints at a Cover-up By Officer in Louima Case
description: Federal prosecutors said in a letter filed this week that days before Justin A. Volpe pleaded guilty to assaulting Abner Louima in a Brooklyn police station, he was overheard assuring a lawyer for a second officer that he would not implicate him as an accomplice.

The former civil rights lawyer said he had been inspired to fight for better public schools by his fourth-grade teacher in Harlem.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND RAISES RATES
description: As expected, the Bank of England said it would raise its key interest rate by a quarter point, to 6 percent. The move is the fourth increase in six months. The rate increase is meant to moderate Britain's economy, which has been moving along at breakneck speed. Andrew Ross Sorkin

description: RUDOLPH-Blanche H.. Died on February 9, 2000. Blanche was a dedicated and gifted educator who inpired her thousands of students with a respect for learning. She is survived by her loving cousins and her many cherished and devoted friends and colleagues. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY at 12:30 today.

title: Leaping on the Laughs In a Shavian Confection
description: Audibility, at least, is not a problem in the Roundabout Theater Company's production of ''Arms and the Man.'' The actors' voices, though congested with mossy English accents, boom, shriek and bellow even in calmer moments, giving the Gramercy Theater a decibel level to match that of Irving Plaza, the nearby rock arena. Somewhere along the way, it seems, a decision was made to take the words ''screamingly funny'' to heart.

title: Houston, a Star at Last, Is Taking It All in Stride
description: On occasion, Allan Houston and his wife will pull into the parking lot of a movie theater. And as Houston unbuckles his seat belt and gathers his things in the slow, smooth motions of a scuba diver, Tammy Houston has already hustled to the line, has a ticket in her hand and is heading for the concession stand.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about early-bird dining specials in Manhattan, and a brief article listing restaurants that offer them, misidentified a restaurant that serves half-price sushi. It is Match, at 160 Mercer Street (between Houston and Prince Streets), not March.

description: As the rap impresario Sean Combs glared and scowled, a Manhattan prosecutor yesterday accused him of sparking a December shooting at a Times Square night club.

title: Investors Shun Auction of U.S. Bonds, Causing Yields to Jump

There have been sharp daily moves, then reversals a day later. And traders say that they have often been on the wrong side of the action, causing painful losses for some.

title: Easy Prey Online
description: The computer attacks that brought a half-dozen or so of the most popular sites on the World Wide Web to their knees this week took advantage of a security weakness that some experts have known about for at least two years. The computerized ''switches'' that relay information along the Internet can't cope with a flood of invalid data coming from a great many different electronic addresses at once.

title: Hacker Attacks on the Internet
description: Just when Americans have begun to get accustomed to the pervasive influence of the Internet, a wave of anonymous assaults on Web sites has roiled the stability of the newly emerging cyberworld. The latest hacker attacks, which have disrupted some of the Web's most popular sites, are especially insidious because they seem so nihilistic. None appear to have been motivated by blackmail or other monetary purposes. They may even have been carried out as a perverse warning, to prove the vulnerability of the Internet to attack. Whatever the twisted motive, prosecutors are right to investigate the causes and recommend safeguards, though it may well be that no safeguard will work perfectly.

title: Rocker States His Case at Appeal of Suspension
description: John Rocker's words earning him a 73-day suspension appeared in a national magazine for all to read. His words concerning his remarks and his subsequent suspension were recited in private, aimed only at the arbitrator who will decide Rocker's immediate future.

title: In promoting Valentine's Day gifts and services, dot-coms show how event-specific they can be.
description: THE deluge of advertising spending by dot-coms has not ended with the Christmas shopping season or the Super Bowl. Instead, scores of e-commerce entrepreneurs are making Valentine's Day the next battleground.

description: All the problems with New Jersey's new motor vehicle inspection system have suited Rafael Ottenwalder and Jesus Valle just fine, the police say.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Speaking to the Heart Without a Single Word

On Sunday night at 8 Mr. Dorsky will make his first New York City appearance in 12 years, as part of the Walter Reade Theater's Image Innovators series, to present three relatively recent works from a career that has spanned 30 years.

title: Teacher's Aide Held Hostage For 3 Hours by Student With Gun
description: An 18-year-old student at a southern New Jersey school held a teacher's aide hostage at gunpoint for three hours yesterday, demanding cigarettes and a cell phone from police negotiators before surrendering peacefully, officials said.

title: Jets Move to Keep Lewis Out of Free-Agent Clutches
description: The Jets prepared for the start of free agency by essentially putting a ''Do Not Disturb'' sign around the player other teams most wanted to pluck from their roster.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday about the Companhia de Danca Deborah Colker, from Brazil, misstated its opening date at the Joyce Theater. Performances begin next Wednesday, not Tuesday. The article also characterized the New York engagement incorrectly. The company's North American debut occurred this week, in Toronto.

title: Web Security Companies Profit From Attack Scare
description: Web Security Companies Profit From Attack Scare

title: Port Authority Agrees to Let Piers Be Used for Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: After years of battling over conflicting visions of the waterfront piers below Brooklyn Heights, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to allow its prime property there to be developed as public parkland.

title: Devastating Wound Came Late, Diallo Defense Contends
description: Two experts called by the defense in the Amadou Diallo trial testified today that the bullet that tore through Mr. Diallo's aorta and spinal cord was among the last of the 19 that struck him, contradicting the prosecution's expert, who had said it was among the first.

title: Brooklyn Nights Turn Brighter
description: GO out in Brooklyn? On the weekend? For groovy New Yorkers, that was once an unbearably tepid proposition. Russian immigrants may drink vodka in Brighton Beach leisure palaces, and Trinidadians let loose to soca near Nostrand Avenue. But the students, artists and hipsters seeking the cultural edge started their evenings on the subway to the Village and beyond.

title: Review/Fashion; New Wrinkles At Lang and Sui
description: Helmut Lang and Anna Sui are hardly two peas in the same fashion pod. Mr. Lang is a minimalist from Vienna who likes reruns of ''The Golden Girls.'' Ms. Sui is an extravagant from Dearborn, Mich., who can remember what Bianca Jagger wore the day she wed Mick.

title: Vlasic to Explore Options, Including Merger
description: Vlasic Foods International Inc. is hiring an investment bank to explore options, including a merger, and is eliminating 45 corporate staff positions as its shares languish at record lows.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Mae Faggs Starr, Champion And Track Mentor, Dies at 67
description: Mae Faggs Starr, an Olympic champion sprinter and the first renowned athlete of the Tigerbelle women's track teams at Tennessee State University, died Jan. 27 at her home in Woodlawn, Ohio. She was 67.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Democrats who cross party lines to vote for John McCain in Republican primaries referred imprecisely to California's system. The names of all candidates will appear on the same ballot there, regardless of party. But the ballots will be coded so that only Republican votes count toward selecting Republican delegates and only Democratic votes pick Democratic delegates. (In a closed primary, by contrast, voting is restricted by party.)

title: On the Republican Trail, and Off
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FINLAY ENTERPRISES INC., New York, the largest operator of fine-jewelry counters in United States department stores, will buy some assets from Jay B. Rudolph Inc., Tampa, Fla., which operates leased jewelry departments, for about $23 million in cash.

title: Nature's Crown Inspires Regal Design
description: Fashion-related art shows keep lining up on the runway. The latest arrival is ''Hair in African Art and Culture'' at the Museum for African Art. And it's a smashing creation: generously contoured, rich in detail. It should provide a box-office hit for an institution with a proud scholarly track record.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: 'Hairspray'? No Teasing?

title: Bradley Tries to Link Gore to the N.R.A.
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley sharply questioned Vice President Al Gore's commitment to gun control today, saying Mr. Gore had a voting record in Congress that could make him a ''poster child'' for the National Rifle Association.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.

title: Desire to Close Digital Divide
description: Desire to Close Digital Divide

title: A Founding Father and Perhaps the Mother
description: He was a prominent politician, a widower who had vowed never to remarry. She was the beautiful, brilliant, socially inferior mistress he could never acknowledge, despite the many children she bore him. And at times throughout the three decades of their illicit love affair, she would toss his own words back at him. During one nasty lovers' quarrel, she yells, '' 'We hold these truths to be self-evident.' What truths? To whom?''

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Campaign Briefings
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: INGERSOLL-RAND AGREES TO SELL PUMP UNIT TO FLOWSERVE
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company agreed yesterday to sell its pump unit to the Flowserve Corporation for $775 million in cash in a deal that would make Flowserve the world's second-largest maker of pumps. Last year, Ingersoll-Rand, an equipment maker based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., bought the remaining 49 percent stake it did not already own in Ingersoll-Dresser Pumps for $377 million. The pump unit had revenue of $838 million in 1999, Ingersoll-Rand said. The sale is part of Ingersoll-Rand's plan to sell noncore businesses and focus on climate control, security and industrial equipment businesses. Ingersoll-Rand's shares fell $2.5625, to $40.1875, while Flowserve, based in Irving, Tex., was down $1.25 at $13.5625.

title: A Monastery in Thrall To an Addictive, Rowdy God
description: The Cup

title: Lightning Brings Out The Best In Islanders
description: All things considered, Islanders Coach Butch Goring said, it was kind of fun to watch.

title: Two Top Researchers Join the Disney Exodus
description: Two of the Walt Disney Company's top research scientists said today that they were leaving to form their own technology company, becoming the latest in a series of defections from the big entertainment company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELVIRA, PABLO
description: ELVIRA-Pablo. New York City Opera mourns the passing of our good friend and colleague, Pablo Elvira. He joined our company in 1974 and remained with us until 1989, providing us with many memorable evenings in the theater as a leading baritone in the Italian repertory. He was a gifted artist with a larger-than-life personality and a popular company member who we will remember with great fondness. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and his many friends. Paul Kellogg General Director

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ALLOUF, ALICE
description: ALLOUF-Alice. (nee Stoloff) February 11, 1998. We miss you and cherish the memory of you. Joseph and Michael

title: In Politics, Still a Man's World
description: In 1873, the Supreme Court declared in Bradwell v. Illinois that the state was justified in denying Myra Bradwell a license to practice law on the basis of her gender. The court informed Bradwell that despite her education and skills, as a woman her best roles were wife and mother.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Wuxtry! Greed Uncovered in Plainville!
description: Few plays in all dramatic literature are as timeless as Gogol's ''Inspector General.'' Human greed and corruption can be found just about anywhere at any time, and in ''Small Potatoes,'' a contemporary retelling by Bob Rogers, they abound in an upstate New York town called Plainville.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHULTS, ROY THEODORE MD.
description: SHULTS-Roy Theodore MD.. 12/17/20-2/11-98. Cherished and missed forever. Your loving wife Eleanor, Tom, Ted, Kate, Byron and Elain

title: AETHER IS BUYING RIVERBED FOR $800 MILLION
description: Aether Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Riverbed Technologies Inc. for about $800 million in stock, in a deal intended to strengthen Aether's line of products for mobile computing. Riverbed, based in Vienna, Va., makes software for hand-held computers. Aether, based in Owings Mills, Md., licenses software that acts as a bridge between companies' applications and hand-held wireless devices. Separately, Aether formed an alliance with an Internet consulting and electronic business development company, Proxicom Inc. of Reston, Va., to develop wireless Internet products. Aether's shares jumped $41.0625 each, or 23 percent, to $220.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANS, ROSLYN (NEE COHEN)
description: HANS-Roslyn (nee Cohen). February 23rd, 1910 to Jan. 29th, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Daniel Hans and loving sister of Jeannette Seidman and the late Lottie Brillson, Charles Cohen, and Elihu Corwin. Loving aunt and great aunt to many nieces and nephews. Graveside services were held February 1st at the New Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: A Matter of Promises
description: The campaign of Gov. George W. Bush unspooled a 30-second television commercial on Tuesday that escalated Mr. Bush's attacks against Senator John McCain. The advertisement, titled ''Promised,'' takes Mr. McCain to task as failing to live up to his promise to run a civil campaign for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Resenting African Workers, Spaniards Attack
description: The sun-drenched shores of southern Spain have long been overrun by foreigners. But seldom, until a few days ago, has the line been so sharply drawn between those who are welcome and those who are not.

title: Northern Ireland's Reversal
description: The Irish Republican Army's delays in spelling out a clear plan for turning in its vast store of hidden weapons led Britain to take the regrettable but necessary step yesterday of suspending Northern Ireland's 10-week-old power-sharing government. The launch of that promising experiment in local self-government last December was one of the most significant achievements produced by the 1998 Good Friday peace agreement. For more than two months, representatives of the province's main Protestant and Catholic parties, including the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sinn Fein, worked side-by-side on a regular and constructive basis.

title: Smithsonian Appoints a Political Savant
description: Sheila Burke, the top aide to Bob Dole when he was majority leader of the Senate, was named to a high-ranking position at the Smithsonian Institution today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, JAMES M.
description: EDWARDS-James M.. Died Feb. 7, 2000. Age 68. Beloved husband of the late Veronica. Devoted and loving father of Nina and Philip, brother of Robert and Harold. Memorial service, St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue, Saturday, February 12th, at 2:30.

title: New Violence Ends Lull in South Lebanon
description: Just after headlines here pronounced an easing of this week's heightened violence in southern Lebanon, Shiite Muslim guerrillas killed another Israeli soldier today, and Israeli warplanes responded swiftly with air strikes at suspected guerrilla targets.

title: Giants' Ad: Cornerbacks Wanted, Experience Preferred
description: Big-name players are falling into the National Football League free-agent market in record numbers. Unfortunately for the Giants, who are looking for a replacement for Phillippi Sparks, the talent windfall is not ripe with cornerbacks.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VIASOFT INC., Phoenix, a maker of computer software, said it would dismiss about 70 employees and take a third-quarter charge of about $1.4 million to cut costs after its failed merger with the Compuware Corp., Farmington Hills, Mich.

title: Fog Delay Of 3 Hours Hits JetBlue On First Flight
description: Stymied only by weather, the nation's newest discount airline, JetBlue, began service yesterday in its main market -- upstate New York -- with a flight from Buffalo to Kennedy International Airport.

title: Questions on Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: All-Star Players 2000: Younger and Plugged In
description: Shaquille O'Neal, a Web site guru, spoke at a technological summit today, espousing the virtues of a new era in the National Basketball Association. Not to be outdone, Kobe Bryant rehearsed lyrics to his rap song with the model Tyra Banks while Vince Carter walked down a runway in a resplendent suit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHNAYERSON, EDWARD
description: SHNAYERSON-Edward., M.D. Of Englewood, N.J. On February 11. Beloved husband of Francine. Devoted father of Jill Cohen and Leslie Breslin. Cherished father-in-law of Peter Cohen and Julian Breslin. Dear brother of Thelma Fishman. Adored uncle of Gregg Fishman. Loving grandfather of Matthew, Alison, Samantha and Kimberly. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J. Sunday, 10:30AM. Should friends desire contributions to Englewood Hospital or the University of Arkansas Medical School would be appreciated.

title: Colorado Panel Defeats Move to Close a Gun-Show Loophole
description: A measure that would have required private firearms dealers at gun shows to conduct the same kind of background checks that licensed dealers perform was narrowly defeated today in the Colorado Legislature.

title: The Few, the Proud: The Islanders' Fans
description: Section 316 of Nassau Coliseum was empty. So was 320. Five fans occupied 310. Three more inhabited 308. You could hold a bar mitzvah in 306. Only 4,785 people showed up Thursday night when the Islanders beat Tampa Bay, 5-4, in overtime. They found easy parking, short lines at the concession stands and abundant legroom almost anywhere they chose to sit.

title: Mighty Symphony Looms Over Small-Scale Chaos
description: The Concertgebouw Orchestra made the trip from Amsterdam to Carnegie Hall this week with a brief history lesson at the back of its mind. On Wednesday, Riccardo Chailly conducted the Bruckner Seventh Symphony and on Thursday pieces by Varese and Ligeti. Triumphant humanity at the end of the 19th century meets puzzlement in the middle of the 20th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRENN, MARY A.
description: WRENN-Mary A.. Former Vice President and Managing Director of Merril Lynch, died Thursday, February 10, 2000 in her home in Easton, CT following a long illness. She was 74 years old. Ms. Wrenn was a longtime resident of Greenwich, CT and New York City, before moving to Easton 5 years ago. Born in Danbury, CT, Ms. Wrenn was the daughter of the late Delia Kelley Wrenn and Andrew Wrenn. She was an accomplished businesswoman who was said to have forged new paths for women in the male-dominated investment banking business. She was elected the first woman Vice President of any worldwide investment firm in 1967, and the first woman Managing Director of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in 1978. Ms. Wrenn was a magna cum laude graduate of Albertus Magnus College, New Haven, CT, and received an Honorary Doctor of Law degree from that college in 1977. She also held graduate degrees in economics and banking and finance from New York University. Ms. Wrenn was predeceased by her brother William A. Wrenn, and her two sisters Joan D. Wrenn and Elizabeth Wrenn Richter. She is survived by four nieces Catherine Wrenn Gombos of Easton, CT, Patricia Wrenn Murphy of Redding, CT, Elizabeth Wrenn Adams of Plano, TX, and Mary Wrenn Cordeiro of Bristol, RI; two nephews Kevin P. Wrenn of Boston, MA, and Christopher W. Wrenn of Monroe, CT. She also leaves behind 12 great nephews and nieces. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Tuesday, February 15, 2000 at 10 AM at Notre Dame of Easton Church, Morehouse Road, Easton, CT. Interment will be at St. Peter's Cemetery, Danbury, CT. Friends may call on Monday, February 14, 2000 from 3-5 PM and from 7-9 PM at the Lesko-Miner Funeral Home, 155 Main St. (Route 25), Monroe, CT.

title: Despite Options on Census, Many to Check 'Black' Only
description: This year's new, racially inclusive census might have seemed tailor made for Michael Gelobter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, FR. DANIEL, S.A.
description: EGAN-Fr. Daniel, S.A.., a Friar of the Atonement, Graymoor, Garrison, NY, died on Thursday, February 10, 2000. Referred to as the ''Junkie Priest,'' he became internationally known for his work in drug abuse prevention, rehabilitation and education. Visitation will be held at Pilgrim Hall, Friars of the Atonement, Graymoor, Garrison, NY on Mon., Feb. 14th from 2:00-7:30PM. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Pilgrim Hall on Mon. at 7:30PM. Interment will be Tues., Feb. 15th at the Friars' Cemetery, Graymoor. For further information call DorseyCarlone Funeral Home, Peekskill, NY. (914) 737-0848.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBLER, JOYCE
description: LEIBLER-Joyce. So accomplished, elegant and most dear. Your spirit will live on. Jerry and Penny

title: No, I'm Not With the Mob
description: Ask an Italian-American privately about prejudice, and you'll hear about the offhand remarks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDNICK, PAULINE, M.D.
description: RUDNICK-Pauline, M.D.. The faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine mourn the passing of Pauline Rudnick, M.D., Clinical Professor of Psychiatry. Having practiced pediatrics for many years, she came in 1954 to Bellevue Hospital Center where she completed her residency in psychiatry. She joined the school's faculty in 1958 and gave decades of service in the Department of Psychiatry at Bellevue including directing it's Mental Hygiene Clinic from 1970-90. She subsequently served in the Student Health Service of NYU at Washington Square until 1999, all the while continuing to make contributions to the school through her lectures, supervision and membership on various committees. Her loss will be felt throughout the NYU community but her commitment to service and to her field will be long remembered. Robert M. Glickman, M.D. Dean, NYU School of Medicine Robert Cancro, M.D. Chairman, Department of Psychiatry NYU School of Medicine

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts & Ideas pages last Saturday about utopias misidentified the publisher of ''The Utopia Reader.'' It is New York University Press, not Routledge.

title: Job Aid in C.I.A. Case
description: A former C.I.A. director recommended a top agency official for a job at the bank where he was a board member as she monitored an inquiry into whether he had mishandled classified information. Article, Page A10.

title: Behind a Murder Suspect's Cool Facade, Emotional Turmoil
description: All week long, a small, close-knit group of students at Columbia University has puzzled over the paradox of Thomas G. Nelford Jr. What inner torment could have possessed a bright young man they knew as a pacifist, artist and all-around mellow California dude to suddenly slash the throat of a woman he had just taken home for Christmas?

title: BRITAIN SUSPENDS SELF-GOVERNMENT IN NORTH IRELAND
description: The government of Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland that held out the tantalizing promise of an end to the British province's dangerously polarized political life came to a halt today after only 10 weeks in operation.

title: Why Pick a Winner? There's Boy George
description: As news of John McCain's New Hampshire landslide hit the networks, I was in Beverly Hills interviewing Warren Beatty on a subject other than his unconsummated political striptease of last fall. But Mr. Beatty can't stop talking about politics, and while he has yet to endorse a candidate, he couldn't contain his ebullience about Mr. McCain, whom he regards as a friend. Yes, the Arizona senator (like the other candidates of both parties) is well to the right of Bulworth -- even on his signature issue of campaign finance reform. But still, Mr. Beatty avows: ''John is a good man.''

title: 2 Who Exposed Corruption in District Council 37 Not Chosen for Board
description: The official appointed to clean up District Council 37, the largest union of New York City municipal employees, has appointed 14 members to the union's exective board, but has come under fire for not appointing the two officials who have done the most to expose corruption at the council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, DOROTHY
description: BARRETT-Dorothy. Died on February 10th, 2000. She was 94. Wife of the late Maxwell Barrett. Loving mother to Martin Barrett. Cherished grandmother to David and Stephen Barrett. For information call Zion Memorial Chapel 914-381-1809.

title: Afghans and Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A movie review in Weekend yesterday about ''The Ice Rink'' misstated the length of its run at Anthology Film Archives in the East Village. It continues through Feb. 29, not through Feb. 17.

title: Fighter Gets First Shot at the Real Thing
description: Zab Judah's boxing friends kept telling him to be patient, that one day his time would come in spite of the obstacles that had come his way. But it is difficult for an athlete to wait when his talent is racing ahead of schedule.

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES TO TAKE OVER NETWORK DEVICE
description: Alpha Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase closely held Network Device Inc. for $141 million, in a move to expand its presence in the wireless communications market. Alpha Industries, based in Woburn, Mass., makes integrated circuits and semiconductors for wireless voice and data communications. Network Device, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., provides advanced technology integrated circuit design and fabrication for the wireless telephone market. Alpha Industries' shares fell $1.9375, to $115.8125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: The Future of Figure Skating Arrives
description: She wore a white costume, which can engulf a skater on an ice surface, but Sasha Cohen hardly disappeared tonight. After Michelle Kwan fell on her most reliable jump, the 15-year-old Cohen performed a wonderfully lyrical and impossibly flexible routine to take first place in the short program at the national figure skating championships.

title: Ventura Quits Reform Party, Citing Leaders
description: Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, the Reform Party's highest-ranking elected official, said yesterday that he was resigning from the party over his growing dissatisfaction with its fractured leadership.

title: Amazon Sells Convertible 10-Year Notes
description: Amazon.com Inc., the online retailer, sold 690 million euros ($681 million) of convertible 10-year notes yesterday to finance expansion and investments in other online companies.

title: SWEDISH MATCH ADDING BRANDS OF NATIONAL TOBACCO
description: Swedish Match A.B., maker of Cricket lighters and White Owl cigars, agreed yesterday to buy the brands owned by the closely held National Tobacco Company for $165 million to add the Beech-Nut and Durango names to its Red Man chewing tobacco line. Swedish Match said it was buying the brands, formulas and inventory of National Tobacco, based in Louisville, Ky., which has annual chewing tobacco sales of about $50 million. Swedish Match is No. 1 in United States sales of chewing tobacco. National Tobacco brands will give the Stockholm-based Swedish Match about 55 percent of the United States chewing tobacco market and greater control over prices, which have been falling because of competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERSCHLAG, HELEN
description: HAMMERSCHLAG-Helen. On February 11th, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Frederick. Loving mother of Mark and Lynne. Dear sister of Ethel Zuckerman and Renae Weiner. Adoring grandmother of Jessica, Jack, Alexander and Nicholas. Service Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hong Kong's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Asylum Issue After Hijacking Creates Headache for Britain
description: A jet chartered to fly Afghan hostages home arrived in Britain today. But the government said it still did not know how many people from this week's hijacking wanted to fly back and how many would ask to stay in Britain.

title: Jets Eye Bills' Smith To Help Pass Rush
description: On the first day of National Football League free agency, the Jets were relatively quiet: Coach Al Groh hired two assistants -- including his son -- and the Jets confirmed they had tendered offers to all seven of their restricted free agents and had reviewed the list of free agents.

title: 2 Top Newsprint Producers In Canada Agree to Merge
description: Abitibi-Consolidated Inc., the world's largest newsprint producer, announced today that it was merging with Donohue Inc., its biggest Canadian rival, creating a company that can supply more than a third of North American demand.

title: Cuts at Software Maker
description: The Policy Management Systems Corporation, which sells software to insurance and financial-service companies, said late on Thursday that it planned to cut 350 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force. About 200 of the job cuts are at Policy Management's headquarters. Based here, the company said it was seeking to cut costs by $20 million.

title: Where Rocker's Rights End
description: When John Rocker arrived in New York this week to appeal his suspension from Major League Baseball, he was greeted by catcalls and angry demonstrators, exactly the sort of indignant response he should have expected to get, given the slurs he has directed at blacks and other people. But Rocker also has his defenders -- and not only the white supremacists who have taken up his cause on the Internet.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Stepping Out Of UConn's Shadow
description: In a state where Huskymania runs rampant even when the defending national champion University of Connecticut men's team has lost five games -- not much attention is paid to the basketball feats of Central Connecticut State University.

title: WESTPOINT STEVENS CHIEF TO TAKE COMPANY PRIVATE
description: WestPoint Stevens Inc. the maker of textile products, said yesterday that its chief executive, Holcombe Green Jr., had offered to take the company private in a transaction that values the company, the largest United States maker of bedding and towels, at about $1.12 billion. Mr. Green, who controls about a third of the shares outstanding, offered $21 a share. The stock last traded at $14 on the New York Stock Exchange before trading was halted. It had been above $37 a share last April. The company, which makes Martex, Utica and Lady Pepperell-brand linens, hired Merrill Lynch & Company in November for advice on options including a sale or merger. The board asked the firm to help evaluate Mr. Green's offer and explore alternatives.

title: NatWest Board Gives In to Buyout by Royal Bank
description: After a bruising four-month battle for control of National Westminster Bank, the Royal Bank of Scotland emerged the winner today.

title: Cyberdreamers Beware: Danger Ahead!
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STASSOU, ERNEST
description: STASSOU-Ernest. On February 11, 2000. Beloved husband of Anne (nee Tsamisis). Loving brother of Maria and Efegenia. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd St. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Nicholas G.O. Church. Interment Flushing Cemetery.

title: RATE RISE IN HONG KONG
description: The Hong Kong Association of Banks followed the United States Federal Reserve's lead and raised interest rates by a quarter-point. The association increased short-term savings rates to 4 percent from 3.75 percent, and the city's biggest lenders immediately began announcing rises in their benchmark retail lending rates. Hong Kong's currency is pegged to the United States dollar, so changes in United States monetary policy are often followed by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and by the bank association.

title: Zimbabwe Constitution Vote Is a Showdown for Mugabe
description: Citizens in this economically struggling nation go the polls this weekend for what is in fact, if not in name, a referendum on the only leader whom this country has known, President Robert Mugabe.

title: Corrections
description: The Spare Times guide in Weekend yesterday misstated one date for ''Ghostly Love Stories for St. Valentine's Day,'' a walking tour of lower Manhattan, given by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. It is tomorrow (not today) at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m., starting outside the Second Avenue Deli, at 10th Street in the East Village. As noted, it also takes place on Monday at 2 and 6 p.m.

title: Senate Refuses to Discuss Rowland's Proposed Budget
description: For the first time since Connecticut lawmakers began passing two-year budgets in 1991, a powerful group of legislators -- in this case, Democrats in the State Senate -- are insisting that the state not tinker with a budget in progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELVIRA, PABLO
description: ELVIRA-Pablo. We note with great sadness the death of Pablo Elvira, a good friend and colleague. His memorable performance in Donizetti's ''La Favorita'' with Barbara Hendricks, Shirley Verrett, Alfredo Kraus and James Morris will long be remembered, as will his appearance in Boito's ''Nerone.'' Mr. Elvira will always be thought of with affection and respect by all at Opera Orchestra and his ringing baritone voice will be missed. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his wife Signe, his son Pablo, and his family. Eve Queler and Opera Orchestra of New York

title: MCI Worldcom May Issue Internet Unit Tracking Stock
description: MCI Worldcom May Issue Internet Unit Tracking Stock

title: MAPLE LEAF FOODS TO ACQUIRE HUB MEAT PACKERS
description: Maple Leaf Foods Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Hub Meat Packers Ltd., a meat processing company in Moncton, New Brunswick. The value of the deal was not disclosed. The acquisition includes the meat processing plants operated by Hub in Moncton and by Larsen Packers Ltd. in Berwick, Nova Scotia. The Hub and Larsen brands are also included. Hub, a privately held company with 1,000 employees, currently has annual sales of about $186 million. Larsen Packers is majority-owned by Hub and has about 400 employees. Maple Leaf Foods is a food processing company based in Toronto.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHIPMAN, MARY DANA
description: SHIPMAN-Mary Dana. Born in NYC. Died on February 1, 2000. A memorial service is in the meeting room of Duncaster, Bloomfield, Conn. on Saturday, February 26th at 11am.

title: SPANISH CORPORATE ALLIANCE
description: Spain's secondlargest bank and its biggest phone company, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria S.A. and Telefonica S.A., said they would swap shares and appoint vice chairmen to each other's boards as part of a broad alliance to develop online banking. Telefonica will buy 3 percent of Banco Bilbao on the open market and its chairman, Juan Villalonga, will become the vice chairman of the bank. Banco Bilbao, which already is the No. 1 shareholder in Telefonica, will raise its stake to 10 percent from about 8 percent now. It will also have a vice chairman on Telefonica's board.

title: WASSALL TO BE ACQUIRED
description: The world's largest buyout firm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, will buy Wassall P.L.C. for $:627 million ($1 billion) in cash as it seeks to create the biggest company in Europe's fragmented lighting business. Kohlberg Kravis offered 400 pence for each Wassall share. The New York-based firm is selling Thorn Lighting Group, Wassall's main operating asset, to Zumtobel, a family controlled lighting company in Austria. Kohlberg Kravis will get a third of Zumtobel after the swap. With Thorn's business, the company will be one of Europe's two largest makers of lighting fixtures.

title: Valuable 'Work Colleges'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, JOSEPH (GEORGE)
description: POLLACK-Joseph (George). Loving husband of Helen, proud father of Richard and Michael, adoring grandfather. Silver and Bronze star W.W.II veteran. Funeral service, Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Sunday, 11:30 A.M.

title: Cyberdreamers Beware: Danger Ahead!
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Die and a Fourth Is Badly Burned in a Staten Island Fire
description: A fire that broke out in a Staten Island building early yesterday morning killed three recent immigrants, sent one man rushing outside in flames and forced two people to jump from a third-floor window. Fire officials said the blaze appeared to have been deliberately set.

title: Geoffrey de Ste. Croix, 89, Historian of Ancient Greece
description: Geoffrey Ernest Maurice de Ste. Croix, a Marxist historian of ancient Greece and Rome whose erudition and sweeping, passionate style won the admiration of colleagues even when they disagreed with his conclusions, died on Feb. 5 at a hospital in Oxford, England. He was three days short of his 90th birthday.

title: High Oil Prices Aren't a Bad Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Not Fat and Happy?
description: There is a curious thing about the John McCain phenomenon. Populist campaigns usually arise from adversity. In this time of unprecedented prosperity, one would expect voters to be fat and happy, contented with the status quo. Why, then, are so many turning to an iconoclast, a candidate who promises to shake things up?

title: FRANCE TELCOM READY TO SHOP
description: Europe's second-biggest telephone company, France Telecom S.A., said it was interested in buying Orange P.L.C. to strengthen its international business and better compete with Vodafone AirTouch. Orange ''would be perfectly complementary,'' Jean-Louis Vinciguerra, executive vice president for finance, told analysts at a meeting to discuss 1999 sales performance. The company will be aggressive in pursuing Britain's third-biggest wireless operator, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, HAROLD, DR.
description: BLANK-Harold, Dr.., at home CA, February 1. Survived by wife Ruth, sons Ron and Terry, grandchildren Dan, Marni, Eliza, Willa. Sister Muriel Hirsch. A talented and respected Dentist from Great Neck, NY, retired. We will all miss his courageous vitality. Burial private in Lake Placid.

title: Roger Vadim, 72, Director Who Propelled Bardot, Dies
description: Roger Vadim, the French film director who turned Brigitte Bardot into an overnight star and potent sex symbol in his first movie, ''And God Created Woman,'' died today in a Paris hospital. He was 72.

title: Jordan Finds A New Arena To Play In
description: IN the conference room of a downtown office building here yesterday morning, a small group gathered at the Bill Bradley campaign headquarters to watch the start of his new national ad campaign featuring Michael Jordan.

title: ANDRX IS SET TO PURCHASE VALMED PHARMACEUTICAL
description: The Andrx Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Valmed Pharmaceutical Inc., adding a distributor of generic drugs to a company that already develops generic and controlled-release medicines. In a statement, Andrx said it would make the purchase in cash. It did not disclose how much it would pay for closely held Valmed, which was described as profitable, with $40 million in distribution revenue recorded in 1999. Valmed is based in Grand Island, N.Y. Andrx, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., fell $2.1875, to $65.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Whitman Withholds Pay To Auto Test Company
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman withheld $10 million in payments this week to the company hired to conduct the state's new auto-emissions test, demanding a report on expenses related to the payment and plans for solving the test's problems.

title: Amid Attacks, a Battle to Claim High Ground
description: Capping a week of ceaseless attacks in the Republican presidential race, Gov. George W. Bush today recited a litany of what he said were contradictions between Senator John McCain's words and actions, while Mr. McCain pledged to end television advertisements that belittle Mr. Bush's character.

title: Pets.com Gets Lukewarm Reception on Wall Street
description: Pets.com Gets Lukewarm Reception on Wall Street

title: A Flutist Has His Day At Last
description: Normally Jeffrey Khaner is to be found sitting in the principal flutist's chair with his colleagues in the Philadelphia Orchestra, but on Monday night at Cooper Union he was performing just with Charles Abramovic, at the piano, in a recital of mid-20th-century sonatas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, JOSEPH, DR.
description: MANDELBAUM-Joseph, Dr.. Of Brooklyn, N.Y., died peacefully at home at age 87. After graduating from Columbia College in 1931 and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1935, he conducted research on dark adaptation and subsequently went into the private practice of ophthalmology. He was Medical Director of the HIP Flatbush Medical Group and also was a Founding Executive of the League for Emotionally Disturbed Children. Despite the demands of his busy professional life, he found time for world travel and photography. Born November 7, 1912, he was the son of Rose Breitman and Meyer Mandelbaum. He was married for 59 years to the late Hattie Golubow and is survived by their children Paul, Jill and Joel and their grandchildren Hanna and Max. The family will receive friends at his Brooklyn home Sunday afternoon February 13th. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Attacks on Internet Sites Divide the Nation's Hackers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, EDWARD A.
description: WAGNER-Edward A.., on February 10, 2000. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Greenstein). Loving father of Lauren, Eric, Elise and Elizabeth. Caring son of Sidney Nathan Wagner. Devoted brother of Michael and Susan Wagner. Loving husband, father, son and uncle. Funeral service on Sunday, 1PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Memorial contributions to American Diabetes Foundation, 200 White Plains Road, Tarrytown, NY 10591 or Cancer Care, 101 N.Central Ave, Hartsdale, NY 10530 would be appreciated.

title: Valentines Day Prompts Surge in Web Traffic and Ads
description: Valentine's Day Prompts Surge in Web Traffic and Ads

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Club Owner, Short on Bail, Is Accused Anew
description: A wealthy Miami nightclub impresario, already accused of murder and running with a vicious New York Mafia crew, also skimmed profits from one of his own trendy dance spots and burned down another to collect the insurance, federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAMAGUCHI, WILLIAM E. SR
description: YAMAGUCHI-William E. Sr., died at home in Larchmont, NY on February 10, 2000 at the age of 75. Following a long career with Time-Life, he set up a consulting practice, bridging the Japanese and American business cultures. Survived by his wife Kim; his children Ellen, Chip and Susan; and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Sunday, February 13th at the Larchmont Avenue Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSNER, HELEN KUNZE (TUPPY)
description: MESSNER-Helen Kunze (Tuppy)., on February 9, 2000 in Trumbull, CT, formerly of the Bronx and Sag Harbor, NY. Beloved wife of the late William A. Messner. Devoted mother of Elizabeth Bales, William Messner, Katherine Coffey and Mary Messner Martin. Grandmother of seven, great-grandmother of one, and friend of one special dog, Rudi. Longtime volunteer of Southampton Hospital Thrift Shop, and wonderful homemaker and cook who loved her home in Sag Harbor. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Inc. Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-5 PM Sunday. Services at the Village Lutheran Church, Bronxville on Monday, February 14th at 11 A.M.

title: High Oil Prices Aren't a Bad Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Fair Tests for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 Points Good for 12 Tricks: That's Known as a Good Fit
description: Barring freak distribution and two void suits, a partnership will hardly ever have an unbeatable slam with fewer than 20 high card points in the combined hands. This generalization was shattered by the diagramed deal from the final session of the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams in Boston at the end of November. East-West held 12 high card points, including a useless jack, but could not be defeated in six diamonds.

title: Bush and McCain in Ad War, To the Delight of Democrats
description: Dick Harpootlian, the chairman of the South Carolina Democratic Party, sounded as giddy as a lottery winner.

title: Northwest Airlines Offers New Type of Business Fare
description: Northwest Airlines is offering a new type of air fare intended to make business travel less onerous.

title: School Board Seeks Curb On Gay Tolerance Clubs
description: Already ordered by a federal judge to allow meetings of a gay tolerance club at a high school, the Orange County board of education voted on Thursday night to restrict clubs at elementary and middle schools to those related to studies in an effort to block similar organizations at lower grade levels.

title: Marriage-Tax Quick Fix
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a statement by Vice President Taha Yassin Ramadan of Iraq that United Nations weapons inspectors would not be allowed to return to the country misstated the timing of the statement. It was made on Thursday, not yesterday.

title: SALE OF OKLAHOMA ARCO UNIT TO EASE BUYOUT CONCERNS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company plans to sell oil pipelines, connections and storage tanks near Cushing, Okla., to eliminate one obstacle to its proposed $30 billion buyout by BP Amoco. The Federal Trade Commission sued last week to block the merger, partly because of concerns that the Cushing operations would enable the combined company to manipulate the price of the most commonly traded oil futures contract. Arco and BP Amoco face other challenges from the F.T.C., some related to oil pumped from Alaska's North Slope. Separately, Reuters reported that Judge Susan Illston of United States District Court scheduled the last two weeks of March to hear arguments in the case.

title: For Valentine's Day, Americans Cite Their Favorite Poems
description: Robert Pinsky, the poet laureate, invited Americans from all over to write about their favorite poems. A salesman from New York, a retired artist from Kansas, a handyman from North Carolina, a marine from Virginia -- some 17,000 people in all responded, sharing poems and explaining their meaning in their lives. These excerpts are from ''Americans' Favorite Poems'' (W. W. Norton), an anthology published last fall that grew out of the Pinsky project. JOYCE JENSEN

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the death of an infant son of the New York Rangers hockey player Adam Graves, misstated the number of days the child lived. It was 24, not 25.

title: Using Genetic Matchmaking to Help Save Endangered Species
description: In a laboratory at Columbia University, biologists are studying the DNA of black lion tamarin monkeys, using the latest genetics technology to accomplish a seemingly old-fashioned goal: matchmaking.

title: $100 MILLION INVESTMENT IN INFOCURE ONLINE UNIT SET
description: The Healtheon/WebMD Corporation will invest up to $100 million in the InfoCure Corporation's online health-care practice management unit, VitalWorks.com, InfoCure said yesterday. InfoCure, an Atlanta seller of health care software products and services, said Healtheon would pay $10 million for convertible preferred stock that, if converted, would equal 1 percent of VitalWorks' shares outstanding after the company's planned initial public offering. Healtheon, based in Santa Clara, Calif., will invest an additional $40 million in cash and $50 million in Healtheon stock upon completion of the offering. Shares of InfoCure were up $4.4375 at $24.625 in Nasdaq trading, where shares of Healtheon were unchanged at $55.

title: Officials Identify 1 Computer Site
description: Another university's computer system was identified yesterday as a conduit in the attacks earlier this week that blocked several leading Web sites, but network officials and law enforcement authorities reported no new attacks.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- San Jose, Oakland, Calif.

title: Voters Say Character, Not Issues, Is Their Concern in Race for White House
description: When they are asked how they go about choosing a president, voters usually frown, cock their heads and finally end up saying in effect that they are looking not so much for a candidate they agree with as one they admire.

title: In Riot-Torn Kosovo City, Serbs Force Albanians From Homes
description: Despite the presence of several hundred added peacekeeping troops, Serbs continue to threaten ethnic Albanians who live among them on the northern side of Mitrovica. The Serbs are forcing the Kosovars to leave their houses and take refuge in the city's Albanian half, south of the Ibar River.

title: The Profiteers of Elder Care
description: For the Russian immigrants spending their old age in Brooklyn these last three years, the Parkshore adult day-care centers must have seemed wonderful. Ambulance vans picked them up and brought them home whether they needed transportation or not, and at the centers, waiting for them, were free beauty parlors, Russian-language television, borscht and herring, golden gift watches and, for a time, bonuses of $50 just for signing up friends to enjoy more of the same.

title: A Carville of California Politics Plans to Deliver for Gore
description: IN 1991, Garry South arrived here with no job, few contacts and $16,000 from cashing out his pension after three years as communications director for the embattled Democratic governor of Ohio, Richard F. Celeste. To keep busy, he freelanced features for The Glendale News-Press, a local weekly. At $60 a pop, he wrote about subjects like a 50-year-old turtle, and a Girl Scout troop that marched in the Tournament of Roses Parade.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This was not a war. It was like some sort of strange tornado came and wiped everything out.''

title: On the Job or in the Home, A Decision to Help Others
description: While many of New York's charities are following the work of a dedicated group of young Wall Street analysts who each year raise money for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, workers in other industries have also given to the fund year after year, often to less fanfare.

title: Mrs. Clinton Backs Tax Relief for College Costs
description: Seizing on one of the central proposals of Charles E. Schumer's successful campaign for the United States Senate in 1998, Hillary Rodham Clinton today took her campaign to two Long Island campuses and pledged to push to make college tuition tax-deductible.

title: A Big Nyet To Shareholder Input; A Too Private Privatization Of a Russian Utility
description: After years of share dilutions, lock-outs from annual meetings and the occasional outright expropriation, foreign investors understand that most Russian companies care little for shareholder rights.

title: Doctor Says Harm to Children Is Unlikely in Questioned Study
description: Faced with questions about whether more than two dozen childhood brain cancer patients may have been exposed to the viruses that cause AIDS and hepatitis C during a gene therapy experiment, the scientist conducting the study said today that the chance that any children were actually harmed was ''infinitesimally small.''

title: Aircraft Inspections Reveal Problems in Tail Parts
description: Inspections of 1,100 airliners ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration revealed further problems today in tail parts that are suspected to have had a role in the crash of an Alaska Airlines plane last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, HOWARD A.
description: WHITE-Howard A.. Age 72, died February 10, 2000. Loving husband of Joan. Beloved father of Steve and Dr. Richard White and Riva White. Beloved brother of Dr. Marvin White, beloved grandfather. Funeral services will be Sunday, Feb.13, 2:30pm at Joseph N,. Garlick Funeral, Monticello, NY.

title: Lewis Indicted in Deaths In Brawl at Nightclub
description: Ray Lewis, the Baltimore Ravens' All-Pro linebacker, was indicted today on two murder charges by a Fulton County grand jury, charged with six counts in connection with the stabbing deaths outside an Atlanta nightclub 11 days ago.

title: It's Hunters, Not Gatherers Who Collect Pelts on ABC
description: ON Thursday evening, a few minutes after much of America watched her try to win $250,000 by identifying a pseudonym used by disgruntled movie directors (Alan Smithee, which she didn't guess), Judy Tigay addressed a more interesting question: Why do so few women play ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire''?

title: Remade Militant Group Learns Press Kits and Web Sites Have Their Uses
description: Within three hours of the killing of the latest Israeli soldier, smiling officials of Hezbollah, the Lebanon-based Party of God, summoned fresh cups of Turkish coffee for Western reporters, handed out a communique about the attack and released a freshly printed sheet of statistics, complete with a pie chart, listing all seven Israeli soldiers killed by Hezbollah in the last 18 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABINO, JOSEPH
description: SABINO-Joseph. Born July 19, 1921. Died February 4, 2000 after a long illness which he fought with great courage. Beloved husband and father.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil approached the nine-year high it reached last month after an industry agency said global oil inventories were at two-year lows. In New York, the March contract was up 1 cent, to $29.44 a barrel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 2 about John McCain's victory over George W. Bush in the New Hampshire Republican primary referred incorrectly in some copies to the year in which Ronald Reagan defeated George Bush there. It was 1980, not 1988.

title: Clinton Imposes Tariffs on Steel Imports That Exceed Quota
description: President Clinton imposed punitive tariffs on steel imports valued at $410 million today, answering pleas from steel makers and labor unions but raising tensions with South Korea, Brazil, Germany, Japan and other major trading partners.

title: Gorgeous and Young, Yes, but They Can Also Dance
description: The Jeune Ballet de France from Paris is a special company, intended to give novice dancers performance experience for a year after their basic ballet training.

title: Patient Settles Case Of Initials Cut in Skin
description: A woman whose doctor carved his initials into her skin after he delivered her baby by Caesarean section has settled a lawsuit against the doctor and dropped her claim against Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, the hospital said yesterday.

title: Ambulance Workers Told to Shave Beards; Union Objects
description: The Fire Department has ordered all New York City ambulance workers to shave their beards, trim their mustaches and ditch their mutton chops.

title: Finish for Woods: Watch the Birdies
description: Through nine holes today, Tiger Woods was in danger of missing the cut. After 18, he was back in contention.

title: For McCain, a New Ardor Gets Spun Into New Money
description: The candidate small-talked his way through the crowd, made some self-congratulatory remarks, cracked a few jokes -- everything about the fund-raising lunch for Senator John McCain in Manhattan yesterday had a familiar feel. Except for the people who showed up.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Candidate for Senate Tries To Bask in McCain's Glow
description: Senator John McCain's surging presidential candidacy is lending hope to another Republican maverick seeking higher office: the Essex County executive, James W. Treffinger, who is considered a dark-horse contender to succeed Senator Frank S. Lautenberg when he retires.

title: Former C.I.A. Director Helped Official Monitoring Inquiry of Him to Find a New Job
description: John M.
