Deutch, a former director of central intelligence, recommended a top C.I.A. official for a management job at Citibank even as she was monitoring an internal investigation into evidence that he had mishandled classified information, according to agency records and interviews with officials.

title: KONRAD LATTE'S LIST
description: For every Jew who was able to evade capture by the Nazis, dozens of ordinary German citizens performed everyday acts of heroism, proving that obedience wasn't the only option. A report by Peter Schneider in The Times Magazine.

title: Police Officer Dies In Station Shooting
description: A Glastonbury, Conn., police officer died at Hartford Hospital after a shooting in the town's police station yesterday afternoon.

title: White House Raises Questions About Governors Island Plan
description: A month after Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a long-awaited plan to redevelop Governors Island with parks, a conference center and museums, a senior White House official has called the proposal ''only a conceptual framework'' and urged the city and state to provide more details.

title: High Oil Prices Aren't a Bad Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICK, LIONEL A., M.D.
description: DICK-Lionel A., M.D.. Age 75, eminent dermatologist, after a long illness. A wonderful and gentle man devotedly cared for by his beloved wife, Karen. Lovingly remembered by his brother, Dr. Frederick (Marion) S. Dick, niece Barbara Rich, nephew Michael (Marjatta) Dick.

title: Wall St. Firms Reward Chiefs For Strong '99
description: Running an investment bank may not be the most lucrative job around anymore, but, judging by the compensation numbers from two of the biggest firms on Wall Street, the pay is still very good.

title: Clinton Sees No Instant Solution to Web Attack
description: Clinton Sees No Instant Solution to Web Attack

title: 2 Works Win History Prize
description: An intellectual biography of Abraham Lincoln and a study of runaway slaves are to share this year's Lincoln Prize, the most lucrative award for a work of American history.

title: Bradley and Gore Finding Ammunition in Abortion
description: With Bill Bradley questioning Vice President Al Gore's veracity over abortion, Mr. Gore is trying to shift attention away from his voting record on the subject and toward the question of who would be a better standard-bearer for the Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAR, ARLINE
description: HAAR-Arline. Age 72 of Cliffside Park and West End, NJ. Formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ, on February 11, 2000. Survived by her sons, Geoffrey and his wife, Jane; Robert and his wife, Beth; and Gary and his wife, Natalie. Predeceased by her husband George in 1998 and her son Marc in 1989. Her grandchildren Alison, Joshua, Jonathan, Jamie, Justin, Adam and Marc. She was a member of Fair Lawn Jewish Center, Jewish Community Center of Fort Lee and Temple Beth El of Oakhurst, NJ. A past President of Sisterhood at FairLawn Jewish Center. A lifetime member of Hadassah. Supported many programs at the Jewish Theological Seminary, NYC. Funded many scholarships to Camp Ramah and a major contributer to other Jewish causes and organizations. Contributions in Arline's memory may be made to the Haar Family Foundation, 849 Newark Turnpike, P.O. Box 524, Kearny, NJ 07032. Services are Sunday, 10:00 A.M. at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Hard-Fought Legacy of Catholic Power; Next Archbishop Will Inherit a History as Scrappy as New York
description: As Pope John Paul II surveys the Vatican's secret list of candidates to succeed Cardinal John O'Connor as archbishop of New York, he may wish that the walls of a little-known gallery at St. Joseph's Seminary could talk.

title: Yanks' Williams Is Now a New Yorker Full Time
description: Bearing his quiet and isolating shyness, Bernie Williams may never seem more than a visitor, no matter where he resides. He has been playing in Yankee Stadium for nearly a decade and he still often responds to fans with a tentative wave, as if he would rather not be noticed.

title: Mayor Says, 'I'm Running'
description: One could be forgiven for thinking that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has raised $12 million for his United States Senate race against Hillary Rodham Clinton, was already running.

title: 'Black Boxes' Are Fine
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOFIELD, FANNIE
description: SCHOFIELD-Fannie., 98. Beloved mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother. Devoted Aunt Fannie to 3 generations. Volunteer extraordinary within the organizations she loved-ORT and the Godmother's League. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Godmother's League, NYC.

title: Bomb Explodes Outside Wall Street Tower, Disrupting Morning Rush
description: A small explosive packed inside a military ammunition can shattered windows in two Wall Street towers early yesterday, just hours before workers began thronging to their jobs in the financial district.

title: Wrestling Free in Minnesota
description: The Reform Party that Ross Perot founded eight years ago under the banner ''United We Stand, America'' lost its highest elected official yesterday when Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota bolted what he called ''this dysfunctional national party.'' The reasons for Mr. Ventura's bailout may not be easy to decipher at this stage, but the former wrestler's departure, like his entry into the strange Perot family a few years ago, certainly offered this campaign season another theatrical moment. Standing in the chill of a St. Paul afternoon, his breath fogging over the microphones, Mr. Ventura literally fumed about his newly shed party's swing toward Patrick Buchanan as its nominee. Mr. Buchanan departed the Republican Party last year to angle for the Reform Party presidential nomination and its $13 million in federal election funds.

title: Review/Fashion; Homages to Trigere And 'Grey Gardens' Flair
description: By the time one sat down to witness a parade of perfectly lovely ball skirts whirl by at the Heidi Weisel show on Thursday afternoon, it was easy to feel as if Fashion Week had become the longest running and least funny Woody Allen movie of all time. More than a few designers played out a romance with New York -- a Bobby Short New York -- so giddy, so unquestioning, that it seemed they had turned into the kind of teenager who stared out a window from the concrete banality of Roosevelt Island, certain that all the answers lay across the water between the walls of the River House.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AGAPITO, KARIN HEIDER
description: AGAPITO-Karin Heider. 2/12/87 Dear, dear Karin, you are with me every day. I will never stop loving you. Love, Ton

title: Internet Seen Helping Drillers Pump More Oil
description: Internet Seen Helping Drillers Pump More Oil

title: When Armies Of Conquest Marched In, So Did Saints
description: The Old World may have conquered and colonized the Americas largely for commercial gain, or the extraction of gold and silver, or imperial expansion, or sheer adventure. But the grand endeavor was sanctified by the Catholic and Protestant churches as the greatest religious campaign since the Crusades.

title: Why Bite the Bullet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel on Lawyer Discipline Begins Case Against Clinton
description: After nearly a year of unexplained delays, the committee of lawyers in Arkansas that had been asked to investigate whether to discipline President Clinton by removing or suspending his law license has begun to move forward, Arkansas lawyers said today.

title: 'Nothing Is Left' in Grozny, Returning Refugees Discover
description: Russian soldiers did not capture Grozny. They obliterated it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DI SANTO, ANNA
description: DI SANTO-Anna. Devoted wife of the late Michael. Loving mother of Michael, Richard and Robert. Dear mother-in-law of Kathleen and Muriel. Also survived by seven grandchildren and one greatgrandson. Loving sister of Mary Wayne. Reposing at Leahy-McDonald, Atlantic Ave. at 111 St., Richmond Hill. Mass Mon., 10:30AM, Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church. Visiting 2-4:30 and 7-9PM

title: Beau Jack, 78, Lightweight Boxing Champion in the 1940's
description: Beau Jack, a one-time Georgia shoeshine boy who became the world lightweight champion and Madison Square Garden's biggest boxing draw of the 1940's, then toiled again at a bootblack's stand when the cheering stopped, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Miami. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, RONALD
description: ROSEMAN-Ronald. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the death of Ronald Roseman, a member of the School's faculty since 1982. A brilliant oboist, creative composer and arranger, dedicated teacher and coach, and caring human being, he was a greatly respected member of the Juilliard community. As the oboist of the New York Woodwind Quintet, in residence at the School since 1987, he and his colleagues developed one of the finest chamber music programs for woodwinds in the United States. We express our condolences to his wife Okkyu, and his entire family. Mary Rodgers Guettel, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIKER, ALEX
description: BRIKER-Alex. Formerly of Liberty, New York. Died February 8, 2000 in Dania Beach, Florida. Services Sunday, February 13.

title: GERMAN PRICES RISE
description: German consumer prices rose 0.3 percent in January, raising the annual inflation rate to its highest level in two years, as the euro's decline pushed import prices higher and oil costs surged. Prices rose 1.6 percent from a year earlier, the largest increase since December 1997, the Federal Statistics Office said. Preliminary figures released Jan. 25 had shown prices rising 0.4 percent in the month and 1.7 percent in the year. The cost of oil more than doubled last year, while the euro declined 14 percent against the dollar, raising import prices across the 11-nation euro zone.

title: Western Suitors Appear Victors in Polish Bank Bids
description: In the wake of two highly politicized takeover battles, Citigroup Inc. and Deutsche Bank are about to become key players in Poland.

title: Barkley Rejoining Team When It Needs Him Most
description: When it was his turn on the teleconference call on Thursday, Erick Barkley, in a halting voice, asked a National Collegiate Athletic Association appeals subcommittee to reinstate him. The St. John's guard told the five-member panel that he had done nothing wrong and that he was sorry to be caught in the middle of a whirlwind week that he believed had shattered his reputation.

title: Hasbro Will Make Harry Potter Cards
description: Hasbro Inc., the world's No. 2 toymaker, won a contract today from Warner Brothers to make trading cards, electronic games and candy based on the popular Harry Potter children's books after losing the coveted toy contract to its rival, Mattel Inc.

title: Corrections
description: The soccer report on the scoreboard page on Tuesday referred incorrectly to Eric Wynalda's participation in the World Cup tournament of 1998. He indeed played that year, as well as in 1990 and 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, LILLIAN
description: KRAMER-Lillian., on February 10, 2000, in Hollywood, Fla. Beloved wife of the late Rube. Loving mother of Judy Katz and her husband, Stanley, and Phyllis Gumbrecht and her husband, Gary. Cherished grandmother of Andy and Cheryl.

title: New York Can Save On Adult Day Care
description: To the Editor:

title: VODAFONE SOCCER DEAL
description: The world's richest soccer club, Manchester United P.L.C., signed a four-year sponsorship pact worth 30 million ($48 million) with Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C., which is also to provide wireless services to the club. Vodafone UK will become the main sponsor of Manchester United merchandise from June 1, and will also develop phone and wireless Internet information services for the club and its supporters. Manchester's sponsorship agreement with the Sharp Corporation ends this season after 18 years. The new contract with Vodafone is the most lucrative in British soccer, after a series of prominent companies have bid to put their company name on the shirts of the most successful team in Europe.

title: Volunteers Actions Lead Skeptics to Question McCains Online Donations
description: February 12, 2000

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro gained ground as a sharp decline in United States stock prices discouraged demand for dollars among international investors. In New York, the euro rose to 98.69 cents, from 98.62 cents on Thursday.

title: F.D.A.'s Good Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Stocks Join Steep Market Decline
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling more than 200 points as technology stocks -- which had been setting records -- joined in a decline that had been affecting most other industries for several weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISCHLER, DR. STANLEY
description: TISCHLER-Dr. Stanley. State University of New York-Health Science Center at Brooklyn, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology was saddened to hear of Dr. Stanley Tischler's death. Dr. Tischler was a clinical professor in the Department. He was a member of the faculty for a period of 23 years. He retired from his faculty position in 1996. The Department extends its heartfelt sympathy to his family.

title: Some Signs of a Conflict In the Episcopal Church
description: Last month ended on an unsettling note for the Episcopal Church's leadership, the result of an unexpected event halfway around the world that continues to reverberate through the 2.4 million-member denomination.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: After Long Delay, Russia Sets Date for Space Station Module
description: The next component of the International Space Station, the long-delayed Russian crew module, will be launched in July, NASA and the Russian Space Agency announced today.

title: A Wise Pause on Dietary Supplements
description: In a prudent turnabout, the Food and Drug Administration has decided to suspend a regulation that it issued last month that would have allowed the manufacturers of dietary supplements to assert that their products ease the symptoms of pregnancy. Faced with sharp protests from public health experts, the agency has decided to hold public meetings to review this dangerous new rule as it applies to pregnancy-related claims.

title: Hlavac Gets the Message And Shoots Down Boston
description: The Rangers have been imploring Jan Hlavac to shoot more. Apparently Hlavac got the message. Last night the 23-year-old rookie wing scored his first career hat trick.

title: INSIDE
description: For Dow Jones Average, Quickest Retreat Since '55

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARAFOLA, LOUIS S.
description: GARAFOLA-Louis S.., on February 10, 2000 age 88. Beloved husband of the late Rose (nee Marchione). Loving father of Lynn and Robert. Dear brother of Salvatore. Devoted grandfather of Daria Rose. Visiting Saturday 7-9pm & Sunday 2-4pm at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. Funeral Mass will be held Monday 9:30am at Blessed Sacrament Church, 71 St. betw. Columbus & Broadway.

title: Unwanted Pets Ditched In a Brooklyn Dog Haven
description: For dog lovers in New York City, it is tough to top the hospitality of Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: Slam Dunk for a Jump Shooter
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley, a member of the National Basketball Association Hall of Fame, yesterday began running advertisements that feature a testimonial from the basketball superstar Michael Jordan.

title: CAMERON ASHLEY GETS OFFER FROM GUARDIAN INDUSTRIES
description: Cameron Ashley Building Products Inc. said yesterday that it had received an offer of $148 million from Guardian Industries, topping a $142 million bid from a group including a New Jersey building products distributor, the Bradco Supply Corporation. The Guardian bid is $17 a share. Shares of Cameron Ashley were up $1.875 at $16.0625. Cameron Ashley, based in Dallas, distributes building products used in home improvement, repair work and in new residential construction. The Bradco-led offer of $16.25 a share was announced late on Thursday. Cameron agreed last month to be acquired for $132 million, or $15.10 a share, by a group including Citigroup.

title: Reincarnation With a Green Thumb
description: Certain performers, an elect group particularly noticeable in that endangered genre known as the musical comedy, seem to carry their own personal spotlights. Their built-in glow is so intense that it can match whatever electric wattage is thrown upon them. And no matter where one of them is actually standing on any given stage, it is de facto dead center, the place where an audience's eyes are destined to gravitate.

title: In the Soccer Stadiums of Italy, a Fight to Break Grip of Racism
description: ROME  Every time Bruno N'Gotty put his foot to the ball  maybe 25 times in the Lazio-Venezia match at the Stadio Olimpico on Thursday  a dismal bellow welled up from the North Curve, the stadium's end zone of dark rage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIGER, EILENBERG, JEANETTE
description: KLIGER - EILENBERG - Jeanette. Formerly Professor of Comparative Literature and German and Associate Dean at Brooklyn College. Devoted wife of the late Samuel Kliger. Dear sister of Sophie B. Rothstein and the late Bertram Eilenberg. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, 11 AM. Interment private.

title: In World of Hackers, Good Guys And Bad Guys Are Often a Blur
description: The computer industry has a long, respected tradition of hiring so-called tiger teams of professional hackers to attack a computer system to determine how secure it is. The idea is that only by waging a full-scale siege on a system with an authorized break-in can its true level of vulnerability be determined.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Blaming the Messenger
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On Would-Be Umpires' Test, If It's Just 85%, You're Out, Pal
description: THE SETTING -- Twenty-four people, many wearing baseball caps, filed into Room 143 of Russell Sage Junior High School last Tuesday evening. Each one handed over $25 for the right to take a 50-question examination that would determine whether he -- there were no women -- knew the rules of baseball well enough to be a high school umpire. Successful candidates, after completing a field clinic, will be eligible to work public and private school contests, earning $49 to $82 a game.

title: Miro and Murrow, D.C.'s Latest Attractions
description: VISITORS to Washington frequently arrive with a mental itinerary taking them from the lofty precincts of Capitol Hill and the White House to the greensward of the Mall with its museums, monuments and memorials. And visit them all one must, for they provide an encyclopedic view of America's culture and historic legacy.

title: Something's Lost and Something's Gained
description: FEW contemporary voices have aged more shockingly than Joni Mitchell's. The craggy alto on ''Both Sides Now,'' her intermittently magnificent new album of standards (including two of her best-loved original songs), is so changed from the sweetly yodeling folk soprano of her earliest albums that it hardly seems possible the two sounds could have come from the same body.

title: Dubbing Made Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Line Up to Back Primary Day Favorites
description: WHILE Hillary Rodham Clinton's senatorial campaign has been drawing the political spotlight in the county, supporters for all the major candidates for president -- as well as for a few minor ones -- are quietly organizing their charge to March 7, Primary Day in New York State.

title: Dangerous Plans for Colombia
description: Colombia is Latin America's most complex and troubled country. Its two overwhelming problems -- a booming trade in cocaine and heroin, and a vicious, nearly 40-year-old civil war -- are intertwined and getting worse. Increasingly they threaten not just Colombia, but neighboring countries as well, including Venezuela, one of the largest suppliers of oil to the United States.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Female Athletes Have Dual Burden
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Susan Piper, Adam Winstanley
description: Susan Wood Piper, the daughter of Ruth and Thomas Piper of Concord, Mass., was married there yesterday to Adam David Winstanley, a son of Barbara and David Winstanley, also of Concord. The Rev. Dr. John Lombard performed the ceremony at the Trinitarian Congregational Church.

title: Telling a 13-Billion-Year Story With the Tools of the Moment
description: RALPH APPELBAUM, the exhibition designer, strides confidently down the Cosmic Pathway, covering about 75 million years of cosmic evolution with each step. The 360-foot ramp wraps one and a half times around the Hayden Sphere. Along it hang astronomical images of the 13 billion-year history of the universe. Toward the bottom of the ramp, the age of the dinosaurs is played out in about two feet, and the time of man on Earth is the width of a hair.

title: What No School Can Do
description: I taught public school in the South Bronx in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Traub put his finger on a problem that was painfully obvious to me: children were entering school without being intellectually prepared to learn. Children need stimulation. They need to be put on a parent's lap and read to; they need to be exposed to books, to museums, to things that spark curiosity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLLER, JOSEPH
description: ZOLLER-Joseph. L The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Zoller, associated with The Times from 1967.

title: Congo's War Overshadows Tribal Fight
description: Another ethnic war is erupting in central Africa, this time a tribal conflict in Congo fought mostly with machetes and barbed arrows that nurses in a hospital near here collect in a little white box. Some of the barbs are still covered with blood and flesh.

title: Jill Wolinsky, Jeffrey Goldberg
description: Jill Sarah Wolinsky, the daughter of Rosalie and Alan Wolinsky of Woodbury, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Alan Goldberg, the son of Norman Goldberg of Plano, Tex., and the late Irene Neuman Goldberg. Rabbi Brooks Susman performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: Arrows of Desire
description: THE DRESS LODGER

title: THEATER; A Composer Unlocks The Lyricist Within, Helped by a Hot Poem
description: FROM the ball in ''My Fair Lady'' to the bar in ''Miss Saigon,'' musicals are so associated with larger-than-life public emotions that it is easy to forget that their creative roots lie in more private feelings. Perhaps the most powerful of them occurs when a book writer, composer or lyricist finds a show's source material and, like Keats looking into Chapman's Homer, becomes a ''watcher of the skies/ When a new planet swims into his ken.''

title: Tom Landry Dies; Coached Cowboys
description: Tom Landry, the head coach who led the Dallas Cowboys to five Super Bowls as the franchise became known as America's Team, died yesterday in Dallas. He was 75.

title: Two Shows Sample Contemporary Art
description: ONE of the goals of arts councils, art centers and artists' guilds is to increase cultural opportunities on a grass-roots level. Many of those institutions, which are, either in part or wholly, supported by an active artist membership, give curators a chance to obtain a sampling of the contemporary art being created within each organization's geographical area.

title: Money and Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: The White Plains Watch Was Omitted in Article
description: Your interesting survey of local newspapers left out a feisty newcomer, the monthly White Plains Watch. This carefully researched, well-written paper concentrates on White Plains, providing in-depth coverage of issues that are barely mentioned elsewhere, such as the ongoing hassle over the proposed Tischman Speyer development on the old Macy's site. The paper is distributed free but asks for voluntary subscriptions at $25 a year.

title: Your Home; A Condo Or Co-op? Read On
description: PEOPLE thinking about buying an apartment usually know that there are two kinds available -- condominiums and co-ops -- and that the main difference is that the owner of a condominium owns real estate while the owner of a co-op owns shares in a corporation.

title: On Harassment Of Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column on Jan. 23 about a takeover battle involving Societe du Louvre, the company that controls Taittinger Champagne, misidentified a business development client of Barbara de Portago, who attended a dinner given by the Societe's chairman. Since July 1, 1999, Ms. de Portago has represented Givenchy Haute Couture, not Christian Dior.

title: Brookhaven Lab's Old Reactor Is Finally Being Dismantled
description: STANDING atop the green-carpeted core of the Brookhaven National Laboratory's graphite research reactor, it is chilling to think of the photographs, taken from this same area in 1951, showing a sedated woman, gravely ill with a malignant brain tumor, being lowered into the reactor so doctors could fire a beam of neutrons into her head.

title: An Innocent's Exuberant Vision Of Corruption
description: IN the 80's, presented with merger mania and junk-bond madness, Hollywood produced movies like the polished ''Wall Street'' and the glossy ''Working Girl,'' films about the nexus of big money and big morality. Now the current Money Moment, this dot-com expansion, or bubble, or souffle, or whatever it turns out to be, has its first opus: ''Boiler Room.''

title: Q and A
description: Day Trips From Heathrow

title: Cynthia Fitzgerald, Stephen Schluter
description: Cynthia Jolan Fitzgerald, the daughter of Patricia and Edward Fitzgerald of Fairfield, Conn., was married last evening to Stephen Albright Schluter, a son of the Rev. Nancy H. Schluter and State Senator William E. Schluter of Pennington, N.J.

title: Boola, Boola, E-Commerce Comes to The Quad
description: WE always thought our new competition was going to be 'Microsoft University,' '' the president of an elite eastern university ruefully remarked to a visitor over dinner recently. ''We were wrong. Our competition is our own faculty.''

title: Wall Street After Dark; Extended Hours Hold Promise for Markets, Pitfalls for Investors
description: A FEW weeks ago, I took the plunge into the after-hours stock market, trying to buy 100 shares of the Superior National Insurance Group.

title: Rocker No Exception
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Pelham Weekly Offers Local News Too
description: As a 28-year resident of Pelham, I believe your reporter missed a key point in the article on local newspapers that appeared on Feb. 6 [''From Traditional to Niche, Newspapers Keep Piling Up''].

title: More Complaints About Negative Phone Calls
description: As John McCain's campaign bus rolled up to a tent this morning for a town hall meeting, Ed Cheek was waiting. And he had a tale about the phone call he received at home two mornings ago.

title: Ads Deface a Landmark District, Residents Say
description: Last summer, when the city created the NoHo Historic District, many preservationists and residents thought they had won a victory against outdoor advertising. But such commercial signs continue to go up in the protected zone.

title: Diana Rich, John Kriz
description: Diana Jeanne Rich and John Miroslav Kriz were married yesterday by the Rev. Laurie J. Ferguson, a Presbyterian minister, at the Nyack Seaport Center in Nyack, N.Y.

title: The Definitive Hipster
description: LAST WORDS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, JOSEPH, DR.
description: MANDELBAUM-Joseph, Dr. Of Brooklyn, N.Y., died peacefully at home at age 87. After graduating from Columbia College in 1931 and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1935, he conducted research on dark adaptation and subsequently went into the private practice of ophthalmology. He was Medical Director of the HIP Flatbush Medical Group and also was a Founding Executive of the League for Emotionally Disturbed Children. Despite the demands of his busy professional life, he found time for world travel and photography. Born November 7, 1912, he was the son of Rose Breitman and Meyer Mandelbaum. He was married for 59 years to the late Hattie Golubow and is survived by their children Paul, Jill and Joel and their grandchildren Hanna and Max. The family will receive friends at his Brooklyn home Sunday afternoon February 13th. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date.

title: Instead of a Pink Slip, Pure Gold
description: Klaus Esser may be losing the title of chief executive and the independence of his company, Mannesmann A.G, but his paycheck won't be like that of some pink-slipped employee. Mr. Esser, who gave in to Vodafone Airtouch's $183 billion hostile offer a week ago, stands to earn $29 million in salary and bonuses this year. He is expected to leave the company this summer.

title: A Charge of Corruption
description: Sick, reviled and in seclusion, former President Suharto of Indonesia faces a legal threat from the government, which said it would charge him for corruption in the amassing of illegal wealth. The government's move seemed part of a serious effort to come to terms with the abuses of the past. SETH MYDANS

title: Political Briefing; In-Fighting in G.O.P. For House Seat
description: The 10th Congressional District of Illinois, along Lake Michigan's wealthy North Shore, is considered a Republican-leaning district. But going into this fall's elections, it is also an ''open'' district, up for grabs because of the retirement of Representative John Edward Porter, a Republican first elected 20 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRENN, MARY A.
description: WRENN-Mary A. Former Vice President and Managing Director of Merril Lynch, died Thursday, February 10, 2000 in her home in Easton, CT following a long illness. She was 74 years old. Ms. Wrenn was a longtime resident of Greenwich, CT and New York City, before moving to Easton 5 years ago. Born in Danbury, CT, Ms. Wrenn was the daughter of the late Delia Kelley Wrenn and Andrew Wrenn. She was an accomplished businesswoman who was said to have forged new paths for women in the male-dominated investment banking business. She was elected the first woman Vice President of any worldwide investment firm in 1967, and the first woman Managing Director of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in 1978. Ms. Wrenn was a magna cum laude graduate of Albertus Magnus College, New Haven, CT, and received an Honorary Doctor of Law degree from that college in 1977. She also held graduate degrees in economics and banking and finance from New York University. Ms. Wrenn was predeceased by her brother William A. Wrenn, and her two sisters Joan D. Wrenn and Elizabeth Wrenn Richter. She is survived by four nieces Catherine Wrenn Gombos of Easton, CT, Patricia Wrenn Murphy of Redding, CT, Elizabeth Wrenn Adams of Plano, TX, and Mary Wrenn Cordeiro of Bristol, RI; two nephews Kevin P. Wrenn of Boston, MA, Christopher W. Wrenn of Monroe, CT and her sister-in-law, Lillian T. Wrenn of Monroe, CT. She also leaves behind 12 great nephews and nieces. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Tuesday, February 15, 2000 at 10 AM at Notre Dame of Easton Church, Morehouse Road, Easton, CT. Interment will be at St. Peter's Cemetery, Danbury, CT. Friends may call on Monday, February 14, 2000 from 3-5 PM and from 7-9 PM at the LeskoMiner Funeral Home, 155 Main St. (Route 25), Monroe, CT.

title: In Texas, Turtle's Friends Are Split Over Shrimping
description: Despite stepped-up efforts to protect them, sea turtles keep washing up on Texas beaches, and environmentalists are calling for new limits on the state's $600 million-a-year shrimping industry that they believe will solve the problem.

title: Cashing In Gets Tougher at Tyco
description: Late last year, after questions about his company's accounting practices and a big stock drop, L. Dennis Kozlowski, the head of Tyco International, announced that Tyco would have to hit impressive financial targets for executives to exercise future stock options.

title: Travel Advisory; A Busy Month for Black History
description: Throughout February, cities across the United States are acknowledging Black History Month with exhibitions, performances and other events.

title: Mixing the Personal And the Professional
description: To the Editor:

title: That's Alan, With an A, The Guy Who Sets Rates
description: As interest rates creep up, it is only natural for investors to keep a sharp eye on Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.

title: A Likely Story!
description: A VAST CONSPIRACY

title: SOAPBOX; Why BID's Are Bad Business
description: BUSINESS IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS, or BID's, are celebrated as major components of New York City's renaissance. Who can object when landlords and their commercial tenants voluntarily pool resources to keep their neighborhoods clean? If only it were so.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-13-00: How It Works; Starved for Attention
description: The Forced Advertising MarchWhen sites first started offering sweepstakes and lotteries just to attract visitors, the concept seemed almost like a gag -- like paying people money to enter a store. But the offers were serious, and so far, they seem to be working: iWon.com, which is backed by CBS, attracted three million new visitors with everything from Quick-Draw Poker and Three-Eyed Bingo to $10,000 daily drawings and monthly $1 million jackpots. FreeLotto.com, which has awarded two $1 million prizes since last summer and expects to mail out 240,000 smaller checks this month, has watched its new traffic jump from 400,000 last September to two million by December. More important, because visitors to FreeLotto must click through a series of ads before qualifying for any prizes, the site has won raves from advertisers, like the stationery superstore OurBeginning.com. The drawback: there's no guarantee that all those people who visit the sites because of the sweepstakes have any intention of spending money there.

title: Stern Says Rockets Could Leave Houston
description: In his nonthreatening but persuasive way, David Stern laid down an ultimatum tonight. Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner, all but begged the city of Houston to help finance a new arena for the Rockets by 2003, or else.

title: Michigan Students Protest Campus Club's Indian Relics
description: A group of minority student protesters occupying the quarters of a prestigious student club at the University of Michigan here has forced a debate that somewhat mirrors the nation's struggle to come to terms with its history of racism.

title: Baseball Announcer Who Broke Barriers
description: IT was opening day at Yankee Stadium last season. The full-house crowd was on its feet cheering. Yogi Berra, fired by George Steinbrenner 16 games into the 1985 season and so bitter he had vowed never to return while Steinbrenner owned the team, was walking onto the field to throw out the first pitch.

title: Fauxhemian Rhapsody
description: Rob Walker's depiction of Manhattan's nouveau hipsters is dead-on accurate (The Way We Live Now, Jan. 23). It does, however, lead to the question, What's a Gen-X'er to do? We are the children of the greatest Bohemian sellouts of all time, the baby boomers. So it makes sense that my generation would have a split affinity for corporate trappings and earthy cachet.

title: Royal Anthem Wins
description: Royal Anthem, bred in Kentucky but raced mainly in Europe, returned to the United States yesterday and showed why he is widely regarded as one of the world's classiest horses when he won the Gulfstream Park Breeders' Cup Handicap in Hallandale, Fla., by three lengths.

title: U.S. Investigators Examine Maintenance at Alaska Air
description: Whatever brought down Alaska Airlines Flight 261 is only half of the airline's problem. The other half is in its maintenance hangar here, where workers and supervisors sign their initials to thousands of work orders as they complete them.

title: All-Star Who Never Was Sees Life From Jail
description: ''Hook was the greatest playground player ever from Oakland. He could jump over cars and dunk. He was better than all of us. He could have been one of the best players in the N.B.A. It was just one of them things. He took one route and we took another route.'' -- Gary Payton, All-Star guard

title: Summer Jobs
description: The county is now accepting summer employment applications for parks and pool attendants, lifeguards, laborers, office workers and cashiers, ride operators and ticket takers at Playland Park in Rye.

title: In Central Africa, Signs of Hope and Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: BackTalk; A Besieged and Beloved Guru's Worthwhile Lessons
description: ''If they think I'm bad,'' Jack Scott liked to say, ''they ought to see what's going to come after me. The next reformers may be anarchists and much more vicious than I am.''

title: What No School Can Do
description: James Traub's exploration of why even good schools can't help children overcome the disadvantages of inner-city poverty and chaos (Jan. 16) is also a powerful argument for expanding residential schools for children from abusive or neglectful homes and violent neighborhoods. Residential education is not a cheap alternative -- approximately $25,000 per year per student, including school, food, clothing, shelter and after-school activities. But as Traub writes, ''ghetto children need an enveloping environment that is secure and nourishing, as the streets and often the home itself are not.''

title: Sites of Struggle Emerge From Obscurity
description: Places of asylum, suffering and hope, they are markers of black history in the city. Some are well known and well documented, like Weeksville, a Brooklyn neighborhood settled by blacks after New York abolished slavery in 1827, and Sandy Ground, an area in southwestern Staten Island settled by free blacks in the 1830's. But most are not preserved, and no signs speak to the history of these corners, parks and buildings.

title: A Ban for a Gay Club
description: A high school gay tolerance group in the conservative community of Orange, Calif., held its first meeting in school Wednesday over the objections of the school district, which argues that the club should be banned because its issues of sexuality are inappropriate. On Thursday, school officials banned noncurricular clubs in elementary and middle schools.

title: French Sandwich to Make for a Valentine
description: IF you care that tomorrow is Valentine's Day and have planned dinner at home, the menu has probably been decided, the buying done and some, if not all, the preparation under way or completed. But how about a last-minute suggestion?

title: Into the Sunset Ride An Era's Heroes
description: THOSE who grew up on television and movie westerns may find a kind of frontier order in the passing of four of the genre's iconic actors as the century closed.

title: A Bloated Tax Cut for Marriage
description: The House passed a Republican-sponsored bill last week that would give a big tax cut to all married couples -- even those who are benefiting from the existing tax code and not suffering at all from the so-called ''marriage penalty.'' The G.O.P. points to married couples who, under the current code, pay more in tax than they would as two unrelated individuals. That penalty, say the Republicans, amounts to an unconscionable attack on marriage.

title: Manhattan Transfer
description: If William Weld continues to eat a lunch of a falafel or a gyro or a hot dog ''almost every day,'' he may well have difficulty running for governor of New York in the future. Heart disease or diverticulitis may catch up with him. I enjoy his wit too much for that to happen.

title: Galway to Appear at Purchase
description: JAMES GALWAY, the most often recorded and, by most appraisals, the best flute player in the world today, has never been content to stay with the tried and true.

title: Fattening Up a World Body
description: Kofi Annan might think he runs the United Nations, but no, at the moment, it is George Lang, the New York restaurateur (Cafe des Artistes) and entrepreneur. At the least, Mr. Lang is in charge of the delegates' dining room.

title: City Highways Aren't Built For Sport Utilities
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, RALPH S.
description: BAER-Ralph S. Died at home in Yonkers, NY, on February 11th, 2000, at the age of 85. Beloved husband of Dorothy nee Griesheimer. Devoted father of Denise Resnik, grandfather of Andrew and James Resnik, and brother of Lisa Messinger. He was an active volunteer for the New York Public Library. The family will receive friends at his home. His love and grace will be long remembered.

title: Whose Prosperity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERSCHLAG, HELEN
description: HAMMERSCHLAG-Helen. On February 11th, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Frederick. Loving mother of Mark and Lynne. Dear sister of Ethel Zuckerman and Renae Weiner. Adoring grandmother of Jessica, Jack, Alexander and Nicholas. Service Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: State Looks Inward as Bias Crimes Continue
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: The Victor Is a Victim In Liberty's Triumph
description: IN the nearly two years since Indonesia's strongman, Suharto, stepped down in May 1998, it is the press that has been the most free, and the most tumultuous, of Indonesia's institutions. It has been the fundamental underpinning for the continuing move toward a democratic society.

title: Pressure Is on the New Zealand Crew
description: The opportunity was just too tempting to pass up.

title: Tours of Japan
description: To the Editor: The Q & A column Nov. 28 mentioned Esprit Travel of Santa Monica, Calif., as offering unusual tours of Japan.

title: New Guys on the Block: Getting a Date With a Gavel
description: BACHELOR NO. 1, Bryan Orjuela, 40, a stockbroker from Long Beach, danced down the runway, swiveling his hips provocatively, tossing out roses to the squealing throng.

title: Baby Seats
description: To the Editor: Melissa Balmain's essay ''And Baby Makes Friends'' (Jan. 9) brought back memories of traveling with my two sons when they were young 15 years ago. On one business trip, I was on the New York-Washington shuttle with my sons, who were then 2 years old and 3 months old. I had called ahead and was assured by the airline that my older son could sit in a car seat buckled into the airline seat. So I boarded with the car seat, folding stroller and various other baby necessities.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Campaign Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Doug Levin, 38

title: A Singer Who Is Also a Scholar
description: THE baritone Thomas Hampson would never call himself a musicologist. He lacks the academic training and has too much respect for the field to claim a place in it.

title: Aquamarines Are Forever
description: IT used to be that if you worked in an office in Manhattan, once or twice a month a different young woman would come running through the cubicles showing off her new engagement ring -- a solitaire diamond flashing like an S O S signal. While diamond engagement rings are still popular, many women are now wearing ones with purple amethysts, red rubies, emeralds and, especially, aquamarines that come from flea markets, stylish relatives, auctions and antique stores.

title: I.R.S. IS BOLSTERING EFFORTS  TO  CURB CHEATING ON TAXES
description: Warning that continuing cuts at the Internal Revenue Service threaten the nation's tax system, the Clinton administration is proposing more money to find cheaters and make them pay up. And the agency's top official has begun emphasizing that catching cheaters is as important as helping honest taxpayers.

title: A Wasteland Of One's Own
description: The tv ads for IVillage.com, one of the rising stars in the ever-expanding galaxy of women's Web sites, suggests that, for the modern woman, logging on to the Internet provides all the comfort Mom found in the long hot bath combined with the fun and fellowship of an evening out with the girls. The animation of the actresses playing ordinary women intensely engaged with their computers implies that the after-hours ''cybervisit'' is the perfect antidote to an exhausting day of work or child care, or both. It promises relaxation and distraction, solitude and community, the I and the Village, all during a few precious moments stolen -- just for us! -- from our families and jobs.

title: Sports of The Times; Payton Returns Home With All-Star Student
description: JASON KIDD and Gary Payton sat across the room from each other Friday afternoon as the news media swarmed into a huge ballroom for the ritual of All-Star media day. Kidd and Payton were separated by only a few feet, though the journey they have traveled, from childhood to adulthood, from Oakland to the National Basketball Association to this lofty All-Star perch has been a phenomenal mixture of coincidence and hard work.

title: The Hard Reality of Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Stiffening Resistance to a Planned Megamarket
description: For weeks, community groups and elected officials in Clinton say, they have not been adequately informed about Costco's plan to build what would be Manhattan's largest supermarket.

title: Gone to Seed
description: Reap

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Excursion; Camping With the Incredible Hulk
description: OR all the cargo capacity of the 2000 Ford Excursion, it enters the market carrying almost more baggage than it can handle. Ford's introduction last year of its uber-utility provoked protests and galvanized a coalition of sport utility haters -- from environmentalists to intimidated drivers of small cars -- for whom the 7,000-pound Excursion was a big, fat bete noire.

title: Time, and Time Again, as Science and as Art
description: THE British and French have famously different perceptions of time: the British view French tardiness as a serious character flaw, the French mock British punctuality as simple lack of imagination. But this is just the anecdotal side of things. Time also reflects deeper cultural differences between the two. Or so it would appear from the way in which London and Paris have each addressed large millennium exhibitions dedicated to the subject of time.

title: United States Defeats Haiti
description: The Gold Cup, a biennial event that features the United States men's soccer team against the best from Central and Latin America, is a sizable notch below the World Cup in prestige. Yet it is enough of a barometer of the United States team's progress under Coach Bruce Arena that he brought in two of his best players from overseas to continue the modest momentum established by a late January victory over Chile.

title: Review Urged Before Sale Of School Board Building
description: Resisting Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's call to sell the Board of Education's labyrinthine headquarters posthaste, the board president said yesterday that he first wanted a ''top to bottom review'' of all the board's administrative buildings and central staff.

title: Practical Traveler; In Winter, Parks Offer Quiet Fun
description: SOME national parks are strictly warm-weather friends. By early September, the Going to the Sun Road across Glacier National Park is dicey: You can get a certain distance and find the road shut because at those altitudes, it's already snowing on a perilous route. And on the Blue Ridge Parkway in the Great Smokies, drives in early spring in search of an ideal hike can also be frustrating because runoff congeals into sheets of ice, and barriers are up at tunnel entrances and along cliffs.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Battle Cries and Lullabies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, DOROTHY
description: MOSS-Dorothy. On February 11, 2000. Beloved wife of Milton. Loving mother of Clifford Janoff. Adoring grandmother of Sarah Janoff. Devoted aunt of Corinne and Harold Simkin, Chester and Guy Moss and Roger and Burton Fox and families. Dear sister-inlaw of Nanette Fox and Tobias Moss. Service Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINSLEY, ROSE DANIELS
description: PINSLEY-Rose Daniels. Died January 4. Social worker, arts activist, grandmother of Adam Levin, aunt of Les Daniels. Info: 516-747-6144.

title: Teenage Driving at Issue
description: IT is the moment 16-year-olds anticipate and their parents dread: getting a driver's license.

title: Rutgers Sets Pace, But UConn Wins Game
description: As the buzzer sounded today at the Louis Brown Athletic Center, the scoreboard clearly showed the University of Connecticut women's basketball team earning a 49-45 victory. If you did not believe that, all you had to do was watch the Scarlet Knights players gathering by their bench, heads bowed in disappointment and exhaustion, while the Huskies danced across the floor to the locker room.

title: OPINION; The Maze of County Assessments
description: THE recent decision by a federal court dismissing a case that alleged discriminatory residential tax assessment in Nassau County has nothing to do with the merits of the accusation and everything to do with the complex legal question of jurisdiction.

title: Europe Looks for Reassurance as U.S. Pursues a Missile Shield
description: European allies have expressed increasing concerns about the Clinton administration's plans to negotiate with Russia to allow deployment of a missile shield, and about how much the Europeans are being consulted in the matter.

title: For a Caretaker, the Gift of Extra Help
description: Helen Palmieri was at the dinner table, but her special dishes, homemade Italian bread, sausage and stuffed celery, were missing.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: With Violin in Hand, Mutter Takes a Stand
description: ANNE-SOPHIE MUTTER finds her way along a musical tightrope, balancing her developing interest in new music with program approaches that don't ignore audience appeal. The act she has got together and taken on the road is a survey of 20th-century violin works -- glamorous orchestral events with difficult concertos, and more seasoned, benign pieces assigned to solo recitals.

title: Mae West, Still There for Us to Come Up and See
description: IMAGINE, if you can, the spectacle of Mae West playing Norma Desmond in ''Sunset Boulevard.''

title: Marianne Hodson, Robert Stevenish II
description: Marianne Elizabeth Hodson and Robert John Stevenish II were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Park Bodie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SYLVIA HARRIS
description: BERNSTEIN-Sylvia Harris. On January 27, in Mexico, at 92. NYC advertising executive-one of the first women to hold such position. Widow of the writer Hillel Bernstein; mother of Mary Bernstein and grandmother of Jessica Bernstein-Wax, both of San Francisco; sister of the late Jed Harris, the late Mildred Harris, Florence Levine of Los Angeles, and Saul Howitt of New York. She will be greatly missed.

title: Executives Make Trade With China a Moral Issue
description: When a group of Florida businessmen paid a visit one recent afternoon to Corrine Brown, their Congresswoman, they put her on notice that they consider trading with China a moral crusade.

title: Shakespeare in Less Than 10 Minutes
description: SILENT SHAKESPEARE

title: Seton Hall (18-4) Shows It's Serious About N.C.A.A. Bid
description: Seton Hall discovered tonight that it can be businesslike, too. The Pirates did not have an undefeated team to upset in its loud arena, as they did last Monday at Syracuse. They did not have to squeak by their intrastate rival in a roller coaster of a game, as they did at Rutgers last Wednesday.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-13-00: On Language; Broadband
description: His necktie was defiantly ripped away. His old-fashioned mustache was shaved off. All but rocking on the soles of his feet and snapping his fingers to illustrate his with-it-ness, the new boss of AOL Time Warner Inc. announced to the world, ''I am a broadband person.''

title: BUSINESS; In Search of Profit, Outside the Power Grid
description: THERE haven't been any blockbuster deals to attract much attention.

title: BASEBALL: Heavy Burdens Behind the Plate; Refueled Piazza Plans to Go Distance for Mets
description: Mike Piazza's last hit of 1999 was a two-run seventh-inning homer in Atlanta that tied the score in the final game of the National League Championship Series. It was heroic, an indication to the Mets' manager, Bobby Valentine, that his tattered catcher belonged to that elite company of athletes who can overcome pain when it matters most.

title: Winding Down, In Any Language
description: British executives are far more likely than other Western European executives to raise a glass after a stressful day at work, according to a new survey, while Italian executives are most likely to burn off stress with after-work exercise.

title: SHORE DEVELOPMENT PLAN
description: The state's blueprint for development at the shore took effect last week, having survived a state Senate resolution to kill the building restrictions and protests by some environmental groups that the rules were too lax. Both sides said they would renew the fight over the regulations, which were written by the state Department of Environmental Protection and forged from years of negotiations. Governor Whitman, considering the revised regulations to be part of her ''smart growth'' legacy, had met with opponents to defend them. Last week she said they would ''protect our beaches, control sprawl and direct development to those areas best suited for growth.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE LETTERS OF WILKIE COLLINS Volume 1: 1838-1865. Volume 2: 1866-1889. Edited by William Baker and William M. Clarke. St. Martin's, $55 each.

title: Manhattan Transfer
description: Given the jovial flavor of Daniel B. Schneider's pithy ''Questions for William Weld'' (The Way We Live Now, Jan. 23), the former Massachusetts governor may have been joking when he called graffiti a ''humanizing force.'' Graffiti, and its unwelcome cousin, scratchiti, are expensive blights that often accompany other criminal activities, particularly drug dealing.

title: Beyond 'Eeeww!': A World of Insects and Spiders
description: 'Millennium Bug'

title: Bookend; The Man Who Knew Shakespeare
description: Not only did Ben Jonson know Shakespeare, he said he loved him. ''I loved the man and do honour his memory (this side idolatry) as much as any,'' he wrote in 1619, three years after Shakespeare's death. He also falsely criticized several plays, especially ''Julius Caesar.'' Why? The obvious answer is envy, and resentment of the only poet and playwright he knew to be his superior. Yet in February 1616 -- with Shakespeare still living! -- King James had been persuaded to honor Jonson as England's poet laureate.

title: THEATER; Already Reworking the Classics of Modern Realism
description: ONE of the most famous scenes in modern drama is when Stanley Kowalski clears the table at Blanche DuBois's birthday party in Tennessee Williams's ''Streetcar Named Desire.'' Who can forget Stanley hurling his plate, cup and saucer to the floor? ''That's how I'll clear the table!'' the brute roars. But in Ivo van Hove's 1999 New York Theater Workshop production, Stanley slowly rose from his chair (there was no table, no food, no cake), calmly walked upstage to where a props person had placed a pile of plates, and methodically smashed them all, one after the other. It was strong theater but it wasn't ''real'' -- and it was not what Williams had in mind.

title: Herding Cats, Lassoing Viewers
description: People in the technology industry have a saying for an impossible task: ''It's like herding cats.''

title: With Other Alternatives, Why Cut Bus Subsidy?
description: Why does County Executive Thomas Gulotta [''Missing the Bus,'' Jan. 30] propose to cut the subsidy for buses, a necessity upon which the poorer county residents rely, when he doesn't mind the subsidies the county gives to golf courses, elegant parks in upper-income neighborhoods and county employees, like himself, in the guise of inflated salaries and county cars and phones?

title: Completing Sterling Forest
description: Two thoughts came to mind when Gov. George Pataki announced last week that nearly all the money had been found to complete the purchase of Sterling Forest, some 19,000 acres of unspoiled woodlands, streams and lakes 40 miles northwest of New York City that were very nearly lost to residential and commercial development. One was that the citizens who supported the cause of Sterling Forest deserve great credit for sticking with an endlessly frustrating project over the years. The second was that there must be an easier way of doing business. This saga would have been concluded much more expeditiously had Congress honored a promise made back in the Johnson administration to provide a reliable annual stream of money for open space acquisition.

title: Getting a Day in Court
description: Victims of gay-bashing, wife-beating and other crimes based on gender or sexual orientation could have an easier time in court if the Illinois General Assembly approves a bill introduced in the House of Representatives that would enable them to sue any person, company or organization responsible for the attack.

title: POSTINGS: German Investments in Next 3 Years; $6 Billion to Buy U.S. Properties
description: Germans are expected to invest $4 billion to $6 billion in American real estate over the next three years, according to a survey of 60 German investment groups by Jones Lang LaSalle, a real estate services and management company. Assuming that the equity investments would be leveraged by mortgages of 50 to 60 percent of the total value of a property, the company estimated, that could mean that the investors could acquire $10 billion to $15 billion in property by the end of 2003.

title: Circling, High Above the Traffic in Stamford
description: WHILE we were seated in Vuli, a restaurant on the 17th floor of the Stamford Marriott, and watching the room revolve almost imperceptibly, we were reminded of Calvin Trillin's comment that he never eats ''in a restaurant that's over a hundred feet off the ground and won't stand still.''

title: Zoning Fight: Do Big Macs Have 'Ambiance'?
description: LOOKING out at the boarded-up former restaurant next to his own Dock Side Restaurant a block from the Port Jefferson ferry, George Wallis lamented, ''It looks like the South Bronx over here.''

title: Carving Up the Desert
description: EMPIRES OF THE SAND

title: Carefully Casual
description: AFTER a few visits to the Freelance Cafe and Wine Bar, you begin to realize that what seems simply casual is in fact meticulously orchestrated. The Freelance Cafe, which started in 1989, is part of Xaviar's restaurant group, a no-reservations, no-dress-code contrast to two fine-dining establishments named Xaviar's (one next door and the other in a country club in Garrison, N.Y., offering weekend wine dinners) plus an enormous chophouse called Restaurant X in Congers, N.Y.

title: Fantasy on a Smaller Scale
description: In ''Pumpkin Puke,'' the latest Super 8 short by James D. Barfield, an evil jack o'lantern spews a small creature who announces, in rhyme, that he intends to kill two men sitting on a nearby porch. Later, the creature lays crushed under a book and watches while one man eats pumpkin pie.

title: Commercial Property/Verona, N.J.; Onetime Gristmill Becomes Offices and a Showroom
description: THE first thing a visitor to the Behrle Group's offices here notices is wood, lots of unpainted, exposed wood. There are tan horizontal timbers bolted to the darker wooden columns that support the interior of the building. The roof is supported by more massive wooden beams, all visible from the second floor.

title: An Image Left Twisting in the Wind
description: IT is a photograph washed in sepia tones that lend its scene -- the 1930 lynching of Tommy Shipp and Abe Smith and an approving white mob -- an otherworldliness. Perhaps it was my father who first showed it to me. Yet, growing up black in Kentucky, with its not-so-distant past of lynching and other violent expressions of racism, I knew that this picture depicted a hatred that was embedded in my country. This lynching occurred in Marion, Ind., 24 years before I was born, but that gave me little comfort as a boy.

title: From K-Cars to E-Business, Iacocca Generates Traffic
description: Lee A. Iacocca stresses that, in deciding to become a board member and pitchman for the Online Asset Exchange, a business-to-business Web site, he wasn't about to join just any e-business. ''I have been getting about one offer a week,'' he said last week. ''Everybody has a concept out there. But these people are just so damn good, so I let them use my mug.''

title: What's Doing In; Cape Town
description: Cape Town is always popular around December and January, which means that the next couple of months are in some ways the best time to visit. The weather is still warm but the crowds have thinned out a bit, and the prices have come down, too, at least from the mad levels of the millennium.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Campaign Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: The Biology of Doom'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bigger Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend
description: ''A card and some flowers? That's so 1999.''

title: Willa Bernstein, Daniel Braz
description: Willa Jane Bernstein and Daniel William Braz were married last evening at Oheka, the Otto Herman Kahn mansion in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Allen Block officiated with the Rev. Salvatore Umana, a priest of the Federation of Christian Ministries.

title: A Gift for Your Boss
description: Gristina's 1997 cabernet franc, an ambitious and promising red, is still very much a work in progress. Its near-opaque ruby color is a clue to its heft, its fleshiness.

title: How Does It Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Safety
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has formed a Task Force on Campus Fire Safety to protect students at public and private colleges and universities in the state. The group will develop a campus fire safety plan that could include changes in state laws, regulations and policies covering fire safety in college dormitories and residence halls.

title: OUT THERE/Auckland, New Zealand; Hey, Sailor, Looking Good
description: ALONG the docks of this sailing-obsessed city, there is a brand name as deeply coveted as it is on the stiletto-trod avenues of Manhattan or Milan. Known far and wide for its image of extreme urban chic, exemplified by a black nylon backpack, that brand is Prada.

title: Weighing the Value of Corporate Largess
description: AT a time when the traditional bonds between employees and companies are loosening and a growing share of the economy's work is done by freelance, part-time and temporary workers, the Ford Motor Company took a giant step in the other direction when it announced that it would offer each of its 350,000 employees a computer, printer and unlimited Internet access for $5 a month. Delta Air Lines followed with a similar though less heavily subsidized plan for its 80,000 workers.

title: Foreign Man
description: LOST IN THE FUNHOUSE

title: Eustace Tilley, Call Home
description: ABOUT TOWN

title: In the Region/Long Island; Southampton's Moratorium Proposal Roils Builders
description: AFTER five years of working to meet all the subdivision requirements by the Town of Southampton for the development of a 28-acre parcel on Mecox Road in the hamlet of Water Mill, Jed Schutz is close to getting final approvals. Under ordinary circumstances this would take about 30 days.

title: Giuliani Pushes President on Oil Heat Costs
description: In a move clearly meant to attract the attention of upstate voters in his bid for the Senate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had urged President Clinton to tap the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to bring down the soaring price of home heating oil.

title: Worlds Within Themselves
description: UNLIKE other artists, gardeners are allowed to steal ideas. Why else do we take back roads in unfamiliar towns looking for something that might not exist? In our own small Sag Harbor garden, along with the usual Sissinghurst and Giverny and Roman influences, I have been using a little symbolism here and a faux gate there, alluding to Chinese gardens I had never seen.

title: What's Not So New Anymore
description: PERHAPS now that we have reached the 21st century, music of the 20th doesn't seem so scary any more; certainly it has a healthy representation among this week's concerts.

title: If It's the Internet, Down Must Be Up
description: THE Internet got some really bad news last week, so naturally it was really good news too. Sure, cyber-hackers paralyzed a number of powerhouse Web sites, including Amazon.com, Yahoo and eBay. But now Internet security consultants find themselves doing a land-office business.

title: Q&A/Patricia F. Gorski; A Force Behind the Board of Legislators
description: THERE are some who may wonder how Patricia F. Gorski keeps 17 bosses happy. Ms. Gorski, the clerk and chief of staff to the County Board of Legislators, says it is easy -- just treat the 17 legislators as equals.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-13-00: Counter Culture; Fixing the First Lady Problem
description: Compare her with her rivals for first lady, and it's hard not to get a little excited about Ernestine Schlant. Compare her with Hillary Clinton, and it's hard not to get ecstatic. The wife of Bill Bradley, Schlant is an undemonstrative feminist, a mother of two (one of whom is from a previous marriage) and an academic with her own solid career. She has had the same simple, close-cropped haircut for 30 years. Her relationship with her husband seems devoid of any agenda but that of simple romance. When she met him, she was eight years his senior and barely knew what a New York Knick was. She has never even hinted at the idea of gaining political power through marriage, and yet she is anything but a demure or perky appendage to her lofty spouse. Barring an upset, she won't ever be first lady of the United States. But given what has happened to the East Wing of the White House in recent years, this is one small reason for hoping that upsets can happen.

title: INVESTING WITH/Peter A. Vlachos; Forum Austin Global Equity Fund
description: IN the 1950's, during the cold war, Peter A. Vlachos traveled the world as a sergeant in the United States Air Force Strategic Air Command, repairing advanced electronics. His interest in such gadgetry continues today as he buys shares of communications and electronics companies for his $38.3 million mutual fund, Forum Austin Global Equity. Such stocks account for 42 percent of the portfolio.

title: Top Regulator Tells Investors It's Time to Be More Prudent
description: The nation's top securities regulator warned yesterday that some of the most popular stock market strategies, including buying stocks with borrowed money and rushing into hot new issues, may be hazardous to investors.

title: Standouts In the East 20's
description: 27 STANDARD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHNAYERSON, EDWARD, M.D.
description: SHNAYERSON-Edward, M.D. Of Englewood, N.J. On February 11. Beloved husband of Francine. Devoted father of Jill Cohen and Leslie Breslin. Cherished father-in-law of Peter Cohen and Julian Breslin. Dear brother of Thelma Fishman. Adored uncle of Gregg Fishman. Loving grandfather of Matthew, Alison, Samantha and Kimberly. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J. Sunday, 10:30AM. Should friends desire contributions to Englewood Hospital or the University of Arkansas Medical School would be appreciated.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In Carlstadt, Industrial Space for Cyberspace
description: IN an area around Central Boulevard in Carlstadt dotted with low-slung warehouses and manufacturing complexes the steel skeleton rising on a 12-acre site at the far western end of the thoroughfare is an anomaly. For it has more to do with cyberspace than industrial space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBLER, JOYCE
description: LEIBLER-Joyce. The Officers, Board of Governors and Members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member and extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Charles and her family. Jay M. Rosen, President Corey B. Rabin, Secretary

title: A Passion for Making Music With Others
description: WHEN Jaime Laredo performs at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, celebrating the 40th anniversary of his debut there, the program will be very different from the violin recital he played as a young man. Mr. Laredo will be seen in all the spheres of musical activity that he has embraced, each with complete comfort and astonishing success: violinist, violist, conductor, chamber music partner, teacher. What is especially pleasurable about this concert, with the Brandenburg Ensemble, is that it celebrates not only Mr. Laredo's musical virtues but also his personal ones.

title: The War to Begin All Wars
description: CRUCIBLE OF WAR

title: Keeping Up With the Expanding Meaning of Craft
description: SINCE the beginning of time, craft makers have transformed clay, sand, fiber, wood, stone and metal into all sorts of ordinary and wondrous objects -- pots, vases, tapestries and necklaces. At first they made everything by hand. But over time, they added machines, and most recently computers, to improve or quicken the molding, weaving, carving and welding of objects.

title: Saving Konrad Latte
description: Among the many memorials recalling the persecution and destruction of Berlin's Jews, not one honors the Berliners who hid and protected the fugitives from Nazism. Historians estimate that between 5,000 and 10,000 German Jews went underground before and during the war, about half of them in Berlin; about 2,000 Jews actually lived out the war in Berlin. Compared with the 170,000 or so Jewish citizens of Berlin who were driven out or murdered or both, that's a very small number. But when you consider how frequently they changed hiding places and how many people helped them do so, the demographics of resistance change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JERRY, MARTIN
description: JERRY-Martin. On February 7, 2000. Devoted father of Christine and Ashley. Beloved brother of Peter. Loving uncle of Michael and Robert. Cherished brother-inlaw of Ronnie. Co-founder of Jerry/Haines Design Studio, NYC. Memorial service on Wednesday, February 16 at 6:30PM at Chat and Ciao, 18 West 18th Street, NYC. He was larger than life and will be missed by many.

title: Black Tie Optional
description: Dressing up for art, opera and education.

title: Barkley Returns Just in Time For the Storm
description: There was the no-look bounce pass to complete a three-on-one break. There were the windmill hands that knocked the ball loose, followed by the quick-thinking reflex of banging it off Villanova center Malik Allen's knee. Then Erick Barkley lofted an alley-oop pass to Lavor Postell and, in just four minutes of play, the guard rediscovered a smile that had been missing for a week.

title: Al Gore Moves Beyond Meta
description: James Bennet's article on Al Gore (Jan. 23) is insightful. He captures the paradox of Gore's success, writing, ''Before Gore can hope to seem like less of a politician, he will have to become more of one.''

title: As a Bachelor's Biological Clock Ticks Away . . .
description: WE'VE all heard how women rounding 30 start yearning to experience the joys of heavily sedated childbirth, how their little genetic time bomb turns career-absorbed power gals into mating-obsessed baby machines. Enough about them already!

title: Like Magic, Witchcraft Charms Teenagers
description: OCCUPYING a place of honor in Emn Haddad-Friedman's bedroom in Brooklyn is a trunk. ''Just a box really,'' Ms. Haddad-Friedman said, one that doubles as an altar, providing a perch for such items as a pair of candlesticks, an incense burner, a cast-iron cauldron and, she said wryly, sometimes her cats.

title: For Immigrants Chasing a Dream, Citizenship Doesn't Come Easy
description: AMID flag waving and cheers, 350 new citizens at the County Courthouse here last month declared their allegiance to the United States, their numbers but not their enthusiasm diminished in recent years.

title: THE GUIDE
description: The Human Figure

title: Bringing the Universe Inside
description: AS visually stunning as the new planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History is -- a huge sphere in a glass box -- the architecture of the universe is more wondrous still. Each year astronomers bring down from their heights more views of the awesome cosmic edifice stretching in all directions out to the beginning of time. Its dimensions are beyond mundane measure, its structure shaped mostly by unknown matter.

title: MORE STUDY OF ROUTE 92
description: The Army Corps of Engineers ordered the New Jersey Turnpike Authority last week to conduct an environmental impact study on the proposed construction of Route 92, a toll road that would connect Route 1 with the turnpike Interchange 8A in Cranbury. Environmental groups have opposed the construction of the $300 million road, saying it would destroy 14 acres of wetlands and could increase development in the environmentally sensitive area. The study is expected to take up to five years to complete and could cost $5 million. More than $30 million has already been spent on determining the proposed road effect on the environmental, hearings and engineering studies on the construction.

title: The Grand Exit
description: How does it feel to tell the boss you're leaving? More and more workers are finding out, as the record-setting economic boom creates more jobs and job-hopping. Some people go with a laugh, some with a snarl, some with a dash of creativity. What has been your most memorable manner of leaving a job? Or the most striking voluntary departure you have witnessed? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Pure Poirot? Such a Feat Is Herculean, No?
description: Hercule Poirot is back, that fastidious and infinitely inquisitive Belgian detective whose little gray cells are in perpetual action. Tonight, David Suchet fixes his analytical eye on ''The Murder of Roger Ackroyd,'' the first of two new Poirots on A&E. Having acted in 40 of the Agatha Christie stories on television, Mr. Suchet has far outdistanced all others who have previously played the role. From pomaded mustache to penguinlike walk, he is pure Poirot.

title: Governor's Involvement In the Global Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 26 about a walking tour in Yokohama misidentified the street closest to the waterfront and misstated the age of a restaurant. The street near the waterfront (and once known as the Bund) is Yamashita Koen Dori, not Honcho Dori. The restaurant, Yamate Jyuban-kan, was built in 1967, not in the Edwardian era.

title: On the East Side, Back to the Land
description: The cream of French producers use a virtually untranslatable term, terroir, about wine that expresses its unique agricultral origins. In the 90's, terroirism -- insistence on authenticity -- became a semi-movement. With luck, American consumers will embrace it in the 00's.

title: A Politician Sees Future Of Japan In Its Past
description: By midday, the visitors were spilling out of the waiting room and into the corridor outside the office of Shizuka Kamei, the longtime machine politician who has suddenly become one of this country's most powerful and solicited figures.

title: Manhattan Transfer
description: Weld comes off as open, intelligent and charming in your interview. However, it is interesting that he describes himself as ''a subway person.'' It is common knowledge in Massachusetts that it was not Weld but another governor who rode the subway to work every day. A man named Mike Dukakis.

title: Secure or Not, the Internet Has Become a Part of Life's Routine
description: When Jon Tara first heard that unknown vandals with unclear motives had managed to sabotage several of the Internet's most prominent businesses last week, the San Diego software engineer posted a probing message to an online investing forum that he frequents.

title: ROSY REPORT
description: New Jersey is enjoying its longest economic boom in history, one that is likely to continue, a report released by the state-appointed New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors says.

title: Pi as Art
description: To the Editor: The stunning use of pi by the French artist Francois Morellet on the facade of the Musee Zadkine (''Geometric Abstraction Adorns Paris Museum,'' Travel Advisory, Jan. 23) is reminiscent of a permanent installation called ''Sliding Pi'' in the Downsview subway station in Toronto. This work, created by the Canadian artist Arlene Stamp, consists of thousands of colored tiles all neatly arranged through the use of a complex algorithm based on the decimal expansion of pi.

title: THEATER; The Best Way to Bridge 400 Years
description: IT begins with a fight. One of a pair of small-time con men pours a bottle of toxic chemicals on his colleague, who shoots back a stream of invective as caustic as the noxious liquid itself. Their partner, a strung-out prostitute desperate to calm them, resorts to the moves of a street fighter skilled in the art of the low blow.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Honoring a House at a Long-Gone Reservoir
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the Reservoir Keeper's House in Williamsbridge a landmark last week. The 1889 house overlooked the Williamsbridge reservoir, which delivered water to the Bronx. Construction of the Jerome Park Reservoir at the turn of the century rendered the Williamsbridge Reservoir obsolete. It was drained in the 1930's.

title: A Golf Tour Plays the Internet
description: Professional golfers can be gamblers at heart: they risk a lot of money if they miss a putt in a tournament.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Cash and Time, Gone With the Wind
