description: THE $2,000 was eating me up. It wasn't the amount that got me; it was the way I lost it. Tricked. Scammed. Thieved by a carpenter who ''needed the money for the windows in advance.''

title: West African Rhythms in Morristown
description: The drums of Africa will reverberate in the Community Theater of Morristown as part of the theater's celebration of Black History Month.

title: South Carolina: Bush Intensifies His Push Again
description: Gov. George W. Bush's campaign has scrapped trips to California and Arizona, bought the advertising time once held by Steve Forbes and started contacting 135,000 independents and Democrats in an all-out bid to stop Senator John McCain from winning the South Carolina primary a week from today.

title: The Schopenhauer Method
description: The 19th-century German philosopher offers answers to love in three easy steps.

title: Public Housing's New Face: Will It Lift the Urban Poor?
description: UNDER a late morning sun the landscape is a stark profile, a jumble of bulky brick boxes that make up the Migliore Manor public housing complex in the Elizabethport section of this Union County city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROPPA, RICHARD A.
description: GROPPA-Richard A. Of Darien, CT, on February 10, 2000. Husband of Judith C. Groppa. Father of Christopher C. Groppa. Son of Thomas A. Groppa. A memorial service will be held Monday, February 14, 2000, at 1 PM, at the First Congregational Church of Darien, CT. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to Person to Person, 1864 Post Rd, P.O. Box 3128, Darien, CT 06820.

title: Saying It With Insurance
description: Valentine's Day has always been a big day for diamonds, rubies, emeralds and other sparkling expressions of love. But how many recipients open their valentine cards to read ''P.S.: It's insured''?

title: Jitters on Wall Street and Elsewhere
description: Wall Street could not shake the nervousness that descended for reasons not entirely related to the market's own doings.

title: No Untested Pills For Mothers-to-be
description: When the Food and Drug Administration recently announced that dietary supplements could be marketed for morning sickness, experts in birth defects were outraged. They reminded the agency of how, in the 1960's, it refused to approve thalidomide, a drug that maimed thousands of babies whose mothers took it overseas. The arguments worked; the agency forbid supplement manufacturers from marketing to pregnant women until the risks can be studied. SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

title: At Wijk-aan-Zee, Kasparov Shows He's Still Top Human
description: After reigning as world champion for 15 years, Garry Kasparov has suffered only one major dent in his armor, the six-game match he lost to the marvelous I.B.M. computer Deep Blue in 1996. Humans he just clobbers.

title: Inheriting a Museum
description: THE WHITNEY WOMEN AND THE MUSEUM THEY MADE

title: The Return of Mortadella
description: For 30 years, the traditional pork sausage of Bologna, mortadella, was as illegal in the United States as Cuban cigars, and accordingly, just as valued by connoisseurs.

title: Sabbath Elevator: 'Leniency' or Nuisance?
description: On a Saturday morning, the steel doors of the left-side elevator in the lobby of the Seward Park Cooperative slide open. A visitor steps in, headed for the 12th floor. But a voice calls after him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSS, LOUISE FILER
description: SCHLOSS-Louise Filer. In her 78th year. Died peacefully on February 4, after a long illness. Loving wife of Walter, beloved mother of Stephanie Scott, Edwin and sister Elizabeth (Betty) Filer. Nana to Katie, Emily and Jamie. Laid to rest February 9. Contributions in her memory would be appreciated to the Children's Book Committee of Bank Street College, 610 W. 112 St, NYC 10025, or the Mental Health Association of NYC, 666 Bway, NYC 10012.

title: Con Edison Cleanup
description: Fifteen years after it began the process, Consolidated Edison has completed a $3 million cleanup of a suspected cancer-causing agent at its now abandoned Echo Bay substation in New Rochelle. Other substances found in the soil, however, could delay the state's approval of the cleanup.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Page 20 of The Times Magazine today about the methods used by Web sites to attract interest includes an outdated reference to the online retailer Buy.com, and its pending initial public offering, for which it applied in the fall. On Tuesday, after the magazine had gone to press, the stock began trading.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 13, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAMAGUCHI, WILLIAM E.
description: YAMAGUCHI-William E. Sr, died at home in Larchmont, NY on February 10, 2000 at the age of 75. Following a long career with Time-Life, he set up a consulting practice, bridging the Japanese and American business cultures. Survived by his wife Kim; his children Ellen, Chip and Susan; and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Sunday, February 13th at the Larchmont Avenue Church.

title: Robin Hood Didn't Do It
description: Computer hacking is usually performed for one of two reasons: either to impress other hackers with one's technical prowess, or to teach a moral lesson, to send a statement, as when supporters of East Timorese independence hacked into an Indonesian government Web site.

title: Wherefore Art Thou Pokemon?; Tales From Toy Fair: 'Action Man' Finds His Motivation
description: Philip Buch, actor, clutched his script and did the spiel one more time. ''So, Super-Ninja Action Man senses the evil of Dr. X,'' he enthused, ''and is now ready to turn Dr. X into sushi!''

title: The Melting-Pot Politics of 2000 Are Truly Soupy
description: PITY the poor presidential campaign strategists. With make-or-break primaries fast approaching, they're frantically trying to cobble together winning strategies to appeal to an electorate so diverse, cacophonous and in flux as to make the folks trying to build the Tower of Babel sound like a harmonious glee club. With no big issue like war, recession or incumbency to give the 2000 race some shape, America looks more than ever like an indistinct montage of contending groups -- some new, some old standbys.

title: Claudia Bernheim and Leo Raphaely
description: WHILE many of their peers are focusing intently on careers, Claudia Elinor Bernheim and Leo Raphaely prefer to work sporadically and freelance, she as an industrial designer, he as a computer consultant.

title: Drummond Posts A National Best
description: Damion Drummond of Paul Robeson High School in Brooklyn posted the season's national best for the third time this year in winning the 1,000 meters yesterday in 2 minutes 28.58 seconds at the sixth annual Evian Mayor's Trophy Meet at the Armory Track and Field Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNNER, FREDA (NEE DEBOLD)
description: BRUNNER-Freda (nee Debold). Born in New York City, September 30, 1899; died February 4, 2000 in Pompano Beach, FL at age 100having lived in 3 centuries. She formerly resided in Forest Hills, NY. She was preceded in death by her husband of 57 years, August Brunner, on March 12, 1980. Surviving is her daughter, Bernice Brunner DeBragga of Greensboro, NC; sister, Elsie Debold Barth of Rego Park, NY; four grandsons and five greatgrandchildren. Interment will take place at a later date in Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Maspeth, NY.

title: Avoiding a Night in Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Slinging Mud Among the Palmettos
description: Gov. George W. Bush won in Delaware, but Senator John McCain got 25 percent of the vote and never even showed up. Meanwhile, the two are getting down and dirtier as the February 19 primary looms.

description: The Third Eye

title: Chain Chewer
description: I thoroughly enjoyed Deborah Solomon's Lives column (Jan. 23). I quit smoking seven years ago and replaced that addiction not with gum but with Tic-Tacs. I often find myself buying in bulk, spending as much as I did on a pack of cigarettes a day. One thing recently made me cut back: my dentist told me I had cavities!

title: Nuclear Rivals Marshal Armies of Lobbyists in Washington
description: Pakistan and India, the world's newest nuclear rivals, have brought their battles to Washington, where each country has assembled a bevy of highly paid lobbyists already tested in one fight -- Pakistan won -- and now engaged in another: whether President Clinton should visit Pakistan as well as India next month.

title: One High School Standout Has Many Footsteps to Follow
description: ONE of the best guys I ever saw in high school in Jersey was Gene Hudgins,'' said Allen (Boo) Pergament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REUTLINGER, JOSEPH
description: REUTLINGER-Joseph. On February 8th. Beloved husband of Belia. Devoted father of the late Andy. Sadly missed by brother, sisters, nieces and nephews. Burial took place on February 11th. Donations can be made to The Sephardic Jewish Congregation and Center of Queens, 101-11 67th Drive, Forest Hills, NY 11375

title: Untitled, Leaving Viewers on Their Own
description: THE Akus Gallery at Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic has a show with the intriguing title ''Drawing in the Present Tense.''

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Page 1 of the Connecticut section today describes the persistence of hate crimes in the state. It cites an Aug. 17 incident in which medical-waste containers marked with swastikas were left in front of a Stamford synagogue, and says there have been no arrests in the case. On Thursday, after the section had gone to press, federal agents arrested a suspect, Alan J. Lorenz of Weston.

title: On Campuses, Warnings About Violence in Relationships
description: In the week since a young woman was slain at Columbia University and her boyfriend committed suicide shortly afterward, the university and its students have grappled with an issue of increasing concern on campuses around the country: violent relationships among students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, FORTUNE
description: RUSSO - Fortune. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: How to Get in Early on a Hot Offering
description: THE initial public offering of Palm Inc., scheduled for Feb. 28, promises to be the next hot deal unavailable to most individual investors. But there's a twist. Because Palm is being spun out of the 3Com Corporation, which will still own 80 percent of the company after the offering, buying 3Com today means owning Palm tomorrow and sharing in the potential upside.

title: High School Breaststroke Contender Reaches Even Higher
description: THE best high school breaststroker in Westchester County is a girl without a team at a school without a pool.

description: The anticipated rally by Tiger Woods today was answered by the splendid play of Phil Mickelson.

description: ACROSS the street from the American Museum of Natural History, Betsy Gotbaum, director of the New-York Historical Society, has been watching the construction of the dazzling, hugely trumpeted $210 million planetarium with great interest and strong emotions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Jan. 30 comparing New York's annual snowfall and January low temperatures with those of Buffalo, Detroit and Fargo, N.D., misstated the city's reported snowfall for 1996. It was 61.3 inches, according to meteorologists at Pennsylvania State University, not 26.2.

description: To the Editor:

description: Renegades

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Family Works to Prove Its Ties to Jefferson
description: SIX years ago, the phone rang in the Cheshire home of Alice Woodson Smith. It was a cousin who had some electrifying news: She was descended from Thomas Jefferson and his slave, Sally Hemings.

title: 1990's Productivity Makes It Best Decade Since 1960's
description: The 1990's economic expansion, now the longest expansion in the nation's history, draws its staying power from various wells -- the two most important being the booming stock market and labor's rising efficiency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVENSEN, BRYN
description: EVENSEN-Bryn. 46, of a heart attack on January 4, 2000. A man of extraordinary wit and energy, who could scull ten miles, build out a kitchen, manage a fund raiser and play concertos -all before cocktails. Fresh out of Harvard, he built one of the most successful U.S. fund raising companies and was personally devoted to several charities. His family, many, many friends, and more than a few nonprofit organzations will miss him. A remembering party will be held in March.

title: Telephone Company at Sea On Suffolk's New Code
description: The announcement in November 1999 of the Suffolk County area code change to 631 has been a joke perpetrated by the telephone company on the residents. We had our stationery reprinted, our millennium calendars sent out with the new area code and our business cards redone. But attempting to dial our office from around the country simply results in a constant busy signal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLMAN, JEANETTE NEE GOLDBERG
description: ELLMAN-Jeanette nee Goldberg, on February 11. Forever loved by husband Sidney, daughter Joyce, son Michael and his wife Sue Ann, grandchildren Jared, Courtney and Chelsea. Jeanette was a wonderful wife and inspiring mother who served her country in the U.S. Army as a sergeant in '42-'45 and devotedly cared for public school children in the NYC Board of Health '66-'75. Services Sunday, February 13, at the Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel, 12 noon, 1439 Unionport Rd, Bronx, NY.

title: The Truths Of 'Hurricane' Are Complex
description: THE bar where the triple murder in the Hurricane Carter case took place 34 years ago is now called Len's Place. The neighborhood has gone from white to black and Hispanic, as have the bar's patrons. But you can still get the local buzz along with your drink. As for the case, now the subject of a hit film, a woman behind the counter one night last week said, ''I don't think people even mention it.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 30 about learning Spanish in Santiago, Chile, misstated the nationality of the South American revolutionary Bernardo O'Higgins. He was born in Chile; he was not an Irish immigrant.

title: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; Lights, Action in France For Second Disney Park
description: THE early struggles of Disneyland Paris, which the Walt Disney Company opened at Marne-la-Vallee east of Paris in 1992, may have led some to believe that Europeans don't like amusement parks. But in fact, the eventual huge success of the park prompted Disney to announce in September that it would build a second theme park next door to the first.

title: A Dog Run Too Close To Eleanor Is Rejected
description: After more than two years of debate among West Side residents, the city's Parks Department last week rejected a plan to put a permanent dog run in the south end of Riverside Park. Opponents had complained that, among other things, the run would be disrespectfully close to a statue of Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: The Deep, Dark Secrets Of How We Get Chocolate
description: PEOPLE in Central and South America have eaten chocolate for more than a thousand years and even used cocoa beans as currency. Local chocolate devotees can celebrate the bean at ''Chocolate, Please!'' week, starting on Saturday at the New York Botanical Garden. One can see the red pods of a live Theobroma cacao plant, taste-test the nib, or meat of the bean, crush cocoa beans and warm up with a mug of hot chocolate.

title: Prescription Drugs Should Cost Less
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW TRUCKS OUT OF LINDEN
description: General Motors Corporation is building a 24,000-square-foot addition to the body shop of its Linden assembly plant to make way for production of a new four-door pickup. Construction at the site began in December, and the addition is expected to be in operation by early summer. The new model, which was announced last week at the Chicago auto show, will be available in September. The truck, a ''crew cab,'' can accomodate up to five passengers and features four front-hinged doors. David Caldwell, a spokesman for the General Motors truck group, said there were no plans to phase out any of the current models produced at the Linden plant, which employs 2,300, and said there might be a need for new workers there but could not say how many.

title: Travel Advisory; Oregon's Winterfest Has a Russian Theme
description: A glimpse of life in Imperial Russia, with all its trappings, is coming to Portland, Ore., and the city is celebrating with a festival of events.

title: Children's Books
description: HOW TO CATCH AN ELEPHANT Written and illustrated by Amy Schwartz. Richard Jackson/DK Ink, $15.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Couple Sell Family Photos As Ready-Made Nostalgia
description: One Valentine's Day card at Scaredy Kat, a card shop at 219 Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, shows a black-and-white photo of an exotic flamenco dancer, head thrown back, ruffled costume baring her torso. Pasted on another card is a 1953 snapshot of a girl squinting at the camera, holding out a birthday cake. On still another: a woman, her hair swept into a severe bun, gazes solemnly ahead.

title: An Educator Shines At the Planetarium
description: IF any students from the Astrophysics 203 class at Princeton University had sneaked into last week's preview of New York's renovated Hayden Planeterium, they would have seen their professor, Neil de Grasse Tyson, fielding questions from a clutch of people.

title: What's Love Got to Do With It?
description: Tomorrow will mark nine years from the day that Karen Shuster received a Valentine's Day card signed ''Your Secret Admirer.'' Tomorrow will also begin a new round in the litigation that followed, a tangle of claims and counterclaims turning on that card and two others Ms. Shuster received during a long and strange relationship with her former boss.

title: Space for Research Is Expanding in Cambridge
description: DEVELOPERS and life-science companies are planning to invest about $1 billion to build more than three million square feet of new research labs in Cambridge, more than doubling the amount of research and development space in this six-square-mile city.

title: The View From/Guilford; State's Rose Business Hangs On -- Just Barely
description: ALTHOUGH roses are going to be delivered all over the state tomorrow, it's a safe bet that most of them were grown any place but here. Roses have never been a huge crop in the state and if it weren't for William Pinchbeck, the business would be dead in Connecticut.

title: BASEBALL: Heavy Burdens Behind the Plate; Catching for the Yanks: It's Jorge Posada's Job
description: The sun was out, the fans were loud and Joe Torre stood at the microphone at the end of the Yankees' victory parade last October, praising his team for its third championship in four years. Torre turned and beckoned one player to his side to illustrate a point: Jorge Posada. ''Tell them what we say at the end of our meetings, Jorge,'' Torre said.

title: On a Wing and a Prayer, The Bluebird Returns
description: I COULDN'T believe my eyes last spring, when a bluebird flew out of a walnut tree on our farm in Maryland. But that iridescent blue is unmistakable. The color of blue, blue sky, with a sheen like water.

title: Taking A Shot At Their Olympic Dreams
description: THREE years ago, while attending Connecticut College in New London, Gregory Skidmore attended a lecture expecting to learn about the Olympic experiences of Timothy Young, an alumnus who won a silver medal with the 1996 crew team that competed in Atlanta. He left the room inspired to fulfill his childhood dream of sailing in the Olympics.

title: When Home Is a Foreign Notion
description: YOU know it's time to go home when you turn giddy over a new issue of Delta Air Lines' in-flight magazine. You find yourself muttering about seat-back trays in the upright and locked position and eating 12 peanuts for dinner.

title: The Ultra-Orthodox And Their Women
description: IN the bedroom of an ultra-Orthodox couple in Jerusalem, a man rises, takes three steps, washes his hands, and recites the morning prayer, thanking God for preserving his soul all night, and for not having created him a woman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: Rescuers of Schools Now Need Rescuing
description: Disclosures that Newark schools operating for the last four years under the state's strict financial and educational control -- managed to amass a $58 million budget deficit are exposing ills that are about to be painfully dissected by the State Legislature.

title: McCain Broke With His Party in Licensing Flap
description: Buried in the two-foot stack of more than 500 letters from Senator John McCain to federal agencies released by his office several weeks ago is a strongly worded appeal to the Federal Communications Commission written in Mr. McCain's very first week as chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: Woman Caught in a Net
description: THE worst present I ever got was a black silk teddy, because it came from a man I had no interest in. The fact that he gave it to me was nerve of the highest order -- though clearly, his opinion of himself far exceeded mine. We had dated only a few times, and I had kissed him good night -- reluctantly -- on the street, clambering into a cab. Any cab.

title: Manhattan Transfer
description: Weld was asked why New Yorkers wait ''on line, not in line.'' When I attended P.S. 213 in Brooklyn, there were painted white lines in the schoolyard and we all stood on line, waiting in straight rows to march into the building, class by class. Brooklynese must have won out.

description: DURING years of focusing his camera on sites from one end of Long Island to the other in search of the unique as well as the commonplace, Bob Cammann never encountered a ''no trespassing'' sign he could -- or would -- respect.

description: To the Editor:

description: TOMORROW is Valentine's Day, a time for champagne, roses and sappy expressions of affection.

title: Smart Growth
description: State Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky of Elmsford, chairman of the Committee on Environmental Conservation, and Prof. John Nolon director of the Land Use Law Center at Pace University, have announced $150,000 in grants available for Hudson Valley communities in Westchester and Rockland that allow development but also encourage land preservation.

title: Relying on Artistry, Kwan and Weiss Win Titles
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 12 -- The tug of war between artistry and sport was on contentious display today at the national figure skating championships, and the judges sent a clear message in the men's long program that they preferred completeness over jumping, no matter how innovative and historic.

title: Torricelli on a Gore Ticket? What's That Troubling Ring?
description: Democrats have six months and countless Presidential primary battles before the national convention, but that doesn't mean it's too early for enterprising politicians to begin positioning themselves for the consolation prize, the vice presidential nomination.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MUSEUM MILE

title: Highlights in the Life Of Marian Anderson
description: MARIAN ANDERSON'S most famous recital was sung into a microphone. It was only half an hour, outdoors on a cold Washington Easter in 1939, and the selections, including ''Ave Maria'' and ''America,'' were not showy or virtuosic.

title: Hoop Dreams Revisit Camden
description: THE grand Gothic-style building bespeaks an era of a greater Camden. Camden High School was built on the hill in Parkside, long Camden's finest residential area, when the city was flexing its muscles as a prime industrial center of post-World War I America and the home of such businesses as RCA Victor, New York Shipbuilding and Esterbrook Pen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, DOROTHY
description: BAUMAN-Dorothy. February 11, 2000, age 96. Wife of the late John Sprague Bauman, beloved mother of Mrs. Patricia Bauman Farnes of Minnesota, and Mrs. Gay Bauman Stodder of California and the late Corbin C. Bauman. She is also survived by ten grandchildren, 20 great grandchildren, and three great great grandchildren. Raised in Minnesota, she served as first vice president of The League of Women Voters, President of Planned Parenthood and one of the founders of the Walker Art Museum. She was a Director of Social Services for the WPA and the Federal Works Agency under the Roosevelt Administration. As a freelance journalist, she covered the Greek war in 1948 and the first free Italian Elections. She lectured under the sponsorship of ColstenLeigh and the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations. She served as a consultant on Women's Affairs for USIA under the Eisenhower administration and in 1952 was instrumental in founding the Committee of Correspondents. She served as the Director of the Panel of Americans, as Director of the Sterling Forest Gardens Foundation, and as Associate Secretary of the Metropolitan Museum Centennial Committee. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Cosmopolitan Club of New York.

title: RABBI'S MURDER TRIAL SET
description: The trial of Rabbi Fred Neulander of Cherry Hill, charged with arranging the murder of his wife more than five years ago, will begin June 19. The date was set in Camden last week by Superior Court Judge Linda Rosensweig, three days after she rejected a defense motion to dismiss the indictment against the rabbi for insufficient evidence. Jury selection is expected to begin the week before the trial starts before Judge Rosenzweig; lawyers expect the trial to last two to three weeks. Rabbi Neulander, 58, the rabbi of Congregation M'Kor Shalom in Cherry Hill, is accused of conspiring to have his wife, Carol, 52, bludgeoned to death in November 1994 so he could carry on an affair. His lawyers say she was killed during a robbery attempt.

title: The Talented Mr. Burr
description: DUEL

title: Rudd Making a New Start as a Driver for the Yates Team
description: It's like something from a Hollywood script. Before last season the veteran Nascar driver Ricky Rudd tells his main sponsor, Tide, that it needs to double its financial commitment in order to compete with the sport's heavyweights. After a study, the detergent company decides to do so, but in the process severs ties with Rudd at season's end. For the next month, Rudd scrambles to find a major sponsor, a time of soul-searching and uncertainty for the 43-year-old. Suddenly, though, comes an offer that figures to change his life dramatically.

title: Lisabeth Miller, Stephen Kaufman
description: Lisabeth Susan Miller, the daughter of Phyllis Miller and Dr. David Miller of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married last evening to Stephen Elliot Kaufman, the son of Lucille and Theodore Kaufman of Manhattan. Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum officiated at the Plaza.

title: Dim Sum for 2000, 40 Seats at a Time
description: As the New Year began -- the Western one, not the Chinese one -- Tom Lau and his family opened the Century Cafe at 123 Bowery (between Grand and Hester Streets) in Chinatown. Century serves dim sum like pork, chicken and sausage buns, steamed or baked, (60 cents each), and its 40 seats are packed daily until at least 4 p.m. The cafe continues serving other items like coffee and tea (60 cents), sandwiches ($1.25) and pastries, all baked on premises, ($9 to $10 per pound), until 8 p.m.

title: The Death Penalty: When There's No Room for Error
description: WHEN Gov. George Ryan of Illinois called last month for a moratorium on executions in his state, he focused on the fact that 12 men on death row had recently been proven innocent. Sentencing an innocent person to death was, the governor said, ''shameful,'' but he said little about how the legal representation these inmates had received at trial may have contributed to justice gone wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, HOWARD
description: WHITE-Howard. An uncle by birth, but so much more. Larry and Lewis

title: Jubilee Year
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed your articles on Jan. 23 on Rome and the Jubilee. I spent the New Year there and was happy to see the many positive changes since I lived there in 1995, particularly the new museums and houses for classical collections that had been stored or dispersed.

title: Digital Shrinkage Leaves Us All Thumbs
description: ELECTRONICS manufacturers seemingly have ample tech nology and ample will -- to create wondrously tiny, portable gadgets. If only they could engineer smaller human beings.

title: With Victory, the Islanders Have a Rare Winning Streak
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins skated into a time warp tonight at Nassau Coliseum. Big crowd, short-handed goals, power-play goals, plenty of fisticuffs, tough defense. Were these the same cellar-seeking Islanders who had been outscored by 17-5 in three previous meetings with the Penguins?

title: Sprung
description: ACTUAL INNOCENCE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, DOROTHY
description: HOFFMAN - Dorothy. Beloved wife of Lionel B., loving mother of Steven and Howard, cherished grandmother of Eran and Andrew. Service 12:45 Tuesday, February 15th, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Fleeting Glory Is No More
description: This might be a great year for a certain Knicks player turned New Jersey politician. But it will be a decidedly poor year for another, four years after his death.

title: U.S. Victims of Chile's Coup: The Uncensored File
description: Twenty-six years ago, as the forces of Gen. Augusto Pinochet overthrew the Socialist government of Salvador Allende, two American supporters of President Allende were killed in Chile under circumstances that stirred suspicions of C.I.A. involvement.

title: Noshing for Research
description: Eating peanut butter or applesauce may not sound like science. But Rutgers is looking for snackers in a study of what tastes good, or not so good, to different people. Cook College's sensory evaluation laboratory first tests whether people are sensitive to a chemical compound called 6-n-propylthiouracil, which 70 percent of people find bitter and the rest cannot detect, according to Dr. Beverly Tepper, director of the study. Then they sample ordinary foods and rate them. The idea is to see whether likes or dislikes are tied to the sensitivity to the chemical. The findings could be used to make healthy foods more appealing or, commercially, to develop products consumers will, well, consume. About 125 volunteers have been tested during the past year and at least another 30 are needed, mainly men aged 21 to 50, in two 45-minute sessions. Dr. Tepper would not reveal the amount subjects are paid -- it's small, she said -- because she wants to gauge their interest in taking part in research. Information: (732) 932-9611 extension 227.

title: Mixing the Personal And the Professional
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSSEL, ELEANOR
description: BRUSSEL-Eleanor. Died December 5, 1999. Memorial service in the Recital Hall, Horace Mann School, 231 W. 246th St., Bronx, NY, on Saturday, February 26, at 2 PM.

title: Letting It Rip, French Style
description: THE French, having legally limited the workweek to 35 hours, are filling their free time this winter searching for ''nouvelles sensations de glisse.'' This refers to new ways of sliding down mountains with the aid of technology and the moral support of no-premiums national health care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SETTEL, SYLVIA
description: SETTEL-Sylvia, 86. Died February 11th. in Syracuse, NY. Born in NYC. She studied at the NY School of Design and the Art Students League. She was an independent artist who had exhibits at the Donnell Art Library in NYC, the Harriman Library and the Hudson River Museum. Several select pieces of her work are on permanent exhibit at Syracuse University School of Information Studies. She was a member of the National Association of Artists. Her husband Harold died in 1972. Survived by daughter Barbara Settel of Lafayette, NY, and son William of Elkton, MD, six grandchildren. Contributions to ALS research.

title: For the Moment, at Least, Small Is Beautiful
description: WONDERING what happened to the bull market in big blue-chip stocks? It got downsized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, BONNIE
description: CASHIN-Bonnie. The California Institute of Technology feels privileged to have been a focus of fashion designer Bonnie Cashin's interest during the past 22 years of her life. She was intrigued by the confluence of art and science and encouraged our students to maximize their creativity. She generously established a lecture series, a scholarship and even the Bonnie Cashin Prize for Imaginative Thinking at Cal Tech. How fortunate we were to have been the recipient of her philanthropy. Her enthusiasm and sense of adventure endeared her to the Institute and will be sorely missed.

title: Children's Books
description: The Huckabuck Family

title: Jubilee Year
description: To the Editor: Regarding the articles on Rome, I thought more emphasis could have been given to the problem of pickpockets. I have been a victim and know how difficult it can be to have a passport, airline tickets, money and other items stolen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHYLANDER, ANNIE E.
description: SCHYLANDER-Annie E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Annie E. Schylander, associated with The Times from 1948 until retiring in 1971.

title: Replacing Handles on Tools
description: MANY craftsmen have a favorite hammer or other hand tool that was purchased many years ago or one that was inherited from a relative.

title: . . . A Bachelorette Fears Making A Commitment
description: AT a cocktail reception at the Museum of Television and Radio recently, I lived the dream of many single women my age: meeting Mary Tyler Moore. She was being honored on the eve of ''Mary and Rhoda,'' her TV-movie reunion with Valerie Harper, which was broadcast Monday night on ABC. I went to ask a few questions about Mary Richards -- the heroine of ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and mine, too -- in search of the meaning of single life.

title: After Week of Ulster Turmoil, a Glimmer of Hope
description: A frantic week of talks, ultimatums and deadlines that fed the grim conviction that Northern Ireland was discarding a promising chance to escape its rancorous past ended today on a surprisingly benign and forward-looking note.

title: Critiquing the Syntax Of a Theater Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: Hijacking Ends
description: The four-day hijacking of an Afghan airliner at Stansted Airport outside of London ended peacefully and with no injuries when the hijackers surrendered unconditionally on Thursday.

title: SCHOOL CHOICE
description: The Department of Education announced last week that it received 147 applications for the first class of its school choice program, which will allow students to leave their home districts to attend school next fall in one of 10 selected districts around the state, tuition-free. There were 650 openings. Education Commissioner David Hespe said the low number of applications were received because the process gave families only two weeks to decide if they wanted to participate. Six districts will be added to the program next year, and five more the year after.

title: 100 Rms, Lake Vu
description: THE VISION OF EMMA BLAU

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Host Family

title: As Mergers Get Bigger, So Does The Danger
description: MERGERS today are something to behold. The big ones are four or five times pricier than the biggest in the 1980's, and the number keeps climbing like an airliner gaining altitude. Giant companies on different continents come together as easily as neighborhood stores, and hardly a week goes by without another huge deal. The time has come to stop gawking at this spectacle and to figure out what is happening to so many of the corporations that shape our lives.

title: Anxious G.O.P. Leaders Want Mayor's Attention Upstate
description: Alarmed that Hillary Rodham Clinton may be making inroads among voters in upstate New York, Republican Party leaders have begun expressing frustration and anger that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has spent so little time campaigning in a region that is essential to winning the race for United States Senate.

title: Under Attack at Home, Indonesia's Military Reels
description: Perhaps the most telling insult to Indonesia's armed forces, people here say, is that mothers no longer encourage their daughters to marry a military man.

title: Frozen Sprouts Aren't So Tasty
description: Now is the time when many people go wrong in starting seeds. Those packets of Caspian Pink and Green Grape tomatoes, Applegreen eggplant and Blushing Beauty peppers may be clamoring to be planted, but it's too early.

title: Russia Agrees On a Plan For Repaying Some of Debt
description: Russia has reached an agreement with foreign commercial creditors to restructure $31.8 billion of its external debt, handing Acting President Vladimir V. Putin an important political victory and helping to clear the way for the country to tap international money markets again.

title: No U.S. Funds Allotted To Upgrade Plum I. Lab
description: The White House has turned down a request by the Agricultural Research Service, an agency of the United States Department of Agriculture, for $24 million to upgrade the Plum Island Animal Disease Research Center.

title: For the Truly Avant-Garde, Black Is the Color of a True Love's Rose
description: Perhaps embracing the darker side of life, Manhattanites have been going mad for black roses for Valentine's Day.

title: Vita Buffa
description: MOZART A Cultural Biography. By Robert W. Gutman. Illustrated. 839 pp. New York: Harcourt. $40.

title: French, With Italian Overture and Finale
description: IT'S new. It's French. And Mitchell Hauser, the chef and owner of Barney's in Locust Valley, is in the kitchen. These are a few of the reasons crowds have been packing Aix-en-Provence since it opened last month. But it is the food that brings them back.

title: Words That Can't Be Set to Music
description: MISSION statements -- those distilled essences of corporate goals -- will never be confused with works of Donne or Shakespeare. Yet they have caught on like Britney Spears's latest hit, becoming poetry to executives' ears, sonnets to shareholder value, so much so that 86 percent of American corporations have their own carefully worded, neatly printed, widely disseminated statements.

title: Streetscapes/The North Side of West 81st Street, Between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue; Across From the Rose Center, a High-Rise Universe
description: THE glass facade of the new Rose Center for Earth and Space is a startling sight on the south side of 81st Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. But next Saturday, when the public finally gets into the 21st-century replacement for the Hayden Planetarium, museumgoers will also have a remarkable view looking out -- to the north side of 81st, which started as a street of mansions but became a cliff of apartment towers.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE CONTRACT SURGEON

title: Los Angeles Tests Its Limits in Quest to Grow
description: This is the last frontier, the place where the suburban sprawl of Los Angeles meets a peaceful patch of live oaks, rolling hills and quiet back roads along the Santa Clara River, one of a tiny handful of wild waterways left in Southern California. It is also a battle zone, the future home of Newhall Ranch, the largest housing development ever approved by Los Angeles County, with 21,600 units for 70,000 people to be built over the next 20 years.

title: Organ Recital
description: THE MYSTERIES WITHIN A Surgeon Reflects on Medical Myths. By Sherwin B. Nuland. 286 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: Buying at Markdown?
description: The Franklin Mutual group of funds has been buying the stocks of department store companies like Saks and J. C. Penney, arguing that investors have beaten down such shares to bargain levels.

title: Political Briefing; Keyes Hangs On After Slipping
description: He has slipped back into single digits in the polls after a brief moment of glory in last month's Republican caucuses in Iowa, in which he finished a surprisingly strong third, with 13 percent of the vote. And all of the other Republican laggards have dropped out of the contest, convinced that only Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona have the money and votes to see the fight through to the end.

title: Fresh Ideas From the Jazz Underground
description: MOST big-picture conversations about jazz these days come down to the same question: how can it become important again? The answer has to be more than once-every-five-years phenomena like Cassandra Wilson or Diana Krall. Jazz needs what rock has had since the 80's, an organized proliferation of termitelike hipster activity wherever there are young people playing and listening. There needs to be better music education. There need to be more clubs booking jazz where people under 25 feel welcome. And there needs to be a thriving independent-label record business, one that plots the daily graph of where jazz musicians are heading.

title: A Trump Card for Unusual Risks
description: IT'S halftime at the Nokia Sugar Bowl. The crowd quiets down as a randomly chosen fan, Robert Moderhak, a 54-year-old retired school administrator, walks onto the field to try winning $500,000 by throwing a football through a 2-foot-square target 15 feet away.

title: Corrections
description: An interview with William Weld on Jan. 23 about his move to New York from Massachusetts misspelled the name of a Manhattan club where he played squash with Mortimer Zuckerman. It is the Harmonie Club, not Harmony.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a brief report about the trial of four police officers charged with the murder of Amadou Diallo misspelled the given name of his mother. She is Kadiatou Diallo, not Kadiadou.

title: A Buzzer That Kept Buzzing
description: Q I live in a rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper West Side. A few weeks ago, the buzzer system in the building went awry and was buzzing constantly. Tenants who called the owner's office were assured that someone would fix the problem by the end of that day, as the next day was a legal holiday. The buzzer was not repaired as promised and was going all night, keeping me and other tenants awake. I called a 24-hour locksmith and paid out of pocket for the buzzer to be disconnected. When I sent the receipt in with a reduced rent check the following month, the owner returned both the receipt and the check with a letter saying that the deduction was ''unapproved and unacceptable.'' How do I get him to reimburse me without going to Housing or Small Claims Court? . . . Madeleine Tress, Manhattan.

title: North County News Also Covers Westchester
description: I read with much interest the story about the number of local newspapers in Westchester County . However, there was a glaring omission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STACKHOUSE, THELMA
description: STACKHOUSE-Thelma, of New York City. Died on February 10. The Board of Directors, staff and children of Leake & Watts Services, Inc., mourn the death of Mrs. Thelma Stackhouse who served as an active member of the Board of Directors for sixteen years. Her compassion, her advocacy and her wisdom will be remembered and she will be missed.

title: U.S. Seeks More Care for Disabled Outside Institutions
description: Following up on a Supreme Court decision, the Clinton administration has told states to evaluate hundreds of thousands of people in nursing homes, mental hospitals and state institutions to see whether they could instead be receiving care in their own homes or elsewhere in their communities.

title: Meetings Around Staten Island
description: DISTRICT 1 -- St. George, Mariners Harbor, Port Richmond, Rosebank, West Brighton, Clifton, Concord, Silver Lake, Westerleigh, Stapleton; regular meeting is second Tuesday of the month; next meeting is March 14, 8 p.m.; All Saints Episcopal Church, 2329 Victory Boulevard, at Wooley Avenue. Agenda: To be announced.

title: Sports of The Times; It's All Madness Before March Play
description: IT is a good thing for college basketball that March is on the way and a sport that is creatively defined by hypocrisy will emerge from the madness it descends into the other 11 months.

title: Carter Flies to Dunk Contest Victory
description: It was just as he had envisioned. Vince Carter took a bounce pass from his teammate, catapulted himself as high as he could and somehow managed to put the ball between his legs in midair. Carter was not done, but the rest of the slam-dunk field was tonight. He kept levitating before finally depositing a malicious windmill slam that rocked the Arena in Oakland.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Year of Reading Proust: A Memoir in Real Time

title: Cultivating Young Audiences
description: Adults and children can attend free and discounted performances, classes and tours at theaters throughout New Jersey during the third annual AT&T Family Week at the Theater, from March 4-12.

title: Coming Home To Bach
description: THE WELL-TEMPERED CLAVIER'' appeared in two installments during the first half of the 18th century. The style and content look back in time, as Bach often did, but there is something futuristic about how these pieces are used. Musical progress, like any other kind of progress, goes in circles, and in the year 2000 we seem to be overtaking the 18th-century world that the 19th century left in its rear-view mirror.

title: Becoming Bolder With Bets on Gold
description: WHEN Barrick Gold, the most successful hedger in the mining business, curtails the practice, that's news. And when the same company gives up some of its locked-in gains to make a bet that gold will rally, something has changed in this precious-metal market.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Suzanne Somers; Keeping Company
description: SUZANNE SOMERS knew to keep them waiting. On Wednesday night, inside the Kit Kat Klub near Times Square, the air jingled with anticipation -- and costume jewelry. More than 150 guests, who had been invited to a private party she said she was giving to ''thank everyone who had supported me throughout the years,'' were buzzing and nibbling hors d'oeuvres.

title: Travel Advisory; London Underground Adds 10-Mile Extension
description: The recent completion of the Jubilee Line on London's Underground makes many tourist sites in South and East London more accessible. The 9.93-mile extension runs from Green Park in Mayfair to Stratford in East London. It crosses the Thames four times: from Westminster to Waterloo; Canada Water to Canary Wharf; Canary Wharf to North Greenwich, and North Greenwich to Canning Town.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MACKINTOSH, ROBERT
description: MACKINTOSH-Robert. Two years and still missed. Maria and Betty Lee

title: Travel Advisory; Airlines Old and New Cut New York Fares
description: Less expensive air fares are coming to New York, with JetBlue, a new airline based at Kennedy International Airport, starting operations this month, and Southwest Airlines, the biggest discount airline, starting service from Albany in May.

title: Vicious Cycle
description: On Parole

title: Suffolk Drunken Drivers Still Face Murder Trials
description: A jury in Suffolk has rejected murder counts against Edwin Rodriguez, a New York City prison guard from Medford, who was drunk and speeding when his car slammed into the rear of another near Exit 62 of the Long Island Expressway on New Year's Eve in 1998, killing three people. Instead, he was convicted of manslaughter.

title: Hope Beats Lint Every Time
description: To be rich in spirit is paramount. That's the message from Charizmatik, a California clothing company whose Walk With Me pants are designed to cheer customers when they reach into their pockets and come up empty.

title: What No School Can Do
description: Traub accurately points out that schools are not enough to help impoverished children become successful adults. Children need after-school programs, especially adult mentors. At Mentoring U.S.A. (MUSA) -- a national initiative that matches at-risk children in kindergarten through eighth grade with trained adult volunteer mentors -- we believe that the approach of parenting, school and mentoring is the key to assisting these children.

title: Again, It's Microsoft vs. the World
description: STEVEN BALLMER, the president of the Microsoft Corporation, returned again and again to a single question. ''What is the soul of MSN?'' he asked, referring to Microsoft's consumer Internet business by its three-letter logo.

title: Courting Web-Head Cash
description: SENATOR John McCain hosted a landmark fund-raising event the other night. There were no buffet tables or stump speeches or grip-and-grin photographs. Instead, Mr. McCain held a question-and-answer session beamed live over the World Wide Web. It was believed to be the first ''cyber-fund-raiser'' in American political history.

title: Big Bang Reproduced Small
description: The birth of the universe is looking less mysterious all the time. Scientists in Geneva announced that they had recreated a bizarre form of matter that probably filled the entire universe when it was a mere 10 millionths of a second old and expanding as a fireball. The scientists, at the CERN particle physics laboratory, succeeded in getting the reclusive particles called quarks to roam freely for the first time in an experiment. Quarks are normally locked inside protons and neutrons and cannot be knocked loose.

title: Tom Landry Is Dead at 75; Innovative Coach of Cowboys
description: Tom Landry, the taciturn Texan who coached the Dallas Cowboys for their first 29 seasons and led them to five Super Bowls, died last night in Dallas. He was 75.

title: It's No Wonder That Good Teachers Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Dock Work Results in Fine For a Ship Repair Company
description: State and city environmental authorities have been investigating a ship repair company at the Brooklyn Navy Yard that has been cited for violating air pollution laws.

title: It's a Jungle Out There
description: MOST people reared on Tarzan movies have a romantic idea of exploring the jungle. Personally, my curiosity was totally satisfied by Johnny Weissmuller and Maureen O'Sullivan. So, you may wonder what I was doing chugging up a narrow tributary of the Amazon River with 15 other people, peering out into the pitch dark and listening to a chorus of monkeys, birds and other creatures. Good question.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDNICK, PAULINE, M.D.
description: RUDNICK-Pauline, M.D. On February 11th, 2000, at the age of 84. Adored mother of Judith Adler and Joan Lampert. Memorial services Sunday, 4 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to NYU School of Medicine Student Loan Fund.

title: Jubilee Year
description: To the Editor: After reading the article ''For a Price, There's Room in Rome,'' as manager of the Hotel Hassler, I feel obliged to tell Paul Hofmann that our hotel (featured in The Times in ''Roman Roost for the Rich and Famous,'' Dec. 6, 1998) also has some rooms available. Long the haunt of the famous and the fortunate, the Hassler, atop the Spanish Steps, is pleased to provide a quiet haven for its guests.

title: Seeking Laurels for an Outpost of the Revolution
description: At the urging of local leaders and historians, the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission is weighing whether to list the Hadley House, which may be the oldest home in the Bronx and which played a role in the American Revolution.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Campaign Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Mourning Big Pun on the Latino Streets He Never Left
description: Reminders of his life and his sudden death Monday were visible in poignant detail last week on the streets that Christopher Rios, the rapper known as Big Punisher, called home.

title: Habitats/Chelsea; The Key: Proving a Bed Could Fit in the Bedroom
description: THE 600-square-foot one-bedroom apartment in a prewar building had an exposed brick wall, the ''suggestion'' of a fireplace -- which in brokers' language means one that doesn't work -- and pleasing south light from a tree-filled block in Chelsea. The asking price was $210,000, a reasonable amount in today's market. But 150 people had looked at the apartment in two and a half months, and no one had bid.

title: Opening the Gates for Black Opera Singers
description: IT must have seemed like such an inconsequential decision back in 1939. By barring Marian Anderson from singing at Constitution Hall simply because she was black, the Daughters of the American Revolution were merely following Washington custom. Yet this single act of discrimination would have an impact far beyond the capital's cultural life. It would, in fact, light a slow-burning fuse, one that set off an explosion in late 1955 when another black woman -- Rosa Parks -- refused to move to the back of a Montgomery, Ala., bus.

title: Critic Rex Reed Arrested On Shoplifting Charges
description: Rex T. Reed, the film critic, columnist and actor, was arrested yesterday at an Upper West Side store after a security guard told the police that he saw Mr. Reed put three compact discs in his jacket pocket and try to walk out of the store, the police said.

title: A Different Outlook at the Jail
description: EDWARD REILLY, the nominee to become the next Nassau County sheriff, does not come across as a forceful man. His manner is reserved, almost bookish.

title: Hopes and Doubts in the Gestation of a Dance
description: IN July 1998, the dancer and choreographer Bill T. Jones began to think about making an evening-long work for himself. He was 46 at the time and in 25 years of performing in the company he and Arnie Zane started, he had never done a solo of this magnitude. He called the piece ''The Breathing Show,'' and, with Janet Wong, his rehearsal director, he began to select the music and experiment with movement. The dance, which can be seen this week in New Jersey, had its premiere in Iowa City last October, but Mr. Jones still considered it a work in progress. He continued to refine the elements of the piece, which incorporated singing, talking, film and, of course, dancing. Following are excerpts from Mr. Jones's journal of that process, begun before the premiere and completed during a European tour with his company in November.

title: Children's Books
description: THE BIG BOX By Toni Morrison with Slade Morrison. Illustrated by Giselle Potter. Jump at the Sun/Hyperion, $19.99. (Ages 8 and up)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARKEY, GEORGE W.B., MD
description: STARKEY-George W.B., MD, 81, a resident of Brookline, MA and Norfolk, CT, died February 5 in Boston. He was a graduate of Trinity College and Harvard Medical School. A thoracic surgeon, he was Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery at Harvard Medical School. In WWII, he served as a battalion surgeon. He leaves his wife Lois (MacMurray); two daughters, Joan S. Palmer and Alison Starkey Morozovsky; son, Hugh Starkey; and five grandchildren. Memorial service 3pm Feb 18, in Memorial Church at Harvard University, Cambridge, MA; reception to follow at the Harvard Faculty Club. Donations made to the Grace B. Starkey Scholarship Fund, C/O Trinity College, 300 Summit Street, Hartford, CT. 06106.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: COMING TO TERMS South Africa's Search for Truth. By Martin Meredith. PublicAffairs, $27.50

title: How to Catch a Trophy Fish And Not Go Near the Water
description: Mark Hayward has caught dozens of smallmouth bass in the Delaware River over the years, so it is not surprising that he decided one day to have a taxidermist put one on a plaque.

title: How to Navigate A Comeback Tour
description: Remember when an employee sendoff party meant that you'd never see the departing co-worker again?

title: Africans Want U.N. to Play A Stronger Role in Congo
description: African governments, unable to bring about a cease-fire in the widening war in eastern Congo, want the United Nations to take on the job of disarming combatants, diplomats from the region say. They also want a peacekeeping force much larger than the 5,537-member mission now being proposed in an American-sponsored Security Council resolution.

title: Sweet Sentiments of Hearts and Flowers
description: TOMORROW will be full of sentiments, with candy, cards and, above all else, flowers being bestowed upon sweethearts throughout the land.

title: PULSE; Perfect Snowballs
description: For those who find hand-packing their own ammo for a snowball fight to be too much trouble, the latest edition of the Martha by Mail catalog features the Snoballer. The bright red plastic tool, which looks like two crisscrossed ladles that open and close like fireplace tongs, is designed to scoop and shape snow into uniform fist-size snowballs.

title: It's No Wonder That Good Teachers Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Perot Supporters Take Back Reform Party in Chaotic Meeting
description: The Ross Perot faction of the Reform Party retook control of its ruling machinery today during a meeting here of party leaders that was so rowdy and divisive that the police threatened at several points to intervene.

title: Sarah Church, Braden Josephson
description: Dr. Sarah Hanley Church and Dr. Braden Roberts Josephson, both psychologists, were married yesterday in Providence, R.I. Richard J. Israel, an associate justice of the Rhode Island Superior Court, officiated at the Providence Biltmore Hotel.

title: Pamela Carrington, Harry Edwards
description: Pamela Carrington, a retailing executive, and Harry T. Edwards, a federal appeals court judge, were married yesterday at the Supreme Court in Washington. Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a friend of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony in her chambers.

title: A Gallic Way With Handbags, Just East of Lafayette
description: Soco, a French handbag store, opened last month at 55 Spring Street (between Lafayette and Mulberry Streets). Soco's handmade and vintage bags, which cost $19 to $395, can also be found at the original 70-year-old Soco location on Rue Bonaparte in Paris, as well as at French department stores and at Le Tanneur stores in Europe and Japan. Le Tanneur is the 102-year-old company that owns Soco. ''Soco is the trendier, younger division,'' said Heidi Golding-Bongiorno, retail director for Soco.

title: Panel Faults Energy Unit On Plan for Nuclear Agency
description: A special House panel, unusually united across party lines, criticized the Energy Department on Friday, saying it did not follow Congressional guidance in creating an agency to oversee nuclear weapons programs.

title: Feb. 14: Doggerel's Day in the Sun
description: A MONDAY morning in February is not the time for romance. But tomorrow, there's no choice. The unstoppable Valentine juggernaut is heading straight at us. Some people may have a hard time getting in the mood, especially if it snows again.

title: The Cartoonist
description: Last fall, when Marisa Acocella, a cartoonist for The New Yorker, went to interview the New York Knicks, she couldn't decide whether to wear blue or black pleather pants. Her editor's advice? ''Be arty. Wear blue.''

title: Choice Tables; Istanbul, Where Fussy Eaters Demand the Freshest Fare
description: THE BOSPORUS is just one of several waterways that lap the shores of Istanbul. The city and its suburbs sprawl from the entrance to the Sea of Marmara to the southern edge of the Black Sea and along the inlet called the Golden Horn. No wonder Istanbul is a mecca for seafood lovers.

title: Rehab for 70's Threads
description: Some rock 'n' roll fashion is now deemed high art, worthy of an exhibit at the Metropolitan. Then there's Filthmart, an East Village vintage store content to preserve rock's low-end classics, from AC/DC concert T's to vintage Levis, customized with studs, lace eyelets and rhinestones on request.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 13, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Liberties; King Of the Hoods
description: Everyone knew that South Carolina would jump ugly. And it did.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 6 about implications of recent mergers in the recording industry included an Internet company erroneously among those being sued by recording companies over the creation of online archives. While My.MP3.com is being sued, myplay.com is not.

title: An Undersea Tribute to Little-Known Victims of the Cold War
description: On Jan. 15, 1961, an Air Force radar platform 75 miles off Barnegat Inlet toppled into the Atlantic during a storm. It took 28 men with it, 14 servicemen and 14 civilians there to repair damage from a previous storm. Only two bodies were ever found. Two of the legs of what was called the Texas Tower -- for its resemblance to oil derricks in the Gulf off Texas -- collapsed, and the platform sank to the seabed 180 feet below. Although the accident was reported in the press, the military said little about it because of the nature of the tower, and the victims received no recognition.

title: A Pillar of Harlem Gets Lift From Teenagers
description: The teenagers who write, edit and produce the online newspaper HarlemLive report stories, create Web pages and devise promotions for their site. But they had not been exposed to deadlines until last month, when a famous Harlem institution asked for their help on its own Internet project.

title: Low-Key Spot for Homey Food in Peekskill
description: THE dining demands of this city's burgeoning artistic community seem to keep an increasing number of diverse eating spots bustling, particularly on weekends. And Division Street is claiming its share. One of the cheeriest restaurants on the street is Susan's, which has held its ground for more than a dozen years. In the last six, as chef and new owner, Evan Thompson has been transforming the place, phasing out the bar and concentrating on food.

title: Megan Freher, Samuel Hage II
description: Megan Patricia Freher, a daughter of Elizabeth and Edward Freher of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Samuel Melvin Hage II, the son of Lu Hage of Moline, Ill., and the late Dr. Samuel M. Hage. The Rev. Linford Houck, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: When Sex Education Promotes Values
description: ''Planned Parenthood Gets Limited Permit'' [Feb. 6] quotes Jerome Higgins as saying, ''Their whole thrust is to promote value-free sex education in the schools, which leads to promiscuity, which leads to pregnancy, which leads to abortion.'' As co-chairman of the education committee of Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, to which Mr. Higgins is referring, I suggest that if he would attend one of our education workshops or speak to any child or parent who has attended, he might be better informed.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Bravissimew!
description: When, some years ago, a movie called ''The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing'' came out, I was severely disappointed to discover that the title referred to a person, not an activity. What fulfillment, then, to happen upon DANCING WITH CATS (Chronicle, paper, $16.95), in whose marvelously silly photographs -- there are more than 90 of them -- men, women and children do just that. The book, by Burton Silver and Heather Busch, contains, in addition to those hilarious images, much helpful instruction for aspiring dancers with cats -- hints about picking up energy field vibrations, for instance, and tapping into the profound energy of feline peace. There are also practical tips from practitioners: Fred, for one, dresses up in striped tights and striped body paint, to which he adds a tail, to aid in his becoming a psychic extension of his cat, Fluff; Max, who wears Goth makeup, tight black leather pants and black nail polish, recommends visualization and mime to inspire his cat, Wiky; and Ivan, who wears practically nothing and dances with between one and five Abyssinians -- only Spike seems to have a name -- points out that when dancing with two cats, you must make sure that their tails are in opposing positions to balance positive and negative forces. Cynics might note that many of the dancing cats seem to be reacting to less esoteric stimuli, leaping to grab at a floating scarf or veil; extreme cynics might even suspect that some of the higher-leaping animals have simply been flung into the frame by an unseen hand. The latter will be comforted by a disclaimer that no cats were harmed in the making of this book. Silver lectures on feline energy-field dynamics, while Busch runs cat-dancing therapy workshops. Make of that what you will. Sarah Ferrell

title: Law Officers and Community Leaders Gather for a Meeting of the Minds on Police Brutality
description: Striking an uncharacteristically harmonious and conciliatory tone, longtime critics of the police like the Rev. Al Sharpton joined law enforcement officials from across New York State in a gathering yesterday to examine what could be done to combat police brutality.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  METZ, HAROLD
description: METZ-Harold. February 13, 1997. I treasure your memory and will love you always. Barbar

title: Future Shock
description: The Testament

title: What No School Can Do
description: College professors, even those at schools like Yale and Harvard (where I have taught), will tell you that many students (who typically come from middle-class suburban schools) cannot write well or think critically. If middle-class communities in this country, with all their economic resources, are failing to produce well-educated young people, how can we expect communities lacking in these resources to produce such results?

title: L.A.P.D. Blues
description: A brutal police corruption scandal that had largely been contained to one anti-gang unit is now threatening to engulf the Los Angeles Police Department, with the district attorney having declared for the first time that the investigation has broadened to other police divisions and that the police have been dragging their feet.

title: The View From/Rye; In the Name of a Saint, Blessing the Throat
description: KASEY RYAN'S mother survived throat cancer; now Ms. Ryan, 42, is particularly conscious of that part of the body. And so, every year on Feb. 3, she receives a special blessing, for that is the feast day of St. Blaise, who is said, among other things, to be able to cure diseases of the throat. A priest holds two unlighted candles in the X-shape of a St. Andrew's Cross against her neck and invokes the intercession of the saint.

title: A Working Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Working Out the Kinks, Publicly and Very Painfully
description: EVEN though Playwrights Theater has a mission, the premature production of a double bill titled ''Fathers and Sons'' suggests that it may also have a motive.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: JOURNALISM never seemed so glamorous. Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman make the Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein look great as they uncover the Watergate scandal in Alan J. Pakula's ALL THE PRESIDENT'S MEN (1976). It's a political drama (presidential downfall), a detective story (clues galore) and a thriller (you remember Deep Throat). Jason Robards won the best supporting actor Osca as The Post's editor Ben Bradlee. William Goldman won for his screenplay, too - Sunday at noon on the History Channel.

title: Company Cited in Fatal Collapse
description: A Brooklyn contracting company has been cited for violating federal safety standards at a Williamsburg construction site where an accident in November killed one worker and injured 11.

title: Rock Wall Has an Unwanted Alpine Climate
description: The indoor recreational mountain climbing wall on Broadway and 62nd Street was intended to be rugged in terrain, not in climate.

title: Ignorance Is Bliss, My Vacuous Valentine
description: LOVE is swell, but unless it comes equipped with a constant sense of rediscovery it can get stale faster than an 89-cent loaf of bread. You should always be learning things about your significant other -- ''Hon, you never told me you were in the Weather Underground'' or, ''You had what kind of implants?''

title: Maria Paasche, 90, Helped Jews in Germany Flee Nazis
description: Maria Paasche, who helped Jews escape from Nazi Germany on the back of her motorcycle and whose father and brothers conspired to kill Hitler, died Jan. 21 in a San Francisco nursing home. She was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, EMANUEL M.
description: HECHT-Emanuel M., of New York, White Plains and Lincroft, NJ, died on February 2nd at age 90. Mac was a compassionate listener and energetic helper and lived his strong belief that giving is better than receiving. His many friends and loving family will remember...and smile.

title: In Central Africa, Signs of Hope and Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Says Lewis Acted Only as a Peacekeeper
description: Lawyers representing the All-Pro linebacker Ray Lewis detailed today the step-by-step movements of the football star from the time he left a post-Super Bowl party at an Atlanta nightclub and minutes later became entangled in a street brawl that left two local men stabbed to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCHESE, FLORENCE (LEVINE)
description: MARCHESE-Florence (Levine) Schneider. Dearest Camp Ta-GoLa Friend-a lifetime of memories and laughter. I will miss you greatly and keep you in my heart always.-TTFN Ellie Levine Koslow Shuman

title: Daniel Egan, 84, Drug Fighter Known as 'Junkie Priest,' Dies
description: The Rev. Daniel Egan, whose tireless work in rehabilitating drug addicts brought him the nickname ''the Junkie Priest,'' died on Thursday at a hospital in Peekskill, N.Y. He was 84 and lived at the Graymoor Friary in Garrison, N.Y.

title: U.S. Court Can Be Large Family and Small World
description: It's a small world, that federal courthouse in Manhattan. Take all the interpersonal connections that surfaced in a recent hearing before Judge John F. Keenan.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Hicksville, N.Y.; Snug Houses, Giant Stores in Mid-Nassau
description: IF Hicksville, like so many other Long Island places, had an Indian name, it might be translated as ''place of many little houses and big stores'' in tribute to this solid, old-line, mid-Nassau County community's expanses of snug Cape Cods, split-levels and ranches, and its two retail giants.

title: Ancestral Voices That Speak to Racial Attitudes
description: HOW heartless it must seem to dismiss a play that struggles to unite us all, as it leaps onto lyric flights, spanning the ages with earnest compassion. Oh, never mind.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the arrest of 34 members of a community group known as the Universal Zulu Nation referred incorrectly to the status of their case. A judge dismissed all charges last month; he did not issue summonses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIES, JANE B.
description: DAVIES-Jane B. On February 9, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Lyn Davies. Loving sister of Warren Badger and his wife, Harriet Ann. Cherished aunt of Anne, David, Wayne and Wayne's wife, Karen. Fond grand-aunt of Stephen, Mark, Eric and Katie. Architectural historian and eminent scholar of A.J. Davis. Longtime rare book cataloguer at Columbia University. Rare friend to many. Private services to be arranged.

title: Layering It On
description: Fashion is about the many tastes and styles that make up its multifaceted magnetism. From the understated to the over-the-top, it was all on display last week on guests at the Seventh on Sixth collections for next winter. The style of fabulousness, seen on hippies in the 60's, in swinging London and on Japanese youth of the last decade, has moved back to New York. Many of those setting the pace are music-world celebrities, seated in the front rows in Bryant Park, but the look could also be seen in the standing-room sections, worn by those who follow their own personal way of dressing.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-13-00: Questions for Macy Gray; Soul Reviver
description: Q: You're 30, which is kind of late in the game for becoming a pop star, especially in an age of teen queens like Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera. What took so long?

title: Republicans to Test the Religious Right's Strength in South Carolina
description: There are not many states where a presidential candidate is asked -- by a teenager, no less -- whether God had called him to lead the country. But South Carolina is not the kind of place where religious issues hover silently beneath the surface, and the fervent campaign for the religious right is as likely to veer into predestination as it is into tax cuts.

title: Fractured Third Party
description: A Reform Party meeting yesterday turned into shouting matches and a scuffle as the Ross Perot faction retook control a day after Gov. Jesse Ventura broke with the party.

title: Anatomy Lesson
description: Unearthing the Past

title: It's Something New Under the Stars (And Looking Up)
description: THE new Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History brings us face to face with something commensurate to our capacity for wonder. Night and day, astronomers, astrophysicists and weekend stargazers behold awesome images of the unknown. Even reading about their exploits can give a person goose bumps.

title: What's a Nice Liberal Multimillionaire Doing In a Race Like This?
description: Jon S. Corzine has spent the last several months learning the difference between office politics and politics. In his previous line of work, at the investment firm of Goldman, Sachs, where he served as chairman and C.E.O. until early last year, Corzine was counted a master politician -- the kind of executive who understood the secret ambitions and fears of everyone around him. On Wall Street, being a good politician had a lot to do with being likable. Now, however, Corzine is running for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in New Jersey, a state whose politics do not typically reward amiability. Corzine's opponent is Jim Florio, the former governor of the state and a man who is, for good reason, invariably referred to as ''an ex-boxer.'' Last month, according to a news account, Florio fired his media adviser when the adviser refused to follow Florio's ''scorched-earth policy.''

title: Around Grand Central, New Office Towers And a 54-Floor Residence
description: IN 1994, when it still had eight years remaining on its lease at 245 Park Avenue, smack in the middle of the tony Grand Central area between 46th and 47th Streets, the investment banking firm of Bear Stearns & Company began looking for a new home, and soon its name was linked to sites from Times Square to the financial district.

title: Amid Campaign Hoopla, One Region Feels Left Out
description: Ethanol plays so large a role in the agricultural economy of Iowa that candidates campaigning before the January caucuses there, the first test of presidential aspirations, ignored the issue at their peril.

title: Building Dining Empires Partner by Partner and Dish by Dish
description: WHEN we think of restaurant conglomerates, we usually think fast-food franchises, the likes of McDonald's, Denny's and Taco Bell. But in recent years a different kind of mini-empire has emerged in Connecticut, usually the outgrowth of a single enterprise and the brain child of an entrepreneur whose goals are mostly local, not global.

title: Some Truths Are Not So Self-Evident
description: An American President is having an affair with a young woman who works for him. Newspapers publish rumors of their relationship, and scandal envelops the White House. Soon members of Congress are calling for his resignation.

title: Manhattan Transfer
description: Graffiti writers use graffiti as dogs use urine -to mark their territory. Their message is always the same: this neighborhood is a slum -- nobody is safe here. When another man from Massachusetts, William Bratton, succeeded in controlling graffiti writers, crime went down. William Weld wants to bring back graffiti. Does he also want to bring back crime?

title: Viewed From Below
description: To the Editor:

title: Longing For a Return To Value
description: NOT so long ago on Wall Street, as elsewhere, thrift was a virtue. Nowadays, it seems that only the highest-priced spread will do.

title: When an Aging Cupid's Arrows Can't Find Their Mark
description: SELMA WERNICK just got bad news: she has breast cancer. But at 75, she's learned to take the long view and a positive attitude.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''No Place for a Woman: A Life of Senator Margaret Chase Smith,'' by Janann Sherman, in The Times Book Review last Sunday included the book's erroneous attribution of a precedent to Senator Smith of Maine. She was not the first woman elected to the Senate without having first been appointed to complete an unexpired term. Gladys Pyle of South Dakota was elected, not appointed, for an unfinished term in 1938, 10 years before Senator Smith's election.

title: Out Front When Jazz Freed Itself
description: A GIVEN in much of the literature on jazz is that a player's sound on his instrument is an extension of his speaking voice, a clue to his personality. The pianist Paul Bley is an exception to this rule. In the 1960's, on albums like ''Footloose,'' with the bassist Steve Swallow and the drummer Pete LaRoca, and ''Closer,'' with Mr. Swallow and the drummer Barry Altschul, Mr. Bley trimmed the outsize emotions of that decade's jazz avant-garde to fit the more intimate setting of the piano trio -- a major contribution to jazz, though one initially drowned out by the angry rant of many of Mr. Bley's contemporaries on saxophone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIGER, EILENBERG, JEANETTE
description: KLIGER - EILENBERG - Jeanette. Formerly Professor of Comparative Literature and German and Associate Dean at Brooklyn College. Devoted wife of the late Samuel Kliger. Dear sister of Sophie B. Rothstein and the late Bertram Eilenberg. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, 11 AM. Interment private.

title: The Next President's Duty to Intervene
description: Sometime in the next president's term, civilians in a foreign country will be driven from their homes and massacred. We don't know where the trouble will start -- the Balkans, the Caucasus, central or western Africa, even the Indonesian archipelago -- but the results will be horrible, and they will be all over our television screens. The question is what, if anything, the president should do.

title: On Hazing at Vermont
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Campus Politics Young and Anarchic, the Angry Left Is Reborn in Mexico
