description: DURING the cold war, when Latin American leftists gravitated toward Communism, it was easy for them to identify their enemies: local military dictators or American corporate imperialists. They had an economic system to demonize -- capitalism -- and an alternative -- socialism --- to put in its place. And they had a playbook, written by Marx and Lenin and Fidel Castro, to guide their thinking and strategy.

title: Are You Now . . . ?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Chappaqua, First Potluck for the Clintons
description: IT was billed as a potluck supper to meet the new neighbors. That the neighbors in question were President Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton and their daughter, Chelsea, lent the evening considerably more cache than the usual Saturday night get-together.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People fled New York to come here, and once you've lived in a single-family house with your own backyard, you're basically not interested in moving back to what amounts to a Holiday Inn-like existence.''

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: N.F.L.'s Newest Line Is the Unemployment Line
description: It was late in the regular season, and the Buffalo Bills wide receiver Andre Reed, in one of many frustrating outbursts, said something prophetic to a small group of reporters. His words may be remembered for decades.

title: Peter Tripp, 73, Popular Disc Jockey
description: Peter Tripp, a popular disc jockey in New York in the late 1950's whose career peaked when he stayed awake for more than eight days as a stunt but later plunged when he was found guilty of accepting thousands of dollars in payola, died Jan. 31 in a hospital in Northridge, Calif. He was 73.

title: INSIDE
description: Evaluating Care for Disabled

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, STEPHEN M.
description: ROBERTS-Stephen M. One week ago today God welcomed you to His home. You will live on in our home, our safe haven always. Your unconditional love and friendship, your infectious optimism, sunny disposition and smile, your loyalty, boundless generosity will live on in my heart. Our time together, although too short, has provided me enough happiness to last a lifetime. The sun will shine forever through the window of my heart that you opened. Remember Tuesday. Our Love, Susan, Bubba and Blondie

title: A Former Rug Installer Takes On ABC Carpet
description: Donovan Byfield remembers the job in Chelsea, where the door to the apartment opened and the owner's German shepherd charged in and bit him as he was laying carpet.

title: A National Hero, National Mourning
description: FIRST is impressive. When George Washington died, he became America's first national hero and mourning became contagious. Around the country there was a swell of creative mourning -- draping homes with black crepe, wearing black, and then applying the new custom to personal mourning.

title: Finding a Cure for 'Angry Nurse' Syndrome
description: ON the brink of shutting down little more than two weeks ago, St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Smithtown is close to emerging under new ownership from what could be described as a near-death experience for the once-thriving community hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, RONALD
description: ROSEMAN-Ronald. We mourn the death of our colleague, teacher and friend. Superb oboist, consummate musician, talented composer, perceptive and dedicated teacher, and warm human being, Ronnie will be profoundly missed. We extend our sympathy to his mother, his wife, and his children. The faculty, staff and students Aaron Copland School of Music Queens College

title: Prescription Drugs Should Cost Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Creative Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: With Other Alternatives, Why Cut Bus Subsidy?
description: ''Missing the Bus'' [Jan. 30] did Nassau County residents a great favor by shedding light on the importance of bus service, not only for people who don't have cars but for the employers of Nassau County who rely on people who don't have cars.

title: Lives; The President and Me
description: ''As Mr. Clinton heads into the eighth and final year of his presidency, he is a blur of motion -- but he is also very alone. His only child is away at college. His wife has moved out to start a career of her own. His vice president is on the road seeking to become his successor. Left behind, at least, is Buddy, the Labrador, who now spends all night with the president when Hillary Rodham Clinton is away.'' -- The New York Times, Jan. 19, 2000

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS; When It's Nobody's Business but Your Own
description: ON Nov. 15 last year, Philip Tsitseklis, a Greek tourist shopping for sunglasses at Bloomingdale's in Manhattan, reported noticing a clerk swipe his credit card twice -- once through the cash register and once through a hand-held scanning device she had taken from her pocket.

title: Life in Itta Bena
description: Boy With

title: Political Briefing; Brouhaha Over Visit By George Bush
description: The Democratic leader of the Florida Senate, Buddy Dyer, has never been on very good political terms with the state's governor, Jeb Bush, George W.'s brother. So as the senator tells it, when he learned 10 days ago that the Bush boys' father, former President George Bush, would be making a speech to the State Legislature on March 9, he concluded that some partisan politicking was afoot and called on fellow Democrats, as well as fair-minded Republicans, to boycott the affair.

title: Adjusted Auction Fees
description: Faced with class-action lawsuits and a three-year-old antitrust investigation into possible collusion between Sotheby's and Christie's, the world's two largest auction houses, Christie's said it was changing its fees. The English-based house has raised its buyer's commissions, charging 17.5 percent on the first $80,000 and 10 percent of any amount over that. Since 1993 both Christie's and its archrival Sotheby's charged buyers 15 percent for the first $50,000 and 10 percent for everything after that.

title: Hair Dryer and Microscope As Weapons Against Lice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSDORF, GEORGE
description: WALSDORF-George. Age 50 years, died February 11, 2000, in Rome Memorial Hospital, Rome, NY. He was born March 21, 1949; the son of Murray and Fannie Wyoukark Walsdorf. Last known to have resided in NYC. Will any kin or anyone knowing any next of kin contact Central NY D.S.O. collect at 315-336-2300, regarding any special funeral arrangements.

title: Looking at a Company For the Stocks It Owns
description: VALUE isn't necessarily an oxymoron in the highflying technology sector.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: LITTLE BO: The Story of Bonnie Boadicea. By Julie Andrews Edwards. Illustrated by Henry Cole. Hyperion. $16.99. (Ages 7 and up) A rich woman's prize Persian cat has a litter of kittens on the wrong side of the blanket. The runt, named Boadicea but called Little Bo, is eventually adopted by a sailor and sets off for a perilous life at sea. It's an old-fashioned story of bicycle-riding butlers, snowy country lanes and small fishing boats, told and illustrated with great charm. And yes, the author is also the well-known (as Julie Andrews) actress and singer.

title: Sports of The Times; Landry Was in Control As Cowboys' Coach
description: HE was known as Ol' Stone Face, and on the sideline it was easy to see why. However well or poorly the Dallas Cowboys were playing, Coach Tom Landry's expression under his snap-brim fedora never changed. But that's the way he wanted it.

title: If It's Air Force One, It Must Be Sit and Wait
description: THE Clintons are far from being the first couple to commute to a home in the suburbs, but the regular comings and goings of the president and his family in Westchester has added a new dimension to the already busy airport here.

title: Nervous Nassau Faces Cuts in Its Bond Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service put Nassau County on notice last week that it may downgrade the county's short- and long-term bonds. The warning came a month after another major agency, Standard & Poor's, gave Nassau one month to develop a financial recovery plan or face further drops in its rating. The services currently rate Nassau's long-term bonds just two notches above noninvestment grade, and borrowing costs rise when bond ratings fall.

title: Two Take Differing Tacks In a Sea of Gore Support
description: With the lopsided support of Democratic Party loyalists here, Vice President Al Gore rallied his party today with a sweeping condemnation of Bill Bradley as a quitter and a pessimist, a former senator who has run down the party and is not a real Democrat.

title: A Setback in North Ireland After Delay in Disarmament
description: Only 10 weeks after it began, the power-sharing government of Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland was halted, stymied by the continuing conflict over the issue of paramilitary weapons. Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson said he acted because the Irish Republican Army refused to give any sign that it was going to dismantle its arsenal. He expected the government to return ''on an even firmer footing,'' he said, if the long-running dispute could be resolved.

title: Complete Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APTAKIN, TOBIE
description: APTAKIN-Tobie. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Frances Aptakin and Suzanne and Richard Holwitt. Loving grandmother of David and Ben. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, Sunday 12:30PM.

title: Judah Defeats Bergman for Title
description: Using blinding speed, elusive defense and punishing power, Zab Judah demolished Jan Bergman to win the International Boxing Federation junior welterweight championship last night at the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, Conn.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; State Expected to Change Affordable Housing Law
description: THE General Assembly is expected to enact changes in Connecticut's 11-year-old Affordable Housing Appeals Law in April, based on recommendations made earlier this month by Gov. John G. Rowland's Commission to Study Affordable Housing.

title: Trained to Be Wild
description: The stereotype about theatrical couples is that their lives are as dramatic offstage as on: nightly debauches, unconventional menages, bitter rivalries sheathed in endearments. When the spotlight dimmed, the Lunts apparently fought like the Kramdens. But Taye Diggs and Idina Menzel live like athletes in training, or seminarians. One night, between late rehearsals and a preview performance of ''The Wild Party'' -- the first of two new musicals this season that are based on the notorious 1928 Joseph Moncure March poem -- they outlined their typical day. Wake up. Check to see if their voices still work. Tea, hot cereal, morning news. Then to the gym (separate gyms). Rehearse all day. Dinner break. Warm up the voice. Perform. Eat again. Rush home to bed. Watch a movie, at most. Repeat as directed.

title: Back in Time In Old Beijing
description: IT is still possible, just barely, to get a glimpse of what daily life for Beijingers was like at the last turn of the century. You can't do it by touring the Forbidden City or by competing for dubious antiques in the ersatz Qing dynasty market of Liulichang. But you can by taking a relaxed stroll through one of the city's oldest residential quarters, near the string of willow-lined lakes to the northwest of the Forbidden City above Beihai Park.

title: Meghan Harris, Michel Zeisser
description: Meghan St. Clair Harris, a daughter of Joan and Don V. Harris Jr. of Washington, was married there yesterday to Michel Pierre Zeisser, the son of Ute and Leon Zeisser of Lutterbach, France. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Georgetown.

title: Heartburn
description: THE DANGEROUS PASSION

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-13-00: The Ethicist; Docu-Drama
description: After working as an assistant on a documentary about gay and lesbian issues, I interviewed for a job with a conservative company. I described my duties on the film but avoided mentioning its subject. My hollow rationalization was that since I'm not gay, I wasn't betraying my identity, and that it was senseless to jeopardize my chances for this job by bringing up something controversial. But now I'm afraid that I treated homosexuality as shameful and secretive. Still, since the film's subject wasn't germane to my qualifications for the job, was it necessary to bring it up? -Anonymous, Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGAL, VIVIAN
description: SIEGAL-Vivian. The Board of Directors and Staff of the 92nd Street Y mourn the passing of Vivian W. Siegal, our dear friend and esteemed board member for over 40 years. Her years of commitment to the 92nd Street Y are deeply appreciated. Our hearts and prayers go out to Vivian's brother Leonard Weiner, son and daughter-in-law, Frederick P. and Marta Siegal, daughter and son-inlaw, Marian and Jack Krauskopf, as well as beloved grandchildren David, Nina, Lewis and Katie. She will be missed by all who knew her. Philip Milstein, President Joseph Leff, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director

title: Shannon Johnson, Gregg Honigblum
description: Shannon Zoe Johnson, a daughter of Jane Wulsin of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., and Stephen Johnson of Gainesville, Fla., was married last evening to Gregg Richard Honigblum, a son of Elaine Honigblum of San Antonio and the late Jay Honigblum. Rabbi Monty Eliasov officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Austin, Tex.

title: A Realtor Finds a Niche, Gay Couples Find Homes
description: When Mark Hoebee and Larry Elardo decided two years ago that is was time to leave Manhattan for the suburbs, they wanted a place where a gay family could feel at home. A quick search on the Internet led them to Jaan Henry, whose agency these days lists and sells about 40 houses a year and boasts sales of $8 million to $12 million.

title: SOAPBOX; The Road More Traveled
description: I USED to dread the turnpike portion of my drive down to Maryland, where my parents live. The lack of hairpin turns and breathtaking landmarks was mind-deadening, and I had to resort to tricks like chewing gum and pinching myself to stay alert. But now I'm grateful for the ability to turn on cruise control and glide along the tracks of my thoughts.

title: A Family and a Museum Seek the Same Bucolic Home
description: A family of six is locked in a battle with a small museum over the right to buy a house that has a view of New York Harbor and is nestled in a city park.

title: By the Numbers
description: I have no problem ordering my food by menu number, but with time the charm of Extra Value Meal No. 2 wears thin. Thankfully, there are places where every sandwich, regardless of number, tastes like a perfect 10. Such a place is Jerome Scott's, a working caterer's kitchen that delivers meals each day to numerous office parks around Morris County. But you don't have to have a corporate account to sate your hunger here. You just have to make up your mind.

title: Children's Books; Gravel for Dessert
description: Sascha and Iguana and I have run away to Key West. Sascha is 4, I am not, and Iguana is the heroine of THE NIGHT IGUANA LEFT HOME, by Megan McDonald, illustrated by Ponder Goembel (Richard Jackson/DK Ink, $15.95; ages 5 and up), a book we are reading in the shade of an ylang-ylang tree. Iguana's story is a familiar one: she was living contentedly in Schenectady, N.Y., at the home of her ''friend and almost sister,'' Alison Frogley, who provided a closet with a heating pad, a free library card, a personal e-mail address and plenty of anchovy pizza. Nonetheless, Iguana began to peel and crack and droop. Then she noticed a poster in Alison's room: ''Key West.'' ''Florida! No passport necessary!'' she thought. ''Iguana woke up the next morning and added an n to her name. Iguanna, she scrawled, in cursive, in the steam on the bathroom mirror. Then she kissed it.'' Then, having spiked her hair, she took the bus south. ''For a short time, Iguana lived the high life. . . . She ate snails and caviar, papaya and mustard greens, hibiscus flowers. And gravel for dessert.'' Alas, it ended as unconsidered flights to Key West so often do. The money ran out, and Iguana had to wash dishes in a restaurant. One night, she realized that Gallina de Palo on the menu meant iguana stew. She swam for her life up the keys to Big Pine, where she found a job licking ''60 stamps a minute'' at the post office. A few days later Iguana mailed herself safely back to Alison's house in Schenectady, where they stuffed themselves with anchovy pizza. Nowadays, Alison mails Iguana to Key West in a very long (six and a half feet) box containing a heart-shaped pillow embroidered Iguanna, and twice a year Iguana mails herself back for a visit with her true friend. Sascha is a little young for some of the more sophisticated bits (she perfectly understood the hair spiking, but was confused by the idea of gravel for dessert), but it doesn't matter. This enchanting book, marvelously written (and obviously thoroughly researched) by McDonald, and gloriously illustrated by Goembel (Iguana surfing is a masterpiece), is destined to become for Key West what ducklings are to Boston and Eloise is to New York. Jane O'Reilly

title: Style and Entertaining; The Art Of the Meal
description: It's the fate of all New York hostesses. An hour before any midday conviviality can begin, the phone rings, and rings again.

title: Court Reporters Hear the Tap, Tap, Tap of Obsolescence
description: EU

title: Children's Books
description: LANCELOT

title: Anne Meara: The Right Touch
description: NOW are the times (count them) to honor Arthur Garden for his metaphysical writings on alternative realities, alternate routes, infinite horizons, infinite probabilities, probable paths. Whatever. Perhaps you'd like to settle for his mother's description of the, er, quantum theories of her famous intellectual son, the science writer, amateur juggler and public television host. ''Shoulda, woulda, coulda,'' or ''some other somewhere,'' Stella Garden calls them, not that she's read Arthur's best seller under any title, in any time.

title: POSTINGS: Former Showroom in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Is Turned Into 27 Rental Apartments; Old Studebaker Building Has New Tenants
description: Alfred Thompson never owned a Studebaker. But Mr. Thompson, a Brooklyn-based developer, has long been a fan of the distinctive, futuristically designed car, which ceased being made in the 1960's -- and of the five-story Studebaker building at Bedford Avenue and Sterling Place that once housed offices and a big-windowed showroom.

title: Mixing the Personal And the Professional
description: To the Editor:

title: George Koltanowski, 96, Chess Master Known for Playing While Blindfolded
description: George Koltanowski, an international chess master and author who excelled at beating opponents without looking at the board, died Feb. 5 in a hospital in San Francisco. He was 96.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-13-00; Crack Country
description: There wasn't much to do where I grew up, out in Minnesota dairy country. A mini-mart, a theater, two bars and, on fall Friday nights, a football game followed by a kegger at the lake. In one way, though, my friends and I had everything: acid, pot, speed, pills and even cocaine. Bought at the kitchen table of a farmhouse whose windows were sheets of plastic hung with tacks, then consumed in our cars on gravel county roads. Where were the cops? At the diner, all two or three of them, eating cherry pie.

title: Grandmother, Nude Photos And Charges
description: When does a 65-year-old social worker, doting grandmother and published photographer become a child pornographer? Law-enforcement officials say that Marian Rubin of Montclair crossed the line between the legitimate and the lascivious when she snapped a roll of pictures that captured her two granddaughters, ages 4 and 6, without clothing, their genitalia exposed.

title: Al Gore Moves Beyond Meta
description: Gore is a well-informed policy wonk, indistinguishable from thousands of others but for his role as partisan apologist for the Clinton administration. Remember how poorly he did when he ran on his own in 1988? Tight, humorless and dour, he is a candidate who paints by numbers. His debt to organized labor and special-interest minority groups will ill serve the nation should he become president.

title: Melissa Baron, Robert Gordon
description: Melissa Beth Baron, a daughter of Ellen and Richard Baron of South Setauket, N.Y., is to be married today to Robert Seth Gordon, a son of Natalie and Jules Gordon of Oceanside, N.Y. Rabbi Moshe Edelman will perform the ceremony at Temple B'nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Redeemed by Language
description: Assia Djebar is an Algerian novelist who was educated in France, and her sweeping and impressionistic new novel, SO VAST THE PRISON (Seven Stories, $24.95), is about cross-cultural conflict -- it takes us into the life of an educated Algerian woman who is caught between traditional Islamic mores and her longing for a more modern, European way of life. When Isma, who is 37 and married, has an affair with a younger man, her husband not only beats her but attempts to blind her. Fighting a sense of overwhelming imprisonment, Isma eventually abandons her marriage and becomes a filmmaker, savoring a taste of freedom in her middle age. (She attains, at least in part, her adolescent desire for ''not happiness but joy.'') She has escaped the ''community of women shut away yesterday and today'' -- the women of Islam, who are ''completely veiled in white cloth'' -- and gained the power to gaze back at them through the camera's lens. Djebar breaks up Isma's story with detours into Algerian history, in particular the story of Tin Hinan, ''the fugitive princess, who made her way into the very heart of the desert of deserts,'' and ends with a lament for modern Algeria, a land of ''dark, incomprehensible deaths.'' Her novel, ably translated from the French by Betsy Wing, deliberately confuses time and character to stress the timelessness of its themes, notably the hardships faced by women, the oppressions of colonialism and the redemptive power of language and writing. Djebar's prose can occasionally seem overwrought, but her often elliptical style effectively transmits the potent feeling of dislocation at the heart of Isma's story. Erik Burns

title: Climber for the Ages Has the Next Peak in View
description: Ed Viesturs, clad in a charcoal sweater and jeans, stood chatting with acquaintances last Monday evening in a corner of the chapelesque auditorium of the Society for Ethical Culture on West 64th Street, shortly before he would present a slide show to an standing-room crowd on his exploits as a mountaineer. A beefy, twenty-something man dressed for success in a smart wool topcoat shouldered his way through the growing throng and inserted himself in front of Viesturs. ''Hey dude, sorry to interrupt,'' he interrupted. ''But you are, like, the man, you are, like, totally awesome.''

Operated by Atria, a company in Louisville, Ky., the building is intended for well-off elderly residents who have no medical need for a nursing home but may require some help taking care of themselves.

James Karwisch, a director with the Missoula Children's Theater program, explained how the auditions, the following workshops and rehearsal, and performance would go. In the lobby, youngsters lined up for a lesson in stage marching, while Daria Kryova covered her ears as some of her colleagues tested their voice projection skills. Khaliah Kendrick, top left, tried out a line for the play, which was a country and western adaption of the ''Beauty and the Beast'' fairy tale.

When the leaders of each country recently wanted to send a message to one another after the breakdown of peace talks, they used their own ''shouting valley.'' It is called Lebanon.

Located in Great Neck at 37 Cutter Mill Road (516-504-7600), it is a reflection of the rich and growing ethnic diversity there. At least half of its customers are Iranian Jews who have immigrated to this area in recent years. They come to Darvish in large family groups, arriving rather late in the evening. At 7:45 on a recent Saturday night, the restaurant was empty, but by 9 things began to hum.

description: PROSHANSKY-Etta W. Age 74, of New York, NY, and Redding, CT, suddenly on February 12. Her 35 years of professional life were dedicated to early childhood education. She began as a classroom teacher, then became a staff developer and later Director of Early Childhood Education and Staff Development in District 3 of Manhattan. After retirement from the NYC Board of Education, she continued as advisor in the Educational Leadership Department at the Graduate School of the Bank Street College of Education. She was the wife of the late Harold M. Proshansky, former President of the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. Mother of Eric and Ellen, both of New York City, and grandmother of Kate and Lucas. Etta lived life to the fullest in the company of friends and family who loved her a lot. A memorial gathering will be held at her home on Saturday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Benign Essential Blepharospasm Research Foundation, P.O. Box 12468, Beaumont, TX 77726-2468.

title: New York's Missing Facilities
description: A decade would seem to be an excessive amount of time to wait for public toilets in New York City. But as Clyde Haberman reminded us in Friday's Times, this somewhat mysterious delay has left many New Yorkers and perhaps even more tourists stranded without some of the most basic facilities of a civilized world. Several mayors have circled this problem but never found a solution. The plan that disappeared about three years ago under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's watch would have added toilets to small public oases around the city, where a visitor could use the phone, buy a newspaper, wait for the bus or use a modern outdoor privy.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Feb. 1 about an auction of early medical texts misstated the historic place of a work by Gaspare Tagliacozzi, ''Surgery for the Mutilated Through Grafting.'' Printed in 1597, it was among the first books about plastic surgery in the West, but it was preceded by the Sushruta Samhita, an Indian medical treatise begun in the last centuries B.C. and completed in the seventh century A.D.

title: Heady Days When Words Led to Death
description: Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of the famous duel between Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr was that it took place at all. Tonight's ''American Experience'' notes that challenges in matters of honor were not unknown among politicians in the Revolutionary era. (Hamilton was involved in 11 of them.) But by and large they were settled without bloodshed. The point seems to have been to advertise one's courage without undue risk.

Trump has decided to end his brief and flamboyant exploration of a run for president, concluding that the Reform Party, whose support he had sought, was so beset by internal fighting that he would have no chance of winning the White House as its nominee, his associates said last night.

title: U.S. Colleges Attempt to Redress Gender Balance : Men Go Missing on Campus
description: WASHINGTON  Where have all the young men gone? The question was a line in a popular antiwar song of the 1960s, and it is a refrain that college admissions directors are singing a lot these days as they ponder the growing feminization of colleges and universities in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVACK, JOHN D.
description: SPIVACK-John D. 80, passed away December 23, 1999, in Suffern, NY, after a long struggle with Alzheimer's disease. He received his Ph.D. in chemistry from McGill in 1947, married, emigrated to the United States, and became a loving father to three children. He worked for thirty-six years for Ciba Geigy Corporation in Ardsley, NY, on light stabilizers and antioxidants and was considered an international expert in the field, credited with over 125 patents. He was politically active throughout his life, and culturally involved in Yiddish language and cultural activities. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Thelma Goresky Spivack of Chestnut Ridge, NY; two sisters, Ruth Rubin and Esther Marks; three children, Berel, Ellen and Simon; as well as three grandchildren, Daniel, Jordan and Jacqueline. Private services were held at the family home. Donations to the Alzheimer's and Parkinson's foundations are appreciated.

title: Britain's Health Care, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Bassist and Drummer Make the Right Connection
description: Christian McBride

title: Rafalski Leads Offense, And Devils Trap Sharks
description: No one around the Devils is surprised at the offensive efficiency displayed by the rookie defenseman Brian Rafalski. The Devils said they knew from the first week of training camp that the 26-year-old had the ability to carry the puck out of the defensive zone and be creative at the other end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, ALMA
description: MARSHALL-Alma (nee Cohen). February 12, 2000, aged 103, peacefully in her sleep after a brief illness. Juilliard graduate, with a lifelong passion for music, who taught piano and sang in the Metropolitan Opera chorus when she was young. Proud and devoted mother and mother-in-law of Jill and Richard Gallen, proud and loving grandmother (and grandmother-in-law) of Jonathan and Amy Gallen and David Gallen, ecstatic great-grandmother of Hannah and Samuel Gallen. Graveside service 2 PM, Tuesday, February 15, Salem Fields Cemetery, Cypress Hills, Brooklyn. Family will receive visitors Tuesday after 7 PM at home. May the Lord bless you and keep you, and cause the light of His countenance to shine upon you.

title: South Koreans Link Bullying to 'Pressure-Cooker' Society
description: SEOUL  The pressures of social change, rigidly competitive testing, rapid industrialization and overcrowding are turning adolescence into a mad dash for success in South Korea. While the strongest go to college or find steady jobs in factories, shops and stores, the weakest struggle to survive.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''So the Reform Party now includes a Klansman, Mr. Duke, a neo-Nazi, Mr. Buchanan, and a communist, Ms. Fulani. This is not company I wish to keep.''

title: Covering the Campaigns for the Citizen-Browser
description: EVERY reporter who has ever dreamed of a world without editors might see Jacob Weisberg as a man who has achieved nirvana. Every libertarian Internetophile who believes that the World Wide Web will democratize information might see Mr. Weisberg, Slate magazine's leading political correspondent, as the man to unlock the medium's revolutionary potential.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCH, LOUIS
description: KIRSCH-Louis. Beloved husband of Ethel (nee Margolin); devoted father of Joan and Nancy; cherished grandfather of Ezra and Grayson. His sense of humor will be greatly missed. The family will receive friends at his home.

title: Worn Part Found In '97 on Jet in Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said that Alaska Airlines found a part of the tail assembly on the jet that crashed last month to be worn in a September 1997 inspection. But the board said the airline later decided the part was good enough to keep in use.

title: Zigzag in Jakarta: General Is Suspended
description: President Abdurrahman Wahid on Sunday backed away from his demand for the resignation of his defiant security minister, General Wiranto, then turned around hours later and suspended him.

title: Accent Provincialism
description: To the Editor:

title: Omnicom Unit Buys Agency in Canada
description: The Interbrand Group in New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group that specializes in corporate and brand identity consulting services, has expanded into Canada by acquiring Tudhope Associates in Toronto, a strategic design agency. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHORODZANER, CHAIM
description: BOHORODZANER-Chaim. Young Israel of Jamaica Estates is deeply saddened and mourns the loss of our esteemed member, Chaim Bohorodzaner. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shlomo Hochberg, Rabbi Jay Grunfeld, President

title: Kozmo.com and Starbucks Enter Marketing Deal
description: February 14, 2000

title: New Wave in Angola's War Ends Moment of Hope
description: The astonishing news crackled over the radios in this crumbling town of faded colonial mansions and rolling green hills. One by one, the radio announcer said, the nearby rebel strongholds were falling into government hands.

title: Seeking the Spiritual Core
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra, just past the midway point in its season-long survey of the 20th-century orchestral literature, brought Bartok's Third Piano Concerto and Henryk Gorecki's Third Symphony to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening in a concert conducted by Wolfgang Sawallisch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODKIND, LOUIS W.
description: GOODKIND-Louis W., Esq. Of Irvington, NY; born St. Paul, MN, August 29, 1914, died at his home on February 13, 2000. He is survived by his wife, Carol Eaton Bourquin Goodkind, his three daughters, Barbara Pepper, Mary Goodkind Garner and Kathryn Goodkind Boyle, and his stepchildren, Philip F. Eaton and Dorothee Bourquin Caulfield, and his five grandsons and one great-granddaughter. Visiting will be at the Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (Exit 17 Saw Mill), in Dobbs Ferry, NY, on Wednesday, February 16, 2000, 7 PM until 9 PM. Funeral mass will be on Thursday, February 17, 2000, at 10 AM. Burial service will be private. In lieu of flowers please send conributions to either The Community Hospital at Dobbs Ferry or the Irvington Volunteer Ambulance Corps.

title: A Lively, Star-Filled Evening Of Weill
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's monthlong celebration of the centenary of Kurt Weill's birth builds to serious business with a film festival beginning on Thursday and a production of ''Der Weg der Verheissung'' (''The Eternal Road''), an epic musical and theatrical interpretation of Jewish history, on Feb. 28. But the opening program, ''Weill Style,'' conceived by Ken Bloom and presented on Thursday evening in the academy's Opera House, was mostly a delightful lark.

title: Soft Money Sets Off Rivals' Hard Words
description: After a tense stretch of harsh attacks and paradoxical resolutions to run their campaigns on positive tracks, Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain used their appearances on Sunday television news programs today to take renewed aim at each other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERTZ, IRMA
description: GERTZ-Irma. Beloved mother of Jeffrey and the late Betsy. Loving grandmother. Devoted daughter of Ruth Isserman. Sister of Ferdinand Isserman Jr. Graveside services today, 1 PM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions to the Kolman Foundation for Breast Cancer, PO Box 97100, Dallas, TX 75397.

title: Giuliani Vows More Attention To Upstate Vote
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said during a brief trip to Long Island yesterday that he would eventually spend more time in upstate New York campaigning for United States Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNNING, WINIFRED WITTMANN
description: LUNNING-Winifred Wittmann. On January 23, 2000, at home. Wife of the late Just Lunning. Mother of Frederick and Elizabeth. Sister of Otto Wittmann.

title: Churning on Campaign Reform
description: Americans looking for progress this election year on the issue of campaign finance reform got some conflicting signals last week. Proclaiming himself a ''reformer with results,'' Gov. George Bush accused Senator John McCain of hypocrisy for accepting donations from political action committees and lobbyists. This was clearly an effort to find some flaw in Mr. McCain's reputation as a reformer. It was also, in a backhanded way, a tribute to Mr. McCain's efforts to illuminate the issue, as well as further evidence that the issue has begun to appeal to voters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLISON, BILLY GENE
description: ALLISON-Billy Gene. 67. Family and friends deeply mourn his passing on February 12. Following a distinguished U.S. Army career, his interest in physical conditioning and exercise led him to become a personal trainer in NYC with a large and loyal following. Known for his rapier wit and love of words, he was also a dedicated outdoorsman and experienced woodsman. In addition to his loving companion, Holly Drew of NY, he is survived by his mother, Verna Allison of Overland Park, KS; by a daughter Cynthia Jangel and her family, Jeff, Allison and Scott of Claremont, NH; and by two sisters, Barbara and Cheryl, and a brother, Roger. Services will be held in Claremont, NH. A memorial service will be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls at 1157 Lexington Ave., NYC, on Sunday, February 20, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the national or a local chapter of the Humane Society.

title: Church and State
description: To the Editor:

title: The Push for Patients' Rights
description: Last year, the Senate and House approved vastly different patients' rights bills. After months of delay, a conference committee will meet later this month to reconcile the differences. It is crucial that any compromise bill apply to all insured Americans and give them a meaningful right to sue health plans for damages incurred when care is improperly denied.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, FLORENCE
description: LEFF-Florence (nee Siegel). Formerly of Merrick, Long Island, passed away February 12, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Cherished mother of Barbara (Arlene K. Singer) and the late Roberta Leff. Beloved aunt of Debbie, Eileen and Alan. She was a ''Grande Dame'' who knew how to enjoy life and lived it to the fullest. The world is a sadder place as a result of her passing. Chapel service Monday, February 14, 2:15 PM, at Star of David Cemetery & Funeral Chapel, 7701 Bailey Road, North Lauderdale, 954-722-9000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, BERTHA
description: JACOBSON-Bertha. On February 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Loving mother of Lorraine Podell and her husband Herbert, Gary Jacobson, and the late Audrey Jacobson. Cherished grandmother of Pamela and Allison Podell. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Race Declines In Importance In Board Search For Chancellor
description: Harold O. Levy was an unusual choice as New York City's interim schools chancellor, and not only because he was a banking executive with little educational experience. Unlike all but one of the previous seven chancellors, who were black or Hispanic, Mr. Levy is white.

title: Refresher Course for the Last 50 Years
description: At the intermission of ''Our Place in Time'' the other night, a woman turned to theatergoers standing beside her and asked brightly, in a tone that suggested no one had ever thought of this before, ''Is there anyone here who doesn't know where they were when Kennedy was shot?'' That's just the kind of originality that went into this play.

title: INSIDE
description: Worn Jet Part Found in '97

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLIN, CHARLES
description: COLIN-Charles. On February 7, 2000. Beloved trumpet luminary, renowned publisher of Brass and Jazz Methods; founder of the NY Brass Conference for Scholarships. A Memorial Concert by the Empire Brass Quintet will highlight the 28th Annual Brass Conference on Sunday, April 2, at NYC's Lighthouse Conference Center. NY Brass Conference for Scholarships

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Pacific Islands Seek Control Of Internet Designations
description: The 49 residents of Pitcairn Island, a British territory in the South Pacific, are proud descendants of the infamous Bounty mutineers. So perhaps it is fitting that they are now leading a mutiny of sorts on the Internet -- a rebellion of the little guys that has already spread to one other Pacific island and is expected to grow among the tiny nations and territories worldwide.

title: A Gift to Staten Island?
description: To the Editor:

title: TERM LIMITS BRING WHOLESALE CHANGE INTO LEGISLATURES
description: As term limits gradually take effect in 18 state legislatures across the country, the time strictures so popular with voters are turning seasoned leaders from office, nipping political careers and prompting unusual party maneuvers.

title: Albany and Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: For Bradley Campaign, Contest for Democratic Nomination Has Become a Three-Way Race
description: In a speech to California Democrats on Saturday, former Senator Bill Bradley had just reached the part where he usually contrasts himself with Vice President Al Gore when he swerved into new territory and began drawing distinctions with a Republican, Senator John McCain of Arizona.

title: Criminal Justice Breakdown
description: The gruesome problems in the criminal justice system that have been overlooked for so many years are starting to burst into public view, and the system is breaking down in some parts of the country.

title: A Soprano Who's at Home With Speed and Fun
description: Lynette Tapia, soprano

title: Patents; An inventor makes good on a third-grade notion.
description: IN 1985, when Tahira Reid was in third grade at Public School 97 in the Bronx, she dreamed up an invention that would allow her to double-dutch jump-rope even when she couldn't find two friends to swing twin ropes in eggbeater fashion. Her poster drawing of the hypothetical double-dutch machine won her a first prize in a schoolwide competition.

title: Head of a Core AT&T Unit To Leave After Year on Job
description: Barely a year after joining AT&T, H. Eugene Lockhart, president of the company's core consumer unit, intends to step down, executives close to the company said yesterday. An announcement of Mr. Lockhart's departure is expected today, the executives said.

title: For the Reds, a Faustian Bargain
description: Even at 30 years old, Ken Griffey Jr. still has a smile fit for a prom king, broad and beaming. He donned the billed crown of the Cincinnati Reds the other day and grinned and it was all feel-good: hometown kid eschews the biggest dollars to sign with his hometown team.

title: Paul Robeson Girls Take Brooklyn Title
description: Paul Robeson High School, with four individual winners, won the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League girls' team title yesterday with 86 points. South Shore was runner-up with 83 points in the competition at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan.

title: Data Offer A Head Count In Health Care
description: For the first time, consumers can learn how often a particular doctor or hospital in New York performs a certain type of surgery, in what consumer advocates call an important step toward arming patients with the information they need to shop for health care.

title: MediaTalk; Investor Quandary for Internet Magazine
description: The Industry Standard is the fastest-growing publications in the Internet field. Advertising is up by more than 400 percent in the last year. Times are good.

title: The Patriarch as Pariah; Embracing McCain, Molinari Finds Loyalty Has Its Limits
description: According to the natural rhythms of political life, this should be a time of reflection and joy for Guy V. Molinari. At 71, the Republican patriarch should be gathering his proteges around him to share lessons from three decades of public service, to reminisce about presidents he has known.

title: World Bank Unit to Join In Internet Start-Up Finance
description: The Internet, with English as its dominant language and the United States its dominant backer and beneficiary, has created a digital divide, with some poor nations watching from afar as the World Wide Web transforms commerce and creates vast new sources of wealth in the developed countries.

title: Lord Kitchener, 77, Calypso Songwriter Who Mixed Party Tunes With Deeper Messages
description: Lord Kitchener, whose sly wit and graceful melodies made him one of Trinidad's most beloved calypso songwriters, died on Friday at a hospital in Port of Spain, Trinidad. He was 77 and lived in Diego Martin, just outside Port of Spain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROZOVSKY, LEV
description: GROZOVSKY-Lev. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Men's Club and Couples Club, mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member, Ilya Grozovsky, and extend their heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Taking Virgin's Brand Into Internet Territory; Richard Branson Says the Web Is Ready for His Style of Business
description: Richard Branson was fiddling with one of his new Virgin-branded mobile telephones in the living room of his Notting Hill town house here last week.

title: It's Mardi Gras Time With Battle Songs for Partying
description: Wild Magnolias

title: Islanders Break Out At Bad Time For Rangers
description: Despite their poor play against the Islanders last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers still had a chance to tie the score late in the second period. The wings on their Czech line had both scored and now its center, Petr Nedved, streaked in on Kevin Weekes in the Islanders' net.

title: Feminists' Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Teligent Is Said to Forge Link to Mannesmann
description: Expanding its presence in the fast-changing European communications market, the American company Teligent Inc., a leader in providing high-capacity communications links using wireless technology, intends to announce today that it has formed a partnership with a unit of Mannesmann of Germany, executives close to the deal said yesterday.

title: A Gaggle of Cartoonists, but It's Not All Smiles; At a New Yorker Exhibit, Some Artists Revere the Old Days. Others Don't.
description: Under the fine lines and smooth washes of The New Yorker's cartoons, it is stormy weather. The magazine's funnymen are frowning.

title: Kansas Suspension:'System Run Amok'
description: THE AMERICAN Civil Liberties Union, concerned that students' rights may be jeopardized by the strict application of zero-tolerance-type policies, was heartened by a recent court victory in Kansas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSDORF, GEORGE
description: WALSDORF-George. Age 50 years, died February 11, 2000, in Rome Memorial Hospital, Rome, NY. He was born March 21, 1949; the son of Murray and Fannie Wyoukark Walsdorf. Last known to have resided in NYC. Will any kin or anyone knowing any next of kin contact Central NY D.S.O. collect at 315-336-2300, regarding any special funeral arrangements.

title: At Edges of Elian's Spotlight Are Other Divided Families
description: Lazara Brito and her three children huddled over the kitchen table in their Havana apartment on a recent day and thumbed through a pile of letters and drawings. These scraps of paper have been the only physical link to Ms. Brito's husband, Jose Cohen, who left Cuba on a raft in 1994 and has been waiting in vain for them to join him in Miami.

title: Calender
description: MONDAY

title: They've Got Hostages, and They Want Their MTV
description: Stevie and Rocky are a Bonnie and Clyde for the MTV generation.

description: AT&T's Consumer Chief Is Expected to Resign

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, PAULINE O'GORMAN
description: MORRISON-Pauline O'Gorman. Died February 9. The memorial service date has changed to Tuesday, March 7, at 11 AM, at The Church of Christ the King, New Vernon, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, GEORGE
description: JACKSON-George. On February 10, 2000, in NYC at 41. Forever loved by wife Yuko, daughter Kona Rose, mother Henrietta Jackson, sister Dr. Sharon Jackson and brother Bobbie Stancil. His spirit and vision lives in his family and his friends at Urban Box Office. Service Monday, February 14, 2000, at St. Paul the Apostle Cathedral, 405 West 59th St., at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The George Jackson Memorial Scholarship Fund, c/o De La Salle Academy, 200 West 97th St. For information: 212-316-5840.

title: MediaTalk; A Star Is Born (or Morphed Is More Like It)
description: Move over, Diane Sawyer. Ananova Ltd., the interactive-services division of the Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, has developed a computer-generated newscaster -- part bombshell, part Max Headroom. The newscaster -- also named Ana nova -- will begin broadcasting news from a Web site (www.ananova.com) in April. Later this year, it will give information from British databases, tapping into the resources of ticket outlets and weather services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, EDWARD BENJAMIN
description: KATZ-Edward Benjamin, Dr. Lifelong resident of NYC, was born March 13, 1927, and died February 7, 2000. Dr. Katz graduated from Bronx High School of Science in 1945, and received his B.S.S. from City College of New York in 1949. In 1952, Dr. Katz received his M.S.L.S. from Columbia University School of Library Science. Dr. Katz was the librarian at Brooklyn Technical High School until his retirement in 1984, serving as an Examination Assistant for the NYC Board of Examiners from 1969 to 1970. Beginning in 1977, Dr. Katz began his studies with the Graduate Faculty of the New School for Social Research, earning his Ph.D. in 1991, and was certified as a Clinical Psychologist by New York State in 1995. His second career in psychology began in 1986 at South Beach Mental Health Center, and at the time of his death he practiced clincial psychology at the Department of Veterans Affairs New York Harbor Health Care System and the Health Care for Homeless Veterans Program. Preceded in death by his parents, Herman Katz and Minnie Davis Katz; his brother, Joseph P. Kates, and his sister, Edna B. Rosen. Survived by his nephews and nieces: Dr. Ronald E. Kates and wife Dr. Nadia Harbeck of Munich, Germany; Phyllis R. Rosen of Walkersville, MD; Kenneth H. Kates, Esq., and wife Linda Weingarten Kates of Houston, TX; Jay H. Rosen and wife Catherine Green Rosen of Clackamas, OR; and Lawrence P. Rosen and wife Susan Bell Rosen of Richmond, VA; by five great-nephews and four great-nieces; and by his brother-in-law, Robert Rosen, of Coconut Creek, FL. He loved the arts, fine literature, theater and travel. He devoted his life to helping his students, his patients, and providing encouragement and love to his family and friends. He will be greatly missed. Funeral services 11:30 AM, Wednesday, February 16, 2000, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan. Burial following at Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Metropolitan Museum of Art or a charity of choice.

title: Birth-Control Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Twin Towers Star as the West Comes Up Big
description: Fed up with a colossal mismatch in the low post, Grant Hill, that undersized power forward, tried to shove Shaquille O'Neal out from under the basket in the first quarter. When the 7-foot-1-inch, 320-pound center did not budge, Hill simply applied the only defense he had left. He began laughing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNS, PHILIP OLCOTT
description: STERNS - Philip Olcott. Died peacefully on February 11 in Vermont. Born Detroit, February 9, 1917. Philip will be sorely missed by his many friends, particularly his colleagues within the military miniatures and historical societies the world over. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Dorset Players. For information, Brewster Funeral Service, Manchester Center, VT.

title: Mr. Suharto as Suspect
description: During his 32-year rule over Indonesia, former President Suharto is widely believed to have amassed billions of dollars in illegal wealth for himself, his children and his political cronies. An investigation of Mr. Suharto was one of the loudest demands of opponents whose demonstrations helped bring an end to his military-backed dictatorship in May 1998. But until now, no serious effort had been made to bring Mr. Suharto to account.

title: Lands' End Expands Role of Omnicom Unit
description: Lands' End, the catalog and online retailer, has expanded its relationship with DDB Worldwide, a unit of the Omnicom Group, by naming the DDB Chicago office as agency of record, handling tasks that include creative, media and strategy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Friday about the appointment of a security coordinator by the United Nations misstated the number of relief workers killed since 1992. It is 184, not 18.

title: Council Democrats Plan To Dare a Giuliani Veto
description: Over the next few weeks, Democrats in the City Council, led by Speaker Peter F. Vallone, are planning to approve a barrage of legislative initiatives that have been strongly opposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, all but daring the mayor to use his veto powers.

title: Working Better Or Just Harder?
description: The United States ended 1999 on a truly spectacular note -- two consecutive quarters of close to 5 percent growth in worker productivity, according to government figures reported last week. The long boom, which many economists attribute largely to growing productivity, seems to be moving into uncharted territory. Little wonder, with each worker producing more and more per hour, that inflation remains at bay, or that corporate earnings and the stock market continue to surge.

title: Murder Case With No Body Is Challenge for Prosecutors
description: With 125 witnesses but no body, prosecutors are to begin their complex circumstantial case today against Sante and Kenneth Kimes, the mother and son accused of killing a wealthy widow in a plot to steal her Upper East Side mansion.

title: Society's Ills Invade the Classroom : A Sense of Crisis
description: PARIS  Around the world, governments see violence in schools as a growing problem.

title: It's Return To Rotation For Jones
description: Same time, same joke, new spin.

title: Institute Split Over Future Role : Asia's MIT Faces A Midlife Crisis
description: PATHUMTHANI, Thailand  Correction published in the International Herald Tribune, February 21, 2000:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, DOROTHY
description: HOFFMAN - Dorothy. Beloved wife of Lionel B., loving mother of Steven and Howard, cherished grandmother of Eran and Andrew. Service 12:45 Tuesday, February 15th, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Sports of The Times; Francis Works Hard To Remake His Image
description: STEVE FRANCIS stood in one of the busiest corridors of the All-Star Game weekend on Saturday afternoon. This was the lobby of the Arena in Oakland, a control center where all the stars and entourages entered.

title: Owners to Scale Back Ratner's, a Lower East Side Landmark
description: Ratner's may not be dead, but to some customers, after hearing the owners' plans for the nearly century-old Lower East Side landmark restaurant, it may as well be.

title: Bombay Journal; A World Pays Tribute to India's Master Drummer
description: The mingled sound of splashes and shouts from the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Olympic Pool drifted into the cool, dark room when the park attendant, clad in black Lycra bicycle shorts, opened the padlocked doors, insisting that all who entered must first take off their sandals as a sign of respect.

title: An Ailing Cardinal Inspires With a Sermon on Suffering
description: Back from a journey to the Holy See that was most likely the last of his life, Cardinal John O'Connor spoke to worshipers at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday about the ''power of suffering'' in a homily that for many crystallized his own illness and his impending retirement as archbishop of New York.

title: A Pianist Who's Happy With Today
description: Geoffrey Burleson, a pianist based in the Boston area, is that rare performer who plays works by living composers not from some sense of duty but because they engage him. If the field of classical music were not so worrisomely preoccupied with maintaining old music rather than cultivating new music, Mr. Burleson's empathy for the music of his own time would not be so exceptional. But the field is conservative, and audiences, sadly, are wary of programs entirely devoted to composers who are still with us.

title: Treasury Offerings This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Hezbollah Says It Will Not Halt Its Attacks as Long as the Israelis Remain in Lebanon
description: After a three-week offensive against Israeli forces in southern Lebanon, the militant Islamic group Hezbollah, the Party of God, says it has no plans to halt the attacks so Israel can fulfill its promise to withdraw from the area by early July without further losses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. Sentiments of love and gratitude to a mother who gave so much of herself in bringing joy to others

title: New 'Vast Conspiracy'
description: The religio-politician Pat Robertson, host of TV's Hour of Smarm, took to the airwaves yesterday to peddle the Bush campaign's vast-conspiracy theory.

title: Zeile Steps Into the Breach
description: Todd Zeile was asked to switch to first base before, and he was furious. Zeile was in his first full season with the St. Louis Cardinals in 1990 and had been assured by his manager, Joe Torre, that he would be the everyday catcher, that there were no plans to shift him to another position to get playing time for Tom Pagnozzi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AYRES, C. BURGESS
description: AYRES-C. Burgess. In Bedford, MA, formerly of Wallingford, CT, and Jaffrey, NH, February 12. Husband of Katharine (George). Father of Margo Smith of Dedham, MA, Susan Noble of Stony Brook, NY, Burgess N. Ayres of Sheffield, MA, and Robert Ayres of Concord, MA. Brother of Edward B. Ayres of Guilford, CT. Also survived by nine grandchildren, four greatgrandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Memorial services in Jaffrey will be announced in the spring. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be sent to the Choate Rosemary Hall School Scholarship Fund, 333 Christian Ave., Wallingford, CT 06492.

title: Charles M. Schulz, 'Peanuts' Creator, Dies at 77
description: Charles M. Schulz, the creator of ''Peanuts,'' the tender and sage comic strip starring Charlie Brown and Snoopy that is read by 355 million people around the world, died in his sleep on Saturday night at his home in Santa Rosa, Calif., just hours before his last cartoon ran in the Sunday newspapers. He was 77.

title: Misjudging a Book by Its Cover
description: Two years ago, the authors of ''The Beardstown Ladies' Common-Sense Investment Guide'' watched their sales deteriorate along with their savvy reputation when the group of women from Beardstown, Ill., acknowledged that their dust-jacket boast of having beaten the stock market with 23.4 percent annual returns was actually inflated by a computer data error.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, WILLIAM J.
description: LEONARD-William J., Rev., S.J. Of Boston College. February 11. Visiting hours at St. Mary's Hall, Boston College, Monday, 7-9 PM, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Concelebrated funeral mass in St. Ignatius Church, Newton, MA, Wednesday, Febuary 16, at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, LILYAN
description: HYMAN-Lilyan. On February 14, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Allan. Loving mother of Allan, Bernard and Andrew. Cherished grandmother to Jeffrie, Rick, Erik, Jenny, Ali and Monique. Fond great grandmother. Private family service.

title: BID FOR COURTALDS
description: Courtaulds Textiles P.L.C., a clothing maker whoseshares have declined 73 percent in five years, rejected a $165 million takeover bid from the Sara Lee Corporation, saying that the company's worth is ''very significantly in excess'' of the offer. The cash offer of 100 pence a share was 60 percent more than the 62.5 pence closing price of Courtaulds on Friday. Shares of Courtaulds rose 84 percent, to 115 pence, suggesting that investors are expecting a higher bid. Sara Lee said that it was eager to expand in Europe.

title: Improving Motherhood
description: To the Editor:

title: GUILTY PLEAS SEEN IN THE LAUNDERING OF RUSSIAN MONEY
description: Two major suspects in the federal investigation into the illegal transfer of billions of dollars from Russia through the Bank of New York have agreed to plead guilty to money laundering charges, people involved in the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMGARTEN, BESSIE
description: BAUMGARTEN-Bessie (nee Largeman), on February 13, 2000 at the age of 97. Beloved wife of the late Max. Loving, devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Dear aunt, friend and dedicated volunteer at White Plains Hospital for over 20 years. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her, but most especially by Mal, Joyce, Beth, Scott, Doug, Lauren, Jennifer, Jamie and Amy. Interment private. Friends welcome at the home of Mal and Joyce on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

title: Applause, Respect, Gasps and No Cell Phone Ringing in an Audience of Children
description: Wave upon wave of cheers, gasps and murmurs of ''Oh, wow!'' swept through the New York State Theater at a special performance by the New York City Ballet on Friday. The occasion was a morning matinee for city schoolchildren presented by the City Ballet education department as part of Ballet Bridges, one of several programs intended to involve public-school children in dance on and off the stage as part of their cultural training. The children made for a dream audience, though adults at a City Ballet performance last Tuesday night at the State Theater did not do badly either.

title: Which Path for America Abroad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Advanced Micro to Release Faster Chip
description: Advanced Micro Devices announced a new version of its flagship processor yesterday, saying that it runs faster than the latest chip from the Intel Corporation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Fallon McElligott Opening Outpost
description: Fallon McElligott, now part of the Publicis Group unit of Publicis S.A., is opening a creative outpost in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOW, MEL
description: SOKOLOW-Mel. We adore you, miss you, and are inspired by you. Love and hugs forever. Diane, Betsy, Alec, Sam

title: HOCKEY: Taking Lemieux at Face Value; This Devil Has Smile of a Family Man and Scars of a Warrior
description: When she first saw the man she would marry, Deborah Lemieux was a little intimidated. Here, late at night in a trendy Manhattan restaurant, stood this rugged young guy in a sharp suit, his craggy facial features decorated with a black eye.

title: Earth's Solitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLINSON, VIVIAN
description: BELLINSON-Vivian. Born NYC on December 19, 1914, died on February 13, 2000. Mourned by her family and friends.

title: Europeans Move Toward Backing German to Lead the I.M.F.
description: The European Union appears set to back a German finance ministry official to head the International Monetary Fund, giving a boost to a candidate Clinton administration officials privately argue is ill-suited for the job.

title: Bradley, Outraged, Defends His Health Plan
description: A visibly incensed Bill Bradley lashed into Vice President Al Gore for turning sharply negative in recent days, accusing him of resorting to ''outrageous scare tactics'' in criticizing Mr. Bradley's plan for universal health care.

title: Man Arrested With Missile Guidance Gear
description: The federal authorities here have arrested a man they say was trying to leave the country with military technology used in missile guidance systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, LESTER
description: LORD-Lester. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Lester Lord, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Beatrice, and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Dr. Norman Doctor, President

title: Tornadoes Tear Through Georgia In Middle of the Night, Killing 22
description: Attacking under cover of darkness and with little warning, tornadoes rumbled through southwest Georgia early this morning, killing at least 22 people, injuring more than 100 and transforming peaceful subdivisions into wastelands of debris.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about efforts to sell The San Francisco Examiner misstated the given name of a former mayoral candidate who broke an ankle in a scuffle with the newspaper's editor in 1993. He is Clint Reilly, not Curt.

title: U.S. Skating Tops the Ratings
description: In the first weekend without pro football since September, the highest-rated televised sports event was the United States national figure skating championships. Michelle Kwan's victory in the women's competition on Saturday night helped ABC to an 8.5 overnight Nielsen rating, up 23 percent from last year. The pairs competition, which was shown during the first hour, rated a 7.6. But from 10 p.m. to 10:30 p.m., the women's competition between Kwan and Sasha Cohen rated a 9.2, then jumped to a 9.7 from 10:30 p.m. to 11 p.m.

title: Huskies Find Old Form to Stop Surging Pirates
description: For seven minutes at least, the Connecticut Huskies looked tonight like the team of last season that often stitched vivid sequences together into a deep, textured blanket of basketball. That kind of play kept Huskies Coach Jim Calhoun comfortable, and it knitted up perfectly to a national championship to warm fans in a hoops-crazy state.

title: George Jackson, Movie Producer, Dies at 42
description: George Jackson, who grew up in Harlem to become a movie producer, record company executive and Internet company founder, died yesterday at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. He was 42.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCURLEY, NORA ESTHER
description: McCURLEY-Nora Esther. In her 93rd year, died peacefully on February 11, 2000 after a short illness. She is survived by her sister Elsa M. Crosa and daughters Doreen McCurley and Mary Lukinich and son-in-law Rex Lukinich. A requiem mass will be held at St. Agnes Church, 143 East 43 St. at 10:00 AM on Thursday, February 17. Interment will be at Arlington National Cemetery next to her beloved husband, Oscar Guinn McCurley.

title: Talk of a Telephone Bidding War Roils Asian Markets
description: Politics and the ambitions of a seductive Internet start-up have thrown Asian markets into confusion over a proposed merger between two of the region's communications giants, Cable and Wireless HKT Ltd. of Hong Kong and Singapore Telecommunications Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DUSTIN
description: LEVINE-Dustin. The Board of Trustees, Clergy and staff of Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester note with profound sadness the death of Dustin Levine, the beloved son of our members Valerie and Robert Levine. We share in their grief, along with Quinn and their entire family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Chaim Stern, Rabbi Dana Anesi, Cantor David Thomas, Rabbi Stephen J. Adler, President

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATIONAL PENN BANCSHARES INC., Boyertown, Pa., agreed to buy Panasia Bank, a Fort Lee, N.J., bank that mostly serves Korean-Americans, for about $20.4 million in cash.

title: Albany's Snoozing Leadership
description: Now that a federal court has blocked attempts to keep Senator John McCain off the ballot in New York's March 7 presidential primary, the state's top lawmakers need to turn their attention to permanent reform of New York's insane presidential ballot rules. So far only one Albany leadership figure, the State Senate's Democratic minority leader, Martin Connor, has shown any interest in this vital project. The real powers in the capital -- Gov. George Pataki; Joseph Bruno, the Senate majority leader; and Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker -- are demonstrating a collective failure of leadership.

title: President and Executives Say Regulations Will Not Stop Hackers
description: President and Executives Say Regulations Will Not Stop Hackers

title: In Sandwich Shop, 2 More Columbine Students Are Killed
description: Less than a year after the massacre at Columbine High School, two sophomores were found shot to death today in a sandwich shop near the school.

title: Communal Memory: Autobiography With a Headstand
description: Hannah was one stressed-out single mom in the late 60's. Schoolteachers didn't understand her creative, art-loving daughter Deborah. Her ex-husband's family despised her. With work, protest marches and two little girls, she was constantly exhausted. So when some really nice people offered her an ''alternative lifestyle, kind of like a kibbutz'' in Southern California, she packed up the children and moved in. It looked like a commune but turned out to be, or grew into, a cult.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ESTEE LAUDER COS., New York, named Edward M. Straw to the new post of president for operations. He had been senior vice president for supply chain management at Compaq Computer Corp.

title: Woman Who Lost Home to $58 Bill Will Own It Again
description: Rockland County woman who lost her town house to foreclosure because of a missed $58 tax payment and a whole lot of red tape will get it back under an agreement reached today with the county government and the man who bought the foreclosed house.

title: Top Aide to Giuliani To Resign Her Post
description: Ninfa Segarra, the deputy mayor for education and human services, is expected to announce this week that she will be leaving City Hall for a senior staff position at the City University of New York, advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Queens Councilman to Oppose Congressman
description: A longtime city councilman from Queens announced his plans yesterday to challenge United States Representative Joseph Crowley in the Democratic primary.

title: Call to Halt the Penalty for Social Security Recipients Who Work
description: Republicans in the House today introduced legislation that would allow most Social Security recipients to earn as much money as they want without giving up any of their retirement benefit. President Clinton said he would sign the bill if it passed Congress and came to him without being linked to other issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTANGELO, ROBERT C.
description: SANTANGELO-Robert C. On February 8 of ALS. Beloved brother of Renzo Santangelo of West Roxbury, MA., and Tillie Boyle of Lewes, DE. Loving uncle of many nieces and nephews and cherished by friends galore. Memorial service will be held at Oak Crest Chapel, 8200 Walther Blvd., Parkville, MD on March 5 at 2:00 PM. Contributions in his memory to ALS Association, 116 John Street, Suite 1304, New York, New York 10038.

title: Giuliani Goes North to Criticize Clintons on Heating-Oil Issue
description: Soothing Republicans who complained that he had not campaigned enough upstate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a hastily arranged trip here today to criticize Hillary Rodham Clinton and President Clinton for their handling of rising heating-oil prices, a pressing issue in northern New York State.

title: For Women in Astronomy, a Glass Ceiling in the Sky
description: Before they could even vote or control their own property, women had reached for the stars -- and rigorously picked them apart. For more than a century, they have earned at least 10 percent of the doctorates in astronomy, often to luminous ends. In 1908, for example, Henrietta Leavitt discovered Cepheid variable stars, which have proved crucial to the measurement of cosmic distances. Some 25 years later, Cecilia Payne-Gaposchkin determined that stars are composed mainly of hydrogen -- a finding that her colleagues at first refused to believe.

title: Troubled Nassau Jail Gets a New Sheriff
description: A new sheriff was approved yesterday to oversee Nassau County's troubled jail, which in the last year has faced allegations of brutality and fiscal mismanagement.

title: TOSHIBA INTERNET UNIT
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it was setting up a wholly owned subsidiary to provide Internet services through mobile terminals like cellular phones and digital personal assistants. Toshiba estimated that its overall Internet-related activities would produce 500 billion yen, or $4.63 billion at current exchange rates, in revenue through 2003, with about 150 billion yen, or $1.38 billion, coming from the new business, called I-Value Creation Company. Toshiba will spend half of those revenues on its Internet-related businesses by 2003. Stephanie Strom

title: Which Path for America Abroad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiny Beads Allow Close Study of DNA
description: The more biologists understand of living cells, the more daunting seems the task of figuring out everything they do. The average human cell is too small to be seen, yet at any moment up to 30,000 of its 100,000 genes may be flicking on or off, executing the cell's housekeeping needs or responding to messages from other cells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARQUIS, ROY PORTER
description: MARQUIS-Roy Porter. Age 57, died February 10, 2000, at home after a brief illness. A memorial gathering was held February 13th at the home of Anita Rogers, his loving companion and partner of 34 years. In addition to Anita Rogers, Mr. Marquis was survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roy Marquis, and brothers, David and Harry. Mr. Marquis was an attorney, and will be sorely missed by his many friends in New York and those with whom he carried on an extensive and voluminous correspondence since moving to New York. Mr. Marquis was known for his repartee, cornucopia of knowledge, and insatiable appetite for reading. Interment will be private.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES TO BUY STERLING SOFTWARE
description: Computer Associates International Inc., a maker of software that improves computers' performance, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Sterling Software Inc. for $4 billion in stock, gaining computer-storage management products. Computer Associates will exchange 0.5634 share, or $39.05 a share, for each Sterling share. The exchange is based on Computer Associates' trading between $77.12 and $63.10. The purchase will give Computer Associates access to Sterling's data storage management products, software to protect and deposit corporate information and tools for creating Web programs. Shares of Computer Associates, which is based in Islandia, N.Y., fell 43.75 cents, to $69.3125. Shares in Sterling, which is based in Dallas, rose $1.8125, to $36.25.

title: New Emphasis in Cancer Drug Tests: The Elderly
description: Every winter in the frigid town of South Bend, Ind., Dr. Rafat Ansari notices a definite increase in the number of his breast cancer patients who choose to have mastectomies rather than lumpectomies. The reason, he says, is quite simple.

title: National News Briefs; Plea in August Shootings
description: The white supremacist accused of shooting five people in a Jewish community center last August and then killing a postal worker pleaded not guilty today to federal charges that could bring the death penalty.

title: News Corporation Studying Merger of Its Satellite Units
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation said today that it was strongly considering consolidating all its satellite-related businesses into a single company that could provide Internet service from space to nearly the entire globe.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: DYNATECH UNIT TO ACQUIRE WAVETEK WANDEL GOLTERMANN
description: The Dynatech Corporation said yesterday that its TTC unit, a leading maker of telecommunications-testing equipment, had agreed to buy the closely held Wavetek Wandel Goltermann Inc., of Research Triangle Park, N.C., and Eningen, Germany, for about $600 million in stock and cash. . The combined company will have more than $800 million in revenue.

title: Thwacking and Squeaking As the Audience Crows
description: The percussion parts in operas are often extensive and difficult, especially in modern operas. But the instruments called for in the majority of scores are fairly traditional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSLOW, RICHARD SEARS
description: WINSLOW-Richard Sears. Died February 10, 2000, at age 91 in Exeter, NH. Predeceased in 1998 by Lucy P. Winslow, wife of 56 years. Social worker in Boston in the 1930's. Private in U.S. Army in WW II. Director of post-war refugee camp in Europe. Administrator in international affairs and city government until retiring at age 86 from NYC's Bureau of Corruption Prevention. Avid supporter of conservation causes. Superb tennis player into his 80's, and lifelong fan of Boston Red Sox. Devoted husband, nurturing father of three, adoring grandfather of three. Beloved by large extended family of nieces, nephews, cousins and inlaws, and by countless friends and co-workers. Memorials to Massachusetts Audubon Society, 208 S. Great Road, Lincoln, MA. 01773.

title: Seeing Stars
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Panel Rules Against Interpublic Group
description: An arbitration panel has ruled against the Interpublic Group of Companies in a contract dispute with a former top agency executive. .

title: Shares of Maytag Tumble on Latest Warning About Profits
description: Shares of the Maytag Corporation, the giant appliance maker, fell sharply today after the company warned that earnings this year would not meet Wall Street expectations.

title: Flashing Diamonds, and Hungry Children
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Striker Is Coming
description: METROSTARS

title: Making Inroads in Fight Against Shingles Pain
description: For John V. Cody, 77, an artist in Lynnfield, Mass., it has been two months and counting since his personal introduction to one of the most unpleasant and underpublicized rites of getting older: a bout of the shingles.

title: Fairness for All Couples
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, BERTHA
description: JACOBSON-Bertha. On February 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Loving mother of Lorraine Podell and her husband Herbert, Gary Jacobson, and the late Audrey Jacobson. Cherished grandmother of Pamela and Allison Podell. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Business; Russ Berrie Talks End
description: Russ Berrie & Company said yesterday that talks with the buyout firm Evercore Partners ended without an agreement.

title: Government Fights Spread of Online Auction Fraud
description: February 15, 2000
