title: Privacy Advocates Fault New DoubleClick Service
description: Responding to growing criticism of its tracking of consumers as they make their way around the World Wide Web, DoubleClick, the Internet's leading advertising placement company, began a new service yesterday along with an educational campaign to help Web surfers protect their privacy.

title: An Ominous Obsession at Women's Gym
description: When Dr. Amanda J. Gruber, a Massachusetts psychiatrist, meets with patients, the last thing she wants to do is discourage them from exercising.

title: Austria Under Siege By Artists (and Artifice)
description: Thanks to Jorg Haider's Freedom Party, Vienna has two new schools of art: the small and bitter Get-Out-Now movement and the larger, angrier Stay-and-Fight club.

title: The Comedy of 'Peanuts'
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: And Next Week, Heeeeere's David

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELSON, OLE WILLIS
description: DANIELSON-Ole Willis. Formerly of New York City, died February 7, 2000 at the age of 83 in Newark, DE after a long illness. His wife, Hazel (''Bunny'') Hill Vial died in 1984. He was a 1938 graduate of West Point, and served in World War II in Europe. Joining the United Nations afterwards, he held posts in Korea, Chile and New York. He retired to Walnut Creek, California in 1976 & enjoyed golf, hunting, fishing and travel. He is survived by his son, Ole N., and two grandchildren in West Chester, PA. Burial services will be held at West Point in April.

title: Chat Systems Yield Clues in Web Attacks by Hackers
description: Evidence fueling the search for suspects in the recent attacks on leading Web sites may have been found in a set of online conversations secretly monitored by computer security experts before and during the attacks.

title: WORLD ACCESS TO EXPAND EUROPEAN OPERATIONS
description: World Access Inc., a long-distance telephone company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy WorldxChange Communications, which is closely held, for $709 million in stock, adding business customers in six European countries. The company, which is based in Atlanta, will pay 31 million shares, or $709 million at Friday's closing price, and assume $225 million in debt. Shares of World Access fell $1.125, to $21.75. The acquisition, World Access's third in eight weeks, is part of a plan to provide telephone, data and Internet services in Europe. World Access will add Belgium and the Netherlands to its markets, said Stephen Shook, a Wachovia Securities analyst.

title: Ed Linn, 77, Chronicler Of Baseball
description: Ed Linn, an author and magazine writer who collaborated with the maverick baseball owner Bill Veeck on three books and wrote widely on the Yankees and the Red Sox, died on Feb. 7 at his home in Spring Valley, Calif. He was 77.

title: Ronald Roseman, 66, an Oboist, Composer and Music Professor
description: Ronald Roseman, an oboist, composer and teacher who was admired as a soloist and for his work with the New York Woodwind Quintet and the Bach Aria Group, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66.

title: Guilt So Deep That It Derails Words and Intentions
description: Words stick and clog in the mouths of the title characters of J. T. Rogers's ''White People'' as though language were a gummy, swelling substance as difficult to spit out as to swallow.

title: Goldman Sachs Proxy Shows Chief Made Over $25 Million
description: Henry M. Paulson, the chairman and chief executive of the Goldman Sachs Group, was one of at least five top executives on Wall Street to take home more than $25 million last year, according to the firm's first proxy statement.

title: Cage Is Waived by the Nets
description: The respected career of Michael Cage came to an end today when the Nets requested waivers on the 38-year-old center. Cage, who was playing in his 15th season, had been on the injured list since Jan. 21 with a sprained big toe and a bone spur on his left foot. The injury requires joint replacement surgery that would have forced Cage to miss the rest of the season. He had said since training camp that he would retire after the season.

title: For Some, Vegan Diet Relieves PMS
description: Those who champion the low-fat vegetarian vegan diet have long made broad health claims for the regimen. Now one of the diet's biggest advocates is making a new claim; he says it can greatly reduce menstrual pain and the symptoms of premenstrual syndrome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSBERG, HELENE H.
description: HASSBERG-Helene H. On February 11, 2000. Devoted sister, aunt and friend. Retired employee of the Board of Education, New York City. For information, call Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 1-800-690-1646.

title: Theorist Ponder a Cosmic Boost From Far, Far Away
description: The discovery two years ago that the expansion of the universe is speeding up has presented physicists and cosmologists with a major problem. The gravity of all the known matter and energy in our own universe should slow that expansion, not speed it up. Looking for a way out of this perplexity, several cosmologists are now suggesting that the cosmic acceleration may be an effect from some other universe.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about night life in Brooklyn misspelled the name of a restaurant in the Fort Greene section. It is Lucian Blue, not Lucien Blue.

title: Kin Not Told of Death, Hospital Admits
description: The family of a Virginia man who died at Beth Israel Medical Center in 1998 has charged in a lawsuit that the hospital failed to notify them, then performed an unauthorized autopsy and had him buried in a pauper's grave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTACUZINO, STEFANA
description: CANTACUZINO-Stefana. February 11, 2000, beloved wife of the late Mircea, loving mother of Dan Cantacuzino, M.D., loving motherin-law of Barbara Cantacuzino. Funeral service Thursday February 17th, at 1 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: H&R Block Consolidates
description: H&R Block Inc., the world's largest tax preparation company, said today that it was merging its retail mortgage operations into one company as it tries to get more customers to use its financial services. The new company, the H & R Block Mortgage Corporation, will combine the retail operations of the Option One Mortgage Corporation and the Assurance Mortgage Corporation of America. It will be based in Burlington, Mass.

title: Cairns Suspended Four Games for Hall Fight
description: They didn't fight on the ice, but maybe they should have. Islanders defenseman Eric Cairns drew a four-game suspension and Pittsburgh Penguins forward Matthew Barnaby was suspended for five games by the National Hockey League yesterday for scuffling in the Nassau Coliseum hallway between periods Saturday night.

title: Once Near Death, A Comeback Bird Thrives in Cities
description: This is a story about a man and a bird. The man is Tom Cade, admired for his vision, ingenuity, passion and persistence, who defied naysayers and spearheaded the rescue of the bird. The bird is the peregrine falcon, admired for its power, speed, nobility and hunting prowess, which 30 years ago was perched on the brink of extinction.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about the stock market misstated the change of the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond on Friday. It was a drop to 6.26 percent from 6.32 percent. The 6.43 percent figure was for a different bond on Thursday.

title: Republicans Resolve Suit On Opening Of All Polls
description: A legal challenge that sought to block Saturday's Republican presidential primary in South Carolina was dropped today after the state Republican Party agreed to open every available polling place, including those in heavily Democratic and black areas that were closed in previous years.

title: Spacecraft Is Orbiting Asteroid, A First for a Man-Made Satellite
description: With a nudge from its small rockets, the spacecraft NEAR gently embraced the asteroid Eros today to become the first man-made object to orbit such a space rock.

title: PHONE.COM IS IN $787 MILLION DEAL FOR ONEBOX.COM
description: Phone.com Inc., which makes software that lets wireless telephones browse the Internet, agreed to buy Onebox.com Inc. for about $787 million in stock to add Web-based e-mail, voice mail and faxing services. Phone.com will exchange 6.5 million of its shares for closely held Onebox.com. Shares of Phone.com have soared fifteenfold since the company went public in June at $16 each. The stock fell $2.625, to $118.50. Onebox.com's Web-based services will let Phone.com offer products to traditional phone companies. Phone.com, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., now sells only to their wireless divisions.

title: Youth Today: Not So Bad, by Comparison
description: Adults who like to think of America's young as a bunch of lazy, cigarette-packing television addicts may be disappointed by a major new study that finds that adolescents in the United States smoke and watch television less than those in many other industrialized nations.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Cemetery's Overseer
description: The court-appointed official who has been managing the troubled affairs of the Cypress Hills Cemetery will remain on the job despite attempts by state officials to remove him.

title: E*Trade Filings With S.E.C. Omitted Data
description: E*Trade Group, the most visited investment site on the Internet, has spent millions of advertising dollars to build its reputation as a company that empowers individual investors. Along the way, however, it has been slow to provide investors some crucial information about itself.

title: Picking the Winners And Splitting Hairs
description: Rio rocked Madison Square Garden last night. A 13-month-old Doberman pinscher, a mere baby who began his career last month in Florida, upset a floorful of veterans to win the Working group at the 124th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 30 about New York State's delay in producing the detailed performance reports on hospitals required under a 1996 state law included an incorrect reference to one set of data. A lobbyist who favors the law was quoted as saying that figures for mastectomies performed at each hospital were not available; in fact, such figures are available from the state Health Department for mastectomies and cardiac surgery, but not generally for other procedures.

title: Tony Lee Bettenhausen, 48, Part of Auto Racing Family
description: Tony Lee Bettenhausen, a member of a prominent auto racing family who owned a racing team and drove Indy Cars for more than a decade, died yesterday in the crash of a small plane on a farm near Leesburg, Ky. He was 48.

title: Metro Business; Amerada Hess to Expand
description: Amerada Hess Corporation, one of the biggest fuel sellers in the New York City area, agreed to buy the 51 percent of the Meadville Corporation that it does not already own for about $168 million.

title: At Beth Israel, Lapses in Care Mar Gains in Technology
description: On Sept. 7, when Liana Gedz was rolled into the operating room at Beth Israel Medical Center for a Caesarean section, life at the hospital's obstetrics and gynecology department seemed to be back on track at last.

title: Merrill's Chief Financial Officer Moves Into Line for Top Position
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has put its chief financial officer, E. Stanley O'Neal, in charge of the nation's biggest brokerage operation and on track to be the next chairman of the firm.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Oil Price Exceeds $30 a Barrel For the First Time Since 1991
description: The price of crude oil jumped to more than $30 a barrel yesterday for the first time since the 1991 Persian Gulf war, and a sharp run-up in gasoline prices looks increasingly likely this summer.

title: Big Publishing House May Quit Manhattan for Hoboken
description: John Wiley & Sons, the 193-year-old company that published ''Moby- Dick,'' is close to a deal to move its world headquarters and about 900 employees from its longtime home on Third Avenue to the Hoboken waterfront, according to real estate executives.

title: Things Big and Serious Suddenly Turn a Bit Sunny
description: Jazz still trips over the concept of the commissioned piece. On one hand it's worth paying any amount of money to make jazz rely less on quartets jamming through chord changes and more on composition. And commissions can bear flowers beyond the initial bloom: after a one-shot concert performance, they can jump-start material for a new record or trigger a new working method for a band leader.

title: Factions Scuffle as Mexican Campus Reopens
description: Scuffles broke out at the national university today as tens of thousands of students returned for the first official day of classes since a strike started last April 20.

title: In Better Eras, Sopranos Sang in Choirs
description: YESTERDAY being Valentine's Day, it seemed only right to get in the spirit with a bit of nostalgia. The St. Valentine's Day Massacre came to mind.

title: 3 Charged in Kickback Scheme At Long Island Housing Agency
description: A former maintenance supervisor for the Hempstead Housing Authority was charged today with forcing companies to pay kickbacks totaling more than $35,000 in return for contracts to repair the agency's buildings.

title: Sports of The Times; Europeans' Success Has a Price
description: IT was not that long ago that European players, generically known as ''Chicken Swedes,'' were pummeled regularly on the premise they would crumple onto the ice and give up their fancy-skating ways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZMAN, POLA
description: SALZMAN-Pola, on February 14, 2000. Owner and Chief Executive of Paramount Cosmetics. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Sherry and her husband Gabriel, Sandy and his wife Nina. Adoring grandmother of Saskia, David, Valerie, Lauren and Nicole. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Wednesday, 11:30 AM, with interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Earth's Solitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Web Design Firm Sold
description: The marketing company Xceed Inc. has agreed to acquire methodfive Inc., a closely held Internet design firm, for $75 million in cash and stock, Xceed announced yesterday.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: State Power Authority in $800 Million Deal to Sell 2 Nuclear Power Plants
description: The New York Power Authority announced yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to sell the only two nuclear power plants owned by the state to Entergy Corporation.

title: At Sugar Refinery, A Melting-Pot Strike; Workers of Many Nations Besiege Brooklyn Relic of Industrial Age
description: They call themselves a league of nations, this group of workers who trudge day after day outside the Domino Sugar refinery, a Brooklyn landmark that towers like a fortress over the East River, a monument to New York's great industrial past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, RALPH
description: BAER-Ralph. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to our member Lisa Messinger on the loss of her brother, Ralph Baer. May the family be conforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Cleaning Up the Dry Cleaners; High Cost of Going Green Limits Promising Technology
description: For over a decade, the dry cleaning business has looked like a tantalizing opportunity for environmentally minded entrepreneurs. Despite increasing regulations aimed at cutting air pollution and groundwater contamination, not to mention criticism from groups like Greenpeace and Consumers Union, a vast majority of the nation's roughly 33,000 dry cleaners persist in using toxic chemicals linked to cancer, nervous system ailments and other health hazards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANZER, LAWRENCE
description: TANZER-Lawrence. On February 14, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Estelle. Loving father of Martin, William and Leonard. Father-in-law of Marilyn and Lola. Beloved brother of Marilyn. Cherished grandfather of Jason, Lauren and Taryn & Briana. Services at 11 A.M., graveside Tuesday at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. For information on Shiva, please contact Schwartz Bro.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, (718-263-7600).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEARNS, PHILIP OLCOTT
description: STEARNS-Philip Olcott. Died peacefully on February 11 in Vermont. Born Detroit, February 9, 1917. Philip will be sorely missed by his many friends, particularly his colleagues within the military miniatures and historical societies the world over. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Dorset Players. For information, Brewster Funeral Service, Manchester Center, VT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKMAN, SUE
description: BERKMAN-Sue. Writer, editor, dog lover, animal rescuer died December 19, 1999 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, New York City. Memorial service: Thursday, February 17, 2:00 P.M., at the Unity Center, 213 W. 58th St. NY, NY.

title: Turkey Accused of Arming Terrorist Group
description: A growing scandal stemming from a crackdown on a religious terror group has led to accusations that the group may have received weapons from the Turkish government.

title: Detaining Falun Gong
description: To the Editor:

title: Muckler Sounds Alarm To Wake Up Rangers
description: With every shriek from the whistle of Rangers Coach John Muckler, the sound of skates scraping hard across the ice grew louder as the players circled around the rink with an energy that was absent the night before.

title: When Women Find Love Is Fatal
description: They had little or nothing in common. And in the normal course of events, it is unlikely their worlds would ever have intersected.

title: Pipeline Venture Is Set
description: The Duke Energy Corporation and the Williams Companies, two of the largest owners of interstate natural gas pipelines, have formed a partnership to build a $1.5 billion pipeline into Florida that Williams had planned to build on its own. Each company will own half of the 674-mile Buccaneer pipeline that will begin near Mobile, Ala., cross the Gulf of Mexico and emerge near Tampa, Fla. Construction on the pipeline, which will carry as much as 900 million cubic feet of gas a day, is scheduled to be completed in April 2002.

title: Motion Is Filed Opposing Iridium Takeover
description: Bondholders of Iridium have filed a motion opposing Craig McCaw's plan to take control of the company, which is involved in satellitetelephones, and asked a bankruptcy court for permission to sue Motorola Inc. for more than $2 billion.

title: Watching Gallstones Prepare for Attack
description: By the time most gallstones make their painful presence known, there are not always a lot of options. An estimated half a million Americans a year, mostly women, end up having to have their gallbladders removed in what is the most common operation in the nation, experts say.

title: Eagles Sign Runyan To 6-Year Contract
description: The Eagles signed the former Tennessee Titans offensive tackle Jon Runyan to a six-year contract yesterday. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the endorsement of Al Gore by the Human Rights Campaign, a gay and lesbian lobbying group, referred incorrectly in some copies to the year in which a gay college student, Matthew Shepard, was killed. It was 1998, not 1999.

title: OFFICER RECOUNTS DIALLO'S SHOOTING IN DAY ON STAND
description: His head low and his voice halting, Officer Sean Carroll broke a year of public silence today to describe how he led his three partners into the shooting of Amadou Diallo, who was struck by 19 of 41 police bullets fired at him as he stood, unarmed, in the lobby of his apartment building in the Bronx.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Healtheon Agrees to Buy 2 Competitors
description: In a strong bid to dominate health care on the Internet, the Healtheon/WebMD Corporation agreed yesterday to buy two competitors, the Medical Manager Corporation and CareInsite Inc., both led by the New Jersey financier Martin J. Wygod, for $5.2 billion in Healtheon stock.

title: Taking Readers Inside the Writer's Notebook
description: CITY OF GOD

title: Shifting Politics of the Confederate Battle Flag
description: The Republicans began this election cycle with a conciliatory tone on race, hoping to attract support from members of the black middle class, many of whom fit the G.O.P. profile but were put off by the race-baiting and Willie Hortonizing that dominated Republican politics during the 1980's. George W. Bush seemed to be reaching out to black voters early on, when he took his message of inclusion and ''compassionate conservatism'' into African-American communities that had rarely seen Republican candidates in the flesh.

title: Some Like It Straight, And Some Like It Hot
description: Kenneth Klein led his New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony in a celebration of black composers at the Kaye Playhouse, but he seemed intent on shoehorning two very different programs into a single evening.

title: Study of Buses Using Natural Gas Could Diminish Demand for Them
description: Buses powered by compressed natural gas -- long viewed as the cleanest alternative to diesel buses -- are no better for the environment than buses powered by a combination of diesel and electricity, according to a study that could have broad implications for vehicle fleets nationwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIKORA, ALEXANDER J.
description: SIKORA-Alexander J. Jr. Of Yonkers. On Sunday, February 13, 2000 at age 71. A former engineer with ABC Mutual Broadcasting Company and WOR Radio. Beloved husband of Marion (Saban) Sikora. Devoted father of Alexandra Harp, Alexander J. Sikora III, Andrew J. Sikora, Dr. Janet Amendola and Jonathan M. Sikora. He is also survived by his five grandchildren and three sisters Johanna De Pouli, Alvina Soltis and Clare Chiascione and predeceased by Helen, Adeline and Marian Sikora. Visiting hours will be at the Whelan and Ball Funeral Home, 168 Park Avenue, Yonkers on Tuesday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial in Holy Trinity Catholic Church on Wednesday, February 16 at 10 A.M. Donations may be made to the church. www.obitdetails.com

title: James M. Edwards -- Lawyer, 68
description: James M. Edwards, a senior partner in the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore who counseled a number of multinational corporations, died Tuesday in a hotel in Grand Anse, Grenada, in the West Indies, where he was vacationing. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: OP-ART; What a Swell (Reform) Party
INSIDE
description: New Focus in Cancer Studies

title: A Star Glows, Right on Schedule
description: Astrophysicists do not often have the chance to predict an event in the heavens before it happens. An exception is the recent flare-up of a ring of material around a star whose cataclysmic explosion astronomers observed in 1987.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: DEBATE: Republican candidates, Columbia, S.C.

title: On Baseball; Valentine Uncertain About Uncertainty
description: Bobby Valentine tried not to focus on his uncertain future last November, he tried not to let it dominate December and he promised himself that it would not ruin January. But now it is February, spring training is here and Valentine cannot stop himself. He sounds confused and he is obsessed with something. This time it is himself.

title: Deal for Swiss Drug Labs
description: Solutia Inc. has agreed to buy a Swiss research and development company, CarboGen Laboratories, as a first step in its plan to enter drug-ingredients manufacturing. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Solutia, a 1997 spinoff from Monsanto, produces Wear-Dated brand carpet fibers and Saflex auto-glass liner. It has annual sales around $2.8 billion. The closely held CarboGen, which develops drug production processes, had 1999 sales of more than $20 million.

title: A Matter of Compromise and Acceptance
description: ''I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change.'' The title of this long-running off-Broadway show sums up the source of most marital problems. All too often, the very characteristics that initially attracted partners to one another or the disturbing behaviors that at first were ignored or considered unimportant eventually become marital sore points and the cause of repeated arguments and chronic unhappiness.

title: Toe-Tapping Bach Could Be a Slave to Fashion
description: Andras Schiff has danced his way through the keyboard suites of Bach this month, ending with an afternoon of all six Partitas at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday. The audience was large and devoted, the program long: nearly three hours. Dancing was the craze of the early 18th century, and composers responded by elevating accompaniments for the feet to purely musical collections of sarabandes, allemandes, correntes and gigues. Endearingly, we discover in Bach's treatments the monumental defender of tradition behaving like a slave to fashion.

title: The Truth About Chile
description: Thanks to a powerful nudge from President Clinton, the secrecy that has too long shrouded Washington's role in the 1973 political convulsions in Chile is lifting. The picture painted by newly disclosed passages from State Department papers is profoundly disturbing. It is now clear that the American government knew far more about the disappearance and murder of two American citizens in Chile than it acknowledged at the time. Indeed, American intelligence and military officials may have encouraged Gen. Augusto Pinochet's security forces to round them up even though it was clear that the two men, like thousands of Chileans arrested during the same period, were likely to be mistreated, if not killed.

title: Dividing Kosovo Won't Bring Peace
description: There was so much fog when I crossed the bridge in Kosovo's divided city of Mitrovica a few days ago I could barely see 10 yards ahead. Heavily armed French soldiers loomed as vague shapes. Coils of barbed wire looped into the mist. Self-appointed Serbian ''bridge keepers'' kept watch in case Albanians tried to infiltrate the city's northern districts, which the Serbs have made their own.

title: Takeout Order: Bucket o' Bach; 153 CD's? How Can You Face the Music?
description: The Teldec company hasn't offered to send me its recorded collection of Johann Sebastian Bach's music complete, but if it does, I have a gracious letter of refusal ready. Never mind when I would listen to it; where would I put it?

title: In Memoirs, Diabetics Tell of Troubles and Triumphs
description: Early in her memoir on living with diabetes, Lisa Roney describes a hike through the Great Smoky Mountains and her frustrating inability to keep pace with her group. Elevated blood sugar, probably from eating too much gorp, was making her lethargic and confused, and she had to keep sitting down to rest along the narrow trail.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Land Rover Narrows List to 5 Agencies
description: Land Rover North America, part of BMW A.G., said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $35 million, to five agencies from nine.

title: 'Soft' Van Horn Takes Hard Look at Himself
description: At the beginning of the season, most members of the Nets' organization and many people throughout the National Basketball Association expected Keith Van Horn to earn a berth in last weekend's All-Star Game. It seemed the natural progression for a player who had been compared to Larry Bird, called by a teammate the most exciting rookie to enter the league since Michael Jordan and featured as one of the top eight young stars of the new millennium by the respected analyst Hubie Brown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAR, RUTH
description: BEAR-Ruth. In Florida on Sunday, February 13, 2000 at the age of 82. She is survived by her husband and six sons. Funeral arrangements are pending.

title: In a Fax War, Candidates For Senate Step Up Attacks
description: Faced with a daunting monetary disadvantage in the Democratic primary battle for United States Senate, former Gov. Jim Florio has been taunting his multimillionaire rival, Jon S. Corzine, for refusing to face him in a debate.

title: Brain Abnormality Linked To Pathology
description: Ask the average social scientist why people become criminals, and the answer is apt to center on poverty and abuse, not brain structure and neurochemicals.

title: The Silly-Candidate Shortage
description: Donald Trump has dropped out of the presidential race. This will not have any impact on our actual search for a new chief executive, but it will be a terrible blow to the second-most-important function of a national election. Which is, of course, comic relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, DONALD
description: WEINBERGER-Donald. The Capital Defender Screening Panel for the Second Department expresses sympathy to the family of our colleague and good friend, Donald Weinberger. He will be missed. M. Arthur Eiberson Jeanne E. Mettler Cynthia Diaz-Wilson

title: Russians Order Grozny Residents To Leave, Sealing Off Ruined City
description: Russian commanders today ordered the devastated city of Grozny emptied of its surviving residents and sealed.

title: Perot and the G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGELIER, LAURA A.
description: LANGELIER-Laura A. The Murray Hill Medical Group notes with great sadness the passing of Laura A. Langelier, the mother of Dr. Carolyn Langelier, our beloved friend and partner. We extend our deepest condolences to Carolyn and her family.

title: 13 Are Charged in Hijacking of Afghan Jet as 73 Seek Asylum
description: Thirteen Afghans were charged today with hijacking the airliner that spent last week parked on a remote runway at a British airport with more than 150 people aboard. The men, ranging in age from 18 to 36, could face long prison sentences if convicted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEEFELD, RENA
description: KLEEFELD-Rena (Wertheimer). On February 10, 2000 after a valiant battle for life. Beloved wife of the late Robert O. Kleefeld, dearest mother of Kenneth, devoted twin sister of Amy Hawkes, dear sister of the late Sydney B. Wertheimer, and grandmother of Joshua and Eric Kleefeld. Services were private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRENCHER, ESSIE B.
description: TRENCHER-Essie B. Beloved wife of the late Murray, loving mother of Judith and Jonathan Marshall, cherished grandmother of Christopher and Timothy Marshall, great-grandmother of Harrison, devoted sister of Lillian Handelman and Miriam Bindman. Service 12:45 P.M., Wednesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Missile Test Is Rushed, Pentagon Official Says
description: The Pentagon is facing undue pressure to meet an ''artificial'' deadline for recommending whether to deploy the national missile defense system, the project's senior weapons tester said in a report released today. He said the current timetable disregarded enormous technical problems.

title: 8 Runners Nominated
description: Grete Waitz of Norway never considered herself a marathon runner. She liked to say she ran track.

title: Jets Evaluating Free Agents Without a Personnel Director
description: As the free-agency signing period was about to get under way last week, the Jets lost their director of pro personnel, Scott Pioli.

title: Front Row; Fashion Week parties go to the dogs Bonnie Cashin's instant legacy The anti-fur faction's new target is leather.
description: Fashion Week: So Much for Socializing

title: A Mexican Official's Account of His Back-Door Escape
description: A former governor who fled to avoid arrest on drug charges as his term ended last year is ''living like a guerrilla'' in a tropical region, sleeping by day and often moving by night, a journalist who met him recently said today.

title: ING GROEP PROFIT
description: The Dutch banking company, ING Groep N.V., said profit soared 76 percent in the fourth quarter, in part, because its investment banking unit, ING Barings, succeeded in restoring profitability after losing money in emerging markets in 1998. The earnings report by ING Groep beat the expectations of analysts. Profit from operations increased to 814 million euros, or $804 million, from 462 million euros during the earlier period. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Study Finds Families Bypassing Marriage
description: The number of couples who live together out of wedlock, often with children, is increasing rapidly, a new study reports.

title: Flag Overshadows Marathon Trials
description: A pall has been cast over the Olympic women's marathon trials later this month in Columbia, S.C. The presence of the Confederate flag, which flies over the South Carolina Capitol, has forced track to enter the politics of race.

title: A Dog Lover Finally Has His Day as Judge
description: MAYBE it all started when his mother, with the frugality-before-frivolity ethos practiced by so many Depression-era moms, wouldn't let him have a canine companion back in Boston no matter how passionately he pleaded. Then as now, for Chester F. Collier, dogs are serious, serious business.

title: Governing Tortuously: Indonesia's President Outflanks the General
description: In the end, President Abdurrahman Wahid got just what he wanted: the suspension of his troublesome general today along with new affirmations of support from the country's querulous military.

title: Police Corruption Case Draws Quiet Response
description: Raul Rodriguez remembers his two and a half years in jail on murder and drug charges as a journey through shades of blackness. He refused to allow his youngest son to visit him. He lost a promising job as a salesman at a software company. The gangs that he had tried to escape by leaving central Los Angeles surrounded him.

title: Earth's Solitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONDI, KATHRYN A.
description: BONDI-Kathryn A. In New York City, on February 13, 2000, of Hamden, CT. Wife of Joseph. Mother of Jessica and Peter. Daughter of Violet Head and the late Charles Head. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, 12 noon, at the Weller Funeral Home, 493 Whitney Ave., New Haven, CT. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 767 Fifth Avenue, NY, NY 10153.

title: Candidates Say Crossover Voters Hold Key on Saturday
description: With polls indicating a race down to the wire in the Republican presidential primary on Saturday, Senator John McCain of Arizona and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas began the final week of campaigning by pleading with independents and Democrats to show up on Election Day and provide victory's edge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILTZIK, ABRAHAM
description: HILTZIK-Abraham. We mourn the passing of our dear husband, father, grandfather and greatgrandfather. He has left a legacy of love, integrity and family unity. He will be mourned, missed and never forgotten by his wife, Anne; his children, Louise and Arthur Schwartz, George & Linda Hiltzik, Henry and Jacqueline Bloomstein, Rachelle and Josh Weisberger & Yolande Bloomstein Aronowitz; his children Peter and Margaret Schwartz, Ellen and Jonathan Kleinhaus, Matthew, David and Sara Hiltzik, Mindy Weisberger and Michael Baker, Jim and James Schalbe, Dina Weisberger & Raphie, Adam and Lisa Aronowitz & his great-grandchildren, Samantha and Jordan Kleinhaus, Robert Schwartz and William Schwalbe.

title: Knicks Set For Part II, Old Warts And All
description: It was around 5 a.m. today when Jeff Van Gundy and Allan Houston returned from their All-Star Game weekend, and about 4 p.m. when Marcus Camby limped away from the practice facility after some rehabilitation work on his injured right knee.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Aggressive Crickets

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I said, 'Oh, my God.' I just held his hand and rubbed his face and said, 'Please don't die.''

title: A Tribute to Thomas Offered by Kansas City
description: Moments past noon today at Arrowhead Stadium, a sleek B-2 stealth bomber glided overhead, slipping across the sky like a huge, flat and thin shiny silver coin. Below, in a gold coffin in one of the end zones, lay the body of Derrick Thomas, No. 58, the great Kansas City Chiefs linebacker who died of a blood clot last Tuesday, 16 days after an auto accident had left him paralyzed from the chest down.

title: When Alcohol Knocks You Off Your Feet
description: Falling-down drunk, as the expression has it, is the kind of condition that on its face would seem to require little in the way of explanation. One drinks too much, one tries to stand up, one does not succeed. The rest is history.

title: Earth's Solitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Earth's Solitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-IBM Official Joining Network Solutions
description: February 15, 2000

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Union to Back German Official for I.M.F.

title: Stop Stereotyping Italian-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Have Two in Mind for Backup Spot
description: The Giants moved patiently last weekend as the National Football League's signing period for free agents dawned, but they did take steps to find a backup quarterback to Kerry Collins. They contacted Jason Garrett of the Dallas Cowboys and Mike Tomczak of the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Jan. 25 about the stability of plutonium used in the nation's nuclear warheads referred incorrectly to the views of Dr. Matthew G. McKinzie, a researcher with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a Washington-based group that tracks nuclear arms issues. He said that in theory instability in plutonium could reduce the lifetime of weapon cores, not that it might cut their lifetime to as little as 20 years.

title: CHOICEPOINT AGREES TO BUY DBT ONLINE FOR $423 MILLION
description: ChoicePoint Inc., a provider of information to the insurance industry, agreed to buy DBT Online Inc. for about $423 million in stock to add DBT's online public-record services to its offerings. DBT Online shareholders will receive 0.525 share of ChoicePoint stock for every DBT share. ChoicePoint, which is based in Alpharetta, Ga., said the purchase of DBT would add civil public-record information to its offerings. DBT is based in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: $1 Million Bail Is Set For Lewis In Slayings
description: A state judge ruled tonight that the All-Pro linebacker Ray Lewis may be released on $1 million bail but must remain at his home in Maryland except for court appearances here. Lewis faces murder charges in connection with two stabbing deaths after a Super Bowl party two weeks ago.

title: Justice Dept. Opposes SBC In Texas Bid
description: Using unexpectedly strong language, the Justice Department said yesterday that SBC Communications Inc., the No. 1 local phone company, should not be allowed to sell long-distance communications services to its customers in Texas.

title: 2 Lawmakers Accuse Port Authority of Lagging in Jet Noise Abatement Efforts
description: Two members of Congress said today that the Port Authority had lagged behind other airport operators in devoting federal funds and airport revenue to noise abatement.

title: Religion in Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Compromise on Confederate Flag Gains Support
description: Gov. Jim Hodges won the support of several ranking black state legislators today for a proposal to remove the Confederate battle flag from atop the State Capitol and to raise a smaller version of the flag near a monument on the side of the Statehouse.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Feb. 8 with the Personal Health column, about nuts, misstated the allergenic risk of nut oils. Most nut oil refined in the United States is free of protein, the allergen in nuts, and therefore does not cause problems for people with nut allergies. But oil extracted by certain methods, like the cold-pressed process, may still contain protein and can indeed pose a risk. Information is available from the Food Allergy Network at www.foodallergy.org or (703) 691-3179.

title: Hackers' Tools, Online
description: To the Editor:

title: KERR-MCGEE PLANS TO ACQUIRE TWO CHEMICAL PLANTS
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy titanium dioxide plants in Savannah, Ga., and Rotterdam, the Netherlands, from Kemira Oy, Finland's biggest chemicals maker, for $403 million. The purchase will make Kerr-McGee the world's third-largest producer of the pigment. Its share of the market will rise to 16 percent from 10 percent. Kerr-McGee, which is based in Oklahoma City, said it expected to save $40 million a year and increase profit by combining the plants with its existing pigment operations.

title: Kosovo Peacekeepers Warn That Extremists 'Want Peace to Fail'
description: The two men in charge of this divided town, a United Nations administrator and a French general, said today that they were counting on two foreign judges to punish extremists after 12 days of violence.

title: Scientists Defend Suspended Gene Therapy
description: In a vigorous defense of their suspended gene therapy program, officials at the University of Pennsylvania said today that while there were administrative lapses they did not in any way contribute to the death of an 18-year-old patient and amounted to little more than ''minor deviations'' in bookkeeping.

title: CMGI TO BUY STAKE IN TALLAN, E-COMMERCE CONSULTANT
description: CMGI Inc., an Internet venture fund, agreed to buy 80 percent of an electronic commerce consultant, Tallan Inc., for $920 million in cash and stock to enlarge its Web-services unit before spinning it off. CMGI, whose shares have more than quadrupled in the last year, will pay $580 million in stock and $340 million in cash for the stake in the company, which is based in Glastonbury, Conn. Tallan helps companies develop electronic commerce strategies and create Web sites. Tallan will be merged with CMGI Solutions, the Internet software and consulting unit that CMGI created in December. CMGI Solutions will be spun off within six months, CMGI said.

title: Q & A
description: Pinched Nerves

title: Computer Associates to Purchase Sterling Software for About $4 Billion
description: February 14, 2000

title: At 'Camp Hyundai,' North Korea's Closed Society Opens Up  a Bit
description: JANGJEON, North Korea  The advice of the tour leader aboard the cruise ship was explicit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, EDITH
description: KANE-Edith. On February 14, 2000 at age 93. Her beloved sisters, Fay Kane and Evelyn Moss, her brother-in-law Irving Moss, and her nieces, nephews and friends mourn her loss. Contributions to favorite charities are suggested in lieu of flowers. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., at 12 noon, Friday February 18th.

title: W. A. Andres, 73, Executive Who Led Growth of Dayton Hudson
description: William A. Andres, who led the Dayton Hudson Corporation's expansion from a regional department store chain to a national retailing powerhouse, died Wednesday of lymphoma in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 73.

title: McCain Embraces the Press And Open Campaigns of Old
description: Senator John McCain often says he wants to imitate his hero Ronald Reagan and broaden his party's appeal. But it is one of those odd twists of politics that he is trying to do this by running against the controlled, high-gloss techniques that Mr. Reagan as much as anyone brought to presidential campaigns.

title: Yankees Look for Diamonds in Pitching Rough
description: With the Yankees' pitchers and catchers beginning workouts in four days in Tampa, Fla., the pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre and General Manager Brian Cashman reviewed their list of spring training goals yesterday for each of the pitchers in camp. They had a long list of young pitchers to discuss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODFRIED, BENJAMIN
description: GODFRIED-Benjamin. 79, died February 13. Survived by loving wife Sylvia, sons Bob and Larry. All loved this Bronx druggist.

title: Years Ago, Bush Adviser in Texas Helped Draft a Poll Using Disputed Method
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has expressed outrage at the accusation from the McCain camp that his campaign is involved in the controversial political technique in which workers give the impression of taking a public opinion poll while actually spreading negative charges about a candidate.

title: Jupiter's Stormy Weather Is Like Earth's, Only More So
description: The weather on Jupiter seems always stormy. Lightning flashes deep in the enveloping gas clouds. Eddies of atmospheric turbulence bob along the margins of jet streams, feeding energy into titanic, long-lived whirlpools. Thunderheads tower more than 30 miles above surrounding clouds, and new observations reveal that moist heat rising in these stormy updrafts probably supplies the energy driving most Jovian weather.

title: Hostile Takeover Bid in Japan Ends on an Educational Note
description: A deal described as Japan's first indigenous hostile takeover attempt ended in what Americans would call a failure today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOKVIS, JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: STOKVIS-Joseph William. Dear Daddy, on the first anniversary of our terrible loss, we miss you more than ever. I talk to you every day. We celebrated Mom's ninety-second birthday with her. She talks to you too. With so much love always, Irene, Paul and Jonathan

title: Angry Chorus Monitors the Proceedings
description: The hooting started around the time that Sean Carroll said that he had become a police officer because he was raised to help people. For the busload of people who had come from New York City to the overflow courtroom in the Albany County courthouse, where the trial can be seen daily on closed circuit-television, that answer was only one of many that strained credulity.

title: The Hackers' Lessons
description: To whoever it was out there in cyberspace who launched last week's ''smurf'' attacks that temporarily crippled Yahoo, Amazon.com, E-Trade, eBay and CNN.com by overloading their web servers with fake requests for data, let me just say on behalf of all of us: Thank you.

title: Trail Leads to a Transformed State
description: The popular perception that Michigan elections are still dominated by legions of auto workers toting lunch pails is as dated as a Chevrolet Citation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ALLAN D.
description: SIEGEL-Allan D. Most wonderful, loving father to Julie Bennett, Jodi Siegel and Jocelyn Siegel. Loving Grandpa to Max and Shaefer Bennett, Isaac and Simon Davenport. Beloved brother of Florence Goldberg and Martin Siegel. Loving friend to many. His humor, love of life, dedication to family and generosity of spirit made many lives happier and fuller. He will be deeply missed. Services at Gutterman Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, February 16, at 1 P.M.

title: NO SANCTIONS FOR TALISMAN
description: A report for the Canadian government into the activities of Talisman Energy Inc. in Sudan, which has been devastated by civil war, is critical of the company's role in providing indirect support to government forces. Canada will not, however, impose any sanctions against Talisman or against Sudan. Shares of Talisman, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, rose 10 percent on the news, to $26.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange. John Harker, the Canadian diplomat who wrote the report, said that the company ''does seem to want to do what is right,'' but that it had turned a blind eye to atrocities and had allowed the military of Sudan to use airstrips at Talisman oil drilling sites.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR STRENGTHENS. The dollar gained against the euro as American stocks rebounded from a plunge on Friday. In New York, the dollar ended trading at 97.86 cents a euro, compared with 98.69 cents on Friday.

title: Provident Bankshares Faces Proxy Fight
description: The Provident Bankshares Corporation faces another proxy fight from a group of investors who have renewed their call for the bank, one of the biggest in Maryland, to put itself up for sale.

title: Untangling a Complex Chain of Schemes
description: A mother and son accused of murdering an Upper East Side millionaire devised a scheme to steal her town house with so many details that they were eventually tripped up by the complexity of the scheme, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the cartoonist Charles M. Schulz misidentified the NASA moon mission in which the lunar excursion module was nicknamed Snoopy and the command module Charlie Brown. It was Apollo 10, not Apollo 11.

title: Safe Stolen at Restaurant
description: Two men stole a safe containing $200,000 yesterday at a Greenwich Village restaurant, the police said.

title: The Latin Files
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODKIND, LOUIS W.
description: GOODKIND-Louis W., Esq. Of Irvington, NY; born St. Paul, MN, August 29, 1914, died at his home on February 13, 2000. He is survived by his wife, Carol Eaton Bourquin Goodkind, his three daughters, Barbara Pepper, Mary Goodkind Garner and Kathryn Goodkind Boyle, and his stepchildren, Philip F. Eaton and Dorothee Bourquin Caulfield, and his five grandsons and one great-granddaughter. Visiting will be at the Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (Exit 17 Saw Mill), in Dobbs Ferry, NY, on Wednesday, February 16, 2000, 7 PM until 9 PM. Funeral mass will be on Thursday, February 17, 2000 at 10 AM, Immaculate Conception Church, N. Broadway, Irvington, NY. Burial service will be private. In lieu of flowers please send conributions to either The Community Hospital at Dobbs Ferry or the Irvington Volunteer Ambulance Corps.

title: North and South Koreans Meet on a Mountain Path
description: The last time Yoon Chun Ok and Yoon Chun Sook climbed this majestic mountain, which Koreans consider sacred, was in 1948, when the Korean peninsula had not yet been divided by war.

title: Sao Paulo Journal; Rich Brazilians Rise Above Rush-Hour Jams
description: At night the skyline in this city of 16 million is a dazzling display of lights that can easily remind visitors of Manhattan.

title: Ex-Attica Inmates Recount Shattered Lives and Dreams
description: Gary Haynes, Attica survivor, waited almost 30 years for this day.

title: Lear Posts Quarterly Profit, Reversing Loss
description: The Lear Corporation, the world's largest maker of automotive seats and interiors, said today that it had earned $92.7 million in the fourth quarter, reversing a loss a year earlier, when it posted a one-time charge related to a restructuring.

title: Suspicion Grows About Flaw Before Crash
description: An investigator at the National Transportation Safety Board said today that its experts were increasingly convinced that a jackscrew in the tail of an Alaska Airlines jet was damaged before the plane crashed and was a factor in problems controlling the aircraft just before it went down in the Pacific Ocean last month.

title: Aid for Parents Who Are Overwhelmed
description: On a cold day in East New York recently, the ice and snow drifted up against abandoned buildings and empty lots.

title: EUROPEAN DEFENSE INTEGRATION
description: The three companies that are trying to form the European Aeronautics Defense and Space Company moved a step closer toward achieving their goal by announcing the lineup of top management and the distribution of labor between the German, French and Spanish participants. The new company, built from the aerospace divisions of DaimlerChrysler A.G. in Germany, Aerospatiale Matra S.A. of France and Construcciones Aeronauticas S.A. of Spain, named a carefully balanced roster of 25 French executives, 23 Germans and 4 Spaniards. As previously announced, the co-chief executives will be Philippe Camus of Aerospatiale and Rainer Hertrich of DaimlerChrysler.

title: Lenore Wingard, 88, Swimmer Who Won Two Olympic Medals
description: Lenore Kight Wingard, an American swimmer who won medals in the 1932 and 1936 Olympics, died Wednesday at a hospital in Cincinnati, where she lived. She was 88.

title: Richard McCormick, Theologian, Dies at 77
description: The Rev. Richard A. McCormick, for many years the dominant American voice in Roman Catholic moral theology, especially on the daunting questions of medical ethics that have emerged in recent times, died on Saturday. He was 77 and lived at the Colombiere Center in Clarkston, Mich., a residence of the Society of Jesus.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Executives hope the marriage of interactive television and consumers will be prosperous.
description: BUILD it, and they will come, advertising executives seem to be saying about interactive television, according to a new survey.

title: Which Path for America Abroad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILLERSDORF, ADELE
description: PILLERSDORF-Adele. Beloved wife of the late Herbert, devoted mother of William Rosenblum, Steven Rosenblum and Donna Mann, adored grandmother of six, dear sister of Bunny and Max Nevis, cherished aunt. Service at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Ave. L), Brooklyn, Wednesday, 1:15 P.M.

title: Review/Fashion; Placid Times at Klein and Karan, As Daryl K Tries to Stir a Storm
description: It was beautiful. Calvin Klein had wrangled two of the biggest stars, Gwyneth Paltrow and Julia Roberts, for his front row on Friday night. Other designers had celebrities, even bona fide examples of royalty, but they did not compare to what Mr. Klein had. And what were these two star catches doing throughout most of the show? They were chuckling and talking and beaming their 250-watt ceramic smiles . . . at each other.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a protest by members of the Students of Color Coalition at the University of Michigan over a student club's past practice of adapting American Indian traditions in its rituals misspelled the last name of the coalition spokesman. He is Joe A. Reilly, not O'Reilly.

title: WATERFORD WEDGWOOD SALES
description: The Dublin-based luxury goods manufacturer Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C., the parent company of Waterford Crystal, announced record group sales of 879.6 million euros, or $866.8 million, for the fiscal year that ended Dec. 31, an increase of 20.4 percent over 1998. In the last year Waterford Wedgwood acquired the cookware manufacturer All-Clad Inc., which accounted for sales of 36.7 million euros, or $36.2 million, and appointed Sarah, Duchess of York, as its American spokeswoman. Brian Lavery

title: Intel Shows Faster Chip Yet
description: Intel Shows Faster Chip Yet

title: 3 Retirees Rate Life After Work
description: How's retirement? Here is what a few retirees have to say about how they are managing, especially financially.

title: House Passes $6.9 Billion Computer Research Bill
description: House Passes $6.9 Billion Computer Research Bill

title: CHECKFREE HOLDINGS BUYING A RIVAL, TRANSPOINT
description: The CheckFree Holdings Corporation, which lets consumers pay bills online, agreed yesterday to pay $1 billion in stock for its closely held rival TransPoint, a joint venture of the First Data Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation. CheckFree said it would exchange 17 million shares for TransPoint, giving First Data, Microsoft and a TransPoint investor, Citigroup Inc., a combined 23 percent stake in CheckFree. The three companies agreed to pay CheckFree, which is also backed by Intuit Inc., $100 million in cash when the transaction is completed. CheckFree is looking to lock up a dominant position in electronic bill payment. The deal for TransPoint was announced after the close of trading yesterday; shares of CheckFree fell $1.875, to $68.25.

title: Honors
description: * Two trade publications -- Media, in Asia, and Strategy, in Canada -- named Optimum Media Direction, part of the Omnicom Group, New York, agency of the year.

title: TOWER AUTOMOTIVE AGREES TO BUY DR. MELEGHY
description: Tower Automotive Inc., the maker of stamped parts for automobile frames, agreed to buy the closely held Dr. Meleghy for about $110 million to expand in Germany. Dr. Meleghy, which has operations in Germany, Hungary and Poland, makes metal stampings and assemblies for the European auto industry, including suspension links, brake parts and muffler hangers. The company has annual revenue of about $120 million. Tower, with 1999 sales of $2.17 billion, wants to broaden its product offerings outside of North America as automakers increasingly look to suppliers that can provide entire sections of cars, rather than individual parts, and provide their products worldwide.

title: British Court Orders Disclosure of Pinochet's Medical Records
description: In a decision extending Gen. Augusto Pinochet's enforced stay in England, the High Court today ordered Britain to disclose a doctors' report on his health to four countries seeking his extradition to face criminal charges.

title: Vatican and P.L.O. Sign Pact Guaranteeing the Church's Rights
description: Seeking to secure the rights of the Roman Catholic Church in a future Palestinian state, the Vatican signed an agreement today with the Palestine Liberation Organization that would protect freedom of religion and the legal status of Christian churches.

title: Paying for the Uninsured
description: At the end of last year, Gov. George Pataki and New York State legislative leaders approved a commendable new program called Family Health Plus to provide coverage for uninsured low-income parents and other adults. But now the governor is battling with the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, and the Democrat-controlled Assembly over how that program is to be financed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Kosovo Flashpoint
description: NATO-led peacekeepers in Kosovo are facing their biggest challenge since the air war ended last June. Serbs and Albanians in the ethnically divided city of Mitrovica have been attacking each other for the past two weeks, and NATO has increasingly been drawn into the conflict.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the baritone Pablo Elvira on Friday misstated the nationality of the cellist and conductor Pablo Casals, who invited him to sing an early Casals composition. Although Casals lived for many years in Puerto Rico, he was Spanish.

title: Lions Recoup Some Of Sanders's Bonus
description: The Lions were awarded some -- but not all -- of the money they wanted to be returned from the retired running back Barry Sanders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMES, WALTER J.
description: HOLMES-Walter J., 93, formerly of the Bronx died Friday in Albany, NY. He retired as Director of Public Relations for NYS Comptroller Arthur Levitt. He was a 60 year member of the Bronx and Albany Lions Clubs. He was a past district governor of Lions district 20-R2, past International Counselor and receipient of the Lions Melvin Jones Award. He was the husband of Grace Pritchard Holmes; father of Ellen Misita of North Merrick, NY; Grandfather of Andrew Misita. Contibutions to Albany Lions Club or Bronx Lions Club.

title: Their Way: Short, but Straight Down the Fairway
description: SOME of the happiest people I know are the retired folks who have made a home-away-from-home, a sort of earthly Valhalla, at their local golf course. I hope to join them one day, and though I haven't asked, I'm pretty sure they'll have me. They're not choosy.

title: RECORD BANK EARNINGS
description: In the best earnings performance ever for a Brazilian bank, Banco Itau S.A.'s net income more than doubled in 1999, to 1.87 billion reais, or $1.06 billion. In the fourth quarter, earnings at Itau rose nearly 50 percent, to 411.1 million reais, or $233.6 million. Prescient bets in foreign exchange trading, before and after Brazil's currency devaluation a year ago, were largely responsible for the earnings growth. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALSIMER, ADELE M.
description: DALSIMER-Adele M. Cherished friend, you will live in our hearts forever. Susan, Elliot, Andrew and Liza

title: Say Goodbye to the Office, Say Hello to Who Knows What
description: MAYBE next week, Joe Volz will roll over in his bed at 7 a.m., tucking the blankets under his gray beard, and go back to sleep.

title: BCE of Canada Offers $6.7 Billion to Buy the Rest of Teleglobe
description: Canada's largest telecommunications company, BCE Inc., took a big step today toward its goal of expanding globally with a $6.7 billion stock deal to buy the 77 percent of Teleglobe Inc. that it does not already own and invest in Teleglobe's network linking 160 cities around the world.

title: Like a Lover Reincarnated, 'Vanessa' Boldly Returns
description: That Samuel Barber's opera ''Vanessa'' has slipped from the active repertory is surprising. When the work received its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in 1958, with Dimitri Mitropoulous conducting an illustrious cast headed by the soprano Eleanor Steber, its prospects for lasting success seemed good. Audiences were enthusiastic. That summer ''Vanessa'' became the first American opera to be performed at the Salzburg Festival. It also earned Barber the 1958 Pulitzer Prize in Music.

title: Berkshire Lists Some Holdings In U.S. Filing
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, reported stakes in Citigroup, Liz Claiborne, Jones Apparel Group and Dun & Bradstreet, among others.

title: Motorola Forms Chip Unit for Emerging Businesses
description: Motorola Forms Chip Unit for Emerging Businesses

title: FOOD STUFF
description: French Potatoes A Cut Above Frites

title: N.C.A.A. Asks More Questions As St. John's Picks Up Victory
description: ''Here we go again,'' St. John's guard Erick Barkley said tonight as he passed reporters surrounding Coach Mike Jarvis in the Conte Forum.

title: Our Towns; A Name Left On Collars, And a Dogg
description: THIS dog may not have been what Charles M. Schulz had in mind.

title: Production Surged 1% In January
description: United States industrial production in January posted its largest gain in 18 months as factories, utilities and mines all increased output, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: GERMAN-FRENCH INTERNET DEAL EXPECTED
description: Germany's largest telecommunications company, Deutsche Telekom A.G., is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire Club Internet, France's third-biggest online service provider, executives close to the talks said. Lagardere, Club Internet's parent company, would receive about a 5 percent stake in T-Online, Deutsche Telekom's Internet service provider, the executives said. Deutsche Telekom is planning on spinning off T-Online this spring and taking the company public. The tie-up would create an Internet service provider with more than 4.5 million customers. The move is part of Deutsche Telekom's plan to create a pan-European telephone network that offers voice, data and mobile telephone services. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Allow Rape Victims To Seek Final Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUIRK, WILLIAM T.
description: QUIRK-William T. The staff of the Kings County District Attorney's Office mourns with deep sorrow the passing of William T. Quirk, father of Dennis Quirk, President of the New York State Court Officers Association and our dear friend. We send our heartfelt condolences to his entire family and know that he will be truly missed. Charles J. Hynes, District Attorney and the Staff of the Kings County District Attorney's Office

title: Thomas Is Remembered For His Heart and Drive
description: Comedy and dance, music and songs, tributes, video highlights and prayers were offered today in a high-spirited memorial service for Derrick Thomas here at Kemper Arena before several thousand people.

title: Nets Resume Woeful Play Under Scrutiny
description: Michael Rowe, the president of the Nets, vowed last week that things would be different and changes would be made in the second half of the season. Speaking powerfully and optimistically, Rowe said he would attend road games, get a closer look at the team's problems and play Mr. Fix-It.

title: A Most Delicate Balancing Act
description: WHO made the last dozen calls to your pager or cell phone? Was the boss on your list? The baby sitter? The carry-out place on the corner? Added together, such numbers are likely to form a mosaic of your life.

title: McCain Catches Mud, Then Parades It
description: Under withering attack from Gov. George W. Bush and his conservative allies, Senator John McCain and his insurgent campaign fought hard today to build public resentment against the assault and try to turn it into a boomerang against Mr. Bush.

title: For Some, Retirement Begins The Instant the Check Clears
description: JERRY BAKER, an early-retired millionaire who lives on a few acres across the Columbia River from Portland, Ore., has just one problem five and a half years into his postwork life.

title: Commuter-Tax Repeal Goes Before Top Court
description: The repeal of New York City's commuter tax went before the state's highest court today, and the judges reacted skeptically to the city's claim that the state could not end the tax without the city's consent.

title: But Which to Bring Home? A Buyer's Guide
description: BUYING good bacon does not have to involve a trip to a specialty food shop. Most supermarkets carry slab bacon in addition to the commercial presliced kind, either at the butcher counter or prepackaged in the meat department.

title: Loss Widens at Lycos
description: Loss Widens at Lycos

title: Taking the Dangers Out of Hanging Around the House
description: SEVEN years ago, Rosemary Bakker received a dreaded phone call: her aging mother had fallen, broken a hip and needed to be hospitalized. As upsetting as that was, Ms. Bakker soon found that more trouble lay ahead.

title: Sale Planned by TV Guide
description: TV Guide Inc., publisher of the weekly television-listings magazine, said today that it was in talks to sell part of its SSDS unit, a computer consultant and employee recruiter. TV Guide, which is being acquired for $9.2 billion by Gemstar International Group, is negotiating with unidentified parties to sell the consulting division of SSDS, said Peter C. Boylan III, the president of TV Guide. The division has been a drag on earnings, said John Corcoran, an analyst at CIBC World Markets. The company, based in Tulsa, wants to keep the Knowledge Workers Inc. employee-recruiting division of SSDS, Mr. Boylan said. SSDS, based in Denver, has 330 employees and annual sales of $37 million, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, EDWARD
description: KATZ-Edward, Ph.D. The membership, faculty and candidates of the American Institute for Psychoanalysis mourn the passing of a valued colleague and student. Dr. Katz's enthusiasm and love of learning will be greatly missed.

title: Knicks Have No Match For the Magic of Carter
description: All the grim-faced starters finished the fourth quarter sitting on the bench, staring at a game that seemed like a reflection in a fun-house mirror.

title: Voodoo Priest Goes on Trial in Fire That Burned Woman
description: Anguished about evil spirits and noises in the basement of her home, a Haitian pop singer sought help from a voodoo priest in October 1997. In the last of nine prayer rituals around the priest's altar in a rented garage in Irvington, N.J., the singer's hooded white robe started burning, and she suffered severe burns to her neck, face and chest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, RUTH
description: SIEGEL-Ruth. On February 13, age 87. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Mother of Jonas and Judy Siegel, Arnold Siegel & Susan Futterman. Grandmother of Michele and Phil Eisenberg, Lawrence, and Lauren Siegel. Sister of Charlotte Jacobson and the late Miriam Tabak. Formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY, and Lake Worth, Fla. Dedicated Hadassah leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROFFMAN, RUTH L.
description: ROFFMAN-Ruth L. Of Teaneck, NJ on February 14. Beloved and adored wife of the late Sidney. Most precious mother of Barbara Wider and husband Jerry. Loving Nana to Todd, Jedd, Jena & Erez. The memory of her devotion, praise and love will sustain us always. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St, Hackensack, N.J., Wednesday, 12 noon. Should friends desire, contributions to the Sidney and Ruth Roffman Scholarship Fund at the Teaneck Jewish Center would be appreciated.

title: I.B.M. Offer on Shipping
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it would begin shipping computers to customers on the same day as ordered if the order was placed through its Web site. I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, said it would ship orders the same day for customers in the United States who place orders by 3 p.m. Eastern time for nine computer models, including ThinkPad notebooks and Aptiva personal computers. The company said the move would enable it to cut prices for PC's and notebooks.

title: Mets' Hampton Decides Contract Talks Can Wait
description: When Mike Hampton said he was willing to negotiate a contract extension after his trade to the Mets last December, the team was pleasantly surprised.

title: These Trips Fill Up Fast, No Matter the Destination
description: FOR Ruth McCormick, getting lost in the Costa Rican rain forest and trudging about until covered head to toe in mud was a nuisance. Being told that she and the 15 other older adults in her tour group would have to walk a tattered rope bridge strung high across a crocodile-infested river to reach safety was another problem altogether.

title: Hearing on Suit by Reporter Held Captive
description: A federal judge took the first step today in awarding damages in a lawsuit filed by Terry Anderson seeking $100 million from the Iranian government for the pain and suffering he experienced during nearly seven years as a hostage in Lebanon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARTH, EDITH
description: BARTH-Edith. February 16, 1997. Forever mourned, forever missed, forever loved and always in our thoughts. Your family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAO, PAUL K.T.
description: ZAO-Paul K.T., Rev. Dr. Age 87, died on February 15, 2000, Carmel, IN. Ordained in Rome, Italy on December 12, 1953. Born in China. Professor of Economics Lewis University, Lockport, IL. Fond uncle of Yi Ren Shao, Yi-Chang Shao, Yi Shi Shao, Mary Shao, YiCi Shao and Theresa Shao. Family will receive friends Friday February 18 from 2-5 & 7-9PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 St, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, February 19, St. Johns R.C. Church (Kingsbridge, Bronx) at 10:45AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, JEROME
description: FRANKEL-Jerome.Passed away February 14. Devoted and loving husband to Lydia. Father to Joshua and Peter. Grandfather to Jake, Madeline and Aerin. A fighter to the end, he will be deeply missed. Invictus.

title: Valentine's 'A' Lineup Was Quickly Revised
description: Bobby Valentine has had spare time in recent weeks. He has flown thousands of miles, to Japan and Italy, New York and Texas and, now, spring training in Florida. Not once, however, has he written out a lineup for the 2000 Mets, whose pitchers and catchers had their first spring workout today at Thomas J. White Stadium.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Study Says the Internet Increases Social Isolation

title: A Plan Is Unveiled for a Women's League
description: Saying that the time seemed right, John S. Hendricks, chairman and chief executive officer of Discovery Communications, announced yesterday the formation of the Women's United Soccer Association, or W.U.S.A., a women's professional league scheduled to begin play in the spring of 2001.

title: 2 Resign From Gymboree
description: The Gymboree Corporation, a retailer of children's clothing and accessories, said Gary White, its chief executive, and Melanie Cox, the president, resigned amid lower-than-expected sales and a loss in the fourth quarter. The company, based in Burlingame, appointed the chairman, Stuart Moldaw, as chief executive. Lisa Harper, senior vice president for merchandising and design, will become general merchandising manager. Gymboree warned this month that its fourth-quarter results would fall short of expectations. Shares of Gymboree, which operates 605 stores, fell 53.125 cents, to $3.96875.

title: People
description: * Richard Constant was named chief executive at Gavin Anderson & Co., New York, part of the Omnicom Group, succeeding Gavin Anderson, who remains chairman. Mr. Constant had been chief executive of the London office, and will remain based in London. Also, Robert Mead, president and chief executive of the New York office, heading North American operations, was named to the new post of president of the agency, and Eugene Golembeski, chief financial officer, was named to the new post of chief operating officer.

title: New Argentine President Orders Purge of 'Dirty War' Remnants
description: Just two months after taking office, President Fernando de la Rua has ordered a purge of the military and civilian intelligence apparatus that will eliminate many of the last suspected participants of the notorious ''dirty war'' of the 1970's and 80's from the government payroll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOPHER, IRENE
description: SOPHER - Irene. Congregation Chasam Sopher mourns the loss of the mother of our supporters and congregants, Joseph and Jacob Sopher. She was a shining example for the family of how to live life properly. May they know no further sorrow and be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Azriel Siff Eugene Weiser, President

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wal-Mart Has Its Ups And Downs
description: Propelled by strong growth in its superstores and international operations, Wal-Mart Stores reported another year of record sales and profits yesterday. So, naturally, its stock declined.

title: Apple Introduces New Computers
description: Apple Computer announced a series of new portable and desktop computers in Tokyo today including a translucent graphite-colored version of its consumer iBook portable.

title: Sorting Out The Accessible Barberas
description: YEARS ago, I stumbled on the perfect everyday red wine: barbera. Its combination of sweet fruit and buzz-saw acidity made it a delicious and versatile companion for robust foods like pasta and tomato sauce or a broiled steak, yet it was pleasingly untannic and would not overwhelm more delicate fish or chicken.

title: Saving Enough? Ask a Web Site (Or Better Yet, More Than One)
description: ALL over the World Wide Web, calculators are available to tell people how much money they ought to be saving for retirement.

title: Tandycrafts to Sell Unit
description: Tandycrafts Inc., the No. 2 United States maker of picture frames, plans to sell its gifts and office supplies units as it reorganizes to focus on decorating lines and home furnishings. The Tandycrafts gifts division includes a maker of buttons and ribbon, a sports memorabilia marketer and a Christian products seller. Its Sav-On Office Supplies unit is a 41-store chain operating in 11 Southern states. Tandycrafts, which is based here, will use sales proceeds for continuing operations and to reduce debt, and may take a charge related to the sales, depending on proceeds.

title: A New Sizzle In the Kitchen
description: THE potato cake at Monkey Bar is a study in simple luxury: tender layers of potato and melting Gruyere, beautifully bound by mahogany bands of bacon. The dish is as well crafted as a Shaker table, sturdy yet elegant in its countrified way, and thoroughly satisfying. You hardly notice the steak alongside it.

title: Housing the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: The Democratic Word On McCain: Ambivalent
description: Senator John McCain's surge in the Republican presidential race has unsettled some prominent Democrats, who worry that his compelling biography would overshadow his conservative record and find broad appeal among Democrats and independents in a general election.

title: Wilpon's Expectations
description: Fred Wilpon would not say the Mets must reach the World Series for the 2000 season to be considered successful, but the team's president and chief executive officer admitted that the obvious mandate is to qualify for the postseason for the second straight year.

title: Senior Bank Official Took Bribe, U.S. Says
description: The Justice Department has evidence that a senior Bank of New York official accepted a bribe from the husband and wife implicated in the money laundering investigation at the bank, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: China's Latest Theft
description: Reports that the Chinese government intercepted $25,000 in foreign donations intended for the families of those killed in the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests may have shocked some, but not me.

title: Judge Approves $8 Million Deal for Victims of Attica Torture
description: A federal judge approved a settlement today in which New York State is to pay $8 million to the inmates who were tortured after the 1971 Attica prison uprising, paving the way for the end of one of the longest and messiest chapters in criminal justice history.

title: Police Union Official Concedes Advising Silence on Louima to Officers
description: His voice seething with controlled rage, a high-ranking police union official grudgingly testified yesterday that he had told several officers at the 70th Precinct in Brooklyn to ''sit tight'' and not talk to investigators about the vicious assault on Abner Louima. But he denied that he had coached the officers in getting their stories straight.

title: Odjick Traded Before Loss Ends Streak
description: The young Islanders got their first reality check this morning when their popular wing Gino Odjick was abruptly traded to the Philadelphia Flyers for the veteran Mikael Andersson. They got their second when the San Jose Sharks took the ice at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: You Don't Have to Be Old to Sue for Age Discrimination
description: THE nation's courts may have spent years issuing opinions that make it harder for older workers to sue their employers for age discrimination, but that has not discouraged a younger generation of employees from using the antidiscrimination laws more often to challenge being fired or not being promoted fast enough.

title: A Lively Look at the Staff of Life
description: IN France, a baguette weighs 250 grams and a flute only 200. Ancient Pompeii had more than 40 bakeries, whose style of domed oven is still used for hearth-baked breads. Powdering wigs with flour-based cosmetics was prohibited during famines in the 17th and 18th centuries. And phallus-shaped breads were once baked for weddings in parts of Germany.

title: Harry Prichett Sr., 79, a Creator of Early Attempt at Interactive TV
