description: Harry William Prichett Sr., an architect of television's first attempt at interactive broadcasting with the 1950's children's program ''Winky Dink and You,'' died on Feb. 5 at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHBY, LUCILLE E.
description: ASHBY-Lucille E. Regret to announce the passing of Lucille Ashby of Brooklyn, NY. Services will be held at Frank R. Bell Funeral Home in Brooklyn on February 17th at 10 A.M.

title: Treasury Prices Fall on Report of Higher Factory Output
description: Prices of Treasury securities were down moderately yesterday, after a stronger-than-expected gain in industrial production raised investor concern about further interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve Board in the months ahead.

title: Want to get yourself some opera tickets? Just go down to the soda machine and swipe your card.
description: IF advertisements already seem to be everywhere, just wait. New technology now makes it possible to place multiple Web-based marketing on vending machines, A.T.M.'s and even office equipment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a change that lets census respondents assign themselves to more than one race misstated the name of a Web site run by Charles Byrd, who expressed hope that a time would come when race did not matter. It is Interracial Voice, not Inter Racial Voice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACKER, LILLIAN
description: PACKER-Lillian. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member Lillian Packer. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President

title: Reno, Freeh Testify on Obstacles to Fighting Internet Crime
description: Reno, Freeh Testify on Obstacles to Fighting Internet Crime

title: BRAZIL THREATENS TRADE LAWSUIT
description: Escalating a trade dispute over tariffs imposed by the United States on steel imports, Development Minister Alcides Tapias said the country might file a complaint with the World Trade Organization. Last week, the United States imposed tariffs of up to 19 percent on some steel imports from Brazil and other countries. Displeasure with the measure soured a brief visit by Commerce Secretary William M. Daley. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: THE CHEF
description: DURING the last few years, fish marinated in miso has become a popular dish in restaurants all over town. It is not hard to understand why. The preparation is instantly appealing: the miso transforms the texture of the fish while adding an intriguing interplay of sweet, salty and tangy flavors.

title: DYCOM TO BUY RIVAL NIELS FUGAL FOR $84.1 MILLION
description: Dycom Industries, a cable layer for telephone and cable-television companies, agreed to buy a rival, Niels Fugal Sons for $84.1 million in stock to expand in the West. Dycom, which is based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., said it would exchange about 1.82 million shares of common stock for the closely held Niels Fugal, which is based in Pleasant Grove, Utah. Niels Fugal is a telecommunications construction and maintenance company with 260 employees and revenue of $52 million for the year ended Jan. 31.

title: On L.I., a Cautionary Tale Of 2 Different Governments
description: The political and fiscal landscape certainly changes east of Exit 48 on the Long Island Expressway, where cash-starved Nassau County gives way to solvent Suffolk.

title: Oil-Reserve 'Swaps'
description: To the Editor:

title: Council's Vote On Three Bills Could Provoke Mayoral Vetoes
description: In the first of a series of bills expected to provoke a confrontation with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a City Council committee approved a proposal yesterday that would create 2,500 ''transitional jobs'' a year for welfare recipients.

title: Gore Says Clinton Choice for Election Panel Is 'Unfit' for Office
description: In a split from President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore said today that he would not have nominated Bradley Smith, a Republican who opposes the overhaul of the campaign finance system, to the board of the Federal Election Commission and that he would urge the Senate to reject the president's nomination.

title: Known From the 1900's, Sailing Into the 2000's
description: An overused word, gala derives from the Old French ''gale,'' which signifies merrymaking. The routine rather than the festive, however, colored an evening billed as Millennium International Ballet Gala, Stars of the 21st Century, on Monday night at the New York State Theater. There were exceptions, notably with the dancing of Agnes Letestu of the Paris Opera Ballet and Lucia Lacarra of San Francisco Ballet. Nonetheless the 13 dancers, mostly familiar from these companies and American Ballet Theater, New York City Ballet, the Bolshoi and Kirov Ballets in Russia and the Royal Ballet in England, were more solid than spectacular in a program of pas de deux and two solos.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday describing a Bill Bradley advertisement that features Michael Jordan misstated the name of the hall of fame for basketball players and coaches. It is the Naismith Memorial Hall of Fame, not the National Basketball Association Hall of Fame.

title: Capricious Georgia Tornadoes Killed Young and Old
description: As they picked through the rubble of their lives, the people of southwest Georgia learned firsthand today about the capriciousness of nature. It was not just that the killer tornadoes that roared through on Monday night demolished some houses while leaving neighboring ones unscathed. It was that the storm selected its victims from across the spectrum of life, taking both those who were nearing the end and those who had barely begun.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When you spend your time on the Internet, you don't hear a human voice and you never get a hug.''

title: Tenure Gridlock: When Professors Choose Not to Retire
description: LIKE many college presidents, Arthur Taylor has strong feelings about tenure.

title: Reno and Freeh Testify on Internet Security
description: Reno and Freeh Testify on Internet Security

title: Clerk Vote Validated In Dutchess County
description: New York State's highest court yesterday rejected attempts by the losing candidate in the close race for Dutchess County clerk to hold another election, thereby validating the November upset.

title: Duty Calls the Guard, but Some Bosses Resist
description: Greta M. Powell, a staff sergeant in the 49th Armored Division of the Texas National Guard, taught algebra at Sharpstown High School in Houston -- until word came that she was going to Bosnia for nearly nine months. Then she had to fight to keep her job.

title: Tampa Bay Signs Christy
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers have signed the former Minnesota Vikings center Jeff Christy to a five-year contract. Christy, a 31-year-old free agent who was the National Football Conference's starting center at the Pro Bowl the past two seasons, started 92 of the Vikings' past 96 games.

title: National News Briefs; Living in Projects Raises The Risk of Being Shot
description: A new study by the federal government has found that despite falling levels of crime over all in public housing projects, residents there are more than twice as likely to be shot as Americans generally. The findings, in a report on violent crime in public housing that was compiled by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and is to be made public today by President Clinton, coincide with the administration's expanded efforts on a variety of fronts to deal with gun violence.

title: UNILEVER AND IVILLAGE TO SET UP INTERNET COMPANY
description: Unilever, the maker of personal-care products and ice cream, said yesterday that it would combine with iVillage Inc. to invest $200 million and set up an Internet company aimed at selling beauty products to women. Unilever will provide capital, sponsorship and promotional activities. IVillage, which runs a network of Web sites for women, will contribute its Beauty Channel and Internet expertise. The new venture, based in New York, is expected to generate revenue through advertising, sponsorship and the sale of beauty products online, and will be profitable more quickly than the average for start-up companies, said Christiaan Brakman, a Unilever spokesman.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Easy Call on Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Oh, Those Daring Old Men in Their Virtual Flying Machines
description: WHEN Ezra Howland, 79, wants to start the engines of his World War II bomber, he types ''control-8'' four times. To converse with his Wings of Death Squadron mates, nice chaps from Wales, Russia and New Zealand, he types a ''q'' to talk through the microphone. To hear from his three gunners via intercom, he types ''shift-q.'' There are ''ack-acks'' (antiaircraft guns) to take out; ammo dumps to bomb to kingdom come; and ''vulching'' maneuvers expected from the airfield's defenders, known as vultures.

title: Who's the Boss? Who's a Worker?
description: Last year, a group of temporary employees at ARCO sued the oil company, arguing that they were really full-time workers who deserved better benefits.

title: BP Amoco's 4th-Quarter Profit Doubled on Rise in Oil Prices
description: BP Amoco, the world's third-biggest publicly traded oil company, said today that profit more than doubled in the fourth quarter because of rising oil prices and cost cutting.

title: A Smoky Pepper's Seductive Power
description: PEPPERS release their heat in many ways, whether in a straight drive like cayenne or a consuming explosion like a jalapeno. The Aleppo pepper is more seductive, exuding a mellow, earthy warmth that seems to expand rapidly, then slowly dissipate.

title: Making a Snappy Entrance
description: Each year, we have a senior executive conference. The first year, I rode into a big outdoor rodeo arena in Phoenix on a horse and delivered some remarks. It was a lot of fun. So the next year, the question was, ''Can you top that?''

title: TEXACO AND ENRON TO COMBINE SOME NATURAL GAS UNITS
description: Texaco Inc., the No. 3 U.S. oil company, and the Enron Corporation plan to combine their Louisiana natural gas pipelines and storage operations in a joint venture to reduce costs and expand services in the state. The venture, called Bridgeline Holdings, will have more than 1,000 miles of pipeline and 7 billion cubic feet of storage. The companies expect to complete the transfer March 1. Texaco and Enron, the energy trader, are seeking ways to cut costs amid declining profit margins on sales of the fuel.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Dow Jones yesterday about the acquisition of methodfive Inc., an Internet design firm, by Xceed Inc. described Xceed incorrectly. It helps companies develop electronic commerce and electronic business technology; it is not a marketing company.

title: A B.Y.O.B. Lesson Direct From Burgundy
description: THERE are moments of self-indulgence in the wine trade,'' the London wine merchant Simon Loftus once wrote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIDALA, ARTHUR
description: AIDALA-Arthur. Beloved husband of the late Marietta (nee DeLuca). Loving father of Louis R. Aidala and Lorraine Ambrosio. Adored grandfather of Arthur L. Aidala, Lori Aidala Bambina, Joseph Ambrosio and Anthony Ambrosia. Reposing at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleeker St, NYC, Wednesday 7-9:30, Thursday 2-5 & 79:30 & Friday 2-5 & 7-9:30. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10am at Saint Joseph's Church. Interment Moravian Cemetery.

title: CALENDAR
description: Managing a Restaurant

title: Marriage, Fairness and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Insurance You Really Hope You Will Never Need
description: ALONG with the good news that Americans are living longer comes the sobering prospect that many will lose the ability to take care of themselves. And long-term care -- whether in a nursing home, in an assisted-living center or in one's own home -- can be frightfully expensive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTACUZINO, STEFANA
description: CANTACUZINO-Stefana. February 11, 2000, beloved wife of the late Mircea, loving mother of Dan Cantacuzino, M.D., loving motherin-law of Barbara Cantacuzino. Funeral service Thursday February 17th, at 1 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARD, EUGENE
description: RICHARD-Eugene. On February 12 in Gaithersburg, Md. Beloved husband of Gertrude and father of Eric. Services will be held at Summerville at Potomac, 11215 Seven Locks Rd, Potomac, Md. at 2PM on Saturday, February 19. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Family Link, 317 Castro St, San Francisco, Ca. 94114.

title: A Different Voice, Strongly Anti-McCain
description: If the news media are accused in some conservative quarters of muting criticism of Senator John McCain, there is at least one publication that is all but shouting its hostility toward him: World magazine, a little-known newsweekly for evangelical Christians.

title: Defense Keeps St. Raymond's Unbeaten in League Play
description: Once considered an underdog, St. Raymond's has adapted very well to the role of Catholic League favorite.

title: Legendary Rock 'n' Roll Club Will Reopen in Asbury Park
description: The Stone Pony, the shuttered former mecca of New Jersey rock 'n' roll that gained fame as the cradle of Bruce Springsteen's career, is to reopen on Memorial Day under new ownership as a rock venue true to its roots, lawyers for the buyer and seller said yesterday.

title: Online Ethics Should Begin in Classroom, Educators Say
description: February 16, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSHOT, VIRGINIA HOSLEY
description: HENDERSHOT-Virginia Hosley. February 14, 2000. Beloved and adoring mother of Joan Hendershot Miller & her husband Herbert. Cherished grandmother of Christopher Alan Miller & his wife Gina. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Mass of Christian burial Thursday February 17, 2000, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84th St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, CHUN
description: CHU-Chun. Passed peacefully on February 12 in New York City joining his wife Chin-Shun Chao and son Norton Yuen Chu. Survived by daughter-in-law Frances Lian Ghu, sons Suen Heong and Shiu Ying Chiu, and Jose and Shuk Fong Chau, grandchildren Roderick G.W. Chu, Laura and David Burke, So Kuen and Kan Y. Wong, Robert Chiu, David and Amy Chiu, Tony and Linda Chiu, Kwong Cheuk and Yi Lam Chiu, and Mei Kuen Chiu, and 9 great grandchildren. Born in Toi Shan, China on August 25, 1899, his family and friends were blessed with his love and example in 3 centuries. The family will receive friends on Friday, February 18 from 3:00 to 7:00 PM and Saturday, February 19 from 9:30 to 10:30 AM at Ng Fook Funeral Home, 36 Mulberry Street, New York, NY, telephone 212-374-1003, followed by services at 11:00 AM at The First Chinese Presbyterian Church, 61 Henry Street. Interment in Kensico Cemetery. In Lieu of Flowers, donations to the Rotary District 7230 Foundation Scholarship Fund, 97 Highland Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583 would be appreciated.

title: A Fraternity of 34, Adding Members Very Slowly
description: IT seems unlikely that Bill Clinton will leave the presidency in January to a reception anything like that given to his most distant predecessor, George Washington. When Washington was taken by carriage home to Mount Vernon in 1797, the route was lined with well-wishers wanting to anoint him king of America.

title: In Japan, Golden Years Have Lost Their Glow
description: TAIZO KOMURASAKI has lived the quintessential Japanese life. A salaryman at a trading company that he joined straight out of college, he specialized in arranging financing for the company's activities. He retired, as is the norm in Japan, when he became eligible for his pension at age 60. That was two years ago.

title: Accounts
description: * TiVo, Sunnyvale, Calif., an interactive television service, to Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been at the Los Angeles office of Campbell-Ewald, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about George Jackson, a movie producer, record company executive and Internet company founder, misstated the day of his death. It was Thursday, not Monday.

title: Turning From the Workaday World to the Spirit's Concerns
description: ON weekday mornings, Rabbi Marion Shulevitz, 67, either heads to the gym or to the early minyan at her Manhattan synagogue. Then she attends to her duties as the director of hospice chaplaincy for the New York Board of Rabbis and as a chaplain at the Amsterdam Nursing Home.

title: Rise in Ads Gives a Lift To CBS Profit
description: The CBS Corporation, which is being bought by Viacom Inc. for about $37 billion, said fourth-quarter profit rose, fueled by higher advertising revenue at the television and radio operations.

title: The Smoky Trail To a Great Bacon
description: SIN is in, gastronomically speaking. Which is why I found myself pulling up to Nueske's Hillcrest Farm, about 65 miles west of Green Bay, at midmorning one crystalline day in January, with the car's digital thermometer stuck at 5 implacable degrees below zero.

title: The Mental Challenges of Metal (Really)
description: Anyone who thinks metal is stultifyingly simple stuff hasn't heard Dillinger Escape Plan, a new quintet from New Jersey that headlined a mammoth seven-hour bill at CBGB on Monday night. Typically, the band crams a tune into three minutes, making musical jack-in-the-boxes: the songs change structure and tempo constantly, with equal amounts of cantankerous rage and fiddly, intricate technique.

title: Imagining a Ticket Booth As a Stairway to the Stars; A New Design for the TKTS Booth Off Times Square
description: A familiar New York landmark, the ramshackle pipe-and-canvas TKTS booth at the northern end of Times Square, will be transformed into a bright red grand staircase that will provide visitors to the city with front-row seats to one of the best shows in town.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: What Our College Years Were Meant to Be
description: To the Editor:

description: Home Improvement for Academy

title: Reckonings; An American Pie
description: Talk about globalization. Michel Camdessus probably knew that his last speech as managing director of the International Monetary Fund might be accompanied by some protests. But he surely did not expect an American activist to follow him to Bangkok and throw a cream pie in his face.

title: Making Your Way Through the Maze of Medicare Options
description: IN 1966, Medicare was created with a noble ambition: to provide health care coverage for America's elderly. In practice, advocates for the elderly will tell you, Medicare falls far short of paying for the health care most people need.

title: Coast Guard Starts Review of Its Account
description: The United States Coast Guard is beginning a mandatory review of its account, which has been handled by Emmerling Post Inc. in New York since 1994. Media billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Greece in Midtown

title: After Uprooting Gardeners, City Razes a Garden
description: The narrow lot on East Seventh Street, wedged between two apartment buildings and showing the remains of last fall's crop of vegetables and herbs, would hardly seem capable of attracting attention in the bustle of New York.

title: TV Game Show Angst
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Not the Best?
description: To the Editor:

title: Never Too Old for Exercise (or Teaching It)
description: THOUGH aerobics isn't generally considered a spectator sport, the Combo Deluxe class at Q The Sports Club in Memphis generally draws a crowd. This particular session is a show stopper for one reason: rubberneckers can't help gawking at Peggy Metz, the 68-year-old Energizer bunny of an instructor shouting instructions through a headset microphone as she and her 30 or so sweaty participants go for the burn.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- Buffalo, Rochester and New York City.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE MIDWEST

title: A Hospital's Staff
description: To the Editor:

title: Out-of-the-Way Places That Are Worth the Effort
description: IF visibility is necessary for success, ZIA TONIA is in trouble. This little Italian takeout shop is not easy to stumble upon. You must first decide to enter the blocklong Chelsea Market and then find your way to BuonItalia, an Italian grocery.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES INC., Murray Hill, N.J., the phone-equipment maker, plans to spend $30 million to hire at least 500 people and quadruple production of parts used in fiber optic gear.

title: Moon Over...Nevada?
description: Florida and Pennsylvania have the highest concentrations of retirees now, but in the 21st century they may find themselves eclipsed by some surprising newcomers.

title: My Memo Said What?
description: In the past two weeks, there has been a steady stream of articles about Vice President Al Gore's apparent need to ''embellish what is already an impressive resume,'' as the columnist Arianna Huffington put it. ''Gore keenly senses he's not perfect and rewrites history to try to make it so,'' Margaret Carlson wrote in last week's Time magazine.

title: Clinging to Fantasy Behind Cuban Walls
description: Roughly a century ago three daughters of a dying order of gentility looked to the distant metropolis of Moscow as a symbol of deliverance. They were the Prozorov girls, the unhappy heroines of Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' and it was always clear in the play that told their story that they would never escape the drabness of their shared existence. By the end, they could hope only that life might be brighter for the generations to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, DANIEL
description: ROTH-Daniel. On February 14, 2000, beloved husband of Irma, devoted father of Joan Roth and Dr. Douglas, caring father-in-law of Ron Stack and Amy Roth, doting grandfather of Jason, Craig, Stacey, and Ilana, dear brother of David and Anna Landy, brother-inlaw of Michael and Nancy Neuman, Phyllis Roth and Norman Landy, loving uncle of many neices and nephews, and good friend to many. Services Thursday February 17th at 11:30 A.M. at The Reformed Temple of Suffern, 350 Haverstraw Road, Suffern, N.Y.

title: On the Brink of a Mountain
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Beyond the Pale of the M.T.A.; On City-Run Buses, Getting to Work Can Be Work
description: A jam-packed express bus from the Flatlands in Brooklyn barrels toward Lower Manhattan, its standing-room-only passengers struggling to keep their balance with each bump and turn. In southeastern Queens, a driver who should be on the road sits at the depot while his bus is repaired. And at a Jackson Heights bus stop, more than 50 wind-chilled commuters wait impatiently in a line that runs up and back down the block.

title: A Price Too High?; Deal to Save Charter Behavioral May Have Harmed It
description: The nation's largest chain of psychiatric hospitals lies in tatters. More than half of the roughly 90 hospitals and treatment centers operated by Charter Behavioral Health Systems will soon be closed and the company is expected to announce as early as today that it is seeking bankruptcy protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, ELLIOT
description: FEINBERG-Elliot. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its long time member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi Stephen Merkel, Cantor Jack Stern Jr., Rabbi Emeritus

title: Stresses and Strains of Backpacks
description: To worried parents, they can look like pack mules on two legs -- students who are not only carrying a load on their minds but also a load on their backs.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM SURGES. Palladium had its biggest gain in 19 months, after export restrictions by Russia limited supplies. In New York, palladium for March delivery rose $52.85, or 8.7 percent, to a record $658.35 an ounce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORIARTY, MICHAEL J.
description: MORIARTY-Michael J. Michael in his career worked for First American Title Insurance Company of New York for over 20 years. He held various positions with the company starting as Branch Counsel and rising most proudly to Senior Vice President, as well as a member of the Board of Directors of the company. All of us who knew and worked with Michael have experienced a great loss. We will miss his sage contribution and wonderful spirit for years to come. Michael's work, his kindness, care and concern for all who he met and worked with touched and helped us all. We are left with the memory of his upbeat, outgoing and wonderful optimistic attitude that infected all of us. We all have a piece of Michael that shall endure. In memory of Michael, the company has established a scholarship fund at Siena College. We remember Michael Moriarty and reach out to his wife Aileen, his children and grandchildren at this time and extend our heartfelt sympathy to them on the passing of their husband, father, and grandfather. George A. Metzger Chairman of the Board James M. Orphanides, President

title: Spaniel Follows in Sire's Footsteps
description: At 10:30 last night, the call went out for the seven finalists to take the stage at the 124th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

title: Alvin M. Liberman, 82, Expert In Study of Speech Perception
description: Dr. Alvin M. Liberman, a retired professor of psychology and linguistics whose innovative research was influential in the study of speech perception, died on Jan. 13 at a hospital in Mansfield Center, Conn. He was 82 and lived in Mansfield Center.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday about the dry cleaning industry's use of the chemical known as perc omitted a scale label. The quantities were expressed in millions of pounds: consumption declined from 235 million pounds in 1988 to 72 million in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, BEATRICE
description: RUBENSTEIN - Beatrice. The trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Beatrice Rubenstein, a volunteer for JBFCS's Family Court program and a member of our Geller House Divisional Committee for more than 25 years. In both roles, Mrs. Rubenstein worked tirelessly on behalf of troubled children and demonstrated a unique commitment to those in need. We express our deepest sympathy to her husband, Sol; her three children; her eight grandchildren; her sister; and other members of her family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Chairman of the Board Barbara Peck, Chairwoman, Geller House Divisional Cmte. Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President Paul Levine, CSW, Associate Executive Vice President Beryl Kende, ACSW, Director, Geller House

title: CREATIVE BIOMOLECULES TO MERGE WITH BIOTECH FIRMS
description: Creative BioMolecules Inc. said yesterday it would merge with the privately held Ontogeny Inc. and Reprogenesis Inc. to form one of the biggest companies working on stimulating human tissue growth to treat problems from broken bones to baldness. Shares in Creative BioMolecules gained as much as 42 percent on hopes the merger of the three Boston-area rivals would create a leader in the emerging field of regenerative medicine. The new company, Curis Inc., will have one product awaiting regulatory approval to treat severe bone fractures, other experimental treatments in clinical trials and earlier-stage compounds that have yet to be tested on humans.

title: CYBERWORKS SHARES RISE
description: Investors appeared to lend their support to the Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li's plans to bid for part of the Hong Kong telephone operator Cable and Wireless HKT. Shares of Mr. Li's Internet start-up Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd. rose nearly 7 percent in their first day of trading since the plans were disclosed. The jump added $2.2 billion to the 10-month-old money-losing company's market capitalization. Cable and Wireless HKT, which had gained 50 percent on the news, became less expensive a target as its shares slid 7 percent. Shares in Singapore Telecommunications, its merger ambitions potentially jeopardized by the CyberWorks bid, fell 1.5 percent to a 10-month low. CyberWorks has yet to make a formal bid. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Extra-Credit Class: Figure Out 401(k)'s
description: FOR a growing number of entrepreneurs, demographics are now destiny, as millions of workers worldwide see retirement looming less than a decade before them. Responding to the needs of these future retirees, a generation of financial educators has sprung up to offer money counseling for the days ahead. But these new services are not just for older people: younger workers are keeping a watchful eye on their retirement accounts as well.

title: The Firefight in South Carolina
description: As their debate in South Carolina demonstrated last night, Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain are in more than a scorched-earth battle for the Republican presidential nomination. They are also offering different approaches to conducting and financing campaigns. Mr. Bush sought to re-establish his presidential stature, accused Mr. McCain of starting the mudslinging, and proclaimed himself again a ''reformer with results.'' Mr. McCain tried to be even-tempered while blaming the governor for shameful negative attacks and being a come-lately to campaign finance reform. He cast himself as the one Republican who could rebuild the Reagan coalition by pulling Democrats and independents into the Republican fold, while Mr. Bush insisted he was the only Republican who could ''end the Clinton era.''

title: From Mild Bantering to Florid Bullying, With Keyes in the Middle
description: For the first 15 minutes, Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain exuded all the aggression of a pair of dowagers at a late-afternoon tea party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, HANNAH
description: DOHERTY-Hannah (nee O'Shea). On February 15, 2000. Native of County Kerry, Ireland. Loving wife of John. Beloved mother of John, Dennis, Joan, Ellen and Kathleen Devoted grandmother of Colin, Allison, Nicole, and Daniel. Fond aunt of Maureen and Sally. Reposing Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway (207 St), Wednesday, 7-9PM and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Good Shepherd Church, Friday 11AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Let's All Grow Old Together, Right Here in Pennsylvania
description: IT is scarcely news that Florida has the nation's highest percentage of residents 65 and older -- 18.3 percent, according to 1998 Census Bureau figures.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Short Lesson In Crowd Courtesy

title: China Reports A Suicide In Tiananmen
description: An explosion in Tiananmen Square this afternoon was set off by a suicidal farmer who was a psychiatric patient, according to the police and the New China News Agency.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Iran Holy City Doubles as Hotbed of Reform Politics
description: In this most devout of Iranian cities, a battle to emancipate the nation's rigidly controlled political life is being waged by a stern black-turbaned cleric with impeccable Islamic credentials.

title: Business Travel; The publisher of InsideFlyer has made a career of explaining the minutiae of frequent-flier awards.
description: RANDY PETERSEN talks a mile a minute, which figures. Among people who rack up the miles on business, Mr. Petersen is generally considered to be the world's leading expert on airline frequent-flier programs.

title: America's Nest Egg Is: a. Big b. Paltry c. All of the Above
description: BY some measures, Americans are growing increasingly profligate, choosing to spend everything they have, and more, on big-screen televisions, restaurant meals and vacations. How many will spend it all by the time they retire?

title: Bush Campaign Rushes to Refill Dwindling Coffer
description: The campaign of Gov. George W. Bush is spending close to $3 million a week, a rate that alarms his top fund-raisers and has forced Bush finance officials to schedule a number of unplanned money-raising events in the coming weeks.

title: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL
description: CONNECTICUT 85, ST. JOHN'S 43

title: A Bullet Cripples a Child, Changing 3 Lives Forever
description: One day in September when Liliam Pagan walked into her baby sitter's apartment to call for her 3-year-old son, Anthony, she found him lying on the floor in a pool of blood, shot in the chest.

title: Top Executive Is Leaving J. P. Morgan
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that its vice chairman, Roberto Mendoza, who helped turn it into an investment bank from a traditional lending bank, would resign effective April 12.

title: Medicaid Billing Is Checked At Women's Clinic in Queens
description: The State Department of Health is investigating Medicaid billing practices at a Queens women's medical clinic that hired an obstetrician after he carved his initials into a patient's belly, department officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, DR. EDWARD J.
description: SHAW-Dr. Edward J., 84, January 14, St. Louis, MO. Surgeon Yale Medicine '37, in New York City until 1965. Memorial service Saturday, February 19, 2:30PM, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th & 5th. Donations may be made in his name, Doctors Without Borders, 6 East 39 St, 8 Flr, NY, NY 10016

title: Joseph A. Rothschild, 68, History Professor
description: Joseph A. Rothschild, a longtime professor of history and political science at Columbia University and one of the nation's leading authorities on East Central Europe, died on Jan. 30 at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: Enjoying the Ex-Presidency? Never Been Better
description: JIMMY CARTER calls it his involuntary retirement.

title: BARCLAYS PROFIT UP
description: Britain's second-largest bank, Barclays P.L.C., said profits during the second quarter doubled, beating analysts' expectations. Net income rose to $:1 billion, or $1.6 billion, from $:431 million during the period a year earlier. Like many investment banks that had lost money in emerging markets, Barclays's investment banking unit, Barclays Capital, recovered this year. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Mystery of Mysteries: Whodunits and How They Did
description: In the introduction to his hefty new anthology, ''The Best American Mystery Stories of the Century'' (Houghton Mifflin), Tony Hillerman takes on Edmund Wilson, whom he calls ''America's most portentous literary critic'' of the 1940's, for dismissing the whole mystery genre as beneath comment.

title: Defense Sees Rush to Judge In Arrest of Mother and Son
description: Lawyers for the mother and son accused of killing an Upper East Side woman opened their defense yesterday by describing the case as a miscarriage of justice comparable to the cases of the boxer Rubin Carter and of Richard Jewell, who was wrongly accused of planting a bomb at the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRO, MYRNA
description: SPIRO-Myrna. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Myrna Spiro and extends heartfelt sympathy to her husband Stanley and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Dr. Norman Doctor, President

title: A Door to an Intensely Personal World (No Key Required)
description: Twenty-five years after Shostakovich's death, the question of who he was, what he believed and what his music means is more hotly contested than ever. The dominant impulse is to make him what we have always wanted him to be, and perhaps what he wanted to be: a subversive diarist of sorts whose music captures the passions of an artist buffeted by a tyrannical system. The fact that he also wrote works that seemed to glorify that system -- something troubling to some and explained away by others -- adds to the Shostakovich mystery. Were such works the price of maintaining a career (or of staying alive), or was there bitter criticism encoded beneath their celebratory surfaces?

title: Thomson Set To Sell Off Newspapers
description: NEW YORK  Thomson Corp. said Tuesday it would sell its remaining newspapers except for its flagship Toronto daily, The Globe and Mail, completing its reorientation from a publisher to an information provider for businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, JOAN
description: PORTER-Joan (nee Hastings), on February 11, 2000, formerly of Old Westbury, presently resided at Christian Fellowship House, Syosset, LI. Beloved wife of the late Kenneth Porter. Devoted mother of Steven K. Porter and Grant A. Porter. Loving grandmother of Whitney K. Porter, Steven L. Porter and Christina C. Porter. Private service will be held for immediate family. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to Winthrop University Hospital, Mineola, New York.

title: Finding a Substitute For Office Chitchat
description: WHEN Chas Brown of San Francisco decided to retire four years ago, he envisioned a life in which he would get up in the morning and decide to fly to New York for fun. ''I thought I could wake up every day and decide what to do,'' he recalled.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Vows to Spend More Than Ever Before on Candidates
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. said today that it would spend more money than ever before to help elect worker-friendly candidates to the White House and Congress and would devote more resources than in past elections to mobilizing volunteers.

title: Commercial Real Estate; The Flatiron District Is Getting an Upscale Fashion Makeover
description: For almost two years, the managers of Sephora, the French cosmetics company that is part of the LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury goods group, searched for space for a store on lower Fifth Avenue, south of the Flatiron Building. Recently they signed a 15-year lease for a store at the northeast corner of Fifth and 19th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITING, JANE
description: WHITING-Jane (nee Semple), 73, of Heritage Village, Southbury, formerly of Greenwich, CT, died on Wednesday, February 9th in Antibes, France. She is survived by her husband, Royal, of the home address, two daughters, Emily Kane of Seattle, WA, and Sarah Jenkenson of Wexford, PA. Another daughter, Susan, predeceased her. She is also survived by two brothers, Lorenzo Semple of N.Y.C. and Santa Monica, CA, Churchill Semple of West Sussex, England, and a sister, Katharine Hirschberg of Old Greenwich. Funeral arrangements have not been completed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, MORTON
description: MAXWELL-Morton H., M.D. Adored husband, father & brother, devoted physician & distinguished Professor of Clinical Medicine at UCLA; died at home in Santa Monica, California on February 15. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to the charity of your choice.

title: Air Canada Grapples With Its Takeover of Canadian Airlines
description: It took a distracting three-month takeover brawl for Air Canada to emerge as the winning buyer of Canadian Airlines, shrinking the nation's major air carriers from two to one. That may have been the easy part.

title: Walter Fletcher, 93, Is Dead; Writer on Dogs for The Times
description: Walter Fletcher, who covered dog shows for The New York Times for more than 60 years and became something of a celebrity in the sport, died yesterday at a hospital in Niceville, Fla., where he lived in a retirement community. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZMAN, POLA
description: SALZMAN-Pola, on February 14, 2000. Owner and Chief Executive of Paramount Cosmetics. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Sherry and her husband Gabriel, Sandy and his wife Nina. Adoring grandmother of Saskia, David, Valerie, Lauren and Nicole. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Wednesday, 11:30 AM, with interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOGARTY, MATTHEW J.
description: FOGARTY-Matthew J., 1950-1997. NYPD Detective retired. The tears still flow and the pain goes on. We miss you more each day. We love you. Mom and Dad

title: Insurer Drops a Therapy for Breast Cancer
description: Reversing a policy that dates back almost a decade, one of the nation's largest insurers has decided to stop paying for a grueling and controversial breast cancer treatment that has not been proved to work.

title: Brodeur And Devils Keep Rolling
description: The Flyers are the closest challengers to the Devils for the Atlantic Division title, if a gap of 15 points is considered a challenge. That margin separates the teams after the Devils' 4-2 triumph over the Flyers tonight at Continental Arena.

title: Retirement
description: Jimmy Carter left the White House badly defeated and broke. In the 19 years since, his efforts for peace and humanitarian causes have made him one of the most admired ex-Presidents. Also: Financial and healthcare planning; how Japan copes with its rapidly aging population; and making the transition from a working life to whatever is next.

description: FOR about a year when she was young, Maria Napoli lived in a graveyard.

description: George Bush fighting the wimp factor? That rings a bell.

title: Even Cookies Can Be Healthy
description: THERE'S a tradition of baking with olive oil: focaccia, most pizza dough and some breads rely on it. But olive oil, a fat that is among the most healthful imaginable, is unusual in sweet baked goods.

title: Poll Finds Education Is Chief Concern of Likely Voters
description: Education is the top concern among voters this election season, ranking above health care, Social Security and tax cuts, according to a national poll, scheduled for release today, that shows strong support for more federal money and involvement in public schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGLIS, LEONARD J.
description: INGLIS-Leonard J., 84. On February 15, beloved husband of Marjorie, loving father of Susan Seal and her husband David Seal. Cherished grandfather of Heather and Katherine Seal. Brother of Florence Packman. Funeral on February 17th, 10:45 AM., IHM, Scarsdale, NY. Contributions may be made to the Cancer Support Team of Rye, NY or Hospice of Stamford, CT.

description: SHOR-Helen M. On February 14. Devoted wife to the late Sol; loving mother of Hillary and Tony; dear sister to Zelda; and adoring grandmother to Andrew and Zoey.

title: Ticket Sales Surpass 2 Million
description: Preseason ticket sales for Cardinals games have surpassed 2.3 million and could challenge the franchise record of 2.5 million set last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKMAN, SUE
description: BERKMAN-Sue. Writer, editor, dog lover, animal rescuer died December 19, 1999 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, New York City. Memorial service: Thursday, February 17, 2:00 P.M., at the Unity Center, 213 W. 58th St. NY, NY.

title: ZIMBABWE REBUFFS LONGTIME LEADER
description: Voters in Zimbabwe have dealt President Robert Mugabe a stinging setback, rejecting a draft constitution that his opponents charged would have entrenched his powers.

description: February 16, 2000

title: Ervin Litkei, 78, Composer Of Many Patriotic Marches
description: Ervin Litkei, a music business executive who owned several companies but whose passion was the composition of patriotic music -- including marches dedicated to every United States president since Franklin D. Roosevelt -- died on Feb. 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: A Conservative Picks a Path Less Taken
description: TOURING South Carolina, John McCain is accompanied by Lisa Keegan, the magnetic schools superintendent from Arizona, his home state, who handles inquiries about his education proposals. Widely admired by conservatives, Ms. Keegan would be on a short list for secretary of education in any Republican administration.

title: The Life of a Rabbi
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILTZIK, ABRAHAM

title: TV NOTES
description: White and Male On 'Millionaire'

title: Leak at Indian Pt. Nuclear Plant Prompts Shutdown and an Alert
description: A leak in a steam generator at the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor in Westchester County released a small amount of radiation from the plant last night, forcing officials to shut it down and declare an alert.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ICON is swanky, slinky, murky. Located in the W Court Hotel in Murray Hill, it has a mildly lurid decor and a lighting philosophy perfectly designed for illegal trysts and furtive meetings. The name, blank and inscrutable, suits the setting. It could mean everything, or nothing.

title: THOMSON SELLING NEARLY ALL PAPERS
description: The Canadian publisher Thomson Corporation plans to sell all of its newspaper assets, with the exception of the Toronto-based flagship Globe and Mail, to focus on electronic services, where Thomson now derives about 50 percent of its revenue. Thomson publishes 50 daily newspapers in the United States and 5 in Canada, most of them with circulations below 50,000. Thomson said it would keep The Globe and Mail, Canada's pre-eminent daily, because of what the company called the newspaper's strong fit with its financial-information business. Media analysts said the papers for sale could be worth $2.5 billion. Potential buyers include the Gannett Company and the Hollinger Corporation, controlled by Conrad Black, who owns The Globe and Mail rival, The National Post. Thomson shares jumped 12.5 percent, to 46.90 Canadian dollars, or about $32.36, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: The Pundit Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Officers Back Story Of Partners
description: The third and fourth police officers who shot at Amadou Diallo testified today that they thought Mr. Diallo had a gun, backing up their two partners, who testified on Monday that they feared for their lives when they killed Mr. Diallo a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about James M. Edwards, a senior partner in the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, misstated the day of his death and the given name of his wife. He died on Feb. 7, not Feb. 8. His wife, who died in 1998, was Veronica, not Marian.

title: What to Call It When Chefs Boil in Bags? Cuisine
description: DAVID BOULEY was in mad-scientist mode, sealing foie gras in plastic bags, inserting temperature probes, consulting time-temperature charts. He was showing off $30,000 worth of new technology in the kitchen at Danube, technology that has turned him into the American king of boil-in-the-bag food. Last week, through a lunch of food cooked in the bags -- beef cheeks, boiled beef, salmon, veal shank, artichokes, zucchini -- he kept popping up in the dining room with other experiments in plastic packages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, EDWARD P.
description: MURPHY-Edward P. suddenly on February 15, 2000 of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Eileen nee Cuff. Loving father of Charles F., Donna M. O'Brien, Thomas Cuff and Edward P. Jr. Dear grandfather of Edward, Charles, Julia, Mary Beth, Patrick, Thomas, John, Eryl, Jessie, Adam and Abigail. Loving brother of the late Charles F., Jerimiah G. and John D. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Wednesday 7:00-9:00 PM and Thursday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Friday 10:00 am. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Mercy Medical Center, Rockville Centre, New York appreciated.

title: 'Beauty' Leads Wide-Open Oscar Field
description: ''American Beauty,'' a vinegary comedy about suburbanites whose lives are so askew that they seem to have turned dysfunction into an art form, came away with the most Academy Awards nominations today, but it was a close call. Share the wealth seemed to be the theme of the day.

title: On YankeeNets, Schiller Teams Up With Friend
description: Harvey Schiller, a longtime friend of George Steinbrenner's, is now one of his employees after being named yesterday as the chairman and chief executive officer of YankeeNets.

title: Woman Freed After Pleading In Border Case
description: A Canadian woman whom Federal investigators initially linked to a murky, cross-border terrorism plot involving smuggled explosives and illegal aliens, was freed from a Vermont jail yesterday after prosecutors announced that she had not knowingly aided any planned violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, PERCY
description: SIMMONS-Percy. Age 93, passed away peacefully in Indianapolis, Indiana on February 15, 2000. Born in London, England, he resided in Indianapolis for 60 years. He was the former French Consul in Indianapolis, a patron of the arts, founder of the Indianapolis Chevalier du Tastevin Society, a man of myriad accomplishments. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Hinda, his children Nina and Don Frenkel, Rica and Harvey Spivack; four grandchildren, David Spivack, Ellen Schifman, Tamar Hauptman, and Ruth Frenkel. Also seven great grandchildren. His loss is greatly felt by family and friends.

title: Flensburg Journal; Is the Frankfurt Stock Exchange a Place for Sex?
description: This is a formal country. Herr-This. Frau-That. No first names. Bone-breaking handshakes, humor with the lightness of a large dumpling, and lace curtains guarding the coy privacy of every home.

title: Greek Food With a Difference, and a Romantic Setting
description: IN one great wave a few years ago, Greek restaurants seemed to wash over Manhattan, coming to rest in almost every neighborhood and asserting their place in the mid-90's vogue for Mediterranean food. The appeal of these restaurants, which specialized mostly in seafood, was their elemental ease: simple ingredients, simple preparations, simple enjoyment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTINE, SYDNEY A.
description: GOLDSTINE-Sydney A., MD. 91 years. Passed away on February 13 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Beloved and loving husband of Tamie Laurance Goldstine. Loving father of Jonathan and Thea. Loving grandfather of Susan. A man of great dignity. Cherished physician and friend to many over a long medical career. Memorial services to be held at Temple Emanuel, 64th Street and 5th Avenue, NYC on March 1 at 4 PM.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICO-EUROPE INSURANCE DEAL
description: Savia S.A. de C.V., the holding company of Mexico's largest insurance firm, Seguros Comercial America, has joined a partnership with ING Group, a financial services company based in Amsterdam. ING will pay $555 million for a 39.7 percent stake in the new venture and Savia will get the rest. Alfonso Romo, Savia's chairman, said the alliance would give Seguros Comercial America greater flexibility because of the strong financial position of its new partner, which has global assets of over $450 billion. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: A Dark View Of Orthodoxy In Jerusalem
description: ''Kadosh,'' an outraged portrait of an ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in the Mea Shearim quarter of Jerusalem, is so grim that before it's over what began as a fictionalized expose of a group of religious extremists has assumed the ominous tone of a psychological horror film.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the investigation of the crash of an Alaska Airlines plane last month misidentified the manufacturer of the jackscrew, the part that has come under scrutiny. The maker was Peacock Engineering, which is now defunct, not Trig Engineering Holdings, which entered that business only last year.

title: East Timor, Stuck at 'Ground Zero,' Lacks Law, Order and Much More
description: While Indonesia begins to investigate some military officers accused in last year's violence in East Timor, the people who live in that devastated territory are unable to arrest or jail even local thieves and robbers.

title: Mohegans to Build $800 Million Casino Expansion
description: Straight out of the depressed backwoods of southeastern Connecticut, an incongruous image emerges: a glittering 40-story hotel, a 10,000-seat sports arena and a second casino building featuring a perforated-steel planetarium 150 feet in diameter on its ceiling.

title: New York Is Ranked High For Deadly Heart Attacks
description: White women in New York State had the highest death rates from heart disease among white women in the United States, and New York ranked second highest in the number of deaths among women over all, the first national study of heart disease in women by region, race and ethnic origin has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, HELEN
description: ROTHENBERG-Helen, age 86 of Westwood, NJ formerly of Delray Beach, FL and Williamsburg, NY. She fulfilled her dream of being in all ways caring for us. We thank you mother dear, your children, Steven (EunHye) and Fredda (Sean) and your grandchildren Hanna, Sara, Molly and Ben. For information Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ.

title: Muckler Shuffles the Deck and Ends Up With a Tie
description: Coach John Muckler decided the timing was right tonight to experiment with his lineup.

title: Speaker Fines Kohl's Party $21 Million Over Illegal Payments
description: Formally rebuking Helmut Kohl, the speaker of Parliament today imposed a devastating $21 million fine on the former chancellor's Christian Democratic Party for accepting illegal financing.

title: In New Blow to Peace in Ulster, I.R.A. Quits Arms Talks
description: The Irish Republican Army retaliated tonight for Britain's shutdown of the power-sharing Northern Ireland government by ending its contact with disarmament mediators and withdrawing newly offered proposals to abandon its weapons.

title: MPOWER WILL EXPAND ITS INTERNET WORK FORCE
description: The Mpower Communications Corporation, a provider of local phone and communications services to businesses, said it would triple its work force to expand its Internet services nationwide. The company, based in Pittsford, N.Y., said it expected to expand its work force to more than 2,500 employees over the next 12 to 18 months. The company plans to offer advanced communications services, including high-speed data transmission and Web-site management, to customers in the 50 largest United States cities this year.

title: Metro Business; Manufacturer Cutting Jobs
description: Forward Industries, a maker of carrying cases for cell phones and laptop computers, said yesterday it would close its offices in Westbury, N.Y., and in Indiana.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORIN, MARGARET
description: GORIN-Margaret. 10/31/11-2/16/97. Beloved sister to Irene and Leo, aunt of Kathy and Mark, greataunt of Alex and Destiny Rose. We miss you always

description: GOLDSTEIN-Henni. Agunah International mourns the untimely loss of our beloved Board member, Henni Goldstein, a woman of beautiful spirit and infinite courage. title: Kremlin Insiders Acquire Big Siberian Aluminum Plants
description: Boris A. Berezovsky and Roman Abramovich, financiers with close ties to the Kremlin, have acquired three important Russian aluminum smelters in eastern Siberia in deals that would give them nearly full control over the country's enormous aluminum industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERT, DENIS
description: HALPERT-Denis. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved father of its devoted Ritual Director, Mr. Yisroel Halpert and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: A Newer, Lonelier Crowd Emerges in Internet Study
description: The nation's obsession with the Internet is causing many Americans to spend less time with friends and family, less time shopping in stores and more time working at home after hours, according to one of the first large-scale surveys of the societal impact of the Internet.

title: When Young Managers Deliver the Pink Slips
description: They were in high school or college when the great wave of layoffs swept corporate America in the early 90's. And while they heard stories about neighbors who had lost their jobs, they didn't give them much thought.

title: Excerpts From Television Debate Among 3 Remaining G.O.P. Candidates
description: Following are excerpts from the debate of the Republican presidential candidates, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, Alan Keyes and Senator John McCain of Arizona last night on ''Larry King Live'' on CNN, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: The Big City; 'Hurricane' Motivates A Real Critic
description: CAL DEAL admires Denzel Washington's skill in front of a camera, but he did not applaud Mr. Washington's nomination yesterday for the best actor Oscar. Mr. Deal maintains a Web site titled, ''Hurricane Carter: The Other Side of the Story,'' and it portrays a lying thug who bears little resemblance to the martyr played by Mr. Washington in the movie ''The Hurricane.''

description: NEWS

title: Jury Says Officers Violated Rights of 2 Men in Traffic Stop
description: A federal jury in Manhattan ruled yesterday that two members of the New York Police Department's Street Crime Unit violated the rights of two men who were stopped by the police in 1997, after which the driver said he was thrown to the ground and beaten.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO IS UP. The euro rose against the dollar on speculation that a report will show increased business confidence in Germany, bolstering confidence in Europe. In New York, the euro settled at 98.12 cents, up from 97.96 cents.

description: Marching aggressively onto Senator John McCain's signature turf, Gov. George W. Bush promoted a package of suggested changes to campaign financing today, including a ban on soft money from corporations and labor unions and a prohibition against lobbyists' making contributions while Congress is in session.

Bush and Senator John McCain lashed into each other's negative campaign tactics tonight, with Mr. McCain lecturing Mr. Bush that he ''should be ashamed'' that a surrogate had accused Mr. McCain of abandoning veterans.

title: Sports of The Times; Boxing's Alphabet Soup
description: THE thick glass door with ''I.B.F.'' in red is open. The receptionist is working the switchboard. On the top floor of the office building at 134 Evergreen Place, it's business as usual here in the International Boxing Federation's suite of offices where photos of Robert W. Lee Sr. adorn the walls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, JOHN DILLON

title: In Tribute To Your Year Of Service
description: A GOLD watch as a retirement gift? A hopeless anachronism, snorted Edward L. Hansen, a former director of marketing at William M. Mercer, a consulting firm in New York.

title: Mahler, Who Needs No Aid, Gets a Little After All
description: Mahler's Second Symphony tells its big story of death, distraction and the rising promise of eternal life so vividly that almost any performance is going to work. Of course a performance can intensify and enrich the story. Or it can proceed as if all is well without coming near engaging with the piece. That was what happened the other night, with Zubin Mehta conducting the New York Philharmonic.

title: Clinton Isn't Running for Office, but He Has a Lot to Say About the Race
description: His name is not on the ballot, he reminded the audience. He is just another voter, he said. But President Clinton could not resist weighing in today on the first political campaign season in decades that did not directly involve him.

title: A Chapter 11 Filing by Charter Behavioral
description: Charter Behavioral Health Systems, the nation's biggest operator of psychiatric hospitals and treatment centers which has gone into a financial free fall, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERK, AMELIA
description: BERK-Amelia. February 16, 2000. Wife of the late Dudley Berk. Mother of Philip and June Heimann. Grandmother of Andrew and Jessica Ross. The family will receive friends Friday, February 18th, 9:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St.

title: Bones May Be Those of Ancient Athenians in Pericles' Funeral Oration
description: Early in the Peloponnesian War, the remains of Athenian soldiers killed in battle against the Spartans were interred in communal tombs outside Athens's west gate, off the road to the academy where Plato taught. It was at this cemetery in 431 B.C. that the statesman Pericles, speaking from a high platform at the funeral, described the greatness of Athens in one of history's most eloquent orations.

title: Statehouse Journal; Ban on Suing Gun Makers Is Gaining Steam
description: For all the political oratory and legislative proposals prompted by the Columbine High School shooting rampage, one of the few fast-moving firearms bills in the nation's statehouses this year is not a gun control measure. It is a ban promoted by the National Rifle Association against cities suing gun manufacturers for liability in deadly sprees by citizens.

title: Voters Skeptical of Motive Of McCain in Pulling Ads
description: Huntington Smith, restaurateur and political independent, thinks highly of Senator John McCain, but not as highly as he did a week ago.

description: FACES: THE ULTIMATE COMPOSITE PICTURE

title: Delegating the Dirty Work of Cleaning Up
description: IS there a secret grapevine for cleaning companies that spreads the word about which houses to avoid? Is it possible that the last cleaning crew who came to my house could have taken photographs and showed them to the competition?

title: Essay; Political 'God's World'
description: Picking up an armload of mail early this week, I noticed an unfamiliar magazine in my box.

title: Jury Instructions Remain Crucial Issue for Verdict
description: For all the courtroom drama the trial of the four officers accused of killing Amadou Diallo has presented, the outcome of the case could rest on behind-the-scenes negotiations on how the judge will instruct the jury to apply the law.

title: Running Into Controversy
description: The presence of the Confederate battle flag above South Carolina's State Capitol is a hot-button political issue that has reverberated beyond Saturday's state Republican primary and into the world of Olympic distance running.

title: Crisis Session on Ulster Ends, Still Divided on Arms Issue
description: Demands by the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, that Britain restore the suspended Northern Ireland government were met with counterdemands today from other participants in a crisis session at 10 Downing Street that the Irish Republican Army first return to disarmament talks.

description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISSELBACHER, ALFRED
description: ISSELBACHER-Alfred. February 15, 2000. Age 73. Beloved husband of Carmen. Loving and devoted father of Audrey and her husband David Liebman. Cherished grandfather of Josh and Katie. Devoted brother of the late Hilda Berney and the late Henry Isselbacher. Loving uncle of Jesse, Tina and Gail. He was a noted art dealer in both the United States and abroad and was the Director of the Isselbacher Art Gallery in New York City since 1965. He was born in Isselbach, Germany and later came to the U.S. in 1938, where he served in the Coast Guard during World War II. He shared his enthusiasm and passion for art with the public and in so doing enriched many lives. Service Friday, February 18, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: What's Love Got to Do With It?
description: Whatever happened to working for a living and marrying for love? O.K., we can understand shows like ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?'' and ''Greed,'' where you can make millions for answering some questions correctly. At least you have to be smart or shrewd!

title: Loading Up on Personality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, DR. JOSEPH.
description: MANDELBAUM-Dr. Joseph. The Board of Trustees and their families and the staff of the League Treatment Center mourn the passing of Dr. Joseph Mandelbaum. Joe and his devoted wife Heddy founded the League Treatment Center. They devoted their energies to creating treatment and education for seriously mentally handicapped children. Our sympathy goes out to his children, his daughter Jill and sons Paul and Joel, and his many friends. Bernice Sherman, President Hannah Achtenberg Kinn, Executive Director The League Treatment Center

title: Stop the Cycle, Break Kosovo Up
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Investigating DoubleClick Over Privacy Concerns
description: February 16, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNIK, IRVING
description: HARNIK-Irving. Age 83. Died on Feb. 15, 2000. Beloved and loving husband of 56 years to Isabelle (nee Erlich). Adored father of Alan and Lois. Caring father-inlaw of Gillian and Stuart. Cherished grandfather of Vanessa, Paul and Jessica. Dear brother to Seymour and his wife Shelia. One of the dearest, special people ever, and forever remembered. Funeral service today, 11 AM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue, NY, NY 10003.

title: Hezbollah Not Moved By Barak Vow To Pull Out
description: The leader of the Hezbollah guerrilla movement said today that his organization's forces in southern Lebanon would continue to kill Israeli soldiers despite Prime Minister Ehud Barak's pledge to make an unconditional withdrawal of Israel's forces from the area by July 7.

title: Banker and Husband Tell Of Role in Laundering Case
description: A former executive of the Bank of New York and her husband told a federal judge yesterday that they helped a group of small but politically connected Russian banks create an elaborate money laundering scheme that moved billions of dollars out of Russia through the American bank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, PERCY
description: SIMMONS-Percy. Age 93, passed away peacefully in Indianapolis, Indiana on February 15, 2000. Born in London, England, he resided in Indianapolis for 60 years. He was the former French Consul in Indianapolis, a patron of the arts, founder of the Indianapolis Chevalier du Tastevin Society, a man of myriad accomplishments. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Hinda, his children Nina and Don Frenkel, Rica and Harvey Spivack; four grandchildren, David Spivack, Ellen Schifman, Tamar Hauptman, and Ruth Frenkel. Also seven great grandchildren. His loss is greatly felt by family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, ELLIOT, M.D.
description: FEINBERG-Elliot, M.D. Ridgeway Country Club mourns the passing of its esteemed former president, green chairman and Board member, Dr. Elliot Feinberg. His leadership and friendship will be missed by all. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Lita, and their family. Board of Governors Ridgeway Country Club

title: In Hostile Bid, Germans Buy 35% of Japan Drugmaker
description: A large German pharmaceutical company secured a foothold in the Japanese drug industry today through a successful and unsolicited takeover effort -- something still highly unusual in this country.

title: The Market for Dog Paintings Refuses to Play Dead
description: WHEN the John Emms painting of dogs called ''A Jack and Two Knaves'' sold on Tuesday for $140,000, more than three times the low estimate, the audience let out a collective whoop -- and the auctioneers breathed a sigh of relief. Only two lots before, another Emms painting ''Sailor and Bramble'' didn't sell at all.

title: Lost in Brooklyn: A Dog Should Be Loved
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Ward's Injury Swings Mood For Knicks
description: IN the new, new National Basketball Association, you really don't know exactly what is going to emerge from the runway -- the A effort or the B effort. The players themselves usually don't know. They are just trying to keep healthy for the long march from autumn to spring.

title: Metro Business; Fewer Apartments Available in 1999
description: The results of the city's newest housing survey should surprise no one: it is harder than ever to find a vacant apartment, let alone an affordable one, in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Israel Expands Daylight Time, and a Religious Dispute Erupts
description: Daring single-handedly to alter a calendar that is as politically sensitive as everything else here, Interior Minister Natan Sharansky decreed today that ''summer time'' will be longer this year by 34 days.

title: A Fire Wall Weakens
description: The South Carolina primary is no longer a sure thing for front-runners or a fire wall against insurgents. A new generation of voters is conservative, but it is not predictable, or necessarily Republican. This new political culture could help Senator John McCain on Saturday.

title: Life With AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Says White Officer's Shooting of Black Boy Was Justified
description: The deadly shooting last spring of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer, though a ''terrible tragedy,'' was justified under Connecticut law governing the police use of deadly force, according to a state report that was released today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Los Angeles Police Officials Admit Widespread Lapses
description: Top police officials here offered a scathing public indictment of the command and supervision within their troubled department today, saying that thousands of new officers had been hired with little vetting and then allowed to run virtually out of control.

title: Doctor and 2 Pharmacists Charged in Suspected Prescription Drug Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors charged a Manhattan doctor and two pharmacists yesterday with taking part in a conspiracy to illegally distribute prescription narcotics. The prosecutors said the three men were charged after a federal agency shut down a network that they said transported drugs from New York City to Virginia and West Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, REGINA E.
description: CALLAHAN-Regina E. On February 16, 2000. Beloved sister of the late Grace Costello and Vincent H. Devoted aunt of Vincent, Elizabeth, Regina Milkowski and Anita Aherne. Survived by 12 grand nieces and nephews and 7 great grand nieces and nephews. Visiting Friday, 2-5 and 7-9P.M. McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Friday 9:30 AM St. Patrick's Church.

title: Stop the Cycle, Break Kosovo Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Arrests Overloading Court System
description: A citywide antidrug crackdown that was spurred by higher crime figures has swamped the court system over the last two weekends, bringing a record number of arraignments to Manhattan courts one night and leading to complaints that hundreds of suspects were detained illegally for more than 24 hours.

title: Democrats Criticize Governor for Delay in Calling Special Elections for Vacant Senate Seats
description: Two Democratic strongholds in southeast Queens and Buffalo will be left without a voice in the State Senate for nearly three months because the Republican governor has waited longer than usual to call special elections for empty seats in those districts.

title: Leagues to Use Two Referees
description: The United States Soccer Federation, the sports national governing body, said it will experiment with a two-referee system through this year.

title: Browser
description: A selection of events and sites on the Web.

title: Giuliani, in Cold Cities Upstate, Faults Clinton on Oil Reserves
description: In a campaign sweep of Plattsburgh and Syracuse meant to quell criticism that he is spending too little time in upstate New York, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today repeated his criticism of the Clinton administration for refusing to free up part of the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to counterbalance the soaring cost of oil.

title: Senaor Kerrey Accepts Presidency of New School
description: Senator Bob Kerrey, the Vietnam War hero and political maverick, is leaving the Senate -- and Nebraska -- for Greenwich Village, where he will run the New School University, known for both its strong graduate programs and its sometimes quirky classes like ''Gym Culture and the Modern Amazon.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALUSKIN, SAM
description: ZALUSKIN-Sam. We mourn the loss of our friend and client. Graveside services at United Hebrew Cemetery in Staten Island at 10:30 AM on Thursday, February 17, 2000. Seymour and Esther Kane

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions On Oil Venture in Sudan
description: The United States imposed sanctions today on a multinational oil venture in Sudan, a project that critics say has helped the government there finance a religious war against southern rebels.

title: Wary Farmers Are Quiet After Victory in Zimbabwe Referendum
description: A day after helping forge a major political victory over President Robert Mugabe, the Commercial Farmers Union, which represents this country's biggest planters, was not bragging -- or even talking.

title: AMBEV TAKES COKE TO COURT
description: Brazil's biggest beverage company, Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, or AmBev, took legal action in a Rio de Janeiro court against the Coca-Cola Company, accusing the company, the world's leading soft drink maker, of unfair practices. AmBev, a combination of Brazil's two largest beverage concerns under a deal announced last year, said Coke had unfairly sought to influence the Brazilian public against the merger. AmBev's competitors, including the Companhia Cervejaria Kaiser brewery, in which Coke owns a minority stake, have raised concerns about the size of the proposed merger. Kaiser said it would counter AmBev's complaint with its own legal action. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRADO, FRANK L.
description: CORRADO-Frank L. On February 15, 2000 of Douglaston, NY. Beloved husband of Pearl. Loving father of JoAnna, Frank, Jr., Katherine and Christopher. Grandfather of six. He was an attorney for over 50 years in Queens. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Thursday 3-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 10:45 AM, St. Anastasia R.C. Church, Douglaston. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Francis Bread Line, Church and Friary of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West 31st Street, New York, NY 10001-3435.

title: Carbon-Copy Madness
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, CHUN
description: CHU-Chun. Passed peacefully on February 12 in New York City, joining his wife Chin-Shun Chao and son Norton Yuen Chu. Survived by daughter-in-law Frances Liang Chu, sons Suen Heong and Shiu Ying Chiu, and Jose and Shuk Fong Chau, grandchildren Roderick G.W. Chu, Laura and David Burke, So Kuen and Kan Y. Wong, Robert Chiu, David and Amy Chiu, Tony and Linda Chiu, Kwong Cheuk and Yi Lam Chiu, and Mei Kuen Chiu, and 9 great grandchildren. Born in Toi Shan, China on August 25, 1899, his family and friends were blessed with his love and example in 3 centuries. The family will receive friends on Friday, February 18 from 3:00 to 7:00 PM and Saturday, February 19 from 9:30 to 10:30 AM at Ng Fook Funeral Home, 36 Mulberry Street, New York, NY, followed by services at 11:00 AM at The First Chinese Presbyterian Church, 61 Henry Street. Interment in Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of Flowers, donations to the Rotary District 7230 Foundation Scholarship Fund, 97 Highland Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583 would be appreciated.

title: How Not To Be A Zombie
description: IN the 1977 film ''Telefon,'' dozens of otherwise ordinary Good Guy citizens were secretly hypnotized and brainwashed by the Bad Guys. They lived and worked among their fellow Good Guys for months or years. Then one day, a simple telephone call from the Bad Guys triggered these pre-programmed Good Guys to stop whatever they were doing and, like zombies, to start attacking military bases and assassinating their own leaders.

title: Havana Journal; To Latin Neighbors, Cuba Plays the Good Doctor
description: Nieves Dinora graduated from high school in Nicaragua with good grades and no prospects. Since her father, a farmer, had no money to send her to college, she figured marriage and motherhood were her only options.

title: Offices So Green, They're Practically Outdoors
description: You know the grass has to be greener when a firm of ecologically smart German architects does a sustainable project for professional environmentalists in the Netherlands. Much greener. Behnisch, Behnisch & Partner used off-the-shelf greenhouse parts to build two glass-roofed gardens enclosed by offices for Alterra, Green World Research, in Wageningen.

title: Tantalizing Hope: Looking for Yeti
description: News Watch: Tantalizing Hope: Looking for Yeti

title: U.S. Resists a Proposal by Japan to Cut Money for U.S. Bases
description: Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott called on the Japanese government today to reconsider a proposal to reduce its financial support for American troops in Japan.

title: Nuclear Plant Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore and Mrs. Clinton Keeping A Wary Distance as Candidates
description: They talk about the same record and initiatives, and assiduously avoid public discussion of certain shared memories from their years in Washington. They court the same supporters and seek money from the same contributors. Last Sunday morning, their motorcades passed just miles from each other, as they campaigned for votes in churches and restaurants in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Using Humor To Reach Gay Market
description: An unusual campaign for a financial Web site aimed at gay men and lesbians is approaching a serious issue with humor.

title: A Feast for a Soprano, Partaken With Friends
description: Many ''forgotten masterpieces'' are forgotten for good reason, and yet the relative eclipse of Donizetti's ''Lucrezia Borgia'' remains a puzzlement. Musically rich and swiftly dramatic (providing one buys into the formulaic melodrama of the 1830's Italian theater), this is the Donizettian model at its best. The rest of the 19th century seemed to agree; only in recent generations has the opera slipped perhaps not out of sight but to a more dimly perceived background. The Opera Orchestra of New York performed one of its regular acts of resuscitation on Monday night, returning ''Lucrezia'' to Carnegie Hall in a concert version wildly received by New York's opera fans.

title: A Plug With a Shrug
description: Ask just about any store, restaurant or business owner in this northeastern Louisiana city, and they'll tell you that there is no better way to spend $15 than to give it to Pearlee Toliver.

title: Mining Tourists, Not Lodes, Up North (Pack Your Woolies)
