description: What is hard labor like? Now that mining is almost a thing of the past in North America, it's hard to imagine all the dangers that were braved to build our dot-com economy. So, if you can't conceive of what mining copper where the tree line meets the tundra was like, it's time to visit the Chibougamau Mining Center, about 430 miles north of Montreal. It's succinct and visceral.

title: Story Ideas From Coppola
description: The short story, an entire genre that has been more or less remaindered by book publishing in recent years, seems to be having a revival of sorts, and within the last couple of weeks it has been very visibly celebrated. The New Yorker, the premiere showcase for short fiction, observed its 75th anniversary on Monday with its book awards entertainment at the Public Library, and two of its top winners were short-story collections.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Maps a Fight Against an Easing of China Trade
description: A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials today outlined an ambitious campaign to persuade Congress to oppose President Clinton's efforts at normalizing trade relations with China.

title: Deal to Sell Film Rights to 'Harry Potter'
description: Bloomsbury Publishing P.L.C., the British publisher of the ''Harry Potter'' series, agreed to work with Creative Artists Agency, whose clients include Gwyneth Paltrow and Tom Cruise, to sell film rights for its books to Hollywood studios.

title: An Old Master Sold at Auction Raises Doubts; Sotheby's Did Not Report Concerns About Authenticity
description: It was such a classic tale of rags to riches that Oprah Winfrey featured it. So did the ''Today'' show. A 500-year-old painting that had been lying face down in the attic of a Massachusetts rectory, a work that a parishioner had described as ''huge, gold and gaudy,'' turned out to be worth $1 million. Experts at Sotheby's auction house estimated that the painting, believed to be by the Italian Renaissance artist Andrea del Sarto, would sell for $1 million to $1.5 million. At an important sale of old master paintings on Jan. 28, it went for $1.1 million, a record price for the artist.

title: Spartans Goalie Stops N. Michigan
description: A record-tying weekend for Ryan Miller was not what Northern Michigan wanted.

title: Search Software That Compares Apples and Oranges
description: FOR years, experts in digital imagery have been puzzled by a major technical challenge: Can technology be developed that enables people to search for images by visual characteristics alone? Will searchers someday be able to find photographs of, say, a basketball game by searching for an image of a basketball, instead of relying on keywords tagged to that photograph?

title: Europeans Celebrate Their Freedom to Dwell in Hollywood's Shadow
description: For its 50th-anniversary edition the Berlin Film Festival has moved its headquarters from the former West Berlin to Potsdamer Platz, a new urban complex that symbolizes the unification and rebirth of this long-divided city. Yet while the festival now has a home fit for the 21st century, the Berlinale, as it is widely known, is still struggling to find a new identity 10 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

title: New Clarity From a Colorblind 'Othello'
description: Remove the appearance of sharp racial differences from ''Othello'' and the difference in the play is so striking that it makes you wonder how many other stories have been distorted in our imaginations by our historical obsession with race.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a conference in Chicago examining the relationship between arts and society in light of the outcry over the ''Sensation'' show at the Brooklyn Museum reversed the initials of a University of Chicago art professor whose program organized the conference. He is W. J. T. Mitchell, not W. T. J.

title: 76ers Acquire Kukoc in 3-Team Trade
description: The Philadelphia 76ers were stuck in the middle of the Eastern Conference. Like Toronto, Milwaukee, Charlotte and Detroit, they fit somewhere between a playoff-bound team and a championship pretender. Yesterday, the 76ers upgraded their status and caused concern throughout the conference.

title: Town Confused on a Day The Sirens Didn't Go Off
description: Mitchell M. Vanderveer was running on a treadmill at a health club here this morning when he heard that the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant had apparently released a small amount of radiation on Tuesday night. Suddenly, his heart rate spiked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSHOT, VIRGINIA HOSLEY
description: HENDERSHOT-Virginia Hosley. February 14, 2000. Beloved and adoring mother of Joan Hendershot Miller & her husband Herbert. Cherished grandmother of Christopher Alan Miller & his wife Gina. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Mass of Christian burial Thursday February 17, 2000, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84th St.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Shrinking Treasury Debt Creates Uncertain World
description: Lawrence H. Summers, secretary of the Treasury, is clearly relishing his role as the man who put the nation on a no-debt diet. In Congressional testimony last week, Mr. Summers predicted that by 2013, the $3.6 trillion in Treasury debt held by the public would be eliminated, repurchased by funds from budget surpluses that the roaring American economy has wrought. The result, he said, will be an even stronger economy and lower interest rates for all.

title: Clinton Moves to Give Northeast Aid With Fuel Oil
description: President Clinton today pledged even more money for Northeasterners grappling with the soaring cost of home heating oil, even as he acknowledged that federal heating assistance funds may not be adequate to help low-income families endure the winter.

title: Many Questions Remain On Pinochet's Condition
description: Spanish news reports citing a confidential British doctors' examination of Gen. Augusto Pinochet said he suffers from a number of ailments that make him mentally unfit to stand trial. But the news accounts were based on excerpts from the doctors' full report and leave unanswered many medical questions about what ails General Pinochet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, STANLEY
description: MARCUS-Stanley. On Feb. 15, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Father of Aileen, Stephen and Jeffrey. Adored grandfather of Dianna, Matthew, Sara, Amy, Andrew and Michael. Valiant W.W. II soldier and fighter, proud graduate of St. John's University, long practicing CPA.

title: Technology Stocks Gain Ground as Rest of Market Slides
description: Technology stocks stood their ground yesterday but the rest of the market declined as investors awaited January inflation figures and Alan Greenspan's assessment of the economy, with its implications for Federal Reserve Board monetary policy.

title: In Disney's 'Aida,' Le Corbusier Takes a Trip to Ancient Egypt
description: Why not take an 1871 Italian opera set in ancient Egypt, turn it into a rock musical by Elton John and Tim Rice, and stage it against a wall of big art, glowing bright as an Imax screen? Here comes Disney's ''Aida.'' With previews beginning Feb. 25 at the Palace Theater, Disney's revamped production will finally make its Broadway debut. For inspiration, the Irish set and costume designer Bob Crowley (''Carousel'') looked at Abstract Expressionist paintings, architecture by Le Corbusier and drawings by Egyptologists. He then translated it all into huge projections and constructions like the closet of Amneris, the jilted Egyptian princess, above. If palm silhouettes on orange skies and swimmers in turquoise pools remind you of Las Vegas or Los Angeles via David Hockney and Dan Flavin, that's fine, too.

title: TOOLMAKER TO ACQUIRE AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSTRIES
description: The Danaher Corporation, which makes Craftsman hand tools, agreed to buy American Precision Industries for $250 million in cash and assumed debt to expand its motion-control systems business. Danaher said it would buy all shares of the company, which is based in Buffalo, for $19.25 each. Danaher also agreed to assume an undisclosed amount of debt. Motion-control systems are used in factory automation, packaging and semiconductor manufacturing. Shares of Danaher, which is based in Washington, were 31.25 cents lower at $40.875. American Precision was up $7.375, to $18.8125.

title: Jacqueline Auriol, Top French Test Pilot, 82
description: Jacqueline Auriol, the glamorous French flier who set several speed records as one of the world's leading military test pilots in the 1950's and 60's, died Saturday at her Paris home. She was 82.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Sing, Ride, Wait, Fly, Run, Sing

title: PATH Trains Continue To Gain Passengers
description: Ridership on the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's PATH trains was 67.3 million last year, a rise of 3 percent over 1998 and a continuation of a steady increase in passengers since 1996.

title: Hard Work, Being a Man Of Steel
description: AMERICANS consumed 130 million tons of steel last year. Some were extremely fussy about it.

title: Exchange to Offer Derivatives Linked to the Fortune 500 List
description: Move over Dow Jones and Standard & Poor's, here comes the Fortune 500 stock index.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Mystery by Night

title: Black Brother-Sister Duo Pursue Olympics
description: Almost any time he's skiing -- on any slope anywhere -- the Alaskan downhiller Andre Horton seldom sees another black person on the mountain. If he does, that other skier is probably the only other African- American besides himself out there that day. Despite years of ski racing, the realization still gives Horton pause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRIESMAN, MIRIAM
description: DRIESMAN-Miriam. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, sadly mourns the death of Miriam Driesman, our beloved colleague. Miriam, along with her late husband Alfred, was a cherished supporter of the Hadassah College of Technology and the Hadassah Medical Organization. Among their many generous contributions were the medical library at Mt. Scopus and Yag Laser at Ein Kerem. Miriam was a shining example of selfless leadership and dedication, serving as a respected mentor to future generations of Hadassah leaders. She served with distinction as a National Vice President and a member of the Honorary Council. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUMAN, NATHAN
description: GRUMAN-Nathan. On February 16th, 2000. Loving husband of Beatrice, loving father of Mitchell, Stuart & Lori, loving grandfather of Jeremy, Alison, Carly, Tracy and Brett. Contributions to Columbia Presbyterian Hospital Heart Failure Clinic.

title: Climbing Down From His Neo-Classical Column
description: FREDDIE LEIBA is a fashion designer (uniforms for Ian Schrager's hotels), stylist (Elizabeth Hurley's ads for Estee Lauder) and creative consultant (to the couturier Rebecca Moses). He is good at creating tasteful images for other people. Surprisingly, he was a latecomer in forging a style identity all his own.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Offers Aid on Oil Bills

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, JAY M.
description: BERMAN-Jay M. Died peacefully on February 15, 2000 at the age of 89. Beloved husband of Sara, loving father of Dr.Richard, John and Sandra. Loving grandfather of Lawrence, Juliet and Amanda. Graveside service Thursday, February 17, 1PM, at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale NY. Contributions in Jay's memory may be made to Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, East Patchogue NY.

title: Specs
description: FREDDIE LEIBA and Richard Gillette, his interior designer, transformed Mr. Leiba's duplex apartment from neo-Classical to ethnic-eclectic. In the bedrooms, Mr. Gillette installed shelves 18 inches from the ceiling to display books and vases, and also to hide recessed lighting. In the bedrooms and beneath the fireplace ledge, he chose incandescent light for its warmth.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend on Friday about the Roundabout Theater Company's production of ''Arms and the Man'' misidentified the role played by Kevin Kline in 1985 at Circle in the Square. It was Bluntschli, not Sergius.

title: Why They Became Film Directors
description: ''Terrifying'' is Jane Campion's description of working with actors back when she was a fledgling director. ''I was like a control freak. I thought, actors are going to have their own ideas! Terrible. No way.'' It wasn't until her third and breakthrough feature, ''The Piano,'' that she embraced the concept that actors sometimes have ideas better than her own. Casual, witty and exceptionally lucid about her creative development, Ms. Campion is the first guest on a new monthly series, ''Conversations in World Cinema,'' and she gets it off to a smashing start.

title: Carbon-Copy Madness
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams And Nets May Hurry His Return
description: Throughout the season, Jayson Williams has joked about the Nets' feelings toward him. During the rough times, Williams says, team officials nag him to return from the knee and broken leg injuries that have kept him sidelined since last April. But when the team prospered in December, Williams said they urged him to take his time and perhaps wait until next season to play.

title: The Road to Toyland Is Paved With Chips; Technology Takes Over the Nursery
description: E-Specially My Barney, expected in stores by August, comes with a cord so the purple plush figure can be plugged into the nearest computer, where information can be downloaded daily from a Web site and ''personalized'' for a particular child.

title: The Gossip of Europe: Talk About Mergers Surrounds Automakers
description: Europe's automobile industry has gone into overdrive on merger speculation. Today, shares of PSA Peugeot Citroen again rose on rumors that the French automaker was in talks with DaimlerChrysler.

title: Stop the Cycle, Break Kosovo Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning Pixels Into Panache
description: Four years ago, Frank G. Zarb, chief executive of the Nasdaq stock market's parent company, decided to take the role of visionary leader to a new level: he would commission a Times Square sign so big and bright that it would make all the others blur into the background.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hewlett-Packard Earnings Beat Analysts' Estimates

title: Nassau's Bonds Are Downgraded As Its Fiscal Problems Worsen
description: Nassau County's troubled financial outlook worsened significantly today when Moody's Investors Service downgraded the county's bonds to the last level above junk-bond status.

title: Carbon-Copy Madness
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILTZIK, ABRAHAM
description: HILTZIK-Abraham. We mourn the passing of our dear husband, father, grandfather and greatgrandfather. He has left a legacy of love, integrity and family unity. He will be mourned, missed and never forgotten by his wife, Anne; his children, Louise and Arthur Schwartz, George & Linda Hiltzik, Henry and Jacqueline Bloomstein, Rachelle and Josh Weisberger & Yolande Bloomstein Aronowitz; grandchildren Peter and Margaret Schwartz, Ellen and Jonathan Kleinhaus, Matthew, David and Sara Hiltzik, Mindy Weisberger and Michael Baker, Jill and James Schwalbe, Dina Weisberger & Raphie, Adam and Lisa Aronowitz & his great-grandchildren, Samantha and Jordan Kleinhaus, Robert Schwartz and William Schwalbe.

title: Police Official Said to Lead Crisis-Management Agency
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to name a senior police official to head the city's Office of Emergency Management, a four-year-old agency created to handle municipal crises ranging from subway crashes and water main breaks to potential chemical or biological terrorist strikes, city officials said yesterday.

title: Stereotypes and Diallo
description: To the Editor:

title: Love, Honor, Cherish. But Reveal My Password?e
description: SUSAN FLIESS had been looking forward to receiving pictures of a friend's baby through e-mail. She never got the chance. The pictures arrived at fliess1@netscape.net, the e-mail address she shared with her husband, Kevin, but then: ''Kevin was, like: 'What's this big, huge file? You know what their baby looks like,' '' Ms. Fliess said. ''The next thing I knew, he'd deleted it.''

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY

title: New Online Photo Network For Speedier Processing
description: For people who are tired of hanging around the mall waiting for photos to be processed at the one-hour photo developing store, help is on the way. Canon USA and PhotoLoft.com, an online photo-sharing site, have joined forces to create the HyperPhoto Network, which will provide a number of services for picture takers.

title: Woman Fatally Beaten At Home in Queens
description: An elderly woman was found bludgeoned to death early yesterday in her home in Jamaica, Queens, where the authorities believe she may have interrupted a burglary or been the victim of a push-in robbery, officials said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, EDITH
description: KANE-Edith. On February 14, 2000 at age 93. Her beloved sisters, Fay Kane and Evelyn Moss, her brother-in-law Irving Moss, and her nieces, nephews and friends mourn her loss. Contributions to favorite charities are suggested in lieu of flowers. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., at 12 noon, Friday February 18th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROCTON, PHYLLIS ANN (NEE EPSTEIN)
description: PROCTON-Phyllis Ann (nee Epstein). On February 15th. Beloved wife of Al. Mother of Lauren, Lloyd, Risa. Grandmother of Rebecca, Nathan, Andrea, Melissa, Sarah, Lydia. Sister of Eileen and Lois. Artist and teacher. Funeral services at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY, Thursday, 10:30AM. Donations to Temple Isaiah, Great Neck.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an agreement to restructure some of Russia's debt to foreign banks and investors referred incorrectly to the price of oil, a major Russian export. The figure of $30 a barrel is not unprecedented; oil rose to that price before the Persian Gulf war in 1991.

title: Martin Orne, 72, Psychiatrist And Expert on Hypnosis, Dies
description: Dr. Martin T. Orne, a psychiatrist whose work on hypnosis influenced its use around the world and helped limit its role in criminal investigations, died on Friday in Paoli, Pa. He was 72.

title: A Linguistic Pas de Deux By a Beauty And a Beast
description: You can get two people to meet over a drink, over an accident, over a wedding. But how in the world do you get them to meet (and fight) over a word?

title: Ward Sidelined for a Month With a Fracture of the Pinkie
description: For more than a week, Charlie Ward simply taped his right pinkie and played through the pain until he realized the swelling was not going down. Last night, the rugged Ward finally gave in and had an X-ray after the Knicks beat the Timberwolves and discovered he had a nondisplaced fracture.

title: Old-Line Republican Finds an Independent Streak Among the Voters
description: Not quite a decade ago, Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina bought an airplane ticket to Germany and brought home a BMW. Not a car, but a factory. For Mr. Campbell, who had a talent for luring foreign industry, the arrival of BMW meant thousands of new jobs and international cachet for a state once dismissed as a redneck backwater.

title: PURCHASE TO GIVE NET MARKETER AD-TRACKING TECHNOLOGY
description: Be Free Inc., which provides Internet-marketing services for online merchants, agreed to buy the closely held TriVida Corporation for as much as $185.9 million in stock. Be Free, which is based in Marlborough, Mass., will pay 1.56 million shares, valued at $165.8 million, and assume outstanding options to buy TriVida's capital stock for an additional 190,000 shares of Be Free stock, valued at $20.2 million, based on yesterday's closing price of $106.25. TriVida, based in Culver City, Calif., has technology that tracks consumer preferences and purchases, and suggests goods and services for consumers to buy while using the Internet. Be Free helps online merchants and companies track the performance of their promotions on other Web sites.

title: In Japan, Apple Unveils New Items and Upgrades
description: Apple made no new-hardware announcements at its big Macworld computer show in San Francisco last month, but it made up for the lapse in Japan yesterday when it unveiled new and upgraded versions of its PowerMac, PowerBook and iBook product lines.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: A Ticket Booth For a New Century
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia and NATO, Split Over Kosovo, Agree to Renew Relations
description: In a sign of his desire to cultivate closer ties with the West, Acting President Vladimir V. Putin agreed today to end an 11-month estrangement between Russia and NATO and rebuild what the Kremlin called an alliance aimed at ''a stable and indivisible Europe.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, VALERIE
description: MEYERS-Valerie, of Rye Brook, New York, on February 14, 2000. Beloved wife and friend of Walter. Loving mother and step-mother of Patricia, Laurie, Henry, Walter and Veronica. Devoted Nana and Grandma of Ryan, Conor, Matthew, Christian, Melissa, Jessica, Rebecca, Walter Ernest, Joanna and Anthony. Sister of Lillian (San Mateo, Ca.) and Eleanor (Melbourne, FL.). In lieu of flowers, friends may send memorial donations to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

title: Lights, Camera, Marriage and Big Ratings
description: The mystery man sits in the shadows. The prospective brides stand on a stage in wedding gowns, waiting for a proposal. Every moment, the suspense builds -- and so do the ratings.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Maria Paasche, who helped Jews flee Nazi Germany, misspelled the surname of the former German chancellor who praised her father, Gen. Kurt von Hammerstein, for his part in a plot to kill Hitler. The chancellor was Heinrich Bruning, not Brening.

title: A China in Transition
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHEIN, ERNEST
description: RHEIN-Ernest. It is with profound sadness that we note the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Ernest Rhein. He was a devoted, dedicated and loyal associate loved by all. The Philipp Brothers Chemicals Inc. family grieves with his loving wife, Getta, his children, Miriam and Ezra, their spouses and their children. Jack C. Bendheim, President and all the employees of Philipp Brothers Chemicals Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, DANIEL
description: ROTH-Daniel. On February 14, 2000, beloved husband of Irma, devoted father of Joan Roth and Dr. Douglas, caring father-in-law of Ron Stack and Amy Roth, doting grandfather of Jason, Craig, Stacey, and Ilana, dear brother of David and Anna Landy, brother-inlaw of Michael and Nancy Neuman, Phyllis Roth and Norman Landy, loving uncle of many neices and nephews, and good friend to many. Services Thursday February 17th at 11:30 A.M. at The Reformed Temple of Suffern, 350 Haverstraw Road, Suffern, N.Y.

title: For Home Users, No Need To Rush Out for Windows 2000
description: Most home computer users can safely ignore Windows 2000, which goes on sale today as the newest version of the Microsoft Corporation's flagship operating system software. Windows 2000 is designed mainly for large corporations and network-intensive businesses. Even Microsoft concedes that it is not designed for the majority of individual PC users.

title: Working After Retirement
description: A proposal in Congress to repeal limits on what Social Security recipients can earn after retirement is a reasonable move that will allow people between the ages of 65 and 70 to work without losing all or part of their Social Security benefits. The idea is popular with older Americans, and President Clinton endorsed it a year ago. While piecemeal changes to the Social Security system are rarely a good idea, this particular proposal is acceptable because it will have no significant effect on the solvency of the trust fund, and it can help retirees who need to supplement their benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KENNER, MORTON
description: KENNER-Morton. 2/17/99. Many beautiful memories and everlasting love. I miss you. Yours, Edyth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUELLER, SYLVIA (NEE PRICE)
description: MUELLER-Sylvia (nee Price). On February 14, 2000. Survived by her brother Norman, nephew Michael Price and niece Claudia Forbes.

title: African-American Sites Look Back and Forward
description: THE sepia-colored words are evenly spaced and have a schoolmarm's pedantic forward tilt. Looking at the letter quickly, you might think it a recounting of a debutante's ball, not the correspondent's matter-of-fact telling of being sold five times in as many years, and the hope that her current owner will buy her daughter.

title: Vargas and Quartey Sign for Title Bout
description: The official announcement of a title bout between Fernando Vargas, the International Boxing Federation junior-middleweight champion, and Ike Quartey, a former World Boxing Association welterweight champion, was set for noon yesterday in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Bronx Woman Is Killed in an Elevator Accident
description: A 21-year-old woman was crushed by an elevator yesterday in a Bronx apartment building, the police said.

title: Cars to Be Booted In Child Support Cases
description: Following the lead of neighboring Suffolk County, officials in Nassau County proposed legislation yesterday that would give the police the power to disable the vehicle of a parent who failed to make child support payments.

title: Exploring Zulu History on the Web
description: FOR roughly 60 years during the 19th century, the Zulu kingdom that had been forged by the warrior leader Shaka was one of the mightiest black states in Africa. It took a full military campaign by Britain to pull it down.

title: An Undercurrent of Drama In a Tightly Plotted Recital
description: Mahler, who spent much of his working life in opera houses, never wrote an opera of his own. Or perhaps he did. Thomas Hampson's recital at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday, the first of two devoted to the composer, had the form of a three-act drama, and not the least of its virtues was the persuasive shaping Mr. Hampson brought to the evening.

title: FRICTION EASES AT GOLD MINE
description: The Ashanti Goldfields Company, Africa's third-largest gold company, said disgruntled investors agreed to drop a lawsuit in Ghana after seven directors resigned, clearing the way for a mine sale to raise much-needed cash. Adryx Mining and Metals Ltd., which represents investors with about 5 percent of Ashanti shares, won a court order last week forcing the company to hold a shareholders' meeting to consider disbanding the board. That order, which froze the company's assets, was lifted after the agreement was reached, Ashanti said.

title: Metro Matters; Murder Trial But Not a Case For Murder
description: THE relief was palpable in Justice Joseph C. Teresi's courtroom here yesterday, when he said that the defense and the prosecution had agreed that the jury should consider less serious charges than murder in the trial of four police officers accused in the killing of Amadou Diallo.

title: Rangers Aim at Bure but Miss Target
description: The Florida Panthers right wing Pavel Bure is so good that teams have devised an all-out strategy to contain him, a sort-of National Hockey League version of basketball's box-and-one defense.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Friday about the Bombay Company's appointment of its president and chief operating officer to the additional post of chief executive referred to the executive incorrectly. Carmie Mehrlander is a woman.

title: Life With AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Come to Work Early, Hoping They Get to Stay Late
description: Standing alongside Derek Jeter at a batting cage near home plate, Tino Martinez shielded his eyes from the sun and tried to identify the broad-shouldered man entering the field in the distance, in the right field corner. ''Bernie,'' Martinez finally said, somewhat fooled by Williams's newly muscled physique, and he and Jeter and Williams all traded handshakes and hugs, two days before the Yankees officially open their training camp.

title: Life With AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Mirror Is Selling Sporting News
description: Paul G. Allen, who co-founded Microsoft with Bill Gates, announced yesterday that his company, Vulcan Ventures Inc., is buying The Sporting News, the country's oldest sporting magazine, from the Times Mirror Company.

title: Michigan Finds Itself in a Secondhand Role as Primary Nears
description: Michigan may be the first big state that the Republican presidential candidates are competing for -- with more delegates at stake in its primary next Tuesday than in New Hampshire and South Carolina combined -- but it is a secondhand campaign that they are giving it.

title: Tantalizing Hope: Looking for Yeti
description: In the past nine months, the

title: With Help, Realizing a Dream of College
description: Jessie Lett had big plans, but she did not know how to achieve them.

title: Ronnie Robertson, 62, a Skater Who Entertained With His Spins
description: Ronnie Robertson, a silver-medalist figure skater in the 1956 Winter Olympics and an ice-show star who was known as the Blur for his uncanny spins, died on Feb. 4 at a hospital in Fountain Valley, Calif. Robertson, who lived in Irvine, Calif., was 62.

title: St. John's May Retain a Law Firm Adept in Dealing With N.C.A.A.
description: As the National Collegiate Athletic Association investigates whether there had been improper contact between St. John's players and representatives of sports agents, the university has contacted a law firm specializing in the policy and procedures of the N.C.A.A.

title: Questions of Veracity Have Long Dogged Gore
description: Questions about Vice President Al Gore's honesty have emerged as a recurring motif of his contest with former Senator Bill Bradley for the Democratic presidential nomination. Mr. Bradley has angrily accused the vice president of a systematic effort to distort Mr. Bradley's record while whitewashing his own.

title: Logging On to Find Out What's Going On at School
description: THREE years ago, David Leahy, a fourth-grade teacher at the Greenaway Elementary School in Beaverton, Ore., anointed himself the school's Webmaster and started work on his labor of love.

title: CADBURY SCHWEPPES PROFIT
description: Growth of soft drink sales in the United States contributed to a 9 percent gain in the 1999 earnings of Cadbury Schweppes, maker of Dr Pepper and 7Up. The British company posted annual pretax profit of $:686 million, or $1.10 billion, for 1999, up from $:628 million a year earlier. Shares in Cadbury rose 6 percent, to 342 pence. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERBER, STEVEN
description: FERBER-Steven. 2/17/61-9/27/97. Time will never heal the pain of losing you. The precious memories you left with us will always be alive in our hearts. Loving you forever, Mom, Family & Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEN, MORTON IRVING
description: SEIDEN-Morton Irving. The Brooklyn College community mourns the passing of Professor of English, Morton Irving Seiden. His 46 years of teaching and service will long be remembered. Christoph M. Kimmich President, Brooklyn College

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, DAVID
description: MERRILL-David. We mourn the loss of our dear friend on February 13, in his Washington, DC home at 38. Formerly of New York City, he is survived by his parents, Lois and Edward Merrill, of Glen Rock, NJ; a brother, Ted, and a sister, Ruth, and his partner, David Carrig of Washington, DC and colleagues at Discovery Channel. He graduated Emerson College. He had the right perspective on life and though his days were short, he truly lived to the fullest. His dry wit and knack for telling funny stories helped us take ourselves a little less seriously. Services will be held at Browning-Forshay Funeral Home, 557 Lafayette Avenue, Hawthorne, NJ at 3:30pm Saturday, February 19 with visitation on Febraury 18, 7-9pm and February 19, 2-3:30pm. Memorial contributions may go to GLAAD (Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation), 1825 Connecticut Ave NW, 5 Flr, Washington DC 20009 or God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10013.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHORODZANER, CHAIM
description: BOHORODZANER-Chaim. The Young Israel of Holliswood mourns the loss of our esteemed Board Member, Chaim Bohorodzaner. He inspired us with his courage and with his commitment to his family, his community and his faith. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jeruslaem. Marc Penner, Rabbi Dr. Rubin Cooper, Dr. Alan Schnall Presidium

title: Government Was 'Napping' On Oil Cost, Energy Chief Says
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson stood penitent here today before a crowd of regional politicians, truckers, industry representatives and consumers at the first New England Heating Oil Summit, and confessed, ''We were caught napping.''

title: Data on Housing Industry Is Stronger Than Expected
description: Construction of new homes and apartments increased unexpectedly in January, and permits for new projects climbed to the highest level in a year, suggesting builders will stay busy in months ahead even as interest rates rise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINDLER, DINAH
description: ZINDLER-Dinah. 89, died on February 16, 2000. She was married to Elias Zindler until his death and is survived by her loving family; sister, Estelle Minkowsky of White Plains, daughter, Rita Asch, and partner, Frank Magalhaes of Princeton, NJ, son, Jerrold Zindler, and wife, Linda Zindler of Brookline, MA; grandchildren, Eric and David Asch and Ethan and Rachel Zindler, and a great-grandson, Peter Adler Asch. Funeral service will be held at the Riverdale Temple at 1 P.M., on February 17th, 2000. The family requests that in lieu of flowers a donation be made to a Jewish charity.

title: U.S. Officials Lay Out Plan To Fight Computer Attacks
description: A week after unidentified hackers paralyzed several commercial Internet companies, the country's chief law enforcement and legal officers said today that threats against computer networks had outstripped the government's efforts to keep up with them.

title: America's Design Legacy . . . . . . Going, Going, Going
description: IN London, Washington and, most recently, New York, attendance at the traveling exhibition on Charles and Ray Eames, the postwar design mavericks, broke museum records. But people filing by to marvel at their plywood molding experiments -- prototypes that didn't cut it and (eureka!) ones that did -- were unaware that nearly every major American institution had passed up the chance to buy the Eameses' legacy of furniture invention.

title: In America; Destroyer of Lives
description: Dana Garner is a man who lies as easily as most people breathe. But he is more than a compulsive destroyer of the truth. Dispensing his lies like poison, he has become a menace to the criminal justice system in Brooklyn, and a destroyer of lives.

title: Two Drug Giants Report Earnings
description: The two British drugmakers that merged last month to create Glaxo SmithKline P.L.C., the world's largest pharmaceutical company, posted their 1999 earnings today and demonstrated what analysts called the necessity for the marriage.

title: Mets' Cook Is Hoping To Stick Around
description: The slogan on Dennis Cook's T-shirt, ''Go Hard or Go Home,'' is faded, as is the small Florida Marlins logo that accompanies it. The Mets' left-hander has not been a Marlin since 1997, and this is the first time in his 12-year major league career that he has been with the same team three springs in a row.

title: Accounts
description: BBDO Houston, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, was named to handle four accounts with combined billings estimated at $10 million: Cooper Industries, Houston, for its first corporate image research and branding; Office Domain, Austin, Tex., for its first print campaign for Message ASAP, an e-mail, voice mail and fax message service; Pizza Hut, Dallas, a unit of Tricon Global Restaurants, for its first national radio campaign; and Shell Chemical Co., Houston, part of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Cos., for a branding assignment for Corterra polymers.

title: In Search of a Simple Machine That Is Dedicated to the Basics
description: In Search of a Simple Machine That Is Dedicated to the Basics

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO CONTINUES TO CLIMB. The euro rose for a second day against the dollar in advance of a report today that is expected to show business confidence is rising in Germany. The euro rose to 98.68 cents from 98.12 cents.

title: Coast Guard Plans to Move From Ft. Totten in Queens
description: The Coast Guard agreed yesterday to move out of a spectacular slice of waterfront in Fort Totten in Queens, Representative Gary L. Ackerman said, but who would take over the valuable land remained in question.

title: Hewlett-Packard Earnings Exceed Estimates in Quarter
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported fiscal first-quarter earnings today that exceeded Wall Street estimates by a couple of pennies, excluding costs associated with the spinoff of its test- and measurement-equipment maker, Agilent Technologies.

title: FOOTSTAR PLANS TO PICK UP SOME ASSETS OF JUST FOR FEET
description: Footstar Inc., the No. 2 retailer of athletic footwear and apparel, said it planned to acquire some assets of its money-losing rival Just for Feet Inc. for about $70 million, to expand in the Midwest. Footstar will pay $69.7 million in cash for Just for Feet's brand name, 79 superstores, 23 specialty stores, its Internet business and corporate headquarters. It will also assume $2.9 million in Just for Feet debt. Footstar shares rose $1.9375, to $24.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Just for Feet, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., filed for bankruptcy protection on Nov. 4.

title: Metro Business; Bank Votes Allowed
description: Two big Wall Street firms will be able to vote next week in a hotly contested election for two positions on the board of Carver Bancorp, the largest black-run bank in the country, a Delaware court ruled yesterday. Dissident shareholders who are running for Carver's board had asked the court to block the votes of the two Wall Street firms, which bought their shares from Carver last month for about $2.5 million. The two firms, Morgan Stanley and Provender Capital, now control about 8 percent of Carver's shares.

title: Lost in Brooklyn: A Dog Should Be Loved
description: To the Editor:

title: Exhibitions, Talks, Film Screenings
description: Filipino Fashion

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: February 17, 2000

title: H & R Block's Tax Web Site Has a Mix-Up
description: At least nine people who logged on to the H & R Block Web site to do their taxes last week ended up with data from other customers' returns mixed in with their own, the company said yesterday.

title: It's a Party, And He's Checking Out Funk and Soul
description: Beck's challenge during his two-night stand at Radio City Music Hall was to perform songs in real time that are dedicated to shattering mere linearity. On Tuesday night he didn't quite pull it off, held back by physical constraints that he can escape in the studio.

title: Americans Bring Air of Irreverence to Prada
description: With mischief in his eye, and the trace of a grin shadowed in his thick red beard, Doug Peterson looks like a man enjoying the calm within the eye of a storm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULRYAN, JANICE KALNA
description: MULRYAN-Janice Kalna, on February 16, 2000, of Great Neck, NY. Beloved wife of Rev. John Mulryan. Loving mother of Louis Mulryan. Cherished sister of William Kalna and aunt of Amy and Jonathan Kalna. Mrs. Mulryan was a guidance counselor at Garden City High School. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Friday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious services Saturday, 11 AM, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society or St. Paul's Church.

title: Victor Edward Cohn, 80, Science Reporter
description: Victor Edward Cohn, a prize-winning science reporter, editor and columnist for The Washington Post and, earlier, The Minneapolis Tribune, died on Monday at his home in Washington. He was 80.

title: Bradley Says Clinton and Gore Neglected Upstate New York
description: Turning his attention to upstate New York, Bill Bradley said today that the federal government had not invested enough money in the region's depressed economy and criticized Vice President Al Gore for not spending enough time here.

title: Financial Sites Are Said to Seek Merger
description: TheStreet.com, whose fledgling stock soared and then dipped sharply during the last six months, is in preliminary merger discussions with MarketWatch.com, a leading rival in the hotly contested business of delivering financial news online, a person close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Six Wrestlers in Connecticut Are Charged in Hazing Case
description: Six wrestlers from Trumbull High School in Connecticut were charged yesterday with repeatedly hazing two teammates.

title: At Seton Hall, State Assumes Responsibility In Fire Checks
description: New Jersey officials have taken over the local government's job of conducting fire inspections at Seton Hall University after discovering fire code violations and gaps in the village's record of inspections at the campus here, where three freshmen died last month in a dormitory fire.

title: In Search of a Simple Machine That Is Dedicated to the Basics
description: Q. We are retired and only want to do word processing and use the Internet. Is there a simple machine out there that will let us just use word processing programs and go out on the Internet?

title: Pulling for, and Pushing, an Urban Internet
description: DARIEN DASH has piled on the gold chains and partied with Puffy, then put on his three-piece suit for a Rose Garden briefing with President Clinton on the perils of Internet illiteracy in black and Hispanic communities.

title: School Board May Sell Its Brick Symbol of Bureaucracy
description: The New York City Board of Education voted unanimously yesterday to explore the sale of its headquarters at 110 Livingston Street, which critics have attacked as a symbol of ineffective bureaucracy and managerial failure.

title: A High-End Top 30 List: Myths About Nietzsche
description: WHAT NIETZSCHE REALLY SAID

title: Company Plans Move to Nasdaq From Big Board
description: Aeroflex Inc., a maker of communications equipment, will announce today that it is moving its stock listing from the New York Stock Exchange to Nasdaq, becoming the first company to make that move.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., the No. 1 maker of gas-fired turbines, said it won a $900 million order to supply 10 turbines for Turkish power plants being built by InterGen, Boston, a joint venture of Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and Enka Holding Yatirim, Istanbul, one of Turkey's biggest construction companies.

title: McCain Picks Up a Valuable Endorsement From Bauer
description: Senator John McCain won the endorsement today of Gary L. Bauer, a former presidential rival and prominent social conservative, who called him the ''best shot we have to end the era of Bill and Hillary and Al Gore.''

title: Out of Site!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARY MURRAY
description: BROWN-Mary Murray. Beloved and loving wife of Leland Scott Brown. Loving mother of Morgan Scott Brown and Janet Brown Jussel. Beloved mother-in-law of Suzanne R. Brown and Christian Jussel. Grandmother of John Bradbury, Sara B. Robbins, Catherine M. Jussel & David S. Jussel. Died February 17, 2000. She was known for years of service to the Bedford Free Library, Bedford, New York, and her deep love of Chappaquiddick Island. A memorial service will be held Monday, February 21 at 11:00 at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford. In lieu of flowers it is suggested that gifts be made to the Bedford Free Library, Bedford, NY 10506.

title: Knicks Give Wolves Lesson in Waste Management
description: At first glance, Kurt Thomas is just a sleepy-eyed big man with a body that has the lumpy and frumpy characteristics of a garage-sale couch. It's just part of his act, part of the deception.

title: The Once and Future War
description: To the Editor:

title: Taming the Crude Metals
description: Ask any architect: metal rules. The trouble is that sheet metal is wavy, heavy, scratchable, hard to cut -- and costly, too. Now, a patented process that fuses premium metals with ''proprietary polymers and ceramics'' will deliver copper, bronze, brass, gunmetal and nickel silver in useful shapes and sizes. Questech metal tiles feel like standard ceramic tiles, but they look like cast metal. Clear-coated to resist scratching, the tiles (which can be used for walls, as in the kitchen below, or for flooring) are available in a range of metals, finishes, sizes and prices. A 6-by-6-inch tile costs from $7.50 to $10. Information about distributors is available from Crossville Porcelain, (800) 809-6555 or www.crossvilleporcelain.com.

title: In Chechnya's Shattered Capital, Survivors See Their Own Reflection
description: The battle for Grozny ended too late for Klavdiya M. Nefyodova. Her son was killed three weeks ago by a band of rebel fighters after he refused to dig trenches for the defense of the Chechen capital.

title: Giving Men Something to Do
description: While women load up on handbags at Kate Spade on Broome Street, their men can now meander around the corner to a new store called Jack Spade. And it's all in the family, although its founder, Ms. Spade's husband, is named Andy, not Jack.

title: Music From Inside an Egg
description: You don't have to enjoy listening to music to enjoy the egg-shaped U-Vola hi-fi speaker, designed by Alessandro Copetti for Arte & Suono. The U-Vola, which has won 10 design awards, hangs on a steel wire. It comes in finishes like polished silver (left), $2,000, and hand-painted watermelon (far left), $2,666. To order from Zao, 175 Orchard Street (Houston Street); (212) 505-0500. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Christian Groups Urge a Vast, Coordinated Attack on Poverty
description: Concerned that poverty persists in America despite a prolonged period of national prosperity, a broad group of Christian leaders gathered in Washington yesterday to call for an effort by churches, businesses, labor and government to help poor people.

title: A Defense More Ulterior Than Inferior
description: There are some defensive problems that seem insoluble no matter much thought is devoted to them. Consider the diagramed deal played in a money game at the Regency Club in Manhattan. The declarer in four spades was Freddy Bienstock, a regular player in that game. He pointed out in the post-mortem that the defense had missed a rare opportunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKEL, HERBERT F.
description: MARKEL-Herbert F., died February 13, 2000 at the age of 78 at his home in Rye Brook, NY after a long illness. He was a graduate of Port Chester High School, graduated Columbia University and Columbia University School of Law attaining Law Review Honors. A veteran of the Pacific Theatre with the U.S. Navy in WW II, he later attended Officer Training School at Harvard University achieving the rank of Ensign. Mr. Markel was a corporate attorney and his career spanned four decades culminating in retirement in 1986 from GTE Corporation in Stamford, CT. He is survived by his wife, Madeline G. Markel, his three children Loren, Kenny and Susan, cousins Ruth and Sara Karnes, and Esther Karnes Hausman, and niece Helen Eichler Krigsman. He leaves a legacy of love, compassion and integrity and will be sorely missed by family and friends. Memorial services will be held on February 17, 2000, 1:00 p.m. at KTI Synagogue in Port Chester, New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAR, ARLINE
description: HAAR-Arline. The Gerrard Berman Day School of North Jersey notes with great sadness the death of Arline Haar. She and her late husband, George, have been and will continue to be an inspiration to all of us in the Jewish community. Our heartfelt sympathy and condplences to her children, grandchildren and entire family. Lawrence Traster, President Gerrard Berman Day School

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, WALTER NILS
description: FRANK-Walter Nils, 91. Died Tuesday at Kendal at Hanover, NH. He was born April 22, 1908 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of Louis and Selma (Persson) Frank. He attended Brooklyn schools and entered New York University in 1924. He was married on April 22, 1931 to Ruth Carlson. Mr. Frank had been a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1937 and served as chairman of the Board of Governors from 1965-1967. He was predeceased by his wife in 1998 and by his son, Walter Nils Frank, Jr., in 1995. He is survived by his daughter, Judith Frank Ketterer of Lyme, NH; his sister, Elsa Hintze of Hanover; six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Calling services will be held from 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday at Rand-Wilson Funeral Home at 11-1/2 School Street, Hanover. Funeral services will be held at 1 PM Saturday in the Rand-Wilson Funeral Home. Burial will follow at Pine Knoll Cemetery. Contributions in Mr. Frank's memory may be made to the Cadbury Fund at Kendal, 80 Lyme Road, Kendal at Hanover, Hanover, NH 03755 or to the Children's Hospital at Dartmouth (CHAD), c/o Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, One Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, RAYMOND W.
description: EISENBERG-Raymond W. Loving husband of Estelle, devoted father of Robert, Barry (Teresa), Glenn (Gigi). Loving grandfather of Philip, Mathew, Jackie and Emma. Dear brother of Marvin (Audrey). Services, Friday, February 18th, 9:30 AM at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 5808 W. Atlantic Avenue, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, CLEMENTINE
description: HERZ-Clementine. On February 15, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Loving mother of Ellen. Dear sister of Marcelle and Maurice. Adoring meme of Heath and Rebecca. Dearest friend of Kurt. Dear mother-in-law of Stuart. Service on Friday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Wrong Man for the F.E.C.
description: Vice President Al Gore has wisely joined Bill Bradley in calling on the Senate to reject President Clinton's nomination of Bradley Smith to the Federal Election Commission. The decision is another sign that Mr. Gore now appreciates the need to reform a campaign finance system that he and Mr. Clinton so brazenly abused in 1996. Mr. Smith, a Republican and a law professor who opposes reasonable limits on campaign money, is the choice of G.O.P. senators who oppose reform. Mr. Gore should help Tom Daschle, the Senate minority leader, wage a fight to block Mr. Smith's confirmation.

title: Oil and the Market
description: To the Editor:

title: PARTY HEAD QUITS IN GERMAN CRISIS
description: The crisis of the conservative party that has governed and stabilized Germany for most of the postwar years deepened today with the abrupt resignation of its leader, Wolfgang Schauble.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Sailing, Italian Style: Fashion, Top-Siders
description: The night that the Prada sailboat Luna Rossa wound up qualifying for the America's Cup finals -- the first Italian boat to do so since 1992 -- the coach of the A.C. Milan soccer team blacked out the players' training camp television sets, fearful that they would blow their next match by staying up all night to watch the chic gray-and-red Prada sails edge ahead of America One in the deciding race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YARIN, MURRAY
description: YARIN-Murray. Of Bronxville, N.Y. lost a brave 18-month battle against pancreatic cancer February 15, 2000. Beloved and loving husband of Barbara. Loving and cherished father of Susan, Daniel (Louise). Adoring brother of Marvin (Susan), Jack (Cynthia), brother-in-law (Helen and Howard Glick). Loving uncle and friend. Services Thursday, February 17 at 12PM at Garlick Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers. The family would appreciate donations in his memory to Cancer Care, 275 7th Ave, NYC 10001 or Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St, Tuckahoe, N.Y. 10707.

title: Involving the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Plant Had Warning Over Leakage
description: Consolidated Edison officials said tonight that the steam generator that leaked radioactivity Tuesday night at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, setting off a wide alert, had begun showing signs of a leakage problem several weeks ago.

title: Sanitation Worker Killed By Hit-and-Run Driver
description: A sanitation worker who held down two jobs to put his sons through college was killed in a hit-and-run accident on Tuesday night in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday through Monday with 1,225 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 979 said they were registered to vote.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Death of a Garden
description: On Tuesday morning, Esperanza Garden, a community garden on East Seventh Street in Manhattan, was bulldozed after 22 years of existence. Its destruction marked the latest battle in the long-running war between Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and community advocates over the use of city-owned lots for community gardens. City Hall contends that many lots were only lent to the neighborhoods for gardens with the understanding that they would ultimately be taken back. Now, the mayor says, the lot on East Seventh Street should be sold to a developer to build low- and middle-income housing.

title: No Fiscal Conservatives Here
description: George W. Bush and John McCain both claim to be fiscal conservatives. But what is a fiscal conservative? And who is the true conservative when it comes to fiscal matters?

title: Tigers Win Big One On Assist From Selig
description: The season hasn't even started, and the Detroit Tigers have already registered a victory. They scored one over Commissioner Bud Selig, and the surprising aspect of it was he let them have it. Not a good start to the season for the commissioner. Baseball's impartial arbitrator may be the next to hand him a loss, that one on the John Rocker grievance.

title: An American Sells Britons 'Their' Rose
description: WHEN Elton John sang ''Goodbye England's Rose'' at Westminster Abbey in 1997, who knew it would lead to ''Hello Garden Sales''?

title: NPRs Instrumental Bits Become an Online Music Show
description: February 17, 2000

title: New Heights (or Depths) of Blood and Gore
description: SOME of the most popular computer-based games today are invitations to grab a joystick and enter exquisitely rendered, full-color combat zones in which players assume the identities of superhuman gladiators whose survival depends upon their being able to turn opponents into canned ham -- without the can.

title: 2 SIDES RECOMMEND DIALLO JURY HEAR REDUCED CHARGES
description: Testimony in the trial of four white New York City police officers charged with killing an unarmed black immigrant in a barrage of bullets last year drew to a surprisingly quick conclusion today, as both the defense and the prosecution recommended that the jury be allowed to consider charges less serious than murder.

title: A Ticket Booth For a New Century
description: To the Editor:

title: DASSAULT SUCCESSION
description: France's only maker of combat jets, Dassault Aviation, said Charles Edelstenne, now vice chairman, would take over the top job when Serge Dassault steps down in April. Mr. Edelstenne, 62, has been executive vice president in charge of economic and financial affairs since 1986. He is also chairman and chief executive of Dassault Systemes, which was spun off from Dassault Aviation and makes computer-aided design software for airplanes, automobiles and other products. The changeover, which becomes effective April 4, when Mr. Dassault turns 75, was widely expected, since Dassault Aviation's bylaws require that the chief executive step down by that age.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the sale of an equity stake in the Zagat Survey to a group of outside investors misstated the affiliation of one investor, Nathan Myhrvold. He is on leave from Microsoft, where he was chief technology officer. He was not a founder of Microsoft.

title: Will 'Peanuts' characters remain effective images, or will they go the way of the Schmoo?
description: DURING the last 50 years, Charles M. Schulz built the comic strip ''Peanuts'' into one of the most powerful and effective brands in entertainment marketing. The adventures of characters like Charlie Brown, Snoopy, Linus and Lucy spawned billions of dollars worth of licensed merchandise from companies like Fossil, Hallmark, Hasbro and Pez; inspired scores of advertising campaigns for products like Ford automobiles, Dolly Madison snack cakes and Metropolitan Life insurance; and generated hundreds of promotions for fast food, soft drinks and other mass-market goods and services.

title: For Shoppers' Senses
description: To the Editor:

title: American Topics : Raised From the Ashes  an Art Form
description: Walk through the glass doors of Commander's Gallery in Biloxi, Mississippi, past the conventional oil and pastel paintings, past the green curtains and you will find a new art medium  human ashes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWLES, MARGARET C.
description: COWLES-Margaret C. formerly of Ardsley-on-Hudson. Survived by her son Donald, daughters Susan Synder and Sara Walden, eight grandchildren, 11 great grandchildren, two nieces and five nephews. Predeceased by her husband Noble Pitt Cowles and a daughter Nancy. Visiting Friday 24 and 7-9 PM, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY. Services Saturday 11 AM, Aldersgate Methodist Church, N. Broadway, Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to the church or Community Hospital at Dobbs Ferry.

title: Excerpts from Clinton's Comments at Wide-Ranging News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Labor Urges Amnesty for Illegal Immigrants
description: Adopting a sharp change in policy, the American labor movement today called for blanket amnesty for illegal immigrants and an end to most sanctions against employers who hire them.

title: BRAZIL INTERNET PURCHASE
description: Portugal's largest Internet company, PT Multimedia, agreed to buy Zip.net of Brazil for $365 million in one of the largest Internet takeovers ever in Latin America. The acquisition of Zip.net, Brazil's third-largest portal, will give the Portuguese company greater firepower to compete with Terra Networks of Spain, which has made significant investments in Brazil's Internet industry. Simon Romero

title: Surgical Report Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: Take That, Winter Blahs: Aids to Urban Hibernation
description: NOW is the discontent of our winter. If you are not getting to a spa for Presidents' Day weekend, you can still pamper yourself in new ways at home and feel nearly as restored.

title: Curbing Free Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: What to Do With Hemp And Chicken Feathers
description: Didn't know you needed a vase bristling with hemp-paper twine (right) or one covered with Capiz shell or chicken feathers? Design fuels desire; desire fuels the economy. That is the revelation behind ''Fuzz, Feathers and Beyond,'' an exhibition now at Material Connexion's minigallery at 4 Columbus Circle (information: 212-445-8825). And that's why the Philippine government had the architect Carlo Tanseco work with 15 local manufacturers to turn tropical resources into decorative arts. On March 15, their wares go on sale at the American Craft Museum, from $40 for a candleholder to $500 for a jade-mosaic bowl.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It took something like this to make the Miss America pageant look good to me.''

title: A Way to the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MAURICE
description: BERNSTEIN-Maurice. On February 10, 2000 in Keene, N.H., formerly of NYC. Loving father and fatherin-law of Peggy and Bill Heyman. Beloved grandfather of Lynn and Chris Hansen, Mark Heyman and Jay Heyman. Dear great-grandfather of Laura and Kyle Hansen. Raised in the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, he rose to become the HOA's Director until its closing in 1941. He had a distinguished career as a social worker retiring as Senior Consultant and Director of Community Planning from the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds. A memorial service will be held in NYC on March 13, 2000 at the 92nd St. YM-YWHA at 10:00 AM in the Weill Art Gallery.

title: An Italian Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: INDONESIAN ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: Indonesia's economy, which has languished through much of the recovery elsewhere in Asia, appears to be picking up. Data released by the government showed that the nation's economy grew at a 5.7 percent annualized rate in the fourth quarter of 1999, enough to eke out growth of 0.2 percent for the year. Household and government spending led the growth, which appeared to exceed most economists' predictions. Wayne Arnold

title: Piano Tuners Have Built a Bridge To 18th Century
description: PIANO tuning is a quirky, sparsely populated profession. Like glass blowing, the skill is often handed down from one generation to the next. And it is difficult to learn. The traditional rule of thumb, or ear, is that it can take three years, or 1,000 tunings, before a professional tuner can tune a piano well.

title: Olivadotti to Take Over as Giants' Linebackers Coach
description: Tom Olivadotti, an assistant coach known mostly for his nine years as the Miami Dolphins' defensive coordinator under Coach Don Shula, was named the Giants' new linebackers coach yesterday. He replaces Mike Haluchak, who left the team to take a similar position with the St. Louis Rams.

title: Spanish Newspapers Disclose Secret Pinochet Health Report
description: Two Spanish newspapers, citing copies of a secret British medical report they had obtained on Gen. Augusto Pinochet, reported today that he suffered brain damage from minor strokes last year, which doctors said left him mentally unfit to stand trial in Spain.

title: Mobile E-Mail and Web Access For Users of Palm V and Vx
description: Hope is in the airwaves for Palm V and Vx owners. The OmniSky Corporation and AT&T have teamed up to provide a wireless modem and Internet services for the users of the tiniest of the Palm organizers. The combination package is undergoing a public beta trial by thousands of Palm V owners, and OmniSky plans to release the final version in the spring. Prices have not been set.

title: Bush Loses Luster in a Poll As Gore Sheds Poor Image
description: As Gov. George W. Bush of Texas finds himself in a rancorous primary struggle, voters' impressions of him nationally have diminished so substantially that now as many people dislike him as like him, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANTONI, HON. ALBERT
description: DANTONI-Hon. Albert. Formerly of New City, NY. He served as Commissioner and Chairman for the New York Workman's Compensation Board. Reposing Friday, 2-4, 7-9PM at Shook's Cedar Grove Funeral Home, 486 Pompton Ave., Cedar Grove, NJ, (973) 239-1489. Donations in his memory can be made to the St. Jude Children's Cancer Research Hospital or to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Life With AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: CISCO BUYS PRODUCER OF CHIPS FOR NETWORKS
description: Cisco Systems Inc., a leading maker of Internet equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Growth Networks Inc. for about $355 million in stock, to add semiconductors that speed computer networks. Growth Networks, founded in 1998 and based in Mountain View, Calif., makes chips that help information flow faster through network switches and routers. Cisco wants to offer faster versions of its most expensive switches and routers to fend off competition from Lucent Technologies Inc., Juniper Networks Inc. and other phone-equipment makers. Cisco is based in San Jose, Calif.

title: Forced Dash to a Missile Defense
description: Perfecting and building a limited national missile defense would give America added security against future threats from North Korea, Iran and Iraq. But a weapons system this complex must go through long and rigorous testing before engineers can be sure it will reliably shield American cities from enemy missile attack. Until that standard has been met, a decision to begin construction of the proposed $27 billion missile system would be premature, and not worth the risk of imperiling nuclear arms control treaties with Russia.

title: Web Site Gets $12 Million in Financing
description: ELance.com, a World Wide Web site that has added an auction twist to the buying and selling of professional services online, said yesterday that it had received $12 million in financing from the venture capital firm of Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEZOZA, GERRY
description: BEZOZA-Gerry, on February 15, 2000. Beloved wife of Nathan, loving mother of Ira and Howard, cherished grandmother of Jenna, Michel, Dana, Amanda and Tori. She will be forever remembered by her family and friends. Services at 12PM, Thursday, February 17 at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Saudi Oil Minister Hints OPEC May Feel Compelled to Raise Output
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer, signaled that prices have climbed too high and may need to fall to ensure stable growth in the world's economies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLANTYNE, MARION C.
description: BALLANTYNE-Marion C. Died peacefully at home on February 15 in her 94th year. Beloved widow of the late Jacques C. Nordeman and the late John J. Ballantyne. Loving mother of Mary Ann and Jacques Nordeman, devoted grandmother of Landon, John and Eliza. Private services will be held for the immediate family. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Friday, February 25, 6-8PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory can be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, 8th floor, NY, NY 10022, a park which Marion loved dearly.

description: AIDALA-Arthur. Beloved husband of the late Marietta (nee DeLuca). Loving father of Louis R. Aidala and Lorraine Ambrosio. Adored grandfather of Arthur L. Aidala, Lori Aidala Bambina, Joseph Ambrosio and Anthony Ambrosia. Reposing at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleeker St, NYC, Wednesday 7-9:30, Thursday 2-5 & 79:30 & Friday 2-5 & 7-9:30. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10am at Saint Joseph's Church. Interment Moravian Cemetery.

title: First Lady and Charlie Rose: Cooking, Brevity and Baseball
description: For nearly an hour at the 92nd Street Y last night, Hillary Rodham Clinton answered questions about her politics and her husband, about her failures as first lady and as a candidate for office, about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and about her kitchen skills (or lack thereof).

title: Corrections
description: A report by Reuters in the World Briefing column yesterday about the resignation of the head of the World Food Program in Iraq misspelled her surname. She is Jutta Burghardt, not Purghart.

title: Taiwan's Governing Party Accuses a Rival of Embezzlement
description: The bitter rivalry between Taiwan's president, Lee Teng-hui, and a leading contender to succeed him took its nastiest turn yet today as the governing Nationalist Party requested prosecution of the candidate for embezzlement and forgery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTACUZINO, STEFANA
description: CANTACUZINO-Stefana. February 11, 2000, beloved wife of the late Mircea, loving mother of Dan Cantacuzino, M.D., loving motherin-law of Barbara Cantacuzino. description: EISENSTADT-Elaine. Loving wife of Martin. Devoted mother to her daughters Jane and Randi. Adoring grandmother of her grandson Will. Beloved daughter of the late Fannie and Lou Land. Sister of Mark Land. Cherished cousin, niece and friend. All will miss her caring and generous spirit.

title: Bush Left in Want of a Wand As Questioners Look for Help
description: For a few seconds, Gov. George W. Bush sounded less like a presidential candidate than a charity auctioneer.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: Churchgoers; Solidly Republican But Split on Choices
description: The white-collar professionals at a midweek buffet supper at East Cooper Baptist Church, a big congregation in this growing, affluent suburb of Charleston, take their politics seriously.

title: Honoring a Heretic Whom Vatican 'Regrets' Burning
description: In 1992, 359 years after condemning Galileo as a heretic, the Vatican apologized and admitted the astronomer had a point. So far, however, the Roman Catholic Church is holding the line on Giordano Bruno, a rationalist philosopher who was burned at the stake for heresy 400 years ago today.

title: Karsten Solheim, 88, Is Dead; Creator of the Ping Golf Club
description: Karsten Solheim, one of the world's leading innovators in golf club design, died on Wednesday at his home in Phoenix. He was 88.

title: Gang Robs Teenagers on a Queens Train
description: A group of 10 to 20 teenagers, one of them with a gun, boarded a crowded subway car in Queens yesterday afternoon and robbed at least six passengers, the police said last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUER, WILSON, JOY
description: SUER-WILSON-Joy., 39, of Peekskill. Beloved wife of Greg Wilson. Loving daughter of Shirley Parnell, went home to her Lord and Savior on February 15, 2000. Survived by aunt Bev McGann, cousin Rudy McGann, uncle Nev Parnell, grandmother Everil Parnell. Memorial service at Refuge Temple, 2081 7th Ave, NY, Monday at 6PM; visitation from 4 PM-6 PM.

In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to the Harvard Club of New York Foundation-General Scholarship Fund, 27 W. 44th St., NY NY 10036.

title: Brain Surgeon Cited In Bungled '95 Case Faces a New Inquiry
description: The state Health Department has ordered Staten Island University Hospital to ban any treatment of patients by its chief of neurosurgery, after the death of one of his patients. The same doctor was fired five years ago from Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center for operating on the wrong side of a patient's brain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTROWITZ, LINDSEY
description: KANTROWITZ - Lindsey. We mourn the loss of Lindsey, beloved son of Paul and Greta, brother of Eden and dear grandson of Judith Dubins. Temple Sinai of Long Island Paula Winnig, Rabbi Dr. Richard Storm, President

title: In Life's Race, The Hurdles Come Earlier
description: IN this city where aspirations are high and anxiety levels even higher, thousands of parents will be walking around today with sweaty palms, furrowed brows, stomachs tied in knots, heads pounding like hammers on an anvil -- choose your cliche. The point is they will be in a state.

title: Feast of Illuminations and Drawings
description: The Robert Lehman Collection does not have a spectacular profile at the Metropolitan Museum, but it relates (often discreetly) to many of the museum's more conspicuous departments.

title: Biotechnology Rally Continues
description: Shares in gene discovery companies soared for a second consecutive session yesterday, following Wednesday's announcement by Human Genome Sciences Inc. that it had received a patent on a gene involved in the transmission of the virus that causes AIDS. Blocking the gene would provide a new mechanism for attacking AIDS.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: Retirees; Split Loyalties Revive Long-Lost Excitement
description: ''In the beginning I was neutral,'' John F. Carson said of the state's Republican primary. ''But as I've watched and listened, I've even gotten a little excited now. About McCain, I mean.''

title: Nasdaq Surges as Dow Drops After Greenspan Comments
description: Shrugging off the ever-more-likely prospect of additional interest rate increases this spring, technology stocks powered the Nasdaq market to a new record yesterday as turnover surged past two billion shares for the first time.

title: 'I Was Angry at the Time,' Volpe Says
description: Here are excerpts from testimony in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday by Justin A. Volpe, who was convicted last year of torturing Abner Louima at a Brooklyn police station in 1997. In this exchange, he is being questioned by Ronald Fischetti, the lawyer for Charles Schwarz, who is accused of trying to cover up the attack.

description: Deitch Projects

A funeral will be held at the Incarnation Church, Madison Avenue at East 35th Street on Tuesday, February 22 at 5:30PM. Miss Russell's courage, elegance and wit will be greatly missed by her friends.

title: EATING OUT
description: By the Glass

title: Public Interests; Who Wants to Be a Voter?
description: Station WTAT-TV scored a big coup on the evening news this week when its resident psychic announced the winner of the upcoming presidential primary. Somewhere between a story about a fire and a report on child molestation, Lou Wright (''Elvis's personal psychic'') took viewer calls and delivered predictions about financial windfalls and the imminent arrival of curly-haired suitors before raising her thumbs and revealing that ''it's McCain.''

title: Chechens Tell of Torture in Russian Camp
description: Three men seized by Russian troops and imprisoned at a detention camp in northern Chechnya this winter have told human rights observers of beatings, torture and rapes they say took place there before they bribed their way to freedom this month.

title: STRAIGHT TO VIDEO
description: Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a theater release, appeared on television or been on videocassette in earlier editions.

title: Vox Populi
description: Conversations with voters across South Carolina reveal that the Republican primary tomorrow is a close, divisive contest and that the outcome will hinge on the turnout. But it is hard to judge exactly who will vote.

title: BRITISH INTERNET BANK
description: The British bank and mortgage lender, Abbey National P.L.C., said it planned to spend $:300 million over the next three years developing an electronic bank on the Internet called Cahoots. The electronic banks services will also be accessible by telephone and digital TV. Andrew Ross Sorkin

description: STERNHEIMER-Rudolph Max. Suddenly on February 16, 2000 at age 73. Retired Senior Physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory where he worked for over 40 years. Beloved husband of Betty Sternheimer. Dear brother of Paul Sternheimer and his wife Hanne and Michael Sternheimer and his wife Karine. Devoted uncle of John, Philip, William and Jennifer Sternheimer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Saturday, Sunday and Monday 2-5 PM with services Tuesday 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: I.N.S. Official Held On Spying Charges
description: A supervisor in the Miami office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service was arrested today and charged with spying for the Cuban government.

title: Tiny Historical Society in Huge Power Struggle
description: It has been the kind of civil trial normally associated with huge corporations: five weeks of mind-numbing testimony on bylaws and parliamentary procedure, reams of meeting minutes and financial statements, and long discourses on dates of record and proxy votes.

title: Edwin Singer, 85, a Philanthropist in Texas
description: Edwin Singer, a Texas businessman, rancher and philanthropist, died on Saturday at a hospital in Houston. He was 85 and lived in Corpus Christi.

title: Shock of Kosovo Violence May Prove Incentive for Peace
description: The explosion of violence in and around this northern town during the past two weeks, which left 11 dead and dozens wounded, may not prove so much a disaster for Kosovo as an event that shocks and galvanizes society, leaders here are saying.
