description: A month into this campaign-compressed legislative year, it is still hard to tell which Republican-controlled Congress will prevail.

title: Twilight Of Turboprops?; Passengers Go Out of Their Way To Catch Jets
description: Like many other airline passengers, Michael Gallagher has gone out of his way to avoid flying a turboprop plane. When he attended an Orbital Sciences shareholder meeting a few years ago in Washington, for example, he changed his schedule at the last minute to fly on a jet.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Czech Bank Loses Chief Amid Inquiry Into Fraud
description: The chairman of the Czech Republic's Komercni Banka has resigned during an investigation into a suspected fraud at the ailing state-controlled bank, which is the largest in Central Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARLEY, THOMAS M.
description: FARLEY-Thomas M.. of Hampton Bays on February 17, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Catherine. Loving father of Thomas M. & Stephen. Cherished brother of Beryl Graham and grandfather of seven. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 7-9 pm at the R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 94 East Montauk Hwy, Hampton Bays. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday at 9am from St. Rosalies Church, Hampton Bays followed by an interment at Calvary Cemetery.

title: LENNAR AGREES TO BUY U.S. HOME FOR $476 MILLION
description: The Lennar Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the U.S. Home Corporation for $476 million in cash and stock to create the nation's largest homebuilder. Lennar said it would pay U.S. Home shareholders $36 a share, half in cash and half in stock. Lennar, which is based in Miami, expects to benefit from U.S. Home's position in the fast-growing markets for retirement and active-adult housing. The shares of Lennar rose 93.75 cents, to $16.9375, and those of U.S. Home, which is based in Houston, rose $10, to $34.875.

title: Corrections
description: A credit on Wednesday misattributed a picture of a rally outside the site of the Republican presidential debate in Columbia, S.C. The picture was by The Associated Press.

title: Minimal Research Prepared On AOL-Time Warner Deal
description: Wall Street analysts spend a lot of time talking about how companies in industries from retailing to telecommunications had better prepare for the changes the Internet will bring in the next few years.

description: BERGSTEIN - Frances. Loving wife of the late Dr. David Bergstein. Devoted mother of Carol and Arthur H. Wolintz, and Elaine and Jonathan Z. Smith. Proud grandmother of Robyn and Paul, Ellen, Siobhan and Deon and Jason. Cherished sister of Rosalind and Ted Vidair. Services Fri. 10am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1901 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, N.Y.

description: Charlie Gordon is a tough role for any actor. Oscar voters recognized that and gave Cliff Robertson the best actor award for the 1968 film ''Charly.'' (Spelling consistency has never been the entertainment industry's strong suit.)

description: White & Case, the international law firm based in New York City, has chosen Duane D. Wall to be its new managing partner, or chief executive. He will succeed James B. Hurlock on April 1.

description: EISENSTADT-Elaine. We lost a good friend. We wish you sunny days and good golf in heaven. Joan Reider and Frances Anchin

description: BASEBALL

title: Committee Calls for Suspension of Military's Anthrax Shots
description: A House subcommittee released a scalding critique today of the Pentagon's effort to vaccinate American troops against the biological agent anthrax, and said the program should be suspended.

title: NEW YORK LIFE WINS APPROVAL TO OPEN SAVINGS BANK
description: The New York Life Insurance Company, a leading life insurer, won approval from federal regulators to open a savings bank. The New York insurer's bank, called the New York Life Trust Company, will offer individual retirement accounts, life insurance trusts and personal trust accounts to individuals, according to the Office of Thrift Supervision. New York Life, a mutual insurer owned by its policyholders, already offers trust services to financial institutions.

title: Transition in the Chief Executive Post at Coca-Cola Comes Early
description: Douglas N. Daft became chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company yesterday as M. Douglas Ivester moved up his retirement date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, PERCY
description: SIMMONS-Percy. Age 93, passed away peacefully in Indianapolis, Indiana on February 15, 2000. Born in London, England, he resided in Indianapolis for 60 years. He was the former French Consul in Indianapolis, a patron of the arts, founder of the Indianapolis Chevalier du Tastevin Society, a man of myriad accomplishments. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Hinda, his children Nina and Don Frenkel, Rica and Harvey Spivack; four grandchildren, David Spivack, Ellen Schifman, Tamar Hauptman, and Ruth Frenkel. Also seven great grandchildren. His loss is greatly felt by family and friends.

title: Hayes Leads At Riviera, But Woods Is Lurking
description: Rain-softened fairways at Riviera Country Club gave players the chance to lift, clean and place their balls today. The only question was why Tiger Woods, the world's hottest golfer, did not shoot lower than three-under-par 68 during the first round of the Nissan Open on a course that surrendered birdies to anyone with enough patience to wipe the mud from their irons.

title: Auditing Firm Plans to Split Its Businesses
description: The world's largest accounting firm, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which audits and advises many of the world's biggest corporations, announced yesterday that it planned to separate its auditing and consulting businesses into at least two, and possibly more, free-standing organizations.

title: As Rangers Struggle, Messier Looms Large
description: The Rangers find themselves stuck at another crossroads to the playoffs. For all the roster tinkering, they have regressed to a one-line team. The confidence and momentum built from 21 magical days in January have become a distant memory.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARCUS, ANNE MARISSE FREED
description: MARCUS-Anne Marisse Freed. The beauty of your voice and the goodness of your heart are with me each and every day. Jerry Marcu

title: German Stock-Sale Plan Is Delayed a Year
description: A tax proposal aimed at dismantling the cross-shareholdings of corporate Germany will take effect a year later than originally planned, the government said today, a move that sent down stock prices of German banks and insurance companies.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Putting the Muscle Back on a Rare Car's Bones
description: ANYONE who has tried to restore an old car can talk at length about the frustrations -- a months-long search for a small strip of original chrome, a replacement convertible top that didn't quite fit. The stakes are higher if the car isn't just old, but is one of a kind. That is especially true if one is dealing with a muscle car that doesn't just have to look aggressive, but also needs the guts to back up its macho image.

title: Sports of The Times; Hoop Dreams And Reality, The Collision
description: DURING a 1979 recruiting visit to Albany, Keith Glass, a former assistant basketball coach at U.C.L.A., was asked a favor by Sam Perkins's guardian: Would Glass drive the blue-chip prep star across town, to his home, in a vicious snowstorm?

title: Technology Investors Tune Out Greenspan
description: When Alan Greenspan speaks, the Old Economy trembles. But the new one thinks it is impervious to higher interest rates, and shrugs off warnings from the Federal Reserve chairman.

title: Giuliani Says He'd Welcome Lazio Challenge in Primary
description: In comments that appeared to call the bluff of Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would welcome Mr. Lazio as a competitor in a Republican primary for United States Senate.

title: Special Elections Set For 2 Senate Vacancies
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday ordered special elections to fill two empty Senate seats, in Queens and in Buffalo, after being criticized by Democratic lawmakers who said he had delayed the elections to help Republicans.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAHN, EMILY
description: HAHN-Emily. You are with me every day and we all miss you so much. Love, Carola

title: Possible New Treatment Found for Serious Liver Disease
description: A possible new approach to treating cirrhosis of the liver, the seventh-leading cause of death in the world, has emerged from studies of telomerase, a recently discovered agent that indefinitely prolongs the life of human cells grown in the laboratory.

title: Expressions So Ancient, Yet Familiar
description: EVERYONE is cordially invited to a reception at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It's a daily, come-as-you-are affair, just a casual little party for friends you haven't met.

title: Intervening Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Cozying Up to Labor, Gore Vows to Shift China Trade Policy
description: In seeking to please organized labor and inspire it to work hard for his election, Vice President Al Gore could become a potent weapon against his own administration.

title: 'Six Abstract Artists at the Millennium'
description: Dorsky Gallery

title: A Substitute Teacher Is Put to the Test
description: Zhang Yimou's ''Not One Less'' enlarges the possibilities of filmmaking even as it grounds itself in one of cinema's oldest, most basic principles: the camera's ability to document reality.

title: Northern Ireland's Path
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTTAHEDEH, MILDRED R.
description: MOTTAHEDEH-Mildred R.. on February 17, 2000. Distinguished leader in the decorative arts field and Bahai faith and friend of the disadvantaged peoples of the Third World. Beloved wife of the late Rafi Mottahedeh. Survived by her children Dr. Roy P. Mottahedeh of Brookline, MA and Peri Yusef of London, England. Loving grandmother of Melissa Halpern, Alexander Halpern, Stephanie Halpern, Rafi Mottahedeh and Rostam Mottahedeh and great grandmother of Jamie Waldman and Benjamin Halpern. Services will be held at Frank. E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, Febraury 20 at 11:30am. Contributions in her memory may be made to Mottahedeh Development Services Inc., 2370 Wesley Chapel Road, Decatur, GA 30035 for the Mildred R. Mottahedeh Memorial Fund for Scholarships to Children of the Third World.

title: Fears Encircle War Games on India-Pakistan Border
description: More than 100 Indian tanks are churning up billowing clouds of sand as they rumble across the Rajasthani desert this week in war games about 60 miles from India's border with its longtime foe Pakistan.

title: Iran Election Today a Referendum on Reform
description: At the age of 19, Abdi Manoumshah found himself at the epicenter of revolution. An Iranian Army officer, he was on guard duty outside the United States Embassy in the fall of 1979 when student firebrands seized what they called the ''nest of spies'' and took American diplomats hostage. Loyal to the new Islamic Republic, he stepped aside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSMAN, SAM
description: OSMAN-Sam. Passed away February 15, 2000. Founder and owner of New York's legendary store, Job Lot/Pushcart. Beloved husband of Eve. Adored and cherished by his loving extended family: Robbie, Donny, Janna and Daniel Osman; Peter, Joan, Vicki, Rachel and Andrew Bergang; Mimi, Nancy and Marc Hirschmann. He was a man of dignity and integrity and will be deeply missed.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- New York City, Seattle.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column yesterday, about reducing the nation's debt, misstated the number of times the Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates since June. It is four, not three.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGHERTY, ELIZABETH
description: DOUGHERTY-Elizabeth. On February 16, 2000 at age 69. Beloved sister of John J. Dougherty and his wife Christina, Mary Jane Hansen and Genieve Dougherty and many nieces and nephews. Memorial mass at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 135 West 31 St., Saturday February 19th at 11AM.

title: Sam Taylor-Wood
description: Matthew Marks

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A Story Twice Told

title: Details Count In Blue Room Renovation
description: This year is the 200th anniversary of Abigail and John Adams's move into the White House. As its first residents, they had very little furniture, and Mrs. Adams complained about the spartan surroundings. The current White House curator, Betty C. Monkman, said that at the top of her wish list for future acquisitions would be ''something -- anything -- associated with the Adams family, be it silver, furniture or a portrait of Mrs. Adams.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EFFMAN, KARLIN, TESSIE
description: EFFMAN - KARLIN - Tessie. Be loved wife of the late Hyman Effman and Reuben Karlin. Loving companion of Sandor Herskovitz. Beloved mother of Norman and Paul. Dear sister of Rose Benjamin Rubin and the late Ethel Ochs and Sadie Haimowitz. Adored grandmother of Jason, Hutch, Lucy and Jesse. Cherished great grandmother of Zachary. Services today 10am at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI.

title: Beholding Bald Eagles
description: Sullivan County has become a winter haven for a new vacationer, the bald eagle. The bald belt covers the Upper Delaware Valley, where 175 bald eagles spend the season. Although they are America's national symbol, most of the birds fly from Canada to a snowy preserve where they are a winter attraction.

title: Sephora Shifts An Account
description: The New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, is losing an assignment gained last summer -- to create a campaign to introduce the beauty retailer Sephora to American consumers -- as the scope is narrowed and shifted to a small shop.

title: Ex-Officer Details Surge of Rage As He Began Attack on Louima
description: The former police officer sentenced to 30 years in prison for torturing Abner Louima in the bathroom of a Brooklyn station house took the witness stand yesterday and described in detail a simmering rage that led to the attack and an anguish that eventually caused him to come forward and confess.

title: Bill Clinton's Asian Itinerary
description: Since 1978 no American president has visited South Asia, a region with one-sixth of the world's population. For that reason alone, President Clinton's planned trip to India and Bangladesh next month is long overdue. Conspicuous by its absence on the presidential schedule, however, is Pakistan, where a military coup last October has aggravated tensions with India. Pakistan is now warning that a snub by Mr. Clinton could worsen tensions even further. But the president is right not to stop in Pakistan unless it makes tangible progress in returning to civilian rule, cracking down on terrorist groups and working with India to curb their dangerous nuclear arms race.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.

title: PHILIPS PROFIT
description: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's largest consumer-electronics maker, returned to a profit in the fourth quarter, beating expectations, as it sold more mobile phones and semiconductors. Fourth-quarter profit from operations was 687 million euros ($682 million), or 2.04 euros a share, in contrast to a loss of 308 million euros, or 0.86 euro a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter sales rose 4 percent, led by a 22 percent surge in semiconductors and 7 percent growth in sales at the mobile phone unit.

title: Mall Developer Sells Naming Rights
description: Those dismayed at the proliferation of commercial names for sports stadiums will soon have another reason to complain: In what is being described as a first, a shopping center in Georgia to be opened in fall 2001 has sold naming rights.

title: Craggy Faces and Rugged Mountains, Scaled by the Pen
description: If life, as Forrest Gump said, is like a box of chocolates, we might consider the Morgan Library's exhibition of Northern European master drawings a box of truffles. The 109 sheets in ''From Bruegel to Rubens: Netherlandish and Flemish Drawings'' -- all but three of which are from the library's collection -- are dependably high in quality and consistently delectable. And unlike edible morsels, they pose no threat to the viewer's blood-sugar level.

title: Respect New Borders
description: To the Editor:

title: Respite for Bank of New York, Then Back in Thicket
description: Only a week ago, the Bank of New York enjoyed a brief respite from the money laundering investigation that has engulfed it for the last 18 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILENKER, MORTIMER D.
description: BILENKER-Mortimer D.. Of Elizabeth, NJ February 16, 2000 in Boynton Beach, FL. Loving husband of the late Hinda F. Bilenker to whom he was married 59 years. Adored father of Dr. Robert (Barbara) Bilenker, Judith (Maynard) Rabinowitz, Ellen (Dr. Martin) Lebofsky and Dr. Arthur (Teri) Bilenker. Cherished grandfather of Ted, Alan, Joshua and Stephanie, Jennifer, Eric, Janine, Daniel and Carrie. Beloved brother of Eugene, Audry and the late Norman. Services today February 18, 2000 9:30am at the Jewish Educational Center, 330 Elmora Ave. Elizabeth, NJ. Memorial contributions to: Ruth Rales Jewish Family Services, 21300 Ruth & Baron Coleman Blvd. Boca Raton, FL 33428-1757. For further information, Gutterman-Warheit 1-800-992-9262.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE POLLS

title: FAMILY FARE
description: An Actor Makes a Splash

title: Cell Phone Frolics And Dear, Ditsy Dad
description: It's clear that Eve Marks (Meg Ryan), a harried professional party planner, has reached the end of her rope when she arrives home one day to find a big shaggy dog munching on the telephone and doesn't have an instant conniption. Eve, who practically lives on the phone, hastily retrieves the instrument, then thinks twice and tosses it back to the insatiable pooch, who resumes his meal while she dashes around her fancy Los Angeles house ripping every phone and fax connection out of the wall.

title: INDONESIAN STOCK SLUMP
description: Indonesia's stock market slumped, as a government plan to increase excise taxes and more concerns about the stability of President Abdurrahman Wahid's, left, government led to across-the-board selling. The Jakarta Stock Exchange ended down 21.728 points, or 3.5 percent, at 600.174. The market is down 5.3 percent since Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ELIAS W.
description: GORDON-Elias W.. Entered into rest February 16, 2000, Elias W. Gordon, of Tucson, AZ and Maui, HI, formerly of Lowell, MA, a graduate of Lawrence Academy and the Univerity of New Hampshire, aged 64 years. Founder and President of Furnistall, Inc. Well-known patron of the arts. Beloved brother of Helene G. Cohen and Carolyn G. Siegel; uncle of Lisa Deutsch, Russell K. Siegel, and Matt G. Siegel; great-uncle of Nicole, Robyn, Alyson, Emma, and Brett. Services at the Morse-Bayliss Funeral Home, 122 Princeton Blvd., Lowell, MA, Sunday at 11 AM. Friends invited. Interment in Montefiore Synagogue Cemetery, Pelham, NH. There will be no memorial observance. Friends who wish may make memorial contributions in his name to American Lung Association, ARDS Research, PO Box 265, Burlington, MA 01803. Funeral Director, Walter F. Bayliss, Jr.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Early Test In Florida For Derby Hopefuls
description: It is still nearly three months and many adventures away, but the Kentucky Derby cast its spell across the country's leading 3-year-old horses today when 11 of the promising candidates were entered in the $200,000 Fountain of Youth Stakes, the first Grade I race for Derby hopefuls in the East.

title: Marbury Eludes Questions As Deftly as Opponents
description: Stephon Marbury said the Philadelphia 76ers had improved themselves on Wednesday in the three-team trade that brought them Toni Kukoc from the Chicago Bulls. The Nets' point guard was asked about his own team standing pat.

title: BRAZILIAN POWER PURCHASE
description: A consortium formed by Iberdrola, Spain's second-largest utility, and Banco do Brasil, agreed to pay $1 billion for Companhia Energetica de Pernambuco, a state-controlled electric company in Brazil's northeast. With the deal, the Iberdrola group expands its holdings in the relatively underdeveloped region, where demand for electricity is growing faster than in other parts of Brazil. Simon Romero

title: I Take This Man, for Richer Only
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: Blacks; Democratic Help? Not in This Town
description: Republicans sometimes seem to be everywhere in South Carolina. But not in this small city an hour's ride south of Columbia. It remains a Democratic stronghold, particularly a stronghold of black Democrats, the backbone of the party in this state.

title: Producer Price Index Is Flat As Cost of Cigarettes Drops
description: Prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers were unchanged in January as the cost of cigarettes unexpectedly fell, the government reported today. Other prices were tame, a sign inflation is being kept in check.

title: New Jersey Police Unveil Plan to Monitor Troopers
description: Racial profiling complaints against the New Jersey State Police tripled in 1999, as publicity about the shooting of three unarmed minority men on the New Jersey Turnpike made the pattern of discrimination a bitter political issue.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FEDEX CORP., Memphis, the largest overnight-delivery company, said it would buy a shipping unit, Tower Group International, Buffalo, from McGraw-Hill Cos., New York, publisher of Business Week magazine and textbooks, for an undisclosed price and create a new division, FedEx Trade Networks Inc., to help businesses with international shipping.

title: Sell Enough Dicey Stocks to Hinterland Rubes, and You Can Buy Ferraris
description: About a third of the way into ''Boiler Room,'' Seth Davis (Giovanni Ribisi), a young stockbroker-in-training at a fly-by-night company called J. T. Marlin, drops by a co-worker's house for an evening of pizza and beer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, JANE G.
description: POLLACK-Jane G.. On February 16, 2000. Cherished daughter of Ann and the late Harry. Loving sister of Marilyn Braunstein and Steven Pollack. Dear aunt of Dean and Rachel Braunstein. Devoted student, teacher and friend. Services Friday, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, CORA
description: FINE-Cora. On February 17, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Daniel and Eugene. Loving sister of Edna. Grandmother of Rebecca, Jocelyn, Benjamin and Jonathan, and great grandmother of Marco. Service Friday, 12 Noon at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: From Classic and Modern To Acrobatics With Props
description: If you are turned on by lively dancers who slow down to do headstands and attach themselves to a revolving wheel, then the Brazilian choreographer Deborah Colker and her company from Rio de Janeiro are for you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISSELBACHER, ALFRED
description: ISSELBACHER-Alfred. February 15, 2000. Age 73. Beloved husband of Carmen. Loving and devoted father of Audrey and her husband David Liebman. Cherished grandfather of Josh and Katie. Devoted brother of the late Hilda Berney and the late Henry Isselbacher. Loving uncle of Jesse, Tina and Gail. He was a noted art dealer in both the United States and abroad and was the Director of the Isselbacher Art Gallery in New York City since 1965. He was born in Isselbach, Germany and later came to the U.S. in 1938, where he served in the Coast Guard during World War II. He shared his enthusiasm and passion for art with the public and in so doing enriched many lives. Service Friday, February 18, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Schwarz Sues Chief for Move To Toys 'R' Us
description: In what amounts to a grown-up toy war, F.A.O. Schwarz is suing John Eyler, its former chairman and chief executive, for jumping to the rival Toys ''R'' Us last month. The complaint says Mr. Eyler violated the terms of his employment contract, which required him to provide a year's notice before any departure and barred him from working for a competitor for two years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an effort by Norway's foreign minister to start talks between the government and rebels in Sri Lanka referred incorrectly at one point to Sri Lanka's president. As noted elsewhere in the article, Chandrika Kumaratunga is a woman.

title: Time Inc. decides a magazine about simplifying life might strike a chord among harried readers.
description: IN a frenetic era when most women feel more pressed than ever, how can a publisher persuade them to squeeze another magazine into their busy lives? With some help from a longtime agency executive, Time Inc. believes it's really simple -- er, make that Real Simple.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIDALA, ARTHUR
description: AIDALA-Arthur. Beloved husband of the late Marietta (nee DeLuca). Loving father of Louis R. Aidala and Lorraine Ambrosio. Adored grandfather of Arthur L. Aidala, Lori Aidala Bambina, Joseph Ambrosio, Anthony Ambrosio and the late Louis Ambrosio. Reposing at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC, Wednesday 7-9:30, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9:30 and Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10AM at Saint Joseph's Church. Interment in Moravian Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLISLE, CAMILLA
description: CARLISLE-Camilla. 77, of Ridgewood, NJ died February 16, 2000. Survived by her daughter Nancy and sons John and Peter and two grandchildren. A funeral service will be held March 4, 2000 at 11 AM at St. Elizabeth's Church, Ridgewood, NJ.

title: STRONG PROFIT AT MANNESMANN
description: Illustrating why it was the object of the world's largest hostile takeover effort, Mannesmann of Germany reported a surge in profit and sales in what will probably be its last annual report as an independent company. The German engineering and telecommunications company, which capitulated to an unsolicited $180 billion acquisition effort by Vodafone Airtouch of Britain on Feb. 3, said revenue climbed 22 percent, to 23.2 billion euros, or $22.9 billion, while earnings before taxes, depreciation and interest rose 37 percent to 4.3 billion euros, or about $4.2 billion. The growth came almost entirely from Mannesmann's wireless telephone businesses. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Matthew Higgs 'Look Now, Pay Later'
description: Murray Guy

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Feb. 5 about the threat of nuclear conflict since the end of the cold war misstated the size of the Russian and American nuclear arsenals. Russia has about 6,000 long-range nuclear weapons and the United States has about 7,000; they do not have 2,000 to 2,500 each. (The smaller figure is the number each country has on alert and ready to launch.)

title: Judge in Diallo Case Allows Jury to Consider Lesser Charges for Officers
description: The state judge presiding over the trial of the four police officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo said today that he would accept a request by prosecutors and defense lawyers to add lesser charges to the two counts of second-degree murder each officer faces.

title: GREENSPAN WARNS OF ANOTHER RISE IN INTEREST RATES
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the powerhouse economy shows few signs of slowing despite four interest rate increases over the last eight months, and he warned in unusually direct terms that the central bank would probably raise rates further to avert a buildup of inflation.

title: Bavarian Glimpses Vacancy at German Center Stage
description: The ambitions of Edmund Stoiber, the conservative premier of Bavaria, to lead Germany have never been much of a secret. But with the Christian Democratic Union in turmoil, he has abruptly emerged as a formidable national force.

title: BAAN EQUITY SHORTFALL
description: Baan, a Dutch business-management software maker, must raise enough equity to cover its liabilities by mid-March or be dropped from the Netherlands' benchmark AEX index, Amsterdam regulators said. Baan shares fell as much as 1.33 euros, or 19 percent, to 5.65 euros, the lowest price since 1995. Baan, which has suffered from slumping sales and accounting irregularities, had $9 million in equity and $197 million in cash on Dec. 31.

title: A Magical City of Bridges, Festivals and the Harvest Moon
description: Not the world's most enchanting city, Tokyo has never looked so good as in ''100 Famous Views of Edo,'' a series of color woodblock prints made in the mid-19th century by the Japanese master Utagawa Hiroshige (1797-1858). The series (there are actually 120) was begun in 1856 by the artist and ended with his death. It includes a few post-mortem prints by his disciple Shigenobu.

title: Chancellor Revises Policy Of Job Reviews in Transfers
description: Taking his first stab at the myriad regulations that protect New York City teachers, interim Chancellor Harold O. Levy yesterday ended a decades-old policy that allowed teachers to leave poor job reviews behind when they transferred schools.

title: Marcel Duchamp/Man Ray
description: Sean Kelly

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. *denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: A Texas-Style Bashing: Double-Teaming 'Dubya'
description: SHRUB

title: How to Help Colombia
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Says Web Cookies Allow Illegal Stalking
description: February 18, 2000

title: Bank Inquiry's Trail Leads to Top Levels Of Power in Russia
description: In a city where banks sprout like mushrooms, and die just as fast, the money-moving network described in the unfolding Bank of New York case quickly branches into a web of control and ownership. Some strands reach to the highest levels of Russian finance and government.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: As Commerce Chairman, McCain Is Hard to Define
description: In their spirited primary battle, George W. Bush uses the sobriquet ''the Chairman'' to tar John McCain as a Washington insider.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, ROBERT E.
description: GOODMAN-Robert E.. Age 72. Television Director, Songwriter, died at his home in Manhattan on January 31, 2000, from the after effects of a stroke. He is survived by a niece, Betty Jane Goodman, of Munster, Indiana, and his friend of 50 years, Ron Peters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUELLER, CARL ROBERT
description: MUELLER-Carl Robert. Of Basking Ridge, NJ and Dyken Pond, NY on Wednesday, February 16, 2000. Husband of ten years to Merideth Susan Krug Mueller, son of Kreszentia Bigelmaier Mueller of Yeadon, PA and the late Carl Mueller, Sr. Also survived by aunts and uncles, both in the U.S. and Germany. Memorial service at the Liberty Corner Presbyterian Church, Liberty Corner, NJ on Saturday, February 26, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts may be made to the Liberty Corner Presbyterian Church, 45 Church St, Liberty Corner, NJ 07938 or Fellowship of Christian Athletes, 500 Route 35, Red Bank, NJ 07701. Layton Funeral Home, 475 Main St. Bedminster, New Jersey.

title: H. C.Westermann 'Death Ship'
description: Lennon, Weinberg

title: Wes Mills 'Missoula Drawings'
description: Joseph Helman Gallery

title: Confused Markets: Tobacco Stocks Crumble, Bonds Don't
description: THE stock market is worried that Philip Morris -- under attack from all sides -- is going to die. The bond market is quite unconcerned. Somebody is wrong.

title: ISRAELI DIAMOND DEAL
description: Angola gave an Israeli merchant exclusive rights to sell its rough diamonds, Israel's Trade and Industry Ministry announced. The ministry said the exclusive marketing deal was aimed at making it more difficult for Angolan rebels to market diamonds illegitimately, an important source of income for them. The diamonds will be imported by Lev Leviev, who runs a joint-venture company, Ascorp, with the Angolan government, the ministry said. Israel imported $3.9 billion in rough diamonds in 1999. William A. Orme Jr.

title: I Take This Man, for Richer Only
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, DAN
description: GREENBERG-Dan. We mourn the passing of our friend and business associate, a man of high standards and high integrity who we held in high esteem. He leaves a wonderful legacy of good family values. The Mack Family

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 28 about the success of mass-market retailers in developing their own brands misstated the owner of White Cloud toilet tissue. It is Paper Partners L.L.C., not Procter & Gamble.

title: I Take This Man, for Richer Only
description: To the Editor:

title: Trailblazing Craft Exposes an Asteroid
description: The asteroid Eros, now under the constant gaze of a satellite from Earth, appears to be both composed of dense material and battered by many ancient collisions, scientists reported today.

title: Dark and Dismal Doings on a Planet With Three Suns
description: With his elephantine glare and trapezius muscles that could support a Mack truck, Vin Diesel, who appears in two films opening today, is definitely the flavor of the movie weekend. In ''The Boiler Room'' he is a hulking illegal stock trader who would be right at home in the world of ''The Sopranos.'' And in the snazzily atmospheric sci-fi horror film ''Pitch Black'' he is Riddick, a fiendishly grinning murderer with a nose for menstrual blood. In the movie's opening scenes, in which Riddick tears off his manacles, he suggests a bone-crushing hybrid of Hannibal Lecter, Harry Houdini and Hulk Hogan stomping out of a leather fetishist's private dungeon.

title: This, Alaskans Find, Is the Year of the Avalanche
description: One moment all was quiet, and the Chugach Range stood out in the snowcapped splendor of a timeless winter scene. The next, recalled Keith Burton, a track-repair man for the Alaska Railroad, ''it was like a huge billowy cloud just jumped right off the mountains and started rolling straight down toward us.''

title: John Rocker's Team
description: To the Editor:

title: Choices for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Approves Costly Meningitis Shots
description: The first vaccine to prevent a leading cause of meningitis in infants and toddlers was approved today by the Food and Drug Administration, one day after a panel of scientific experts recommended against giving it to all children under the age of 5 in part because of its high cost.

title: Rutgers Is Committed to Plan To Award Donors Best Seats
description: The Rutgers athletic director insists that a new points system that will award the best seats at football and men's basketball games to the most generous donors is a matter of planning for success.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a citywide antidrug crackdown that has swamped the court system misstated the given name of the judge who handled the most arraignments on Sunday night. He is Neil E. Ross, not Harold Ross.

title: 'Street Agent' Part of Inquiry Into St. John's
description: An investigator from the National Collegiate Athletic Association wants to talk about the St. John's basketball team with a New York City basketball enthusiast who was implicated in a recruiting scandal at Syracuse a decade ago that resulted in a two-year probation for the university's men's basketball team.

title: Patrick Tosani 'Masks'
description: Zabriskie Gallery

title: TV's Millionaire Groom Has a Past in Entertainment
description: Days after marrying, on national television, a woman he had never met before, Rick Rockwell, identified on the show as a multimillionaire real estate developer, yesterday became the talk of his hometown, San Diego.

title: Sam Osman, 88, Founder of Job Lot Trading
description: Sam Osman, who emerged from the throng of pushcart peddlers on the Lower East Side of Manhattan to become the founder of Job Lot Trading, a legendary emporium with a staggeringly unpredictable mix of ultracheap merchandise, died Tuesday at a Manhattan hospital, his son Robby said. He was 88.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen dropped to a five-month low against the dollar after Moody's Investors Service said it might lower Japan's credit rating. The yen fell to 110.59 to the dollar from 109.39 on Wednesday.

title: Foreign Affairs; My Kinda Town
description: Boy, I feel better now. The leading Internet execs met with the president at the White House Tuesday and they all agreed that despite the recent hacker attacks that disrupted major Web sites, there was no need for any government regulation or taxation of cyberspace. When George W. Bush and John McCain were asked about this they both said: Hands off the Net -- we've got to nurture this new baby.

title: Can-Do African Boy Wins and Evil Sorceress Loses
description: ''Mother, bring me into the world,'' demands Kirikou, the infant protagonist of the animated fable ''Kirikou and the Sorceress.'' Like its tiny hero, ''Kirikou'' proceeds at its own pace, and that pace is a more willful and slower piece of storytelling than children are accustomed to getting from American animated films, in which emotional crises are worked out like story problems (if Buzz and Woody need to get to point A . . .). The director Michel Ocelot's belief in his film is as winning as his title character's confidence, even though ''Kirikou'' is probably a story more suitable for younger children than for older ones.

title: Winter Finds Renee Fleming Basking in the Seasoned Glow of Success
description: Right now the soprano Renee Fleming, who is in her vocal and artistic prime, could write her ticket to any concert hall or opera house in the world, with the possible exception of La Scala in Milan. She had a bad experience at that fabled house in 1998 when she sang the title role in a production of Donizetti's ''Lucrezia Borgia'' conducted by Gianluigi Gelmetti: her performance was met with a lusty chorus of boos, whistles and jeers from segments of the audience, a demonstration that Ms. Fleming suspects was organized, though by whom and why she does not know. Moreover, like many other artists, she has found the company's autocratic music director, the conductor Riccardo Muti, exasperating to deal with.

title: D'Amato, Officially for Bush, Praises McCain
description: Former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, one of most influential supporters of Gov. George W. Bush in New York, hailed Senator John McCain yesterday, saying Mr. McCain had the political magnetism of former Presidents Ronald Reagan and John F. Kennedy.

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES SETTLES U.S. ANTITRUST CLAIMS
description: Miller Industries, the world's largest integrated provider of vehicle-towing equipment and services, agreed to settle Justice Department antitrust claims by licensing patents to competitors. A consent decree settling the case was filed yesterday in federal court in Washington along with a Justice Department suit challenging Miller's acquisitions of the Vulcan Equipment Company in 1998 and Chevron Inc. in 1997. The government said the acquisitions reduced competition in the design, manufacture and sale of light-duty tow trucks and car carriers and increased Miller's ownership of valuable patents.

title: Ward, Rugged and Durable, Is Hard to Replace
description: Over the years, Charlie Ward's rugged body has taken the beating of third-class mail with every charge he has absorbed and every loose ball he has tumbled to reach. Always, he has popped right back up.

title: Experts Want to Dissect McCains Internet Fundraising
description: February 18, 2000

title: Entering The Ranks Of Racists
description: ''Pariah,'' which begins a weeklong engagement at the Screening Room tonight, opens with the voice of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. warning that ''racism is a sickness unto death.'' But this new film by Randolph Kret mistakes the study of a particularly virulent set of symptoms for a diagnosis.

title: Sisters Scare Away Man In Assault in a Convent
description: A nun was attacked last night by a man who rang the doorbell of her convent in Queens and asked to use the bathroom, then choked her until other nuns came to her aid, a Police Department spokesman said.

title: As an Industrial Building in Chelsea Goes 'Shabby Chic,' Charges Fly
description: Irving Fox had his first inkling that something was amiss at the Starrett Lehigh Building in Chelsea when the new landlord complained that Mr. Fox's die-cutting, stamping and folding machines made too much noise.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Bar Scene Gets Zagat Treatment

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHMAN, TERRY ROSS
description: LACHMAN-Terry Ross. Friends and family are deeply saddened by the unexpected death of Terry Lachman at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, MD on February 15, 2000. He sustained a cervical fracture in an automobile accident on February 3 and developed complications. Mr. Lachman was originally from Chester, PA, and was 57 years old when he died. He taught physically handicapped children in the New York City public school system for more than 20 years, and retired to Bethesda several years ago. Funeral will be held at Gawler's Funeral Home, 5130 Wisconsin Ave. NW, Washington, DC on Saturday Feb. 19 at 3:00pm.

title: G.E. Achieves Breakthrough In Gas Power-Turbine Design
description: The Energy Department and General Electric will announce on Friday a major breakthrough in natural-gas- powered generating plants that will result in production of electricity using 5.3 percent less fuel than the best current technologies.

title: Struggling to Reconnect What Chaos Rips Apart
description: ''Beautiful People'' ends in a flurry of rapid cuts, with a series of perfectly ordinary moments: a man reads a picture book to a child; a family sets out on vacation. There is a wedding party, a birthday party, and a raucous game of cards around a hospital bed. Jasmin Dizdar's camera hurtles through these scenes like a child in a toy store, grabbing at every detail as though it were a shiny, precious prize. The screen hums with the vital cacophony of daily life, and glows with the thick, bright colors of human emotion -- unspeakable pain, inexplicable loss, and sheer irrational pleasure at being alive.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Small Panel, Great Surprise

title: Christian Democrats Urge Hesse PremierTo Resign in Scandal : Kohl Party Split Over Succession
description: FRANKFURT  Demands grew Thursday for the resignation of a second leader from Germany's Christian Democrats as a battle for succession broke into the open following the departure of Wolfgang Schaeuble, the party chairman.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: Suburbanites; Playing Up Character And Plying Crossovers
description: When Senator John McCain's campaign decided it wanted to hold a rally in a Jewish community in South Carolina, it asked to use the parking lot of the Beth Shalom Synagogue in this suburb of Columbia. There were a only a few grumblings in the congregation, said Rabbi Philip Silverstein -- the campaign had chosen its neighborhood well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIDLOFF, GUSTAV A.
description: LEIDLOFF-Gustav A.. A Vice President of DB Alex. Brown, died suddenly on February 11, 2000 at the age of 76. Gus Leidloff was born in Magdeburg, Germany on February 23, 1924. He, his sister, his late mother, Olga De Mooy, moved to Switzerland just before the outbreak of World War II and came to the United States in 1947. Gus became a United States citizen and served in the United States Army. After several years of teaching in California, he settled in New York where he embarked on a long, successful and satisfying career as an investment advisor. Gus was a co-founder of LandCare Incorporated in Charleston, South Carolina. He was also an avid equestrian. Gus is survived by his sister, Marlis Beets of Brussels, Belgium; his brother, Armin Leidloff of Einbech, Germany; two nieces; three nephews; two godsons; and by several grand nieces and nephews. He leaves behind his companion, Michael A. Ferrazzano of Charleston, South Carolina. He will be sorely missed and remembered with love by his many friends and clients.

title: UCAR WILL KEEP ITS GRAPHITE SPECIALTIES UNIT
description: Ucar International Inc. said yesterday that it would reorganize its graphite specialties business instead of selling it, several months after the company settled lawsuits from a price-fixing conspiracy. Demand for graphite specialties has slowed and Ucar has been unable to get a fair price for the business, the company said. Net sales of the unit, which is based in Clarksburg, W.Va., represent about 9 percent of Ucar's total sales, which were about $947 million in 1998. Ucar said it would take a $26 million fourth-quarter charge, or 57 cents a share, related to the slowdown in the graphite specialties business.

title: Closing In On Vocal Perfection
description: Not since the heyday of Birgit Nilsson and Luciano Pavarotti have critics and audiences held a vocal artist in such esteem as that now enjoyed by the soprano Renee Fleming (right). The opera star brings her love of the art song and commitment to the music of her own time to Alice Tully Hall on Sunday when she performs, with the actress Julie Harris, in the first of two recitals devoted to recent American songs.

title: Sergei Bugaev Afrika 'Mir: Made in the XX Century'
Star-Crossed in Israel, Like a West Bank Story
description: Can Arabs and Jews live in peace?

title: A Flag's History
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: A year after Ruby Foo's Dim Sum and Sushi Palace opened with a bang on the Upper West Side, the silliness has spread south to Times Square. The new Ruby Foo's is huge, with 300 seats. It is loud. It is as corny as a plastic-wrapped fortune cookie. And it is jammed.

title: AIDS Official Sparks Inquiry Over a Grant
description: The inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services was asked today to investigate whether a former government health official who recommended a multimillion-dollar federal research grant involving an experimental AIDS vaccine violated post-employment restriction policies by working for the vaccine's manufacturer, federal health officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLK, HAROLD
description: WOLK-Harold. On February 17, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Fran. Loving father of Michael and Abby, Richard and Judy. Cherished grandfather of Robert, Lisa, Sara and David. Dear brother of Charlotte and Toby. Services Friday 1:15pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Study Finds Abusive Conditions in Mexico's Mental Hospitals
description: Long-term patients at Mexico's mental hospitals live in filthy, abusive and dangerous conditions, and as many as half are epileptic or mentally retarded and do not even belong in a psychiatric institution, according to a study released yesterday by an international human rights group.

title: Talks Fail, but Rivera Waits for Big Award
description: After a last-minute bargaining session failed to reach a long-term deal, Mariano Rivera, the Yankees' closer, went through an arbitration hearing of nearly four hours today. Whether he wins or loses a decision that is expected to come down on Friday, his will be the highest arbitration award in baseball history.

title: Women and the Taliban
description: To the Editor:

title: $6 Billion Champion Paper Sale
description: UPM-Kymmene of Finland, Europe's second-largest paper company, said today that it would buy Champion International for $6.6 billion to enter the North American market for magazine papers.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Nuclear Leak Prompts Criticism Of Con Edison and Regulators
description: In tones ranging from concern to anger, public officials and citizens' groups accused the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and Consolidated Edison today of mishandling events leading up to the radiation leak at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant this week, and then of not notifying the public properly.

title: Power to the Little People
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, WALTER NILS
description: FRANK-Walter Nils., 91. Died Tuesday at Kendal at Hanover, NH. He was born April 22, 1908 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of Louis and Selma (Persson) Frank. He attended Brooklyn schools and entered New York University in 1924. He was married on April 22, 1931 to Ruth Carlson. Mr. Frank had been a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1937 and served as chairman of the Board of Governors from 1965-1967. He was predeceased by his wife in 1998 and by his son, Walter Nils Frank, Jr., in 1995. He is survived by his daughter, Judith Frank Ketterer of Lyme, NH; his sister, Elsa Hintze of Hanover; six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Calling services will be held from 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday at Rand-Wilson Funeral Home at 11-1/2 School Street, Hanover. Funeral services will be held at 1 PM Saturday in the Rand-Wilson Funeral Home. Burial will follow at Pine Knoll Cemetery. Contributions in Mr. Frank's memory may be made to the Cadbury Fund at Kendal, 80 Lyme Road, Kendal at Hanover, Hanover, NH 03755 or to the Children's Hospital at Dartmouth (CHAD), c/o Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, One Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Double Jeopardy

title: A Keen Memory, and Memorable Tattoos
description: TATIANA COOLEY has five tattoos, speaks four languages and this month, for the third consecutive year, became the national memory champion, which means she can do feats like stare at a 50-line poem for 15 minutes, and then replicate about half perfectly on a blank piece of paper, including capital letters, italics and semicolons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTAS, MARIE
description: COSTAS-Marie. Nee Michel. On February 16, 2000. Loving wife of the late Professor Procope Costas. Dear sister of Dite Fordes and George Michel; loving aunt of William and George Fordes, and William Michel. A cherished aunt and great aunt. Reposing at Dahill Funeral Home 2525 65th Street, corner Avenue P, Brooklyn, NY until 9:30am Saturday. Funeral service at Sts. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 64 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn 10:30am. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. Viewing Friday 4-9pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULRYAN, JANICE KALNA
description: MULRYAN-Janice Kalna., on February 16, 2000, of Great Neck, NY. Beloved wife of Rev. John Mulryan. Loving mother of Louis Mulryan. Cherished sister of William Kalna and aunt of Amy and Jonathan Kalna. Mrs. Mulryan was a guidance counselor at Garden City High School. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Friday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious services Saturday, 11 AM, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society or St. Paul's Church.

title: A New Universe in Manhattan
description: Tomorrow is a day to celebrate the completion and opening of the Frederick Phineas and Sandra Priest Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History. The architecture of this new installation is so invigorating, and the imaginative outreach of the science it presents is so all-engulfing, that it reframes our sense of the museum itself. The most eloquent summary of the museum's achievement will be the look on the faces of children -- a vast, continuous tide of children over the years to come -- as they leave the new Hayden Planetarium, stunned by a virtual trek from Earth to the edge of the observable universe, and begin their walk down a spiraling Cosmic Pathway that leads them from the Big Bang to the immediate now.

title: Metro Business; Action on A.T.M. Fees
description: A federal judge yesterday temporarily blocked a New Jersey town's ban on transaction fees at automated teller machines.

title: Where the Sky Is Not the Limit
description: Five years in the making, the Rose Center for Earth and Space -- a $210 million successor to the old Hayden Planetarium -- will open tomorrow, offering visitors a virtual journey through time, space and the mysteries of the cosmos. It promises to be a fantastic voyage, but as with any trip, expect a few rough spots.

title: CITIGROUP AND COMMERCE ONE START WEB SITE
description: Citigroup Inc. said yesterday that it would start a Web site with Commerce One Inc. to allow its corporate customers to trade goods and services online. The new site, run by Citigroup with software provided by Commerce One, will be introduced to 1,800 multinational companies that are global clients of Citigroup. It will link buyers and sellers of goods and services, and will process transactions. Citigroup will also become the main provider of financial services on Commerce One's online marketplace for businesses. Citigroup wants to tap the growing demand for services that will help companies do more business over the Internet. The companies did not disclose the financial terms of the venture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, MAURICE
description: GREENBERG-Maurice. Died February 16th. Graveside services Sunday, 11AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, Koyen Funeral Home, 732-548-2134. Donations to American Heart Assocn.

title: Editorial Observer; America's Rags-to-Riches Myth
description: Americans cling to the conceit that they have unrivaled opportunity to move up and, alas, down the income ladder. This notion, that families that occupy the bottom rungs of the income ladder readily exchange places with those that occupy higher rungs, breeds indifference to the most glaring economic fact of the past quarter-century: widening inequality. The gap in earnings, for example, between college and high school graduates has more than doubled.

title: G.O.P. Primary Has Voters Talking, Regardless of Party Ties
description: No one who has spent much time talking to South Carolina voters the last couple of days would hazard a guess as to the likely winner of Saturday's pivotal Republican primary here.

title: Advocates for Children Joining U.N. Peacekeeping Missions
description: For the first time in the history of its international peacekeeping missions, the United Nations has begun assigning full-time advocates of children to operations centers abroad, the secretary general's special representative for children and armed conflict said today.

title: Excerpts From Greenspan Remarks at Congressional Hearing
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, presented his semiannual report on the economy to the House Banking Committee yesterday. Following are excerpts from his testimony and an exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa and the chairman of the committee, in a question-and-answer session that followed the testimony, as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription agency:

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption in some copies yesterday with an article about the Rangers' 3-0 loss to the Panthers misidentified the New York player knocked to the ice by Florida's Pat Worrell. He was Theo Fleury, not Kim Johnsson.

title: Tests Rebut 'Terrible Scare' In Gene Study
description: Reports that more than two dozen childhood brain cancer patients may have been exposed to the viruses that cause AIDS and hepatitis C during a gene therapy experiment turned out to be ''a terrible scare,'' a Food and Drug Administration official said today.

title: DOW CORNING AND ALLIEDSIGNAL SETTLE PATENT LAWSUIT
description: The Dow Corning Corporation, which makes coatings for computer chips, has agreed to drop its lawsuit accusing its rival AlliedSignal Inc. of infringing three patents. In exchange, AlliedSignal, which is based in Morristown, N.J., agreed not to use the patented inventions in the United States, according to court documents filed this week in federal court in Wilmington, Del. Dow Corning, which is based in Midland, Mich., and is jointly owned by the Dow Chemical Company and Corning Inc., accused AlliedSignal in a 1998 lawsuit of wrongly using Dow technology for resin that provides a protective layer for semiconductors. The settlement followed pretrial negotiations in recent months, according to court documents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANZER, LAWRENCE
description: TANZER-Lawrence. The Board of Trustees of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care & Rehabilitation extends heartfelt sympathies to Trustee Leonard Tanzer and his family on the passing of his beloved father, Lawrence Tanzer. Lenny, may your memories of him comfort you at this difficult time. Our sincerest condolences to you, Lola and the children. David Taub, Chairman of Board Steven J. Frome and Alan J. Saperstein, Interim Co-Presidents

title: Residential Real Estate; Buyers Waiting for Harlem Apartments
description: The steel skeleton rising in central Harlem has already attracted the attention of would-be buyers for the 240 moderately priced cooperative apartments that over the next year will fill much of the space.

title: Devils Show Balance As They Rally to Tie
description: For about seven minutes, starting late in the second period tonight at Continental Arena, the Devils proved they are vulnerable. They allowed four straight goals, but still earned a 5-5 tie against the Colorado Avalanche.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFSCHUTZ, EZEKIEL
description: LIFSCHUTZ-Ezekiel. Beloved husband of Rachel, loving father of Nehama and Marcia, devoted grandfather of Reeva, Bram, Eric and Mark and caring great-grandfather of Hannah, Adam and Leah. Services are Friday, February 18, 10:00 A.M. at Gramercy Chapel, 2nd Ave. & 10th St. in NYC.

title: Gordon's New Role At Daytona: Underdog
description: A Winston Cup Series overall champion at age 24. Two more Winston Cup titles in the next three years. That was the distinctive swath that Jeff Gordon was cutting through Nascar. Then suddenly he blew a tire on his fast track to greatness.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the dominance of Nasdaq's video screen in Times Square misspelled the surname of a prominent sign designer who compared the square to a corporate theme park and misspelled the name of his company. He is George N. Stonbely, not Stonebly; the company is Spectacolor Communications, not Spectracolor.

title: U.P.S. TO OPEN 4 TEST RETAIL STORES IN SUBURBS
description: United Parcel Service Inc., the world's No. 1 package-delivery company, said it would open four test retail stores in suburban areas to attract individual customers shipping from their homes or home-based businesses. United Parcel wants to make services more accessible as the company steps up competition with the United States Postal Service and the FedEx Corporation. United Parcel and other shipping companies also want to handle more of the packages being ordered over the Internet and shipped to homes. The first retail test store will open in the Atlanta suburb of Alpharetta, Ga., next month.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We wanted freedom to think and act as we liked. That is very much what people are asking for now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARY MURRAY
description: BROWN-Mary Murray. Mutual of America, its Board of Directors, together with all of its Officers and Employees, mourn the passing of Mary Murray Brown. Our sincere condolences to Leland Brown, former Chairman of the Board of Mutual of America, and his family. William J. Flynn Chairman of the Board Mutual of America Life Insurance Company Thomas J. Moran President and Chief Executive Officer Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Saudi Arabia said prices would fall as winter fuel demand waned, and the Federal Reserve chairman said high prices would hurt the economy. Crude oil for March delivery fell 59 cents, to $29.46 a barrel.

title: Charlie Chaplin Beats the Israeli Lottery
description: The Little Tramp trumped the Israeli government in court today.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; PROMINENT JOURNALIST MOVES TO WEB
description: In a move that reflects the growing attraction of the Internet in the Mexican media, one of the country's leading independent journalists, Ramon Alberto Garza, will become the chief editor of a new Web portal introduced by Grupo Televisa, S.A., Mexico's largest broadcast conglomerate. Mr. Garza recently resigned as the top editorial official for a Monterrey-based newspaper group that includes the Mexico City daily Reforma. Whereas Reforma and other newspapers owned by the publisher Alejandro Junco have been freely critical of the government, Televisa until recently had a broadcast monopoly and it tends to be pro-government. Dan Fineren

title: Two Are Nominated for Board of Times Company
description: The board of The New York Times Company has nominated an executive and a psychotherapist for election as directors at its annual shareholders meeting on April 27.

title: McCain Drops a Name: Reagan
description: Senator John McCain began running this 30-second television commercial yesterday in South Carolina. It is titled ''Can Win.''

title: Harsh, Incessant Wave Crosses South Carolina
description: ''Winning ugly'' may be taking on new meaning in the closing days of the South Carolina primary campaign, as the airwaves fill with a new round of acrimonious commercials, virtually all directed toward Senator John McCain of Arizona.

title: Online but Not Antisocial
description: The Internet is a member of our family. According to my monthly bill, each of us spent about 5.4 hours a week online, which makes us pretty much average American Net users. I can't speak for the rest of my family, but I relish my online time. A new study tells me that I should feel bad about that. Bourbon, red meat, whole milk and the Internet, too?

title: BAKER HUGHES TO RESTATE EARNINGS BY $31 MILLION
description: Baker Hughes Inc., which provides services to the oil industry, said yesterday that it would restate earnings for several years, reducing past profit by $31 million, because of accounting errors at its Inteq drilling unit. Baker Hughes said it also planned to sell its Baker Process division, which makes water-filtering equipment, and use the proceeds to reduce debt and focus on oil field operations. The business had 1999 sales of $389.8 million. The earnings restatement will cut profit in the years before 1995 by about $24 million, the company said. Baker Hughes, which is based in Houston, created Inteq in 1993.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: Conservatives; Seeking a Candidate With a Firm Stand
description: Doug Bray and Daryl Renshaw are two old friends from nearby Bob Jones University who like a friendly debate. So this morning, as they often do, the two men shared a pot of coffee at the International House of Pancakes and each tried to convince the other of the error of his political thinking.

title: Man Arrested in Slaying Of Woman in Her Home
description: A teenager was accused yesterday of killing an elderly woman who was found bludgeoned to death in her Queens home on Wednesday.

title: Army Breaks Up Beirut Demonstration at U.S. Embassy
description: Popular anger erupted outside the United States Embassy today, a week after Israel retaliated against Lebanon for guerrilla attacks that killed several Israeli soldiers. Hundreds of Lebanese students joined with other protesters in throwing rocks and tomatoes at Lebanese army and police detachments, which responded with batons, tear gas canisters and high-pressure water hoses.

title: Amid Business as Usual, Gallows Humor and Second-Guessing Haunt the Bradley Camp
description: Douglas Berman, the chairman of Bill Bradley's presidential campaign, was strolling into a hotel bar late one recent evening when he spotted three reporters assigned to cover Mr. Bradley. Months ago, there might have been a dozen or more people.

title: From Disneyland to London Dome
description: LONDON  The former Disneyland Paris executive recruited to revive the fortunes of Britain's Millennium Dome promised Thursday to turn the attraction into the "hottest ticket in town" with sharper marketing and management and a dose of Disney-style fun and excitement.

title: Mayor Denies Ordering Building Knocked Down
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has filed court papers denying that he made the call to tear down a Lower East Side apartment building.

title: Where the Eagles Fly: Seeing the National Symbol
description: It's 15 degrees, and we've been staked out for a half-hour in a wooden hut built on the side of Route 43 in Sullivan County in upstate New York. The hut, which overlooks the Mongaup Falls Reservoir, creaks and groans in an icy 20 mile-an-hour wind. From inside, we scan the trees and ice for a sign of our quarry: the bald eagle, America's national symbol.

title: Medals and Risk Show The Luge Is No Joke
description: Despite their deepest wishes, Gordy Sheer and Chris Thorpe know that the two-man luge is the Rodney Dangerfield of winter Olympic sports. Luge, the odd Nordic sliding sport, seems even more peculiar when done by a two-man team, both on their backs, one atop the other, wearing lycra suits and helmets.

title: Tuvalu, Distrusted by China, Worried by Sea, Can Join U.N.
description: Over the objections of China (population 1.2 billion), the Security Council cleared the way today for the Pacific island nation of Tuvalu (population 10,000) to become the 189th member of the United Nations.

title: Holiday on Monday; Washington's Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be legally observed.
description: NEW YORK

title: Witness Says Socialite Worried About Tenant
description: A caretaker for an Upper East Side woman testified yesterday that his employer was worried from the day she rented an apartment to the man now accused, with his mother, of murdering her in a plot to steal her $10 million mansion.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. *denotes a highly recommended show.

title: 2 Mexicans, Worlds Apart, Stir Countrymen's Passion
description: Marco Antonio Barrera comes from a privileged background by Mexican standards. His father is a backdrop designer for television, and Barrera dropped out of law school at the University of Mexico in his hometown of Mexico City to concentrate on his boxing career nine years ago. Growing up, Barrera chose boxing over soccer, to the dismay of his parents.

title: Islanders Gain Tie by Short-Circuiting Flyers' Power Play Seven Times
description: The Philadelphia Flyers may have looked at tonight's game as a perfect way to exorcise their loss to the Devils, but goaltender Kevin Weekes and the Islanders had other ideas.

title: Ji Pengfei, 91; Helped China Open Links to West
description: Ji Pengfei, who took part as China's foreign minister in the Chinese-United States summitry during President Richard M. Nixon's visit to Beijing in 1972, died on Feb. 10 in Beijing. He was 91.

title: Isidore Dollinger, 96, Prosecutor And Congressman From Bronx
description: Isidore Dollinger, a former congressman from the Bronx who was also a state legislator, a district attorney and a judge, died Jan. 30 in a hospital in White Plains, where he had lived for the last several years. He was 96.

title: Flatbush Roots, Manhattan Dreams
description: They look as if they're waiting to be immortalized by Norman Rockwell, these open-faced Brooklyn lads, but it's clear that they've got the itch, and bad. Restless, randy, hungry for action: you've seen their kind before in American musicals, ready to erupt into violent dance and show-stopping anthems of youth.

title: Greenwich Journal; What Can the Matter Be? Britain's Dome Falls Flat
description: It is hard to pinpoint when the Millennium Dome, the Labor government's $1.3 billion celebration of national pride, clearly became a colossal national joke.

title: Article 2000021800000873470 -- No Title
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Chinese Site Suffers Attack
description: Chinese Site Suffers Attack

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Nassau Has Worst Credit Rating in Nation Among Wealthy Suburban Counties
description: The downgrading of Nassau County's bond rating to the level just above junk-bond status leaves it with the worst credit rating of any New York State county and makes it the lowest-rated wealthy suburban county in the nation, analysts said today.

title: Country's Time of Plenty Leaves Some States Behind
description: The nation's record economic expansion has left most states so flush with tax revenues that lawmakers argue over how to spend a surplus.

title: Design Reflects Dance in Optical Collusion
description: DANCE and theatrical design have had a long but sometimes faithless marriage. Their union began with total commitment about six centuries ago when elaborately dressed performers on sumptuous floats entertained guests at Italian court dinners in ballet prototypes called interludes. Little by little, performers were set loose from such contained worlds and left to wander amid sets that eventually moved around them to change scenes with increasing sophistication and complexity. Costumes grew abbreviated, the better to display the moving body.

title: Finding Karma Through Youth; Woodstock's Tibetan Monastery Prepares for a Lama
description: The Buddhists on Overlook Mountain are waiting.

title: A Schlumpy Dentist and His Wise-Guy Neighbor
description: In ''The Whole Nine Yards,'' Matthew Perry can be seen in the kind of role Bruce Willis used to get in the beginning of his film career (in movies like ''Blind Date''): the likable loser who just wants to do what's right. And Mr. Willis has graduated, if that's the word, to playing the kind of grinning tough guy he used to mock on the old ''Moonlighting'' television series.

title: The C.I.A. and Chile: Opening the Files
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, REGINA E.
description: CALLAHAN-Regina E.. On February 16, 2000. Beloved sister of the late Grace Costello and Vincent H. Devoted aunt of Vincent, Elizabeth, Regina Milkowski and Anita Aherne. Survived by 12 grand nieces and nephews and 7 great grand nieces and nephews. Visiting Friday, 2-5 and 7-9P.M. McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 9:30 AM St. Patrick's Church.

title: Bush and McCain Scurry Toward Showdown
description: With only two days to go before a Republican primary that seems too close to call, Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain raced across South Carolina today, with Mr. Bush continuing a relentless attack on his opponent and Mr. McCain making a broad appeal for the votes of Republicans, independents and Democrats alike.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: 'Cider House' A Dark Horse?

title: Gary Lee Boas 'Starstruck'
description: Deitch Projects

title: Watch It, Nellie Forbush, They're Rockin' the Boat
description: Yee-haaa! That's the wind they call America, pardners, that's sweepin' down the plains of the Performing Garage in SoHo, where the cultural vivisection society known as the Wooster Group keeps camp. Remember those classic musicals that seemed to mirror the strapping, restless soul of the United States -- Rodgers and Hammerstein shows like ''Oklahoma!'' and ''South Pacific''?

title: Torre Enjoys a Quiet Start to Camp
description: On the first day of training camp last year, Joe Torre told David Wells that he was being traded for Roger Clemens in a blockbuster deal that shook the Yankee organization. What Torre also knew, but did not tell anyone, was that there had been some troublesome results in initial tests of his prostate, and that doctors had scheduled further examinations.

title: Fearing Hackers, Environmental Agency Halts Access to Web Site
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had taken itself off the Internet, shutting down public access to its databases on environmental hazards and cutting itself off from e-mail, after a lawmaker complained on his own Web site that the agency's computers were sitting ducks for hackers.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Hints That Fed Will Increase Rates More

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZMAN, MAX
description: WEITZMAN-Max. Died on February 15, 2000 of natural causes. He leaves behind three sons and a daughter, four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He was the owner of a delicatessen on Delancey Street for over 55 years. He will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, BEVERLY
description: WEINBERG-Beverly. Died on February 17, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Edwin and Allan. Cherished mother-in-law of Joanne and Lorraine. A loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. We will love you forever.

title: Annie Leibovitz 'Women'
description: Edwynn Houk

title: And Bardot Created Sizzle
description: It has become a flood: Brigitte Bardot videos. By the end of April there will be 10 Bardot films in recent release, an absolute outpouring for a figure who, though she more than made a mark for herself in the 1950's as the liberating ''sex kitten'' of French film, hardly has the retrospective potential of, say, Humphrey Bogart (the subject of an 18-film video reissue next month).

title: Benitez Gets 4-Year Contract, Avoiding Arbitration
description: As he drove across Florida with his agent today, Armando Benitez thought of San Pedro de Macoris, his home in the Dominican Republic, and of all the things he would be able to do there because of what had taken place before dawn.

title: Off Drugs and the Street, and on Track
description: Magdaline Smith squints hard when she remembers walking those dimly lit streets on too many bitter-cold mornings in Queens.

title: Charter School To Raise Topic Of Creationism
description: A publicly financed charter school scheduled to open in Rochester next fall intends to teach students about creationism as a scientifically based theory competing with the theory of evolution.

title: Prestige and Money Riding On America's Cup Outcome
description: The source of all the hubbub rests in a shatterproof-glass case in a still room on the second floor of the Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron. Wide windows offer a picturesque view of the Auckland Harbor Bridge. Each evening, one of the security guards entrusted with its care packs it into a specially made suitcase and tucks it into the club's vault.

title: Jim Lambie 'Blackgloss'
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: 'Sacred' TV Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILEAN DAM HALTED
description: Empresa Nacional de Electricidad S.A., Chile's No. 1 power generator, said it would halt construction of a $520 million hydroelectric plant, temporarily shelving plans for the country's biggest dam ever. Endesa, as the company is known, plans to stop work on March 1 on the 570-megawatt Ralco hydroelectric dam in southern Chile. Endesa's board told Chilean regulators that the company lacked the concessions needed to move ahead with construction and did not have the necessary transmission lines.

title: Searcy Gets 5-Year Extension
description: Jaguars offensive tackle Leon Searcy has agreed to a five-year contract extension reportedly worth $50 million.

title: Nets Put Heat On the Ropes, Then Hold On
description: Kendall Gill, his eyes wide open and his thoughts racing, could not believe his good fortune. He had just missed the rim completely on a heavily contested, somewhat ill-advised layup and given the Miami Heat a chance to tie the game with less than one minute left to play.

title: 'Young Turks' Stake Their Futures on McCain
description: John McCain is not the only candidate on his campaign bus who has a large stake in whether his ''great crusade'' goes forward or fails in South Carolina Saturday.

title: Federal Inquiry Examines Food Suppliers for Schools
description: The Board of Education said yesterday that the Justice Department has been conducting an investigation into food contracts for city schools and other city agencies. Although no one has been charged, the board has recently asked food wholesalers to prepare emergency bids in case any of the companies that now supply the food are accused of wrongdoing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, MARY REINHARDT
description: COX-Mary Reinhardt. Suddenly on February 14. Beloved wife of Edward V. Cox. Mother of Calvin Deater, David Reinhardt, Andrew Reinhardt. Memorial service Sun. February 20, at 2PM, North Congregational Church, Woodbury, CT. In lieu of flowers gifts may be made to church's memorial fund.

title: U.S. to Seek Death Penalty in Shooting of Los Angeles Mail Carrier
description: Federal prosecutors filed court papers today saying they would seek the death penalty against Buford O. Furrow Jr., the white supremacist accused of shooting five people in a day care center last year and then killing a mail carrier.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Head of W.T.O. Expects China to Gain Entry in 2000

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the campaign in Michigan misstated the number of states holding Republican primaries on March 7. It is 12, not 16.

title: Cheaper Than a Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: SYNTROLEUM SIGNS A $1.3 BILLION GAS CONTRACT
description: The Syntroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a $1.3 billion contract to buy gas over 20 years for a synthetic chemicals plant it is building in Australia from a partnership that includes a unit of the Chevron Corporation. The $400 million Sweetwater Project, which Syntroleum announced Thursday, near Dampier in western Australia will convert gas into synthetic lubricants, drilling fluids and parafin oil used in candle wax.
