North West Shelf Gas Ltd. will supply the gas. The group includes Chevron Australia, Woodside Energy, BP Developments Australia, BHP Petroleum, Shell Development and Japan Australia LNG. Syntroleum, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., sells a process for converting natural gas into synthetic crude oil.

title: Officer Sues Police Dept. Over Arrest
description: A police officer who contends that he was arrested in a drug sweep only because he is Hispanic filed a federal civil rights lawsuit against the Police Department yesterday, charging that it continues to pursue disciplinary charges against him even though his criminal case was dismissed.

title: Alcatel, Newbridge Drop on Takeover Talk
description: February 18, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISSELBACHER, ALFRED
description: ISSELBACHER-Alfred. An amusing and stimulating conversationalist, keen on life and ever ready to defend his views, even as a septagenarian. He never complained and kept going, as best he could, until the end, even though circumstances became hard. He was a remarkable and attractive man and all who knew him were privileged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSH, PATRICIA
description: HERSH-Patricia, R.N., Ph.D./ Ph.N./d, on February 16, 2000, died of end-stage renal disease. Beloved wife of Alexander Hersh, M.D. Dear step-mother of Karen and William. Adored sister of Patrick Breglia and Bernadette Timan. Loving aunt. Services Sunday, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOREEN, DAVID A.
description: FLOREEN-David A. The Board of Directors and employees of The Atlantic Mutual Companies mourn with deep sorrow the passing of a dear friend. David A. Floreen, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer from 1970 to 1976, passed away earlier this week in Durham, N.C., following a battle with Parkinson Disease. Mr. Floreen joined Atlantic Mutual in 1946. He became Sr. Executive Vice President in 1965, was appointed the company's 11th President in 1966 and became Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer in 1970. His vision, leadership and dedication to the insurance industry will be greatly missed. The Atlantic Mutual Companies

title: Chechnya: Steps To Peace
description: With the inevitability of a Greek tragedy, Russia's military intervention in Chechnya has followed the script rehearsed in the war in the mid-1990's.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Wednesday misidentified the South Carolina city where Tuesday's Republican debate took place. It was Columbia, not Charleston.

title: Robots to Study A-Plant Leak
description: Technicians who returned to the containment dome at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in Buchanan, N.Y., said it appeared unchanged despite a radiation leak on Tuesday, and plant managers expected to open up the steam generator where the leak occurred by the middle of next week, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

title: A Well-Scripted Day for Gates Ends With a Bloomberg Feud
description: February 18, 2000

title: No Spending Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: FORD JOB CUTS
description: Citing the ''poor and unacceptable'' performance of its European division, the Ford Motor Company said it would cut 1,500 of the 4,300 jobs at its biggest British plant, at Dagenham, east of London. The plant has been running on a four-day week for more than 16 months. Ford produces far more cars in Europe than it can sell in the face of competition from Volkswagen A.G. of Germany and PSA Peugeot Citroen of France. Nick Scheele, left, Ford's European chairman, said the company needed to reduce production by ''at least 200,000 units.'' Last year, Ford's European division produced 2.25 million vehicles and sold 1.7 million, as its West European market share fell from 10 percent to 9.3 percent. Alan Cowell

title: INSURANCE EXECUTIVE TO LEAVE
description: Prudential P.L.C., the British insurer, said Les Cullen, its finance director, would leave the company in April. Mr. Cullen is the third senior executive of Prudential to announce his departure in two months. Sir Peter Davis, the former chief executive, resigned last month to join J. Sainsbury P.L.C. Prudential's shares fell 9 pence, to 981 pence. Mr. Cullen, 48, was appointed in September to replace Jonathan Bloomer, now acting chief executive.

title: THE SECOND REVOLUTION
description: Viagra is just the beginning. With dozens of new drugs for men and women in clinical trials, multitudes could soon be medicated and wired for high-performance romance. A report by Jack Hitt in The Times Magazine.

title: Peter O'Toole Is Honored At the Olivier Awards
description: The actor Peter O'Toole has been honored for his long contribution to the British stage with the Outstanding Achievement citation at the 24th annual Laurence Olivier Awards in London.

title: Oregon's Governor Favors Breaching 4 Major Dams
description: Lending political momentum to an idea that would have been unthinkable in a different era of Pacific Northwest history, Gov. John A. Kitzhaber of Oregon announced today that he favored breaching four large federal dams on the Snake River in Washington State in an effort to restore endangered salmon populations.

title: Macy's Restaurant to Close, Ending 70-Year Tradition
description: For Ronnie and Ger Petrie, tourists from Ireland, it was a decidedly American moment: sharing a B.L.T. at the eighth-floor diner at Macy's in Herald Square, and chatting with the shopper sitting next to them.

title: Basketball 'Nerds' Get Last Laugh; Boys at Bronx Science Find They're on a Winning Team
description: It's bad enough that all season long, the undersize basketball players of the Bronx High School of Science have been marked by opponents as geeks, resulting in taunts and jeers when they step on the court. Making matters worse, only a smattering of their own fans -- at some games just the security guards, a janitor and one or two student stalwarts -- usually show up to counter the hecklers.

title: Storm Snarls Traffic in Midwest and Northeast
description: A winter storm swept the Midwest and parts of the East today, snarling traffic, canceling flights and closing schools, with more than 10 inches of snow blanketing some regions.

title: Walter Frank, 91, Ex-Chairman of the Big Board
description: Walter Nils Frank, a Wall Street executive who served as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange in the mid-1960's, died on Tuesday at a retirement home in Hanover, N.H. He was 91 and had moved to Hanover in 1991.

title: New Looks at the Death Penalty
description: America is at last beginning to grapple honestly with the profound flaws of the death penalty system. Late last month Gov. George Ryan of Illinois, a Republican, became the first governor in a death penalty state to declare a moratorium on executions, citing well-founded concerns about his state's ''shameful record of convicting innocent people and putting them on death row.'' That has now been followed by moves in Congress and the executive branch to review death penalty policies from a national perspective.

title: Best Missile Defense Is None at All
description: To the Editor:

title: Hat Trick Keys Avalanche's Victory Over the Rangers
description: The sagging Rangers desperately needed a victory at Madison Square Garden last night. Trailing by a goal entering the third period, they probably would have settled for a tie.

title: Investor Fear of Rising Rates Sends Stock Market Plunging
description: The leading stock indexes plunged about 3 percent yesterday, and technology issues finished much lower as investors focused on the stark prospect of rising short-term interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARLEY, THOMAS M.
description: FARLEY-Thomas M. of Hampton Bays on February 17, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Catherine. Loving father of Thomas M. & Stephen. Cherished brother of Beryl Graham and grandfather of seven. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 7-9 pm at the R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 94 East Montauk Hwy, Hampton Bays. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday at 9am from St. Rosalies Church, Hampton Bays followed by an interment at Calvary Cemetery.

title: UBS Ousts Chief Executive Of Its Private Banking Unit
description: UBS of Switzerland, the world's biggest bank in terms of assets, replaced the head of its private banking business today and announced a broad reorganization to stem the loss of wealthy clients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARY MURRAY
description: BROWN-Mary Murray. Beloved and loving wife of Leland Scott Brown. Loving mother of Morgan Scott Brown and Janet Brown Jussel. Beloved mother-in-law of Suzanne R. Brown and Christian Jussel. Sister of Janet Mahony Wilson. Grandmother of John Bradbury, Sara B. Robbins, Catherine M. Jussel & David S. Jussel. Died February 16, 2000. She was known for years of service to the Bedford Free Library, Bedford, New York, and her deep love of Chappaquiddick Island. A memorial service will be held Monday, February 21 at 11:00 at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford. In lieu of flowers it is suggested that gifts be made to the Bedford Free Library, Bedford, New York 10506.

title: Jane Davies, 86, Historian Of Architecture, Is Dead
description: Jane B. Davies, an independent architectural historian whose devotion took her from reference librarian at Columbia University to pre-eminent authority on the 19th-century American architect Alexander J. Davis, died on Feb. 9. She was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Seeking Green in a Concrete Jungle
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day for Others as Woods Lags
description: A week after Tiger Woods's quest to extend his winning streak commanded record television ratings, the P.G.A. Tour leader board turned viewer unfriendly today at the Nissan Open, where the weekend will become a scramble to see who can end losing streaks or notch first career victories.

title: New Jersey Withholds Plan to Reform Auto Inspection System
description: The company operating New Jersey's auto inspection system submitted a plan yesterday to address the long lines and other inconveniences, but the Whitman administration ordered the company not to release it. The order was immediately criticized by Democrats and a trade group representing private service station owners.

title: Ambon Journal; A Year of Holy War Among Neighbors
description: At first glance he is one of the more forlorn of the victims slumped on thin mattresses here in the Christian hospital: a haggard middle-aged man staring at the dirty gauze bandage that covers the stump of his missing right hand.

title: Dutchess County Republican Official Admits Corruption
description: With a stoic face and a soft, gravelly voice, William L. Paroli Sr., the former chairman of the Dutchess County Republican Party, pleaded guilty today to a single federal corruption charge.

title: Big Turnout Seen for South Carolina Primary
description: The fierce struggle between Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain has stirred such keen interest that strategists on both sides predicted today that turnout on Saturday would far exceed the presidential primary record of 276,000 who voted in South Carolina four years ago.

title: Meteorite Dispute Greets Opening of Planetarium
description: Over the last few years, as the American Museum of Natural History put up its sleek new planetarium on the Upper West Side, its enormous sphere and glass walls were erected around one of the museum's oldest treasures, a great 15-ton meteorite that fell to Earth 10,000 years ago.

title: Donations to Needy Fall Behind Last Year's Tally
description: Since The New York Times Neediest Cases appeal of 1994-95, the amount of money readers have given to the fund has increased year after year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, AUGUSTA
description: BECKER-Augusta, of Manhattan on February 17, 2000. Wife of the late David Becker. Beloved aunt of Jonathan and Jane Estreich and Michael Altman. Service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1 PM, Sunday, February 20th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUVANE, GENEVIEVE (NEE RYAN)
description: HUVANE-Genevieve (nee Ryan) died peacefully on February 17, 2000. Beloved wife of 47 years to Matin. Loving mother of Denise Whalen, Michael, Kevin, Stephen, Robert and Christopher. Cherished grandmother to Daniel, Sarah, Conor, Bridget and Declan. She will be forever remembered by her family and friends. Reposing Saturday 7-9pm and Sunday 2-4 & 7-9pm at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. (at West 261st Street), Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 11:30 am at St. Margaret of Cortona. In lieu of flowers please send donations to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105 or Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1st Avenue at 16th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEYER, MURRAY
description: STEYER-Murray. Dear Dad-Got your message-bought the coat. Love you forever, Bets

title: Illinois Governor Hopes to Fix a 'Broken' Justice System
description: SITTING in a chair facing a bronze statue of Abraham Lincoln, Gov. George Ryan shuddered as he recalled ''the most anguishing period of my life.''

title: Who Wants to Be a Contestant?
description: Even Regis Philbin is concerned. Despite the ratings success of ''Who Wants to be a Millionaire,'' the show's host says he is deeply troubled by the lack of diversity among the program's contestants. Mr. Philbin has even made an on-air plea for ''everyone out there who has thought about being on the show who isn't a white male, dial that 800 number'' for the first round of qualifying tests.

title: Lack of Wind Puts Off America's Cup Opener
description: After a long week in which tongues, not sails, were the main things flapping in the breeze, the time for talking appeared to be over. The first race in the five-of-nine-race America's Cup finals between the local heroes, Team New Zealand, and the pride of Italy, the Prada Challenge, was scheduled to begin today but there was barely a breath of air.

title: A Cure for Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Saab Earnings Decrease 38%
description: Saab, the Swedish military company with products ranging from warplanes to radar systems, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 38 percent on reorganization costs and costs for preparing a fighter for export.

title: INPRISE, A SOFTWARE CONCERN, TO SELL ITS HEADQUARTERS
description: The Inprise Corporation, a maker of software to create Internet programs, agreed to sell its Scotts Valley, Calif., headquarters to the ScanlanKemperBard Companies for $47 million. Inprise will sign a long-term lease with ScanlanKemperBard and rent back about 44 percent of the building. The transaction is expected to close in mid-March, the company said yesterday. ScanlanKemperBard, based in Portland, Ore., is a real estate investment banking company. Inprise, which is being acquired by the Corel Corporation, said it would use the money to aid profits and invest in Internet products.

title: Nasdaq Data Flowing Again After Outage of Nearly Three Hours
description: February 18, 2000

title: Lincoln was profoundly influenced by his family's religious faith although he did not share it.
description: As the nation drifts into Presidents' Day, there is a strong suspicion that neither of the men whom it celebrates could get elected today. One formidable obstacle would be their religious beliefs -- or lack thereof.

title: A Colombian Look For the MetroStars
description: The MetroStars, who produced only seven victories in 32 games last season, will have a strong Colombian look on offense this season.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If this is right, this is clearly one of the great discoveries of the last hundred years.''

title: Frank V. Fowlkes, 58, Novelist and Reporter
description: Frank V. Fowlkes, a novelist, journalist and editorial consultant, died on Feb. 16 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 58.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Chechens' accounts of abuses by Russian troops at detention camps in Chechnya misstated the title of Mary Robinson, a United Nations official who has sought to visit sites there. She is the high commissioner for human rights, not for refugees.

title: Putting Steps to Feelings From the Lives of Blacks
description: A dance project got off to a fine start on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Lichtenstein Theater when 651 Arts presented the Philadanco company in a new series called Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation.

title: Seeking Green in a Concrete Jungle
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Lawyers in Murder of Socialite Attack Investigation and Caretaker
description: Lawyers for the mother and son accused of murdering an Upper East Side woman cross-examined the woman's longtime caretaker yesterday, asking about his access to the woman's bank accounts and suggesting that the police did not adequately consider the possibility of other suspects.

title: Miles White, 85, Broadway Costume Designer
description: Miles White, the imaginative costume designer for Rodgers and Hammerstein's first two Broadway hits, ''Oklahoma!'' and ''Carousel,'' and dozens of other musicals as well as movies, ballets, ice shows and circuses, died on Thursday. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Arts & Ideas last Saturday with an article about colonial saints in the Americas misidentified the tribe that killed the Jesuit missionary Jean de Brebeuf in 1649. It was Iroquois, as noted in the article, not Huron.

title: Brazilians Grumble Over Monetary Policy
description: Many Brazilians are growing impatient with the austere monetary policy of the country's central bank, which left interest rates unchanged at 19 percent this week for the fifth time since September.

title: At Daytona, Crash Makes Case For Restricting Overall Speed
description: Geoffrey Bodine's presence in a hospital here today -- he was lucky to have only several broken bones -- serves as the latest and perhaps most compelling reason the Daytona 500 plans to continue its restrictions on speed.

title: On the Front Line When Heating a Home Becomes a High-Stakes Deal
description: Jonathan Norris and David Rome sounded like two stock traders riding a roller-coaster market rather than an oil delivery man and a beleaguered homeowner as they chatted this morning outside Mr. Rome's house on Mount Hope Boulevard here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULHANE, JAMES F.
description: CULHANE-James F. On February 17, 2000 of Garden City, N. Y. Native of Kilelton, County Kerry, Ireland. Beloved husband of Maria Ann, loving father of Noreen, Richard, Ann Tuomey, Mary Hickey, Sheila Winters, James and Kevin. Dear grandfather of twelve. Loving brother of John, Richard, Sheila Dillon and Mena Langan. Visiting at The Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, on Saturday 7-9pm, Sunday & Monday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10 A.M., St. Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY.

title: Coca-Cola's Market Share Is Said to Shrink
description: The Coca-Cola Company's share of the nation's soft drink market slipped in 1999, the first drop in six years, as higher prices cut into sales and consumers shunned cola drinks, an industry newsletter said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEPNER, HERBERT N.
description: SEPNER-Herbert N. Loving husband of Fay. Devoted father of Beth (Sy) Kirshner, Sandra (Stanley) Davidoff, loving grandfather and great grandfather. Services Sunday, Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, Florida.

title: W.T.O. Head Hopeful on China Entry
description: The head of the World Trade Organization said today that he was optimistic that China can be admitted this year.

title: Artie Aidala, 91, Judge at First Ali-Frazier Bout
description: Artie Aidala, a New York boxing judge for almost four decades who was at ringside for the Muhammad Ali-Joe Frazier ''fight of the century'' in 1971, died Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 91.

title: NYT Article
description: F.T.C. Probes Health Web Sites on Privacy

title: A Rebuke for Mr. Mugabe
description: When Zimbabwe achieved independence from white minority rule in 1980 in what had been Rhodesia, its newly elected leader, Robert Mugabe, held out the promise of transforming a state that was not only racist but brutally authoritarian. Many hoped he could make Zimbabwe a model for what was then still an apartheid-ruled South Africa, on its southern border. The former guerrilla leader made progress in dismantling the legacies of racism, but he maintained the machinery of authoritarianism that he inherited from Rhodesia's last white leader, Ian Smith, including sweeping emergency powers.

title: Best Missile Defense Is None at All
description: To the Editor:

title: In Explosive Novelty, a Pride in Roots
description: The imagery was diverse: occasionally outlandish and mostly ingenious. Owing more than something to the model and entertainer Grace Jones, a pantherine woman slithered her leggy form across the stage and snarled. Men and women engaged in karate, celestial style. Feminine power exploded in bursts of dance from African villages turned urban.

title: Immigration Officer In Miami Accused Of Spying for Cuba
description: A high-ranking United States immigration official was charged in federal court today with spying for the Cuban government, after federal officials said he was caught in an elaborate sting passing on what he thought was classified information about a Cuban's plan to defect to the United States.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FRONTIER INSURANCE GROUP INC., Rock Hill, N.Y., a property and casualty insurer, laid off 71 employees, including 60 from its corporate headquarters. The cuts reduced the company's staff to about 640 in Rock Hill, 15 miles north of Middletown, and 1,200 nationwide.

title: NEWBRIDGE SHARES FALL
description: Shares in the Newbridge Networks Corporation fell 6.2 percent to 47.40 Canadian dollars after hitting a nine-month high on Thursday, reflecting investor caution about the terms of a rumored takeover of the Canadian communications equipment maker by Alcatel S.A. of France. European news reports said Alcatel had been negotiating a $4.7 billion share exchange bid that could be announced on Tuesday, when Newbridge releases its third-quarter results. Newbridge, based in Kanata, Ontario, near Ottawa, has consistently failed to deliver the results shareholders have expected and it has been on the block since November. Two other European companies, Siemens A.G. of Germany and L. M. Ericsson of Sweden, had also been talking to Newbridge but are now believed to be out of the running. Timothy Pritchard

title: Pulsipher the Early Favorite in Race for No. 5 Spot
description: The only thing Mets officials have told Bill Pulsipher about his role is that he is competing for the fifth spot in the starting rotation. A more accurate message would be that the job is his for the taking.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a request that the jury in the Amadou Diallo case be allowed to consider charges less serious than murder misstated the standard for criminally negligent homicide. On that charge, even if the officers did not know that there was a risk of killing Mr. Diallo, the jury could decide that they should have known and have been more cautious. The officers need not be judged to have known there was a risk of death.

title: NYT Article
description: Biotech Investors Rewarded for Patience

title: No Second Chance
description: Amando Baptiste was brought to this country at the age of 9 from Cape Verde, the island republic off the west coast of Africa. As a teenager in Boston, which has a community of people from Cape Verde, he joined a gang and mixed in gang fights. He was convicted of assault.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR UP. The dollar hit a five-month high against the yen as data lifted confidence that growth will continue despite the threat of higher interest rates. The yen settled at 111.14 a dollar, compared with 110.59 on Thursday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Judge Sets Nov. 7 as Date For Hempstead Election
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that the first six-district election for the Town Board of Hempstead will take place on Nov. 7.

title: ACNIELSEN, MARKET RESEARCHER, MOVES TO DOUBLE PROFIT
description: The ACNielsen Corporation, the world's biggest market researcher, said yesterday that it would cut about 1,300 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, as it seeks to double per-share earnings within three years. Most job cuts will come in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. ACNielsen expects to take $180 million in charges before taxes: $70 million this year, $80 million next year, and the rest in 2002. ACNielsen, which is based in Stamford, Conn., expects the streamlining moves to save $100 million. The company plans to spend about $160 million through 2002 to improve information delivery.

title: A New Hoffmann: Crazed Storyteller
description: The title role in Offenbach's ''Contes d'Hoffmann'' is a formidable choice of repertory for a young tenor making his Metropolitan Opera debut. So it is to the credit of Keith Ikaia-Purdy, a tenor from Hawaii who has sung so far primarily in Europe and been a member of the Vienna State Opera since 1992, that his debut in the role on Tuesday night was so accomplished. If his was not a star-making performance, it was a winning one.

title: Banks Signs 4-Year Deal
description: The Ravens signed quarterback Tony Banks to an incentive-laden four-year deal yesterday that could be worth as much as $18.6 million.

title: Kurdish Issue Threatens Turkey's Bid to Join European Union
description: Two months of remarkable progress toward building a new relationship between Turkey and the European Union are being threatened by a dispute over whether Turkey will allow European politicians to visit an imprisoned Kurdish leader.

title: NYT Article
description: Gates Unveils Latest Version of Windows

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULDOWNEY, JAMES X.
description: MULDOWNEY-James X., 86, of Southbury, CT, died Tues., Feb. 15 at his home. Mr. Muldowney was born Feb. 6, 1914, in Scranton, PA, son of Thomas and Catherine (Thayne) Muldowney. He worked for Rankin & Co. CPA's and made partner before leaving to form Muldowney & Co. in New York City with his brother, John. They recessed during World War II to enlist in the Navy, where he served as a senior supply officer on the east coast and later directly for the Secretary of the Navy. After release from the service, they resumed practice and he taught accounting in the evening division of St. John's University. In 1974, he withdrew from the firm to become a professional director and business consultant. Among his boards were: Continental Mortgage Investors, Arundel Corp. and Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh. His clubs included Saint Andrews golf Club in Hastings on Hudson, NY and the Canadian Club of New York, both of which he served as a board member. All these activities ceased on or before March 1991, when his beloved wife, Gertrude, had a stroke. He took care of her until she died Oct. 6, 1996. In 1985 he moved to Southbury, CT from Tenafly, NJ. He leaves four sons, Peter of New York City, Michael of St. Simons Island, GA, Jerome of Norwalk, CT and Thomas of Hong Kong; two daughters, Ann Lyddane of Peawaukee, WI, and Kathleen Hintz of Wheaton, IL; one brother, John of Barryville, NY; nine grandchildren and two great - grandchildren. Funeral mass Monday, Feb. 21 at 11:am at Sacred Heart Church, Main Street South, Southbury, CT. Calling hours: Sunday from 3 to 5pm in the daily chapel of the church. Burial in Woodbury, CT in the spring. For information: Carpino Funeral Home, Southbury, CT. Donations instead of flowers would be appreciated by the Society of African Missions (SMA Fathers), 23 Bliss Avenue, Tenafly, New Jersey 07670-9988.

title: Impasse on Coliseum Lease Is Holding Up Isles' Sale
description: When angry Islanders fans chanted ''SMG, set us free'' at Nassau Coliseum last Saturday night, it signified a shift to blaming the team's landlord for the impasse in selling the team to a group led by Bob Gutkowski for $180 million.

title: The Other Oil Economy; Barrel Costs $30 but the Benefits Aren't Trickling Down
description: Oil may not hold sway over the nation's economy the way it once did, but in places like Houma, La., it still, to a large degree, is the economy. Houma, 50 miles southwest of New Orleans, is a major center for oil drilling and oil field services -- the work of helping oil giants like Exxon Mobil find and produce oil.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLER, RICHARD
description: MILLER-Richard. 2/19/29-11/28/99. Happy Birthday, Dicky. Always in my heart. Tommy

title: Murderer Kicks Wall In and Escapes Federal Authorities
description: A convicted murderer with a knack for eluding the authorities escaped yesterday from federal custody at a Brooklyn hospital where he had been taken after apparently faking a suicide attempt at an upstate prison, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a painting auctioned by Sotheby's in January and doubts about its attribution to the artist Andrea del Sarto misstated the surname of the rector of All Saints Church in West Newbury, Mass., where the work was discovered. He is the Rev. William Murdoch, not Murray.

title: What I Saw at the Revolution
description: Don King, the boxing promoter, has stated that my recent presidential exploratory campaign was one of the greatest promotions of all time. Sadly, many have agreed with him and have thought that my foray into presidential politics was done for the purpose of further heightening the Trump name, helping to sell my new book and building even greater awareness of my various real estate developments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSER, IRENE
description: OSER-Irene. Beloved mother of Marty, Neil and David Oser. Dear sister of Esther Rinsky and Jesse Cooper. Cherished grandmother of Michele, Deborah, Gregory, Kim, Randy, Dean and Chris. Services to be held Sunday, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, 5th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, FILOMEN D'AGOSTINO
description: GREENBERG-Filomen D'Agostino. The entire NYU Law School community is saddened by the loss of Filomen D'Agostino Greenberg (Class of 1920). Fil, one of our most vibrant alumnae, had a lifelong commitment to the Law School. From her good counsel to seven deans to her extraordinary generosity to the School, she was an invaluable member of our family. She and her late husband, Max E. Greenberg (Class of 1919), always will be remembered for their support of the Greenberg Faculty Research Fund, the Greenberg Professorship in Contract Law, the D'Agostino Residence Hall, and our beautiful Greenberg Lounge. Throughout her career, Fil was a trailblazer and a truly extraordinary role model for our students and alumni. Our hearts and thoughts are with her family and friends. Lester Pollack, Chair John Sexton, Dean New York University School of Law

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be legally observed.

title: DUPONT AND INTERNET CAPITAL ESTABLISH JOINT VENTURE
description: The DuPont Company, a leading chemical company, said yesterday that it formed a $100 million joint venture with the holding company Internet Capital Group to help develop online businesses including apparel and chemicals. The new venture, called CapSpan, will be based in Wayne, Pa., near Internet Capital's headquarters. DuPont said it would provide two-thirds of the $100 million initial capitalization, and Internet Capital would provide the rest. DuPont expects the venture to contribute the majority of the $1 billion in Internet-related sales it has forecast for the next year, said Chad Holliday, chairman of DuPont. The companies plan to start five new companies in that time through CapSpan. DuPont is based in Wilmington, Del.

title: PUBLICIS-TRUE NORTH DISPUTE
description: Publicis S.A., Europe's biggest advertising company, said a $106 million lawsuit brought against it by True North Communications Inc. was dismissed, ending a dispute over what its former alliance partner said was an inadequate valuation of its stake in the French company. True North, which is based in Chicago and owns FCB Worldwide, filed suit in the London Court of International Arbitration in January 1999 over the previous month's merger of Publicis Communication into Publicis S.A. True North said that the conversion of its 26.5 percent stake in Publicis Communication into 8.8 percent of the holding company was inad equate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTAS, MARIE (NEE MICHEL)
description: COSTAS-Marie (nee Michel). On February 16, 2000. Loving wife of the late Professor Procope Costas; beloved mother of Celia. Dear sister of Dite Fordes and George Michel; loving aunt of William and George Fordes, & William Michel. A cherished aunt and great aunt. Reposing at Dahill Funeral Home 2525 65th Street, corner Avenue P, Brooklyn, New York, until 9:30AM, Saturday. Funeral service at Sts. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 64 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn at 10:30AM. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: Sports of The Times; Benefits, Benefactor, Storm Clouds
description: DURING funeral services for Reggie Carter at Riverside Church in late December, the presiding minister acknowledged the family of the former St. John's and Knicks star. He surveyed the audience and asked if the man who was one of the pillars of the church, and a mentor to Carter, would please stand. The mourners looked over and looked back as an elderly man with white hair, a long face and black horn-rimmed glasses slowly stood. Ernie Lorch nodded and sat back down. Many had probably never seen or heard of Ernie Lorch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNHEIMER, RUDOLPH MAX
description: STERNHEIMER-Rudolph Max. Suddenly on February 16, 2000 at age 73. Retired Senior Physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory where he worked for over 40 years. Beloved husband of Betty Sternheimer. Dear brother of Paul Sternheimer and his wife Hanne and Michael Sternheimer and his wife Karine. Devoted uncle of John, Philip, William and Jennifer Sternheimer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Saturday, Sunday and Monday 2-5 PM with services Tuesday 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Evidence of Mystery Particles Stirring Excitement and Doubt
description: A team of physicists based at the University of Rome has generated both intense excitement and profound skepticism among scientists around the world by presenting evidence that they may have detected a heavy particle that could solve a 70-year-old mystery in astronomy and lead to a conceptual breakthrough in physics.

title: Seeking Green in a Concrete Jungle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTTAHEDEH, MILDRED R.
description: MOTTAHEDEH-Mildred R. on February 17, 2000. Distinguished leader in the decorative arts field and Bahai faith and friend of the disadvantaged peoples of the Third World. Beloved wife of the late Rafi Mottahedeh. Survived by her children Dr. Roy P. Mottahedeh of Brookline, MA and Peri Yusef of London, England. Loving grandmother of Melissa Halpern, Alexander Halpern, Stephanie Halpern, Rafi Mottahedeh and Rostam Mottahedeh and great grandmother of Jamie Waldman and Benjamin Halpern. Services will be held at Frank. E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, Febraury 20 at 11:30am. Contributions in her memory may be made to Mottahedeh Development Services Inc., 2370 Wesley Chapel Road, Decatur, GA 30035 for the Mildred R. Mottahedeh Memorial Fund for Scholarships to Children of the Third World.

title: PLAYSTATION DEMAND STUNS SONY
description: Demand for PlayStation 2, the successor to the Sony Corporation's wildly popular PlayStation game console, overwhelmed the company's computer server. Access to PlayStation.com, a Web site that began accepting advance orders for the new machine at midnight, was blocked for roughly two hours by a surge in hits, and the site had continued difficulties throughout the day, said Ken Kutaragi, head of Sony's PlayStation business. He said about 500,000 people a minute were trying to connect to the site. PlayStation 2 is scheduled to go on sale in Japan on March 4. Stephanie Strom

title: Some Charities Suspected of Terrorist Role
description: Government officials investigating a decade of international terrorist attacks say they have found a common thread, Islamic charities and relief organizations that they suspect are being used to move men, money and weapons across borders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, STANLEY J.
description: MAYER-Stanley J. On February 18, 2000. Loving father of Bobette Lister and Leslie Wexler. Devoted grandfather of Jennifer Cooper, Julie Feinberg (Nee Lister), Paul Lister, Eric Wexler and Todd Wexler. Great-grandfather of Rebecca Cooper, Rachel Cooper, Julia Cooper and Will Feinberg. Brother of Richard Mayer and the late Charles Mayer. You have been loved and will be missed.

title: The Nursing Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Quiet Retired
description: Real Quiet, the 1998 Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner, has been retired, leaving him out of the next month's $6 million Dubai World Cup, the world's richest horse race.

title: NYT Article
description: Sony Web Site Mobbed as Playstation Fever Strikes

title: Clemens Won His Ring, but Wants Another
description: Roger Clemens assured himself of a championship ring by winning the last game of the World Series last fall, and now, with good humor, he is ready to take on the role of ring architect. Armed with gaudy thoughts and pictures, Clemens arrived at Yankees camp ready to lobby for something quite different.

title: The Big City; Sharp Women Left Holding The Remote
description: WE already have the first winner in the Who Wants to Be a Millionairess Contest, which was announced only last week in this space. Readers were asked to redress the gender problem on ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' -- 90 percent of the contestants are male -- by devising a female-friendly game show.

title: A Year in Which Political Bluebloods Are Leaders of the Pack
description: For a country like the United States that has kings only on chessboards, where nobility is a trait rather than a social class, where pedigrees typically concern dogs, there are a couple of peculiar things about this presidential contest.

title: Corrections
description: An article in House & Home on Feb. 10 about a proposed high-rise residence in Battery Park City with special concerns for the environment misspelled the surname of an architect from Malaysia who specializes in such high-rises. He is Ken Yeang, not Leang.

title: American Prudery, And Its Opposite
description: Imagine opening up a magazine, only to see a smiling, naked baby boy urinating in your direction. That's just what readers in Belgium saw when they opened to an advertisement touting my company's spring water. The ad didn't raise an outcry; it didn't cause a stir. It did only what it was supposed to do: illustrate how the water is just as pure and clean as the most innocent of acts.

title: Australia Using Law to Go After Objectionable Sites
description: February 19, 2000

title: World Briefings
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: McCain Fits Quite Well Among His Attackers
description: On conservative talk radio, Rush Limbaugh has painted Senator John McCain as a guy who would fit right in with the ''pro-abortion, pro-affirmative action'' Clinton-Gore crowd.

title: Judge Clears One Suspect In Voodoo Fire
description: In a surprise turn in an already tangled trial about a voodoo ritual, a New Jersey judge has absolved a Brooklyn man of charges that he and a voodoo priest tried to kill a Haitian pop singer by setting her on fire in the ceremony in October 1997.

title: 46 in East Harlem Gang Are Indicted Over Drugs
description: Law enforcement officials yesterday indicted 46 members of an East Harlem-based drug gang whose members brazenly wore shirts and baseball caps advertising their name, territory and sales locations.

title: A Mystery After a Battle at Gallipoli
description: The plot of ''All the King's Men'' is no more original than the title. A group of British Army volunteers in World War I find themselves in a murderous battle. What makes these young men different from other recruits is their prior civilian employment on the royal estate at Sandringham and their fate, which tomorrow night's ''Masterpiece Theater'' says has entered legend.

title: N.C.A.A. Investigates Barkley's Prep School Tuition
description: An investigator from the National Collegiate Athletic Association has spoken with officials at a Maine prep school about whether people associated with the Riverside Church basketball program, or other benefactors, paid part of Erick Barkley's tuition when the St. John's guard attended the school in 1997-98.

title: Russian Aide Opens Door a Bit to U.S. Bid for Missile Defense
description: A senior Russian security official who met with President Clinton today appeared to open the door slightly to meeting the administration's desire to deploy a limited national missile defense system.

title: Gwynn and Padres At an Impasse
description: Tony Gwynn turned down the Padres' offer to add an option year to his contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINDES, MINNA.
description: GINDES-Minna. On February 18, 2000, age 94. Beloved wife of the late Robert Gindes. Loving mother of Toby Landey and Marion Gindes. Proud grandmother of Scott and Shelly Liebler, Todd and Betty Liebler, Jessica and Stephen Murphy, and dear great-grandmother of Eliza, Hannah, Isaac and Samuel. In our hearts forever. Service 11:30 AM, Sunday, February 20 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 76 St.

title: When Life Was a Waltz, The Widow Was Merrier
description: ''The Merry Widow'' does not come willingly into the 21st century, and the Metropolitan Opera has politely declined to prod it in our direction. Ninety-five years separate the house's new production from the Vienna original of 1905. Societies and cultures have come and gone since then, but the Met was in an archaeological mood on Thursday night, seemingly happy to leave Franz Lehar's beloved piece resting comfortably in the vanished world from which it came. The audience had no choice but to look back and hope for as unobstructed a view as possible.

title: E-Learning at Any Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Doctor Agrees To Suspension During Inquiry
description: The head of neurosurgery at Staten Island University Hospital agreed yesterday to stop practicing medicine while the State Department of Health investigates the death of one of his patients earlier this month, hospital officials said. The move came three days after the department, citing possible danger to patients, ordered the hospital to prohibit the doctor, Ehud Arbit, from caring for patients while it investigated.

title: Wild Cards Make Contest Hard to Call
description: Even candidates in close elections usually have some advance knowledge of whether they are going to win. Based on their own surveys and a mix of outside polls and professional wisdom, they can decide whether to order Champagne for election night.

title: Watching 2 Legal Minds Square Off Over Clinton
description: When Richard A. Posner published a book last September analyzing the investigation, impeachment and trial of President Clinton, it was not treated as just another commentator's view of the affair. Not only is Mr. Posner the chief judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit based in Chicago: he is also, to a wide swath of intellectuals, one of the most fascinating contemporary thinkers on the law and an astonishing range of other subjects. Moreover, his book, ''An Affair of State'' (Harvard University Press), did not shrink from blunt conclusions.

title: Too Quick at First Trick? Slow Woe
description: The average bridge player knows in theory that he or she should avoid playing too quickly at the first trick, but the temptation to make an obvious play is often irresistible.

title: Colombia's Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: BID FOR OIL COMPANY STAKE
description: ABN Amro Holding and Dresdner Bank said they had begun an offer for Dordtsche Petroleum, a holding company whose only assets are shares of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company. The offer values Dordtsche at 8.56 billion euros ($8.43 billion). ABN Amro and Dresdner said they would pay 0.96887 Royal Dutch share for every Dordtsche share tendered. Dordtsche owns about 7.2 percent of Royal Dutch.

title: CROSS, FOUNTAIN PEN MAKER, TO CUT IRISH WORK FORCE 60%
description: The A. T. Cross Company, the maker of ballpoint and fountain pens, said yesterday that it would cut about 100 jobs at its Irish plant, or 60 percent of its work force there, and consolidate all pen production in Rhode Island to cut costs. The transition from a plant in Ballinasloe, Ireland, to Cross's headquarters in Lincoln, R.I., should be completed by the end of July. The Irish plant will become a distribution center for markets in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. The move is part of a strategy to bolster the profits of Cross's writing-instrument business, said the chief executive, David Whalen.

title: Queens Groups Plan to Sue To Stop a Baseball Staduim
description: In the latest twist in the Giuliani administration's quest to bring minor league baseball to New York, civic groups and politicians in Queens are vowing to sue to stop the city from building a $5 million ball field at St. John's University for a single-A team affiliated with the Mets.

title: U.S. Says Ties With China Are On the Mend
description: After two days of meetings with senior Chinese officials, an American government delegation left Beijing on a positive note today, with members characterizing the talks as helping to get the bilateral ''relationship back on track.''

title: Concerns on Human Testing Don't Seem to Faze Biotech Investors
description: When 18-year-old Jesse Gelsinger died last September in a gene therapy experiment that went awry, shares of Cell Genesys Inc., a gene therapy company, were selling for about $8. Now they are selling for more than $30. Avigen Inc., another gene therapy company, has zoomed from about $11 to $66. And Targeted Genetics has increased from less than $2 to more than $20.

title: Details Emerge in Kosovo Girl's Slaying
description: As an American staff sergeant appeared today at a hearing on charges of committing indecent acts with an 11-year-old Albanian girl and then murdering her, details emerged about the investigation of a second American soldier linked to the case.

title: The Next Ethnic War
description: To the Editor:

title: In 30-Minute Video Programs, McCain and Bush Look Back and Reach Out
description: As candidate biographies go, one attesting to great suffering under terrible circumstances might be considered something close to ideal.

title: Times Co. Picks Developer For New Home in Times Sq.
description: The New York Times Company has taken an important step toward creating a new headquarters in the Times Square area. It has selected a developer to help in its negotiations with state and city officials to build a 1.37 million-square-foot tower across from the Port Authority Bus Terminal, according to the company and government officials.

title: Iranians in Huge Numbers Vote in Parliamentary Election
description: Clutching palm cards from their favorite political parties and crumpled hand-drawn lists of candidates for their national Parliament, so many Iranians streamed to the polls today that officials were forced to extend the voting time by two hours.

title: NYT Article
description: Faster Web Connections Prompt More Surfing at Work

title: Oil Hogs on the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: A Debut From a Quartet With Works Old and New
description: Soon after the violinist Ida Kavafian and the cellist Peter Wiley left the Beaux-Arts Trio in 1998, they put together a new ensemble, the Opus One Piano Quartet, with the pianist Anne-Marie McDermott and the violist Steven Tenenbom. The group, which takes its name from a dog kennel that Mr. Tenenbom and Ms. Kavafian (who are married) operate in Connecticut, made a promising New York debut on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIS, HENRY J
description: KIS-Henry J, of Cliffside Park on February 17, 2000. Beloved husband of Molly (nee Amir). Devoted father of Daniella Kis and Daphne Kis Bromberg. Loving grandfather of Gabrielle and Talia. Services Sunday at Noon at ''Wien & Wien'' 129 Engle St, Englewood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBACK, HARRY
description: BARBACK-Harry. Beloved husband of the late Clara. Dear father of Spencer (Ronnie), Pamela and the late Michael. Cherished grandfather of Andrea Abolafia and Michelle. Dear brother of Max and respected uncle and brother-inlaw. Also survived by his loving campanion Eve Burtoff. Services Sunday, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Twist in Campaign Trail
description: Gov. George W. Bush began his quest for the presidency in a blaze of promises and good intentions, carrying an emphatically articulated vision of the new image he planned to establish for the Republican Party and the new voters he intended to woo.

title: ISLE OF CAPRI CASINOS PLANS MISSOURI OPERATIONS
description: Isle of Capri Casinos Inc., an operator of seven casinos, agreed to buy Davis Gaming Boonville Inc. to build a riverboat casino on a site Davis owns in Boonville, Mo., between St. Louis and Kansas City. Isle of Capri probably will pay about $75 million to buy Davis and build the casino on the Boonville site, Rex Yeisley, chief financial officer, said, though a final price has not been determined. The purchase is subject to government approvals. Isle of Capri is moving aggressively into Missouri. The company agreed last week to buy the Flamingo Hilton Riverboat Casino in Kansas City for $33.5 million.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PLATINUM DECLINES 4.9 PERCENT. Platinum retreated from an 11-year high after Russian officials signaled an end to export restrictions. The April contract fell $26.20, to $503.20 an ounce.

title: The Giants' Secondary Is Counting on Williams to Cover for the Departure of Ellsworth
description: The remaking of the Giants' secondary continued yesterday as free safety Percy Ellsworth joined the Cleveland Browns and Conrad Hamilton prepared to re-sign with the Giants. Together, the moves make the 25-year-old Hamilton the Giants' starter at left cornerback, while the talented but unproven Shaun Williams, who is 23, becomes the starter at free safety.

title: INSIDE
description: Iran's Reformers See Gains

title: Buchanan Sees Victory in Ventura's Absence
description: Patrick J. Buchanan claimed today that his tenacious, state-by-state struggle for the Reform Party presidential nomination has been helped substantially with the angry departure of Gov. Jesse Ventura from the party.

title: Ripken Gets Early Start
description: Cal Ripken Jr. did not play nearly enough baseball last year, so he decided to get an early start this season.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Cut Loose in the Cosmos, Mites of Dust Without a Home
description: There was a time, not long ago, when the Hayden Planetarium quaintly combined exoticism with worn comfort. Inlaid in the floor, in colored terrazzo, was a representation of an Aztec calendar stone. The massive Willamette Meteorite squatted by the museum entrance, a pitted sculpture created according to some unreadable design. In the lobby a mural depicted the cosmology of the Blackfeet Indians. In the domed hall itself, in the days before prepackaged programming became the rule, a man would stand pointing out the stars and constellations with an arrow-shaped beam of light. And the great Zeiss projection machinery would seem, silhouetted against the heavens, to be a creature out of ''War of the Worlds.'' As the show began, twilight would gradually fall, a mock skyline of houses ringing the dome beneath the blackening sky.

title: Van Gundy Decides Knicks Must Get Bigger Right Now
description: Earlier this season, after Jeff Van Gundy had paired Allan Houston and Latrell Sprewell in the backcourt to start three consecutive games, Houston went to the coach and expressed a discomfort with starting the game at an unfamiliar position: point guard. Van Gundy listened to his All-Star shooting guard and returned to the conventional lineup.

title: In Greenspan Wake, Bad Day for Markets
description: The stock market plummeted a day after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that interest rates would continue to increase until economic growth slows and the stock market cools down.

title: Protests in Beirut Against U.S. and Israel Turn Wrath on CNN
description: A second day of angry street protests against Israel and the United States turned today against the American cable network CNN, with Lebanese soldiers and policemen in riot gear firing tear gas to drive back about 3,000 demonstrators who tried to reach CNN's Beirut offices.

title: Winter Blast Leaves Travelers Wishing It Had Come One Day Later
description: A blast of snow, ice and rain stung the metropolitan region yesterday, confounding thousands of travelers with frozen roads and prolonged airport delays on the eve of a long holiday weekend and midwinter recess in many of the area's school districts.

title: Bass Raises Possibility That It May Get Out of the Beer Business
description: Faced with a falling stock price and dwindling British beer sales, Bass P.L.C. said today that it was considering ''all the options'' for its brewing business, Britain's second largest, raising the prospect that it will be sold as the company concentrates on its hotel and leisure chains.

title: Making the Jalopy an Ethnic Banner; How the Lowrider Evolved From Chicano Revolt to Art Form
description: Half a century ago, when postwar youths sought a means of expressing their rebelliousness, automobiles provided a distinctly American medium. Rear ends were jacked up, muscle was added and hot rods, their radios blaring rock 'n' roll, were created to fly past the dreary old symbols of their elders.

title: After Pushing Oil Prices Up, Mexico Has Second Thoughts
description: For two years, Mexico has worked with other oil-producing nations to lift prices, and their efforts have borne fruit. But in an about-face, senior Mexican officials are now trying to talk prices down.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: MAZDA PROFIT FORECAST
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation, an affiliate of the Ford Motor Company, cut its forecast for net earnings by 38 percent for the year ending in March, on lower-than-expected car sales overseas. The automaker cut its estimate for net income to 25 billion yen ($225 million), down from a forecast of 40 billion yen. The estimate is about 35 percent below net income in the prior year.

title: Democrats Fault Mayor Over Garden
description: In the latest flare-up over the city's demolition of a Lower East Side community garden to make way for a housing and retail development, the chairwoman of the New York State Democratic Committee released records yesterday showing that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had received more than $32,000 in campaign contributions from the development concern at work on the site.

title: SAKS FORESEES PROFIT IN THREE YEARS FROM WEB SITE
description: Saks Inc., the department store retailer, said yesterday that it expected profit in three years from its Saks Fifth Avenue Web site, which will start online sales by June. Saksfifthavenue.com will have a loss this year of about $12 million, or 8 cents a share, on sales of $15 million to $20 million, the company said. The site, which has been open several months, now has information about stores and fashion. R. Brad Martin, chairman and chief executive, said that profit and sales from e-commerce could surpass that of the upscale Saks Fifth Avenue flagship store in New York within five years.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Reuters in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the retirement of Thomas O'Brien next year as chief executive and chairman of the PNC Bank Corporation referred incorrectly to a succession plan. The company indeed identified a successor: its president and chief operating officer, James Rohr, is to become chairman.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- Seattle, St. Louis, Mo., Baltimore

title: South Carolina's Showdown
description: Rarely in recent presidential elections has there been a more pivotal vote than the one in the South Carolina primary today. The entire Republican presidential selection process seems balanced on a knife's edge, with a possibility of either Gov. George W. Bush or Senator John McCain emerging as the overwhelming favorite to win the nomination. The verdict in South Carolina could also shape the party, its demographic composition and perhaps even its philosophy for a long time. Yet the outcome on the eve of the election is entirely unpredictable.

title: Prices Show A Small Rise For January
description: The Consumer Price Index, the nation's best-known inflation measure, edged up only 0.2 percent in January -- the fourth consecutive mild increase -- undercutting numerous forecasts that the booming economy is creating shortages that must inevitably show up in more rapidly rising prices.

title: Yale Professor Admits To Pornography Charge
description: A Yale University professor pleaded guilty in federal court yesterday to downloading ''tens of thousands'' of images of child pornography and possessing two sexually explicit videos involving a child that he had made in his home and his university office, the United States attorney's office said.

title: A Journey With Shostakovich to Deep Within the Self
description: Before Shostakovich, previous masters of the string quartet had used the genre to push the boundaries of music in their times. Take Beethoven. In his early string quartets Beethoven completely reconfigured the existing landscape of music. In the last five he escaped earthly gravity altogether, taking the quartet, and music itself, to some cosmic place that we are still grappling with. In his landmark six quartets Bartok devised a bracingly modern musical language that remains fresh and challenging.

title: Seeking Green in a Concrete Jungle
description: To the Editor:

title: GORE BACK IN STEP WITH WHITE HOUSE OVER CHINA TRADE
description: Just a day after reassuring union leaders that he would negotiate a tougher trade deal with China if elected president, Vice President Al Gore felt obliged to write a letter today to reiterate his support for the trade agreement that President Clinton is trying to push through Congress.

title: Trade Gap Set Record in '99, But Narrowed In December
description: The United States trade deficit in goods and services narrowed in December, as rebounding economies abroad kindled record demand for American goods, government figures showed. Still, the trade gap for all of 1999 set a record.

title: It Was Love for Money, Right?
description: LIKE many Americans so repelled by ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?'' that they watched it in astonishing numbers, Scott Shuger, a columnist for Slate, came away with questions. He wrote: ''How is this show, with its explicit cash and property prizes for the woman, not prostitution?''

title: In Bunuel's Dreams Began Film's Liberation
description: LUIS BUNUEL was born 100 years ago, and, for many of us, finding his work was like holding a key to our dreams. We were seeing strange, yet strangely serene things. They were violent, outrageous even, but was there any need to be shocked? We knew his films had an inner meaning that was for us to puzzle out.

title: Promoting a Monthly Boxing Show That Has an Attitude
description: ''If I had Oscar De La Hoya everyone would know who I am,'' Cedric Kushner said wistfully. His sad eyes and hangdog gray mustache furthered the sense of deprivation; De La Hoya fights Derrell Coley on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden and poor Cedric, like you and me, won't have a piece of the action.

title: Update
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Socked and Molested
description: Understated humor marks Bil Wright's first novel, SUNDAY YOU LEARN HOW TO BOX (Scribner, paper, $12), a gay coming-of-age story set in working-class public housing units in the late 1960's. Louis Bowman has an upwardly striving mother who is raring to ditch the projects and a stepfather who is a mild-mannered sadist. On top of these prickly family politics, Louis must also survive being bright and sensitive, a ''sissy'' who is routinely bullied by other kids. To toughen him up, his mother suggests that his stepfather give him boxing lessons every Sunday afternoon, a ritual that Louis correctly perceives as ''a chance for Ben to hit me like he'd always wanted to, except that now Mom had given him permission.'' There are other miseries -- a racist schoolteacher, a run-in with a child molester, trips to what Louis's mother insists on calling an ''insane asylum'' for useless group therapy sessions -- all of which are recounted with artful observation and a quiet, slow-burning wit. At the somewhat happy ending, Louis gets accepted by an older, tougher kid he has a crush on, and who may even be gay. (The handling of sexual desire is subtle and sure here.) Wright's prose is sometimes too loyal to the tedium and aimlessness of adolescence: Louis's episodic adventures are disjointed and never pick up much momentum. Even so, you're always aware of how Wright's talents might flourish in a better-engineered narrative, and the absence of sentimentality is refreshing. Chase Madar

title: Shared Activities Bridge the Chasm Between Generations
description: IT may take the form of toddlers playing a game with an elderly person in a wheelchair. Or it may be able-bodied older people working on literacy skills with children at a clinic. It may be teenagers baking cookies and sharing stories with older residents from their hometown. Or it may be a choir in which the young and the old raise their voices together.

title: Jody Collins, Carter Lifton
description: Jody Lou Collins and Carter David Lifton were married yesterday by Msgr. Daniel P. Logan at Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

title: In Chinatown, More Choices Than You Might Think
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hobgoblins of Politics: Change and Consistency
description: AS Rice Krispie Treats sailed over John McCain's head -- lobbed by a reporter passing out snacks on the campaign bus -- the senator was asked how he had changed over the course of the campaign.

title: Fat Wallets, Slim Fits
description: As men are putting street fashions on ice in favor of a more bespoke look this season, the question arises: When wearing a suit for flash, where do you keep the plastic and the cash? A brick-size wallet weighing down a back pants pocket can make the sleekest Prada suit jacket look just plain lumpy. And so men's wallet designers have revived the breast-pocket wallet -- the wide, long bi-fold kind designed for an inside jacket pocket -- and have streamlined it for an even flatter fit. Newly tweaked versions of the classic include Coach's polished-calf breast pocket wallet ($150 at Coach stores), a Barneys New York brown calf checkbook-shape wallet ($175 at Barneys), Gucci's extra-thin black calf jacket wallet ($165 at Gucci stores) and a swanky old-fashioned version from Bergdorf Goodman in shiny brown (far right) or black alligator ($625 at the Bergdorf Goodman Men's Store). Despite the wallet's roominess, Patti O'Brien, fashion director at Rolling Stone, warns against overload. ''Keep it clean and uncluttered,'' she said, ''or you'll look like you have lopsided breasts, which is not a pretty look, for either a man or a woman.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: Jazz Latte
description: Each era's important jazz singers amplify the state of the music: how far it has come, how much it is appreciated. In the 40's, the trace of an uncouth honk in Billie Holiday's voice reminded her audience of jazz's demimonde roots. In the 50's, the virtuosity of Sarah Vaughan implied that jazz had become one of the fine arts. The strident rip in an Abbey Lincoln performance embodied jazz in the 60's -- politically ambitious, its structure undergoing major tremors. Diana Krall's dusky, deadpan contralto with its hairline cracks and her studious and tasteful swing might be jazz in 2000. It's gentle but firm, ready to negotiate with popular culture to be accepted through any possible doorway -- as jazz, pop, cabaret, whatever. And its thick layer of emotional neutrality serves to protect it from rejection.

title: Sports of The Times; When All of America Skated on Golden Pond
description: TWENTY years later, Ken Morrow remembered how his United States Olympic teammates jumped over the boards to celebrate Mike Eruzione's go-ahead goal against the Soviet Union, but Morrow, the bearded defenseman who would be on the Islanders' four consecutive Stanley Cup champions, stared at the scoreboard clock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANOFF, JUDITH
description: DANOFF-Judith. (Ignatoff). Age 80, died February 14 in her 60th year of marriage to devoted Abraham. Fighter for humanity. Dedicated teacher, former Director of Early Childhood Education, Kingsboro Community College. Her spirit lives in her children, Saul (Valerie) and Ann, grandchildren (Kimmer, Zachary, Joshua, Sonya, Isabel), and dear friends and students whose lives she touched. Donations in her memory can be sent to Kingsboro Community College Foundation, 2001 Oriental Blvd., Brooklyn, NY 11235.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on Feb. 6 about town houses in the East 50's that are being considered for landmark status misspelled the surname of a member of Community Board 5 who supports the designation. She is Joyce Matz, not Metz.

title: Return Visits Can Prove to Be a Pleasure
description: THINGS change. Nowhere is this more evident than in the restaurant business. Yesteryear's superstar is often today's has-been. There are so many reasons for a restaurant's decline: loss of celebrated chef, management inefficiency or absenteeism, premature expansion, staff arrogance. It happens. Because of such capriciousness, we now and then revisit restaurants we have enjoyed in the past, to see whether they have thrived or dived.

title: Searing Meat for Moistness and Looks
description: CHEFS in restaurants often ''mark'' meat and fish on top of the stove in a skillet and finish cooking it in the oven. Marking gives it a crisp finish and browned skin; the roasting keeps it moist and juicier than when everything is done under the grill.

title: POSTINGS: High Commercial Rents End a Planned Residential Conversion at 48 Wall Street; Offices to Apartments to Offices
description: Almost two years ago interior demolition was well under way on the 34-story former headquarters of the Bank of New York at 48 Wall Street, with the intention of converting it into 277 rental apartments. Instead, the tower -- topped by a soaring copper-plated eagle -- will remain an office building, although a greatly refurbished one.

title: Sundance Film Makes the Island Universal Backdrop
description: THE silent opening images of Eric Mendelsohn's film ''Judy Berlin,'' which premieres Feb. 25, are unmistakably evocative of Long Island: the railroad crossing, the high water tower, the low-slung light brick elementary school, the neat grid of suburban streets lined with vinyl-sided split-levels. But Mr. Mendelsohn, who won the directing award at the 1999 Sundance Film Festival for this black-and-white film, as well as the grand prize at the 1999 Hamptons International Film Festival, said that one reason for using these images was that they were not exclusive to Long Island.

title: From Classroom to Film Festival
description: They were never considered high cinema, but mental hygiene films, a staple of the post-war American classroom, aspired to the lofty goal of shaping young minds in a time of rapidly changing mores and cold-war uncertainty. So says Ken Smith, author of ''Mental Hygiene: Classroom Films 1945-1970.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Glyphs From the Bauhaus
description: When Anni Albers enrolled in 1922 at the Bauhaus, the German art-school-cum-laboratory of modern aesthetics, it wasn't quite progressive enough to admit a woman into the physically demanding painting workshop. Instead she was relegated to weaving. Yet doing something she considered ''as sissy as working with threads,'' Albers raised her textiles to the level of painting with spare abstract designs that were a radical departure from the decorative floral patterns or figural narratives of European tapestries. Her modular forms and improvisational glyphs echo the playful paintings of Paul Klee, who taught Albers a weaving course in which he encouraged students to exploit the innate checkerboard structure of the medium. Also inspirational were the Andean textiles that Albers collected on trips to Mexico and South America after coming to the United States in 1933 with her husband, Josef Albers, the acclaimed painter and color theorist. Her tactile masterpieces and later experiments with printmaking are beautifully presented in ANNI ALBERS (Guggenheim Museum/Abrams, $60), by Nicholas Fox Weber, the executive director of the Josef and Anni Albers Foundation, and Pandora Tabatabai Asbaghi, an independent curator. Weber's is the best of a handful of essays as succinct as the works they illuminate; he chronicles how he first met the aging couple in 1971, when he was 23, and became so close to Anni Albers that he would drive her to the cemetery to read her mail by her husband's grave (she outlived Josef by nearly two decades, dying in 1994 at the age of 94). Weber writes lovingly of how this devout modernist, who valued technology in everything from water-repellent fibers to plastic, and unexpectedly delighted in places like Sears and Kentucky Fried Chicken, would complain of ''craft people,'' saying ''they should simply look at what they were wearing to understand the value of mechanization.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Second Life for Flowers, Dry, Bright and Indoors
description: IT is the season for flowers past in my house. The myriad dried forms and shapes of last year's colorful bounty fill vases with elegant echoes of browns, rusts, purples, tans and silvers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, SOL
description: BRAVERMAN-Sol. Beloved husband of the late Marilyn. Devoted father of Richard, Ira and Randye. Cherished grandfather of Michele and Marc. Loving companion of Dorothy. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, LI.

title: No Such Meanings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTTAHEDEH, MILDRED R.
description: MOTTAHEDEH-Mildred R. on February 17, 2000. Distinguished leader in the decorative arts field and Bahai faith and friend of the disadvantaged peoples of the Third World. Beloved wife of the late Rafi Mottahedeh. Survived by her children Dr. Roy P. Mottahedeh of Brookline, MA and Peri Yusef of London, England. Loving grandmother of Melissa Halpern, Alexander Halpern, Stephanie Halpern, Rafi Mottahedeh and Rostam Mottahedeh and great grandmother of Jamie Waldman and Benjamin Halpern. Services will be held at Frank. E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, Febraury 20 at 11:30am. Contributions in her memory may be made to Mottahedeh Development Services Inc., 2370 Wesley Chapel Road, Decatur, GA 30035 for the Mildred R. Mottahedeh Memorial Fund for Scholarships to Children of the Third World.

title: Philippines
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane's article ''Sweet Deja Vu in the Philippines'' (Jan. 23) says ''Dumaguete doesn't have any real tourist attractions.'' Not so. Many people say that the Claire Isabel McGill Luce Auditorium (named for my late wife) at Silliman University is the best performance space in the Philippines outside of Manila.

title: Janus Capital Likes Apple
description: The Janus Capital Corporation, the white-hot mutual fund group, said it had raised its stake in Apple Computer to 9.99 million shares, or 6.1 percent of the computer maker's stock, as of the end of 1999.

title: E-Profs and E-Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Mother Nature'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSHEIN, MIRIAM
description: GOLDSHEIN - Miriam. Beloved wife of Herman, devoted mother of Mark and Sandy, adored grandmother of Laura and Steven. Died Saturday, Feb. 12, 2000. Her love of life, her kindness and generosity will be remembered by many.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Remembering Blue

title: The Enemy Of Our Enemy
description: Ahmed Chalabi, a Shiite Muslim from a prominent Baghdad family, is by turns haughty and brooding, princely and strangely preoccupied. In the cold weather, he goes about London in a goatskin robe, which he likes to flick grandly behind him, and Gore-Tex hiking boots. But while he may look like some tribal elder who wandered down from the hills (in trendy shoes), he holds a Ph.D. in mathematics from the University of Chicago and is fluent in several languages. He is also the closest thing either the Clinton administration or its Republican opponents have to a strategy for replacing the failed policy of containing Saddam Hussein.

title: Traffic Jams Around Paintings: Trying to Understand Dali
description: THE show of ''Dali's Optical Illusions'' at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is a crowd pleaser and a blockbuster, but soon after entering the exhibition it is clear that it is also is a baffler. With Salvador Dali it could not be any other way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIDON, LORETTA
description: VIDON-Loretta. All of us at the Donna Karan Company are deeply saddened at the loss of our very dear friend Loretta. She shared so much of herself-her passion and commitment. Loretta leaves behind a body of work which is her legacy. Althought she will be greatly missed, she will forever be with us in spirit.

title: More Coffee? Wonder What She Meant by That
description: The Verificationist

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Washington's Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be legally observed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, PHILLIP
description: CONHEIM-Phillip. February 21, 1944. In ever loving memory, Daughter Marilyn

title: Susan Rybak, Steven Feldman
description: Susan Helaine Rybak, who helps develop Web sites, and Steven David Feldman, a lawyer, are to be married today by Rabbi Herschel Cohen at Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York.

title: Islanders' Power Play Turns It Around Against the Devils
description: The Islanders' power play, ranked 26th in the National Hockey League, would not seem much of a challenge for the Devils' penalty-killing unit, which is the league's second best. But the Islanders made a mockery of those statistics this afternoon at Continental Arena.

title: Smoke and Mirrors; Ingenue Engineering
description: Toward the end of the 19th century, the United States government told a doleful public that the frontier was officially closed, and that nearly three centuries of steady westward expansion were now at an end. The public was crushed by this announcement, because the sense of unlimited freedom and potential for self-reinvention that the frontier had long conferred on the American people would now have to be replaced by things far less romantic, like trains, planes, money or alcohol. It was terribly sad, but the American people would just have to deal with it. And deal with it they did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIDT, TRUDE
description: SCHEIDT-Trude (Strauss). On February 2nd, 2000 at 94-1/2. Beloved wife of the late Willy, adored mother of Fred and Werner, mother-in-law of Roz, sister of Eugene Strauss, cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: The View From/Mount Vernon; Holding Young Offenders In a Place With No Bars
description: THE setting is far from elaborate: two modest houses on a street of light industry and empty buildings here, the rooms neat but in need of paint, cracks revealed by bleak florescent lighting. But, as one resident of the Youth Shelter Program of Westchester put it, ''It sure beats jail.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, WILLIAM E.
description: GARSON-William E. Died peacefully in his sleep, February 16, 2000 in Bryn Mawr, PA. Born NYC, December 7, 1908, fourth and last child of Daisy and Eli Garson. Survived by his beloved wife, Diana Hitschler Garson. His remarkably vigorous life spanned almost the entire 20th Century and included service in the U.S. Navy ''Seabees'' in WW II. During his 50-year career as an accomplished general contractor, he took delight in working for some of NY's most prominent and creative personages. He was a devoted member of the ''Y's Men'' of Westport, CT, where he lived for many years. He married five times and left numerous adoring children and stepchildren (Judy, Andy and Jeff Garson, Gail Tirana, Lee Oestreicher, Lynn Jeffrey and Laurie Lowenstein, Sandra Thompson, Wehn Hitschler and Pamela Nagy) grandchildren and great grandchldren. Memorial service Sunday, February 20, 3:00 PM, Beaumont at Bryn Mawr, PA, 601 North Ithan Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions to LSA Family Health Service, 426 East 119 St., NYC 10035 or P. Flag, PO Box 15711, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

title: Boise Journal; Idaho Seeking a More Tolerant Image
description: Greg Carr's native Idaho is a state well known for its spectacular wild beauty. But, he said, it also has a reputation as a haven for racists, an unfortunate distinction generated by white-supremacist groups that congregate in northern Idaho and exacerbated by the fact that it is one of the least ethnically diverse states in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISSELBACHER, ALFRED
description: ISSELBACHER-Alfred. An amusing and stimulating conversationalist, keen on life and ever ready to defend his views, even as a septuagenarian. He never complained and kept going, as best he could, until the end, even though circumstances became hard. He was a remarkable and attractive man and all who knew him were privileged. Dr. Alvin Weseley

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTHAL, LEONA
description: LEVENTHAL-Leona. On February 19, 2000. Beloved wife of Charles. Devoted mother of Terry and Marvin Lerman and the late Linda Warner. Adoring grandmother and great-grandmother. Cherished sister of Selma Schwartz. She was an elegant lady who was loving and kind. She will be in our hearts forever. Service Sunday 12:45 PM at the ''Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGENSTEIN, LILA
