description: DEGENSTEIN-Lila. On February 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Lester. Loving mother of Lee and his wife Joan. Adoring grandmother of David and Michael. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday, February 21, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Generally, the Coasts Still Pay the Most
description: Where you live continues to dictate how much you are paid, with salaries on the West and East Coasts again outpacing the national average, according to a new survey by William M. Mercer Inc., a compensation consulting company based in New York.

title: Unbuttoning Wall Street
description: In the elevators at the Goldman Sachs Group and other Wall Street firms, it is getting easier to pick out the investment bankers. More often, they are the ones without suits or ties.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: Queen Victoria died in 1901; President Clinton was acquitted by the Senate in 1999. Both events are extensively reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES GREAT STORIES OF THE CENTURY (Galahad Books, $29.99), a large-format collection of reproduced front pages from The Times that also includes all the ''jump'' matter -- the continuations of the Page 1 articles inside the paper and the various subordinate articles related to the main occasion. Students of the archaeology of news and of national sentiment may note that when Victoria died, the Arkansas House of Representatives adjourned out of respect, a Briton in Chicago renounced his allegiance to Edward VII, and the members of the McKinley cabinet offered their separate comments to the press. Many Great Stories in the collection are inevitable -- the Titanic, Lindbergh, Pearl Harbor, Men Walk on Moon -- but others show some real thinking as to what was of truly Great significance: New York-London telephone service (Jan. 8, 1927); ''Cigarettes Peril Health, U.S. Report Concludes'' (Jan. 12, 1964); the birth of the first test-tube baby (July 27, 1978).

title: Corruption Charges Swirling Around Japanese Premier
description: In this country's long history of embedded political corruption, few cases have enraged Japanese society more than the bribery and influence-peddling scandal that forced Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita to resign in disgrace 10 years ago.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Old Bridge Township, N.J.; Fast Growing, but With a Rural Ambience
description: ALTHOUGH it has been one of the fastest-growing municipalities in New Jersey over the last 30 years, Middlesex County's Old Bridge Township retains its country ambience. Two-thirds of its 42 square miles remain undeveloped and in the developed areas there are few sidewalks on the major thoroughfares.

title: The Diva Holds Court In Her Natural Habitat
description: IS the George Street Playhouse here revving up for the Diva Project in May?

title: Variations on the Familiar at a Harrison Grill
description: IF ''grill and bar'' conjures up dank, sticky corners and lardy burgers, perhaps Trinity has chosen its name unwisely. Or perhaps with its classically elegant decor and a few interesting variations on familiar themes -- pizzas, pasta, salads, burgers and main dishes -- Trinity seeks to reconstruct the concept of the neighborhood bar. For this restaurant is certainly something more: it is a welcoming place that draws family groups, which no doubt appreciate the menu's range, providing pizza or hamburgers for the young set and something a bit more sophisticated for adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENHOLT, ADELE
description: SCHOENHOLT-Adele. Wife of the late David L. Mother of Donald and Laura. Sister of Larna Donner, the late Ruth Krebs and Mildred Sherman. Loving ''Gran'' of David. In New York 2/15/2000.

title: The Biggest Chill
description: GHOSTS OF

title: Our Towns; Hiring a Guide Just to Find The Camp
description: NOW, you mentioned something tropical,'' Laurel Barrie said into the phone. ''Something along the lines of Belize or Puerto Rico?''

title: Signs of Life Stir in Trenton
description: From the Trenton Convention and Visitors Bureau, Sally Lane can see the parking lot that is supposed to turn into a Marriott and make her job easier. And recently signs appeared there warning of a street closing, the first move on the ground toward the first hotel that Trenton has had since 1985.

title: A Software Shortcut Is Drawing Attention
description: THEY are among the new, new things: application service providers, or A.S.P.'s, companies in the business of renting software to corporations over the Internet. And they have generated enormous buzz recently as their share prices have spiraled higher.

title: Good Clean Literary Fun for 400: A Jewish Exploration of Erotica
description: THE SETTING -- Symphony Space, at Broadway and West 95th Street, where some 400 people listened to authors and actors read Wednesday night from an anthology called ''Neurotica: Jewish Writers on Sex'' (W. W. Norton & Company, 1999). The evening, which concluded with wine and a book signing, was sponsored by the Jewish Community Center on the Upper West Side.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Japanese Fare a Stripe Above Average
description: PEARL HARBOR? An appetizer called Pearl Harbor at a Japanese restaurant? Unbelievable! We spotted it at Bonsai, a sweet and accommodating new storefront on Main Street in Port Washington. Should diners be advised to remember Pearl Harbor and order this startling opener, or give it a miss?

title: Topkapi: You Saw the Movie, Now See the Jewels
description: An exhibition of imperial jewels and other treasures from the Topkapi Palace in Istanbul, including many that have never before left the palace, will be seen this year in Washington, San Diego and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: THEATER; Mozart, Truth and the Demands of Drama
description: ''HISTORY repeats itself,'' wrote the English biographer Philip Guedalla, ''historians repeat one another.''

title: Challenging a Thesis
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Tourism
description: To the Editor: Regarding Sarah Ferrell's article ''If This Is Brooklyn, Why Ever Leave'' (Dec. 26), we agree the New York Marriott Brooklyn is comfortable, with excellent service. My husband and I spent a week there; we acted like tourists and visited with family. This is another answer to the question of who stays in a hotel in Brooklyn: grandparents who have children in the area.

title: The Mechanical Board Is Going. Gazing Will Stay.
description: THE 51,000-square-foot renovation of Pennsylvania Station being undertaken by New Jersey Transit is modest compared with a plan to turn half of the James A. Farley General Post Office across Eighth Avenue into a 360,000-square-foot station intended primarily for Amtrak.

title: In Search of the Long Island Soul
description: MAYBE the oddest thing about Eric Mendelsohn's likably odd debut feature, ''Judy Berlin,'' is that all the characters live on Long Island and nobody seems to hate it -- not even the title character (played by Edie Falco), who is about to leave for ''the coast'' in search of fame and fortune as an actress. This affectionate attitude might actually puzzle filmgoers who have become used to seeing suburbia portrayed as a sick, soul-destroying place, both in independent films like Todd Solondz's ''Welcome to the Dollhouse'' (1996) and ''Happiness'' (1998) and in studio pictures like Sam Mendes's recent awards-gatherer ''American Beauty.''

title: Fitting Tributes
description: Awards and honors all around the city.

title: Korean Fights For Coalition And His Aims As a Reformer
description: Two years into his five-year term as president, Kim Dae Jung is locked in a surprisingly ugly fight for his political life -- or at least to avoid having the remainder of his term turned into an ornamental presidency.

title: Open Wallets Greet Brooks At Mets Camp
description: Each of Al Leiter's 162 strikeouts cost him $100 last year, and the Mets left-hander was happy to pay it.

title: Top Dog for the New Millennium
description: A 5-year-old English Springer Spaniel named Ch. Salilyn 'N Erin's Shameless, who answers to Samantha, won the best-in-show competition at the 124th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Hip Vs. Stately: The Tao Of Two Museums
description: AS two of the most prominent figures in the New York art world, Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Thomas Krens, the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, oversee distinct and often opposing museum models. The Manhattan-bound Met, ensconced in Central Park, and the global Guggenheim, with branches in four countries. The encyclopedic Met, whose territory covers five millenniums, and the contemporary Guggenheim, an evangelist for modern art. The stately Met, which attracts huge crowds for exhibitions on Impressionism, ancient Egypt and Renaissance art, and the hip Guggenheim, where spectacles like ''The Art of the Motorcycle'' and jazz on Fridays are as big a draw as scholarly shows.

title: In a Flash, He's Venezuela's Favorite Son
description: In Venezuela, there is baseball royalty. Then there is Melvin Mora, king of kings.

title: A Series of Tornadoes Rip Through Georgia
description: Residents of southwest Georgia awoke to the sound of wind and snapping pines, and most had little chance to escape the deadliest tornadoes to strike the state in more than 50 years. The twisters killed 18 people, injured more than 100 and destroyed 258 houses, causing an estimated $20 million in property losses. KEVIN SACK

title: The Have-Nots; Casting Calls
description: When you see the name Merrill Markoe (which, by the way, means ''great entertainment'' in Ukrainian), you probably immediately think of some of my most beloved roles from TV and film. Like Marsha, the irritable museum employee from episode No. 2 of ''Friends.'' Or the TV panelist next to Michael Moore in ''EDtv.'' (I've been told that those who have heard me deliver the last lines in the movie -- ''I give him six months. He is the macarena.'' -- have said they've come away feeling somehow changed for the better.) But how, you may wonder, did I get these opportunities? This brings me neatly to our topic: the nightmare that is the auditioning process.

title: Another World
description: The universe is expanding at an increasing rate, and the reason may be a force from another universe. Dr. Andreas Albrecht, a cosmologist at the University of California in Davis, and his colleague, Constantinos Skordis, have published a paper showing that a ubiquitous energy named quintessence could inflate the known universe like a balloon. ''Quintessence is a very ghostly thing,'' said Dr. Nima Arkani-Hamed, who with his colleagues has presented evidence of how it might function within the 10 dimensions predicted by superstring theory, which suggests that all matter is made from small vibrating strings. JAMES GLANZ

title: For Gay Singer, Songs In Chord of Understanding
description: THE lighthouse overlooking the Atlantic Highlands once guided mariners home with its powerful beams. Tom McCormack, a singer and songwriter who lives nearby along the windswept coast, also helps people find their way through rough waters.

title: How to Add New Dog To Resident Dog's Turf
description: THERE can be repercussions when another dog or puppy enters an existing dog's household. How best to deal with them?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, MARGARET A.
description: DAWSON-Margaret A. At age 96, on February 17, 2000. Died at home at Signal Mountain, TN where a memorial mass will be held. Formerly of Brooklyn and for decades, a teacher in the NYC public schools. Beloved sister of the late Bernadette U. Dawson. Loving aunt of Martha D. King of Albuquerque, NM, Joseph S. Dawson of Boca Raton, FL and George Fletcher of NYC, and many great-nieces and nephews. Graveside service was held at St. John's Cemetery, Queens, NY. For further information: Clavin Funeral Home, 718-745-1445.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-20-00: On Language; Say What?
description: 'Why don't you incorporate a running endnote feature on anachronisms in movie scripts?'' suggests Hendrik Hertzberg, senior editor of The New Yorker. (I tell him how to edit his magazine; he tells me how to write my column. Our readers benefit mightily.) My anachronism file is limited to the classic example of Cassius' mention of a clock striking in Shakespeare's ''Julius Caesar,'' set in a time before clocks had been invented. Fortunately, Hertzberg includes a specific example to enliven his broad policy guidance.

title: Towns Maneuver to Protect Scenic Roads
description: IT was a breezy, gray day in January when 21 wild turkeys trotted their prehistoric-looking black bodies down Stilson Hill Road in New Milford, past a large yellow and green diamond-shaped sign that reads ''Scenic Road, 15 M.P.H.'' A few sounds competed with the turkeys: whinnying horses, the wind in the trees, everything one would expect to hear on a back road in Litchfield County.

title: Gore Sees Gains From Party Spat
description: Even before results of the South Carolina primary were known, Vice President Al Gore declared the day a victory for Democrats, saying that Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain had badly wounded each other in the hotly contested Republican race.

title: That Grumpy Old Pianist Is Ives
description: ON four occasions -- in 1933, 1938 and 1943, and at another uncertain date in the mid-30's -- a frail, ailing, wealthy retired insurance company executive named Charles Ives was led into recording studios to play and record the piano music he had been composing on weekends for several decades. The earliest of these recordings were made on soft aluminum Speak-O-Phone discs, the later ones on lacquer-coated discs. Few people suspected at the time what a vast and history-changing body of works those pounded-out snippets of music represented. Who knew that this crusty, eccentric, rapidly aging man banging away at the piano and muttering under his breath would one day be hailed as the greatest American composer?

title: Political Briefing; For Reform Party, More Turmoil
description: In the aftermath of last weekend's free-for-all in Nashville, where Ross Perot forces snatched back control of the Reform Party from allies of Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, a move is afoot to draft Mr. Perot for a third run for president.

title: Bradley Seeks To Get a Push In Northwest
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley's struggle to keep his presidential campaign alive seems to hinge increasingly on this state's primary.

title: Follow the Phony Money
description: A CONSPIRACY OF PAPER

title: An Online Matchmaker Of Athletes and Schools
description: WHEN someone makes a big profit on Wall Street, traders like to say, ''Don't confuse brains with a bull market.'' And when a corporate climber in most any field hits a home run, business friends are apt to attribute it to being in the right place at the right time.

title: The Recycled Generation
description: What a wonderful and, dare I say, sexy shot of the octogenarian on your contents page. How delightful to see a woman at that age so comfortable in her own skin.

title: Celebrating Life
description: To the Editor:

title: The Grand Exit
description: How does it feel to tell the boss you're leaving? More and more workers are finding out, as the record-setting economic boom creates more jobs and job-hopping. Some people go with a laugh, some with a snarl, some with a dash of creativity. What has been your most memorable manner of leaving a job? Or the most striking voluntary departure you have witnessed? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Schneider Vineyards, Not in Name Only
description: SIX years after its founding, Schneider Vineyards brought its label to earth on Monday when the owners, Bruce and Christiane Baker Schneider, bought a 22-acre potato farm in Riverhead.

title: To the Manner True
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheila Curry, Graham Oakes
description: Sheila Marie Curry and Graham Thomas Oakes, who met while playing squash, were married yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club in New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Cannes
description: Ever since 1834, when the Lord Chancellor of England, Lord Brougham, accidentally discovered a minor fishing hamlet on his way to Nice, Cannes has been synonymous with luxury tourism. Legions of aristocrats, fleeing the snows of London and Moscow in favor of the brilliant blue skies and temperate winters of the Cote d'Azur, followed his lead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, AARON M.
description: WEINER-Aaron M. Of Wayne, NJ, formerly of Elizabeth, NJ. On Friday, February 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Jill and her husband Marc. Dear brother of Rose Grossman. Proud grandfather of Danielle and Jessica. Graveside service 1 PM, today, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ.

title: I.N.S. Bars Catholic Group From Counseling Detainees
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has barred a group of Roman Catholic counselors from detention centers in the New York area in what the group is calling an effort to limit asylum seekers' access to advocacy organizations.

title: Shooting Stars; Wrap artist
description: Ali MacGraw never made a dime off the knit caps that everyone wore when ''Love Story'' was released. She never capitalized on the slouchy-chic style that she and Steve McQueen effortlessly brought into vogue -- and Vogue -as a couple. She never profited from the ''Dynasty'' faux couture that swept the country when she was part of that ensemble. So fashion might owe her a little something. Today, in fact -- 30 years since she was at the center of the fashion universe -- the former stylist, cover girl and assistant to Diana Vreeland at Harper's Bazaar is testing exactly how much her celebrity and vibrant personal style are worth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHER, WILLIAM J.
description: ASHER-William J., Innovator. Bill Asher passed away on February 10, 2000, but not before marrying a lovely lady, producing three wonderful daughters and leading an accomplished career in chemical engineering. He left us after an allout brawl with cancer. He was 65. After winning the Westinghouse National Science Talent Search, Bill earned a B.S. in Chemical Engineering from Purdue University, and a M.S. from Ohio State. Bill spent 29 years at Exxon Research in New Jersey, and was most recently a Chemical Engineer at SRI International in Menlo Park, CA. He is the holder of 27 patents in diverse areas including petroleum and chemical processes, and biomedical advancements. His first patents covered a process for recovering raw materials for biodegradable detergents. He held patents in the biomedical field for the invention of artificial blood and an alternative to kidney dialysis. And recently, he invented an entirely new type of chemical reactor that can be applied to dozens of chemical and petroleum processes. Bill's personal interests were as diverse as his career accomplishments. He was a jazz, wine, sports car, and radio-controlled model airplane enthusiast. Bill is survived by his wife Claire, daughter Lynn, son-in-law Ed; daughter Pam, son-in-law David and their two daughters; and daughter Brenda.

title: Library in Great Neck To Keep Vote Separate
description: Great Neck voters have rejected a much-debated proposal to change the date of the vote for library trustees and the budget, which is traditionally in January, to coincide with the school district election in May. Of the 1,227 votes cast in the Jan. 24 balloting, including nearly 500 by proxy, 57 percent of the voters opposed the change, while 43 percent approved of it.

title: Olgita DeCastro, Singer With Sister Group, 65
description: Olgita DeCastro, who performed and recorded with her famous singing cousins, the DeCastro Sisters, for more than 30 years, died on Monday at her home in Las Vegas. She was 65.

title: Q. & A.
description: 'Friends' Staying In a Co-op

title: The College Application Frenzy
description: To the Editor:

title: Rapunzel's Offspring Are Cashing In
description: AT Nina America on West 27th Street, identical female mannequin heads with large vacant eyes and saucy smiles line the office shelves, an army of faces topped with wigs, from flaxen curls to purplish pageboys. Amid stacks of cardboard boxes from China, employees work the phones, brokering human hair.

title: The In-Laws
description: Make Believe By Joanna Scott. 246 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Company. $23.95.

title: PAINT COMPANY CLOSINGS
description: Benjamin Moore and Company, the Montvale-based paint manufacturer and retailer, announced last week that it will close 8 of its 15 plants and reconfigure its distribution centers. The 20 employees at the company's Newark distribution facility will be moved to a new warehouse in Moonachie; manufacturing operations at the company's flagship Newark plant and the 130 people employed there will not be affected, according to Eileen McComb, a company spokeswoman. Production at Technical Coatings Company, a subsidiary in Nutley, will be consolidated with that at the existing plant in Melrose Park, Ill., but all 20 employees will be offered jobs at either the Newark or Moonachie locations, she said. KRISTEN MARTIN

title: True Hospital Crisis: Nurse-to-Patient Ratio
description: The article on St. John's Hospital's near-death experience [''Finding a Cure for 'Angry Nurse' Syndrome,'' Feb. 13] describes a symptom of an acute crisis in hospital care, not just on Long Island but throughout New York State. The ratio of skilled, experienced nurses to patients is perhaps the key issue to focus on when evaluating how healthy our hospitals are now.

title: Mubarak Visits Lebanon, Offering Support After Israeli Raids
description: President Hosni Mubarak made an unexpected visit today to Lebanon to demonstrate Egypt's support in the wake of Israeli bombing raids that destroyed three Lebanese power plants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, NELLIE
description: SMITH-Nellie. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nellie Smith, associated with The Times from 1951 until retiring in 1976.

title: Rockies' Off-Season Was Exhausting One
description: The caller solicitously inquired about the general manager's health. Was he all right, was he feeling O.K.? Yes, Dan O'Dowd replied, puzzled at the question. Well, he was told, you haven't made a trade for five weeks.

title: Good to Be a Nerd
description: Geeks

title: Hispanic Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates For Reform Show Gains In Iran Tallies
description: Strategists for Iran's reformers said today that early election results suggested that the president, Mohammad Khatami, might have a majority behind him in the new Parliament to make good on his promises of creating a more liberal society after 21 years of rule by puritanical Islamic clerics.

title: Tightening Admissions In Condos
description: MORE and more frequently, condominium boards in New York City are acting like co-op boards in screening potential buyers, according to brokers, lawyers and managing agents, a pattern that seems to conflict with one of the primary reasons that condominiums frequently sell for more than similar co-ops.

title: St. Anthony's Sweeps Titles
description: St. Anthony's High School of South Huntington, N.Y., swept the boys' and girls' titles in the Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association cross-country championships last fall. Yesterday the Long Island school duplicated that feat in the C.H.S.A.A. indoor championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan. The St. Anthony's boys tallied 45 points in first with Mount St. Michael of the Bronx second (27). The St. Anthony's girls garnered 41 points in defending their title, with Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn second (27).

title: Legacy; Growing up Weitz
description: 'It was the middle 60's, and I was going back and forth on the train to Richmond, where I am from,'' says the author Tom Wolfe, recalling the moment he first met John Weitz. ''It was a crowded train, and people were walking past. I noticed out of my peripheral vision that this man had stopped in front of me. He looked down and, in this British voice, said, 'Awfully good-looking socks you're wearing.' I thought this was rather cheeky. Then I saw his face and realized it was John Weitz.'' It turned out that Weitz had designed the socks. ''I remember them very well,'' Wolfe says. ''They were a checkerboard design in aubergine and pumpkin.''

title: Taking a New Look At Some Easy Targets
description: Maybe Harold S. Geneen -- the architect behind the ITT Corporation's foray into, well, just about everything -- was right, after all.

title: A Rebound, Then a Basket, And St. John's Tops Syracuse
description: Lavor Postell knew it was an ugly shot -- an across-the-body shot from the right baseline that skittered near the top of the backboard. Reggie Jesse did not think about pretty. He got his hands on the rebound and volleyballed it back on the glass. When it fell, with just 28.9 seconds left, the St. John's faithful really could not be blamed for the guttural growl that accompanied the ball as it fell through the net.

title: A New Avant-Garde
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: 'Boiler Room' Critics Find A Debit Even in the Credits
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, has seen a few financial schemes in his time. As the lead local prosecutor in the world's financial capital, he has battled frauds like the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, which stole billions of dollars from investors worldwide. So Mr. Morgenthau seemed perfect to review ''Boiler Room,'' the film about penny-stock abuses on Long Island that opened Friday.

title: Joachim-Ernst Berendt, 77, Jazz Historian
description: Joachim-Ernst Berendt, a German writer who was best known as a jazz critic but who was also a radio and concert producer and the author of books on nature and acoustical phenomena, died Feb. 4 in Hamburg, Germany. He was 77.

title: The Port Authority Reverses a Case of Terminal Ugliness
description: It was a classic case of a neglectful landlord allowing a building to slide. Only in this case the landlord was the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and the building was the George Washington Bridge Bus Station in Washington Heights.

title: Digging Up the Surreal Underside of Ordinary Life
description: UNDER storm clouds late one August afternoon, the photographer Gregory Crewdson and his swarm of assistants had overrun Tabar Avenue here, transforming the tiny street lined with a dozen 1950's prefabricated houses into a film set. By hooking up cables to the circuit breakers of the homes, Mr. Crewdson had managed to flood the entire neighborhood with cinematic lighting and roily gusts from a fog machine. The photographer directed a cameraman, poised in a cherry picker overhead, to point an 8-by-10-inch view camera at the scene below.

title: High Payout, Little Payoff With Rangers' Free Agents
description: For Theo Fleury, the frustration has increased to the point where broken hockey sticks have turned into obscene gestures. For Valery Kamensky, the frustration stems from what he perceives as not enough ice time.

title: INSIDE
description: Gains for Iranian Reformers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNHEIMER, RUDOLPH
description: STERNHEIMER-Rudolph Max. Suddenly on February 16, 2000 at age 73. Retired Senior Physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory where he worked for over 40 years. Beloved husband of Betty Sternheimer. Dear brother of Paul Sternheimer and his wife Hanne and Michael Sternheimer and his wife Karine. Devoted uncle of John, Philip, William and Jennifer Sternheimer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Saturday, Sunday and Monday 2-5 PM with services Tuesday 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Computer Merger Seen Generating 5,000 Jobs
description: Computer Associates International of Islandia announced last week that it would take over Sterling Software of Dallas for $4 billion in stock, making it the largest buyout in the software industry.

title: BUSH HALTS McCAIN IN SOUTH CAROLINA BY DRAWING A HUGE REPUBLICAN VOTE
description: Gov. George W. Bush surged to victory in the South Carolina primary today, reclaiming his spot as the unmistakable front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination. But Senator John McCain vowed to persevere, warning that if Mr. Bush was nominated, the Republicans would lose in November.

title: Separate but Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Trade Meeting Brings Rich and Poor No Closer
description: A United Nations conference on developing nations concluded today with expressions of good will but no real narrowing of the differences that split a meeting of the World Trade Organization in Seattle in December.

title: THE WORLD: Beirut, Meet Tehran; A Time of Testing for Islamic Zeal
description: A GROUP of hard-eyed men from Hezbollah, the Party of God, were driving an American correspondent down a narrow road outside this village in southern Lebanon last week when the visitor pointed through the open car window toward an Israeli fortification high on a rocky hill to the south.

title: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks; Cashing In on an Alternative
description: In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.

title: A Former Club Kid Takes Office in Washington
description: IT was once a private home, but now the four-floor white building at the intersection of Wisconsin Avenue and Porter Street is filled with studios, offices and dressing rooms. In a way it is still a home, but now to the Washington School of Ballet, founded in 1944 by Mary Day and Lisa Gardiner, and the Washington Ballet, founded by Ms. Day in 1976.

title: 2 Pillars of Neo-Punk Life: Art and Pizza
description: For years, the two independent filmmakers who own the pizzeria Two Boots on Avenue A simply served food. Then, true to their artistic roots and the East Village temperament, they opened a video store next door that specializes in art and independent films. In the video store's basement, they created a performance space and lounge called the Den of Cin.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Searching for Syria

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, ALEX
description: GREENFIELD-Alex (Craig), age 42, February 4th, of a heart attack. Survived by his parents, Don and Elaine of Monroe Twp., NJ, two sisters, Sharon Priore and Gayle Glasson, and niece, Melanie. Services were held February 7th.

title: Foster Care Report
description: A report issued by the nonprofit Westchester Children's Association, based in White Plains, calls for changes in the foster care system to move children more quickly into permanent homes.

title: The Man Who Created the Kid In Us All
description: Charles M. Schulz, the creator of the comic strip ''Peanuts,'' died Saturday night, Feb. 12, just hours before his last comic ran. He was 77. The strip was 50.

title: High Yield Starts Fast on Road to Derby
description: High Yield, a well-traveled son of Storm Cat who traveled from California to Florida this week, won the Fountain of Youth stakes at Gulfstream Park today and took the lead among this season's 3-year-old horses traveling the tortuous road to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EFFMAN, KARLIN, TESSIE
description: EFFMAN - KARLIN - Tessie. Be loved wife of the late Hyman Effman and Reuben Karlin. Loving companion of Sandor Herskovitz. Beloved mother of Norman and Paul. Cherished mother-in-law of Joan and Kathryn. Dear sister of Rose Benjamin Rubin and the late Ethel Ochs and Sadie Haimowitz. Adored grandmother of Jason, Hutch, Lucy and Jesse. Cherished great-grandmother of Zachary. Services and interment were held Friday, February 18th, 2000.

title: 'Cats,' Broadway's Longevity Champ, to Close
description: After almost 18 years, $380 million in sales and untold gallons of makeup, ''Cats,'' the longest-running production in Broadway history, will close on June 25.

title: Guy Waterman Dies at 67; Wrote Books About Hiking
description: Guy Waterman, who wrote books about hiking in the New England mountains and the preservation of their purity, died on Feb. 6. He was 67 and lived in East Corinth, Vt.

title: You Can't Keep A Good Bagel Man Down
description: Three years ago, seven of the eight Manhattan bagel shops that Lyn Moore owned and ran were bought out. Less than a month ago, Mr. Moore and two new partners, Howard Mofshin and Larry Shatzkamer, opened New York Bagel and Bean at 644 Lexington Avenue (near 54th Street). The menu includes overstuffed sandwiches ($3.50 to $5.50), wraps ($4.95) and of course bagels ($7.50 a dozen). Mr. Moore and his partners plan to renovate the bagel store at 828 Seventh Avenue (53rd Street) that Mr. Moore still owns. ALLISON FASS

title: Making Music Urgent in the Electronic Age
description: THE San Francisco Symphony, which has made tours of Europe and Asia, is back on the road. This time it is appearing in 13 United States cities, including New York at Carnegie Hall this week, and in Newark at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on Friday. Its programs are designed to show -- a little -- the skill spectrum of the orchestra's director, Michael Tilson Thomas.

title: Discovering Art With the Aura Of the Outsider
description: WITH a background in music, chemistry and 18th-century English literature, Phyllis Kind became an art dealer by accident.

title: Patricia Neumann, Mark Pawlak
description: Patricia Rowan Neumann and Mark Richard Pawlak were married yesterday by Msgr. John J. Rowan, a cousin of the bride, at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York.

title: Campus Sexual Assault
description: To the Editor:

title: Natural Foods, Certified Organic
description: Natural Frontier Market now has three locations on Third Avenue. The newest opened at 266 Third Avenue (between 21st and 22nd Streets) three weeks ago. The original has been at 162 Third Avenue (16th Street) since 1995. Another one has been at 1424 Third Avenue (81st Street) for almost two years.

title: In Bonnie and Clyde Style, Pair Hits Small Stores
description: A pair of robbers have held up convenience stores on the Upper East Side four times in the last month, the police said. The plunderings are reminiscent of Bonnie and Clyde: a man swoops in with a handgun while a woman wearing a raincoat stands watch.

title: Excerpts from McCain's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from Senator John McCain's concession speech in Charleston, S.C., last night as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Dona Carter, Charles McGee
description: Dona Summers Carter and Charles Edward McGee, jazz musicians, were married on Valentine's Day by the Rev. Lenton Gunn Jr. at St. James Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: IN BRIEF; Lake Success Residents Vote $8.5 Million Bond
description: By a vote of 485 to 365, residents of the Village of Lake Success approved an $8.5 million bond resolution last week to build a new community center and village hall.

title: Downtown Critics Pan Legal Work in Diallo Case
description: In the hallways of the sprawling Manhattan Criminal Courts Building, lawyers have long made a sport of griping about judges' decisions, gossiping about their colleagues' performances and engaging in Monday morning trial quarterbacking. Over the last two weeks, the focus of courthouse chatter has turned northward, to the trial of the four New York police officers who killed Amadou Diallo.

title: The Invisible Children
description: If there is a political issue that has stirred young people in America in recent years, it is the exploitation of child labor overseas. College students have organized to ensure that their university's athletic wear is not sewn by children. Elementary school classes have petitioned Disney and Nike to keep children out of their factories. Because of consumer clout and the importance of reputation to American manufacturers, child labor in their factories overseas has indeed diminished.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Anthony Baratta's New York apartment, completed in 1998, is probably the fullest embodiment of the designer's Mixmaster approach to decorating. Where else would you find 19th-century classical plaster casts, a Victorian sofa covered in harlequin-print wool, a leopard-print sofa on a plaid carpet and a white-leather-covered 1950's ottoman -- all in one room?

title: Counting Flamingos on Great Inagua
description: THIRTY minutes into a jarring ride along a maze of rubble-strewn dikes flanked by shallow salt pans on the southern fringe of Inagua National Park in the Bahamas, the warden, Henry Nixon, pulled the Ford pickup to a stop at a little rise and cut the engine. There was a merciful, joltless silence. Beyond us, hidden by a thick bank of red mangrove, was another hypersaline lake from which I heard one plaintive honk and knew I was about to see what I had come to Great Inagua for: the West Indian Flamingo, second largest of the world's five species of flamingos. Thirty thousand nesting pairs -- more than 60,000 birds -- congregate on this southernmost island of the Bahamas from November to July.

title: Playing It the Company Way, After Hours
description: MANAGEMENT at the Bank of America thought it had a winner. In a program called ''Adopt an A.T.M.,'' begun last June, the bank asked employees to volunteer to look after one of its automated teller machines and to keep the machine's surroundings gleaming with pride -- on their own time and without pay.

title: Benefit of Reputation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Commercial Property/Westchester and Fairfield Counties; Starting Work on Office Projects to Attract Tenants
description: CALL it the developers' dilemma. Lenders want tenants signed to long-term leases before they are prepared to provide capital for the construction of new office buildings. But prospective tenants want to see something more than an architect's rendering and some building plans before making a commitment.

title: Trek West, Commuters, Trek West
description: IT is not the run-down condition of the western end of Penn Station, nor the suffocatingly low ceilings on the New Jersey Transit platforms, nor the last-minute track information that bothers Kris Martin most about her daily commute to Manhattan.

title: THE WORLD: Moda Italiana; Getting Creative About the News
description: TO illustrate an article about a recent conference on breast cancer prevention, Il Messaggero, the daily newspaper, splashed across its front page a picture of a sultry nude starlet, Sabrina Ferilli, reclining on a hammock, touching her breast and wearing a come-hither look that does not seem directed at an oncologist.

title: Crime
description: When it comes time for a great detective to pack up and go, he deserves a decent elegy, and that's what Colin Dexter has given Inspector Morse in THE REMORSEFUL DAY (Crown, $24), the 13th and final book in a series that raised the bar for genre writing. Not since Nero Wolfe has a detective of Morse's ratiocinative skills, refined tastes and tetchy temperament held court in such magisterial fashion.

title: Be It Home or Hardware, a Woman's Place
description: TWENTY-FOUR years ago, when Dorothy Knobel Somogyi began working in her father's hardware store in Darien called Knobel Brothers, customers would ask her, ''Is there a man here that knows something?''

title: Helping Minority Students to Be Teachers
description: IF it had not been for the Today's Students, Tomorrow's Teachers program, Emerly Martinez would not be a student teacher at Ossining High School. He would not be a native son come home to herald the success of a career development program for minorities.

title: The Big Remake
description: Fourteen directors, one question: ''If you could cast any contemporary actress in any role, what would it be?''

title: Tammy Jo Chardavoyne, Steven Sanders
description: Tammy Jo Chardavoyne and State Assemblyman Steven Sanders are to be married today at the National Arts Club in Manhattan. Justice Stephen G. Crane of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is to perform the ceremony.

title: Where Clean and Sober Includes a Hairdo
description: HER eyes didn't match the rather ordinary details conveyed in a cursory glance: a middle-aged woman, small pieces of jewelry, demure sweater set, tentative posture. Her eyes had seen hell.

title: In Grozny, Historic Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: Monitoring Air Traffic of the Feathered Variety
description: Just off the Clearview Expressway in Bayside, Queens, Aline Euler has created a welcoming backyard. From a sprawling sycamore, three bird feeders hang, one full of the premium thistle seed that attracts finches. There are sunflower hearts for the chickadees and, a few trees to the left, a suet feeder that attracts downy woodpeckers and starlings.

title: Lives, Letters, Portraits and Passions
description: THE cellist Harry Clark, a founder of Chamber Music Plus, has produced several programs based on the lives and letters of artistic personalities. Describing the events variously as ''parallel portraits'' and ''a marriage of historical fiction and the art of chamber music,'' Mr. Clark has invited actors to join with singers and instrumentalists in pursuit of ''the most intimate and passionate music, along with interconnections among the great artists who produced it.''

title: In Watching Hong Kong, China Loses The Shades
description: The red wine flowed and the buffet tables groaned with Chinese delicacies like duck's tongue and webbed feet in mustard sauce. Sir Run Run Shaw, Li Ka-shing and other legendary local tycoons mingled easily with their mainland Chinese hosts, while members of Hong Kong's Democratic Party peered around the ballroom like paratroopers caught behind enemy lines.

title: Art Girls Just Wanna Have Fun
description: Why is it that when the magazine covers a young male artist like Matthew Barney whose work is, to put it tactfully, not very deep, he's viewed as important, brilliant? Yet when you write about women who are also exploring erotic imagery and questions of surface, they are ''bad girls'' who ''just wanna have fun''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOTTMAN, ROBERTA A.
description: ZOTTMAN-Roberta A., a New York native and member of the Daughters of the American Revolution, died on January 24, 2000, of a stroke in Sacramento, CA. She was 93. Mrs. Zottman received her nursing degree from Montefiore Hospital School of Nursing in New York City in 1928, and practiced for 50 years as a private duty nurse. Born in Ausable Chasm, NY, on January 5, 1907, Mrs. Zottman lived and worked in New York until 1970, when she relocated to Sacramento, CA. Mrs. Zottman is survived by a son and several grandchildren. Mrs. Zottman will be interred at the Woodstock Hill Cemetery in Woodstock, CT.

title: Marbury's Special Birthday
description: Home for Stephon Marbury was never really the icy terrain of Minnesota, where he started his National Basketball Association career and spent the first two and a half seasons of his career. He lived in an apartment, refusing to buy a house in a place he knew he wanted to leave.

title: Q & A
description: A Day in Brussels

title: Among Mideast Barriers, the Tiniest of Passions: The Bee
description: There is a quiet cult of the bee in the land of milk and honey, and beekeepers, be they Israeli or Palestinian, are the high priests of the hive.

title: Cher! Neil Diamond! Aerosmith! (Not)
description: Apparently being a model who is ''a lot of fun to work with'' was just not enough for Jennifer Lintz. So she applied to compete on ''Your Big Break,'' the hourlong show on which ''regular people become their favorite singers using their own real voices to do it.''

title: Silent Movies
description: There are certain things about John Cassavetes films that have made them, repeatedly, an irresistible inspiration for Terry Richardson. Their realness. Their melancholy. ''The way he shows people going a little crazy,'' explains Richardson, who shot the real and melancholy cover and opening pages of this issue. ''He shows elements of human behavior a lot of people don't show. They're a little depressing, those films.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEEKER, HELEN LENNARD
description: BLEEKER-Helen Lennard, of Cresskill on February 15th, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harold Lennard and the late Nat Bleeker. Dear sister of Lester Bethill and the late Sidney Bethill, Lillian Blum and Emma Klein. Services were held Thursday. For information, ''Wien & Wien'', 800-322-0533.

title: Enraged Riders in Brooklyn Heights
description: Residents say the city does not need to shut the Clark Street subway station for four months for elevator repairs. With other reports from Clinton, the Upper East and West Sides, Harlem, Sheepshead Bay, Greenpoint, Bay Ridge, Riverdale and Mott Haven.

title: Millet and the Poet
description: To the Editor: My experience in Williamstown, Mass., at the Clark Art Institute retrospective of the work of the French painter Millet last summer paralleled Martha K. Baker's article ''What the Docents Don't Know'' (Jan. 30).

title: Headless Body!
description: The Missing Head of Damasceno Monteiro

title: The Recycled Generation
description: The possibility seems real that stem-cell research may offer something more valuable than simply allowing us to spend 50 years in Sun City, but the ethical issues are real as well. However, thanks to Representative Jay Dickey, there is no public money to ensure public scrutiny or debate -- and we know how flexible ethics can become when they get in the way of private profits

title: Room Service
description: This season's sexiest clothes -- from wrap blouses to hot pants -- were clearly inspired by the chic films of the 60's, in which the gorgeously bored were often stranded in hotel rooms, with only cards and sexual games to pass the time.

title: It's Almost 'All Aboard' For Light Rail In Hudson
description: NO passengers were waiting as the new New Jersey Transit train eased into the 45th Street station in Bayonne. It was just a test run; the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail line is set to begin service next month or in early April, connecting Bayonne and Jersey City with the PATH lines at Exchange Place. On Wilson Street in Jersey City, local emergency workers took part in a disaster drill. The control room, below left, is ready. Rails stretch through downtown Jersey City, far left. Ticket machines have been installed at the 12 stations; fares will be announced this week. Next year, service will be extended to Hoboken, and by 2006, into lower Bergen County.

title: Lynda Beenstock, Daniel Bursky
description: Lynda Beenstock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Beenstock of Cheshire, England, is to be married today to Daniel Jay Bursky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman A. Bursky of Lawrence, N.Y. Gabriel Brodie, the spiritual leader of the Great and New Synagogue in Manchester, England, is to officiate with Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman at the Mere Golf and Country Club in Cheshire.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Realm of Secondhand Souls

title: Corrections
description: The View column on Feb. 6, about the 70th anniversary of a music school in White Plains, misstated its name and its relationship to Mercy College of Dobbs Ferry. The school is the Music Conservatory of Westchester, not the Westchester Conservatory of Music. It collaborates with Mercy to offer a Bachelor of Science degree; it is not an accredited branch of Mercy's music department.

title: Trees, Terrain and Sunlight Vs. 12 Upscale Row Houses
description: A proposal to build 12 row houses along the Henry Hudson Parkway is meeting stiff opposition from local residents, and the developer is considering scaling back the plan.

title: Iona Hires Officer
description: In an effort to reduce off-campus drinking, rowdy behavior, littering, noise and other infractions, Iona College in New Rochelle has hired an off-duty police officer to patrol the neighborhood around the college on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays from midnight to 4 a.m. when bar traffic on nearby North Avenue is intense.

title: A Funds Scandal Shrinks To a Shadow of Itself
description: IN the same federal courthouse where Kenneth Starr's grand jury met, Maria Hsia, an obscure California immigration consultant, sits silently at the defense table dressed in a neat yellow sweater set and black skirt.

title: Art Girls Just Wanna Have Fun
description: I suspect the black tape did just as much to make the artwork naughty as if you'd left if off.

title: Danish Design Center Moves Into a New Home
description: The Danish Design Center, a showcase for Danish and international industrial design and graphic arts, moved to new headquarters overlooking Tivoli Gardens in Copenhagen on Jan. 10. The five-story building, created by a Danish architect, Henning Larsen, is clad with an energy-conserving double-glass screen that provides natural climate control.

title: The New Bohemians: Tourists Without a Cause
description: BEING a young American pursuing ''la vie de boheme'' isn't what it used to be. After the image of the bohemian merged with that of the hippie, and a once-marginal drug culture invaded American high schools, the cliches of the urban hipster and the avant-garde were swallowed by the ''cutting edge'' marketing of MTV and the Internet. Yet the archetype of the bohemian rebel hasn't entirely vanished. It has simply been reconfigured as a sporty backpacker combing the globe in search of adventure, a purer environment and better drugs. It's an archetype ready-made for Hollywood, especially when it's embodied by everybody's favorite young rebel, Leonardo DiCaprio.

title: Things to Wear, All by Hand
description: Meredith Kahn and her business partner, Renee Kopec, opened a clothing, jewelry and furniture accessories store at 29A Avenue B (between Second and Third Streets) on Feb. 12 and named it La Mano, Spanish for hand, because everything at the store is made that way. The store, which shares a door with Temple Records, features clothes and knits that Ms. Kahn sewed or crocheted, and jewelry, lamps and sculptures that Ms. Kopec soldered or welded. The women also display the handmade jewelry and clothes of three of their friends. Prices are $15 to $300.

title: Many in Silicon Valley Cannot Afford Housing, Even at $50,000 a Year
description: It is long past midnight as the No. 22 bus lumbers down the spine of Silicon Valley carrying 12 passengers with nowhere to go.

title: Let the Sun Shine In, And Install a Superfast Line
description: BACK in the 60's, ''commune'' was often synonymous with yoga and free love. Inhabitants shared political beliefs, a desire to save the whales, or maybe a penchant for Tofu Surprise. They thought globally and acted locally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, MILES
description: WHITE-Miles. February 17, 2000. Uncle of Carla White, Lee White and Cynthia White. He was a noted theatrical costume designer, the winner of two Tony Awards and two Academy Award nominations. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: For a Balkan Summit
description: To the Editor:

title: Malaysians Are Stunned by Reports Detailing Abuse of Servants
description: One young woman said she was kept in a cage by her employer. One was beaten with a heavy object that fractured her skull. One said she was poked with a stick in the gums and forced to beat herself on the thighs with a cane whenever she ''made a mistake.''

title: Hoping to Bid On Next Year's Bachelors
description: I hope I will be included on the next year's mailing list for Cancer Care of Long Island's benefit bachelor auction. I read the article [''New Guys on the Block: Getting a Date With a Gavel,'' Feb. 13] and it sounds like a lot of fun. I would just love to bid on one of those bachelors!

title: If Henry Ford Met Inspector Gadget . . .
description: IT is, for some men in Glen Ridge and every other small town in America, a day they look forward to all year. A day in which one's engineering and carpentry prowess is pitted against that of every other. It is the ultimate rite of manhood, an initiation of sons into the use of dangerous implements. A day that separates, if not the men from the boys, then the men with workshops from those without.

title: Lives; The Hot Cell
description: Deanna Fermanich is a ''hot cell'' technician at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation. She is one of 12,000 workers hired to clean up the facility that once produced plutonium for the Manhattan Project -- and that Gov. Gary Locke of Washington recently called an ''underground Chernobyl waiting to happen.'' Even though the Department of Energy reports that workers at nuclear-weapons plants, including Hanford, showed elevated rates of numerous kinds of cancer, Deanna prefers this job -- which pays $45,000 a year -- to her last, making $10 an hour as an emergency medical technician. But she's not oblivious to the risk her job entails. ''You've got to respect it,'' Deanna says. ''I'd be lying if I said it wasn't dangerous.''

title: An Exception
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast Company
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Awaiting the New Rich: Alternative Investments
description: RIC C. CALVILLO spent most of his 20's working 80-hour weeks at three companies, two of which he started himself. In August 1998, when he was 29, Mr. Calvillo sold the Conley Corporation, the software company of which he was the founder and a co-owner, for about $50 million to the EMC Corporation, the data storage giant of Hopkinton, Mass., where he continues to work as a division manager.

title: Whatever Happened to the Class of '93?
description: IN the fall of 1995, two years after graduating from Stanford University, Diane Barrum received a call from her sophomore roommate, Srinija Srinivasan, asking her to join a company recently founded by two other young Stanford alumni, Jerry Yang and David Filo. The deal was this: In exchange for 18-hour days, grinding away in overcrowded conditions, Ms. Barrum would get in early on a hot phenomenon called the Internet. But Ms. Barrum, happily employed by a biotechnology company based in Seattle, said, ''I just was not ready to take the risk.''

title: Park Panel Accepts Skateboard Area With Softer Decor
description: A battle pitting beauty against utility ended Monday when the city's Art Commission reversed itself and voted 6 to 1 for a proposed skateboarding area at Owl's Head Park.

title: Sorting Through Disparities In Europe
description: THE FTSE 100 stock index staged a nice rally last week, but so far this year things have generally not been so merry in the City of London.

title: Separate Judges
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fortunes Worsen in Nassau, but Few Talk of Raising Taxes
description: As Nassau County's financial footing grows shakier, with a large deficit looming and its bonds rated just above junk status, it seems that there is one component of any likely recovery plan that dare not speak its name: higher taxes.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about newly declassified United States government documents that shed light on the disappearance and death of two American supporters of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile in 1973 misstated the name of a private group that promotes the declassification of of government documents. It is the National Security Archive, not Archives.

title: Parents and Parks Dept. Clash Over Green Space
description: At one time, the sloping southern tip of the Bronx was so verdant and peaceful that it earned the name Mott Haven, which literally means a sheltering grove of trees. Today, residents say, their neighborhood is hardly a green haven. They point to the many vacant lots that remain after fires in the 1970's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASMUSSEN, KAREN MICHAELIS
description: RASMUSSEN-Karen Michaelis, on February 15, 2000. Loving mother of Bente Slotwiner. Grandmother of David, Peter, Alexander, Daniel and great-grandmother of Harry, Sophia and Peter. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72nd St. Services Tuesday 11am. Interment Trinity Cemetery.

title: Spalding Gray and His Children
description: For a time, it seemed that theatergoers, Spalding Gray fans, or just folks who go for monologuists, would get a jump on their New York counterparts, at least half of them.

title: Music for the Very, Very Young
description: Few classical music performances allow children to sing along, but at ''The Lolli-Pops Concert: Music Tells a Story,'' participation is actually encouraged.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: PICK A CITY, PICK A GUIDE

title: Ensemble's Concerts Honor Shakespeare
description: IT was Shakespeare who pointed out that newborns ''are made and molded of things past,'' and three concerts this week prove that so-called early music can still speak to us with modern eloquence. It is, indeed, Music of Shakespeare's World that the Ensemble Galilei is taking to Sarah Lawrence College today at 4 p.m.

title: The Harbor Nobody Knows; New York's Reviving Waterfront Teems With Hidden Treasures
description: THERE are standard, packaged ways to meet New York Harbor -- taking the Circle Line tour or the Staten Island Ferry -- and in doing so one can see many of its renowned sights. But to learn the essential character of the harbor, one must see its many uncelebrated spaces, large and small.

title: For Drivers of S.U.V.'s, Ways to Make Amends
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Morgan, Peter Hammack
description: Elizabeth Stacy Morgan, a daughter of Eleanor and Howard Morgan of Villanova, Pa., is to be married this evening to Peter Samuel Hammack, the son of Loraine and David C. Hammack of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Richard Chapin will officiate at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Government Overspends on Officers' Housing, Report Concludes
description: The Defense Department has been spending too much money on housing for high-ranking officers, according to the department's inspector general.

title: What No School Can Do
description: James Traub (Jan. 16) underestimates the role that schools do, and can, play in leveling inequalities and lifting everyone from poverty. Indeed, this country has comfortably tinkered with reform, while not doing enough to ''raise the trajectory of ghetto children.'' The trajectory has risen, however, and schools have been key to this rise. Acknowledging this fact is important, not so we may then sit back and expect limited school-reform efforts to cure society's ills but because we must actively pursue the actual great potential of schools to work in conjunction with other institutional change.

title: One Star Is Shooting, the Other is Falling
description: During player introductions at the All-Star Game last week, Allan Houston walked through a pillar of smoke and under a scaled-down model of the Golden Gate Bridge. He emerged on the other side to a loud and prolonged ovation. It was the type of applause reserved for perennial All-Stars, not first-time party crashers. Houston looked at his teammates sheepishly, offering up a ''Who, me?'' shrug.

title: A Year of Sewage, but No Remedy
description: FOR more than a year, a malfunctioning sewage treatment plant in Riverhead has been contaminating the Peconic Bays estuary. And for all that time the state Department of Environmental Conservation, which is charged with policing such plants and protecting the estuary, knew of the violations but took no action.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 20, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Is Nothing Secular?
description: I disagree that ''revived cooperation between church and state'' might be a ''healthy result of treating religion as just another aspect of identity politics in a multicultural age.'' If we sanction political divisiveness based on religious identity, we could find ourselves on the slippery slope toward Northern Ireland or Bosnia. That is one of the evils that the First Amendment wall of separation was created to guard against, and we must never let that wall crumble.

title: Up, Up and Away
description: The Federal Reserve and Labor Department offered proof that the economic expansion continues. The Fed reported that industrial production rose 1 percent last month, nearly twice as much as expected. The Labor Department reported that producer prices were unchanged for January, and actually fell if food and energy prices were excluded. Output up, prices down: it's economic nirvana.

title: At TCBY, Parting Is Sweet Sorrow
description: Frank Hickingbotham's first frozen yogurt store is still open, in a strip mall on the prosperous western edge of Little Rock, Ark. But TCBY (The Country's Best Yogurt) Enterprises, the company that grew over two decades from that single outlet, now includes 3,000 stores in 50 states and 68 foreign countries. Mr. Hickingbotham and his two sons still control 48 percent of the stock.

title: Satire; Annals Of The New New Groveling (syn. new new wallowing)
description: At one time in Hollywood, a social faux pas or small betrayal elicited the aside: ''How may I grovel [to redeem myself]?'' It was a common, if not comical, refrain. When actors' salaries hit the $20 million mark, the query took a serious turn. Power Groveling (i.e., New Groveling) became an industry staple, and we would be hard put to imagine the Hollywood landscape without it. Falling to one's knees is now widely regarded as a necessary tool, the carabiners and rope, if you will, of one's ascent up the cold, steep, expensive incline of the Business. The following are three modern parables on the way we grovel (New New Groveling, hereafter referred to as New2Groveling) today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAINES, HARRIET KALLEN
description: HAINES-Harriet Kallen. Died February 17, 2000 in Albuquerque, New Mexico. She touched the lives of all who knew and loved her with compassion, creativity and the spirit of adventure.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE ROSE GARDEN.

title: In Brazil, Investing For the Good of Nature
description: SEATED in his office in a gaudy new skyscraper here, wearing a tailored suit and cuff links, John Michael Forgach seems every bit the conventional investment banker. Then he starts talking about babassu coconuts.

title: It's Ben Stein's World; the Rest of Us Just Watch It
description: We're not afraid / We're terrified / We're not alone / We're petrified / Talk to me / Walk with me / . . . Shut up and talk.

title: Mosque and State
description: The Last Great Revolution Turmoil and Transformation in Iran. By Robin Wright. 339 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.

title: Indonesian Investigation
description: After a two-week verbal standoff, Indonesia's President Abdurrahman Wahid removed Wiranto, his most prominent general, from his cabinet pending the outcome of an investigation of his involvement in atrocities in East Timor. Despite fears of violence or a military coup, the general went quietly, accepting his suspension with a smile and stating his obedience to civilian authority. SETH MYDANS

title: Los Angeles Board Rules Police Shooting Was Wrong
description: In a vote seen as a crucial test of the city's commitment to change and oversight of the city's police force, the Los Angeles Police Commission has ruled that an officer's shooting of a mentally ill homeless woman last year violated department policy.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Universal Design

title: Finding Lost Bags
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on luggage, ''More Money for Lost Bags'' (Jan. 16), was great. I will add that I have photos of our bags that we keep on our persons. The photos help identify our bags in foreign countries, where we find that a photograph of a bag can be understood more easily than words.

title: A Caribbean Hotel Joins an Upscale Crowd
description: A deluxe new Caribbean hotel, Point Grace, is scheduled to open March 1 on a 12-mile white-sand beach along Grace Bay on Providenciales. The beach is home to an assortment of upscale resorts on the north shore of the island, also known as Provo, the most developed of the Turks and Caicos, an archipelago rich in coral reefs.

title: Debt for the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SLUTSKY, BERNICE
description: SLUTSKY-Bernice. It is now five years without you. You are with me every day, my beloved, my best friend, a shining light forever in my heart. I will never stop loving you. Love, Dadd

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADEL, MANUEL R.
description: NADEL-Manuel R., sunglass industry pioneer. Beloved husband of Gladys, loving father of Richard, Michael & Lisa, dear brother of Irene, devoted grandfather of Traci, Gregg, Jaime and Derek. Service today 1:45PM at ''Gutterman's,'' Rockville Centre.

title: Rivera Loses Ruling on Salary, but Takes It in Stride
description: Mariano Rivera was in the middle of doing sit-ups just past noon today when Rick Cerrone, the Yankees' director of media relations, told him he had lost his arbitration decision. To Rivera, it was a $2 million conversation: the arbitrators ruled he would earn $7.25 million for the 2000 season, rather than the $9.25 million for which he asked.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: DESTINED TO WITNESS

title: Labor Leaders Stand By Gore Despite His Stance on China Deal
description: The leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said this weekend that they would continue pushing union members to campaign aggressively for Vice President Al Gore, even though he has reiterated his support for President Clinton's trade deal with China.

title: Two Stars of Girls' Basketball Ready for High School Playoffs
description: THE first quarter of Ossining High School's basketball game was only a few minutes old and already Brittney Thomas and Stephanie Leveille were delighting their hometown fans.

title: Word For Word/Boredom; Yawn: These Are Such Exciting Times
description: LAST week a Stanford University study, hotly debated, concluded that Internet use increases social isolation. But other experts detect maybe a more significant hallmark of the Internet age: not individual loneliness, but mass boredom.

title: So Elegant, So Understated, So Blass: A Homage Designed by Guess Who
description: THEY canceled their plans, dug deep into their closets for classic gowns and braved a cold February night in little more than sequins and fur stoles. Nothing could keep the F.O.B.'s -- that's Friends of Bill Blass -- from a gala on Wednesday honoring the designer for his 50-year-plus career.

title: An Environmental Suit With the Roles Switched
description: The pretrial litigation has reached the five-year mark with depositions and arguments ever growing in Dickensian stacks dense enough to make the judge cry out.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Ballet's Men Feel the Macho Pull of 'Fosse'
description: JULIO BOCCA, a dashing star of American Ballet Theater, did not look himself as he rehearsed in a mid-Manhattan studio early this month. With his toes turned in, his back arched and his hands placed on his hips, not a trace of Albrecht or Romeo could be discerned in his demeanor. While still jet-lagged from a flight from Buenos Aires and worn from rehearsing his own company, Ballet Argentina, for its recent performance at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, he was trying to absorb a choreographic style as different from Petipa as night from day.

title: Developing a Kind of E-Z Pass for the Eye
description: Two scientific developments caught John E. Siedlarz's attention: in one, the opthalmologists Leonard Flom and Aran Safire discovered in the early 80's that the human iris -- a complex combination of features like pits, feathers, freckles, crypts, striations and radial furrows -- was a more specific way to identify people than a fingerprint. In the other, the mathematician John Daugman came up with a way to convert the image of the iris into a computer code. As a 20-year Air Force veteran with a background in security, Mr. Siedlarz concluded that using the iris as a way of identifying people might catch on commercially. He bought the patents for using an iris recognition system and seven years ago he started a business in Marlton called IriScan. He recently talked about his business.

title: Marvin Miller's Fame Is Subject to Interpretation
description: Ask people connected with baseball and they will say that Marvin Miller, the man who founded the Major League Baseball Players Association and the man who brought free agency to baseball, belongs in the Hall of Fame.

title: Works Reflect a Skeptic's View of Life on Earth
description: ON the checklist of his works, Chong Gon Byun, 51, whose heady, wide-ranging exhibition is at the Hudson River Gallery and Conservators here, appends ''visitor'' to his name. This does not mean he is Korean, for he has spent most of the last 20 years in New York and his art reveals that he is well acclimated to life in America. The reason for the label is that Mr. Byun claims to have come from another planet, the gallery director, Helmut Zitzwitz, said.

title: Warm Welcome in the Jungle
description: SURINAME'S rain forest, one of the least traveled places in the world, spread out beneath my airplane like a great green sea with island mountain ranges and gray granite outcrops rising like surfacing whales. Water glinted through the trees. Few people had been here, and the immensity of it was exhilarating and daunting.

title: Jennifer Lewis, Steven Berkey
description: Jennifer Lewis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Lewis of Armonk, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Steven Mark Berkey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Berkey of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi David Thomas is to officiate at the Manhattan Penthouse in Manhattan.

title: Built, but Not Destined, to Last; A Robert Moses Legacy, Coliseum Is Coming Down
description: While stands the Coliseum, Rome shall stand;

title: Clarifying Whose Data About Banks Was Used
description: To the Editor:

title: Policing the Internet: Anyone But Government
description: THE attacks on eBay, Yahoo, E*Trade and other big Web sites earlier this month showed the Internet to be surprisingly vulnerable to a few laptop-toting cyber-vandals. This is a pressing public concern, surely, as the nation increasingly comes to rely for commerce and everyday communication on this chaotic, global computer network.

title: It's So Palm Beach
description: INDIA is so last year. Africa doesn't interest us anymore, thanks. Right this second? It's all about Palm Beach, as inspired by Michael Kors's collection for spring. Magazines are pushing ''postmodern preppy'' and ''country club chic'' looks as if they were the answer to the question of existence.

title: A Unified Europe (Musically Speaking, at Least)
description: SO far, this has not been a good year for the ideal of a united Europe. The euro, the new currency that was supposed to challenge the almighty dollar for world dominance, has slipped under its rival in value. In elections in Russia and Croatia, lip service is being paid to common European values, but the evidence is mixed. And in Vienna, to the alarm of other European nations, a new Austrian government includes a party that has taken xenophobic stands and found kind words for the Third Reich.

title: Frozen Out Of Summer Camp Before the Lake Thaws
description: IT'S February and it's freezing, but brochures and applications for summer camps and programs have arrived in mailboxes across the state. It may seem an odd time to even think about summer, but winter is when applications come pouring in to camp administrators and the programs begin to fill up.

title: Habitats/Degraw Street in Cobble Hill; Real Fixer-Upper House Gets Its Fixer-Upper
description: EVEN in this real estate market, when many houses and apartments generate instant bidding wars, some properties sit around a long time.

title: On the Nile: Boats for Fishing, Craft for Carrying Kings
description: FOURTEEN model boats are the focus of ''In Style on the Nile: Boats of the Pharaohs,'' at the Maritime Aquarium in Norwalk through March 10.

title: The People's Choice
description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, who has held office since 1980, was given a humiliating vote of no confidence when voters rejected his proposed new constitution. With the economy in a shambles, citizens, urban ones in particular, showed no inclination to strengthen the man many blame for soaring inflation, rising unemployment and a litany of other ills. A new opposition party smells blood, and parliamentary elections in April promise to be interesting. HENRI E. CAUVIN

title: Singer-Guitarist at the Emelin
description: RICHARD SHINDELL is a born storyteller. So it comes as no surprise that on a recent rainy Monday at his Westchester home, the former seminarian-turned-songwriter was more than a little eager to recall younger days he spent ''bumming around'' Paris as a street musician.

title: Old, With and Without the 'e,' Plus Pie
description: I HANKER for pie. Specifically, a pie bursting with cherry filling, topped with a golden, sugary lattice, cooling behind the counter glass. There's bread pudding too, usually served with vanilla sauce, and there's a five-berry pie and good old American apple pie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, TEDDY
description: LIEBERMAN-Teddy, 94, on February 16, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Bertha. Devoted father of Ruth Fritzhand and Jerome and Sandra Lieberman. Grandfather of Ilene and Dr. Larry Parsont, Todd and Stephanie, Drew and Addy Fritzhand, Dr. Cliff and Carol Lieberman, Nancy and Tim Lieberman-Cline, Alan Rosenthal. Great-grandfather of Jason and Blair Parsont, David, Tyler, Troy, Bradley Fritzhand, T.J. Lieberman-Cline, Melissa Lieberman. We love you forever.

title: Sleeking Up Those Pants That Molt
description: Convertibles -- baggy long pants that turn into shorts by unzipping detachable lower legs -- were first rolled out for last year's fall collections on the runways of designers like John Bartlett and Maharishi. They're back for spring, this time in sleeker models.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: For Drivers of S.U.V.'s, Ways to Make Amends
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Acting Up

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, MARY REINHARDT
description: COX-Mary Reinhardt. Suddenly on February 14. Beloved wife of Edward V. Cox. Mother of Calvin Deater, David Reinhardt, Andrew Reinhardt. Memorial service Sun. February 20, at 2PM, North Congregational Church, Woodbury, CT. In lieu of flowers gifts may be made to church's memorial fund.

title: Hitler's Silent Partners
description: Nazi Terror

title: County Getting Gardens
description: Westchester's park system will be enhanced by the addition of a 12.96-acre property in New Castle.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-20-00: The Ethicist; Milking Mr. Softee
description: Microsoft recently offered a $400 rebate if you bought a computer and subscribed to its online service. To comply with a state law, the company allowed California consumers to cancel the service at any time. Many people took the rebate, canceled the service and pocketed $400. Since Microsoft must have anticipated this, is it unethical? / K.J., Mountain View, Calif.

title: With a Big Flop, Childs Is a Star For the Knicks
description: It was just the cellophane-thin Reggie Miller, but upon the slightest contact, Chris Childs's upper body suddenly and violently buckled out like a question mark, his head snapped back and he hit the floor in a heap.

title: Blair England, Peter Carlin
description: Blair Alexandra England, the daughter of Audna Linter Nicholson of Washington and Charles Billings England of Rowayton, Conn., was married last evening to Peter Harold Carlin, the son of Florence Carlin and David H. Carlin, both of New York. The Rev. Philippa Turner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at a club in New York.

title: These Woods Are Southern, Sweet and Deep
description: Old Mattie Collier had mesmerized more than one generation of Savannah children with her tales of runaway slaves, kindly hermits and little boys with portentous dreams. Even after her death, Mattie's stories seemed to take on a life of their own, shaping the destinies of those who had once sat on her knee, listening.

title: SOAPBOX; A Citizen's Oath
description: I JUST became an American citizen.

title: Crowning Kings But Not Queens?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Studying Latin to Meet Higher Standards
description: WHETHER it is through the study of Latin or a focus on classical Utopian texts, many schools' success with such subjects suggests yet another approach to meeting higher state academic standards.

title: Margaret Nocero, Frank Simone
description: Margaret Ellen Nocero, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael A. Nocero Jr. of Altamonte Springs, Fla., was married yesterday to Frank Christopher Simone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Simone of Spring Hill, Fla. The Rev. Robert Fucheck performed the ceremony at St. Mary Magdalen Roman Catholic Church in Maitland, Fla.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Jan. 30 about the reopening of several galleries in the Louvre misstated the building's history. It is not the former Tuileries Palace; that building was damaged in a fire in 1871 and later demolished.

title: Playing It Like a Man
description: MORNING GLORY

title: New Jersey Blew the Chance To Carry Weight in Primaries
description: This was supposed to have been New Jersey's moment.

title: Ranting; Character Assassination
description: Delivering most of his lines in an empathetic murmur, Bruce Willis is the understated soul of ''The Sixth Sense.'' But those who keep an eye out for movie star vanity may have an inkling that something is going on that's just as unusual as young Haley Joel Osment's seeing dead people. It's the type of clue that tells a specific -- and, yes, shallow -- kind of observer that things aren't as they seem. In ''The Sixth Sense,'' the bell went off when Willis wore the same outfit for the entire picture.
