True, the limited wardrobe was a conceit, camouflaged by the styling, which was similar to one of those annual GQ get-the-most-out-of-your-ensemble spreads: sometimes Willis wore the vest with the suit, sometimes just an open-collared shirt instead of the more formal subtle necktie. But such modest costuming of a major male star was, if you'll pardon the expression, a ''dead'' giveaway.

title: Wijk-aan-Zee Results Show The Elite Earn Their Keep
description: The players who captured the first six places at the Corus International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, are among the top 10 in the International Chess Federation's January computer rankings. Yet there are still grandmasters complaining that they are treated as a second tier and denied appearance fees, reimbursement for all expenses and the other usual prerogatives. They insist that they are on a par with the elite, but in competitions like the Corus, they usually take the lower places.

title: Fin; The Story Of Why
description: If one were to make a list of the best movie clothes ever -- a list that excluded the works of Merchant-Ivory and anything else in which people are made to say ''anon'' -- then one would realize that many of the most remarkable outfits have been worn by female characters who make their way in life by taking them off.

title: Vlad the Impaler
description: NABOKOV'S BLUES The Scientific Odyssey of a Literary Genius. By Kurt Johnson and Steve Coates. Illustrated. 372 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Zoland Books. $27.

title: The Assault Of the Salonistas
description: When the internet magazine Salon went public last June, nobody got obscenely rich. But the I.P.O. did underwrite a few perks that give the company the appearance of new-economy prosperity. Its swank new office in downtown San Francisco includes a communal kitchen with an impressive stainless-steel fridge and a balcony where the staff gathers for cocktails every Friday night.

title: At Penn Station, Changes, and More Changes; After Over $100 Million in Renovations, A $788 Million Terminal, but No Tunnel
description: IT is neither the suffocatingly low ceilings on the New Jersey Transit platforms nor the last-minute track information that bothers Kris Martin most about her daily commute.

title: In The Region/Westchester; A Fourth Major Store for Yonkers Retail Complex
description: THE first Target store to open in Westchester will be joining a growing list of retailers and other businesses in a $150 million shopping center still taking form near Austin Avenue at this city's northern border.

title: Art, in the Public Vein
description: If you open your mailbox in the coming weeks and find a postcard of eight disembodied heads, don't panic. If you find a MetroCard on the street whose cheery New York City scene has been replaced with a double helix, don't be alarmed. You are in the flow of a citywide art project.

title: How Waiting Can Pay Off In a Star Role
description: CLOTHES FOLDER. Dog walker. Morning bartender. Those are a few of the glamorous professions undertaken by Mark Setlock during his self-described ''squalor days'' a few years back, when he was living on a ''syringe-lined'' street in the East Village, learning about urban ecology. ''I saw mice, I saw cockroaches,'' Mr. Setlock said cherrily. ''I saw silverfish for the first time.''

title: Planned Parenthood Sees No Restriction at New Clinic
description: It is manifestly unfair to poor women that the proposed Planned Parenthood clinic in Massapequa has had to agree to restrict its reproductive services and exclude the availability of abortions.

title: Old Tune for Starks: New Club, Bad Club
description: John Starks heard that Pat Riley wanted him for a playoff run in Miami. It was the kind of gossip that made Starks daydream of having the ball in his hands with the season on the line.

title: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks; Taking a Toll on Apartments
description: In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.

title: Hitting High Notes With a Diva's Help
description: SINGING an aria from ''Faust'' for the first time in public, a nervous 22-year-old tenor went flat. A few members of the audience twittered.

title: Finding Lost Bags
description: To the Editor: As a traveler experienced in the frustration of missing luggage, I thought I would add the following cautionary anecdote to Betsy Wade's article.

title: Michelle Turco, Robert Schanzer
description: Michelle Loren Turco, a lawyer, and Dr. Robert Joseph Schanzer, a cardiology fellow, are to be married today at the Great Neck Synagogue in Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Yaakov Luban is to officiate.

title: An Effort to Solve a Disappearance From 1985
description: Fourteen years ago, according to prosecutors, Dr. Robert Bierenbaum committed a murder that for more than a decade would stand as the perfect crime. They say he killed his young wife in the couple's Upper East Side apartment, rented a plane and dumped her body into the Atlantic Ocean. She was never found.

title: The Haves; Hitched To A Star
description: John Travolta's is a deep, envy-inducing green. Harrison Ford's is blue and lined with wood. So is Tom Hanks's. Michael Madsen's is a symphony of black, red and leopard skin. Chuck Norris let his wife fiddle with his. Richard Gere gets one for his personal chef. Nicolas Cage uses at least two at a time, while his uncle, Francis Ford Coppola, needs only one -- a custom job he calls the Silverfish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, MOTOKO IKEDA
description: SPIEGEL-Motoko Ikeda. We regret to advise the community that Motoko Ikeda Spiegel passed away suddenly on February 14, 2000 at the age of 72. She was the loving wife of Si Spiegel and devoted mother of Kazuko Ono, Ray Spiegel, and Tamio Spiegel. She leaves five loving grandchildren and a saddened community. Motoko was an artist in oils, woodblock prints, and photography. A 1978 graduate of SUNY Purchase, she was a tireless advocate of the rights of mistreated peoples, particularly Japanese-Americans who suffered internment during WWII and the Ainu people of Northern Japan. She was a generous, caring, and nurturing friend to many artists and activists. A Memorial Service celebrating Motoko's life will be held on Saturday, February 26 at the Nippon Club, 145 West 57th Street, NYC. A selection of Motoko's artwork will be on display at the Nippon Gallery there from February 24 through 26. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to the Motoko Ikeda Spiegel Memorial Fund, 10 W. 66th Street, NYC 10023.

title: Rise of Haider's Party Brings Out Large Protest in Vienna
description: Unbowed by the rain, more than 100,000 people gathered in central Vienna today to protest the formation of a government that includes the anti-immigration Freedom Party of Jorg Haider.

title: Student Club Focuses on Business
description: EVERY week 50 students at Rye Country Day School get down to business.

title: Corporations' Taxes Are Falling Even as Individuals' Burden Rises
description: With incomes rising, particularly among the wealthy, Americans are paying a lot more in federal taxes than they did before the economic expansion of the last decade. Not so, American corporations. Their profits are growing even faster than Americans' incomes, yet the taxes they pay have peaked and have begun to fall.

title: U.S. Parks Face Pressure To Ban Off-Road Vehicles
description: BIG CYPRESS NATIONAL PRESERVE in Florida, 729,000 acres of wetlands and sodden stands of cypress in the Everglades, may not seem to be a likely place for driving through roadless back country. But it has one of the most active off-road-vehicle programs in the nation, issuing about 2,000 permits a year to drivers of sport utility vehicles, airboats, all-terrain cycles and behemoths known locally as swamp buggies.

title: Shocking Visits to the Real World; Even if you're rich, it's uncool today not to have a 'real' job. so you get one. And then what?
description: STARTING in the management training program at Chase Manhattan Bank didn't turn out exactly the way one 29-year-old Upper East Sider expected.

title: Tracing Freedom's Trail Through Philadelphia
description: Before the Civil War, the Underground Railroad helped slaves escape to freedom in the northern states and Canada, and Pennsylvania played an important role in it. The Multicultural Affairs Congress of Philadelphia recently published ''Underground Railroad: Trail to Freedom,'' a guide to sites in the Philadelphia area that were ''stations'' -- the various safe houses and other sites along the secretive network where slaves on the run could find refuge.

title: POSTINGS: Open Meeting of the Superintendents Club; Conservation Of Fuel Oil
description: The soaring cost of fuel oil in recent weeks caught many homeowners and landlords by surprise. While there appears to be no quick fix in sight, one of the best ways to minimize the impact on the wallet is through fuel oil conservation. And one way to learn more about fuel conservation is to attend the meeting of the Superintendents Club of New York on Wednesday.

title: Beyond Lasagna In Little Italy
description: BISTROT MARGOT

title: The Start of Something Big
description: THE ARCADES PROJECT

title: Looking Beyond Messier to Help Rangers
description: Even at a Devils-Islanders game, it is difficult to dodge a discussion of the Rangers. During yesterday's 4-2 Islanders victory, in a rare moment when recorded music was not blaring, a group of fans in the corner of Continental Arena shouted in unison the R-rated version of ''Rangers Stink!''

title: For Would-Be Shakespeares
description: Hoboken's Waterfront Ensemble theatre troupe has expanded its summer playwriting contest and is offering free playwriting workshops on Saturdays through April 15. The workshops, for aspiring writers of all ages and experience levels, begin at 11 a.m. and will take place in Hoboken, Jersey City and Union City.

title: A Roadblock
description: At the point where Heathcote Brook Road intersects Route 27, the street is so narrow you can read the gas meters on the buildings lining the road and see the traces of exhaust soot in the cracked clapboard siding of the 19th-century buildings.

title: Jeter Seeks Improvement, Right Down to Core
description: Mike Buddie played with a skinny kid in Class A baseball seven years ago, so frail, Buddie recalled, that it seemed he might break in half if a runner slid into him.

title: How Slow Can Your Paycheck Grow?
description: AMERICA'S nine-year economic expansion is now the longest in history. Companies everywhere are thriving and sharing this prosperity with workers clamoring for raises. So paychecks must be ballooning, right?

title: Beam Me Up, Desi
description: MR. SPACEMAN

title: Neither Death Nor Fire Stop A Fabric Design Workshop
description: Bette Saunders was once the marketing director of the KLM airline and a tourism liaison for the Ghanaian government. She traveled regularly. But two years ago fate set her on a completely different, very local, course.

title: Women Added to Finalists for Abolitionist's Statue
description: Seven years into a project to honor the rights advocate Sojourner Truth with a bronze statue, organizers are finding themselves in the middle of a dispute over fairness.

title: BENEFITS
description: Art at the Armory

title: Wendy Igleheart, Ron Walker
description: Wendy Igleheart and Francis Ronalds Walker were married last evening by the Rev. Wendlyn McCormick at the First Presbyterian Church in Evansville, Ind.

title: A Family's Treasures Vanish From a Bank Vault, and With Them, Their Magic
description: Every month, like clockwork, Alla Kozirovskaya would leave her tiny apartment in Brighton Beach and walk to the bank to visit her dead mother. It was such a comforting routine. Mrs. Kozirovskaya, 62, would sign in at the bank, wait for a clerk to retrieve her safe deposit box, and then open it up and run her bent, wrinkled fingers over a single ring, a single bracelet and a single brooch.

title: A-List; A Muse On A Muse
description: Lisa Marie is not your ordinary Hollywood actress. She is the essence of being a girl. A real girlie girl. A flower, from the moment she wakes up to when she goes to sleep. No men's pj's or sweatpants to lounge around in. She sleeps in satin slips and walks around in slippers with heels -- even to walk on carpet. She is the vision of Cinderella when the mice and birds are dressing her. You can almost see little birds fly around the head of Lisa Marie.

title: Heat; Ossified
description: ''Fashion isn't just clothes,'' Ossie Clark, the flamboyant British designer, once remarked. ''It's what's happening at the moment in everything.'' Especially if the clothes, like Clark's, embody everything cool about the moment, which in his case was 60's London: the art, the music, the photography, the films, the politics. They offer such a shorthand for the archetype of hip that today's designers -- Miuccia Prada, Tom Ford, Stella McCartney, Christian Lacroix, Emanuel Ungaro, Valentino, Narciso Rodriguez -- have all cribbed from Clark this spring: slinky, bias-cut dresses in pretty print chiffons; tailored suits with skinny, flared trousers; and torso-hugging snakeskin jackets.

title: Elevator Music on Clark St.: Riders Raise Their Voices
description: More than 100 residents and shopkeepers crowded into the Brooklyn Heights Library Tuesday night to oppose a four-month shutdown of the Clark Street subway station for elevator replacement. Representatives from New York City Transit fielded angry questions about the agency's decision to close the station from April 14 to July 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, EMMA LOIS
description: SMITH-Emma Lois. On February 17, 2000. Beloved wife of Edward (E.J.) Smith. Devoted mother of Linda and her husband Dr. Rois Bari, Edward III (Darby), Rodney (Skipper) and his wife Tina, and Stuart. Proud grandmother of Curtis, Xona and Ellington. Sister of Ruby Taylor. Visiting on Wednesday, February 23, 4-8 PM, at J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home, Inc, 179-24 Linden Blvd, Jamacia, NY; 718-526-5656. Funeral service will be held Thursday, February 24, 11 AM, at First Congregational Church of Chappaqua, 210 Orchard Ridge Rd, Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to North General Hospital Cancer Center Foundation Account, NGHCCF, 1879 Madison Ave, NYC 10035.

title: Audi Offers TT Fix After 5 Deaths
description: ACTING in response to continuing complaints that its TT sports car is unstable, Audi of America announced last week that North American owners could have electronic stability systems retrofitted on their 2000-model cars. The company's German parent, Audi A.G., had made a similar offer in Europe on Feb. 4.

title: In Reverse
description: To the Editor:

title: Spring Training
description: Spring is here, at least for baseball fans. Pitchers and catchers from the 30 major league clubs showed up for work, continuing the century-old tradition of spring training

title: Sleep Lola Sleep
description: As Lola in Tom Tykwer's hit German film "Run Lola Run," Franka Potente raced across Berlin. Now, the director is letting his leading lady rest on her laurels in the season's most avant-garde looks.

title: Killings in a Georgetown Coffee Shop Stir Death Penalty Debate
description: Federal prosecutors are pressing for the death penalty against a man charged with murdering three employees at a Starbucks coffee shop here in July 1997, clearing the way for the city's first death penalty case in nearly 30 years.

title: Kindness Of Strangers After Death Of a Father
description: The city knew about Fausta Leon once.

title: Reeling
description: Photographers celebrate those moments in film that left them delirious.

title: Kathy Dropp and David Kirk
description: THE writer, illustrator and self-described bug poet David Kirk is not at all like the main character in his popular children's book series featuring Miss Spider.

title: The Nearness of . . . Who?
description: Ever hopeful that New York can indeed be a warm and fuzzy city, a new crop of restaurateurs have added communal tables, where strangers rub elbows.

title: DUAL JOBS PROHIBITED
description: Town attorneys would be prohibited from also serving as municipal clerk-administrators, the state supreme court ruled last week. Five of the seven justices said that a lawyer who served both capacities presented an impermissible conflict of interest because an administrator's objectivity could be questioned. The case came from Old Tappan, where Gregory C. Heartheld is now the clerk-administrator, and was slotted to become the municipality's attorney. In Old Tappan, a clerk-administrator makes $84,000 a year, and a town attorney makes $110 an hour. WENDY GINSBERG

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Grammy's Kids Are Already The Winners
description: YET another chapter in pop's latest bout with adolescence unfolds this week at the 42nd annual Grammy Awards. The nominee list, as undependable as ever in predicting music's real history-makers, does crackle with one present conflict, between the parent figures who run the event and the kids now paying their allowances. Those kids get on adults' nerves with their obvious commercial music, but these hit makers, sometimes unwittingly, are pointing toward pop's future.

title: The Earth Moved
description: When Mountains Walked

title: Safari in Botswana
description: To the Editor: Reading Alida Becker's article ''Delightfully Beastly Behavior'' (Jan. 23) on Wilderness Safaris' Botswana camps, two of which we visited in autumn 1997, we agree with her -- we want to go back.

title: Have You Heard The New Caruso? (No Kidding)
description: HAVE you ever wondered what it would be like to hear your favorite Caruso recordings freshened up: say, with the great tenor's voice, exactly as it was captured by an acoustic recording horn in the days before microphones, newly cloaked in the lush timbres of a modern symphony orchestra recorded in digital stereo?

title: No Scrunchies!
description: Slab Rat

title: On the Map; Midnight At The Oasis
description: She may not look it, but Michele Lamy, the owner of Hollywood's most happening bote, is the Gertrude Stein of a new Lost Generation. But rather than Americans going to Europe to hang out at Deux Magots, the Europeans (and Americans with Continental temperaments) are coming here to Les Deux Cafes. And instead of penning The Great American Novel, the patrons at the bar are hawking screenplays and talking deals.

title: Natalie Umbert, Igal Feibush
description: Natalie Michelle Umbert, the daughter of Lynda Norton of Laguna Beach, Calif., and Enrique Umbert of Lima, Peru, was married last evening to Igal Jonathan Feibush, the son of Clara Levy of El Paso and Alexander Feibush of Dix Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik performed the ceremony at the Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: The Recycled Generation
description: Hall writes, ''To obtain human embryonic stem cells by currently available technology, you must destroy an embryo.'' Those chilling words should be the end of the discussion. Just because something is possible does not mean that we have the right to do it. And imagine a world crowded with this never-aging generation! Forget ''tee times.'' How will we allocate resources with a segment of the population scientifically engineered to live too long? The words in Ecclesiastes come to mind: ''To every thing, there is a season.''

title: Critics of Park Fences Show Lack of Awareness
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lonelier Crowd
description: Americans are forsaking face-to-face relationships in favor of Web surfing and e-mail, according to a nationwide survey by the Institute for the Quantitative Study of Society . The survey, which is based on 4,113 telephone interviews, suggests that the Web is also cutting into time once spent watching television and reading newspapers.

title: Two Plus Two Need Not Be Divisive
description: THERE comes a time in the life of every marriage when it seems like a good idea to bring another couple on vacation. Usually this does not occur as early as the honeymoon, when bride and groom are still exploring the endless wonders of the beloved (my Aunt Lily did take her psychiatrist on her honeymoon, but the circumstances were extraordinary -- it was her fifth marriage). Multiple-couple travel tends to take place after about 5 or 10 years, when wonder is reduced to what's for dinner.

title: My Brother's Keeper
description: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius

title: 6 Teenagers Accused Of Subway Robberies
description: Detectives have arrested six teenagers on robbery charges, saying they were part of a gang who swept through a subway Thursday and robbed at least six passengers.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: PAY IT FORWARD

title: A Good Secretary Is Hard to Find
description: Lawrence R. Ricciardi, senior vice president and general counsel at I.B.M., is taking credit for bringing Robert Rubin together with Sandy Weill and Citigroup. Several months before Mr. Rubin resigned as Treasury secretary last July, Mr. Ricciardi asked him to present an award to Mr. Weill at a fund-raising dinner for the public library in Greenwich, Conn., where Mr. Ricciardi and Mr. Weill have homes.

title: The College Application Frenzy
description: To the Editor:

title: PATH TO POWER: A political profile.; Putin Steering to Reform, But With Soviet Discipline
description: Nine years ago a sea of Russians celebrating the collapse of a Communist-backed coup jammed the traffic circle outside K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow and stripped away icons of dictatorship, including a bust and plaque honoring the late spymaster and Soviet ruler, Yuri V. Andropov.

title: Another N.J. Encyclopedia Is Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Cause Of Highway Accidents
description: In response to the article on accidents on the Merritt Parkway [''After Fatal Crash, Road Is Studied,'' Jan. 30], I submit that the increase in accidents demands not a change in a historic and picturesque highway but an examination in how we educate and license drivers.

title: 10 Stocks for 2010: Buy-and-Hold Picks From Top Investors
description: DAY traders and momentum investors probably won't be interested in this article.

title: The Twists and Turns In Defining a Crime
description: A WESTON man has told the police that he was behind a two-year series of incidents in which medical waste was dumped outside synagogues and a library in Stamford and Norwalk. Although the man is Jewish, experts said that does not make such hate crimes any less damaging.

title: Catherine Zang, Robert Cunningham
description: Catherine Joy Zang, a daughter of Mabel Bell Zang and Joseph A. Zang Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Burton Cunningham, the son of Anna Mae Cunningham of Hollidaysburg, Pa., and the late Richard Burton Cunningham. Canon Robert Miner performed the ceremony at St. Saviour's Episcopal Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Films at Sarah Lawrence

title: In Parma, Violets Are in the Air
description: ON a Sunday afternoon in Parma, all the shuttered streets seem to lead to the Piazza Garibaldi. Dodging bicycles, pedestrians stroll along the avenue that bisects the square and changes from the Via Mazzini into Strada della Repubblica or vice versa, depending on your direction. Young people, dressed in cutting-edge fashions (drawstring hems, for instance), crowd the tables spilling out from Gran Caffe Orientale and the other restaurants built into the Palazzo del Governatore. The palace is said to have been the first building in town painted Parma yellow, that intense shade between mustard and egg yolk that has become the local color. Or one of the local colors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITMAN, MURIEL
description: LITMAN-Muriel ''Billie''. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Allen, Mark and Larry. Dear sister of Howard Kaplan. Cherished grandmother, greatgrandmother, mother-in-law, sister-in-law and friend. Services Sunday, 2PM at ''Parkside Memorial CHapel,'' 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Birds Hit the Feeder, Hawks Hit the Birds
description: HAWKS, which survive by eating birds and small animals, are increasingly giving up the exhausting flight south for the winter because they have discovered the equivalent of free meals up north, right in suburban backyards.

title: The Nominees Are . . .
description: The Oscar nominations were announced, so the business of trying to divine the collective consciousness of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has begun in earnest.

title: Star Trek; Red-eyed and Bushy-tailed
description: Once, the rich and renowned were separated from the rest of us by the lavatory that divided first class and coach. We knew they were there, for they were accorded the privilege of boarding first, which allowed us the privilege of gawking as we later made our way to the rear. We felt famous by association. We also felt insignificant. If something happened, we knew the headline would read: ''Major Rock Star Killed; 271 Others Die, Too.''

title: OPINION; Spreading the News of Our Lives
description: I HAVE lived in Asharoken for 20 years, and one of the symbols of my community -- not quite as well known as the four huge stacks of the LIPA generating plant, but a symbol nonetheless -- is the community bulletin board at the corner of Ocean Avenue and Eaton's Neck Road.

title: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks; A Cooperative Solution
description: In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.

title: Women and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: She's Driven to Succeed in a 'Brutal' Sport
description: DON'T tell Liz Mueller that women's boxing doesn't have a chance at attracting mainstream audiences. She's already impressed many with her athletic ability. And in January she made history as the first Connecticut woman to headline a professional boxing card.

title: Critics of Park Fences Show Lack of Awareness
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIDLOFF, GUSTAV A.
description: LEIDLOFF-Gustav A. A Vice President of DB Alex. Brown, died suddenly on February 11, 2000 at the age of 76. Gus Leidloff was born in Magdeburg, Germany on February 23, 1924. He, his sister, and his late mother, Olga De Mooy, moved to Switzerland just before the outbreak of World War II and came to the United States in 1947. Gus became a United States citizen and served in the United States Army. After several years of teaching in California, he settled in New York where he embarked on a long, successful and satisfying career as an investment advisor. Gus was a co-founder of Land - Care Incorporated in Charleston, South Carolina. He was also an avid equestrian. Gus is survived by his sister, Marlis Beets of Brussels, Belgium; his brother, Armin Leidloff of Einbech, Germany; two nieces; three nephews; two godsons; and by several grand nieces and nephews. He leaves behind his companion, Michael A. Ferrazzano of Charleston, South Carolina. He will be sorely missed and remembered with love by his many friends and clients.

title: For 1930's Behemoth, a New Upscale Life
description: TALK about turning the Queen Mary on a dime. The Starrett-Lehigh Building, a leviathan from the 1930's whose titanic proportions rival the ocean liners that once berthed nearby, is rapidly being transformed from a somnolent, $6-a-square-foot industrial loft and warehouse into a home for the likes of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, Hugo Boss Fashions and ScreamingMedia, which are paying rents in the $20's and $30's for bare-bones space with drop-dead views.

title: Editorial Observer; Fratricidal Competition in New York's G.O.P.
description: Although nobody wants to talk about it on the record, New York's Republicans are quietly agonizing over the intrigue and backbiting among the state's top party leadership. Gov. George Pataki, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Joseph Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, and William Powers, the state party chairman, are contenders in a struggle for the dominance once exercised by Alfonse D'Amato.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-20-00: Expert Opinion; Uniform of The Day
description: As three highly visible companies -- McDonald's; Amtrak, with its new Acela train; and the new JetBlue airline -- unveil their new uniforms, the line between work clothes and fashion is becoming significantly harder to draw. All three outfits are the work of Stan Herman, who has been designing uniforms since the 1970's. And all three reflect new thinking about the way work attire influences a company's image and its employees' performance. Many of the elements of these uniforms are specifically conceived to address the sartorial needs of their users; others come straight off the runway. ''All those marvelous minimal clothes -- they used a lot of the elements of uniforms,'' Herman says. Below, he explains the evolution of employee chic in three case studies. Melanie Rehak

title: Adopting Teaching as Second Career
description: IT is not quite the same as sitting in a corner office evaluating corporate loans, but Mary Sykes would not trade her current clients for anything.

title: Is Nothing Secular?
description: Is nothing sacred? I guess not. When Al Gore cites the shorthand ''W.W.J.D.,'' he must be feeling self-conscious about the religious content of the full phrase, ''What would Jesus do?'' The full phrase takes five syllables, whereas the abbreviation takes eight. Politicians are stepping gingerly when trying to attract both the born-again and the rationalists to their political camp.

title: The Director's Cut
description: On the eve of his directorial debut, the cinematographer Janusz Kaminski walks you through the visual genius that won him Academy Awards for ''Saving Private Ryan'' and ''Schindler's List.'' Here, he aims his camera at his luminescent wife, Holly Hunter, who dazzles in everything from snakeskin to silk.

title: U.S. Expels Cuban Diplomat Who Is Linked to Spy Case
description: The United States today ordered the expulsion of a Cuban diplomat linked to an American immigration official charged on Friday with spying for the Cuban government.

title: The Neighbors' 150-Foot Problem
description: BATTLES over cell-phone towers are raging in town halls and on village greens throughout Long Island.

title: Political Briefing; But Cheese Heads In North Carolina?
description: The American Dairy Association was casting about for a new way to promote cheese when the bright idea hit. Why not run a television spot keyed to the election season?

title: African Identities in Contemporary Portraiture
description: 'Distinguished Identities'

title: The College Application Frenzy
description: To the Editor:

title: Bricks and Mortars
description: Watching W. in South Carolina was nerve-racking.

title: Double Standard
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Front-Runner Once Again
description: Shortly after President George Bush lost his re-election bid in 1992, George W. Bush told a friend that his father ''should never have let Bill Clinton dictate the terms of debate.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASSIN, WILLIAM F.
description: CASSIN-William F. Although we continue to see you in each other, we miss you none the less. Love, Billy, Danny, Michelle, Brian and Laura

title: Sutherland Has the Lead, But Woods Is Lurking
description: It was difficult enough to dodge the bumps, footprints and spike marks that made every green at Riviera Country Club a potential three-putt for bogey or worse. Now, the leaders of the Nissan Open have another factor, albeit a familiar one, to fear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, EDWIN
description: SINGER-Edwin. The Board of Trustees, Medical Board and Administration of Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) join with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Edwin Singer, brother of former Beth Israel President Emeritus and Trustee Herbert M. Singer, and brother-in-law of Beth Israel Honorary Trustee Nell Singer. Together with their families, Edwin and Herbert Singer shared a wide and visionary scope of philanthropic work for which we are very grateful. To Nell Singer and the entire Singer family we offer our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Boards of Trustees, Continuum and BIMC Robert G. Newman, M.D., President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President and CEO, BIMC Henry S. Singman, M.D., President Medical Board, BIMC

title: The Young Prowl for Pucci at Sleepy Thrift Shops
description: Hanging in the storefront window on the corner of Third Avenue and 83rd Street, the hot pink dresses and lime green suits scream Palm Beach to passers-by. The store is the Spence-Chapin Thrift Shop, and its manager, Barbara Young, says the color scheme has been drawing customers.

title: Greatest Show In Bryant Park
description: The three big tops in Bryant Park for the semiannual showing of the New York fashion collections always create a circus atmosphere. The designers are the high-wire artists, trying to thrill buyers (above, center group) with clothes that have a dash of newness and yet will sell. Across the runway, reporters and editors (above right) are looking for fashions that will leap from their pages like tigers through flaming hoops. Below, at left of oval, Anna Wintour, editor in chief of Vogue. At the end of the runway, international photographers search for fashion pictures that have all the drama of acrobatic bareback riders. Where there is standing room, and scattered through the audience, the fashion groupies clamor to be entertained. They haven't gone to buy, but to yell, ''Bring on the clowns.'' In an added attraction this year, animal-protection advocates (bottom), fleetingly took the runway to protest furs in fashion. They nearly pelted the designer Michael Kors. Afterward (bottom right), women hurried from the show with coats reversed, fur side in. The rest of the women, above and below left, had a special reserve section to insulate them from the peanut gallery. They were the private customers. They were amused by the glittering show-stoppers, what they call Academy Awards clothes, but would never wear them. They want clothes with the quality of a Norman Norell or the fit of a Mainbocher, two towering ringmasters of 20th-century American style.

title: Aid to Lobstermen
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has requested $15 million in aid from Congress for emergency relief to New York lobstermen as a result of widespread lobster deaths in Long Island Sound.

title: Pirates Rally, but Irish Win in the Final Second
description: It was the one critical play that Troy Murphy had nothing to do with. After the Notre Dame star had scorched No. 23 Seton Hall with a career-high 35 points and the Irish had the ball with 37.5 seconds to play and the score tied at 74-74, everybody from the popcorn vendors to the ballboys figured Murphy would get the shot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLANTYNE, MARION C.
description: BALLANTYNE-Marion C. Died peacefully at home on February 15 in her 94th year. Beloved widow of the late Jacques C. Nordeman and the late John J. Ballantyne. Loving mother of Mary Ann and Jacques Nordeman, devoted grandmother of Landon, John and Eliza. Private services will be held for the immediate family. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Friday, February 25, 6-8PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory can be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, 8th floor, NY, NY 10022, a park which Marion loved dearly.

title: Not a Household Name but Good Enough to Be
description: Because Wilson Daniels has brought wine lovers pleasure mostly indirectly since 1978, it is not a household name. A Napa Valley company, it represents producers like Schramsberg, the top-tier Napa sparkling-wine house; Domaine de la Roman'ee-Conti, Burgundy's crown jewel; Salon, the ne plus ultra Champagne; and the brilliant Marc Kreydenweiss of Alsace.

title: Of Wrongful Acts
description: To the Editor:

title: Skeleton Gets Rare Moment In the Spotlight
description: Jimmy Shea is riding a major adrenaline high, he says. And it's not from his usual 80 mile-an-hour slide down a banked ice chute. Shea, a Lake Placid resident and champion World Cup racer in a sport known as skeleton, has gone from alternately training and bartending to being anointed as something of a star for the 2000 Winter Goodwill Games, Ted Turner's made-for-television, five-day spectacle that ends Sunday.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-20-00: Word & Image; You Can't Dam the Money
description: As the primaries go wholesale across the country, it will become even more painfully obvious how much money talks. Money talked on buttons, billboards, bands and bumper stickers in Iowa and New Hampshire, but it now drowns out every other medium as it shouts with television commercials. Now, if money is speech, then political money is political speech. And political speech is protected by the First Amendment: ''Congress shall make no law. . . . '' -- right?

title: Scary Stuff, Indeed: Halloween as Bellwether
description: SELL in May and go away.

title: Political Briefing; N.A.A.C.P. Opposes Compromise on Flag
description: The Confederate battle flag issue was here when the presidential candidates arrived months ago to begin campaigning for today's Republican primary. And it will still be here when they depart, as politically contentious and seemingly intractable as ever.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-20-00; The Good Old Boys
description: Each generation of 25-year-old millionaires makes the previous one look good. Watching the new movie ''Boiler Room,'' about a young man who finds himself working in a corrupt brokerage firm, I actually felt nostalgic for the yuppies of the 1980's. ''Boiler Room'' is supposed to be set in the present, but its main effect is to transport you into the past, into the world of the Drexel Burnham Lambert-era stockjobbers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEIER, ABRAHAM
description: BLEIER-Abraham. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Abraham Bleier, associated with The Times from 1968 until retiring in 1988.

title: X + Y = Z
description: AS NATURE MADE HIM

title: Buffs; They Lost It At The Movies
description: ALEXANDER McQUEEN

title: Columbine Again
description: For the second time in 10 months, students from Columbine High School were shot to death. The bodies of two sophomores, Nicholas Kunselman, 15, and Stephanie Hart, 16, were found behind a counter in a Littleton, Colo., sandwich shop, just blocks from the school where two students killed 13 people, and then themselves, last April. Authorities, who said little about the latest shootings, interviewed scores of people in the area, hoping to learn whether robbery or something else was the motive. MICHAEL JANOFSKY

title: Treatment of Advanced Breast Cancer
description: Women who suffer from advanced, intractable breast cancer have been confronted with discouraging developments over the past year. Thousands had hoped that, after all else failed, an arduous procedure known as a bone marrow transplant might save them. But four major clinical trials reported last May found that women with advanced breast cancer who were given bone marrow transplants fared no better than women given conventional chemotherapy. This month, a well-publicized study in South Africa that appeared to show some benefit of the bone marrow transplant was acknowledged to be a fraud.

title: Replacing Insulated Glass Windows
description: MOST competent do-it-yourselfers can replace an ordinary pane of glass in a window sash without difficulty. A replacement pane can be easily cut to size at the local hardware store or home center, and the actual installation is usually a straightforward matter.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Shannon Zoe Johnson misstated the bridegroom's surname at one point. As noted elsewhere in the report, he is Gregg Richard Honigblum.

title: Overlooked
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Fuller Man

title: After the Chaos, a Happy Couple Get to Work
description: THREE years after they became the most publicized, criticized, scrutinized gay couple in Hollywood, if not the country, Ellen DeGeneres and Anne Heche have had enough.

title: Scholars Program
description: In a partnership of government, colleges and private foundations, Westchester will offer computers and online mentoring to low-income students who show academic promise.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In Carlstadt, Industrial Space for Cyberspace
description: IN an area around Central Boulevard in Carlstadt dotted with low-slung warehouses and manufacturing complexes the steel skeleton rising on a 12-acre site at the far western end of the thoroughfare is an anomaly. For it has more to do with cyberspace than industrial space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, AL
description: COHEN-Al, (Abraham). Devoted father of Judy Fischman, Richard and Rita Russell. Dear brother, of Sam and Nettie Cohen. Adored grandfather of Paula and Richard, Andrew, Paige and Ronnie, and Grant. Cherished great-grandfather of Jordan and Mitchell, Lauren and Zachary. Beloved longtime companion of Gus Salus. Services Sunday 11:30 AM at ''Gutterman's'' (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Boulevard, corner 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: The Belle of the Soft-Money Soiree
description: The gentle ladies on both sides of the political aisle are finding that killer fund-raising is one of the surest ways to be taken seriously in politics. John McCain, who must still raise money while denouncing raising money, has a woman as one of his chief fund-raisers: Georgette Mosbacher, the flame-haired New York businesswoman and socialite who is divorced from Robert Mosbacher, the Texas oilman and financial maestro of Bush p re's campaigns. While McCain brags about his small Internet donations, Georgette Mosbacher is gathering a windfall of $1,000 checks. Bill Bradley's financial Rolodex was built by Betty Sapoch, a New Jersey grandmother. Her fund-raising team surprised everyone last year by keeping pace with Al Gore's money machine. Beth Dozoretz, a top Clinton-Gore fund-raiser, became the Democratic Party's first female finance chairman early in 1999, though she left the job 10 months later after a reshuffling of the Democratic National Committee's leadership.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: STOCKARD CHANNING OWNS THE ROLE OF THE BRITTLE Ouisa Kittredge in SIX DEGREES OF SEPARATION (1993). She originated it in John Guare's stage satire, and she plays it in Fred Schepisi's film version (screen-play by Mr. Guare) to the hilt. Donald Sutherland is her art dealer husband. Will Smith is the young man who turns up at their elegant apartment needing assistance, claiming to be Sidney Poitier's son, offering them roles in the movie version of ''Cats'' and generally charming them to death. No, it's not as remarkable on screen as it was at Lincoln Center 10 years ago, but the style and bite remain - Sunday at 9 p.m., Sunday/Early Monday at 1 a.m., Monday at 1 p.m., Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 12:30 a.m. on Bravo.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PROSPECT HEIGHTS

title: With Cats, It's Living With an Attitude
description: ''LOVE Me, Love My Cat'' was the theme of a big cat show last Saturday at Lake Grove, organized by the Paumanok Cat Fanciers.

title: Health Is the Issue In Cell Tower Dispute
description: As an adamant opponent of the cellular antenna to be placed at Ossining High School, I feel compelled to respond to one of the letters on Feb. 6 [''Questioning the Aims of Tower Opponents'']. It is true that many people who oppose the antenna have cell phones. There was no need to ask this question, as this has never been a secret. In any event, the question of who uses cell phones is beside the point.

title: Kristen Shepherd, Mark Denner
description: Kristen Adelle Shepherd, the daughter of Judith A. Shepherd of Stuart, Fla., and George Shepherd of Tampa, Fla., is to be married today to Mark Andrew Denner, a son of Anne Denner and Dr. Melvin W. Denner of Evansville, Ind. Judge Jeffrey J. Colbath of the Criminal Court of Palm Beach County will perform the ceremony at Pan's Garden, a tropical garden maintained by the Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach.

title: Is Nothing Secular?
description: Rebecca Rivers may have missed the boat on the Bert and Ernie show, but she's right on the money otherwise. She's giving her son the greatest gift possible by breast-feeding him. And by the looks of things, she has got the system down pat.

title: Where Did All the A.T.M.'s Go? Area Becomes a Banking Desert
description: Fertilized by the brisk economy, bank machines have been cropping up in some Manhattan neighborhoods over the past few years. But most of the banks and cash machines serving Clinton have, one by one, closed their doors.

title: Mayor Renews Request for Release of Oil
description: Taking his dispute with the Clinton administration over federal energy policy to Staten Island, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met with a small group of homeowners yesterday and blamed the White House for the shock they are facing over heating bills.

title: Productivity's Up, and What of It?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chimps' Day in Court
description: RATTLING THE CAGE

title: Character Test
description: To the Editor:

title: A Borrowed Pitch Achieves The Desired Result for Bush
description: On the Sunday after Gov. George W. Bush limped out of New Hampshire, two of his aides were deep into a telephone conversation, searching for a new sales pitch that would put some swagger back into their campaign.

title: The American View
description: Fairfield Porter

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CONFESSIONS OF

title: Filmnotes; Marathon Woman
description: ''Run Lola Run,'' in which a determined young woman races through the streets of Berlin to stop her boyfriend from robbing a supermarket, is a toy of a movie, and its high-speed and impatient narrative hurtles along with the determination of a wide receiver stalking the goal. As with any great run by an athlete, ''Lola'' emerges as a star-making turn.

title: The Recycled Generation
description: If the photos (including your cover) that accompanied Hall's article are any indication of how The Times envisions my old age, then count me out. What an insult: a collection of old people dressed like clowns engaged in idiotic activities.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of cruise ships on Feb. 6 included an erroneous reference from the Cunard Line to fares on the Queen Elizabeth2 and the Caronia. Tips are no longer included.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Check Your Doors; Breaking In, Hacker-Style
description: THE first one rattled the doorknob at 3 a.m. Wednesday morning, trying to see if the door was open. The next came by an hour later, then one at 8 a.m., another at 10:30 and yet another at noon. At 1 p.m. a particularly determined intruder arrived, trying entrances that most people would not even think about. The final attempt of the day came at 3 p.m., but like all the rest, it was unsuccessful.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption today on Page 56 of Fashions of The Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about the actress Cate Blanchett, omits several words. It should read: ''With glue, mousse, false eyelashes and rollers, Cate Blanchett is transformed into a glamorous 1930's movie goddess. She couldn't have done it without the help of a top Hollywood makeup artist (Lobell) and hairstylist (Danilo) and of course those fabulous cheekbones.''

title: Food; Coming of Age
description: In a world where loss is measured in passing years and hope rests not in experience but in something new, the term ''well preserved'' summons as much misgiving as respect.

title: No Room for Second Best in Big Bang Race
description: PHYSICISTS at Brookhaven National Laboratory worked for 11 years and spent 600 million taxpayer dollars to build a gigantic machine for the sole purpose of smashing subatomic particles with such tremendous force as to recreate, for an instant, a primordial state of matter believed to have existed in the moments after the Big Bang.

title: Divided by Business Outlook, and by Race
description: PROMINENT black business executives on the Island have a warning for the growing number of black entrepreneurs who choose not to affiliate with established civic and business associations: If you're not in the room, you won't effect change.

title: A Sell-Off Answers a Greenspan Warning
description: Investors bit the bullet on Friday, selling shares with a vengeance and then hunkering down for a long weekend, thankful for Monday's reprieve from the spiraling market.

title: Feting the Founding Father
description: THOUGH the actual day is not until Tuesday, you can observe George Washington's 268th birthday today at ''Washington's Birthday Ball'' at the Mount Vernon Hotel Museum and Garden. Performers in period dress, like these shown above from last year's ball, will do traditional English country dances and teach the steps, to the background of live period music played on the hammered dulcimer, fiddle and flute. Tours of the 200-year-old museum building (formerly the Abigail Adams Smith Museum) will be offered throughout the afternoon.

title: Comparing the Districts: The '99 High School Report Cards
description: Since 1989, the State Department of Education has issued an annual Report Card for every public school in New Jersey - a compilation of data on everything from class size and test scores to per-pupil spending and what languages are spoken at home. The reports are meant to allow parents to see how their schools measure up, taxpayers to see where their money is going, and education officials to monitor progress - or lack of it - in the state's 2,200 public schools.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Sometimes my daughter says, 'Mommy, it's not fair. How come people here have cute houses and we don't? How come other people have cars and we don't?' I say, 'Because we are poor and they are rich, and that's the way it is here.' ''

title: The Recycled Generation
description: Michael D. West may be forgiven for his efforts to portray cell-replacement therapies as a new fountain of youth. After all, as the man who heads Advanced Cell Technology, he has a business to promote. But Stephen S. Hall (Jan. 30) did a disservice in presenting human stem-cell research primarily in these terms. It is unfortunate that as this debate begins, your article distracts us from the real issues by representing stem-cell research as a quest for immortality.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the planned initial public offering of Palm Inc. stock misstated the percentage of the company that will continue to be held by its parent, the 3Com Corporation. It is 92.8 percent to 93.3 percent; it is not 80 percent. The exact amount will depend on whether the underwriters fully exercise an option to buy Palm shares. In addition, 3Com plans to distribute the remainder of its Palm holdings to 3Com shareholders after six months.

title: Is Nothing Secular?
description: My compliments to Jeffrey Rosen on his article (Jan. 30). Today, America does seem to be stuck between the ''rock'' of new-millennium religiosity and ''hard place'' of hard-nosed secularism. Still, I fear the transition to ''the new vision of equal treatment for religion'' may not be all smooth going. Was there not a recent court case concerning armed-forces personnel who practiced witchcraft? ''Equal treatment for religion'' may spawn more such cases, in guises, perhaps, even less socially acceptable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, LILLIAN
description: GROSSMAN-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Stanley. Devoted mother of Barbara and Michael Peters. Dear sister of Esther Stevens. Loving grandmother of Scott, Bradley and Kimberly, Amy and Robert, and Elyssa. Adored greatgrandmother of Emma Hope and Molly Lauren. Services today, 11:30 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

title: Goran Tunstrom, 62, of Sweden; Wrote Novels, Plays and Poetry
description: Goran Tunstrom, one of Scandinavia's most prolific contemporary authors, died on Feb. 5 at his home in Stockholm. He was 62.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Illumination and Night Glare

title: Program Trains Teachers to Be Administrators
description: TEACHERS are not the only ones in short supply in the nation's schools. Superintendents and school boards are increasingly finding themselves scrambling when it is time to fill job vacancies at higher levels. Many teachers are reluctant to step up to an administrative position with more responsibility, pressure and accountability often for little more than they are already being paid.

title: Focus on an Earlier Escape Leads Marshals to a Fugitive
description: Federal marshals captured an escaped murder convict yesterday in Queens after focusing their search on some of the people he had contacted after an escape in 1989, officials said.

title: One-Stop Legal Service For Immigrants
description: THE phone in his home in Port-au-Prince kept ringing. The voices told the 31-year-old Haitian man that they would kill his father and rape his wife and his mother. A few days later, in September 1998, he bought an airplane ticket to the United States.

title: Corrections
description: The caption last Sunday with the Photographer's Journal picture, showing a clown sitting in a subway car, misstated the location. It was an E train in the Lexington Avenue station in Manhattan, not a G train in the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn.

title: The Scars of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Eileen Fennessy, Marc Weller
description: Eileen Catherine Fennessy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Fennessy of Garden City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Marc Denning Weller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Weller of Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Richard Keane performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: What Must He Do to Get Their Attention?
description: HIGHER interest rates, dead ahead.

title: Where Have All the Lyric Writers Gone?
description: NAME the most important lyric writers of the past half-century. Stephen Sondheim, without question; the lyricist who single-handedly deepened the American song tradition with penetrating verbal invention and an enlivening dose of psychological complexity. But also Bob Dylan, Paul Simon and Joni Mitchell, folk balladeers who infused lyric writing with the imagery and confessional aspect of modernist poetry. Their innovations created an entirely new tradition, or perhaps antitradition -- that of the self-absorbed singer-songwriter for whom, in the name of personal expression, all lyric-writing rules could be broken.

title: Jarrett Is Ahead of Field Before Daytona Starts
description: The thrill is far from gone. After a hectic off-season, in which he had to fulfill commitments virtually every day, Dale Jarrett says he is eager to begin defense of his Nascar Winston Cup Series championship. And why not? Robert Yates Racing, for whom Jarrett drives, may have made his job easier.

title: Youths Make Their Case in the Courtroom
description: THE defense lawyer rose from her seat, walked confidently to the lectern and looked Judge Samuel M. Levine squarely in the eye. ''Good afternoon, your honor. My name is Yael Kalban,'' she said, her voice firm and unwavering as she began her opening statement. ''And together with my colleagues, I represent the defendant, Mickey Jackson.''

title: Tale of Two Centuries With Dickensian Touch
description: IF it isn't one mystery, it's another or yet another at the Centenary Stage Company in Hackettstown. That they're all of the academic kind befits a theater company that happens to be part of a college -- Centenary College.

title: New Zealand Begins Defense With Victory
description: Three-and-a-half-million Kiwis let out a collective sigh of relief today after Team New Zealand, an unknown quantity before today's contest, began its first defense of the America's Cup with a decisive victory over Italy's Prada Challenge in Race 1 of the 30th cup competition. Race 2 of the five-of-nine finals is scheduled for Tuesday.

title: From an Era When Equality Mattered
description: OH, whoop-de-do and rah, rah, rah! Things are so great in New York right now! So much more excellent than before! Unless they're not. The death, last month, of the legendary city planner Ed Logue came as another grim reminder that New York's current triumphalist mood is as hollow as a plastic party horn. For many New Yorkers, Logue's name evokes an era when the quality of urban life was measured by something more than skyrocketing real estate prices, the banishment of homeless people from public sidewalks and the glitter of confetti falling from the sky. The ideal of social equality also figured in the equation.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. George W. Bush's victory speech last night in Columbia, S.C., as recorded by The New York Times.

title: A City Always Reinventing Itself
description: HERE are two sociological looks at New York City. One examines how political and cultural forces have influenced the development of the Lower East Side; the other is a sober explanation of how and why New York City became a place of continuous rebuilding. In O. Henry's succinct phrase, ''It'll be a great place if they ever finish it.''

title: Planned Parenthood Sees No Restriction at New Clinic
description: The headline on an article regarding the permit granted to us for a clinic in Massapequa [''Planned Parenthood Gets Limited Permit,'' Feb. 6] implied that Planned Parenthood of Nassau County had agreed to restrict its activities at the health center. This is simply not true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTHBERTSON, CUTHBERT
description: CUTHBERTSON - Cuthbert. Fe bruary 16, 2000. Age 90, in Essex Fells, NJ. He was Works Manager of the Western Electric Co. in Kearney, NJ, when he retired in 1974. Survived by a son, R. Bruce Cuthbertson of Key Biscayne, FL; a daughter, Terry Cuthbertson Pelster of Manhattan; and grandchildren Robert and Siu Mei Cuthbertson.

title: Filmnotes; Let There Be Lighting
description: The year was 1987, and flickering on the big screen of the Fine Arts Theater in Chicago was a film called ''Raising Arizona.'' Sitting in the audience was Janusz Kaminski, a 28-year-old film student, and there was something in the vivid performance of the movie's star, Holly Hunter, that resonated with him deeply, far beyond words. ''I was crazy about her,'' he remembers. ''This girl with this wonderful voice, this beautiful face, who made me cry in her determination to have some kind of romance in her life. She was a very determined character.''

title: Turkish Stores Square Off In a Battle Of Baklava
description: Immigrants in Sheepshead Bay do not expect to become involved in battles between their fellow countrymen. But customers at two Turkish stores have found themselves in just such a spot, caught between two sides of an escalating war for which the weapons include beef, bread and baklava.

title: Streetscapes/19 Gramercy Park South; An 1880's House That Asks, 'What's In a Name?'
description: THE house at 19 Gramercy Park South, with its strikingly elegant 1880's interiors, was called by the late critic Brendan Gill ''the greatest private house remaining in private hands in New York.'' The house was recently put on the market as ''a Stanford White house,'' in part because Mr. Gill had attributed part of it to the famed architect, and the asking price is $18 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINES, ROBERT
description: MINES-Robert. 12/14/37-2/18/00. Devoted husband of Marlene (nee Peck) for 38 years. Great father to Nicole, Craig and Elizabeth, Amy and Jamie. Awesome ''Pop Pop'' of Zachary and Jared. Social worker for 35 years. He helped many people through difficult times. He was always smiling. He will be sorely missed and loved forever. Services today Sunday, 11:00 AM at ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'' (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Blvd., corner of 66th Ave, Forest Hills, NY.

title: A Heavy Turnout Turned Tide for Bush
description: The sidewalk leading to the Oak Grove Civic Club is about 30 feet long, and at 7 a.m. it was packed with people waiting for the doors to open so they could vote. Unfortunately for Senator John McCain, most of them were there to vote for Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Natalie Pospolita, Jonathan Silverstein
description: Natalie Olga Pospolita, a daughter of Olga and Stefan Pospolita of New Haven, is to be married this evening to Jonathan Todd Silverstein, a son of Marjorie Mann of Boston and Dr. Leslie Silverstein of Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi Charles Lippman is to officiate at the Yale Club in New York. The Rev. Paul Luniw, a priest of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, will take part in the ceremony.

title: In London, Executing Triple Axel Jumps
description: ON Wednesday, the fourth day of London Fashion Week, the Evening Standard devoted half of its front page to a story about a leaked medical report concerning Pinochet's health (the headline in inch-and-a-half type read: ''Pinochet 'Now Has Brain Damage' ''). The other side had a full-length picture of Posh Spice walking down the runway for a young designer named Maria Grachvogel in a sleeveless turtleneck and shorts.

title: Following the Pioneers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lying to Get the Bad Guys
description: The Los Angeles County district attorney's office said last week that the city's metastasizing police scandal was likely to result in the overturning of hundreds of criminal convictions. Apparently a number of officers in the city's Rampart District planted evidence and perjured themselves to help get convictions; a few even became criminals themselves, dealing drugs and shooting competing dealers.

title: Ma's Teeth Travel In Cyberspace
description: HERE I am chatting with my mother long distance to Florida, no big news, just catching up, when she hits me with it:

title: A Terminal Takes Off
description: Flying wasn't always warm-up suits and molded plastic chairs. In fact, air travel was quite glamorous in 1935, when an Art Deco terminal was built at Newark International Airport, then seven years old. The building reflected this glamour with its marble columns, ruby terrazzo floor with inlaid eagle and rooftop restaurant. The building hasn't been used as a terminal since the 50's but has been used as administrative space, college classrooms and even a dentist's office. But the airport recently extended its runways, and the building is now too close to one to be inhabited. Rather than let the 380-foot-long terminal lie fallow, the Port Authority will actually move it about a mile west, fix it up and use it for exhibitions and tours. The structure will be cut in thirds and moved via jacks and dollies down a taxiway. Estimated time of departure is this summer.

title: Patricia Parra, Hamilton Hadden IV
description: Patricia Marcela Parra, a daughter of Brenda Memoli Puig of Miami and Aimar Nestor Parra of Buenos Aires, was married yesterday to Hamilton Hadden IV, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton III of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas N. Oates, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Deering Estate in Miami.

title: THEATER; Making Room for Remembering
description: NOT long after the 1991 musical ''Nick and Nora,'' which he directed and for which he wrote the book, became one of Broadway's famous flops, that man of the theater Arthur Laurents said the hell with it and went back to his first job in show business -- writing plays.

title: Seeking a New Bounce at Pepsi
description: GARY M. RODKIN, the chief executive of Pepsi-Cola North America, has not just one all-time favorite film, but four.

title: The Theatergoer
description: Maybe it's a reaction to the dressing down of America, or the fact that she wears jeans every day as a stay-at-home mom to a toddler, but Nicole Vink, 33, has earned a reputation in Glen Cove, N.Y., for being an overdresser. ''When I go out, I always tend to be more dressed than I have to,'' she said. ''When I have parties, I go formal. People are really surprised.''

title: Artist-Run Galleries Open on 'Next Frontier'
description: When four art galleries opened within four weeks and several blocks of one another in the vicinity of Franklin Street late last year, their founders were mystified.

title: Game's Business Side Goes On for Ravens
description: These days have been busy, and stressful, for the Baltimore Ravens' owner, Art Modell. ''I've aged 40 years in the last two weeks,'' he said.

title: Richard Rosenblum, 59, Sculptor And a Collector of Asian Art
description: Richard Rosenblum, a sculptor and a collector of Asian art, died on Tuesday at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 59.

title: He's Looked at Life From Both Sides Now
description: SPENDING half your life among the dead teaches you something about living.

title: It's Not Too Early To Think Spring
description: Branches of winter hazel (Corylopsis), apricot, red maple and quince can be forced into bloom now. Place in buckets of lukewarm water in a cool place for a week, and keep moist by wrapping in wet newsprint to prevent buds from drying out and dropping off before they open.

title: Productivity's Up, and What of It?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWARK ARENA
description: It was one step backward and one step forward this past week for Newark's dreams of being home to a downtown sports arena for the Nets and the Devils. On Monday the City Council voted to start over with hearings to designate as blighted the commercial and residential area where Mayor Sharpe James hopes to build the arena. The rehearing on the plan, already a year old, was an attempt to placate landowners who had tied the city up in court over charges that they were not properly notified. Then on Tuesday, Mayor James got assurances from the YankeeNets' newly-named president and chief operating officer, Harvey Schiller, that locating in Newark ''is a specific objective'' of the sports company. RONALD SMOTHERS

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-20-00: Questions for Helen Fielding; Me and Ms. Jones
description: Q: One of the most striking aspects of the whole Bridget Jones phenomenon is how strongly readers associate with the character -- and how eager they seem to conflate your identity with hers. I was pretty startled when a celebrated novelist actually addressed you as Bridget on a morning news program.

title: Train or Plane To Boston?
description: AMTRAK began all-electric train service between New York and Boston at the end of January, paring 45 minutes off the time for the old part-electric, part-diesel trip, bringing it down to 3 hours 59 minutes. As a way of traversing 231 miles, it is still no world-beater, and in fact, a 1941 timetable shows the Merchants Limited chuffing from Grand Central to South Station in only 16 minutes longer.

title: SMOKING BAN IN PRINCETON
description: Restaurant and bar owners in Princeton and Princeton Borough are opposing a proposed ordinance that would ban smoking everywhere except inside homes, outdoors and in cigar shops. The ban, introduced last week by the Princeton Regional Health Commission, would be the most restrictive smoking law in the state. WENDY GINSBERG

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 6 about a surge in retirements from the Nassau County Police Department misstated the number of detectives who retired in the last two years. A spokesman for the department said it was 6 in 1998 and 12 in 1999; the figure of 35 for each of the two years represented retirements departmentwide, including those of detectives.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 6 about the alto saxophonist Charles McPherson misstated his birthplace. It was Joplin, Mo., not Detroit.

title: In Suit Over Valentines, Life Imitates a Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: In The Region/Long Island; Squeezing Out Space in a Tight Office Market
description: THE announcement by Cablevision Systems Corporation of Bethpage earlier this month that it had signed a long-term lease for a 310,633-square-foot building at 200 Jericho Quadrangle in Jericho has taken a major block of space away from Long Island's already tight office market.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: The picture of Rebecca Rivers and her children was charming (Jan. 30). I liked Rebecca's insight that husbands are ''kind of a convenience.'' She might consider having friends and relatives as father substitutes to share some of the delights of life with Violet and Xavier and to give her some time out.

title: Critics of Park Fences Show Lack of Awareness
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/Bill Lessard; Internet Through the Eyes of an Underling
description: INSTEAD of fuming at your computer's latest problem, thank a technical support person. Understand that he or she may be overworked and underpaid, abused by the employer, a person who may have thought of getting rich in technology but is now a so-called net slave.

title: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks
description: In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.

title: Bookend; Way Behind Every Great Man . . .
description: Hats off to the helpmeet! Her long-suffering martyrdom has paid off, and she's finally getting her due -- from feminists, no less. A few years back, to champion her cause was career suicide. Remember Beatrice Nest, the middle-aged English professor in A. S. Byatt's ''Possession,'' who toiled, mocked by colleagues and snubbed by students, in the basement of the British Museum? Her mistake? Devoting three decades and her scholarly reputation to a Victorian housewife named Ellen Ash, the spouse of an Eminent Victorian. Years of work on her diaries and letters had revealed only that Ellen was dutiful and dull. Who wanted to read about Ellen when you could read her husband's poetry instead?

title: Productivity's Up, and What of It?
description: To the Editor:

title: HEPATITIS B VACCINES
description: The New Jersey Public Health Council last week took the first major step toward requiring schoolchildren to be vaccinated against hepatitis B before entering school. New Jersey is one of only eight states that does not require the vaccination, although the state has one of the highest rates of hepatitis B for infants, said Tom Breslin, a spokesman for the state Department of Health and Senior Services. The council voted to publish the regulation in the New Jersey Register. If it is approved after the public hearings, children entering the public schools in September 2001 and any unvaccinated sixth graders would be required to have the vaccination. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Net's Rise Keeps a Lid On Prices, For Now
description: A FEW weeks ago, I went shopping for a 32-inch television set. I visited a couple of local electronics superstores, read Consumer Reports, talked to friends. And I searched the Internet, where I found just the highly rated, feature-laden model I wanted, for $750, shipping included. No tax.

title: Possible Apollo Strike May Hinder Gore-Bradley Debate
description: Stagehands gathered outside the Apollo theater in Harlem yesterday threatening a walkout, two days before a scheduled Democratic presidential debate at the historic theater.

title: Austria Won't Crawl, Its Chief Says, Scolding Europe
description: Wolfgang Schussel has only to gaze from his window at the creamy Hapsburg palaces to know that the tumult of history is no stranger to this town. But seldom has a modern Austrian leader been as lonely as he is, or as angry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALSIMER, ADELE M.
description: DALSIMER-Adele M. Of Brookline, MA, on February 13th, 2000. Co-founder and Co-director of the Irish Studies Program at Boston College. Distinguished author, scholar, and teacher. Cherished wife of Dr. James S. Dalsimer. Beloved mother of Jennifer Dalsimer Archer and Joshua Dalsimer and proud mother-in-law of Glenn Archer. Doting grandmother of Nate and Samantha Archer. Devoted daughter of Ida and Buddy Mintz and dear sister of Sandy Mintz. Adored friend, cousin, aunt, and colleague to so many. We mourn the passing of this extraordinary woman of passion and accomplishment. She will be deeply missed.

title: The Galapagos, a Bold Eden
description: IN the Galapagos, we walked right up to red-footed boobies sitting on their eggs, and they didn't even flinch. These gull-like birds treated us as if we were invisible. We swam up to sea lions, and they didn't flinch. We might have rubbed noses with them if we hadn't been wearing diving masks. We strolled up to many other animals -- iguanas, giant land tortoises, penguins and Darwin's many varieties of finches -- and none of them flinched.

title: Art Girls Just Wanna Have Fun
description: It is unclear from Deborah Solomon's article (Jan. 30) whether the magazine's censorship of the works by the four artists was a sincere effort to protect readers or a sophomoric joke about the body as a subject in art. But it is certain that the decision to obscure the artwork with black bars was a poor one, indicating little respect for the artists, their work or your readers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: With Governor's Backing, Bush Hopes to Win Next Primary Battle
description: Having won the Republican primary in South Carolina, Gov. George W. Bush plans to spend Sunday and Monday here, seeking to deal another blow to Senator John McCain's aspirations in this state's primary on Tuesday.

title: Indecision Feeds The Dogs of War
description: KOSOVSKA MITROVICA is the divided town in northern Kosovo where Serbia effectively begins. In the last three weeks, long-festering tensions between Serbs to the north of the Ibar River and Albanians to the south have burst into violence that international peacekeepers have only slowly managed to control -- after they, too, became targets.

title: IN MY...BRIEFCASE: GIL D. SCHWARTZ
description: AS the senior vice president of communications for the CBS Corporation, Gil D. Schwartz lives a double life: one is the fearsome public-relations watchdog for the broadcaster; the other is the author and Fortune columnist Stanley Bing, a wry satirist of the business world. His most recent book under the Bing nom de plume is ''What Would Machiavelli Do?'' (HarperBusiness), a tongue-in-cheek guide to success in the 21st century. He has also written novels -- Tom Hanks bought the film rights to one of them, ''Lloyd: What Happened'' (Crown, 1998).

title: A Familiar Friend's Stylish New Entry
description: INTERMEZZO has gone big time. The Fort Salonga storefront trattoria has opened a stylish second restaurant at one of the Island's busiest intersections, hired Roland Iadanza, a highly regarded chef who worked at Bruzell's in Great Neck for the past 11 years, and is serving more sophisticated, upscale dishes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, SARAH
description: SILVERMAN-Sarah. May 30, 1903-February 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Alexander, extraordinarily loving mother of Walter, thrilled grandmother of Aaron, Rachel, Thomas and William. Deeply devoted daughter of the late Rose and Nathan, loving sister of the late Celia, Jeanne and Max. Graduate of the Cooper Union and the Beaux Arts in Paris, silk screen designer, successful and creative businesswoman, owner of Kay Studio, friend and woman of culture, grace and refinement. She loved her life, family and friends immensely. Laid to rest in private graveside services at Wellwood Cemetery. Sarah will forever remain in the heart of her son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELER, INA
description: KESSELER-Ina. On February 19, 2000 in New York City at 89 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Peter J. Kesseler, sister of Irene Gotthelf of Munich, Germany, stepmother of Dr. Howard J. Kesseler of Palm Beach, Florida and the late Dr. Edward P. Kesseler, and loving grandmother of their seven children. A memorial service will be held at the German Evangelical-Lutheran Church of St. Paul, 313-315 W. 22nd St., New York City on Thursday, March 9, 2000, at 2:30 in the afternoon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Germanistic Society of America, Quadrille Account, 6 E. 87th St., NY, NY 10128.

title: 15 Are Dead As Rebels Hit A Helicopter In Chechnya
description: Chechen guerrillas shot down a Russian military helicopter on Friday in mountains near the Argun gorge in southern Chechnya, killing 15 people, Russian officials and Chechen rebels said today.

title: For Richer or Richer
description: ''It's not fair that you didn't get to ask me all those questions, and I didn't get put on the spot.''

title: A Site for Diminutive Offerings
description: The biggest funds and fund families get lots of attention. (See the item above.) But research has shown that it is often the smallest offerings that achieve the best results, although they may warrant nary a mention in business publications.

title: Critics of Park Fences Show Lack of Awareness
description: To the Editor:

title: Allison Coberg, Brian Kelly
description: Allison Kristin Coberg, a daughter of Ann and John Coberg of Valley Cottage, N.Y., was married yesterday to Brian Anthony Kelly, a son of Ann Marie Kelly and Judge William A. Kelly of New City, N.Y. Msgr. Thomas Gilleece performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Chapel in Sparkill, N.Y.

title: What Is a Colonial House?
description: To the Editor:

title: Arms and the I.R.A.
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, who shut down the government of Northern Ireland , continued to keep it shut over disagreements on how the Irish Republican Army should disarm its arsenal of weapons, despite demands from Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, that the government be restored. Mr. Adams's demands were met by counter demands from Mr. Blair, Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, and Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble that the I.R.A. first return to disarmament talks.

title: In Philadelphia, a Speculative Office Project Begins
