description: THE first speculative office project in almost a decade is under way in downtown Philadelphia, as a 20-story building atop a commuter railroad hub is about to be stripped down to its steel skeleton.

title: Unbowed, McCain Insists He Is the 'Reformer'
description: Hardly bowed by his defeat in South Carolina, a defiant Senator John McCain vowed tonight that his insurgent campaign would grow stronger, and he immediately began portraying Gov. George W. Bush as a pretender to the reform mantle.

title: Recipe for Joy: Danish Dogma Plus Samurai
description: THE idea that rules can bring freedom may seem teasingly contradictory, but Soren Kragh-Jacobsen needed little persuading when two fellow Danish movie directors, Lars von Trier and Thomas Vinterberg, invited him to sign onto Dogma '95, their 10-point ''vow of chastity'' designed to liberate filmmaking from technology by banning everything from special lighting to post-production dubbing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREAVES, MELVIN
description: GREAVES-Melvin. February 20, 1995. We miss you O so much. Sally, Leslie and Melanie

title: When It Pays to Argue With A Spouse
description: THERE are those who may think it is something out of an Edward Albee play, or maybe ''The Newlywed Game'' meets Jerry Springer. But for the couple tired of flowers, chocolates and renting Nora Ephron films, it could just be another way to celebrate their love.

title: Our Man in Capri
description: Greene on Capri

title: The Second Sexual Revolution
description: It was only two years ago that Bob Dole went on ''The Larry King Show'' to discuss his prostate-cancer operation. During a commercial break, so the story goes, King leaned over to ask his old friend, confidentially, how he was dealing with the operation's grimmest side effect, impotence. Dole cheerfully informed the talk-show host that there was a new drug, Viagra, and miraculously, it had cured the problem. King asked Dole if he would discuss it on the air, and Dole said sure, why not?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHNEIDER, LORRAINE CONHEIM
description: SCHNEIDER-Lorraine Conheim. February 17, 1955. In ever loving memory, Sister Marilyn

title: Biomedicine Is Receiving New Scrutiny as Scientists Become Entrepreneurs
description: Dr. H. Kirk Hammond, a cardiologist at the University of California in San Diego, never envisioned himself an entrepreneur. ''I'm a blue jeans-wearing, tieless character,'' he said. But when he invented a gene therapy technique to treat heart disease, he did what any self-respecting academic scientist does these days: he started a biotechnology company.

title: Web Site for Views About Brookhaven Reactor
description: I wondered why the public comment period was not mentioned in ''Brookhaven Lab's Old Reactor Is Finally Being Dismantled'' [Feb. 13]. The Department of Energy has invited the public to review the proposed disposal methods for the Brookhaven Graphite Research Reactor and send to them their comments through Feb. 28. The draft document is available on the Web at www.bgrr.bnl.gov /docs.html.

title: A Push to Agree on a Drive-Through Future
description: IMAGINE your car as a digital appliance, like a laptop computer or a cellular phone. Picture rolling through any toll plaza in North America without having to stop -- and picking up your e-mail as you pass. Warnings of traffic jams or poor road conditions ahead pop up on your dashboard, along with a map of the best alternate route. Drive-through fast food, fuel, a wash and wax for the car, parking in a downtown garage, are all charged to your monthly bill without human intervention.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: While I Was Gone

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 20, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Marketing, as Taught By Credit Card Issuers
description: FOR Erica Butts, 18, a freshman at the University of Maryland, the credit card companies scattered around campus offering gifts like drink coolers and pens were hard to miss. They were even harder to ignore.

title: For Drivers of S.U.V.'s, Ways to Make Amends
description: To the Editor:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Reality Check; A Small Step for Man, A Giant Leap of Faith
description: FOR those who grew up in the 1950's and 60's, mesmerized by the predictions in Life magazine or The Saturday Evening Post of exploring the solar system and establishing colonies on the Moon and Mars, it might have been a little depressing to gaze half a century ahead to what counts as a big space story in the year 2000: the visit of an unmanned craft -- with not even a dog or a monkey inside -- to a lifeless asteroid barely beyond Earth.

title: A.T.M. BAN ON HOLD
description: A United States District Court judge last week barred Woodbridge Township from enforcing an ordinance preventing banks from charging a fee to noncustomers using their automatic teller machines. The Township Council unanimously passed an ordinance that would make Woodbridge the first municipality in the state to ban the fees. Two days later, District Judge Joseph A. Greenaway Jr. granted the New Jersey Bankers Association's request for a restraining pending a full hearing of the association's challenge to the ordinance. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: A Drippy Nuclear Plant
description: A leaky pipe inside a steam generator at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in Buchanan, N.Y., may have released a puff of radioactive gas into the atmosphere. The plant's owner, Consolidated Edison, said there had been signs of leaks weeks before, but said that radiation levels near the plant were one-fifth ''the exposure you currently get just from walking in a park, standing on a rock.''

title: Colombia's Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrong Message
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTINE, SYDNEY A.
description: GOLDSTINE-Sydney A., MD. Ninety-one years. Passed on February 13 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Cherished and loving husband of Tamie Laurance Goldstine. Loving father of Jonathan and Thea. Loving grandfather of Susan. Affiliated with Mt. Sinai Hospital forty years, he was a devoted physician and friend to many over a long, satisfying medical career. A true gentleman and scholar. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St., NYC on March 1st at 4 p.m. Donations in his memory may be made to the Palliative Care Program, Attn: Dr. Diane Meier, Mt. Sinai Hospital School of Medicine, Box 1070, NY, NY 10029.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHERTOFF, SKIP
description: CHERTOFF-Skip. You are remembered in books. You are ever present in so many lives. You are always in my heart. We miss you and love you every day. Toni and Deirdre

title: PUBLISHER TO HOBOKEN
description: John Wiley & Sons, the Manhattan publisher, is close to a deal to relocate its headquarters to the Hoboken waterfront. SJP Properties, a Parsippany real estate development firm, is planning to build two office towers totalling 1.1 million square feet on land owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, adjacent to the renovated Hoboken Terminal. If the deal is finalized, Wiley, which employs more than 800 people in Manhattan, would occupy about 300,000 square feet of one of the towers. Groundbreaking for the 18-month project is expected by late summer or fall. Susan Spilka, Wiley's director of corporate communications, said the company had been negotiating about moving to Hoboken, but no agreement had been signed. KRISTEN MARTIN

title: By Bus to Luang Prabang, Home of Laotian Kings
description: THE bus looked empty -- but then I spotted the chicken. Tethered in the aisle by a foot of plastic string, it squawked and skittered around my ankles as I hauled my backpack down the row of empty seats. I chuckled to myself and settled in for a long haul: an 11-hour ride through the mountains of Laos on a public bus from Vientiane to Luang Prabang.

title: Evergreens, the Stalwart Beauties of Winter
description: WINTER'S snowfall always has a magical element. There are tufts of white sitting like outsized hats on the shrubs. Tree limbs hang with fat white sleeves. The lawn has a new carpet. The landscape is made new, and best of all, the evergreens come into their own.

title: Appearances; Two-Faced Woman
description: Movie stars! There's something kitschy in the term -- actors and actresses appearing as constellations in the firmament. Only, unlike Perseus and Cassiopeia, movie stars do not have places assured for millenniums. Each year an Oort Cloud of starlets streaks across our consciousness and fades without a trace. Some faces still shine, however, across tens, if not thousands, of years. These are the ones whose images are archetypes: Katharine Hepburn, the independent woman; Jean Harlow, the platinum seductress; Joan Crawford, the manipulative schemer.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Pontiac Bonneville; A Juvenile Show-Off In a Full-Grown Body
description: FOR better or worse, ''brand management'' is the rage at car companies. The concept -- aiming products at distinct, well-defined target markets -- has thrown Detroit's traditional business model on its ear. Instead of trying to put some sort of Pontiac in every garage, General Motors decides what kind of customers Pontiac should have, asks them what they want and then tries to deliver.

title: Dynamo And Microchip
description: You might have expected that in this election year the economic report of the president -- a survey published each February -- would be a highly political document, eagerly claiming credit for our giddy prosperity. But say what you like about their boss, Bill Clinton's economists have always been admirably honest and evenhanded in their reporting. The self-congratulatory boilerplate is actually minimal, and the thrust of this report is that technology, not policy, is the main source of good news.

title: Kathleen Schmid, Mark Koltko-Rivera
description: Kathleen Marie Schmid and Mark Edward Koltko-Rivera were married on Tuesday in the Lampman Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary in New York. Bishop James C. Green of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints performed the ceremony.

title: New Biography Recalls the Dazzle And Genius of a True Jazz Original
description: IN the jazz world, Rahsaan Roland Kirk was famous as a composer and as a musician who played a multitude of instruments -- sometimes at the same time. His musical ideas encompassed everything from traditional jazz to avant-garde music. He had a zeal for playing that was exceptional even among jazz musicians.

title: About Sam Shepard's Kitchen
description: WELCOME to Sam Shepard's designer kitchen in ''Curse of the Starving Class.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, SYLVIA
description: GOLDNER-Sylvia. On February 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Barney. Loving mother of Jacqueline and Marlene. Proud grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: The View From/Hartford; From the 19th Century, Faces in Formal Style
description: A REMARKABLE, if little known, 19th-century figure comes to life in a new exhibition at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: Welcome to the Onetime Fire Wall State
description: A few days before yesterday's South Carolina primary, a Reuters/ Zogby poll of Republicans, Democrats and independents showed Gov. George W. Bush with 42.7 percent and Senator John McCain with 42 percent. And this was supposed to have been Mr. Bush's fire wall state -- the one he would win in a cakewalk.

title: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks; Big Tanks, Big Bills
description: In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.

title: Style; Floats Like A Butterfly
description: In the world of design, it's common knowledge that Anthony Baratta fears no color. The decorator's New York apartment (The New York Times Magazine, Nov. 1, 1998) is a skillfully controlled riot of warm, saturated hues. But for his Miami Beach pad, Baratta -- in collaboration with his business partner, William Diamond -- turned his genius for color in a lighter, breezier direction. The clashing patterns, abrupt scale changes and juxtapositions of old and new are still there -- but this time, in a resort-wear version.

title: Complex Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Public TV Isn't Public Enough, Producers Say
description: Anna Vitale, president of the Association of Cable Access Producers, says she is working on a satire about dealing with the management of Queens Public Television.

title: Dog Halters Work Well, And They're Not Muzzles
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 36 of Arts & Leisure today about a new generation of lyric writers misattributes the lyrics for ''The Red Shoes.'' They were by Marsha Norman and Bob Merrill (under the pseudonym Paul Stryker), not Susan Birkenhead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINGOLD, SOLOMON
description: FEINGOLD-Solomon. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Solomon Feingold, associated with The Times from 1961 until retiring in 1978.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-20-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Howie Bamforth,

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about an election rally in Iran misidentified a song that was sung at the rally. It was not the former national anthem; it was another patriotic song from the era before the Islamic revolution in 1979.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Media Talk column of Business Day last Monday about the Internet magazine Industry Standard and its quandary in covering companies in which its owners have invested misidentified the magazine's parent. It is IDG. (IDG Books Worldwide is another unit of IDG.)

title: Mr. Bush Swings Back
description: The unpredictable Republican presidential campaign entered a new phase with Gov. George W. Bush's numerically impressive but tactically brutal victory in the South Carolina primary. Having established his resilience as a campaigner, Mr. Bush now has a chance to all but knock out Senator John McCain in Michigan. But the South Carolina spectacle was an expensive contest for both the candidates and their party. It exposed cleavages and identity issues within Republicanism that have been brewing for 20 years. And both the winner and the loser leave their highly personal conflict in South Carolina with big unanswered questions about who they really are.

title: A Jazz Club Turns 65, No Retirement Planned
description: As a jazz-crazed member of the Hot Club of Newark, 17-year-old Lorraine Stein made her first pilgrimage to the Village Vanguard in 1940, five years after it opened in a former basement speak-easy on Seventh Avenue South in the West Village. She and American jazz have not been the same since.

title: Evangelicals Found a Believer in Bush
description: The Rev. Allen Phillips said today that when members of his evangelical church in North Spartanburg voted for Gov. George W. Bush in the South Carolina primary, it was a matter of spiritual affinity rather than an organized effort by the Christian right.

title: Saku Journal; A Postmodern Plague Ravages Japan's Workers
description: The air is remarkably crisp in this town at the edge of Japan's ski country. The streets are uncluttered with traffic. And unlike in high-decibel Tokyo, the prevailing sound here is that of silence.

title: Iran Reformers' Gains Reflected In Homages to Outspoken Cleric
description: Iran's reformers, increasingly convinced that they have wrested control of the Parliament from religious conservatives, put their confidence on full display today by paying homage to the most outspoken clerical advocate of change and democracy, Abdullah Nouri.

title: NPR Starts Music Program Strictly for Internet Users
description: National Public Radio has quietly inaugurated its first Internet-only radio program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REXACH, RODNI L.
description: REXACH-Rodni L. On February 19, 2000. (Former employee of Hermes and Firestone International). Cherished friend of Donald and Dorothy Carroll, Jeff Nichols and Xavier Guerrand. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Brooklyn.

title: Tentative Pact Set to Expand Agents' Power In Hollywood
description: This town's talent agents, facing rising competition from talent managers, are no longer satisfied with merely being powerful and rich. They want an even bigger share of the entertainment industry's financial pie.

title: Serbs in Kosovo Town Stone U.S. Troops, Who Retreat
description: Angry Serbs stoned, punched and kicked American troops in the northern, Serb-dominated district of this town today, forcing them to beat a hasty retreat and cut short their part in a citywide search for weapons. German troops also came under a hail of stones in the same area.

title: A Beer Baron and a Powerful Publisher Put McCain on a Political Path
description: When Senator John McCain of Arizona describes the people who shaped his life, he invariably dwells on the influence of his father and grandfather, both distinguished Navy admirals and larger-than-life figures. Less widely known are the roles played by two other powerful men in launching his political career.

title: Bush Barked, but Voters Felt Only McCain's Bite
description: It was the attack ad that bit back.

title: In the War of 'All Politics, All the Time,' NBC Is Heavily Armed
description: ''Good morning, Ann. On this last day of campaigning, Governor Bush awakes to some good news. Good morning, Ann. On this last day of campaigning, Governor Bush awakes to some encouraging news. Good morning, Ann . . . ''

title: The Army Is American, The General Canadian
description: Soldiers on this sprawling post in central Texas snap to salute when Maj. Gen. Rick J. Hillier strides by. He is, after all, deputy commander of the Army's Third Corps and its 57,000 troops. But there is something unusual about this lanky officer that gives soldiers pause.

title: Make Rules for Copters
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; Central Issue Is Left Unsaid In Diallo Case
description: CALL it the fifth defendant in the case. The unindicted co-conspirator -- the Street Crime Unit of the New York Police Department.

title: OP-ART; Coming Soon To Fox
De La Hoya at the Crossroads
description: A crisis of confidence had struck the resident of the big cedar log cabin at the corner of De La Hoya Street and Golden Boy Avenue in this mountain resort town three hours east of Los Angeles. It clung to him like a sweat-soaked T-shirt before, during and immediately after his loss to Felix Trinidad last September, the first loss of his professional career.

title: A Will to Work, and Finally, a Way
description: One morning last month, Nathaniel Washington was about to leave his Brooklyn apartment for work when his wife, Christine, noticed his left eye drooping and his lower lip quivering. Seeing these telltale signs of epileptic seizures, which have plagued her husband since infancy, Mrs. Washington told him to take his coat off and lie down.

title: UConn vs. St. John's: Having Any Fun Yet?
description: Coach Jim Calhoun of Connecticut heard the leather slam against the hardwood and an anguished bellow as the basketball ricocheted high above the Huskies' home court at the Harry A. Gampel Pavilion. He was not sure who did it, but he knew when and why. It was about three weeks ago, when the police were investigating whether two of his freshmen had improperly received merchandise from a clothing store in Hartford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, ISAAC, JUDGE
description: RUBIN-Isaac, Judge. Of Rye, died February 19, 2000. He was 86. Justice Rubin was born in Mt. Vernon, NY, on May 9, 1913, to Hyman and Celia (nee Kahn) Rubin. He married Lucille Lyons on June 19, 1949. He was a veteran of the army serving in World War II. Justice Rubin's career spanned 30 years of judicial experience. It began as City Court Judge of Rye, NY, in 1970. He was appointed to the County Court of Westchester in 1973 by Governor Malcolm Wilson, then was elected to a full term as County Court Judge in 1974, and to the New York State Supreme Court in 1976. He was appointed Supervising Judge of the Criminal Parts for the Ninth Judicial District. In 1982, Governor Carey appointed Justice Rubin to the Appellate Division Second Department and he was reappointed in 1984 by Governor Cuomo. He retired as a member of the Court in late 1990, and has been serving since then as a Judicial Hearing Officer for the Supreme Court and the Appellate Division. Justice Rubin was President of the Westchester County Bar Association from '71-'73, and a Director of the Westchester Bar for over 20 years. Prior to joining the bench, Justice Rubin was in private practice in Mt. Vernon. Among his many honors Justice Rubin received the Judge Weinfeld Award for Professional Distinction from New York University School of Law and in 1998 received the prestigious Hopkins Award given by the Westchester County Bar. He graduated New York University School of Law with a J.D. degree. Subsequently he was awarded a J.S.D. from St. John's University School of Law. He is survived by his wife, Lucille; children Charles (wife Susan Shapiro) and Carol Rubin Kahn (husband Gary); and his granddaughter Gabrielle Kahn. He was the cherished brother of the late Dr. David Rubin, Milton Rubin and Elizabeth Harr. Service Tuesday, February 22, 1 PM, at the Westchester Jewish Center, Palmer Ave., Mamaroneck, followed by interment at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions are directed to Family Services of Westchester, 1 Summit Ave., White Plains, NY. For more information contact Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck, NY, 914381-1809.

title: Marbury Puts Ghosts to Rest In His Return to Minnesota
description: Stephon Marbury strolled into the Target Center today knowing that an entire state was eagerly awaiting his failure, that almost everyone in the crowd of 19,449 wanted to see him broken and humiliated. He knew there would be boos, taunts and disparaging signs and that the fans who once cheered him would do everything in their vocal power to make his 23rd birthday a horrible one.

title: Brazil Collides With I.M.F. Over a Plan to Aid the Poor
description: A new Brazilian government plan to spend more than $22 billion on social programs in the next decade has led to a squabble with the International Monetary Fund, which argues that the money should be used to reduce Brazil's indebtedness rather than to fight poverty.

title: Republicans Again Courting Democrats and Independents
description: With time, money, momentum and the Republican machine in Michigan working against him, Senator John McCain is trying to corral an unlikely coalition of moderate suburban Republicans, urban Democrats and feisty blue-collar independents.

title: A Pardon for Suharto
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rising Republican Star, and Very Much His Own Man
description: REPRESENTATIVE J. C. WATTS Jr. is the only black Republican in Congress. He is also the communicator in chief for his party in the House, and a rising national conservative star.

title: Working Too Hard?
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Brokers In McCain's Past
description: When Senator John McCain describes the people who shaped his life, he invariably mentions his father and grandfather, both distinguished Navy admirals. Less widely known are two other powerful men who helped launch his political career: his wealthy father-in-law, James W. Hensley, and Darrow Tully, an Arizona newspaper publisher who was part of a group of self-appointed kingmakers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Al Gore's record and personal history referred incorrectly in some copies to the year Arlie Schardt was Mr. Gore's communications director. It was 1988, not 1999.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Once Again, a Generous Dose of Messiaen
description: Who could have guessed a year ago, when there came the seemingly rare opportunity to hear all of Messiaen's organ works in expert performances and relatively quick succession, that another would come around so soon, with the time frame even more condensed?

title: Rebroadcast of Marriage Show Is Canceled
description: Reacting to new questions about the background of Rick Rockwell, the man who presented himself as a multimillionaire and married a woman on a highly rated television special last week, the Fox network yesterday abruptly canceled a rebroadcast of the show that had been scheduled for tomorrow night.

title: A Weekend Sweep for Lukas
description: D. Wayne Lukas completed a sweep of the weekend stakes for 3-year-old horses today when his star filly, Cash Run, won the Davona Dale Stakes at Gulfstream Park by seven lengths.

title: Duplicates in the Name Game
description: Bridge players enjoy duplicate but dislike duplication, which comes in three varieties. One is technical; a suit holding of ace-king opposite a void, for example, is a waste and tends to produce overambitious contracts. The second is organizational; in many tournaments players must duplicate the deals, a tedious job that may lead to penalties if done carelessly. The third is nominal, a duplication of names that confuses matters for everyone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, DORIS
description: SUSSMAN-Doris. On February 19, 2000. Beloved wife of David. Loving mother of Allan Sussman and Elaine Shafran. Dear sister of Shirley Pollak and Hope Hershey. Cherished grandmother to Jordan and Adam Shafran, Dana, Jeffrey, and Wendi Sussman. Services Tuesday, 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: For Yarnall, Success Is Around the Bend
description: If Ed Yarnall's professional self-esteem was built on what others thought of his raw ability, he would be in serious trouble. He knows hitters watch him warm up and see him in the same open-mouthed way lions view a zebra. He knows because he has heard their taunts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, FRANCES
description: LEVINE-Frances. Joy, Barbara, Gail, Norm and all her New York friends mourn with deep sorrow the loss of our dear friend Fran. Her brightness of spirit, love of life, fierce independence, loyalty and sense of humor will be sorely missed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Industry View; The news media provide regular updates on everything from traffic to weather. So why not an 'Internet update'?
description: IN the midst of the recent service disruptions at several high-profile Web sites, television viewers who tuned in to the evening news might have noticed the decidedly technical turn the programs had taken. For those who were otherwise engaged, picture the incongruous image of a network television anchor earnestly explaining the intricacies of the ''denial of service'' attacks that shut down the likes of Yahoo, eBay and E*Trade.

title: For Jarrett, Third Victory At Daytona Is No Breeze
description: The smiles came last on a day of emotional extremes for Dale Jarrett. By today's end, the defending Winston Cup Series champion had won his third Daytona 500, considered the Super Bowl of Nascar, before about 190,000 fans at Daytona International Speedway. And there, to top it off, was the legendary stock car driver Richard Petty, extending his hand in congratulations.

title: N.C.A.A. Bears a Gift, So Coaches Are Wary
description: A BASKETBALL player leaves high school and immediately turns pro. Maybe he or she is enticed by money, maybe by bright lights. The year turns out to be a nightmare: the player does not play, is maladjusted and miserable, and begins to long for college.

title: For Mets' Zeile, Just One Glove
description: The first baseman's glove Todd Zeile will use this year has major league experience, though it took last season off. Zeile did not pack the glove when he played third base for the Texas Rangers last year, leaving it at home in California with a friend, who used it in sandlot games.

title: Raid on Bar Seeks Clues In Fatal Fire At Seton Hall
description: John L. Holland, the owner of The Hall, a bar five blocks from Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., is accustomed to the authorities' checking his place for underage drinkers.

title: A Mexican Village, in Clash, Brings the Police to Their Knees
description: It was not a sight Mexicans see every day, the 60 riot policemen, stripped of their clubs, shields and a good part of their clothes, bound together with the ropes they normally use to bind criminals, down on their knees and shivering in the chill air of a public square.

title: Rare Avalanche Kills One On an Adirondack Slope
description: Six back-country skiers who ventured into a dangerous snowslide area were caught in a roaring avalanche and swept hundreds of yards down a mountainside in the Adirondack High Peaks of northern New York State on Saturday. Rescuers found one dead under the snow and his companions all injured, one critically.

title: INSIDE
description: Marriage Show Canceled

title: Sotheby's and Christie's Face Mounting Suits in Antitrust Case
description: In the art world Herbert Black is known as a man who loves paintings and antiques and loathes the auction houses where he buys and sells them. Suddenly he has a lot of company.

title: DNA as Detective Again, But on a Biblical Case
description: To support their oral tradition that they are a lost tribe of Israel, direct descendants of the biblical patriarchs, the Lemba people of southern Africa point to tribal practices like circumcision, the avoidance of pork, ritual slaughter techniques, the wearing of prayer shawls and skullcaps and the ceremonial blowing of the shofar or ram's horn. Now ''Nova'' reports in tomorrow's intriguing hour that researchers are using genetic markers to test whether there is anything to the Lembas' belief in a Jewish heritage.

title: Bush Redefined McCain and Retained the Right
description: On the morning after a sobering defeat in South Carolina, Senator John McCain of Arizona complained bitterly that his rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, had been swept to victory on a tide of misleading commercials.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHORR, DAVID
description: SHORR-David. We miss you. The Famil

title: Bradley Calls for Inquiry Into '96 Fund-Raising
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: U.S. Welcomes Iranian Election Results
description: In unusually bold language, the Clinton Administration welcomed the election results in Iran today and said it interpreted them as an unequivocal demand for greater freedom within the country and for improved relations abroad.

title: CUTTING CORNERS: A special report.; Builders' Self-Policing Failed Before Brooklyn Floor Did
description: It did not take city inspectors long to figure out why an apartment building being constructed in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, collapsed on Nov. 23, killing a laborer in the debris. They said poorly braced beams gave way as concrete was poured to create the building's third floor.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Working Too Hard?
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet May Be Isolation's Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAFSKY, ROBERT ALAN
description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan Lovingly remembered today and every day.

title: Money and Murder on Their Minds
description: A CONSPIRACY OF PAPER

title: Lessons in Reality
description: John McCain and the media ran into a reality check in South Carolina, where Republican voters decisively rejected the Straight Talk Express and voted instead for the man who once told struggling workers, ''I know how hard it is to put food on your family.''

title: Brooklyn Firefighter Saves a Choking Girl
description: A 13-month-old girl who was choking on a toy baby bottle was saved by a firefighter in Brooklyn last night, officials said.

title: A Treasured Theater's Comeback; At the Restored Royal Court, the Past Is Given Its Due Respect
description: It may have a princely name, but the Royal Court Theater is best known for being where John Osborne's ''Look Back in Anger'' revolutionized postwar British drama in 1956, sicking the angry young man character and his alienated world on the genteel tradition of drawing-room mysteries, parlor dramas and comedies of manners.

title: A Tour Journeyman Ends His Long Wait
description: His wait had spanned 265 P.G.A. Tour events and 71 holes, so Kirk Triplett knew the Nissan Open championship wasn't going to be easily earned. Yet as he stood on the 18th green at Riviera Country Club, he couldn't believe it was about to be stolen from him, either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALVIN, GERALD
description: ALVIN-Gerald. On February 19, 2000. Beloved husband of Shirley; father of Martin and Raymond; grandfather to David, Rebecca, Mark and Matthew. Services Tuesday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave.

title: New Zealand Is Smart And Sharp In Race 1
description: From the transom of Team New Zealand's latest weapon of engagement, NZL 60, Brad Butterworth, the Kiwi tactician, basked in the cheers of thousands of dockside well-wishers moments before pulling into his syndicate's compound Sunday after a businesslike 1-minute-17-second victory over Italy's Prada Challenge in Race 1 of the five-of-nine-race America's Cup finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, WILLIAM
description: GARSON-William. The Little Sisters of the Assumption Family Health Service, Inc., Board of Directors acknowledges the passing of its longtime supporter and beloved father of Sr. Judy Garson, its Executive Director.

title: Selling 110 Livingston
description: Putting a businessman in charge of New York City's 1,100 public schools makes sense only if he plays to his strengths. That means Harold Levy, the interim schools chancellor, should be given his lead to re-engineer and streamline the unwieldy management structure of the nation's largest school system. Such a plan should appeal to Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and offer a first step toward a much-needed working relationship between the mayor and the interim chancellor.

title: The Microsoft-U.S. Negotiations: Tough Talk in Chicago
description: The closing arguments in the Microsoft antitrust case in Washington tomorrow promise to provide moments of courtroom theater, but it is the settlement talks taking place behind closed doors in Chicago that are the greater drama.

title: Israel Seen as Paradise for Money Laundering
description: Summoned to a downtown bank last month, the police arrested a woman who they suspected was laundering profits for foreign racketeers. A native of Chechnya, she had reportedly tried to open an Israeli account with $50 million in Venezuelan checks in the name of an apparently fictitious Gibraltar investment firm.

title: Dean Davenport, 81, Aviator in Doolittle Raid
description: Col. Dean Davenport, the co-pilot of the World War II bomber crew whose role in the Doolittle raid over Japan was recounted in the book and movie ''Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo,'' died on Feb. 14 at a hospital in Panama City, Fla. He was 81.

title: Rangers Finally Solve Vanbiesbrouck, but Not the Flyers
description: The Rangers finally figured out a way to score on the Philadelphia Flyers. Beating them? Now that is another story.

title: A.A. Sobchak Dead at 62; Mentor to Putin
description: Anatoly A. Sobchak, the former mayor of St. Petersburg and democratic reformer who gave Acting President Vladimir V. Putin his start in public life, died of a heart attack this morning, officials said. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, KATHLEEN THERESE
description: GRIFFIN-Kathleen Therese. Of Park Slope, Brooklyn; February 19, 2000. Cherished sister of James, Arthur, Geraldine Griffin Murray. Beloved aunt and godmother. A great friend to all who knew her. Visitation Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM at Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave. (Rt. 110), Huntington. Mass Wednesday, 9:45 AM, St. Patrick's Church, Huntington.

title: Efforts to Close Fresh Kills Are Taking Unforeseen Tolls
description: A half a century after a putrid mountain began to rise from a wetland on Staten Island's western shore, New York City is finally close to delivering on its often repeated vow to close the Fresh Kills Landfill. The city received bids last week from companies eager to take over responsibility for the only trash still being sent to the landfill: about 5,000 tons a day from Queens and parts of Brooklyn.

title: Mrs. Clinton Joins Call for an Oil Reserve
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton joined Northeastern lawmakers today in calling for a regional oil reserve to help states cope with future shortages of home heating oil and tamp down soaring consumer prices.

title: Patents; A California company tweaks an artificial nose in an attempt to sniff out ailments.
description: IT'S not hard to guess that a company named Cyrano might have something to do with noses. It's less obvious that the company produces sensors that could smell a sick person's breath, bodily fluids or a wound and diagnose infections or disease from their odor.

title: Weird and Fun, Anything Goes When It's Cyberpalooza
description: The gathering at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Saturday was something like an academic conference. Lecturers spoke about their latest research, showing slides on a screen overhead. But the slides were of designs for a time machine, alien handwriting and portents of apocalypse.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DUNTON, HARLOW DONALD, M.D.
description: DUNTON-Harlow Donald, M.D. 4/20/22-2/21/98. Forever mourned, forever missed, forever loved by your wife, family, friends, colleagues and patients. You are in our hearts forever. Patricia Dunton

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELER, INA
description: KESSELER-Ina. On February 19, 2000 in New York City at 89 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Peter J. Kesseler, sister of Irene Gotthelf of Munich, Germany, stepmother of Dr. Howard J. Kesseler of Palm Beach, Florida and the late Dr. Edward P. Kesseler, and loving grandmother of their seven children. A memorial service will be held at the German Evangelical-Lutheran Church of St. Paul, 313-315 W. 22nd St., New York City on Thursday, March 9, 2000, at 2:30 in the afternoon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Germanistic Society of America, Quadrille Account, 6 E. 87th St., NY, NY 10128.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You're not a reformer. Anybody who believes you're a reformer, believes in the tooth fairy.''

title: Building an Alternative to Windows
description: The Beatles never got back together, but four members of the original Apple Macintosh team are regrouping. And they mean to take the best of the quirky Apple computer and move it to the world of Linux software.

title: A Possible Conflict By Museums In Art Sales
description: Taken aback by the disclosure that some museums, like dealers, request a commission when art they are exhibiting is sold, museums around the country scrambled last week to plead innocence, profess ignorance or say that they had stopped doing it. Only one of some two dozen museums surveyed -- the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, which is widely known for exhibiting the work of new artists -- admitted to the practice.

title: Take 5 Guys, Blend Voices, Await Fame
description: The story has possibilities: a music manager loses his job with the group he discovered; now he has the chance to create a new group, but only if he can do it in seven days, in time for ''this whopper of a gig'' in Jacksonville, Fla. The form has possibilities: this could be a mock documentary about a fictional band like ''This Is Spinal Tap.'' But ''2Gether,'' a clunker of an MTV movie that has its premiere tonight, is so lacking in wit and point of view that it makes ''That Thing You Do!,'' Tom Hanks's film about a Beatles-like American rock band, look like Chekhov.

title: Nameless in New Jersey; In This Increasingly Suburban World, There's No Place Like Trenton
description: The city is still here. It is just the name, ''Trenton,'' that is slipping fast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZMAN, POLA
description: SALZMAN-Pola. It is with deep sorrow that we acknowledge the passing of our dear friend and neighbor, Pola Salzman. Our condolences go out to the entire family. She will be sorely missed. Harbour House Westhampton Beach

title: Ho Chi Minh Trail's Myth Dazzles Road Planners, Critics Say
description: In the world of transportation, there are few brand names to match that of the Ho Chi Minh Trail, the secret, shifting, piecemeal network of jungle roadways that helped the North win the Vietnam War.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, EDWARD A.
description: LANDAU-Edward A. Beloved and loving husband of Eve, devoted father of Steven, Ellen, and Robert. Cherished twin brother of Ann Kwitman and adored grandfather of Jennifer, Robert, Melissa, Devin, Jessie and Meredith. The family will receive friends at home between 2 & 5 PM, Thursday, February 24. Ann Kwitman will sit shiva at her home on February 22, 23, 25 and 27.

title: F.B.I. Going to Budapest to Hunt the Mob
description: In a move that underlines the growing concern about Russian organized crime, the Federal Bureau of Investigation is opening its first office abroad in which its agents will serve as full-time investigators.

title: Internet May Be Isolation's Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Feb. 10 about Internet communities misstated the sponsorship and the accessibility of H-Net, which offers online discussion groups on the arts, the humanities and the social sciences through a site called www.h-net .msu.edu. H-Net is an independent scholarly society housed at Michigan State University; it is not run by the National Endowment for the Humanities. Most discussion groups are open to the public; they are not all restricted to scholars.

title: E-Commerce Report: Construction Heads Into the Internet Age; Builders Cut Delays And Lift Efficiency By Online Contacts
description: Andy Ball, president of Webcor Builders, a Silicon Valley construction company, can smell inefficiency in a project -- even before he walks around the job site to discuss things with the foremen and supervisors.

title: Anger at TKTS Booth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, RONALD R., JR.
description: ALLEN-Ronald R., Jr. Of New York City, died February 18, while vacationing in Miami Beach, FL. He is survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ronald R. Allen, Sr. of Knoxville, TN; his brother Rick; his sister Jennifer; and his companion Connie Jones. The family will receive friends on Tuesday, February 22, at 6 PM, at Rose Mortuary on Broadway in Knoxville, with the funeral service following at 8 PM. He was loved deeply and will be missed greatly.

title: Compressed Data; Isolated, Maybe, But Not So Divided
description: A Stanford University survey on the social impact of the Internet sparked debate last week because of its contention that the rise of the global computer network is leading to a new wave of social isolation.

title: Washington's Birthday
description: The holiday, actually Feb. 22, is legally observed today.

title: Together On the Stump: Mrs. Clinton And Gore
description: They sat with their heads together, whispering into each other's ears and at one point holding hands. They bobbed and swayed and clapped in syncopation as the crimson-robed choir rocked behind them. They invoked their college days and Bob Dylan and their 1992 bus adventure across America.

title: Milosevic Mounts an Election-Year Crackdown on His Critics
description: The Yugoslav government of President Slobodan Milosevic its support sliding in an election year -- has sharply intensified attacks on the democratic opposition and the news media, calling them traitors and using a draconian press law to intimidate and impoverish independent publications.

title: Out Magazine Acquired by The Advocate, a Key Rival
description: The publisher of Out magazine, the nation's most widely read magazine aimed at gay men and lesbians, has been acquired by the publisher of The Advocate, its major rival, according to the two companies.

title: Microsoft Moving to Ban Long-Term Temp Workers
description: Microsoft Moving to Ban Long-Term Temp Workers

title: Playing It Safe Works For Now
description: It was as if we were watching a cross between ''The Newlywed Game'' and ''The Jerry Springer Show.'' John and Cindy McCain were up there on the podium conceding the South Carolina primary on Saturday night, and they were smiling and nuzzling as if they had just won a dining room set from Bob Eubanks. But if you listened to Senator McCain's words, what you heard was rage and indignation. He basically called George W. Bush a fraud, a sleaze artist and an empty suit.

title: Rudolph Patzert, 88; Transported Jews to Palestine After War
description: Rudolph W. Patzert, the captain of a rusty 1904 gunboat that carried more than 1,380 Jewish refugees from Europe to Palestine as part of a secret rescue operation after World War II, died on Jan. 21 in a nursing home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 88.

title: Drug Makers and Insurers Lock Horns Over Medicare
description: A fight between the pharmaceutical and insurance industries over how to expand Medicare to cover prescription drugs is imperiling bipartisan efforts in Congress to offer drug benefits to the elderly this year.

title: From U.S. Fort To City Park
description: To drive off the dreary Queens expressways and pass through the guarded gate to Fort Totten is to enter a hilly town where the views of the East River, framed by the Throgs Neck Bridge, can be breathtaking.

title: A First for Vrhovnik
description: Matjaz Vrhovnik of Slovenia, one of the most consistent skiers on the circuit, won a men's slalom yesterday in Adelboden, Switzerland, for his first World Cup triumph.

title: New York Lawmaker Switches to McCain
description: Less than 24 hours after Senator John McCain was beaten in the South Carolina Republican presidential primary, he got a boost in New York, where Representative Peter T. King of Long Island announced yesterday that he would drop his allegiance to Gov. George W. Bush and support Mr. McCain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMERMESH, BELLA
description: HAMERMESH-Bella. Our Past Sisterhood President and longtime member has left us. All the East End Temple Family mourn with husband, Harold and sister, Gertrude Schiff. Francine Kolin, Sisterhood Pres. Helene Spring, President Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch

title: Internet May Be Isolation's Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks May Shift Camp Over Confederate Flag
description: After regularly training at the College of Charleston twice a year for eight seasons, Knicks players are considering whether they want the organization to continue its affiliation with South Carolina, where the Confederate battle flag flies above its Capitol even though the banner is considered a symbol of slavery and segregation to many.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: The McCain Comeback
description: The bipartisan Comeback Adviser is again reporting for duty. In light of the rallying round George W. Bush by South Carolina's religious right, John McCain must arouse the Republican center in California and New York. Here's how:

title: Grandmother of Boy Talked of Defecting, According to Report
description: A Roman Catholic nun who was the host of a meeting between 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez and his Cuban grandmothers said she began to believe the boy should stay in the United States after learning that one of the grandmothers wanted to defect to this country, The Miami Herald reported today.

title: Toughest Lies Ahead for High Yield
description: He may be a Western horse who became an Eastern winner, and he may simply be a horse who made the most of the ''track bias'' at Gulfstream Park that favors leaders on the rail. But whatever he is, after his victory in the Fountain of Youth Stakes on Saturday at Gulfstream Park, High Yield stood today at the head of the class of 3-year-olds aiming for the Kentucky Derby on May 6.

title: Pioline Comes Back
description: Cedric Pioline rallied for a 6-7 (3), 6-4, 7-6 (4) victory over Tim Henman yesterday to win the ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

title: Privacy and the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancing In New York, Dreaming Still of Home
description: You would be taxed to name a show with a sweeter temper than ''Letters From Cuba,'' a lovely and contemplative autobiographical morsel by Irene Maria Fornes that opened yesterday at the Signature Theater's Peter Norton Space in Clinton.

title: Justice Demands Fair Pay for Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Reform Tide in Iran
description: The peaceful revolt against clerical repression in Iran that began three years ago with the election of Mohammad Khatami as president is gaining strength. Partial returns from Friday's parliamentary elections suggest that the reform coalition that brought Mr. Khatami his landslide upset in 1997 and then won a broad victory in last year's municipal elections is likely to gain control of the legislature. Reform candidates attracted support not just among women and young people, but among more traditional voters in provincial towns and religious centers as well.

title: Flying Safer Skies
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHER, GUSTAVE
description: FLEISCHER-Gustave. On February 19, 2000, at age 63. Devoted and loving husband to Helen. Beloved father of Cheryl, Linda and son-inlaw Stewart. Graduate of MIT. He was a member of the Moles, American Society of Civil Engineering, the Military Engineer and the British Tunneling Society. He was a remarkably strong individual whose love for life kept him positive even after circumstances became hard. Donations may be made in his memory to the American Cancer Society. Services Monday, 10 AM, Riverside Chapel, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 7 about efforts to spur job development in Willimantic, Conn., referred incorrectly to the many Puerto Ricans among the city's Hispanic population. They are United States citizens, not immigrants.

title: Labs to Relax Security Limits on Israelis
description: The Department of Energy has decided to lift some cumbersome security restrictions on visits by Israeli scientists to American national laboratories, Energy Department and other administration officials said today.

title: Thomson Jumps Head First Into an Electronic Future
description: The last 65 years, the Canadian media giant Thomson has been in and out of nonmedia businesses that held temporary promise -- oil and travel, to name two. But it has always owned newspapers, dailies and weeklies through which millions of Canadians and Americans knew the Thomson name.

title: Drummond Travels Far and Runs Fast to Set U.S. Record
description: Damion Drummond traveled almost 2,000 miles yesterday to reach the Armory Track and Field Center in upper Manhattan and made it in time to shatter the United States indoor high school 600-meter record with a time of 1 minute 18.80 seconds at the Public Schools Athletic League indoor championships. The previous national mark of 1:19.56 was set in 1989 by Brad Sumner of McQuaid Jesuit of Rochester.

title: To Help the Hungry
description: To the Editor:

title: When Art Digests Life and Disgorges Its Poison
description: I watched the 1998 documentary ''The Brandon Teena Story'' and the 1999 feature film ''Boys Don't Cry,'' based on the same events, in one day. In fact, I watched them within an hour of each other, which was harrowing. Of course there was the story. Teena Brandon, free, white and 21, wanted to be free of her female identity. So she left it behind in Lincoln, Neb., and rode into Falls City, Neb., as a man named Brandon. There she won the prettiest girl and hung out with the toughest guys until her past caught up with her, for which she paid by being raped and then, once she brought charges against those same tough guys, killed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the expulsion of a Cuban diplomat in Washington referred incorrectly in some copies to the site of an interview with a spokesman for the Cuban Interests Section -- nominally part of the Swiss Embassy -- who said, ''They need to convince our government that they have proof.'' The interview took place outside the gate of the interests section, not at the embassy, which is in a different location.

title: Marriage, Any Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Ranks In the Middle, But Falls Last On Morality
description: When it comes to American presidencies, Bill Clinton's two terms have been fair to middling, a survey of United States historians has found.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 4 From Original Apple Team Will Focus Efforts on Linux

title: Turks Hold 3 Kurdish Mayors As Hopes for Peace Recede
description: Last Thursday night, Mayor Feridun Celik of the mainly Kurdish city of Diyarbakir dined with government officials and foreign ambassadors at a glittering banquet in Ankara honoring the visiting Swedish foreign minister.

title: Valentine Winds Up, But There's No Pitch
description: It was news to Manager Bobby Valentine today when reporters told him that the Mets' co-owner, Fred Wilpon, planned to wait until after the season to address Valentine's contract extension.

title: Financial Times Wades Into Germany
description: Germany is the world's fourth-biggest economy and home to globe-spanning corporations like the automaker DaimlerChrysler and Bertelsmann, the media conglomerate.

title: SURGE IN OIL PRICES IS RAISING SPECTER OF INFLATION SPIKE
description: For the past year, even as the price of oil nearly tripled to $30 a barrel from less than $11, policy makers, economists and many in the oil industry itself hewed closely to the same line: Oil does not matter much anymore.

title: In an Upset, Canada Eliminates Mexico
description: In a major upset, Canada eliminated Mexico from the Concacaf Gold Cup, winning its quarterfinal, 2-1, yesterday when Richard Hastings scored in the third minute of overtime.

title: Immigrants Rebuild a City That Others Fled
description: An interminably flat, hot and often windy farming town, Homestead became lodged in the annals of natural disasters in August 1992 when Hurricane Andrew, the most damaging storm in American history, destroyed this community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTON, MAURICE
description: BURTON-Maurice. Born December 15, 1912 in Warsaw, Poland. Passed away in Ft. Lauderdale, FL, February 17. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Anna, his sons Philip and Robert, and grandchildren Emanuelle and Joshua. He was a Holocaust survivor who came the to the United States and built a new life. He always fought to overcome obstacles and loved life. He will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, JEAN
description: JOSEPH-Jean. Goodbye Mrs. J., Mama Bear. Love, your family. The Bussos, Beutels, Hogans and Stokolosas

title: John W. Hannon Jr., 77, Retired Banker
description: John W. Hannon Jr., a former president of Bankers Trust, died last Monday at Carolina House, an assisted living facility in Pinehurst, N.C. Mr. Hannon, a resident of West End, N.C., was 77.

title: Larsson Prevails
description: Shaking off a sore knee, Magnus Larsson used a big serve to overcome mistakes and win his first title since 1994, defeating Byron Black by 6-2, 1-6, 6-3 yesterday at the St. Jude tournament in Memphis.

title: Knicks Could Avoid Pattern With Victory
description: The mercurial Knicks have made a habit of following impressive victories with forgettable encores this season. So after their mastery of the Pacers on Saturday, it is only natural for the Knicks to see trouble lurking when the rookie Lamar Odom makes his return to New York as a member of the downtrodden Clippers on Monday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: Giuliani Finds Support In Brooklyn Democrats
description: The Kings Highway Democratic Club in Brooklyn, which has backed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in his previous bids for public office, endorsed him again yesterday, saying that even though he is a Republican he is better qualified than his Democratic opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, in their race for United States Senate.

title: The Truth, Too Late
description: To the Editor:

title: With a Still-Ample Treasury, Bush Builds a Green 'Fire Wall' Against McCain
description: In the South Carolina primary, Gov. George W. Bush reaped the enormous benefits of his overstuffed campaign treasury, which allowed him to refuse federal matching funds and spend as much as he needed to win.

title: Media Talk; Online Hiring Evaluator (or Ego Deflator)
description: How many people have the self-confidence to subject themselves to a public appraisal of their market value? Judging by the early reaction to a new feature of a popular Web site, plenty do.

title: BUSH AND MCCAIN SWAP STRATEGIES FOR NEXT BATTLE
description: As the bitter fight for the Republican presidential nomination shifted to Michigan, Senator John McCain leveled scorching and sustained attacks today on Gov. George W. Bush's reform credentials, while his rival stayed upbeat and campaigned as if he were already in the general election.

title: CLINTON TO ORDER STEPS TO REDUCE MEDICAL MISTAKES
description: President Clinton will order all hospitals in the United States to take steps to reduce medical errors that kill tens of thousands of people each year, and he will urge states to require the reporting of such errors, administration officials said today.

description: Orioles Manager Mike Hargrove is considering the possibility of using Cal Ripken at first base.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TRAUMA; A Caution Flag on Breathing Tubes
description: A study involving California paramedics has found that placing breathing tubes in the throats of unconscious children saved no more lives than the less risky method of squeezing oxygen into their lungs through a mask and hand pump.

title: De La Hoya Takes the Town
description: Oscar De La Hoya plans to make the most of his visit to New York this week, with appearances on television shows. But Felix Trinidad, who took away De La Hoya's World Boxing Council welterweight title in a controversial decision last September, will try to steal some of the spotlight.

title: Taiwan Industry Adopting Transmeta Chip
description: Taiwan Industry Adopting Transmeta Chip

title: Songs and Stanzas That Perch in the Soul
description: ''My Business Is to Love'' was the title of Sunday afternoon's sung and acted entertainment at Alice Tully Hall. The words are Emily Dickinson's, and they carry a characteristically heavy freight of feeling -- negative, unillusioned and bitter as much as positive and abounding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWORCEL, JOSEPH
description: ROSENWORCEL-Joseph. On February 17, 2000. Devoted husband (for 58 years) of Anne. Loving father of Willa and Elliott Rosenworcel and Reyna and Andrew Jassin. Beloved grandfather of Jessica Rosenworcel and fiance Mark Bailen, Brian Rosenworcel, Eric Jassin and Amanda Jassin. City College graduate, Director of the U.S. Customs Information Exchange, legal consultant, adult education teacher. Service Wed, Feb 23, 12:30PM, ''BoulevardRiverside Chapel'', 1450 Bdwy, Hewlett, L.I. Forever in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, FRANCES
description: POSNER-Frances. Beloved wife of the late Reuben Freedkin and the late Harry Posner. Devoted mother of Ellen & Harvey Keller. Cherished grandmother of Robert and Marci Sheps and Nancy and Matthew Burns. Adored great grandmother of Amanda Brooke Sheps. Dear aunt. She gave generously of herself to others. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, Tuesday, at 12:30PM.

title: Automaton Turns Warm With Caprice
description: ''Coppelia'' can make dancers buoyant. The New York City Ballet demonstrated that when it presented this 19th-century choreographic comedy at the New York State Theater.

title: The Last of the Stroganoffs Finally Sees What She Lost
description: Helene de Ludinghausen took one look around the Portland Art Museum here on Thursday, raised both hands to her cheeks and in a deep, throaty voice let out a long ''Ooooohh.'' The joy on her face was as evident as snow in a Russian winter.

description: Pop Diva Sings A Judge's Praises

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCH, WESER, REIMER
description: KOCH-WESER-Reimer, 93, on January 24 at his home after a short illness. Beloved father of Gisela O'Brien and Dr. Peter Koch-Weser. Grandfather of Stephen, Christopher and Dennis O'Brien. Susan Koch-Weser, and Jennifer Cullen. Great-grandfather of Margaret Cullen.

description: THE REPUBLICANS

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Of Survival On the Edge: How a Beetle Led Experts To a New Path
description: It was the American burrowing beetle that tipped off Dr. Rob Channell and Dr. Mark Lomolino, conservation biologists, that one of the basic tenets of modern conservation theory might be misguided, to the possible detriment of many endangered species.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, HELEN
description: EISNER-Helen. Cherished mother of Shirley, Philip and Arnold. Devoted Gaga of Alexandra and Lauren. As a young girl of 13 in Sosnowiec, Poland, she was taken to the Ghetto and then away from her parents by the Germans to the Gleiwicz Camp. She was the sole survivor of the Adler family. Helen was a kind and gentle woman who after coming to America at the age of 23, gave the whole of her life to her children and grandchildren. She was a supportive and giving parent and friend. We will miss her greatly. Services will be held at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla on Wednesday at 1:30PM. The family will sit Shiva at her home in New Rochelle following the funeral 4-8, Thursday 2-7, Friday 10-2 and Sunday 12-5.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about talent agents' efforts to improve their status misstated the name of a Beverly Hills literary agency and misidentified several of its agents. The organization is the Broder, Kurland, Webb & Uffner Literary Agency, not the Broder, Kuland & Webb talent agency. The agents shown, from the left, were Robert Broder, Ted Chervin, Norman Kurland, Chris Silbermann and Elliot Webb.

title: In Quantum Feat, Atom Is Seen in 2 Places at Once
description: Appalled by the weird implications of quantum mechanics, the rules that explain the workings of the tiny particles that make up the universe, Albert Einstein used to stroll the streets of Princeton wondering why the moon wasn't smeared all over the sky.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the planned closing of the Broadway musical ''Cats'' on June 25 referred incorrectly to a record held by its London production, which is still playing. ''Cats'' is Britain's longest-running musical; the longest-running play is ''Mousetrap,'' which opened in 1952.

title: McCain Minces No Words in Attacks
description: Senator John McCain has become more emphatic in his attacks on the Republican establishment and its big-business and conservative allies.

title: No Direct Talks Set by 2 Sides In Boeing Strike
description: Representatives of the Boeing Company and its striking engineers and technical workers are expected to meet separately with federal mediators this week amid signs that tension between the two groups is escalating.

title: Bradley and Gore Trade Jabs In Fiercest Campaign Debate
description: To a chorus of boos, shouts and cheers at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, Bill Bradley and Al Gore engaged last night in the most brutal presidential debate of the year, with Mr. Bradley attacking the vice president as a ''conservative Democrat'' and Mr. Gore caustically describing Mr. Bradley as a ''desperate'' candidate intent on tearing down his fellow Democrat.

title: 2 Large Insurers in Britain To Merge in $12 Billion Deal
description: Two of Britain's best-known insurance companies, CGU P.L.C. and Norwich Union P.L.C., announced today that they would merge in a $12 billion stock swap that analysts depicted as a shield against Continental European predators.

title: Magical Season For Tranmere
description: ENGLAND

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Debate Over Who Must Pay For Calls to Cellular Phones

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: From a Toe Dipped to One Foot Planted
description: About a year ago the United States and its NATO allies found themselves involvedin a war in Kosovo that continues with little prospect of peace or of the West's extrication. Tonight and next week ''Frontline'' offers ''War in Europe,'' a sharply drawn two-hour account of how the allies embarked on NATO's military conflict and the shaky way in which it was fought.

title: Partnership That Contradicts the Lyrics
description: Aimee Mann and Michael Penn are a two-career couple who live in Los Angeles and share the same line of work: songwriting. The other night at Joe's Pub, they shared the stage in affectionate teamwork. They backed up each others' songs and laughed at each others' humor. For an encore they did a fond Sonny and Cher imitation, singing ''I Got You Babe.'' It was a show of companionable partnership that contradicted nearly everything they sang about, as if to prove that art doesn't imitate life.

title: POWER PLANT SALE
description: Vivendi S.A. of France agreed to sell 21 power plants in the United States to Reliant Energy Inc. for $2.1 billion and is in talks to sell more of its Sithe Energies Inc. power unit to concentrate on faster-growing businesses. The plants being sold are in Maryland, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Reliant is based in Houston. Vivendi plans to sell shares in its utilities unit later this year so it can concentrate on its holdings in media and telecommunications.

title: Chicago Council Tries Anew With Anti-Gang Ordinance
description: Trying to thwart gangs without running afoul of constitutional rights, the Chicago City Council has passed an anti-loitering ordinance that allows the police to order suspicious crowds to scatter.

title: To Lighten Backpacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Sometimes, the In-Crowd Turns Ugly
description: Like many other schoolchildren, Claire and Stuart Bullen of Walnut Creek, Calif., have looked in awe at the people in the in-crowd and wondered, how do they do it? What is so special about them? But unlike many of their peers, Claire, 11, and Stuart, 8, do not aspire to be in that social tier: they think being popular means being unkind, making friends and then discarding them.

title: Battle Of the Sexes Is Discerned In Sperm
description: In the battle of the sexes, there are the formal rules -- the rich variety of variously heeded laws and customs by which each society tries to constrain reproductive behavior. Then there are the other rules, often in conflict with the first, which govern love and desire and the delicate games men and women play with one another.

title: Isaac Rubin, 86, Westchester Appeals Court Judge
description: Justice Isaac Rubin, a former New York State appeals court judge from Westchester County, died Saturday in a hospice in the Bronx. He was 86 and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWBOURNE, JOAN TEICHMAN
description: NEWBOURNE-Joan Teichman. Died February 19, 2000 at Harbor View Nursing Home, Jersey City, N.J. at 97 years of age. Single mother, pioneer in the '40's. Export Manager for General Pencil Company of Jersey City. Started her own business, The Victoria Service Company, and Pen and Pencil Company of North America, maintained until 1988. Survived by her son, three grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Closed casket memorial service at Leber Funeral Home, 20th and Kennedy, Union City, N.J. 11AM12N Wednesday, February 23rd.

title: Microsoft Trial Reconvenes Tuesday
description: Microsoft Trial Reconvenes Tuesday

title: Excerpts From Democratic Candidates' Debate at the Apollo Theater
description: Following are excerpts from the debate last night between Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey at the Apollo Theater in New York, as recorded by The New York Times. The first question was asked by the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: A Virginia Tale of Love and Death, Suspicions and Doubt
description: If Roger Zygmunt Comte de la Burde had been found dead in his Jaguar or Mercedes-Benz downtown on Broad Street, David M. Riley, a senior special agent of the Virginia State Police, said ''the whole world would have been a suspect.''

title: Johnson Gets Tough As Knicks Pitch In
description: One after another, the spindly stars of the league came floating into town this past week with helium in their moves and a first razor in their bags. But as the exciting neophytes rounded the corner on their dream paths to glory at Madison Square Garden, they found a crafty former All-Star clogging their way like a Winnebago in the fast lane.

title: Clifton Daniel, a Managing Editor Who Set a Writerly, Courtly Tone In Shaping The Times, Dies at 87
description: Clifton Daniel, the courtly North Carolinian who served as managing editor of The New York Times from 1964 to 1969 after a career as a correspondent in wartime London, war-torn Europe and the Middle East, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 .

title: Divorcing Astronomy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AQUILONE, ROSE MARIE
description: AQUILONE-Rose Marie. ''Forever 27'', died February 19th. Beloved daughter of the late Constantino & Felicia (nee Nicoletti), dear sister of Anthony, Donald, Gus, Patricia, Anna McDwyer, Richard and Phyllis Carre. Loving aunt of the late Joseph Aquilone, and survived by many nieces, nephews and great-nephew and nieces. Mass Wednesday, 11AM, St. Francis Xavier Church. Reposing at the Chapel of Joseph G. Duffy, Inc., 9th St between 4th and 5th Aves., Brooklyn. Visiting hours Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Covenant House, Mercy Home for Children or Cancer Research.

title: Indian Point 2's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPP, PAUL ARNOLD
description: KOPP-Paul Arnold. Died February 20 at the age of 77, his wife Helene Fuld of 57 years at his side with three sons, Larry, Jeffrey and Mitchell. He had nine grandchildren and six great-grandchildren who were the delight of his life. He had been a Cub Scout Master, Little League Commissioner and a Jewish War Veteran Commander. In 1967, he became a Rotarian and the Rotary motto Service Above Self was how he conducted his life. He became District Governor in 1986 and has observed the tenants of Rotary with much love and devotion to them and to his family. Please make any donations to the Rotary Club of Key Biscayne, Fla.

description: Technology Fair in Germany

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Feb. 10 about Jerry Goldman, a political scientist who is making the 12 1/2 hours of Nixon White House tapes available free online, misstated the price he paid for them. It was $732, not $432.

title: Stars, Not Aides, Did the Spinning This Time
description: After every debate comes the candidates' spin; what distinguished last night was the spinners.

description: To the Editor:

title: Germany's Troubled Conservatives
description: Shock waves from Helmut Kohl's illegal fund-raising activities continue to buffet Germany's main opposition party, the Christian Democrats. Last week the party was hit with a stiff, $21 million fine for illegal campaign reporting, and Mr. Kohl's hand-picked successor as party leader, Wolfgang Schauble, announced his resignation.

title: The U.N.'s Unhappy Lot: Perilous Police Duties Multiplying
description: If rock-throwing mobs in Kosovo can turn their rage on well-armed and expertly trained American troops, what can be in store for United Nations police officers when they take charge?
