title: A Flair for Retailing Is Applied to Art
description: A. Alfred Taubman, 75, is a real estate developer who has been given credit for the evolution of suburban shopping centers. But he is also an art collector and socialite, known from Manhattan to Southampton to London to Palm Beach for his luxuriant lifestyle.

title: European Regulators Frown On a Combined MCI-Sprint
description: The European Commission's antitrust regulators said today that they had ''serious concerns'' about the plans of MCI Worldcom to acquire the Sprint Corporation for $130 billion and that they would carry out an intensive four-month investigation into the deal.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''And then, suddenly, it became calm. And the troops started mopping up. We thought they would just check everyone's passports. But it was a cleansing of everything alive. They killed cattle, dogs, people -- children and old people.''

title: When the Elderly Steal Jobs of Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWAN, EUGENE L.
description: SWAN-Eugene L., Jr. 90, on February 19, 2000 in Athens, Maine. Survived by his wife Katharine, two daughters Katherine Francis, Josephine Swan, two sons Ripley and Benjamin Swan and five grandchildren.

title: VITAL SIGNS: BEHAVIOR; When a Weary Brain Hops Over Hurdles
description: A sleepy brain is never as sharp as a rested brain, but the fuzziness can vary with the task at hand, according to a new study that found signs of a mechanism that can sometimes limit the impact of fatigue.

title: A Visible Chief Has a Head for Numbers
description: Diana D. Brooks, known as Dede, is said to have such a keen head for numbers that she can calculate auction totals faster than Sotheby's computers.

title: Zat Frenchwoman Knows About Ze Differences
description: When beautiful women take to comedy, and it doesn't happen often, the world forgives them for being so gorgeous. It worked for Carole Lombard in the 1930's. It worked for Candice Bergen in the 80's and 90's. And it may work for Barbara Blackburn, a former model and soap opera actress who is doing a charming one-woman show, ''Extreme Girl,'' at the Currican Theater through Sunday.

title: 'Miracle on Ice' of 1980 Looks Different Today
description: Twenty years ago tonight, the result of the ''Miracle on Ice'' was well known before ABC showed it in prime time. The live Lake Placid scene behind the host Jim McKay might have been a giveaway that the 1980 United States Olympic hockey team had defeated the heavily favored Soviet Union, 4-3.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Political Briefing Column on Thursday about the endorsement of Senator John McCain by California's secretary of state, Bill Jones, referred incorrectly to his victory in 1998. It was not the only one by a Republican in statewide elections; the insurance commissioner, Charles Quackenbush, also won.

title: Chechens Tell of Murderous Rampage by Russians
description: Refugees trickling out of Chechnya into the makeshift camps that pock the Caucasus foothills near Nazran are bringing stories of what could be one of the worst civilian massacres in the Chechen war.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENERSTEIN, EZRA J.
description: DENERSTEIN-EZRA J. Ever present in our lives. He is dearly loved and deeply missed. Susan and Harris

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture in some editions on Sunday showing Gov. George W. Bush and his wife, Laura, greeting supporters in South Carolina carried an incorrect credit. It was by Agence France-Presse, not The Associated Press.

title: Albanians Rally to Oust Serbs From a City in Kosovo
description: Thousands of ethnic Albanians from throughout Kosovo marched on this divided city today and clashed with a phalanx of NATO-led troops, who used tear gas and fists to keep them from reaching the Serbian district.

title: Hasty Call for Amnesty
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s call for the government to grant amnesty to an estimated six million illegal immigrants currently living in the United States and to eliminate most sanctions on employers who hire them in the future was a surprising turnabout. Until now, organized labor has fought hard to keep illegal workers from taking jobs from higher-paid union workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENSTERHEIM, JOSEPH
description: FENSTERHEIM-Joseph. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved father of its its devoted Director of Student Programming in our Upper School, Dede Benel and extends heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the breaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal Dr. Jay Stone, Chairman, Faculty Council David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Jeanne Simon, 77, a Lawyer And a Senator's Spouse, Dies
description: Jeanne Simon, the wife of former Senator Paul Simon who forged her own public career as a prosecutor, lawmaker and lobbyist for literacy and libraries, died on Sunday at their home in Makanda, Ill. She was 77.

title: Towers Receives 2-Year Extension
description: Padres General Manager Kevin Towers agreed yesterday to a contract extension through the 2003 season.

title: When Patients Want to Know the Distance to Death's Door
description: My patient Charlie did not show up for his appointment this month, an aberration for which I am deeply, selfishly grateful. It means that he is feeling well, since he never fails to check in at the first ache or sneeze. It also means that I get a little break from the relentless cross-examination that is a session in the office with Charlie.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Another Investor Files Suit Over Azerbaijan Oil Deal
description: In the second such complaint by a Wall Street investment fund, a Czech promoter has been accused of fraud by his biggest client in a $450 million Azerbaijan privatization venture dominated by prominent Americans.

title: Yankees' Pitchers Use Time To Tinker
description: David Cone set his right foot against the pitching rubber here last Sunday and leaned forward with his glove held waist-high in front of him, a toy soldier's stiffness to his movements.

title: Hamburg Journal; For a Fresh View, Go to Germany's West Window
description: Hunting for the boom that never happened in post-cold-war Berlin? Try this handsome port city that purrs with prosperity.

title: On Gore's Hyperbole
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Democrats: Gone but Not Forgotten
description: In the Republican primary in Michigan today, both John McCain and George W. Bush will be seeking the support of the elusive Reagan Democrat. Mr. McCain, having lost big in South Carolina when conservative Republicans turned out in force to support Mr. Bush, has a particular stake in courting this mythic bloc of voters.

title: How to Make Globalization Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Designers turn to stylists for inspiration. In defense of the grande dame of British fashion (youngsters, pay attention).
description: The Role of the Stylist

title: Man Is Charged In Neighbor's Death
description: Shimon Sharach, 33, of Borough Park, Brooklyn, was charged with criminally negligent homicide last night in the death of a 75-year-old neighbor who had a heart attack on Saturday night during an argument over a parking spot, the police said.

title: From a Yeast Cell, a New Look at the Process of Aging
description: A gene known to govern the rate of aging in yeast cells has been found to be active in mice, yielding a new insight into why mice and people age and into possible ways of enhancing life span.

title: Sports of The Times; Trading In The N.C.A.A. Straitjacket
description: FOR those still counting, yesterday's loss to the Knicks made 20 defeats for Lamar Odom and the Los Angeles Clippers in their last 21 games. At least Odom got paid, and no one cared what mode of transportation he used to get himself home.

title: Breast Cancer in Blacks Spurs Hunt for Answers
description: When Zora Brown got word that her pregnant, 29-year-old niece, Lea, had breast cancer, she decided it was high time for a serious family meeting.

title: Abortion: The French Solution
description: When Americans speak of the French paradox, we usually mean the bewildering fact that although the French have a suicidal diet of cheese, eggs and red meat, they are not nearly as likely to suffer heart attacks in midlife as we are. One explanation is that the red wine they drink dissolves away cholesterol.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Privacy on the Internet
description: As the Internet matures, preserving user privacy and anonymity is becoming a significant problem. Technology now makes it possible for online businesses and advertisers to turn the Internet into a realm where activities and habits are monitored and recorded, largely without consumer knowledge or consent. Unless businesses can protect privacy, the erosion of trust could seriously harm e-commerce as well as cause the public to become wary about using the Internet for education, research and other important non-commercial functions.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Anonymity Strikes Out as Griffey Joins Reds
description: Ken Griffey Jr. desperately wants to fit in with the Cincinnati Reds. He wants to amble into the clubhouse in blue jeans, a blue T-Shirt, sneakers and gold earring, as he did today, play center field for the team he cherished as a boy and be as anonymous as a utility infielder. Good luck on that last one, Junior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, JEAN L.
description: JOSEPH-Jean L. Died February 20, 2000 at age 82. Loving wife of the late Maurice. Loving mother of Susan and Richard. Also survived by her sister-in-law Anabel Meister, grandson John and daughter-in-law Clare. Services were held February 21st.

title: Expos Quietly Asking To Adjust Irabu Deal
description: The Montreal Expos have spoken confidently of the condition of Hideki Irabu's elbow, indicating he will be ready to pitch. What they are saying to the Yankees, albeit in muted tones, is that they wouldn't mind if the terms of the Irabu trade were adjusted.

title: Falcons in Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, ROLF
description: ARMSTRONG - Rolf. America's foremost portrayer of feminine beauty, February 22, 1960. Friends of the Artist

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSACK, LOUIS
description: CASSACK-Louis. 102, a member of the Board of Directors of Municipal Concerts, Inc., will be missed for his work in bringing live classical music to the communities of our city. Irwin Feigin, President Julius Grossman, Music Director

title: Seeking Pirate Treasure: Captain Kidd's Sunken Ship
description: He lived on Wall Street, a Turkish carpet on his parlor floor, casks of Madeira in his cellar. His tall house had scrolled dormers and fluted chimneys, which ships seeking New York moorage sought out as landmarks. A family man with two daughters, he owned a pew at Trinity Church.

title: In Need of a Latin Lover (and the Betty Ford Clinic)
description: As Leona Samish, the unhappily single heroine of Arthur Laurents's ''Time of the Cuckoo,'' Debra Monk throws out her smile as if it were a baited fishhook. Shiny and sharp, it seems to precede her onto the stage, an invitation cast with energy but only slim expectations of getting a nibble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MAURICE
description: BERNSTEIN-Maurice. The Hebrew Orphan Asylum Association mourns the loss of one of its most beloved members, Maurice Bernstein, who died on February 10th at 95. He had been admitted to the HOA during WW I, having lost both parents. The HOA gave him a college scholarship, sent him to social work school, gave him a job at the home & eventually promoted him to Director. He was the second HOA alumus promoted to that position. After the HOA closed in 1941, Maurice become the alumni association's guiding heart and soul for the next 60 years. The association's monthly publication, The Rising Bell, was named for an HOA literary magazine Maurice had helped start. It's name referred to the First Bell every morning that awaken 10 dormatories of sleeping children. Maurice's death has left us all with feelings of profound loss. He was irreplaceable. Hyman Bogen, Pres. HOA Assoc.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: The Moon at Full Tilt

title: Hard Science: Views Of a Planet at Work
description: Sometimes, it is hard to know where good art ends and good science begins. The photographs of Bradford Washburn, 89, who has spent the past 75 years making his way to the world's least accessible places and then returning with images of startling clarity, are a case in point. A retrospective of Mr. Washburn's work has begun at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. Their beauty aside, said the show's curator, Clifford S. Ackley, the photographs also show the earth at work.

title: Erecting Blue Wall of Solidarity at the Diallo Trial
description: Shoulder to shoulder, they crowd the courtroom's back pews. They are almost all white, almost all male. Many of them wear the blue-and-white button that makes plain their purpose: ''Free the Bronx 4.''

title: Russians Challenge U.S. Over Radar in Norway
description: Russia and the United States are in a drawn-out dispute over a powerful American-made radar in Norway that can track missile launchings in western Russia, according to American and Russian officials.

title: Two Severely Burned in Suspicious Fire
description: A mother and her 6-year-old son were severely burned in one of five Brooklyn fires that the authorities believe were set by the same arsonists yesterday.

title: Cave Dwellers Resent Evictions
description: Wrapped in a head scarf against the rain that lashed the barren rocky hills southeast of Hebron, Mahmud Hamamdeh stood recently in the home that he had been expelled from and extolled the virtues of life in a cave.

title: A Lasting Irish Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy Trails, 2-0, After a Disastrous Day
description: On a day when blood and hope were lost aboard the Italian yacht Luna Rossa, Team New Zealand's NZL 60 sailed to its second straight commanding victory today and took a 2-0 lead over the Prada Challenge in defense of the America's Cup. The margin was 2 minutes 43 seconds.

title: As Iran Counts The Vote, Some Fear Backlash
description: Evidently headed for a major victory in parliamentary elections, Iran's reformers said today their challenge now will be to manage the pace of change to avoid a dangerous backlash from the weakened but still-potent conservatives.

title: From Turbulence to Tranquillity for Actor
description: HE is host of a Middle East television seminar at Columbia University, but his Upper West Side apartment is off-limits, hostage to a sublet until March. Face it, when you've gone and married your accountant, you no longer get to pour money into an abode you rarely inhabit. Prudence dictates otherwise, even if you happen to be Richard Dreyfuss, a movie star with four decades of celluloid service, and a history of imprudence, under your belt.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: For Mets' Zeile, the New Goal Is First
description: After his first day of drills at his new position, Mets first baseman Todd Zeile -- who will never play center in a pickup basketball game -- joked that he worked on getting taller by stretching his body on a rack.

title: Pardon Lets Black Exile Come Home
description: President Clinton granted a pardon today to a 63-year-old political scientist who went into self-imposed exile almost four decades ago after his draft board in Georgia, learning that he was black, refused to address him as ''mister.''

title: How Would Great Composers Play It? Some Clues
description: Anyone who plays Beethoven, Mozart or Bach faces issues that have plagued performers throughout the centuries: namely, the composer's score provides scant guidance on how to approach many facets of the music. Performers make educated guesses as to how loudly to play individual notes, for instance, or how to accent four consecutive quarter notes, but they remain guesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, EDITH
description: BROWN-Edith (nee Singer), February 20, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Milton Brown. Father of Barbara (Dr. Richard) Moss and Kaaren (David) Norman. title: Corrections

title: The Telltale Signs of Sore Throat Danger
description: This is high season for sore throats. One of my friends awakens with a scratchy throat nearly every morning on these cold winter days. Another said the other day that his throat felt sore and he guessed (correctly) that he was getting a cold. A third had gone back to bed with a throat so painful she could hardly talk, let alone swallow.

title: Fox Network Will End 'Multimillionaire' Marriage Specials
description: The Fox Network decided yesterday to kill the potentially lucrative franchise called ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire,'' ending an episode almost as bizarre as programs like ''The World's Most Shocking Moments Caught on Tape'' and other so-called reality-based shows, for which the network has become known.

title: Falcons in Manhattan

title: Review/Fashion; Offhand and Fresh, Prada Breezes In
description: So many Prada bags, so many fabulous pairs of Prada shoes, still gleaming with tissue-paper goodness, bowling ball-size bags, purple ostrich-skin bags, golden tan, deep magenta and navy-piped-in-white bags were lined up at the feet of front-row editors at the Versus show, and it was only Sunday. Six shopping days left.

title: Yugoslav Troops Mass Around Kosovo Borders
description: The NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, said yesterday in Brussels that the alliance was monitoring what he called a buildup of Yugoslav troops in areas bordering Kosovo and that it would not be tolerated.

description: CHARATZ-Louis, February 21, 2000. Devoted father to his children Steven and Philip, Sandy and Pearl. Beloved brother to Nathan and grandchildren. Services at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY at 12:30PM today.

And there he was near the bench, holding a clipboard, standing tall and slim in a gray double-breasted suit, his dome shaved slick, his mustache and goatee flecked with gray.

title: All Aboard for a Big Rail Deal?
description: It is just steel and stone, a rough line scratched across an immense and largely empty landscape. But for much of the last century, as the whistle of Canadian National freight trains pierced the northern night, the ''government railroad,'' as CN was known, helped define Canada.

description: Q. Can hiccups kill you?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERR, DOROTHY WILLIS
description: SHERR-Dorothy Willis. Devoted, adored wife of the late Joseph J. Sherr. Beloved mother of Rose Lynn and Brian. Mother-in-law of Janet Sherr and Jack M. Pollock. Cherished grandmother of Alexa, Elise and Mallerie. Loyal sister of the late Mortimer Willis, Minerva Welitoff and Paula Spivack. Sisterin-law of Charles Spivack, Ruth and Marvin Cohn, Simon and Charlotte Sherr, Irving and Anne Sherr. Loved aunt. Blessed by the friendship and devotion of Olga Williams and Cynthia Dixon. She was a hero to her children and a model of bravery, fortitude, loyalty, dignity and style. She was a woman of valor. Services at Congregation Torah Ohr, Boca Raton, FL, 2 PM, Monday. Graveside service by ''Wien & Wien,'' Tuesday, 2 PM, at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Shiva until February 28 at 255 West 85th St., Apt. 2B, New York City Boca Grove, FL.

description: Astros outfielder Moises Alou went through batting practice and did some light running yesterday as he began his comeback from knee surgery that cost him the 1999 season.

title: Raucous Crowd Puts Stamp on Debate
description: Even before last night's Democratic debate began, one got the feeling that it would be different from the others.

title: 18 Years of 'Cats,' but Ticket Demand Surges for Final Shows
description: After 7,251 performances -- and more lives than even the hardiest feline could reasonably expect -- New York has still not had its fill of ''Cats.''

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; Finding a Down Side to a Cleaner World
description: Scientists investigating the rise in asthma and allergies in developed countries have long wondered whether the increased incidence is the price being paid for the cleanliness of the modern world, of immune systems being inadequately challenged in childhood.

title: Accounts

title: Bob Hite Sr., 86, Voice on 'Lone Ranger'
description: Bob Hite Sr., whose commanding voice made countless fans of ''The Lone Ranger'' pull their chairs closer to the family radio, died on Friday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86 and had lived in Florida.

title: Backing Up the Guard
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking the Long Route
description: Libbie Hickman, the top qualifier for the Olympic marathon trials Saturday, eased into her running career. The daughter of an oil company executive, she finished high school in Cairo. Track and field season usually consisted of one meet, against other Americans attending international schools in places like London or Germany. Mostly, she played basketball. Egyptian women and girls would approach her in the gym and touch her blond hair and tell her it felt like silk.

title: COUNTERFEIT SOFTWARE SEIZED
description: Scores of counterfeit copies of Windows 2000 were seized by Israeli police from street vendors Sunday, a day before the software's official release. The raid was seen as a response to a recommendation in Washington by the International Intellectual Property Alliance, a software and entertainment industry lobbying group, that Israel be placed on a United States government priority list of countries facing trade sanctions for the illegal copying of compact discs. William A. Orme Jr.(NYT)

title: As British Sour on the Euro, Blair Puts the Onus on Europeans
description: Almost a year ago, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain seemed to nudge this country closer to joining in the European single currency, offering a cautious and conditional timetable for signing up to use the euro.

title: No Solace For Widow Of Attica
description: MORE than 28 years have passed, and still Ann Valone chokes up when she talks about what happened at the Attica state prison. Twenty-eight years is not such a long time when the subject is the day your life was turned upside down forever.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Hong Kong's Web Fever Helps Drive a Daring Bid
description: Alex Arena is trying to pull off the biggest deal in the history of Hong Kong -- one that has confounded analysts and roiled markets here for more than a week. But Mr. Arena, the managing director of Pacific Century CyberWorks, seemed remarkably at ease today, as he stopped for a sandwich between meetings in a conference room packed with investment bankers.

The estimate, by the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a coalition of environmental groups, is for 700,000 additional trips per year, not per day.

Later Robin Williams came out in a surgical costume, carrying a cooler marked ''Human Organs.'' (Michael Jackson's old nose and one of Cher's ribs were inside, he said.)

title: Treasury Offerings This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's auction of three- and six-month bills and two-year notes. Yesterday was Presidents' Day, a federal holiday; there was no trading in U.S. Treasury securities and no trading of futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Corrections

Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Arthur G. Degen, Chairman of the Board Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

It has suffered its teething problems, growing pains, setbacks and crises pretty much as an only child, under the tutelage of a corporate parent, Consolidated Edison, that has little experience in the care and feeding of a nuclear reactor.

title: Clifton Daniel Dies; Ex-Times Editor, 87
description: Clifton Daniel, who served as managing editor of The New York Times from 1964 to 1969 after a career as a foreign correspondent, died yesterday at the age of 87.

title: Jacobs Shoots for Fast 1,500
description: Regina Jacobs, the top-rated United States women's miler, said yesterday that she would try to become the first woman to break four minutes in the indoor 1,500 meters next week in New York. She will make the attempt at the Armory Track and Field Center next Tuesday in a race scheduled as part of the Eastern States high school indoor championships.

title: Interpublic Unit Changing Name
description: The giant media services agency owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, Western Initiative Media Worldwide, is being renamed because, executives said, research showed that advertisers perceived ''Western'' to be limited in scope.

title: Body Is Discovered After Fire Under Bridge
description: Firefighters who put out a fire in a storage room under the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn last night discovered a badly decomposed body inside, the police said.

title: MUPPETS ARE BOUGHT
description: EM.TV & Merchandising A.G., a German television program distributor, agreed to buy the Jim Henson Company, creator of ''The Muppets,'' for $680 million in cash and stock to expand into the children's entertainment market in the United States. EM.TV will pay $340 million in cash and give Henson a 5 percent stake in a new, combined company. The German company will get the rights to Henson shows and characters as well as a 12.5 percent stake in the cable-television venture Noggin Channel. Mr. Henson, who created the trademark characters Kermit the Frog and Miss Piggy, founded the closely held Henson Company in 1958. Mr. Henson died in 1990 but the company remains the exclusive character developer for the ''Sesame Street'' TV program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIM, ROBERT
description: KIM-Robert, M.D. Of Portland, OR. A U.S. Air Force veteran and graduate of Union College and Rochester University. Died February 19, 2000. His uncle Philip Hoffer and members of the Hoffer and Liebman families extend their deepest condolences to his mother Pauline, and his wife Barbara and their children.

description: BERNSTEIN-Elliott. February 22, 1954-April 2, 1994. Happy birthday darling. In my thoughts today and every day. Love, Mom

description: Donald Tecumseh (Tee) Carson, who inherited the piano chair from Count Basie after the band leader's health failed, died on Feb. 13 at his home in Cedar Park, Tex. He was 70.

description: Three top creative executives are on the move.

description: Cathy Sample was trapped in an abusive relationship. She said her boyfriend, who had an alcohol problem, would call her names, withhold money from her and lunge at her as if he were going to hit her.

description: Michael I. Sovern, 68, Sotheby's newly appointed chairman, is no stranger to difficult situations.

title: Bush's Goal: Cut the Edge McCain Has as Native Son
description: The home-state headquarters of the campaign that John McCain has called a crusade is a drab stucco office court known as Camelot Square, and today a hardy core of volunteer knights errant like Bryan Erion, a 61-year-old Navy veteran, made a last round of get-out-the vote calls on the eve of the Arizona primary.

title: School Bureaucracy Set in Stone, and Mortar; But Inside Building, Humanity Shows
description: It opened at the height of the Roaring Twenties as the headquarters for the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, a luxurious private club with a ballroom, more than 200 dormitory rooms, a library, bowling alleys, handball courts, Turkish baths and a swimming pool.

description: Following are excerpts from ''The One-China Principle and the Taiwan Issue,'' a report by China's Taiwan Affairs Office and the Information Office of the State Council through the official New China News Agency:

title: Eerie Spaces Where Elegance and Brutality Collide
description: Wolfgang Rihm, now nearing 50, has taken up the solemn mission that sent the last century off on its exploratory musical searches. Yet when Mr. Rihm talks about music, it is not systems and sciences that interest him but the healing powers of intuition. What listeners intuit -- and they had a chance to do so at the Miller Theater on Saturday night -- might be an earnestness of purpose, a carefully constructed density of thought and a fascination with the territory between song and speech. The Ensemble Sospeso, gracefully led by Jeffrey Milarsky, offered the brief instrumental triptych ''Pol -- Kolchis -- Nucleus'' and two vocal pieces: ''O Notte'' after a Michelangelo poem, and ''The Farewell Songs'' to texts by Wolf Wondratschek.

title: Remembering a George for All Seasons
description: Happy Washington's Birthday! Today we celebrate the career of a George who became first in the hearts of his countrymen without conducting a single town meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TASSONE, JOSEPH FRANCIS
description: TASSONE-Joseph Francis. On Feb. 19, 2000. Provider, fixer-upper & guiding light. Loving & devoted husband of Audrey (married 57 years). Mr. T. died as a result of injuries sustained in his heroic effort to save his wife from their burning home February 19, 1999. Member of the Floyd Bennett VFW Post. He faithfully served God, his family, his country and the Kings Highway United Methodist church. He was a pillar of strength for all, ever maintaining his courage, dignity, sense of humor and indomitable spirit. Joseph is survived by three children, Linda Webster, Joseph, Jr. and Thomas, two nephews and seven grandchildren. Calling hours Tuesday 6-9PM, Torregrossa & Sons, Funeral Home, 2265 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn. Service of worship Wednesday, 11AM, Kings Highway United Methodist Church, Kings Highway and East 37th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Lonely on the Net
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: MUSCLE GROUPS; Recruits Gauge Ways to Avoid Injuries
description: Stretching out-of-shape muscles is the best way for the weekend athlete to avoid injury, right? Wrong, says a new Australian study that found no reduction in injuries among soldiers who stretched before workouts, compared with soldiers who did not.

title: An Admired Teacher Is Allowed to Bask
description: Leon Kirchner is admired not only as a major composer of our time but also as an important musical thinker and a powerful teacher. During his years on the faculty of Harvard University he taught a renowned class in the analysis and performance of chamber music, which was formative in the lives of the many young musicians who took it.

title: On and Off Ice, Weekes Makes Positive Impression
description: Kevin Weekes was the losing goalie today when the Detroit Red Wings beat the Islanders, 2-0, at Nassau Coliseum. But in some ways Weekes was the man of the match when one of the National Hockey League's best teams defeated one of its worst.

We extend condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTOCCIA, CARMELA R.
description: MARTOCCIA-Carmela R. (nee Neglia) Age 89. Devoted wife of the late Arthur R. Martoccia, on February 20, 2000. Dear mother of Linda Centurrino and Elaine Pantaleo. Cherished mother-in-law of Robert Centurrino and Robert Pantaleo. Loving grandmother of Brian, Laura, Janine and Kevin. Caring sister of Josephine Neglia. Former department store buyer, dedicated volunteer at Grace Church, Grace Church School and New York Eye and Ear Hospital. She will forever be missed by family and friends. Vistitors may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Thursday 2-4pm & 7-9pm. Services at Grace Church, Broadway at 10th St., Friday 11am. Entombment Woodlawn Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Melissa Neier Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 333, Montville, N.J. 07045.

description: A hearing scheduled for Tuesday to determine whether a federal court has jurisdiction in the Elian Gonzalez custody case was expected to be postponed, because the judge handling it was admitted to a hospital on Sunday.

description: Jason Garrett, the longtime Dallas Cowboys backup quarterback, is expected to visit the Giants today and work out for Coach Jim Fassel and the offensive coordinator Sean Payton. The Princeton graduate is the Giants' leading candidate to replace Kent Graham as the backup to the starting quarterback Kerry Collins.

title: CHINA SAYS TAIWAN CANNOT  CONTINUE DELAYING REUNION

A prolonged lack of negotiations, in itself, China warned, could provoke a military attack.

Earlier in his career, he posted a triple-double against the Nets with 24 points, 28 rebounds and 15 blocked shots. Since those games, he has gotten better, which raised this question for the Nets today: who will stop him Tuesday night?

description: KESSELER-Ina. On February 19, 2000 in New York City at 89 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Peter J. Kesseler, sister of Irene Gotthelf of Munich, Germany, stepmother of Dr. Howard J. Kesseler of Palm Beach, Florida and the late Dr. Edward P. Kesseler, and loving grandmother of their seven children. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Germanistic Society of America, Quadrille Account, 6 E. 87th St., NY, NY 10128.

title: 200 Demand Garden's Return From Lower East Side Builder
description: A week after 31 demonstrators were arrested protesting the razing of a community garden on the Lower East Side, nearly 200 people returned to the site yesterday to demand that the city return the space.

title: Is This Trip Necessary?: Clinton Risks Ire in India or Pakistan
description: Will he or won't he? Should he or shouldn't he?

title: So, They're Not Doctors but They Do Juggle Knives
description: No gift for conjecture is required to imagine that the parents of Jon O'Connor, Rob Williams and Kevin Hunt might have wanted them to grow up to be doctors, lawyers or engineers.

title: An Evening of Spats, Whispers and Passion in the Drawing Room
description: Love's secrets weave through George Balanchine's ''Liebeslieder Walzer,'' a ballet that has always had a special place in the New York City Ballet's repertory.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: AFRICA

title: Dear Ehud, Hafez and Yasir
description: Memo From: Bill Clinton

title: Bradley, Seeking Hispanic Support, Pushes Insurance Plan
description: Courting the Hispanic vote, former Senator Bill Bradley stopped at a Brooklyn elementary school yesterday morning and spoke about the need for universal health insurance, noting the disproportionate numbers of Latinos among the uninsured and questioning Vice President Al Gore's commitment on the issue.

title: A Tea Party Of Players, Instruments And Skills
description: In the 40 years since he made his Carnegie Hall debut, Jaime Laredo has proved himself an energetic, versatile and companionable musician. All those qualities were on full display on Wednesday evening, when he returned to the hall for a celebratory concert. He played in every piece: this was, after all, his show. But every piece was also a collaboration, emphasizing his nature and his value as an instigating member of happy musical communities.

title: Giants Acquire Garrett; Lomas Brown Is Signed
description: The Giants got the backup quarterback they wanted yesterday, signing Jason Garrett, who spent seven seasons peaceably in the shadow of Troy Aikman, Dallas's future Hall of Famer, deftly juggling the delicate responsibilities of a reserve quarterback.

title: Top Court Says New York Can Continue Minimum Wage for Workfare
description: The state's highest court ruled today that New York City could continue to use the minimum wage to put a value on the work performed by welfare recipients, deciding they were not protected by a state law that could have compensated them at the prevailing rate for their skills.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: 25,000 Jobs to Be Cut As Unilever Trims Costs

title: Cuba Refuses To Withdraw A Diplomat
description: Cuba will not withdraw the diplomat linked to an espionage investigation, despite an order from the United States that he leave the country, Cuban officials said.

title: TOKYO BANK PLAN IS CRITICIZED
description: Japan's government said it was worried that a proposed tax on banks by the Tokyo metropolitan government was unfair and would undermine the city's status as a global financial center. The cabinet of Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi urged the Tokyo government to ''consider the plan carefully'' when assembly members meet today to weigh whether to introduce the tax. The tax would be put only on banks with more than 5 trillion yen ($45 billion) in assets. ''We hope the Tokyo assembly will hold a careful discussion'' on the proposal, the chief cabinet secretary, Mikio Aoki, above, said.

title: Lowly Backpack Turned Into Milan Must : Hasuike's No Frills Way
description: MILAN  Makio Hasuike, whose accessories are inspired by strawberry boxes and bra cups, cringes at the thought of frills.

title: McGwire Is Happy Without Attention
description: Mark McGwire arrived at the Cardinals' training camp yesterday in Jupiter, Fla., and liked what he saw -- or did not see. There were only a dozen reporters, not 100.

title: A Second Bout of Food Poisoning Sickens 22 Children at a School in Trenton
description: For the second time in just over four months, children from an experimental charter elementary school in downtown Trenton went to the hospital with food poisoning, today apparently from undercooked sliced beef in their cafeteria sandwiches.

title: Nassau Had Surplus in 1999, But Severe Budget Woes Loom
description: The good news is that Nassau County, for all its fiscal troubles, managed to end 1999 with a $21 million surplus, the county comptroller said today.

title: Rodriguez Keeping His Options Open
description: Alex Rodriguez, the All-Star shortstop who is eligible for free agency after the season, says the Mariners should not even think about offering him a contract extension this spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAST, MIRIAM
description: FAST-Miriam. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University notes with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of Avital Fast, M.D., Professor and Chairman of Rehabilitation Medicine. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Fast and the entire family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Playboy Chooses AG Worldwide
description: Playboy Enterprises said yesterday that it had named AG Worldwide in New York as its chief marketing group and that agency's chairman, Peter Arnell, to the vacant position of chief marketer.

title: From Kosovo, Candor About a Massacre
description: Tonight at 8 on WNYC-FM, American Radio Works, a documentary unit run by Minnesota Public Radio, will present ''Massacre at Cuska.'' The report, which will also be broadcast by a consortium of public radio stations around the country, reconstructs events in a farming village in Kosovo where 41 men were slain by Serbian police, military and paramilitary forces last May 14.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''From 53rd and Fifth Avenue to 57th and Fifth, you could die before you get a cab at 5 o'clock.''

title: Hopper's Restaurant Loners Enter Life's Canvas
description: If some of the people in Lynn Rosen's ''Nighthawks'' are funnier than one can imagine that any of the figures in Edward Hopper's paintings could be, it becomes clear that theirs is the laughter of loss, and that the sharp light of this great realist's canvases illuminates the bitter loneliness of their crowded lives. The unexpected effect of this 90-minute theatrical excursion into the painter's world is that one comes away comforted by the thought that, yes, this is city life and it has probably always been this way.

title: A Marriage Made in a Pot
description: PASTA with cauliflower may sound mundane, but it has a lot going for it: the texture is rich and intriguing, soft little bits of garlic and cauliflower get tangled in the pasta, and a somewhat unusual cooking technique deep ens and intensifies the flavors. When I'm desperate to get something quick, healthy and satisfying on the table, this is the dish I most often turn to.

title: Susumu Ohno, 71, an Authority On Genes' Workings in Embryos
description: Dr. Susumu Ohno, an influential figure in clinical genetics, died on Jan. 13 at the City of Hope Cancer Center in Duarte, Calif., a Los Angeles suburb. He was 71 and lived in the nearby city of Glendora.

title: Saving the Oscar Show From Itself; Mindful of Past Disasters, the Producers Shoot for Simplicity
description: The four-hour Academy Award show is tedious. The jokes often fall flat. The musical numbers can be -- let's face it -- embarrassing. The scripted patter between movie stars is silly. And the barrage of awards leaves television viewers -- especially on the East Coast -- numb and sleepy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LONG, RUTH STODDARD
description: LONG-Ruth Stoddard, M.D. The family, friends and colleagues of Ruth Stoddard Long, M.D. wish to honor her memory on the one year anniversary of her death, February 23, 1999. She is greatly missed, and fondly remembered.

title: HERCULES AND LEHMAN PLAN TO BUY MONSANTO UNIT
description: Hercules Inc., a chemical maker struggling with higher costs, said yesterday that it would form a joint venture with Lehman Brothers combining its food-gums business with the Monsanto Company's Kelco unit. Hercules will own 28 percent of the venture, which will have sales of more than $450 million a year. Lehman Brothers Merchant Banking Partners II L.P. will own the rest. The venture will pay Monsanto $685 million for Kelco, a biogum food-additives maker, and pay Hercules $550 million for its food-gums business. Hercules's food-gums business makes pectin for use in jams and jellies. Kelco makes food additives that thicken soups and salad dressings.

title: Museum Unveils Libeskind's Design
description: The Jewish Museum San Francisco has unveiled a design by the Berlin-based architect Daniel Libeskind -- his first project in the United States -- to be built in the Yerba Buena cultural district downtown.

title: Engler Blames Democrats And Himself
description: This was not exactly what Gov. John Engler had in mind.

title: Fernando Benitez, 88, Mexican Writer, Dies
description: Fernando Benitez Gutierrez, a journalist who helped formulate new visions of Mexican identity in his penetrating reports on the Indian cultures and through the cultural publications that he founded, died of a heart attack on Monday.

title: BIG ORDER FOR BRAZILIAN PLANE MAKER
description: The big United States airline Continental Airlines Inc. will acquire 100 jets from Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. in a deal worth about $1.7 billion. Under the deal, Continental Express, a subsidiary of the Houston-based airline, will buy 75 50-seat jets and 25 37-seat aircraft from Embraer, the leading producer of small passenger jets, by 2003. Embraer's orders now stand at more than $16 billion. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Nudity's Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: G. L. Netterville, 93; Headed Southern U.
description: G. Leon Netterville, a former president of Southern University and A&M College, the largest historically black college in the nation, died on Feb. 12 at his home in Baton Rouge, La. He was 93.

title: Consumer Goods Giant To Cut 25,000 Workers And Push E-Commerce : Unilever To Jettison Brands and Trim Jobs
description: LONDON  For decades Unilever Group, the world's largest consumer products company, has generated billions of dollars in steady profits by selling household brands, ranging from Dove soap and Lipton tea to Calvin Klein fragrances, in more than 100 countries.

title: Discerning Women Reject Game Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, Mr. Green Meets Mr. Koufax
description: Shawn Green, the Dodgers' key off-season acquisition, arrived in camp yesterday in Vero Beach, Fla., and immediately ran into one of his sports idols.

title: On the Wilder Shores of Citrus
description: IN the 40's and 50's, a sure sign that company was coming to dinner was the sight of my mother carefully sectioning white grapefruit halves with a serrated knife, a bottle of maraschino cherries at the ready for topping. If grapefruits weren't exactly exotic back then, they were certainly for special occasions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORVITZ, BIRDIE
description: HORVITZ-Birdie. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member, Birdie Horvitz. Deepest sympathy to her family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Russia's North: Politics and Nuclear Junk Are Hot
description: The citizens of this closed military city, which hides one of Russia's nuclear submarine bases above the Arctic Circle, are staging an extraordinary civic revolt. In a referendum on whether the fleet can put a nuclear waste dump just outside the city limits, they are taking on the navy they have long served.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAER, RITA
description: MAER-Rita, 76, formerly of Siesta Key, Florida, died in Alpharetta, Ga., Monday, February 21, 2000. She is survived by daughters and sons-in-law, Deborah and Gus Mas, of Roswell, Ga., Terry and Lee Goldenberg of New Jersey; son, Jeffrey Maer of New York, and sister, Jean Maer, of Delray Beach, Florida. A memorial service will be held at the family residence, Wednesday, February 23, 2000, at 4:30 PM with Rabbi Scott Saulson officiating. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the hospice of one's choice. For further information, contact Dressler-Ghertner, Jewish Funeral Care/Southcare, 770-437-0095.

title: As Workers Go Off Duty, So Do Cabbies. How Odd.
description: It is as inexorable as the tides, as reliable as the setting sun. And it happens every weekday afternoon around 5, just as office buildings are beginning to empty out, just as hundreds of hands are being raised into the air on hundreds of crowded Manhattan street corners: the Great Taxi Drought begins.

title: GERMAN CABLE DEAL
description: The private equity firm Callahan Associates International L.L.C. bought 55 percent of Deutsche Telekom's cable-television unit in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany's wealthiest state. Callahan, founded in 1996 by a former president of U S West International, Richard Callahan, already has investments in Cableuropa of Spain and NC Numericable of France. The German investment, which the company expects to complete by July 1, would give Callahan access to 14.7 million cable homes in Europe.

title: U.S. Rejects China's Taiwan Views
description: The Clinton administration and Congress today sharply criticized a threat by China to forcibly reunify Taiwan with the mainland if Beijing determines that negotiations between the two are dragging on too long.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WELLS FARGO & CO., San Francisco, the seventh-largest United States bank, said it would buy back as many as 81 million, or 5 percent, of its shares, worth as much as $2.77 billion at current prices.

title: A Heavy Student Backpack? How Uncool
description: To the Editor:

title: Henderson Reports to Camp and Takes His Cuts at Critics
description: Rickey Henderson can never stay on a base very long, so when he says, ''I have to move around,'' he means it. The Mets' left fielder is always going somewhere: from the dugout to the clubhouse when he is taken out of games; from team to team in an itinerant, and highly successful, 21-year career; from topic to topic in a lively monologue on his first day in spring training today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLESCHNER, HELEN
description: FLESCHNER-Helen. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a well respected leader in the Jewish Community, beloved mother of Miriam (and Dr. Alvin I.) Schiff, whose husband is a member of the RIETS Board of Trustees, and of Noah (and Cynthia) Fleschner, and cherished sister of Jerry Reisman, Milton Reisman, Pearl Kaplan and Esther Spiegelman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Yeshiva University Board of Trustees Judah Feinerman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY: Manhattan and Seattle.

title: Home Depot's Quarterly Profits Rise 38%
description: Home Depot Inc., the nation's largest chain of home-improvement stores, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 38 percent as it sold more water heaters, appliances and other big-ticket items.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITCHING, JESSIE
description: KITCHING-Jessie. The New York City Audubon Society records with deep sorrow the passing of Jessie Kitching, a founder, longtime member and supporter of the Society. Our condolenceds to her family and to her companion, Emily Jones.

title: AES EXPANDS IN ARGENTINA
description: Extending its reach in Latin America, the AES Corporation will acquire a controlling stake in an Argentine hydroelectric power plant for $205 million from the Southern Company. AES, which will use the plant in the province of Neuquen to supply electricity to as many as one million homes, expects half of its earnings to come from South America within five years. AES is based in Arlington, Va., and operates in 18 countries. Southern, based in Atlanta, is one of the biggest American power utilities. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: MEDICALOGIC TO ACQUIRE MEDSCAPE AND TOTAL EMED
description: MedicaLogic Inc., a medical-records software company, said yesterday that it would buy two Web-based health services for about $1.24 billion to get more doctors to use its electronic medical record products. MedicaLogic, based in Hillsboro, Ore., will buy Medscape Inc., which runs health-care Web sites, for about $830.1 million in stock and the privately held medical transcription service Total eMed for about $405.5 million in stock.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an Arts in America article about an exhibition of pieces once owned by the Stroganoff family misattributed a portrait of Baron G. A. Stroganoff. The artist was Marie-Louise-Elisabeth Vigee-Lebrun, not Alexander Warnek.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BODE, JANET
description: BODE-Janet. Memorial service Saturday, February 26, 2000 at 1PM at Village Community School, 272 West 10 Street, Manhattan.

title: A Contact Sport Evolves in the Hauraki Gulf
description: In hockey and football and all the other contests where contact is a ritual of the game, the vision of a bloodied combatant translates to business as usual. But when it comes to sailboat racing, the sight of deep crimson flowing freely from a battered competitor, though not unheard of, remains rare indeed.

title: Yanks Lost a Coach, Hernandez a Mentor
description: They ate seafood and sipped wine on Monday night as pupil and teacher, as baseball pitcher and baseball coach and as two proud Cubans who feel fortunate not to be ruled by Fidel Castro. Orlando Hernandez gleefully screamed Jose Cardenal's name when he saw him in a restaurant on Sunday and, 24 hours later, El Duque was sharing a meal with the first man, and maybe the only man, he ever trusted on the Yankees, the man who is now a former Yankee.

title: A Whisper Of Spring In a Sprout
description: IMAGINE if you took a beet, put it through a juicer, then reduced its juice until all that was left was the pure sweet essence of the vegetable. And then you found a way to inject that essence into a frail little leaf, no longer than a blade of grass.

title: Admission to N.Y.U.: More Than Just Scores
description: The glittering silver shoe rimmed in purple feather boa arrived at 22 Washington Square North -- the town house that serves as New York University's admissions war room -- with a note from Jessica. Now that she had one shoe in the door, the note said, she hoped to get the other one in, too.

title: Questions in a Change of Heart
description: UNLIKE most of the Ivy League, Brown University has not added a business school to its campus, despite the obvious perk: wealthy alumni. No matter. Brown's students and faculty got a lesson from the business world this month. The university's barely broken-in president, E. Gordon Gee, stunned the community when he announced that after just two years in office, he had accepted an offer to run Vanderbilt University.

title: Mrs. Clinton Suggests a State Debating Tour
description: Describing the rambunctious presidential debate on racial issues at the Apollo Theater in Harlem on Monday as a valuable exercise for voters, Hillary Rodham Clinton said today she would like to debate Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on the same topics and in the same setting, and suggested that the two embark on a debating tour across New York.

title: Seton Hall To Face Minnesota
description: When Seton Hall scheduled Minnesota for their game tonight at Continental Arena, the Pirates' coach, Tommy Amaker, figured the Golden Gophers would be a sturdy nonconference test to prepare Seton Hall for the postseason.

title: Top U.N. Monitor Named
description: A management expert from Singapore has been appointed the United Nations' second inspector general, a spokesman for Secretary General Kofi Annan said today. The nominee, who must be approved by the General Assembly, is Dileep Nair, a former chief operating officer of Singapore's National Savings Bank.

title: An Outer Hero Shows His Inner Man
description: To see Bill T. Jones, a magnificent dancer, perform alone onstage, is a pleasure. Anyone who remembers his solos before he formed his dance company with Arnie Zane in 1982 will recall a startling agility full of genuine spontaneity and polish. Even then he talked about his life and feelings as he danced.

title: Marijuana, Manuscript And Marriage Are a Mess
description: Michael Chabon's 1995 novel, ''Wonder Boys,'' chronicles a hectic weekend in the life of Grady Tripp, a frustrated, concupiscent college teacher mired in at least three ill-starred relationships: to marijuana, to his elephantine unfinished manuscript and to the wife of his department chairman. More Anne Tyler than John Updike, the book plays Grady's dilemma for gentle comedy and lingers fondly over the quirky geography of a proud, battered American industrial city, in this case Pittsburgh. ''Wonder Boys'' is intoxicated by its setting and enchanted by writing: by the sweet, fizzy soda pop of its own style and also by some unabashedly romantic notions of the literary life. Mr. Chabon's characters tap out their manuscripts on old typewriters, are reckless in love and loyal in friendship and suffer from the creative agitation Grady calls ''the midnight disease.''

title: New campaign about online trading has a traditional message.
description: THE hype is everywhere: stories about 22-year-old Internet millionaires, clerks in start-up companies with stockholdings that rival those of a typical C.E.O. and TV commercials about fortunes made in online trading.

title: Charter School's Learning Curve; Operator Faces Challenges in New Educational Venture
description: Freedom from the educational bureaucracy. Emancipation from cramped, inadequate buildings. Liberty from incompetent teachers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTONUCCI, ANTHONY J.
description: ANTONUCCI-Anthony J. February 21, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Ida. Devoted father of Peter Anthony. Adoring grandfather of Alexander Peter and Nicole Rose. Dear brother of Lydia Musumeci, Dante Antonucci & the late Santino Antonucci. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Wednesday 7:00-9:00 PM and Thursday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, February 25, 10:00 A.M., Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 E. 62 St. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017.

title: Internet and Alienation
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Nod To Clinton On Universal Health Care
description: In a nod to President Clinton's continuing popularity among Democratic voters, former Senator Bill Bradley asserted today that Vice President Al Gore had adopted many core Democratic principles only after becoming Mr. Clinton's ''No. 2,'' and he suggested that the vice president could not be counted on to defend those principles on his own.

title: Corrections
description: A byline on Saturday for an article about a Los Angeles case in which federal prosecutors are seeking the death penalty in the shooting of a mail carrier misspelled the surname of the writer. He is Christian Berthelsen, not Berthelson.

title: Murray Bernstein, West Side Sturgeon King, Dies at 87
description: Murray Bernstein, who took a narrow store on Broadway and turned it into Murray's Sturgeon Shop, a legendary Upper West Side purveyor of salmon and sable, caviar and camaraderie, died Monday at a nursing home in Lauderhill, Fla. He was 87.

title: Mr. McCain's Michigan Surprise
description: Senator John McCain's victories yesterday in Michigan and his home state of Arizona once again scramble the Republican presidential race, and portend more blistering battles to come with Gov. George W. Bush. Stunned by a new defeat so soon after winning in South Carolina on Saturday, Mr. Bush was taking solace last night in his strong showing among Republicans. The results in Michigan do indeed show that Mr. McCain won because of independents and Democrats, with the Texas governor the undisputed choice of the G.O.P. faithful. In future primaries, where crossover voting is barred, Mr. Bush may well have an easier time. At some point Mr. McCain will have to show that he can draw majority support among members of his own party and also convert a reluctant party leadership if he hopes to roll to the nomination. And if Mr. Bush hopes to rebound, he sooner or later must show that he has the ability to win without being propped up by local bosses.

title: N.H.L. and Vancouver Police Are Investigating Stick Attack
description: Two investigations began yesterday after the stick attack by Boston's Marty McSorley against Vancouver's Donald Brashear.

title: Prada Tacks Back to Whimsical '40s Style
description: MILAN  So is this the end of the affair  between Miuccia Prada and modernity? The collection she sent out for autumn 2000 was a remake of the 1940s, beautifully done, with whimsical wisps of dresses and smart tweed suits. But it was indisputably retro  except that the designer herself did not agree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, FRANCES ZISMAN
description: BENJAMIN-Frances Zisman.Died on February 15, 2000, age 97. She outlived two husbands Louis S. Zisman and Abraham I. Benjamin. She was mother of two, grandmother of six, great grandmother of 12. She was the family matriarch with the beauty of a Rachel, the forecefulness of a Rebecca and the fighting spirit of Deborah in her battles against illness and injustice. An era ends. She goes with our love.

title: MERCK TO REPURCHASE $10 BILLION OF SHARES
description: Merck & Company, the No. 1 United States drugmaker, will buy back as much as $10 billion of its shares, which have fallen 18 percent this month. Merck had about 2.3 billion shares outstanding as of Oct. 29, according to regulatory filings. The repurchase would represent about 6.5 percent of Merck's $153 billion market capitalization. The authorization is the biggest since the General Electric Company approved a buyback of the the same size in 1989, according to the Securities Data Company. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., said it had already bought back $3.9 billion, or 54.9 million shares, under a $5 billion July 1998 buyback plan. Merck's shares rose $3.3125 yesterday, to $65.50.

title: Y.& R. and Emotion Form Partnership
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had formed a partnership with Emotion Inc. in Vienna, Va., a digital media management company.

title: Greenlight Offer for BNC
description: BNC Mortgage Inc. said today that the hedge fund Greenlight Capital Inc. had offered to buy the company for $56.1 million in cash, just two weeks after BNC agreed to be acquired by a management-led group of investors. Greenlight Capital is the second-biggest shareholder of BNC Mortgage, a residential mortgage lender, with a 13.2 percent stake. Greenlight offered $11 a share. Earlier this month, BNC Mortgage agreed to be bought by a group led by the company's president and chief financial officer for $10 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUPI, EUGENE
description: CRUPI-Eugene. Born in Reading, PA. Predeceased by Domenico and Antonette Crupi and brother Vincent. Loving brother of Letteria Diefendorf of Farmington, Il. and Joanne Holko of Warren, Ohio. Former partner Main Herdman Certified Public Accountants, graduate cum laude from Pace University. Member New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants and the American Institute of Certified Accountants. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10AM St. Charles Borremeo Church.

title: How Oaxaca Cooks Now
description: IN ''Seasons of My Heart: A Culinary Journey Through Oaxaca, Mexico,'' Susana Trilling includes a recipe for coctel de camaron, a pungent shrimp cocktail. The backbone of the dish is an intense shrimp stock flavored with chilies, but it gains its sweet undertone from orange soda and its satiny texture from ketchup. This type of dish illustrates the essence -- and integrity -- of Ms. Trilling's recipes in ''Seasons'' (Ballantine Books, $25).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAGER, ROBERT G.
description: SCHWAGER-Robert G. A longtime resident of New York City and CEO of International Cultured Pearl passed away February 22, 2000. Born in Vienna, Austria on August 15, 1917. He is survived by his wife Elizabet, his children Susan Wulkan & Ronny Schwager, grandchildren Wendy, Lenny and Joey, and sister Herta Selzer. A Memorial service will be held March 5 from 11 A.M.-1 P.M., at Reddens Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, a contribution be made to your favorite charity in memory of Robert Schwager.

title: PSINet Drops as Its Fourth-Quarter Loss Nearly Doubles
description: February 22, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, FILOMEN D'AGOSTINO
description: GREENBERG-Filomen D'Agostino. The New York University community grieves for the loss of Filomen D'Agostino Greenberg. Trustee, alumna, distinguished lawyer and friend, she maintained an active, life-ong interest in the University. We were deeply grateful for her generosity and appreciative of her commitment to NYU. On behalf of the entire University, we offer our deepest sympathies to her family, loved ones and friends. We were proud to have her in our ranks and she will be missed. L. Jay Oliva, President Martin Lipton, Chairman

title: Reckonings; The Dishonest Truth
description: You don't have to be a brilliant political analyst to realize that the Republican nominee for president (whose identity is still, amazingly, in doubt) is going to have trouble making an economic case for his candidacy. As Bill Clinton put it, declaring that he had a ''lot of sympathy'' for the Republicans: ''I mean, it's hard for them to figure out what to run on. They can't run against the longest economic expansion in history.''

title: Secretary of Education Proposes That Teachers Work All the Year
description: Saying public schools are plagued by ''an old agrarian schedule, an outdated factory model and an antiquated wage system,'' Education Secretary Richard W. Riley proposed yesterday that teachers work year-round, a move he hoped would raise their pay and their status.

title: NYT Article
description: America Online and HomeGrocer in $60 Million Deal

title: For Retrial, Subway Defendant Goes Off Medication
description: As jury selection began yesterday in the second murder trial of a schizophrenic man who pushed a young woman in front of a subway train, attention focused on a rare tactic by his new lawyers: the defendant, Andrew Goldstein, stopped taking his anti-psychotic medication two weeks ago.

title: Tower of Faith and Loyalty
description: I grew up in Ada, a community of about 17,000 people in the southern part of Oklahoma. We spent weekends walking up and down the creek looking for rocks, fossils and Indian artifacts. So, growing up, I had a great interest in archaeology, paleontology and geology.

title: Friedensreich Hundertwasser, Austrian Artist and Architect, 71
description: Friedensreich Hundertwasser, an Austrian painter and architect famous for his undulating forms and color wizardry a s well as for his visceral loathing of symmetry and the straight line, died on Saturday on board the Queen Elizabeth 2, Joram Harel, his manager and friend, told The Associated Press. He was 71 and had boarded the ship in Auckland, New Zealand.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; U.S. Accuses 3 Companies Of Violations
description: The nation's top securities regulator brought civil cases against two stock day-trading companies yesterday and turned a hat trick by also accusing an unregistered hedge fund manager of fraud.

title: Missing: A Death Penalty Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Boys in Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: NYT Article
description: Sony's New Playstation to Spur DVD Industry

title: Dashing Shortlived Hopes of Global Harmony
description: THE COMING ANARCHY

title: S.& P. Concerned About Prospects for Recovery in Japan
description: Standard & Poor's, a leading credit-rating agency, delivered a thinly veiled warning to the Japanese government today that its economic policies and rising levels of debt could threaten Japan's triple-A credit rating.

title: Unilever Plans Huge Cuts In Jobs, Plants and Brands
description: Unilever P.L.C., the world's leading maker of consumer goods that include supermarket mainstays like Dove soap, Ragu spaghetti sauce and Lipton tea, said today that it would embark on a severe program of corporate cutbacks, eliminating 25,000 jobs over five years, closing 100 factories and possibly jettisoning up to 75 percent of its products.

title: Knicks Won't Train in South Carolina
description: The Knicks have trained in Charleston, S.C., for the past eight years, spending a week of preseason training camp at the College of Charleston and then returning there for the period between the end of the regular season and the beginning of the playoffs. But the Knicks won't be there this spring, as they get ready for the postseason.

title: Los Angeles Police Union Seeks Inquiry
description: In an extraordinary step that reflected the plummeting public confidence in the Los Angeles Police Department over a growing corruption scandal, the union representing police officers undercut the department's chief today and demanded an independent investigation of the growing evidence of police brutality.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Changes at River Cafe

title: Taiwan, Brushing Off Threats, Tells Chinese to Be Practical
description: Unbowed by China's latest threat of force, Taiwan called on the mainland today to set aside fruitless debates over sovereignty and resume talks over economic ties and other practical matters to improve relations.

title: Montreal Journal; On Ethnic Battlefield, the French Retake a Bridge
description: To Quebec nationalists, the proposal seemed suspicious from the start: to rename one of the 15 highway bridges leading into this city after an Italian.

title: Lawyers Plead For 4 Officers In Diallo Trial
description: With raised voices and emotional appeals, lawyers for the four New York City police officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo pleaded with jurors today to see his shooting as a tragic mistake brought on by Mr. Diallo's actions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPLIN, ARLENE
description: CHAPLIN-Arlene. Beloved wife of my lifelong friend, Harvey. Arlene was a devoted and loving mother and mother-in-law. Sweet as sugar-how much she will be missed by Harvey and the children. Howard S. Feldman

title: Radicchio and Endive, Free of the Salad Bowl
description: AMERICAN cooks have adopted radicchio and endive as their own. Just try to find a restaurant that doesn't serve one or both of these bitter ''lettuces,'' considered exotic just 10 years ago and impossible to find in many parts of the country. Now, even mini-marts carry bagged tricolor salad mixes with radicchio, endive and some sort of greenery.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Presses Defense As Trial Draws to a Close

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, TIFFANI BEA
description: FELDMAN-Tiffani Bea. Beloved daughter of Lani and Steve. Loving sister of Kerrin. Cherished granddaughter of Muri and Sy Abramson and Muriel Feldman. Soulmate to Michael. Dear cousin, niece and friend. Services Wednesday 1PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, L.I.

title: Outcome Online Before Voting Is Done
description: ''John McCain 48 percent; George W. Bush 46 percent,'' said the story about the Michigan primary on Slate, the online magazine.

title: Zinfandels Play the Clown
description: EVERYBODY knows that wine is a serious, dignified business. The fear of using the wrong word or the wrong glass or even of liking the wrong wine has stifled the pleasure of more than a few would-be wine lovers. Words like funny, silly, informal and relaxed do not come to mind in a world of Chateau Grand Mal de Tete, right?

title: A Victim Of Abuse Now Sees Better Days
description: The long, red scar down the middle of Sam York's back is a constant reminder of a past too painful to remember, but the baby daughter bouncing in his arms, born just days ago, is a sure sign that better days are ahead.

title: Review on Risks of Diabetes Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration is investigating a recent increase in deaths caused by the diabetes drug Rezulin, an agency spokesman said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, ISAAC
description: RUBIN-Isaac. The Westchester Jewish Center family mourns the passing of our longtime member, Isaac Rubin, and extends our sympathy to his wife, Lucille, his son Charles & wife Susan, his daughter Carol Kahn, her husband Gary and their daughter Gabrielle and to the entire Rubin family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Randy Heller, President Jeffrey Segelman, Rabbi Dr. Irving Koslowe, Rabbi Em.

title: Mississippi Power Plant
description: The Calpine Corporation, a developer of power plants, said today that it planned to build a $425 million power plant in Mississippi to expand further in the fast-growing power markets of the southern United States. Calpine said the natural-gas-fired plant planned for Lowndes County, Mississippi, would be able to generate 800 megawatts of electricity, enough to light about 800,000 homes. Construction is expected to start next year and be done by 2003. Calpine, based in San Jose, either owns or has interests in power plant projects in 19 states.

title: A Set Designer's Dream of a Bistro
description: NEW YORKERS tolerate the most cramped and overcrowded living conditions in the United States, so they naturally gravitate to places of entertainment that are even more cramped and overcrowded. This instinct partly explains the overpowering allure of Pastis, a restaurant named after a drink that most Americans would not touch with a 10-foot pole.

title: Land Rover Review Down to 3 Agencies
description: Land Rover North America, part of BMW A.G., said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $35 million, to three agencies from five. The incumbent agency of 13 years, Grace & Rothschild in New York, declined to take part in the review when it began last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTLEDGE, BETH
description: RUTLEDGE-Beth. The Refugee Data Center/ICMC notes with deep sadness the passing of Beth Rutledge of the International Rescue Committee. We will miss this outstanding humanitarian and advocate for refugees. Staff of the Refugee Data Center

title: Economy's Next Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Of Oats and the Meal

title: Sotheby's Head Says Setbacks Will Be Costly But Not Fatal
description: As its stock took another beating yesterday, the new chairman of Sotheby's, the beleaguered international auction house, predicted that an extensive federal antitrust investigation and various class-action lawsuits would be ''expensive but not life-threatening'' for the 256-year-old company.

title: Rangers Hold Off Penguins to End Victory Drought
description: The all-Czech line has been carrying the Rangers since its inception seven weeks ago. Care to guess who powered the Rangers again last night?

title: Another Big Paper Company Acquisition
description: In a move that brings the fourth major paper-industry merger or acquisition in less than two weeks, the big Finnish paper company Stora Enso said yesterday that it would acquire Consolidated Papers Inc., based in Wisconsin Rapids, Wis. The deal is valued at $3.9 billion, plus the assumption of $900 million in debt.

title: Young Designers Give Artisan Traditions a Sassy Spin
description: MILAN  Marco Mazzocchi, the model of a modern businessman, sits in a Milan showroom extolling the virtues of mink hotpants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTMANN, EDITH
description: ANTMANN-Edith. Beloved wife of Charles. Dear mother of Frances and Barbara. Beloved grandmother of Bianca and Yasmin. Loving cousin of Dita. Funeral service at Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, Wednesday, February 23 at 10AM. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Two Pairs Working Opposite Sides of the Same Street
description: Two pairs of musicians with two diametrically opposed approaches -- modernist clarity and postmodernist profusion -- performed last weekend at the Kaplan Penthouse in the Duets on the Hudson series presented by Jazz at Lincoln Center. The pianist Kenny Barron and the saxophonist Gary Bartz took standards and jazz tunes and spun out chorus after savvy chorus within their forms. In contrast, the pianist Paul Bley and the bassist Charlie Haden played as if every form shattered at their touch.

title: Brooks Still Trapped In a Rearview Mirror
description: In some ways, Herb Brooks is a little like Orson Welles. Even in his later years, Welles pitched new movie ideas to studios. Young executives would listen for a while to his proposals while smiling and nodding.

title: Goodrich Stock Buyback
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said today that it would buy back up to $300 million, or 10 percent, of its common stock. Goodrich, a supplier of aircraft products and services to the aerospace industry, has about 110.2 million shares outstanding. Shares of Goodrich showed a rise of 62.5 cents, to $23.3125, at the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: An Oracle Spinoff Will Stress Cell Phone Access to the Internet
description: The Oracle Corporation's chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, announced the formation and spinoff yesterday of a new business to capitalize on the industrywide push to make the Internet accessible over wireless phones and other portable devices.

title: Many Iranian Conservatives Lose Seats
description: Many of the conservative parliamentarians who led the opposition to President Mohammad Khatami's reform program were apparently soundly defeated in their re-election bids in the election last Friday, according to independent analysts who tallied the hard-liners' losses today.

title: Accounts
description: * Pingpong.com, Fountain Valley, Calif., an Internet company planning to introduce an information search engine, to Doner, Newport Beach, Calif., to handle its account, which had been at the office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, in Costa Mesa, Calif. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: MOTOROLA WILL ACQUIRE C-PORT FOR $430 MILLION
description: Motorola Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held chip maker C-Port Corporation for $430 million in stock. C-Port develops technology for routers and switchers, which are used to direct traffic on the Internet. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., makes semiconductors and cell phones. It said that C-Port's technology could be upgraded easily, as opposed to traditional router and switcher technology, which takes a long time to develop. C-Port, which has 90 employees, will keep its headquarters in North Andover, Mass. It will become part of Motorola's Networking and Computing Systems Group, based in Austin, Tex.

title: In His Own Words
description: JOHN McCAIN

title: Too Much Garbage
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, EDWARD
description: LANDAU-Edward. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Edward Landau, and extend to his bereaved wife Eve Landau and the members of his family our sincere condolences. Jeffrey Citron, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRABKIN, STEVEN WAYNE
description: DRABKIN-Steven Wayne. 10/19/61 -2/23/81. We who held him dear remember. Time will never dim the memory of his loving smile or his warm embrace. Mom and Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, HENRIETTA ESTHER
description: SEGAL-Henrietta Esther. October 22, 1904 to February 22, 2000. Your daughter Lita, son-in-law Samuel, grandsons Keith and Evan Torgan all say ''Good night, sleep tight...We love you''. Funeral services at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, 12 noon Friday.

title: Discerning Women Reject Game Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: Baruch and York Reach Final
description: The cream has risen to the top in the City University of New York Athletic Conference tournament.

title: A Flutist Has Fun With Drums
description: No one can accuse the flutist James Galway of running out of ways to present himself. In the nearly 25 years since he left the Berlin Philharmonic to become a solo flutist, he has cruised his way through the recital and concerto repertory, commissioned stacks of works, undertaken an equally large stack of crossover projects in which he has played everything from light pop to country to tangos, and pursued a sideline conducting career.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Office Space Defined by Architecture
description: Built as an artists' cooperative in 1908 and still a residence until two years ago, a 14-story building at 140 West 57th Street has been transformed into an office building.

title: McCain Makes Appeal to G.O.P. Loyalists
description: With his insurgent campaign brought back to life tonight by victories in the Michigan and Arizona primaries, Senator John McCain reached out to loyalists in his party, imploring, ''Don't fear this campaign, my fellow Republicans -- join it.''

title: Experts Cast Doubt on Medical Reporting Plan
description: The official who is leading federal efforts to reduce medical errors told Congress today that he had no firm evidence that mandatory reporting of such errors as proposed by President Clinton increased the safety of patients or reduced the number of mistakes in states where it had been tried.

title: McCain Keeps a Firm Grip on His Home State
