description: In the end, the home-state hero more than held his own here tonight, as Senator John McCain's resounding victory over Gov. George W. Bush of Texas cut across virtually all demographic groups in the Arizona Republican electorate.

title: Simply Korean: Broth and Tofu
description: WHEN I tried to order juk-suk cham-doo-boo, or boiled handmade tofu with special sauce, to go at Cho Dang Gol, a Korean restaurant in Midtown, I got an unusual response.

title: How the Polls Were Conducted
description: The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed yesterday by voters leaving voting stations throughout Michigan and Arizona. The poll was conducted by Voter News Service, an organization created by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, Fox News, NBC News and The Associated Press.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Guy Waterman, a wilderness writer, misstated the birth order of two of his three sons. John, who died in 1978 while trying to climb Mount McKinley, was the middle son; James was the youngest.

title: Sports of The Times; Darryl, Darryl, Darryl
description: THERE must be some new way to approach this saga. The newspapers could finally get tired of all this and confine him to the ''Transactions'' category, the small type reserved for waiver deals and new tennis coaches at obscure colleges.

title: Mildred Root Mottahedeh, 91, Collector of Chinese Porcelain
description: Mildred Root Mottahedeh, a collector of Chinese export porcelains and co-founder of a company that produced porcelain reproductions for several United States presidents and institutions including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died last Thursday at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. She was 91 and lived in Manhattan.

title: McCAIN REBOUNDS IN MICHIGAN, BUOYED BY BIG CROSSOVER VOTE, AND WINS EASILY IN HOME STATE
description: In a brash comeback that threw the Republican presidential race into turmoil, Senator John McCain trounced Gov. George W. Bush on Tuesday in Michigan, the biggest electoral prize thus far, and in the senator's home state of Arizona.

title: Loman's Ghost Haunts Mamet's Turf
description: Shelly Levene is fighting for his life. Shelly is a real estate salesman who has spent his entire life closing deals. ''Always be closing,'' has been his life's creed. But Shelly hasn't closed a sale in a while now, and if he doesn't make one soon he's going to be out of a job.

title: Chechen Refugee Camps: From Crude to Abysmal
description: By any reasonable judgment, life is unspeakable for the 6,000 or so denizens of the Solglacia refugee camp, a network of 250 tents and a strand of rail cars set along the sinuous main road to Grozny.

title: NYT Article
description: Airline Reservation System Crashes Briefly

title: New Tools for Employee Maintenance
description: Wage inflation may have all but disappeared from the economic map, but for companies looking to grow, there is anotherside to that good news. Just about any worker with a marketable skill has by now caught on to corporate America's worst-kept secret: managers are desperate to attract talent and even more desperate to hold onto it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDNICH, JOHN DAVID
description: MINDNICH-John David. Of Basking Ridge, NJ. Formerly of Short Hills, NJ. On Monday, February 21, 2000. Husband of Jean Koellhoffer Mindnich, father of John D. Mindnich, Jr., Peter A. Mindnich, Mrs. Carolyn Benson and Michael G. Mindnich. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Funeral mass in St. Rose of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Ave, Short Hills on Friday, February 25, at 11:15 AM. Entombment Somerset Hills Mausoleum, Basking Ridge. Friends may call at Smith and Smith (Suburban), 415 Morris Ave, Springfield, NJ on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Alzheimer's Disease Research, Attention Dr. Arnold Price, Johns Hopkins Medical Institute, Rm 558, Ross 730 Rutland Avenue, Baltimore, MD. 21205.

title: Near or Far, the Primal Sound Is Om
description: The number of recordings available suggests there is a wide audience for the music of the Italian composer Giacinto Scelsi, who died 12 years ago. But his work is not often heard at concerts, which could be because it demands special techniques, and special dedication, from performers because it is hard to program and because it addresses itself not so much to a large, gathered public as to the solitary listener.

title: The Big City; Paid to Surf (And Filter) Sex Sites
description: IF you had any doubt that the American Dream is alive and well, consider what Yufeng Liang has been through since he left Beijing six years ago.

title: Who Needs Tear Gas?Seoul Puts Policewomen Out Front
description: SEOUL  The national police agency has devised what it believes to be a sure-fire way to turn off demonstrations without firing the peppery tear gas that once floated over the center of Seoul and other large cities during the spring riot season.

title: Arson Becomes Homicide As 6-Year-Old Boy Dies
description: A 6-year-old boy who was severely burned in a suspicious fire in Brooklyn on Monday died of his injuries yesterday.

title: Giuliani Accuses Mrs. Clinton of Negative Calls, Disguised as Polling
description: Officials with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Senate campaign yesterday accused Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign of engaging in manipulative telephone calls to spread negative impressions of the mayor. Mrs. Clinton's campaign immediately responded that the charges were untrue, and that the mayor was a hypocrite.

title: Pain Relief Underused For Poor, Study Says
description: An international narcotics control agency that is better known for raising alarms about the narcotics trade and drug abuse has turned its attention this year to a severe shortage of morphine and other painkillers in poor countries, where many are left to die in agony from cancer and other diseases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSCHALL, RICHARD H.
description: MARSCHALL-Richard H. Died Friday, February 18th in Fort Lauderdale of cancer at 63. He was formerly a practicing psychotherapist in New York City for the last 20 years. Survived by his daughter Susan Marschall Patterson of Maynard, MA, his mother Ann Egan Marschall of Stamford, CT., and a brother Brian. A funeral Mass will be held Thursday, February 24th, 10 AM, Our Lady Star of the Seas Church, 1200 Shippan Avenue, Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to American Cancer Society, 372 Danbury Road, Wilton, CT. 06897.

title: Corrections
description: The Restaurants column last Wednesday, about Icon, in the W Court Hotel in Manhattan, misidentified the company that operates the hotel. It is Starwood Hotels, not Starship Lodgings.

title: Immigrant Amnesty
description: To the Editor:

title: Prep School Denies Barkley Revelations
description: The headmaster of a Maine prep school said yesterday that Erick Barkley's financial aid information had never been released to the National Collegiate Athletic Association because the college sports governing body had not asked for it.

title: THE CHEF
description: MANY people are surprised to find rice pudding, a classic American comfort food, on my menu. But to me, it seems a natural choice. Rice is tremendously important in Japanese cuisine, and I knew we could create a rice pudding that departed from the ordinary. What Christine Chang, our pastry chef, and I came up with follows the typical technique, which is to simmer rice in sweetened milk until it is soft and creamy. But the result has a flavor and texture that are completely unexpected.

title: Filomen Greenberg, 101, N.Y.U. Law Benefactor
description: Filomen D'Agostino Greenberg, a self-taught stock trader who used her good fortune to help her alma mater, New York University Law School, grow into an academic leader, died Friday. She was 101 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: MICROSOFT CHIDED AS ANTITRUST TRIAL DRAWS TO A CLOSE
description: Microsoft had its last chance in federal court today to persuade the trial judge not to issue a stinging antitrust verdict against the company.

title: One China, Two Systems
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Mandela Implicitly Endorses Clinton

title: City's Rules For Shelters Held Illegal
description: A state court said yesterday that the Giuliani administration could not bar single adults from shelters if they failed to meet work requirements and other welfare eligibility rules.

title: Resorting to Typing
description: As a secretary, it never seemed to matter where or even that I had gone to college. My college's name on a resume did not exempt me from the grammar, spelling and typing tests that aspiring secretaries must endure. Nor did it open doors for me. When I get my college alumnae magazine, I catch up on classmates who are physicians, lawyers and late-blooming social workers. I never read about the secretaries or clerks, though I know they exist. In college, there were premeds, prelaws and those who did not know what to do with their lives. It was what I learned in secretarial school, not college, that has sustained me the last 22 years.

title: Giuliani Defends the Police Before Graduating Cadets
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, drawing repeated cheers yesterday from graduating police cadets and their families and friends, called police officers ''civil rights workers'' who are too often unfairly vilified and subject to prejudice.

title: Missing: A Death Penalty Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, LEE R.
description: SILVERMAN-Lee R., M.D. Of West Bloomfield, MI. The Zionist Organization of America extends heartfelt condolences to our esteemed past National President, Sidney Silverman, and to Mrs. Lillian Silverman, on the sudden and untimely passing of their beloved son. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Morton A. Klein, Nat'l Pres. Dr. Janice J. Sokolovsky, National Executive Director

title: Women's Earnings: What a Difference a Degree Makes
description: For women, the pay gap between the educational haves and have-nots has widened inexorably over the last two decades. In 1980, high-school dropouts earned 57 percent as much as college graduates, but by 1998 that ratio had slid to 40 percent.

title: Support for Detainees
description: To the Editor:

title: Voters Defeat Measure on Filters at Library
description: Voters Defeat Measure on Filters at Library

title: New Tension Over Taiwan
description: A dangerous pattern is emerging in the troubled relations across the Taiwan Strait. During Taiwan's last presidential campaign, in 1996, China test-fired missiles over waters close to the island's major cities to protest what it saw as a drift toward independence. Now, with a new campaign under way, Beijing is again trying to intimidate Taiwanese voters and push the island's next leaders into early reunification talks on the mainland's terms.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court Looks at Expansion Of Checkpoints for Drugs
description: A decade after upholding the use of roadblocks to catch drunken drivers, the Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether adding a drug-sniffing dog to the checkpoint renders the practice unconstitutional.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUFSON, JOANNA
description: MUFSON-Joanna. August 16, 1969 to February 23, 1983. ''When you move through a choreographed dance, angels accompany you. Thus, spirit never dies, you are just lighter by far.'' Love, Mom and Abby

title: Refreshed Ripken Set For Quest For 3,000
description: The inner peace that Cal Ripken experienced during a particularly emotionally tugging 1999 season is still there, the Baltimore Orioles' third baseman says. So bring on the scrutiny and glare that will accompany his April pursuit of 3,000 hits.

title: After Mixed Results, Officials Want to Extend Trial of 65-M.P.H. Speed Limit
description: New Jersey's experiment with a 65-mile-per-hour speed limit should remain limited for another 18 months of study, state transportation officials recommended yesterday, saying that their first set of accident statistics was inconclusive.

title: Trinidad Takes Role Of Attention Grabber
description: Felix Trinidad and Oscar De La Hoya were in Manhattan yesterday, each doing his own thing. The proximity was not by accident.

title: Liberties; McCain Picks Up the Mo in Motown
description: It is a campaign straight out of Capra.

title: Sharp Rise Found In Psychiatric Drugs For the Very Young
description: In a finding that medical experts called ''troubling'' and ''very surprising,'' researchers reported today that the number of preschoolers taking stimulants, antidepressants and other psychiatric drugs rose drastically from 1991 to 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWSOM, PHILIP SARGENT
description: NEWSOM-Philip Sargent, died on February 19, 2000, at Rancho Bernardo, California, age 89. Beloved husband of the late Pearl Newsom. Retired Foreign News Editor, United Press International.

title: SAGE BUYING FAROUDJA IN $155 MILLION DEAL
description: Sage Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Faroudja Inc. for $155 million in stock in a move that will add to Sage's product line of video-enhancing technology. Sage said the combined company would be able to develop new products faster and have more marketing, distribution and financial resources. Sage makes semiconductor chips used in video displays for televisions and projectors. It had $12.3 million in revenue in the nine months ended Dec. 31. Faroudja, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., develops technology to enhance video quality.

title: THAI STOCKS IN STEEP DROP
description: Thailand's benchmark stock index experienced its biggest decline in more than a year, dropping 7.1 percent to its lowest level since last October, on concerns that new bankruptcy laws are still too weak to help Thailand's banks recover debts from recalcitrant borrowers. The source of investor dismay, analysts said, was the central bankruptcy court's decision last week to grant the country's largest corporate debtor, Thai Petrochemical Industry, a two-week delay in hearing a petition by its creditors to declare the chemical maker insolvent. More than two years of talks between Thai Petrochemical and its lenders to revamp roughly $3.5 billion in debts have failed to produce an agreement. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Simon Wants Rocker's Apology
description: Randall Simon wondered if he could be teammates again with John Rocker after Simon was widely reported to be the teammate Rocker called a fat monkey in a published interview.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: After 11 Years, Rose Is Still Knocking on Commissioner's Door
description: Almost 11 years to the day he was first summoned to appear before the baseball commissioner about his alleged gambling, Pete Rose yesterday staged his latest public effort to sway the thinking of the current commissioner. By the close of business at Bud Selig's office in Milwaukee, Rose had still not succeeded.

title: Corrections
description: A thumbnail biography in Business Day yesterday about Michael I. Sovern, the new chairman of Sotheby's Holdings Inc., referred incorrectly to his action, as president of Columbia University in the 1980's, in overseeing the admission of women. It applied to the undergraduate Columbia College, not the university over all; many other divisions, notably Barnard College, had long educated women.

title: Crumbling Schools Have Trouble Getting Online
description: February 23, 2000

title: The Perils of Voyeur Television
description: ''Reality-based television'' would seem to involve the very thing that television entertainment was designed to relieve -- reality. So it should not be particularly surprising that the marriage of two strangers on the Fox Network's ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire'' last week foundered before the honeymoon was over. After flying into the sunset, the bride and groom came home separately, the groom facing questions about a police restraining order against him issued nine years ago after a former girlfriend complained that he had physically threatened her. Also, there are some troubling concerns about a good chunk of his autobiography, including worries that maybe he was not exactly a multimillionaire. So how many of the 22 million viewers are really surprised that after a few public minutes of courtship, this instant marriage instantly hits a snag? Even Cinderella and Prince Charming had until midnight.

title: On a Rocky Road, the Race Tightens
description: This road is nothing but bumps.

title: Musical M.C. for the Silk Stocking District
description: SEVERAL measures into the first chorus of ''How excellent thy name, oh Lord,'' Charles Dodsley Walker clapped his hands and brought the proceedings to a halt.

title: Our Towns; A Young Life, Now in Limbo In Burn Ward
description: FOR a month, Alvaro Llanos has been wrapped in gauze and lying silent in the intensive care burn unit at St. Barnabas Medical Center. He is still heavily sedated, his smoke-damaged lungs still aided by a respirator. But last week, his family felt a rush of hope as doctors for the first time exposed part of his face.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Treasury offerings in Business Day yesterday misstated the timing of an auction of a new two-year note. It is today; it was not yesterday.

title: Police Call Suspect in Dormitory Assaults a Shrewd, Cool Predator
description: With the Internet as his guide and a knife in his pocket, a drifter suspected in a series of sexual assaults made his way to elite prep schools and leafy suburban campuses, sheltered places rarely visited by violent crime, the authorities said. Sneaking into dormitory rooms, they said, he placed the blade at the throats of his young victims, all boys from 12 to 16 years old, before abusing them.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS SHARPLY. Natural gas prices fell 4.5 percent after mild weather was forecast for most of the country next week. Natural gas for March delivery fell 11.8 cents, to $2.515 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: Dreamlike States in a Cocoon
description: Cherylyn Lavagnino took an already atmospheric theater and turned it into a vaulting, mysterious cocoon for dance on Friday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. Scott Killian's faintly religious-sounding music and Lap Chi Chu's muted light and shadow provided the setting for ''Chapel Songs,'' a suite of four dances by Ms. Lavagnino. But the dances themselves were disappointing.

title: CALENDAR
description: A Good Reason to Tip

title: WISCONSIN SAVINGS INSTITUTION BUYS A RIVAL
description: Mutual Savings Bank, a closely held Milwaukee-based savings institution, agreed yesterday to buy a public rival, the First Northern Capital Corporation, for $133 million, forming the state's biggest savings and loan. Mutual Savings will pay First Northern shareholders $15 a share in cash and stock in a new holding company for each of their current shares. The purchase of First Northern, based in Green Bay, Wis., will add $840 million in assets and 19 branch offices to the $1.8 billion in assets and 51 offices Mutual Savings now has.

title: Officer Convicted in Torture Case Gives First Account of His Actions in Police Station
description: The former police officer convicted of helping brutalize Abner Louima in the bathroom of a Brooklyn station house and then accused of covering up his role in the attack took the witness stand for the first time yesterday, declaring his innocence and saying that he was ''devastated'' by his arrest.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Pace Finds a New President Nearby

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSIN, SUSAN F.
description: KOSSIN-Susan F. On February 18, 2000. A most courageous woman who will be remembered for her compassion and dignity. A memorial service will be held on Saturday March 4th at 1PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

title: BASEBALL: Strawberry Tests Positive for Cocaine Again; Slugger Is Facing Third Suspension And Legal Trouble
description: Darryl Strawberry has placed his baseball career in jeopardy once more, having again tested positive for cocaine.

title: MANAGEMENT: Joy for Second-String M.B.A.'s; Elites and Internet Change Face of Campus Recruiting
description: For years, America's big-name investment banks and consulting firms considered it a waste of time to send recruiters to second-tier business schools. Harvard, Stanford, the Wharton School at Penn and a handful of others supplied the talent they needed.

title: A Heavy Student Backpack? How Uncool
description: To the Editor:

title: Lakers Bring Reality To Nets' Fantasy League
description: The Nets talked that professional basketball talk before tonight's game against the Los Angeles Lakers. They spoke of being able to beat any team on any given night, of being on top of their game after consecutive victories over playoff-bound Miami and Minnesota, of protecting their home court.

title: Surprise! Making a Meal of Porridge, Chinese Style
description: FOR more than a few years I have been a confirmed congee lover. This is something of a surprise to me, because I loathe oatmeal and other hot cereals, the stuff that supposedly puts such a warm feeling in American tummies on winter mornings. Yet, congee, also known as jook, is nothing more than Chinese hot cereal, a milky rice porridge that is a typical Chinese breakfast dish and is also eaten at other times of the day.

title: Charges at Debate Have Core of Truth Tinted by Spin
description: Did not! Did so!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALATOLA, LOUIS
description: GALATOLA-Louis. On February 21, 2000. Husband and dear friend of Mary Neary. Best friend and father of Mary Lou and Hank, Joanie and Dennis, Jackie and Joe and Johnny Boy. Grampy of Henry Louis, Mary Kathe, Joseph and Andrew. Beloved brother of Lena and Michael. Uncle Lou to 100 plus nieces and nephews. Visiting at Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Friday 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers please support Lou's favorite charity, Frances Pope Memorial, attention Mary O'Dowd, 401 East 81 St., Suite 20A, NY. NY 10028.

title: NATO Says Milosevic Incites Violence Covertly in Kosovo
description: American and NATO officials today accused the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, of fomenting violence in Kosovo and infiltrating his plainclothes police into the province in a deliberate attempt to thwart NATO's peacekeeping efforts.

title: Taiwan's Election, China's Future
description: The light from thousands of red and yellow paper lanterns caught the eyes of porcelain dragons at the Lungshan Temple as people crowded a few days ago to burn ''golden money,'' at 30 cents a bundle, in a tall ornamental furnace. Some asked for blessings in the new year from Kuanyin, the goddess of mercy; others bowed to the red-faced statue of a long-ago Chinese general, known as the god Kuan Kung.

title: MEXICAN MERGER DEAL
description: A leading Mexican car-battery and steel producer, Grupo Imsa, has agreed with creditors of Mexico's largest steel maker, Altos Hornos de Mexico S.A., to restructure $1.8 billion in Altos Hornos debt, paving the way for the two companies to merge. The deal still needs approval of the principal shareholders of Altos Hornos. If the companies merge, Imsa will control the combined company and assume some Altos Hornos debt. Sam Dillon (NYT)

title: Gore Cultivates Image as a Fighter
description: Anyone tuning in to the Democratic debate Monday night saw two extremely aggressive candidates going full tilt at each other. Bill Bradley, who trails Vice President Al Gore in all the polls, had obvious reasons to try to make his mark.

title: Sicily's Bold Cloth Caps Become Symbols of Renewal
description: PALERMO  For half a century, the coppola, the quintessential cloth cap of Sicily, epitomized the Mafia. Indeed, to say that someone was a coppola storta (a crooked cloth cap) was to indicate his obeisance to one of the mafioso families.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Monday about an interview with former Senator Bill Bradley on the ABC News program ''This Week'' said Mr. Bradley had endorsed the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate campaign finance irregularities by the Clinton-Gore campaign in 1996. While the article cited Mr. Bradley's position correctly, the headline overstated it, saying, ''Bradley Calls for Inquiry Into '96 Fund-Raising.''

title: When Every Child Is 'Gifted'
description: Like thousands of students across the country, my daughter has just finished her school applications. She has gathered her test scores, grades and teacher recommendations, completed an exhibit of her creative ability and answered three essay questions.

title: What to Note In the Grammys
description: Watching the Grammys can often be an exercise in tolerance: too many commercials and not enough action. Because listening to music is less of a consensus activity than watching a movie, many viewers of tonight's CBS broadcast will spend most of the evening waiting for a performance or presentation by the one or two acts they like. Or they may simply wait for the inevitable celebrity gaffes and accidents to discuss with friends the next day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINET, DENNIS
description: BINET-Dennis. Age 76, on Feb. 19, 2000. Survived by his partner, Toni Sacks, and her family, his sons, Larry & Tommy, & their families; four grandchildren; two greatgrandchildren; nieces and nephews & many friends. Hungarian immigrant, served in US Army in WWII, co-founder of 47 year old Universal Elevator Company, Inc. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to a cancer-related organization or other charity or hospital of your choice. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Boyfriend Is Charged In Teen-Ager's Strangling
description: A 19-year-old man was arrested last night and charged with strangling his girlfriend with a cord in Harlem on Monday, the police said.

title: Former C.I.A. Director Left Secrets Open to Theft, Agency Investigator Says
description: Investigators scouring home computers used by John M. Deutch, the former director of central intelligence, found 42 secret documents and fragments of 32 others and could not rule out the possibility that some of the information may have been stolen by hackers, according to a report by the agency's inspector general released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPFERMAN, FRANKLYN
description: KUPFERMAN - Franklyn, DDS. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights,NY, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Franklyn Kupferman. We extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas Martin Kay, President

title: Jewelry:The Art of Expressing the Personal
description: ATHENS  Some say it's a southern thing, but Greek women are rarely caught without jewelry. In contrast to the gems flaunted on one-night-diamond-stands like the Oscars, however, cool design here goes beyond conventional flash.

title: Social Security Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain Campaign Admits Calls to Catholics
description: Aides to Senator John McCain acknowledged tonight that the campaign placed thousands of phone calls to Roman Catholics in Michigan in which voters were told about Gov. George W. Bush's appearance at Bob Jones University earlier this month and which described Mr. Jones as someone with a history of anti-Catholic statements.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POSNIAK, EVELYN
description: POSNIAK-Evelyn. Two years have passed and not a day goes by that the girls and I don't think about you. I am sure that you and dad are still going out for predawn coffee. Love always, Fred, Karen, Marissa and Amand

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MARVIN D.
description: ROSEN-Marvin D., DDS. Suddenly on January 31, 2000. Of San Bernardino, Calif. Age 75. Only son of the late Drs. James Ralph and Martha Gluck Rosen. Veteran World War II and Korea. Prestigious oral surgeon, accomplished musician, Marvin will be greatly missed by his aunts, numerous cousins and friends. Services were held Mt. Hebron cemetery, Flushing. For information Malverne Funeral Home (516) 593-7230

title: Texas Board Denies Clemency for Woman, 62, on Death Row
description: The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles today denied the death row clemency appeal of a 62-year-old woman convicted of killing her fifth husband and burying him beneath a wishing well, a ruling that could make her only the fourth woman executed since the United States Supreme Court allowed capital punishment to resume in the mid-1970's.

title: Another Accusation in Coke Bias Lawsuit
description: A motion filed in federal court today by plaintiffs in the discrimination suit against the Coca-Cola Company contends ''possible retaliation'' was taken against an employee who organized a meeting of about 150 black workers. But Coke denies the claim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCH, JACQUELINE B.
description: KOCH-Jacqueline B. Born Nov. 21, 1921 in Zurich, Switzerland. Died in NY February 20. Mother of Stephen, Jeremy and Chapin. Sister and sister-in-law of Anne-Marie and Dick Bullen. Also survived by 7 grandchildren: Eliza, Serena, Nicholas, Charles, Sarah, Peter and Lily. Her love, independent spirit and loyal friendship will be missed by her many friends and devoted family. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 E. 88 St. on March 4 at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of NY Hospice Care.

title: GILLETTE TO SELL SOME OF ITS BRAUN DIVISION
description: The Gillette Company, the maker of razor blades and Duracell batteries, said yesterday that it might sell its slumping Braun household appliance, hair care and health diagnostic operations. Boston-based Gillette has hired the investment bank J. P. Morgan & Company to help explore options for the businesses, which make toasters and coffeemakers. Braun sales fell 9 percent in 1999. In the last three months of the year, Braun's profits plunged 55 percent on a 4 percent sales decline. Gillette is not considering a sale of its Braun electric shaver and dental care product lines, which include Oral-B toothbrushes.

title: Serbs on Edge After a Rally by Albanians in a Kosovo City
description: Serbs living on the northern side of this city were edgy today after a show of force by tens of thousands of Albanian protesters on Monday.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Strong Image Is Helped by Aggressive Promotional Campaigns : Italian Labels Carry Cachet in Asia
description: HONG KONG  For Asia's ardent buyers, nothing says style like "made in Italy." In fact, the marketing power of Italian fashion is so strong that many local manufacturers have chosen to give their collections Italian names in the hope of capitalizing on Italy's reputation for design and quality.

title: No Wine, Please: I'm Drinking
description: SO many wine snobs, so little patience. That's why one of my favorite drinking buddies is Al Hirschfeld, the 96-year-old artist, who can't be bothered with sermons on grassy undertones. He drinks Jack Daniel's. And when we go out together, he prefers to keep drinking it past cocktails and through the meal, which, by the way, he prefers to be steak.

title: Looking to Sonoma for Cabernets, Too
description: WHEN Sonoma County winemakers have nothing better to do, they like to needle the folks over the mountain in Napa County, particularly if there's a gullible audience. To hear the Sonoma crowd tell it, Napa people are social-climbing pseudo-sophisticates who wear designer clothes and get their cars washed. Sonomans, they will insist, are simple country folk, warm-hearted, generous and close to the soil. Napa people make elegant cabernet sauvignon, while Sonomans prefer earthier, more accessible wines like pinot noir and zinfandel.

title: Missing: A Death Penalty Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: MRV IN DEAL TO PURCHASE FIBER OPTIC COMMUNICATIONS
description: MRV Communications Inc., a maker of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that it would buy Fiber Optic Communications Inc. of Taiwan for $263 million in stock and cash. MRV, which makes routers, switches and other products that enhance the performance of telecommunications networks, also said it would take a $13.8 million charge to exit the local area network switching business. Fiber Optic Communications makes passive fiber optic components, including couplers and isolators. With the acquisition, MRV said it would become one of the world's largest makers of advanced optical components and modules. Shares of MRV, based in Chatsworth, Calif., rose $11.8125 each, to $102.3125.

title: Business Travel; Rosenbluth, a trend spotter among travel agents, believes it has found a new one. Think Internet.
description: AMONG travel agents, Rosenbluth International gets credit, though sometimes very grudgingly, for having anticipated several of the economic trends that have shaken that industry recently. In the early 1990's -- years before the airlines enraged travel agents and even drove some out of business by slashing commissions on tickets sold -- Rosenbluth began sharply reducing its dependence on commissions and instead started charging corporate clients fees for providing travel-management services.

title: Metro Business; S.I. Bus Company Is Expanding Its Fleet
description: Atlantic Express Transportation Group Inc., the Staten Island-based school bus company, has bought Robert L. McCarthy & Son Inc. to increase its fleet in central Massachusetts.

title: Schroeder Boulton, 91, Wall St. Executive
description: Schroeder Boulton, a 67-year veteran of Wall Street, died on Feb. 13 at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 91 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDWYN, FRANCES
description: GOLDWYN-Frances. On February 22, 2000, Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Joyce and Barry Spencer, Ellen Goldwyn, Zachary and Henriette Hagopian-Goldwyn. Cherished grandmother to Marc and Eric Goldwyn. Dear sister of Mildred Epstein and the late Leon Bloom. Fond aunt and great aunt. Services Wednesday, 9am at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hadassah or Cabrini Hospice.

title: Riders' Group Doubtful of Natural Gas Buses
description: The group that represents bus and subway riders on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the city should not be required to convert its bus fleet to compressed natural gas, a change long sought by environmentalists.

title: Juilliard Premieres: Eloquent Vocabularies, Imaginatively Expressed
description: What is a sober-hearted reviewer to do? Programs as good as the one presented by the Juilliard School's dance division on Sunday afternoon at the Juilliard Theater come along so seldom that wild hyperbole is all that comes to mind.

title: LIFELINE FOR ASHANTI
description: The third-largest gold producer in Africa, the Ashanti Goldfields Company of Ghana, secured a credit line of $100 million and renewed $270 million in revolving credit, enabling it to keep operating despite bungled hedging operations last year that threatened the company. Ashanti secured the loan after agreeing last week to changes in its board. Ashanti also agreed to accelerate the developing and auctioning of 50 percent of its Geita mining project in Tanzania. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, J. ROBERT
description: HARRIS-J. Robert ''Bob''. Passed away on February 13, 2000, in La Jolla, California. Musician and composer. Beloved husband of Darlene Harris. Dear father of John, Susan, Cynthia, Barbara and Andrea; step-father of Robert, Hanna and Laura. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather. Cherished brother of James Harris. Services Sunday, February 27, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave, New York City. Interment Mt. Carmel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to ''Seeing Eye, Inc.'', Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: SBC Agrees To Acquire Sterling for $3.9 Billion
description: In the biggest move by a major local phone company into the torrid electronic commerce business, SBC Communications said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Sterling Commerce for almost $3.9 billion in cash.

title: Buffett Reluctantly Discloses Berkshire Stake in Microsoft
description: Warren E. Buffett has reported holding stakes in the Microsoft Corporation and several other companies after the Securities and Exchange Commission refused to let Mr. Buffett, a renowned billionaire investor, delay disclosure of these holdings.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Spicy, Savory Pies With an Island French Twist

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTOCCIA, CARMELA R.
description: MARTOCCIA-Carmela R. (nee Neglia) Age 89. Devoted wife of the late Arthur R. Martoccia, on February 20, 2000. Dear mother of Linda Centurrino and Elaine Pantaleo. Cherished mother-in-law of Robert Centurrino and Robert Pantaleo. Loving grandmother of Brian, Laura, Janine and Kevin. Caring sister of Josephine Neglia. Former department store buyer, dedicated volunteer at Grace Church, Grace Church School and New York Eye and Ear Hospital. She will forever be missed by family and friends. Vistitors may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Thursday 2-4pm & 7-9pm. Services at Grace Church, Broadway at 10th St., Friday 11am. Entombment Woodlawn Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Melissa Neier Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 333, Montville, N.J. 07045.

title: NATIONAL ORIGINS: Central Florida; Squeezing Gold From the Groves
description: ''YOU want to look at oranges?'' Jim Walker asked. ''Well, let's go look at oranges.'' Mr. Walker, lean and fit at 70, jumped into his red minivan. I joined him, and minutes later we were deep into Walker Groves, a 70-acre spread of citrus trees midway between Tampa and Orlando that his family has cultivated for more than a century.

title: Marsalis Shows China That Jazz Isn't Just a Word
description: In their first 48 hours of music making here, Wynton Marsalis and his Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra put on two smooth performances before well-dressed audiences, two educational events for Chinese jazz colleagues and schoolchildren, and two smoking jam sessions with local musicians for a small, ravenous circle of fans.

title: A Rookie Coach For Defensive Backs
description: The Jets are bringing in a rookie coach, Todd Bowles of Grambling, to direct the defensive backs, who had been tutored by the respected and experienced Bill Belichick.

title: Dow Jones and Excite@Home To Create Business Web Site
description: In a move combining the news resources of Dow Jones & Company with the technical expertise and audience reach of Excite@Home, the two corporations plan to create a new Internet site devoted to business-to-business communications and transactions for small and medium-sized companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, STANLEY
description: STERN-Stanley, 80, died February 20, 2000, after a long & courageous battle with Parkinsons Desease, loving husband of the late Corrine, he is survived by his two sons, Arthur and Robert, two daughtersin-law, Jean and Dawn, and his beloved granddaughter, Madison. In lieu of flowers, the family request that those desiring contribute to the Parkinsons Desease Foundation, Neurological Institute, 710 West 168th Street, New York, New York 10032.

title: MORE UNEMPLOYED KOREANS
description: South Korea's unadjusted unemployment rate rose to 5.3 percent in January from 4.8 percent in December, but the increase reflected a seasonal slowdown in outdoor jobs and an influx of graduating high school and university students looking for work. With seasonal adjustments, the National Statistical Office said, the unemployment rate fell to 4.6 percent, from 4.7 percent in December. South Korea's jobless rate peaked at 8.6 percent in February 1999. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Ofra Haza, 41, Israeli Pop Singer Who Crossed Cultural Bounds
description: Ofra Haza, one of Israel's leading pop singers and songwriters, died yesterday at a hospital in Tel Aviv, where she was admitted 13 days ago. She was 41.

title: Police Reformer Draws on His Experience
description: THE big guy, Jimmy Fyfe, all hulking 6 feet 7 inches Norwegian-Scottish-Irish of him, with the coarse street talk of a Brooklyn cop, abruptly gets tearful. In June 1998, he recounts, his son-in-law, a black graduate student at the University of Illinois who was a political refugee from the Ivory Coast, was stomped to death by a white bouncer outside a tavern in Champaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, TIFFANI
description: FELDMAN-Tiffani. You lit up our house throughout those growing up years. Your beautiful heart will remain with us forever. We mourn with Lani, Steve, Kerrin, your grandparents and Michael. Randee, Michael, Ilana and Ross

title: A Managing Agent Puts Itself Online
description: IN a city that's all about connections, some 250,000 people were just connected to Harrison Ford and Barbra Streisand. Yesterday, Insignia Financial Group started Edi ficeRex (www.edificerex.com), a Web site that will give residents of more than 65,000 condominiums and co-ops in the city a wide range of Internet services, from paying their maintenance to making dinner reservations at Lespinasse.

title: Cendant Repaid By Ex-Chairman
description: The Cendant Corporation's former chairman, Walter Forbes, has repaid about $2.3 million in travel- and entertainment-related expenses that the company said Mr. Forbes charged improperly.

title: Trump, Out of the Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Cameras Help Teenagers Look Beyond Bitter Conflicts
description: Looking squarely into the camera, Amer Kamal, a Palestinian teenager from East Jerusalem, delivers a message to his Israeli friend, Yaron Avni, who will soon be drafted into the Israeli Army.

title: Nasdaq in Record Gain to New High, but Blue Chips Fall
description: The technology-laden Nasdaq stock index soared 168.21 points yesterday -- its biggest point gain ever -- more than offsetting the losses it incurred in the two preceding sessions and surpassing the high it had set just last week.

title: Feud Over How Port Authority Spends Money Creates an Impasse
description: When the 12-member board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey holds its monthly meeting today, the agenda will be limited to routine capital expenditures instead of the grand bridges, tunnels, airports and development projects the agency has pursued in its 79 years.

title: Gore and Bradley Do Well; Gore Does Better
description: Both Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are viewed favorably by registered Democrats who are likely to vote in New York's presidential primary election next month, but Mr. Gore to a greater degree than Mr. Bradley, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Chinese Immigrants Lose Savings and Hopes in a Citizenship Swindle
description: It was a familiar swindle, but it worked, as it often does, like a charm: A fly-by-night operation promises to smooth the way to citizenship -- for a fee. Then the schemers pull up stakes, and the once-hopeful immigrant is left poorer and afraid of being deported.

title: Retailers Are Rushing To Feather Gen Nest
description: MELANIE LOUCKS had furniture issues. Her roommate was moving out of their two bedroom, two bath loft downtown and taking all her Ikea fornituren with her. That left Ms. Loucks, a 23-year-old theater student at Columbia College here, with rooms to fill. On the El, she had seen an advertisement for Crate & Barrel's new younger, hipper sister store: CB2. So she went. This is what she bought:

title: The Republican Identity War
description: Understandable jubilation -- and abundant positive thinking -- led Senator John McCain to proclaim the emergence of a ''McCain majority'' after his victories on Tuesday. The odds against Mr. McCain's insurgency campaign remain formidable. As Gov. George W. Bush never tires of saying, the Arizona senator failed to attract the support of most Republican primary voters in Michigan and may have trouble doing so elsewhere. But the exit polls and comments from voters also suggest that Mr. McCain has spawned a genuinely new phenomenon that could defy the logic of the professionals and keep right on building. Mr. Bush has to figure out how to overcome it or risk being washed away.

title: Firewood for Those With Money to Burn
description: THE only wood Nancy Friedman will burn in her fireplace is apple or cherry. Absolutely nothing else will do. ''The aroma is wondrous, and the sound is like a bowl of Rice Krispies,'' she said. ''The snap, crackle and pop is amazing to listen to.''

title: Let Doctors Judge Care By H.M.O.'s, Senator Says
description: New Jersey's top lawmaker said yesterday that he supported a proposal to let doctors negotiate which procedures would be covered by health maintenance organizations, and their reimbursement rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFRAN, NATHAN P.
description: SHAFRAN-Nathan P. Beloved husband of Fannye (nee Ratner), devoted father of Joseph (Marla), Paula Krulak of Manhattan, NY and Joan Shafran (Rob Haimes) of Cambridge, MA, dear brother of Faye Chase and Ann Schwartz (deceased), loving grandfather of Roger Krulak (Francine), Robert and Lora Krulak, Ilana, Eric and David Shafran, great grandfather of Julian. Services were held at Park Synagogue, 3300 Mayfield Road, Cleveland Hts., Tuesday, February 22. Interment Bet Olam Cemetery. The family will receive friends at the Shafran residence, 5150 Three Village #

title: Open Positions of Short Sales Drop Again on Big Board
description: Open positions of short sales slipped for the third consecutive month on the New York Stock Exchange, according to the most recent monthly data.

title: Is U.S. a Global Snoop? No, Europe Is Told
description: Fears that the United States, Britain and other English-speaking countries are using a cold-war eavesdropping network to gain a commercial edge roused passions across Europe today, even after Washington and London roundly denied the notion.

title: Web Access, Minus the Monthly Bill
description: INFORMATION, as the saying goes, wants to be free. In this spirit, a growing number of Internet service providers have begun offering completely free Internet access: no monthly charges and no start-up fees.

title: Pope Makes Virtual Visit To Iraqi Site He Must Skip
description: Unwilling to surrender his dream of beginning a Holy Land pilgrimage in Iraq, Pope John Paul II made a ''virtual pilgrimage'' today to Ur, the ancient city that is traditionally held to be the birthplace of Abraham.

title: Santana Dominates Grammy Awards
description: Some may have snickered when Carlos Santana, the psychedelic guitarist of the 70's, informed the public that an angel named Metatron had prophesied his return to pop dominance. After last night's 42nd Annual Grammy Awards at the Staples Center here, there are going to be a lot of young musicians praying to Metatron.

title: Recycling 'Millionaire' (Minus the Money)
description: FASTER than you can say Regis Philbin, your eardrums are rattling with the cheesy, synthesized theme music that opens every broadcast of the trivia quiz show phenomenon ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.'' Seconds later the familiar voice of Mr. Philbin, the television program's host, is urging contestants to answer multiple-choice brain teasers like:

title: Only Republicans Can Help McCain Win in California
description: For Senator John McCain, the California primary is a glittering dream and a surreal nightmare. From the beginning, Mr. McCain's improbable quest was to win the primary election here in his neighboring state, inherit the western cowboy mantle of his political hero Ronald Reagan and become the Republican Party's all-but-inevitable nominee.

title: U.S. and Europe Reach Tentative Pact on Personal Data
description: February 23, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORRIS, ANNE
description: NORRIS-Anne. On February 22, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Sidney C., loving mother of Emily and the late Lee Rome and the late Jane and Julian Perlman, adoring grandmother of Tom, Josie and Andrew, cherished aunt and great-aunt of many. Service Friday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Poverty and Rising Tides
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUSON, HENRY D.
description: LAUSON-Henry D., M.D., Ph.D Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with sorrow the passing of our Professor Emeritus, who was the founding chairman of our department of physiology and biophysics in 1955 and served with great distinction in that position until 1978. We extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Some Foundations Choose to Curb Donations and Pay More Taxes
description: Imagine actually choosing to pay taxes at a higher rate.

title: Amnesty for Illegal Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: WEYERHAEUSER TO BUY BACK UP TO 12 MILLION OF ITS SHARES
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, a forest products concern, said yesterday that it would buy back up to 12 million shares. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 5 percent of the company's stock outstanding. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing the shares outstanding. Weyerhaeuser, based in Federal Way, Wash., had 1999 sales of $12.3 billion. Its stock was down $1.625 a share at $50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLINGER, LEONARD
description: HALLINGER-Leonard Dr. We mourn the death by accident of Dr. Leonard Hallinger in Sarasota, Fla., a devoted friend, a compassionate physician, a loving husband, father and grandfather. Our condolences to his wife, Carol, and to Nina, Philip, Todd, and the grandchildren. Abraham and Vera Buchberg Moses and Hannah Malkin

title: Stretching It a Bit
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets' Robson Shrugs And Helps the Hitters
description: When Mets General Manager Steve Phillips was looking for a hitting coach last fall, Manager Bobby Valentine brought up a name he didn't think would be considered.

title: One of an Honored Baker's Dozen
description: When Lance and Rima Acord decided to remodel and expand their 1940's house in the Hollywood Hills, they chose to do it in a style that would capture the best architecture of that era. Finn Kappe, of Kappe Studio, has remodeled the house and added a pool house, above and top, which synthesizes influences from early and midcentury modernists like R. M. Schindler, Richard Neutra and Edward Killingsworth.

title: Seeking The Next Wave, Not a Star
description: CHRISTOPHE PILLET has a dream that stretches like a beach. And there's furniture in it. And the relaxation and ease of the sea and the sky reside in the forms of the furniture, like the sounds within shells. Mr. Pillet, a 40-year-old French designer, studied at the National School of Decorative Arts in Nice, so he could surf after classes.

title: Metro Matters; Bush Learns A Slip-Up Can Be Costly
description: THE political take on New York, as it gears up for its March 7 primaries, is that it is one tough place. Especially for outsiders, sometimes even for insiders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTENFELD, DOROTHY K.
description: BATTENFELD-Dorothy K. (nee Conelley), 88, of Southbury, CT wife of the late E. Gerard, died February 21 in Naples, Florida. Dear mother of Frederick and Eugene, grandmother, great-grandmother, cherished aunt. Reposing Friday from 6-8 PM, at Sacred Heart Church, Southbury, CT. Mass of the Resurrection Sat. at 11:00AM at Sacred Heart Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave, Hawthorne, NY 10532.

title: Plates Designed To Get in Your Face
description: In cheerful designs for ceramic chargers, Karen Barone aims to create art that is, she says ''not elitist.'' Her Feed Me (foreground) and Between the Buns (top) patterns, 13 1/2 inches and $65 each, may be ordered from the Barone Studio Gallery, 200 South Venice Boulevard, Venice, by appointment; (310) 822-6060. Ms. Barone was chosen by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art for a fund-raising project, for which she has designed a pattern she calls Spiraling Out of Control.

title: Stanley Matthews, 85, Knight and Soccer Star
description: Sir Stanley Matthews, a legendary figure in British soccer who played professionally until he was 50 years old and was the first pro soccer player to be knighted, died yesterday at a hospital in Newcastle-Under-Lyme, England. He was 85.

title: When the Gods Conspire, Even Experts Are Helpless
description: Some deals seem designed by the gods of the game to lure experts into bidding to hopeless contracts. An example is the diagramed deal, played a year ago, which helped decide the world's leading team tournament. It is the Forbo-Krommenie, which will be played tomorrow through Sunday in Scheveningen, the Netherlands, with top teams from France, Italy and China taking part together with many squads from the host country and other parts of Europe.

title: GATEWAY ANNOUNCES ALLIANCES WITH SUN AND OFFICEMAX
description: Gateway Inc., the No. 2 direct seller of personal computers, announced alliances yesterday with Sun Microsystems Inc. and OfficeMax Inc. to improve PC sales, and said it expected revenue to more than triple to $30 billion by 2004. Sun will sell Gateway PC's to corporations, giving Gateway a chance to improve its sales in the business market. Gateway, which has more than 240 of its own Gateway Country outlets, will open 1,000 sales departments in OfficeMax stores. Gateway shares rose $10.3125 each, to $67.625.

title: Puffy Combs Is Charged With Bribing A Witness
description: Hours before he appeared at the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles last night, the rap impresario Sean Combs was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday on charges of bribing a witness, stemming from a Dec. 27 Times Square nightclub shooting.

title: Bush's Secret Weapon: Congress
description: When it comes to politics, it's smart to play your cards straight. George W. Bush's problem is that he hasn't done that, and voters know it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERSTEIN, LES
description: ALPERSTEIN-Les. Our heartfelt condolences to Phyllis, Simon, and Nicky on the loss of your beloved husband and father. He was a trusted colleague and friend. We will greatly miss his professionalism and friendship. We will always remember his kindness and warm smile. Lawrence Ruben Company

title: A Privacy Pact Is Short on Detail
description: After more than two years of negotiations, the United States and the European Union said yesterday that they had reached tentative agreement on privacy laws governing the gathering of personal data about European consumers by American companies.

title: Tracking the Wealth Effect; Imbalance of Supply To Demand Causes Greenspan to Fret
description: Alan Greenspan defended the Federal Reserve's recent interest rate increases today as necessary to keep the current prosperity on track, and denied that he was putting the entire economy at risk just to rein in the bull market.

title: Alphabetical Divertimentos
description: John Adams seems especially well placed at a time when concert programming dotes on themes. Not that he fits naturally into so many concepts, but when programmers run out of real ideas, they tend to fall back on gimmicks involving the alphabet, as the Brooklyn Philharmonic did last season (''AB&C,'' A being Adams) and the Eos Orchestra did last Thursday evening (''American Music, A to Z,'' A being, in part, Adams), to open its fifth season at the Society for Ethical Culture.

title: Rexall Sundown Addition
description: Rexall Sundown Inc., a maker of vitamins and nutritional supplements, agreed today to buy the closely held Worldwide Sport Nutritional Supplements Inc. for $71.5 million in cash. Worldwide makes nutrition bars and shakes under the brand names PureProtein and Burn-It. Rexall, based in Boca Raton, Fla., is adding sports-nutrition companies to broaden its product line. In December, it agreed to buy MET-Rx Nutrition Inc. of Irvine, Calif., for $108 million.

title: Netscape and Rodale Hire Key Executives
description: Two publishing executives are taking new posts.

title: A New Iran, But Not Overnight
description: Yes, the reformers in Iran won big in the parliamentary elections last week -- garnering about 70 percent of the seats. And yes, this election may accelerate economic reform, loosen political and civil repression and soften Iran's hostility toward the West.

title: On the Trail of the Underground Railroad
description: MUCH of the history of American slavery has long been left unexplored out of shame and ignorance, but also because the search for truth has been too quickly abandoned.

title: Gifted Programs Have Downside, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: No Charges Against 2 Doctors In Death of Woman After Surgery
description: The Manhattan district attorney will not file criminal charges in connection with the death of a woman after a botched surgery at Beth Israel Medical Center in 1997, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Pressure Tactics Could Backfire, Candidate Warns : A Taipei Rebuff for Beijing
description: TAIPEI  Asserting that cross-strait relations have hit "a historically low point," a leading presidential candidate on Taiwan warned Wednesday that China might have overplayed its pressure tactics against the island.

title: A Rambling Journey To Very Familiar Places
description: There was a nice misprint in the German text of a Mendelssohn duet as it appeared in the booklet for the New York Festival of Song's concert at the Kaye Playhouse. Instead of ''And after the joy came the grief,'' this version had ''And after the joy came the song.''

title: Providence Is Tough Place to Visit
description: When in Providence this season, visitors could take advantage of the local arts scene, the fine Portuguese and Italian fare on Federal Hill and the two Division I men's hockey teams.

title: Dire Warnings Over China in a Taiwan Race
description: The eminent industrialist made his prediction with confidence: If the opposition party's candidate wins the presidency next month, the Taiwan stock market will crash, no question about it, because investors fearing hostilities with China will yank out their money.

title: Samuelson Retains Olympic Dream
description: The real intrigue about Saturday's Olympic marathon trials for women is whether the 1984 gold medalist, Joan Benoit Samuelson, can make a serious run at qualifying for the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia, by which time she will be 43 years old. To qualify, Samuelson must win the trials or run under 2 hours 33 minutes, the Olympic qualifying standard.

title: INVESTOR CALLS FOR SALE OF PIONEER GROUP FUND COMPANY
description: Lens Investment Management L.L.C., an investment firm, called yesterday for the sale of the Pioneer Group Inc., saying the fund company is undervalued and poorly managed. Lens and its affiliates own about 4.1 percent of Pioneer's outstanding common stock. Lens filed a preliminary proxy statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with Pioneer's annual meeting, scheduled for May 16. The group nominated Richard Bennett, John Higgins, Robert Holmes and Robert Monks for election to the company's eight-member board. Pioneer shares, down 2 percent in the last 12 months, were unchanged at $17.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ARTHUR L.
description: GOLDBERG-Arthur L., Esq. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Arthur L. Goldberg, Esq., husband of Frances Goldberg, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: A STAKE IN EGG
description: Britain's top insurer, Prudential P.L.C., said it would sell up to one quarter of Egg, its online banking unit, in which it invested $240 million last year. The sale could raise up to $1.6 billion. Egg, created in 1998, has about a million customers. It is not expecting a profit until at least next year. Prudential's plans were disclosed as the insurer said its second-half net income after the Egg investment fell to $432 million from $812 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKETT, LOIS KINSELLA
description: HACKETT-Lois Kinsella. Beloved wife and mother. Passed away Saturday, February 19. A memorial service on Saturday, February 26 will be held at Riverside Church, Christ Chapel, 12 noon.

title: Wrestling Captain Charged in Hazing
description: A tri-captain of the Trumbull High School wrestling team in Connecticut was charged yesterday with assault and unlawful restraint in connection with the hazing of a first-year teammate on Feb. 1.

title: Postponement of the America's Cup Race Is Questioned
description: In a decision that disappointed the Italian challengers and prompted an American television commentator to question the motives of the event organizers, the principal race officer of the Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron canceled today's third scheduled race of the five-of-nine finals for the America's Cup between the Prada Challenge and Team New Zealand.

title: Irish Hopes, and Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: One Killed and One Hurt In Shooting in Brooklyn
description: One man was fatally shot and another was critically injured last night in the hallway of an apartment building in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Path for Collins Is Heading in the Right Direction
description: Giants quarterback Kerry Collins sat in a Fairleigh Dickinson University classroom this month as a developmental psychology professor asked her new students to say a little something about themselves.

title: Battling Cookie Monsters
description: IN my neighborhood in the physical world, it is customary to welcome new neighbors with a housewarming gift, perhaps a plate of cookies. It never occurred to me, however, to implant surveillance equipment in the cookies so I can monitor my neighbors' habits and sell that information to advertisers.

title: SMURFIT-STONE TO BUY ST. LAURENT IN LATEST PAPER DEAL
description: Extending a string of mergers in the pulp and paper business, North America's largest manufacturer of paperboard packaging, Smurfit-Stone Container Corporation of Chicago, will purchase St. Laurent Paperboard Inc. of Montreal for about $1 billion in cash and stock. The deal will increase Smurfit-Stone's capacity by 20 percent. St. Laurent's shareholders will get $12.50 in cash and one-half Smurfit-Stone share for each of their shares. The cash portion of the deal totals $625 million. St. Laurent operates 20 plants and had 1999 sales of $916 million. Smurfit-Stone, with sales last year of $7.2 billion, has 300 plants around the world. Timothy Pritchard

title: Little by Little, a California Dream Materializes
description: BUILT in the 1920's, the cute-as-a-button bungalow was a portrait of modesty, hidden behind a thicket of ficus and a set of skyscraping palms. But Marianna Boctor and Jose Fontiveros, young architects at the Santa Monica firm of Sintesi, aspired to literature when they remodeled the house's tiny kitchen and living room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTNOW, FLORENCE
description: PORTNOW-Florence. On February 23, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Alfred. Loving mother of Gayle Halperin, Jay Portnow and Richard Portnow. Dear sister of Al Landman. Adoring grandmother of Samara, Ilana & Maia Halperin and John & Sam Portnow. Services Friday 11:30 AM at the ''Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULAM, GABRIEL
description: SULAM-Gabriel. The trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services are saddened to note the passing of Gabriel Sulam, the father of Carol Zicklin, a trustee of JBFCS and founder of our Carol Zicklin LINKS Program. A loving husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather, Mr. Sulam worked hard to provide for his family and, until recently, owned a candy store in the Wall Street area. He belonged to the Sephardic Brotherhood and the Sun Ray Boys, a fraternal organization whose members were all born in Salonika, Greece, as Mr. Salam was in 1909. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Zicklin, Mr. Sulam's son, Donald, his four grandchildren and his five great grandchildren. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President Paul Levine, CSW, Associate Executive Vice President Pinchas Berger, CSW, Director, Jewish Connections Programs

title: Cramped Gaza Multiplies at Unrivaled Rate
description: Seven months into her seventh pregnancy, Hanan Suelem fidgeted, shifting her weight on a hard bench in a bare-bones clinic. Beneath her floral headscarf, primly fastened at the chin with a butterfly pin, her face was mournful, the face of an old woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, EVELYN
description: WEINER-Evelyn. Of Stamford, CT, on February 23, 2000. She is survived by her husband, Benjamin Weiner, and children Neal Weiner of Greenwich, CT, Tara Rutman of Chappaqua, NY, and Andrea Schirmer of Pleasantville, NY. Also by her mother, Sarah Herscowitz of Brooklyn, and brother, Dr. Herbert Herscowitz of Bethesda, MD. Services at 10 AM Friday, February 25 at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford. Interment in Long Ridge Union Cemetery. For donations, please call 203-327-1313.

title: Right-Wing Baggage Puts Drag on Bush Caravan
description: When his campaign plane touched down in Kansas City, Mo., on Tuesday night, all that Gov. George W. Bush really had to do was acknowledge the bad news from Michigan, utter a few platitudes, paste a brave face over defeat and put a smiling face on his expectations for the next Republican contests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELIKER, JOHN
description: HELIKER-John. Painter. Died at age 91 in Bar Harbor, ME on February 22, 2000. A memorial service will be held at a future date. He leaves his companion of 48 years, Robert La Hotan.

title: Alone, but the TV's Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Sites Help Leaplings Bridge Birthday Gap
description: PEOPLE born on Feb. 29 know just what to expect when others hear about their singular birthday. Many people don't believe them. Some exclaim, ''You poor thing!'' Others say, ''Lucky you.''

title: Summit Bank Executive Sentenced for Theft
description: Carol Lynn Alcott, 47, of Marlton, a former teller at Summit Bank there, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to six months in prison, after she admitted stealing $300,000 in cash deposits from the bank between 1994 and 1998.

title: Disarmament Deadlock in Ireland
description: The peace that has prevailed in Northern Ireland for the past two and a half years will not be truly secure until the Irish Republican Army and Protestant paramilitary forces give up their weapons. But bitter differences over disarmament, which may take months to resolve, should not be allowed to upend the rest of the carefully constructed peace effort. Regrettably, through a series of miscalculations by all sides in recent weeks, that is just what has happened.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: When Grandeur and Gluttony Went Arm in Arm to the Table
description: One way European royalty of the 17th and 18th centuries displayed wealth and power was by showing off extravagant monuments made of food. ''The Edible Monument,'' an exhibition opening at the Getty Research Institute on Saturday, includes a re-creation of a late Baroque edible monument (top), showing the sorceress Circe turning Ulysses' men into swine. It was made of sugar six years ago by Ivan Day, a British food historian (editor of ''Eat, Drink and Be Merry: The British at Table, 1600-2000''), and was flown in its own seat from England. The research institute is also showing early related books, from one of which comes the 1693 etching of a sculpture (above), depicting La Felsina, a female warrior, who is the emblem of Bologna, Italy. The show, whose curator is Marcia Reed, will be on view at the institute's exhibitions gallery at the Getty Center in Los Angeles through May 21.

title: More Carbon Tips
description: To the Editor:

title: Priceline Names Its CFO -- Citis Heidi Miller
description: February 23, 2000

title: AOL and Time Warner Jump After Merrill Report
description: February 23, 2000

title: Louima Trial Nears End; Officer Denies He Conspired
description: Under rancorous cross-examination, the former police officer accused of covering up his part in the assault on Abner Louima acknowledged yesterday that he spoke by telephone with colleagues and police union officials, but angrily denied that he conspired with them to get his story straight.

title: Strawberry Ordered Off Field Until Selig Ends Inquiry
description: Darryl Strawberry loped around the outfield here this morning, joking with teammates, fielding fly balls and grounders. For one more hour, he was a baseball player.

title: Medical Journal Apologizes For Violating Own Standards
description: The New England Journal of Medicine, one of the world's top-ranked scientific publications and a leading critic of doctors' financial ties to industry, apologized yesterday to its readers for violating its own financial conflict-of-interest policy 19 times over the last three years in choosing experts to review drug therapies.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNON, JOHN JOSEPH
description: CANNON-John Joseph, of Princeton, NJ, on February 22, 2000. Loving husband of Lynne (nee Petrolle) Cannon; devoted father of Jacqueline Marie, Katherine Lynne & the late Tracey Cannon; dearest son of Marie (nee Bodine) Cannon and the late Edward Cannon. Visitation will be held from 79 PM Thursday, February 24, in front of Mater's Window of the Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart, 1200 Stuart Road, Princeton, NJ 08540. Funeral mass will be held at 10:30 AM Friday, February 25 at St. Paul's R.C. Church, Nassau Street, Princeton. Interment in St. Paul's Cemetery, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to The Scholarship Fund of the Stuart Day Country School at the address above in memory of John Joseph Cannon. For more information, contact the Mulligan Funeral Home in Harrison, NJ.

title: Tickets: In Line or Online?
description: LAST year, if you had set out to buy tickets to a hot event like a World Series game, a Backstreet Boys concert or the local premiere of ''Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace,'' chances are you would have joined in the traditional rituals of ticket buying: the around-the-block line, the stampede or the keypad race to get through on the telephone.

title: Alcatel Will Buy Newbridge Networks for $7.1 Billion
description: Alcatel S.A., the big French communications equipment maker, has agreed to buy the Newbridge Networks Corporation of Canada in a $7.1 billion stock transaction that will give the combined company a stronger line of products to compete in North America against domestic rivals that dominate one of the world's largest markets.

title: U.N. Food Agency Says Famine Threatens 8 Million in Ethiopia
description: At least eight million Ethiopians are likely to suffer hunger or starvation this year, a crisis that could rival the 1984-85 famine that killed at least a million people, United Nations and independent relief officials said today.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: A Narcissus by Another Name

title: N.H.L. Suspends McSorley for Rest of Season
description: Marty McSorley of the Boston Bruins yesterday received the longest suspension in National Hockey League history for an on-ice incident. As punishment for his stick attack against Donald Brashear of the Vancouver Canucks, McSorley was suspended for the final 23 games of the regular season and also for the playoffs if his team qualifies for them. He will forfeit $72,000 in salary.

title: All's Not Fair in E-Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Agents Accuse Secret Service of Bias in Promotions
description: Last year, after 16 years as an agent in the insular fraternity of the Secret Service, Reginald G. Moore had made it to one of the most prestigious posts in the agency as a lead agent on President Clinton's protective detail, entrusted with Mr. Clinton's life. Mr. Moore seemed to be poised to advance to the agency's managerial ranks.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about setbacks at Sotheby's related to a federal antitrust investigation misspelled the name of a law firm that is representing the auction house. It is Weil Gotshal & Manges, not Gotschal. The article also misspelled the surname of a senior partner in the firm. He is Ira Millstein, not Milstein.

title: Investigation Into Police Is Broadened In Los Angeles
description: In a broad and politically charged expansion of a major police corruption scandal, the United States attorney, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the state attorney general announced today that they were opening criminal investigations into reports of widespread police brutality here.

title: Colombian Army Still Aiding Paramilitary Forces, Report Says
description: Units of the Colombian Army continue to work closely with right-wing paramilitary forces that are involved in killings of civilians and threats against government human rights investigators, according to a report made public today.

title: INSIDE
description: Skepticism on H.M.O. Suits

title: Reaganomics Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Ditka Back on Air
description: One month after being fired as the head coach of the New Orleans Saints, Mike Ditka is returning to television as a studio analyst for The N.F.L. Today on CBS.

title: Stuff for Real Offices
description: How many office furniture catalogs display their products with slovenly workers, papers and cigarette butts? Following in the footsteps of Nest magazine, with its lived-in interiors, Knoll has produced a brochure called Currents Realities for a line of office furnishings that shows life as it is really lived. Knoll commissioned Catherine Opie, a fine arts photographer based in Los Angeles, to do the pictures. Ms. Opie said she was surprised when Knoll went for her informal shots, but the company was intent on getting away from the usual posed look. The brochure is available to design professionals from (800) 343-5665.

title: Pulsipher Hospitalized After Collapse
description: The left-hander Bill Pulsipher, who is vying to become the Mets' No. 5 starter this season, was in stable condition tonight at a Port St. Lucie hospital after a respiratory distress incident at his home late this afternoon.

title: Great Leap Forward
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Diallo Jurors Begin Deliberating In Murder Trial of Four Officers
description: The jurors in the trial of four police officers accused of murdering Amadou Diallo began deliberating today after the judge instructed them for nearly four hours on the legal reasons that could justify the shooting.

title: Honeywell Is Expanding Its Presence on the Web
description: Chalk up another distinction between Honeywell, the $8 billion instruments and controls company, and Honeywell, the $24 billion diversified manufacturer that was formed when it merged with AlliedSignal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NULL, DOUGLAS P.
description: NULL-Douglas P. February 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Marcia, loving father of Lisa A. Holdeman, William S. Null, and Michael C. Null. Devoted step-father of Ilene and Seth Tabor. Dear grandfather of Marjorie, Jake, Danielle, Lauren, Will, Miki and Evan. Caring father-in-law to Trena Weiss Null and Lauren Thaler. He will forever be remembered by his family and friends. In lieu of flowers, please support Doug's favorite charities: UJA-Federation of New York, Juvenile Diabetes FoundationWestchester Chapter, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: VW Stock Is Sharply Lower As Earnings Plummet 80%
description: The shares of Volkswagen had their biggest one-day drop in more than a year today after the company reported that earnings plunged 80 percent in the fourth quarter of 1999.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Threat Seen To Trade Deal To Let China Join W.T.O.
description: Two supporters of China's entry into the World Trade Organization warned the White House today that the administration is in imminent danger of seeing its huge trade initiative die, partly because of Beijing's threats to Taiwan and because Vice President Al Gore appears to have cold feet about the deal.

title: WAP Links Mobiles to the Internet
description: PARIS  With hindsight it is surprising, but two of the success stories of recent communications technology, the Internet and mobile telephony, have followed strictly separate paths. Both are spectacularly successful, both put people in touch with one another and with information, but neither is connected to the other.

title: The Software Side Of Hardware Stores
description: HERE is an example of something that passes for humor down at the mean hardware store in my town: Next to the cash register where the cranky old clerks sit and ignore customers all day is a sign that says ''Complaint Department Take a Number.'' Beneath the sign is a plastic replica of a hand grenade with a card that says ''#1'' and is attached to the firing pin.

title: For Hall, Routine Is an Adventure
description: SETON HALL 64, MINNESOTA 61

title: On Path to Speedy Trial, a Judge With a Firm Hand
description: If Lance Ito, the judge in the O. J. Simpson trial, came to define one extreme of the administration of justice -- slow and indecisive -- Joseph C. Teresi, the presiding judge in the trial of the four police officers charged in the killing of Amadou Diallo, has come to define the other.

title: In America; The Bradley Trip
description: It is a measure of Bill Bradley's distance from the real world of power politics in this country that he seems somehow to have convinced himself that he can revive his presidential campaign by winning the nonbinding Democratic primary in the state of Washington.

title: Loved Her, Hated Him (If They Only Knew)
description: The theater is full of second-act disappointments; it's easier to create conflict onstage than resolve it (just as it is in real life, come to think of it). But some letdowns are worse than others, and the musical ''Splendora,'' which opened last week at the tiny Chelsea Playhouse, is an egregious case.

title: A Little Help Keeps a Mother and Children Together
description: Griselda De Disla lives on a tight schedule.

title: Essay; The 'McCain Majority'
