description: The primary message of Michigan one of the must-win ''battleground states'' in November's election -- is that John McCain would win the state for the G.O.P. and George W. Bush would probably lose it.

title: Setback in Court for Big Credit Card Issuers
description: Visa USA Inc. and MasterCard International Inc., defendants in a possible $24.3 billion antitrust suit, suffered a setback yesterday when a federal judge certified the case against them as a class action.

title: CALENDAR
description: One Couple's Taste

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: S.E.C. Recommendations on Central Market
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission sought public comment today on preliminary proposals aimed at reducing fragmentation in United States stock markets, including the formation of a central market for customer orders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, JOHN W.
description: WALSH-John W. on Feb. 22, 2000. Beloved husband of Catherine. Devoted father of Sean & daughter-in-law Christine, cherished brother of Thomas and Evelyn and the late Anne and Richard. Survived by three grandchildren, Kathleen, Sean, and Stephen. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd, Jackson Heights, NY Thursday & Friday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30am St. Joan of Arc RC Church, Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, SAMUEL S.
description: SCHREIBER-Samuel S. In loving memory of Samuel S. Schreiber, his wife Phyllis H. Schreiber, his sons Dale A. and James, his twelve grandchildren, and two great grandchildren honor his memory with the greatest love and affection. Funeral services will be held at the Greenwich Reform Synagogue, 157 Stanwich Road, Greenwich, CT. at 11:00 AM, Thursday, February 24. Donations may be sent to Greenwich Reform Synagogue or Greenwich Jewish Family Services.

title: Times Is a Top Section Again
description: For the second straight year, The New York Times was selected as one of the 10 best sports sections in the country by the Associated Press Sports Editors. The Times was named in the daily and Sunday categories in judging that ended yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Chechen Children Betray Cost of War
description: In one of the hundreds of tents thrown up on a wind-whipped, treeless plain to house Chechen war refugees, a handful of youngsters perched in a semicircle on wooden stools this afternoon and revealed to a curious visitor their fondest hopes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTLE, S. ANN
description: CASTLE-S. Ann. A nationally recognized authority in Development Research and Women in Philanthropy, died Tuesday, February 22, 2000. Ms. Castle began her career as a development assistant at Smith College and Harvard Divinity School and as Director of Development Research at Wellesley College. In 1989, she became Director of Development Research at Harvard University, where she remained until 1997. She then held that position at Hamilton College, where her husband, Richard Seager is Associate Professor of Religious Studies. Since 1998, Ms. Castle worked as an independent consultant for Slate.com at Microsoft, the United Nations Foundation and the White House Conference on Philanthropy. She is survived by her husband; parents, Dennis and Marjorie Castle; and sister, Jane Castle and her husband, Tom Boldt.

title: Carter and Raptors Humble the Knicks Again
description: Toronto's stardusted Vince Carter swooped and swirled in front of Latrell Sprewell with the unpredictable flight of a paper airplane. Sprewell looked that way, and Carter darted this way. Sprewell lunged forward, and Carter faded back.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Congresswoman Goes on the Attack
description: Representative Sue W. Kelly says she sees nothing unusual in her relationship with her most prominent new constituents, the first couple, whose new house in Chappaqua sits squarely in the 19th Congressional District Mrs. Kelly has represented for five years.

title: A Mac at War With Itself
description: Q. What are extension conflicts on a Macintosh? Can they hurt my Mac?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSEN, LOUISE
description: NELSEN-Louise. 86. Of Morgantown, WV, a longtime resident of Brooklyn, died Feb. 22. Survived by son, John Nelsen. Funeral at Hastings Funeral Home, Morgantown, WV, Monday, at 1 PM.

title: For Next Millennium, Sunset Strip to Flirt With Respectability
description: Sunset Strip, West Hollywood's avenue of billboards, clubs and hotels, is synonymous with sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll. To affluent Los Angeles residents in the hills above it, the Strip is also the main thoroughfare and a cherished neighborhood shopping street. Now, the Strip faces a test of its individual character, just as Times Square did. West Hollywood has announced its intention to begin constructing the Sunset Millennium, a 600,000-plus-square-foot development project on the Strip (above). The development will start near La Cienega Boulevard on the east and run three blocks, to Sunset Plaza Drive.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; NEW OFFER FOR STEEL COMPANY
description: Mexico's largest steel producer, Altos Hornos de Mexico, known as Ahmsa, received an offer from Aceralia Corporacion Siderurgica of Spain that is significantly higher than one made by the Mexican company Grupo Imsa, Ahmsa's executives said. Although Imsa, a manufacturing conglomerate, has been courting Ahmsa for eight months, Mexican law obligates Ahmsa's board to accept the higher offer. Ahmsa gave Aceralia until March 24 to make a complete offer while inviting Imsa to match the new proposal. Dan Fineren

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 9 about the Baltimore Museum of Art stated its ownership imprecisely. The museum is in a city-owned building, receives much of its financial support from the city and is legally considered an agency of the city. But its art collection is owned and controlled by a nonprofit tax-exempt corporation.

title: TRADING DURING LUNCH?
description: As part of measures aimed at increasing trading volume, the Korea Stock Exchange said it was considering trading during lunch hours, effective in April or May. Trading on the main bourse has been sluggish recently, as more and more investors have been flocking to the technology-driven Kosdaq market, which offers higher yields. The stock exchange said it also planned to lower stock trading fees next month, while encouraging listed companies to give dividends based on market prices rather than par value. Samuel Len

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSON, JANE CURTIS
description: HENDERSON-Jane Curtis, 80, died February 21st, 2000 peacefully at home in Erwinna, PA. Beloved wife of Charles N. Henderson. Retired from United Nations, former member of St. George's Church, NYC.

title: R. B. Casey, 48, Prize-Winning Journalist
description: Ronald Bruce Casey, a progressive voice in Alabama journalism as the Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial-page editor of The Birmingham News, died on Monday in Birmingham. He was 48 and lived in Homewood, Ala.

title: GERMAN UTILITY DEAL
description: The big German utility RWE A.G. agreed to buy a rival, VEW A.G., for about 4 billion euros ($4 billion) in cash and stock and said it would cut jobs and sell assets. RWE shareholders will own 83.5 percent of the new company. The purchase, which needs shareholder approval, will make RWE Europe's third-biggest energy company behind Electricite de France and Enel S.p.A. of Italy and set the stage to expand abroad.

title: NATO Chief Makes a Plea for More Kosovo Peacekeepers
description: In an effort to bolster its military strength before the combative ethnic factions of northern Kosovo, NATO's senior commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, appealed to NATO countries today for as many as 1,800 additional troops and said they needed to be dispatched quickly.

title: The Tuxedoed Clinton, Playing Host Again
description: There was a time when President Clinton did not seem to care for getting all gussied up in a tuxedo to entertain the leaders of the world. He preferred rolling up his sleeves in the Cabinet Room to raising his glass in the State Dining Room. Twenty-one-gun salutes, red carpets and fine china -- that was all considered oh so President Bush.

title: U.S. Lets Professor Put Encryption on Internet
description: U.S. Lets Professor Put Encryption on Internet

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Thursday with an Arts Abroad article about the Berlin Film Festival misidentified the actor who plays an impostor czar in ''Captain's Daughter.'' He is Vladimir Mashkov, not Sergei Machovecki.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Muses Wag Their Authors
description: No doubt years from now those afflicted with bibliomania will look back and be puzzled as to why so many of our present-day writers included their dogs and cats and other curious items and achievements in their book flap ''About the Author'' sketches. The information related is bare bones stuff, to be sure, but nonetheless authors put a lot of time into crafting their own versions, autobiographies actually, for their books' back cover flaps.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the appointment of Dileep Nair as United Nations inspector general misstated the name of his former employer. He was chief operating officer of Singapore's POSBank, not National Savings Bank.

title: Debugging Microchips at Light Speed
description: IF microchips were cities, inhabitants would see a virtually constant show of fireworks, with electrons zooming through microscopic roads and throwing out momentary flashes of light.

title: White House Asks Allies to Bolster the Kosovo Police Force
description: The Clinton administration is pushing the NATO allies to send more police officers into Kosovo, arguing that NATO troops are stretched when they are forced to maintain municipal order.

title: Barkley's Tuition May Be Minor Offense
description: St. John's will acknowledge that Erick Barkley received minor financial help from Riverside Church for his tuition to a Maine prep school and may declare him ineligible, perhaps before Saturday's game with Duke, to settle one part of the National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation into the Red Storm's basketball program.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DANA CORP., Toledo, Ohio, the world's largest maker of light-truck axles, agreed to buy a majority stake in Tribometal A.S., Dolny Kubin, Slovakia, an engine-bearings maker, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Buyback at Capital One
description: The Capital One Financial Corporation, a credit card provider, said today that it would buy back up to 10 million of its shares. The buyback, which will take place in the next two years, will involve about 5.1 percent of the company's 197.2 million shares outstanding. Capital One's latest buyback program is in addition to previous plans that were announced in 1997 and 1998. The company can still buy back 2.25 million shares under those programs. Shares of Capital One, which is based in Falls Church, Va., rose 50 cents, to $34.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAVRONICOLAS, JAMES
description: MAVRONICOLAS-James. Age 77. Beloved husband, father, father-inlaw, grandfather, brother, brotherin-law, uncle and friend. Passed away February 23, 2000 in New York, of natural causes. Born Icaria, Greece in 1922, lived in Wilmington, N.C., served in U.S. Army in European Campaign. Creator of Legion Restaurant, Washington Hts., NY 1959, Sage Diner, Queens Blvd, 1962 and developer of real estate. Viewing Hillebrand Funeral Home, 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, N.Y. Friday, February 25th, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Funeral services Transfiguration of Christ Greek Orthodox Church, 38-05 98 St, Corona, New York, Saturday, February 26th, at 10 A.M.

title: The (Female) Candidate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bistro Style, Pret-a-Porter
description: CLASSICS always prevail. And perhaps nothing is as classic as French cafe and bistro style. With many brasseries and bistros opening in the city, some looking more ''old Paris'' than that literary landmark Les Deux Magots, there has also been a deluge of boutiques selling French items. They offer a movable feast of antique furniture and tableware, like Ricard pitchers and bistro tables, as well as reproduction Quimper dinnerware and cafe chairs, to recreate a Left Bank feel at home (minus the Gauloise scent).

title: BUSH SUPPORTERS IN STATE OF SHOCK OVER TWIN LOSSES
description: One day after Gov. George W. Bush's twin losses to Senator John McCain in Michigan and Arizona, many of his staunchest supporters said they were shellshocked. And Mr. Bush himself regrouped by agreeing to a debate in Los Angeles next week, by ripping up his schedule to add a trip this weekend to Washington State, where Mr. McCain is waging an energetic race, and by questioning the senator's Republican credentials.

title: From the Politics-as-Usual Town, Something Different
description: The Washington Ballet is no stranger to New York. But on Tuesday night it returned to the Joyce Theater with a somewhat changed image. There was a new artistic director, Septime Webre, a more ambitious program than usual and two guests from American Ballet Theater, Amanda McKerrow and John Gardner.

title: The End of Free-PC Program Is Windfall for Early Subscribers
description: When eMachines ended its Free-PC program earlier this month, many people were not surprised. For the past year, analysts had questioned whether anyone could make money by giving away computers in exchange for their attention to on-screen advertisements. But for the first batch of people who flocked to the Free-PC offer, the deal turned out to be even better than advertised. The 25,000 people who had received free Compaq and Dell computers in exchange for allowing advertising on their computer screens and their shopping habits to be tracked are allowed to keep the computers -- and the accompanying warranties -- without having to pay a cent. They are also off the hook regarding the advertising and shopping requirements.

title: Giuliani and the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ford Web Venture Will Track Buyers
description: The Ford Motor Company formed a joint venture today with the closely held Trilogy Software Inc. to develop and operate all of Ford's global customer Web sites to reach more car buyers through the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOU, YA, LUN
description: CHOU-Ya-Lun. On February 20, 2000, at 2:00 PM. Devoted husband of Pauline (nee Honadel) for over 36 years. Proud father of Carole, Allan and Barbara. Caring fatherin-law of Ricky, Charlene and Howard. Loving grandfather of Daniel, Justin, Sarah, Katie and Elizabeth. Born on July 7, 1923, in Chungking, China, Allan (as he was called by his friends and loved ones) received a Ph.D. in Economics at the University of Pennsylvania, published numerous books, including ''Statistical Analysis'' and ''Probability and Statistics for Decision Making,'' and contributed many articles to economic, financial and statistic journals. A brilliant statistician and teacher, Allan was a Professor of Quantitative Analysis and Operations Research and Statistics at St. John's University, New York, from 1968 until 1993. In 1995, he taught at Shanghai University of Finance and Economics, China, as a Visiting Professor. A private service will be held on Thursday, February 24, at Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, NY 11358. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory can be made to the World Wildlife Fund, 1250 Twenty-fourth Street, NW, P.O. Box 97180, Washington, DC 20090-7180, an organization that he dearly loved and supported.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NAGER, PHILIP
description: NAGER-Philip on February 24, 1980. He infused our lives with his love, wisdom and caring.

title: A Utopian With a Twinkle and an Idea: Online Democracy
description: IT'S difficult to find a year that was not interesting for Jim Warren, but 1977 was as interesting a year as any.

title: A Splash of Color For Palm's New P.D.A.
description: With a week or so to go until its I.P.O., Palm Computing started this week with a flurry of activity, including a name change. The company is now known as Palm Inc. After the name change, it announced the long-awaited color model: the Palm IIIc.

title: The New York Times: Technology -  Circuits
description: February 24, 2000 Brian Stauffer

title: WIRELESS INTERNET ACCESS
description: The largest mobile telephone service provider in Japan, NTT Mobile Communications Inc., said that starting this summer, all cellular phones it sells will be equipped to provide access to the Internet. The company's i-mode service, which allows users to make hotel reservations, play games and send e-mail by cell phones without connecting to an Internet service provider, has become a global trend-setter. NTT DoCoMo, as the company is known, has 4.2 million subscribers for its Internet service, and it expects the number to grow to 10 million by the end of the year. Stephanie Strom

title: Israel Minister Warns Arabs Of Retaliation If Attacked
description: In the growing war of words between Israel and its Arab neighbors, the Israeli foreign minister took a turn today at fueling the animosities that have risen since the peace efforts stalled.

title: Grace and Swagger of the 70's
description: Remember the 1970's, when Mick and Bianca cut a swath in floating chiffon and crepe creations by Ossie Clark, the British fashion designer, who died in 1996? With the 70's revival comes renewed interest not only in Clark's designs, but also in the fabrics designed by his wife, Celia Birtwell. Vintage suits, dresses and coats by the couple are for sale at Decades, 8214 1/2 Melrose Avenue; (323) 655-0223. Hand-printed fabrics by Ms. Birtwell ($40 to $100 a yard), for curtains, pillows or upholstery, are next door at Jenny Armit Design, 8210 Melrose Avenue; (323) 782-9173.

title: Kuwait Is Said to Be Opposed To U.S. Effort to Cut Oil Prices
description: A consensus on the need for lower or stable oil prices is slowly building among some leading producers, but resistance to the Clinton administration's campaign for increased oil supplies and lower prices is coming not only from Algeria and Iran, but from a traditional Middle East ally, Kuwait.

title: Web Concern Hires Officer Of Citigroup
description: Heidi G. Miller, one of the most powerful women in corporate America, is quitting her job as chief financial officer at Citigroup to join Priceline.com, a two-year-old company that sells discounted airline tickets, hotel rooms and other products over the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELUP, ZULA
description: MELUP-Zula. Beloved sister, cousin, friend. February 19-20, 2000. Services today Riverside Memorial, 76th and Amsterdam, 1 P.M.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro slipped yesterday as surging technology stocks lifted the dollar, but it held above the key $1.00 level of exchange. In New York, the euro closed at $1.0029, down from $1.0036 Tuesday.

title: The House Was a Steal, but Moving It Wasn't
description: A WEB site, Old-houses.com, recently featured this announcement: ''The Schoharie County Planning and Development Agency is offering free, to a qualified individual who can relocate it, a 2,948-square-foot historic home/inn in Fulton, N.Y.'' At the Web site Buildingmovers.com is another enticing offer: ''Small Hotel $1 Must Be Moved.'' And this message: ''Free House, You move it, you own it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUSILI, ANDRES
description: BAUSILI-Andres, on February 22, 2000, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Ines. Devoted father of Andrew and daughter-in-law, Adrienne. Visitation Thursday, 5-7 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. and 66th St. Burial in Most Holy Trinity Cemetery, East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to Boys Harbor, 1 E. 104 St., NY, NY 10029.

title: Long History of Intercepting Key Words
description: The Echelon system was developed in the 1970's. It links computers in at least seven sites around the world to receive, analyze and sort information captured from satellite communications, newly declassified information shows.

title: Bush Allies in Congress Vow to Keep the Faith as McCain Surges
description: If there was one Republican mantra flowing in and out of the Senate cloakroom and Capitol Hill hideaways today, after George W. Bush's defeat in Michigan, it was this: don't panic, don't abandon common sense.

title: Justices Seem Skeptical Over Letting Patients Sue H.M.O.'s That Offer Bonuses to Cut Costs
description: The Supreme Court raised a blizzard of questions today about a patient's challenge to the fundamental principle of managed health care that rewards doctors who hold down costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAIN, HARRY
description: SCHAIN-Harry. Devoted husband of the late Laura, loving father of Martin and Wendy, and Alan and Linda, dearest brother of Nettie and Larry. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Julie, Rebecca, and Gregory. Services Friday 10 A.M. at The Westchester Jewish Center, Mamaroneck, New York.

title: U.S. LOSES DISPUTE ON EXPORT SALES
description: The United States has suffered its largest defeat ever in a trade battle, losing a dispute with Europe about tax policies in a ruling that deals a blow to trans-Atlantic relations and could force American companies to pay billions of dollars more in taxes each year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, EDITH
description: ROBERTS-Edith. Beloved wife of the late Louis, loving mother of Richard. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday, February 24, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Service on Friday, February 25, at 10 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Paying the Price to Hunt In Hot-Ticket Territory
description: WHEN my husband and I recently decided that we would like to see our favorite pro basketball team, the San Antonio Spurs, play at the Alamodome, I began searching the Web for tickets for a home game against the Los Angeles Lakers, which put us into hot-ticket (and perhaps scalpers') territory.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Col. Dean Davenport, co-pilot of the Ruptured Duck, a plane that flew in the Doolittle raid on Japan in 1942, misstated the reason the B-25 bombers were directed to land in China rather than return to the aircraft carrier Hornet. The ship's deck was too short for the planes; it was not that they were short of fuel.

title: Maurine Neuberger Dies at 93; Consumer Advocate in Senate
description: Maurine Brown Neuberger, an Oregon teacher who became the third woman elected to the United States Senate and was an early consumer advocate, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Portland, her hometown. She was 93.

title: Charge for Harding: Domestic Violence
description: The former Olympic figure skater Tonya Harding was arrested Tuesday night after she hit her companion, Darren Silver, in the face with a hubcap and punched him repeatedly, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Jan. 29 about President Clinton's proposal to license new handgun buyers referred incorrectly to the founding of Handgun Control, an advocacy group based in Washington. It was founded in 1974 by Dr. Mark Bo rinsky, not by James and Sarah Brady. Mrs. Brady joined the group's board of directors after the assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan in 1981, in which her husband, the press secretary, was seriously wounded.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBINSON, DR. GEORGE
description: ROBINSON-Dr. George. 10/6/22-2/24/99 I believed you

title: Utah Senate Approves Bill To Fight Polygamist Crimes
description: More than a century after Utah outlawed polygamy, state lawmakers are still trying to fight polygamist clans.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Hong Kong has recovered its appetite for speculation.
description: THE fever over Asian Internet stocks came close to delirium here yesterday as tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents besieged local banks to buy shares in the stock offering of Tom.com, a one-month-old Chinese-language Internet service.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL
description: FRIEDMAN-Samuel. 1/12/20-2/24/ 85. What an empty void-think of you every day. Love, Eleanor and son Arthur

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Lost in G.O.P. Hubbub, The Invisible Democrats
description: Memo from Al Gore and Bill Bradley to the universe: Hello! There is still a Democratic primary going on, even if no one is watching.

title: Standing Up For His Film And for Real Black Heroes
description: For 11 years, Phil Alden Robinson, the director of ''Field of Dreams,'' was obsessed with making a film about the earliest days of the civil rights movement in Mississippi, but every film studio in town rejected the idea.

title: Metro Business; Engineering Unit to Close
description: The Fluor Corporation, an engineering and construction company, said yesterday that it planned to close its unit in Marlton, N.J., by July 1 and cut more than 300 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKER, PAULINE
description: HECKER-Pauline, 91, February 22, 2000. Beloved mother of Judy Keshner & Joel and Lori Hecker. Wonderful grandmother and great-grandmother. Sister of Leonard Bunims. Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY

title: City Agency Messenger Charged in Girl's Rape
description: A messenger for the city's Homeless Services Agency lured an 11-year-old special education student into a Brooklyn crack den, where he fondled her and took drugs, then took her by taxi to another drug apartment and raped her, the authorities said yesterday.

title: POSSIBLE DELAY ON MERGER
description: European Union regulators may delay a ruling for up to a month on the $200 million takeover of Mannesmann A.G. by Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. A spokesman for Mario Monti, left, the union's competition commissioner, said Vodafone had been asked to provide more information about ''certain markets affected by the merger'' after complaints by unidentified third parties. Vodafone, which has already said it will shed Orange P.L.C. to win regulatory approval, said it did not expect the new complaints to lead to so-called second-stage scrutiny, which takes up to four months. Alan Cowell

title: INTERNET SECURITY COMPANY'S RESULTS
description: Baltimore Technologies, a leading Internet security company based in Dublin, reported an unexpectedly strong 28 percent gain in 1999 revenue and announced a strategic partnership with Compaq Computer, which will resell Baltimore's encryption software. But Baltimore shares ended 12.5 percent lower on the London and Nasdaq markets. The shares had more than doubled since January on anticipated demand for software that provides security over the Internet. Brian Lavery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASSBERG, ELLYN
description: FASSBERG-Ellyn. We mourn the loss of our member, and extend heartfelt sympathy to her family. Temple Sinai of Long Island Paula Winnig, Rabbi Dr. Richard Storm, President

title: Online, the Heart Doesn't Need to Be A Lonely Pumper
description: One can look into the heart for love or truth, but there are also veins, valves, arteries and blood to be seen. February is Heart Month, and the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Maryland offers an animated heart at www.biointeractive .org, with pumping muscle, opening and closing valves, and blood flowing from chamber to chamber.

title: MemberWorks Acquisition
description: MemberWorks Inc., a provider of customer-incentive programs for retailers and banks, agreed today to buy the closely held eNeighborhoods Inc. to create a financial-information service for businesses and consumers. Financial details were not disclosed. The new company, to be called iPlace Inc., will combine eNeighborhoods with ConsumerInfo.com, a unit of MemberWorks. Shares of MemberWorks rose $7.625, or 12 percent, to $72 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCANNELL, DANIEL T.
description: SCANNELL-Daniel T. The American Irish Historical Society mourns the passing of its Gold Medalist, Daniel T. Scannell. Kevin M. Cahill, M.D President-General

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Loses Trade Dispute With Europe on Tax Policy

title: With the Right Address, Access to a New Portal
description: SOON, the residents of some of New York's more expensive co-ops and condominiums will have their own free Internet portal combining Web access, all-news radio, discount shopping, reviews and the chance to bid against their peers for tables at top restaurants like Daniel, Lespinasse and the Four Seasons.

title: Tiger Trainer Burning Bright; Circus Artist Spurns Whip and Chair
description: ''Up, Jasmine, up!'' the trainer said, using sheer force of will to urge the 400-pound Bengal tiger to try her signature trick. Jasmine paused a bit -- milking the crowd as usual -- then at long last reared to her seven-foot height, then hopped on her hind legs right across the cage. The crowd of 6,200 in the Hampton Coliseum, which had been holding its breath, offered thunderous applause.

title: Hundreds of Net Disputes in International Mediation
description: February 24, 2000

title: Pataki Presses More DNA Use Against Crime
description: Saying that science has overtaken the state penal code, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed yesterday the most aggressive laws in the nation for solving crimes using DNA analysis. The proposals would abolish prosecution deadlines for 16 felonies and require every person convicted of a crime to provide a biological sample for a state database.

title: Michigan Results Suggest Problems for G.O.P. in Fall
description: Michigan, which in years past has given surprising boosts to candidates as diverse as Pat Robertson, Jesse Jackson and George C. Wallace, sprang another upset on Tuesday, and in doing so gave the Republicans reason to worry about their prospects in November.

title: ASTRA BIDDERS PICKED
description: Indonesia's bank restructuring agency picked three consortiums to bid for its 40 percent stake in the automaker Astra International but threw in a wild card by saying that the Singapore government's investment arm would be included in all three. The Singapore auto distributor Cycle and Carriage Ltd., Gilbert Global Equity Partners and a unit of Lazard Freres & Company will each lead a consortium submitting a bid next month. The sale is part of efforts to pay for the bailout of the country's insolvent banks. Wayne Arnold

title: Gifted Programs Have Downside, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Void Hawaii Setup That Limits a Vote by Race
description: Declaring that ''it demeans the dignity and worth of a person to be judged by ancestry instead of by his or her own merit,'' the Supreme Court today overturned a provision of Hawaii's Constitution under which only descendants of the original Hawaiians may vote for the leadership of a state agency that administers programs and millions of dollars in public money on their behalf.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: TV Marriage Quickly Unravels

title: Mariners' Practice Is Full, But Something Is Missing
description: The player sitting in front of the locker is the son of a former major leaguer, but his father is not Ken Griffey Sr. The locker's occupant is the son of Julian Javier.

title: Stealth Campaigning
description: To the Editor:

title: Science in Off-the-Balcony Labs
description: California's community colleges are not usually noted for their architecture. But Santa Monica College's new science building brings a sense of order to the campus. Designed by Anshen & Allen Los Angeles, the building has a simple clarity and fine detailing, and extends its embrace to the students with inviting public spaces. The 99,500-square-foot building (left) was largely paid for by the Federal Emergency Management Agency after the previous building was damaged by earthquake in 1994. Labs are entered directly from balconies, which is typical of many Southern California buildings, said Andrew Labov, the project's architect. Hanging mesh panels, made of stainless steel conveyor belt fabric, shade and decorate the simple steel-frame structure.

title: Bronx Ministers Hold Marches to Appeal for Calm on Verdict
description: Concerned that disturbances might erupt if the four officers who shot Amadou Diallo are found innocent, dozens of Bronx ministers held four separate marches yesterday to appeal for calm among residents as a jury in Albany deliberated into the night.

title: Will Inquiry's Shadow Chill Art Auctions?
description: As the world's two dominant auction houses find themselves embroiled in a widening federal antitrust investigation, experts at both are racing to get major property for their important spring auctions.

title: Sports of The Times; Dismissal Doesn't Seem So Noble
description: WHAT a coincidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, DOROTHY FRAID
description: BLANK-Dorothy Fraid. On February 22, 2000, at the age of 89. Born in Cornwall, Ontario. Beloved wife of the late Allen. Devoted mother of Matthew and Susan Blank and Roberta and William Sandrin. Grandmother of Jill, Alan, Meredith and Gordon. Greatgrandmother of Hannah. Services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Asbury Foundation, 201 Russell Avenue, Gaithersburg, MD 20877.

title: Comptroller Warns of Big Shortfalls and Cutbacks in Mayor's 4-Year Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's four-year spending plan leaves New York City with dangerously large budget gaps that could force layoffs and cuts in city services after the mayor leaves office, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday.

title: ECHOSTAR TO USE OPENTV TECHNOLOGY IN RETURN FOR STAKE
description: The EchoStar Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had received $339.5 million in stock of the OpenTV Corporation in return for agreeing to use OpenTV's interactive television technology on its satellite dish network. This spring, customers with EchoStar satellite dishes will be able to get weather updates and TV program information by clicking on their remote controls. OpenTV, based in Mountain View, Calif., has agreed to issue 2.25 million of its shares, about 6.8 percent of stock outstanding, to EchoStar. EchoStar's stock was trading at $120.8125, up $20.8125, or 21 percent, on the Nasdaq stock market. OpenTV, a developer of software for interactive TV services, had $26 million in revenue in 1999. Its stock was trading at $165.625, up $14.75.

title: Confidence Restored, McCain Trumpets His Conservatism and Reaches Out
description: With two more primary victories under his belt, Senator John McCain campaigned across the Northwest today with restored confidence, proclaiming himself a ''proud, pro-life conservative Republican'' yet continuing his appeals to Democrats, independents, young people and minorities.

title: Fidelity to Provide Computers to Clients
description: I.B.M. will deliver simple computers for Internet access to Fidelity Investments customers, the computer giant said yesterday.

title: Few Upsets in Match Play, Lots of Holes and Water
description: Most of the top-seeded players advanced, four matches went extra holes, rain suspended two matches and everyone who won breathed a sigh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DI DIA, NANCY
description: Di Dia-Nancy (nee Giampietro), age 81. Born December 1, 1918. Died Sunday, February 20, 2000. Beloved wife of Baldassare Di Dia (deceased). Devoted and loving mother of Nancy J. Di Dia and Maria Di Dia Salmon. Devoted mother-in-law of Douglas E. Salmon. Loving grandmother of Stephanie, Scott, Sean and Seth Salmon. We are eternally grateful for your love and care for all of us. You are now in peace ever after. Funeral services Friday, February 25, at the Volk/Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, NJ. Visiting hours 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Mass Saturday, February 26 at 10AM. St. Cecilia's Church, Englewood, NJ. Cremation private. Memorial donations to the American Diabetes Assn., Summit, NJ Chapter or The Actor's Fund of America, Inc., Nursing and Retirement Home, Englewood, NJ

title: Stealth Campaigning
description: To the Editor:

title: Exposing Medical Mistakes
description: President Clinton moved aggressively on Tuesday to cut down on medical mistakes at the nation's hospitals. Mirroring the recommendations made last November by the Institute of Medicine, he called for mandatory reporting of serious medical errors and for creating a federal headquarters to oversee patient safety. These measures require approval by Congress and the states. On his own authority, Mr. Clinton required hospitals that treat Medicare patients -- meaning most hospitals -- to institute programs to improve patient safety.

title: Corrections
description: The advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about commercials for Alliance Capital, misspelled the name of the responsible advertising agency. It is FerrellCalvillo, not Ferrellcavillo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGNUSS, HENRY
description: AGNUSS-Henry, retired dentist, died on February 21 at the age of 90. He will be sadly missed by his family and friends who truly appreciated his unique individuality, generosity and quick wit.

title: Anheuser Stock Buyback
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the world's largest brewer, said today that it planned to buy as many as 50 million shares to help lift its stock, which last week fell to the lowest level in more than a year. The buyback amounts to 11 percent of Anheuser-Busch's shares and would cost about $3.1 billion at today's closing price. The maker of Michelob and the top-selling Budweiser beer said it planned to buy 3 percent to 4 percent of its stock each year. The stock rose 56.25 cents, to $62.25, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: In a Survey, Americans Voice High Hopes for Cellular Phones
description: Americans are optimistic and imaginative about the ways they think cell phones will be used in the future. At least that's the conclusion of a new survey of 1,013 cell phone users and non-cell phone users conducted by Yankelovich Partners, a market research firm in Norwalk, Conn.

title: 2 Democrats Present Plans About Drugs And Workers
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley and Vice President Al Gore paused in their attacks today to announce proposals for social programs.

title: Amnesty for Illegal Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENKRANZ, WILLIAM
description: EHRENKRANZ - William. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Claire; father of Bea (and Bob) Strauss, Dr. Howard Ehrenkranz, and Elaine (and Jerry) Kaplan; and brother of Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz, a dedicated alumnus, YU Guardian, and honorary degree recipient in whose name the Rare Manuscript Collection was established at our Mendel Gottesman Library. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David. S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FITZPATRICK, WILLIAM J.
description: FITZPATRICK-William J. November 4, 1999. Happy Birthday, Bill, my friend of sixty-four years. Ed

title: Coley, Angry at Slights, Ready for De La Hoya
description: In case anybody was wondering, Derrell Coley is the man Oscar De La Hoya is fighting on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. From the billboards advertising the fight to the news conference announcing it, it has been all Oscar all the time.

title: MGM Grand Makes $3.3 Billion Unsolicited Offer for Mirage
description: MGM Grand Inc., the casino company controlled by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, made an unsolicited $3.3 billion offer yesterday to acquire Mirage Resorts Inc., the innovative-if-struggling company created by the Las Vegas impresario Stephen A. Wynn.

title: Star Light, Star Bright, Inside and Out
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dinosaur Returns With a Sprightly Gait
description: The cruel toll keeps mounting in the very vivid revival of George Kelly's ''Torch-Bearers'' that opened at the Greenwich House Theater last night. There's the man who dies shortly before the play begins, and the fellow who falls unconscious at the end of its first act. Then there are those lesser but undeniably painful moments of injury and humiliation, which require the administering of smelling salts and deep breaths of fresh air. And we haven't even mentioned the damage to the furniture.

title: Best Western beefs up TV spending in what it sees as a key year.
description: WITH a record TV budget, Best Western International has created an ad campaign to try to raise the profile of its brand as it battles higher-spending competitors in the lodging business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAFFIE, DORIS
description: CHAFFIE-Doris. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Loving mother of Joy Greenhouse and Mark Chaffie. Cherished grandmother of Barbara and Andrew. Greatgrandmother of Jake. Funeral services were held. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Sarah Newman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, NY.

title: All's Not Fair in E-Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BINET, DENNIS
description: BINET-Dennis. Memorial service Sunday, February 27, 2000, 1:45PM at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. A gathering to celebrate his life immediately following at Empire Hotel, 44 W. 63rd St., Mezzanine Ballroom, 3:30-5:30PM.

title: You're Never Too Old
description: To the Editor:

title: It Blocks Cat Odors, And Maybe Radiation; Material Used in Litter Is Tested In Sopping Up Nuclear Contaminants
description: Here at the opposite end of New York State from the site of the Indian Point nuclear accident on Feb. 15 lies one of the country's biggest radioactive stains, left behind at a long-mothballed recycling plant for spent nuclear fuel rods.

title: McCain Is Facing Labyrinth (a k a  New York's Primary)
description: Senator John McCain's victories in Michigan and Arizona have set the stage for the first contested statewide Republican primary in New York in 20 years. But Mr. McCain faces two problems as he turns his attention east: a contest closed to non-Republican voters and, yet again, an electoral system designed to assist the candidate favored by the Republican establishment, in this case, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: A Mac at War With Itself
description: A Mac at War With Itself

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAGER, ROBERT
description: SCHWAGER-Robert. In memorium to our esteemed colleague and friend, the Cultured Pearl Association mourns the death of Robert Schwager of International Cultured Pearls. Our condolences to the family. A memorial service will be held at Reddens Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, on March 5th at 11 A.M.

title: OM GROUP TO BUY NICKEL REFINERY FROM FINNISH COMPANY
description: Anticipating higher demand for metals used in fuel cells and rechargeable batteries, OM Group agreed to buy a nickel refinery from Outokumpu Oyj of Finland for about $185 million. OM Group is one of the world's biggest makers of cobalt materials and other metal-based specialty products. The refinery, which is in Harjavalta, Finland, can produce more than 55,000 tons of metal a year and generated $330 million in sales last year. OM Group, based in Cleveland, had sales of $507 million in 1999.

title: Effort to Paint Gore as Conservative
description: Signaling the first significant shift to confrontational advertising in the Democratic campaign for president, former Senator Bill Bradley began using a 60-second radio spot in Washington State yesterday that tries to brand Vice President Al Gore as a conservative.

title: E-Vectra Desktop PC Is Smaller and Simpler
description: The Help Desk just got a little help: a new series of desktop PC's that are smaller and simpler. Announced earlier this week, Hewlett-Packard's new e-Vectra computer is about the size of a hard-cover dictionary, about 75 percent smaller than the average desktop PC. The computer, aimed at the business market but also designed to appeal to home users, is expected to arrive in stores by this summer, with street prices for the low-end models estimated to start at about $549. The e-Vectra weighs about eight pounds. When unhooked from its monitor and keyboard, it can fit inside a laptop computer case for easy transport.

title: Another Big Center, Another Big Night
description: Kendall Gill thought he had seen a defining performance by the Los Angeles Lakers' Shaquille O'Neal on Tuesday night in New Jersey. That was until the Nets' guard saw Heat center Alonzo Mourning tonight in Miami.

title: Revisiting Henry James, Looking for Goose Bumps
description: ''The Turn of the Screw,'' Henry James's most popular and least typical work of fiction, returns this weekend with all its perplexities intact. Are those well-bred but unfathomable children in the grip of mischievous forces, or are they just mischief makers? Is its hapless heroine, their governess, shaken by the wickedness of the world or unstrung by her own emotional fragility? Are a former valet and a former governess, both dead, figments of the heroine's distraught mind or something more palpable and malevolent?

title: D'Arcy Changes Names and Expands
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, part of BDM Inc., said yesterday that its D.M.B.& B. Financial agency, based in London, would be renamed Masius and would open a New York office.

title: Cone Offers His Hand, but Is It Too Late?
description: David Cone locked his skinny right hand into Darryl Strawberry's massive right hand, then reached over and wrapped his arms around his troubled, troubled teammate. Cone was the first Yankee to greet Strawberry awkwardly after he surprisingly came to Legends Field yesterday for his first official spring workout, a workout that was curtailed by Major League Baseball. Strawberry's season should be next

title: Complaint Cites Bias At the Secret Service
description: A black Secret Service agent who was once the highly rated lead bodyguard for President Clinton is the lead plaintiff in a class-action complaint accusing the Secret Service of a pattern of racial discrimination dating to 1987.

title: Town Rejects Bid to Curb Library's Internet Access
description: Voting on the nation's first ballot measure to shackle the Internet on library computers and keep children from being exposed to pornography, the people of this deeply conservative town have chosen not to force a public library to filter computer access to the Web.

title: Screen Mates for Fun or Profit
description: THERE is something decidedly tranquil about sitting back and watching sheep contentedly frolic and graze. And if you're stuck in the office and can't get to the country, watching a little cartoon sheep scamper around your computer's screen and head-butt your icons can be relaxing in its own right.

title: Online, the Heart Doesnt Need to Be a Lonely Pumper
description: Online, the Heart Doesn't Need to Be a Lonely Pumper

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHMAN, FRANCES
description: HOCHMAN-Frances (nee Ginsburg). On February 22nd, 2000. Beloved wife of Dr. Mortimer Hochman. Dearest mother of Dr. Herbert Hochman. Sister of the late Lillian Berg and Elsie Ginsburg. A most gentle, loving, sweet person. Adored by all who knew her. Services Thursday, 12 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: DISMISSAL AT BRAZIL BANK
description: In a shake-up disclosing differences over economic policy within Brazil's government, Andrea Sandro Calabi, left, was ousted as president of the national development bank and replaced by Francisco Gros, a high-ranking banker from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company. The development bank is instrumental in providing long-term lending and in guiding privatizations. Mr. Gros, a former central bank president, is expected to favor greater foreign investment, a departure from Mr. Calabi's tenure, which was seen as excessively nationalistic. Simon Romero

title: Spitzer Urges Further Limits On Ads for Tobacco Products
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer today called for legislation to bar all tobacco companies, not just the industry giants, from advertising or marketing their cigarettes in places likely to be seen by children.

title: Sites and Events This Week
description: Sites and Events This Week

title: A GENTLE FALL
description: The shares of the British bank Standard Chartered P.L.C., which has most of its assets in Asia, rose after it reported a less severe fall in second-half net income than analysts had forecast. The company said second-half profit was $254 million, compared with $318 million a year earlier -- roughly $16 million more than analysts forecast. The company said it expected higher profits as Asian economies rebound. Alan Cowell

title: Rigorous Training for Cross-Country Racer
description: Laura McCabe speaks of it as a hobby. But anyone who has given her body to the long-distance stretch of snow and skid marks that face cross-country skiers in the Birkebeiner knows better. Hobbies are supposed to be fun. But here is what McCabe, the 31-year-old defending women's champion of the 2000 Johnson Bank American Birkebeiner, does to get ready for cross-country's annual classic. On Saturday, the race will traverse the 46.5 kilometers, about 29 miles, between the Wisconsin towns of Cable and Hayward.

title: Directing Traffic in the Radio Spectrum's Crowded Neighborhood
description: IT is a growing, although invisible problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELER, INA
description: KESSELER-Ina. The Trustees, Principal, Faculty and Staff of the German School New York, White Plains, mourn the passing of their long-serving Trustee. She was an active and dedicated Trustee of the school for many years and contributed generously of her time to the school on a regular basis. In addition, she served on a variety of committees of the Board and was noted for her unfailing attendance at meetings and the active interest she brought to the affairs of the school. We will miss her dedication and support and the experience she brought to the Board and extend our deepest condolences to her entire family. H. Peter Thiessen, Chairman

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Some R.N.C. members are saying: 'What is going on here? He's getting his hat handed to him and he can't put down the rebellion.' And that makes them nervous.''

title: Arrests Break Drug Network Based in Queens, Officials Say
description: A drug-dealing network run by Israelis in Queens who sold millions of dollars worth of Ecstasy, the illegal stimulant of choice in nightclubs, was broken up with the arrest of most of its members, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: What People Will Do to See Their Book in Print
description: THE HOOK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINET, DENNIS
description: BINET-Dennis. Age 76, on Feb. 19, 2000. Survived by his partner, Toni Sacks, and her family, his sons, Larry & Tommy, & their families; four grandchildren; two greatgrandchildren; nieces and nephews & many friends. Hungarian immigrant, served in US Army in WWII, co-founder of 47 year old Universal Elevator Company, Inc. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to a cancer-related organization or other charity or hospice of your choice. Memorial service Sunday Feb 27th at 1:45PM at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. A gathering to celebrate his life immediately following at Empire Hotel, 44 W. 63rd St., Mezzanine Ballroom, 3:30-5:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALINGER, FRANCES G.
description: SALINGER-Frances G. (Crystal). Age 88, of Palm Beach, Florida. Passed away on February 23, 2000. Mrs. Salinger, formerly of New York, was active in many community, religious and charitable organizations. She was the second woman in the country elected President of a Jewish synagogue as well as serving as the United Nations Representative of the National Council of Jewish Women. She was a woman of uncommon strength, character, dignity and intelligence and admired by all whose lives she touched. Survivors include loving children Richard (Marilyn Crystal), Andrew Crystal and Libby (Robert Rappaport). Beloved sister of Thomas, Marge and Richard Grumbacher and Ann Lowengard. Adoring grandmother of Deborah, Daniel, Bryan and Emily Crystal; Paul Rosenberg and Alex; David and Toni Reamer. Great grandmother to Courtney, Jacob and Samuel Reamer. Aunt Fran to countless nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held Friday, February 25th, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, N.Y. Family will receive friends Saturday night from 6PM to 9PM at the home of Richard Crystal, and Sunday from 2PM to 7PM at the home of Andrew Crystal. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the 92nd Street YMYWHA.

title: Angry Protests as Council Considers Expanding Restrictions on Smoking
description: Tavern keepers and smokers' rights advocates turned out in force at a City Council committee hearing yesterday to angrily protest calls to expand restrictions on smoking in public places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTONUCCI, ANTHONY J.
description: ANTONUCCI-Anthony J. February 21, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Ida. Devoted father of Peter Anthony. Adoring grandfather of Alexander Peter and Nicole Rose. Dear brother of Lydia Musumeci, Dante Antonucci & the late Santino Antonucci. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Wednesday 7:00-9:00 PM and Thursday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, February 25, 10:00 A.M., Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 E. 62 St. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017.

title: Cities With a Bad Name
description: To the Editor:

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY -- Seattle, Tacoma and Olympia, Wash.

title: After Review of the Tape, Devils Lose
description: Last summer, the National Hockey League eliminated video review for many goals. There would be fewer awkward delays, it was promised, while fans and players waited for judges with television monitors to decide the legality of a scoring play.

title: McCain Courts Republicans, Old and New
description: J. Daniel Price is a silver-haired retired insurance executive, a courtly man who calls himself a ''fifth-generation Abe Lincoln Republican.'' Until today, he supported George W. Bush.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRAVELER
description: As part of its expanded travel coverage, the IHT today launches its International Traveler section, to appear each Friday. With city guides, health news, an international events calendar and advice for getting the best value from hotels and airlines, the section focuses on making life easier and more enjoyable for the frequent traveler. You may have already noticed the increased space devoted to travel news each day on Page 2, which began Monday. In March, the IHT will publish a revamped and enlarged quarterly travel section.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: Police Work: Getting Past Raw Emotion
description: THAT the Rev. Al Sharpton got the honor of asking the first question at the Gore-Bradley debate the other night was in itself interesting. (''Distressing'' might be the word preferred by Mr. Sharpton's critics.) Even more interesting was the question.

title: Rupert Goldsworthy
description: Rupert Goldsworthy Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CIPNIC, HERMAN
description: CIPNIC-Herman. A dearly beloved and deeply devoted father and husband. May 26, 1907-February 25, 1999.

title: Luxury Tax Puts a Damper On N.B.A. Trading Activity
description: In what amounted to one of the quietest trade deadlines in National Basketball Association history, not a single marquee player swapped uniforms yesterday and only one minor deal was completed.

title: Tribe Protests Development of Land It Sold 3 Centuries Ago
description: Long-running land disputes are not unusual on Long Island, but the one that erupted here today goes back more than 300 years.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY: Seattle, Everett, Mount Vernon and Bellingham, Wash.

title: Powerful Virginia Machine Digs In to Tackle McCain
description: All the confident Republican talk of political fire walls has been banished here as a bad establishment dream. Instead, the shifting fortunes in the Republican presidential contest have suddenly made Virginia's wide open, winner-take-all primary an unpredictable prelude next week for the mass of voting to follow on March 7 in the states of Super Tuesday.

title: The Neediest Cases; After Trauma, Man Gets Help on the Long Climb Back
description: George Brown has no recollection of what happened to him on June 21, 1990, the day he was picked up by the police as he wandered along the breakdown lane of the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn, dazed and incoherent.

title: K. D. Nichols, 92, Leader in Early Atomic Age
description: Maj. Gen. Kenneth D. Nichols, an Army engineer who supervised the construction of the plants that produced the nuclear fuel for the first atomic bombs, died on Monday at a retirement home in Bethesda, Md. He was 92.

title: Carjacker Surprised By the Cargo
description: The carjacker who snatched a vehicle from a Brooklyn gas station yesterday evening as the owner was filling her tank got an unwelcome surprise, a police official said.

title: What's Behind Economy's Boom
description: To the Editor:

title: In Fiction and Fact, The Ramsey Family
description: During a two-week period centered around this weekend, television viewers will have seen three Patsy Ramseys, the real-life woman and two actresses playing her. All are dressed in the same black suit and little gold pin, and all repeat the same words. Sitting next to her husband, John, she looks into the CNN cameras on New Year's Day 1997, a week after their daughter, JonBenet, was found murdered in their house in Boulder, Colo. ''There is a killer on the loose,'' she says slowly, leaning into the camera. ''If I were a resident of Boulder, I would tell my friends,'' she warns, pausing as she chokes back a sob, ''to keep your babies close to you.''

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTLEDGE, ELIZABETH
description: RUTLEDGE - Elizabeth. We mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague-Beth Rutledge. Refugees everywhere, whose cause she so tenaciously upheld for 25 years, have lost a great champion and we have lost a devoted friend. The Staff and Board International Rescue Committee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, DR. M. ALLEN
description: ALEXANDER-Dr. M. Allen. On Febraury 18,2000 at age 83. Partner for over 40 years to William August Liebherr. Entombment Saturday, February 26th, 10:30am at Newton Cemetery, Newton, NJ.

title: Moving Out of the Shadow Of Legendary Performers
description: Performers whose parents are show business legends have inescapable ghosts to wrestle with. Their names and strong family resemblances usually ensure that their famous parents are figuratively gazing over their shoulders whenever they perform. Singers who reject their parents' musical values tend to be viewed as rebellious ingrates fleeing the silver spoons that fed them, while those who embrace their legacies often find themselves bucking unfavorable comparisons.

title: Julius L. Katz, 74, U.S. Negotiator on Trade
description: Julius L. Katz, a deputy United States trade representative who was a chief negotiator of the North American Free Trade Agreement, died on Jan. 27 at a hospital in Washington. He was 74 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: U.S. Orders Suspension Of Gun Sales Into Canada
description: The Clinton administration is suspending the export of handguns, rifles and ammunition to Canada after discovering a large volume of sales in the past nine months, American and Canadian officials said today.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Electronic Options Market Granted Approval by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had granted exchange status to the International Securities Exchange, which will become the nation's first all-electronic options market.

title: Woman, 62, Put to Death In Texas
description: Gov. George W. Bush did not grant a stay of execution to a 62-year-old woman on death row in Texas, and she was killed by lethal injection tonight.

title: RWE TO CUT 12,500 JOBS
description: Germany's second-largest utility, RWE A.G., will cut 12,500 jobs to combat sagging energy earnings as it prepares for the 4 billion euro ($4 billion) purchase of its smaller rival VEW A.G. RWE will reduce the number of workers in its main business by 25 percent, to about 40,500, after integrating VEW. It will take a charge of 1.8 billion euros for the cuts, which come after operating profit fell 19 percent in the first half.

title: Accounts
description: * British Airways, London and New York, to Agency.com, New York, as the first agency to handle the account of the airline's new electronic- commerce division. Billings for an unspecified multiyear period were estimated at $30 million.

title: From Ship to Train, New York Loses
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fairy Tale for Adults (Watch for Snow White)
description: Can a plucky young waitress from East 81st Street find happiness with a half-man, half-wolf from a seedy fairy-tale realm who pursues her through a magic mirror? Could you possibly want to hang around for 10 hours to find out?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, DOROTHY FRAID
description: BLANK-Dorothy Fraid. On February 22, 2000, at the age of 89. Born in Cornwall, Ontario. Beloved wife of the late Allen. Devoted mother of Matthew and Susan Blank and Roberta and William Sandrin. Grandmother of Jill, Alan, Meredith and Gordon. Greatgrandmother of Hannah. Services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Asbury Foundation, 201 Russell Avenue, Gaithersburg, MD 20877.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LA BORNE, MARGARET B.
description: LA BORNE-Margaret B. On February 23, 2000 formerly of Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Mary Lynn Downing, William La Borne and Barbara King. Cherished grandmother of Susan and Thomas King, Charlene La Borne Mainville and Thomas Downing. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. on Friday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 10:45 A.M. Saturday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. Donations to St. Joseph's Rest Home, 350 Cuba Hill Road, Huntington, NY 11745 appreciated.

title: DNA Tests and the Road To More Reliable Justice
description: ACTUAL INNOCENCE

title: U.S. Drug Czar Reassures Colombia on Aid
description: The White House's top official on drug policy capped a three-day visit here today by touring a jungle base from which a new Colombian Armed Forces unit hopes to attack Marxist guerrillas involved in the cocaine trade. Aside from that excursion, however, most of his time here was devoted to maneuvering through the thickets of Colombian and American politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPMAN, NATALIE
description: LIPMAN-Natalie. Age 94 of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, formerly of Monroe, NY. Predeceased by her husband Arthur in 1974. Survived by her sons Lewis (Edythe), Alan (Heather) and Kenneth. Services are Sunday, 12 noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUTLEDGE, ELIZABETH
description: RUTLEDGE-Elizabeth. A memorial service celebrating the life of Beth Rutledge will be held at 11 AM, Friday, March 10 at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, 348 East 55 St. between 1st and 2nd Avenues in Manhattan. All Beth's friends and colleagues are welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, GEORGE
description: HERMAN-George. 82, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Ft. Lee, NJ died in Delray Beach on February 23, 2000. Mr. Herman was a US Army veteran of WWII and a former employee of The New York Times and a member of the N.Y. Typographical Union. Beloved husband of May, loving father of Mark Herman and Lauren (Mark) Shaffer, cherished grandfather of Ian and Erika and great-grandfather of Yasmeen and brother of Abraham Herman. Graveside services will be held today in Boynton Beach, FL.

title: American Relations With Iran
description: The victory won by reformers in Iran's parliamentary elections should encourage the Clinton administration to try again to defrost relations between Washington and Tehran. Earlier efforts were rebuffed, in part because Iran's harshly anti-American clerical leaders limited President Mohammad Khatami's options. Those leaders, who outrank both Mr. Khatami and the Parliament, may still prove a formidable obstacle. But their position has been weakened by the parliamentary vote. They cannot ignore the electorate's clear desire to end Iran's international isolation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNI-MARTS INC., State College, Pa., a convenience store operator, agreed to buy 43 convenience stores and related gas stations from the closely held Orloski Service Station Inc., Wilkes-Barre, Pa., for about $41 million.

title: No Ordinary War, No Ordinary Hero
description: John McCain's presidential campaign, more clearly than any since that of Dwight D. Eisenhower, emphasizes military biography over political accomplishments. Just as Eisenhower was embraced by the nation for the leadership he showed in World War II, any discussion about Mr. McCain begins with his ordeal as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam.

title: Naughty Holiday on Ice
description: In John Frankenheimer's hard-boiled film ''Reindeer Games,'' Ben Affleck (above) plays Rudy, fresh out of prison, who assumes his dead cellmate's identity in hopes of getting his girl. But he also gets her brother, who needs help robbing a casino. Since that's not Rudy's specialty, he becomes a lowlife Scheherazade, spinning tales to save his skin.

title: Metro Business; Jersey City Building Sold
description: Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate owner and developer based in Cranford, N.J., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 621,900-square-foot office building in Jersey City for $152.5 million.

title: An Eye for the Details of His Era And a Wink at Timeless Foibles
description: HONORE DAUMIER aided, abetted and recorded the emergence of so many aspects of modern art and life as we know it that you may have trouble keeping track. Look in any direction in the sprawling, illuminating retrospective of his work at the Phillips Collection here -- the largest Daumier show ever held in this country -- and you'll see the start of something big: the modern newspaper, the modern city and public transportation, working-class consciousness, agitprop and political caricature, popular art and entertainment.

title: F.T.C. Proposal On Data Privacy
description: The Federal Trade Commission proposed rules today that would require check cashers, credit counselors, travel agencies and other financial services firms to tell customers when data about them will be disclosed to outsiders.

title: China and Europeans Break Off Talks on W.T.O. Membership
description: Chinese and European Union negotiators broke off talks today on China's entry to the World Trade Organization, further complicating the country's troubled bid to join the body. No date was set to resume the talks.

title: LITTLE MOVEMENT FOR NEW YORKERS IN SENATE CHOICE
description: Despite a steady diet of speeches, candidate jousting and almost nonstop news coverage, New Yorkers seem largely to be locked in place in their attitudes toward Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton, though the first lady has begun to show some success in dispelling her image as a carpetbagger, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14.

title: RES-CARE PURSUES BUYOUT TALKS AFTER BID IS WITHDRAWN
description: Res-Care Inc., a provider of education and training services to people with mental and developmental disabilities, said yesterday that it was in buyout talks with a management-led group, even as a $441 million offer was withdrawn. The talks are aimed at raising Res-Care's share price, which had lost half its value in the last year before yesterday. The shares plunged 24 percent yesterday, falling $2.8125, to $9.0625. A group of managers of the company, which is based in Louisville, Ky., and three investment funds had offered to buy Res-Care for $18 a share in cash. Res-Care said the offer was withdrawn when the lead fund backed out because of financing concerns. Res-Care said it was continuing discussions with the two other funds and the managers.

title: The King Says No. That's Trouble, No?
description: Imagine the Trojan War fought not over Helen of Troy but over a pretty, gay young man named Gaveston, the 27-year-old son of an Irish butcher, and you have a sketchy sense of the plot of ''Edward II,'' Bertolt Brecht's one tragedy.

title: Review/Fashion; Up and Out, Jil Sander Makes a Clean Sweep
description: ''Chin up, shoulders back, look forward,'' read the program notes today to Jil Sander's auf Wiedersehen collection, the last she will give in the house she once called grandly, brilliantly her own.

title: Venture Is Formed by Publishers Of Magazines for Black Readers
description: BET Holdings Inc. and Vanguarde Media have announced they will join in a management and investment agreement that would ally the two groups' magazines under Vanguarde Media, making the partnership one of the largest publishers of magazines for African-Americans.

title: France, Philosophy and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Thuggery on the Ice
description: Hockey is at once an elegant and punishing sport, where a crushing but legal body check is as much a part of the game's tactical ebb and flow as a crisply executed pass. The game's furious pace and frequent collisions also lead to fistfights -- relished by some spectators, condemned by others as an unnecessary intrusion. But everyone agrees that deliberate violence inflicted on an unprotected opponent should be severely sanctioned.

title: A Woman Who Needs A New Job
description: In Lodge Kerrigan's elegantly gloomy film ''Claire Dolan,'' Midtown Manhattan is a forest of chilly glass towers whose inhabitants gaze forlornly through floor-to-ceiling windows at other glass towers in which only a few fitful stirrings of human activity can be glimpsed.

title: Metro Business; State Pension Money To Leave the Market
description: New York's comptroller, H. Carl McCall, said yesterday he planned to shift almost $5 billion of the state's $120 billion pension fund out of the stock market and invest it overseas or in real estate.

title: A Jazz Age Tale Of Lust and Death
description: A PLEA to compassionate New Yorkers: the time has come to open your wallets and help send a chorus boy or girl away from Manhattan for a week of clean country air and sunshine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLEL, FRANK HARON
description: HILLEL-Frank Haron. On Thursday, February 24, of Weston, MA formerly of Rye. Beloved husband of Violette (Dallal) Hillel. Loving father of Donald, Lawrence, Richard and Allen Hillel. Cherished grandfather of Julie, Nancy, Alexander, Liza, Rebecca, Anna, and Hadley. Dear brother of Shlomo Hillel of Jerusalem. Services on Sunday in Boston, MA. Shiva Monday 1:30-4:00 PM at 99 Norumbega Rd., Weston, MA. Donations may be made to Hebrew University, Jerusalem.

title: A DAUNTING EDGE IN CAMPAIGN CASH NARROWS FOR BUSH
description: After spending a record $60 million, Gov. George W. Bush now holds only a slim financial advantage over Senator John McCain as both candidates prepare for expensive and crucial primaries in New York, California and other states on March 7.

title: From Violent Upheavals To Spiritual Anxiety
description: Midlife crises on both sides of the cold war took up much of the San Francisco Symphony's programs at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday. Leonard Bernstein's ''Age of Anxiety'' and the Shostakovich 11th Symphony were at opposite ends of the second evening. American anxiety also came on Tuesday with Copland's brief ''Inscape,'' immediately followed by Tchaikovsky's B flat minor Piano Concerto, with Arcadi Volodos as soloist.

title: 2 Accused of Using E-Mail To Commit Stock Fraud
description: Federal authorities accused two men yesterday of manipulating penny stocks by using e-mail to promote the stocks and illegally profiting from the ensuing rally.

title: Michael Ashkin
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, CATHERINE
description: GREEN-Catherine, of Miami Beach, formerly of Harrison, NY. Funeral services will be at 9:45 AM Sunday, February 27th., at The Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, Manhattan.

title: Mr. Bush's New York Friends
description: When they endorsed Gov. George W. Bush for president last year, Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani spoke enthusiastically of Mr. Bush as a proven winner who could reach out to minorities and women. But since then the Texas governor has run hard to the right in South Carolina and elsewhere, adopting positions and allying himself with groups that are anathema to many New York Republicans. When Mr. Bush campaigns in New York next week, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani need to press him to reject these extreme tactics or, alternatively, make it clear why they may be willing to overlook them.

title: Crime And (Much) Punishment
description: GUILTY. We are all guilty of something. Plus, just look at the mugs around us in sports the last few days.

title: A City in Full: Venerable, Impatient Atlanta
description: This is a city without a historic core, a city in constant evolution -- a Deep South version, you might say, of Los Angeles.

title: SMARTDISK IS IN $81.6 MILLION DEAL FOR VST TECHNOLOGIES
description: The SmartDisk Corporation, a computer disk maker, agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held VST Technologies Inc., a maker of computer disk drives, for $81.6 million in stock and cash. With the purchase, SmartDisk, based in Naples, Fla., is getting computer data storage products for Apple computers and more distributors for its own products. Besides disk drives, VST makes computer accessories like adapters, batteries and disks. The company, based in Acton, Mass., had $55 million in revenue in 1999. SmartDisk had $40.3 million in revenue in 1999. Its stock was down 75 cents at $42.

title: Tom Holland
description: Charles Cowles

title: Gotti's Accuser Is Accused in Phoenix Drug Ring
description: Eight years after his turncoat testimony helped bring down John J. Gotti, Salvatore Gravano, the Mafia killer whose ferocity earned him the nickname Sammy the Bull, was arrested yesterday on charges that he helped control a multimillion-dollar drug ring in the Phoenix area with the help of members of a white supremacist youth gang.

title: Task Force to Address Killings of Livery Drivers
description: After a livery cab driver was found dead in the Bronx yesterday morning, Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced that he would form a task force to address a string of several killings of drivers this year.

title: Day Trading's Risk and Pressure Are Described to a Senate Panel
description: A study of day trading for a Senate subcommittee says that day traders face tough challenges to make profits, concluding that a typical trader must gain more than $111,000 a year to break even after paying commissions.

title: MEDICAL COMPANIES TO MERGE
description: Two Canadian medical companies -- MDS Inc. of Toronto and Phoenix International Life Sciences Inc. of Montreal -- have agreed to a merger that would create the world's fifth-largest contract research company. MDS will pay 16 Canadian dollars a share in cash, or four-tenths of a MDS share, for each share of Phoenix. Timothy Pritchard

title: Port Authority Remains At Impasse on Big Issues
description: The 12-member board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey met yesterday and considered an agenda of routine actions, but remained stalemated over three big-ticket initiatives that are at the heart of a dispute between the two states over the allocation of the agency's capital projects.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A 10th Life For 'Cats'?

title: Carver Shareholders Argue Future of a Troubled Bank
description: A lot of Harlem's past -- and some of what may be its future -- clashed yesterday as shareholders voted on the fate of the financially troubled Carver Bancorp, the largest black-run bank in the country.

title: You're Gonna Fly Now, Like Rocky
description: The night before her title bout for the women's lightweight boxing crown, Isabelle Alvarado (Sophia-Adella Hernandez), the beautiful, brave, loyal contender who has weathered two successive family tragedies, has a dream in which her dead parents appear in a silvery mist to offer words of divine encouragement. ''It's all right,'' they soothe. ''It's your time to shine! Let your light shine! Let it shine!''
