description: LEVINE-Solomon Dr. Died 2/25/ 99. Solly we miss you so much. We'll love and remember you forever. Bea and famil

title: Giuliani Isn't Rushing To Fight At Bush's Side
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sidestepped questions yesterday about how much campaigning he will do on behalf of Gov. George W. Bush, whom he has endorsed, and again praised the upstart candidacy of Sen. John McCain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HYMAN
description: STEIN-Hyman. Died February 24, 2000, in New York City at age 90. Beloved father of Drs. Harry and Berta Stein Bienenstock; husband of Celia K. Stein; and husband of the late Dorothy M. Stein. Loving grandfather of Michael and Felice (Bienenstock) Friedson, Drs. David and Arielle (Bienenstock) Kauvar, Jordan Bienenstock and Ethan Bienenstock. Proud greatgrandfather of Jonathan, Lyndon and Gavriel Friedson and Ellery and Darien Kauvar. Brother of Max and Aaron Stein. Funeral services at 11 AM Friday at Shomrei Hadas, Brooklyn, NY. Shiva will be observed at the Bienenstock residence in Belle Harbor through Thursday, March 2.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest on Feb. 17 about Viacom's earnings for the fourth quarter misstated the amount by which they exceeded expectations. It was 5 cents a share, not 1 cent.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption yesterday about next month's presidential election in Taiwan misstated the position of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. While it long advocated formal independence for Taiwan, the party's presidential candidate recently moderated this stance, saying a formal declaration was unnecessary.

title: Residential Real Estate; Tenant-Leaning City Council Prepares to Continue Rent Rules
description: With little echo of the protracted, headline-stirring bombast of the 1997 rent-regulation struggle in Albany, the New York City Council is to hold its first public hearing this morning on legislation required to extend rent control and rent stabilization for 1.1 million city apartments for three more years.

title: Israelis Are of 2 Minds About John Paul's Coming Sojourn
description: A group of senior rabbis asked Pope John Paul II today to cancel plans for a daytime Saturday Mass in Nazareth during his visit to Israel next month, contending that security arrangements would cause ''massive desecration'' of the Jewish sabbath.

title: Gore Gets Environmental Boost in New York
description: Against the backdrop of a placid Hudson River on an unusually balmy winter afternoon, Vice President Al Gore today received the endorsement of the New York League of Conservation Voters, racking up one more special-interest group in his seemingly lopsided race against former Senator Bill Bradley.

title: Getting Into Character In Life-or-Death Fashion
description: The theater is by its very nature a con game. Starting with the playwright and the actors, down to the designer's paper moon and cardboard sea, all conspire to deceive the audience into buying into an illusion. And somewhere backstage is the mastermind of manipulation, the director, pulling all the strings that, if it works, will completely take us in for two or three hours and maybe, if we're lucky, show us something about ourselves we never before suspected.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Rogue Worth Knowing
description: As the song says: You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind's blowing. All you need, actually, is to look at the recent Iranian elections, where the Great Satan had a Great Week.

title: Richter Says He Will Play As Hasek Awaits Rangers
description: Mike Richter was on the ice today and said he would be ready to play Friday night when the Rangers travel to Buffalo for a game with playoff implications. But it wasn't Richter, who has missed six of nine games with an ailing left knee, who was being tested in practice.

title: EATON MAY SELL PART OF SEMICONDUCTOR UNIT TO PUBLIC
description: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to explore selling as much as 20 percent of its semiconductor equipment-making business to the public, capitalizing on the high demand for those products. Semiconductor equipment sales jumped almost 50 percent, to $397 million, in 1999. The Cleveland-based Eaton said on Jan. 24 that it expected semiconductor sales to rise an additional 30 percent in 2000 and to continue the increase for at least three more years. Eaton's shares jumped $12.4375, to $78, their biggest gain in more than a year. Before yesterday, they had fallen 4.8 percent in the last 12 months.

description: Five weeks into his tenure as New York City's interim schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy is trying mightily to shake things up.

title: J. C. Penney to Close 45 Department Stores
description: The J. C. Penney Company, which has lost $16 billion in stock market value in about two years, said yesterday that it would shut about 45 unprofitable department stores and 289 Eckerd drugstores as part of a plan to cut costs.

title: CANADA'S INFLATION EASES
description: Canada's inflation rate dropped to 2.3 percent in January from 2.6 percent in December, despite a huge increase in prices for gasoline and heating fuel, Statistics Canada reported. Gasoline cost 25 percent more than a year earlier, but some other costs -- notably for autos and air travel -- fell. Timothy Pritchard

title: After a Pardon and 39 Years, a Black Exile Comes Home
description: After 39 years of exile in Britain, Australia and Africa, Preston King finally woke up at home today in America.

title: Bush Keeps His Faith in Victory
description: It is easy enough for most people to muster a semblance of optimism that is not really there, to feign good cheer, to stare at a cluster of clouds and pick out only the silver linings.

title: Dow Ventures Below 10,000 But Rebounds
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell below 10,000 at four different times yesterday, but rebounded each time.

title: DIAGEO PROFITS RISE
description: Demand for hard liquor including Smirnoff vodka and Johnnie Walker Scotch whiskey pushed first-half profits up 3.5 percent, to $1.2 billion, at Diageo P.L.C., the world's biggest liquor concern, the company said. The rise in profits from liquor sales partly offset reduced margins in the Green Giant and Pillsbury food divisions, where analysts had expected bigger gains. Alan Cowell

title: In Return to University, Clinton Focuses on China and Economy
description: In 1992, the last time Bill Clinton talked economics at the University of Pennsylvania, he was a governor, times were tough, and his campaign manager kept saying, ''It's the economy, stupid.''

description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to send a heavily fortified peace monitoring mission to Congo, but delayed deploying it until the United Nations can be assured that the force will be safe and can operate effectively.

title: Park View: Two Views of Diallo Case
description: While the jury deliberated today in the trial of four New York police officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo, a carnival-like atmosphere prevailed outside the courthouse here. The drumbeats of a Japanese Buddhist nun echoed through the air, and a bus from Harlem unloaded about 40 protesters who waved antipolice placards while tramping through mud.

title: Pulsipher's Collapse Still Puzzles Mets
description: Bill Pulsipher does not want to think about what could have happened if his wife, Michelle, had not discovered him collapsed on the bathroom floor of their home Wednesday afternoon. He was unconscious and having trouble breathing, and his heart rate had dropped significantly.

title: Who wants to buy ad time on reality programming after the 'Multimillionaire' debacle?
description: MADISON AVENUE is joining in the chorus of catcalls being heard by the Fox Broadcasting Company in the wake of the embarrassing end to the ratings sweeps special ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?'' But opinion is divided over whether the hasty demise of the once-promising show will break up the shotgun wedding between television and the genre known as reality programming, even though Fox is promising to stop relying on such fare to fill gaps in its prime-time schedule.

title: Metro Business; Powered by Fuel Cells
description: United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had sold a $1 million fuel-cell system that will produce electricity for the Conde Nast building, at 4 Times Square.

title: Walter H. Zinn, 93, Physicist Who Helped Create Atom Bomb
description: Walter H. Zinn, a nuclear physicist who oversaw construction of the world's first nuclear reactor as part of the Manhattan Project, pioneered the development of commercial atomic reactors and was the first director of the Argonne National Laboratory, died on Feb. 14 at a hospital in Clearwater, Fla. A former resident of Connecticut, he was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, ALEXANDER
description: MOORE-Alexander. Alexander Moore of Cincinnati, Ohio and Yemassee, SC died Friday, February 18, 2000 in Colleton Medical Center in Walterboro, SC. Born August 3, 1923 in Bar Harbor, Maine, he was a son of Benjamin and Alexandra Emery Moore. He grew up in Long Island, NY. He graduated from Harvard University in 1949 (Class of 1946) with a degree in chemical engineering. A highly decorated pilot in World War II, he earned two Distinguished Flying Crosses and Seven Air Medals for his service with the Army Air Corps in the China-Burma-India Theatre. Passionate about the care and stewardship of land and wildlife habitat, he and his wife supported the S.C. Coastal Conservation League, Ducks Unlimited, Tall Timbers Research, the LowCountry Open Land Trust and the S.C. Waterfowl Association. He also supported the S.C. Historical Society, the Spoleto Festival in Charleston and the Johnson & Wales University in Charleston. He was a member of the Carolina Plantation Society and the Carolina Yacht Club. In Cincinnati he was a major contributor to the Emery Center and a number of other arts and educational organizations through the Greater Cincinnati Foundation. He also supported Harvard University and the renovation of the Fly Club at Harvard. He was a member of the River Club in New York and the Camargo Country Club in Cincinnati. Surviving are his wife, Jacqueline Griswold Moore; children, Christina Millet of Needham, Mass, Benjamin Moore of Milwaukee, Wis., Jessie ''Jay'' Reighley of South Freeport, Maine, Robert Moore of Freeport, Maine and Rosita Moore of Pownal, Maine; step-children, John Earls of Cincinnati, Ohio, David Earls of Kansas City Missouri, Christopher Earls of Cincinnati, Jeffrey Earls of Fairfield, Conn., and Michael Earls of St. Helena, Calif, 11 grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. A memorial service was held Sunday, February 20, 2000 at Combahee Plantation in Yemassee, SC. A second service is planned at a later date in Cincinnati. Burial will be in Laurelton Cemetery in Cold Spring Harbor, NY, according to the Fred Parker Funeral Home in Walterboro, SC. Donations may be made to the Low Country Open Land Trust, 456 King St, Charleston, SC 29403 or the organization of one's choice.

title: Panning for Nuggets in a Stream of Raucous Hilarity
description: Four hundred years ago, Ben Jonson's traveling companion William Drummond described the playwright as ''a great lover and praiser of himself, a contemer and scorner of others, given rather to lose a friend than a jest.'' Jonson's raucous play ''The Alchemist'' is a case in point. The language is uproarious. But there is such a flood of it that you wonder whether Jonson should have dropped some jokes and gained some fans.

title: Short-Term Treasury Prices Rise Amid Optimism on Inflation
description: Most Treasury securities rose in price yesterday on increasing optimism that the Federal Reserve will be successful in slowing growth enough to keep inflation from accelerating in the months ahead.

title: Two Art Fairs
description: ''The Art Show,'' sponsored by the Art Dealers Association of America, runs through Monday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue at 66th Street. Hours: Today, tomorrow and Sunday, noon to 7 p.m.; Monday, noon to 6 p.m. Admission is $12 a day, with all proceeds to benefit the Henry Street Settlement. A panel discussion, ''So Much Art, So Little Time: The Critic's Role in the Contemporary Art World,'' will be held today from 3 to 4:30 p.m. Information: (212) 940-8925.

title: Daniel T. Scannell Dies at 87; Led New York City Transit
description: Daniel T. Scannell, a former police officer who worked his way up to become head of New York City's subway and bus system and later held nearly every important executive job at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, died Tuesday at the Mary Manning Walsh nursing home in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The Path To a 'Psycho'

title: About Man and Nature, Both at War and at Peace
description: The documentary photographers who are members of Magnum Photos, the cooperative founded by Henri Cartier-Bresson and four other freelance photographers in 1947, share a fierce sense that photography is much more than aesthetics. As if holding fast to a dictum in the classic Cartier-Bresson book ''The Decisive Moment'' -- ''You must be on the alert with the brain, the eye, the heart, and have a suppleness of body'' -- Magnum photographers have roamed the earth to produce images that often stun the eyes, provoke the mind and stab at the heart.

Westcott, Lynn A. Ducommun and William F. Laporte, III, and devoted grandmother of eight children. Funeral service Monday February 28 at 11am at Saint James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NYC. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to The National Society of Colonial Dames in The State of New York, 215 E. 71st Street, NYC.

description: ''The Armory Show 2000: The International Fair of New Art'' began life six years ago in the bedrooms and bathrooms of the Gramercy Park Hotel. Suitcases served as storage space. Sculptures teetered on bedside tables. Pictures were taped to the walls.

title: A DROP AT ASTRAZENECA
description: The pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca P.L.C. reported a 3 percent drop in its fourth-quarter profits, and its stock fell to the lowest level since the company was formed last April. Fourth-quarter profit fell to $564 million from $583 million. The drop was attributed to higher spending on research to find a replacement for its anti-ulcer drug Prilosec, whose United States patent expires in April 2001. AstraZeneca is developing a successor to Prilosec, called Nexium, and said the drug looks better than Prilosec. ''This is going to be a megabrand,'' said Thomas McKillop, the chief executive. Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELER, INA
description: KESSELER-Ina. The Officers and Directors of the German American Partnership Program (GAPP) note with sadness the passing of our Board member and Vice President, Mrs. Ina Kesseler. Since the very inception of our Program, she has given wholeheartedly and unhesitatingly of her time and contributed generously to our projects. Her dedication, support and experience will be missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Werner Walbroel, President

title: Umpires Get New Union as Phillips Is Out
description: The controversial, often raucous 22-year reign of Richie Phillips as the major league umpires' labor leader came to a quiet end today with a three-paragraph pronouncement from the National Labor Relations Board.

title: A Thankful Few Advance in Match Play
description: Tiger Woods barely escaped defeat. Colin Montgomerie, Ernie Els and Lee Westwood were eliminated. And a tournament that began with 64 players has been reduced to a fortunate 16.

title: Kuwait, in a Switch, Agrees to Consider Increasing Output of Oil
description: In a shift that could set the stage for lower oil prices, Kuwait agreed today to at least consider raising output levels, joining other major petroleum exporters that appear to be leaning toward more production.

title: A Rich Mix of Styles and Stimulations Under One Roof
description: The Picasso count seems higher than ever at this year's version of ''The Art Show,'' the 12th annual trade fair staged by the Art Dealers Association of America. Many an exhibition booth holds a work or two by the maestro, seemingly a sort of benchmark that attests to the overall quality of the other wares on view. And perhaps by the same token, Miros, de Koonings and Franz Klines abound, along with more current icons like Warhol and Lichtenstein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERSTEIN, LES
description: ALPERSTEIN-Les. Dear Phyllis and family, we again express our sincere condolences for your loss of Les. He touched all our lives with his kindness and gentleness. He was enjoyable to be with, always having a positive pleasant attitude. Les was a role model to all who worked with him, for his dedication, application and ethics were incomparable. As the rabbi said today ''He was a true mensch.'' We shall miss him much. Judy and Harvey E. Rothenberg

title: Dole Urges End to Bush and McCain Attacks
description: Bob Dole, the Republican presidential candidate four years ago, stepped into the increasingly nasty race between Gov. George W. Bush and Sen. John McCain today and called for ''a time out'' in the candidates' assaults on each other.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Bare Bones Setting For Moral Comeuppance
description: In 1995 the Danish filmmakers Lars von Trier and Thomas Vinterberg promulgated a list of 10 principles -- the now notorious Dogma 95 ''vow of chastity'' -- in the hope of rescuing world cinema, once again, from decadent bourgeois individualism. To earn the Dogma 95 seal of approval, a film must forswear such emblems of false consciousness as props, genre conventions and ''temporal and geographical alienation.'' Cameras must be hand held, only available light and sound may be used and all traces of directorial personality, including the director's credit, must be expunged.

title: People
description: * David Steward was named to the new post of chief executive at Earthnoise.com, New York, a Web video-broadcasting service. Elan Dekel, who had served as interim chief executive, becomes president. Mr. Steward had most recently been president and chief executive at TV Guide magazine, New York, owned by TV Guide Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALINGER, FRANCES G. (CRYSTAL)
description: SALINGER-Frances G. (Crystal). Age 88, of Palm Beach, Florida. Passed away on February 23, 2000. Mrs. Salinger, formerly of New York, was active in many community, religious and charitable organizations. She was the second woman in the country elected President of a Jewish synagogue as well as serving as the United Nations Representative of the National Council of Jewish Women. She was a woman of uncommon strength, character, dignity and intelligence and admired by all whose lives she touched. She was the widow of Fabian M. Crystal and Benjamin D. Salinger. Loving mother of Richard (Marilyn) Crystal, Andrew Crystal and Libby (Robert) Rappaport. Beloved sister of Thomas, Marge and Richard Grumbacher, Ann Lowengard and the late Catherine Myers. Adoring grandmother of Deborah (Paul) Rosenberg; Daniel, Bryan and Emily Crystal; and Alex, David and Toni Reamer. Greatgrandmother to Courtney, Jacob and Samuel Reamer. Aunt Fran to countless nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held Friday, February 25th, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, N.Y. Family will receive friends Saturday night from 6PM to 9PM at the home of Richard Crystal, and Sunday from 2PM to 7PM at the home of Andrew Crystal. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the 92nd Street YM-YWHA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONOW, IRVING
description: ARONOW-Irving. Beloved husband of Annette. Devoted father of Janet Carlson (Karl), Arlene Sanders (Barry), Stephanie Shapiro (Marty). Adored grandfather of seven. Graveside services were held on February 25. ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY

title: DUBLIN BUILDING COMPANY ACQUIRES ASPHALT CONTRACTOR
description: The international building and construction company CRH P.L.C. said yesterday that it had acquired the privately held Shelly Company, a Thornville, Ohio, asphalt and paving contractor, for $362 million. The deal adds to CRH's Midwest holdings. Last year, the company, which is based in Dublin, acquired the Thompson-McCully Company, a road building company based in Belleville, Mich., for $422 million. CRH sees its latest acquisition as a growth opportunity, saying increased federal spending on highway projects is benefiting the two markets Shelly serves -- southern Ohio and West Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, LAWRENCE M.
description: ROSNER-Lawrence M. Beloved husband of Tobe, father of Caren, David and Susan. Grandfather of Ben, Jonah, Jennifer, Matthew and Emma. Services Sunday, 12 noon at the Westchester Reformed Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Hazing Scandal At High School Horrifies Town in Connecticut
description: After weeks of ominous rumors, officials in Trumbull, Conn., disclosed allegations of nightmarish hazing on a high school wrestling team yesterday, including charges that a 15-year-old boy had been hogtied, slammed into a wall, locked up for a half-hour several times in a gymnasium locker and held down once while teammates forced a plastic knife into his rectum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORRIS, ANNE
description: NORRIS-Anne. On February 22, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Sidney C., loving mother of Emily and the late Lee Rome and the late Jane and Julian Perlman, adoring grandmother of Tom, Josie and Andrew, cherished aunt and great-aunt of many. Service Friday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Radio Chief Presses U.S. to Do More About Missing Reporter
description: The American employer of a Russian reporter missing after covering the conflict in Chechnya accused the Clinton administration today of not pressing Moscow hard enough on his behalf.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is for a dog to live like this.''

title: Cheating on Statewide Tests Is Reported in Massachusetts
description: In the latest example of cheating on high-stakes standardized tests, administrators, teachers and students in at least 19 Massachusetts schools violated the rules when taking statewide exams last spring, according to a Boston Magazine article to be published on Tuesday.

title: Thompson Wins An NCR Account
description: The NCR Corporation has named the J. Walter Thompson Technology Communications Group in San Jose, Calif., part of the J. Walter Thompson unit of the WPP Group, to handle its worldwide account. Spending for 2000 was estimated at $36.5 million.

title: NYT Article
description: Brazil Carnival Turns Into Cyberfest

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKETT, LOIS KINSELLA
description: HACKETT-Lois Kinsella. Beloved wife and mother. Passed away Saturday, February 19. A memorial service on Saturday, February 26 will be held at Riverside Church, Christ Chapel, 12 noon.

title: In Making I.M.F. Choice, U.S. Must Decide Whom to Offend
description: The Clinton administration found itself at the center of a clash today that will force it to choose between angering close European allies or the world's developing nations in appointing the chief of one of the world's important financial institutions -- the International Monetary Fund.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Maurine Neuberger of Oregon, the third woman elected to the Senate, referred incorrectly to the precedent set by an earlier senator, Hattie Wyatt Caraway. She was the first woman elected to the Senate, not the first to serve there. The first to be seated -- though for only one day -- was Rebecca Latimer Felton; she was appointed.

title: Luanda Journal; For an Adrenaline Rush, Try an Angola Vacation
description: The cynics of the world might be doubtful, but Jorge Aliceres Valentim is a true believer. Someday soon, he declares, this fading, crumbling city will transform itself into a glimmering magnet for foreign tourists.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; It's The Stars' Cars That Steal the Scene
description: THEY have won Emmys and an Oscar. One has spent month after month on the best-seller lists, and one has risen to the top of the fashion world. So why are these celebrities, their wealth and social status assured, competing in beauty contests?

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: CNN Anchor Goes Coast to Coast

title: NYT Article
description: China Taps Shanghai for Internet Project

title: Public Interests; Read the Small Print
description: After years of complaining about low election turnouts, the Republican Establishment has been shocked to discover that when previously apathetic voters start showing up at the polls, they do not necessarily support the candidate you want them to support. Lucky for them that the primary campaign is now turning toward New York, the state that has made a science out of keeping its population at home on Election Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, GLORIA SHANNON
description: HALL-Gloria Shannon. On February 22, 2000 in Jupiter, FL. A resident of both Greenwich, CT., and Juno Beach Fl. She leaves her husband, Gordon B. Hall, Jr., her daughters, Diane Hall Juan, Meredith A. Hall and her sons, Dixon M. Hall II and Gordon B. Hall III. Visitation will be Sunday, February 27, 2000, 5 PM-7PM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home in Greenwich Ct. 203-869-1513. Services will be Monday, February 28, 11 AM at St Michael's Church, Greenwich Ct. Donations can be made to the Greenwich Chapter of the American Red Cross.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Without Barricades

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the oboist Ronald Roseman on Feb. 15 omitted a survivor. She is Gabrielle Anne Roseman, a daughter from his first marriage.

title: NYT Article
description: U.S. Lets Professor Put Encryption on Internet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERER, NORMA JEAN
description: LEDERER-Norma Jean, 69, on February 24 at Calvary Hospital after a three year fight against esophageal cancer. Musician, caterer and life force who commanded friends and admirers on the upper west side where she lived for more than 30 years, the West Coast, Switzerland and her native Chicago. Survived by her partner, Milton Moskowitz; daughter and son-in-law Patricia and Timothy Michaels, sister Patricia Taylor, and mother Hortense Harris. Contributions to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth-Israel Hospital.

title: Lowe Lintas Forms A Marketing Unit
description: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide in New York has formed a direct and retail marketing unit, Lowe Lintas Direct, by combining two divisions, APL Direct and Lowe Fox Pavlika, that had been part of the agencies that merged to form Lowe Lintas, Ammirati Puris Lintas and Lowe & Partners/SMS.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chairman of Fox Unit Vows To End 'Exploitative' Shows

title: St. John's Gathers Facts on Barkley
description: St. John's Athletic Director Ed Manetta Jr. said yesterday that the university is gathering information about Erick Barkley's tuition arrangement at a Maine prep school and has yet to report its findings to National Collegiate Athletic Association investigators.

title: U.S. Opens New Review of Ex-C.I.A. Chief's Case
description: The Justice Department said today that it had opened a new legal review of the mishandling of classified material by John M. Deutch, the former director of central intelligence.

title: Crackdown on Rebels Renews Fears of War and Terror in Turkey's Kurdish Region
description: Fears are mounting that the war and terror that plagued this Kurdish region for 15 years could flare again after a crackdown on officials accused of supporting Kurdish rebels and their jailed leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENDERGAST, MARIA (NEE NEALON)
description: PRENDERGAST-Maria (nee Nealon), on February 23, 2000. Native of Lacken, Killogeary, Co. Mayo, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Devoted mother of Michael, William, Mary and Kevin. Cherished grandmother of Meghan, Brandon, Kate and Mark. Loving sister of Sarah Healy. Reposing from 2-5 and 7-9 PM at McNulty Funeral Home, Inc., 3006 Middletown Road, Bronx, NY. Mass of Christian Burial at 10:30 AM Saturday at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, with interment in St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Marriott Companies in Settlement Of Lawsuit Brought by Investors
description: The Marriott hotel chain has tentatively agreed to pay more than $400 million to settle a series of lawsuits that contend it defrauded investors who had bought interests in its hotels in the late 1980's.

title: Pope Is in Egypt, Tracing Moses' Path and Urging Dialogue
description: Beginning a pilgrimage to retrace the steps of Moses, Pope John Paul II arrived in Egypt today seeking to use ancient biblical symbols to reduce modern religious tensions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROPPER, LILLIAN (LOLLY)
description: GROPPER-Lillian (Lolly). Age 96. Of Rockville Centre, NY. Loving and loved wife of the late Bernard. Mother of Judy and Ira Robinson, Susan and Leon Brachman. Grandmother of Ronni Adler and Douglas Robinson, Mitchell and Sheila Brachman and Linda Brachman. Great grandmother of Chelsea and Logan Adler, Erin and Rachel Brachman. We will miss her. Services Sunday, 11AM at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Rd.. Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Y2K Center on Alert for Leap Year Problems
description: Y2K Center on Alert for Leap Year Problems

title: Santa Would Surely Be Useful Right Now
description: As an actor, Ben Affleck often suggests one of the Kennedys playing Clark Kent: he wants to keep his light under a bushel, but he's not quite up to it. He looks as if he has never missed a party or a night's sleep. He's game, though, and his slight dislocation works to the advantage of ''Reindeer Games,'' the newest wheel-within-a-wheel script from Ehren Kruger (''Scream 3,'' ''Arlington Road''). As directed by John Frankenheimer, the movie (which has the best title of the year) is a lot of fun until it becomes, near the end, a Xerox of a blueprint for a hit.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 16 to 22 with 1,897 adults throughout the state. Of those, 1,440 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

title: From Virginia, an Outside Bid For 2 New York Nuclear Plants
description: A Virginia company made an unsolicited offer late today to buy the New York Power Authority's two nuclear power plants, Indian Point 3 in Buchanan, in Westchester County, and James A. FitzPatrick in Scriba, on Lake Ontario, creating the possibility of a bidding war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, JERRY
description: MARKS-Jerry. On February 24, 2000. Beloved husband of Caroline Marks. Cherished father of Alice Marks and devoted stepfather of Karobi and Susan Sachs. Also survived by many loving grandchildren. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, Fri, February 25th 12:15PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice. Friends may call after Friday afternoon at the home of Caroline Marks.

title: Oxford Health Returns to Profit in Quarter
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said today that it earned $268 million in the fourth quarter, reversing a loss in the quarter a year earlier and beating Wall Street's estimates.

title: Bradley Hit by Questions Raised by McCain's Success
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley opened a five-day stand today in Washington, a state he views as crucial to his insurgent campaign's survival, but he was dogged at almost every turn by questions about whether his campaign was suffering from the success of the Republican insurgent, Senator John McCain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLINE, CARROLL
description: CLINE-Carroll, died at home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan Thursday morning, February 24th, 2000. He is survived by Katherine, his wife of thirty years, his children, Henry and Rachel, and daughter-in-law, Patricia Wolff, his twin sister, Dorothy Yunghans, sister, Elizabeth Canady, and brother, Alan Cline. Memorial services to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Exploring the Classical and the Light Sides of Broadway
description: The ''Other Side of Broadway,'' according to the concert under that name produced and performed by Barbara Irvine at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night, is where the classical music grows. It is also the side on which most composers of musicals and film scores began their careers.

title: Shifting Views Over Abortion Fog Gore Race
description: In the fall of 1984, when President Ronald Reagan was on a triumphal march to re-election and Southern Democrats feared devastating losses across their region, Victor Ashe, a Republican candidate for Senate in Tennessee, was stalled and frustrated in his campaign against Al Gore Jr.

title: Report of China Delay Hurts Qualcomm
description: Qualcomm Inc. shares fell 4.9 percent today after a report said that China had delayed plans to build a digital mobile phone network using the company's technology.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: France, Philosophy and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Mr. Smith' Goes to DVD
description: ''He should have seen it coming but didn't,'' Frank Capra Jr. said the other day. By 1939 his father, who died in 1991, had directed films like ''It Happened One Night'' and ''Mr. Deeds Goes to Town.'' When he went to Washington to plan ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' released this week in a fine DVD edition by Columbia Tri-Star, his reputation helped speed the preparations. ''He had some very good help from the Senate and the Washington press corps,'' Mr. Capra said.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS BELOW $1. The euro slipped after a European Central Bank official dampened prospects of an interest rate rise in the near future. In New York, the euro closed at 99.33 cents, down from $1.0029 on Wednesday.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: In stark terms, a meal at Avra is a blind date with a fish. The concept, a success at other Greek restaurants like Estiatorio Milos and Trata in Manhattan and Elias Corner in Astoria, is simple and apparently irresistible. The customer picks out a whole fish, priced by the pound, from a lineup of glistening beauties arrayed on a bed of ice. Then the restaurant grills it.

title: Owner Is Killed at His East Side Restaurant
description: One of the owners of an Upper East Side trattoria was found dead in the restaurant's kitchen yesterday, the victim of an apparent slashing attack, the police said.

title: Monuments to the Thai Debt; Real Estate Fiascoes Rear Their Heads On Bangkok Skyline
description: At night, the beer garden outside the World Trade Center shopping center here fills with some of the thousands of customers who have recently begun returning to the mall, its movie theater, its ice-skating ring and its Pizza Hut -- as sure a sign as any that this Southeast Asian economy has turned the corner.

title: In Sleepy Suburbia, a Total Eclipse of the Heart
description: ''Judy Berlin'' was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times last March 26. The film opens today in New York City.

title: Police Say Web Site Was Sham to Sell Drugs
description: The Web site for Biotech International looked like a legitimate Internet advertisement. But the New York police said yesterday that Biotech was a fraud, and that the Web site served as a billboard for a sham company that offered so-called date-rape drugs for sale around the world.

title: MARTHA STEWART TO BUY BACK SOME SHARES FROM TIME INC.
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc. agreed yesterday to repurchase about 1.4 million of its shares from Time Warner's Time Inc. for $23.79 each -- below current market value -- in a transaction valued at $32.5 million. Time Inc. will retain 1.22 million shares for about three years. Time Inc. also agreed to extend the term of its magazine distribution, fulfillment and services agreements with Martha Stewart for an additional three years. The shares of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia were down $1.4375, to $26.5625. The company had its initial public offering in October at $18 a share.

title: Souls Lost and Found Connected by a Newborn
description: ''We are not called upon to do great tasks, but everyday tasks,'' Mother Superior (Sonia Gessner) tells her young nuns in her even, unruffled tone. In ''Not of This World,'' it is sometimes a great task to get through the everyday. Everyone in this loamy soap opera seems slightly depressed -- even Sister Caterina (Margherita Buy), the focus of most of the film. She is roused from her commitment to God and the church when a jogger (Stefano Abbati) stops long enough to light up a smoke and hand her a newborn boy that he found on his run.

title: Jurors to Rehear Testimony And Elements of Defense
description: The jurors in the Amadou Diallo murder trial returned to the courtroom at 10:40 last night after a second day of deliberations and asked to hear again some of the testimony from officers that they had heard reread on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, FREDERIC S.
description: PRICE-Frederic S. Beloved son of Ruth and the late Harry Price. Contributions in his memory may be made to UJA-Federation of New York.

title: Little Accord in a Round Table of Diet Experts
description: Several of the nation's best-known nutritionists and diet promoters agreed on very little today when they sat down for what the Agriculture Department billed as ''the great nutrition debate.''

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, SAMUEL S.
description: SCHIFF-Samuel S. Died on February 19, 2000 after a long illness. Widower of Isabelle Pendleton Schiff, with whom he shared a wonderful life for 57 years, who died in October 1998. Beloved brother of Ester Schiff Rom, brother-in-law of Philip Rom and uncle to Alan Jay Rom, Louis Rom and their families. Veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade; contribution to Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives honors his memory, 799 Broadway, Suite 227, New York, New York 10003.

title: Steady Hand, Stirring Hopes
description: Dawn was an orange pinstripe, and already Temple's basketball team was 30 minutes into its daily practice. The assistant coaches handle the first half-hour each morning, the shaking out of stiffness from the legs and sleep from the eyes. The head coach John Chaney arrived a few minutes later, his 68 years visible in his knees, a slight limp in his gait. But he walked purposefully toward his team at the far basket, his feet pointed in the youthful pigeon-toe of a point guard.

title: INSIDE
description: Oil Prices Could Decline

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINET, DENNIS
description: BINET-Dennis. Age 76, on Feb. 19, 2000. Survived by his partner, Toni Sacks, and her family, his sons, Larry & Tommy, & their families; four grandchildren; two greatgrandchildren; nieces and nephews & many friends. Hungarian immigrant, served in US Army in WWII, co-founder of 47 year old Universal Elevator Company, Inc. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to a cancer-related organization or other charity or hospice of your choice. Memorial service Sunday Feb 27th at 1:45PM at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. A gathering to celebrate his life immediately following at Empire Hotel, 44 W. 63rd St., Mezzanine Ballroom, 3:30-5:30PM.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Broker Site Is Disrupted In New Attack On Internet
description: NDB, an online broker, was cut off for more than an hour yesterday because of what it said was an attack by computer vandals that was similar to those against several prominent Web sites earlier this month.

title: A Cat Now and for 17 Years (Nearly Forever)
description: HERE we have a woman who has been in the cast of ''Cats'' the length of its lengthy run: 17 years, 9 months of putting on the yak hair wig and the tail, painting on the whiskers, crawling around the stage on all fours and being flung thither and yon in a junkyard set.

title: Group Led by Softbank Wins Right to Buy Nippon Credit
description: A group led by the Softbank Corporation of Japan, a global leader in Internet-related investments, won the negotiating rights to buy the Nippon Credit Bank, one of two failed banks nationalized by the government in the depths of the country's financial crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROYAL, AMELIA R.
description: ROYAL-Amelia R. On Feb. 22, 2000, age 97 years of Medford, NJ. Formerly of Manhattan. Wife of the late Peyton K. Survived by a nephew, Henry Rianhard of Bozrah, CT., and a niece, Alice R. Tenbeau of Warren, VT. A Memorial service will be held in March at Medford Leas, Medford, NJ.

title: Hans van Bentem
description: Garth Clark Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, PETER H.
description: FREEDMAN-Peter H. Of Miami, FL on February 21, 2000 in his 40th year. Son of Dr. Edward S. Freedman of Lancaster, PA and Reva M. Rohlfs of Exton, PA. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from Temple Shaarai Shomayim, 508 N. Duke St. Lancaster, PA on Sunday at 11:30AM with Rabbi Jack P. Paskoff officiating. Entombment in Roosevelt Memorial Park, Philadelphia, PA. The family will receive friends at the Temple on Sunday from 10:30AM until time of service. In lieu of flowers memorials may be sent to the Betty Finney House, 40 W. Orange Street, Lancaster, PA 17603. Fred Groff Funeral Home, 717-397-8255.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
A Treacherous Undertow Mars an Endless Summer
description: ...And they'll be bummed, bummed, bummed now that Daddy took their manhood away.

title: Fred Cray
description: Richard Anderson

title: NYT Article
description: Microsoft Foils Hacker Assault on Web Site

title: Woman Critically Injured In Upper Manhattan Fire
description: A woman was critically injured and 200 people were left temporarily homeless yesterday after a four-alarm fire broke out in an apartment building in Upper Manhattan.

title: Russian War Crimes?
description: To the Editor:

title: '175th Annual Exhibition'
description: National Academy of Design

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Toward a Sensible Homeless Policy
description: New York City and advocates for the homeless have been battling for 20 years over policies that govern the housing of the city's most vulnerable men, women and children. The advocates captured the legal high ground in the case of Callahan vs. Carey in 1981, in which the city signed a consent decree conceding that single homeless men had a right to public shelter. This protection was extended to homeless families with children in 1986.

title: For Theatergoers
description: Theatergoers looking for a place to eat in or near Times Square have more choices these days. Here are a dozen options, including some old favorites and some newcomers. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHRENSTEIN, PAULINE
description: OHRENSTEIN-Pauline. Of Delray Beach, Fla. died at her home on Wednesday, February 23, 2000 at the age of 87. She was pre-deceased by her husband Louis in 1992. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law Carole and Ken Mersel of New City, N.Y. and her sister Mary Karmazin of Hallandale, Fla. She was also survived by her 3 granddaughters Fran, Jill and Mindy. For more information contact Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, N.Y. 10977. 914-356-8600.

title: Trivia Is a Male Pursuit
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stroganoffs: Wealth and Taste
description: The truth of an old Russian saying, ''Richer than the Stroganoffs you'll never be,'' can be appreciated in ''Stroganoff: The Palace and Collections of a Russian Noble Family,'' an exhibition of 230 works of art that opened last week at the Portland Art Museum in Oregon.

title: WESTAFF EVALUATES $159 MILLION MANAGEMENT BUYOUT BID
description: The staffing company Westaff Inc. said yesterday that it was evaluating a $159 million buyout offer from an investment group that included members of Westaff's management. The buyout group is offering $10 a share of Westaff. The shares were down 6.25 cents, to $8.1875. Westaff said it had been disappointed with its margins overseas, especially in Australia. Last year, Westaff sold its medical services division. Westaff, which provides temporary employees, has about 360 offices in the United States, Britain, Australia, New Zealand, Norway and Denmark.

title: Coley Is Nowhere In Ads for His Fight
description: Oscar De La Hoya's face stands 50 feet high on an HBO billboard in Times Square. ''DE LA HOYA,'' it says. ''LIVE FROM MADISON SQUARE GARDEN.''

title: Ballot Initiative That Would Thwart Gay Marriage Is Embroiling California
description: Its proponents call it the ''California Protection of Marriage Initiative,'' a way to prevent gay and lesbian couples from marrying in another state, then moving to California and asking that their unions be ruled valid here.

title: More Jobs for All Ages
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Consider Life After Strawberry
description: The Darryl Strawberry watch trudged into its second day today with the Yankees and their fans wondering about his perilous future while waiting for a ruling from Commissioner Bud Selig. The Yankees worked out without Strawberry at Legends Field, but the distraction continued to hover over them.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: TRACY CHAPMAN: ''Telling Stories'' (Elektra). Tracy Chapman is one of those quiet ones you have to watch. She speaks not for the cool, who hold their tongues, but for the shy, who struggle to say things that won't misrepresent them. Her plain melodies and simple lyrics serve the confessions people usually can't bear to make.

title: Why Lowering Crime Didn't Raise Trust
description: As the trial of the four white police officers accused of murdering Amadou Diallo draws to a close, I am reminded of a recent conversation I had with Zachary Carter, the former United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS HIRES FIRM TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had hired the investment banking firm of Warburg Dillon Read L.L.C. to explore strategic alternatives to increase shareholder value. ICN, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., makes and sells a wide range of prescription and over-the-counter drugs. The company said the review would focus mainly on its Eastern European operations and the three businesses of ICN's Biomedicals group. Shares of ICN were up 6.25 cents at $21.

title: Lautenberg Backs Corzine As His Successor in Senate
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who won election 18 years ago as a millionaire businessman who had never held elective office, tonight endorsed Jon S. Corzine, another wealthy newcomer to politics, as his successor, over former Gov. Jim Florio.

title: 3 Luxury-Car Makers to Leave New Jersey
description: The Jaguar, Aston Martin and Volvo car companies are leaving their North American headquarters in New Jersey and heading for California, to be closer to the wealth and trendiness of the West Coast market.

title: 'Artists Books'
description: Brooklyn Museum of Art

title: After Wedding Fiasco, Fox Vows No More Exploitation
description: Sandy Grushow, the chairman of the Fox Television Entertainment Group who canceled ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?'' last week after it blew up in Fox's face, said yesterday that the network would never again turn to the kind of programming that made such shows as ''When Good Pets Go Bad'' and ''World's Scariest Police Videos'' part of the prime-time landscape.

title: Candidate For Mayor Drops Out
description: Fran Reiter, a former senior adviser and campaign manager for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani who last year joined a crowded field of Democrats in the 2001 mayoral race, said yesterday that she was withdrawing because she had failed to attract enough financial support or media attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSHALL, G. WILLIAM
description: PARSHALL-G. William. Of Sudbury, MA, February 23, 2000. Husband of Anne (Perkins) and the late Mary Lou (Larpenteur), father of B. Lynne Parshall and her husband David Bromley of Carlsbad, CA and Richard W. Parshall and his wife Janet Lee of Washington, NJ, grandfather of Jennifer and Sarah Bromley and William Dale Parshall. Memorial services in Sudbury United Methodist Church, 251 Old Sudbury Rd, Sudbury Center, Saturday, February 26 at 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be sent to: Tufts Veterinary School, 200 Westboro Rd., N. Grafton, MA 01536 or The Massachusetts Audubon Society, 208 S. Great Rd., Lincoln, MA 01773.

title: Like It or Not, Henderson Says He's Needed
description: Steve Phillips strode out of the Mets' clubhouse today and opened the door to his recurring nightmare: Rickey Henderson talking to the news media.

title: Drug Lapse and Relapse
description: To the Editor:

title: Take Me to the Planets
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the International Narcotics Control Board, a United Nations body based in Vienna, misstated the number of board members. It is 13, not 26.

title: Italians Irked as Official Defends Delayed Race
description: There was no disputing the fact that the wind conditions that led to the cancellation of Race 3 for the America's Cup between the Prada Challenge from Italy and Team New Zealand were light, fluky and highly variable.

title: Little Films, Big City: A Love Story; New Yorkers Get Attention, If Not Riches, After Sundance
description: The morning after Peter Sollett flew back to New York from the Sundance Film Festival, the buzzing of his pager woke him at 6. A production company wanted him to install a film editing computer system, something Mr. Sollett has been doing to pay the bills.

title: An Afghan Mosaic of Misery: Hunger, War and Repression
description: As snow melted on his cheeks, the tall, stout man -- a father of seven -- reached past the firm red apples on a vendor's pushcart and began to choose from the rotting ones, assessing the brown and the speckles and the mushiness.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Random Hearts

title: Wanted: American SWF's With a Thirst for Blarney
description: ''Lush green fields . . . tiny villages by the sea.'' The young narrator of ''The Closer You Get'' is dutiful enough to keep the boredom out of his voice, but the theater will fill with tired sighs from the audiences attending another high-concept Irish Spring comedy -- collect 'em all! -- from the folks at Fox Searchlight. After the success of ''The Full Monty'' and the, er, release of ''Waking Ned Devine,'' apparently someone felt that the hunger for comedy featuring pale, badly dressed, hearty men clutching pints of stout hadn't quite been satisfied yet.

title: A TKTS Booth for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Feb. 10 with an article about attacks against several Web sites referred imprecisely to the durations of the interruptions. Keynote Systems, a company that measures Internet performance, supplied data ranging from the point of less than 5 percent availability to the point of at least 80 percent availability. The sites were not necessarily blocked altogether during the periods shown, and some say their disruptions were shorter than indicated. The sites and the times they observed were Amazon, 1 hour 7 minutes; Buy.com, 3 hours 10 minutes; E*Trade, 1 hour; Yahoo, 3 hours 10 minutes; ZDNet, 2 hours 32 minutes.

title: On Health Care, Gore or Bradley?
description: To the Editor:

title: With Childs Yelling Charge, Knicks Storm Back
description: Chris Childs began his evening by answering questions about how fortunate he felt to still be a Knick. His name had been prominent in trade speculation, and he was supposed to speak enthusiastically about remaining in New York.

title: New Jersey Looks West For Advice On Flood Aid
description: It is not that the public officials in Somerset County were not happy for their counterparts in Grand Forks, N.D., who explained in a video teleconference tonight how far along they were in recovering from a devastating flood in 1997.

title: Rage Boils Over, and Some Shout 'Murderers' at Police
description: Since the day Amadou Diallo was shot at 1157 Wheeler Avenue, the building has served as a focal point for anger over the shooting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHR, LEO
description: LEHR-Leo, 82, passed away on February 25, 2000 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Shirley, adored father of Janet & Gerald Lazar and Marilyn Lehr. Grandfather of David & Amy Lazar, Jeffrey Lazar and Deborah and Paul Galant. Cherished grandsons William and Andrew Galant, Michael Lazar. Surviving sister, Helen Mark and brother, Sidney Lehr. He will be dearly missed by all of his family and friends for his strength and courage, wonderful heart and sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Parkinson Foundation. Graveside service to be held on Sunday, February 27, 2000 at 2:00PM at Montefiore Cemetery in Springfield Gardens, Queens.

title: City to Replace Largest Homeless Shelter in Part With Brooklyn Site
description: The Giuliani administration plans to replace the city's largest shelter for homeless men, on the East Side of Manhattan, in part with a shelter in a former factory in the East Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The nonprofit Doe Fund would buy the building, renovate it and run the new shelter under a $180 million, 22-year contract, according to a legal notice in the City Record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLINGER, LEONARD, N., M.D.
description: HALLINGER-Leonard, N., M.D., age 81, in Sarasota, FL. Beloved husand of Carol; father of Nina, Philip and Todd; grandfather of Nathan and Joshua. Loved and respected by the many whose lives he touched. Todd and Colleen Hallinger will be receiving at home on February 27th, between 1-5PM.

title: Study Casts Disputed Map As False Link to Vikings
description: A study conducted in preparation for an exhibition on the Vikings at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington in April has concluded that the Vinland Map, which purports to show that Norse explorers charted North America long before the voyages of Columbus, is almost certainly a fake.

title: Medical Report Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The NYC column yesterday, about the high emotions surrounding the Amadou Diallo case, referred imprecisely to remarks by the Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson, at a bail hearing last year. Mr. Johnson said the four police officers who shot Mr. Diallo should be treated ''like any other individual who would have rolled up in front of a building, pulled out a gun and commenced to fire at another individual with the intent to cause their death.'' The phrase ''drive-by shooting'' should not have appeared in quotation marks.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Criticizes China

title: Newark Officers Suspended For Actions in Haircut Case
description: Two days after the Newark police hauled an 11-year-old girl away from her school and to a holding cell on assault charges for surreptitiously cutting a lock of another student's hair, three police supervisors have been suspended from duty and are facing administrative charges.

title: Baruch Wins Title
description: After losing by 28 points in their only previous trip to the City University of New York Athletic Conference championship, Coach Ray Rankis and his Baruch Statesmen upset York by 52-50 last night, ending York's 15-game winning streak and giving Baruch its first CUNY tournament title.

title: NATWEST POSTS A GAIN
description: Britain's third-largest bank, National Westminster Bank P.L.C., which succumbed earlier this month to a hostile bid from the Royal Bank of Scotland, said its profit increased 6.4 percent, to $:1.67 billion, up from $:1.57 billion a year ago. The bank posted second-half net income, which dropped to $:853 million, from $:876 million in the period a year earlier. The bank also said it had spent $:65 million, or $104 million, defending itself against its hostile suitors in its failed effort to remain independent. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: 4,000 Serbs Vow to Defend Town Sector In Kosovo
description: Four thousand Serbs rallied here today and promised to defend the Serbian district of this ethnically divided town. They called for international peacekeepers to organize a plan to let them return to their houses.

title: Times Co. to Sell 7 of Its Small Newspapers
description: The New York Times Company announced plans yesterday to sell some of its small newspapers and all nine of its telephone directories to devote more attention to its larger regional newspapers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELIKER, JOHN
description: HELIKER-John. We mourn the passing of John Heliker, artist and friend for over 50 years. His gentle and sensitive nature lives on in his art. Kraushaar Galleries

title: Campaign Cools Friendship Between McCain and Phil Gramm
description: It was a small but telling slip.

title: City's Trash Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died Feb. 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILLINGER, JAMES J.
description: PILLINGER-James J. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Devoted father of Marc and Ava,Michael and Judy. Dear brother of Ray Pillinger and Helen Diamond. Adored grandfather of Mara, Ian, Kaley. Services Sunday, 10:30AM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Drug Experts Report a Boom In Ecstasy Use
description: Some of the small tablets are shaped like the familiar Playboy magazine rabbit ears and are known as Bunnies. Others are called Buddhas because they bear his likeness. Some are stamped with the Nike swoosh, a shamrock or Dino the Dinosaur.

title: YOUR TAXES
description: A step-by-step guide to completing Form 1040, with articles focusing on some of the thorniest issues: stock options, disaster losses and filing in more than one state. Also: A look at the tax proposals of contenders for the presidency. A special Part 2 of Money & Business.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 18 about a lawsuit filed by Charlie Chaplin's heirs against Israel's national lottery, for unauthorized use of his character in advertising, misstated a comment made by Woody Allen recently about 20th-century comic geniuses. He said they numbered six -- Chaplin, W. C. Fields, Buster Keaton, Groucho and Harpo Marx, and Peter Sellers -- not just Chaplin and Fields.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; INTEREST IN SERFIN
description: Mexico's largest banking company, Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival, known as Banacci, is interested in buying Grupo Financiero Serfin, which was the country's third-largest bank before it was taken over by the government in a bailout. Banacci said it would pay $25,000 to take part in the first stage of the Serfin sale. Banacci wants to get a look at Serfin's financial records before deciding whether to make an offer. Others that have expressed interest in Serfin include Mexico's second-largest bank, Bancomer; two of Spain's biggest banks, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya and Banco Santander; and Citibank Mexico. Dan Fineren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAULTASCH, ARTHUR
description: MAULTASCH - Arthur. Passed away February 24, 2000. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Loving husband of Bernice. Adored father of Ronni (Michael) Blitstein and Rick (Carol) Maultasch. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Jennifer and Alyssa. Services at 11 AM Sunday, February 27, 2000 at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: 2nd Gunman in Pizza Delivery Slayings Sentenced to 51 Years
description: The second defendant in the 1997 ambush killing of two pizza deliverymen was sentenced today to at least 51 years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, ETTA
description: FINK-Etta. On February 24, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Isidor. Loving mother of Lyn, Michael and David. Adored sister of Mildred Shipman and Paul Janofsky. Graveside service Sunday, February 27, 10:45 A.M. at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: The Crucial Defense Element: the Judge's Instruction
description: By this afternoon, what had once seemed unlikely that a jury would find four officers blameless in the killing of Amadou Diallo -- seemed almost inevitable. Soon after hearing lengthy legal instructions and beginning deliberations on Wednesday, the seven white men, one white woman and four black women seemed to begin what one defense lawyer called ''an inexorable march'' toward acquittal.

title: Without Mom's Blessing, a Marathoner Drives On
description: Kim Pawelek was 15 months old in April 1975 when she, her sister and their parents were airlifted out of Saigon during the American departure from Vietnam.

title: Remaining With the Mets Is the Best Option for Payton
description: To the Mets, Jay Payton has that extra something, whatever it is and however it is defined. The outfield prospect strikes the ball hard, and loudly, with uncommon force. He is not the kind of player the Mets want to give away.

title: 'Gifted' Traps Parents and Their Children, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Experiments at Stanford Shake Dark-Matter Claim
description: A team of physicists announced today that a highly sensitive experiment at Stanford University to detect the so-called dark matter particles that could account for most of the mass in the universe had contradicted a stunning and controversial announcement by a team of Italian and Chinese physicists last week that they had detected the elusive particles.

title: Hazing Is Team Tradition, A Defendant's Lawyer Says
description: Even as residents here reacted with astonishment to allegations that a high school wrestler was brutalized by older teammates in a series of violent hazing rituals, a lawyer for one of the students facing criminal charges said today that sports team initiation rites were a Trumbull High School tradition that took place with the full knowledge of school officials.

title: The Diallo Verdict
description: Yesterday's verdict of not guilty for the four New York City police officers who killed Amadou Diallo cannot erase the traumatic effect this case has had on the city's collective consciousness. The shooting enraged those who thought that Mr. Diallo had been victimized solely because of his race. It also stirred deep feelings of uncertainty about police aggression. The verdict does not address these profound concerns, nor does it vindicate the police practices and belief patterns that made this grievous error possible.

title: Elliot A. Caplin, 86, Writer Who Devised Comic Strip Plots
description: Elliot A. Caplin, a writer who worked in deep obscurity to produce the plot lines for scores of cartoon strips, died on Sunday at his home in Stockbridge, Mass. He was 86.

title: Women Win a Battle, but Job Bias Still Rules Japan
description: When Tomoko Haneda took a job at Sharp Electronics in 1963, she dreamed of building a career, of working hard and of being rewarded for her labors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWIT, FRANCES
description: COWIT-Frances. Loving wife of the late Henry. Cherished mother of Gerald and Joel. Devoted grandmother of Stephen, Lawrence, Ronald, Ricky, Debbie and Lana. Great grandmother of nine. Special thanks to Judy for her loving care. Funeral service Sunday, February 27, at 10:30AM at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL SURGES. Crude oil prices set nine-year highs after a Saudi Arabian minister dampened the outlook for more output. In New York, crude oil for delivery in April closed at $30.35 a barrel, up from $29.97 on Thursday.

title: Another Finn Tests Positive for Drugs
description: While men's cross-country skiers, including the eventual gold medalist Johann Muehlegg of Spain, battled bitter cold and fatigue over 50 kilometers (31 miles) in the final race of the Nordic world ski championships in Lahti, Finland, Finnish team officials were disclosing that another one of their athletes had tested positive for a banned substance.

title: Arizona Democrats Given U.S. Approval for Internet Primary
description: Arizona Democrats Given U.S. Approval for Internet Primary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLISON, WALTER
description: WALLISON-Walter, on February 24, 2000, at the age of 93, and even then too soon. The beloved husband of Pearl, adored father of Peter and Frieda, and Jane and Hugh, revered grandpa to Ethan, Jeremy, Elizabeth and George, Rebecca, and Amanda, a gentle, loving and inspiring friend and companion to his adoring family, he chose his path to the very end, and will live always in our memories. For more information, please call Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, (201) 843-9090.

title: A Voice Fits the Mezzo Definition to a Trill
description: The great mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne has often said, only half jokingly, that quite a few opera conductors she has worked with think that most mezzos are, in fact, just lazy sopranos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, BEA
description: RUBIN-Bea. Beloved wife of the late Ira. Devoted sister of Leona. Cherished aunt and great aunt. Wonderful confidante to friends of each generation. Lover of art, opera, music and ballet. Her spirit, compassion, intelligence, and conversation will be missed by all who knew her. Memorial Service on February 27 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad, Mt. Vernon at 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Ira Rubin Memorial Fund at Montefiore Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINET, DENNIS
description: BINET-Dennis. Age 76, on Feb. 19, 2000. Survived by his partner, Toni Sacks, and her family, his sons, Larry & Tommy, & their families; four grandchildren; two greatgrandchildren; nieces and nephews & many friends. Hungarian immigrant, served in US Army in WWII, co-founder of 47 year old Universal Elevator Company, Inc. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to a cancer-related organization or other charity or hospice of your choice. Memorial service Sunday Feb 27th at 1:45PM at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. A gathering to celebrate his life immediately following at Empire Hotel, 44 W. 63rd St., Mezzanine Ballroom, 3:30-5:30PM.

title: Shinnecocks Interrupt Construction of Housing
description: The Shinnecock Indians of eastern Long Island won a temporary restraining order yesterday halting the construction of a 38-house subdivision near their 800-acre reservation in Southampton.

title: An Ugly Lapse of 17 Seconds Keeps the Devils Sliding
description: In a season this good, the Devils were due for a skid like this one. Now they must wonder: how long will it last?

title: Verdict Trumps TV Schedule
description: The news that the jury had reached a verdict in the trial of the death of Amadou Diallo was first reported on New York 1 News late yesterday afternoon, but moments later all the major cable news channels and most of the city's local stations dropped their programming to tune to the reading of the verdict.

title: Exploring Payton's Place, Where Jazz Languages Meet
description: Success in the jazz business can mean a lot of touring, and a lot of touring can mean a bona fide group sound: the sort of thing that's crucial to jazz and that casual listeners often take for granted. The career of the strong, self-assured trumpeter Nicholas Payton has been an example: now on his fourth album for Verve/ Universal (''Nick @ Night''), released last month, he has achieved record sales that are more than respectable for mainstream jazz and has managed to keep the same core of players together for four years.

title: The Kaplan-Sheinwold Legacy: A System a Team Can Agree On
description: Most expert partnerships have sophisticated bidding agreements that are nullified when they have to separate. The Betty Kaplan Teams, played in Manhattan two weeks ago, presented a challenge, because the players were required to rotate partners.

title: Ohio Like Michigan, With Higher Hurdles
description: This state resembles Michigan in its demographics and politics, and on March 7, Senator John McCain hopes to replicate here his stunning victory in the Michigan Republican primary on Tuesday.

title: Redefining Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: With a Rematch Looming, De La Hoya Won't Retreat
description: In his last fight, against Felix Trinidad, Oscar De La Hoya held back, because he wanted to save something for the finish. He did, but when it was over, he was done as the World Boxing Council welterweight champion. Trinidad lifted his title on a controversial split decision, primarily because De La Hoya retreated in the last four rounds.

title: Rhode Island and Slavery? How Much to Read Into an Old Name
description: If the presidential candidates thought they were finished with bitter and parochial historical debates like whether the Confederate flag should fly over South Carolina's state capitol, they were mistaken. Tiny Rhode Island, which will hold its primary on March 7, could offer another uncomfortable controversy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Jones Falls 230 Points, To End the Week at 9,862

title: South Africa's Embattled Press
description: Redressing a tradition of racist journalism was bound to be one of the most important and complex challenges for South Africa's fledgling multiracial democracy. But a campaign by a government-appointed commission to coerce journalists into answering charges of racism discredits that legitimate cause and undermines an otherwise impressive record of respect for constitutional freedoms.

title: T. H. Watkins, 63, Environmental Writer and Historian
description: T.H. Watkins, a historian of the American West, a magazine editor and a prolific writer on environmental issues, died on Wednesday at his home in Bozeman, Mont. He was 63.

title: Lehman Paid Its Chief $16.8 Million in '99
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. paid its chairman and chief executive, Richard Fuld, $16.8 million last year, up 26 percent from 1998, after a record year for earnings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, ALVIN
description: SCHNEIDER-Alvin. On February 24, 2000. Devoted husband of the late Carolyn. Loving father of Steven, Elyse and Pam. Dear brother of Edward. Cherished companion of Sara. He will be missed by everyone. Memorial service on Sunday, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Saving Gas, and Lives
description: To the Editor:
