description: MARKS-Jerry. On February 24, 2000. Beloved husband of Caroline Marks. Cherished father of Alice Marks and devoted stepfather of Karobi and Susan Sachs. Also survived by many loving grandchildren. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, Fri, February 25th 12:15PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice. Friends may call after Friday afternoon at the home of Caroline Marks.

title: St. John's Focuses on Duke, Not N.C.A.A. Investigation
description: For two hours today, St. John's will forget about investigators. Instead, the Red Storm will remember it is a near lock for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and take an early measure of itself against the No. 2-ranked team in the nation: Duke.

title: Le Big Mac, This Was Not; Meal Fit for a President With the Aid of a Chef Barely Fit for the Kitchen
description: The question is, what did the president know and when did he know it? Did he know about me and the lobster salad he ate at that three-star restaurant on Thursday night? Or me and the mushrooms?

title: Abroad at Home; Willie Horton Redux
description: In a penetrating and otherwise critical piece on George W. Bush in The New York Review of Books, Lars-Erik Nelson called him ''an intelligent man with a formidable memory, enormous charm and a sense of humor.'' By Texas Republican standards, he added, Governor Bush is a moderate.

title: Yankees Won't Rush To Fill the Hole at D.H.
description: Darryl Strawberry was the chrome in the Yankees' lineup, a gaudy presence. He intimidated pitchers and launched mammoth home runs, but the Yankees' offense was not any less functional in those many months when he was not around, which is why club officials will most likely wait to decide on a replacement.

title: Big Gap in Screening U.S. Infants for Hereditary Ills
description: Two babies: Mubashir Younis and Bryce Burke. Both were born with rare metabolic diseases. But one was lucky in the time and place of his birth, and one was not.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: When Childhood Becomes a Disorder
description: To the Editor:

title: At a Brooklyn Precinct, Tension, Then Jubilation
description: At the 84th Precinct in downtown Brooklyn, the officers on duty started gathering in the lounge when word came that the verdict would soon be announced. It would be ridiculous to say that the half-dozen patrolmen who gathered were anxious or concerned or rapt. It was more than that: a tidal wave could have engulfed the neighborhood and still they would have sat there, waiting, listening, eyes glued to the set.

title: Stepping Into the Breach With Style and Subtlety
description: What a wonderful reservoir of talent the New York City Ballet is. That was demonstrated when the young Abi Stafford replaced the injured Miranda Weese in the leading female role of George Balanchine's ''Ballo Della Regina.''

title: Europeans Deplore Executions in the U.S.
description: An average person in France could not help but be familiar with the case of Betty Lou Beets, the Texas woman who was executed on Thursday for killing her fifth husband. Her story, with particular attention to her assertion that she was abused by her father and husbands, has been on the front page of many newspapers here.

title: NYT Article
description: Microsoft Sees Big Growth in Thailand

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRIGAN, MATTHEW J.
description: CORRIGAN-Matthew J. On February 25, 2000. World War II and Korea veteran. Lieutenant Commander, U.S. Navy. Senior Partner in Mendes & Mount law firm. Beloved husband of the late Mary Patricia. Dear brother of Raymond and Adelaide Fisher. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, , Rye, NY, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial, Church of the Resurrection, Monday, 10:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to Westchester Golf Association, Caddy Scholarship Fund, would be appreciated.

title: McCain and Perot Stealing Glances, Some Say
description: John McCain will take votes from anyone: Democrats, independents, even vegetarians, as he joked last Sunday. But could he embrace the party of Ross Perot, the man Senator McCain once described as ''nuttier than a fruitcake''?

title: Making a Science Of Looking Out For No. 1
description: Over the last few decades a divide has opened between political scientists who practice what is known as rational choice theory and those who follow more traditional approaches relying on the historical and cultural record, political psychology, polling data and the like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERSTEIN, LES
description: ALPERSTEIN-Les. Passed away February 22. ''Kindness and good deeds.'' Fondly remembered and saddly missed. Morris and Jean Goldberg and family.

title: Nets' Feick Stays Put, But Thinks, What If?
description: Jamie Feick sat at home on Thursday waiting out the National Basketball Association trade deadline and wondering where he would be playing today.

title: Galyon Signs With Dolphins
description: Scott Galyon, the Giants' nickel linebacker and a rising star until a serious leg injury sidelined him late in 1998, signed a free-agent contract with the Miami Dolphins yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about threatened species that are being pushed to the edges of their original range misspelled the name of a rare insect and referred incompletely to its current range. The insect is the American burying beetle, not burrowing beetle. Besides Rhode Island, it is still found in Nebraska and on the Oklahoma-Arkansas border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, CATHERINE
description: GREEN-Catherine, of Miami Beach, formerly of Harrison, NY. Funeral services will be at 9:45 AM Sunday, February 27th., at The Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, Manhattan.

title: In a Softer Mode, Giuliani Expresses Sympathy for All
description: Trying to strike a balance in a case that has troubled his administration for more than a year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday expressed ''very, very deep, heartfelt sympathy'' to the family of Amadou Diallo, but said that the acquitted police officers had experienced a nightmare and that it would take ''a long time to recover from what they've gone through.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I ask for your calm and prayers. As we go on for the quest of justice, life, equality -- I thank you all.''

title: PINNACLE HOLDINGS TO BUY 233 TOWERS FOR $100.5 MILLION
description: Pinnacle Holdings Inc., an owner and manager of transmission towers used by cellular phone companies, said yesterday that it would buy 233 towers for $100.5 million to expand its services in the Southeast. The acquisition includes the entire 197-tower portfolio of LCC International Inc., at a cost of about $80 million. Pinnacle did not disclose the other sellers but said there were 21 other transactions. Most of the towers being bought are in the South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, JEAN A.
description: MILLS-Jean A., on February 25th, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Susan Birnbaum (Howard) and Michael (Barbara). Adored grandfather of Megan, David, Howard Joshua and Marisa. Cherished brother-inlaw, uncle and friend. Retired NYPD. Service at 12:30 PM, Sunday, at Riverdale Temple, 246th St. and Independence Ave.

title: Bush Says He Is Reagan's Heir and Candidate of Future
description: Coming out of a break back home in Texas, Gov. George W. Bush returned to the campaign trail today and seemed to veer a bit toward the political middle ground, talking warmly about compassion and the Internet rather than about potentially divisive issues like religion or abortion.

title: Duval Does His Talking, Loudly, On and Off the Course
description: For David Duval, today's match against Sergio Garcia was not only about winning. It was also about pride. It was about respect. It was a chance to show everyone that while Garcia has undeniable talent and flamboyance, Duval remains one of golf's most formidable players.

title: CISCO TO BE INVESTOR AS SPANLINK GOES PRIVATE
description: Spanlink Communications Inc., a maker of computer telephony software, said yesterday that it planned to take the company private and that Cisco Systems Inc. would invest in the newly private company. Spanlink said it would offer shareholders $10.50 a share in cash. Spanlink shares fell 75 cents, to $10. They were as low as $2 in October. Founders and management who own more than 50 percent of Spanlink are creating a holding company that will tender the offer to buy the publicly held shares, starting no later than Wednesday. Cisco, the world's No. 1 maker of computer-networking equipment, will invest in the company by buying convertible preferred shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HELENE
description: SCHWARTZ-Helene. On February 22. Beloved wife of Leslie. Loving mother of Sue and Andy. Cherished grandmother of David and Sara. Memorial services Sunday,February 27, 2PM, at the Menorah Gardens Funeral Chapel, 9321 Memorial Park Road and North Lake Boulevard, West Palm Beach, 1/4 mile past Ibis on right side of road. 561-627-2277.

title: Indian Point 2 Using Robots To Study Leak
description: Remote-control robots are expected to begin probing the faulty steam generators at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant sometime Saturday to determine the cause and extent of last week's radiation leak, Consolidated Edison officials said today.

title: Busboy Is Charged With Killing Owner of East Side Restaurant
description: The police have arrested an employee of an Upper East Side restaurateur on charges he murdered his boss in a bloody confrontation with kitchen knives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, STANLEY H.
description: SHAPIRO-Stanley H. Of Fort Lee, N.J. on February 24, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Devoted father of Barbara and George Shapiro. Dear brother of Marilyn Chait. Loving grandfather. Services Sunday 11:30am at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J.

title: BRAZIL DEBT SALE
description: Brazil has sold $1 billion of 30-year bonds in international markets, seizing on improved confidence in the economy to issue its longest-maturing debt in more than three years. The government's foray into foreign debt markets is seen as paving the way for similar issues by Brazilian companies. For instance, Banco Itau S.A., a large bank, has just sold $100 million of two-year bonds. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROSE
description: MILLER-Rose. Died February 25, 2000 at age 98. Beloved mother of Norman, Edward and the late Sherman Miller. Sister of Ruth Piller and Raye Cohan. Beloved grandmother and great grandmother. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, N.Y. Sunday, 10AM.

title: G.M. WILL TEMPORARILY CLOSE 4 NORTH AMERICAN PLANTS
description: The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest automaker, will temporarily close 4 of its 13 North American car-assembly plants next week to try to reduce inventories of several slow-selling models. The company will close its Saturn plants, in Wilmington, Del., and Spring Hill, Tenn., a spokesman, Tom Wickham, said. It will also halt its Fairfax, Kan., plant which makes the Oldsmobile Intrigue and the Pontiac Grand Prix, and the Ste. Therese, Quebec, plant, which builds the Pontiac Firebird and Chevrolet Camaro. The plants will stop production for one week.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COPPENRATH, LUCETTE I. H.
description: COPPENRATH-Lucette I. H. (1932-1996). Four years today. Our love is all that remains. Bob-Margaret-Martina-Robby

title: Elusive-Cab Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: John MacFadyen, 76, Architect of Performing Arts Center
description: John Hayter MacFadyen, an architect who designed several of the nation's premier performing arts centers and was the founding executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, died on Feb. 18 at a hospital near his home in Damariscotta, Me. He was 76.

title: CARMAKERS TO BUY PARTS ON INTERNET
description: General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler announced today that they would set up the world's biggest online marketplace for the auto industry's private use, a giant auction site like eBay through which they plan to buy the nearly $250 billion worth of parts and other goods they need each year. The site would dwarf all previous commercial activity on the Web.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW; On the Road To Freedom, United Yet Also Split
description: There is a scene in the early minutes of the TNT movie ''Freedom Song'' that is so painful the eyes can't look away.

title: U.S. Report Harshly Criticizes China for Deterioration of Human Rights; Russia Also Faulted
description: Using the toughest terms since the pro-democracy movement was crushed in Beijing more than a decade ago, the United States sharply criticized China today for what it called a marked deterioration in human rights.

title: Damascus Sends A New Signal
description: To the Editor:

title: Nasdaq Data on Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 8.45 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the market, said yesterday.

title: U.S. Surprise: 6.9% Growth In 4th Quarter
description: The economy barreled ahead at a breathtaking 6.9 percent annual rate in the last three months of 1999, the most rapid rate of quarterly expansion in more than three years, the Government reported yesterday.

title: Canada Screening Licenses For Gun Imports From U.S.
description: The Canadian government said today that it was reviewing all licenses issued for the import of firearms from the United States to be sure that they were for valid business or sporting purposes.

title: EVEREST RE TO BUY GIBRALTAR CASUALTY FROM PRUDENTIAL
description: The Everest Re Group, an insurance company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a property-casualty company, the Gibraltar Casualty Company from the Prudential Insurance Company of America for $49 million. Gibraltar originally was formed by Everest Re in 1978, when Everest Re was part of Prudential. Prudential spun off Everest Re in 1995 in an initial public offering. Everest Re, based in Liberty Corner, N.Y., had revenue of $1.31 billion in 1999. It is the parent company of Everest Reinsurance Company, which specializes in reinsurance through which the company assumes part of the risks of policies written by other insurance companies.

title: Arena League Owners Suspend 2000 Season, Citing an Antitrust Suit by the Players
description: The Arena Football League, the spring and summer indoor version of traditional football and the most successful of the myriad second-tier sports leagues, canceled its 2000 season yesterday after the league could not reach a contract agreement with its players.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Michael I. Sovern, the new chairman of Sotheby's, misstated his age. As noted in the adjacent thumbnail biography, he is 68, not 69.

title: Sports of The Times; Compassion From One Who Knows
description: EVEN from the far-flung vantage point of Sioux Falls, S.D., Darryl Strawberry's self-induced predicament looks pretty bleak: a fourth drug policy violation, the breach of trust. A relapse, the sliding back down a long and steep mountain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROPPER, LILLIAN (LOLLY)
description: GROPPER-Lillian (Lolly). Age 96. Of Rockville Centre, NY. Loving and loved wife of the late Bernard. Mother of Judy and Ira Robinson, Susan and Leon Brachman. Grandmother of Ronni Adler and Douglas Robinson, Mitchell and Sheila Brachman and Linda Brachman. Great grandmother of Chelsea and Logan Adler, Erin and Rachel Brachman. We will miss her. Services Sunday, 11AM at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Rd.. Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEWIS, CARRIE P.
description: LEWIS-Carrie P. You have been gone one year ago today. I miss you so, gone but never forgotten. Your precious memories will remain forever. Your loving sister and family, Marian P. Jones

title: 3 Taiwan Contenders All Urge Reform
description: ''The party and the government are like Siamese twins,'' says James Soong, independent candidate for president, waving his finger with a touch of outrage.

title: Census Bureau Begins Count With 120 Million Wrong Addresses
description: Just as it is about to begin, the 2000 Census has had a little glitch.

title: Frank Robinson Is Appointed
description: Twenty-five years after Frank Robinson became baseball's first black manager, he will become the first official other than league presidents to discipline players, managers and coaches for on-field acts. With league presidents and offices relegated to baseball history, Commissioner Bud Selig named Robinson Major League Baseball's vice president for on-field operations yesterday. The creation of the position brings baseball into conformity with the other major sports leagues.

title: 'Not Guilty' Is Not the End, Not Nearly
description: THIS is a hard one. A very hard, hurtful one.

title: STOCKS IN TURMOIL AS WORRIES GROW ON HIGHER RATES
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, which reached a peak of 11,723 last month, closed below the 10,000 mark yesterday for the first time in 10 months as investors dumped shares of companies most vulnerable to higher interest rates. The other popular stock indexes followed suit.

title: Long, Long Way Home For Cab's Young Rider
description: Laurie Kogan ushered her daughter, sobbing with a bruised knee, into the lobby of her Upper East Side building Thursday night and turned around to see the taxicab that had brought her and her children from Newark Airport drive off.

title: URBAN DECAY FOR LVMH
description: The French luxury goods company LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. has acquired the United States cosmetics company Urban Decay. LVMH declined to disclose financial details of the deal or Urban Decay's sales and earnings performance. Founded in the mid-1990's by Sandy Lerner, above, the Los Angeles-based company produces and distributes cosmetics but does not have its own outlet chain, a spokesman for LVMH said. ''Urban Decay is a very successful, entrepreneurial and edgy cosmetic company that complements our existing portfolio of brands extremely well,'' he added.

title: INVESTMENT GROUP MAKES OFFER TO ACQUIRE SHELDAHL
description: A group led by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs offered yesterday to buy the 89.5 percent of Sheldahl Inc. that the group does not already own for $8.50 a share. That tops a bid of $7.75 a share from Molex Inc., based in Lisle, Ill., which is Sheldahl's largest stakeholder. Mr. Jacobs said he talked with Sheldahl's chief executive, Edward L. Lundstrom, yesterday and was told that Sheldahl officials would discuss a letter containing the Jacobs bid. Sheldahl makes printed circuits and is based in Northfield, Minn. Terms of the discussions between Sheldahl and Molex call for Sheldahl not to entertain any other offers before March 10 and for Sheldahl to pay Molex $750,000 should that agreement be breached.

title: 4 OFFICERS IN DIALLO SHOOTING ARE ACQUITTED OF ALL CHARGES
description: Four New York City police officers were acquitted today of all charges in the death of Amadou Diallo, the immigrant from Guinea who was fired on 41 times as he stood, unarmed, in the vestibule of his apartment building in the Bronx.

title: When Stakes Are High, Rationality Kicks In
description: Political scientists are inveterate borrowers. Consequently we regularly debate the benefits and costs of appropriating models, methods and concepts from other fields.

title: States Confronting Challenge of How to Respond to the New World of the Internet
description: The Internet, an unruly technology that respects no boundaries, is making life increasingly uncomfortable in state capitols. The biggest source of the unease has been the threat of a punishing loss of state sales-tax revenues as more goods are sold over the Internet, often by faraway companies beyond the reach of state tax collectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIHLER, REV. JOSEPH J.
description: BIHLER-Rev. Joseph J. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of Father Bihler at Queen of Peace Residence on February 25. Reposing at Queen of Peace Residence, 110-30 221 St, Queens Village on Sunday, February 27 from 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass on Monday, February 28 at Queen of Peace Residence at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daly Bishop of Brooklyn

title: McCain Factor Quiets Talk of Dwindling Turnout
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona has provided at least a short-term answer to the political prophets of doom who study the vanishing American voter.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the management of the radio spectrum referred incorrectly to the Federal Communications Commission. It is an independent agency, not part of the Commerce Department. The article also classified sound incorrectly. It is produced by the vibration of molecules; it is not part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

title: US LEC TO RECEIVE ABOUT $300 MILLION FROM INVESTORS
description: The US LEC Corporation, which sells telecommunications services in the Southeastern United States, said yesterday that it would get as much as $300 million from Thomas H. Lee Partners L.P. and Bain Capital Inc. to finance expansion. US LEC said each company had agreed to buy as much as $150 million of its convertible preferred stock and would receive a seat on its board. US LEC is among the communications companies proliferating since the 1996 United States Telecommunications Act opened competition in local markets. It plans to use the Internet to sell services. US LEC, based in Charlotte, N.C., sells local, long-distance, data and Internet services in the Southeast.

title: NESTLE PROFIT JUMPS
description: The world's biggest foodmaker, Nestle S.A., said its second-half profit rose 24 percent after it cut costs and focused on its main brands. Net income rose to 2.64 billion Swiss francs ($1.63 billion) in the six months that ended on Dec. 31, from 2.13 billion francs the year before. The results show Nestle's cost-cutting is ahead of rivals like Unilever, whose fourth-quarter profit rose 2 percent, and Danone S.A., whose second-half earnings rose 14 percent..

title: Crackdown Will Continue
description: Major League Baseball continues to crack down on teams that sign under-age players.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TI GROUP, London, a specialized engineering and manufacturing company, said its vehicle-parts manufacturing unit, TI Group Automotive Systems, would cut 105 jobs and close a factory in Valdosta, Ga., in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSMAN, ANNE
description: PRESSMAN-Anne. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Michael and Edward. Loving grandmother of Laurie, Susan, Mark, Dana and Deborah. Greatgrandmother of Alexandra and Madeline. Dear sister of Robert Engel. Service 10:00 AM Sunday at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel'', Queens Blvd & 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Federal Panel Visits Texas to Probe Shortage of Tech Workers
description: Federal Panel Visits Texas to Probe Shortage of Tech Workers

title: On Health Care, Gore or Bradley?; Why McCain Thrives
description: To the Editor:

title: WARBURG, PINCUS AFFILIATE TO BUY CENTENNIAL
description: The Centennial HealthCare Corporation agreed yesterday to be acquired by an affiliate of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company for about $65.5 million in cash. Centennial, based in Atlanta, provides long-term health care. Warburg, Pincus would pay $5.50 for each of Centennial's 11.9 million shares outstanding. The stock soared $2.3125, or 73 percent, to $5.1875, in Nasdaq trading. Centennial, which reported $390.8 million of revenue for the last 12 months, currently operates 100 nursing centers. Warburg, Pincus, based in New York, is a private-equity investment firm that has invested more than $9 billion in over 300 companies.

title: Eva Julia Neer, 62, Biochemist Known for Work With Proteins
description: Eva Julia Neer, a biochemist and heart researcher at Harvard University and Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, died on Sunday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 62.

title: Trying to Assist Others, She Finds Help for Herself
description: Connie Ricciardi's former bed, a tiny, tattered twin-size, sits a few feet from where she now sleeps, its worn brown bedspread still draped on top.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORRISSEN, WILLY E.
description: GORRISSEN-Willy E. 87, died February 18 at Kendal at Hanover(NH). Beloved husband to the late Jane(McDonald) Gorrissen. Former partner in the ship brokerage business of Jones & Gorrissen in New York City. Retired to Norwich, Vt in 1973. Survived by 2 daughters, Jeanne E. Gorrissen, Hopewell, NJ and Ann F. Gorrissen, NYC, NY, 1 son Willy J., Gig Harbor, Wa., 1 grandson, 1 granddaughter, 4 nieces & nephews. Memorial service, March 4th, 11AM at Kendal at Hanover(NH).

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; LITTLE HOPE FOR MEXICAN AIRLINE
description: Doubts have grown that Taesa, the Mexican airline, will recover from the financial collapse that grounded it three months ago after a fatal crash. This week Taesa was ordered into bankruptcy protection, and banking officials said at least a third of its $380 million in debt would never be repaid. Taesa amassed the debt as part of an effort to offer cut-rate fares. Other carriers have begun flying some of Taesa's routes. Dan Fineren

title: Nedved's Hat Trick Trumps Peca's in Rangers' Rally
description: Six weeks remain in the regular season, but the Rangers and Buffalo Sabres played tonight as if it were a deciding game in a Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: CARNIVAL AND FAIRFIELD END MERGER PLANS
description: The Carnival Corporation and Fairfield Communities Inc. yesterday ended their previously announced plan to merge. On Jan. 24, Carnival signed a letter of intent to acquire Fairfield for about $775 million, including debt. Fairfield shareholders would have received 0.3164 Carnival common share for each Fairfield share. Carnival's stock has fallen from above $50 in mid-January to yesterday's close of $27.725, down 37.5 cents. Carnival said both parties had agreed to pay their own expenses and had eliminated the breakup fee. Carnival said it was ''extremely disappointed'' to have to withdraw from the transaction. The company said it intended to continue working with Fairfield, a vacation ownership company based in Orlando, Fla.

title: Mexican Arrested in a String of Kidnappings
description: Using legal wiretaps, investigators located the roadside phone that Nicolas Caletri Lopez, the reputed mastermind of many kidnappings, used to call his girlfriend, and this week a SWAT team arrested him there.

title: At More Modest Clinton Meal, Big Tip and Hoopla
description: President Clinton, a seasoned veteran of the campaign trail, made sure this morning that his wife, in her first run for elective office, did not make the same mistake twice.

title: Local Child Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: Colleges Target Music Web Sites
description: Colleges Target Music Web Sites

title: Battle for Hong Kong's Leading Phone Company May Be Near End
description: The roller coaster battle for Hong Kong's flagship telephone company was headed for a climax today, as the board of the company's British parent, Cable and Wireless P.L.C., prepared to meet over the weekend to consider competing offers for Cable and Wireless HKT.

title: Betty Buckley's Memories
description: Sometimes all it takes for a cabaret performer to make a great leap forward is the decision to relax and let go. By dropping her normally imperious guard in her new act, ''Heart to Heart'' (the title of a forthcoming album), which plays at the Cafe Carlyle through March 17, Betty Buckley has shed several defensive barriers between herself and her audience.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BINET, DENNIS
description: BINET-Dennis. Memorial service Sunday, February 27, 2000, 1:45PM at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. A gathering to celebrate his life immediately following at Empire Hotel, 44 W. 63rd St., Mezzanine Ballroom, 3:30-5:30PM.

title: Authorities in Arizona Explore a Mafioso's New Links
description: After Salvatore Gravano's arrest here on Thursday, residents have been left to wonder how the onetime Gambino family underboss and eventual turncoat ended up in the company of what the police called a group of young white supremacists selling the drug Ecstasy to teenagers around Phoenix.

title: Biggest Canadian Phone Company Offers to Buy TV Network
description: The owner of Canada's largest telephone system, BCE Inc., made a $1.6 billion cash offer for the country's No. 2 television network today, a move to give it more programming to carry into battle against cable television and Internet services.

title: Civil Rights Prosecution Is Considered
description: Legal experts said today that federal prosecutors might face obstacles in bringing a civil rights case against the four New York City police officers who were cleared of all charges in the shooting of Amadou Diallo.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about screen mates, cartoon characters that can be downloaded to roam the screen, misstated the address for the site where Briskmates can be found. It is www.liptonbrisk.com.

title: Kurdish Rebels' Bid to Enter Turkish Politics Wins a Supporter
description: A prominent Kurdish politician said today that Kurdish rebels in Turkey should be allowed to transform their guerrilla army into a political party.

title: Singapore Man Indicted in Donations Inquiry
description: The independent prosecutor investigating Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman has returned an eight-count indictment charging a Singapore businessman with lying about the source of $200,000 in political contributions to Democratic Party groups, court records show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONAUER, BEATRICE
description: ARONAUER - Beatrice. Loving wife of Irwin and beloved mother of Susan, Billy, Elyse, Sandy and Peri. Loyal sister to Milton, Janet and the late Harriet. Loving grandmother to Judy (Wilfried), Robby (Felicia), Carol (Todd), Ondine, Ari, Aaron (Laura), Ani (Tyler), Jacob and Rebecca. We will miss her kind and loving spirit. Funeral services at Gutterman's Chapel in Rockville Centre on Sunday 12 PM

title: RANK PROFIT DROPS
description: The British company that owns the Hard Rock Cafe restaurant chain and other entertainment-related properties, Rank Group P.L.C., said its profit dropped 7.8 percent in 1999. The company said profit from operations fell to $:177 million, or $282.8 million, from $:192 million in 1998. Rank attributed its poor performance to a drop-off of sales at Hard Rock Cafe. Rank also said it planned to buy back 10 percent of its shares. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: The Verdict: Poor Training and Supervision
description: So what are we to think? Amadou Diallo, an innocent unarmed African man, standing in front of his apartment building in the Bronx, was gunned down last year by four white New York City police officers.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Advising McCain, Rudman Is Happily Back in the Fray
description: IT seems only natural in these muddy campaign days for a chat with former Senator Warren B. Rudman to begin, ''Well, sir, and are you 'a vicious bigot'?''

title: NYT Article
description: I.B.M. and AT&T to Offer Wireless Web Access

title: Trailblazing Textiles Lure Clients Who Revel in Color and Texture : With Exotic Fabrics, Designers Meet a Desire to Break Away
description: MILAN  One remarkable trickle-down effect of Italian ready-to-wear fashion has been the general availability of well-designed, well-cut garments for all purses. As a result, Italian women in general are reliably elegant. Yet such reliability conceals the grub of predictability. And this provokes reaction.

title: Questions on the Auction Block
description: No indictments have been handed down yet, and the scope of the inquiry is still unclear. But both Christie's and Sotheby's, New York's leading art-auction houses, are preparing for their spring sales under the cloud of an antitrust investigation for possible collusion in setting the commissions they charge. Spokesmen for both houses say they are going about business as usual despite the investigation, putting together spring sales catalogues that they hope will not reflect too sharply, in either number or quality of works to be auctioned, the pall this investigation casts.

title: Democrats Look to Montana For Break in Republican Sea
description: The Rocky Mountain West is about as Republican as any region of the country gets these days. All five states -- Colorado, Montana, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming -- are led by Republican governors, and each state has a Congressional delegation that is overwhelmingly Republican.

title: Jerry Brown Backs Gore; Rivals Attack G.O.P.
description: Vice President Al Gore, the buttoned-up moderate who has tried to loosen up, today picked up the endorsement of Jerry Brown, the quirky liberal who is sounding more conservative lately.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO PLUNGES. The euro declined further below parity with the dollar after fears of higher American interest rates were fueled by a report on economic growth. The euro declined to 97.42 cents, down from 99.33 on Thursday.

title: Aetna's Chief Steps Down Under Pressure From Shareholders
description: Richard L. Huber, 63, the embattled chief executive of Aetna Inc., the nation's biggest health insurance company, resigned yesterday in response to pressure from shareholders frustrated by a 50 percent decline in the stock since last August. He was replaced by William H. Donaldson, a Wall Street veteran whose first task may be trying to repair frayed relations with unhappy investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAJTHENYI, GABRIELLA
description: MAJTHENYI-Gabriella, 91 of White Plains, NY. Died February 23, 2000 of a heart attack. She was born August 21, 1908 in Pecs, Hungary to Ilona and Joseph Roboz. Gabriella is survived by her son Alexander Majthenyi of White Plains, her daughter Klara King of England and 5 grandchildren. For information contact McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 914-949-7777.

title: Samuel S. Schreiber, 91; Modernized Mass Transit
description: Samuel S. Schreiber, an urban traffic engineer who became a major force in the conversion of the old trolley lines to modern bus systems in New York, Yonkers and other cities across the country, died Tuesday in Stamford, Conn., after a long illness. He was 91.

title: In Tehran, Tearing Away the Veils
description: Whenever a female journalist reports from Iran, the visual image of her is as chilling as anything she might say. Forced to cover her head in public, she is a walking, talking reminder of how strictly the Islamic government controls its people. Christiane Amanpour, one of the most recognizable and toughest of international reporters, wears a bright green head scarf when she is on the street in ''Revolutionary Journey,'' but the point of this lively and revealing personal report is to tear away all veils, to take viewers behind the scenes of an Iran in the process of surprising reform.

title: Fox's Point Man For Perversity; 'World's Scariest Programmer,' Starring Mike Darnell as Himself
description: In the cleaned-up new world of Fox television, pet poodles won't attack their owners, fake military surgeons won't perform autopsies on fake aliens, and 303-pound tumors won't be removed from patients on prime-time television.

title: On the Road To Freedom, United Yet Also Split
description: There is a scene in the early minutes of the TNT movie ''Freedom Song'' that is so painful the eyes can't look away.

title: Priceline.com's Latest Turn Takes It to the Gas Station
description: Just when gasoline prices are making some drivers hot under the collar, along comes Priceline.com with a program that the company insists will enable people ''to simply ignore the price at the pump.''

title: Pope Seeks to Heal Divisions With Egyptian Coptic Christians
description: Warning that ''there is no time to lose,'' Pope John Paul II implored the leader of Egypt's Coptic Church today to renew dialogue with the Vatican and end ''painful divisions'' within Christianity.

title: Not Enough Troops in Kosovo, NATO Says
description: NATO said today that it did not have enough troops on the ground in Kosovo to contain the growing ethnic violence that threatens to undermine peacekeeping efforts there.

title: MORE ON THE VERDICT
description: MARCH TOWARD ACQUITTAL -- The judge's instructions to the jury on the charges the officers faced and the three legal reasons that could justify the shooting shifted the atmosphere in court and seemed to come down on the side of the defense. PAGE B6

title: Verdict Bares Sharp Feelings On Both Sides
description: Strong and deeply polarized emotions -- anger, bitter indignation and stunned disbelief on one side, and expressions of relief and vindication on the other -- rippled across the metropolitan area last night as politicians, community leaders and ordinary New Yorkers reacted swiftly to the acquittal of four white police officers in the killing of an unarmed black immigrant, Amadou Diallo.

title: Future Prospects Viewed Positively
description: Although Standard & Poor's has assigned a junk-bond rating to the YankeeNets' coming sale of $250 million in debt, the firm is positive about the company's future prospects. The B rating given to the seven-year bonds is below investment grade level and signifies more inherent risk to investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, LAWRENCE M.
description: ROSNER-Lawrence M. Beloved husband of Tobe, father of Caren, David and Susan. Grandfather of Ben, Jonah, Jennifer, Matthew and Emma. Services Sunday, 12 noon at the Westchester Reformed Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Rio de Janeiro Journal; Famed Carnival Beaches Incur Share of Indignities
description: The days have been warm and clear, with refreshing sea breezes, and the aquamarine waters of the South Atlantic continue to sparkle and beckon. But for the 6.5 million residents of this metropolis that likes to call itself the ''wonderful city,'' this has become the summer of their discontent.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND SELLS STAKES IN 3 VENTURES
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company, a maker of construction equipment, said yesterday that it had sold its interest in three automotive steering-column assembly ventures to its partner NSK Ltd. for $53 million. The company sold its 50 percent interests in Nastech, based in Bennington, Vt., and Nastech Europe Ltd., based in Coventry, England, to Tokyo-based NSK. It also sold its 25 percent interest in the Siam Nastech Company, based in Bangkok, Thailand. Ingersoll-Rand is selling slow-growing businesses to focus on those with better profitability. The company will continue to make other steering-column components through its Torrington Company unit.

title: Public Schools Official To Leave Job in 2 Weeks
description: Lewis H. Spence will step down in two weeks as deputy chancellor for operations for the New York City public schools, a job he has held for four years. He will spend the next five months at the College Board, the nonprofit group that oversees the Scholastic Assessment Tests.

title: Conflicts of Interest
description: To the Editor

title: A Story The Jury Never Heard
description: In the end, the defense humanized the four police officers who shot Amadou Diallo, and the prosecution left the dead man without face, without voice.

title: A Model That Pretends to Explain Everything
description: Consider this: The last 40 years have seen an enormous infusion of the methodologies of economics into the academic study of politics, but the practitioners would be hard pressed to tell you what has been learned as a result.

title: Kiwis Are Turning America's Cup Finals Into a Blowout
description: Taking another giant step toward a conclusion that seems more inevitable with each passing contest, Team New Zealand recorded its third straight victory over Italy's Prada Challenge today to secure a commanding 3-0 lead in the 30th competition for the America's Cup.

title: Kenyans Get O.K. for Meets
description: Kenya's Olympic distance runners will be allowed to compete in the lucrative Golden League series this summer after all.

title: The Clergy and the Confederate Flag Unfurled
description: When Bishop Dorsey F. Henderson Jr., the Episcopal bishop in Columbia, S.C., steps out the door of Trinity Cathedral there, he need only lift his gaze a bit to see the object of a bitter controversy that has spilled over into national politics.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: The Girls From Ipanema
description: Forget coffee and nuts. This season, beauty is Brazil's hottest crop. ''We had the English girls, then the Israeli girls, then the Russian girls,'' said Marilyn Gauthier, owner of Marilyn, the modeling agency. ''Now, it's the Brazilian girls.''

title: Mad Max
description: STROHEIM

title: Q&A/Dr. Ellen M. Umansky; Teaching Judaism at a Jesuit University
description: HAD she been born just a few years later, Dr. Ellen M. Umansky might have become a rabbi. But when she graduated from college in 1972, with an interest in Jewish studies, it did not occur to her that a woman could become a rabbi. Instead, she went to graduate school to study religion and philosophy.

title: Artillery From G.M.'s War Room
description: IF you think that a Chevy Suburban or Ford Expedition amounts to a tank with cup holders, just wait: General Motors is putting its considerable marketing muscle behind the war-ready Hummer.

title: Under the Volcano
description: Catastrophe

title: If Only Stocks Were Votes . . .
description: Gary Bauer may be out of the race for the White House, but victory is still apparently his. Last year, according to his disclosure forms, he held some of the market's best performers, including Qualcomm (a $15,000-to-$50,000 stake as the year began, according to the forms) and i2 Technologies ($50,000 to $100,000). For the year, Qualcomm gained 2,683 percent, and i2, 542 percent (with a Friday sell-off still leaving it above last year's close). The value of his entire portfolio gained 183 percent, he says.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZAGAT, ELEANOR PASNER
description: ZAGAT-Eleanor Pasner. February 28, 1959. After 41 years your love and influence remains. Mathilde Christato

title: Getting Out
description: Colors of the Mountain By Da Chen. 310 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Books From The Times
description: Volcanoes, earthquakes, ice ages and mass extinctions don't happen every day, but often enough to keep science reporters on their toes. THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF NATURAL DISASTERS, edited by Nicholas Wade (Lyons Press, $25), is a collection of reporting on catastrophe from The New York Times's weekly science section; it explores topics like the apparently increasing vigor of hurricanes and northeasters, the heat sources under the boiling pools of Yellowstone, the dimming hopes for earthquake prediction and the possibility of doing something useful if a comet is found headed straight for the earth. Another volume, THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF LANGUAGE AND LINGUISTICS (same publisher, price and editor), deals with scientists who listen to the noises we think with, trying to learn if all languages are related, and if so how; whether animals ever have speech, and if not why; what makes it possible for children to acquire language almost overnight without even trying; and where (and how many times) human beings invented writing.

title: De La Hoya Drops Coley In the 7th
description: Derrell Coley did a lot of talking before his fight against Oscar De La Hoya last night at Madison Square Garden. He fumed that he had been ignored. He said he was going to destroy De La Hoya, because De La Hoya had made him wait so long for a shot.

title: After 20 Straight Victories, The Irish Run Into a Wall
description: The Notre Dame women's basketball team saved its worst game of the regular season for last -- a showdown that decided the Big East Conference championship.

title: On Staten Island, the New Media Are the Message
description: PETER EISENMAN'S design for the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences brings into focus a theme that has preoccupied him in recent years: the relationship between the history of places and the history of ideas. The $65 million project, which partly straddles the St. George terminal of the Staten Island ferry, is a favorite of the borough president, Guy V. Molinari. The building will house a new branch of the Staten Island Institute, called the Center for Electronic Culture, and will feature displays on the new media that are helping to bring a global culture into being.

title: System Is Corrupt
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bus Opponents' Latest Fear: Garbage Trucks as Well
description: A coalition of West Brighton civic groups who oppose putting a city bus lot on a five-acre site in their area got good news last week. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority disclosed that if it bought the disputed land at the $590,000 price, it would not park buses there.

title: A Teachers's Wish List For Education System
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Nothing Secular?
description: Jeffrey Rosen may be right to announce the collapse of church-state separation. Sooner than he expects, however, I think that we will recognize the folly of having abandoned strict separation in favor of a fuzzy civil Christianity. And those who expect religion to take its place meekly alongside ''race, sex and ethnicity'' as a token of identity politics will discover that they have badly underestimated religion in its capacities to inspire and sow strife.

title: 'Johnny Mac,' Jack Nicholson Said, 'Don't Ever Change'
description: As a lifelong tennis player and fan, I read Julian Rubinstein's article on John McEnroe with great interest (Jan. 30). I agree that he is one of the finest tennis players of all time. However, I take strong exception to the suggestion that he performs at anywhere near the same level as an announcer. His commentary is insightful at times. But mostly, it is strident, intrusive, self-absorbed and irrelevant -- and so destructive to my pleasure in watching the match that I am often forced to turn off the sound.

title: Preparing to Ride A New Hobby Horse
description: I NEVER was gifted as a collector. While other boys avidly wrote down lists of railway engine numbers, or pasted exotic foreign stamps into their albums, my own efforts were half-hearted. For a while, I collected cigarette cards. But, because I wasn't allowed to smoke, this hobby seemed to lack authenticity. My collection of dead frogs was swept out of the house before it got properly started. My proposal to subsititute live frogs was vetoed. I finally had to admit that collecting was a talent that, like so many others, had passed me by.

title: Warming Up In Ankle Muffs
description: Jeans were beaded, embroidered and painted by 60's flower children and hippies. Today, jeans are knee-deep in fur for a new walk on fashion's wilder side, from Fifth Avenue ladies (far left), to rappers with mink appliques and coq feathers. Leather jeans are cuffed in lamb and fringes of mink tails. One young man slit open the cuff of his jeans to accommodate a two-pelt gusset, below.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JANSON, RICHARD W.
description: JANSON-Richard W. (Rick). February 27, 1946-December 20, 1987. ''Here's looking at you, kid.'' My love always, Frank Nash.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHIELDS, EILEEN R.
description: SHIELDS-Eileen R. It has been a terrible year. I lost you and then Brooke. Sandy, your cousins, your friends all miss you. I miss you the most. I love you. Your Father

title: Carroll Cline, 72; Added Light to Architecture
description: Carroll B. Cline, a lighting designer whose clients included the Santa Fe Opera Theater in Santa Fe, N.M., the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., and the lobby of 1251 Avenue of the Americas, died Thursday at his home on the Upper West Side in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Girardi Prefers Security Over Another Series Ring
description: ''I think the role that they had for me was not the role I really wanted,'' Girardi said, discussing his departure from the Yankees as a free agent. ''They offered me a one-year deal to be the backup. To me, that wasn't a good deal.''

title: Near 70, Paul Taylor Isn't Looking Back Or Standing Still
description: TO the Degas-drunk balletomane, dance studios are mirrored temples of mystery and romance. To the weary dancer, they are places of business and, not infrequently, pain. Certainly there is not anything mysterious about the headquarters of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, unromantically situated above a Banana Republic on lower Broadway. The peeling paint on the walls is a bleak shade of unpasteurized cream; the floor of the rehearsal room is littered with backpacks, paperbacks, water bottles and plastic salad containers. It looks like every other studio in the world, only grubbier.

title: The First Fine Day; Prague
description: Spring leads to new green shoots and delusions of grandeur, so what better place to celebrate the afternoon sun in Prague than in the gardens of the Wallenstein Palace (Valdstejnsky Palac) in Mala Strana, protected and hidden from the street by 30-foot walls.

title: Tobacco Suit Payments Put Nassau in the Black
description: EVEN as Nassau County officials grappled with the grim news that Moody's Investors Service had downgraded the county's bond rating to one notch above junk status, the county comptroller announced last week that the county had actually squeaked out of 1999 with a $21 million surplus.

title: You Can't Get There From Here
description: IN SEARCH OF DEEP TIME

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROPPER, LILLIAN
description: GROPPER-Lillian (Lolly). Age 96. Of Rockville Centre, NY. Loving and loved wife of the late Bernard. Mother of Judy and Ira Robinson, Susan and Leon Brachman. Grandmother of Ronni Adler and Douglas Robinson, Mitchell and Sheila Brachman and Linda Brachman. Great grandmother of Chelsea and Logan Adler, Erin and Rachel Brachman. We will miss her. Services Sunday, 11AM at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Rd.. Rockville Centre, LI.

title: European Flavor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In Atlanta, Both a Feast and a Famine of Jobs
description: THE layoff announcements have seemed to come in waves in the last month.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORVITZ, BYRDIE G.
description: HORVITZ-Byrdie G. Beloved wife of the late Bernard H. Horvitz. Cherished mother of Janie Bernstein. Adored grandmother of Barra, Craig and Garrick Bernstein. A woman of character, kindness and generosity. Her memory will live in our hearts forever. She will be missed by all who knew her. Contributions may be made to the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine for Stroke Research, or Visiting Nurse Service of N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSMAN, ANNE
description: PRESSMAN-Anne. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Michael and Edward. Loving grandmother of Laurie, Susan, Mark, Dana and Deborah. Greatgrandmother of Alexandra and Madeline. Dear sister of Robert Engel. Service 10:00 AM Sunday at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel'', Queens Blvd & 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: More Rainfall Adds to Woes In Wide Swath Of Africa
description: Several weeks of torrential rains and floods, made worse when a deadly storm lashed the heel of Africa this week, have killed more than 150 people and swept away the homes and livelihoods of more than one million in four countries, relief agencies and government officials say.

title: On the Road Toward Hope: Kurt Weill's Celebration Of the Jews
description: AFTER 63 years of dormancy if not oblivion, ''The Eternal Road,'' Kurt Weill's vast, emotionally gripping musical pageant of Jewish history, is returning to the city of its premiere, but in a form that may perplex and even infuriate its audience.

title: Fort Bragg's Changing Tide
description: WHEN I'm walking on Fort Bragg's Glass Beach, I'm easily distracted. If I look out to sea, restless swells break over seaweed-drenched boulders. At my feet, the sand glitters with pebbles of green, red and yellow. This rough beach was once the town dump -- hunks of rusted metal blend into the dark rocks -- and now, after decades of sea-polishing, trash has turned into jewels. On the headland shore above, huge smokestacks at Georgia-Pacific, the forest products company, belch white and gray dragon-puffs into the sky.

title: What It Means to Be Both Cuban and American
description: A GENERATION separates the Cuban-American playwrights Maria Irene Fornes and Nilo Cruz. Ms. Fornes was 15 when she left Cuba in 1945 -- long before Fidel Castro seized power in the 1959 revolution. Mr. Cruz was 9 when he and his parents left in 1970.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. In a Kidbot world, Patty Playpal is just so last century, but if you're old enough to remember that disconcertingly life-size plastic companion, you're also old enough to remember giant rollers (do frozen-juice cans ring a bell?), like the ones Christophe Saluzzo used to give Chandler Hecht's hair that extra lift. There was no star attitude on this set. During the time it took to do her hair, Chandler, 6, who that very morning had calmly reminded her mother, Ellen, that ''this is my first print assignment,'' read (a) ''Sayonara, Mrs. Kackleman'' (Barnes & Noble, $17). Shawn Huang (b) also submitted cheerfully to the indignities of rollers -- which is a lot to ask of anyone, especially a 5-year-old guy.

title: Adding Waste to Landfill Further Imperils Pinelands
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, JOHN T.
description: O'MALLEY-John T. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John T. O'Malley, associated with The Times from 1960 until retiring in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEER, EVA J.
description: NEER-Eva J., M.D. Professor of Medicine at Harvard University on February 20, in Cambridge, MA, of breast cancer. Survived by her husband, Robert Neer, M.D., sons, Robert Jr. and Richard and daughter-in-law Erika Dudley. The Class of 1963 of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons deeply mourns the untimely loss of their classmate, friend, and colleague, an outstanding molecular and cellular biologist, member of the National Academy of Sciences and its Institute of Medicine, and recipient of many major scientific awards. Her linguistic, artistic, and mentoring talents were equally memorable and she will be deeply missed by all those fortunate enough to have known her ebullient spirit and gallant courage. A memorial service will take place at Memorial Church, Harvard University, 3 PM, on March 4. The Class of 1963 Columbia P & S

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 6 about the personal-finance issues that arise from receiving a windfall, like a $1 million prize on a television quiz show, misstated a federal tax rule about exemptions for children. A parent who can claim such an exemption may not shelter income from taxes by declining that exemption and having the child claim it for himself, in a presumably lower tax bracket. Exemptions are not transferable.

title: Something for Everyone at the Outdoor Expo
description: Now in its 23rd year, the World Fishing and Outdoor Exposition will return to the Rockland Community College Fieldhouse next Thursday through Sunday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-18

title: When Doing Wrong Isn't Wrongdoing
description: THE book is closed on this case,'' the judge said on Friday, moments after an Albany County jury acquitted four New York City police officers of all charges in the killing of Amadou Diallo a year ago. That is true only as far as Justice Joseph C. Teresi's courtroom goes. It may take a while before the book closes, if it ever does, on the troubled collective conscience of New York and, perhaps, other corners of America.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The 'Bomb-itty' Boys; Perchance to Rap
description: A SUNDAY night of Shakespeare might not sound like a college student's idea of a rocking time, yet there they were last weekend jamming, not cramming, at ''The Bomb-itty of Errors,'' an ad-rap-tation of ''The Comedy of Errors.'' Four twenty-something friends who all recently attended New York University and a brother who is still there serve up the farce about reunited twins, mixing drag, a D.J. and contemporary riffing. (''You want offensive, man? Take a look at thy mama.'') Picture the Beastie Boys having taken over their literature class -- to the delight of the professor.

title: Czech Women Take Chisel to Stone Wall of Male Government
description: After almost two years of total exclusion from the government, some Czech women feel the time has come to break into the old boys' club.

title: Looking for 'Connecticut' in the Credits
description: HOW many times do you go to the movies and see places that look like the wood lot down the road or the center of a neighboring town? The location may not show up in the credits, but there's a good chance you were right, because Connecticut is still a popular spot to shoot movies.

title: Learning How To Be King
description: Nothing symbolizes the new Middle East realities better than your photo of Crown Prince Hamzeh sitting playfully on the lap of his half-brother, King Abdullah. But is that a holster protruding from under the crown prince's jacket?

title: Cuban Envoy Is Deported After Defying Expulsion
description: The Cuban diplomat ordered expelled last week by the United States on spying charges gave up his diplomatic immunity today and was taken into custody by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after he challenged American officials to arrest him so that he could prove his innocence.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 27, 2000
description: Weeks

title: How Art's Meaning Drifts With the Tides of History
description: THE piece is called ''The Wild Man,'' and it comes from a late-14th-century choir stall in Cologne, Germany. Human in form but animal in its sculptured curly hide, the 11 3/4-inch oak figure is a denizen of the medieval imagination. For Germans in the Middle Ages, this figure, seen in its ecclesiastical setting, evoked the fond myth of the German people descending from a land of rural tribesmen in prelapsarian synthesis with nature. For Germans in the 1930's, ''The Wild Man,'' isolated and abstract in its Bauhaus-style museum case, appealed to other sentiments, including a visceral resentment of Christianity that was channeled into bellicosity and a hatred of Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDWATER, JOHN L.
description: GOLDWATER-John L. 2/14/06-2/ 26/99. Pop, it's been one year and we miss you more than ever. Love, Your Family

title: Medical Errors Can Be Prevented
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRE AND PEOPLE
description: The state Department of Community Affairs has allocated $7.5 million to buy thermal imaging cameras, which allow firefighters to see through dense smoke, for all 700 of the state's fire departments. The cameras, which sense body heat, can locate people trapped in burning buildings. A handful of state fire departments bought cameras through grants or fund-raisers, but most do not have one. A decision is expected soon on a company to provide 1,000 cameras. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Suddenly, a Kiwi Sweep Is Looking More Than Likely
description: After an America's Cup week in which the lasting images will be those of an Italian crewman laid low by a blow to the head, and the Prada Challenge's silver boat Luna Rossa in relentless and fruitless pursuit of Team New Zealand's powerful NZL 60, perhaps only one more symbolic picture is necessary.

title: West Bank Standoff
description: The Israeli-Palestinian peace effort, which American envoys have been busy trying to revive this week, is deadlocked over the fate of this unprepossessing Arab town on the eastern outskirts of Jerusalem.

title: Paintings Do the Talking, Without Too Many Specifics
description: GARY KOMARIN doesn't want to say too much about his paintings, but he's not brusque about it. He's almost apologetic, actually, but in the course of explaining why he'd rather let the paintings speak for themselves, he ends up telling quite a bit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAFF, SYLVIA
description: BRAFF-Sylvia. On February 25th. Beloved wife of Lewis; adored mother of Shelly and George, Jonathon and Lynne, and Michael and Gladys. Most cherished and devoted grandmother. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Mason's Arrest Adds to the Hornets' Troubles
description: Running through drills at their shoot-around this morning, the Charlotte Hornets appeared no different from any other team on any other day. But perhaps more than any other team, the Hornets could handle the latest development without flinching.

title: A Bond Master Reflects On Flirting With Disaster
description: IN the $14.7 trillion bond market, Bill Gross, who manages $90 billion directly for the Pacific Investment Management Company, is the big name -- and he has a track record for being right.

title: Students in West Bank Throw Stones at the French Prime Minister
description: Angry Palestinian students pitched stones at French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin today and pummeled his car with rocks as he was concluding a visit with Palestinian intellectuals at the leading university in the West Bank.

title: How the 2000 Ballot Could Amend Form 1040
description: RARELY have voters had such a clear opportunity to let Washington know what they want to do about taxes.

title: A Mini-Tuesday, With Its Quirky Prize, Looms Larger
description: When the 2000 presidential campaign began, the Republican and Democratic primaries that will be held in Washington State on Tuesday were hardly more than blips on the political horizon, arcane little contests lying somewhere out on the trail between the first-in-the nation Iowa caucuses and the could-end-it-all mass of 13 primaries scheduled for Titanic Tuesday, March 7.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: I'LL BE RIGHT BACK Memories of TV's Greatest Talk Show Host. By Mike Douglas with Thomas Kelly and Michael Heaton. Simon & Schuster, $25.

title: Where All Trails Lead To the Sea
description: ON the lead horse, the guide raised his hand to signal a halt. He tilted his head. So did the horse. They had heard a noise somewhere in the still redwood forest. All we could hear was horses' breathing and the wind through the tops of the trees.

title: Tunisia Revisited
description: The plane from palermo to tunis was late leaving, and we passed the time speculating about our fellow passengers: which were Sicilian, and which Tunisian (not easy to guess); which were honeymooners on their way to the new beach resorts of Djerba or Port El Kantaoui. Thirty-five years earlier my husband, Tonino, and I had spent our honeymoon in Tunisia, North Africa's smallest country, with a population of more than nine million people living in an area slightly larger than the state of Georgia. Then it had been a newly independent country poised on the edge of a tourist boom. Now we were going back to see what remained of the Tunisia we had explored and loved in 1964, and what had changed beyond all recognition.

title: With Africa Watching, Senegal Casts Votes That Count
description: The presidential election on Sunday in Senegal has one critical difference that sets it apart from past votes and that offers a snapshot of the evolution of democracy in sub-Saharan Africa: no one knows who will win.

title: Torn Mitrovica Reflects West's Trials in Kosovo
description: Muhamat Uflla, 57, ran for his life on the tempestuous night of Feb. 3, when Serbs rampaged in their enclave of northern Mitrovica after a grenade attack on a Serbian cafe. At least eight Albanians died that night, but today Mr. Uflla was registering with the United Nations police to try to return to his apartment.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: REMEMBER when Emma Thompson and Kenneth Branagh seemed destined to become the Lunt and Fontanne of their generation? That ended with their 1995 divorce, of course, but at least we have ''Henry V'' and DEAD AGAIN (1991), their American-made film noir about reincarnation and murder. Ms. Thompson plays an amnesiac who has recurring dreams that she is a concert pianist murdered in the 1940's. As the investigating detective and the murdered pianist's husband (flashbacks), Mr. Branagh, who directed, does both American and German accents. Sir Derek Jacobi is fabulous as an antiques dealer who dabbles in hypnosis - Saturday at 3 p.m. on Sci Fi.

title: Cristyne Lategano, Nicholas Nicholas
description: Cristyne Ford Lategano, a New York City tourism official and the former communications director for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, was married in South Carolina yesterday to Nicholas Stratis Nicholas, a sportswriter. The Rev. Ernest Grey performed the ceremony at the Johns Island Presbyterian Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, E. CLIFTON
description: DANIEL-E. Clifton. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passin of E. Clifton Daniel, associated with The Times from 1944 until retiring in 1977.

title: Young Filmmakers Seek The Next 'Blair Witch'
description: AFTER the success of ''The Blair Witch Project'' last year, it seemed that anyone with a dream, a camera and an Internet account could get a film made -- or, at least, market it cheaply once it was made. After all, if two 20-somethings could shoot a movie and then hype it online, garnering phenomenal media attention and millions of dollars, why couldn't the average Joe?

title: A Mighty Fortress
description: To get to the house where Stephen and Megan Scheibner live with their seven children, you skirt past Allentown, Pa., and drive for another half-hour into the hills above the Lehigh Valley. The Scheibner place is on Blue Mountain Road, a few miles past a forlorn establishment called Binnie's Hot Dogs and Family Food. Standing behind their white clapboard farmhouse, where the backyard unfurls over three and a half acres and where, in summer, you can see a tangled strawberry patch and a tree fort, you could swear you were deep in the country and maybe deep in the past too. The front of the house is a different matter. It's practically on top of a busy road that leads to the local ski resorts; the view is of a housing development under construction.

title: Check the Map, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Conflict of Interest Raised in LIPA Deal
description: KeySpan Energy, which manages the electric system for the Long Island Power Authority, has helped award a major LIPA contract to one of KeySpan's affiliates, raising questions about possible conflicts of interest, LIPA acknowledged this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAVID, JACOB M.
description: RAVID-Jacob M., M.D. In loving remembrance as ever forever. On February 26, 1967. Family, Friends and Associates

title: Waiting for Lefty, Then Righty
description: THE PARADOX OF AMERICAN DEMOCRACY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIDT, TRUDE
description: SCHEIDT-Trude (Strauss). On February 2nd, 2000 at 94-1/2. Beloved wife of the late Willy, adored mother of Fred and Werner, mother-in-law of Roz, sister of Eugene Strauss, cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: 'Johnny Mac,' Jack Nicholson Said, 'Don't Ever Change'
description: It is tempting to compare your celebration of John McEnroe's obnoxious behavior on the tennis court with baseball's suspension of John Rocker for offensive remarks in Sports Illustrated. Nobody ever suggested that McEnroe needed psychological testing for berating officials or for tasteless behavior. ''A screw loose,'' indeed! Rocker's remarks were politically incorrect and certainly stupid, but hardly a psychological ''disorder.'' Unlike in the case of McEnroe, this is something that, hopefully, Rocker will outgrow.

title: Blind Children Take a Small Step Toward Public School
description: Grasping a bar designed to help blind children keep their balance as they play, 4-year-old Monique jumps up and down on a small yellow trampoline.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Sunday with the Frugal Traveler column, about a bus trip to Luang Prabang, Laos, located Chiang Mai, Thailand, incorrectly. It is some 400 miles southwest of Luang Prabang, not just across the border from Vientiane. (The place labeled Chiang Mai was Si Chiang Mai.)

title: Food; Chichi Cabbage
description: Cabbage reigns where fear presides; at least that has been its history. In times of scarcity -- as the ''rose'' of various famines, or simply as one of the few green vegetables that could endure long, cold winters -- cabbage has always been king.

title: An Unusual Case of Role Reversal
description: IN 1980, before ''True West,'' his play about the contorted reunion of two estranged brothers, opened at the Magic Theater in San Francisco, Sam Shepard was asked by a reporter why he wrote it.

title: An Artist From Prison
description: John Rich was a busy man in the eight years he spent in prison on a drug charge. While other inmates were fighting, Mr. Rich spent hours painting surreal images on canvases as part of a prison art class.

title: All the Kings' Pets
description: REIGNING CATS

title: Just Don't Mention the Nose
description: SO I AM GLAD By A. L. Kennedy. 276 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ALBERT J.
description: ROSENBERG-Albert J. Age 90, of Trumbull, CT, and Delray Beach, FL, on Friday, February 25, 2000. Educator, Senior Corporate Executive, and Philanthropist. Born November 25, 1909, in Baltimore, MD, son of Henry and Laura (Hollinder) Rosenberg, graduated Carnegie-Mellon University (Class of 1932) with a degree in Aeronautical Engineering and a master's degree from New York University. Mr. Rosenberg was Vice President/General Manager of the McGraw-Hill Book Company, who developed the Text-Film Division, subsequently educating millions of children/adults worldwide with motion pictures, recordings, and slide films as textbook teaching aids. Mr. Rosenberg served as President of a private philanthropic foundation, providing millions of dollars of funding for all manner of educational, cultural, medical, and general not-for-profit charities benefiting the people of the City of New York. Surviving Mr. Rosenberg are his wife Edith (Hammond) Rosenberg, a brother Jesse Rosenberg of Baltimore, MD, two sons William F. Rosenberg of Westport, CT and Dr. Lawrence E. Rosenberg of Newton Centre, MA, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, March 1st, at 11 AM at the Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT. Contributions may be made to Connecticut Hospice or The National Parkinson Foundation.

title: For the Fare, a Driver's Sit-Down Comedy
description: STANLEY COLEMAN'S thought of the day: ''Some days you're the pigeon and some days you're the statue.''

title: Yes, Travel Can Be Murder
description: SOME people travel to find the perfect beach, or the biggest, tallest, highest something or other. I go to find the perfect place to kill somebody.

title: Blaming Your Neighbor For That Messy Desk
description: You resolved to become more organized at work this year, but you're already waving the white flag. Look on the bright side -- a new book may offer a ready-made excuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, FREDERICK THOMAS
description: CLARK-Frederick Thomas. 84, on February 25th, 2000. Survived by wife of 57 years, Betty Clark, father of Margaret and Michael Lingle and Patricia and David McCarthy, grandfather of Michael, Chris, Ami, Brad, Donna, Kristen, Joe, and Jen, great-grandfather of Katie and Andrew. Services at First Methodist Church in Dalton, GA.

title: When Cabaret Had an Edge
description: KURT WEILL rarely wrote for the notorious Weimar-era cabarets of Berlin. Still, the popular misimpression that identifies him with the Berlin haunts of Christopher Isherwood and Sally Bowles is understandable. Weill's music from this period sounds so deliciously dangerous. Its harsh beauty and dissonant lyricism embody everything we believe Berlin cabaret to have been: sardonic, sophisticated, gorgeously profane.

title: McCain's Character
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Fights
description: For overworked Americans, the two-martini lunch, or a series of hurried snacks, consumed at the desk or in a Spartan break room. Etiqueete hasn't kept up. Half-eaten sandwichs are stolen from their owners' desks, while office microwaves and refrigerators ooze with months of grime. And few workplaces seem to have an desk-top-dining rules. Send your spiciest stories to On the Job, Money & Busines, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Samantha Haywood, Steven Boughal
description: Tami Samantha Haywood, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Holt Haywood of New York, was married yesterday to Steven Boughal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Boughal of Bayport, N.Y. The Rev. Bruce Forbes performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Erica Rutkin, Jeffrey Keswin
description: Erica Lynne Rutkin, a daughter of Gail Rutkin of Fairfield, Conn., and Arnold Rutkin of Milford, Conn., was married last evening to Jeffrey Alan Keswin, a son of Janice and Steven Keswin of Plymouth, Minn. Rabbi Sarah Reines officiated at the Puck Building in New York.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-27-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Jon Barton, Bandera, Tex., December 3, 1999

title: CHEMICAL SPILL
description: A six-month investigation into a chemical spill at a Burlington warehouse has ended with one federal agency citing another for endangering workers. The United States Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration said last week the General Services Administration was guilty of serious and willful violations of OSHA regulations that resulted in 27 workers at the G.S.A. warehouse in Burlington being hospitalized following an August spill of the chemical used to chlorinate swimming pools. The G.S.A. failed to have an emergency response plan and failed to give workers respirators and chemical safety goggles, according to Chester J. Fultz, an OSHA spokesman. Since the spill, G.S.A. has corrected the violations and the safety officer at the warehouse is no longer with the agency, said James Gillern, a G.S.A. spokesman. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Quick Bright Things

title: Generational Divide on Freedom's Trail
description: When Danny Glover was growing up in San Francisco in the 1950's and 60's, he and his four siblings spent every summer at their grandparents' farmhouse in rural Georgia. ''It was like a fantasy,'' Mr. Glover says now. ''You come from the city, you go to the farm.''

title: Two Yankees Reflect on Fathers
description: Maury Brosius lived just a couple of minutes from his son's family in the hamlet of McMinnville, Ore., and it was habit to include him in the smallest snippets of life. If one of Scott Brosius' young children said something funny, well, you picked up the phone and called Dad. If you went somewhere, you called Dad.

title: Don't Blame Me, I'm Only the Underwriter
description: Would you lend money to someone who said he might not be telling you the truth about his ability to repay the debt? That is sort of what many municipal bond underwriters are asking of prospective buyers in the disclaimers they attach to offering documents, and a trade group wants to make it a standard practice.

title: Under God, Not Indivisible
description: No one knows who will win the presidential election, but it is already clear that the conservative Christian political movement has lost.

title: In the World of City Parks, A Living Bridge to the Past
description: On June 26, 1944, the day Mary Purcell was hired at the New York City Parks Department, Robert Moses issued a press release on park vandalism and the Goldman Band gave a free concert in Central Park. That same week, the 10th annual barbershop quartet competitions were held and Starlight dances for servicemen began.

title: Lorraine Breitman, Alan Eras
description: Lorraine Ruth Breitman and Alan Joseph Eras are to be married today by Rabbi Azriel Fellner at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Red Storm Begins Madness a Bit Early
description: This scramble had no purpose: Bootsy Thornton drifted to midcourt. Lavor Postell hopped toward the free-throw line. Erick Barkley skipped toward the baseline and his joyous teammates. The horn had just sounded on St. John's 83-82 upset of second-ranked Duke, and the Red Storm players did not quite know how act.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, LAWRENCE M.
description: ROSNER-Lawrence M. You will always be in our hearts. Sympathy to Tobe, Caren, David and Susan. Eleftherion Family

title: The Grunts Of Grozny
description: The first thing Lieut. Vyacheslav Kiselyov did before leading his platoon into Grozny was to yank the metal plates from his bulletproof vest, leaving only the panel that covered his heart. Then he crammed the jacket with extra cartridges of ammunition. It was one of those trade-offs Russian soldiers make to maximize their chances of survival. The regular supply of ammo -- four magazines with 32 cartridges each -- is good for only about 20 minutes of fighting. The fire from Chechen rebels can sometimes get so intense, however, that it sounds like eggs on a griddle, and Vyacheslav felt his best protection was having enough bullets to answer back. He also put aside his helmet. It was nice to have if you were manning a checkpoint. But when a soldier has to run for his life and dodge snipers, the ill-fitting helmet just gets in the way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, GEORGE
description: HERMAN-George. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George Herman, associated with The Times from 1973 until retiring in 1981.

title: Staking Claims To New Frontiers In Education
description: THE day after charter school legislation was approved in January 1996, Maureen Quirk, an electrical engineer, received an e-mail from another Princeton parent suggesting that she dive into these new educational waters.

title: How to Beat Mr. Greenspan's Stock Market
description: WHEN Alan Greenspan frets openly that stock prices have been rising faster than household incomes, it's a good idea to assume that this is highly practical information, something other than his frequently opaque comments.

title: Lori Greifer, Glenn Kaufman
