description: Lori Beth Greifer, a social worker, and Glenn David Kaufman, the president of an Internet start-up company in Boston, were married last evening by Rabbi Myron Fenster at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: But Will It Have Toll Booths?
description: Maybe they'll call it the Ho Chi Minh Highway. In a hopeful lunge at development, Vietnam announced it would carve a north-south road through its western mountains along the route of the former Ho Chi Minh Trail.

title: In Meadow or Garden, Counting Butterflies
description: PEOPLE in Connecticut are batty for butterflies. Or, to be more scientific about it, they're loopy for Lepidoptera (the butterfly's scientific order meaning scaled wing).

title: Mao's Accomplices
description: To the Editor:

title: Listening to the Grammys
description: AMERICANS bought an estimated $14 billion or more of recorded music last year. And music, arguably even more than movies or television, has been the vanguard of the post-World War II American cultural onslaught that has swept through the world.

title: A Call for Pension Plan Changes
description: Traditional defined benefit pensions are slowly dying, strangled by too much regulation, the New York State Bar Association said in a report calling for wholesale revision of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.

title: Old-Time Italian Food at Pleasing Prices
description: BEFORE the arrival of the stylish Tuscans, before the sleek, neon-edged pasta cafes, before the avalanche of Italian family-style spots, there was Taverna. It remains an Italian restaurant in a time warp.

title: New College Sticker Shock: Junior's Credit Card Bill
description: PARENTS who thought they had planned enough, saved enough and struggled enough to see their children through college are confronting a challenge they never anticipated -- what to do when junior comes home one weekend and announces that he is deep in debt on credit cards they didn't even know he had.

title: If Not One China Now, Then When?
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST PERSON; The Big Bang
description: THE day started out nicely enough. My two little girls and their baby sitter were playing in the neighborhood park. My husband was in his downtown Manhattan office, and I was alone at home, engrossed in my work. It was nearly lunch time, and I was facing a deadline on a project, with several hours' of editing left.

title: Little Boxes, Little Boxes
description: JERRY NOONAN has what he calls ''a nice problem.'' Nearly all 400 boxes at his Mail Boxes Etc. outlet on the Avenue of the Americas near 14th Street have been rented, so Mr. Noonan, who owns the franchise, has come up with what he calls the ''virtual mailbox.'' Instead of getting keys to an actual box, customers go to the desk and ask for their mail.

title: The Defector From the Big Board
description: It was just good old-fashioned marketing by Nasdaq -- and not an old school connection -- that led Michael Gorin to urge his company to become the first in 60 years to voluntarily leave the New York Stock Exchange, long regarded as the market to which all of corporate America ultimately aspired.

title: A Wit Who Wrote As He Gardened
description: ON a gray day in January, when I should have been working, I burrowed into my couch and opened ''Merry Hall,'' by Beverley Nichols.

title: A Long Triumphs In the Olympic Trials
description: She moved from the anonymity of the pack into sudden contention in today's Olympic marathon trials, surging into third place, second, then first after 20 miles, and finally, all the runners with faster qualifying times and bigger reputations were behind her. At that moment no one was more surprised to be ahead than the leader herself, Dr. Christine Clark.

title: Miami Beach Clubgoers Creating New, Unwanted Image
description: It is just past 9 o'clock on a Sunday morning and the Kit Kat lounge in South Beach has closed. A boy and a girl stand motionless on the sidewalk, clinging like mortared bricks. Three shirtless boys in black pants mill around them, and a girl in a white T-shirt gyrates and claps, lost to a beat that still hammers her head. She is a ''roller,'' high on the drug Ecstasy.

title: High Hurdles Await McCain in the All-Important Race for G.O.P. Delegates
description: Eventually, the quest for presidential nominations comes down to delegates. Numbers start counting for more than buzz, bump and momentum.

title: Nets Maintain Their Focus and Finish Off the Hornets
description: It was an odd twist for the Nets tonight, shaking their heads before the game at the trouble and turmoil surrounding their opponents down the hall. Then as the game wound down, the Nets again were out of character, playing with poise and aggressiveness as they ran away from the Charlotte Hornets, 104-93.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; Exhibition Selected in Cyberspace
description: For its latest exhibition, curators at the Montclair Art Museum have left the selection of works to Web-savvy art lovers.

title: Henderson Has His Say on Meeting Valentine
description: Rickey Henderson predicted that he would be as important to the Mets as any other player this season, insisted that Manager Bobby Valentine's decision to modify his playing time in 1999 had nothing to do with his finest statistical year in a decade and had to be joking when he said that he disliked the spotlight.

title: Criticism for Law Barring Foster Parents With Past Felonies
description: Under a far-reaching new federal law designed to protect children's safety, New York State officials for the first time are conducting criminal background checks on all current and prospective foster and adoptive parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAIEFF, MARY ELISABETH
description: RAIEFF-Mary Elisabeth. 83. On February 25, 2000. Survived by her husband Josef, two daughters Alexandra and Valerie and one granddaughter. Beloved music teacher who received a double graduate fellowship from the Juilliard School. Interment private.

title: Style; Maid to Order
description: As someone whose autobiography might be titled ''Too Far to Walk,'' I love the idea of robots. How nice it would be to push a button -- no, my robot will be voice-activated! -- and have a machine write my thank-you notes (the Etiquetti 1320X); find my keys (a Ferretizer); fill out insurance forms (the Toshiba Triplicate Man); argue with Bell Atlantic over my bill (#*@!!! ); make up my mind about what to order at restaurants (le Cuisinateur); tell me what to wear in the morning (the Mombot); get rid of the clothes in my closet that I never wear (the Incinerator II); buy gifts for my friends and relatives (the Santoid); stand in line to have those gifts wrapped (the WaitMate); read the newspaper and provide me with daily synopses (Pentium News Processor); make witty repartee in my place at cocktail parties (the Banteraton); fix my computer, program the VCR and in general be in charge of all the other robotlike appliances in my house (a PowerOmniboss); and then, never flagging, finish writing this article (the Me2).

title: A Preservationist Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Redeeming the Irish
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dance Retelling of 'Othello'
description: MORE than 100 performers -- 20 dancers, 65 singers and more than 20 instrumentalists -- will come together for a millennium engagement performance of the Jose Limon Dance Company at the Riverside Church. The choir and musicians of the church will accompany the dance troupe in a full performance, including ''Evening Songs'' by Jiri Kylian set to the music of Dvorak, and two works by Limon, who died in 1972.

title: At Least for Now, Retirees Find That New Jobs Come at a Price
description: AMERICA needs more workers. Without them, the nation's economic boom may be threatened, if current workers can command big pay raises and thus bring inflation into the picture. Luckily, there is a solution readily at hand: a gray horde of retirees, many of whom want to work at something.

title: Leave Cooperation On Guns With Merchants
description: Why not rely on the cooperation of merchants not to sell toy guns that resemble the real ones [''Bill to Control Toy Guns Moves Forward,'' Feb. 6]. Banning their manufacture through legislation invites a legal challenge and associated costs. Any enforcement scheme would require that police officers visit merchants and issue summonses.

title: Sentimental Education
description: The Romantics

title: Neighborhood Exotic
description: AFTER a parade of carpaccio and creme brulee served in rooms in varying degrees of chic, I was more than ready for kabobs and baklava in a low-key neighborhood place. Samdan, a perennially popular Middle Eastern spot here, seemed like just the spot.

title: Fixing the First Lady Problem
description: Andrew Sullivan paints a fascinating portrait of Ernestine Schlant and her relationship with her husband, Bill Bradley (Counter Culture, Feb. 13), but his not-so-subtle bashing of Hillary Clinton doesn't do justice to either woman.

title: Subjecting Greenspan's Theories to Peer Review
description: ECONOMIC theory is wonderfully pliable. Just when the Federal Reserve seemed to be running out of reasons to slow the economy in anticipation of a rising inflation rate that is taking forever to rise, Alan Greenspan has in the last 10 days come up with a new theory that requires the Fed to act, and quickly.

title: Psychiatric Drugs for Tots
description: A study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association reported a ''troubling'' rise in the number of preschool children being medicated with stimulants, antidepressants and other psychiatric drugs. From 1991 to 1995, it found, stimulants including methylphenidate, the generic form of Ritalin, increased two to three times for children aged 2 to 4 in the programs studied, while antidepressant use doubled and the use of clonidine, a blood pressure drug, also jumped. It was the first study to document an increase among children younger than 5.

title: A Burmese Cruise Far Beyond Mandalay
description: East is east and west is west, but for four years they have met on the Road to Mandalay, a luxury ship sailing the Irrawaddy River in Myanmar. It has allowed Westerners to explore the exotic land that many still call Burma, mainly between Mandalay and Bagan to the south. This August they can sail north to and beyond Bhamo in a special sailing through the rarely visited Three Narrows area of the Irrawaddy.

title: Keeping a Stiff Upper Lip During the Barrage
description: ''I think I'm going to win the presidency, really,'' Gov. George W. Bush told a reporter on the day after a 6-point loss to Senator John McCain in the Michigan primary. Under the circumstances, he sounded like one of the heroic optimists who got London through the blitz.

title: One Legacy of a 41-Bullet Barrage Is a Hard Look at Aggressive Tactics on the Street
description: The death of Amadou Diallo last year became a defining event for the New York Police Department. The shooting of the unarmed West African immigrant by four white officers spurred protests, prompted various examinations of the department's admittedly aggressive tactics, and attracted so much attention that police officials blamed the news media for what they said was a sudden timidity among the rank-and-file.

title: A Claim of Bias in the Secret Service
description: Led by Reginald G. Moore, a Secret Service agent who once held a top spot on President Clinton's protective detail, black agents last week filed a class action discrimination complaint with the agency charging systematic bias in promotions, assignments and transfers. Although Mr. Moore had received outstanding performance evaluations, he was denied a promotion last year to the agency's managerial ranks, required to train the white agent promoted ahead of him and transferred to a counterfeiting squad in Dallas. The agency would not comment on the complaint, but said that it had worked hard to create a diverse work environment.

title: QUICK BITE/Trenton; Dome-Style Cooking
description: For the last 10 years, famished Trenton lawmakers had to wander the streets in search of a bite to eat. Even in clement weather they trudged to a stretch of fast-food joints in a pedestrian mall blocks away, or else snagged a plastic-wrapped sandwich and a cup of soup from a newsstand in the basement of the State House. It was a bone of contention that popped up in conversation: Other state capitals had on-site eateries. Why didn't Trenton?

title: The Tax Maze Begins Here. No, Here. No . . .
description: MUCH of the tax agenda that Republicans promised in the ''Contract With America'' has been enacted into law in the last five years. But as Newt Gingrich, the contract's author, is fond of saying: There is no free lunch.

title: China's Own Witch Hunt
description: ''WHO LOST TAIWAN?''

title: The Mutual Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Mano a Mano at the Market
description: First, Gary J. Fernandes and George T. Shaheen were rivals in high-technology consulting, Mr. Fernandes as vice chairman of Electronic Data Systems and chairman of its consulting unit, and Mr. Shaheen as chief of Andersen Consulting. Then they became legal adversaries, as Mr. Fernandes testified for Arthur Andersen, according to court records, in its continuing battle with Andersen Consulting over the terms of their corporate divorce.

title: Hotels Open, Ready or Not
description: LAST fall I spent a night at the W Tuscany, a stylish, newly refurbished hotel in New York. My room was comfortable, quiet and, for the most part, smartly renovated. The lobby was another matter. No one had warned me when I made my reservation that it was still under construction. The elevators opened near a new front desk still shrouded in packing wrap. In the morning, the hotel set up a Continental breakfast in an old sitting room next to the new lobby. As I poured my coffee, buzz saws screamed and hammers pounded. I fled to my room, appalled but not particularly surprised.

title: Bonding Across Cultural Boundaries
description: STANDING behind me in a hotel lobby in London was an unmistakably familiar figure, who had bobbed up to ask for something at the reception desk. June 1993: I was there to give the BBC Reith Lectures but had coincidentally bought a ticket to hear Daniel Barenboim play Bartok's First Piano Concerto with Pierre Boulez and the London Symphony Orchestra. And suddenly there was Mr. Barenboim himself in the same line. I'm not one for importuning celebrities, and to be honest, he was so identified as an Israeli musician that the barrier for me as an Arab was hard to overcome. But there he was, and overcome it I quickly did.

title: Period Detail
description: To the Editor:

title: Adding a Dose of the Arts To a Batch of Academics
description: Victoria CLARK is showing her students what she expects of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLETCHER, WALTER R.
description: FLETCHER-Walter R. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Walter R. Fletcher, associated with The Times from 1927 until retiring in 1976.

title: A Hotel Group for Branson and Friends
description: Richard Branson, who is almost as well known for piloting a hot-air balloon as he is for founding Virgin Atlantic Airways, is a man who readily mixes pleasure with business. And when he recently announced his new hotel collection, Limited Edition by Virgin, Mr. Branson said that it was more about good times than good strategy.

title: Our Towns; A Boy Fumes, And Suddenly, A Frenzy
description: THE incident at Cottage Lane School began with the private seething of a 10-year-old boy. His teacher had kept the class inside at recess to punish students for talking, and he was mad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELNICK, BABS
description: MELNICK-Babs. Of Forest Hills, NY, died in Washington, D.C. 01 February 2000, of complications from a fall in 1997. A wonderfully warm and open-hearted person loved by all, who never spoke ill of anyone, Babs travelled the world with her beloved daughter Ronnie and welcomed family and friends from far and wide to her home and table. Babs, predeceased by her husband Jack in 1980, is survived by her devoted daughter Ronnie Mae Melnick of Washington, D.C., daughter Carolyn Goldberg and grandson of Phoenix, AZ and brother Isidore Zaroff of Hollywood, FL. Burial was at Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY, 04 February. A memorial service is planned for a later date. As a tribute to her precious mummy, Ronnie has created the Babs Melnick Memorial Fund at the African Wildlife Foundation. Babs always encouraged Ronnie to be adventurous, and was particulary proud of Ronnie's lifelong love of and devotion to Africa. The Babs Melnick Memorial Fund will honor and perpetuate Babs and Ronnie's abiding interest in African wildlife, children and the environment. Contributions in Babs's memory can be made to African Wildlife Foundation/Babs Melnick Memorial Fund, c/o African Wildlife Foundation, 1400 Sixteenth Street, N.W., Suite 120, Washington, D.C. 20036.

title: In the Region / Connecticut; Rehabilitating Historically Significant Enclaves
description: WORK will begin next month on restoring 16 deteriorating houses in Frog Hollow, a devastated area of Hartford long plagued by drugs, crime, vandalism and large-scale abandonment. The project is the first to be implemented under a new state law, effective Wednesday, called the Connecticut Historic Homes Rehabilitation Tax Credit Program.

title: La Paz: Memoirs of a Dancing Devil
description: In La Paz, the sun shines from April to October, nightfall the only significant interruption. Two and a quarter miles above sea level, the light of Bolivia's capital is so clear it begins to seem a form of cognizance. It showers like pure gold from the flawless paint-blue sky, filling perception with an ethereal, incorporeal splendor that challenges even the solidity of the carved granite that composes large parts of the city streets and buildings. This is no less than Inti, I decided, the mystical sun worshiped by the great Andean empires, Tiahuanaco and Inca.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEAKE, DAVID WAINWRIGHT
description: PEAKE-David Wainwright. 75. Of Houston, TX, died February 20. Survived by his wife of 51 years, Ann Journeay Peake, father of Robin Peake Stuart of Lake Forest, IL, David W. Peake, Jr. of Fredericksburg, TX, and Susan S. Peake of Houston. Also survived by seven grandchildren, and his sister, Alison, Mrs. Basil Duke Henning of New Haven, CT, and a brother J.H. Cameron Peake of Essex, CT. Graduate of Kent School and Yale University, Class of 1950, where he was a member of the Fence Club and Wolf's Head Senior Society. Member of the 2nd and 5th Divison of Marine Corps in World War II. Memorial contributions to Kent School, Yale University or Ducks Unlimited.

title: Home Court Advantage
description: A generation ago, the Camden Bullets would draw a couple of thousand people to Camden Convention Hall across from Cooper Hospital Coached by Pete Monska, a young Cherry Hill schoolteacher, the Bullets, part of the Eastern Basketball Association, often featured raw players just short of making the National Basketball Association, and older guys, like the former Warrior Paul Arazin, looking for a few weekend bucks after the prime of their careers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAHORIC, SYLVIA
description: BAHORIC-Sylvia. On Saturday, February 19, 2000 in Brooklyn, New York at 83. Beloved wife of the late Bozidar Bahoric. Devoted mother of Dr. Allan Bahoric of New York City, and Carol Bahoric and Myron Meisel of Los Angeles, California. Adoring grandmother of Laura and Sascha Meisel.

title: Science Fiction
description: You think the Internet has been commercialized? Wait until the entrepreneurs get into space. In THE MARTIAN RACE (Warner Aspect, $23.95), Gregory Benford, a professor of physics at the University of California, Irvine, foresees a near future in which the expense of mounting a manned expedition to Mars will be assumed not by NASA or some similar agency but by media-savvy promoters competing for a $30-billion there-and-back-again prize.

title: Pearl Harbor Was a Day Of Infamy, Not Whimsy
description: I was not amused to read that a Japanese restaurant in Port Washington had named one of its appetizers ''Pearl Harbor'' [''Japanese Fare a Stripe Above Average, Feb. 20]. Even at a distance of almost 60 years, the 31 months I spent in the South West Pacific Theater during World War II is hardly a subject of levity. The Bonsai restaurant trivializes the event that in the minds of Americans will always stand for treachery. I trust the owners will find a more appropriate name for their appetizer.

title: Albert Cleage Is Dead at 88; Led Black Nationalist Church
description: Bishop Albert B. Cleage, who after the urban riots of the 1960's built his Detroit church, the Shrine of the Black Madonna, into an important center for black theology and political power, died on Feb. 20 in Calhoun Falls, S.C. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDSTEIN, GLADYS M.
description: BRANDSTEIN-Gladys M. 91. Born in New York City, January 14, 1909. Died in NYC February 21, 2000. Devoted wife of Dr. Philip L. Brandstein, deceased in 1968. One of the first women to receive a law degree from NYU Law School. A progressive Attorney involved with civil rights and antipoverty programs. Managed a redevelopment housing projects in Crown Heights. Operated summer camps Wabigoon and Wahanda and was a positive influence in the lives of hundreds of children over two generations. In her elderly years, she served as a volunteer for a public library and as a mentor for newly arrived immigrants. She leaves her sons Lawrence Z. and David Z. Brandstein, grandchildren Kendra-the special apple in her eye, love/light in her life, Vicente, Asha, Owa & ''nephews'' and ''nieces'', Herman and Sunny Berkowitz and Ralph and Marilyn Berkowitz -sons of her life-long best friend Irma, deceased.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-27-00: On Language; Come Heavy
description: What's a goomah, and how does it differ from a goombah? Is the adjective skeevy somehow related to the slang noun for underwear, skivvies? Does the come-heavy Mafia talk on television give you agita?

title: Gumshoes on the Danube
description: With globalization making it as easy for the mob as it is for the corporation to operate across borders, the Federal Bureau of Investigation is going abroad in pursuit of the Russian mafia -- really, a collection of mafias -- whose tentacles have spread globally and now reach into Brighton Beach, South Miami, Philadelphia and Los Angeles. When the mob leaders are not in Moscow, they have been hanging out in Budapest, a pleasant city on the Danube and a fine way station on the path to Western Europe. So that is where, next month, the F.B.I. will be opening its first full-fledged office beyond American shores.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Exhibition of Woodcuts

title: Rising Tax Bills Fuel Anger in Canada
description: In a hotel restaurant here, Jordan switched her cell phone to voice mail, nibbled on a slice of cold salmon, and then spun a libertarian view of taxes.

title: Mao's Accomplices
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLISON, WALTER
description: WALLISON-Walter, on February 24, 2000, at the age of 93, and even then too soon. The beloved husband of Pearl, adored father of Peter and Frieda, and Jane and Hugh, revered grandpa to Ethan, Jeremy, Elizabeth and George, Rebecca, and Amanda, a gentle, loving and inspiring friend and companion to his adoring family, he chose his path to the very end, and will live always in our memories. For more information, please call Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, (201) 843-9090.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESEROLE, JERE S.
description: MESEROLE-Jere S. Of Burlington, VT, and Boca Raton, FL, died February 24, 2000, at home in Boca Raton with his family. Born May 19, 1922 in Englewood, NJ, son of Clinton and Ida Meserole, graduated Princeton University ('44), decorated veteran of WW II, lived in Burlington, VT, and ran several small businesses and was a Vice President of Chittenden Bank. Survived by his wife, Carole Howe Meserole; his children, Jere S., Jr., Gregg R., Rolf H. and Kristin; stepchildren Laura Howe-Koh, James R. Howe, V, Sally C. Howe-Viens and Christopher T. Howe; and eleven grandchildren. Memorial service will be on May 6, 10 AM, First Congregational Church, Burlington, VT.

title: When Disaster Strikes, the Tax Code Comes Part of the Way to the Rescue
description: ANTHONY SILVA remembers the heavy rain on that September day, and how the waters rose by the hour around his three-story home. Sometime after dark, Mr. Silva, 55, and his girlfriend, Peggy Marish, conceded defeat to Tropical Storm Floyd, and fled their home, which eventually was filled with five feet of water.

title: Slide May Cost Seton Hall Bid to N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Darius Lane said Seton Hall was tired. Shaheen Holloway reasoned that the team was going through its ups and downs. Instead of surging toward their first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament berth in six years, the Pirates are stumbling at the finish line, losing by 87-74 today to Villanova.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BINET, DENNIS
description: BINET-Dennis. Memorial service Sunday, February 27, 2000, 1:45PM at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. A gathering to celebrate his life immediately following at Empire Hotel, 44 W. 63rd St., Mezzanine Ballroom, 3:30-5:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, JEAN A.
description: MILLS-Jean A., on February 25th, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Susan Birnbaum (Howard) and Michael (Barbara). Adored grandfather of Megan, David, Howard Joshua and Marisa. Cherished brother-inlaw, uncle and friend. Retired NYPD. Service at 12:30 PM, Sunday, at Riverdale Temple, 246th St. and Independence Ave.

title: Entering New Castle, Del.
description: For years, i confess, i'd come to think of Delaware as that long, rather terrifying bridge between Maryland and New Jersey -- specifically, the Delaware Memorial Bridge that you cross (and cross and cross) on the way to Washington from New York. So it was a revelation and a pleasure actually to stop in Delaware, and to discover that what lives more or less underneath the bridge is not the troll one might sensibly expect, but rather the attractive town of New Castle. Old and lovely without being

title: Some Creepy Predators From Mamet
description: IT was just another Wednesday night at the McCarter Theater here, the actors just back after two days off. That means an off night. Especially right after the rush of opening night on Friday, the tension of press performances the rest of the weekend. Now for an ordinary night to regain wind, energy, momentum.

title: 'Who Turned The World Around?'
description: AUGUST WILSON'S chronicle of the black experience in America in the 20th century -- a play for every decade -- is nearly complete. Previews of the New York premiere of ''Jitney,'' set in a gypsy cab station in the playwright's hometown of Pittsburgh in 1977, begin on April 8 at the Second Stage Theater, directed by Marion Isaac McClinton. Mr. Wilson's eighth and newest installment, ''King Hedley II,'' had its world premiere in Pittsburgh in December, also directed by Mr. McClinton. The production is scheduled to begin performances on March 6 at the Seattle Repertory Theater. Set, as is ''Jitney,'' in Pittsburgh's Hill District, a still predominantly black neighborhood, this comic tragedy takes place in 1985 and revisits some characters introduced in ''Seven Guitars,'' which was set in the 40's. ''King Hedley II,'' the playwright has said, focuses ''on the breakdown of the black community's extended-family structure.'' Here is an excerpt from the play.

title: II. The Chechens
description: ''We put this big gun on top of a car, and we went with it and started shooting. They immediately came with their aviation. We tried to run away but we couldn't do it. And the planes started bombing. I thought no one would be left alive. But fate is in the hands of Allah. I was wounded and that was that. . . . They stole my youth -- how would you say, the beauty, the blossoming of life. It's all war, war, war.''

title: Trying Not to Terrify New Audiences
description: EVERYTHING that's new is old again. The latest game plan for creating theater in Stamford appears to be based on just that reversal.

title: BATTLESHIP NEW JERSEY
description: Hoping the Navy's decision to dock the decommissioned battleship New Jersey in Camden will help revitalize the city, the Camden Empowerment Zone Corporation allocated $950,000 last week toward a waterfront museum. Bonnie K. Finnie, head of the corporation, which allocates federal grant money for development projects, said the allocation included a stipulation that there be long-term museum jobs for local residents. The plan is to build a $20 million floating museum similar to the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum in Manhattan. It would include an interpretive walkway detailing the history of the ship from its construction in 1942 at the nearby Philadelphia Naval Shipyards, a display area and a theater. KRISTEN MARTIN

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS; Those Stock Options Are for Outsiders, Too
description: MARILYNN MOBLEY, a public relations consultant in Atlanta, was thrilled when a client offered to give her stock options in exchange for her consulting services. With stories of technology millionaires abounding, Ms. Mobley hoped to share in the potential wealth of the customer, a promising Internet company.

title: Making Teaching A 12-Month Job
description: Aiming to boost teachers' salaries -- and status -- Secretary of Education Richard W. Riley proposed that teaching become a year-round profession. He left to states and school districts the question of whether to extend the school calendar for students as well, but said teachers need more professional development in this era of high-technology and high-stakes testing, ''The educational paradigm of the factory age is no longer appropriate,'' the secretary said at a high school in Durham, N.C., in his seventh annual address on the state of American education. JODI WILGOREN

title: Flora vs. Fauna, Clashing at the Green Thumb Garden
description: Four hens and a rooster alighted on the high branch of a slim tree near Manhattan Avenue on a recent afternoon. The rooster fluttered its heavy wings and jumped, with limited grace, from limb to limb, causing the rest of the tree's branches, and the chickens, to bounce in sync. Below, two white rabbits bounded from a fence toward a garden plot, where they munched on a few desiccated weeds that broke the soil.

title: The View From/New Haven; Sister City Responds With Hue, Vietnam, in Need
description: IN 1994, New Haven became the first American city to establish formal Sister City ties with a Vietnamese city. It was a controversial alignment at the time, with many speaking out against befriending a former ''enemy.''

title: A No to Internet Censors
description: Every parent faces the dilemma: Restrict a child too much and she may learn little, but let her roam free and she may run into trouble. That conundrum lies at the heart of an acrimonious dispute in western Michigan over whether Internet access at public libraries should be restricted to protect children from pornography. Christian conservatives put the issue to a referendum there and lost, as some local residents contended that software filters restricted free speech and would inevitably block access to some useful sites too. KEITH BRADSHER

title: Lives of Leisure
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSHEIN, MIRIAM
description: GOLDSHEIN - Miriam. Beloved wife of Herman, devoted mother of Mark and Sandy, adored grandmother of Laura and Steven. Died Saturday, Feb. 12, 2000. Her love of life, her kindness and generosity will be remembered by many.

title: Hearty Dishes From the Tuscan Table

title: Ways to Install Single-Strip or Composite Baseboard Moldings
description: BASEBOARD molding is the wood trim that runs around the perimeter of the wall at floor level. It serves as a decorative accent; it also conceals the expansion joint between the edge of a wood floor and the wall and covers gaps and flaws created as the house settles and heaves.

description: The National Hockey League said yesterday that it was willing to negotiate paying a higher fee to the International Ice Hockey Federation for using foreign players. The league, though, will not tie the negotiations with getting approval from the federation to participate in the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: Illegal Immigrants Find Danger and Appeal in Northern Route
description: In the winter, the frozen river here creaks and moans as if lost souls were being swept along by the relentless current underneath the ice. It is this unlikely spot, where the St. Clair River separates this rural Michigan region from Canada, that has lately become a passageway for illegal immigrants.

title: Peeking Under the Bearskin Rug
description: IT has been a long time since the year 1984 seemed futuristic, but those of us who are old enough to have read George Orwell's classic before the actual year in question remember it as a terrifying story of an all-powerful state, regulating not only the deeds of its citizens but their thoughts as well. Writing about 1984 in the year 2000 makes it actually seem quaint, like the term ''test-tube baby.'' That's the way the future goes.

title: Lightening the AOL Load
description: Investors trying to get a handle on the prospects of the America Online-Time Warner deal could do worse than to sound out the opinion of William H. Miller III, portfolio manager of the Legg Mason Value Trust.

title: Conservative Bard Of the Demimonde
description: PAUL MORRISSEY disdains rock music, abhors recreational drugs and thinks even less of liberal politics. When asked his views on sex, he pauses for a moment, looks his inquisitor in the eye and says: ''I'm Catholic. I'm with Rome 100 percent.''

title: Monsignor Farrell And St. Joseph's Win
description: Monsignor Farrell and St. Joseph's By the Sea won the team titles yesterday in the Staten Island high schools' borough championships. Competing at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan, Farrell scored 142 points in the boys' competition, while St. Joseph's scored 117 to win the girls' crown. Tottenville was runner-up in both competitions with 94 points in the boys' and 114 in the girls'.

title: Ms. Smith, Alone Again, Is Going to Washington
description: SHE tried not to get up there onstage and do it herself. For the first time since she became famous for recreating -- to the last gesture and vocal tic -- dozens of real-life individuals based on her actual conversations with them, Anna Deavere Smith decided not to perform her own work. Instead, she cast actors in ''House Arrest,'' her latest foray into the nation's psyche, this time focusing on the role of the American presidency, from Thomas Jefferson to Bill Clinton.

title: Taking Show and Arena on the Road
description: DESCENDING from the rafters on flying saucers or putting the drummer on a moveable platform that turned him upside down was not enough for the contemporary Christian rock act Newsboys, so this time around they are bringing their own arena on tour.

title: Curtains for 'Cats'
description: For more than a decade, musicals like ''Les Miserables'' and ''Phantom of the Opera'' have anchored the Broadway industry, drawing millions of tourists to Times Square and keeping their theaters lit during even the hardest of times. The specter of a world without them is harrowing to many who make their living along the Great White Way. So an announcement that ''Cats,'' the longest-running show in Broadway history, would close at the end of June set off a fervent guessing game among amateur handicappers: which mega-musical might be the next to shutter? In the meantime, ''Cats'' was enjoying a renaissance. By week's end, the show had sold more than $1 million in tickets, making it once again the hottest ticket on Broadway. JESSE McKINLEY

description: I AM a librarian, and I am often asked, ''Why can't public libraries be more like Barnes & Noble?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, WILLIAM E.
description: GARSON-William E. Died peacefully in his sleep, February 16, 2000 in Bryn Mawr, PA. Born NYC, December 7, 1908, fourth and last child of Daisy and Eli Garson. Survived by his beloved wife, Diana Hitschler Garson. His remarkably vigorous life spanned almost the entire 20th Century and included service in the U.S. Navy ''Seabees'' in WW II. During his 50-year career as an accomplished general contractor, he took delight in working for some of NY's most prominent and creative personages. He was a devoted member of the ''Y's Men'' of Westport, CT, where he lived for many years. He married five times and left numerous adoring children and stepchildren (Judy, Andy and Jeff Garson, Gail Tirana, Lee Oestreicher, Lynn Jeffrey and Laurie Lowenstein, Sandra Thompson, Wehn Hitschler and Pamela Nagy) grandchildren and great grandchldren. Contributions to LSA Family Health Service, 426 East 119 Street, NYC 10035 or P. Flag, PO Box 15711, Philadelphia, PA. 19103.

title: Big City Country Roads: Short on Charm, Long on Potholes
description: Earlier this month, as snow fell on the city, John Elio looked out of the window of his two-story house and shook his head in dismay. Watching the neighborhood quickly being covered in a white blanket, he sighed as he pondered the shoveling ahead.

title: Alfred Isselbacher, 73, a Dealer Who Specialized in Art Prints
description: Alfred Isselbacher, an art dealer who specialized in 19th- and 20th-century prints, died on Feb. 15at a hospital in the Bronx. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, MARGARET A.
description: DAWSON-Margaret A. At age 96, on February 17, 2000. Died at home at Signal Mountain, TN where a memorial mass will be held. Formerly of Brooklyn and for decades, a teacher in the NYC public schools. Beloved sister of the late Bernadette U. Dawson. Loving aunt of Martha D. King of Albuquerque, NM, Joseph S. Dawson of Boca Raton, FL., and George Fletcher of NYC, and many great-nieces and nephews. Graveside service was held at St. John's Cemetery, Queens, NY. For further information: Clavin Funeral Home, 718-745-1445.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-27-00: The Ethicist; A Degrading Experience
description: In more than 25 years of teaching, I have never agreed with my students on what to do when one of them gets an answer wrong and I inadvertently mark it as correct. If the student lets me know, I praise him for his honesty, then take off the points I should have in the first place. Is this right, or should I let him keep the points because the mistake was mine? -- Sandra Martin, Ramsey, N.J.

In the early days of the business, many directors based in New York, which was a hub of moviemaking long before Hollywood, came to Greenwich to make their films.

description: LOEB-Harriet. February 26, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Rene. Devoted mother of Peter and his wife Linda. Loving sister of Leo Bloch. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral private.

description: Gov. George W. Bush's unexpected loss in Michigan's primary last Tuesday, despite strong support from virtually all of the Republican establishment here, has left the state's Republican leaders divided over what went wrong.

Far down in the lineup are the white marble capitol and surrounding gardens, the historic homes, the Willamette Valley's celebrated iris and tulip farms, berry and vegetable farms and some 20 wineries that dot the surrounding hills.

description: When 19th-century German immigrants joined the Southern Uplanders and flinty New Englanders already on the prairie at Indianapolis, the city's thrifty, conservative character was forged. Hoosiers still tend to make do and reuse, gently stitching new ideas onto old.

description: Shannon Denise Snead and Daniel Robert Jones were married on Wednesday at the Community Church of New York. The Rev. Judith Long, a Unitarian Universalist minister and a college friend of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Gore as Mountain Conqueror
description: It might be called ''Al's Excellent Adventure.'' Last summer, Vice President Al Gore and his son, Albert Jr., climbed to the top of 14,000-foot Mount Rainier in Washington. In this new 30-second spot that began running yesterday, Jim Frush, the president of the American Alpine Club and the climber who led the expedition, recounts the experience.

title: Habitats/72nd Street Near Central Park West; As the Family Expands, So Does the Living Space
description: JEREMY AND SUSAN BERMAN live in a white brick high-rise on West 72nd Street, the urban equivalent of a 1960's ranch house. And just as suburban ranch houses are being renovated to reflect the styles and needs of today, the white brick buildings, erected in the same era, are undergoing their transformations, although the results are not as obvious as, say, a new French-country facade.

title: And Now a Word From . . .
description: THE nation's first television studio in a shopping center opened here this week in a sleek glass box overlooking the food court of the Palisades Center mall.

title: New Opera: At No Loss For Words
description: WORDS have been much on music's mind lately, and the two have been as much opponents as colleagues. Watching important literary properties (''The Great Gatsby,'' ''A Streetcar Named Desire'') being wrestled to the ground musically has become a sporting event. For better or worse, words seem to be coming out on top. New operas have to have selling points, and music is not first among them.

title: The Case of the Disappearing Bus Stops . . .
description: Patricia Dolan was riding the Q74 bus on Vleigh Place in Kew Gardens Hills two weeks ago when it whizzed by her stop at 76th Avenue and pulled over half a block away. It was then that she realized that her corner stop had been moved to the middle of the block.

title: Sharing the Credit For Library Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Bathed in Tradition In Istanbul
description: It was the end of the summer in 1983, and I was sitting with friends in a taverna on the harbor at Hydra, a Greek island that remains a haven for writers and painters. The waterfront, bright with gaily colored lights, looked like the setting for an operetta. So it was hardly surprising when the Egyptian cotton broker at our table turned his sly eyes on me and sang, ''You must go to Istanbul and take the honey baths!'' True, we were talking about travel, and we had been drinking that cold gasoline the Greeks call retsina. But I knew immediately that I wanted to go.

title: Welcome to the Megastore
description: Nobrow

title: Moving Beyond the Old Song and Dance
description: TO the uninitiated, the four syllables didn't sound like a mantra. What did they signify, after all? One of the 50 states and, for a smaller group, the title of an old Broadway hit. But for the members of the cult, the word was uttered with the religious hope reserved for references to messiahs and second comings: ''Oklahoma!''

title: Take Me Out to the Bears Game
description: Every sports team has a theme song, one of those songs no one seems to know. The Newark Bears minor-league baseball team wants a song of its own, and it will be memorable to at least one person, the one whose composition is chosen in a Bears theme song contest. The songs, two to four minutes long, must be recorded on a tape cassette or CD and must, of course, sing the praises of the Bears. So far, entries have ranged from a full instrumentalmix to ''a guy with his Casio keyboard in the basement with a tape recorder,'' according to Dave Popkin, a team spokesman. The winner will get $500, attend a game in a luxury box and have his or her name up in lights on the stadium video board when the song is played. And if the winner can sing, he or she might get to perform the national anthem. The deadline is March 17. Entries must be mailed to Newark Bears Song Contest, Riverfront Stadium, 450 Broad Street, Newark, N.J. More information: (973)848-1000, extension 118.

title: From Medieval Motets To Dylan and the Doors
description: MARKING the millennium is the Waverly Consort with ''Revelations 1000-2000.'' Today's 4 p.m. concert, part of the Candlelight Series at Wilton Congregational Church, displays songs and instrumental pieces spanning 10 centuries. '' 'Revelation' is a multicultural tour of the ages,'' said a series representative, Dana Prinz, ''with music on spiritual themes from medieval motets, Sephardic Hebrew cantillations and Renaissance liturgy to Ethiopian ritual music, American gospel hymns and bluegrass; from Des Prez and Monteverdi to Leonard Bernstein, Bob Dylan and the Doors.''

title: Hot Headdress
description: Before flying to Rio for New Year's Eve 1999, Frederic Fekkai designed a ''Brazilian feel'' hairpin for Elizabeth Johnson to wear at the festivities. The result, a spray of feathers and sequins on a bobby pin, was so admired that he now sells versions of it at his hair salon and store. Salma Hayek, Mira Sorvino and Ashley Judd have requested the $100 hairpin as a possible Academy Awards accessory.

title: Ex-Knick Mason Charged in Fight in a Bar
description: Anthony Mason, the former New York Knick who now plays for the Charlotte Hornets, was charged with assault early yesterday after he and a group of friends were involved in a barroom brawl that left three people injured, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOD, CORNELIA ELY
description: WOOD-Cornelia Ely, died on February 12, 2000 at home at Tryon Estate, Columbus, NC. She was the daughter of the late Augustus and Grace Ely of Morristown, NJ. She was the wife of the late Arnold Wood. Surviving are three sons, William A. Wood, Steven H. Wood and Winston E. Wood. A memorial service will be held next summer in the Community Church in Elk Lake, PA. Memorials may be made to The SPCA of Monmouth County, 260 Wall St., Eatontown, New Jersey 07724.

title: PLAN TO IMPROVE INSPECTIONS
description: The company hired to perform the state's enhanced auto inspections told transportation officials last week that understaffing, inefficient use of lanes and programming oversights were to blame for long waits, and that the problems would be solved by June 30. ''We need more staff, we need more capacity, and we have to reconfigure the software,'' said Carl Golden, a spokesman for the company, Parsons Infrastructure & Technology Group. Dana Sullivan, a spokesman for the Division of Motor Vehicles, said officials would review the report to determine whether it agreed with Parson's plans to address the problems. The state had planned to withhold the 38-page report pending the review, but released the report after learning that the Federal Highway Administration would make it available. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: The Two Faces of Bushwick; A Troubled Brooklyn Neighborhood Is Mending. But Its Leaders Are Feuding Over the Size of the Gains and What to Do Next.
description: THREE paces down the front walkway, Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez stopped to admire the two-story brick house before him. The home was one of the first his social service organization helped build in Bushwick a decade ago. Since then, he has spurred the construction of hundreds more new houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATLICK, FLOYD Z.
description: MATLICK-Floyd Z. February 21, 2000. Survived by his wife, six children and 12 grandchildren. Services were held.

description: DON'T fight the Fed. That is one of Wall Street's must venerable and trusted dictums.

title: Marchers Protest Diallo Verdict, Taunting Police Along the Way
description: After a day of relative quiet, a Midtown Manhattan rally to protest the acquittal of four police officers in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo turned into a fast-moving march yesterday, with more than 2,000 protesters sweeping down Fifth Avenue and one large group marching about four miles to City Hall.

title: Madden Pulls Devils Out of Their Rut
description: Trailing by a goal entering the third period tonight, the Devils were looking at the possibility of a third consecutive defeat. But a goal by Patrik Elias midway through the period and a short-handed goal by John Madden with 4 minutes 48 seconds remaining gave the Devils a 5-3 victory over the Florida Panthers at Continental Arena.

title: Uniforms or Else
description: As of Wednesday, Yonkers Public Schools will send home students who do not wear school uniforms in class, Andre J. Hornsby, schools superintendent, said.

title: THE NATION: Expectations; What to Do if You're Stopped by the Police
description: THE four New York City police officers who shot an unarmed African immigrant last year were acquitted of murder charges on Friday. Nevertheless, their testimony was particularly instructive in one aspect of police-community relations: How police officers expect you to behave when they confront you.

title: Rules Eased for Home-Office Deductions
description: FEW people who work at home are surrounded by a flock of sheep. But Penny and Thomas Noack, who work out of their home on 60 acres in Sisterdale, Tex., keep 21 Barbado sheep, two rabbits, three cats, a dog and a 250-pound pet potbelly pig named Pickles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINGOLD, ROBERT ADAM
description: FEINGOLD-Robert Adam. Died January 21, 2000, at age 30, of Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Robert was a wonderful son and friend. He is missed already. Be in peace. Love ya, Ma

description: WHEN a Realtor tries to sell his own house, does he have a fool for a client? Harding T. Mason is not quite sure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERMAN, MICHAEL E.
description: COOPERMAN-Michael E. Devoted son of Sandy and Jay. Dear brother of Karen Alford. Loving uncle of Dana, Julia and Jordan. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 12:30 PM, Sunday.

title: Jarmusch Still Fills the Role of Favorite Outsider
description: ONE day a few weeks ago, the filmmaker Jim Jarmusch was hunkered down in a corner of the Pink Pony, a favorite hangout near his Lower East Side home, trying to have a quiet conversation. But a steady flow of colleagues and well-wishers kept wandering by -- drawn, it seemed, by his signature silver hair, as well as by his laid-back manner. After the umpteenth interruption, Mr. Jarmusch smiled wryly. ''It's still odd to me if somebody on the street knows who I am,'' he said. ''I'm not interested in the whole celebrity cult thing. Is it better to be semi-known or semi-unknown?''

description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry

title: Is Nothing Secular?
description: Thank you for Jeffrey Rosen's thoughtful article on the complex issue of the separation of church and state (Jan. 30). Rosen writes, ''It's impossible to imagine a neutral prayer; prayer, by definition, isn't neutral.'' I would like to point out the existence of a neutral prayer, ''May Peace Prevail on Earth.'' This prayer can be said by people of all religions or no religion.

title: A Recent Drive Into a Road's Past
description: BOBBY TROUP, who wrote the song, ''Get Your Kicks on Route 66,'' never did a song about it, but Route 6, the state's longest road, has an understated history, a road where the drive can be the destination.

title: MOONLIGHTING JUDGES
description: New Jersey is one of three states that does not allow judges to have another source of income, but under a resolution introduced in the Assembly, Superior Court judges would be allowed to hold second jobs. The bill's sponsor Assemblyman Michael Patrick Carroll, a Republican from Morris Plains, said the resolution would help entice lawyers to enter the public sector rather than higher-paying private practice and give judges incentive to be adjunct professors at local law schools. To change the current law, legislators would have to pass the resolution to amend the state constitution, and then voters would have to approve the amendment in November. WENDY GINSBERG

title: Let's Hear It for God!
description: ON a wintry weekend in February, when the nuns held a ''come and see'' retreat here for young women who are considering joining the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, four women came.

title: The Precarious Nature of Latin Democracies
description: In August 1962, the National Observer newspaper carried a report from South America with the headline ''Democracy Dies in Peru, but Few Seem to Mourn Its Passing.'' The story described the indifference of Peruvians to a military coup that had just installed a junta in power. The young reporter was Hunter Thompson, who later became famous for a different style of journalism. As for Peru, much the same article could be published today.

title: Building a Better Pigeonhole
description: THE CLUSTERED WORLD

title: Richter Brilliant, but Not Brilliant Enough
description: KANATA, Ontario, Feb. 26 -- Rangers goalie Mike Richter was supposed to have the night off. Instead, he had his hands full.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS; A Munch Moment 'The Scream' or 'The Whimper'
description: FOR a brief period during my years of surgical training in the late 1950's, I worked under a tough-minded senior resident who conducted what he called ''narcotic rounds'' every evening just before midnight. The purpose of the former Army medic's solitary nocturnal perambulations through the wards was to decrease, or sometimes cancel, the dosages of post-operative pain medication junior members of his team had ordered during the day. Should any of us have the temerity to reinstate those dosages the following morning, the miscreant was sure to be subjected to a string of invective, ''lily livered'' being the least indelicate of the terms he used. The ex-sergeant's message to us was that all complaints of pain were exaggerated, if not phony.

title: Keep Disease In Check
description: Monitor trees and shrubs, weakened by last year's drought, for bacterial and fungal diseases. Dogwood anthracnose can quickly travel from foliage to wood and kill the tree. Water shoots (weak, succulent growth on branches often stimulated by pruning) provide a perfect route into the trunk and should be cut out. If you cut branches of rhododendron and viburnum for forcing, look for chocolate brown, pie-shaped stains on cut surfaces: this may indicate the fungus Botryosphaeria. Prune infected branches back to healthy wood. PATRICIA JONAS

title: Taking Art History to New Heights of Revisionism
description: DEJA VU: Reworking the Past,'' the current exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art, challenges the way we understand and interpret the thrust of art history. In selecting and amassing such a radical variety of artists who explore and re-evaluate some of our most beloved and important works of art, the curator, Barbara Bloemink, seems to have raised revisionism to new heights.

title: Inside Politics
description: DELANCEY'S WAY

title: Baroque Festival Set For Scarsdale Church
description: BACH and Handel nestle comfortably together at the New Choral Society's Baroque Festival next weekend. The Cantata No. 147 by Bach and the ''Utrecht'' Te Deum by Handel will be performed next Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 3 p.m. in Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale.

title: A Threat Shadows a Relic From a Grim Era
description: For nearly two decades, a 60-by-100-foot mural depicting a ravaged-looking man wearing a crucifix earring and a bandanna and smoking a cigarette has loomed over St. Marks Place between Second and Third Avenues.

title: The Downtown Gospel According to Reverend Billy
description: ''I think of a child's mind as a blank book. During the first years of his life, much will be written on the pages. The quality of that writing will affect his life profoundly.''

title: Bush Aide Says McCain Misled Public on Calls
description: Senator John McCain has acknowledged approving a telephone campaign in Michigan criticizing Gov. George W. Bush's visit to a conservative Christian college. The Bush campaign said that contradicted statements Mr. McCain made earlier.

title: A Super Satellite
description: To the Editor:

title: Signals on Interest Rates Confuse the Stock Markets
description: Wall Street went through a confusing week, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing 3.5 percent and closing below 10,000 for the first time in 10 months. Its performance contrasted with the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index, which is up 12.81 percent this year and which showed a small gain for the week. The divergence seemed to reflect expectations that the Federal Reserve will continue raising interest rates, and that this will hurt traditional companies more than it will hurt new technology companies, since the Old Economy organizations are more dependent on bank loans for raising capital.

title: Plan for Memorial to Civil War Group Splits Texas Town Anew
description: When the Civil War broke out in 1861, military authorities in Texas issued an ultimatum to the citizens: take oaths of allegiance to the Confederacy or suffer the consequences. A group of nearly 100 immigrant German intellectuals now known as ''freethinkers,'' opposed to slavery and secession, fled south from here toward the Mexican border to join the Union forces or wait out the war in Mexico.

title: R2 Me2
description: Battery-operated with remote control - you flick the switch and wathc bro'bot go?

title: Rijker's Island
description: The fighters' daughters are fighting now, and a profitable glamour circus spins around their marquee names. What began with Laila Ali -- Muhammad Ali's daughter -- quickly spread to include the daughter of Ali's archrival, Joe Frazier. Soon after Jacqueline Frazier-Lyde made her professional debut in the ring came news that the great Roberto Dur1/3n's daughter Irichelle wants to try on the gloves. Then big George Foreman's daughter Freeda announced her own pugilistic intentions.

title: 'Johnny Mac,' Jack Nicholson Said, 'Don't Ever Change'
description: The smartest person in John McEnroe's life is his son, Kevin, who has banned his father from his basketball games because he is too vocal a spectator; McEnroe's parents, the United States Tennis Association and the press should have muzzled him years ago. If society continues to accept talent without control, then it had better be prepared to accept more Littletons.

title: For Bruce Smith, Things Happen for a Reason
description: One day last week Bruce Smith sat in his new office in Norfolk, Va., signing payroll checks. Smith has a new team. Actually, he has two.

title: Metal Chairs and More At an Unusual Mall
description: The Real Form Girdle building, once a gritty factory, now houses a hip minimall of 16 stores (13 completed) at Bedford Avenue and North Fifth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The sleek space houses many creative boutiques that make this mall a far cry from typical.

title: Lynching Victim Is Cleared of Rape, 100 Years Later
description: In 1906, the lynching of a young black man named Ed Johnson was a public spectacle in the heart of this Smoky Mountain city. Just before he was hanged, he said to the crowd of white men, women and children who were watching: ''God bless you all. I am innocent.''

title: Journalist, Rearrested After Release by Chechens, Assails Russia
description: The Radio Liberty journalist Andrei Babitsky, re-arrested Friday after surfacing from more than a month's detention in Chechnya, has told his colleagues at the American radio network that Russian officials violated the agreement under which he voluntarily agreed to be exchanged for Russian soldiers.

title: POSTINGS: Art Commission Awards; 8 Are Honored For Excellence In Design
description: What is the architectural firm du jour -- lionized for the sphere-in-a-jewel-box Rose Center at the American Museum of Natural History -- doing at a sewage plant on the banks of Newtown Creek?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Page 52 of The Times Magazine today about campaign advertising renders a word incorrectly in a sentence comparing negative and positive ads. The sentence should read, ''Yet is being positive so 'different'?'' -- not ''difficult.''

title: Taking Sides in the 6 Percent Evolution
description: THE deed, dated July 20, 1668, conveys a 15,000-acre swath of northern New Jersey, now including the Borough of Rutherford, from Tantaqua, a chief of the Lenni Lenape Indian Nation, to an Englishman, William Sandford, ''for the following consideration:''

title: A Voiceless Fan Longs for the Return of Messier
description: I want Mark Messier and I want him now. Don't tell me about salary caps, dunce caps, capped teeth. Just go buy Mark Messier and stuff him back in a Ranger uniform and push him out on the prime line with Adam Graves. Do it before baseball melts the ice.

title: Limiting Liabilities for '99 While Planning Ahead
description: TAXPAYERS can pare their 1999 tax bills by knowing how to report income and take advantage of the available breaks. But they also can make their annual paperwork exercise do double duty by using it as an opportunity to plan financial strategies for 2000 and beyond.

title: Globe Theater at Hofstra Celebrates Its 50th
description: JOHN CRANFORD ADAMS was a man obsessed. The Shakespearean scholar and second president of Hofstra University was so enamored of the playwright and his creative milieu, he painstakingly designed and built a reproduction of the Globe Theater, the 17th-century home of Shakespeare's dramatic work.

title: Sit Still Now, Class: It's Time to Get Serious
description: IN 1990, Congress passed the Children's Television Act, which required every broadcast station desiring to keep its license to run programming that ''furthers the positive development of the child.'' Then, in 1996, after the television industry was publicly embarrassed when some chuckleheaded station executives tried to pass off shows like ''The Jetsons'' as educational -- it ''teaches children what life will be like in the 21st century,'' executives told federal regulators -- the Federal Communications Commission spelled out what stations had to do: three hours a week of ''core educational programming.'' The three-hour rule, as it is popularly known, took effect in the fall of 1997.

title: A Bit of Help, and a Start-Up Is a Success
description: Eight months ago, Yaridy Ortiz was on welfare. Five months ago, she and her four children were almost evicted from their Washington Heights apartment. Today, after years of dreaming, she supports her family on the profits of her own women's clothing store.

title: Yacht Club Gives Neighbors Growing Pains
description: BEFORE he bought his house eight years ago on a knoll that offers a panoramic view of Huntington Harbor, Richard Maurer asked his real estate agent about the possibility that the Huntington Yacht Club, to his south, would expand and detract from that scene.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Feb. 6 about cruising through the Virgin Islands on the Nantucket Clipper misstated the location of a stop called Christmas Cove. It is on Great St. James Island, not St. Thomas, which is nearby.

title: Goodbye, for Now, to Dow 10,000
description: April seems so far away. Not the coming month, but the one almost a year ago when the Dow Jones industrials first marched past the 10,000 mark amid much fanfare.

title: British Columbia's Long Road to the Far North
description: A gas station on the corner of Route 16, at Kitwanga in the northwestern quarter of British Columbia, displays a homemade sign: ''North to Alaska.'' The station marks Kilometer Zero off Route 37, the Cassiar Alaska Highway, at its junction with the section of the Yellowhead Highway between Prince George and Prince Rupert on the Pacific Coast. From Kitwanga, the Cassiar runs 446 miles to join the main trunk Alaska Highway at Watson Lake in the Yukon Territory.

title: Effort for Lowering Oil Prices Gains at U.S.-Saudi Meeting
description: The American effort to secure lower oil prices took an important step forward today when senior Saudi and American oil ministers agreed that there could be a better balance between oil supplies and demand.

title: Art Now, Art Then
description: EVENING HOURS Correction: March 5, 2000, Sunday A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about an opening party for the International Fair of New Art at the Jacob K. Javits Center misspelled the name of a guest. She was Valerie Shields, not Vakrie Sheilds.

title: Map of Life
description: GENOME The Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters. By Matt Ridley. 344 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $26.

title: THE WORLD: Clerical Error; Iran's Self-Fulfilling Prophecy
description: THE best-selling books here these days are all by jailbirds. Among the hottest are the bound transcripts of defense arguments from the trials of an iconoclast Muslim cleric, Abdullah Nouri, and the activist former mayor of Tehran, Gholamhossein Karbaschi. Even the essays of the journalist and erstwhile hostage-taker Abbas Abdi -- the same ones that landed him in prison when he published them in his magazine last year -- have been reprinted in paperback and fly off the shelves of Tehran's busy book shops.

title: Manhattan Up Close: Board Meeting Dates in 12 Districts
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Battery Park, Civic Center, Financial District, South Street Seaport, TriBeCa; next meeting March 21, 5:30 p.m.; Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chamber Street, between Greenwich and West Streets; Richard Harris Terrace. (212)442-5050.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, DAVID
description: RABINOWITZ - David. Passed away on November 24, 1999. In his memory, we will celebrate Dave and Anna's unwavering commitment to each other and their joint commitment to a socialist dream. They touched all our lives with compassion and generosity. Commemoration on March 19. Call 212222-2536; 718-721-7368 for details

title: A Japanese Treasure Moves to the Midwest
description: OVER 20 years, Alan Strassman, a Boston investment manager, collected 95 Japanese paintings from the Edo period (1615-1848). Twenty were gloriously painted screens that included depictions of a field of tall grasses glowing gold in the moonlight, corpulent gods wrestling, evocative scenes from ''The Tales of Genji,'' wild dancing in the streets near a tea house and a Noh theater performance in an aristocrat's courtyard. His collection became one of the largest and finest of its kind in private hands.

title: For Buyout Firms, A Simmering Stew
description: REMEMBER when buyout firms were big and venture capitalists weren't masters of the universe?

title: The First Fine Day; Paris
description: The storms that blasted across Europe during the Christmas holidays, knocking down some 270 million trees in France, will probably be felt most acutely this spring, when strollers return to the Bois de Boulogne, the Bois de Vincennes and the gardens of Versailles.

title: Crockery for a Futuristic World
description: Jonathan Adler's Brasilia Collection is a stark, stackable table-top version of Brasilia, the city of the future. Plates double as bowl lids; $22 to $110, at Barneys New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIDDLETON, ESTELLE
description: MIDDLETON - Estelle (Stevie). Wife of the late Drew Middleton of The New York Times, on Friday February 25, at her home in Stamford, CT. She is survived by her daughter Judith of Mt. Kisco, NY; and her sister Annette Edwards of Weston, CT.

title: Cape Town Scenic Road Closed by Falling Rocks
description: Chapman's Peak Drive, one of the Cape Town area's most breathtaking routes, will be closed until the end of May. The road was closed after a motorist was killed by a falling boulder last month. The coastal road, about six miles long, has become a popular route for sightseers traveling between Cape Town and Cape Point, the tip of South Africa. But with lots of loose rock, the hills that overlook the drive have made it risky, forcing frequent closings during heavy rain or strong winds. This time rock climbers have been sent up to remove or secure the boulders thought most likely to fall.

title: The Evolution of Style: A Look Across Time For an Abstract Painter
description: 'James Brooks Revisited'

title: CIRCUS; Youthful Hobbies Meet Careers With Panache
description: WHEN the creme de la creme of Brooklyn's New Way Circus Center comes to the William Mount-Burke Theater at the Peddie School in Hightstown on Saturday, everything in sight will be rising -- not to mention swooping, rolling, flying, and tumbling. This troupe of young professionals, known as the Russian American Kids Circus, makes spirits soar and crowds roar. The 2 p.m. performance, which closes this season's Family Theater Series, will be followed by a 30-minute workshop for young audience members.

title: Choosing Oil Heat or Natural Gas
description: HOMEOWNERS who have been thinking about converting their oil heating systems to natural gas recently found a reason to stop thinking and start acting when heating oil prices rose earlier this month to more than $2.60 a gallon in some areas.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-27-00; Little Boy Pink
description: Last fall, my 3-year-old son, Zander, fell passionately in love with a little girl named Marley, who wore a pink tutu every day. As his obsession increased, Zander developed a serious case of tutu envy. So a friend of mine offered to buy him one. ''They come in blue, extra-manly,'' she said. ''You don't mind, do you?''

title: INVESTING WITH/Amy Hogan, Thomas Callan and William J. Wykle; BlackRock Mid Cap Growth Equity Portfolio
description: NOT to take anything away from the Standard & Poor's 500, the Dow industrials or the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks, but the Russell Mid-Cap Growth index has had quite a run recently. It returned 46.9 percent in the 12 months through January -- more than double the percentage for any of those other benchmarks.

title: With Commerce in Mind, TV Studio Opens in a Mall
description: THE nation's first television studio in a shopping center opened here this week in a sleek glass box overlooking the food court of the Palisades Center mall.

title: THE WORLD: Propaganda's Return; Popular War, Russian Style
description: OH, what a lovely war. Or so the Kremlin would like its citizens to believe.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OROBELLO, NICK
description: OROBELLO-Nick. On February 24, at age 62. Beloved husband of Stella; loving father of Cristina and her husband Randy and Angela. Dear brother of Antonino. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday 1-8 PM. Memorial Mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89th Street, Monday, 10:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Friends of Photography/Ansell Adams Center, 415-495-7000 x303; or The Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian, 202-357-3164; or Futures for Children, 800-545-6843.

title: In Bangkok, the Hot Places Are Cool Enough for Westerners
description: WHETHER you want an elegantly cooled-down version of Thai food where the chilies offer just a fleeting sensation of heat, or prefer the long slow burn that natives demand, Bangkok has so many restaurant choices today that on a November visit, I talked to a half-dozen Thais and expatriate friends to whittle down an ''explore'' list.

title: Bringing the High Drama of Real Life to the Stage
description: THEATER, a medium reliant on flights of imagination, is not exactly a place where precise depictions of real events are common.

title: For Czarist Russia's Jews, a Look at a Promised Land
description: SEVERAL empires back, on the eve of World War I, the ghettos and market towns of the Russian Pale were transfixed by a sensational new motion picture attraction. The feature-length documentary ''The Life of the Jews in Palestine'' was, according to the future Israeli film exhibitor Yaacov Davidon, then a young man, received with ''indescribable enthusiasm.'' He said, ''Tears of happiness gleamed in the eyes of Jewish audiences, thirsty for redemption.''

title: African-American Sites
description: Westchester is presenting its plans for a Heritage Trail of significant African-American historic sites to residents at public meetings this week.

title: For Latins From Manhattan
description: Brazil held its first Fashion Week last month, but its influences can already be seen in New York stores. Khajak Keledjian, owner of the women's clothing chain Intermix, will prominently display fashions designed by the Brazilians Clements Ribeiro, Rosa Cha and Jussara Lee this season.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Long Island City, Queens; Industrial in Places, but Residential Too
description: LONG ISLAND CITY is easy to recognize from a distance, or from an airplane. It is punctuated by the Citibank building (at 50 stories, New York's tallest structure outside of Manhattan) and the Citylights tower, the lofty co-op that inaugurated the Queens West development. There's also the beloved red Pepsi-Cola sign, a vestige of a company that departed decades ago.

title: Adding Waste to Landfill Further Imperils Pinelands
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Suburban; Still XXXL, but Softer
description: BY the early 90's, as Chevrolet Suburbans multiplied on American roads, they came to be viewed as symbols of automotive excess. The Suburban had big V-8 power, 18 feet of pressed metal, seats for up to nine and enough room to move a lot of Hillary Clinton's White House mementos up to Chappaqua.

title: Deer May Lose Sunday Day of Rest From Hunters
description: New Jersey legislators have proposed a number of laws, including one that would end a 97-year-old ban on Sunday hunting, in an effort to control the exploding deer population.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINET, DENNIS
description: BINET-Dennis. Age 76, on Feb. 19, 2000. Survived by his partner, Toni Sacks, and her family, his sons, Larry & Tommy, & their families; four grandchildren; two greatgrandchildren; nieces and nephews & many friends. Hungarian immigrant, served in US Army in WWII, co-founder of 47 year old Universal Elevator Company, Inc. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to a cancer-related organization or other charity or hospice of your choice. Memorial service Sunday Feb 27th at 1:45PM at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. A gathering to celebrate his life immediately following at Empire Hotel, 44 W. 63rd St., Mezzanine Ballroom, 3:30-5:30PM.

title: Temples Drawn on a Tabula Rasa
description: WATER, fertile soil and vegetation everywhere: Bengal, once India's easternmost province, was a treasure house for centuries. The Mogul Empire grew rich on Bengali taxes; the British founded their empire there. Then came independence and partition. Today, West Bengal, one of the 23 states of India, is best known for the travails of Calcutta, its capital. East Bengal has become Bangladesh, a separate and desperately poor nation.

title: Bookend; Freud's Second Thoughts
description: You are trying to get to an exam (meet a friend, deliver a message), but there are endless corridors (the stairs are blocked, the elevator gets stuck, the room has changed). We have a dream like this about getting to Freud. In the past decade especially, his serious readers in English have had an increasingly uncomfortable sense that language itself is an obstacle. One of the master German stylists of the 20th century, Freud wrote colloquially; the commonly used translation (''The Standard Edition of the Complete Psychological Works of Sigmund Freud,'' edited by James Strachey and published by Norton) imposes pseudoscientific terminology on his prose. Take a notorious example: Freud uses the ordinary Besetzung (charge or investment) to say that an idea can become charged or intense; he is rendered as saying that an idea can become ''cathected'' with energy. That language like this -- foreign to Freud's German -- permeates the standard English edition of his work is a matter of more than aesthetic significance. The shape of the psychoanalytic profession was influenced by the choice of the words.

title: Niche No More
description: While it is indispensable to observant Jews that the '98 Herzog late-harvest white riesling is kosher, the general consumer may not notice or care. Like other premium kosher wines from the Royal Wine Corporation in Brooklyn, it competes with dessert-wine peers based on the price-quality relationship.

title: Bryant, at the Age of 21, Transcends Borders
description: IN the old days, Kobe Bryant would have been a college senior.

title: Learning How To Be King
description: There is much to praise in Goldberg's article about Jordan's Abdullah II. It was lively, pointed and gives the ''flavor'' of this young man faced with incredible challenges.

description: To the Editor:

title: Melissa Algranati, Kenneth Berger
description: Melissa Joy Algranati, a heath and fitness consultant, and Kenneth Edward Berger, a sportswriter, are to be married today in Fresh Meadows, Queens. Rabbi Hyman Levine will perform the ceremony at the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center.

title: Reviving the Waterfront: Victory and Frustration; For Many Communities Along the Hudson, Development Remains a Dream After Long Delays
description: WITNESSING the rebirth of the waterfront here an area of the village once thought to be irrecoverable -- Mayor Dennis Flood is scarely able to contain his pride these days.

title: Beating the Tuition Blues and Earning Some Tax Breaks
description: THERE are many ways that Eleanor Terzian and Antonio Ciolino could save on income taxes while also saving for their son's college education. They could invest in a child's name, buy savings bonds, open an Education I.R.A., build up savings in a state-sponsored tuition-payment plan or even increase contributions to their own retirement plans.

description: In his tiny cubicle in the Russell Senate Office Building, in the lowest foothills of political power, a frustrated Navy officer wrestled with friends over what to do with his life.
