title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONAUER, BEATRICE
description: ARONAUER - Beatrice. Loving wife of Irwin and beloved mother of Susan, Billy, Elyse, Sandy and Peri. Loyal sister to Milton, Janet and the late Harriet. Loving grandmother to Judy (Wilfried), Robby (Felicia), Carol (Todd), Ondine, Ari, Aaron (Laura), Ani (Tyler), Jacob and Rebecca. We will miss her kind and loving spirit. Funeral services at Gutterman's Chapel in Rockville Centre on Sunday 12 PM

title: Talk of a Merger Raises New Concern for Hotel-Hungry Atlantic City
description: It has been more than four years since the Las Vegas casino magnate Stephen A. Wynn announced plans to build a $2 billion hotel and gambling complex on a landfill in Atlantic City's marina district, and almost as long since MGM Grand said it would build a $700 million resort at the northern end of the Boardwalk.

title: New Union to Meet To Elect Officers
description: Major league umpires will meet in Phoenix tomorrow to elect officers of their new union, the World Umpires Association. John Hirschbeck, who headed the fight to oust the old union that was directed by Richie Phillips, is the nominee for president, Joe Brinkman for vice president and Tim Welke for secretary-treasurer.

title: For Wilson, Arm Injuries Put New Spin on Pitching
description: The signs read like the morals of the stories in a series of children's sports books.

title: Making Summer School Succeed
description: Over the next three months, Harold Levy, the interim schools chancellor, faces the challenge of organizing a summer school program for an estimated 320,000 students in New York City. Among his duties are notifying students who need to show up for summer session, hiring 17,000 teachers, providing transportation and helping district superintendents develop programs that will allow the lowest-achieving students to catch up.

title: With an Optimistic Outlook, Bush's Colleagues Offer Unwavering Support
description: Unshaken in their view that George W. Bush will vanquish his Republican opponent, the nation's Republican governors rallied today around Mr. Bush, a fellow governor, and said they were confident voters would embrace the man has who won over many Democrats, minorities and women in his own state of Texas.

title: Diplomat Is Deported
description: F.B.I. agents last night took the Cuban diplomat accused of spying to the airport, where he was put on a flight to Canada. He had refused to leave the United States voluntarily.

title: 'Johnny Mac,' Jack Nicholson Said, 'Don't Ever Change'
description: As the former chairwoman of a national art show by and for people with epilepsy, I applaud John McEnroe. He gave his name, his personal appearances, his gallery, his staff and a significant donation for many years. It was a huge boost for our fund-raising efforts. We all saw a warm and generous side of John McEnroe that is rarely reported.

description: WHEN Michael Dubb and Leslie A. Lerner, principals of the Beechwood Organization, decided three years ago to build both town houses and detached houses in a 193-unit development called Country Pointe at Melville, their idea was to encourage people of all age groups to buy there by offering a mix of housing.

Powers, the feared and powerful chairman of the New York State Republican Party, was one of only 87 marines stationed in Cuba on the day the Cuban missile crisis broke out. And although reinforcements arrived within hours, Mr. Powers said, he spent much of the next few days in a foxhole awaiting nuclear war.

description: Karen Chasin Spitzberg's work seems contradictory: she is an art history teacher for the blind.

description: In the photograph of the marine sergeant, whipping recruits into a frenzy of ''controlled rage'' (Feb. 13), there is one young man standing at the corner of the platform, pensively studying his hands. I'd like to know what he was thinking.

description: China's abrupt shift to a more aggressive stance on Taiwan left the Clinton administration scrambling this week for a response and struggling to temper increased pressure for new sales of sophisticated arms to Taiwan, Congressional and administration officials say.

title: The First Fine Day; Alaska
description: Perhaps no state anticipates spring more than Alaska, where an eight-month winter is stripped away with a fury that astonishes even the oldest of sourdoughs. Intense daylight, trees and plants gorged with fresh life and a stirring of animals from various stages of dark-season sloth combine to make the northern spring a thing of sudden drama.

title: Dreaming of Elsewhere
description: A REGION NOT HOME

title: The Scene Heats Up Under the Miami Sun
description: THE talk was fast and furious on a January evening that was distinctly chilly by Miami standards. ''Did you know this building used to be a cocaine factory?'' asked one of the guests at the opening of a new exhibition at the Rubell Family Collection's gallery. A mile and a half northwest of downtown, the 40,000-square-foot warehouse once served, in fact, as a storage facility for contraband seized by the Drug Enforcement Administration. But on this night, when many new acquisitions by the New York and Miami collectors Donald and Mera Rubell were on display for the first time, most of the comments centered on how the Miami art scene was coming of age.

title: Lauren Gottlieb, Blake Kassel
description: Lauren Kerry Gottlieb, a daughter of Irene and Sherman Gottlieb of Willowbrook, Staten Island, was married last evening in Short Hills, N.J., to Blake Allan Kassel, a son of Leslye Kohl of Manhattan and Robert Kassel of San Francisco. Rabbi Dennis Tobin officiated at the Short Hills Hilton.

title: Keeping Bluegrass Sound Alive
description: SOUTHERN RAIL'S visit to the Sounding Board in West Hartford this Saturday evening may possibly prove that more than just folk music juices the caffeine circuit. This bluegrass quartet has in fact been introducing folk fans to its traditional style of acoustic music for 21 years.

title: Lives; A Different Kind of Killing
description: Six months ago, I was sent by an American magazine to cover NATO's first great triumph, the military operation in Kosovo. The NATO operation had triggered an all-out attack by the Serbian military on the civilian population, and thousands of ethnic Albanians were thought to have been killed. My assignment was to write about the F.B.I. pathologists who were sent over to gather evidence for war crimes trials at The Hague. I'd been in Balkan wars before -- five months in Bosnia and Croatia, then in Kosovo after the first massacres in the spring of 1998 -- and my disgust with the Serbian government was in full bloom. I knew, intellectually, that the Serbian people had suffered as well -- at the hands of opposing armies as well as at the hands of their own government -- but that did little to blunt my feelings. Kosovo in the spring of 1999 was as close to black-and-white as it gets with journalism, and I was eager to go there and document proof of my own beliefs.

title: On the Front Line in War Against Dropouts
description: If the 100 seventh-grade students at the Promise Charter School here get their high school diplomas five years from now, their principal, Joseph V. Conway, will feel the school has accomplished its mission.

title: Lorna Thomas, Eli Kabillio
description: Lorna Elizabeth Thomas and Eli Michael Kabillio, documentary filmmakers, were married yesterday by Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, at the Masterview Studio, a loft in Manhattan.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pope Visits Mount Sinai and Its Orthodox Monastery
description: Saying he felt ''great joy and deep emotion,'' Pope John Paul II prayed today at the spot where tradition says Moses once stood, and called himself a pilgrim ''in the footsteps of God.''

title: Visit to Defense Lawyers Tests Evenhanded Image
description: In the hours after their sweeping courtroom triumph on Friday, the lawyers who defended the four police officers in the Amadou Diallo case gathered at the Albany bed-and-breakfast that has been their home for the past month. They soon had an unexpected guest: the trial judge, Joseph C. Teresi.

title: Corrections
description: A brief review of ''Bloomsbury and France: Art and Friends'' on Page 23 of the Book Review today gives the surname of an author incorrectly at one point. As noted elsewhere in the review, the co-author with Mary Ann Caws is Sarah Bird Wright, not Bird.

title: Italian Women's Clothier Opens First U.S. Store
description: The Genny Boutique, an upscale women's fashion retailer at 831 Madison Avenue, between 68th and 69th Streets, is owned by an Italian company with stores in Italy, France, Greece, Japan and elsewhere. But this new outlet, which opened on Feb. 9, is the company's first in the United States. It is part of an aggressive expansion.

title: Alcohol Units 6, Cigarettes 45, Husbands 0
description: Bridget Jones

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILLINGER, JAMES J.
description: PILLINGER-James J. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Devoted father of Marc and Ava,Michael and Judy. Dear brother of Ray Pillinger and Helen Diamond. Adored grandfather of Mara, Ian, Kaley. Services Sunday, 10:30AM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: A Presidential Favor For a Steady Supporter
description: Michael D. Granoff offered President Clinton an invitation he could not refuse.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 27, 2000
description: Weeks

title: The First Fine Day; Boston
description: The obvious thing to do when spring finally comes to Boston is to wander out onto the Boston Common to inhale the scent of thawing ground.

title: Argument Over Change Ends Up in Court
description: SOME people picture their local historical society as a quaint clapboard house inhabited by tweedy genealogists. Others see a preppy bastion of exclusionary conviviality amid Colonial-era decor.

title: Through a Very Different Looking Glass
description: In a rather short period of time, network television has acquired yet another trademark that has become as much a fixture as the wacky neighbor, the evil-twin subplot or a host asking about someone's final answer. Ever since the 1996 broadcast of ''Gulliver's Travels,'' a huge ratings success for NBC, special-effects-laden mini-series inspired by famous literary tales have become inevitable prime-time events. In the last few seasons, viewers have been inundated by the genre, with everything from ''Merlin'' to ''Alice in Wonderland.'' Each production utilized stunning visual tricks and exotic locations to be more spectacular than the last. However, comparing these efforts to NBC's ''10th Kingdom'' is like comparing ''Adam 12'' to ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.''

title: 2 JURORS DEFEND DIALLO ACQUITTAL
description: Jurors stood firm yesterday in their pledge to remain silent on how, and why, they had acquitted the four police officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo. But one member of the panel, speaking generally about how they had reached their decision, pointed to the prosecution.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERN, KEITH
description: STERN-Keith. 2/28/39 to 1/7/00. Dearly loved by mother Ethel, late father Nathanael, sister Priscilla, daughters Alessandra and Marnie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORRICK, WILLIAM PENDLETON
description: ORRICK-William Pendleton. Died February 24, 2000, in New Jersey; he was 93. Teacher of Latin, English, Athletic Director, Coach St. James School, Trinity College, The Solebury School. US Navy Aerial Navigator WW II, flew Admiral Ernest King to Potsdam, Yalta conferences, Admiral Bull Halsey US Farewell Tour, Air Medal with Citation; Headmaster, Solebury School, 1/9/49-1/9/68; Vice President, American Field Service (AFS) 1/9/68-1/9/77. Escort, US Department of State International Visitors' Program, 1979; Director of Archives, AFS, 1980-1996. He is survived by wife Kathryn, sister Lucy Bolling, son William Pendleton II, daughter Margaret Hayt-both by first wife Mary Norton Wroth, by daughters Nancy Bird and Jessica James Bentley, by stepchildren Richard and Bronwyn Duffy, and by grandsons William Pendleton III, John Jesse, Homer Samuel Bentley, and William Wroth Chalfant. A bird watcher, an avid golfer, a tender steward to his lily pond and its frogs, a reciter of verse, a man of his word, he never put soap in an iron skillet. He will be sorely missed. Memorial service May 6, 10 AM, Solebury School, New Hope, PA.

title: The Diallo Case Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Music Urgent and Fresh
description: THE San Francisco Symphony, which has made tours of Europe and Asia, is back on the road. This time it is appearing in 13 United States cities, including Hartford at the Bushnell Auditorium tomorrow. Its programs are designed to show -- a little -- the skill spectrum of the orchestra's director, Michael Tilson Thomas.

title: A Revival of Older Suburbs As Ethnic Businesses Take Hold
description: FOR years, the old central core of this aging Long Island suburb seemed in permanent decline. Yet today, the once nearly deserted shopping areas have become a beehive of activity, much of it fueled by newcomers from Central America.

title: County Matters, Candidates Say From Afar
description: THEY all profess the importance of Westchester, naturally, but to date none of the four principal presidential candidates have aggressively courted voters here.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS: Taking Stock Of the Competition; SFX Entertainment Expands Its Scope To Include the Lucrative Sports Market
description: You are SFX Entertainment, and you are dominating the world of live entertainment. In three years, you have bought your way into concert tours, touring Broadway shows and family entertainment. You have shaken up an industry of small independent firms, consolidated them and recast them as a behemoth.

title: For Star Jones, Life's Good, Not Phat
description: IMAGINE a world in which you're free to eat macaroni and cheese without paroxysms of guilt. Imagine a world in which you can boast loudly, name-drop gleefully, smother people with affection and boss them around as if you were their big sister. A world in which you go out every night without having to apologize. A world in which doors can be opened, with a little nudge or a call from your publicist.

title: To Follow the Races, Follow the Money
description: Campaign finance is a hot-button issue in the presidential race, but it is also important in New York City politics. A Web site set up by the city's Campaign Finance Board allows people to track contributions made to most candidates for city office since 1994, including donations for the 2001 elections.

title: Eh?
description: THE FARFARERS

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BLOOMSBURY AND FRANCE

title: Dow Wow, Dow Ow
description: Early in his forthcoming book, ''Irrational Exuberance,'' Robert Shiller -- who has done more than any other economist of his generation to document the less rational aspects of financial markets -- describes the full-page advertisement that Merrill Lynch ran a year ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average passed 10,000. ''Even those with a disciplined long-term approach like ours have to sit back and say 'wow,' '' the ad declared. And the accompanying stock market chart bore the caption ''HUMAN ACHIEVEMENT.''

title: Suggestions for Using Winter's Bounty of Root Vegetables
description: AS fresh corn is to summer, so root vegetables are to winter. And with good reason. Traditionally, the sturdy roots sheltered underground were the last of the plant to be harvested. Once pulled up they could be kept in cold storage for many weeks at a time when there was little else to be had in the way of fresh vegetables. Potatoes are a classic example, but other roots can be added to the category, including turnips, parsnips and carrots.

title: Downloads From Uptown: A Web Portal in Harlem
description: As the co-producer of ''New Jack City,'' a 1991 film starring Wesley Snipes as a Harlem drug lord, George Jackson introduced a mass audience to the sounds and sensibilities of inner-city streets.

title: Fame Revisited
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: CHAMPEEN

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-27-00: Salient Facts: Landing A Plane In Water; Water Wings
description: IF A PASSENGER JET ENDS UP IN THE WATER, IS THERE ANY HOPE?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, FRANK
description: CUNNINGHAM-Frank Sr. On January 30, 2000. Former President and CEO of John R. Robinson, Inc. He will be greatly missed.

title: Frozen Out
description: To the Editor:

title: The Complex Issues In Assessing Property
description: I do not understand the furor regarding the Nassau County real estate assessment methods. The assessments do not establish the taxes collected; the taxing jurisdictions do. The assessments merely provide a basis for distributing them across the population to which they apply.

title: Respect the Text
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lofty Vision of a Better Musical Theater
description: AUDRA McDONALD, the theatrical mezzo-soprano who has drawn the kind of acclaim on which legends are built, is a singer of such impeccable taste that she can turn the most rough-and-tumble Broadway showstopper into a concert gem. Listening to her exquisitely phrased, finely shaded performances of a program of mostly show tunes on her second solo album, ''How Glory Goes,'' you come away captivated by as lofty a vision of nonclassical American theater music as any singer has dared put forth.

title: A Screen-Size Encounter With Art Appreciation
description: WHEN viewers turn on the small screen to see arts meant to be visited in person, there is a lot they give up: the sight of brush strokes an inch away; the muttered comment of the couple behind; the audience's ecstatic stamping; the chance to catch the singer's eye or the rose she tosses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNON, JOHN
description: HANNON-John. Members of the Board of Trustees and staff of the American Red Cross in Greater New York note with sadness the loss of John Hannon. Mr. Hannon was a member of our Executive Board beginning in the early 1960's and served ably as our Treasurer. He was a great supporter of Red Cross programs in New York, chairing our fund campaign and contributing generously to our efforts. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Vivien, his children, Bruce, Elizabeth and Christine, and the entire Hannon family. American Red Cross in Greater New York Jonathan O'Herron, Chairman Robert M. Bender, Jr., CEO

title: 76ers Present New Look And Challenge to Knicks
description: Larry Johnson does not pretend to have the Philadelphia 76ers' best interests at heart, but if he did he would have advised them against trading Larry Hughes for Toni Kukoc. It is not that Johnson does not respect Kukoc's game; it's just that Johnson believes the athletic and acrobatic Hughes gave Philadelphia a dimension that could be as rewarding for the 76ers as it was aggravating for their opponents.

title: Deep in the Heart of Houston
description: There is big houston and little Houston. It is possible to edit the city into an extraordinarily pleasant, civil, amenities-rich archipelago of urban spaces -- always aware, however, in the back of one's mind, of that infinitely nondescript, ever-expanding strip-mall, industrial edge of town, the receding periphery that is larger Houston. But then, this is what the intrepid traveler always does: edits a personal version of Florence, say, into a set of reliable gelaterias and inspiring Botticellis or restful Boboli Gardens benches.

title: For House Candidates, Inflation Is a Big Issue
description: The cost of living is high in this state, for politicians as for everybody else. And this year, while complaints focus on a Senate race that promises to devour millions, House seats are going to be expensive, too, and a few will be amazingly expensive.

title: Above All, Ravello
description: Ravello is all vantage points, a town where everything overlooks something else.

title: Squeezewords
description: William Safire's discussion of improving speech by digitally eliminating ''y'know'' and ''uh'' and snafus of usage leaves out an important consideration (On Language, Feb. 6). The public has a right to know how intelligent these candidates really are or aren't. They've already had the advantage of ghostwriters and spin artists. Therefore, unedited speech is our only chance to glimpse the real and make our judgment.

title: Helping Hispanic Clients Adjust to a New Life
description: IMAGINE being the new kid on the block. Then imagine that you are not a kid -- and that no one on the block speaks your language.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died Feb. 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co.

title: The Big Board and Nasdaq Wave a Flag on Margin Buying
description: Are you concerned about the tide of margin debt fueling the stock market? You've got company -- big company.

title: Leko Shows the Vast Gulf Separating Good and Best
description: The player rankings of the International Chess Federation are based on actual competitive results weighted by the strengths of the opponents encountered. The formulas, worked out in the 1950's by Arpad Elo, emeritus professor of physics at Marquette University, eliminate human biases. They are an accurate indicator of achievement.

title: Meet Alex, a Today Woman . . . er, Doll
description: ''CAN you undress her? Can I?'' I was sitting in a booth at the Jacob J. Javits Convention Center during Toy Fair a few weeks ago, and a gentle doll dress designer, Tim Alberts, was, I thought, taking way too much time unsnapping the tiny pink chiffon skirt from the cinched vinyl waist of a new doll called Alex Ford.

title: The Widening Road to a Speedier Internet
description: IT is rush hour and the expressway traffic is crawling. Just as regrets intrude about not taking the train, a new road appears where cars are cruising at Daytona speeds.

title: 'Quality of Life' and a Few Nightmares
description: HE still has nightmares, like the one in which he is locked in his jail cell with the crack-crazed man. During his waking hours he runs when he sees the police.

title: Ohio Museum Explores Midwestern Identity
description: An exhibition at the Columbus Museum of Art in Columbus, Ohio, examines the Midwest through historical works and four newly commissioned pieces. ''Illusions of Eden: Visions of the American Heartland,'' continuing through April 30, tries to place past artists in a contemporary context. Works by 31 painters from the first half of the 20th century, including Grant Wood, Thomas Hart Benton and John Steuart Curry, will be on display, along with photographs by Margaret Bourke-White, Walker Evans and others. Newly commissioned work by Malcolm Cochran, Maya Lin, Mary Lucier and Kerry James Marshall forms the contemporary component.

title: How a Balanchine Masterpiece Got to Russia
description: LAST October, St. Petersburg's venerable Maryinsky Ballet (as the Kirov calls itself again in Russia) presented George Balanchine's opulent masterpiece ''Jewels.'' It was the first time all three acts of the ballet had been staged in Europe.

title: An Opera Director's Optimistic Libretto
description: WEBSTER YOUNG is a realist. He knows that opera is a difficult sell on Long Island; that despite the presence of a coterie of devotees, a major company has not prospered, or even survived, on the Island.

title: Zoning Incentives
description: Hoping to attract developers of high-rise apartments to downtown White Plains, Mayor Joseph M. Delfino is backing more relaxed zoning laws.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Wendy Cohen and Craig Teper
description: IT'S hard to imagine a couple more excited about having a baby than Wendy Cohen and Craig Teper. They are expecting a girl in May and have already built a tiny, bright nursery for her in their one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan, and given her a name -- Zoe. While some couples might be encouraged to downplay a pregnancy at their wedding, Ms. Cohen and Mr. Teper, who call Zoe ''the icing on our cake of life,'' chose to do the opposite and built their celebration around her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NODEL, NORMAN JOSHUA
description: NODEL-Norman Joshua. Beloved husband of the late Helen; devoted father of Deborah Gordon and Maxine Nodel. Cherished grandfather of Daniel and Jacqueline. Services Sunday 12:30PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: A Performance That Goes With the Grain
description: WOODEN'' is normally a harsh criticism for actors in an opera. But it's nothing more than fact in the productions of the Salzburg Marionette Theater, where marvelously managed stringed figurines romp through enchanting sets, to music of first-rate recordings. Art imitating art is the company's hallmark.

title: That's Laird To You, Mister
description: IT'S no longer very hard to enjoy the trappings of a financial mogul or earn an aristocratic title conveying pomp and privilege. Just visit the Internet.

title: Family Pictures, Frame by Frame
description: SOMETIMES the generations flow like frames in animation, one much like the next, with only gradual changes. But it is the changes that make the thing come to life.

title: Following Moses
description: In Egypt to follow in the steps of Moses, John Paul II began his long-awaited spiritual pilgrimage by also retracing modern religious tensions.

title: Learning to Teach the Book
description: HUCK FINN has been in trouble, it seems, from the get-go.

title: Some Can't Warm Up To the Global Outlook
description: Members of the Baltimore Orioles, notably Albert Belle, have complained that the team's trip to Cuba last March served as a distraction and caused their team to start the season poorly. Rickey Henderson, the Mets' problem child, said he doesn't want to go and won't go to Japan, where the Mets and the Chicago Cubs open the 2000 season in a month.

title: Facing the Form 1040
description: AMERICANS are eager for tax breaks, and Congress has obliged with child and education credits and Roth I.R.A.'s, for example. But the breaks come at a price: paperwork.

title: Making the Most of That Stock-Option Gold
description: THOSE poor dot-commies. Not only do they work themselves to the bone, but they also face the ominous task of paying taxes on all their hot stock options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLINE, CARROLL
description: CLINE-Carroll. The entire staff and family of Cline Bettridge Bernstein Lighting Design note with great sorrow the passing of Carroll Cline, our co-founder, partner, colleague, and friend. Carroll was a brilliant and innovative architectural lighting designer and was a leader among the profession's first generation of designers. His work garnered over 30 awards for his designs. A past President of the International Association of Lighting Designers, he was elected a Fellow in 1989. He served on the Board of Managers of the NY Section of the Illuminating Engineering Society. Francesca Bettridge and Stephen D. Bernstein

title: A Death in Laramie, Reimagined as Drama
description: IN the frigid early-morning hours of Oct. 7, 1998, a bicyclist found the beaten and bloodied body of a 21-year-old college student tied to a buck-rail fence in a remote field outside Laramie, Wyo. Matthew Shepard was not dead yet, but within five days he would be. Two local roofers about the same age as the victim were arrested and charged with a murder they eventually confessed to committing.

title: The First Fine Day; Tokyo
description: In crowded Tokyo, the rites of spring recall the pastoral delights of another era. And whenever the first warm afternoon actually arrives, there is nothing in the hearts of the Japanese to rival the hanami, or cherry blossom-viewing party.

title: Jane Shickich, Robert Cabes Jr.
description: Jane Annette Shickich and Robert Louis Cabes Jr. were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Mark Hallinan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: BENEFITS
description: For Talent and Toe Shoes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANOFF, JUDITH
description: DANOFF-Judith (Ignatoff). Age 80, died February 14, in her 60th year of marriage to devoted Abraham. Fighter for humanity. Dedicated teacher, former Director of Early Childhood Education, Kingsboro Community College. Her spirit lives in her children, Saul (Valerie) and Ann, grandchildren (Kimmer, Zachary, Joshua, Sonya, Isabel), and dear friends and students whose lives she touched. Donations in her memory can be sent to Kingsboro Community College Foundation, 2001 Oriental Blvd., Brooklyn, NY 11235.

title: What's Coming, From 'Squonk' to Shakespeare
description: On and off Broadway, in and out of New York, the months ahead are filled with theater openings galore. New works are in the minority; Tom Stoppard, David Mamet, Arthur Miller and Andrew Lloyd Webber are represented, but like Ibsen, O'Neill, Brecht and Shakespeare, only by successes of the past. Which may be the wave of theater's future.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Lover of Justice, All Kinds
description: The acknowledgments to Grace Paley's BEGIN AGAIN: Collected Poems (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23) include thanks to a friend for ''extracting many of the poems in this book from Grace Paley's notebooks.'' That captures the private and casual feel of most of the pieces gathered here; the art that Paley has displayed in her celebrated short stories is generally replaced in her poems by spontaneous, personal speech. These poems provide a tour through Paley's life, telling of her friends, her childhood memories and her struggle to come to terms with age and mortality. Readers familiar with her fiction and essays will recognize the childhood in an immigrant family, Greenwich Village street scenes, and Vermont landscapes, as well as the left-wing politics whose various crusades, from Vietnam (''In Duc Ninh a village of 1,654 households / over 100 tons of rice and cassava were burned'') to El Salvador, are nostalgically recalled. Such politics rarely lend themselves to ambiguities, as is shown in the ringing calls to action in ''Responsibility'': ''It is the responsibility of the poet to say many times: there is no freedom without justice and this means economic justice and love justice.'' Nor do the hymns to her friends (''I thought I would / sit down . . . / and write a poem honoring / the occasion which is May 25th / Evelyn my best friend's birthday'') and family entail much linguistic or emotional surprise. Only Paley's meditations on old age and her Jewish identity are exceptions to the generally cozy atmosphere. Adam Kirsch

title: New Landlord, Old Tenants, Hard Questions
description: ''IT was a beautiful offer,'' said Marie Johnson, a former homeowner from Queens and a tenant since 1991 at the Martha Washington Hotel. ''But some of the women did not believe it was possible. They thought he was tempting us and would not live up to his promises.''

title: Sharing the Credit For Library Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Employees. No Headquarters. $45 Million Payoff.
description: FOR its first two and a half years, the Valent Software Corporation was a most virtual of companies. The chief executive lived in Massachusetts, the president was parked in Utah, the engineering team was based in Ohio and a handful of other employees worked out of their dining rooms and basements. The ''workplace'' consisted largely of cell-phone calls, e-mail correspondence and meetings in hotel lobbies.

title: Old and New In the West 20's
description: BONGO

title: The Color Of Indecision
description: ''You don't know me,'' said the voice on the telephone, ''but I'm hoping you'll help me.'' The supplicant was Rick Moranis, the actor who played the nerdy neighbor in the film ''Ghostbusters.'' His problem: ''I just had the living room painted, and it's the color of a banana.''

title: Amid Nosegays in Bronxville
description: IF flora were the focus of our critical purview, we would certainly cite the bouquets at Underhills Crossing as among the loveliest of any we have seen: coolly elegant pastels in silver julep cups on every table, brilliant sunbursts of color at the edge of the bar. Unfortunately, care for the diner's comfort is considerably less than the care lavished on nosegays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTINE, SYDNEY A.
description: GOLDSTINE-Sydney A., MD. Ninety-one years. Passed on February 13 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Cherished and loving husband of Tamie Laurance Goldstine. Loving father of Jonathan and Thea. Loving grandfather of Susan. Affiliated with Mt. Sinai Hospital forty years, he was a devoted physician and friend to many over a long, satisfying medical career. A true gentleman and scholar. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St., NYC on March 1st at 4 PM. Donations in his memory may be made to the Palliative Care Program, Attn: Dr. Diane Meier, Mt. Sinai Hospital School of Medicine, Box 1070, NY, NY 10029.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: The $12 Million Man; Buchanan Waits by the Side Door for the Party to be Begin
description: FOR all the money and fury being invested in the parallel primary campaigns of the two major parties, there is another Presidential war game going on under the radar, among the mud-spattered troops of the Reform party slogging through their own wilderness campaign. Sooner or later, however, the winners of the Democratic and Republican fights will have to pay attention. For, barring direct intrusion by Ross Perot himself, the current expectation among political professionals is that the Reform line could very well be resurrected this fall by none other than Patrick J. Buchanan, the turncoat Republican and chronic Presidential candidate.

title: On to Washington State
description: Now that the presidential race is reaching full throttle, each new election barrels down on the candidates before they can even catch their breath from the one just past. The three states voting Tuesday -- Washington, Virginia and North Dakota -- pose the toughest challenges for former Senator Bill Bradley and Senator John McCain. For the first time since New Hampshire, they will now be scrambling with each other for crossover votes from all parties. But since Mr. Bradley has not won a primary yet, he is fighting hardest to hang on. Washington is the place he has chosen for a showdown with Vice President Al Gore. With the state's prosperous high-tech-oriented voters likely to be receptive to his appeal, Mr. Bradley needs to do well, or risk falling back even further.

title: A Chardonnay With Oomph
description: Talk about staying power.

title: Claudine All Grown Up
description: Creating Colette Volume II: From Baroness to Woman of Letters, 1912-1954. By Claude Francis and Fernande Gontier. 298 pp. South Royalton, Vt.: Steerforth Press. $27.

title: Sour Pickles and Waiters And 7 Building Violations
description: Carving up huge meat sandwiches for three generations, the Carnegie Delicatessen on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan has become a New York institution, a must-see stop on the tourist trail.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Medical Errors Can Be Prevented
description: To the Editor:

title: Purrs, Furs and Instant Bonding At a Cat Adoption Fair
description: THE SETTING -- With the stray cat population on the rise, cat rescue groups organized Adoptarama, an adoption fair, in Expo Center at Madison Square Garden Tuesday.

title: Those Negative Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: JAMAICA

title: Schools Seeking to Skirt Rules That Bar Ten Commandments
description: Trying to make the Ten Commandments part of public school life in ways that could survive constitutional challenges, Indiana has passed a bill that permits schools to post the religious edicts as historical documents, and several other states are pondering similar measures.

title: The View From/Yorktown Heights; Wanted: Help in Writing Novel of Family History
description: WHEN the people who live on the sprawling properties near the Croton Reservoir here advertise for live-in help, it is likely to be for a nanny or an au pair. But Raymond E. Ballinger recently ran advertisements in The Pennysaver and The North County News, a local weekly, looking for a different kind of assistant.

title: Correspondence/Uncovering Science; A Perpetual Student Charts a Course Through a Universe of Discoveries
description: AFTER 22 years as a science writer I recently retired to cut firewood in Vermont and enjoy the memories of an exciting life, in which I covered a half-dozen wars before discovering the deeper satisfaction of observing and reporting the achievements of scientists.

title: Maria Carthy, Sam Barclay
description: Maria Jan Carthy, a lawyer, and Sam Barclay, a computer executive, were married yesterday in Christchurch, New Zealand. The Rev. Richard Easton, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the Anglican ceremony at St. Barnabas Church.

title: If Not One China Now, Then When?
description: To the Editor:

title: Behrens in Form With Easy Victory
description: He may not have been elected Horse of the Year last season, when Charismatic got the votes. He may not have won his debut this year, when Stephen Got Even outran him in the Donn Handicap three weeks ago. But yesterday, still rocketing along at the age of 6, Behrens won the Gulfstream Park Handicap for the second straight year when he scored by five lengths over Adonis in Hallandale, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, PAUL
description: COHEN-Paul. 1927 to 2000. A man with an acute sense of social justice and a lifelong commitment to living his ideals, stalwart of the union and civil rights movements, a talented amateur photographer, a vital repository of New York history, and raconteur extraordinaire. His loss will be deeply felt by his many family members and friends. Pre-deceased by wife Claire and son Michael. Survived by sisters Ethel and Gerti, partner and sole mate Helen, childhood friend Danny, loving daughter and son-in-law Debby and Joe. Graveside service at Beth Moses Cemetery, 1pm Monday, February 28th

title: In the Region / New Jersey; As Mortgage Rates Rise, Options Help Buyers Cope
description: NO ONE will argue with the truism that with every upward tick in mortgage interest rates some people are pushed out of the housing market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDERICH, PETER A.
description: FRIEDERICH-Peter A., age 71, on February 21, 2000, in a motorscooter accident in Lighthouse Point, Fla. Loving father of Cindy, Peter and Thomas; cherished grandfather of Brandon and Brittany; adored brother of Terre and Barbara; a favorite uncle to many nieces and nephews; an army veteran, he was a retired VP of RCA. He joins his soul mate Lenore in heaven. We miss you Dad.

title: Manifest Density
description: A NEWER WORLD

title: Fixing the First Lady Problem
description: Here we go again. For years now, all sorts of people have been taking gratuitous swipes at the Clintons. It has become the fashionable thing to do. Now Sullivan is hopping on the bandwagon, expressing his distaste for Hillary in the guise of a ''comparison'' with Ernestine Schlant. What is apparent is that he dislikes Hillary so much that he could not suppress his urge to vent his spleen, spoiling what could have been more honestly an informative tribute to Schlant. There is no ''First Lady Problem'' and Sullivan certainly didn't ''fix'' anything, except to set in the public mind his hatred of the Clintons.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-27-00: Test Run; Clown for a Day
description: During the recent round of men's fashion shows, designers presented a wide variety of looks, from the traditional to the futuristic. They were great on the runway, but I began to wonder how they'd fare on the mean streets of Manhattan. I called Walter van Beirendonck, an up-and-coming Belgian designer who showed perhaps the most outre outfit of all, and asked to borrow it for a day.

title: In the Wake of Four Murders, Politicians and Gay Groups Urge Action
description: Jerry Colella was found murdered in his West 122nd Street apartment in January 1997. Then, in August 1998, Ernest Watts was found dead at his home in the Delano Village housing complex on West 139th Street. Nathanial Hayden, who also lived at Delano Village, was killed last October. The Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project said all three were gay men who had been stabbed to death.

title: At Kmart in Riverhead, A Debate on Gun Sales
description: The Kmart store on Route 58 in Riverhead was the scene of protests last week, both in favor and against the sale of firearms in the sporting goods department.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 6 about the stage production of ''Jane Eyre'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music reversed the identities of two actresses. Penny Layden was on the left and Harriette Ashcroft on the right.

title: Learning How To Be King
description: It seems that King Abdullah's penchant for incognito forays has a precedent in Arab folkore (Jeffrey Goldberg, Feb. 6). It reminded me of a cherished fairy tale I read in my youth titled ''Haroun al Rashid, the Caliph of Baghdad.'' In the tale, the caliph wanted to hear for himself what his subjects thought of him. So he and some trusted men of the court went disguised into the city. They, too, were recognized, but with more serious results than in the case of King Abdullah: they were transformed into storks by a sorcerer who was working for the caliph's enemies at court.

title: Houston Expands Its Profile in Fine Arts
description: FOR years the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston has enjoyed a national reputation and attracted prominent traveling exhibitions, most recently the work of Diego Rivera. Last year, 1.3 million people visited the museum, underscoring its importance in Houston's profile as a cultural destination.

title: Populist Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Hometown Basketball Stars, Decades Apart
description: INSTANT recognition ''That's Gus Williams!'' -- accompanied by awe is what the name of the 46-year-old Williams inevitably invokes, even among those less than half his age. In the 1970's, Mount Vernon High School had an astonishing seven players go on to play in the National Basketball Association. Of those seven, Williams had the most illustrious pro career, playing a game marked by quicksilver moves that earned him the nickname the Wizard.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Weill's World
description: ''I decided to develop a type of musical play which leans more and more toward opera,'' Kurt Weill declared in 1946, after he fled Nazi Germany and came to New York. ''In the 11 years I've been here, the musical theater on Broadway has developed tremendously,'' he added, referring primarily to his own contributions. The son of a cantor, Weill (1900-50) studied classical music with Humperdinck and Busoni. His works would come to reflect the cultural and political upheavals of his time, even as they blurred the distinctions between serious and popular music. Though ''The Threepenny Opera'' (1928) -- the greatest of his collaborations with Brecht -- was little known in the United States at the time of Weill's death, a number of his innovative Broadway musicals brought fame and critical respect, including ''Lady in the Dark'' (1941) and ''Lost in the Stars'' (1949). As painstakingly assembled by David Farneth, director of the Weill-Lenya Research Center, with Elmar Juchem, a German musicologist, and Dave Stein, an archivist at the Weill-Lenya Research Center, KURT WEILL: A Life in Pictures and Documents (Overlook, $75) demonstrates the degree to which Weill was a fierce protector and aggressive promoter of his own work. While focusing on Weill's compositions and career, this lavishly illustrated volume employs letters, production shots, posters, record labels and newspaper clippings to evoke the day-to-day existence of an industrious artist. The 17-year-old Weill announced that he wanted to ''work until I drop''; he reaffirmed, ''I completely fall apart when I'm not working.'' This begins to explain how Weill accomplished so much during his relatively brief life. ''He was probably the most original single workman in the whole musical theater, internationally considered, during the last quarter century,'' Virgil Thomson wrote in an obituary. Weill certainly would have agreed. David Kaufman

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: On the Carpet; Why Certain Political Symbols Stick

Lover of art, opera, music and ballet. Her spirit, compassion, intelligence, and conversation will be missed by all who knew her. Memorial Service on February 27 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad, Mt. Vernon at 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Ira Rubin Memorial Fund at Montefiore Hospital.

title: After Space, Hughes Battles Time; Chasing Cable Foes To a Web Future
description: WHEN Hughes Electronics was first developing a service to beam television programs from satellites to home antennas, skeptics joked that D.B.S., the industry shorthand for direct broadcast satellite, actually stood for ''Don't Be Stupid.''

title: The Fear of Loathing on the Campaign Trail
description: Earlier this month, as the Republican contenders for president were bickering over who was the bigger meanie, I paid a visit to Greg Stevens, who was hard at work creating two commercials for his candidate, John McCain, in a rent-by-the-hour video editing studio across the river from Washington in Arlington, Va. The son of a minister, Stevens, who is 51, speaks in mild tones and dresses in muted colors; that day he was wearing pressed gray flannels, a light gray shirt and a dark gray and black sweater. His commercials, in contrast, sparkle with color, swoop through blurring camera pans, shake with sound.

description: In a splashy ceremony at Rockefeller Center earlier this month, cameras rolled and an adoring throng applauded as a redheaded, freckle-faced puppet was elevated into the television pantheon.

description: Westchester Medical Center has become the first, and only, center in the United States to offer a new treatment for liver cancer authorized by the federal Food and Drug Administration.

description: THERE was a time when I grew African violets. They were beautiful plants. The leaves were strong and the plants had noble stature.

title: One More Strike
description: His teammates on the Yankees were surprised when they learned that Darryl Strawberry had flunked a drug test -- he took cocaine -- but none seemed particularly shocked, speaking in monotones about the terrible burden of addiction. They have been through this many times before. This is Strawberry's third strike under baseball's drug aftercare program, and he has received suspensions of 60 and 120 days in the past; Commissioner Bud Selig is considering suspending him for the entire season this time. BUSTER OLNEY

title: The First Fine Day; Kansas City
description: It is easy to imagine the way spring will burst on Kansas City. Blossoms will cascade from the Bradford pear trees that line Brush Creek for several blocks as it winds through the Country Club Plaza district, and thousands of daffodils will open on the banks of the creek. And I will be there, with nothing better to do on the afternoon when the temperature first touches 70 than to disappear from my nearby office and stroll the walks that line its banks.

title: Dig They Did Under Verdi Square and Out Scrambled Rats

title: Asian Cuisine That Sings With Flavor
description: NEXT month is a time for birds, bees, buds, baseball and new East End restaurants. A new eatery in Sag Harbor that promises to be one of the spring and summer seasons' biggest hits opened quietly a couple of months ago and is already wildly popular among East Enders. So much so that it's difficult to get a table on weekends, even now (its no reservations policy adds to the difficulty).

title: A Finger Is Pointed At Milosevic
description: The Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic has been making life difficult for NATO peacekeepers in the troubled city of Mitrovica. NATO and Administration officials acknowledged they had intercepted radio transmissions between Serbs in the northern part of Mitrovica and Mr. Milosevic's security police in Serbia proper. As well, Mr. Milosevic has been sending plainclothes police into the city to help train and encourage Serb militants who want to expel the remaining Albanians in northern Mitrovica. NATO commanders vowed they would ensure the return of Albanian residents who fled their homes in the north. Whether that can happen seems likely to be a fundamental test of the Administration's Kosovo policy. JANE PERLEZ

title: 'Gertrude and Claudius'
description: The King was irate. His daughter, Gerutha, though but a plump sixteen, had voiced reluctance to marry the nobleman of his choice, Horwen-dil the Jute, a beefy warrior in every way suitable, if Jutes could ever suit in marriage a Zealand maiden born and reared in the royal castle of Elsinore. "To disobey the King is treason," Rorik admonished his child, the roses in whose thin-skinned cheeks flared with defiance and distress. "When the culprit is the realm's only princess," he went on, "the crime becomes incestuous and self-injuring."

title: Streetscapes / Herbert Tannenbaum on the Gorham and United States Rubber Buildings; At 90, Architect Reflects on Remodelings He Regrets
description: PRESERVATIONISTS wince when they see how architects in the 1950's renovated majestic old structures like the United States Rubber building at 58th Street and Broadway and the Gorham building at 36th Street and Fifth Avenue. Such remodelings epitomize the era when the marble, granite and bronze of the American renaissance was considered just so much scrap. The architect responsible for those two renovations, Herbert Tannenbaum, is still practicing at age 90 -- and it turns out he didn't like what he did either.

title: Choir Boys Back With New Director
description: The Vienna Choir Boys are on tour so often that their performances in Princeton and Morristown this week are hardly news. Even less newsworthy is the fact that another man has been appointed artistic director. He is Norbert Balatsch, who like his new deputy, Gerald Wirth, is a former member of the Choir Boys.

title: Hit Musical From London Staged in Rockland County
description: AMERICAN and English tastes are often an ocean apart. Example: ''Honk!'' won the Olivier -- the British equivalent of the Tony Awards -- as best new musical, over ''The Lion King,'' the 1998 Tony winner and still Broadway's hottest ticket.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline on Feb. 20 about renovations at Penn Station in Manhattan omitted a word in stating the cost. It should have said, ''After More Than $100 Million,'' not ''After More Than $100.''

title: 'Seinfeld' Actress in New Role Giving Advice Online
description: ''Is there life after 'Seinfeld?' '' That is the question being asked on Oracle's e-business network, a new online service announced earlier this month. The answer can also be found there: Estelle Harris, the actress who played the character George Constanza's cranky mother on ''Seinfeld,'' is starting a weekly computer-advice program on the Oracle network.

description: Matt Galloway talks in sporadic, sometimes emotional bursts. His hands fly around. His body tries to keep up. At least that is how Stephen Belber portrayed him onstage.

description: Stephanie Lynn-Harrison, 41, was pregnant and unemployed. She recalls that she became increasingly worried about how she was going to provide for her children, and that the stress eventually became too much. She began to feel a depression that at its worst points was so deep it was as if ''a complete fog'' had moved in, she said.

description: ''I should have been more clear in disassociating myself from anti-Catholic sentiments and racial prejudice. It was a missed opportunity, causing needless offense, which I deeply regret.''

description: Bella Chiarra, a 5-year-old daughter of Phone Trick, won the $200,000 Rampart Handicap yesterday at Gulfstream Park in Hallandale, Fla., for her third victory in four starts since Patrick Byrne succeeded the late Charlie Whittingham as her trainer.

title: Madman or Martyr, He Endures As an Antislavery Champion
description: To the North's abolitionists John Brown was a martyr. To many Southerners he was a fanatic murderer. ''John Brown's Holy War,'' tonight's 90-minute account of his committed life and memorable death finds justification for both opinions.

title: Pupils Glimpse an Idea; Teacher Gets a Gold Star
description: The first time I taught a writing class I was scared stiff. This was at a private school where I was filling in for a teacher who had left suddenly in the middle of the semester. Nothing I had done before -- editing a magazine, publishing five novels -- prepared me for trying to explain how I'd done it or, more daunting still, to translate what I worked at every day into curriculum.

description: GOLD-Annalee. 74. On February 26, 2000. Contributions in her memory can be made to Caring Community, 20 Washington Sq., NY, NY 10011 or Village Center for Care, 607 Hudson St., NY, NY 10014.

title: Old-Fashioned Reporting, New Medium
description: In many ways, the world-beating scoop last week by TheSmokingGun .com, which revealed that the ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?'' groom, Rick Rockwell, was once the subject of a restraining order, says a lot about the fledgling Internet's place in the new order of American journalism.

title: McCain Opposes Tax Breaks Important in Washington State
description: Two days before the Republican primary in Washington State, Senator John McCain said today that he opposed a tax provision that has saved some of that state's largest employers, including the Boeing Corporation and Microsoft, hundreds of millions of dollars each year.

title: John Heliker, 91, Versatile Painter and Teacher
description: John Heliker, a painter and teacher who was a fixture of the New York art world for nearly seven decades, died on Tuesday at the Sonojee Estate, a health center in Bar Harbor, Me. He was 91 and had lived in New York during most of his career, spending summers on Cranberry Island, Me.

title: For Sosa, Steals Are Back In the Plan
description: Demonstrating veteran wiliness, Sammy Sosa stopped running. The Chicago Cubs were running their post-workout sprints in the outfield, and Sosa badly trailed the pack. But this was the last sprint, so Sosa stopped well short of center field, his destination, spun around and raced back to the right-field line, easily beating the rest of the players. Then he collapsed to the ground, exhausted.

title: Bradley Hits His Stride In the Other Washington
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley never seems to hit his oratorical stride until about midafternoon. So it was shocking to see him stroll into an ornate hotel lobby packed with supporters at 9:30 a.m. recently and bellow with unusual verve, ''Good morning, Spokane!''

title: Nibbling at the Corners Simply Consumes Leiter
description: Al Leiter held the ball in his left hand, lifted it above his shoulder to signal to Mike Piazza and the minor league catcher Alan Probst that he was tossing a fastball and then he unleashed the pitch. But Leiter was not tossing a four-seam fastball and he was not being the same Leiter that the Mets know so well.

title: Backers Struggle to Invigorate Black Patriots Memorial Plan
description: Conceived as a way of giving the 5,000 black soldiers and sailors who fought in the Revolutionary War their rightful place in the nation's history after centuries of neglect, a memorial to honor them remains unbuilt. Fifteen years, four presidents and four missed deadlines later, the charity created to erect the memorial is $7 million short of the $8 million it needs by October to avoid losing its choice site in Washington between the Lincoln Memorial and the Washington Monument.

title: Campaigns Spread Thin
description: With 17 states holding primaries in the next nine days, the leading candidates are engaged in a feverish hopscotch of the nation. Page A13.

title: Breeze Rules The Schedule
description: The ultimate fate of the 30th America's Cup match between Team New Zealand and Italy's Prada Challenge continues to rest on the whims of a most fickle sea breeze, the lack of which canceled Sunday's scheduled fourth race of the five-of-nine-race finals. The Kiwis are holding a 3-0 lead.

title: Corrections

description: In the waning days of his 16-year tenure as archbishop of New York, Cardinal John O'Connor canceled his customary celebration of Sunday morning Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday after suffering what a spokesman called another and more pronounced episode of weakness in recent days.

description: The News Corporation, the holding company for Rupert Murdoch's media empire, and Yahoo Inc., the giant Internet portal, are discussing an alliance that could include stock investments in each other's operations, according to News Corporation executives close to the talks.

title: Handsome, Narcissistic And Tangled

What they don't say is: We are so self-absorbed we make the women of ''Sex in the City'' look like a band of Mother Teresas.

title: Joseph Wolfson, Surf Legend, Dies at 50
description: Joseph Wolfson, an aquatic Peter Pan who was one of the first surfboarders to master complex maneuvers on the smaller ''body board'' in the 1970's, died in a car crash on a Los Angeles freeway last Monday. He was 50.

title: Battling in Colombia but Touring Together in Europe
description: Officially, peace talks between the Colombian government and the largest rebel group are stalled, with no date set for them to resume. Yet just the other day, the government's chief negotiator boasted that ''we have advanced further this month than in 40 years of conflict.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer malfunction, a passage was omitted in some copies yesterday from the front-page article about continuing violence in Kosovo. The affected section is reprinted today, on Page A3.

title: At the Heart of the Diallo Case
description: The cops had their day in court and were acquitted. The system was twisted this way and that to insure that they were treated fairly. More than fairly. The judge, Joseph Teresi, trumpeted his sympathies as soon as the trial was over by hobnobbing at a bed and breakfast with the defense lawyers.

title: Two companies say their new tests for cervical cancer will be more reliable than Pap smears are.
description: FAMED for its inventor, George Nicholas Papanicolaou, the Pap smear has saved millions of women's lives since it was introduced in the United States in the 1940's.

description: JACOBS-Nathan P. Age 91, of NYC, and Palm Beach, FL. Died peacefully in his sleep on February 27, 2000. He is survived by his beloved wife, Lucille (Lucy) and his loving children Carol Ann Leibner, Judith Lynn and Daniel Pace, Alan S. Jacobs and step-daughter Kay Hope Seligson. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, David and Elizabeth Leibner, Michelle Golda and Garrett Charles Pace and great-grandfather of Joseph Daniel Pace. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Anti-Defamation League.

A memorial service will be held in Vermont. Date and church will be announced later.

title: Cash-Poor Jets Are in a Salary Straitjacket
description: Searching for a pass-rusher -- the Jets have not had a defensive lineman with more than 10 sacks since 1990 -- the club's scouting brain trust and assistant coaches finished poking the country's best collegians yesterday as the annual combine in Indianapolis ended.

title: Brooklyn Choir Wins Praise by Singing the Lord's Praises
description: The halls of the Brooklyn Tabernacle shook with the exhortations of the Rev. Jim Cymbala yesterday, and Carol Cymbala, leading the choir, worked the piano as she has done for 27 years, as if nothing at all were different about this day. But there was.

title: Knicks Contain Iverson, and Then Stop Him
description: Chris Childs dutifully followed Allen Iverson around screens for most of the day, trying everything to disarm pro basketball's most potent offensive weapon. Lock and trail, coaches call this -- a strategy aimed more at containment than at prevention, aimed at letting the All-Star get his points with minimal damage.

description: KRUMHOLZ - Shirley. Dearest darling wife of Marvin; precious beloved mother of Drs. Ellen and David Mandel and Dr. Martin and Susan Shulman. Adored nanny of Leigh and Susannah Mandel, Lawrence, Dina and Andrew Shulman. Dear sister of Gertrude. Very much loved aunt, great-aunt, and great-great-aunt of many nieces and nephews. Services Monday 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Under Fire, Japan Sect Starts Over
description: Outside the local office of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect here, dozens of riot police officers have been permanently stationed to control angry Japanese mobs that gather to denounce the sect, which killed 12 people five years ago when it released deadly nerve gas in the Tokyo subways.

title: An Emerging Team, an Emerging Star
description: After Hofstra won the ECAC Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden in December, Norman Richardson gave his most valuable player trophy to his teammate Speedy Claxton. ''To the real m.v.p.,'' Richardson declared in a locker room ceremony.

title: G.O.P. Divide Grows Wider In California
description: As the presidential campaign moves to the biggest states, George W. Bush and John McCain are battling squarely for the biggest prize of all: California, whose once-mighty Republican Party propelled Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan to the White House but has languished and feuded for much of the 1990's as President Clinton and the Democrats came to dominate the state.

title: Yanks Get Green Light Around the Basepaths
description: Chuck Knoblauch exuded a base-running arrogance when he played for the Minnesota Twins, striding purposefully off first base, far from the bag. His body language screamed to pitchers and catchers that he was going to run, and that there wasn't much anybody could do about it.

title: Britain's Prudential Considers Bid for Rival
description: Prudential P.L.C., the British insurance company, is considering a bid of as much as $:4 billion, or $6.4 billion, for its rival, the Equitable Life Assurance Society, executives close to the company said today.

title: NATO General Hopes G.I.'s Will Return to Kosovo Town
description: Because of the risk to the soldiers, the Pentagon has refused to allow American troops to return to northern Mitrovica, the section dominated by Serbs in the divided town that has become a flash point of ethnic tension in Kosovo, senior United Nations and Western officials say.

Total billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Lindberghs Express Dismay Over Biography
