title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DAVID
description: LEVINE-David, Dr., of Englewood, NJ, on February 26. Beloved husband of Shirley (nee Hagel.) Devoted father of Joshua and Howard. Dear brother of Sara and Celia. Loving grandfather of four. For information: ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Season May Be Run at Gulfstream
description: A spokesman for Frank Stronach, who bought Gulfstream Park last year, calls it a long shot. John Brunetti, who owns Hialeah Park in Florida, says it is a dead deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, BEATRICE
description: RUBIN-Beatrice. The Executive Committee of the Montefiore Staff and Alumni Association records with deep sorrow the passing of Bea Rubin, devoted wife and helpmate of our late esteemed past president, Ira L. Rubin, M.D. A gracious lady; a kind and gentle spirit. Jacqueline A. Bello, M.D., Pres. Margaret Pinsker, Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAVISKY, CHARLOTTE
description: STAVISKY-Charlotte. Died peacefully on February 26, at the Mary Manning Walsh Senior Facility at the age of 92. Ms. Stavisky was an actress and sculptress. For additional information, please contact Riverside Memorial Chapel at 212362-6600.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Agreement on Digital TV Appears Unfinished, Again

title: The Lessons of the Diallo Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Smaller Is Better in State Elections in India
description: Regional parties have humbled both of India's national parties in state elections whose results became final today, emphatically reaffirming that the days when a pan-India party could dominate the nation's politics are dead and gone.

title: Closed Book or New Chapter?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Game Film Brings Out A Tougher Van Horn
description: Midway through the fourth quarter on Saturday night, Charlotte Hornets forward Derrick Coleman found his spot just outside the lane, set himself and turned for a routine jump shot. But as he released the shot, the long arm of Keith Van Horn suddenly rose in front of him, snapping the ball back over Coleman's head.

title: The Lessons of the Diallo Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Old-Line Women's Magazines Turn to Sex to Spice Up Their Sales
description: Deeply offended by the sexually explicit magazine covers spreading across newsstands, a watchdog group called Morality in Media last month pressed the Kroger supermarket chain to conceal explicit cover lines like this one on Cosmopolitan: ''Sex Tricks Only Cosmo Would Know: 20 Earth-Quaking Moves That Will Make Him Plead for Mercy -- and Beg for More.''

title: Gotta Dance! But Oscar Won't Let Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Skirmishes Defining New Jersey Senate Primary Race
description: In a season dominated by presidential politics, the Democratic rivals for the Senate from New Jersey have yet to take center stage. But former Gov. Jim Florio has been attacking Jon S. Corzine, his virtually unknown opponent, every day and from every angle, as if the June 6 primary were right around the corner.

title: Year 2000 Rollover Problem, the Sequel
description: Four years ago tomorrow, on Feb. 29, 1996, malfunctions in computers that did not recognize that year's leap day forced Belgium to close its stock exchange, stopped the Arizona State Lottery from selling tickets and locked all the doors at Johnson County Community College in Kansas.

title: When Case Was Weighed, Prosecution Was Wanting, Juror Says
description: A juror who helped acquit four police officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo said today that the prosecution had failed to prove its case, but she still believed that the officers should be held responsible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, HARRIET
description: LOEB-Harriet. February 26, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Rene. Devoted mother of Peter and his wife Linda. Loving sister of Leo Bloch. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral private.

title: The Lessons of the Diallo Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Deal In Hong Kong Said to Get A New Player
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has agreed to make a $1 billion investment in Singapore Telecommunications, which could enable it to sweeten its offer for Hong Kong's dominant telephone company, Cable & Wireless HKT Ltd., executives close to the negotiations said this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died Feb. 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co.

title: Voices From a Forgotten Landscape
description: The premise of the American West has always been that there is another west lying just over the horizon, a place to annul the past, to re-originate. That premise was never completely true, but it was a way of making sense of such a vast quantity of land. Now, however, the next west lies well within the circle of the immediate horizon, and it is annulling the past at an unforgiving, and unforgivable, rate. East of Denver, heading west, you almost hate to come to a ridgeline on the prairie for fear of what will unfold before you. First a lone outpost of houses clustering on a slope, still raw from the earthmovers' work, then garrison after garrison of signature subdivisions closing in on Denver itself.

title: BUSH RUES FAILURE TO ATTACK BIGOTRY IN VISIT TO COLLEGE
description: Gov. George W. Bush expressed regret today for not speaking out against racial and religious intolerance during a visit to Bob Jones University in South Carolina, an appearance that has come to haunt his campaign and challenge his claim to being a new kind of conservative eager to expand the Republican Party's appeal to all voters.

title: For online businesses, alliances with bricks-and-mortar retailing chains promise many benefits.
description: A RECENT deal between Starbucks and the urban delivery specialist Kozmo.com -- in which Starbucks will essentially set aside space in its coffee shops for Kozmo -- may be the first example of an established retailer offering its floor space and personnel to an e-commerce company. But it is unlikely to be the last.

title: Gifted Programs Are Right for Only the Gifted
description: To the Editor:

title: Pills for the Very Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Umpires and Major Leagues Start Negotiations Today
description: Richie Phillips, the major league umpires' newly deposed labor leader, formulated a mass resignation strategy last July in an effort to induce baseball officials to begin early negotiations for a new labor agreement. Seven months later, those talks will begin, without Phillips.

title: Farrakhan Ends Longtime Rivalry With Orthodox Muslims
description: Declaring an end to more than two decades of bitter rivalry, Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam today embraced W. Deen Muhammad, the son of the late Elijah Muhammad, and said the two men ''will be together until death takes us over.''

title: Amtrak to Expand Service, Copying Strategy of Airlines
description: After years of trying to balance its books by cutting service, Amtrak has concluded that to succeed it should instead create routes, offer more frequent service on existing lines and organize itself more like the airlines, so people can change trains and get to places more efficiently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZMIERSKI, JOHN T.
description: KAZMIERSKI-John T. Age 79, of Edge-water, NJ. Died on February 25, 2000. Upon retiring from the IBM Corporation in 1987, he was involved with volunteer activities, mainly relating to blind people and tutoring student immigrants. Visiting Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St, NYC, Tuesday, 9 AM to 10:45 AM. Mass of Christian Burial to follow at 11 AM, at St. Bernard's R.C. Church.

title: Yankees Have an Eye on Erstad
description: The Anaheim Angels' Darin Erstad is the type of player Yankees officials love: he plays hard, he is talented, he is fast, he is a lot like a young Paul O'Neill.

title: A Kennedy Speaks Out for Gore
description: Once it was the L-word that candidates seeking the political center sought to avoid. Now, it's the C-word -- for conservative -- that Democrats are fighting over. Partly in response to efforts by former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey last week in a debate and on the airwaves to paint him as an ally of social conservatism, Vice President Al Gore began running a 30-second commercial yesterday on New York stations spotlighting an endorsement from Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

title: For EM.TV, a Muppet Mission Accomplished
description: ''Here, you have to see this,'' insisted Thomas Haffa, founder of EM.TV and Merchandising A.G., as he ordered the video to be cued.

title: Corrections
description: An article about erroneous addresses on Census Bureau letters to 120 million households was omitted from some copies of the Late Edition on Saturday although it was listed in the contents on Page A1. The article is reprinted today on Page A15.

title: Sports of The Times; Kukoc Joins the 76ers To Speed the Process
description: BEFORE yesterday's game against the Knicks, Pat Croce, the 76ers' energetic 45-year-old president, conceded that this game at Madison Square Garden was a litmus test for his team.

title: Indian Tea Company in Deal for Tetley
description: Tata Tea Ltd. said today that it would pay $:271 million, or $431 million, to buy the Tetley Group, Britain's No. 1 maker of tea bags, marking the biggest overseas purchase yet by an Indian company.

title: AN ARAB MILITIA, GLIMPSING VICTORY, COULD LOSE PEACE
description: No man has made himself more Israel's enemy in recent years than Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the portly, bespectacled Shiite Muslim cleric who leads Hezbollah, the Lebanon-based, Iran-backed Party of God that has evolved into a formidable guerrilla movement and political party from the umbrella organization that once directed the Middle East's most brutal Islamic terrorists.

title: Domingo's New Season: The Accent Is Spanish
description: In announcing next season's schedule at the Washington Opera, where he is artistic director, the Spanish tenor Placido Domingo let it be known with a smile last week that he had just realized that six of the eight works were set in Spain.

title: Devils End Skid Behind Brodeur and a Relentless Offense
description: Unaccustomed to losing four in a row, the Devils came out firing this evening. Their shots in the first 25 minutes were either wide by inches or pushed aside, but 3 of their 48 shots eventually found the net for a 3-0 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBMAN, LEONARD
description: TAUBMAN-Leonard. Of Bronx, NY. On February 26. Beloved husband of Sylvia (nee Rosenbaum). Devoted father of Fred and Wendy. Dear brother of Irving and Zelda, and most beloved grandfather of Cara and Alanna. Family services will be held today. For information, ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800322-0533.

title: From Pulpits to Politics, Angry Voices on Diallo
description: Words of anger, frustration and bewilderment rose from pulpits across New York City yesterday, while more than 1,000 demonstrators took to the streets for a third day of prayer and protest, evidence of the still roiling emotions after the acquittal of four officers on Friday in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo.

title: Health Care's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lessons of the Diallo Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: To Many in the Court of Public Opinion, the Prosecution Is Now the Accused
description: Lawrence Teele, a school custodian, said while walking home in Harlem on Saturday that the prosecution lawyers had lacked passion and conviction. Barbara Ford, a Bronx woman attending a rally up the street at the National Action Network, the Rev. Al Sharpton's headquarters, said they had not prosecuted the case ''as fully as it could have been.'' Francis Kallon, protesting near the United Nations yesterday, said he was angry that they had not cross-examined the defendants more aggressively.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETLUCK, ROBERT F.
description: PETLUCK-Robert F., Dr. Graduate of Fordham, retired Principal of PS 86 of the Bronx, attorney and former NY Times employee. Of Hampton Bays, formerly of the Bronx. Died on February 25, 2000, at the age of 90. He leaves his dear wife of 67 years, Estelle (Rosenthal). He is survived by his son Richard A. and his wife Arlene of Israel. He leaves his two grandchildren, David Petluck and Joyce Pinto, and his great-grandchildren Boaz, Lillian, Daniel and Amos Pinto. A private cremation was conducted by the J. Ronald Scott Funeral Home of Hampton Bays.

title: I.B.M. to Introduce Advance in Chip Manufacturing
description: Technologists for I.B.M. will describe new details this week of a next-generation chip-making system that uses beams of electrons, rather than light waves, to etch circuits onto chips.

title: The Next Leader of the I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund, the guardian of global financial stability, will soon select its next director. Unhappily, and true to form, it is proceeding in secret, with little opportunity for the public to appraise the leading candidates or their views on critical questions about the future of the fund. The lack of openness is intolerable for one of the world's most influential organizations.

title: The Fast Coalition Broadens Its Focus
description: A coalition devoted to interactive advertising and marketing has named a new leader amid plans to broaden its focus.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about the acquisition of VST Technologies by the SmartDisk Corporation referred incorrectly to SmartDisk's business. It makes floppy disk adapters and other products that transfer data among PC's, the Internet and digital appliances; it does not make computer disks.

title: AOL Europe to Announce Bank Alliance
description: AOL Europe, a joint venture between America Online and Bertelsmann, will announce an alliance tomorrow with Deutsche Bank for AOL customers to bank over mobile phones, said the venture's chief executive, Andreas Schmidt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREINDLER, RUBY
description: KREINDLER-Ruby. Loving wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Judge Robert and Donald. Grandmother of Keith, Charles, Dorian and David, and five greatgrandchildren. At her request, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the donor's favorite charity. No one was sweeter, kinder, or more loving.

title: Equity and Debt Expected to Be Offered
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ALBERT J.
description: ROSENBERG-Albert J. The Board of Directors of the Henry Nias Foundation, Inc. records with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed president emeritus. He will be remembered for his wisdom, compassion and sense of humor. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Edith and his sons, Dr. Lawrence and William. We mourn with them and share their loss. Stanley Edelman, M.D. Chairman, Board of Directors Henry Nias Foundation, Inc.

title: Confronting the Reality Of a Health Care Vision
description: It is show-me time for Healtheon/ WebMD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELIKER, JOHN
description: HELIKER-John. We mourn the passing of John Heliker, artist and friend for over 50 years. His gentle and sensitive nature lives on in his art. Kraushaar Galleries

title: INSIDE
description: Memorial Plan Languishes

title: Henry Tobler, 34, Who Saw the Value of Folk Art
description: Henry Jernigan Tobler, a gallery director, collector and writer who specialized in contemporary art and folk art, died on Friday at the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. He was 34 and lived in New York until June, when he moved to Houston for treatment.

title: De La Hoya Able to Keep One of His Two Promises
description: Oscar De La Hoya had promised to be more aggressive and seek the knockout, after a disappointing loss to Felix Trinidad last Sept. 18. Against Derrell Coley on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, De La Hoya was not any more aggressive than he had been in the past, but he did seek the knockout.

title: Metro Matters; Amid Outrage, Defending Police Work
description: THE voice on the phone message was polite, calm, reasoned. He did not give a name.

title: A Business Stunt Misses The Mark
description: Sun Microsystems' chairman, Scott McNealy, is well known for his merciless teasing of William H. Gates and Microsoft. (Mr. McNealy likes to point out, for instance, that while both he and Mr. Gates attended Harvard, only Mr. McNealy graduated.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANIS, MARGARET
description: CHANIS-Margaret. February 26, 2000. Beloved widow of the late Mark Chanis. Devoted mother of Ellen, Amy, Jonathan and Abigail. Loving grandmother to Daniel, Jessica, Matthew, Lauren, Rebecca and Samuel. Retired nurse midwife and former Director of the Teenage OBS Clinic at Kings County Hospital for 25 years. Most recently RSVP volunteer in local parenting program. Services were held at Beth Shalom Chapels, Inc., Smithtown, NY.

title: Serious About Research, Microsoft Makes Time for a Game
description: When Rick Rashid, Microsoft's vice president for research, utters, ''Set your phasers to stun,'' he isn't preparing to begin one of his company's famous take-no-prisoners assaults on some hapless competitor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORT, KENNETH
description: CORT-Kenneth. President of Centrex, Inc. On February 26, 2000. Of Glen Cove, NY. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Robert and Yvonne. Loving father-in-law to Margaret and Dennis. Dear brother of Annemarie Cohn. Cherished grandfather, uncle and cousin. Services today, 12 noon, at North Country Reform Temple, Crescent Beach Road and New Woods Road, Glen Cove, NY.

title: Forfeitures and Fairness
description: The civil forfeiture laws that allow the government to confiscate the property of narcotics dealers even in the absence of a criminal conviction have proved to be a valuable weapon against wealthy drug dealers, some of whom fear losing their money more than they fear prison. But the laws have also spawned a growing number of cases in which people guilty of no wrongdoing have had their assets seized -- giving rise to civil liberties concerns, as well as a promising reform movement in Congress.

title: The Nationalistic Euphoria Fades, And the Public Trust Goes With It
description: Two hundred days before much of the world turns its attention to Homebush Bay, the unlikely hub of the next Summer Olympics, there is only one building crane still in operation today on the vast site that was once a slaughterhouse and then a dumping ground for household and industrial waste in Sydney, Australia.

title: FALLING BACK: A special report.; Puerto Rican Presence Wanes in New York
description: A stretch of 116th Street in East Harlem -- increasingly marked by Mexican restaurants and Dominican bodegas -- nonetheless still bears the name ''Luis Munoz Marin Boulevard'' after the first native son governor of Puerto Rico. On the blocks around ''El Barrio,'' Puerto Rican music still wafts out of certain storefronts.

title: Net Draining Talent From Print Media
description: The Internet, a phenomenon that has filled the pages of newspapers and magazines since 1995, is now emptying a few of their newsroom cubicles.

title: Fatigue Syndrome Awaits a Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Board Begins To Advertise In Wide Search For Chancellor
description: The New York City Board of Education has formally begun its search for a new schools chancellor, advertising not only in education journals but in more than a dozen ethnic newspapers, from India Abroad to the Greek National Herald, and on a Web site called sixfigurejobs.com.

title: Engineers Reject Offer In Strike Against Boeing
description: After three fruitless days of discussions with a federal mediator, talks between the Boeing Company and its striking engineers and technical workers broke down on Saturday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIDDLETON, ESTELLE
description: MIDDLETON - Estelle (Stevie). Wife of the late Drew Middleton of The New York Times, on Friday February 25, at her home in Stamford, CT. She is survived by her daughter Judith of Mt. Kisco, NY; and her sister Annette Edwards of Weston, CT.

title: 2 Online Services Appoint Agencies
description: Two advertisers are naming agencies to handle accounts.

title: Equal Trivia Experts
description: To the Editor:

title: ICANN Launches Site for New Membership
description: February 28, 2000

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Mexico City Journal; Tough, Cheerful Mayor Wins Hearts
description: The first woman to become mayor of Mexico City, Rosario Robles Berlanga, liked what she heard from her police chief over her cellular phone. She snapped it shut and broke into one of her broad, beaming smiles.

title: AIRLINES CUT SEATS TO ADD TO PROFITS
description: Passengers who fly economy class may soon find the back of the plane a little more comfortable -- if they can find seats.

title: The Lessons of the Diallo Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Matches Bradley Efforts With Washington State Visit
description: Washington State, which will account for only 2.2 percent of delegates at the Democratic National Convention this year, has unexpectedly emerged as a battleground for the two men seeking the party's presidential nomination, and Al Gore spent much of the weekend here trying to make sure that Bill Bradley would have nothing to show for his effort to win the state's primary on Tuesday.

title: Kohl's Party, Wounded by Scandal, Falls in a State Election
description: Germany's Christian Democratic Union, punished for the financial scandal that has engulfed the party and its former chancellor, Helmut Kohl, crashed to a heavy defeat today by the governing Social Democrats in an election in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein.

title: A Correction; Census Letters Go to 120 Million Wrong Addresses
description: Just as it is about to begin, the 2000 Census has had a little glitch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEPPEL, CONSTANCE D.
description: KOEPPEL-Constance D. Beloved daughter of Elinor Koeppel and Bevin Koeppel, and dear sister of Gerard, sister-in-law of Diane, and aunt of Jackson, Harry, and Katherine, passed away February 26, 2000, after a long illness. Blood donations in Connie's memory would be appreciated.

title: Rabin Vowed To Pull Back From Golan, Barak Says
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel told his cabinet today that Yitzhak Rabin, the prime minister who was assassinated in 1995, had given guarantees that Israel would fully withdraw from the Golan Heights in exchange for security commitments by Syria.

title: Sharing a Nation's History and Culture, a Coin at a Time
description: THE golden coin's message is as revolutionary as this city gets these days: Put aside revered dead presidents and contemplate Sacagawea, the Shoshone woman who courageously guided Lewis and Clark in the 19th-century expedition that redefined America.

title: This Time, It's Woods Who Falters
description: It was the kind of beating that Tiger Woods has given to many others, but this time, he was on the receiving end.

title: Kamensky Can't Find His Place or His Goals
description: It isn't so much what Valery Kamensky says after games. It's his body language, during games that says it best. The shrugs. The frowns. The shaking of his head.

title: Super Tuesday Forces Adjustments
description: With limited resources and a staggering media challenge getting their message out in the 17 states that are holding primaries in the next nine days -- the four leading Republicans and Democrats in the race for president are engaged in a feverish hopscotch of the nation, targeting television markets in certain states, bypassing others and relying on the ''free media'' supplied by the press to make their cases to a larger extent than before.

title: Mixing Church and State
description: To the Editor:

title: With Aid, Restrained Police Defuse a Volatile Standoff
description: The most volatile moment at the demonstrations yesterday over the verdict in the Amadou Diallo case came minutes after 4 p.m., at the end of a rally that had been permitted by the police near the United Nations. As the rally turned into the weekend's second march to City Hall, about 150 protesters burst through the police lines at East 47th Street and blocked Second Avenue.

title: Prime Minister Of France Under Fire On 999th Day
description: Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France came close to celebrating a highly successful first 1,000 days in office today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: An Epic Effort Redeems a Weill Opera
description: For John Mauceri the path to Kurt Weill's ''Eternal Road,'' which he is conducting for six performances beginning tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has been long and winding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OROBELLO, NICK
description: OROBELLO-Nick. On February 24, at age 62. Beloved husband of Stella; loving father of Cristina and her husband Randy and Angela. Dear brother of Antonino. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday 1-8 PM. Memorial Mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89th Street, Monday, 10:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Friends of Photography/Ansell Adams Center, 415-495-7000 x303; or The Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian, 202-357-3164; or Futures for Children, 800-545-6843.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWITT, JOHN HAMILTON
description: HEWITT-John Hamilton, Jr. Died at home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Friday afternoon on February 25, 2000. He is survived by Vivian Davidson Hewitt, his wife of 50 years; his son, Dr. John Hamilton Hewitt III; daughter in-law, Marie Anne Mallonga Hewitt; granddaughters, Leigh Ann and Marivien of Hagerstown, MD; brother in-law Earl Davidson of Waldo, FL; and nieces, Joyce, Natalie and Elena of Fort Washington, MD. A memorial sevice will be held on Saturday, April 15, 2000, at 11:00 AM, at St. Philip's Church, 204 West 134th Street (Manhattan). In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Philip's Church would be appreciated.

title: Shaking Up a Harlem Museum; New Leaders Want New Definitions and Goals
description: The revitalization of 125th Street, one of Manhattan's premier commercial boulevards, is well under way. Shops are looking smart; Old Navy and Starbucks have arrived. And beyond commerce there are major changes at one of the street's cultural landmarks, the Studio Museum in Harlem.

title: Omnicom and Grey shore up fast-growing media businesses with reorganizations.
description: TWO giant agency companies -- the Omnicom Group and Grey Advertising Inc. -- are making changes in fields outside the realm of traditional advertising. The moves are indicative of the additional emphasis being placed on fast-growing services like media as well as the increasing importance of segments of the mass market like youngsters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSON, JACK M.
description: SELIGSON-Jack M. Age 86, longtime Harrison, NY, resident passed away in Boynton Beach, FL, on February 25, 2000. Survived by wife, Lillian, and two sons, Captain Harold E. Seligson, USN, Retired (wife Marilyn) in Virginia and Dr. Charles D. Seligson (wife Elizabeth) in New Jersey. He leaves seven grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.

title: A Hard-Tapping Tribute, Hobbyhorses Included
description: Bill Irwin, as urbane a clown as ever, did a Whoopi Goldberg, changing costumes between acts. While host of a program aptly titled ''The Elegance of Tap and the Comedy of Tap,'' he also pretended he could tap dance only with the aid of kneepads and a harness that kept him from toppling over the nonexistent footlights.

title: Life, Liberty and Excessive Force
description: The police killing of Amadou Diallo and the exoneration of the four officers who shot him have naturally set off heated debates on police procedures and race relations in our cities. But this tragedy has implications of a broader and more profound nature: when viewed in light of ongoing trends in our criminal justice system, it exposes deep-seated contradictions in our conception and practice of personal liberty.

title: Quiz Show Draws More Women Contestants
description: Still concerned that lack of diversity among the contestants is the one flaw in the otherwise idyllic success of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' Michael Davies, the show's executive producer, said he was gratified by the initial results of an on-air appeal for more women and minority viewers to enter the selection process.

title: How Ideas Can Be Seriously Infectious (Consider Paul Revere)
description: THE TIPPING POINT

title: Treasury Set to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a fifty-two week bill being auctioned tomorrow.

description: LACK-Herbert. 2/28/99. My life, my love, my everything, I miss you so. Your Miget

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HELENE
description: SCHWARTZ-Helene. The Board of Governors and we of North Shore Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed former member, Helene Schwartz. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Jerome H. Grossman, President Enid Rosenthal, Secretary

title: Mother to Be Charged In Stabbing Death of Baby
description: A 26-year-old Bronx woman was arrested yesterday in the fatal stabbing of her newborn son, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer malfunction, a passage was omitted in some copies yesterday from the front- page article about continuing violence in Kosovo. The affected section is reprinted here:

title: Taking stock of the differences between the consumer Internet market and its business-to-business cousin.
description: THE latest entrant in the Internet economy's continuing game of buzzword bingo is ''business to business,'' predictably shortened to ''B2B.''

title: A Superstar Evokes a Superpower; In Diva's Voice, Adoring Fans Hear Echoes of Soviet Days
description: Some 12,000 Russian-Americans went home to day to the Trump Taj Mahal.

title: Early Results in Senegal Indicate Tight Race
description: The results of this West African nation's presidential election began trickling in tonight a few hours after polling stations closed, showing a close race between the two men most favored to lead Senegal for the next seven years.

title: Booksellers Grab a Young Wizard's Cloaktails
description: The young and Harry-saturated arrived at Joseph-Beth Booksellers in Cincinnati in numbers that startled adults like a Hogwarts magic spell.

title: Culture Over Biology?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREAMER, THOMAS F.
description: CREAMER-Thomas F. Age 82, former resident Scarsdale, New York, died February 26th, Hilton Head, SC. Retired EVP of Citicorp, Vice-Chairman Economic Development Council, and Director of National Executive Service Corp. Class 1940 MIT. Former director of MIT Corp., US Life, Lord Abbet Managed Funds, St. Joseph Light & Power, Property Capital Trust. Trustee Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Governor White Plains Hospital. Memberships included: University Club, Pine Valley Golf Club, Scarsdale Golf Club, Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers, Mid-Ocean Club, US Seniors Association. Survived by his wife, Phoebe; five children: Elizabeth C. Vinton, Tom C. Creamer, George W. Creamer, Jane C. Plank, Deane C. Close; 16 grandchildren; one great grandson. Memorial service at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, in spring. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Scarsdale, New York, or White Plains Hospital, New York.

title: New Providence Journal; Bahamians Resent the Loss of Beaches to Luxury
description: The tourists who scuba dive among the reefs and tan themselves on the sandy shores have probably seen more of this island's coastline than Therell Bethell ever has. She cannot remember the last time she visited a decent stretch of beach, since the development boom over the last decade brought gated communities and exclusive resorts.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about free Internet service omitted an operating system that is compatible with the Freewwweb service. The service works with Macintosh as well as Windows computers.

title: Man Says Murder Suspects Discussed Dumping a Body
description: A man who said he was mistreated by the mother and son accused of killing an Upper East Side woman testified yesterday that the pair stopped on a New Jersey roadside on their way to New York and discussed disposing of a body.

title: People
description: Chris Traina was named to the vacant post of corporate communications manager at Saatchi & Saatchi, New York. He had held a similar post at Matthew Bender & Co., New York, part of Reed Elsevier.

title: Workers Are Trapped In Limbo By I.N.S.
description: Like thousands of other professionals, Nick Saw came to this country to apply his skills in the booming high-technology industry, working under a temporary visa. And like many temporary workers, Mr. Saw wants to stay.

title: Amateur Athletes Turn to Pro Trainers
description: Ed Sher, a 38-year-old St. Louis lawyer, is nothing if not goal-oriented. A bit of a tennis fanatic, he has his sights set on winning the Meadowbrook Country Club Tennis Championship in August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROUWER, HENRI
description: KROUWER-Henri. Of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Died peacefully on Feb. 10, 2000. Dearly beloved husband of Nadia. Devoted and loving father of Tom, Peter, & Jan. Proud grandfather of Jennifer, Margot and David. Loving and beloved husband of the late Margot Krouwer. Born in Holland Sept. 5, 1907. Colonial in the Dutch Army. Studied in Switzerland and France; 10 years in Indonesia with the company Europa-Azia, founded by his father Abraham Krouwer. Emigrated 1940 to U.S.A., first working for the Netherlands Purchase Commission, then Founder and President of Kroulee Corporation. Henri loved life, travel, the arts, poetry, music and had great respect for the sciences. He was a devoted family man, caring, compassionate, charitable, open-minded, gracious host and great cook. His sense of humor was inevitably contagious. Henri, you touched our lives deeply and you will always be in our hearts. Memorial service March 4, 4 PM, Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave, White Plains, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, N.Y. 10601.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, FREDERICK THEODORE ''TED''
description: STEINBERG-Frederick Theodore ''Ted'' February 27, 2000, of Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of Scarsdale and Chappaqua, N.Y. He was a visionary in the formation of the shopping center industry as it is today. He started the first shopping center on Central Ave. in Scarsdale. He and his brothers were instrumental in the development of the ICSC. He was a WWII US Army Veteran. He attained the rank of First Lieutenant and served in the European theatre. Husband of Ethel, father of Lyle, Spencer and the late Glenn Steinberg. Stepfather of Leslie Platto, and Marc and Bruce Stoller. Grandfather of Rachelle, Jared, Jamie, Carey, Jodi, Terry, Jason, Corey, Andrew and Erick. Funeral service at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester in Rye, N.Y. on Tuesday at 2pm. Interment Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Hospice By The Sea, Inc., 1531 W. Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, Fla., 33486 or the American Cancer Society.

title: When Genes Are Decoded, Who Should See the Results?; Many 'greatly overestimate the risk'
description: President Clinton issued an order this month prohibiting federal agencies from using genetic information in any decision to hire, promote or dismiss workers. The order protects 2.8 million federal employees, and Mr. Clinton said Congress should pass legislation to prevent private employers from discriminating against workers on the same basis. Such legislation has been introduced by Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, and Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIG, FREDERICK J.
description: WILLIG-Frederick J., on February 27, 2000. (Ret. Capt. U.S. Navy.) Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Jean, Barbara, Tim and Stephen. Dear brother of Warren, John and Edwina. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Visiting Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, McLaughlin Funeral Home, 3 Ave. at 97th St., Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, 9:30 AM, St. Patrick's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, DOROTHY (NEE GREENBERG)
description: MOSES-Dorothy (nee Greenberg). 87, beloved wife of George, most devoted mother and motherin-law of Dr. Percy and Jacqueline Moses and Evelyn Kunstler, dearly beloved grandmother of Ylan and Gregory Kunstler, Nicole and Steven Moses. Services Tuesday, February 29 10 AM at Schwartz Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd and 76 Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Settlement Reached in Canadian Web Case
description: Settlement Reached in Canadian Web Case

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, RICHARD
description: ROSENBAUM-Richard. Beloved husband of Dr. Diana Richardson. Dear, dear son of Herbert and Florence. Adored brother of Barbara and Jim Carey. Loving uncle of Jason and Rita Carey. Richard died on February 28 of cancer, not polio. He was an extraordinary person.

title: STRONG GROWTH AT TERRA
description: Europe's biggest traded Internet company, Terra Networks S.A. of Spain, said its users had increased fivefold and its revenue had grown a better-than-expected 50 percent in 1999, as it added clients in the fast-growing Latin America market. The results are the first reported by the unprofitable Internet service provider, whose public share sale gave it a market value of 37 billion euros ($36 billion), topping Amazon.com Inc. Revenue rose to 78.5 million euros.

title: A Composer's Diary, Turned Page by Page
description: The Emerson String Quartet played the last 3 of Shostakovich's 15 quartets at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. It was the fifth of five extraordinary concerts covering this repertory. The house was packed, the audience more than enthusiastic.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE WEST

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, SAMUEL S.
description: SCHREIBER-Samuel S. The Board of Directors and the staff of Makor: The Partnership for Jewish Life mourn the death of Samuel S. Schreiber, father and father-in-law of our Board members, James and Wendy Schreiber. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. Michael H. Steinhardt, Chairman Jonathan J. Greenberg, Treasurer Rabbi David Gedzelman, Director Donna Lieberman, Director

title: Black Women and Cancer
description: Often, when a patient raises breast cancer treatment options with a physician (''Breast Cancer in Blacks''), she gets the answer that some of these tests, drugs and procedures are expensive, and/or insurance companies will not cover them because they are not currently recognized as ''standard of care.''

title: The Candidates' Homework on Schools
description: In Gov. George W. Bush's model schoolhouse, every student would have to sit for an annual state test, and those students whose schools consistently failed to make the grade would be given a government check that they could use to attend a parochial or other private school.

title: Surface or Air? The Great Debate Continues
description: When the debate over global warming burst into prominence more than a decade ago, scientists based their assessment that the earth's temperature was rising on a single set of observations, those at the planet's surface. Dr. John R. Christy and Dr. Roy W. Spencer were troubled by that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, JOSEPH
description: DONAHUE-Joseph. Age 87. The Transport Workers Union of America mourns the death of retired International Vice President, Joseph Donahue, a true stalwart of the American labor movement. Viewing February 29, March 1, 48pm at the Hodder Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue, Yonkers. Funeral mass Thursday, March 2, 9:45AM, St. Ryamond's Church, Tremont and Castle Hill Avenues, Bronx. Sonny Hall, International Pres. Frank McCann, Exec. Vice Pres. John Kerrigan, Secy Treasurer

title: Museum Sues to Keep Meteorite Sought by Indian Group
description: The American Museum of Natural History asked a federal court in Manhattan yesterday to declare the museum the rightful owner of one of its oldest and most treasured exhibits, the 15-ton Willamette Meteorite, which an Indian group in Oregon is claiming as a sacred tribal object.

title: Tijuana Governor Says Slaying Shows Drug Traffickers' Power
description: A day after gunmen killed the police chief in Tijuana, the sprawling city that borders California, the state governor said drug traffickers were out of control there partly because many federal authorities were in their pay.

title: St. John's Responds Orders by Postell
description: St. John's leap back into national basketball consciousness had nothing to do with a National Collegiate Athletic Association's inquiry. It began, instead, at a team meeting a few days before investigators showed up on the Queens campus.

title: Closing Arguments Heard in Case of Three Officers Accused of Cover-Up in Louima Torture
description: The three police officers accused of covering up the assault on Abner Louima perfected a tapestry of lies about the attack in a collusive web of telephone calls each time a new development in the case arose, a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Quentin Crisp Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to Quentin Crisp, the writer, actor and raconteur, will be held on Friday night at 7 at Cooper Union, Seventh Street at Third Avenue, East Village. Mr. Crisp, author of ''The Naked Civil Servant,'' died in November at 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, ANNA
description: SAMUELS-Anna. On February 27, 2000. Beloved mother to Roberta Litsky, Marilyn Mazur, and Elaine Cohen. Grandmother to Michael and Karen Litsky, Matthew, Zachary and Alexandra Mazur. Services today 12:30 at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, JOSEPH
description: BERGER-Joseph. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Joseph Berger, father of Carol Goldsmith, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Winless In Seattle
description: It would be nice if Bill Bradley could win the Washington primary today. He deserves one really good night from this campaign. Even Steve Forbes had his presidential moment, for heaven's sake, when he came in first in the Arizona primary four years ago. (The Forbes campaign tended to describe that victory, which involved 34 percent of the vote, in terms normally reserved for the winning of World War II, or at least the invention of penicillin.)

title: McCain Eases The Stigma Of Vietnam
description: LET'S not go overboard on this one. It isn't as if the entire generation of Vietnam War veterans parades around now in faded Army fatigues, buttonholing everyone in sight and nattering on about those scary marches through the rice paddies and elephant grass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCPARTLAND, MARGARET M.
description: McPARTLAND-Margaret M. on February 27, 2000 of Hampton Bays, L.I. Formerly of the Bronx, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Prayful aunt and protector of the 8 orphaned Daly children and their families. Loving sister of Sarah O'Leary. Cherished guardian to Liz Daly Byrne and Neil Daly. For information O'Shea Funeral Home, 94 E. Montauk Hwy., Hampton Bays, L.I. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 9:30 AM at St. Rosalie's R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y. Family will receive friends Tuesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at the funeral home.

title: Getting To the Core Of Mistakes In Medicine
description: Doctors have amputated the wrong leg, killed patients with overdoses of medications and committed other serious errors for centuries. So why only now is a United States president calling for the first national plan to reduce such errors?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OAKLEY, WALTER THURSTON
description: OAKLEY-Walter Thurston, 86, on February 25, 2000, in Manhasset, NY. Survived by his wife, Helen; two daughters, Valerie Oakley and Deborah Bodner, and four grandchildren. Donations to the Shepherdstown Public Library, P.O. Box 278, Shepherdstown, WV 25443. Funeral service 10 AM, Wednesday, Christ Episcopal Church, Manhasset, with interment to follow at Flushing Cemetery, Flushing.

title: Linking Allergy, Asthma and Infant Diets
description: Allergies and asthma in children are on the rise in industrialized countries and medical scientists are searching for ways to stem this mysterious trend.

title: Gore's Intervention Restores Care for Ill Baby
description: In all the hyperbole of political campaigns, it is rare that a candidate gets quick, tangible results, but Vice President Al Gore seems to have done it, persuading the nation's biggest health insurance company to show more generosity to one of its subscribers.

title: NiSource in $6 Billion Deal To Acquire Columbia Energy
description: NiSource, the owner of Indiana's largest utility, agreed today to buy the Columbia Energy Group for $6 billion, ending a pursuit that began with a hostile bid nine months ago.

title: Diverse Selections, Consistent Energy
description: Staunch advocates of thematic programming would have found the New York Chamber Symphony's Saturday evening program at Alice Tully Hall distressingly motley, but listeners who like variety could not have asked for more. On the first half of the program, Andrej Panufnik's solemn ''Autumn Music'' was countered with a burst of 19th-century virtuosic exuberance, the Bruch Violin Concerto in G minor. After intermission ''The Lost Lover,'' a highly charged setting of a section of ''Song of Songs'' by Deborah Drattell was followed by the innocent folkishness of Kodaly's ''Dances from Galanta.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, BRENDA L.
description: ROBINSON-Brenda L. On February 26, 2000. Loving mother of Christopher; beloved daughter of Marion Chambers; loving great niece of Dorothy White. Viewing Thursday, March 2, 3-7, Granby's Funeral Service, 4021 White Plains Road, Bronx NY. Burial on Friday, March 3 at Fairlawn Cemetery, NJ departing from Granby's at 9AM.

title: CANADIAN TAX CUT
description: Under increasing pressure by Canadians weary of paying high taxes, Canada's Liberal government cut federal taxes for the first time in 12 years in its budget for the fiscal year that begins in April. In the next five years, tax payments are expected to drop by 58 billion Canadian dollars, or about $40 billion, mostly because of an 18 percent reduction planned for low- and middle-income earners. In July, tax rates for nine million middle-income Canadians would be trimmed to 24 percent from 26 percent. The level at which capital gains are taxed would be lowered to 65 percent from 75 percent. Corporate taxes would be cut by 4 billion Canadian dollars. Timothy Pritchard

title: BASEBALL: Strawberry Suspended for One Year; Selig Takes a Firm Stand, Leaving Slugger's Career in Doubt
description: Darryl Strawberry was suspended for one year today by Commissioner Bud Selig, a ruling that could signal the end of Strawberry's calamitous career.

title: Review/Fashion; A Web-Savvy Versace, A Knowing Lagerfeld
description: Donatella Versace, who still has people chuckling over the on-the-air call she made to a local radio station to complain that its impersonator didn't sound a bit like her, gave the world-weary fashion crowd something new to talk about on Friday night. At the conclusion of her racy show, Ms. Versace came out in a see-through pants ensemble that, top to bottom, left little doubt about where the sun shines.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Issues Regulations To Control Tax Shelters

title: AOL, Microsoft, BellSouth Announce Wireless Deals
description: February 28, 2000

title: Emotional Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: PROFIT RISES AT HSBC
description: Europe's largest bank, HSBC Holdings P.L.C., said pretax profit rose 21 percent, to $7.98 billion in 1999, from $6.57 billion the year before. The bank's earnings, which exceeded analysts' expectations, were higher in part because its business in Asia rebounded after being hurt by the region's poor economic conditions in 1998. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Executives Form E-Commerce Agency
description: Two senior executives formerly at the Wilton, Conn., office of Brann Worldwide have joined with Source Marketing in Westport, Conn., to form an agency dedicated to encouraging loyalty among customers of e-commerce brands. The agency, called eSource, will be based in Westport, with seven employees working on projects for two online marketers, WingspanBank.com and Onvia.com; billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: U.S. Takes Aim At Tax Shelters For Companies
description: The government issued new rules today to discourage abusive corporate tax shelters. Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said the proliferation of such shelters ''may be the most serious compliance issue threatening the American tax system today.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, ELI ELIYOHU BEN DOVID
description: ROSENBLATT-Eli Eliyohu ben Dovid. Deceased February 19, 2000, 13 Adar 5760, in Delray Beach, FL. Caring father of Etta, Helen and Ruth, grandfather of Jason and Scott, and father-in-law of John. We will miss you.

title: ISRAEL TRADE DEAL
description: President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico will sign a free-trade pact next week in Israel, making Israel the first country to conclude free-trade agreements with all three nations in the North America Free Trade Agreement. The Israel-Mexico pact will eliminate tariffs on most goods by 2005 and help Israeli companies compete against United States and Canadian companies in Mexico, the ministry said. Israel was the first country granted duty-free access to the American market and later signed a free trade deal with Canada.

title: Campaigns and Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Mark Twain and His Angel In a Modern Incarnation
description: Sometimes clever theatrical artists can become much too ingenious. For instance, take the very clever members of the Big Dance Theater who created ''Another Telepathic Thing,'' presented on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, BEN
description: ROSEN-Ben. On February 27, 2000. Beloved husband of Selma, loving father of Edward and Michael. Cherished grandfather to Jared, Eric, Lisa and Jessica. Dear brother of Esther Kaplan and Evelyn Kahn. Services Tuesday 12pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: McCAIN DENOUNCES POLITICAL TACTICS OF CHRISTIAN RIGHT
description: Taking his presidential campaign to a stronghold of Christian conservatism, Senator John McCain of Arizona delivered a harsh attack today on the ''self-appointed leaders'' of the religious right, depicting them as intolerant empire builders who ''have turned good causes into businesses'' while trying to exclude all but ''card-carrying Republicans'' from the party.

title: John N. Irwin II, 86, Diplomat And Ex-Aide to MacArthur
description: John Nichol Irwin II, a Manhattan lawyer and diplomat who served under General Douglas MacArthur during World War II and later became ambassador to France, died yesterday at a hospital in New Haven, Conn. He was 86.

title: Gangsta Rap's Choices in Life, Death and Love
description: Crack use has stayed constant over the last decade, government statistics say. So has the gangsta rap that presents the drug trade as a ghetto survival strategy, a source for true-crime stories and a metaphoric template for the rap business.

title: Council Committee Backs Voter Registration Bill
description: Nearly 20 city agencies and the city's community boards would be required to offer voter registration forms under a bill endorsed by a City Council committee yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBLATT, ROSLYN
description: WEINBLATT-Roslyn. We join our dear friend Susan Weinblatt in mourning the death of her loving mother, Roslyn and send our sincere condolences to the entire Weinblatt family. Congregation B'Nai Olam Fire Island Pines

title: Lockstep to Putin's New Military Order
description: In the nearly two months since Vladimir V. Putin became acting president of Russia, the world has barely begun getting to know him. But already, he is building a clear record in one area of policy: little noticed by the West, Mr. Putin, a former lieutenant colonel in the K.G.B., is rapidly remilitarizing Russian society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, JACK
description: DEUTSCH-Jack. Died February 15 in Goshen, NY, at age 91. He is survived by one son, Stephen Deutsch; two grandsons, David and Gregory Deutsch; one sister, Tina Senft, and several nieces and nephews. Cremation took place. Burial will be private.

title: AMKOR AGREES TO BUY THREE PLANTS IN SOUTH KOREA
description: The Amkor Corporation, the world's largest provider of semiconductor testing and packaging services, agreed yesterday to acquire three semiconductor assembly factories in South Korea from Anam Semiconductor Inc. for $1.4 billion in cash and stock. The plants, which are around Seoul, have about 6,600 employees. Amkor has more than 10,000 employees worldwide. The purchase will give Amkor seven semiconductor testing and packaging plants. The company, based in West Chester, Pa., said the plants packaged 4.1 billion integrated circuit semiconductors in 1999, about 6 percent of the world's consumption of chips for the year. Anam's sole remaining principal asset is a semiconductor wafer foundry in South Korea.

title: Israelis Ask if Their Exchange Is an Endangered Species
description: When the chairman of the Nasdaq stock market visited Israel recently, he was not a traveling salesman drumming up business. He was more like a potentate inspecting the outer realms of a fast-expanding empire.

title: Court Is Told Subway Killer, Off Medication, Hit a Social Worker
description: Andrew Goldstein, the schizophrenic man who pushed a woman to her death in front of a subway train, has twice punched a court social worker since he stopped taking his anti-psychotic medication, court officials and lawyers disclosed yesterday.

title: Like Life, but More Interesting
description: Over the course of the last week, we've heard a lot of outraged observations by critics of ''reality-based'' television. The phenomenon was alleged to have reached its nadir with the on-air selection of a wife and the subsequent marriage (soon to be annulled) of Rick Rockwell to Darva Conger on Fox Television's ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?'' Feminists, intellectuals, ''family values'' fundamentalists and students of American culture have expressed shock and disgust at what television is coming to.

title: Radioactivity in Two Students' Apartment Baffles Columbia
description: It is a puzzle baffling enough to furrow the brow of scholarly types, and serious enough to raise concerns of city and federal officials about a security lapse at biological research laboratories using nuclear materials.

title: SONIC FOUNDRY IN DEAL FOR STV COMMUNICATIONS
description: Sonic Foundry Inc., an Internet software maker, plans to buy the closely held STV Communications Inc. for $66 million in stock to add Web broadcasting and other services to its media software products. Sonic Foundry, based in Madison, Wis., will issue about 1.07 million shares to acquire STV, which has 80 employees. STV, based in Santa Monica, Calif., is a provider of Web broadcasting and hosting services that help deliver music, movies, television, radio and other media to the Internet. Sonic Foundry makes software that helps convert media to formats usable on the Internet. Sonic Foundry's shares rose $1, to $62.75, in American Stock Exchange trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSH, MICHAEL
description: MARSH-Michael. Cherished son of Roberta and Daniel Marsh. Dear father of Jonathan and Jaclyn Marsh. Devoted brother of Helene Kimber and Joyce Kroft and beloved fiance of Susan Gilbert. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: College Admissions: Hard Choices?
description: To the Editor:

title: When Genes Are Decoded, Who Should See the Results?; 'Every one of us is at risk'
description: President Clinton issued an order this month prohibiting federal agencies from using genetic information in any decision to hire, promote or dismiss workers. The order protects 2.8 million federal employees, and Mr. Clinton said Congress should pass legislation to prevent private employers from discriminating against workers on the same basis. Such legislation has been introduced by Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, and Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York.

title: Love as a Distraction That Gets in the Way of Art
description: IN AMERICA

title: Reed Announces Plans to Step Down as Co-Chief of Citigroup
description: John S. Reed, co-chief executive of the financial services giant Citigroup, said yesterday that he planned to retire on April 18 after the company's annual meeting.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro sank against the dollar as investors continued to sell the currency on expectations that the European Central Bank would not raise rates soon. In New York, the euro fell to 97.19 cents from 97.42 on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, FLORENCE (NEE TALBERTH)
description: SIEGEL-Florence (nee Talberth). Died peacefully in her 99th year on February 27, 2000 in Hollywood, FL. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Devoted mother of Barbara and Martin Somach and Howard and Elaine Siegel. Loving grandmother of Brian (Joy), Cara (Robert), Blaine, and Richard (Jennifer). Cherished great grandmother of Samantha, Zachary and Joshua. A dedicated lifetime member of Hadassah. Services Wednesday, 10:00 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: MALAYSIAN FREEZE TO END
description: Stock exchanges in Singapore and Malaysia reached an agreement to end a freeze of nearly 18 months on trading of more than $4 billion in Malaysian shares held by investors in Singapore. The exchanges said the 172,000 owners of the shares, whose trade was outlawed when Malaysia imposed currency controls in September 1998, would be able to choose between two plans for releasing their shares onto the Malaysian market for a fee. If investors accept the solution, it will remove a diplomatic sticking point that had hurt Malaysia's reputation among foreign investors and led Singapore to threaten legal action.

title: Bradley's Supporters Baffled in New York
description: With the New York primary just one week away, many top supporters of former Senator Bill Bradley in the state have become bewildered by his strategic decisions and pessimistic about his chances in a state that had once been seen as the vanguard of his presidential hopes.

title: Haider Gives Up His Party Post, but Not Austrian Politics
description: Bowing to international pressure, Jorg Haider resigned today as leader of the anti-immigrant Freedom Party that he has taken from a marginal fringe group to a powerful national force in Austria during the last 14 years.

title: A Support System For the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Sticks to the Middle to Blunt McCain's Attacks
description: Continuing a prolonged zag to the political middle, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas campaigned furiously in Washington State today and reached out to moderate voters by focusing on issues like education and tax cuts.

title: Internet Strains the Ties of Record Companies and Stores
description: The advent of e-commerce and the prospect that consumers will buy music by downloading it directly from the Internet has strained the traditionally congenial relations between record labels and record stores and set off a power struggle between them.

title: Ford's campaign for its Focus car will be remade into a hybrid of television and online media.
description: FORD is overhauling a highly visible element of a big campaign for an important new car line as the company seeks to become part of a hot trend: transforming television advertising into a hybrid of the TV and online media that could be called dot-commercials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, RONALD
description: ROSEMAN-Ronald. The members of the American Composers Alliance mourn the passing of longtime member and friend, Ronald Roseman. Richard Brooks, President

title: Wall St. Helps Wrap Up Neediest Cases Season
description: ''Many of us on Wall Street are doing well,'' wrote Andrew D'Ambruoso of Deer Park, N.Y., a donor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Battle Over I.M.F.
description: President Clinton has vowed to block the man Europe wants to head the International Monetary Fund, a German finance ministry official, setting off a contest for control of the institution. But the United States is not yet backing an alternate candidate who is an American.

title: Heat Leaves Knicks Looking for Clues
description: It was late in the Knicks' blissful first quarter, when they were making off with the milk money of the Heat, a team turned weakling without Alonzo Mourning, and a loose ball trickled toward the sideline.

title: One Party Quite Divisible
description: Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain are seeking the support of what amounts to two separate and quite different Republican parties.

title: BROADCOM IN ACCORD TO ACQUIRE DIGITAL FURNACE
description: The Broadcom Corporation, based in Irvine, Calif., a maker of computer chips that make it easier to send video, data and voice content over the Internet, has agreed to buy Digital Furnace of Atlanta for $136 million in stock. The acquisition will help Broadcom to deliver more information faster over cable lines, said Henry T. Nicholas III, Broadcom's chief executive. Digital will be integrated into Broadcom's cable business unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLO, SUZANNE
description: GALLO-Suzanne. Merce Cunningham and the dancers, faculty, staff, and board of directors of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and Cunningham Dance Foundation mourn the passing of our beloved costume designer and wardrobe supervisor, Suzanne Gallo, whose brilliant and innovative designs enriched many of Merce Cunningham's works. We will miss her unfailingly cheerful presence and extend our deepest sympathy to the members of her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEPPS, EDNA
description: SCHEPPS-Edna. On February 28, 2000, cherished wife of the late Nathaniel Schepps, beloved mother of Jill and Jack Butterly, and John and Janice Schepps, devoted grandmother to Kelly Tedesco and Adam Schepps, adoring great grandmother to Casey & Emily Tedesco. Edna is survived by her sister, Doris Schmidt, dear cousins, Ruth Sherman & Natalie and Steve Gross. Forever young and beautiful, we say goodbye for now to our precious ''Eddy Spaghetti.'' We'll see you in our dreams.

title: College Admissions: Hard Choices?
description: To the Editor:

title: Undue Optimism When Death Is Near
description: Sometimes, it just doesn't pay to be optimistic, or, at least, overly so.

title: Bradley Presses a 'Reform-Plus' Image
description: At a rally at the University of Washington that drew more than 2,000 students despite a cold drizzle, Bill Bradley sounded the populist tone marking his recent events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELSEL, EDITH
description: HELSEL-Edith of Boca Raton formerly of Cliffside, NJ and Jericho, NY. Passed away Feb. 27, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Murray Helsel and the late Jacob Moss. Mother of Judy (Jeff) Morton and Richard (Jill Kaplan) Moss. Stepmother of Judy (Jeff) Posner, grandmother of Jonathan (Karen) Morton, Amy (Dan) Hodges, Eric (Amy) Posner, Michael Morton, Jacob Moss and Zachary Moss. Great grandmother of Matthew Hodges and Rachel Morton. Service Graveside 3:00 PM Tuesday, February 29, 2000, New Montefiore Cemetery, Wellwood, New York. For further information RiversideGordon Delray Beach, Florida, 800-844-0979.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My Dad died recently. He was proud of what I did overseas, but that was nothing like what he felt about what I've done here. He clipped all the stories.''

title: Fighting Cyber Crime Starts With Industry, Official Says
description: Fighting Cyber Crime Starts With Industry, Official Says

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETONIAK, STEVEN G.
description: PETONIAK-Steven G. Died February 24, 2000 of complications from AIDS. Age 46. A direct marketing executive for CBS, Ogilvy and Mather, and Time-Warner, Inc, he was the founder of Lesbians and Gay Men at Time, one of the first corporate gay and lesbian employee groups. He was a driving force behind two highly successful art auctions to benefit ACT UP, the AIDS activist organization, as well as the Out Auction to benefit the Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Community Center. He is survived by his mother, Stephanie, of Cedar Knolls, N.J. and two brothers, Peter, of Green Bay, Wisconsin, and Edward, of New York City. He will be sorely missed by his family and numerous friends. A memorial mass will be held on Saturday, March 4, at 1 PM, at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47 Street, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERN, PAUL
description: ALPERN-Paul Age 90, beloved husband of Trudy Alpern. Devoted father, grandfather and great grandfather. Died peacefully on Sunday, February 27, 2000. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, N.Y. at 12:30pm on Wednesday, March 1st. Shiva at Mrs. Alpern's apartment 1207 E. Broadway, Apt. 15E, Hewlett, N.Y.

title: PBS Network Hires Publicis Unit
description: The Public Broadcasting Service in Alexandria, Va., has named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, part of Publicis S.A., to handle duties that include the creation of campaigns to promote the PBS brand and programs as well as planning and buying in paid media outside the network's own air time. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Accounts
description: HealthCentral.com, Emeryville, Calif., a health content and e-commerce Web site, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Mulling Messier (?), Devils Go on Road
description: The time to fine-tune for the playoffs is beginning to grow short for the first-place Devils. They begin a seven-game trip tonight in Nashville and will not return to the Meadowlands until March 15, a day after the National Hockey League's trade deadline passes.

title: Internet Spurs Huge Job Growth in the New York Area
description: Internet-related jobs in the New York area are growing at an explosive rate, to 250,000 now from 106,000 in 1997, and are responsible for an $8.3 billion payroll that has tripled during that period, according to an industry-sponsored survey released yesterday.

title: Demonstrators Turn Focus On Training Of the Police
description: On the fourth day of protests over the acquittal of four police officers in the death of Amadou Diallo, about 100 demonstrators converged on the New York City police academy yesterday afternoon before embarking on a peaceful if impromptu progression through lower Manhattan.

title: The Faith of Simon Estes And the Soul of Dr. King
description: In his prime, the American bass-baritone Simon Estes had a faultless voice: impressively resonant, well supported and even throughout its registers. It was an ideal sound for the weightier bass-baritone roles, like Verdi's King Philip and Wagner's Amfortas and Wotan. He made history in 1978 by becoming the first African-American man to sing a major role at the Bayreuth Festival, the Dutchman in Wagner's ''Fliegende Hollander,'' which remained a signature role for him.

title: Authority Agrees to Delay Sale Of Two Nuclear Power Plants
description: The New York Power Authority agreed today to delay the planned sale of two nuclear power plants to a New Orleans company after lawmakers asked the authority to explore a higher, last-minute bid from another company.

title: U.S. Stiffens Its Opposition To European I.M.F. Choice
description: President Clinton has vowed to block the man Europe wants to head the International Monetary Fund, setting off a possibly protracted contest for control of the financial institution and most likely casting the United States in the role of kingmaker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSHNICK, LAUREN BETH
description: SOSHNICK-Lauren Beth. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: Sports of The Times; One Issue Is Settled; Others Await
description: AS a caring American and concerned parent, I was relieved to know that Major League Baseball was right on top of the scourge that is Darryl Strawberry's sickness or stupidity, depending on one's chosen level of compassion, or understanding.

title: Couple With Computer Riches Give M.I.T. a Record $350 Million for Study of the Brain
description: A computer publishing billionaire and his wife pledged today to give the Massachusetts Institute of Technology the largest single donation yet to a university -- $350 million over the next 20 years -- to finance research on the brain.

title: A Jewish Enclave Reclaims Its Children; Cultural Ties and Low Costs Lure Orthodox Couples to Lower East Side
description: It was a homecoming no one in their families could have predicted, to the Lower East Side neighborhood their parents' generation could not wait to leave.

description: When it comes to business, John Grisham provides no suspense. Each February he turns out a novel with a first printing of 2.8 million copies. Instantly it becomes the nation's No. 1 best seller; movies, paperbacks, and foreign editions follow apace.

title: Jacobs Seeks Record In the Indoor 1,500
description: For those who may wonder where the next generation of great American middle-distance runners is, Regina Jacobs, the top female miler in the United States, pointed to tonight at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Democratic contest for United States Senate from New Jersey misstated former Gov. Jim Florio's approval rating in a survey released last week. The 39 percent figure was his favorable rating among registered Democrats, according to the Quinnipiac College Poll -- not his unfavorable one, which was 17 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Henry Jernigan Tobler, a gallery director, art collector and writer, misstated his age and the year his leukemia was diagnosed. He was 33, not 34; he became ill in 1994, not 1993.

title: Internet Recharges Reformers In Korea
description: With his one-day beard and tousled hair, Park Byung Ok retains a hint of the look of the student protesters who lobbed rocks and gasoline bombs at the police, who replied with tear gas and rubber bullets, in the often turbulent 1980's here.

title: Islanders Don't Have An Answer For Caps
description: If tonight's game was something of a test for the Islanders, then it came in their worst subject -- the Washington Capitals, whom they had not beaten at home since 1996.

description: To the Editor:

title: Eyes On the Prize
description: So China is now telling Taiwan: Marry me or I'll kill you. And Vice President Al Gore is now telling the unions: Vote for me and I'll get you a better deal with China next time, even though my own administration negotiated this deal. And together they are making a God-awful mess of what is a fundamental U.S. interest -- that Congress ratify China's entry into the World Trade Organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LI, ZEN ZUH
description: LI-Zen Zuh, on February 26th, 2000, age 100. Beloved husband of the late Fong Soong-jen Li and father of Ellen, Yijun, Yisheng, Yunzhu, Lillian, and the late Pearl and Richard. Also survived by ten grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Family service in Media, PA. Funeral and interment Chapel-Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, Wednesday, March 1, 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in the name of Zen Zuh Li to U.S. Fund for UNICEF.

title: The Message of the Diallo Protests
description: The thousands of marchers who filled New York City streets last weekend were shocked and pained by the verdict acquitting four police officers in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo. They were understandably outraged that an innocent man had been shot down in his own doorway by officers who thought he was acting suspiciously. But even for those who accept the jury's verdict as legally sound, the marches sent a powerful message that many New Yorkers, especially in minority communities, think the police are a threat to their lives and safety. Indeed, it is hard to believe that a white resident, standing in his own vestibule, would have been gunned down under similar circumstances by the four white officers. The Diallo case, and the restrained weekend protests it inspired, are an urgent call for police reforms designed to minimize the likelihood of another such tragedy.

title: Supporters Fear Bradley May Miss His New York Chance
description: With the New York primary just one week away, many of Bill Bradley's top supporters have become bewildered by his strategic decisions and pessimistic about his chances in a state that had once been seen as the vanguard of his presidential hopes. Mr. Bradley's decision to spend six consecutive days in Washington State is increasingly being viewed as an emblem of a campaign that has lost its way.

title: McCain Putting Bush-Leaning California in Rearview Mirror
description: To Californians, it was all a little baffling. Why would Senator John McCain pull out of the only Republican debate scheduled in the nation's most-populous state the week before the highest-stakes primary on the calendar?

title: Dow Surges Above 10,000 Again on a Blue-Chip Rally
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rebounded above 10,000 yesterday as investors, at least temporarily, moved back into blue-chip stocks, which have been battered in recent weeks.

title: McEnroe Gets Commitment From Sampras
description: John McEnroe yesterday named his dream pairing, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi, to the Davis Cup team that will face the Czech Republic in the quarterfinals in April.

title: A Tight Race in New York
description: The battle for the Republican presidential nomination remains tight in New York State and most voters might still change their minds, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Mr. McCain's Challenge
description: After weeks of debate over the role of religion in American politics, Senator John McCain issued a courageous challenge yesterday to both his opponent and his party to end their entangling alliances with ''self-appointed leaders'' of the religious right like Pat Robertson and Jerry Falwell. The challenge, issued in Virginia, followed by one day George W. Bush's attempt to defuse the controversy over his visit to Bob Jones University in South Carolina with a regretful letter to Cardinal John O'Connor of New York. Yesterday, however, Mr. McCain rolled right past the Bush apology, hardly acknowledging its existence while pounding his rival as a ''Pat Robertson Republican'' and asserting that the time had come to free the Republican Party from two decades of subservience to the ''union bosses'' of the religious right.

title: Executive Says Philip Morris Is Open to Some Regulation
description: A top executive of the Philip Morris Companies, the nation's largest cigarette maker, said yesterday that it would no longer oppose some government regulation of the tobacco industry.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Can Cybershop Explain This To Investors?
description: In searching for winners in the electronic retailing business, profits are hard to find. So investors have focused on revenue, figuring that rising sales are a sign of success.

title: High Infant Mortality Rates In Brooklyn Mystify Experts
description: In central Brooklyn -- where storefronts are boarded, housing projects stand in defiant opposition to the boom times, and the hospitals are more or less broke -- babies are dying at rates that the city as a whole has not seen in nearly two decades. And they die, in some cases, at a rate double what the federal government has set as the infant mortality goal for the nation.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: BILL BRADLEY: San Francisco and Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, HERBERT M., DDS.
description: PARKER-Herbert M., DDS. Died on February 19; he was 87. He practiced dentistry in NYC, and taught at NYU Dental School until 1992. He published articles in prosthodontics and was elected a fellow to a number of dental societies. He was married to Dorothy R. Parker for over 50 years. They lived in Scarsdale for more than 35 years where they were involved in local activities. He is survived by a daughter, Elissa, and a son, Cary. He is missed by colleagues, friends, and family.
