title: The Nets Play Tough But It's Not Enough
description: Two hours after showering the Nets' Keith Van Horn with a thunderous standing ovation during the pregame introductions tonight, the fans of the Utah Jazz were booing him with all their might. It was the midway point of the fourth quarter, the score was tied and Van Horn was at the foul line with the chance of an upset appearing very real.

title: A Brief History of Beauty, Terror and Trial by Fire
description: The earth's habit of forever remaking itself in paroxysms of fire and violence is sometimes hard on its inhabitants, a lesson borne out again last week when villagers in Legaspi, Philippines, fled eruptions of the deadly volcano Mayon. In a new book, ''Vulcan's Fury: Man Against the Volcano'' (Yale University Press), Alwyn Scarth uses witnesses' accounts to tell of 15 great eruptions and of the people who lived through them. Here is a sampling.

title: A Cure for Acne, a Treatment for Angst
description: Courtney McGrath now is a confident, clear-skinned undergraduate at Cornell. But when she had teenage acne, she was so shy she hated to go out.

title: New Method of Altering Plants Is Aimed at Sidestepping Critics
description: Researchers estimate that rice and corn began evolving their separate ways from a common grassy ancestor at least 60 million years ago. But how far did they travel?

title: Last-Place Angels Had a Season to Remember, and a Season to Forget
description: If uncertainty resides in the Anaheim Angels' clubhouse this spring, it is more welcome than the chaos that dominated the clubhouse last season. One or more of the players who are here now may not be by the time the season begins. Jim Edmonds, for example, has been mentioned in trade talk for months. Darin Erstad is a player the Yankees are said to covet. They are discussed in possible trades because the Angels have an excess of starting outfielders. Last year they had an excess of intramural strife.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, SEYMOUR M.
description: KENT-Seymour M. of Scottsdale, Az. formerly of Manhattan died February 28, 2000. Mr. Kent was the Corporate Vice President, Product & Package Design Avon Products. Prior to Avon he was with Helena Rubinstein, Dorothy Gray and Revlon. Mr. Kent is survived by one son Christopher, one sister Shirley Kantor, one grandchild Jamie and four nieces, Hope A. Dolcetti, Caryl K. Gheen, Wendy D. Kaye and Sheila Iacovelli. Funeral Wednesday 10AM, EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, New York.

title: City Hall Backs Law to Sterilize Pets for Sale or Adoption
description: The Giuliani administration and several prominent City Council members are supporting legislation that would require all dogs and cats sold at pet shops in the city or any animals adopted or reclaimed from city shelters to be sterilized. Officials said such a law would sharply reduce the number of animals euthanized in the city each year.

title: Jury Deliberations to Begin In Gore Fund-Raiser's Trial
description: After listening to testimony for nearly three weeks, a federal jury will begin deliberating on Tuesday the fate of Maria Hsia, a longtime fund-raiser for Vice President Al Gore who is charged with operating a scheme to disguise campaign donations to Mr. Gore and the Democratic Party.

title: Early Test Spots Tube Crack At Con Edison Nuclear Plant
description: A preliminary inquiry into a radiation leak this month at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant suggests that a single crack in a steam-generator tube was responsible, Consolidated Edison officials said today.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUOZZI, JOSEPH M.
description: SUOZZI-Joseph M. We extend our most sincere condolences to the entire family on the sudden and untimely loss of Joseph M. Suozzi. As the son of our trustee, Judge Joseph A. Suozzi, he was a member of our extended ''health system family''. We join in sharing the family's sorrow on the loss of this young and vital man. Saul B. Katz, Chairman, Board of Trustees John S.T. Gallagher, CEO David R. Dantzker, M.D., President North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNBAR, ALEXANDER H.
description: DUNBAR-Alexander H., on February 18, 2000 in Washington, DC at 76 years of age following a long illness. The Partners of Saugatuck Capital Company mourn the passing of their esteemed partner and longtime friend. He was our partner for 13 years and a dedicated executive and tireless worker. Alex was a true professional in every sense of the word but had the ability and compassion to deal with all types of people. Born in Scotland, he served as a Major and demolition expert in the British Army during World War II in the Burma Campaign and on Lord Mountbatten's staff in India. He came to the U.S. in the mid 1950's and enjoyed a long and distinguished career as corporate executive. He was President of Uniroyal Tire Company; Group Executive of Amtel, Inc.; Executive Vice President and Director of the Singer Company; and Vice President of Amphenol-Borg. We shall miss him and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Elizabeth, his daughter, Cindy, and his two granddaughters. Memorial contributions may be made to the Support Fund of Ingleside Presbyterian Retirement Community, 3050 Military Road NW, Washington, DC 20015.

title: Huskies Stave Off A Rutgers Comeback
description: The final score showed that Connecticut beat Rutgers by 5 points tonight, but the Huskies really just seemed to outlast the Scarlet Knights, merely surviving them the way a person overcomes a late-winter bout with the flu. Connecticut's lead was 15 points early in the game, but it dwindled to a single point near the end. Free throws and a last-minute steal helped nurse the Huskies to a 74-69 victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKER, JENNIE
description: DRUCKER-Jennie. Died February 27, 2000, dearly beloved sister of Tanya Adler, loving aunt and loyal friend. Interment private.

description: The hometown hero beat the foreign interloper today in the battle for Hong Kong's telephone company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, SOL
description: FELDMAN-Sol. The Community Synagogue Max D. Raiskin Center along with the frields and alummni of the East Side Hebrew Institute mourn the loss of our longtime Board member and supporter, Sol Feldman. Our condolences to his wife Jean, to his sons Howard and Gerry and to their families. May they be consoled amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: HEINZ TO BUY MILNOT HOLDING, MAKER OF BEECH-NUT
description: The H. J. Heinz Company agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Milnot Holding Corporation, maker of Beech-Nut prepared infant foods, a move that would make the company the No.2 United States baby food company. Terms were not disclosed. Milnot is owned by Madison Dearborn Partners Inc., a Chicago-based investment firm. Milnot has about $226 million in annual sales and employs 540 workers. Heinz, said the purchase would raise its share of United States sales of prepared baby food to about 24 percent from about 11 percent. The Gerber Products Company has about 73 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENNERT, JOSEPH, PROF.
description: RENNERT-Joseph, Prof. The Faculty and Staff of the Chemistry Department of The City College of New York deeply regret the loss of our longtime friend and colleague, Prof. Joseph Rennert. At this very difficult time, we extend our deepest condolences and sympathy to Helen Rennert, his devoted and loving wife, to his children, Michael and Karen, and to the entire Rennert family and friends. Prof. Rennert's warmth, caring, and good humor will always be remembered by his colleagues and students.

title: Leaving Hoop Dreams for the Boardroom
description: IF you're an enterprising type like Steve Mills, this is what you do with your life once you come to grips with a reality that snubs you, that regrets to inform you that you possess just enough game to play ball anywhere in the world except your dream destination, the National Basketball Association. You activate your backup plan.

title: QUINTUS, SOFTWARE MAKER, IN DEAL FOR MUSTANG.COM
description: The Quintus Corporation, a software company in Fremont, Calif., agreed yesterday to acquire Mustang.com Inc. in a stock swap valued at approximately $290 million. Mustang.com, based in Bakersfield, Calif., makes e-mail services and products. Quintus makes customer relationship management software. Quintus will exchange 0.793 share for each share of Mustang.com. At the Quintus closing price on Friday, the transaction values each Mustang.com share at roughly $38.26. Shares of Quintus were down $7.50 each, at $40.75, in Nasdaq trading, where Mustang.com was up $3.75 a share, at $29.625.

title: DISTRICT ATTORNEY DEFENDS HANDLING OF THE DIALLO CASE
description: The Bronx district attorney, facing criticism for failing to get a conviction of the four officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo, repeatedly insisted yesterday that his prosecutors had presented a strong case for conviction and suggested that he did not understand the jury's verdict.

title: Varla Jean's a New Gal, But Life's Still a Drag
description: Any woman who loses 80 pounds in four months (red meat, coffee and obsessive exercise, she says) is bound to have an identity crisis, mostly a good one. But when it happens to a voluptuous red-haired drag queen like Varla Jean Merman (a k a Jeffery Roberson), the new look presents special problems. Those difficulties seem mostly worked out, though, in the entertaining one-woman show ''Enough About Me: An Unauthorized Biography,'' which she performs on weekends at the Chelsea Playhouse.

description: Mayors of three mostly Kurdish cities in southeastern Turkey were released on bail today after more than a week of imprisonment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN II, JOHN NICHOL
description: IRWIN II-John Nichol of New Canaan, CT. Died Monday, February 28, age 86. Attorney with Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler and former diplomat serving the Truman, Eisenhower, Johnson and Nixon Administrations. Mr. Irwin was Deputy Secretary of State from 1970-73 and Ambassador to France 1973-74. Born in Keokuk, IA, graduated Lawrenceville School, Princeton University, Oxford University and Fordham University. Mr. Irwin was married to Jane Watson until her death in 1970. On September 30, 1976 he married Jane G. Reimers. He is survived by his wife Jane, his children: Jane W.I. Droppa and John N. Irwin III, his stepsons: Watkins W. Reynolds III, Thomas B. Reynolds, and Carl D. Reimers III and 12 grandchildren. Throughout his life, Mr. Irwin was described as a modest, honest and caring man, and a wonderful listener. There will be a memorial service on Friday, March 10 at 2PM at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave and 91 Street in NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Wildlife Conservation Society, Bronx Zoo, Bronx NY 10460, or the Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, 178 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: When Despair Invades the Blood Vessels
description: Feeling hopeless is not just unpleasant: it may also be bad for the health.

title: Carter Under Glass, and Over the Top, on NBC
description: NBC invited its new best friend, Vince Carter, Skywalker, to a national party on Sunday. It was a belated invitation; NBC's original schedule did not include the game between Carter's Toronto Raptors and Phoenix. NBC placed it in the 12:30 p.m. slot earlier this month, to be seen by parts of the country not slated to see the Knicks play Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODNE, MARY MAZO
description: BODNE-Mary Mazo. Long time co-owner and ''matriarch'' of the Algonquin Hotel in NYC. The quintessence of southern graciousness, a giving heart, and family dedication. Adored widow of hotelier Ben B. Bodne. Loving sister and friend. Cherished, devoted mother of Renee Colby Chubet and Barbara Anspach. Revered grandmother of Michael, Douglas, and David Colby, Elizabeth Colson, and Roxanna Devlin. Proud great grandmother of Steven, Annie, Margaret, and Bennett. There will be a private service on March 1st at 11 AM, Santuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Save the Children Federation. ''A friend may well be reckoned the masterpiece of nature.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about support for John McCain by Reform Party members misstated the number of candidates seeking the Reform nomination for president. Patrick J. Buchanan is among 12 who have notified the party that they intend to pursue the nomination; he is not the only one.

title: John Blassingame, 59, Historian; Led Yale Black Studies Program
description: John Blassingame, a scholar of the history of slavery in America and a former chairman of the African-American Studies program at Yale University, died on Feb. 13 at his home in New Haven. He was 59.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZILBAN, BORIS
description: ZILBAN-Boris. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member Elliot Zilban and family on the loss of his beloved father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabb

description: JACOBS-Nathan P. Congregation Emanu-El of the city of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Nathan P. Jacobs, our deepest sympathies on the occassion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: The Two Worlds of Teenage Pregnancy
description: The United States may be at the top by most economic measures, but for an important measure of social health -- teenage pregnancy and childbearing -- it moves among the poorest.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the resignation of three labor leaders from a presidential advisory panel on global trade misstated the title of one, Lenore Miller. She is president emeritus of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, not its current head.

title: Making Theater Of Shostakovich; The Emerson Uses the Last Quartet As Inspiration for Something More
description: When you've played all 15 Shostakovich string quartets in five programs over three weeks at Alice Tully Hall, what do you do for an encore? If you're the Emerson String Quartet (which has also recorded the works in a fine new release from Deutsche Grammophon), you play the 15th Quartet all over again and build an intricate theatrical program around it.

description: The Giants may not be able to keep pace with the Washington Redskins, who seem to reinvent their roster every day, but the Giants have positioned themselves at the front of the line in the sweepstakes for the free-agent linebacker Mike Barrow.

description: BRAFF-Sylvia. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Sylvia Braff, beloved wife of Lewis Braff and sister of our member Enid Feldman. We extend deepest condolences to Lewis, Enid and their entire family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: Delphi Buys Parts Shipper
description: The Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, an automotive components giant, said yesterday that it had acquired the Automotive Products Distribution Services business of the AP Group of Britain for about $65 million. The distribution services unit, which has total annual sales of about $175 million, is a leading distributor of products for passenger cars and commercial vehicles throughout Europe. The unit will be renamed Delphi Lockheed Automotive and integrated into Delphi's after-market operations division. Delphi, a General Motors spinoff, is based in Troy, Mich.

title: Program of Drug-Testing Pregnant Women Draws a Review by the Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a South Carolina public hospital conducted unconstitutional searches when it tested pregnant women's urine for drugs so it could report illegal drug use to the police.

title: DaimlerChrysler Reports 16% Rise in 1999 Profit
description: DaimlerChrysler said today that its profit for 1999 increased 16 percent, in line with analysts' expectations, as it benefited from cost cuts, stronger vehicle sales and a rich mix of high-profit models.

title: Foiled Terror Plot On Tourists Linked To bin Laden Aide
description: Middle Eastern and American officials say they believe that a key lieutenant of Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile, coordinated a terrorist plot that was aimed at Western and Israeli tourists in Jordan in December.

title: Worries About Internet Crime Spark Legislative Blitz
description: February 29, 2000

title: Hampton Is All Business On the Field
description: Mike Hampton's first act of spring training, two weeks ago, was to announce that negotiations on a long-term contract were off until after the season. The Mets' new ace did not want to be distracted.

title: Risks and Realities in Congo
description: The United Nations Security Council gave its unanimous support last week to an American-backed plan to send a peace-monitoring mission to Congo. In principle, the decision is sound. The ruinous war there must be brought to an end, and international engagement will be essential to untangling a conflict that involves at least six countries and multiple rebel groups and proxy militias. But the dangers associated with the creation of a credible U.N. force are daunting, and the Security Council is right to move ahead with caution.

title: Global Warming: The Contrarian View
description: Over the years, skeptics have tried to cast doubt on the idea of global warming by noting that measurements taken by earth satellites since 1979 have found little or no temperature rise in large parts of the upper atmosphere. The satellites' all-encompassing coverage yields more reliable results than temperature samplings showing a century-long warming trend at the earth's surface, they argued.

title: Defense in Trial of Ousted Pakistani Leader Quits in Protest
description: The hijacking trial of the deposed prime minister of Pakistan -- already a cavalcade of the unexpected and the bizarre -- took another odd twist over the weekend as his entire defense team quit to protest supposed government unfairness.

title: Young Lovers for a Young Company
description: Dance Connecticut got a rocky start to life, founded as it was on the ashes of the popular Hartford Ballet, which disbanded last year. But the new troupe chose wisely for its first major production. It would be tempting to describe Jean Grand-Maitre's opening premiere as ''Romeo and Juliet Lite.'' But light and sweet is a much better description.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a meeting of shareholders to elect two members to the board of the Carver Bancorp in Harlem misstated the elected office once held by Percy E. Sutton, who supported Carver's management at the meeting. He was borough president of Manhattan, not the Bronx.

title: New Jersey Center Outlines Its Performance Season
description: Highland pipers, Chinese acrobats and Viennese choirboys are among the performers who are to appear during the 2000-01 season of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.

title: In the Dark Matter Wars, Wimps Beat Machos
description: The last hopes for a universe filled with familiar stuff behaving in comprehensible ways died here in Los Angeles County last week. It showed in the head-turning attire of at least two of the scientists who carried the news to a major conference on cosmology in a hotel across the street from a restaurant called Killer Shrimp.

title: Campaigns and Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Oracle to Build Market Site For Sears and French Chain
description: The Oracle Corporation said today that it would join with Sears, Roebuck & Company and Carrefour of France to create a global online marketplace for the retail industry.

title: BASS PLANS TO ACQUIRE THE REMAINDER OF BRISTOL HOTELS
description: The British brewer and hotel operator Bass P.L.C. offered yesterday to buy the 90.1 percent of Bristol Hotels and Resorts Inc. it does not own for $169.2 million in cash. The deal would give Bass more hotels in the United States. Bristol, based in Dallas, leases or manages 112 hotels in the United States and Canada. Bass offered $9.50 a share for Bristol. Bristol's stock jumped 62 percent, rising $3.5625 a share, to $9.3125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Bristol had $756.3 million in revenue in 1999. Bass Hotels and Resorts, the hotel division of Bass P.L.C., operates or franchises more than 2,800 hotels worldwide.

title: Unsolved Mystery in Prague/The Death of a Humanitarian : Jewish Leaders Remember One Who Helped All
description: PRAGUE  A fisherman found Charles Jordan's bloated corpse bumping against a weir on Prague's Vltava River, four days after Mr. Jordan had stepped out of his hotel room on a hot August night in 1967 to buy cigarettes.

title: Excerpt From McCain's Speech on Religious Conservatives
description: Following are excerpts from a speech that Senator John McCain of Arizona delivered yesterday in Virginia Beach as provided by his campaign's Web site:

title: Acquiring a Taste for Cold Weather
description: It's not just various foods that cause the tongue to experience the pleasures and discomforts of flavors.

title: The Religious Right Is Not a Burden
description: Yesterday Senator John McCain delivered a speech in Virginia in which he was critical of several leaders of the religious right. Commentators have interpreted this as a political tactic in his struggle with George W. Bush, and as an apparent admission that conservative Christians have become a burden for the Republican party. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mayor Says Criticism of Him Over Diallo Verdict Is Political
description: After three days of attacks from protesters and black clergy infuriated by his defense of the police and the Amadou Diallo verdicts, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani fought back yesterday and called remarks made by the Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, his former ally, ''extremely political'' and ''hateful.''

title: SILVER GIANT RESUMES PRODUCTION
description: The world's largest producer of refined silver, Industrias Penoles S.A., has resumed full production after the authorities forced it to cut back by as much as 50 percent for a year because more than 4,000 children living near its main plant were found to have dangerous levels of lead in their blood. Penoles paid more than $35 million to sweep nearby neighborhoods for lead dust and build enclosures around polluting sites, company officials said. An undetermined number of children have suffered permanent injury because of the lead poisoning. Julia Preston

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER SLIDES. Copper fell 4 percent as record inventories indicated that production was outpacing demand from builders and manufacturers. In New York, copper for May delivery fell 3.35 cents, to 79.4 cents a pound.

title: Annan Wants U.N., Not Saddam, to Control Money for Mecca
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan, in a decision that is unlikely to be welcomed in Baghdad, has devised a plan to pay for Iraqi pilgrimages to Mecca without letting the government of Saddam Hussein disburse the money.

title: An Evening Of Extremes, Mechanistic And Steamy
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic's evening at the Harvey Theater on Friday flirted heavily with popular culture. Robert Spano conducted music that a) translated Conlon Nancarrow into orchestral terms, b) watched Kurt Weill moving from complication to simplicity, c) indulged Toru Takemitsu's unashamed indulgence in Hollywood soundtrack style and d) luxuriated in Astor Piazzolla's elevation of the tango to high art.

title: A DEPRESSING DREAMCAST
description: The struggling video game company Sega Enterprises Inc. more than doubled its estimate of the losses it will sustain in the year that ends on March 31. Citing slow sales of its Dreamcast video game console, the company said its losses were likely to hit 44.9 billion yen, or about $412 million at current exchange rates, compared with its earlier forecast of a loss of 19.8 billion yen. Sega will also sell stock worth 101.4 billion yen, or $920 million, to its majority shareholder, the CSK Corporation, and its chairman, Isao Ohkawa. Stephanie Strom

title: NETIQ AGREES TO BUY MISSION CRITICAL, A RIVAL
description: The NetIQ Corporation, whose software monitors the Microsoft Corporation's Windows systems in corporate computer networks, agreed to buy a rival, Mission Critical Software Inc., for $1.3 billion in stock. NetIQ will pay 0.9413 of a share for each Mission Critical share. A new name and stock symbol will be chosen for the combined company. NetIQ, based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell $5.50 a share, to $68, in Nasdaq trading, where Mission Critical, based in Houston, fell 59.375 cents a share, to $61.656.

title: Most New Jersey Dorm Rooms Found Lacking Sprinklers
description: A new survey, prompted by last month's fatal fire at Seton Hall University, has found that 71 percent of college beds in New Jersey are not protected by sprinklers, officials said yesterday.

title: Ioanna, Ex-Queen of Bulgaria, Dies in Portuguese Exile at 92
description: Ioanna, the Bulgarian queen whose marriage was blessed by Mussolini and whose husband, King Boris III, may have been poisoned by Hitler, died Saturday in her home in Estoril, Portugal. She was 92.

title: Handel's Holy Work, Born of Scandal
description: There is a great story behind the creation of Handel's ''Messiah.'' The London premiere of the work was nearly sabotaged by the vehement opposition of the church, political conspiracies, dueling divas and a sex scandal. And Handel is a great story unto himself, this stout, imperious, German musical genius and savvy theatrical entrepreneur who settled in London and had a long streak of success writing exotic Italian operas for an enthralled English public, until tastes changed and the composer panicked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEER, ALEXANDER E.
description: SCHEER-ALexander E. On February 28, 2000. Beloved husband of Flora. Loving father of David and father-in-law of Tracey. Cherished grandfather to Benjamin and Samantha. Services Tuesday 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Beth David cemtery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MARSHA
description: MILLER-Marsha. Beloved wife of Stephen J. Devoted mother of Beth (Albie), Randy and Jeffrey (Jennifer), cherished daughter of Mollie Miller, loving sister of Al. Services Wednesday 9 A.M. at ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, GENEVIEVE TYNAN
description: DALY-Genevieve Tynan. Born June 30, 1900, died February 26, 2000, in Charleston, S.C. Longtime resident of Pelham and Southold, NY. Survived by sons, Thomas of Charleston, SC, Robert of Darien, CT, David of Pelham, NY, and daughter, Genevieve McGrath of Pelham Manor, NY, 17 grandchildren and two great-grandsons. Reposing at DeFriest Funeral Home, Southold, NY, on March 1, 2-4 PM & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial March 2 at 10 AM at St. Patrick's Church, Southold, New York.

title: Return Passage to India: Emigres Pay Back
description: During the past generation, tens of thousands of Indian engineers left home for America and many got rich -- some fabulously rich -- in the technology boom. Along the way, they became symbols of a brain drain that scholars believed was sucking the best and brightest minds out of third world countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMET, GERTRUDE L.
description: SAMET-Gertrude L. On February 27, 2000. Age 82. Loving wife of the late L. Reyner Samet. Beloved mother of Howard and Stephen Conn. Dear sister of Doris Sostmann. Services Tuesday, Febrauary 29, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65 Street.

title: No More Chanting, No More Sweet Swings, No More Tomorrows
description: It was a warm September evening in 1990 and Darryl Strawberry had just sent everyone home from Shea Stadium with a titanic two-run homer off Lee Smith. After missing the press elevator, I tried to hustle down to the clubhouse to interview Strawberry and ran into every Darryl fan in Flushing clogging the runways, screaming his name and making it impossible to budge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARNIVAL, JOSEPH D.
description: CARNIVAL-Joseph D. On February 26, 2000. World War II veteran, 8th Air Force, past Grand Knight, Castillian Council #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELIKER, JOHN
description: HELIKER-John. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of art.

description: Life After Pollution

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, SOL
description: HELLER-Sol. The Partners, Associates and Staff of Thurm & Heller, LLP are saddened by the passing of Sol Heller, father of our partner, Anthony Heller, and extend our sincerest condolences to the family.

title: Poll Finds That Half in State Disagree With Diallo Verdict
description: Half of all adults in New York State disagree with the verdict acquitting four New York City police officers in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: A Support System For the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Incomes Rose Faster Than Spending In January
description: Americans' incomes rose in January at the fastest pace in three months, government figures showed today, suggesting that consumers could be poised to increase spending.
